title: Miriam Midlarsky, Theodore Lichtenfeld
description: Miriam Joyce Midlarsky, a daughter of Dr. Elizabeth Midlarsky and Dr. Manus Midlarsky of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married today to Rabbi Theodore Adam Lichtenfeld, the son of Florence and Kurt Lichtenfeld of Dresher, Pa. Rabbi Ira Stone will officiate at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Allan D. Kensky, the dean of the rabbinical school at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Private Sector; Sooner or Later, Numbers Add Up
description: Robert E. Rubin joined about 80 women at the Four Seasons restaurant for lunch last week to kick off a financial services unit for women at Citigroup, where he is chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Rubin -- a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs and the lone man in the crowd -- said he was worried that the economy would end up in the same stalled position as it was in the late 1980's.

title: Combined Vaccine For Hepatitis A and B
description: World travelers have fewer needle jabs to worry about since the Food and Drug Administration recently approved a combination vaccine for hepatitis A and B in adults. Twinrix, manufactured by Glaxo SmithKline, is the only available dual vaccine.

title: 10 Blocks of Commercial Hallmarks Transformed Into Landmarks
description: A chunk of lower Midtown entered the official historical record on Tuesday when the Landmarks Preservation Commission, under its new chairwoman, Sherida Paulsen, designated the Madison Square North Historic District. It encompasses 10 city blocks and 96 buildings, many of them stone, brick and terra cotta, which represent a vital era in New York's bustling commercial history.

The Rev. Derick A. J. Maregele, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn., with the Rev. William G. D. Sykes, an Anglican minister and a chaplain at Oxford University in England, taking part.

title: Milwaukee Reaches Its Highs and Lows
description: When the Milwaukee Brewers arrived at Wrigley Field last weekend, they encountered a team that had won its last 13 home games and had the best winning percentage in the National League. Moreover, they had to face, in the series opener, Kerry Wood, a hard-throwing pitcher who had a six-game winning streak that included a one-hit shutout.

title: Bloomberg Starts Filling In the Gaps in His Public Portrait
description: Michael R. Bloomberg says he supports the posting of surveillance cameras in New York City parks to fight crime, but thinks that another of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's more distinctive initiatives -- erecting pedestrian barriers to control jaywalking -- has not worked.

title: Chicken, Beef or Fish? (Please Pick Something)
description: You probably don't need a survey to learn that few passengers, especially those sitting in coach, rave about airline meals. But just the same, the International Air Transport Association recently asked some of its member airlines to find out what passengers do like to eat. The unscientific results were released today.

title: Making Rain Runoff a Friend to Your Garden
description: THE fifth graders were out in the hot sun recently, weeding the rain garden they had planted from seed last November.

title: High Hopes, And Shadows
description: The optimistic picture that Vice President Dick Cheney's doctors painted today after successfully implanting a pacemaker and defibrillator in his chest is based on a number of recent studies of similar cases, but is shadowed by the frequent cardiac related episodes that Mr. Cheney has suffered in recent months.

title: Truths, Half-Truths, And the Census; In Describing Us, the Count Has Its Limits
description: Every 10 years, the United States Census Bureau unleashes a swarm of numbers that affect everything from the political power of states to the municipal budgets of cities and the clout of ethnic groups. And every 10 years, anyone who knows anything about how those precise-sounding numbers are arrived at knows there is no way they can be absolutely true.

title: 'Extreme' and 'Schundler': Perfect Together?
description: He was a young Republican with strong religious views and a record of staunch opposition to abortion. His opponent painted him as an extremist, and the people who write about such things said that suburban New Jersey was too moderate to elect such a one as he.

title: Trade Panel Wants Global Economy's Riches Available to Poor Nations Too
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 29  A panel of financial and development experts has called for a new round of international trade talks devoted primarily to helping countries too weak to reap any benefits from the growing global economy.

description: They may look alike, but that's where the similarities end. Mary-Kate, the tomboy, is an expert equestrian who has won championships riding her own horses; Ashley, the ''girly girl,'' is an accomplished jazz and modern dancer.

description: A panel of the world's leading financial and development experts called today for a new round of international trade talks devoted primarily to aiding the poor countries too weak to reap any benefits from the growing global economy.

title: Leisurely Meals in a Beautiful Setting
description: SET in a verdant corner of Westchester, Auberge Maxime draws its local patrons from an area that attaches more importance to preservation than to fashionable renovation. While other restaurants come and go, or reinvent themselves to match the moment, Auberge Maxime adheres to a traditional model, that of a gracious country house where hospitality and civility are a matter of course.

title: Reckonings; The Smell Test

title: Ideas & Trends: The Age of Revolution; Founding Fathers Dreamed of Uprisings, Except in Haiti
description: AMERICANS celebrate the Fourth of July Americana-style, much like the way the nation thinks about the revolution it commemorates. The rituals of family picnics, parades, fairs, fireworks, stories of midnight rides and tea parties reinforce a sense of the Revolution's Americanness: singular, exceptional, unrelated to any history beyond the territory that would become the United States. Yet when Americans isolate the Revolution, they diminish it. It becomes parochial.

title: Commercial Property/Sublets; Sublease Space Surges Onto Market in Manhattan
description: SUBLEASE space is flooding onto the market in Manhattan, as dot-com and telecommunications companies go out of business or greatly shrink their operations. According to a survey by Julien J. Studley Inc., a brokerage that specializes in representing tenants, there is more than 10 million square feet of sublease space currently on the market, compared with slightly less than 2 million square feet a year ago.

title: Working Against the Clock for a Cure
description: ONE day after Kathy Giusti testified with Geraldine A. Ferraro at a congressional hearing on blood cancers late last month, she was zipping up the Merritt Parkway on her way home to New Canaan, cell phone to ear, catching up on her kids, the media, a cure for multiple myeloma.

title: Corrections

description: Who says monetary policy is dry? Or that Alan Greenspan lacks a sense of humor?

title: A Legal Breakthrough for Immigrants
description: Despite the promise of the Statue of Liberty, noncitizens have rarely been treated as constitutional equals in this country. Yet in two surprising decisions handed down last week, the Supreme Court has come close to recognizing that immigrants are persons entitled to the same basic constitutional protections that apply to citizens. In doing so, the court broke from its own ignoble history of slighting immigrants' interests and may well have embarked on a new era in immigrants' rights.

description: ALTHOUGH Alan A. Winter is a periodontist, he longs to be something else: a novelist. And because he has been unable to secure a publisher, or even a literary agent, he decided to enter the world of Internet vanity publishing.

title: Another War in Macedonia Yields an Israeli Victor, 23
description: The Israeli grandmaster Emil Sutovsky, 23, defeated Ruslan Ponomariov, 17, a Ukrainian grandmaster, in a playoff and took the European Championship June 1-15 in Ohrid, Macedonia. After both had gone through the 13-round Swiss-system tournament with 9 1/2-3 1/2 scores, Sutovsky drew the first tie-break game, 15 minutes for each for all moves, and then won the second.

description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: Cooperstown
description: There is a feel of Brigadoon to Cooperstown, the lush village of baseball and opera tucked into the middle of an idyllic nowhere in upstate New York. Here you can find gangs of sensible grown men dressed up in baseball jerseys, dreamily touring the Babe Ruth exhibits at the National Baseball Hall of Fame. Or you can find them like I did, parked in the Cooper Inn parlor one pristine Sunday morning, earnestly recalling wondrous moments of baseball games past. When I asked what brought them to town, the answer was obvious: ''Ten middle-aged guys escaping for the weekend.''

title: Teenagers' Traumas, Without the Clichs
description: FAMILIES with teenagers looking to test attitudinal fault lines (without imperiling health, safety or the family car) might profitably watch ''Crazy/Beautiful,'' which opened on Friday.

description: Bats aren't yet turning to sawdust, and pitchers haven't planted flags on the mounds and declared dominance over the diamonds. But Major League Baseball's offense has slumped this season.

title: NATURAL GAS PIPELINE
description: A Texas company has drastically scaled back plans to lay natural gas pipelines through New Jersey. Williams Gas Pipeline Transco submitted a proposal to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission last week to lay almost 10 miles of pipeline in Somerset and Hunterdon counties. This was scaled down from a proposal for 60 miles of pipeline, including some through the environmentally sensitive Great Swamp in central New Jersey. The company already has received approval for 30 miles of pipes through the Woodbridge and Bordentown areas. Karen DeMasters

title: June 24-30; A Disunited Front on Mideast
description: The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, arrived in Washington asserting that the Palestinians were ignoring a cease-fire pact the United States had arranged two weeks earlier. President Bush surprised his guest by publicly challenging Israel's position. ''Progress is being made,'' he insisted as the two men met at the White House. The president dispatched Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to push for a permanent halt to hostilities. But after three days, he left the region with the cease-fire dispute unresolved, as sporadic shooting continued and Palestinians and Israelis sparred over details of a U.S. plan for a new seven-week truce. William A. Orme Jr.

title: Political Briefing; In Mississippi, A Democratic Feud
description: Mississippi Democrats have been fighting among themselves off and on for the better part of 40 years, going all the way back to the 1960's, when the often bloody struggle to desegregate the state polarized the once-dominant party into white and black factions. Many whites eventually jumped over to the Republican Party, making Republicans full players in Mississippi politics for the first time in decades.

title: The Nation: Morality and Medicine; Reconsidering Embryo Research
description: IN his more than two decades as a United States senator, Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, has been firmly, fervently, against abortion. But about a year ago, Mr. Hatch said, he began wrestling with a question that challenged his beliefs: should the government pay for research on stem cells derived from human embryos, which are destroyed by the experiments?

title: Scissor Rebellion
description: Fashion experimentation was in high gear in Greenwich Village last Sunday at the festivities surrounding the annual Gay and Lesbian Pride Day parade. All you needed to enter the deconstructed fashion fray was imagination and a pair of scissors strong enough to cut through denim or to reduce a T-shirt to bolero proportions. A leather jacket was demolished to a single sleeve. Tennis netting was transformed into a one-arm glove. Pant legs were amputated and used as knee-high leggings (bottom right). Faded jeans were cut in streamers and worn over new denim pants (left). Waistlines plummeted. A punk safety-pin revival made for jeans that might be dangerous in a lightning storm; fashion fads often reappear 20 years after their initial popularity in more extreme versions and then quickly disappear for good.

title: Style; What Are Friends For?
description: I had a friend, Larry, who insisted in a soapy moment that his wife was his best friend. I didn't challenge such a dopey sentiment because I was a true friend. Although I will now point out that she was at the time his second wife and is now as I speak his ex-wife. Proclaiming a spouse as a best friend seems like fool's gold, about as reliable as a politician's identifying a rival as ''my good friend.'' Ultimately, true friends are bound together by altruism and kindness and unspoken but clear expectations of uncluttered generosity. Husbands and wives are joined by something steelier -- a biological imperative, not to mention the law. It has nothing to do with friendship.

Rowland, on how to best spend that money over the next two fiscal years.

title: Darkness Camouflaged By Hanoi's Seductive Sun
description: THE Vietnamese director Tran Anh Hung says he first fell in love with Hanoi over Christmas 1994, when he was in Vietnam shooting his second film, ''Cyclo,'' and had traveled north to that city for a few days' rest.

title: CHERRY HILL DESEGREGATION
description: The state Department of Education, which had singled out Cherry Hill as not doing enough to meet desegregation guidelines in its elementary schools, has tentatively approved a plan by the township. State guidelines say that each district's schools must reflect the racial makeup of the district as a whole. Cherry Hill had long insisted that the disparity of numbers at the elementary level was too low to consider fixing. The latest proposal includes developing committees to look into both elementary school redistricting and providing magnet elementary schools. Robert Strauss

description: Be honest. Who cares what happens to those piles of prefabricated concrete that squat in the middle of the Meadowlands?

title: June 24-30; Senate Passes Patients' Bill
description: After two weeks of debate, the Senate passed a sweeping bill to define patients' rights, guaranteeing access to emergency care, medical specialists and an independent medical review of decisions denying claims. A 59-to-36 vote sent the bill to the House, where Republican leaders say they will try to accommodate presidential concerns about a possible increase in lawsuits, insurance premiums and the number of uninsured. The passage was a victory for the new majority leader, the Democrat Tom Daschle.

title: Heels in Fact and Fiction: Just Stay Away From Grates
description: THE SETTING -- Shoes, shoes and more shoes in jelly-bean tones were the setting Monday at Sigerson Morrison, the Mecca for footwear on Prince Street. But the store also served as a suitable site for a reading by Anna Maxted, the author of a new single-girl book, ''Running in Heels'' (Regan Books).

title: Mr. Bush's Miscalculation
description: For more than three decades, Americans have demonstrated a commitment to environmental values that transcends party and ideology. History shows that politicians who threaten these values usually pay a stiff political price, as Newt Gingrich and the Contract-With-America Republicans learned when they tried to rewrite the country's basic clean air and clean water laws in 1995.

title: Sports of The Times; The Yanks Reach for New Heights at an Old Altitude
description: THE knees knock. The lungs labor. The brain disengages.

title: Growth in Visits To National Parks Slows
description: FOR years, the managers of the national parks and the people who visit them have talked about how crowded they are becoming and how budgets have not kept up with visitors' demands. Entry fees have been raised to help pay for improvements; better transportation and lodging have been planned to avoid further overloading the parks, especially the most popular ones, like Grand Canyon and Yosemite. And some have said it is time to stop expanding the park system and to start spending more to maintain existing parks, where repairs costing billions are needed.

title: The Rural Life; Volunteers and Pioneers
description: Iowa farmers used to call a stalk of corn growing in a soybean field a ''volunteer.'' I've always loved the personification lurking in that use of the word, as though a corn stalk among the soybeans were like a zealous schoolgirl sitting in the first row of desks, arm thrust in the air after every question. I don't know how farmers get rid of volunteers anymore, but in the early 1960's they organized gangs of kids to walk through the bean fields pulling up volunteers as well as the real weeds. This was called ''walking'' or ''cleaning'' beans. The goal, of course, was higher yields, but there was also a German vanity lurking in the desire for a perfectly clean field and perhaps also a perfectly disciplined child.

title: Lives; Red Terror
description: In 1979, in my homeland, Ethiopia, it was the time we call the Red Terror. The military government was killing people -- there was a fight between the government and an opposition group -- and there were bodies on the street every day. They left them out each morning for everybody to see, with slogans painted on them like, ''This Is an Enemy of the People.''

title: With Victory, Fleet Renee Moves to Head of Class
description: Sometimes, the trainer Michael Dickinson conceded, the handicappers know more than the horsemen. On the first Friday in May in the Kentucky Oaks, many professional horseplayers predicted that Dickinson's filly Fleet Renee would bounce, or show fatigue, from the blazing victory she recorded in her previous outing.

title: Talk Radio
description: CHICKENBOY: Hey, who's that out there? You got the Chickenboy over here.

title: The Choices
description: To The Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on June 17 about traveling to China with children misstated the Web site of Lotus Tours. It is www.lotustoursltd.com.

title: 'S' Is for Satisfactory, Not for Satisfied
description: These are the things that Donna Moffett will remember about the end of her first year teaching, now that the end has come:

title: Perennial Waterside Favorite in Montauk
description: WHEN East End diners tire of the latest see-and-be-seen restaurants, they head for Dave's Grill. This perennial favorite is now in its 14th year. Set on Montauk Harbor beside day-fishing boats, seafood shacks and ferries to Block Island, Dave's appears to fit right in. It has a modest, rustic exterior, but closer inspection reveals charming refinements: attractive postage-stamp gardens flanking the entrance and window boxes crowded with cascading blooms.

title: The Close Reader; Ahead of Her Time
description: Mary Wollstonecraft invented modern women, if invention means reimagining the world so as to make a new kind of life possible. In ''A Vindication of the Rights of Woman'' (1792), feminism's founding document, Wollstonecraft asked for what, two centuries later, we got -- the same education as men, legal equality, professional opportunity -- as well as what we're still trying to get, such as an end to objectification. She wasn't the first writer to be angered by the stifling of female potential, but she was the first to turn her frustration into a critique of polite society. She prosecuted its hypocrisies with high rhetoric, liberating sarcasm and a firm late-18th-century respect for reason as the anchor of individual rights.

title: Michele Cavataio, Antonio Sacconaghi Jr.
description: Michele Cavataio, the daughter of Barbara and Michael Cavataio of Rockford, Ill., is to be married this afternoon to Antonio M. Sacconaghi Jr., the son of Mary Louise and Antonio Sacconaghi of Montreal. The Rev. Howard O'Shea, a Roman Catholic priest, will perform the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Aspen, Colo.

title: Beth Thompson, Michael Power
description: Catherine Elizabeth Thompson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Thompson of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Michael Gerald Power, the son of Patricia Power and Gerald Power, both of Cortland, N.Y. The Rev. James Hreha performed the ceremony at St. Edmond's Roman Catholic Church in Rehoboth Beach, Del. Rabbi Bruce Freyer took part in the ceremony.

title: Minor League Player Races the Calendar
description: THE Mets are hurting. The Mets are not hitting. The power shortage in the outfield is worse than the one in California.

title: An 8th-Street Form of Flattery
description: TAKING in the windows of Joyce Leslie on East Eighth Street, Dany Levy pointed to the black and white graffiti-print T-shirts on display and said, ''See the Louis Vuitton-Stephen Sprouse inspiration?'' She entered the store and made her way past a wasteland of leopard-print miniskirts and gold lam halter dresses, zeroing in on Lycra-cotton tube tops in solid colors, for $7.99. ''I go after little basics like these,'' she said with satisfaction. ''They could be at Intermix for $45 to $60 just because they have a Daryl K label.''

title: Federal Money Is Following Rebuilt Beaches Out to Sea
description: Even the Army Corps of Engineers concedes that its costly and monumental projects along coastlines like this one are ultimately fruitless.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 10 about the exhibition ''Inventing New Britain: The Victorian Vision'' at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London misstated the number of Queen Victoria's children. It was nine, not seven.

title: Crossing Boundaries in Fine Arts Annual
description: THE Noyes Museum of Art is by far the smallest and the southernmost of the museums among which the New Jersey Fine Arts Annual is rotated. But in terms of ambition and good eyes behind it, it is right up there, as evidenced by this year's edition.

title: Exploring Roots of East End Farm Families
description: WENDY CHAMBERLIN concedes that her professional life has not followed any particular path. Most of her career moves have resulted ''by luck,'' she said.

title: Appointing Judges: Checks and Balances
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not how old you are, but how you are old.''

title: Mildly Ambitious
description: Joseph Lieberman is a dedicated public servant, a good friend and a decent man (James Traub, June 10). He does not need a publicist to take a position on family values; he lives them. His friends know that the fire in his belly may not have driven him to rudeness or discourtesy. But the fire is there.

title: Free Agents And Knicks Unlikely To Mix
description: A year ago, the Knicks fancied themselves as players on the free-agent market, going through all the motions of a team in serious contention for big-time talent. They flew to Detroit to show Grant Hill a video of celebrities pleading on their behalf and took Brian Grant for a lavish yacht cruise on the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRICKER, PETER JOSEPH
description: FARRICKER-Peter Joseph. On June 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Mandy Farricker. Devoted father of Jack Farricker. Dearest son of Elbee Farricker and the late Dick Farricker. Fond brother of Kate Farricker Bazylewicz, Robert and Myke Farricker, and the late Steven and Mary Farricker. Funeral Mass Monday, 10AM, St. Mary RC Church, 178 Greenwich Ave., Greenwich, CT. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Norwalk, CT. Family will receive friends from 58PM Sunday at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Mary Fund, 122 Palmer's Hill Rd., Unit 1316, Stamford, CT 06902.

title: The Allergy Prison
description: Susan Dominus's sensitive report (June 10) on severe food allergies, an often misunderstood issue, validates the experiences of parents of allergic children. By making it your cover article, you have provided a valuable tool to educate teachers, school nurses, friends and family.

title: Sharon Rudich, Jeremy Wallach
description: Sharon Esther Rudich, a daughter of Tamar Rudich of New York and Tel Aviv and the late Dr. Akiva Rudich, is to be married today to Jeremy Wayne Wallach, a son of Paula Wallach and Dr. Lawrence Wallach of Wallingford, Pa. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.
DISASTER!

title: Dorm Rooms and Spotlights
description: IT'S no wonder theater veterans sound like college kids when they talk of the ''Powerhouse experience.'' After all, it takes place on a college campus, they sleep in dorms and bathrooms are down the hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, MILDRED GRALLA
description: MARKS-Mildred Gralla. Loving wife of the late Benjamin Gralla and the late Louis Marks. Devoted mother of Audrey Einhorn, Toby Cohn and Stephen Gralla. Dear sister of Anna Lubin, Gertrude Kleinman and Dorothy Price. Cherished grandmother of Jaymie, Debra, Meryl, Shari, Douglas, Saul and Beni. Adored greatgrandmother of Benjamin, Jason and Alex. Services today, 12 noon, at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, Inc., 1625 Coney Island Ave. (corner Ave. M), Brooklyn, 718-377-2700.

title: POSTINGS: Project Will Create 22 Apartments, 2 Stores; Lofts for Lower East Side
description: Barbara Rohregger and Harris Barer have spent years around real estate, but not as developers -- until this year. Mrs. Rohregger is still a broker with WRA Weprin Realty in Manhattan, and Mr. Barer is still a real estate lawyer with the Manhattan firm of Fischbein, Badillo, Wagner & Harding. But by this time next year, the first tenants should begin moving into the apartments that the two of them are jointly developing in what will be two contiguous loft buildings running between Essex and Ludlow Streets in the Lower East Side Historic District.

title: Fire at Co-op Cuts Power To 2800 Units
description: A fire cut power to a co-op complex in Chelsea for several hours yesterday, prompting many residents to seek refuge from the heat in air-conditioned buses that had been provided by the city.

title: POSTINGS: Midtown Tops National Cost Survey; $7,000 a Year For Parking
description: It should not come as much of a surprise to anyone who drives to work in Manhattan, but a recent national survey found that Midtown and downtown are the most expensive places to park a car in the country.

title: Political Briefing: In Mississippi, a Democratic Feud
description: Mississippi Democrats have been fighting among themselves off and on for the better part of 40 years, going all the way back to the 1960's, when the often bloody struggle to desegregate the state polarized the once-dominant party into white and black factions. Many whites eventually jumped over to the Republican Party, making Republicans full players in Mississippi politics for the first time in decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBARINI, CHARLES J. SR. ESQ.
description: GARBARINI-Charles J. Sr. Esq. 90 years old. The Garbarini/Penna and Petro families deeply mourn the passing of our beloved CJ. He was our ''Great One.'' His long and difficult battle with Glaucoma and Parkinson's disease only enhanced his appreciation of life. He never lost his intelligence, sense of humor and wit. He was a wise, compassionate and charitable man. Charles had a devoted and deep love for Lillian, his wife and ''life support'' of the past 64 years. He was a loving father to his children: Charles, Rita Nugent and Stephen. He was a wonderful father to his son-in-law, William Nugent, and to his daughters by marriage, Ruth and Karen. Unsurpassed was his love for his grandchildren: Christopher Nugent, David Nugent, Samantha Garbarini, Alexandra Garbarini and Micah Singer, Jennifer Layton and Sarah Layton. We cannot imagine life without him, so great is our loss.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SAMUEL
description: WEINTRAUB-Samuel. June 30, 2000. Dad, we think of you each day. With Love, Jerry and Jane; Mel and Linda, your grandchildren and great-grandchildren

title: Long-Range Justice Raises Fears for Sovereignty
description: From Augusto Pinochet to Slobodan Milosevic, the arm of the law is growing longer and the world smaller for national leaders and others accused of atrocities.

title: Help for a College Short on Alumni
description: NO matter what a new school may offer, it lacks one important thing: an alumni association and the financial support that can generate.

title: Rabbi Ira Eisenstein, 94, Dies; Led Reconstructionist Jews
description: Rabbi Ira Eisenstein, a key figure in the creation of the Reconstructionist movement in American Judaism, died on Thursday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 94 and lived in Silver Spring.

title: Nuns' Army Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LOUISE A.
description: LEVINE-Louise A. On June 29th, 2001 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Devoted wife of the late Seymour Levine. Loving mother of Arthur and Margaret. Adoring grandmother of Sabrina, Zachary, Alex, Jennifer and Stephanie. Services will be graveside Monday, July 2nd, 3 PM, Westchester Hill Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: GYPSY MOTHS
description: The New Jersey Department of Agriculture's Division of Parks and Forestry estimates that close to 200,000 acres of foliage in Bergen, Passaic, Hunterdon and Essex Counties have been destroyed by gypsy moth caterpillars in what it calls the worst deforestation in a decade. Officials have been trying to combat the problem since mid-May, but weather conditions curbed their efforts. Within the next week most of the caterpillars will begin to spin cocoons and begin the transformation to moths. Park officials say that depending on weather conditions some of the foliage could return by mid-July. John Holl

title: Political Briefing; Hastert Quashes Retirement Rumors
description: House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois finally grew tired of the swirl of rumors that had him retiring. So the other day in a closed-door meeting with other House leaders, he went out of his way to quash the speculation, declaring there was absolutely nothing to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THACKARA, JAMES J.
description: THACKARA-James J. A retired economist and banker, died on June 24. He was 87 years old. He graduated from Harvard College in 1936 and entered banking in 1937. During World War II, he served with the US embassy in Brazil and then in the US Navy. In 1946, he was advisor to the Brazilian Delegation to the International Monetary Conference in Savannah, Georgia, and was later decorated by the Brazilian Government with the Order of the Southern Cross. He then joined the Latin American Division of the International Monetary Fund where he served as an economist until 1955. Later that year, he joined the Chase Manhattan Bank where he became Vice President in charge of the bank's branch in Paris, France. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the American Hospital in Neuilly, France. Returning to New York, he was appointed head of the bank's Middle Eastern Division. Between 1970 and 1979, he represented the Credit Lyonais, Paris, in North America. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the UBAF Arab American Bank. In 1975, he was decorated by the French Government with the National Order of Merit. He is survived by his wife, the former Shirley Ingalls of Pelham, NY, a daughter Lucy Kennedy, a son John, a son James, a brother Alexander, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at the Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham, NY on July 7 at 11 AM. The family suggests that any memorial contributions be sent to the Carmel Valley Manor Building Fund.

title: County Cracks Down On Unlicensed Contractors
description: A crackdown by county officials has caught 61 unlicensed contractors working in Westchester. County law requires that home improvement contractors be licensed and display bumper stickers on their vehicles stating the expiration date of the license.

title: Aged Beefcake Calendar Turns Gray Heads
description: The pinup models sat in the quiet library, free, at least for a while, from the burdens of their celebrity. They grumbled about the popularity that dogged them, one pair of sensible heels at a time, since their sold-out calendar, ''The Men of the Carlisle,'' was published this spring.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the pop singer Rufus Wainwright misspelled the name of a concert tour on which he is to perform this summer. It is Wotapalava, not Wotaplava.

title: A Changing World Is Forcing Changes on Managed Care
description: The backlash against managed health care that pushed a patients' bill of rights to the top of the political agenda in Washington has already forced important changes in medical care for millions of Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'FARRILL, ARTURO ''CHICO''
description: O'FARRILL-Arturo ''Chico''. On June 27, 2001. Dearly beloved ''Ito''. Cherished husband of Lupita ''Neca''. Loving father of Georgina and Arturo. Adoring grandfather of Adam, Isabel, Zachary and Aslan. We miss you and ''we love you madly''.

title: Erin Daoust, Gregory Comella
description: Erin Christine Daoust, a social worker, and Gregory Fitzgerald Comella, who plays fullback for the New York Giants of the National Football League, were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Daoust, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: The Nation; The Land of Monopolies
description: AFTER Thursday's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which threw out out District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's order to break up Microsoft, the big question seemed to be: Who won? It's an interesting question, given that the court agreed with Judge Jackson that Microsoft was, after all, a predatory monopoly.

title: Recycling Men Say a D'Agostino Is Making a Hard Job Harder
description: Joe Andrews is a recycling man. He spends his days wheeling a cart heaped with aluminum soda cans across the Upper East Side, putting his back into the work. Some cans he rescues from trash cans. Others he collects regularly at neighborhood buildings, like the complex on York Avenue that leaves him 13 bags every Tuesday. Each can brings in 5 cents. On a good day, he can make $50 or $60. He inherited his business from a man called Country.

title: When a Cruise Goes Off Course
description: EARLY in May, the Marine Expeditions cruise line, headquartered in Toronto, assured a Canadian newspaper that its problems were over. Those problems included financial difficulties that caused the company to suddenly cancel trips to Greenland last summer, leaving about 400 would-be passengers high and dry with vouchers for future trips instead of refunds.

title: A Little Bit of the East, on Fifth
description: HIGH above Fifth Avenue in a duplex apartment brimming with Matisses, Picassos and presidential autographs, the talk turned to saris. Can Western women get away with traditional Indian garb and not look as if they're wearing a bedspread?

title: Always Home
description: My thanks to David LaChapelle (June 10) for his touching and sensitive look into a few remarkable lives ''contained within four walls.'' The stories show how our memories, dreams and inner resources can sometimes stretch far beyond our physical space.

title: INVESTING WITH/Richard C. Pell and Rudolph-Riad Younes; Julius Baer International Equity Fund
description: MANY financial experts have been saying that Americans should keep their money at home. As the performance of foreign stocks becomes more highly correlated to that of Wall Street, so the argument goes, overseas investments do not offer much diversification.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing on Page 32 of Arts & Leisure today for ''A Thousand Clowns'' at the Longacre Theater includes an outdated reference to the show's opening. On Friday, after the section went to press, the producers announced that the show would open on July 11, not July 17.

title: June 24-30; Landmark Cell Phone Ban
description: Despite scant evidence that talking on a cellular telephone causes traffic accidents, New York banned using handheld cell phones while driving. Forty-one other states have considered the issue in the last three years, but New York is the first to adopt a ban. The law does allow drivers to talk with a headset or earphone, as long as both hands are on the wheel.

description: To the Editor:

description: THE INVISIBLE HEART Economics and Family Values. By Nancy Folbre. 267 pp. New York: The New Press. $24.95.

title: Megan Clark, Joshua Eisenberg
description: Megan Elizabeth Clark, a daughter of Nancy W. and J. Thomas Clark of Old Chatham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joshua Sevin Eisenberg, a son of Betsy Sevin Eisenberg and Philip M. Eisenberg of New York. The Rev. Gary P. Gelfenbien, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, with Rabbi Charles Davidson taking part.

title: Transpac Is Amusing to Disney
description: As the man in charge of animation for the Walt Disney Company, the brainchild of his famous Uncle Walt, the studio executive and filmmaker Roy E. Disney admits to enjoying one of life's more mirthful occupations.

title: A Parade of Suburban Progress
description: IT could be argued that some things are just fine the way they are, and that includes parades.

title: June 24-30; U.N. Confronts AIDS
description: Twenty years into the AIDS pandemic, the United Nations' General Assembly held a special session on the disease, its first ever devoted to a health issue. But the debate among delegates and the ensuing declaration outlining how the world should fight AIDS went far beyond medicine, delving into the sensitive cultural, political and economic issues that have contributed to H.I.V. transmission worldwide. The result was a strong call for prevention, and less of a focus on treatment. Jennifer Steinhauer

title: High Hopes for a Patch of Colonial History
description: It's not much of a road. The pavement has long since given way to patches of gravel. Garbage is strewn about. Children drag sticks and skid bicycles, and pale gray cobblestones peek between bits of concrete.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 1, 2001
description: Weeks

title: A Fighter for Rights But a Conciliator, Too
description: CARI M. DOMINGUEZ does not need to be convinced that discrimination exists. The woman whom President Bush has nominated to run the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission brings with her a solid background in civil rights, according to former colleagues and civil rights advocates.

title: Elisabeth Sperling, Neal Shultz
description: Elisabeth Esther Sperling, the daughter of Dr. Eva Sperling and Dr. Edward Sperling of New Rochelle, N.Y., is to be married today to Neal Harry Shultz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Shultz of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Sharon Brous is to perform the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: A Musical Comedy About, Yes, Poverty
description: WHEN Willie Reale and his older brother, Robert, moved to New York in the early 1980's, they got apartments in what everybody then called Hell's Kitchen, where the screaming and the gunshots kept them up until 3 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOOMER, GEORGE DU PONT
description: BOOMER-George du Pont. October 31, 1921 to July 1, 1999. A second year of life without you. I miss you and love you so. Nola

title: Poles and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Shape-Shifting At Little Bighorn
description: THE last time I made the trip to the Little Bighorn Battlefield in Montana, John F. Kennedy was president and Gen. George Armstrong Custer was still a hero. In fact, it was his battlefield, the Custer Battlefield, and stayed that way until Congress changed its name in 1991. I don't recall seeing another human being except a park ranger whose only advice was to ''watch out for rattlers when you walk out in that grass.'' My father and I ended up walking about a mile and a half down the barely visible path on which Custer had ridden to immortality on June 25, 1876, reasonably certain that we had identified the spots where he had foolishly split the 7th Cavalry into three battalions. We were off the mark by at least two miles.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBAKCS
description: THE WATER IN BETWEEN: A Journey at Sea, by Kevin Patterson. (Anchor, $13.) A young Canadian doctor with no nautical training, fresh from an army stint and feeling rudderless, tells of how he refreshed his soul by sailing in a 37-foot boat from British Columbia to Tahiti and back. Patterson, at right, didn't run into any killer sharks or perfect storms, but he came up with ''a delightful, finely written and, in the end, wise book,'' Christopher Buckley wrote here in 2000. Monsters of the Sea, by Richard Ellis (Lyons, $22.95), is a historical survey of mermaids, giant squids, sea serpents and other spooky creatures -- both real and mythological -- that lurk in the deep. In 1994 our reviewer, Janet Lembke, admired Ellis's ''insatiable curiosity'' and ''wry sense of humor.'' In Search of Moby Dick: Quest for the White Whale, by Tim Severin (Da Capo, $13.50), is the colorful account of how the author roamed the South Pacific with whale hunters to determine whether Ahab's nemesis ever existed and whether similar whales exist today. Last year in these pages, W. Jeffrey Bolster called this an ''original, audacious and exuberant'' blend of ''imagination, action and myth.''

title: Summertime, When Lead Poisoning Lurks in a City's Fetid Air
description: THOSE carefree days of summer are, in parts of our state, not so carefree at all, thanks to an old mistake that won't go away. That mistake is lead, and if you think lead poisoning is a problem from a bygone day, doctors and social workers and poisoning victims wish you'd think again.

title: A Company That Keeps Its Eye on the Ball
description: IT was a beautiful night for a ballgame, and the Mets were playing the Arizona Diamondbacks at Shea Stadium. But instead of soft spring breezes ruffling their score sheets in the press box, two broadcast technicians, Dan Beard and Ron Klimkowski hunkered down at a worktable in the drab, windowless innards of a television studio. Three monitors, one beeping and scrolling down lines of numbers every few seconds, faced them.

title: Q and A
description: A Brazilian Wildlife Haven

title: The Way We Live Now: On Language; Quick, Henry, the emollient!
description: 'I hope the notion of a unilateral approach died in some people's minds here today,'' President George W. Bush told a NATO news conference in Brussels, bridling at having been saddled with the dirty diplomatic word. ''Unilateralists don't come around the table to listen to others. . . . Unilateralists don't ask opinions of world leaders.'' In case anybody didn't get his point, he gave a definition: ''A unilateralist is one that doesn't understand the role of NATO.'' Were it not for the ghost of the Nixonian ''I am not a crook,'' he would surely have added, ''I am not a unilateralist.''

title: For the Dying, a New Lease on Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to Bates Motel Summer Rental
description: ICKY New York summer is upon you. Garbage has started to smell beyond the service door of your apartment. The super is in rehab. The passenger elevators are down for an overhaul. The freight car is run by the porter who never showers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, FREDA L. (NEE LEVINE)
description: ZUCKER-Freda L. (nee LeVine). Died at Verrazano Nursing Home, Staten Island, on June 30, 2001. She was 88, and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for ten years. The youngest member of the LeVine family, she survived two brothers and four sisters. Freda LeVine was born 1913, in Elmira, New York, and raised in New Haven, Connecticut. She moved to New York City in 1942 when she married William J. Zucker, an attorney, who served in the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. Before he retired in 1955, Mr. Zucker served as chief of the Chinese and immigration law divisions of the New York District, district operations officer, district administrative officer, assistant district director and acting district director. Mr. Zucker died in 1968 in Teaneck, New Jersey. An independent woman, Mrs. Zucker worked in the garment industry beginning in 1957 at West Point Pepperell, New York City. She ended her career in 1983, at age 70, as Office Manager of Dotti Originals, New York City. Mrs Zucker led a Jewish life and was active in B'nai B'rith and Hadassah. She was a founding member of Southbridge Hadassah. She traveled extensively, particularly after her retirement, to the Costa del Sol, Spain, with her companion of many years, the late Saul Herzfeld, Southbridge Towers, Manhattan. There was always music in her home, and she frequented the Metropolitan Opera. She is survived by her only daughter, Jane Z. Smith, of Staten Island. Mrs. Zucker will be buried in Beth Hamedrosh Cemetery, New Haven, CT. Donations in memory of Freda Zucker should be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of Staten Island or to Hadassah.

title: A Jigsaw of Memories At the Site of a Fatal Blast
description: The sky is still there. Harriet and Leonard Walit and Khay Cochran are not.

title: Poverty Forces New Methods For Educating Turkish Youth
description: Ibrahim Betil was standing outside a mobile classroom in southeastern Turkey recently when a teenager approached, a flock of 20 or 25 sheep trailing in his wake.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for ERNEST W. DuBESTER; In Defense Of the Oldest Labor Law
description: IN January, the airline industry faced the prospect of strikes at four of the country's largest carriers. Since the 1930's, labor disputes in the industry have fallen under the Railway Labor Act, which empowered the National Mediation Board to try to resolve disputes between management and labor while minimizing the disruption of air service.

title: June 24-30; Cheney Receives Implant
description: After nearly 25 years of heart disease, Vice President Dick Cheney had a sophisticated device implanted in his upper chest that is ready to correct an abnormal heart rhythm, even shock his heart if necessary. It's ''like having an emergency room implanted in your chest,'' said one doctor. Before entering George Washington Hospital for the procedure, Mr. Cheney insisted that his heart problems would not interfere with his performance as President Bush's point man.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Homeless, and Legit

title: NUDE SUNBATHING
description: A three-judge state appellate court panel has upheld a Lower Township ordinance prohibiting nude sunbathing at Higbee Beach, a state park in Cape May Country. Though there had been nude sunbathers at Higbee Beach for several decades, Lower Township passed an ordinance in 1999 to stop the practice. Two sunbathers, Bill and Arlene Vogt, challenged the ordinance, primarily by saying the beach was on state and federal property and, therefore, the local ordinance did not apply. It is their suits that the appellate court rejected, writing that whatever personal right one has to be nude, that right becomes subject to government regulation when one seeks to exercise it in public. Robert Strauss

title: In Mississippi, a Democratic Feud
description: Mississippi Democrats have been fighting among themselves off and on for the better part of 40 years, going all the way back to the 1960's, when the often bloody struggle to desegregate the state polarized the once-dominant party into white and black factions. Many whites eventually jumped over to the Republican Party, making Republicans full players in Mississippi politics for the first time in decades.

title: A Serious Student Of Cartoons
description: A TOUR of J. J. Sedelmaier's animation studio is an introduction to his passions. He keeps his collection of comic books close at hand in his office, near a fleet of toy trains and a library of books on everything from Leonardo da Vinci to Bruce Lee. Antique telephones, including an early touch-tone model that predates the advent of the pound and star keys, have a wall of their own.

title: Queen of the Harbor
description: ''Statue of Liberty: Building a Colossus,'' on Wednesday at 7 p.m. on the Learning Channel, traces the history of the 560,000-pound Lady Liberty -- from her conception by the French sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi to her placement in New York Harbor in 1886 and her refurbishment a century later.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE WIDTH OF THE SEA By Michelle Chalfoun. Cliff Street/HarperCollins, $25.

title: For Six Decades, a Colorful Mirror of Popular Culture
description: SINCE its birth more than 60 years ago, the album cover has mirrored popular culture's obsessions, from jazz crooners to hot pants, from tattoos to all things digital. Now ''The LP Show,'' one of the summer's most unusual and daunting exhibitions, surveys more than 2,500 of these cardboard icons from the past six decades. It remains on view at Exit Art in SoHo through Aug. 17.

title: Article 2001070192706951215 -- No Title
Shakespeare to Rossini to Verdi: The Metamorphosis of Othello
description: FOR centuries, the plays and poetry of Shakespeare have lured composers to interpret them. From ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' to ''West Side Story,'' western music owes a wealth of orchestral works and all manner of song to Shakespeare. This year's Caramoor International Music Festival centers on two stagings of his Othello tragedy: Rossini's ''Otello'' and a later version by Verdi.

title: Yankees Add Wohlers to Their Growing Bullpen Roster
description: Mark Wohlers announced his potential itinerary as if he were a college student leaving for spring break. Wohlers wanted to get a flight from Cincinnati to New York last night or very early today so he would make it to Yankee Stadium for the game. Wohlers, who allowed one of the most memorable homers in recent Yankee history, was so eager to become a Yankee that he waived his no-trade clause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATOUR, DONALD D.
description: LATOUR-Donald D. Of Sea Cliff, NY, formerly of Bronxville, NY, on June 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Lois. He is also survived by his aunt Doris Tether and cousins. Visiting Monday, 7-9 PM, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Funeral service Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Sea Cliff. Interment East Hillside Cemetery, Old Brookville, NY.

title: 'Ghost Soldiers'
description: To the Editor:

title: June 24-30; Cheers
description: Great Bordeaux wine has never been inexpensive. But no one in the wine world can recall anything to match the newly released opening prices of the 2000 vintage. They have reached record highs -- over $1,000 a bottle in some cases -- for wines that won't even arrive here from France for another two years. Perfect growing conditions and the absence of any truly superb vintages in the past decade have contributed to the frenzy, but so, apparently, has the magic number -- 2000 -- on each label. Buyers want the vintage just because it's 2000, wine merchants say. Frank J. Prial

title: A Demoralized Force Failed To Police Itself, a Report Says
description: A state agency has found that the Police Department here, suffering from low morale and widespread cynicism, failed to fairly police itself.

title: The Way We Live Now: Salient Facts - Extreme Gardening; The Green Reaper
description: Gardening has long enjoyed the reputation as the most leisurely of leisure activities, a gentle hobby that produces beauty, serenity and compost. And so it may be in the pages of some long-ago seed catalog, but in real life -- or its frequent usurper, the Internet -- a hardy gardening counterculture has taken root. The ''extreme gardening'' its adherents practice includes cultivation in severe conditions as well as some social and aesthetic affinities that make high-altitude subzero planting seem tame by comparison.

title: Blues Man at the Newark Museum
description: Born the 14th of 17 children in the Mississippi Delta, Mississippi Charles Bevel, blues singer, multimedia artist, lecturer and Tony-nominated playwright (''It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues''), has learned how to stand out in a crowd. He will discuss his thoughts on the universality of blues music, and on other subjects bridging the arts and humanity, at 1:30 p.m. Thursday at the Newark Museum. Robbie Woliver

title: Michelangelos Highlight Atlanta Exhibition
description: Nine Michelangelo drawings are making their American debut during the Italian Summer Festival sponsored by the High Museum of Art in Atlanta.

title: Article 2001070193168637217 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: The Subtext
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREYER, NORMAN L.
description: DREYER-Norman L. Beloved husband of Jackie. Devoted father of Janine and Nils Nichols, and Dianne. Adoring grandfather of Skylar. Loving brother of Robert and Peter. Services ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, today, 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Andrew Dreyer Memorial Fund, c/o William Frischling, 444 E. 86th Street, 8F, New York, NY 10028.

title: He's Just a Guy Who Can't Say No (to Directing)
description: JOHN RANDO says yes a lot these days. It was the word that sprang to mind when Neil Simon's people came calling. It was his instinctual response to a young songwriting team's idea for a musical set in, of all places, a public urinal. And it was his reply yet again after a meeting in Los Angeles with Tom Selleck, a television and movie star eager to make his Broadway debut in a play from the 60's by Herb Gardner.

title: AID FOR POOREST DISTRICTS
description: The state's 30 poorest school districts will receive $315 million in supplemental state aid for next school year, only about a fourth of the $1.2 billion in supplemental aid the districts had requested, the state Department of Education announced last week. Supplemental aid pays for programs, like full-day sessions for preschoolers and increased teaching staffs, that were required by the state Supreme Court in the long-running dispute over funding for poor, mainly urban districts known as Abbott vs. Burke. The supplemental aid is in addition to the $2.9 billion the state already has allocated for the 30 poorest districts out of the nearly $6 billion that is appropriated for all school districts. Karen DeMasters

title: Roger Miller
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Sometimes, It Takes a Village
description: THE success of Mount Vernon students in raising reading test scores is symbolic of a national trend for urban schools educating what some call a ''difficult population.''

title: Habitats/Beechhurst, Queens; Finally Fulfilling a Dream Of Living on the Water
description: BELLA CHAZIN and Marty Ogoff were sitting on their patio toward sunset, drinking wine just a few steps from Little Bay by the East River, with the Throgs Neck Bridge riding majestically above them. The sound of traffic was muted, so unexpectedly quiet that it seemed more like a bridge in a movie set than in real life.

title: Is My Mom Better Than Yours?
description: I AM tired. I have been out all week covering the Mommy Wars, those long-running hostilities between working moms and stay-at-home moms. I'd like to say something calming and equitable, like, ''You're all wonderful mothers, whether you work or not.''

title: Tokyo's Peace and the American Agenda
description: Those responsible for Japan policy in the Bush administration, particularly Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage, have all shown a willingness, even eagerness, to rethink the security relationship between the United States and Japan. The idea is that Japan should use its self-defense force more like an army. Junichiro Koizumi gave this idea new life when he became prime minister in May. However, the self-defense force is restrained from any aggressive act by Japan's pacifist constitution. And so, one way or another, the Americans and Mr. Koizumi are talking about revising the constitution. Such a revision would not, as its advocates claim, make Japan a ''normal'' country. It is more likely to create a political and moral disaster.

title: New England's Coast, By 160-Foot Yacht
description: For those who think the New England coast is best explored by sea, the Arabella, a 160-foot steel-hull schooner, offers that opportunity with modern comforts. This week, the yacht, which cruises the Virgin Islands in winter, is scheduled to begin a season of four- and six-night cruises out of Newport, R.I., docking overnight at Martha's Vineyard, Nantucket, Provincetown, Cuttyhunk and Plymouth. Its New England season will continue through Oct. 18.

title: Tracy Mack, Michael Citrin
description: Tracy Dawn Mack, the daughter of Elaine and Stephen Mack of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Peter Citrin, a son of Myra Citrin of Sanibel Island, Fla., and the late Martin Citrin.

title: Serbian Tells of Spiriting Milosevic Away
description: Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic of Serbia said today that he had feared that the army would try to stop the transfer of Slobodan Milosevic to an international tribunal this week and that he had set up an elaborate series of ruses and decoys to spirit the former president out of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELSH, MSGR. ROBERT E.
description: WELSH-Msgr. Robert E. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the Pastor Emeritus of Good Shepherd Church, 1950 Batchelder St., Brooklyn, on June 30. Reposing in Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Sunday, July 1, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, and Monday, July 2, 2-5 PM, Mass of Transferral at Good Shepherd Church at 7:30 PM. Funeral Mass at Good Shepherd Church, Tuesday, July 3, at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Isuzu's U.S. Presence Leans on G.M.
description: AMERICAN ISUZU MOTORS is introducing its all-important sport utility vehicle, the Axiom, at a time when its Japanese parent company is in turmoil and its future as a retailer of passenger vehicles has been questioned.

title: Letters: Gay Sitcom Writers
description: The Source of Humor

title: Sports of The Times; Wimbledon: It Is a World Unto Itself
description: HERE in the insular and tabloid-driven world of grass-court tennis, sex, serve and volley remain the popular and predominant themes, I was reminded yesterday after showing up, soggy and sleep-deprived, following a two-year absence.

title: Comedy Act and Door Prizes: It's CVS's Way of Recruiting
description: ''You may walk away with a trip to the Bahamas and a new career!'' read the advertisement that CVS Corporation, the pharmacy chain, placed recently in Westchester newspapers. The ad, which invited potential store managers and pharmacists to a reception at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown, promised a comedy act, hors d'oeuvres and door prizes, including a vacation in the Bahamas.

title: Investing; Polaroid Makes a Digital Leap, but Is It Enough?
description: FOR investors in the Polaroid Corporation, prospects appear dim. Shares in the company have dropped more than 55 percent this year. The stock hit $2.45 on Wednesday, its lowest level in at least three decades. It now trades at $2.60 or 90 percent below its price less than four years ago.

title: Honk if You're Ticked Off
description: It's no mistake that out-of-staters think New Jersey drivers are obnoxious. In fact, New Jersey drivers are the first to admit it.

title: A Ros to Stir The Appetite
description: Tavel fans will relish Wlffer Estate's stylish 2000 ros from the South Fork of Long Island. It is salmon-coral and smooth; the finish prolongs its tender fruitiness. This snappy wine -- some might say steely -- gives 100 percent aperitif value: the quarter grilled chicken you plan to eat becomes half a bird. Union Square Wine and Spirits, 33 Union Square West (17th Street), charges $11.

title: The Ravages of Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Sergeant Questioned and Released in Okinawa Rape
description: A United States Air Force sergeant, who has become the main suspect in the rape of a Japanese woman in Okinawa early Friday, underwent questioning for a second day today but was released this evening without being charged, the local police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALCOFF, HARVEY K.
description: WALCOFF-Harvey K. On June 30, 2001. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Jonathan and Andrew. Dear uncle. Funeral services Monday, 1 PM, ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMBOY, BERTHA ARMEL
description: POMBOY-Bertha Armel. On June 27, 2001, at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Emil Pomboy. Devoted and loving mother of Patricia LeVay (Edward) and Richard (Sissel). Adoring grandmother of Peter Mintz (Etta), Stephanie, Eric and great-grandmother of Alexander. Dear sister of Molly Richman and the late Philip Armel. Services Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Sunday, 11AM. Interment private.

title: A Queens Booster Rebuts a Criticism
description: To the Editor:

title: Graft's Impact on Health
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 29  Government corruption is undermining health services in many countries, depriving the poor of treatment for epidemic diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, an independent organization that monitors bribery and graft said today.

title: Leaving Home, Taking the Hearth
description: YEARS ago, when I was a novice traveler, I made a grave error packing for a trip to Tuscany -- I forgot the pepper grinder. Others may travel to get away from the kitchen, but for me, part of the pleasure of another place is experiencing it through the market and the stove. I want to visit street vendors and tiny shops, spice markets and roadside stands.

title: June 24-30; Interest Rates Cut Again
description: The Federal Reserve eased its campaign to avert a recession, cutting interest rates for the sixth time in six months, but by only a quarter of a percentage point, not the half-point many economists had been calling for. On Wall Street, investors were less interested in the Fed than in the deterioration of corporate profits, which seem unlikely to perk up immediately.

title: Embracing Gay Identity With Candor And Pride
description: A RECENT cartoon in The New Yorker divulged shifting social mores by moving the former inhabitants of a closet to a comfy couch. Two men recline reading the paper, one petting a dog. The other, on the telephone, says: ''We're not doing anything for Gay Pride this year. We're here, we're queer, we're used to it.''

title: Political Briefing; His Past Haunts House Candidate
description: When Max Kennedy dropped out of the race to fill the House seat in Boston left vacant by the death of Representative Joe Moakley, a popular state senator from the district, Stephen Lynch, moved to the top of the list of Democrats (Democrats dominate the district) most likely to replace Mr. Moakley.

title: Deborah Shapira, Barry Stern
description: Deborah Beth Shapira, a daughter of Karen and David Shapira of Pittsburgh, is to be married today to Dr. Barry Lawrence Stern, a son of Ruth and Samuel Stern of Wappingers Falls, N.Y. Rabbi Stanley Urbas, an uncle of the bridegroom, will officiate at the Regent Wall Street in New York

description: Union organizers are turning their attention to upscale food stores, like the Jefferson Market, Balducci's, Gourmet Garage and Dean & Deluca, pressing for better benefits for their workers.

description: They say a spirit has returned to Indian country.

description: Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text. Body Text.

title: The Trout Were Too Stuffed To Snag
description: With national parks and forests, there is not much posted land in the Smokies, though thick growths of wild rhododendron block access to miles of stream banks. But the Deep Creek Missionary Baptist Church does warn: ''No Fishing on Sundays.''

title: Julia Ott, Richard Vermillion
description: Julia Cathleen Ott, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Ott of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Charles Richard Vermillion III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vermillion Jr. of Houston. The Rev. David Fulton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military & fraternal organizations. A funeral service was held on June 27, at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, followed by private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY, on June 28. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011. May flights of angels attend her to her resting place.

title: Paper, Paper And Even More Paper
description: MOST people who have been to real estate closings are eager to tell anyone who will listen about the dozens of documents the buyers had to sign if they were taking out a mortgage. Well, real estate columnists are no exception.

title: The Way We Live Now; What They Were Thinking
description: Dawn Kelly, Jaredd Mooney, Jessie Kremidas and Nate Peterkin, Perkins School for the Blind, Watertown, Mass., June 7, 2001

title: Patriotic Gore
description: THE LAST EMPIRE

title: James T. Ellis, 45, a Developer Of Internet Discussion Network
description: James T. Ellis, a computer scientist who was one of the creators of Usenet, an international electronic discussion network that played an integral role in the growth of the popularity of the Internet, died on Thursday at his home in Harmony, Pa. He was 45.

title: A Musical Legacy Fills the Summers
description: CARUSO sang there, Rachmaninoff played there, Sibelius came there for the premiere of his latest symphonic poem -- there being the visually impressive, acoustically ideal Music Shed, built in 1906 on the Stoeckel estate in Norfolk.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Little Boy's Escapes to the Country Become a Family Tradition
description: ''You never know how people are going to affect your life,'' said Ervin McIntyre, chuckling with amazement.

title: The She Decade
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tug-of-War Standoff With an Exotic, Runaway Weed
description: Janice Flood was hiking along the east bank of the Bronx River looking for a place for a gardening project with her middle-school students when she noticed some unfamiliar plants.

title: Liberties; From Bloomberg With Love
description: Here are some things you might not know about Michael Bloomberg:

title: Watershed Warrior
description: RONALD GATTO is an unlikely environmental hero. A former power-lifter, he once bench-pressed 595 pounds and his left biceps bears a tattoo of a police bulldog with handcuffs and a nightstick. He loves cars, and has two vintage Chevrolets in his garage, a green 1960 Impala and a bright red 1971 Chevelle Supersport.

title: Chet Atkins, 77, Is Dead; Guitarist and Producer Was Architect of the 'Nashville Sound'
description: Chet Atkins, the versatile guitarist and record producer who was a leader in the growth of Nashville as a music center in the 1950's and part of the elite force that transformed country music and affected popular musical taste in America, died on Saturday at his home in Nashville. He was 77.

title: Food Diary; Dinner At 8
description: The Julia Child issue was gaining momentum, and my guilt was turning into paranoia: I called myself a food writer and yet I hadn't even studied Julia's work. Mr. Latte soothed me with gentle words for a little while. Then he put an end to it. ''Why don't we have a dinner party,'' he said, ''and you can cook from her books?''

title: Stephanie Nussbaum, Michael Kress
description: Stephanie Nicole Nussbaum, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Tsvi C. Nussbaum of New City, N.Y., is to be married today to Michael Lawrence Kress, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney C. Kress of Manor Heights, Staten Island. Rabbi Shai A. Held is to perform the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Behind a Closed Door
description: FOR three days in mid-June, institutional investors converged on the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan for Bear Stearns's 12th annual technology conference. Some 1,600 investors were there, eager to hear about business trends at 200 top technology companies.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE UNKNOWN ERRORS

title: The State's New Pastime: Looking For a Job
description: THE state's unemployment rate is one of the lowest in the nation, but State Department of Labor statistics released last month show that workers have been losing their jobs at a brisk clip -- 2.4 percent were out of work in May, compared to 1.9 percent in March. Unemployment claims have also jumped, , rising 8 percent from March to May and almost 63 percent from May of last year.

title: It's Camden County. Make No Mistake About It.
description: There's Camden, and there's Camden County, and the county thinks it's worth the better part of a half-million dollars to make sure that distinction is spelled out as clearly and publicly as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE GENDRE, HENRI
description: Le GENDRE-Henri. Beloved husband for 39 years to Hannelore, passed on June 10, 2001. Loving father, grandfather and great grandfather. Mein Geliebter, ever mine, ever thine, ever for each other.

title: Fuel Truck Causes Collapse in Parking Garage
description: A fuel truck collapsed through the floor of parking garage in East Elmhurst, Queens, yesterday, leaving a gasoline spill in its wake and damaging about a dozen parked cars, fire officials said.

title: Watt by Watt, Brazilian Industry Makes Do With Less
description: IN June 1 at 5:45 p.m., a steam whistle blew for the first time ever at a Unilever factory here that makes Omo laundry detergent and Comfort fabric softener.

title: Vacation With a Mission
description: WHEN it comes to bonding, nothing beats nine hours in a rented van with five strangers. We ranged in age from 32 to 59, came mostly from the mid-Atlantic states and worked for companies as diverse as New Jersey Transit, McDonald's and a traveling puppet theater company. We had all signed up with a nonprofit group called the Global Citizens Network based in St. Paul, Minn., for a ''volunteer vacation'' in late September on an Indian reservation in South Dakota.

title: Millburn Student Wins Writing Award
description: The actor Robert Redford won it for sculpture and the photographer Richard Avedon for poetry. Now, Katherine Reilly, a 17-year-old senior from Millburn High School, has received one of five top national honors for her writing portfolio in the 2001 Scholastic Art and Writing Awards.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Lindsay Kneisel, Richard Gagnon Jr.
