Gagnon Jr., the son of Estelle and Richard Gagnon Sr. of Danvers, Mass. The Rev. Ted Hoskins, a United Church of Christ minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Trinitarian Parish Church in Castine, Me.

title: What About Sosa?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan Maxman, Rolf Sauer
description: Susan Abel Maxman and Rolf Eric Sauer, architects, were married on Monday at Cape Fear Point Beach in Bald Head Island, N.C. The Rev. James Brown, a Churches of Christ minister, officiated.

title: June 24-30; Talk About Global Free Trade
description: It is the kind of thing the folks at the World Trade Organization might dream about: last week, a product from North Africa made its way unfettered across the Atlantic and through the Caribbean before being distributed across Texas. Five thousand miles without a single tariff.

title: Curbing Arms Brokers
description: Since his arrest last week in Venezuela, Vladimiro Montesinos, the former Peruvian spy chief, has begun answering charges of torture and death squad activities, money laundering and arms trafficking. At the heart of the arms trafficking case being assembled by Peruvian officials is a convoluted deal in 1998 in which Jordan allegedly sold nearly 10,000 Kalashnikov assault rifles through Peruvian, Lebanese and American middlemen to drug-trafficking leftist guerrillas in Colombia. That deal opens a window on the shadowy world of small-arms trafficking just as the United Nations is about to convene a conference this month to devise international standards and procedures for curtailing this destructive trade.

title: 'I Used to Be Snow White, but I Drifted'
description: COME UP AND

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 1, 2001
description: Weeks

title: 2 Approaches to Winning Over Diners
description: DINERS may complain about shoddy service in Westchester restaurants but they are just as vocal in recognizing superior effort. Last week, when the latest Zagat dining guide to Connecticut and Southern New York came out, two area spots had significantly raised their scores for food and overall service.

title: City Presses for Share of State 911 Surcharge
description: New York City Democrats pressed in recent days for the city to share in state revenues from a monthly surcharge on cell phones that is intended to help meet the cost of handling emergency 911 calls. The effort follows Republican efforts earlier this year to address the same issue.

title: Austrian Airlines Sells Discount Coupons
description: Austrian Airlines is offering discounted travel throughout Europe with its Discover Europe Pass. Bought in conjunction with a round-trip ticket from North America to Vienna, the pass consists of coupons for up to 10 flights within Europe and Russia.

title: On the Upper East Side, A Cap on Pay Phones
description: Upper East Side residents were upset when the city announced plans late last year to install 1,062 pay telephones in their neighborhood.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE WIND DONE GONE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENITS, ALAN N. ''BUDDY''
description: BRENITS-Alan N. ''Buddy''. February 1, 1930 to June 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Nancy (Rush). Devoted father of James, Donald and Andrew. Adored grandfather to Ariel, William, Joshua and Sophie. Loving brother of Helen Glantz and Evelyn Bier. His kindness and compassion will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral service Sunday, July 1st, at 1PM, at ''The Riverside-Nassau North Chapel'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Soap's Up: Water World in Your Purse
description: Last year, Wet Naps were upgraded into fancy wipes. This summer, drugstore hand sanitizers like Purell have trickled up to department store beauty counters in the form of ''cleansing waters.'' Reaching beyond scented mists, these new ablutionary agents are meant to be used for makeup removal and face-cleaning without water. This month, Make Up For Ever introduced Eau Demaquillante -- a pump bottle of clear fluid with a slight scent ($25 at Henri Bendel); Sephora brought out its own light-blue Cleansing Water with moisturizing agents ($7.50).

title: Film Goes All the Way (In the Name of Art)
description: THE fainthearted have learned to close their eyes in the dark of the cinema when faced with a too-violent image. But who can bear to look away during a sex scene? Regardless of how we might judge it later, it's hard to take our eyes off that car wreck of human flesh.

title: June 24-30; Papal Tour of Ukraine
description: John Paul II came at least physically closer to his dream of visiting Moscow with a five-day visit to neighboring Ukraine. His trip had two, at times clashing, goals. He wanted to celebrate the rebirth of the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, which follows Eastern rites but is loyal to Rome, after decades of Soviet oppression. But he also hoped to soften the resistance of the Russian Orthodox Church, which views the pope's support for Ukraine's five million Greek Catholics as one of the chief obstacles to reconciliation. The 81-year-old pope is in no mood to wait and see how Patriarch Aleksei of Russia responds. In September, he plans to visit two other former Soviet republics with Orthodox and Catholic populations, Kazakhstan and Armenia. Alessandra Stanley

title: U.S. Goes Against Mexico, And a History of Failure
description: Despite all the problems within the Mexican soccer team, Bruce Arena, the United States coach, still professed great respect and concern going into Sunday's World Cup qualifying match.

title: Say It With Patches
description: What's the best way to cover all the little holes punched into clothing by the rock-style pins of spring? Patches -- this summer's add-on accessory. While fashion-types have been scouring flea markets for old Boy Scout uniforms to poach patches from, there are easier ways to acquire the latest quick fix. At all Levi's stores, actual vintage patches are $3. They're from the Rose Bowl flea market in Pasadena and most are one of a kind. The roster includes script diner-uniform name tags (''Fernie,'' ''Tucker''), zodiac symbols and an assortment of endearing slogans like ''Truckers Make Better Lovers'' and ''I Love Roller-Skating.''

title: Even the Mets Are Tired of Their Futile Act
description: Mike Piazza was on the Mets' bench, resting his fractured left big toe. Edgardo Alfonzo was in Norfolk, Va., preparing for the first of two minor league games to test his strained lower back. Darryl Hamilton was at home in Houston, dropped from the team.

title: The Reigns in Spain
description: Philip V of Spain The King Who Reigned Twice. By Henry Kamen. Illustrated. 277 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: Bush Backs Japan's Economic Plans, Sidestepping 2 Disputes
description: Meeting in the relaxed setting of Camp David, President Bush and Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, jointly embraced a rapid reform of Japan's recession-plagued economy but carefully sidestepped major differences on global warming and missile defense.

title: Sturdy Mysteries of the Southwest
description: The enigmatic dwellings and timelessness of Mesa Verde survived last summer's wildfires. By Judith Anderson9 The ancient secrets of Tyuonyi fascinate at Bandelier National Monument.  By Stephen Kinzer8

title: The Death, and Troubled Life, of Victor
description: MY son, Victor, is dead now.

title: The World; A Time to Judge What Began and Ended in Kosovo
description: FROM the moment he declared to a delirious crowd at Kosovo Field in 1989 that Serbs ''never conquered or exploited others,'' Slobodan Milosevic sought to shroud his deeds in a fog of myth and denial. He had only one theme: Serbian victimhood and self-defense. The specters changed -- Croatian ''fascists,'' reincarnated Ottomans in Bosnia, Kosovo Albanians bent on ''genocide'' against the Serbs. But the disavowal of any Serbian responsibility for the repetitive bloodshed of Yugoslavia's destruction did not.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: AMTRAK ANNIVERSARY -- Amtrak has extended its 30th anniversary fares, which are 30 percent below regular prices, through August. Reservations must be made by Aug. 24, with reservations made at least a week ahead of the trip, and the tickets must be paid for at least three days ahead; this offer is not valid on July 4 or on trips on the Acela and Northeast Corridor trains; other restrictions apply, too. The 30 percent discount cannot be used with any other special offer, except for an Auto Train offer for children 2 to 15. Under that deal, children pay 25 percent of the regular fare while adults pay 70 percent on the train, which runs between Lorton, Va., just south of Washington, and Sanford, Fla., near Orlando. Call (800) 872-7245 and ask for promotion code H146 for the 30-percent discount and H151 for the children's discount. Availability is limited.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELIAS A.
description: COHEN-Elias A. Although 49 years have passed, since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige'' his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its' 83rd year. Tranquillity Camp Inc Earlton, NY Pearl C. Miller, President

title: A Blessing Five Years in the Making
description: AT the start of this tale, five years ago, a Connecticut priest is wandering in Siena, a walled city in Tuscany. A mix-up occurs. Coincidence -- or is it divine providence? -- fills the middle of the story. By the end, on July 2, the priest and his now-triumphant tale will have galloped full circle back to Siena.

title: A Museum Where All That Glitters Are Minerals
description: The Franklin Mineral Museum's display of fluorescent rocks that shine brilliant shades of red, blue, green, yellow, orange and purple has been fascinating schoolchildren since the museum opened in 1965. Children still come here to see the exhibits of minerals, some found only in Franklin, and to dig in the waste pile left by years of mining. But the museum has expanded its exhibits, thanks to a large donation of specimens from a local teacher, Wilfred Welsh, and his wife, Mary. John L. Baum, a geologist and curator emeritus of the museum, talked recently about the museum and the area.

title: His Big, Brash Works Pass Mayoral Muster
description: WHAT with Rudolph W. Giuliani's commission to make the streets safe from indecent art, one has to wonder: What kind of art does the mayor like?

title: There's Another Big Band From Cuba
description: IN a living room in central Havana, Jess Alemay sat as still and silent as a statue while his bandmates kept urging, ''Say something, say something.'' He was too busy to respond, because he was dissecting every beat and note of a Latin version of Bob Marley's ''Could You Be Loved.''

title: A Teenager Who Dispenses All the Right Moves
description: LOOK up Wade Robson on the Web, and the entries seem to run on forever. Thousands of teenagers spend hours chatting about the 18-year-old choreographer who, for the 1999 MTV Video Music Awards, engineered Britney Spears's conversion to womanhood, squeezing her into a skintight black leather outfit no less, and worked the same magic on the too-cute boy band 'N Sync, so that the quintet now projects an image of real men with some serious urban vibes.

title: Training a New Generation of Workers in Alaska
description: LOUIS PEOPLES was a young man when he came to the Alaskan Arctic in 1977 to help build and then run the industrial web that pumps oil from the North Slope and sends it south to market.

title: A Parade of Suburban Progress
description: IT could be argued that some things are just fine the way they are, and that includes parades.

Lyons and Dr. Charles M. Lyons of Scarborough, Me. Rabbi Stephen I. Kahn is to perform the ceremony at the Beaulieu Garden, an estate in Rutherford, Calif.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Way to Live? With Your Feet on the Table
description: A man named Mikey was drinking at Pete's Tavern, the dark old saloon down in Gramercy Park. It was one of those dog day afternoons, a Sunday, and the city was empty except for the half-million people who were left to pay the bills.

title: Legislature Quietly Passes Many Bills to Help the Poor
description: In a year notable mostly for stalemate, the Legislature has quietly passed a flurry of bills to aid the poor and help them balance the requirements of the welfare system with child care and transportation challenges.

title: The Made-to-Order Savior
description: Henry Strongin Goldberg was the first to arrive in Minneapolis. His parents decorated his room on the fourth floor of the Fairview-University Medical Center with his inflatable Batman chair, two Michael Jordan posters, a Fisher-Price basketball hoop and a punching bag hanging from the curtain rod over the bed. They took turns sleeping (or not) in his room for more than a month. It was too risky for his little brother to visit, but there was a playground across the courtyard, and if Henry, who was 4, stood at the window and Jack, who was 3, climbed to the top of the slide, the boys could wave to each other.

title: Taking Liberties With Bach
description: MURRAY PERAHIA'S new recording of three Bach keyboard concertos pays a little attention to history but not too much, and this may be its main attraction. All of these pieces display a secondhand authenticity to begin with. The popular D minor began as a violin concerto, but we have lost the original. The gentler E major has clouded origins. The A major, say the program notes for this Sony Classical release, first had an oboe d'amore as its solo instrument.

title: Who Died? Me, but Fiddle-de-dee, My Chin Is Up
description: REMEMBER the scene in ''Gone With the Wind'' where Scarlett and Melanie huddle in a horse-drawn buggy at the Atlanta train station, frantically scouring the latest list of Civil War dead? Ashley! Ashley! Would his name be there?

title: A Second Oil Shortage: Experienced Workers
description: FOR Pablo Hadzeriga to leave the profession he loved, it took a terse letter from his employer as he returned from his honeymoon.

title: Corrections

He is Timothy M. Ghriskey, not X.

title: Rock Groups That No Longer Rock
description: IS there anything more old-fashioned than a rock group? These days, pop stars are playing with samplers and string sections, computers and keyboards, turntables and tapes. But if you go to see a rock concert this summer, whether it's U2 or blink-182, you can expect to see a show based on the same basic elements bands were using 50 years ago: vocals, guitar, bass and drums. The songs may have changed, but the line-up remains the same.

title: Selling Big Dreams On the Potomac
description: THE dimly lighted, dmod Eugenia Room on the fourth floor of Sardi's in New York is not the usual site for an announcement by the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. But one morning in June, buttressed by six staff members, there is Michael M. Kaiser, the Kennedy Center's president, introducing three of the directors of six musicals by Stephen Sondheim that will be performed in repertory next year.

He is remembered as the beloved husband of 67 years of Gertrude, sister of Bea Shapiro, dear father of Philip and Robert, father-in-law of Eileen and Carol, adoring grandfather of Peri, Jacqueline, Paula, David, Allison and Lawrence, and great-grandfather of Jake. Memorial services will be held in NYC, at Riverside Chapel, 76th St, on Monday, July 2, at 11:15 AM.

title: News Analysis: Despite Optimism, Cheney's Health Is a Concern

title: June 24-30; Freelancers' Rights Upheld
description: Among a flurry of decisions the Supreme Court released before ending its current session -- including rulings reining in local regulations on tobacco advertising and affirming some immigrants' rights -- was one on the intellectual rights of freelancers. Six such writers took on three major media companies, including The New York Times, over the unauthorized inclusion of their printed work in databases. The justices agreed 7 to 2 that the practice infringed on the freelancers' copyrights. The publishers said they would start removing freelance material from electronic archives, an outcome that could diminish the writers' pleasure in their David and Goliath victory. Linda Greenhouse

title: Edgar's Ordeals
description: Brady Udall's rambling and generous first novel, THE MIRACLE LIFE OF EDGAR MINT (Norton, $24.95), begins when its half-Apache protagonist is 7 and a mail carrier drives a Jeep over his head. Edgar survives -- a miracle -- but the ordeals that follow make the travails of Dickens's hard-luck children look easy. Edgar's father decamped before his son was born, and the boy's beer-swilling mother abandons him following the accident. He is sent to a school for Indian delinquents, where he is tortured and nearly killed by other boys; later, he moves in with a dysfunctional Mormon foster family. Throughout, he is pursued by a demon in the shape of the drug-peddling doctor who saved his life. Contemporary fiction is full of cynical, world-weary protagonists. One of the strengths of this big, uneven novel -- it reads at times like a John Irving novel touched up by Roy Blount Jr. -- is the lovely and complex character of Edgar, an innocent whose struggle to survive is at odds with his fundamentally gentle nature. (''Don't go bad, Edgar,'' an aide at the Indian school whispers to him after a fight.) The conflict is never presented as simple; Edgar almost does go bad. But he manages to detach himself from miserable experiences by setting them down on paper. Other characters are less rich, the denouement seems rushed, and the book is too long. But it is also sweet, sad and refreshing. Jennifer Reese

title: Secret Fund For Officials Questioned By French
description: Once a month, an armored car delivers state funds in cash to top government officials -- over a year, more than $50 million. The public has no idea what happens to this money. No legal inquiry can ever reach the truth because the funds are treated as a state secret.

He graduated from the Citadel in 1955 and from UCLA Executive Program in 1967. He is survived by three children Maia Dixon of Chagrin Falls, OH, Ashley Lueders of Brooklyn Heights, NY & Matthew Lueders of Stamford, CT and three grandchildren Kenny and Grace Dixon & Tyler Lueders.

title: Mildly Ambitious
description: Traub describes Lieberman's all-American qualities -- ''character, earnest, hokey, friendly and sincere'' -- as Christian traits. Is the implication that the opposite qualities are Jewish? Lieberman represents the best of America precisely because he is all those and very Jewish to boot. An all-American Jew is not an oxymoron; on the contrary, it affirms the pluralism we stand for.

description: When Secretary of State Colin L. Powell left the Middle East after his first intensive immersion in Israeli-Palestinian diplomacy, he declared that he was happy to have accomplished more than ''a lot of handshaking and smiling.''

title: The Poor Man's Capitalist
description: It's Monday night in Haiti, and Hernando de Soto is talking about the barking dogs again. They're everywhere. In his book. In his slide show. In briefings at the palace for President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. In sweaty sessions with threadbare villagers. They're peppered through the 60-year-old Peruvian's cocktail chatter, figure in his critique of the World Bank, sum up what he has done to date in Lima. De Soto came across the dogs in Bali, he says, not long after he had begun what may, in the fullness of time, prove to be among the more consequential crusades in economic history. It was a simple question: How do you know in Bali where one man's property ends and another's begins?

title: Preparing Boomers For Long-Time Care

Then my dislike of video games seemed perfectly reasonable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, ELIZABETH PETERSON
description: HERZOG - Elizabeth Peterson. Mrs. Elizabeth Peterson Herzog, 93, died peacefully May 24, 2001 in Ithaca, New York. She had moved to New York City after marrying Paul M. Herzog in 1981 and continued to live there after his death in 1986. She was a Vassar graduate who did postgraduate work at Radcliffe and in Europe. She married Max Habicht in 1932 and brought up her children in Geneva, Switzerland where she served on the board of the International School and founded the Cercle International des Amis de la Musique and the International Forum. In 1962, she married Paul Shipman Andrews, who died in 1966. In 197074, she served in the U.S. Peace Corps in Tunisia and helped to develop the nascent tourist commission. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club of New York City, and past chair of its Foreign Visitors Committee. She is survived by her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, step children and their families, and an ''adopted'' daughter and family. Her family and friends are thankful for her sharp mind and the sunshine she brought to them throughout her life. A memorial service will be celebrated for her in Duxbury, Massachusetts at the Peterson family plot on August 11, 2001. For information call Margareta Robinson in Switzerland 4122-348-87-11 before July 15, 2001. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to the non-profit development organization, Trickle Up Program, 121 West 27th Street, Suite 504, New York, NY 10001. (www.trickleup.org)

But the engineers from Boeing aren't really trying to fix the bell so much as they're giving it a physical -- albeit of the sort usually administered to high-tech metals.

title: Wielding a Magic Of Uncanny Images
description: THE Czech filmmaker Jan Svankmajer is known primarily in this country for feature films that combine meticulous stop-motion animation and live action in bizarre, dreamlike narratives. Perhaps his best known is ''Alice,'' a 1987 adaptation of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' But as impressive as his use of puppets in ''Alice'' and ''Faust'' (1994) may be, his features contain only a fraction of the imagination that can be found in his short films, a body of work that articulates one of the most individual and fascinating world views in the annals of animation.

That has happened to archaeology as it applies to the early settling of the Americas. Evidence is emerging to suggest that the first humans may have been in the New World thousands of years earlier than was previously believed. Even the old presumption that these people walked here across the Alaska land bridge is being challenged again.

As the heron flew by, representatives of the Westchester Land Trust, the city of New Rochelle, Westchester County and the Glenwood Lake Neighborhood Association were celebrating 18 months of joint efforts to save the site on which a developer had hoped to construct up to 11 houses.

Ellis that he misled students at Mount Holyoke College, as well as reporters from The Boston Globe, when he claimed to have spent the 1960's as a combat veteran in Vietnam, a civil rights worker in Mississippi and an antiwar protester at Yale has raised some obvious questions: Why did he do it? title: Business; In a Consolidating Industry, Peugeot Goes Its Own Way
description: JUST because Peugeot sat out the round of automotive mergers and acquisitions in recent years, don't count it out. Its web of alliances and its two-pronged brand approach illustrate the fiercely independent strategy of its chairman and chief executive, Jean-Martin Folz. And the strategy appears to be working.

title: Too Good to Live
description: THE HOTHOUSE

title: QUICK BITE/Hammonton; Who Needs Dry? Try Blueberry Bubbly.
description: The North American Blueberry Council's Web site suggests that blueberries make you younger. It cites research from the National Institutes of Health finding that the consumption of blueberries not only prevent some of the problems associated with aging -- O.K., in rats -- but can also reverse them. But what about blueberry champagne? Fernando Velasquez, the winemaker at Renault Winery in Egg Harbor (www.renaultwinery.com), doesn't exactly say his blueberry champagne is what Ponce de Leon was searching for, but he does promote it as a fun drink. ''This is something for a special occasion,'' Mr. Velasquez said. ''It is sweet.'' The Renault Winery is only a few miles up the White Horse Pike from Hammonton, which in 1984 Ronald Reagan proclaimed the Blueberry Capital of the United States. So the fruit in Mr. Velasquez's wine is fresh and local. We tried it twice: once before a barbecue and another shared as an aperitif with old friends from South Jersey. The wine has a rosy tinge, with only a splash of blue, but you can definitely taste the blueberries. It is indeed sweet, but probably no sweeter than your average spumonte. While most of the best champagnes are much dryer, it is hard to compare something with blueberries from New Jersey costing $12.99 a bottle with something from the chalky earth of Rheims going for at least three times that. But as a sometime thing before a barbecue or after a day at the pool or beach, a quick glass of blueberry bubbly might just bring back some youthful tingles. As Mr. Velasquez said, ''It is something to drink any time you are feeling good.'' Which is probably all Seor Ponce was after. ROBERT STRAUSS

title: The Age of Anxiety
description: Children's fears are ''all too real,'' according to the headline of your feature showing pictures drawn by children of what most frightens them -- guns, tornadoes and, well, mostly guns (The Way We Live Now, June 10).

title: In Manhattanville, Hard Way to the Subway
description: Every day, Raphael Landes slowly climbs the 76 steps to the platform of the elevated 1 and 9 subway station at 125th Street and Broadway. He prefers an escalator, but two of the station's three escalators have been shut down for the past eight months while the city has spent $4.9 million to replace them. The working escalator is often packed with riders. The other two were supposed to open this spring.

description: Retirement isn't too far in the future for many baby boomers, who grew up in the 1950's and 1960's. But while this generation may be thinking about more leisure days ahead, many are unprepared for their long-term health care needs, according to survey results released last week.

description: BEFORE Lisa Torrieri was told she had Hodgkin's disease, she was planning to have a big sweet 16 party. Chemotherapy treatments, however, sapped her energy, putting celebrations on hold for awhile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, JOHN J. FORHAN
description: CAHILL-John J. Forhan, 79, of Vero Beach, Florida, and Martha's Vineyard, a much beloved husband and father, died at his home on June 27 of brain cancer. Mr. Cahill was born in 1921, in New York City to the late Stella Forhan Cahill and Russell Cahill. He graduated from Iona School, where he hired an unknown band leader named Glenn Miller to play at the senior prom. After graduating from Columbia Univeristy, Mr. Cahill was an ensign in the U.S. Navy on a patrol craft that convoyed fleets from New York to Cuba. Later as a lieutenant, he commanded a submarine chaser in the Pacific. Mr. Cahill developed The Mortgage Center on Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket. Prior to that he was Vice President of Marketing for the Xerox Publishing Group, Vice President of Marketing for Mohasco Industries, a consultant with Robert Heller Associates in Ohio, and sales manager of Dobbs Hats for women. Throughout his life he was also an avid golfer and gardener. Married for 58 years, John is survived by his wife Isabel Schaefer Cahill; four daughters, Susan Gebhardt of Mercer Island, WA, Geraldine Ordway of Houston, TX, Julia Cahill of New York City, NY, and Elizabeth Cahill Ruksznis of New Canann, CT; and son John Cahill of Rowayton, CT; and eight grandchildren. He also had three brothers, now deceased, Anthony, Peter and David Cahill. A Mass of Christian Burial is being held at Holy Cross Church in Vero Beach on Monday, July 2 at 11:00 am. Those wishing to remember John may do so by contributing to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Rd., Des Plains, IL 60018, or to the Hospice Center, 1111 36th St., Vero Beach, FL 32960

title: The Play's The Thing
description: When children play at stick swords or army on a sandhill, they will experience the pain associated with their own bumps and lumps and, more to the point, see for themselves what their actions actually inflict on others, if only a bloody nose or a bruise.

title: Restrictive Covenants in a Sale

Upon selling my house, is it legal to include a restrictive covenant forbidding its razing or making major renovations that compromise its architectural integrity? . . . Edwin Hanft, Great Neck, N.Y.

description: THREE decades ago, the United States went to the Moon with a lofty scientific goal: gathering rocks and soil to gain insight into the origins of the solar system.

title: A Loner Who Found a Universe in His Studio
description: TO win recognition as an artist's artist might seem to be the ultimate accolade. Yet all too often the compliment also implies that the artist in question is not that well known, that he or she is something of an acquired taste, that the public at large may be puzzled. Giorgio Morandi certainly fits that description. During his lifetime, he did not seek out fame. And since his death in 1964, while hailed by some artists and critics as Italy's most important 20th-century painter, he has remained an oddly peripheral figure in the history of modern art.

title: All the Winning Horses
description: TONY BLACK looks out from the jocks' room onto the shaded paddock area at Delaware Park Racetrack. It's a 90-degree day, so the air-conditioning is blasting inside the spare quarters decorated in Early Rumpus Room -- a beat-up pool table, a few worn couches, strewn cups on battered tables.

title: In Stamford, a Scout Troop Is Evicted, but Prepared
description: On a steamy night this week, several scouts from Troop 15, their fathers and their scoutmaster rented a truck, pulled up to the Jewish Community Center here and loaded tents, camp stoves, tarpaulins and a half-century of memories.

title: Timeless Mesa Verde
description: I CAN'T say for certain why I'm called by the long road up to Mesa Verde. There's one particular spot, coming around a bend, where I can look out and see Ship Rock rising out of the distant haze in New Mexico. That vast, dispassionate vista feels as if it has always been there and always will be. But disaster threatened my personal lodestone last summer, when rampaging wildfires encroached on Mesa Verde and its extraordinary concentration of cliff dwellings.

title: Plan to Shut Smithsonian's Laboratory Is Reversed
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee has voted to keep open a Smithsonian Institution center that analyzes and researches the conservation of art, artifacts and scientific specimens, pending a review by a science advisory commission.

title: A Special Invitation (to Anyone)
description: LIKE most of us, Ann Hamman is deluged with mail offering ''preapproved'' credit cards and various lines of credit from banks and financial services companies, large and small. Gold cards, platinum cards, titanium cards. Credit lines of as much as $100,000.

title: No Model Student, And Too Burdened To Bear the Scars
description: NO one would contend that Victor Toner had been a model student or a problem-free teenager. He smoked pot. He cut classes, talked back to teachers, boasted to fellow students. His decidedly less affluent crowd of friends, described by some of its own members as ''thugs,'' didn't fit in with the two largest segments at Moorestown High School -- the jocks and the preppies. His two-year relationship with his girlfriend was volatile, and his parents had announced plans to separate once he finished school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORG, DR. SIDNEY F.
description: BORG-Dr. Sidney F. Died peacefully in his sleep on June 26, 2001, after a long illness. Loving father of Nicholas Borg, Andrew Borg, and Jill Spitzer and grandfather of Kristina, Laura, Margo, & Alexander Borg & Rebecca Spitzer. Also survived by two brothers, Robert F. Borg & Matthew F. Borg. Dr. Borg's wife, the former Audrey Elliott, died in 1989. Dr. Borg was Professor Emeritus and retired head of the Department of Civil Engineering of Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, New Jersey, where he taught for 35 years. He was the author of 6 books and dozens of technical papers on structural engineering & earthquakes. After attending NY City public schools, he graduated from Cooper Union in New York, receiving a degree in Civil Engineering in 1937. He later received a Masters Degree from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute & then a doctorate in Civil Engineering from Johns Hopkins University

description: Ever since a knife-wielding man killed eight children at an elementary school near Osaka on June 8, schools across Japan have wasted little time adopting security measures that until the stabbing would have been unthinkable in a country of little violence.

title: Warning: Forecasts May Reduce Your Wealth
description: THE slowdown drags on, but with each passing day, most of the nation's forecasters stick stubbornly to their optimism, as if the tottering economy requires a particularly vigorous whistling past the graveyard. The great majority predict that the economy will revive by year-end. They may even be right. But that is a lot of certainty for practitioners of a craft that so often misreads the future.

title: The Allergy Prison
description: It was refreshing to read an article that places as much emphasis on the social and emotional issues surrounding food allergies as on the medical facts. Our 10-year-old son is well versed on the safety issues and is extremely responsible. The hardest thing is dealing with the lack of understanding. We have been patronized and insulted. But we are resilient. We have defined our friendships by those who are willing to learn and those who want to be involved in our lives.

title: Charity Funds Shift to West, Spreading The Wealth
description: For decades, New York has been the capital of the foundation world, home to the Ford Foundation, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Carnegie Corporation and dozens of other old-line philanthropies.

title: Walking A High Wire Of Words
description: ALAN BENNETT, like Dennis Potter, is remarkable among British dramatists in that his finest work has been done for television. The prolific Mr. Bennett, who received his training in the early 60's as a writer and performer in the stage revue ''Beyond the Fringe,'' has written plays (''The Madness of King George'') and screenplays (''A Private Function,'' ''Prick Up Your Ears''). But it's his teleplays -- exquisitely sculptured, astonishingly economical, with a master's command of tone -- that place him in the highest tier of English dramatic writers.

title: Answered Prayers
description: Prayer seems a private act, a murmur at loudest. Yet Mary Reath found about 125 public figures willing to share their favorite prayers for her new book, ''Public Lives, Private Prayers.'' The book, published by Sorin Books, Notre Dame, Ind., is $14.95 in paperback, and is available from the big online booksellers. Ms. Reath, who with her husband runs a small publishing business in Princeton, was finishing an anthology of children's prayers when she got the idea of connecting private faith with familiar faces. She requested prayers of about 1,000 people and printed the responses, some with a reproduction of the originals, the stationery of Queen Noor of Jordan (with a line from the prophet Mohammed), for example, or a drawing of a flower from Brigitte Bardot. Many prayers are straight from Scripture, but not all. Jane Alexander, for example, quotes Tennessee Williams: ''Sometimes -- there's God -- so quickly!'' Bill Bradley contributes a Zen text on ''the art of living.'' And from George Plimpton, a Latin proverb, ''When there is no wind, row.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUD, ROSALIE KEITH KERR
description: LOUD-Rosalie Keith Kerr. Rosalie Keith Kerr Loud, known to her family and friends as Kiki, died peacefully June 10, 2001, in Paris, France while vacationing with her husband. Born in New York City, Kiki was the beloved wife of Theodore Ewald Loud, formerly of Grosse Pointe, Michigan, and New York City. Kiki was the daughter of the late Albert Boardman Kerr, Esq., lawyer and author from New York City and Rosalie Kerr McGavock, who moved to Charlottesville in 1938. Prior to her marriage to Ted Loud in 1982, Kiki was a professional actress, model and singer in New York City. She appeared in numerous movies, television series, commercials and print advertisements. When Kiki and Ted moved to Charlottesville in 1986, she became active in the Albemarle Garden Club, of which she served as president for two years in the mid-nineties. She was also a charter member of the Contemporary Club. Kiki attended St. Anne's School in Charlottesville, National Cathedral School and Vassar College. Kiki is survived by her husband of nineteen years, the aforementioned Theodore E. Loud; two daughters from a previous marriage, Keith Randolph Deering Morgan and Alexandra Kerr Deering Haigney; and two grandsons, Keith Robinson Morgan and Andrew James Morgan. A memorial service was held on June 21. Contributions to Garden Club of America.

title: When the Heels Are Here to Stay
description: MAYBE it's because I'm 4 foot 11, or because I'm a masochist. But when it comes to shoes, I always choose aesthetics over comfort, trudging around in sky-high stilettos -- which is just what I was doing on the fateful mid-October afternoon when my foot in its Christian Louboutin decided it had had enough. While shopping on Elizabeth Street, I suddenly felt a sharp stab and sat down on the sidewalk. The pain in the ball of my left foot was unbearable; I stayed there on the concrete and massaged it for 20 minutes.

description: Kyoko Inouye and David Gelber were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Rachel B. Cowan at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: In Wisconsin, a Golf Resort With Irish Soul
description: IT was midsummer, but standing on the seventh tee, I felt a blustery wind blowing hard in my face. The green, 175 yards away, was framed by dunes covered in golden fescue and protected by natural-looking sand traps pockmarked with stones and tufts of grass. Stretching from the craggy beach to the eastern horizon was a vast body of water. A brief rain squall broke out as the sun struggled to poke through the clouds.

title: Where Opera Is a Natural Pastime
description: IN the gymnasium of a community center in this village just north of Cooperstown, the cast of the Glimmerglass Opera's new production of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' gathered for the first time. It was a soggy, chilly Monday in June, and most of the singers had driven in over the weekend. Now they convened to meet one another and the production team, and to hear the English director Stephen Lawless explain his concept of the work.

title: Weekend Arrangement
description: ABC Flowers' Summer Bouquet, a bucolic consolation for New Yorkers stuck in the city on long, hot weekends. Every Saturday and Sunday through Labor Day, ABC Flowers is offering a bouquet for a special price of $25 (the bouquet costs $45 on other days). Already, numerous shoppers have been spotted in the Flatiron district toting the bright assortment of blooms in ABC's signature purple box, looking as though they had just come from a wedding with centerpiece in tow. Delivery, $15 extra, is available on Saturdays only; you supply the vase. Orders, (646) 602-3711. The shop is at ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street).

description: WHAT do you call a long bullet-shaped vehicle with rubber tires that zips along roads, stops for traffic lights and carries lots of people?

title: Kristina Ritter, Francis Loverro
description: Kristina Larissa Sarah Ritter, the daughter of Edith Ritter of Coopersburg, Pa., and Don Ritter of Washington, was married last evening to Francis John Loverro, a son of Diane and John Loverro of East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Grant E. Harrity, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBIN, RICHARD
description: ROBIN-Richard. Your colleagues mourn your passing on June 12, 2001, and also celebrate your long and interesting life. Many will miss your sparkling wit, countless stories, your support and the many entertaining political and social discussions of your well travelled life as a man of peace and goodwill. Our heartfelt condolences to your wife, Therese, of 58 years who will keep your spirit alive in the company and to your children, Jacky and her husband, Jeff, and your grandchildren, Scott and Mark Shawn. The staff/Avirex NYC

title: An American Family Living in a New America
description: ONE afternoon in the autumn of 1998, a young filmmaker named Aaron Matthews paid for a membership at the Museum of Television and Radio in Manhattan, checked into its library and began screening the public television documentary ''An American Family.'' He had been just 2 years old and living in Venezuela when the series, about the Loud family of Santa Barbara, Calif., was broadcast to enormous critical and popular attention. And even now, midway through his 20's and the creator of two short films, he had only the vaguest sense of ''An American Family,'' drawn mostly from the Albert Brooks parody ''Real Life.''

title: Kim France, Michael Morse

Rabbi Alon Levkovitz officiated at the Channing Daughters Vineyard in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

Funeral services Adat Shalom Reconstructionist Congregation, 7727 Persimmon Tree Lane, Bethesda, MD, 11AM Sunday, July 1. Interment at Judean Memorial Gardens, Olney, MD. title: Corrections
description: A series of interviews on June 10 with elderly longtime residents of Manhattan apartments misstated the year that one resident, Doris Pollard, moved into her apartment. (She was 100 when she was interviewed and has since died.) It was 1962, not 1947.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Portland's Art Moves Outdoors
description: It sounds like a movie title: ''Seven Days for Seven Sculptures.'' The Percent for Art program in Portland, Ore., installed seven major pieces in just a week at the end of May, bringing the city's outdoor public art count to well over 100 works. (The program's name comes from local ordinances requiring that 1.33 percent of construction costs for public buildings or spaces be dedicated to art.) Four went in along the waterfront, two at a renovated baseball park and one at the Portland Metropolitan Exposition Center.

title: June 24-30; Peru's Spy Chief Captured
description: After an eight-month international manhunt, Vladimiro Montesinos, former President Alberto K. Fujimori's top spy for a decade, was captured in Venezuela and returned to Peru in handcuffs and a bullet-proof vest. Trying to win the best possible prison conditions from six Peruvian judges, he offered to release 30,000 videotapes that could incriminate businessmen, congressmen, military officers and even foreign diplomats. But so far, he has not turned over anything except an excuse that everything he did was under orders of Mr. Fujimori, who remains in comfortable exile in Japan.

title: The Nation: Second Thoughts; Cracking the Door for Immigrants
description: FIVE years on, it takes some effort to recall the full fury of the anti-immigration hurricane that hit Washington in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDOUKIAN, PAUL ZAREH
description: BEDOUKIAN-Paul Zareh. Age 89, of Wilton, CT, on Friday, June 29. Renonwn chemist, author, numismatist. Beloved husband of Vicki and loving father of Joan, Betty and Robert. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at St. Gregory's Armenian Church, White Plains, NY. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Armenian Library and Museum of America, 65 Main St, Watertown, MA 02472; or Fund for Armenian Relief (Orphan Fund), 630 2nd Ave, NYC 10016.

title: Doctors Implant Heart Regulator in Cheney's Chest
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Doctors successfully implanted a sophisticated pacemaker and defibrillator in Vice President Dick Cheney's chest today, his medical team said. It was the third significant cardiac procedure Mr. Cheney has undergone since his election as vice president.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: FIVE QUARTERS OF THE ORANGE

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on June 17 about prices at rest stops on New Jersey's toll roads misstated the cost of gasoline on the New Jersey Turnpike. The average price is similar to what is charged at nearby service stations off the turnpike, not 5 cents a gallon higher.

title: A Dangerous Pursuit of Beauty, in Life and on the Screen
description: IN both his art and his life, the director Sergei Paradjanov embraced beauty and extravagance and did not shy away from the outrageous. He lavished fanciful hats and dolls and collages he had crafted on his friends. He was fond of telling people that he was the only Soviet filmmaker to have been imprisoned under Stalin, Brezhnev and Andropov.

title: For a Legend, a Night of Good Vibrations
description: ACOLYTES in the cult of Brian Wilson may be disappointed to hear that his favorite Beach Boys song is ''California Girls.'' In a recent telephone interview he reserved his strongest praise for that bouncy ode to fringe-bikini-wearing beauties.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Robert Royston; Happy Feet
description: THE dancer-teacher Robert Royston insists that anyone (anyone) can learn to dance. ''Everyone, deep inside, they have rhythm,'' he said Wednesday night. ''Sometimes it's been repressed for so many years, you have to go deep to dig it out.''

title: Stones on Her Skin: Is This the 92nd Street Y?
description: WHEN you think of the 92nd Street Y, which of the following comes to mind?

title: BackTalk; A Day at the Races Offers a Checkup As Another Pit Stop
description: I had my body in line for a free checkup at Pfizer's traveling men's health inspection station last Memorial Day weekend when I started talking to Phil Koon, a 41-year-old tool-and-die maker. This was the day before the Coca Cola 600 in Concord, N.C. Like a lot of Nascar fans, Koon hadn't seen a doctor for preventive maintenance in years. Other men waiting with us said their companies tested their blood annually, but mostly for drug use.

title: Suing for the Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Parasites in Prt--Porter
description: On a Sunday afternoon, the Omotesando neighborhood in Tokyo swarms with women in their 20's and 30's. They spill out of stores with bags marked Gucci, Jil Sander, Issey Miyake, Comme des Garons. They crowd cafes and snack on coffee and cake specials. They finger sleek tchotchkes on the shelves of home design stores, occasionally shouting, ''Kawaaaaaiiiii!'' the compliment supreme, which means, essentially, ''cuuuuuuute!'' As I cross the main thoroughfare, three women in their late 20's pass by, arms linked. They are actually singing ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun.''

title: Nicklaus Clubhouse Leader at Soggy Senior Open
description: For the first 13 holes of the United States Senior Open today, Jack Nicklaus struggled. At three over par for the round, he was on the verge of disappearing in another major championship, outplayed again by competitors he had soundly defeated in his prime. He looked his 61 years.

title: Status Quo on Social Security
description: President Bush has talked a lot about giving working Americans more control over their Social Security contributions, perhaps by letting them invest some of that money in stocks. He has even appointed a commission to study the issue. But it seems that a large number of people like things just the way they are.

title: June 24-30; NATO Acts in Macedonia
description: The worsening crisis in Macedonia drew in NATO troops for the first time, in an unplanned evacuation of ethnic Albanian rebels from the town they held within shelling range of Skopje, the Macedonian capital. NATO officials sold the intervention as a one-time effort aimed at removing the threat to the capital and jump-starting peace talks, between minority Albanians, who make up roughly one third of the population, and Macedonian Slavs. But the Macedonian Slavs took to the streets to protest an operation they saw as aiding the rebels. Complicating matters in Washington, the NATO troops were entirely U.S. soldiers, now under the direction of a president who has not been keen on extending America's reach in the Balkans. Ian Fisher

title: The Week in Review: June 24-30
description: U.N. Confronts AIDS

title: The Way We Live Now: The Ethicist; Lax Behavior
description: My son's lacrosse team was being bused home from a game. When a rival school's women's lacrosse team pulled alongside, two boys in the back of the bus mooned them. The coach ordered the entire team to sign a letter of apology. I have encouraged my son not to sign: he was not responsible for the deed or even aware it was occurring, and these incidents can come back to haunt one later in life. Your comments? - Laura Marcusa, Ridgewood, N.J.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: GEORGE M. COHAN was ''just a song-and-dance man,'' as he declares in Michael Curtiz's YANKEE DOODLE DANDY (1942), but some of his songs are patriotic classics. James Cagney, who won the best actor Oscar for playing Cohan, performs some of the man's best work, including the title song (about ''a real-live nephew of my Uncle Sam''), ''You're a Grand Old Flag'' and ''Over There'' (a goose-bump-producing group rendition), in this charming if predictable biography. Cohan enters show business as part of his Irish-American parents' vaudeville act, gets into constant trouble because of his arrogance, becomes the king of Broadway and receives the congressional Medal of Honor -- Wednesday at 3 p.m on TCM.

title: At Lunchtime, Tin Is Gold Again
description: Forget those insulated-canvas zip-up lunchboxes with geeky monograms. This summer, lunchboxes are turning back to tin -- and children heading to day camp will have something to clank about. In an attempt to recapture the trend that put those familiar clasp-shut boxes over the 120 million mark by the 70's, manufacturers are once again peddling metal, albeit in some new shapes and sizes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 17 about the American Fashion Awards presentation at Avery Fisher Hall on June 14 misspelled the name of a writer for People magazine who was a guest. He is Steven Cojocaru, not Cojaracu.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday on the global tradeoffs in the fight against AIDS referred incompletely to the multibillion-dollar AIDS fund proposed by the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan. The fund is also intended to address malaria and tuberculosis.

title: Making the Calls Everyone Hates
description: WITH Communists now as scarce as flat earth theorists, politicians have turned twitchy to find someone -- anyone -- to keep us safe from.

title: Up From Bridgeport
description: BIG AS LIFE

title: Mets Seeking Turnaround Minus Big Guns
description: ATLANTA, June 30  It would be a stretch to say that the Mets reached the second half of their season in turmoil. There was drama in the tensions that erupted between Bobby Valentine and Darryl Hamilton on Friday, when the Mets played their 81st game, but Hamilton's status does not greatly affect the team.

title: Back to the Shore for Bacons
description: The Bacon Brothers are spending at least part of the Fourth of July holiday where they spent summer weekends in their youth, the Jersey Shore. Kevin and Michael Bacon, who are Philadelphia natives, and their band will be playing at 8 p.m. Thursday at the Ocean City Music Pier. Kevin Bacon, whose extensive movie rsum has made him the subject of a parlor game connecting him to nearly every actor, has joined his brother, Michael, a composer and performer, to play live pop and rock. The Bacons, whose father, Edmund, is a former Philadelphia city planner, will be performing with Paul Guzzone on bass, Marshal Rosenberg on percussion, Frank Vilardi on drums and Ira Siegel on electric guitar. Robert Strauss

title: Streetscapes/89th Street and Broadway; In a 1916 Astor Building, a Private Garden Grows
description: IN May they're nice, in June they're good -- but in July they are outstanding,'' Annick Cooper, president of the co-op board at Astor Court, said of the plantings at the 1916 building at 89th Street and Broadway. The co-op has a sophisticated facade designed by Charles Platt for the Astor family and a colorful interior private garden that is rare for a large Manhattan building.

title: Introduction
description: The cover article on severe food allergies extracted dozens of war stories from parents who are continuously battling ''wholesome poisons.'' Other readers parsed our profile of Joseph Lieberman, the Connecticut senator with presidential aspirations, for signs of anti-Semitism.

title: Computer Associates: 2 Widely Diverging Views
description: ERIC R. SKELL recalls the two years he worked as a network systems administrator for Computer Associates as a low point in his career.

title: The Allergy Prison
description: I hope your article will convince people that food allergies are serious and can be life threatening. Family and friends have accused me of overreacting when I tell them that my son cannot touch (and certainly not eat) even a trace of forbidden foods. Now, if only you had included a recipe for an egg-free, butter-free, milk-free cake (with frosting) for his upcoming birthday!

title: Where Does History Stand on the Last Stand?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Timeless Tact Helps Sustain A Literary Time Traveler
description: My writing desk is a tankard-scoured tavern table that once saw service in an 18th-century inn. When I look up, the waved and bubbled window panes of my study offer a view that has changed very little in the 200 years since the glass was set in place. A small paddock rises gently to an apple orchard, the trees laced with white blossoms. An elderly stallion flicks at flies with a long, supple tail.

title: Paris Stores Expand To Lure New Clientele
description: PARIS  With men ever more conscious about their clothes and their appearance, department stores here, eager to get in on the action, are refurbishing and expanding their men's stores.

title: Wohlers Gets a Feel For Playing in the Bronx
description: Mark Wohlers said it was not until he shook hands with his teammates after yesterday's game that he realized he was a Yankee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOTZ, NORMAN I.
description: STOTZ-Norman I. June 29, age 70. Born Pittsburgh, PA. Graduated Lehigh University, 1953. Singer, actor, humorist, polymath, distinguished member and officer of NYC Audubon Society. Survived by his cousins Virginia Stotz of Manhattan, Alice Diehl of Annville, PA, Jane Matz of Traverse City, MI, David Stotz of Charlotte, NC, his niece Nancy Larson of Far Hills, NJ, his nephews William Stotz of Westland, MI, and Ted Stotz of San Diego, CA. Donations in his memory may be made to NYC Audubon Society, 71 West 23rd St, NY, NY 10010

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEARN, DANIEL J.
description: FEARN-Daniel J. On July 1, 2001, of Garden City, NY. Loving husband of Helen Bishell. Beloved father of Daniel J. Fearn Jr. and his wife Kirsten. Devoted grandfather of Hilary Ballesteros, Erik, Eva and Ian. Also survived by four great-grandchildren and Helen's children Neil T. Chapman and Nancy Grayston Chapman and grandchildren Nancy G. Worsham and James Chapman Worsham. Memorial service on Tuesday, July 10, at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, at 10 AM.

title: Reach for Snack Turns Fatal As Girl, 9, Finds a Handgun
description: A 9-year-old Bronx girl, reaching for a peanut butter jar to prepare an early-morning snack, instead picked up a .22-caliber handgun atop a kitchen cabinet and accidentally shot herself in the chest, the police said. The girl, Taniqua Hall, died shortly afterward.

title: Cheney Returns to Work With Pacemaker
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  Vice President Dick Cheney returned to work at the White House today, saying he felt "pretty good" two days after doctors successfully implanted a sophisticated pacemaker and defibrillator in his chest.

title: On Television; 'Six Feet Under,' a morbid new comedy, tugs at HBO's evolving identity.
description: IS ''Six Feet Under,'' the dark new HBO comedy about a family in the undertaking business, ready to stake a claim as successor to ''The Sopranos'' and ''Sex and the City'' as the next breakthrough, high-quality, award-worthy hit series for that cable network?

title: On Land and Sea, Florida Plans For Turmoil After Castro's Death
description: Hours after images of President Fidel Castro's near collapse recently while making a speech flashed across television screens, the Miami Police Department went on alert, bracing for the possibility of a large and emotional public reaction here if the Cuban leader became incapacitated or died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, ABIGAIL JANA
description: BRODSKY-Abigail Jana, March 14, 1991-June 30, 2001. Precious daughter of Ronni Mann and David Brodsky. Cherished sister to Jacob and Emma. Beloved family member to Eli, Gertrude, Jack, Vivian, Philip, Lynne, Lou, Marje and Mary. Your beautiful face and spirit will live on forever in our hearts. You will always be an inspiration to those who knew you and to countless families touched by Rett Syndrome. Memorial contributions may be made to the International Rett Syndrome Association Research Fund, 9121 Piscataway Rd., #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, LUCILLE
description: RICHMAN-Lucille. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Amy Mayer, Lenore Sirner and Ilene Richman. Dear motherin-law of Melvin Sirner. Cherished grandmother of Laurel and Jonathan Hecht, Rebecca and Marci Mayer, Gabrielle, Abigail and Ari Sirner. Proud great-grandmother of Jessica and Sophie. Funeral service Monday, July 2, 12 noon at the Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapel, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, NY. For information call 1-800-624-8282.

title: No Affinity for Trees, but a Nature Crusader Nonetheless
description: HE was never exactly Mr. Outdoors.

title: Donating Blood: Willing but Unable
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Reportedly Weighing An End to Honeywell Bid
description: General Electric may officially abandon its proposed acquisition of Honeywell International today, withdrawing its application for approval of the deal from European regulators before they can formally block it, executives close to the companies said.

title: Roy Longmore Dies; Australian 'Legend,' 107
description: Roy Longmore, who was proclaimed a legendary figure by the Australian government last year as one of the nation's last surviving veterans of the World War I battle at Gallipoli, died on June 21 at a nursing home in Melbourne. He was 107.

title: A Certain Age, Uncertain Income
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Say They, Not U.S., Will Try 11 in '96 Bombing
description: Saudi Arabia's interior minister said today that 11 of the 13 Saudis indicted by the United States about 10 days ago in connection with the truck bombing of the Khobar Towers apartments in 1996 were in prison in the kingdom and that the case would be referred to Saudi, but not American, courts soon.

title: Thunderstorms Fell Trees and Delay Flights
description: Lightening, gusty winds and heavy rains swept through the region yesterday with thunderstorms that arrived in two waves, leaving fallen trees and power wires and flooded roads in parts of New Jersey and New York. The fast-moving but severe weather caused delays at the three major airports -- Kennedy, Newark and La Guardia -- ranging from 15 minutes to three hours, officials said. Sgt. John Mariano, a spokesman for the Port Authority Police, said lightening prompted most of the delays.

title: Sports of The Times; Kidd Putting Big Mistake Behind Him
description: AT one point during the Sydney Olympics last year, the United States basketball team went to breakfast in its quarters and discovered that a dozen roses had been placed on each of the tables there. Jason Kidd had arranged the floral display to celebrate the birthday of his wife, Joumana, who had accompanied him.

title: INSIDE
description: New Challenge for Ulster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLWEISS, NATHAN M.
description: ALLWEISS-Nathan M. On Friday June 29, 2001, Nathan M. Allweiss in Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Ida Mae Allweiss and the late Mary and Tilly Allweiss. Devoted father of Sharon (Louis) Fanelli, Judith (Irwin) Herskowitz, Helaine Schilling, Vicki (Sidney) Irgang and Irwin (Fay) Gold. Loving brother of Frances Clair, Toby Pinck and Edith Niesen. Also survived by 14 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren. Graveside service was at Judean Memorial Gardens, Olney, MD. Memorial contributions may be made to Alzheimers Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAHRBURG, DOROTHEA G.
description: WAHRBURG-Dorothea G. Beloved wife of the late David. Cherished mother of Jane Wahrburg and William and Ronnie Wahrburg. Devoted grandmother of Lara and Eric. Loving sister of Jean Klepper, Shirley Gitlin and the late Larry Goodman. Services Monday, 12 noon, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: A Weak Summer, but a Faith, Based in Part on a Company Name
description: The Walt Disney Company is not having the brightest of summers. First, its hoped-for blockbuster film ''Pearl Harbor'' got bombed by critics and faded fast at the box office. Then the public all but shrugged at the arrival of the Disney animation ''Atlantis'' -- even as rival DreamWorks' computer-animated ''Shrek'' was turning into a summer hit.

title: Albert the Great Lives Up to His Weight
description: It turned out that the Suburban Handicap was far more competitive last week, before it was ever run. The trainer Nick Zito frowned when he learned that his Albert the Great would carry the most weight, 123 pounds, in the 115th running of the Grade II Suburban yesterday at Belmont Park. Zito's fellow trainer, Buddy Delp, countered that his colt, Include, assigned 122 pounds, should have been spotted more than a pound and would have been if the race were contested anywhere but Belmont, Zito's and Albert the Great's home court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, RABBI MORDECHAI
description: BERKOWITZ-Rabbi Mordechai. The Bialystoker Synagogue mourns the passing of its distinguished member Rabbi Mordechai Berkowitz, Rabbi Emeritus of the HILI Synagogue in Far Rockaway.

title: In Year of Florida Vote, Supreme Court Also Did Much Other Work
description: The year the court picked the president: the Supreme Court's 2000-2001 term will always be known as that, and undoubtedly, in the view of many people, it will be remembered for that extraordinary event alone.

title: Sampras's Reign at Wimbledon Is Over
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2  There was the solitary figure of Pete Sampras, with a bag slung over his shoulder and flip-flops on his feet, cutting through a courtyard outside the locker room, where several players milled about.

title: Rulings Represent the First Check on Mahathir Regime in a Decade : Judicial Bravery Startles Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR  A series of high-profile court rulings against the government recently has surprised lawyers in Malaysia and has provided the first significant legal check on the administration of Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad in more than a decade.

title: Getting the Charity Debate Back on Track
description: President Bush is busy this week trying to save his plan to expand government financing of charitable work by religious groups. But now that the proposal is being renegotiated, gutting it of much of its uniqueness, maybe it's time to figure out whether there is a better way to help nonprofit organizations do their work.

title: Star Witness Against Microsoft Finds a Wary Vindication
description: On the bookshelves in Steven McGeady's third- floor study are a small sign and a mock license plate. The sign says ''Why be normal?'' and the license plate reads ''Unix: Live Free or Die.''

title: The Rights of Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Certain Age, Uncertain Income
description: To the Editor:

title: A Text Message That Simply Spells Romance
description: PARIS  Like a text message between two young lovers  Romeo and Juliet with cell phones  the words were printed on a peach-colored shirt, white Levis or flowered pants: "You break my heart;" "You make me happy." Or, on a black T-shirt, worn with plaid pants and sneakers, the universal message of "love, love, love."

description: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, FLORENCE GRUBER
description: SCHWARTZ - Florence Gruber. Wife of the late Louis, mother of George and James, beloved grandmother of Sarah, sister of Herbert and the late Ruth, on June 30, 2001. Services July 3, 11:30 AM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave., NYC. Donations to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation.

title: Charlottesville Journal; Cry That Debts Repaid Fell Due Again
description: ''I honestly thought they were calling me in to tell me I got a raise,'' said Mary Smith, one of nine workers who were dismissed from their jobs in May by the University of Virginia Medical Center after a hospital rape scandal caused officials to vet files for workers admitting to criminal records.

title: No Lawless Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

description: BEDOUKIAN-Paul Zareh. Age 89, of Wilton, CT, on Friday, June 29. Renowned chemist, author, numismatist. Beloved husband of Vicki and loving father of Joan, Betty and Robert. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at St. Gregory's Armenian Church, White Plains, NY. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Armenian Library and Museum of America, 65 Main St, Watertown, MA 02472; or Fund for Armenian Relief (Orphan Fund), 630 2nd Ave, NYC 10016.

title: Miami Herald's Editor Named to Top Post at Boston Globe
description: Martin Baron, the executive editor of The Miami Herald, has been named editor of The Boston Globe.

title: Promenade at East River Park Is Closed Indefinitely for Repairs
description: A popular parkside promenade running along the East River for more than a mile on Manhattan's Lower East Side has been closed indefinitely for structural repairs, depriving Fourth of July celebrants of a waterfront site for watching fireworks this week, as well as joggers, bikers and strollers who use it daily.

title: MediaTalk; CNN Chairman Resigns, Without the Spin
description: For months, people inside and outside CNN had predicted that the network's chairman, Tom Johnson, would not be long for his position. After all, CNN's ratings continued to sag. And CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting System, had just come under the stewardship of a new executive, Jamie Kellner.

title: It's Raining Tigers and Dragons; Asian Filmmakers Rush to Repeat an Oscar Winner's Success
description: In the copycat world of cinema, it was inevitable that someone would try to replicate the success of ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' Ang Lee's romantic martial arts epic.

title: Article 2001070293723573220 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Northern Ireland Paramilitary Groups Ignore Disarmament Deadline
description: LONDON, July 2  The international commission responsible for the disarming of Northern Ireland's paramilitary groups said today that the Irish Republican Army had passed the July 1 deadline for weapons moves without taking any steps to dismantle its arsenal or to indicate how it planned to do so.

title: For City Council's Top Republican, a Bright Political Future Darkens
description: The setting for the fund-raiser was elegant but not overly so, a loft and rooftop patio at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, with an open bar and shrimp hors d'oeuvres.

title: New Economy; Selling a Vision Of the Future Beyond Folders
description: The fawning introducers burbled. The rock music blared. And out of the wings of the vast auditorium at PC Expo, New York's glitziest high-technology trade show, walked the computer scientist David Gelernter.

title: Article 2001070291184645684 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version
