description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Sampras's Reign at Wimbledon Ends
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2  There was the solitary figure of Pete Sampras, with a bag slung over his shoulder and flip-flops on his feet, cutting through a courtyard outside the locker room, where several players milled about.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: New Players and New Coach Renew Mexico's Hopes
description: Mexico is a country that celebrates rebirth, the survival of its dreams and legends, during chaotic modernity.

title: After Patients' Rights: Vast Needs, Higher Hurdles
description: The patients' rights legislation that cleared the Senate last week is the product of five years of struggle to overcome intense industry opposition and brutal partisan maneuvering. But in the world of health policy, this was supposed to be the easy one.

title: Law Firms Cut Partners In Slowdown
description: Last year was a banner year for many law firms, but an increasing number of partners did not partake directly of the profits.

title: The Airmen and Women Who Made a Leap of Faith
description: In nearly 100 years air travel has evolved from flying too high with some guy in the sky to waiting too long with a throng at the wrong airport with nothing to do. If you'd like a bit more detail, the history of commercial aviation has been distilled into a four-part documentary, ''Chasing the Sun,'' which begins tonight on PBS. Often fascinating though occasionally ponderous, the film ultimately feels like your usual airline trip. It gets you safely from Point A to Point B without a great deal of excitement. Still, you may get a kick out of it.

title: Welfare's Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Message Is the Medium
description: Under the headquarters roof held up by the Seven Dwarfs, Michael D. Eisner is nervous.

title: Nickelodeon's Bilingual Cartoon 'Dora' Is a Hit
description: When Nickelodeon started three shows with Latino themes over the last year, officials said they wanted to reflect the world children lived in. All the shows, the first of their kind for the cable network, have done well but the big hit features as its star a 7-year-old Hispanic girl who speaks both English and Spanish and lives in a fantasy world -- that of cartoons.

title: Book Returns Rise, Signaling A Downturn In the Market
description: Book publishers are once again facing a rising tide of unsold books returning from bookstores, a painful phenomenon that just a few years ago became severe enough to cause a crisis in the industry and widespread cutbacks in the publication of new books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, NETTIE
description: KLEIN-Nettie. On July 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Al. Loving mother of Rheba Rosenbluth and Stanley Klein. Dear sister of Manny Roberts. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Joshua, David and Heather. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOWAN, GERARD J., SR.
description: McGOWAN-Gerard J., Sr. Of Mount Vernon, NY, on July 1, 2001. Husband of May Hughes McGowan. Father of Gerard McGowan Jr., Barbara McGowan Lee, Susan McGowan Holleran. Brother of Vincent E. McGowan. Grandfather of Michelle and Thomas Holleran and Tiffany and Christopher Lee. Father-in-law of John Lee III and Thomas Holleran. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Sts. Peter and Paul Church, Fleetwood, Tuesday, July 3, at 10 AM.

title: Article 2001070291444335240 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: MediaTalk; Group Says Fox Has a Right-Wing Slant
description: The momentum Fox News Channel is enjoying is causing considerable chagrin to some liberal groups, disturbed by what they call its decidedly conservative bent.

title: A Sophisticated Square Dance, Called by Tharp
description: Twyla Tharp's new ''Westerly Round,'' performed on Saturday afternoon at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here, is hard to know but easy to love, the choreographic equivalent of a mirror ball that throws off imagery as well as glints of light.

title: Janitors' Union and Contractors Reach a Deal
description: After months of trying to organize thousands of janitors in North Jersey, labor union officials have achieved a breakthrough by gaining an agreement that grants union recognition and substantially higher wages to 500 workers in Hudson County.

title: Compressed Data; Site That Monitors Exercise Is Running on Wobbly Legs
description: The concept was straightforward: create an Internet community of people who use belt-clip fitness monitors that measure workouts one step at a time, awarding points for each step. But the company behind the idea, SportBrain, may have stepped its last.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Danbury: School Harassment Charged
description: The mother of two girls attending Roberts Avenue Elementary School has filed a lawsuit against school officials contending that they neglected to stop sexual assaults by a fourth-grade boy despite repeated complaints. Joseph Secola, the lawyer representing the family, said post-traumatic stress disorder, as a result of harassment spanning two school years, had been diagnosed in the girls. Bobby J. Poole, chairman of the Board of Education, said school officials were reviewing the case.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Independence Fete In Chinatown
description: In what organizers described as the first parade of its kind, Chinatown yesterday staged a celebration of the Fourth of July and the Declaration of Independence. Hundreds gathered along the parade route, winding from Division Street to Chatham Square to Mott Street. ''Every time there's a parade down here, people think it's got something to do with the old country,'' said Steven Ting, a parade organizer. ''We want to show everybody that the Chinese and Asians are as patriotic as other Americans.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONHEIM, MARTA S.
description: BRONHEIM-Marta S. Beloved wife of Bert. Mother of Joan and Gary. Mother-in-law of Jim and Ellen. Adoring grandmother of Lindsey, Melanie and Seth. Donations to Women's American ORT.

title: Mobil Is Faulted for Payments in Central Asia
description: An internal inquiry conducted by the Mobil Corporation before its merger with Exxon in 1999 found that the company had paid more than a billion dollars to foreign companies in connection with arrangements in Russia and Kazakhstan that had no apparent business purpose, The New Yorker magazine reported this week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'll never forget studying documents while hearing the loudspeaker saying 'Two Whoppers to go, a shake and fries.'''

title: A Grand Plan Meets Skepticism in Mexico's South
description: Miguel Lpez, a peasant farmer, stood on an empty railroad track, glancing up from his muddy boots. He looked a tad skeptical about President Vicente Fox's vision of factories sprouting from this rich farmland, filling freight trains roaring down this rickety line.

title: Supreme Court Term: Beyond Bush v. Gore
description: The Supreme Court's 2000-2001 term will always be known to many as the year the judiciary picked the president. But in all, 79 decisions were issued, providing a report card on the elected branches and on the balance of the court itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINN, TED
description: ZINN-Ted. New York City Audubon Society notes with profound regret the passing of our past Board member and longtime contributor of superb nature articles to the ''Urban Audubon.''

title: After a Late Night Out, King Rallies
description: Almost all the golfers had left the site of the ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic on Saturday night, and women in evening gowns were entering the Seaview Marriott Resort to socialize. Dusk was turning into darkness, but Betsy King was out by the practice green, working on her chipping.

title: Rent a Tape, Buy a Disc
description: It has been evident since the rollout of the DVD movie format four years ago that pricing and distribution of the discs are creating a business distinct from the VHS videocassette market. Now, data from Adams Media Research, which tracks the video market, makes clear just how wide the gulf is.

title: Metro Matters; Ideology? Well, Who's To Judge?
description: WHILE New York waited for its mayor to finally say good night to Gracie, its senior senator was promoting an idea last week that could reform Washington, or split the Republican-Democratic rift wide open.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the American Indian writer Jamake Highwater on June 16 by The Associated Press misstated the given name of the travel publisher who commissioned Mr. Highwater to write ''Fodor's Indian America.'' He was Eugene Fodor, not Arthur.

title: A Coney Island Kind of Fun
description: Something about the seashore lends itself to nostalgia -- something to do with childhood memories, or the ceaseless murmur of the waves, or maybe too much sun.

title: Essay; The New Patriotism
description: My compatriots:

title: Sofitel Offers Summer Rates and Air Miles
description: Sofitel has doubled its frequent-flier mileage bonus to 1,000 miles per stay, good through Sept. 4 at 130 hotels worldwide. Miles are on American or Air France. This bonus is in addition to reduced summer rates at several hotels. In the United States, rates are now $119 to $269 (versus $149 to $399) at the Sofitels in New York (the priciest), Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Minneapolis, Miami and Philadelphia (the cheapest). Rates are per room and include breakfast and local taxes; one child under age 12 can stay in a parent's room for free. Similar discounts apply at Sofitels in Paris, Tokyo and Melbourne, among other cities. Information: (800) 763-4835.

title: Four Villages Are Seized By the Rebels In Macedonia
description: Albanian rebels in Macedonia have taken control of four villages in the western part of the country, not far from the border with Kosovo, an army spokesman said today, and are apparently preparing for a new fight with government forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, HAWLEY COHEN
description: LEVENSON-Hawley Cohen. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York extends its heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Board member, Mark Levenson, on the loss of his mother. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ezra G. Levin, Pres. Michael S. Miller, Exec. V.P.

title: MediaTalk; Striking up the Band, Despite Tough Times
description: The Internet bubble has burped, but that doesn't mean that The Industry Standard, the newly redesigned once-proud bible of the Internet economy, can't string up some lights in the barn and be host to a star-studded technology conference as it did in the good times.

title: E-Commerce Report; Internet ads, considered a 'creative wasteland,' are starting to get more attention.
description: SINCE the birth of the commercial Internet, publishers and online marketers have grumbled about the dearth of good advertising. Even the best ad agencies, they complained, were churning out work that looked as if it had been done by the custodial staff, rather than top designers.

title: Donating Blood: Willing but Unable
description: To the Editor:

title: Meddling With the City's Charter
description: When Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appoints a commission to revise the New York City Charter, as he did a few weeks ago, a little healthy skepticism is in order for two reasons -- his 1998 charter commission and his 1999 charter commission.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Advertising; The upfront market for TV time gets curiouser and curiouser with CBS's claims on performance.
description: AS the broadcast television networks suffer a substantial decline in the amount of money coming in as they finish selling commercials ahead of the fall prime-time season, a vituperative dispute has erupted over the success or failure of the risky strategy that one network, CBS, pursued in negotiating with the media agencies that make the buying decisions.

title: Donating Blood: Willing but Unable
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the American Indian writer Jamake Highwater on June 16 by The Associated Press misstated the given name of the travel publisher who commissioned Mr. Highwater to write "Fodor's Indian America." He was Eugene Fodor, not Arthur.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: United Airlines Abandons Merger With US Airways

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Police Lineups Unchanged
description: Justice Steven Lloyd Barrett of State Supreme Court in the Bronx declined last week to change a traditional tool of police work: the lineup. In the case of a 16-year-old suspected of assault, the teenager's lawyer, David Feige, argued that a lineup where a witness views suspects one at a time, instead of all at once, can reduce false identifications by more than 50 percent. Although such a procedure may be an improvement, Justice Barrett wrote, police procedures should be determined by lawmakers or administrators, not by the courts.

title: In 3 Million Pounds of History, Views of Day-to-Day New York
description: Of all the remarkable things about New York City's Municipal Archives, the most extraordinary, by far, is its very survival.

title: Ships and Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROULET, JEAN
description: ROULET - Jean. Elaine still grieves. We understand. Joanmarie and Suzann

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY: Personal Income, May

title: A Certain Age, Uncertain Income
description: To the Editor:

title: Monet's Haystacks Ignite Bidding at Sotheby's in London
description: For what seemed like an endless nine minutes, the audience at Sotheby's here on Tuesday night was tense with excitement as five bidders fought for one of Monet's ''Haystack'' paintings. As the price rose and the competition stiffened, gasps were heard throughout the salesroom. The painting, which had a high estimate of $10 million, eventually sold for $14.2 million; it was the highest price ever paid for a work in this famous series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RABBI IRA
description: EISENSTEIN-Rabbi Ira. You taught us the true meaning of devotion and we are grateful. Mel Scult

title: In Churches, Candidates Call For Black Voters to Respond
description: On his first foray to a predominantly black church in New York City, Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire businessman and novice political candidate, learned at least one lesson yesterday: ''It is very different than temple,'' Mr. Bloomberg joked as he left the service at Memorial Baptist Church in Harlem.

title: Americans Finally Lose in Cup Qualifying
description: After a run of regional domination by the United States in the first five games of the round-robin tournament, World Cup qualifying slowed to a more realistic pace over the weekend.

title: Crew of Listing Bush Ship Draws Republican Scowls
description: Many prominent Republicans who once marveled at the Bush administration's agility say the president's lieutenants are increasingly stumbling in ways that are not merely embarrassing but also perilous to Mr. Bush's political standing.

title: New York City Tops In All-Star Game
description: A fourth-quarter interception by Holy Cross's Victor Parsley at his team's 10-yard line in the final minute enabled New York City to hold on for a 17-10 victory over Long Island in the Outback Steakhouse Empire Challenge all-star game Saturday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, N.Y.

title: China's Leader Urges Opening Communist Party to Capitalists
description: China's president and Communist Party general secretary, Jiang Zemin, marked the 80th birthday of the party today by declaring that private business owners and other members of China's increasingly diverse society ought to be allowed to join.

title: Article 2001070292171044061 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Dark Streets, Stolen Goods And a Hard-Bitten Dame
description: FEARLESS JONES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed In Machete Attack
description: A 55-year-old Brooklyn man was charged with murder yesterday after he slashed his girlfriend to death with a machete, the police said. The man, Winston McKenzie, was arrested about 6:30 a.m. yesterday at the apartment at 376 Amboy Street that he shared with the victim, Doreen Harriott, 36. Ms. Harriott was found dead in the hallway of the apartment. The police recovered a machete that they believe was used in the killing. It was unclear what motivated the attack, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes in Media
description: Rebecca Hill was named to the new post of international marketing manager at National Geographic magazine, Paris, owned by the National Geographic Society. She had been senior European media planner at the Media Planning Group France, Paris, part of Havas Advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARTH, FLORENCE
description: SWARTH-Florence. On July 1. Beloved wife of David, mother of Kenneth Jay, Amy Dee, and Peter Carl, grandmother of Brian Daniel & Kimberly Jill. Services private.

title: A Diva Who Holds Fans In the Palm of Her Hand
description: ''Well, she certainly can still command an audience,'' said a tickled woman leaving Carnegie Hall after Nina Simone's brief but riveting performance on Thursday night as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. The fan meant it literally. The crowd was crunched into the exits because the 69-year-old Ms. Simone had hushed its loud demands for a second encore with an admonishment to go home, and everyone had instantly complied.

title: A CHANGING WORLD IS FORCING CHANGES ON MANAGED CARE
description: The backlash against managed health care that pushed a patients' bill of rights to the top of the political agenda in Washington has already forced important changes in medical care for millions of Americans.

title: Lewis L. Coriell, 90, Virologist Who Set Stage for Polio Vaccine
description: Dr. Lewis L. Coriell, a virologist who helped create the technology used to develop the polio vaccine and who founded the Coriell Institute for Medical Research, died on June 19 in Camden, N.J. He was 90.

title: Mets Offense Still Asleep, but Appier Is the Great Equalizer Against Atlanta
description: Kevin Appier is a perfectionist, which is a hard role to play in baseball. Too much failure, too many variables. But Appier strives for perfection, and as a Mets pitcher, he almost needs it to win.

title: Flaws Seen In Effort to Fill Police Class
description: The New York Police Department, laboring to find qualified candidates for the Police Academy class that will be sworn in today, took some aggressive measures, including asking immigration officials to expedite the citizenship process for dozens of candidates.

title: Charter Removes ESPNews From Some Cable Systems in Dispute
description: For years, technology experts have speculated about what the Internet could mean for the television industry. They may want to ask sports fans in about 250,000 households who buy cable television service from Charter Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SALLY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sally. July 1, 2001, at age 85. Beloved wife of the late Victor Goldstein. Adoring mother of Andrew Goldstein. Caring mother-in-law of Gillian Jolis. The family will be receiving from 6 to 9 PM, July 3, 2001, at 87 Jericho Rd., East Hampton, NY. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the East Hampton Health Care Foundation, PO Box 4184, East Hampton, NY 11937.

title: Light-Speed Loft Renovation
description: Dan Rhatigan evinces a mixture of modesty and pride when he talks about the large number of superhero action figures he has amassed over the years. "I'm not a serious collector," he demurs, when queried about the various displays throughout his loft in East Williamsburg. But in the next breath, the thirty-year-old graphic designer and computer technician betrays unmistakable enthusiasm as he points to a row of female warriors standing guard over the stove, saying, "They're my kitchen goddesses  the super-powered women who look after me."

title: Robinson Finds Game After a Subpar Season
description: Ask Crystal Robinson about tennis and she opens up. Robinson, the Liberty's private and reserved forward, will lean in close and capture her listener with her eyes to make sure she is being followed.

title: A Certain Age, Uncertain Income
description: To the Editor:

title: London Journal; Writer, Actor, M.P. (and a Reliable Source of Spice)
description: With scandal-prone celebrities off on vacation and out of the public eye, summer can be a cruel season for Britain's tabloids.

title: Five Teams at European Event Win the Right to Play in Bali
description: The two United States teams due to compete in the Bermuda Bowl at the 2001 world championships in Bali, Indonesia, in October will face a strong challenge. Five powerful groups qualified for the Bermuda Bowl at the European Championships that ended on Saturday in Tenerife, the Canary Islands. Italy came in first with 647 victory points, followed by Norway, 639; Poland, 624; Russia, 616.5; and Israel, 594. Denmark, sixth with 592, and France, seventh with 590, just failed to qualify. More information is available at e-bridgemaster.com

title: Connecting Dots, Linking to Roots; In Caribbean Enclaves, Dominoes Are a Summer Fixture
description: Hermanos Unidos brims with the usual stuff of a Dominican sports club on a Friday night: beer so cold the bottles sweat in the air-conditioned air, a frenzy of merengue on the speakers, the boastful racket of middle-aged men released from their jobs.

title: Article 2001070290130443463 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: The Real Justice Thomas
description: To the Editor:

title: A Healthy Testaverde Is Set to Face Challenges
description: There came a point last year when it would have been useful to consult ''Gray's Anatomy'' when discussing Vinny Testaverde. In a season of transition and tumult, Testaverde was something of a piata, a sitting duck for both physical and psychological bruises, until the season fell in chunks at his feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOLAR, RABBI MICHAEL
description: SCHOLAR-Rabbi Michael. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Jeffrey Sinensky, President

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Dawn Kelly, Jaredd Mooney, Jessie Kremidas and Nate Peterkin, Perkins School for the Blind, Watertown, Mass., June 7, 2001

title: U.S. and U.K. Yield on New Iraq Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 2  The United States and Britain, unwilling to force a showdown with Russia in the Security Council, decided today to give up trying to win approval now for a plan that would expand civilian trade with Iraq while narrowing its ability to smuggle out oil or bring in prohibited weapons.

title: Primedia Is Seen Announcing Emap Magazine Deal Today
description: Primedia, the publisher of New York, Modern Bride and more than 100 specialty magazines, is expected to announce today that it has acquired the United States magazine business of Emap, the British publisher.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Overrides Benefit Veto
description: The City Council has voted to override Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's veto of a law that guarantees about 152,000 retired city employees full reimbursement of their Medicare Part B premiums, a benefit already enjoyed by state retirees. The city had been fully reimbursing retirees until 1991, when the City Council did not pass the annual legislation that raised the reimbursement rate to the actual rate. Laws over the past decade have increased the rate of reimbursement, but they have not kept pace with the actual cost. The current discrepancy is $13.50 a month. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, MORRIS
description: MEYER-Morris. 82, died June 30, 2001. Beloved husband of Marion. Wonderful father to Alan and Anne, Mark and Carol, Jeff and Terri. Beloved grandfather of Joshua, Corey, Tara, Matthew, Lana, Jessica and Robert. Funeral service 1 PM, Monday, Temple Beth-Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Memorials to Hemophilia Society of NY.

title: Rusch Drops His Sinker And Revives His Form
description: In the middle of June, Glendon Rusch asked himself a fundamental question about his pitching: ''Why go out there with something mediocre when I have something better?''

title: Patents; Draw water from air, measure how much water you drink and be kind to the fish you catch.
description: SINCE the air we breathe is free, why not our water, too?

title: Publicizing Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Room for Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, GERTRUDE
description: RUBENSTEIN-Gertrude. 99 years old, of West Chester, PA, died on June 30, 2001. Gertrude was a homemaker and the wife of the late Herman Rubenstein. Beloved mother of Sonia Schwartz and the late Maxwell Rubenstein. Beloved grandmother of Hedda Rubenstein Dimenstein and David Rubenstein. Beloved great-grandmother of Daniel Dimenstein, Robert Dimenstein and Jonathan Rubenstein.

title: Mickelson Achieves A Positive Outcome
description: Phil Mickelson began the final round of the Greater Hartford Open today with a one-stroke lead, but for Mickelson that was no sure thing.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Review Of Police Searches
description: John J. Farmer Jr., the New Jersey attorney general, said last week that he would review what are known as consent searches conducted by the state police for the last few years. Police officers ask permission of drivers before they conduct a search, but critics say the method is intrinsically coercive and that three-quarters of drivers stopped are members of minority groups. The police will review tapes of roadside searches that are recorded by video cameras mounted in patrol cars.

title: Child-Death Case in Texas Raises Penalty Questions
description: The complicated case of Andrea P. Yates, the mother charged with drowning her five children in a bathtub, has raised a complicated question: In a county that has sent more people to death row than any other in the nation, will prosecutors seek the death penalty against her?

title: $4.2 Billion Hostile Bid for Italian Utility
description: Fiat of Italy and lectricit de France are planning a hostile bid for control of Italy's second-biggest utility, Montedison, in a deal worth $4.2 billion, executives close to the discussions said today.

title: Bonds Cements His Place in Giants History
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) — After taking a day off to nurse a bruised right wrist, Barry Bonds sunk his hands into wet cement outside Pacific Bell Park near where his 500th career home run splashed into San Francisco Bay.

title: Another Second Chance Leaves Fleisher in First
description: Bruce Fleisher seems to embrace second chances. A prime example is the way he has flourished on the Senior PGA Tour since his debut in 1999 with 14 victories after floundering in his first career as a professional golfer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Desolation of Desire, Divided by Four
description: Despite its rap as the hottest of the deadly sins, lust can be a chillingly lonely feeling. Especially when it's driving you to places where you're not sure you belong, where you might get lost. Just look at the faces of the sex-seeking characters in ''Four,'' Christopher Shinn's smart, brokenhearted new play at the TriBeCa Playhouse, and you'll see the desolation in desire. The flesh may be willing, but the spirit is in limbo.

title: Article 2001070290573847743 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: 'Aida' Confronts a Wild Mike System
description: Camp is an important part of opera. So it's an accolade to say that it was gloriously present in the New York Grand Opera's ''Aida,'' presented at Central Park's Summerstage on Wednesday evening. If Vincent La Selva's company were to perform this opera regularly in a theater, people might start showing up costumed as their favorite ''Aida'' character, in the vein of the sing-along ''Sound of Music.'' It had all the ingredients of a cult classic.

title: In Today's Games, Computers Must Be Faster and Stronger, Too
description: For 17 days in February 2002, an intricate empire of technology three years in the making will spring to life around Salt Lake City -- a network of 32,000 miles of fiber optic cables, 10,000 mobile phones and more than 5,000 computers.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on June 15 about summer books misstated the title of an archetypal beach book. It is ''Valley of the Dolls,'' not ''Beyond the Valley of the Dolls,'' which is an unrelated 1970 movie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, CHRISTINA W.
description: ADAMS-Christina W. On June 30, 2001. Graduate of the Hewitt School and Curry College, Milton, MA. Beloved daughter of Maryalice and Peter Adams. Sister of Monica and Daniel. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in her name to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International. For further information please call the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 212-288-3500.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From warranty troubles to warring views on Chrysler minivans, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Just About Everything's Right With the Yanks
description: There are games when the Yankees outdo even themselves in theatrics, in combining half a dozen dramas at one time, in being, well, the Yankees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military & fraternal organizations. A funeral service was held on June 27, at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, followed by private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY, on June 28. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011. May flights of angels attend her to her resting place.

title: Gene Data to Be Kept Private So Company Can Make Drugs
description: A pioneering database of human genes is now available for licensing again. But Human Genome Sciences, which controls the database, no longer plans to offer broad access to the data, the company's chairman and chief executive, William A. Haseltine, said over the weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALCOFF, HARVEY K.
description: WALCOFF-Harvey K. On June 30, 2001. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Jonathan and Andrew. Dear uncle. Funeral services Monday, 1 PM, ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Compressed Data; Group Encourages Workers to Turn In Software Pirates
description: For those who have been overlooked, slighted or perhaps even fired by an uncaring employer, an opportunity for revenge may be at hand.

title: Kenneth Lynn, 78, Hemingway Biographer
description: Kenneth Schuyler Lynn, an author, editor and educator best known for his writings on American thought and his analytical studies of Mark Twain, Charlie Chaplin and Ernest Hemingway, died June 24 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 78 and lived in Washington.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Cheney, With Heart Device Implanted, Prepares to Carry On
description: On his first full day after a heart device was implanted in his chest, Vice President Dick Cheney rested at his home and prepared to return to work at the White House early on Monday.

title: In Bronx, an Antipoverty Empire Tries to Shed a Power-Broker Past
description: Amid the cheering crowds, blaring music and billowing flags at the National Puerto Rican Day Parade three weeks ago, a quiet drama unfolded, not visible in any activity along the route. It presented itself in two absences.

title: A Certain Age, Uncertain Income
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Credit Offerings
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a 9-day cash management bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, RICHARD
description: ARMSTRONG-Richard. Of Old Tappan, NJ, died on Friday, June 29. He is survived by his wife, Virginia, his stepdaughter Jean Rettig-Carr and her husband Daniel Carr, and his granddaughter, Jessica. Burial services were private. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Pius Church, Old Tappan, on July 7, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Christophers, 12 East 48th St., NY, NY 10107 or the Hospice Program of Hackensack University Medical Center, 30 Prospect Ave., Hackensack, NJ 07601 or to a charity of your choice. Mr. Armstrong was a writer and fundraiser. He is a former director of The Christophers, and the author of ''Out to Change the World,'' a biography of James Keller, M.M., the founder of The Christophers.

title: Tech Future Is Said to Brighten
description: A new survey of chief information officers suggests that the drastic recent cuts in corporate technology budgets may be starting to end. Still, the free-spending days of last year are not likely to return soon.

title: Schrder, Like Germany, Looks Harder at the Past
description: It is a scene of modern Germany: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder in his new office opposite the Reichstag gazing in wonder at a photograph of the father he never knew, Cpl. Fritz Schrder with a Nazi swastika on his helmet.

title: United Is Said To Give Up Bid To Buy US Air
description: Facing what it believes to be intractable opposition from federal antitrust regulators, United Airlines has decided to abandon its proposed $4.3 billion takeover of US Airways, an executive at the airline said yesterday.

title: Free-Agent Market Opens But Stars Elude Rangers
description: Hockey's free-agent season opened with a flurry of important deals yesterday and the Rangers were not involved in any of them. The major trades sent goalie Dominik Hasek from Buffalo to Detroit and center Doug Weight from Edmonton to St. Louis. The Blues almost got Hasek and may still be looking for a goalie.

title: The Military Spending Crunch
description: Last week the Bush administration added a further $18 billion to its Pentagon budget request for next year, bringing the total to $329 billion. That is a lot to be spending on defense programs in a world where America confronts no superpower rivals. Yet most of the latest additions are reasonable, with the bulk of the $18 billion going for improvements in military pay, housing and health care, training and spare parts. There is also new money for additional research and testing of missile defenses.

title: Case Against Milosevic Is Not Simple to Prove
description: On Tuesday, when Slobodan Milosevic enters the court here and for the first time faces Carla Del Ponte, his United Nations prosecutor, the case against the man whom the world has seen stoke a decade of war and bloodshed in the Balkans may seem deceptively simple.

title: Big Decisions Loom for Sampras
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2  The 19-year-old challenger in the white bandana and short ponytail spanked the match-winning forehand past the champion who helplessly watched nearly a decade of dominance sail by. Then Roger Federer sank to his knees, rolled onto his side and let his emotion spill over after almost four grueling hours of keeping it contained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROTSKY, LUCY
description: GROTSKY-Lucy. On July 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Grotsky. Devoted mother of Stephen Grotsky and Connee and Barton Sadowsky. Cherished grandmother of Matthew and Brooke. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz Brothers, Forest Park Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Right at His Fingertips, A Whole World of Music
description: In the middle of ''Body and Soul'' last Monday night at Birdland, the pianist Hank Jones played a solo with such a minimum of fuss that it wasn't immediately obvious how many idioms he was juggling. A few bars were bebop, followed by a drawling blues, a stubborn little repeated riff, some refracted harmony.

title: Cult Agrees Not to Clone Human in U.S.
description: Federal regulators have inspected a laboratory run by a secretive religious sect intent on cloning a person and have obtained a written pledge from the group's lead scientist not to experiment with cloning in this country, both the scientist and the Food and Drug Administration said.

title: A Certain Age, Uncertain Income
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Leveling the Playing Field, but for Whom?
description: WASHINGTON  A NEW freshman class is about to enter the University of California, a class in which the percentage of Hispanic students leaped by 18.2 percent and the percentage of Asian-American students rose by 8.7 percent.

title: Chet Atkins, 77, Is Dead; Guitarist and Producer Was Architect of the 'Nashville Sound'
description: Chet Atkins, the versatile guitarist and record producer who was a leader in the growth of Nashville as a music center in the 1950's and part of the elite force that transformed country music and affected popular musical taste in America, died on Saturday at his home in Nashville. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTON, BURTON S. OF ENGLEWOOD
description: MANTON-Burton S. Of Englewood. Passed away at the age of 77. Beloved husband of Constance. Devoted father of June and Ronnie. Loving grandfather of Nathaniel. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle St, Englewood, on Monday, July 2, at 11 AM.

title: The Message in the Sinking Polls
description: The past two weeks have not been good ones for George W. Bush.

title: Burden Seems to Be on Japan to Salvage the Fast-Eroding Climate Treaty
description: Japan is in the driver's seat to determine whether a global climate treaty will ever take effect. And supporters of the treaty said yesterday that they were discouraged by the remarks made on Saturday by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi when he met with President Bush, a fervent opponent of the treaty.

title: The Look Matters More Than 'Riding' Skills : Tokyo's Skateboard Cool
description: TOKYO  It used to be that surfers were the Kings of Cool, whether they were the real thing, just-learning or just-wannabes. Now guys are still on boards but the scene has shifted from beachfronts to inner-city streets and the grungier, the better. Which means of course, skateboards.

title: AT&T and British Telecom Study Possible Closing of Joint Venture
description: AT&T and British Telecommunications are exploring the possibility of ending a joint venture that focuses on providing large corporations with telecommunications services, people close to the companies said yesterday.

title: Capriati and Agassi Set For Bigger Tests Ahead
description: An irritated Jennifer Capriati had turned her racket into a drumstick, beating it on the court and whacking it on her bag, coming undone against the nonthreatening Lisa Raymond.

title: Israel Kills 3 Militants and Hits Syrian Site in Lebanon
description: In a day of expanding violence, an Israeli helicopter gunship killed three Muslim militants today in a rocket attack on a car in the West Bank, hours after Israeli warplanes struck a Syrian radar station deep in Lebanon in retaliation for a guerrilla attack on Friday.

title: Ulster Leader's Resignation Shakes Fragile Government
description: First Minister David Trimble of Northern Ireland resigned his post today, casting the struggle to bring political stability to the conflicted province into uncertainty at the beginning of Ulster's most turbulent period, the Protestant marching season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, FREDA L. (NEE LEVINE)
description: ZUCKER-Freda L. (nee LeVine). Died at Verrazano Nursing Home, Staten Island, on June 30, 2001. She was 88, and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for ten years. The youngest member of the LeVine family, she survived two brothers and four sisters. Freda LeVine was born 1913, in Elmira, New York, and raised in New Haven, Connecticut. She moved to New York City in 1942 when she married William J. Zucker, an attorney, who served in the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. Before he retired in 1955, Mr. Zucker served as chief of the Chinese and immigration law divisions of the New York District, district operations officer, district administrative officer, assistant district director and acting district director. Mr. Zucker died in 1968 in Teaneck, New Jersey. An independent woman, Mrs. Zucker worked in the garment industry beginning in 1957 at West Point Pepperell, New York City. She ended her career in 1983, at age 70, as Office Manager of Dotti Originals, New York City. Mrs Zucker led a Jewish life and was active in B'nai B'rith and Hadassah. She was a founding member of Southbridge Hadassah. She traveled extensively, particularly after her retirement, to the Costa del Sol, Spain, with her companion of many years, the late Saul Herzfeld, Southbridge Towers, Manhattan. There was always music in her home, and she frequented the Metropolitan Opera. She is survived by her only daughter, Jane Z. Smith, of Staten Island. Mrs. Zucker will be buried in Beth Hamedrosh Cemetery, New Haven, CT. Donations in memory of Freda Zucker should be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of Staten Island or to Hadassah.

title: New Queen Rules Over Balanchine's Magic Forest
description: Before closing its season at the New York State Theater yesterday, the New York City Ballet offered a surprise by thrusting a young dancer into a major role. Carla Krbes, a 19-year-old corps member from Brazil, has not gone unnoticed this year. But even her unforced, strong technique and long-legged allure did not prepare the viewer for the magic of her Titania, the fairy queen in George Balanchine's ''Midsummer Night's Dream.''

description: MILAN  The sweet revenge of the double-breasted jacket, high-rise pants, full-sleeved shirts and sleeveless sweaters  those were the strong trends of the Milan 2002 menswear season, as well as color and pattern.

description: CANTOR-Sarah Kaltman. On June 29, 2001, at age 39. Beloved wife of Kevin. Loving mother of Sam. Cherished daughter of Sandra and Alfred. Beloved sister of Lucy. Dear step-daughter of Bunny. We will always love and remember her. Sarah's unlimited kindness, caring, warmth and generosity will be sorely missed by her family and all that knew her. Service Monday, 11:45 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or the Vascular Anomalies Center at Boston Children's Hospital.

description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2  There was the solitary figure of Pete Sampras, with a bag slung over his shoulder and flip-flops on his feet, cutting through a courtyard outside the locker room, where several players milled about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLIAR, ESTHER
description: SMOLIAR-Esther. June 29, 2001, in Prairie Village, Kansas. Formerly of Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan and Clearbrook in New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Milton Smoliar. She will be remembered fondly by her son and daughter-in-law, Burton and Barbara Smoliar, her grandchildren, Dr. Laura Smoliar Arbore and David Smoliar, and her great-granddaughter Sara Ann Smoliar.

title: A Health Infrastructure for AIDS
description: At the United Nations special session on AIDS last week, one of the biggest challenges the countries discussed was the creation of working health care systems. High drug prices remain a primary obstacle to treating AIDS, but even if drug prices are dramatically reduced, many of the hardest hit countries in Africa and Asia lack the clinics, laboratories and medical personnel to get the drugs to many AIDS patients.

title: The Heroic Life, Captured by Beethoven, Lived by All
description: Heroes are special cases of a heroism shared by humanity in general, as represented by massed voices in full song and an exuberant orchestra: that is one message of Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' and it is being forcefully projected from the stage and from the pit in the new Glyndebourne production here this summer. The chorus is youthful, keen and vigorous and made a rousing sound in the finale, where the orchestra whooped exhilaratingly at the most extreme of Simon Rattle's many fast tempos.

title: Reckitt Benckiser Consolidates Account
description: Reckitt Benckiser in London has consolidated the North American advertising account of its household-products division at the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Ads Brawl in a Never-Ending Political Season
description: With jittery House Republicans complaining that President Bush is losing the important opening skirmishes over energy policy, a political rescue squad has hit the California airwaves.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Too Few Muscles Instead of Too Many
description: That the men's clothes shown on European runways rarely make it onto the backs of the real men who take depositions, pump gas or merge and acquire things for a living should not come as news to anyone who has had dealings with the male sex in the last dozen or so years. But during the spring 2002 men's shows that ended in Milan on Friday, it came as some surprise to realize that the plunging V-neck sweaters, the leather pants with racing stripes, the shirts printed with calla lilies would probably not even make it into the closets of the men who are paid to care about such imponderable expressions of style.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: U.S. Told To Turn Over Serviceman
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Yutaka Kawashima summoned the American charg d'affaires, Richard Christianson, and demanded that the United States hand over an Air Force sergeant suspected of raping a Japanese woman in Okinawa last week. The authorities said the victim had identified Sgt. Timothy B. Woodland, 24, who is stationed at Kadena Air Base, as her attacker and that they had found his and her fingerprints on a car parked in a lot where the incident occurred. An Okinawa court issued a warrant for his arrest. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: Gauging the Health of Surviving Spouses
description: Aperson whose spouse dies relatively suddenly is more likely to suffer a greater deterioration in health during bereavement than is someone whose spouse dies after a lengthy illness, a study published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association concluded.

title: International Ulster Panel Blames I.R.A. for Unresolved Issue of Disarmament
description: The international commission responsible for disarming Northern Ireland's paramilitary groups issued a bluntly worded report today saying the Irish Republican Army had taken no steps to dismantle its arsenal and would not indicate how it planned to do so.

title: McCall Accuses Pataki of Inconsistency in Policies for Indian Casinos
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said today that the Pataki administration had been inconsistent in handling gambling compacts with American Indian tribes, allowing one tribe to have slot machines while denying similar gambling devices to another.

title: Mordecai Richler, Author, Dies at 70
description: Mordecai Richler, the cranky and combative Canadian novelist and critic whose often ribald writing celebrated the bygone era of old-world Montreal while skewering bourgeois ambition, the roots of Jewish identity and the Quebec separatist movement, died on Monday in Montreal.

title: AT&T UNIT SELLS $2.6 BILLION OF ASSETS TO PAY DOWN DEBT
description: AT&T Broadband has completed the sale of $2.6 billion of cable systems to three companies to pay off debt, which the company said was $47.5 billion on March 31. AT&T said it sold systems in St. Louis, Reno, Nev., and parts of Alabama to Charter Communications for $1.75 billion and a cable system in Sebastian, Fla., valued at $24 million. It also sold a system in Baltimore to Comcast for $518 million and one serving parts of Missouri to Mediacom Communications for $309 million. Charter is based in St. Louis, Mediacom in Middletown, N.Y., and Comcast in Philadelphia.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fulfilling the Brady Act's Promise
description: This week the Brady Act, which requires background checks for gun buyers, received its most comprehensive report card to date. A study by the Justice Department shows that background checks by the F.B.I., as well as by state and local agencies, have barred criminals from acquiring guns hundreds of thousands of times. Praise for the law's performance -- tempered by a proposal that would weaken it -- came from none other than Attorney General John Ashcroft, who as a senator had long received campaign contributions from the National Rifle Association in appreciation of his stance against gun control. But truly clamping down on gun crime would require more legislative action.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Man Who Raped Child Is Sentenced
description: A man convicted of raping and beating a 9-year-old girl in a Chicago housing project was sentenced to 120 years in prison, the maximum allowed. The man, Patrick Sykes, 29, was convicted of luring the girl into his apartment, assaulting her, spraying cockroach repellant in her mouth and leaving her for dead. The child, who became known as Girl X, was left paralyzed and unable to speak or see, but she testified against Mr. Sykes by moving her head and eyes in response to questions.

title: Venerable Institution In a Season Of Turmoil
description: In November 1988, Andrei Sakharov, the Russian physicist, political dissident and Nobel Peace Prize winner, came to the United States after he was released from years of house arrest. One of his first stops was an Italianate building on East 63rd Street that is home to the New York Academy of Sciences. There, at an emotional reception in the academy's travertine marble halls, Sakharov thanked the academy for leading the fight for his freedom. It was a proud moment in the history of the academy, which, since its founding in 1817, has claimed Thomas Jefferson, Charles Darwin and Albert Einstein as members.

title: Misfortune For Justice, A Shot for Knoblauch
description: Four at-bats after being activated from the disabled list, David Justice went back on the 15-day disabled list after re-straining his left groin, and it may be that Justice will be out until the end of the month.

title: Vandalism Follows Event For Ex-Radio Employees
description: At the Cinema Arts Center, vandals stole two safes, damaged computers and scrawled graffiti denouncing the radio station WBAI-FM after a Saturday fund-raiser at the theater that featured an Internet simulcast by fired, banned and exiled employees of the station and their supporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, WHIPPLE VAN NESS
description: JONES-Whipple Van Ness of Las Vegas, Nevada and Aspen, Colorado died Friday June 29th in Tallahassee, Florida after a long illness. He is survived by three sons Richard McCulloch Jones of Boca Raton, FLorida, Whipple Jr. of Tallahassee, Florida, Carey Etnier Jones of Carbondale, Colorado, Stepson Andrew Doremus of Aspen, Colorado, and two daughters Diane Carroll Blow of Greenwich, CT., and Melanie Roseberry of Dillen Beach, CA. His daughter Daphne predeceased him. Also surviving are 20 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren. Mr. Jones, known as ''Whip'' was born November 8, 1909 in Oconomowoc, Wisconsin, the son of Frank and Esther Whipple Jones. He was a long time businessman in Aspen, Colorado where in 1958 he developed and operated the internationally renowned Aspen Highlands ski area. In 1992 after the longest continuous ownership of any ski area in Colorado Mr. Jones donated Aspen Highlands to Harvard University where he had graduated in 1932. He also built and operated The Smuggler, one of Aspen's first ski lodges. In 1998 he was inducted into the Aspen Hall of Fame and in October 2000 into the Colorado Ski Hall of Fame. Before World War II Mr. Jones was a captain in the Missouri State Guard and worked as a Trust Officer at the St. Louis Union Trust Co. At the outbreak of war Mr. Jones transferred to the Army Air Corps and rose to the rank of Lt. Col. Funeral Services will be held in Aspen, Colorado July 10 at 2 P.M. at Christ Episcopal Church with burial to follow. A memorial service will be held July 20th at 11 A.M. at St. John's Episcopal Church in Tallahassee, Florida.

title: Tales of Ephemeral Love From an Enduring Singer
description: Hadda Brooks, an 84-year-old singer, songwriter and pianist, played cat and mouse with her songs at Joe's Pub on Saturday night, where she appeared as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. She has been performing since the 1940's, and she did enough name-dropping, as she called it, to remind listeners that she has sung in movies starring Humphrey Bogart and Jack Nicholson. She recounted teasing Mr. Nicholson, responding to his praise by asking pointedly, ''And who are you?''' She continued, ''I had a smirk on my face and he had one on his face, but neither one of us knew what it meant.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: Aid From West Drops Sharply
description: Aid to Africa from rich Western nations fell by a third between 1994 and 1999, a United Nations report found. At the same time, investment in Africa stagnated. Africa still attracts less than 5 percent of all investment in the developing world at a time when it faces its severest health crisis with AIDS and suffers from low prices of commodities produced by many of its countries. The report was prepared for the United Nations Economic and Social Council, now meeting in Geneva. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNER, SMITH, C.
description: BRUNER-SMITH-C. On June 26, 2001, at the age of 97. The Trinity School community deeply mourns the loss of our inspiring teacher who served the School from 1927 until his death. He will be remembered for his gentle dignity, loving wit, and unique way of making the past come alive. In keeping with Mr. Bruner-Smith's wishes, there will be no funeral service, but there will be a celebration of the life of this fine man at a memorial service to be held on September 30 at Trinity Church. Gifts in Mr. Bruner-Smith's memory may be made to the C. Bruner-Smith Fund for Financial Aid at Trinity School, 139 West 91st Street, NY, NY 10024.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: New Uconn Campus Delayed
description: The opening of a Waterbury campus for the University of Connecticut has been delayed so a state agency can assess the environmental impact of heavy construction and rapid development in the area. This is the second six-month delay for the $22 million campus, which was initially expected to be ready by the fall of next year but which has been rescheduled to 2003, said Karen Grava, a spokesman for the university. When it does open, the new campus will replace an older facility less than a mile away and will more than double student enrollment to 1,250.

title: House Democrats Trumpet Record Off-Year Fund-Raising, and Credit Bush's Policies
description: Capitalizing on voter anger over the disputed presidential election, House Democrats raised $18 million over the first six months of the year by stepping up their direct-mail solicitations and holding a string of fund-raisers.

title: Coke May Want to Review Its Procter & Gamble Deal
description: The Coca-Cola Company is rethinking the wisdom of handing over some of its most promising brands to a joint venture with Procter & Gamble that may offer little in return, one of Wall Street's most influential beverage analysts said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: A Dispute Over Deliveries
description: The Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation has published a series of articles in its official newspaper to pressure the postal administration to back off in a dispute over foreign express delivery companies. The postal service argues that it alone has the right to deliver letters and parcels in China. But the ministry, which licenses companies such as FedEx, United Parcel Service and DHL Worldwide Express, thinks the law allows foreign operations. The dispute will ultimately be settled by China's State Council, or cabinet. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Metricom Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: Metricom, which operates the Ricochet high-speed wireless Internet service, filed for bankruptcy-law protection yesterday, underscoring difficulties in what had been the much-vaunted mobile Internet industry. The move by the company, based in San Jose, Calif., may create headaches for several large creditors, including WorldCom, that provided the company with unsecured financing. Ricochet, which cost $70 to $80 a month in addition to requiring a wireless modem for about $300, failed to sign up enough customers to turn a profit. Metricom which was backed by Microsoft's co-founder, Paul Allen, said yesterday that it would continue to provide service to its 40,000 or so subscribers, but the eventual fate of its 15-city network is unclear. Simon Romero (NYT)

Interment will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Family requests donations in Sadye's name be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind or Dorot.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Clues to Benefits of Fruit and Vegetables
description: A new study has found that vegetarians have high blood levels of salicylic acid, the active ingredient in aspirin. Given that aspirin can prevent heart attacks, the new findings may help explain other studies that have found lower levels of heart disease among people who eat a lot of fruit and vegetables.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: City Doesn't Want Informers
description: The mixed Jewish-Arab city of Akko, also known as Acre, petitioned the Supreme Court to stop the Shin Bet security agency from resettling any more Palestinian informers in their northern Israeli coastal city. Mayor Shmaryahu Biran said ''there is a consensus in Akko not to settle collaborators'' and not to become a ''collaborators' haven.''

title: PLAYBOY TO ACQUIRE 3 SEX TV CHANNELS, AND A NETWORK
description: Playboy Enterprises has agreed to buy three sex television channels -- Hot Network, Hot Zone and the Califa Entertainment Group -- for $28.3 million, exercising an option obtained when it purchased Spice Entertainment two years ago. Also, Playboy said it would buy Vivid TV networks for $41.7 million from V.O.D. The prices may rise by $12 million if the companies meet performance goals. Playboy, based in Chicago, also extended by 10 years a contract with Vivid Video, which gives Playboy television rights, video-on-demand and video-streaming rights.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Not-Guilty Plea In Hofstra Killing
description: Shaun T. Alexander, 23, the Long Island college student indicted on first-degree murder charges in the killing and mutilation of a classmate at Hofstra University, pleaded not guilty to all eight counts at his arraignment yesterday. Mr. Alexander, of Dunwoody, Ga., is charged with killing Max B. Kolb, 20, at a Hicksville motel on April 25. The Nassau County district attorney, Denis E. Dillon, has 120 days to decide if he will seek the death penalty. Mr. Alexander's lawyer, Eric W. Naiburg, has 45 days to file a motion that his client was not responsible by reason of mental disease or defect. Al Baker (NYT)

Reposing in Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Tuesday, July 3 from 2-5 and 7-9PM and Wednesday, July 4th from 2-5. Mass of Transferral in St. Ann's Church at 7:30PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, July 5th at 10:30AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: No Mandatory Sentences For Drug Dealers
description: Under a law that took effect on Sunday, the state has eliminated mandatory prison sentences for many convicted drug dealers. The old law required 20-year sentences for possession of at least three grams of cocaine. The new law gives judges the authority to impose any sentence they see fit, including drug treatment instead of prison. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Move in G.O.P. To Block Study Of Embryo Cells
description: House Republican leaders urged President Bush today to prohibit the spending of federal money on biomedical research that used cells derived from human embryos. The research, they said, relies on ''an industry of death.''
