title: For Sojo, the Yankees' Gain Is Worth His Pain
description: Luis Sojo knows he will hurt this morning, like so many weekend warriors. He will push himself off the bed in his Baltimore hotel room and his 36-year-old quadriceps will be stiff from running. His hamstrings will ache from bending for almost three hours, in his first game at third base in six weeks. His arms will be sore. His forearm will be bruised, in the spot where he was hit by that wayward slider.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: I.M.F. Is Not Happy
description: The International Monetary Fund postponed an important review of Turkey's economic progress, saying the government had not adopted enough reforms, particularly in the banking sector. The delay means that Turkey will have to wait to receive its next installment of $1.6 million from the fund.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Gauging the Health of Surviving Spouses
description: A person whose spouse dies relatively suddenly is more likely to suffer a greater deterioration in health during bereavement than is someone whose spouse dies after a lengthy illness, a study published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association concluded.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mays Landing: Rape Case To Be Retried
description: The Atlantic County prosecutor's office said it would retry a man whose 1987 rape conviction was overturned on June 22 if the victim agreed to testify again. A federal appeals panel found that an assistant prosecutor improperly told jurors 14 years ago that the man, Clarence McKinley Moore, 52, who is black, had chosen his victim because, like his wife, she was white. Mr. Moore's lawyer, Paul Casteleiro, said the victim at first could not identify his client and then picked out his photograph only after she had been hypnotized, a method that he said he would discredit in a new trial. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: A Fitter Serena Williams Is Ready for Capriati Now
description: In a hurry to dispense with their Round of 16 opponents today, Jennifer Capriati and Serena Williams played with a fast-forward approach.

title: Alone, US Airways Faces Tough Choices
description: Memo to US Airways workers, managers, passengers and shareholders: Get ready for Plan B.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASTA, JOHN EDWARD, JR.
description: NASTA-John Edward, Jr., 52. On July 2, 2001 of Upper Saddle River, NJ. Beloved husband of Annette (nee Annunziata). Loving father of Lauren Alexandra and Taylor Beth. Cherished son of Theohara Mary (Pappas) and the late John Nasta. Dear brother of Vincent, Michael, Carmella Fiumarra and Raefel Spero. John was a member of the General Partner of Omega Advisors in New York, NY. He was a parishioner of the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, and was a member of Tiro A Segno (Italian social gun club) in New York City. Visitation will be held on Tuesday from 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave., Ramsey, NJ. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Thursday, July 5, 2001 at 10:00 A.M. at the Church of the Presentation, 271 W. Saddle River Rd., Upper Saddle River, NJ. Interment to follow at the Ascension Cemetery in Monsey, NY. Donations to the Imus Ranch, 660 AM, WFAN RADIO, 34-12 36th Street, Astoria, NY 11106 Attn: Kara Dugan or The American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For directions or further information please call 201-327-0030 or visit us at www.vanemburghsneider.com

title: BP'S OIL AND GAS PRODUCTION FALLS 4% IN LAST QUARTER
description: The oil company, BP P.L.C. said yesterday that oil and gas production in the second quarter fell some 4 percent from a quarter earlier because of maintenance work at certain fields. Natural gas production from April to June declined to 8.57 billion cubic feet a day from 8.9 billion in the previous quarter, while oil supplies fell to 1.87 million barrels a day in the similar period from 1.94 million barrels, the company said. BP, based in London, has pledged to raise petroleum production by at least 5.5 percent this year.

title: Miami Herald's Top Editor To Lead The Boston Globe
description: Martin Baron, the executive editor of The Miami Herald, will take over as top editor of The Boston Globe next month, succeeding Matthew V. Storin, who is retiring after leading The Globe, New England's largest newspaper, for eight years.

title: Role of Martyrdom Is Debated In Sentence for Embassy Bombing
description: Federal prosecutors and a defense lawyer stood before jurors in the embassy bombings trial yesterday and talked to them about the death penalty for the last time.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Letters: Of Time and Space
description: Of Time and Space

title: Russian Jetliner Crashes in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, July 3  A Russian airliner with 143 passengers and crew crashed tonight near the Siberian city of Irkutsk on a flight from Yekaterinburg in the Urals to Vladivostok in the Far East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARGUILO, EMILY ANNE
description: GARGUILO-Emily Anne (nee Emily Anne Black of Dallas, Texas). Died Monday, July 1, St. Vincent's Hospital, New York City. She was the daughter of the late Dr. James Harvey Black & Alleen Patton of Dallas, Texas. Mrs. Garguilo was a graduate of Southern Methodist University and received a MSW from Columbia University School of Social Work, where she was also an Alumni Trustee and past President of the Alumni Association. Mrs. Garguilo was a founding member and former President of the New York Freudian Society and a member of the Council of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapists, Society of Clinical Social Work Psychotherapists and Coalition of Social Work Psychoanalysts. She was also a devoted gardener and longtime resident of Greenwich Village, where she settled and raised her family. Mrs. Garguilo remained an active member of the community. A great believer in the value of education, she was an original founder of the Village Community School on Geenwich Street. She married the late Armand Gargiulo, a fellow psychologist and psychotherapist in New York in 1957. She was the beloved mother of the late Anthony Patton and Lois Christina Korsupsin of New York, the darling grandmother of Sasha Antonia, Christina Annette and Justin Armand and the devoted mother-in-law of Charan Korsupsin. In addition to her daughter, son-in-law and grandchildren, she is survived by her sister Lois Black of Crosland, Texas. Graveside services in Sherman, Conn. For further info call Frank E. Campbell,-The Funeral Chapel 212-288-3500. Contributions in her memory may be made to AMFAR or GMHC.

title: VITAL SIGNS: OUTCOMES; Special Milk May Help Children's Health
description: Children given milk treated with beneficial bacteria missed less day care because of illness than did those who drank ordinary milk, a study in Finland found.

title: Mr. Milosevic Faces the Court
description: It took years of legal perseverance and international cooperation to bring Slobodan Milosevic before the war crimes tribunal in The Hague today to answer charges of crimes against humanity involving the mass deportation and murder of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. Securing his conviction will require a similarly determined effort. Prosecutors have abundant evidence showing that these brutal crimes were committed. To prove that Mr. Milosevic ordered them, prosecutors must reconstruct the chain of command through which specific orders and approvals were transmitted.

title: L'Oral Buying Colorama
description: The cosmetics maker L'Oral has agreed to buy Revlon Inc.'s Colorama line of make-up and shampoo in Brazil for $55 million as L'Oral expands in emerging markets.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Medical Examiner's Office Faulted
description: A state audit of the office of the chief medical examiner found ''questionable practices'' that included awarding too much vacation and other compensatory time. The report, released on Friday, said that Dr. H. Wayne Carver 2nd, the chief medical examiner, had received slightly more vacation days per month between 1997 and 2000 than state regulations allowed. Also, the deputy chief medical examiner, Edward T. McDonough, was given 15 vacation days he ''did not appear entitled to.'' Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Squad Leader Surrenders
description: Alfredo Astiz, a retired navy captain and former death squad leader who once bragged that he was the ''best trained man in Argentina to kill journalists and politicians,'' turned himself in to the police to face charges of kidnapping three Italian citizens during the 1976-83 military dictatorship. An Italian court sought his arrest. He now awaits an extradition hearing. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CAROLE H.
description: KLEIN-Carole H. Passed away suddenly on July 2, 2001 at age 67. Author of 7 nonfiction books, most notably ''Aline'' and ''Gramercy Park.'' Member of PEN, The National Arts Club and the Board of Goddard College. She was a faculty member at The New School. Loving wife of the late Ted U. Klein. She is survived by her family: devoted children, William and Emily; loving brother, Les Honig; cherished grandchildren, Samuel, Dylan and Sophie. Services will be held on Thursday, July 5, at 10 AM at The National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC.

title: Holiday Tomorrow: Independence Day
description: NEW YORK

title: New Jersey Power Broker Extends His Reach; As Influence Grows in Congress, Menendez Is Keeping His Options Open
description: Robert Menendez was riding the elevator in the Capitol the other day when a colleague stepped through the door and offered a flattering but disarming greeting.

title: I.M.F. Decision on Loan To Turkey Is Delayed
description: The International Monetary Fund delayed a decision today on whether to make a $1.5 billion emergency loan to Turkey, saying its government had failed to carry out promises to overhaul the banking industry.

title: Accounts
description: Canon, Tokyo, expanded its relationship with CIA Medianetwork, Dusseldorf and London, part of the Tempus Group, by naming the agency to handle its first consolidated media services account in Africa, Europe and the Middle East. Spending was estimated at $45 million. CIA Medianetwork already works with Canon in other countries, including Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGNA, PETER P.
description: REGNA-Peter P. The entire Polytechnic University family mourns the passing of Peter P. Regna, alumnus, distinguished scientist and generous benefactor. Dr. Regna's career spanned half a century. He played a pivotal role in discovering, developing and manufacturing drugs that revolutionized medical practice. At Pfizer Inc., he was part of a team that, in 1950, discovered Terramycin; he also played a key role in the production of penicillin, streptomycin and other antibiotics. At Squibb Institute for Medical Research, he was among the first to explore the new field of genetic engineering. Dr. Regna held more that 35 patents and received many honors, including the Perkin Medal from the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry. At the time of his passing, he was cofounder and managing partner of Harrington Research Co. Dr. Regna earned his bachelor's, master's and doctorate degrees at Polytechnic University, where he endowed a student center and a cutting-edge laboratory in biotechnology, and was awarded an honorary doctorate of science in 1994. We extend our condolences and profound sympathy to his wife, Barbara; two sons, Richard and Peter J; and all the other family members upon their loss.

title: New Peril for Campaign Reform
description: In the climactic weeks before the House is to vote on campaign finance reform, the drive to enact a comprehensive bill faces a major new peril. On Thursday, a sham alternative advanced by Republicans who oppose true reform drew support from an important member of the Congressional Black Caucus whose decision to co-sponsor the bill might cause other Democrats to abandon the cause of reform. Blacks and Hispanics are wavering on the specious ground that huge sums of money from corporations, unions and rich donors are needed to carry out voter registration and get-out-the-vote drives. Such misguided thinking could wreck the best chance to clean up the system in years.

title: A Ceremony Evokes Truth That Hides In Mourning
description: As a modern-dance choreographer, Ronald K. Brown has moved over the last 15 years into a class by himself. The depth of his work lies in an original high-energy idiom drawn from various sources and in the way this vocabulary fuses with his themes.

title: EFFORT TO RECAST IRAQ OIL SANCTIONS IS HALTED FOR NOW
description: Facing a Russian veto in the Security Council, the United States and Britain today abandoned efforts for now to change the rules for permissible trade with Iraq.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Arbitron Buys Measuring Firm
description: Arbitron Inc., which compiles radio and television ratings, has purchased the radio-audience-measurement service of Statistical Research Inc. for $25 million. Statistical Research, based in Westfield, N.J., operates a service that measures the size of the audience for commercials on 29 radio networks, Arbitron's chief executive, Stephen Morris, said.

title: Shipbuilders' Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenneth S. Lynn, 78, Biographer of Hemingway and Chaplin
description: Kenneth Schuyler Lynn, a historian of American thought noted for his analytical studies of Mark Twain, Charlie Chaplin and Ernest Hemingway, died on June 24 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He was 78 and lived in Washington.

title: The Cuban Missile Crisis As a Sex Stimulant? Yup.
description: ''Down South,'' a comedy by Doug Field at the Rattlestick Theater, is a cheerfully raunchy satire of the strait-laced Middle-American values that are usually associated with the 1950's. If this sounds like a not terribly crucial avenue of inquiry, well, the play is far more interested in giddy innuendo and sexual slapstick than genuine social criticism. This playwright's tongue-in-cheek contention is that the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, with its threat of nuclear holocaust, freed the inhibitions of repressed Americans and, for a brief time anyway, unshackled their true desires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANKIN, JULIUS
description: SANKIN-Julius. The Joseph L. Morse Geriatric Center in West Palm Beach, Florida is deeply saddened by the recent passing of Mr. Julius Sankin of Delray Beach, Florida on Saturday, June 30, 2001. He was 83. Mr. Sankin was born in Brooklyn, New York. After serving in the Army during W.W. II, he moved to Washington, D.C. to work as an Attorney at the Office of Price Administration. Mr. Sankin was the recipient of numerous awards and honors for his community and philanthropic service in Washington, D.C. and Florida. In Florida, he served as President of the Ruth Rales Jewish Family Service of the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County and the Board of Directors of the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County in Boca Raton, Florida. In addition, he was a member of the Board of Directors for the Joseph L. Morse Geriatric Center and its affiliate agency, The Lola and Saul Kramer Senior Services Agency in West Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Sankin was the beloved husband for 58 years of Jeanne Sankin. He was the loving father of a daughter Marilyn Tushman of Scarsdale, NY; two sons Andrew Sankin of Bethesda, Maryland and the late Steven Sankin and a grandfather to Jonathan and Rachel Tushman of Boston, MA. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, July 3rd at Temple Sinai in Washington, D.C. and he will be buried at King David Cemetery in Falls Church, Virginia.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; N.A.S.D. Rule Would Oversee Analysts on TV
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it had proposed a rule requiring that equity analysts at the nation's brokerage firms clearly and prominently disclose to investors the potential conflicts of interest that may influence their stock recommendations.

title: U.S. Toughens Terms for North Korea Talks
description: Though the Bush administration has now agreed to reopen talks with North Korea, it has set demands far broader than those pressed by President Bill Clinton, raising the prospect of protracted negotiations while Pyongyang continues to sell missiles around the world.

title: Russian Airliner Disappears in Siberia
description: MOSCOW (AP) -- A Russian airliner disappeared near the Siberian city of Irkutsk, Russian news agencies reported Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Infineon Plans Offering
description: The European chip maker Infineon Technologies said yesterday that it would sell new shares worth about 1.7 billion euros ($1.4 billion) to finance investments, acquisitions and refinance debt. The company will sell as many as 60 million shares in Germany and the United States and in private placements. Siemens, which owns 56 percent of Infineon, will not buy shares, Infineon said. Shares have fallen as much as 24 percent since June 20 when Infineon forecast a loss in the latest quarter because of slack demand and falling prices. The shares will be priced on July 12 and start trading July 13.

title: Epidemic Takes Toll on Black Women
description: Here in the rural South, the image of AIDS today looks very much like Tyeste W. Roney.

title: Men Were Her Victims, or So She Thought
description: The lobbyists for gun control and nuclear disarmament have yet to register complaints about Anna Friel's legs, which are currently gracing the stage of the Eisenhower Theater of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: OBITUARY : Edwin D. Morgan, 80, Businessman Who Befriended Writers in Paris
description: WASHINGTON  Edwin D. Morgan, 80, an independent businessman who was a well-known figure in the expatriate American literary community in Paris in the 1950s and 1960s, died Thursday in New York of complications from cancer.

title: Joe Henderson, Saxophonist And Composer, Dies at 64
description: Joe Henderson, one of the great jazz saxophonists and a composer who wrote a handful of tunes known by almost every jazz student, died on Saturday in San Francisco. He was 64 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Webvan Shareholders Approve Reverse Split
description: Shareholders of the online grocer Webvan have voted to approve a plan for a 1-to-25 reverse stock split, in the hope of preventing the company's stock from being delisted by the Nasdaq stock market. Webvan said it had been notified by Nasdaq that the company must put the reverse stock split into effect by July 23. Even so, Webvan must still meet Nasdaq's minimum-bid requirements after the split in order to avoid being delisted, which Nasdaq typically does when a company's stock consistently trades below $1. Webvan shares closed yesterday at 7 cents, down 1 cent. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Pantani Provides Intrigue in Buildup to Tour de France
description: The weirdest prediction about this year's Tour de France is that Marco Pantani, the Italian climber who won the Tour in 1998 but whose team was denied an invitation this year, will be at the start on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STETSON, JOHN CHARLES
description: STETSON-John Charles. Age 68, of Port Washington, LI, on July 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Elise, Craig and Jonathan. Devoted and happy grandfather of Caleb, Kate and Lydia Stetson and Thaddeus Charles Allen. Dear brother of Ruth Anderson of Escondido, CA. A celebration of his life will be held on July 6, 2001, 10:00 AM, at the Congregational Church, Manhasset. Contributions to the American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, New York, New York 10019, or the charity of your choice would be greatly appreciated.

title: Capriati-Williams Episode Complete With Chills
description: WIMBLEDON, England -- If people here thought the Royals were strange, they hadn't yet experienced an afternoon at Center Court with the Williams's and the Capriatis. Or in the contrived lexicon of all-American entertainment, "One Life to Live" meets "The Simpsons."

title: New Approach to a Discoloring Skin Disorder
description: Loretta C., who has a skin condition called vitiligo that literally turned her skin from black to white, was brought up to cherish her African-American heritage. So the disparagement that she and her husband and children have suffered from fellow blacks has been especially painful.

title: Fawning and Insulting: How Not to Interview
description: Jiminy Glick is arguably the world's worst television interviewer. He asks awful questions. He fawns over celebrities like Steve Martin, Kathie Lee Gifford and Billy Crystal. He talks endlessly about twin sons, Matthew and Modine. And Jiminy -- everyone calls him that -- often babbles away in a stream of non sequiturs that turn into insults.

title: Deep Pockets Not Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Internet Ad Agencies Merging
description: ValueClick of Westlake Village, Calif., which offers performance-based Internet advertising and Web publishing services, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Mediaplex in San Francisco, a marketing technology services company. The stock deal was valued at $43 million. Mediaplex, which has about 250 employees including those at its subsidiary, AdWare in Louisville, Ky., works for clients like McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, Sony and Young & Rubicam Advertising. It will initially operate as a subsidiary of ValueClick; Tom Vadnais, 53, president and chief executive at Mediaplex, will continue in that post. In the fall, though, when the deal is expected to close, the technologies of both companies will be combined, said Elizabeth Lloyd, a spokeswoman for Mediaplex. Last week, Mediaplex acquired the client base and sales team of Interadnet, an online advertising services and technology provider. Terms were not disclosed. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Tamoxifen Gets Mixed Review in Study
description: Researchers in Seattle reported today that a breast cancer drug, tamoxifen, may have an unexpected effect on the development of subsequent cancers.

title: One-Third of Public School Students Enroll for Summer School
description: As a first wave of more than 80,000 students started summer classes yesterday, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced that a total of 327,000 students had registered, or roughly one of every three students in New York City's public schools.

title: Yankees Stretched In the Seventh Inning
description: Their performance in the first six innings at Yankee Stadium yesterday is what creates concern in the minds of some people about the Yankees. There they were hitting against a pitcher who in his previous 11 starts had an 0-9 record and an 8.11 earned run average, and they had managed only two hits. One was a home run, but it was a fly ball to right field that an ordinary right fielder would have caught before it barely cleared the fence. The problem for the Tampa Bay Devil Rays is that Ben Grieve is no ordinary right fielder.

title: Well-Prepared Critics of Health Industry Shaped Debate on Patients' Rights
description: What stopped the political juggernaut of the health insurance industry?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, ROBERT M.
description: SILVER-Robert M. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. On July 1, 2001. Husband of Carolyn; father of Janet (Allen) Podell, and Robert E.; grandfather of Nicole (John) & Randall. Loving great-grandfather. Veteran of World War II and 50 years in book publishing. Interment private. Memorial service 7PM Tuesday, July 3, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From making the perfect cucumber sandwich to seeking out local wines in France, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Is John Adams Overrated?
description: Tomorrow, on July 4, could we tip our hats once again to the memory of Thomas Jefferson? In past years, it might hardly have seemed necessary. Jefferson's ''peculiar felicity of expression,'' as John Adams put it, led not only to his selection to write the Declaration of Independence but to over two centuries of acclaim for his sublime articulation, in that document and others, of core democratic values. But this is the season of John Adams, not Jefferson. And as Adams's star has shone more brightly among the historians, Jefferson's has seemed to dim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUDE, VERA
description: BRAUDE-Vera. Died peacefully in her home on July 1, 2001. Truly a person of unique generosity and strength, she enjoyed her independence and expressed herself through art and sculpture. Her hospitality, reciprocated by her friends, neighbors and caregivers, helped to make her last years at home possible. Loving mother of Kiki and Henry Etingin and Alex and Tu Braude. Beloved grandmother of Karen (Jin), Gregory (Milene) and Ani. Cherished great grandmother of Rebecca, Amanda, Guilian and Albert. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Dispute On the Taconic: Either Safety Or Convenience
description: A small sign outside the Muscoot Restaurant North here simply warns, ''Please stay off lawn.'' It is intended to protect not the thick grass, but the customers who would otherwise stroll right up to one of the most dangerous intersections on the Taconic State Parkway.

title: Carrin Races to Catch Up in Bid for Borough President
description: A day after he spoke at two churches and conferred with his campaign workers, Adolfo Carrin Jr. began work yesterday at 7 a.m. with a series of political meetings in the headquarters of the Bronx Democratic Party. He spent the afternoon planning a dozen or so fund-raising events he intends to hold in the next two weeks.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PROGNOSIS; A Clue for Predicting Chronic Whiplash
description: People with very stiff necks shortly after car accidents are the ones most likely to suffer from chronic whiplash, a new study in Denmark concluded.

title: Rowland Signs Last of Tardy Bills on Budget
description: Gov. John G. Rowland signed the last of the State General Assembly's tardy budget-related bills today, putting an end to nearly four weeks of overtime bickering and compromise over the state's two-year, $26.5 billion revenue and spending plan.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wal-Mart Markets Camera Tied To Internet
description: Wal-Mart Stores has begun selling a disposable camera whose $6.84 price includes loading the developed photographs onto the Internet. When the single-use camera is returned to Wal-Mart for developing, the photographs are automatically loaded onto the Walmart.com Photo Center site, where the user can sign in and decide to order prints or share the pictures using e-mail.

title: A Delicacy's Delicate Future
description: As a chef and a lover of good food, I have long enjoyed caviar. On special occasions, my family and I like to eat it plain, or with bread and butter. When my daughter was a year old, I gave her a tartine -- caviar on french bread with butter -- for the first time. She licked the caviar jar, gave me back the soggy piece of bread and said, ''Encore, Papa.''

title: Kentucky Patient Receives Mechanical Heart Replacement
description: Surgeons in Louisville announced today that they had for the first time given a fully implantable artificial heart to a dying patient. The patient, whose name and gender have not been disclosed, was described as resting comfortably, awake and responsive after a seven hour operation at Jewish Hospital on Monday.

title: Sports of The Times; Sampras's Opponent: The Future
description: THE 19-year-old challenger in the white bandanna and short ponytail spanked the historic and match-winning forehand past the champion, who helplessly watched nearly a decade of dominance sail by. Then Roger Federer sank to his knees, rolled onto his side and let his emotion spill over after almost four grueling hours of keeping it contained.

title: Fleisher, Late Bloomer, Hits Stride in His 50's
description: Bruce Fleisher could be the most dominant player in the history of the PGA Senior Tour, yet he admitted today, the morning after capturing the Senior Open, that he still needs a confidence check.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, RABBI MORTON
description: BERKOWITZ-Rabbi Morton. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved father of our esteemed faculty member, Dr. Avi Berkowitz. We extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Netpliance Fined By F.T.C.
description: Netpliance, which sells a small computer called the i-opener as a less expensive alternative to the personal computer for Internet access and e-mail, has settled with the Federal Trade Commission on charges that its advertising, sales and billing practices violated federal laws, agency officials said. The agreement with the commission requires Netpliance, of Austin, Tex., to reimburse an unspecified amount to consumers who were improperly billed and to pay the government a $100,000 civil penalty. Netpliance contended that the i-opener would allow very easy access to the Web, without special software or boot-up delays, for about $199. But the F.T.C. said the company failed to disclose extra costs and restrictions, including monthly Internet service fees and long-distance telephone charges. In addition, the commission said, the company, which still sells i-openers at Circuit City and CompUSA stores, billed some customers' credit cards without their consent.

title: A Delicacy's Delicate Future
description: As a chef and a lover of good food, I have long enjoyed caviar. On special occasions, my family and I like to eat it plain, or with bread and butter. When my daughter was a year old, I gave her a tartine  caviar on french bread with butter  for the first time. She licked the caviar jar, gave me back the soggy piece of bread and said, "Encore, Papa."

title: Milosevic to Represent Himself at His Arraignment Today
description: Signaling contempt for the international tribunal that has indicted him, Slobodan Milosevic indicated today that he would refuse legal counsel and face his accusers alone in court on Tuesday.

title: Physicist Nikolai Basov, 78; Won Nobel for Laser Research
description: Dr. Nikolai G. Basov, who shared a Nobel Prize in Physics for research that led to the development of lasers, has died, Russian news sources reported Monday. He was 78.

title: A Program's Goal: Evaluate and Rehabilitate Problem Doctors
description: It was in May 1999 that a Colorado plastic surgeon's world blew apart. A malpractice suit was brewing against him, and he knew his name had come to the attention of the Colorado medical board, the state agency in charge of investigating doctors. Even so, the official letter from the board stunned him.

title: An Old Observatory Finds a New Life
description: ''Over here is the holy of holies,'' the guide said, nodding toward the white domed building housing the telescope with which Edwin P. Hubble in 1929 observed that galaxies appear to be racing outward, and the farther away they are, the faster they are receding. He had, in short, discovered that the universe is expanding.

title: Clues to Benefits of Fruit and Vegetables
description: Anew study has found that vegetarians have high blood levels of salicylic acid, the active ingredient in aspirin. Given that aspirin can prevent heart attacks, the new findings may help explain other studies that have found lower levels of heart disease among people who eat a lot of fruit and vegetables. The study, published last week in The Journal of Clinical Pathology, compared the salicylic acid levels of a group of Buddhist monks (who are vegetarians), non- vegetarian residents of the same region and a group of diabetic patients taking 75 milligrams of aspirin daily. One of the researchers, Dr. John Paterson of the Royal Infirmary in Dumfries and Galloway in Scotland, said that he was not surprised to find higher levels of the acid in the blood of the monks than in their neighbors'. He recounted an old joke: What's a Scotsman's favorite vegetable? A sausage. But Dr. Paterson said he was surprised that some of the monks had as much salicylic acid in their blood as some of the diabetics taking aspirin. Eating foods rich in salicylic acid does not provide all the cardiac benefits of taking aspirin, Dr. Paterson said: aspirin helps block the formation of blood clots, while fruits and vegetables do not. But salicylic acid from either source reduces the kind of inflammation that can contribute over years to the hardening and narrowing of the arteries and to certain kinds of cancer, he said. Before aspirin was synthesized in the late 19th century, Dr. Paterson said, doctors gave patients extracts of willow bark and other plants high in salicylic acid. The new study shows that significant levels of the chemical can come in a more palatable form.

title: U.S. to Seek Christie's Data For Use in Antitrust Trial
description: Government prosecutors have agreed to ask Christie's for company documents that lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, the indicted former chairman of the rival Sotheby's auction house, think can help in his defense.

title: Special Milk May Help Children's Health
description: Children given milk treated with beneficial bacteria missed less day care because of illness than did those who drank ordinary milk, a study in Finland found.

title: Santa Luca Journal; Flipper's Trainer in Crusade Against Dolphin Exploitation
description: When the sun sets over this town, Turbo and Ariel leap into the air in a ritual that dolphins have known for millions of years.

title: 6 Korean Newspapers May Face Tax Evasion Charges
description: South Korean tax authorities have recommended that six major newspapers face criminal prosecution on suspicion of evading taxes.

title: Sharing a Fear (of Success) With a Ghost
description: Two things stand out in Richard Willett's intermittently entertaining new play, ''Random Harvest'': Patricia Randell's portrayal of the ghost of Greer Garson and a famous 1943 photograph that is never seen.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Suspends Service During 'Upgrade'
description: Napster users were unable to access the file-swapping service for much of the weekend and yesterday while the company worked to transform itself into a fee-based business. A notice posted on the site said: ''File transfers have been temporarily suspended while Napster upgrades the databases that support our new file identification technology. All previous versions of Napster have been disabled. We're making this change as part of our ongoing effort to comply with the court's orders.'' Napster is trying to adhere to a court order issued in March that bans the trade of most copyrighted works. The company has said it will begin its fee-based subscription service later this summer, but has not set an exact date. Use of the service has fallen sharply, to 320,000 users sharing an average of 1.5 songs each recently, down from 1.6 million people sharing 220 songs each in March according to the Webnoize Web research company. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Clarkson N. Potter, a publisher, writer and literary agent, described one of his survivors incorrectly. Christian Potter Drury of Litchfield, Conn., was a daughter, not a son.

We remember many special occasions Mrs. Richman shared with her family and our community. Heartfelt condolences to Lenore, Amy and Ilene, and the entire family. Bert Schwarz, President

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Steady Population Growth
description: The state's population will officially hit six million later this month, state demographers announced. The milestone is not exactly a cause for local celebration, especially in the Puget Sound region, where sprawl and traffic congestion have become major quality-of-life issues. Washington had one million people in 1906, two million in 1940 and three million in 1962. The population has doubled since then, with the state picking up one million residents just in the last decade. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Fiat and French Utility Make Bid for Montedison
description: Fiat and its principal shareholder, the Agnelli family of Italy, joined with the French national utility today in a hostile bid for control of Italy's second-largest utility, Montedison.

title: Milosevic Refuses to Enter Plea
description: THE HAGUE, July 3  Slobodan Milosevic, who plunged the Balkans into the worst European violence since World War II, appeared today before an international tribunal that has accused him of crimes against humanity and dismissed the court with disdain as an "illegal organ."

title: The Cat, Updated: Can It Still Catch Mice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thrifty Sather Steers Clear of High-Priced Stars
description: Without mentioning his predecessor or any free agents of recent seasons, Glen Sather spoke bluntly yesterday about the dangers of big spending on the open market. Beginning his second year as the Rangers' general manager, Sather explained why he avoided the high-salaried players who changed teams over the previous two days as unrestricted free agents across the N.H.L.

title: Mayor Vows to Tow Cars Of Some Scofflaw Diplomats
description: The Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it would soon begin towing the cars of some diplomats who flout the city's parking laws and ignore the tickets they are issued, a move that drew immediate criticism from the United States State Department.

title: Cheney, Back At Work, Says He's Feeling 'Pretty Good'
description: Vice President Dick Cheney returned to work at the White House today, saying he felt ''pretty good'' two days after doctors implanted a sophisticated pacemaker and defibrillator in his chest.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rising Debt-Equity Ratios
description: Some conglomerates appear to have reverted to some of the practices that brought about Korea's economic crisis in 1997. The debt-equity ratios of some conglomerates have risen above the level of 200 percent that the government demanded during the crisis, the financial supervisory commission reported. The worst offender was the Hyundai Group, whose debt-equity ratio more than doubled, from 229.72 percent last year to 477.56 percent. The debt-equity ratio of the Samsung Group, Korea's largest conglomerate since the breakup of Hyundai last year, improved to 151.04 percent from 193.97 percent last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Special Milk May Help Children's Health
description: Children given milk treated with beneficial bacteria missed less day care because of illness than did those who drank ordinary milk, a study in Finland found. The children who drank the so-called probiotic milk got almost as many infections during a Helsinki winter, but they had fewer complications and slightly fewer ear infections and needed less antibiotics. The bacteria included in the milk, lactobacillus, have been found to stimulate the immune system's response to infections, the researchers reported last month in The British Medical Journal. They said that earlier studies showed that the bacteria could also help reduce the amount of diarrhea that accompanies use of antibiotics. The researchers, from Helsinki University Central Hospital, said that children in day care were more likely to suffer from respiratory and gastric infections than children spending their days at home or in small groups. Having children drink probiotic milk appears to be an easy way to improve health with no adverse effects, they wrote. "A 10 percent to 20 percent reduction in absences from day care, which our results indicate is possible, could have important clinical, public health and economic consequences," the study says.

title: Balancing the Equation of Science and Politics
description: Good science is supposed to be based on facts, not politics. Dr. John H. Marburger III, the director of Brookhaven National Laboratory, was apparently betting that politics indeed posed no barrier to solid science after the White House announced last week that he was being nominated to be presidential science adviser, a post that has been vacant since President Bush took office.

title: Roche Buys Drug Rights
description: Roche Holding, Europe's fifth-largest drug maker, said today that it had bought the rights to use an ICN Pharmaceuticals compound, levovirin, to help treat hepatitis C, which infects 170 million people worldwide. Roche, a Swiss company, did not say what it paid for the rights to levovirin. Roche will combine the therapy with its Pegasys drug. Roche said preclinical studies show that the combination may be better than Pegasys and ribavirin, the most successful treatment for hepatitis C. Roche has had a series of research setbacks and faces a delay for Pegasys, the only potentially top-selling medication it planned to introduce in 2001, analysts said. Roche will pay a one-time licensing fee, milestone payments and, if the drug gets regulatory approval, royalties to ICN, based in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: Fox's Marriage Is a Major Personal and Political Step
description: First came the close-up of a petite bride in a shimmering white suit, her face aglow with excitement. Then the camera zoomed over to the strapping groom, towering more than a foot over his betrothed, his face frozen in a smile. There were close-ups of the wedding rings -- the groom's was so small that he wore it on his pinky -- followed by the newlywed's first public kiss.

title: The Wrong Way to Protect the Jewish Past
description: When Pope John Paul II joined the chief rabbi of Ukraine for prayers at Babi Yar last week, he performed an important act of commemoration, reminding Ukraine and the world of the atrocities that occurred at one of the most infamous killing sites of the Holocaust. But such high-profile commemorations cut two ways. They can encourage communities to protect their sites of Jewish heritage and of Holocaust horrors. But they can also absolve communities of responsibility by making commemoration the duty of some distant authority.

The case was prompted by a dozen complaints filed against Mr. Sharon charging that he was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Palestinians by Christian militiamen in Beirut in 1982 when Mr. Sharon was Israel's defense minister. A 1993 law allows Belgian courts to prosecute foreign officials for human rights violations committed outside Belgium.

Some had come down with uncommon infections. Others had contracted weird forms of common infections. And still others had developed a rare cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Insurance Information In Spanish
description: The New York State Insurance Department said yesterday that it had added a Spanish version to a Web site that provides information about a state program to make reduced-cost health insurance available to small-business owners and their employees, and to sole proprietors and to workers whose employers do not provide health insurance. The program, called Healthy NY, was enacted last year, and its Web site, www.healthyny.com, has until now been in English only. The site provides information about eligibility criteria and rates, which vary by county. Information can also be obtained by telephone, at (866) 432-5849. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Fight For Phone Company
description: Poland's largest mobile phone operator, Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa, is the object of a new battle between Vivendi Universal of France and Deutsche Telekom. Last week, the supervisory board of P.T.C.'s majority owner in Poland, Elektrim, accepted an offer of 709 million euros ($603 million), which would give Vivendi control of the phone company as well as Elektrim's cable television and fixed-line telephone assets, and float the combined communication company on the Warsaw exchange. The supervisors had rejected an offer by Deutsche Telekom, which controls 49 percent of P.T.C. and operates the company. Deutsche said it would press ahead with arbitration for 3 percent of P.T.C. that it claimed Elektrim owed it from an earlier deal. Peter S. Green (NYT)

description: Ending a battle over the operation of a public school by a private for-profit company, the San Francisco school district has agreed to let the company, Edison Schools, apply to the State Board of Education for a five-year renewal of its contract to operate a charter school. If approved, the agreement would put the school under Edison's direct supervision, rather than that of the local district. The school would be able to stay in its building for at least two years, although it would begin paying rent to the district. The district agreed to discontinue efforts to revoke the school's charter.

title: Predicting Chronic Whiplash
description: Rushing to the courthouse after a car accident does not appear to prolong the symptoms of whiplash, a new study in Denmark concluded. The study, published last month in the journal Neurology, followed 141 patients who suffered whiplash, an injury to the neck and back most commonly caused by the sudden jolt of a car crash. Most whiplash victims recover quickly, but a small number are disabled for years. It has not been clear why some patients do well and others do poorly, leading a number of researchers to suggest that the possibility of awards in lawsuits could lead some patients to hang on to their symptoms. In the new study, researchers from Aarhus University found that people who could not move their necks much after their injuries were more likely to have lingering problems. Neck mobility was a much better predictor of later disability than were reported levels of pain and reductions in strength. Litigation, however, was not. People with whiplash injuries who sued within 30 days after injury were not at higher risk for long-term problems than were other participants, the researchers said. But the researchers noticed that when patients with ankle injuries, in a control group, were questioned repeatedly about neck and shoulder pain, they tended to report whiplash-like aches, too. These findings suggest that focus and attention may play a role in the development of symptoms, the researchers concluded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RABBI IRA
description: EISENSTEIN-Rabbi Ira. We record with profound sadness the passing of our honored and deeply respected teacher and colleague, past president (1952-54) of the Rabbinical Assembly, who through classroom, written word, and tireless dedication left an enduring legacy upon contemporary Jewish life. He was rabbi of the Society of the Advancement of Judaism in New York City and founding rabbi of the North Shore Reconstructionist Congregation on Long Island which he served until he became rabbi emeritus. He was the founder of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College and president of the Jewish Reconstructionist Federation. He is the author of numerous works including Judaism Under Freedom and Reconstructing Judaism. We express our deepest condolences to his children, Ethan, Miriam, and Ann and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.
