title: The Sheraton on the Hudson
description: The Manhattan skyline is impressive, and it looks even better when you aren't paying Manhattan hotel rates. The Sheraton on the Hudson in Weehawken, N.J., has rates of $164 a night in its 347 suites, which have a bedroom, living room with a sleep sofa, refrigerator and microwave. There are also views of Manhattan. The hotel is near a ferry to Manhattan (two free ferry tickets are included, as are four breakfast for all guests), and parking is free. There's also a heated indoor pool. Call (800) 325-3535.

title: Product to Protect Women From H.I.V. Is Elusive
description: Twelve years ago, when Salimata Niang first began talking about the risk of AIDS in her native Senegal, women asked her for something she did not have: a product they could use without their husbands' knowledge to protect themselves from infection with the AIDS virus.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Records BooK Sold
description: Diageo, the British beverage and food company, said that it had agreed to sell its Guinness World Records publishing business to Gullane Entertainment, which owns the rights to Thomas the Tank Engine, for 45.5 million ($64 million) in cash. Diageo, which will still own the Guinness brewing business, said it was selling the publishing unit that records all sorts of world records as part of its effort to shed noncore businesses. The Guinness Book of Records was first published in 1955. The book is sold in more than 77 countries. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: War's Toll On Children
description: In a grim accounting of the death toll for schoolchildren in war-torn Chechnya, a Russian official said today that 329 students were killed during the military campaign that began in September 1999, while 617 were disabled and more than 2,000 orphaned. Vasily Mizherikov, described by the Interfax news agency as in charge of the restoration of the republic's educational system, said that about 80 schools and 26 preschool facilities had been destroyed and that, despite the formal end of hostilities, there were no provisions for the ''upbringing or education'' of thousands of handicapped and orphaned children. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: 30 Years After the Music's Over, Morrison Still Attracts Crowds
description: PARIS, July 3  In the decades since Jim Morrison died, his grave  with his name on a simple bronze tablet and the words, in Greek, "`According to his Own Spirit"  has attracted crowds of quiet pilgrims and soulful admirers that have made it the principal attraction in the big Pere Lachaise cemetery in eastern Paris, a special place of homage for the international rock scene.

title: Supreme Court's ruling in a tobacco case is hailed as a victory for commercial freedom of speech.
description: A RULING by the Supreme Court that overturned efforts by Massachusetts to restrict tobacco advertising is being hailed by the trade associations that represent agencies and major marketers, which have long pressed to have commercial speech more fully protected under the First Amendment.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bank Shares To Be Sold
description: Indonesia will offer 10 percent of PT Bank Central Asia to the public, raising as much as $47 million, as the government reduces its stake in a lender that was nationalized during the Asian financial crisis. The lender will sell 589 million shares in a move that is expected to raise about $47 million. The sale is part of a plan to sell as much as a 40 percent stake in the lender, a quarter of which is earmarked for the public with the rest being sold to a strategic investor. On Friday, the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency delayed announcing the winning bid for the strategic stake ''to ensure an optimal outcome.''

title: Article 2001070393870958813 -- No Title
description: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Article 2001070393384805479 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Company Selling Shares
description: The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, or Sinopec, said it planned to sell as much as 12 billion yuan ($1.4 billion) worth of stock in what would be China's biggest local share offering. Money raised in the share sale would be used to buy an oil producer from its state-owned parent and to build pipelines. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: An Old (Not Oldies) Band That Still Casts a Spell
description: Depeche Mode is a lucky cult band: it happens to have a cult following big enough to fill Madison Square Garden for two nights straight. Though the 80's, the glory years for the band's dark-romantic synth-pop, are two decades behind us now, it would be a mistake to call Depeche Mode an oldies band. This is because only a cult band, not an oldies band, could have pulled off what Depeche Mode did in the first of its two Madison Square Garden shows on Wednesday night.

title: Article 2001070390221154475 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIES, HARRY
description: DAVIES-Harry. On July 1, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Jeanette. Loving father of Robert and Richard Davies. Cherished grandfather to Pamela, Sara, Hans and great grandfather to Samuel and Ian. Services Thursday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Of Time and Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; The Summer of '82
description: There was a moment during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982 when an Israeli sniper in Beirut had the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in his gun sight. The sniper, though, was under orders not to kill the Palestinian leader, because Israel felt that the world fallout would be too great -- so he snapped a picture of Mr. Arafat instead. Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was defense minister at the time. Nineteen years later Mr. Sharon and Mr. Arafat are again stalking each other. It looks like much has changed since that wild summer of '82. But don't be fooled. These two old warriors once again have each other in their gun sights. Mr. Sharon still views Mr. Arafat as a lying terrorist out to destroy Israel, and Mr. Arafat still views Mr. Sharon as a brutal thug out to destroy Palestinian nationalism. They would each like to finish what they started in 1982 by eliminating the other politically.

title: The Cubs Are Armed and Dangerous, and in First Place
description: On May 24, Jon Lieber pitched a one-hitter for the Chicago Cubs, beating the Cincinnati Reds, 3-0. The next day, Kerry Wood, like clockwork, pitched a one-hitter for the Cubs, beating the Milwaukee Brewers, 1-0.

title: The Devil Is in the Details
description: In 1922, Dr. Lewis Fry Richardson, a British physicist with a penchant for grand ideas, described how to forecast the behavior of the atmosphere.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Shunned by Mother, Tiger Gets a Human Surrogate
description: Rocky Jr., a Siberian tiger, was born on April 6 at the Six Flags Great Adventure park here to a mother who had already successfully raised two sets of twins. But the next day, zoo workers discovered that he had become a victim of a type of animal behavior they did not quite understand: his mother had abandoned him.

title: Capriati Makes Semifinals at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 3  Two points from the end of any grand slam ambitions today, on the edge of vanishing inside a Center Court turned trauma center, Jennifer Capriati rummaged through a mental hope chest, of sorts.

title: World Briefing | World: Food Illnesses Are Spreading
description: Two United Nations agencies said that food-borne illnesses once found mostly in third world nations are now a problem in industrial nations, and asked all countries to meet international standards of quality control. ''In a globalized world, we all swim in a sea of microbes,'' said Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland, director general of the World Health Organization. The Food and Agriculture Organization joined in the call. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Slaying of Jewish Settler Deals New Blow to Israeli Cease-Fire
description: JERUSALEM, July 3  The body of a Jewish settler shot and stabbed by Palestinians was found early today in the West Bank, dealing another blow to a cease-fire that has all but collapsed in a surge of violence.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report in Business Day yesterday about new forms of Internet advertising misstated the title of an executive who commented on improved creativity of ads and misspelled the name of his company, a network of sites aimed at young adults. Rick Boyce is the president, not chief executive; his company is Snowball.com, not Snoball.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRICK, SEYMOUR J.
description: BRICK-Seymour J. Of Greensboro NC (formerly, Neponsit, LI, NY; West Palm Beach, FL; Coral Springs, FL). Died on Monday, July 2. He is survived by three children, Larry, Mary-Ann and Judy; ten grandchildren; nine great grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at the Jonas home, 264 Gorden Drive, Paramus NJ on Wednesday July 4 and Thursday, July 5. Memorial contributions may be made to any Jewish charity or The National Association of the Deaf, 814 Thayer Avenue, Silver Spring, MD. 20910. Seymour was a very active, charitable member of the Jewish community and was very interested in the education of deaf children and in medical research on deafness and blindness.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Englewood: Toddler Left In Hot Bus
description: A school bus driver accused of leaving a 3-year-old boy alone in the hot bus for 90 minutes has been arrested and charged with child endangerment, the police said. They said the driver, Ismael Hertz, 38, of Englewood, drove the bus to his home last evening, thinking he had dropped off all the passengers after their first day of camp at the Lollipop Day Nursery School and Day Camp in Park Ridge. The boy, frightened but in satisfactory condition, was found around 6:30 p.m. after his mother reported him missing, the police said. The camp director, Jim Angelillo, said Mr. Hertz was fired. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: First, the Nature Bug Bit. Now It's the Ticks.
description: ABOUT four times a year, Laurence T. Penny's too-intimate working relationship with ticks of all stripe -- as natural resources director for the Town of East Hampton, he patrols some 25,000 open acres of picturesque wetlands and woodlands here and was diagnosed with advanced Lyme disease in 1986 -- shuts down his own personal resources like a bout of amnesia. Mr. Penny, 65 and known as Larry, gets disoriented, vaguely paranoid. It now seems like a bad idea watching all those bug-and-crustacean-dominated horror flicks as a kid.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: A.M.D. Settles Suit Against Alcatel
description: Advanced Micro Devices said yesterday that it settled its flash memory lawsuit against Alcatel Business Systems, a unit of the French telecommunication equipment maker Alcatel. A.M.D. originally filed suit in April asserting that Alcatel had not honored the terms of its supply agreement which stipulated that Alcatel purchase flash memory products over a two-year period. A.M.D. said that terms of the settlement had been sealed as part of the agreement. As of last quarter, A.M.D., the second-largest flash memory supplier, received 35 percent of its revenue from its flash memory business. Flash memory, which retains information even when a device is turned off, is commonly used in cell phones, digital cameras and other electronic devices. A.M.D. shares ended the day at $29.74, up 84 cents. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALTERMEIER, GLORIA J.
description: FALTERMEIER-Gloria J. On July 1, 2001 after a long and courageous battle with cancer at Cabrini Hospice. Beloved daughter of John and Gloria and sister of John Jr. and Brad. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of Rockville Centre and a 1982 graduate of University of California at Santa Barbara and 1988 recipient of a Master's degree from Columbia University School of Social Work, she was a psychotherapist practicing in NYC. Services will take place on Thursday, July 5 at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue, NYC, interment following at Greenwood Cemetery, 500 Twenty Fifth Street, Brooklyn, and further services following at Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston Street, New York City.

title: F.D.A. Faults Johns Hopkins Over Process in Fatal Study
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that researchers at Johns Hopkins University who conducted an asthma experiment that led to a healthy volunteer's death last month had not sought or received F.D.A. approval to use an unlicensed drug that was involved in the experiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MARY
description: KELLY-Mary. On July 1. Beloved wife of the late Michael J. Kelly. Devoted mother of Michael J., Eileen Cotter, Kathleen McCaul & the late Mary McDonald. Loving aunt of John, Donald and Francis O'Grady. Loving grandmother of nine and great grandmother of 20. Services were held at Leo Kearns Inc., 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, NY. Mass at Resurrection Ascension Church, Tuesday, at 9:45 AM. Interment Long Island National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Ozanam Hall, 4241 201 Street, Bayside, NY 11361.

title: Tunnel Vision; Underground And Now Cool: The L Train
description: In 1997, to the groans of everyone in the neighborhood whose lease was coming up, Utne Reader magazine declared Williamsburg to be the third-hippest place in America to live. (Just behind the Lower Garden District in New Orleans and the Inner Mission in San Francisco.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Utility Agrees To Sale
description: Eircom, the former Irish state phone company, said it had agreed to terms for its acquisition by Valentia, a consortium led by Sir Anthony O'Reilly, left, and backed by George Soros. Valentia presented an outline of its offer to the Irish markets, which allows shareholders the option of a smaller up-front payment in exchange for additional cash after several years. But the rival bidder, the eIsland Consortium, asked Eircom to explain why it chose Valentia's lower offer. If all shareholders took the deferred payments in both bids, eIsland would value Eircom at 3.03 billion euros ($2.6 billion), compared with Valentia's 2.9 billion euros. The consortium has not ruled out making another bid or challenging the decision in court. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: People
description: Alison Canning was named president for international operations at Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, London, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc., succeeding Michael Morley, who remains deputy chairman. Ms. Canning continues in her post as chairwoman at First & 42nd, London, which is being acquired by Edelman.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about federal money spent to repair eroded beaches misstated the given name of a Duke University geologist who is critical of beach replenishment. He is Orrin H. Pilkey Jr., not Owen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWSON, THOMAS DAVID
description: LAWSON-Thomas David. Age 57, died Sunday, July 1, with his family by his side. Beloved husband of thirty-three years to the love of his life, Fay. Adoring father of Allysa & Benjamin Goldman and Steffie and Andrew Gorenstein. Loving grandfather known to all as ''Bobo'' to Justin, Harris & Dylan. Son of Sally Protell and the late Leonard Lawson. Brother to William and Jon Lawson. Devoted son-in-law to Leon and Estere Milchikier. There never has been nor ever will be a man like Tom Lawson. Services Tuesday 11:45 AM, July 3 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: FED APPROVES CITIGROUP DEAL The Federal Reserve Board approved the purchase of European American Bank by Citigroup Inc. yesterday. Citigroup, which hopes to increase its commercial banking presence in New York City and on Long Island, agreed in February to buy European American, which is based in Uniondale, N.Y., for $1.6 billion, from ABN Amro Bank of the Netherlands, and to assume responsibility for $350 million in E.A.B. preferred stock. European American has 97 branches in New York City and on Long Island. Citibank has 96 branches in New York City and 27 branches on Long Island. Citigroup announced in May that it would close 19 E.A.B. branches and 5 Citibank branches if the sale was approved, and convert the remaining E.A.B. branches to Citibank branches. (Reuters)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deliberations In Terror Trial
description: The jury considering whether to impose the death penalty on Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, left, convicted of the bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania and the death of 11 people, was sent home early yesterday, in part because a juror felt ill. The jury will begin its deliberations tomorrow. Last month, the same panel declined to return a death verdict against another terrorist in the case, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24. As a result, he will receive life imprisonment. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Liberties; The Relaxation Response
description: You won't believe this: The White House is trying to get W. to relax.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Man Said to Accept Spy Case Deal
description: Robert P. Hanssen, a former senior F.B.I. agent, has agreed to plead guilty to spying for Moscow in exchange for a commitment from the government that it will not seek the death penalty against him, people familiar with the case said today.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Unions Call Two-Day Strike
description: The Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions called on workers to stay home in a two-day strike that left many businesses shuttered. The workers were protesting a recent increase in gasoline prices. The government declared the strike illegal and sent riot police on patrol, but observers reported that the streets were mostly peaceful. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Attuned to Hear 'Ka-Ching'
description: I come from a family of retailers. My mother worked for Casual Corner and my father was vice president of Federated Department Stores. We got Women's Wear Daily at home and I read it like other children read Sports Illustrated.

title: They See Dead People, and Lots More
description: Maybe the biggest laugh in ''Scary Movie 2'' comes from watching Shawn and Marlon Wayans playing college students. It's one of the few things that made me laugh, anyway -- that and Shawn's sporting what looks like Samuel L. Jackson's hair from ''Unbreakable.'' (Probably the funniest thing to the film's director, Keenen Ivory Wayans, and its co-stars and co-authors, his younger brothers Shawn and Marlon, is breaking the ''No Sequel'' promise in the ad campaign for the first ''Scary Movie.'') Otherwise, this crude comedy delivers on the ''No Shame, No Mercy'' threats from the original. Unfortunately, it all adds up to ''No Good.''

title: Cubs Too Much for Met Toothpicks
description: Rick Reed works quickly. He has been the Mets' best pitcher this season, but against the Cubs' Sammy Sosa last night, he was trying to work carefully, too.

title: Recipe: Garlic-Lemon Rotisserie Chicken With Moroccan Spices
description: Time: 2 hours

title: Decathlon Champion Broke His Idol's Record
description: Roman Sebrle of the Czech Republic was unaware of the brilliant late-May sun setting over the tiny Msle Stadium, in Gtzis, Austria. His mind was focused on the 1,500-meter race, the final event of the decathlon. He needed to run at least 4 minutes 26.68 seconds to break the world decathlon record held by his friend and countryman Tomas Dvorak.

title: Corrections
description: A listing with an article on June 20 about food programs on the radio misstated the broadcast time of ''New York and Company'' with Leonard Lopate, a weekday program on WNYC-AM that occasionally has food and wine experts as guests. It begins at noon, not 11 a.m.

title: Pelotas Journal; Of Gays and Gauchos (and Brazilian Gaucherie)
description: This city looks much like any other its size in Brazil, but its 325,000 residents are victims of a peculiar prejudice they cannot seem to escape. For more than a century, Brazilians of every class in every part of the country have believed that all the men here are homosexuals.

title: Sports of The Times; Center Stage For Families And Dramas
description: IF people here thought the royals were strange, they hadn't yet experienced an afternoon at Center Court with the Williamses and the Capriatis. Or in the contrived lexicon of all-American entertainment, ''One Life to Live'' meets ''The Simpsons.''

title: Recipe: Green Apple Pucker Float
description: Adapted from Four Seasons Hotel

title: Auto Sales Increased in June, Despite Decreases at Ford and G.M.
description: Auto sales last month rose 0.3 percent from June last year, the first monthly increase over 2000's record pace. The increase surpassed the expectations of analysts, who continued to be surprised by the strength of auto sales despite the sluggish economy. Foreign automakers, however, are still reaping most of the rewards.

title: She's Ready to Shimmy, Twirl and Roar
description: After half a century as a singer, Cheikha Rimitti didn't sound a bit old-fashioned when she made her American debut on Saturday afternoon at Central Park Summerstage. Her music has changed through the years; her backup band now is plugged in. Yet the earthy ecstasy of her music was both true to its roots and as immediate as the latest dance tracks.

title: A Stream Of Images Inspired by Surrealism
description: At the end of ''Near the Terrace,'' a dance work unlike any other, which the Chinese-born choreographer Shen Wei presented at the American Dance Festival here on Sunday, a woman clad only in a purple skirt stands atop a stagewide series of steps.

title: Racing With Ghosts: Earnhardt Will Cast a Long Shadow at Daytona
description: Stock cars are set to rumble back into Daytona International Speedway this weekend for the first time since Dale Earnhardt was killed there in February. Inside the racetrack, on the other side of the imposing asphalt banks and the white concrete walls and the hovering catch fences, a sanctuary will be established in which the participants in the Pepsi 400 will need to worry only about racing.

title: DRUG DATA COMPANY IS TOLD TO SHARE ITS GERMAN SYSTEM
description: The European Commission has ordered IMS Health, the largest collector of pharmaceutical sales and prescription data in the world, to license the way it organizes information on the German market. By denying competitors a license to use IMS's so-called brick structure, IMS, based in Westport, Conn., is abusing its dominant position in that market, the commission said yesterday. The commissioner for competition, Mario Monti, said the pharmaceutical industry in Germany was economically locked into the brick structure, closing the market to competition. IMS was the sole provider of pharmaceutical data in Germany until 1999, when NDC Germany and AzyX Geopharma entered the market. IMS has said it will appeal the decision. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: BOEING PICKS 3 COMPANIES TO HELP WITH COAST GUARD BID
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had picked three companies to work with it in a bid for a Coast Guard order for aircraft and ships valued at as much as $20 billion over 40 years. Boeing said it had chosen the Spanish and Eurocopter units of the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the engineering firm John J. McMullen Associates of Alexandria, Va., and the Litton Avondale shipbuilding unit of Northrop Grumman. The team is competing against two others for the contract. The Coast Guard is scheduled to award an initial five-year, $2.3 billion contract in April. The program, called Deepwater, aims to modernize a fleet of more than 300 ships, planes and helicopters, as well as radar and communication systems.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: A Job For All The King's Men
description: The final pieces of a Navy surveillance plane whose collision with a Chinese fighter on April 1 scarred relations between Washington and Beijing were flown from China's territory in a giant Russian-designed cargo plane. The parts were headed for Marietta, Ga., where engineers will determine whether the EP-3E Aries II can be put back together and flown again, military officials said. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Reinventing John Jay High Amid Charges of Exclusion
description: When the long-troubled John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, closed its doors for good a week ago today, the goodbyes were tinged with a mix of emotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAOR, ELIAHU
description: LAOR-Eliahu. Mitchell and Ronda Benson and Carl and Mary Olsson mourn the passing of a colleage and a friend. Our deepest condolences to his family.

title: Music to a Retailer's Ears; Sorry. Springsteen Won't Be Playing at Pottery Barn Today.
description: Billy Straus was browsing at the Virgin Records Megastore in Union Square when he saw it. There, atop a display of acid jazz and trip-hop import compact discs, was a large red placard that read: ''Music You Won't Find on a Pottery Barn CD.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGIN, STUART M., MD.
description: DOLGIN-Stuart M., MD. Son of Israel, and Diana, brother of Kalmon, Gail and Neil, beloved husband of Ellie (Roberts) and loving father of Rebecca, Ari and Heather. He was a noted gastroenterologist, beloved by his patients for the depth of his caring. Though his life was shorter than expected, he accomplished so much and touched so many. His long, courageous, painful journey has come to an end, but a new one has begun. His memory is truly a blessing for all who knew him. Services were held at the Woodbury Jewish Center on Tuesday, July 3rd. Donations may be made in his memory to the ''Woodbury Jewish Center'' to be held pending formation of the ''Dr. Stuart Mark Dolgin Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.'' Shiva will be observed at Dr. Dolgin's home. Ellie, Rebecca, Ari, Heather, Israel, Diana, Kalmon, Peggy, Brynn, Alan, Josh, Rebecca, Daniel, Gail, Amelia, Neil, Cindy, Carly, Grant, Brett, Chad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNASTER, BARUCH
description: KNASTER-Baruch. The International Network of Children of Jewish Holocaust Survivors mourns the passing of Baruch Knaster, father of our founding member Rebecca. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Rebecca and her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIB, ROSE (NEE GROSSBERG)
description: SCHEIB-Rose (nee Grossberg). Passed away July 1, 2001 at the age of 89 in San Francisco. She was the loving and loved wife of the late Sol Scheib, mother of Hilda Scheib, mother-in-law of David Handsher and grandmother of Jesse and Nora Handsher. Rose graduated from Hunter College and earned a Master's degree in German Literature. She spent 37 years teaching Hebrew at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn, N.Y She will be remembered by all who knew her for her wise heart and her kind and peaceful nature. Funeral services will be held at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens, July 5th, 2PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, SARAH
description: CANTOR - Sarah. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our member, Sarah Cantor. Our deepest sympathy to her beloved family, her husband Kevin and their son, Samuel, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Mogilny to Leafs for $22 Million, 4 Years
description: The Devils lost their second unrestricted free agent in a week when right wing Alexander Mogilny, their leading goal-scorer last season, signed a four-year contract yesterday with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Manager Still Needs To Motivate the Team
description: As manager of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, the worst team in the major leagues, Hal McRae has an unenviable job. Yet he isn't faced with a problem that managers of some better teams have: underachieving players undermining what was supposed to be a playoff season. But as McRae explained earlier in the week when his team was visiting New York, it's the manager's responsibility to get players to play up to their capabilities.

title: Washington Gets a Taste Of a Big Apple
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer may want to consider the convenience of mail-order bialys.

title: Albanians Say Trying Top Leaders Isn't Enough
description: Slobodan Milosevic was on the television, defiant. An old man drinking bitter tea looked down at a bowl of sugar.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Study of Car Loans Shows Racial Disparity in Costs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RABBI IRA
description: EISENSTEIN-Rabbi Ira. We record with profound sadness the passing of our honored and deeply respected teacher and colleague, past president (1952-54) of the Rabbinical Assembly, who through classroom, written word, and tireless dedication left an enduring legacy upon contemporary Jewish life. He was rabbi of the Society of the Advancement of Judaism in New York City and founding rabbi of the North Shore Reconstructionist Congregation on Long Island which he served until he became rabbi emeritus. He was the founder of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College and president of the Jewish Reconstructionist Federation. He is the author of numerous works including Judaism Under Freedom and Reconstructing Judaism. We express our deepest condolences to his children, Ethan, Miriam, and Ann and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. The Rabbinical Assembly Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. V.P.

title: N.F.L. Rookies Go to Class Before Going to Camp
description: When the Jets rookie Santana Moss was preparing to attend last week's National Football League rookie symposium, a sort of life-skills blueprint for young players to stay out of trouble, Moss's thoughts probably echoed those of other rookies: Do I really need to go? Aren't there better things to do with my time? Is there a showing of ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider'' I can catch?

title: Article 2001070494105218236 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Rescuers' Mission Remains Steadfast; Time's Erosions Do Not Deter Coast Guard's Vigilance on L.I. Sound
description: Everything about this place flows from a single, immutable fact: when the wailing siren of the search-and-rescue alarm rings, young men and women run down the hill from the station house to the boats. There they scramble for a few minutes with ropes and vests and clattering metal hatches, and then without ceremony they launch themselves in a small vessel onto the water to face what may come. Their breathing, in these rarefied moments, comes in truncated puffs of exhilaration. Muscle and energy are unbound.

title: The Basics: Pierce, Turn, Heat
description: ROTISSERIES come in a variety of models, but all have three main parts: the spit, the motor and the heat source.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Long-Distance Expansion
description: Verizon Communications says it intends to seek approval from the Federal Communications Commission to provide long-distance phone service in New Jersey by the end of the year. Verizon, based in New York, made the announcement on Saturday in a wide-ranging statement on the anniversary of its formation by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE on June 30, 2000. Verizon and other companies derived from the breakup of AT&T in 1984 are barred from long-distance service until they can show regulators that their local calling markets are open to competition. Verizon expects to seek long-distance approvals this year in Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Vermont, said Ivette Mendez, a Verizon spokeswoman. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: As Changeable as the Weather
description: Anyone interested in clearly understanding Japan's position on the Kyoto Protocol on global warming would search in vain through Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's statements over the last several days, during his first official overseas trip.

title: Sports of The Times; N.B.A. Stars Use Camp to Unite Children of War
description: VLADE DIVAC stood perspiring in the middle of a hardwood court a few days ago, in the middle of a summer melting pot. There were children from Croatia. From Macedonia and Slovenia. From Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Serbia and Montenegro. All playing the same game.

title: Stars Halfway To Big Numbers
description: The Yankees have played exactly half their games, a benchmark that provides a rather tidy insight into some individual performances.

title: The Final Strokes Are Kensett's Best
description: With ''Eatons Neck, Long Island,'' the Luminist landscape painter John Frederick Kensett did not have far to go for subject matter. In the late 1860's he bought land and built a studio on an island near Darien, Conn., off the shore of Long Island Sound. And in the summer of 1872, he painted about 40 views, including many of the points along the Sound and the Connecticut shore. As a group, they are known as the ''Last Summer's Work,'' since he died in December of that year at age 56.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Complaint Against Ashcroft
description: Common Cause and the Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence filed a complaint against Attorney General John Ashcroft, maintaining that he committed an ethics violation by taking a position contrary to the stance that federal prosecutors have taken in a case still unresolved. In a letter to the National Rifle Association in May, Mr. Ashcroft wrote that he believed the Second Amendment protects the right of individuals to bear arms. But in prosecuting a man for violation of a law that bars people under restraining orders from having guns, the government has argued that by Supreme Court precedent, the Constitution guarantees only a collective right to guns, through a militia. The complaint asks the inspector general of the Justice Department, the White House counsel and a judicial board on professional responsibility to investigate. Fox Butterfield (NYT)

title: Self-Contained Mechanical Heart Throbs for First Time in a Human
description: Surgeons announced here today that they had placed the first fully implantable artificial heart in a human being.

title: Accord Is Set on Timor Gap Energy Revenue
description: Australia and East Timor have agreed on how to split potentially lucrative energy revenue, a deal that is expected to channel millions of dollars to the struggling East Timorese economy, as development of rich gas and oil deposits beneath the Timor Sea begins.

title: Officer Who Shot Bronx Youth Is Fined and Avoids Jail Time
description: A New York City police officer convicted last month of shooting an unarmed youth near a Bronx housing project in 1999 was ordered to perform community service and fined $1,000 yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest In Phone Company
description: Microsoft is considering an investment in Korea Telecom, the government-controlled telephone company and software manufacturer, said Korea's minister of information and communication, Yang Seung Taik. Mr. Yang said Microsoft was one of the companies with which his ministry was negotiating. The government, which owns 40 percent of Korea Telecom, failed in February to sell nearly 15 percent of the shares locally. But officials hope that Microsoft and other foreign companies will see Korea Telecom as a route into Korea's burgeoning Internet and mobile telephone markets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: COURT TELLS ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO PAY $140 MILLION
description: St. Jude Medical, which makes devices used to treat heart disease, said yesterday that a jury had ordered the company to pay its rival, the Guidant Corporation, $140 million in a patent dispute. St. Jude, based in St. Paul, said it would ask a judge to set aside the verdict or reduce the award. Guidant, based in Indianapolis, sued St. Jude in 1996, saying the company infringed four patents related to implantable defibrilators, which are used to restore normal heart rhythm. Guidant dropped its claim on one patent, and the court dismissed another. The federal jury in Indiana ruled that St. Jude had infringed one of the remaining patents, though the infringement was unintentional, St. Jude said. That patent has expired, so the ruling will not affect St. Jude's defibrilator sales or product introductions, the company said.

title: Our Towns; Washington Slept Here. Ate Here, Too.
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON'S portrait is on the mantel downstairs. On a table upstairs sits a framed portrait of Bonnie Caffray's family. A first-floor closet is stuffed with clothes from the Revolutionary War era. Upstairs are the clothes Mrs. Caffray wears to work at Bergdorf Goodman in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, ISABEL W.
description: ROSENBERG-Isabel W. Isabel dearest.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HANSEN, FREDERICK H.
description: HANSEN-Frederick H. Happy 70th Birthday in Heaven. Craig, Jamie, Astar and Jeff

title: The 2001 All-Star Rosters
description: The All-Star teams, which were completed yesterday. Number of All-Star Games includes this year.

title: Ford Wants to Send Drivers of Sport Utility Vehicles Back to School
description: The Ford Motor Company wants to send Americans back to school to learn how to drive sport utility vehicles.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Japan Pledges $200 Million For Disease Fund
description: Japan will give an initial contribution of $200 million to a global fund to fight AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis, matching the pledge from the Bush administration. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was formerly a health minister and has supported spending on international health programs. Japan leads industrial nations in the amount of foreign aid to developing countries. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Teenage Sex Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001070494035608162 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Ex-Teacher Guilty In Sex Case
description: Frank Bauer, a former schoolteacher, pleaded guilty yesterday to coercing a 15-year-old boy to make pornographic videos of himself. Mr. Bauer, an art teacher at Salesian High School in New Rochelle until his arrest in October, met the boy online in 1999, presenting himself as a teenage girl, according to the Westchester County district attorney's office. Mr. Bauer threatened to distribute explicit pictures of other children to the boy's classmates and claim that they were pictures of the boy if the boy did not make erotic videotapes for Mr. Bauer, officials said. Mr. Bauer faces up to 15 years in prison at sentencing. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIN, JOHN A.
description: REIN-John A. Dr. John A. Rein passed away on Sunday, July 1. Born in Brooklyn, NY, in 1926 to Maxwell and Sadie Rein, Dr. Rein served in the U.S. Army as part of the Japanese Security Forces after World War II as a Second Lieutenant. He attended Ohio State on the G.I. Bill, and medical school at the University of Basel, Switzerland. After residency in Internal Medicine and Radiology, Dr. Rein was in private practice in New York for 35 years and was affiliated with St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. He served as secretary of the New York County Society of Internal Medicine from 1986 to 1990. He was a lover of opera and classical music, a gourmet chef and a Yankee fan. For the past several years he had been on the Board of the Dicapo Opera Theatre. Dr. Rein, who lived in New York City and Tuxedo Park, is survived by his wife of 28 years, Inger, and his son Jonathan, of London, England. He is also survived by his sister Constance Leeds, of New York, and eleven nieces and nephews in the U.S. and Europe. Family will receive friends Thursday evening from 79PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral services will be held Friday, 11:30 AM, from Frank E. Campbell. Private interment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Tuxedo Park. A memorial service will be held Saturday at St. Mary's in Tuxedo at 11AM. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to be made in his name to the American Heart Association.

title: Club Med Giveaway
description: Book a seven-night Club Med vacation with Vacation.com by July 15 and you won't have to worry about luggage. No, these aren't clothing-optional resorts  the offer includes a 22-inch piece of Samsonite commuter carry-on luggage. The booking must be made with a MasterCard credit card and travel must be completed by Aug. 19. The Club Meds available under this offer are Cancun (from New York) for $899 a person, and Ixtapa, Mexico, (from Los Angeles) for $1,350 a person. Prices are based on double occupancy and include air fare; only one piece of free luggage per couple. To find a Vacation.com travel agent, call (800) 876-4581.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STARBUCK'S CORP., Seattle, plans to open up in Vienna in December. Austria will be the second country in continental Europe where Starbuck's will operate. It has opened three stores in Switzerland this year.

title: Jack Welch's Legacy
description: Yesterday the European Commission officially decided to block General Electric's merger with Honeywell. For G.E.'s chief executive officer, John F. Welch Jr., the deal would have been the capstone of an illustrious 20-year career at the helm of one of the world's biggest corporations. Now, in his last six months as boss, he has to clean up the aftermath of the botched merger instead. It is a last act that casts a shadow on Mr. Welch's reputation as an infallible visionary. But if he wants to leave his post on a heroic note, he could readily do so by turning his attention to a different, longstanding problem on which he has been stubbornly retrograde -- the overdue need to cleanse the Hudson River of PCB's.

title: Can Good Public Relations Beat Brains? Look Around
description: Here is a movie that addresses a deep and painful division in American society, a schism that divides families, threatens the civility on which a democratic society depends and provokes endless, often intemperate arguments. No, I don't mean religion or the culture wars or that comparatively trivial business about red states and blue states, but the more profound and intractable antagonism between cat people and dog people.

title: Rootless as the Zip Codes Churn
description: A FRIEND of mine has spent nearly all of his working years overseas. His oldest son was born in Hong Kong, then spent his toddlerhood in China and his early school years in Japan.

title: Milosevic on Trial: Trouble Ahead?
description: To the Editor:

title: Guitars Gently Weep as Nashville Pays Tribute to Chet Atkins
description: Chet Atkins was as lean and spare and intense as Nashville is boisterous, a reticent musical craftsman who shaped and defined a city of showmen. At his funeral today, a worshipful country music industry tried to define its debt to him, finally giving up on superlatives and expressing itself as he did in the gentle picking of a Gretsch electric guitar.

title: Article 2001070491417535298 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Bush Aides Seek Compromise On Embryonic Cell Research
description: As President Bush nears a decision on whether the government should pay for research on stem cells extracted from human embryos, his advisers are struggling to mold a compromise that would satisfy both patients' advocates, who say the experiments may save tens of thousands of lives, and religious conservatives, who say the studies are tantamount to murder.

title: Capriati Rally Runs Serena Williams Off Court
description: Two points from the end of any Grand Slam ambitions today, on the edge of vanishing on a Center Court turned trauma center, Jennifer Capriati rummaged through a mental hope chest of sorts.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Taxi Drivers Strike
description: Many Chicago taxi drivers went on strike to protest a city rule that they pick up at least one fare a day in underserved areas. The Chicago Professional Taxicab Drivers Association, which represents about 2,400 of the city's 6,600 cabbies, called the 24-hour strike. City officials said the new rule was the taxi industry's idea, part of a deal that included a 17 percent fare increase. The rule is intended to stop the practice of refusing service to minorities and the disabled. Bill Dedman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Ex-Communist Named Premier
description: Lithuania's last Communist boss and popular former president, Algirdas Brazauskas, won Parliament's approval as the next prime minister after a center-right coalition collapsed in disputes over privatization and the pace of economic reforms. Mr. Brazauskas is expected to place greater emphasis on social welfare programs for people in the former Soviet republic, but President Valdas Adamkus warned that he would not tolerate any government that undermined Lithuania's strategic goals for reform and entry into the European Union. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Desert Boot Camp for Youth Is Shut Down After a Death
description: The authorities here are investigating how a 14-year-old boy died this week while participating in a rigorous boot-camp program for troubled youth in the desert west of Phoenix.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: LONG-DISTANCE EXPANSION Verizon Communications says it intends to seek approval from the Federal Communications Commission to provide long-distance phone service in New Jersey by the end of the year. Verizon, based in New York, made the announcement on Saturday in a wide-ranging statement on the anniversary of its formation by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE on June 30, 2000. Verizon and other companies derived from the breakup of AT&T in 1984 are barred from long- distance service until they can show regulators that their local calling markets are open to competition. Verizon expects to seek long-distance approvals this year in Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Vermont, said Ivette Mendez, a Verizon spokeswoman.

title: Article 2001070490157878906 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTOCK, SAM
description: ROSENSTOCK-Sam. On July 2, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Lila. Loving father of Susan, Linda Kahner, Harold, Bruce Grilikhes. Dear brother of Jack. Adoring and devoted grandfather of Jesse, Neil, Bryan and Nicole. Service Thursday 11:45AM at the ''Riverside, 76 St. & Amsterdam Av. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Red Cross or the American Heart Assoc.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I2 Technologies Forecasts A Loss
description: I2 Technologies, a maker of business-to-business software, said it expected to report a loss for the second quarter of 12 cents a share on revenue of $235 million to $240 million. The projected loss was more than double the 6 cents a share expected by analysts. ''Market conditions were much more difficult than we had anticipated this quarter -- even more difficult than we experienced in the first quarter,'' said Greg Brady, who was named chief executive two months ago. Shares closed up 37 cents, at $18.60. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Milosevic on Trial: Trouble Ahead?
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Kilgallen, a San Francisco Artist, 33
description: Margaret Kilgallen, an artist who contributed to the vibrant fusion of graffiti art, folk art, painting and installation art that emerged in San Francisco in the 1990's, died Thursday in San Francisco. She was 33.

title: Apple Will Halt Production Of Its Cube-Shaped Computer
description: Apple Computer said today that it would stop making its Power Mac G4 Cube, a machine heavy on design innovation but short on buyers, less than a year after the product line was first sold.

title: Mayor's Office Plans To Scrutinize Cuts In School Spending
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani fired yet another salvo in his long-running crusade to force the Board of Education to trim spending on central administration, with his aides announcing late yesterday that they intend to play a more active role in reviewing and proposing school spending cuts.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BroadVision Warns On Outlook
description: Shares of BroadVision Inc., a maker of e-business software, fell 18 percent yesterday after the company warned that it would post a much wider quarterly loss than expected. Citing the slowing economy, BroadVision said it expected to lose 17 to 20 cents a share for its just-ended quarter, compared with the 11-cent loss anticipated by Wall Street. Revenue will be $52 million to $58 million, it said, substantially less than the $84 million expected by analysts. The stock fell 89 cents, to $4.04. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I consider this tribunal false tribunal and indictments false indictments.''

title: THE CHEF
description: I TREAT most summer fruits like tomatoes. I keep them out of the refrigerator so they will be about the same temperature as a glass of good red wine and will give me that wonderful perfume. Peaches, nectarines and apricots especially benefit from this treatment: it gives the flesh a lush texture and keeps them juicy.

title: Article 2001070491695701329 -- No Title
description: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

title: The Quest for an Artificial Heart
description: Just when the nation was focused on Vice President Dick Cheney's electronic defibrillator, heart surgeons in Louisville took a much more dramatic step forward on Monday by implanting the first self-contained artificial heart in a desperately ill patient. The two-pound device, a small battery-driven pump about the size of a grapefruit, is to be implanted in up to four other severely ill patients as well in a small-scale clinical trial authorized by the Food and Drug Administration. The new AbioCor replacement heart, as it is called, appears to mark a major technical advance over the clumsy artificial hearts whose disastrous effects in the early 1980's threw a cloud over the field and greatly slowed further progress.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times yesterday about computer climate predictions, describing which natural features of the earth computer models can accurately represent and which they cannot, put mountains into the wrong category represented by labeling them with red, not yellow. The computer models ''struggle with'' predicting the effects of mountains; mountains are not a feature that the models ''render well.''

title: Web Sales of Airline Tickets Are Making Hefty Advances
description: The bargains available to shoppers on the Internet are becoming scarce in all but one place: the sky.

title: Big Trade Not Enough for the Big Red Machine
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Leaders To Meet
description: President Joseph Kabila and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, left, are scheduled to meet in Tanzania today in what would be the first such meeting since Mr. Kabila succeeded his assassinated father in January. Uganda, with Rwanda, has been backing rebels opposed to Congo's government of Kinshasa for the last three years. Tanzania's Foreign Ministry said the talk would focus on bilateral relations. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Reinventing the Local Diner for a Bohemian Community
description: DINERS for the most part are bygone expressions of Americana in the same way egg creams are relics of New York City's past. Decades ago diners were community hubs, slinging the sort of hash that was standard fare at the time, rich and pliable enough symbolically to fit into the universes of both Edward Hopper and Norman Rockwell.

title: 30 Years Later, He Still Lights His Fans' Fire
description: In the decades since Jim Morrison died, his grave, with his name on a simple bronze tablet and the words, in Greek, ''True to his own spirit,'' has attracted crowds of pilgrims that have made it a special place of homage for the international rock scene and the principal attraction in the big Pre-Lachaise cemetery in eastern Paris.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: First Mad Cow Case
description: The government announced Greece's first case of mad cow disease. The infection in a dairy cow in the north was detected in testing dictated by European Union regulations in response to the recent outbreak of the disease in Europe. Cases have been confirmed in 13 countries in Western Europe and in the Czech Republic but a vast majority have been in Britain. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: West Bank Settler Dies, Another Blow to Faltering Cease-Fire
description: A Jewish settler's body was found today in the West Bank shot and stabbed, apparently by Palestinians, dealing another blow to a faltering cease-fire that has all but collapsed in a surge of violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSEY, ADRIENNE
description: WALSEY-Adrienne. Of NY. On July 2, 2001. Beloved mother of David (Jennifer) and Craig (Meredith) Walsey. Cherished daughter of Doris and Joseph Kirsch. Dear sister of Lynne (Neal) Dorf. Services to be held at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY., on Friday, July 6th at 3 PM. Information ''Gutterman's'' 1-800-992-9262.

title: What Arafat Didn't Say
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Diplomat at U.N. Seeks Asylum in U.S., Police Say
description: One of the highest-ranking Iraqi diplomats at the United Nations has asked for asylum in the United States, the police in New York said today. And a second Iraqi diplomat, who is thought to have disappeared about two weeks ago, may also be trying to defect, other envoys say.

title: BOMB PLOT INSIDER DETAILS TRAINING
description: An Algerian convicted of trying to carry out a terrorist attack in Los Angeles on the eve of the millennium celebration testified yesterday that he had received money and training at camps in Afghanistan that American officials say were run by Osama bin Laden.

title: A Delicacy From the Land of Palms
description: HEARTS of palm have a place in the minds of many Americans. It's somewhere among white leather loafers, Waldorf salad and country clubs. It's a nostalgic little spot, worthy of parody perhaps, but not one that makes you very hungry.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Moves To Cut Costs
description: Deutsche Bank plans to reduce its annual expenses by ''significantly more'' than the 600 million euros ($508 million) the company earlier announced as it tries to increase profit as markets fall. The bank, based in Frankfurt, is looking to cut costs across the board, a company spokesman, Walter Schumacher, said without being more specific. Earlier, the bank said it planned to eliminate 2,600 jobs, leading to costs savings of 1.5 billion euros through 2003. Expenses were up 4.3 percent in the first quarter after rising 34 percent last year.

title: On Board the Bombay Express: A Rolling Feast of India
description: THE most important thing when traveling by train in India is not whether you have a seat in first class (more comfortable) or second class (more congenial), not whether you have confirmed tickets or even your destination. The most important thing is the size of your neighbor's tiffin carrier, the Indian lunchbox. If you are lucky, you will be seated near a generous Marwari matron whose way of making your acquaintance is to hand you a hot roti stuffed with potato saag.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. On this our anniversary day, July 4, our memorable moments linger on. Children, Grandchildren & Joyce

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARGIULO, EMILY ANNE
description: GARGIULO-Emily Anne. The Society and the Institute of NPAP sadly mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague. Harvey A. Kaplan Sy Coopersmith Presidents

title: Cuba After Castro
description: To the Editor:

title: Review of Nissan Car Loans Finds That Blacks Pay More
description: A statistical study of more than 300,000 car loans arranged through Nissan dealers from March 1993 to last September -- believed by experts to be the largest pool of car loan data ever analyzed for racial patterns -- shows that black customers in 33 states consistently paid more than white customers, regardless of their credit histories.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space yesterday about the length of time that three Bronx politicians served in prison for their roles in protesting bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques misspelled the given name of one of them. He is Councilman Adolfo Carrin Jr., not Adolpho.

title: Recipe: Wild Strawberry Float With Raspberry Champagne
description: Adapted from Le Bernardin

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Restroom Surveillance Alleged
description: A superintendent of a Midtown Manhattan office building placed small cameras in two women's restrooms and watched the closed-circuit signal, the authorities said yesterday. The superintendent, Zdenko Ceselka, 34, of Iselin, N.J., installed cameras on the sixth and seventh floors of 597 Fifth Avenue, near 47th Street, in February, the Manhattan district attorney's office said. Mr. Ceselka was charged yesterday with unlawfully installing a viewing device, a violation, which carries a maximum penalty of 15 days in jail. Had the images been recorded, he could have been charged with a felony and faced four years in prison. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CAROLE H.
description: KLEIN-Carole H. Passed away suddenly on July 2, 2001 at age 67. Author of 7 nonfiction books, most notably ''Aline'' and ''Gramercy Park.'' Member of PEN, The National Arts Club and the Board of Goddard College. She was a faculty member at The New School. Loving wife of the late Ted U. Klein. She is survived by her family: devoted children, William and Emily; loving brother, Les Honig; cherished grandchildren, Samuel, Dylan and Sophie. Services will be held on Thursday, July 5, at 10 AM at The National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 22 about high school students who invest in the stock market misidentified the person shopping for clothes with Anish Vora. He is Vikram Venkatraman, not Nirav Patel.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraqi Diplomat Defects

title: New Jersey Legislature Advances Special Taxing Plan for Arenas
description: A bill authorizing a sports and entertainment tax district to help pay for a $355 million sports arena here has been introduced in the Assembly, a development that some lawmakers said moved the project one step closer to reality.

title: Bodies Surge Back and Forth, As Lives Are Lived in a Night
description: There was a thudding sameness to four of the pieces Nicholas Leichter presented on Thursday at the Flea Theater. But with his new ''Free the Angels,'' Mr. Leichter establishes himself as a choreographer exploring the fusion of concert and popular dance forms with imagination and authority.

title: Gina Cigna, Operatic Soprano, Dies at 101
description: Gina Cigna, a dramatic soprano whose career flourished in the 1930's and 40's, and who was the first to record the title role of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' died on June 26 in Milan. She was 101.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Drugstore Credit Upgraded
description: The credit and loan ratings of Duane Reade Inc. were raised yesterday by Standard & Poor's after the company, a drugstore chain based in New York City, raised $130.6 million to pay down debt. Standard & Poor's said it raised Duane Reade's corporate credit and senior secured bank loan ratings to BB- from B+ and increased the company's subordinated debt ratings to B from B-. S.&P. also took the ratings off CreditWatch. Duane Reade runs 180 stores, more than half of them in Manhattan.

title: College Graduates Will Train for 5 Weeks as They Teach Summer School
description: Teach for America, which recruits college graduates to go into inner-city and rural schools, has opened a training institute in New York City that will help staff this year's summer school program in city schools.

title: What Arafat Didn't Say
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADDOCK, JAY JOSEPH
description: RADDOCK-Jay Joseph. Died peacefully at home in Boca Raton on July 3. Jay was the son of David and Rebecca who came to this country from Galicia. From his days at Yeshiva Torah V'odath in Brooklyn's Williamsburg, to his last years as philanthropist at Florida Atlantic University, he was a unique personality and achiever. He valued Jewish causes and education in general, and gave of himself generously to both. He was a major influence on his children and wife and loomed larger than life. He never realized in life how much he was revered and loved. He is survived by his wife Sharon; his chilren David, Kiki, Jonathan and Bert; and grandchildren, Juliet, Jacob, Gregory, Rebecca, Alexander, Jessica and Michael. Funeral will be held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, at graveside on July 4, 3:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PINE, HELEN C.
description: PINE-Helen C. 1921-1997. Dearest Muttie. Happy birthday. Dearest love and best friend. Miss you every day. Love, Leslie

title: Falun Gong Deaths Set Off Dispute on Suicide Report
description: At least 10 followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement were reported on Tuesday to have died at a labor camp in northeast China last month, either in a group suicide or from torture.

title: Boxer Injured in Fight Aboard Carrier Dies
description: A boxer who sustained severe head injuries in a bout last week aboard the U.S.S. Intrepid died on Monday night, a hospital official said yesterday.

title: U.S. Accuses Emery Airlines Of Racial Bias
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit yesterday against Emery Worldwide Airlines, accusing it of racial discrimination and harassment against black employees at a trucking center in Kearny, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JACK
description: COHEN-Jack. Dearest cousin Jack, you always stood tall, even unto death. Miriam, Charlotte and families

title: Recipe: Rotisserie Baby Back Ribs With Herbes de Provence
description: Time: 1 1/2 hours 2 racks baby back ribs (about 1 pound each)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Racial-Profiling Rally
description: A white supremacist plans to hold a rally today to support racial profiling by the police. The organizer of the rally, Richard Barrett, 57, leads the Nationalist Movement of Pearl, Miss. Last year, also in Morristown on the Fourth of July, he held a rally opposing affirmative action. This year's rally is scheduled to be held on the steps of the Morris County courthouse. Annette Alston, an organizer of a counterdemonstration, called Mr. Barrett's gathering a hate rally.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Conservationists Buy Island
description: A 21-acre island just three miles from downtown Portland has been bought by the Maine Coast Heritage Trust, a conservation group, which will prevent development there. The island, last owned by a Hollywood producer and a Maine real estate developer, cost $1.5 million. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Curious Fallout From Bush v. Gore
description: The final months of the Supreme Court term that ended last week brought a spate of unexpected decisions and unusual voting lineups. The decisions can best be understood against the backdrop of this term's most controversial decision, Bush v. Gore -- the decision that handed the presidency to George W. Bush.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: World Briefing | World: China Set To Join Trade Group
description: Negotiators on China's membership in the World Trade Organization said the major obstacles had been overcome, making it likely the country could join the group either this year or early in 2002. The deal, which cleared up questions about services and agriculture, is expected to be sealed at a trade meeting in November. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: U.S. Price Controls Are Said To Worsen Power Shortage
description: Officials in California and Nevada said today that the controls the federal government recently imposed on wholesale electricity prices throughout the Western states appeared to have caused some generators to withhold supplies, worsening power shortages this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWSON, THOMAS
description: LAWSON-Thomas. Dear, dear friend for over 40 years. The ''Doc'' as he was known to his inner circle of friends was my adopted brother. Thanks for all the fabulous times, the ups and the downs. We shared them all. Tommy was so much a part of our family. We will miss you more than you will ever know. Sincere condolences to his wife Fay, also my lifelong friend, and to his daughters Allysa and Stephanie, to his brothers Jon and Billy, to his mother Sally all I can say is we lost a real gem. We share your pain. Janie and Larry David Joan David

description: To the Editor:

title: American Crews Gain in Henley Regatta
description: American crews dominated the first of five straight days of knockout elimination heats at the Henley Royal Regatta yesterday in England, advancing five eight-oared crews to the Round of 16 in the Temple Challenge Cup.

description: William C. Thompson Jr., who is running for city comptroller, dismissed a report in The Village Voice that accused him of breaching federal securities laws while working as an investment banker.

description: A new battleground for viewers is emerging in cable television: late night.

description: Time: 10 minutes 1 tablespoon orange blossom or other mild honey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTELIUS, MARGARET M. (NEE BOWER)
description: HARTELIUS-Margaret M. (nee Bower), 78. Of Manahawkin, NJ on July 3, 2001. Beloved wife of Paul V. Hartelius Jr. Loving mother of Paul V. Hartelius III of Fanwood, NJ and Sharon A. Siefken of Cape May, CT. House, NJ. Also survived by 4 grandchildren. For information Thos L. Shinn Funeral Home, 10 Hilliard Dr., Manahawkin, NJ. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Manahawkin Methodist Church. In lieu of flowers Memorial contributions can be made to Pine Shore Art Association, 94 Stafford Avenue, Manahawkin, NJ 08050, Scholarship Fund.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Traffic In Northerners
description: Desperate North Koreans fleeing their impoverished Communist country are getting into the South on Chinese boats with the help of local brokers, South Korean officials said. The police arrested five broker suspects and six Koreans they said had entered illegally. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESLIE, CHARLOTTE ELIZABETH (NEE BROWN)
description: LESLIE-Charlotte Elizabeth (nee Brown). On July 2, 2001 following a long illness. Beloved mother of Judith L. Wallick of Stowe, VT; Robert E., Jr. of Brooklyn Heights and Donald F. and Charlotte of Fairfield, Connecticut, and loving grandmother of Duane, Leslie, Taylor, Jennifer, Amanda and Joshua. A 1945 graduate of Connecticut College, she retired from Dewey Ballantine in 1991. She was a volunteer with The Junior League, the Garden Education Center, and the Arts Council of Greenwich, CT and a member of the New York Horticultural Society and Shenorock Shore Club. Funeral services will take place on Friday, July 6 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Riverside, CT at 10:00AM. Burial to follow at White Plains Rural Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Brussels Sues Swissair In Move to Aid Sabena
description: The Belgian government sued the Swissair Group today, escalating a dispute over keeping Belgium's troubled national carrier, Sabena, afloat.

title: Pilots Protest an Airline's Bid To Switch Hawaii Flight Plan
description: American Airlines pilots are protesting a plan by the airline to trim its flying time from Dallas to Honolulu, saying a flight plan used by the airline would force pilots to fly dangerously low.

title: From the Cretaceous To a Pan Near You
description: The Cayuga Lake air had been so still at night that sitting on the porch swing, by the water, it seemed as if you might hear a car door slam two miles away. Morning broke, hot and hushed.

title: Article 2001070493469163880 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Mets and Yankees Asking State For $300 Million in Transit Work
description: The Yankees and the Mets are seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in highway and transit improvements from the state as part of their efforts to build new stadiums in the Bronx and Queens.

title: MOTOROLA AND DELPHI TO DEVELOP ENGINE CONTROLS
description: The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, an auto-parts maker, and Motorola said yesterday that they would develop electronic control systems to make engines more efficient. Terms were not disclosed. The systems would help manage automobile engine functions like spark ignition and fuel injection, said Heather Drake, a Motorola spokeswoman. Delphi, based in Troy, Mich., and Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., developed the first engine-control unit more than 20 years ago, they said in a statement. Shares of Motorola rose 13 cents, to $16.90. Delphi fell 43 cents, to $16.35.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the start of summer school in New York City misstated the percentage of students in grades three to eight who were ordered to attend summer school last year but did not enroll. The percentage was 12.1 percent of the 62,537 students, not 2.1 percent.

description: The OMI Corporation, which transports crude oil and petroleum products, said it had asked banks for a $280 million in loans to pay for 10 new ships.

description: YANKS

title: Congressman Is Accused of Asking Woman to Lie
description: A flight attendant has accused Representative Gary A. Condit of asking her to lie in connection with the investigation into the disappearance of a Washington intern, but Mr. Condit today denied making such a request.

description: McGLINCHY-Rev. Edward Hugh John, S.J. Beloved brother of Agnes Masterson, Alice Kellecher and James. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at MurrayWeigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road, Bronx, N.Y. on Wednesday, 7-9PM and Thursday, 10:3011:30AM. Mass of Christian Burial is at Murray-Weigel Hall on Thursday 11:30AM. For more information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: The Rotisserie Reignites
description: AMERICANS fell out of love with rotisserie grilling sometime after the 1950's, seduced away by hibachis, then kettle grills, then inexpensive gas grills. But rotisseries are back with a vengeance -- both in restaurants and in backyards -- thanks to a renewed interest in live fire cooking, new technologies and the return of some old-fashioned tastes.

title: Business Travel; Some changes in corporate policies could have long-term consequences for airlines and hotels.
description: TO better understand the reasons for the recent collapse in the business of business travel, you might want to go back to last summer.
