description: KAUFMAN-Esther Goldring. July 4, 1919. Happy Birthday Mom. We miss you. Love, Paul, Kitty, Rocky, Willy

title: Close Calls at Wimbledon
description: Of Jennifer Capriatis 19 straight victories in the majors this year, only five matches went three sets.

title: Founding Fathers, Warts and All
description: To the Editor:

title: Potato Salad With a Bang
description: POTATO salad is almost as much a part of the Fourth as fireworks, and this one, combining potatoes, mussels and a light vinaigrette, is far more colorful and festive than the usual potato-and-mayonnaise combination.

title: History Is Remade, One Bronzed Gentleman After Another
description: While most of his countrymen are firing up the grill and checking out the fireworks, Ben Franklin will spend today resting inside a studio on the Brooklyn waterfront, alongside his associates George Washington, James McHenry and Charles Pinckney, or at least Charles Pinckney's head.

title: A Parade of Floats Up and Down the Avenues
description: AS the silver tray held aloft by a waiter passed through the dining room at Le Bernardin, heads turned. On it were six Champagne flutes filled with a jewel-like crimson liquid, each capped with a bit of pink froth and a scoop of magenta sorbet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUTCH, MARION
description: KLUTCH-Marion. On July 2, 2001. Former Professor of Guidance and Counseling at Hunter College. Loving mother of Richard & Ellen Esformes. Cherished grandmother of Rachel Esformes. Memorial service on Thursday 1 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Recipe: Ginger Float With Green Tea-Wasabi Ice Cream
description: Adapted from Atlas

title: Honeywell Regroups as Chief Resigns
description: Hours after the European Commission rejected the $45 billion acquisition by General Electric of Honeywell International, Michael R. Bonsignore, the chairman and chief executive of Honeywell, tendered his resignation.

title: Why Not to Stonewall in the Midst of a Scandal
description: David F. D'Alessandro could not believe what he was hearing. His fellow executives had just agreed to lie to the federal government.

title: Tampa Scans the Faces in Its Crowds for Criminals
description: Camera shy? Then steer clear of Tampa's nightlife district.

title: King Makes An Offer To Lewis
description: Don King has offered Lennox Lewis's promoters $12.5 million to turn over promotion of the expected Lewis-Hasim Rahman rematch to King. Otherwise, King said, they can pay him the same amount of money to obtain Rahman's participation in the fight.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday about campaign finance reform incorrectly identified the home state of Bob Ney, the chairman of the House Administration Committee. He is from Ohio, not California.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Penalty For Silvester-Linked Firm
description: An investment fund that received lucrative government contracts from Paul J. Silvester, left, the former state treasurer who pleaded guilty to federal bribery charges in 1999, has agreed to pay a $5 million settlement to the State Ethics Commission. Between 1997 and 1999, Crescendo Venture Management and two affiliated firms paid more than $1.1 million in consulting fees to three men. Federal authorities are investigating the men for their roles in funneling illegal payments from investment firms to Mr. Silvester in exchange for contracts. The authorities contend many of the consulting fees were made more for political access than for work done by the three men, John F. Droney; his former partner, Peter Kelly; and Mr. Kelly's friend George C. Finley. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Meets With Pope
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi had his first private audience with John Paul II since taking office last month. The visit gave the leaders a chance to discuss the pope's pet projects, ranging from state support for Catholic schools to globalization and third world debt relief. As they parted, the 81-year-old pope said to Mr. Berlusconi, 64, ''You are a youngster; I am not.'' Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Quickly at Home on the Upper West Side
description: OUEST broadcasts its exuberance in a big, bold sign with big, fat letters that hit you like a slap on the back. Inside, red-leather booths wrap around diners like a bearhug that can't be wriggled out of. The place looks good and it feels good. Long before the food arrives, Ouest, with disarming confidence, has most diners eating out of the palm of its hand. It obviously thinks it's the sexiest thing to land on upper Broadway in many a day. And it's right.

title: A Success for BP in Moscow: Fill It Up, Boris?
description: Almost four years after sinking half a billion dollars into a Russian oil company, BP still has had more frustrations than profits. But it has met with quiet success in one of the least likely places -- Moscow's retail gasoline market.

title: Recipe: Hazelnut-Coffee Float With Hazelnut Brittle
description: Adapted from Strip House

title: Spiritual Ecstasy and Klezmer Frenzy
description: The gymnastically based choreography of the Pilobolus Dance Theater has often been eye-catching, mind-boggling, quirky, witty, sexy and creepy. Once in a while, it can also suggest spiritual themes, as it did on Monday night when the company opened a four-week engagement at the Joyce Theater.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Shadowy Party Heats Up British Racial Tensions
description: The sudden spasm of racial violence that tore through this former mill town the last week in June, leaving in its wake burned-out stores, boarded-up windows and a shaken and angry population seemed on the surface to have come from nowhere.

title: Excerpts From Europe's Statement
description: Following are excerpts from the European Commission's statement yesterday on why it was blocking General Electric's proposed acquisition of Honeywell International:

title: Executives At Goldman Selling Shares
description: As chief financial officer of the Goldman Sachs Group, David A. Viniar has had plenty of practice handling large sums of cash. That experience should be serving him well this year as he takes in more than a quarter-million dollars a day from the sale of his own stock in the firm.

title: California Gas Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the effect of the collapse of the merger between General Electric and Honeywell International on the reputation of G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr., misstated the title of his successor, Jeffrey R. Immelt. He is president and chairman-elect, not chief executive.

title: New Findings Likely to Prompt More Study of Cancer Drug
description: Researchers in Seattle reported on Tuesday that a breast cancer drug, tamoxifen, may have an unexpected effect on the development of subsequent cancers.

title: Badillo Accuses Bloomberg of Conducting Smear Campaign in Mayor's Race
description: Herman Badillo yesterday accused his Republican rival for mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, of engaging in a smear campaign against him, a charge dismissed immediately by his opponent's representatives.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Don't Cry The Blues, Just Kidnap A Chanteuse
description: ''Everybody's Famous,'' which was nominated for an Oscar as best foreign film this year, might be described as a cuddly Flemish remake of Martin Scorsese's ''King of Comedy.'' The clammy chill of desperation that made that film as creepy as it was funny is replaced, in Dominique Deruddere's new movie, by antic, compassionate good cheer. Mr. Deruddere, who both wrote and directed this picture, occasionally glances toward the troubling underside of our obsession with celebrity, but he waves away the sharp, satirical potential of his story in favor of plucky, genial optimism.

title: U.P.S. AGREES TO BUY 75% OF UNI-DATA OF GERMANY
description: The United Parcel Service has agreed to buy 75 percent of the closely held Uni-Data of Germany to increase its business of managing inventory and distribution for technology companies in Europe. Terms were not disclosed. U.P.S. expects to complete the cash purchase in two to three months, a spokeswoman, Lynette McIntire, said. Uni-Data will become part of the UPS Logistics Group. Uni-Data, based near Munich, had sales of about $150 million in 2000, United Parcel said.

title: Prosecutor Says Guilt Is Clear In Killings At Muffin Shop
description: A man who was stopped by the police minutes after a deadly robbery attempt at a Manhattan muffin shop was ''like the little kid caught with his hands in the cookie jar,'' a prosecutor told a jury yesterday. While he denied all charges, physical evidence and police and civilian testimony linked him to the crime, the prosecutor said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Rutherford: Stagehand Dies At Arena
description: A stagehand at Continental Airlines Arena fell 20 feet from a ladder to his death Sunday night, after he apparently failed to attach a safety harness properly, officials said. The stagehand, Kevin Finn, 41, of Brooklyn, fell just before the performance of ''Feet of Flames,'' an Irish dance show starring Michael Flatley, known for ''Riverdance.'' Mr. Finn landed behind the curtain just six feet from Mr. Flatley. His fall prompted a 40-minute delay in the show, said Sgt. Al Della Fave, a state police spokesman. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Poll Shows McGreevey With a Big Lead Over Schundler
description: A day after he got a promise of political help from President Bush, Bret D. Schundler, the Republican candidate for governor, found out today just how much he may need it over the next few months. The latest and most extensive of three post-primary surveys showed New Jersey leaning heavily in the direction of his Democratic rival, James E. McGreevey.

title: Founding Fathers, Warts and All
description: To the Editor:

title: Inheriting the Future
description: On the Fourth of July, the instinct is always to look backward in time, to the first news of that great Declaration or to the days when Emerson could truly say that ''the vast majority of the people of this country live by the land, and carry its quality in their manners and opinions.'' That habit of looking backward is, for most of us, a little like taking a rowboat under the pier once a year to see for ourselves that the pilings are still sound. It restores our confidence. It also reminds us how many transfigurations this nation has gone through over time and assures us that through all those changes there is a discernible continuity of political purpose, the same vested interest in independence. We still carry the scale of this land in our manners and opinions, if no longer the actual touch of its soil. We also carry something that our ancestors could not: the scale of our own history.

title: His Palette Is Fire, His Canvas the Sky
description: OOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOH . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASTA, JOHN EDWARD, JR.
description: NASTA-John Edward, Jr., 52. On July 2, 2001 of Upper Saddle River, NJ. Beloved husband of Annette (nee Annunziata). Loving father of Lauren Alexandra and Taylor Beth. Cherished son of Theohara Mary (Pappas) and the late John Nasta. Dear brother of Vincent, Michael, Carmella Fiumarra and Raefel Spero. John was a member of the General Partner of Omega Advisors in New York, NY. He was a parishioner of the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, and was a member of Tiro A Segno (Italian social gun club) in New York City. Visitation will be held on Tuesday from 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave., Ramsey, NJ. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Thursday, July 5, 2001 at 10:00 A.M. at the Church of the Presentation, 271 W. Saddle River Rd., Upper Saddle River, NJ. Interment to follow at the Ascension Cemetery in Monsey, NY. Donations to the Imus Ranch, 660 AM, WFAN RADIO, 34-12 36th Street, Astoria, NY 11106 Attn: Kara Dugan or The American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For directions or further information please call 201-327-0030 or visit us at www.vanemburghsneider.com

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARMON, BERT
description: HARMON-Bert. It is ten years since you passed away. You're always in our hearts. We miss you. The Harmon Family

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Battle For Oil Company
description: A small oil company is at the heart of a battle between Russia's fourth-largest oil producer, Tyumen Oil, and Norex Petroleum, a Cyprus-registered oil service company that is owned by Canadians. Tyumen took over management of the oil company, Yugraneft, which is owned jointly by Norex and a Tyumen subsidiary, after a regional court prevented Norex from voting most of its shares at a key shareholder meeting. Norex, owned in part by Alex Rotzang, a Russian-born Canadian national, said the takeover was illegal and pledged to fight it in court.

title: Factory Orders Rose in May Led by Demand for Vehicles
description: Orders placed with factories rose in May for the third time in the last four months, led by increased demand for autos and semiconductors, the government said today. Inventories fell for a fourth consecutive month, suggesting manufacturers may have to bolster production after an eight-month decline.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Japan Pays a Return Visit

title: A Local Institution Makes His Rounds
description: They are everywhere, it seems, those brown United Parcel Service trucks and white FedEx vans that rumble down the street to deliver books, legal documents, computers, swimsuits, gifts, CD's and the like to America's homes and businesses.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Toast to Independence

title: Vallone Seeks an Issue to Rev Up His Mayoral Campaign
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who has languished for months in the back of the Democratic pack, has begun to retool his low-flying campaign for mayor. The goal, Mr. Vallone's advisers say, is to find an issue that can galvanize his candidacy and change his image with voters, to the extent that voters have an image of him at all.

title: Ruth Sanger, 82, Expert on Blood Grouping
description: Dr. Ruth Ann Sanger, a blood researcher and a co-author of a blood-group manual that helped make transfusions safer, died on June 4 in Britain. She was 82.

title: Article 2001070491641993626 -- No Title
description: Iconsider this tribunal false tribunal and indictments false indictments.

title: On This Fourth: The Choices Before Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, BENJAMIN, DR.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Benjamin, Dr. Died peaceably and courageously on July 2. He was a devoted and loving husband of Irene for over 65 years. He adored his sister Shirley, and an inordinately proud father of Larry, Peter and John. Loved by his daughters-in-law Robin, Kerry and Blair. He saw his future in his grandchildren Mara and Jeff Tanzman, Eve, Michael, Noah, James, Jill and Adam Rubinstein. He relished being a great grandfather to little Noah. Of strong constitution and opinions, he served as a caring dentist to generations of patients and maintained loyalty to the Educational Alliance and Surprise Lake Camp for their support of his growth and development in his youth. As a proud and loving Jew, he supported the state of Israel from its birth and always cared about the well being of synagogues. His memory will be a blessing.

title: Founding Fathers, Warts and All
description: To the Editor:

title: Parts of Free Trade Pact Are Made Public
description: The draft text of parts of the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas agreement was made public yesterday, giving the first official view of negotiations to create a trade area stretching from the Arctic circle to the tip of South America.

title: Black Patriotism Enlarges The American Tradition
description: As the country celebrates Independence Day, it is still difficult for many to accept that our wonderful political legacy is, in part, the work of people who owned people very much like me. It is possible that some of those they owned were among my ancestors. The lives and characters of these founders were indelibly marked by that fact.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLAN, MARK J.
description: CAPLAN-Mark J. Remembered always, forever in our hearts and minds. Love Mom and Dad

title: An Economy for Kosovo, One Building Block at a Time
description: Two years have passed since NATO successfully expelled Serbian forces from Kosovo, a remarkable achievement. The experience of NATO and the United Nations in the subsequent occupation, however, has proved that it is easier to liberate a territory than to develop it.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 84.78 cents, up from 84.65 cents on Monday. The dollar traded at 124.34 yen, down from 124.35 yen.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Signs Wireless On Standard
description: Nokia, the largest maker of mobile phones, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay royalties to Qualcomm on sales of next-generation phones, expanding a 1992 agreement. The announcement is a lift for Qualcomm, which vigorously sought to bring Finland's Nokia into a group of companies including Motorola and Ericsson that had previously agreed to pay the company royalties on its code division multiple access technology. Qualcomm shares surged 10 percent on the news, to close at $63.87. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHTIGAL, BEATRICE K., MD.
description: NACHTIGAL-Beatrice K., MD. On July 3, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Irving. Devoted mother of Suzanne, Maxine and Daniel. Cherished grandmother of Katherine, Elizabeth, Kim, Ariel, Julian and Mischa. Services Thursday 1PM at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Dawn Kelly, Jaredd Mooney, Jessie Kremidas and Nate Peterkin, Perkins School for the Blind, Watertown, Mass., June 7, 2001

title: Taking Home a Taste of Puerto Rico
description: THOUGH it was decidedly not served in my house when I was growing up, somewhere along the way I acquired the taste for roast suckling pig. If I see it on a menu, I can't pass it up. So when I heard about a wonderful little Puerto Rican restaurant in East Harlem that specializes in roast suckling pig -- a lechneria -- I was on my way.

title: The Henley Scheduled To Begin
description: Since it began in 1839, only the two world wars have forced the cancellation of racing at the Henley Royal Regatta. But this year Britain's foot-and-mouth disease outbreak followed by the worst flooding of the Thames in a century almost canceled this venerable grande dame of rowing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the reinstatement of a lawsuit challenging Yeshiva University's policy of excluding same-sex couples from university housing misspelled the surname of a Court of Appeals judge in some copies. She is Judge Carmen B. Ciparick, not Ciparik.

title: Mordecai Richler, Novelist Who Showed a Street-Smart Montreal, Is Dead at 70
description: Mordecai Richler, the cranky and combative Canadian novelist and critic whose sometimes ribald writing exposed the heart of Old World Montreal while skewering bourgeois ambition, the roots of Jewish identity and the Quebec separatist movement, died yesterday in a Montreal hospital. He was 70.

title: Sampras May Be Gone, But Agassi Keeps Focus
description: The moment Pete Sampras's hold on Wimbledon was interrupted by Roger Federer and Lleyton Hewitt's winning streak was snipped by Nicolas Escud, Andre Agassi was in position to have a clear view of a Wimbledon title.

title: Carole Klein, 67; Biographer and Writer on Youth
description: Carole Honig Klein, a biographer and author of other nonfiction works, died on Monday from injuries after being struck by a car on the Upper East Side. She was 67 and lived in Manhattan.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Branch From Paris

title: Op-Art; Carrying a Torch
Poison Control Center Loses Certification Amid Staff Upheaval
description: A poison control center that fields 30,000 calls a year from 24 upstate counties has lost its national certification after a turbulent month in which all 14 staff members resigned to protest the firing of the center's administrative director.

title: TV Notes: Cable Expands Its Late Shows
description: Anew battleground for viewers is emerging in cable television: late night.

title: Carmen Bucher Wirth, 88, Hotel Owner in Rome
description: Carmen Bucher Wirth, the owner of the Hassler Hotel in Rome, died on June 27 in a Rome hospital. She was 88.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Friday about posters in Berlin seeking the return of Lucian Freud's portrait of the painter Francis Bacon, stolen there in 1988, misstated the ages of both artists at the time the portrait was painted. Mr. Freud was 29, not 42; Mr. Bacon was 42, not 31. The article also misstated the year of the portrait. It was 1952, not 1951. In addition, the article misstated which of Mr. Freud's birthdays will be celebrated next year in a major retrospective of his work at the Tate. It will be his 80th, not 90th.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Making Way For Stock Exchange
description: As of last Saturday, residents had vacated 335 of the 435 apartments in a building to be razed to make way for a 50-story New York Stock Exchange tower, the landlord said yesterday. The landlord, Rockrose Development Corporation, has a contract to sell the building, a 28-story tower at 45 Wall Street, to New York City and New York State for $160 million, and it expects to deliver the building empty by the end of the year, when demolition is scheduled to begin, said Sofia Estevez, director of operations at Rockrose. Rockrose has been battling a tenants' association that disputes the public need for the $1 billion subsidized stock exchange project, the start of which faces the possibility of a delay. The developer is using relocation benefits to encourage renters to leave.

title: The Briton in Charge: Sober, Polite, and Tough
description: Inside the austere courtrooms where Balkan war crimes are tried, the judges have at times fallen asleep, lost their temper with witnesses and scolded lawyers, even reminding one from the United States that she was not on an American television show.

title: Public Lives: No Affinity for Trees, but a Nature Crusader Nonetheless
description: WASHINGTON  HE was never exactly Mr. Outdoors.

title: Leveling the Playing Field, but for Whom?
description: WASHINGTON  A NEW freshman class is about to enter the University of California, a class in which the percentage of Hispanic students leaped by 18.2 percent and the percentage of Asian-American students rose by 8.7 percent.

title: Independence Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Milosevic on Trial: Trouble Ahead?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Help From The Heavens
description: State officials are hoping that rain will help douse fires that have burned 193,000 acres across Alaska and kept more than 1,000 firefighters busy. ''It's been really dry,'' said Joe Zoleell, a spokesman for the State Forestry Division. ''The fire season has been kind of big the past couple of weeks.''

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on June 22 about high school students who invest in the stock market misidentified the person shopping for clothes with Anish Vora. He is Vikram Venkatraman, not Nirav Patel.

title: AT ARRAIGNMENT, MILOSEVIC SCORNS HIS U.N. ACCUSERS
description: Slobodan Milosevic appeared today before an international tribunal that has accused him of crimes against humanity, and he dismissed the court with disdain as an ''illegal organ.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Kingfisher Selling Superdrug
description: The hardware retailer Kingfisher, whose stock has dropped 20 percent this year, said it would sell Superdrug and spin off Woolworths within a month, almost a year after announcing plans to focus on home-improvement and consumer electronics. Kingfisher said it would sell Superdrug to Kruidvat Beheer for 280 million ($397 million). Kingfisher said in September that it planned to spin off Woolworths and Superdrug. Eight months later, it said it would sell the businesses, but last month, the company said the spinoffs would go ahead. ''It's yet another flip-flop from Kingfisher,'' said Simon Irwin of BNP Paribas.

title: World Briefing
description: WORLD

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Deutsche Telekom Expands
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest telephone company, has extended its reach into Eastern Europe, after Croatia's government agreed to sell it an additional 16 percent of the country's fixed-line phone monopoly, Hrvatske Telekomunikacije, for $424 million. In 1999, Deutsche bought an initial 35 percent for $850 million. H.T. posted profits of about $100 million last year. Deutsche Telekom already owns Hungary's main fixed-line phone company, Matav, and controls or operates telecommunications companies in the Czech Republic, Poland, Slovakia and Ukraine. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Kitchenware For a Kitchen In the Canyon
description: AS my husband and I were stocking up on camping gear for two nights in the Grand Canyon, a question arose: Which would be more difficult, the seven-hour hike down the trail or eating well once we got there?

title: Little Bighorn Reverie
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Appeals Court Bars Firing of Transsexual
description: A New Jersey appeals court said yesterday that transsexuals were protected by state laws against discrimination, as it ruled in the case of a doctor who was fired after he began dressing as a woman in preparation for a sex change.

title: The Rugged Trail Above Silicon Valley
description: OF course,'' said David Bruce, with a touch of pity and mild condescension, ''you are a flatlander.'' Sooner or later, one gets called lots of things in this dodge, but flatlander was something new.

title: Alfonzo Returns In Nick Of Time
description: Ailing players have contributed to making the Mets an ailing team, unable to score and play consistently.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Fighting Uproots 72,000
description: More than 72,000 people were displaced in two states after the outbreak of two separate ethnic clashes in the last month, according to the Nigerian Red Cross. Muslim Hausas and Christian Jarawas fought over the imposition of Islamic law in one northern state, causing 22,000 people to flee; 50,000 more are said to have fled another state after clashes between the Azara and Tiv ethnic groups over the killing of a traditional ruler. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Working By The Rules
description: Pilots at Cathay Pacific Airways began a job action yesterday after negotiations with the carrier's management over salary and job conditions foundered. The protest took the form of a work-to-rule policy, under which the pilots strictly adhered to Cathay's operating manual on issues like when they report to work. Such actions typically cause delays, although Cathay reported only routine delays yesterday. John Findlay of the Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association told The Associated Press that the pilots would not escalate their action as they await a move by Cathay. The airline said it would not reopen talks until the union called off the action. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Hail to the Sweets
description: WHEN it comes to choosing wines for all-American holidays, the reflex action is to summon up zinfandel as America's own wine. Pshaw. Zinfandel is genetically identical to primitivo, a southern Italian red grape, so you may as well drink an Apulian red at your barbecue today.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Victory For Contraception Law
description: A state appeals court upheld a California law requiring employers to cover contraceptives in their prescription drug plans, rejecting Catholic Charities' argument that the law infringed on employers' religious freedom. Since the California law took effect last year, both the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and a federal court in Washington State have said that an employer's offering a drug plan without contraceptive coverage amounts to discrimination against women. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: 143 Are Reported Dead in Crash Of Russian Airplane in Siberia
description: A Russian airliner with 143 passengers and crew members crashed tonight near the Siberian city of Irkutsk on a flight from Yekaterinburg in the Ural Mountains to Vladivostok in the Far East.

title: True or False Or a Bit of Both
description: A COMMON indictment of public schools is that they no longer offer upward mobility to most immigrants. It is said that in the first half of the 20th century, children learned English, went to college and joined the middle class but that many of today's immigrants are more likely to drop out, take dead-end jobs or end up in prison.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Lernout Sells A Unit
description: Lionbridge Technologies will buy the Mendez unit of Lernout & Hauspie, the troubled Belgian speech technology company, for $27 million in cash plus an additional $6 million to pay off Mendez debt. Mendez, a translation services and software provider, had been for sale for months as part of Lernout & Hauspie's bankruptcy restructuring. The unit, which is profitable, has about $80 million in annual revenue and was initially valued at $160 million, but the asking price was lowered repeatedly when few interested buyers appeared. Lionbridge, based in Waltham, Mass., provides multilingual content management systems. It said it would finance the purchase by selling preferred stock to institutional investors. The transaction, which is expected to be completed in the third quarter, is subject to approval by courts in the United States and Belgium. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Houston Is Ready To Talk To Knicks
description: Allan Houston and the Knicks cannot sign a new deal until July 18, but they are taking a first step toward each other this week, hoping to begin negotiating a new contract by Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 13 with an article about a series of disputes at the National Arts Club referred incorrectly to Nilda Mesa, a painter and member of a dissident group, Concerned Artists of the National Arts Club. She participates in many of the club's activities, including its annual meeting, and her husband is a third-generation club member, but she is not a member.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Bank to Consolidate Staff In New Tower on 42nd St.
description: CIBC, formerly the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, has had a presence in New York since 1869, two years after it was founded in Toronto. But that presence has become diffused. CIBC World Markets, the investment and merchant banking operation of CIBC, is scattered throughout Manhattan, with employees at 200 Liberty Street in the financial district; at 425 Lexington Avenue, across from Grand Central Terminal; and in other locations.

title: Founding Fathers, Warts and All
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Buddha Bar In Chelsea
description: The State Liquor Authority held a hearing yesterday for a proposed restaurant at Chelsea Market that would be an offshoot of the Buddha Bar, a popular Paris establishment. Irwin Cohen, the market's developer, said that the Buddha Bar in Chelsea, owned by the same group of international investors that owns the one in Paris, would accommodate 500 people, but would not seek a cabaret license. Mr. Cohen said a lease had been signed for the space on 16th Street and Ninth Avenue, but no work would begin until all permits had been granted for the project, which was reported yesterday in The New York Post. An authority spokeswoman said no date had been set for a decision on the liquor license. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Europe Ends Bid by G.E. For Honeywell
description: As Europe's chief antitrust regulator bristled at what he called ''political interference'' from the United States, the European Commission today formally blocked General Electric's proposed $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International.

title: Yankees Showing Championship Strut
description: Baseball's sleeping giant has awakened, and the way the Yankees are playing at the midpoint of their season, it might be that only the All-Star Game break will stop them.

title: In Politics, A Billionaire Is Just Mike
description: MIKE had someone call to extend an invitation to drop by and talk politics for a while. Why not? You go through life only once. So the other morning was spent schmoozing with the candidate while he polished off a bowl of cold cereal at Mike for Mayor headquarters, on East 56th Street.

title: A New 'Big Brother'
description: When the new edition of ''Big Brother'' kicks off tomorrow night, it will resemble its previous incarnation in almost no way other than its title and its host, Julie Chen, the reporter from the CBS ''Early Show,'' who, despite some pretty nasty comments about her role last year, is back. Otherwise CBS and the show's new producers seem to have decided to wipe out the experience of last summer as if it were an especially traumatic memory.

title: Life, Liberty And the Pursuit Of Oratory; The Declaration's Musical Cadence To Be Heard Today in Philadelphia
description: It was sweltering in Philadelphia that day. Mosquitoes and horseflies from the stable next door drilled in the stifling air of the Pennsylvania State House. But the delegates were stoic in formal coats, wigs and frilly shirtfronts, swatting and sweating through the hot, slow hours as they debated the treasonous document.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, JUDITH (NEE ENTIN)
description: LEVITT-Judith (nee Entin). Age 60, of cancer on June 15, 2001 in Palo Alto, CA. Graduated from Evander Childs HS (1957), CCNY (1961). Librarian (Stanford, UC Davis, UC Berkeley and Storyteller. Beloved wife of Karl Levitt (of Palo Alto) for 41 years; mother of Larry Levitt (of Oakland, CA) and Deborah Pasturel (of Los Altos, CA); sister of Ken Entin (of San Jose, CA) and Bruce Entin (of Los Gatos, CA), and grandmother of Ciera Pasturel & Forrest Pasturel (of Los Altos, CA). Contributions may be made to: Friends of the Palo Alto Library for the Children's Library, 270 Forest Avenue, Palo Alto, CA. 94301.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ELLEN (NEE MANION)
description: SULLIVAN-Ellen (nee Manion). On July 1, 2001, of Garden City, New York. Beloved wife of Joseph. Loving mother of Ellen, Jenifer, Joseph, David, Pamela and Marina. Dear sister of Peter and the late Edward. Cherished grandmother of six grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave., at 12th St, Garden City, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Thursday, 10 AM. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Guard Accused Of Assaulting Inmate
description: A Camden County corrections officer was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting a female inmate. The officer, Sgt. George Dobleman, 33, was arrested in Florida by the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Department and is being held there in $250,000 bail. Sergeant Dobleman, who has worked in the county for 13 years, has been suspended without pay, according to the Camden County prosecutor's office. Officials said the sexual assault occurred on June 16 and the charges were filed by the county prosecutor's office on June 29. Sergeant Dobleman left for Florida one day before the charges were filed, officials said. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Maybe Mies and Le Corbusier Could Tell the Diff
description: Those midcentury-modern designs may be beautiful, but they can be expensive. Now a European company, Steelform (www.steelform .com, 011-39-0577-310-051), is offering reproductions of items by Mies van der Rohe, Eileen Gray and Le Corbusier, among others. A current sale offers two Le Corbusier leather and chrome chairs like the one below and one Eileen Gray chrome and glass side table for $1,999, a price that covers shipping, delivery (about four weeks), taxes and duty. The furniture is assembled in Italy and, if the customer is dissatisfied, can be returned within seven days -- at the company's cost.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: O'Neill Optimistic Before G-7 Address
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that he would carry a message of optimism about the United States economy to a meeting with his counterparts from the other big industrial nations on Saturday in Rome, where the main topic will be the faltering world economy.

description: What if a madman had invaded Andrea Yates's home in suburban Houston and drowned her five children?

title: Producers And Actors Reach Accord
description: About 10:30 p.m. here on Tuesday, after reaching a tentative agreement on a contract that ends months of trepidation about an actors' strike, the chief bargainer for the producers turned to the man who represented actors for a moment of reflection.

title: And the Decorators Said, Let There Be Pink
description: MANY who have passed through this sleepy hamlet on eastern Long Island have wondered about the huge stucco house sitting just off Montauk Highway at the western edge of town. The 42-room mansion, Villa Maria, is owned by the Amityville Dominican Sisters, a Roman Catholic congregation with headquarters on Long Island. This month it has been transformed into a decorator show house by 37 interior designers, decorators, decorative painters and landscapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, BENJAMIN, DR.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Benjamin, Dr. Died peaceably and courageously on July 2. He was a devoted and loving husband of Irene for over 65 years. He adored his sister Shirley, and an inordinately proud father of Larry, Peter and John. Loved by his daughters-in-law Robin, Kerry and Blair. He saw his future in his grandchildren Mara and Jeff Tanzman, Eve, Michael, Noah, James, Jill and Adam Rubinstein. He relished being a great grandfather to little Noah. Of strong constitution and opinions, he served as a caring dentist to generations of patients and maintained loyalty to the Educational Alliance and Surprise Lake Camp for their support of his growth and development in his youth. As a proud and loving Jew, he supported the state of Israel from its birth and always cared about the well being of synagogues. His memory will be a blessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRAY, GEER, ANNA YVONNE, M.D.
description: WRAY - GEER - Anna Yvonne, M.D. Passed away after a long illness on June 30, 2001 in New York City. Services will be held on Friday, July 6 at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive. Viewing 4-6, service to follow. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions in memory of Anna Yvonne Wray-Geer, M.D. to The Sickle Cell Disease Association of America, 200 Cooperative Pointe, Suite 495, Culver City, CA. 90230-8727 or Association of Black Cardiologists, 6849 B-2 Peachtree Dunwoodey Road, Atlanta, GA. 30328.

description: THIRTY years have passed, so I am ready to admit publicly that my mother was right when she warned that I would ruin my eyes if I read in bed with a flashlight. But I still maintain that it was worth it.

description: THE HOTHOUSE

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Catholic Man Shot To Death
description: A breakaway Protestant paramilitary group, the Red Hand Defenders, claimed responsibility for killing a Roman Catholic man in Antrim. The man, Ciaran Cummings, 19, was waiting for a ride to work when two men on a motorcycle shot him at close range. Residents said the killing was intended to heighten tensions before the Protestant Orange Order's parade at Drumcree on Sunday, which has become an annual flash point. But the Red Hand Defenders said the killing was retribution after a local election gave two council seats to Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Cheaper and Hand-Held, With a Retooled Engine
description: If they build it cheaply, will they come? That is the question Casio is posing with its new Cassiopeia BE-300 hand-held Pocket Manager. At first glance, the $299 BE-300 looks like a bargain compared with other Pocket PC devices. Like Compaq's popular iPaq hand-held as well as Casio's own line of more expensive devices, the BE-300 has a bright screen (capable of showing more than 32,000 colors) and a Compact Flash expansion slot that accepts plug-in wireless modems, more memory and Ethernet connectors for tapping into corporate networks.

title: A Monkey Saves a Monk, Who Thereby Is Made Wiser
description: Light and dark struck a satisfying balance in the second program presented by Pilobolus Dance Theater on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Ely Callaway, Golf Club Maker, Dies at 82
description: Ely Callaway, a versatile and charismatic business leader who founded the Callaway Golf company, the world's largest maker of golf clubs, died today at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 82.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Plans To Free 400 Civilians
description: India announced steps to improve ''people to people'' ties with Pakistan, saying it wanted to set a positive tone for next week's summit meeting. India said it would release more than 400 Pakistani civilian prisoners, 200 of them fishermen held for straying into Indian waters. Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, who will meet in India from July 14 to 16 with the Pakistani military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, announced that the prisoners, some held in Indian jails for years, would go home as soon as legal formalities are completed. The coast guard was ordered to stop making arrests. John F. Burns (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: AFAMILY PRODUCTION Scott Lipsky, a former vice president of Amazon.com, has been named chairman and chief executive of Lot 47, a Manhattan independent film distribution company he founded with his brother Jeff in 1999. Jeff Lipsky, a co- founder of October Films (which was sold to Barry Diller, also in 1999, for $150 million) serves as president of Lot 47, which has released 15 low- budget films, including "The War Zone," a drama about incest in a rural English home that was directed by the actor Tim Roth; and "The Ballad of Ramblin' Jack," a documentary about the singing cowboy Ramblin' Jack Elliott made by his daughter Aiyana. A third brother, Mark Lipsky, a veteran film and television marketing executive, is the company's executive vice president.

description: REDDOCK-Philip, 88. Of Hollywood, FL, passed away July 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Judith, a loving father of Jason, Carol (Howard) Feldsher, a cherished grandfather of Lauren and Ross, a devoted brother of Shirley (Paul) Rosenthal and brother-in-law to Frank Milner. Funeral services are today, Thursday, 12:30 PM at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: North Korean's Trip Barred
description: Hwang Jong Yop, the top North Korean to defect to the South, was denied permission to go to Washington to testify before Congress. South Korean officials said they were concerned about the safety of Mr. Hwang, 78, former secretary of North Korea's Workers Party, who defected in Beijing in early 1997. The National Intelligence Service said talks with Washington were needed before such a trip. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Connecticut Takes Action Against Rental-Car Tracker
description: For now at least, it looks as if only the highway patrol can enforce speeding violations. The Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection has filed a complaint against a New Haven car rental agency that used Global Positioning System equipment to track speeding customers.

title: Mayoral Ambitions, Paired With Tradition
description: It was a day filled with parades, street fairs and large crowds, precisely the kind of day in which New York City politicians immerse themselves in the time-honored tradition of person-to-person contact.

title: Buy, Buy. Sigh.
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting the Gulf of Mexico
description: Balancing energy and environmental interests in the Gulf of Mexico has long been a challenge to Washington and state governments along the Gulf Coast. After initially planning to open a vast new area to oil and gas drilling, the Bush administration has wisely scaled back its expectations. But even its more modest proposal for drilling in eastern gulf waters should be blocked for now by Congress.

title: MetroStars Strike Late For Victory
description: At the end, the MetroStars' players hugged as if they had just won the Major League Soccer title. Winning a game that appeared lost is one thing, but an added bonus tonight was that the MetroStars buried a substantial winless streak with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, KATHARINE MOTT
description: MARTIN-Katharine Mott. Died Sunday, July 1, 2001, at the age of 102. Wife of the late George Read Martin. Mother of the late William Mott Martin. Survived by one son, George Jr., six grandchildren, thirteen great-grandchildren and two great-great grandchildren.

title: Glitches Stymie Medical School Applicants
description: APPLICANTS to medical school could end up learning more about bugs this summer than they ever thought they would. But they aren't getting a crash course in viruses; rather, they are learning about all the ways a computerized system can go wrong.

title: Famiglietti Likes Clearing Barriers
description: Until the United States national track and field championships in Eugene, Ore., two weekends ago, Anthony Famiglietti, a 3,000-meter steeplechaser, planned to get a summer job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUBIN, JOHN
description: TRUBIN-John. On July 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna (Glassman) and loving father of Priscilla and Andrew Trubin, their devoted spouses Richard Lewis & Virginie de Haugoubart; four grandchildren: Beatrice and Judd Lewis and Paul and Edouard Trubin. Beneficiary of kind and caring friends. Funeral services Friday 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment to follow at Knollwood Park Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Capriati's Rush to Win at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England -- Bounce, bounce, serve, winner. Ball, please. Jennifer Capriati was clearly in a hurry today on Center Court, and it was all going her way, at sub-hour speed. "I was such an early starter and prodigy but I feel like a late bloomer," she would say, perhaps guilty on this day of trying too hard to make up for lost time.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: It's a Wrap; It's a Laugh

title: Oshima Journal; After 90 Years, Small Gestures of Joy for Lepers
description: On a recent dreary afternoon, as heavy rain drenched this remote island in the Inland Sea, the sounds of unbridled merriment resonated through the scrubbed halls of the Oshima National Sanitarium, where leprosy patients were conducting their annual karaoke contest.

title: You've Got Maelstrom
description: Jed Horovitz considers himself a fairly spare and organized person. At Video Pipeline, the New Jersey-based video promotion company of which he is president, he keeps a clean desktop, both real and virtual.

title: Taking a Breather on the Mideast
description: After suffering two major rebuffs in the Middle East in less than a week, the Bush administration is now expected to pull back and reconsider what kind of leadership role the United States should play in the region, senior officials say.

title: Spain Botches a Tourney, But Spaniards Play Well
description: The European Championships that ended Saturday in Tenerife in the Canary Islands seem to have earned the distinction of being the worst organized tournament in the history of international bridge. The Spaniards got the blame for inadequate preparation, and the tournament came close to collapse. It was a nightmare for Gianarrigo Rona of Italy, president of the European Bridge League, and he pulled no punches at a news conference.

title: Play Money? Not to These News Investors
description: JUST as a day trader combs business publications for tidbits that could affect a share price, Jrme Charretier, a 24-year-old French business student, anxiously listens to the news stations in his car, hoping to make it home in time to adjust his portfolio.

title: State of the Art: Portable Keyboards Let You Process Words Anywhere
description: Max parks his hoverbike in front of his housing pod's acrylic dome; the artificial-intelligence sentry scans his retinas, then waves him inside. After switching on the hologram player, Max unloads his laptop, a $200 tablet that weighs one pound, contains no moving parts and can be dropped without damage. Its batteries are half depleted  only 350 hours of power left. He points the machine at his home computer and presses the Send button; the words he wrote on the road are silently beamed to the desktop machine, where they appear as though being typed by a secretary high on caffeine.

title: Economic Scene; Living wages are practical and don't let theory get in the way.
description: IN an era of increasingly free markets, it is a little surprising that the ''living wage'' movement has caught on in America.

title: Christian School Questioned Over Discipline for Wayward
description: Charles Sharpe made millions in the insurance business, then decided to use his wealth to make the world a better place, one child at a time.

title: Bush Focuses on Football And Religion-Based Plan
description: Two hundred and twenty-five years ago Thomas Jefferson was worrying about last-minute changes to his prose in the Declaration of Independence, and pesky insects.

title: Slow and Steady Wins, if Not Lost in the Mail
description: Tired of seeing flags, birds and flowers on stamps? At Sea Turtle Postage Stamps of the World, a collection compiled by two philatelists, there are more than 800 images of turtles (www.2xtreme.net/nlinsley/).

title: All-Stars as Rare as Winning Streaks for Mets
description: When he called in his final All-Star selections about 11:15 a.m. yesterday, Bobby Valentine did not know Yankee Manager Joe Torre had selected seven of his own players. Even if he had, Valentine said, it would not have made a difference.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a letter from the family of a convicted drug dealer to Roger Clinton, former President Bill Clinton's half-brother, misstated the surname of the Clintons' mother in some copies. She was Virginia Clinton Kelley, not Clinton.

description: Eric Lindros said last night that he wanted to play for the Rangers and that he had asked them to try to trade for him.

Ratko Mladic.

description: WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Bush today nominated a seasoned criminal prosecutor, Robert S. Mueller III, to be the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, an agency buffeted in recent months by accusations that it has been undisciplined, mistake-prone and poorly managed.

description: An article last Thursday about a decision that the United States had violated international law in the case of two German brothers who were executed in Arizona in 1999 misstated the name of the international accord that requires the police to inform foreign detainees of their right to seek help from consular officials from their own countries. It is the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, not the Vienna Convention on Consular Protection.

title: Assessing a Curmudgeonly Existence
description: When people are driven to describe Desmond Drumm -- and he tends to drive them to do just that -- they call this severely repressed lifelong Irish civil servant things like ''a bitter old pill.'' And even he admits that the chief mourners at his funeral ''are likely to be a small group of unsplit infinitives.''

title: Faith, Public Dollars and Charity; Religion and Government Aid Intertwine in Some Programs
description: The state government pays all the cost of running the Lutheran Home for Children on Hoboken Street here, but as far as Michele Peavey is concerned, she and the dozen or so young homeless children she helps care for are in the hands of God, not Caesar.

title: Piazza To Stay On Active Roster
description: The Mets expect to keep Mike Piazza on the active roster through this weekend's series at Yankee Stadium, but Piazza felt some pain in his fractured left big toe when he got into a crouch yesterday. He may not catch until next Thursday, the Mets' first game after the All-Star Game break.

title: Laura Foreman, 64, Director Of Dance at the New School
description: Laura Foreman, the director of dance at the New School University and a visual artist, writer and teacher, died on June 15 in Manhattan. She was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADDOCK, JAY JOSEPH
description: RADDOCK-Jay Joseph. The membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Florida, announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member Jay Raddock and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Sharon, and their family. Robert P. Adler, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

title: The Graduation of Ms. Moffett
description: To the Editor:

title: Predictions Come and Go, But No Word On Stadiums
description: George M. Steinbrenner's birthday came and went. (He turned 71 yesterday.) And on the eve of the latest installment of the subway series, there still was no semblance of a deal in sight for new ballparks for the Mets and the Yankees.

title: CURRENTS: COLLEGE BUILDING; So That Electrons May Dance While College Actors Strut
description: Nicholas Grimshaw, 61, the London architect responsible for the Channel Tunnel's sleek Waterloo Station terminal and the Eden project in Cornwall, has won a competition to design a $50 million electronic media and performing arts center at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. Dr. Shirley Ann Jackson, president of Rensselaer, is to make the announcement today. The center, whose glass atrium overlooking the Hudson is shown in a rendering above, will have multimedia performance rooms and studios, galleries for electronic and traditional visual arts, a multipurpose theater and a recital hall. It is to be completed in fall 2003. Mr. Grimshaw's first American building, the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center in St. Louis, is to open in November. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIN, JOHN A.
description: REIN-John A. Dr. John A. Rein passed away on Sunday, July 1. Born in Brooklyn, NY, in 1926 to Maxwell and Sadie Rein, Dr. Rein served in the U.S. Army as part of the Japanese Security Forces after World War II as a Second Lieutenant. He attended Ohio State on the G.I. Bill, and medical school at the University of Basel, Switzerland. After residency in Internal Medicine and Radiology, Dr. Rein was in private practice in New York for 35 years and was affiliated with St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. He served as secretary of the New York County Society of Internal Medicine from 1986 to 1990. He was a lover of opera and classical music, a gourmet chef and a Yankee fan. For the past several years he had been on the Board of the Dicapo Opera Theatre. Dr. Rein, who lived in New York City and Tuxedo Park, is survived by his wife of 28 years, Inger, and his son Jonathan, of London, England. He is also survived by his sister Constance Leeds, of New York, and eleven nieces and nephews in the U.S. and Europe. Family will receive friends Thursday evening from 79PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral services will be held Friday, 11:30 AM, from Frank E. Campbell. Private interment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Tuxedo Park. A memorial service will be held Saturday at St. Mary's in Tuxedo at 11AM. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to be made in his name to the American Heart Association.

title: Some Clinton Policies Find a Home With Bush
description: From the stage of a small auditorium at Harvard, Robert E. Rubin prodded the Bush administration to carry on Bill Clinton's economic policies. And in many ways it is. Despite their clashes, a number of Mr. Clinton's policies march on under President Bush.

title: Perceptions of the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINLEIN, JOSEPH J., JR.
description: HEINLEIN-Joseph J., Jr., age 65. Of Sayville, NY, suddenly on Wednesday, July 4th. Retired Vice President with Avon Products in NYC. Life Loyal Sigma Chi. Member of Sayville Yacht Club and Board Member of Mercy Center Ministries. Loving husband of Lorraine. Dear father of Michael (Maria), Joseph (Lisa), and Katherine. Devoted grandfather of Bryan Joseph, David Michael, Jordan Joseph and Matthew Benjamin. Brother of John. Cherished son-inlaw of Ruth Kelly and brother-inlaw of George Kelly and Carol Capel. Reposing on Friday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM, at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Hwy., West Sayville. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Saturday, at St. Lawrence RC Church. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Mercy Center Ministries, 436 W. Main St., Patchogue, NY 11772, appreciated.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Standards, Handled With Care
description: Diana Krall is a strange sort of jazz-world pop star. On Friday night, when she walked onstage at Carnegie Hall for what is now her annual JVC Jazz Festival performance (imaginative bookings aren't the festival's forte), her gait and gestures were awkward. She then sat at her piano, with her back to half the audience, and remained seated with little animation throughout the show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, MYRNA
description: HELLER - Myrna. Cherished mother of Marc and Martin. Dear sister of Helene Elfman. Dear friend of Richard Pleninger. Loving grandmother of Brandon, Rory, Jonathan & Alyssa. Services at Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave, Maplewood, NJ, Thursday at 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWEK, ALICE
description: DWEK-Alice. Your legacy will live forever in the hearts of those who love you. Our deepest sympathies to Cyril, Myrna, Nevil, Alicia and Stanley. Lauren and Eyal

title: Forest Officials Address Unusual Uses of Land
description: By statute, and by roadside proclamation, the national forests, that vast empire of public lands that stretch across one-twelfth of the United States, are lands of ''many uses,'' including logging, ranching, hunting, skiing and camping.

title: Sheik, a New Yorker, to Be Tried In Turkey Over a Prayer Session
description: A Muslim preacher who is an American citizen has been ordered to stand trial on charges of insulting the secular government, his assistant said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHNER, CLAIRE
description: SCHECHNER-Claire. Beloved wife of the late Louis, loving mother of Rhoda Tagliacozzo and Janet Phillips, grandmother of Eric, Amy, Alex and Abigail.

title: To See the Cutting Edge Against a Soft-Focus Background
description: Repertoire, a contemporary-furniture company that helped introduce Bostonians to cutting-edge design 15 years ago, is challenging the competitive New York market with a showroom and retail shop in SoHo. Its most compelling feature is a 15-foot-square luminous conference room wrapped in soft fabric. ''The furniture here is about shape,'' said David Piscuskas of 1100 Architects in Manhattan, who designed the shop. ''I wanted to silhouette those forms against this glowing background.'' The store, owned by Rick Garofalo, has exclusive New York rights to handmade furniture by Romeo Sozzi, a Milanese designer. (His Theo leather desk is $10,975; his Isotta chair, $1,283.) It also has the Victor sofa by Antonio Citterio for Flexform (with upholstery as chic as a Chanel jacket, $7,595 depending on fabric) and porcelain bowls, plates and vases from Hering Berlin ($85 to $300). 75 Grand Street (Greene Street); (212) 219-8159. DONNA PAUL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CAROLE. MEREDITH MONK
description: KLEIN-Carole. Meredith Monk / The House Foundation deeply mourn the passing of our longtime supporter and friend. Our deepest condolences to her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWAIK, STANLEY NATHAN
description: ZWAIK-Stanley Nathan. 82, died on July 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Anne (Lehman) for more than 53 years. Loving father of Judith Tarlo and Stephanie Greenberg and father-in-law of David Tarlo. Adored ''Papa'' of Howard and Joseph Tarlo and Andrew and Dori Greenberg. Cherished brother, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. For more than 50 years, Stanley distinguished himself as an attorney specializing in immigration law and as an active member of his community. His devotion to the causes of war veterans led to his staunch activism in the Jewish War Veterans of America. He was elected National Commander of the JWV in 1982 after serving two terms as National Judge Advocate. Whether serving nationally or locally as Commander of Post 90 in Jamaica, Queens, Commander of Queens County, Commander of New York State or member of numerous committees, Stanley led this organization with the wisdom and sound judgment demonstrated in all aspects of his life. He was a mentor, leader, confidant and friend to all who knew him. Funeral services will take place on July 5, 12:30PM at Nassau-Riverside North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI. For information about Shiva please call Riverside 516487-9600. Donations in his memory may be sent to: Jewish War Veterans of America, 1811 R St. NW, Washington DC 20009, att: Karen, or to a charity of your choice

title: A Playwright Who Found the Courage to Look
description: THE struggle to become what we long to be is often defeated by the labels forced upon us. Tags are easier to digest than the complexities and yearnings of a human soul. They rarely wash off. Our job defines us. Race defines us. Poverty defines us.

title: Medical Examiner Is Still Trying to Determine Exact Cause of Boxer's Death
description: The New York City medical examiner is still trying to determine the exact cause of death for Beethavean Scottland, the boxer who lapsed into a coma and later died after being knocked out in a fight aboard the U.S.S. Intrepid on June 26. Meanwhile, Hasim Rahman, the heavyweight champion who trains at the same gym as Scottland, has agreed to pay for Scottland's funeral.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Davenport Revving Up For Williams
description: Lindsay Davenport was the one slumped in a courtside chair while Venus Williams's father started a euphoric tap dance atop a Wimbledon television booth after the final last year.

title: Last Bell Rings for Historic Schools
description: SHORTLY after vacation-bound boys and girls streamed into the early afternoon sunlight two weeks ago, a Mayflower van pulled up to the McMillan School in Detroit, and workers unloaded 1,000 cardboard moving boxes. The school, built in 1895, had been ordered closed, but there were rumors of a reprieve. As they left, the students and teachers did not know if they would return in the fall.

title: Two Worlds, Gently Colliding
description: SHE'S a babe and he's a slacker, but there's more to it than that.

title: At Belmont, Xtra Heat Shows She Belongs
description: Last November, Xtra Heat looked hopelessly outclassed as she stumbled past the wire at Churchill Downs after finishing 10th in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies. But her trainer, John Salzman, knew his chestnut was still developing and plotted out an ambitious schedule.

title: Senior Savings at Pan Pacific Hotels
description: Travelers 55 and older can take advantage of senior rates at several Pan Pacific hotels. In San Francisco, for example, the senior rate is $189 through Aug. 31 (versus the standard $365 rate). Through October in Vancouver, seniors pay $208 for a harbor-view room or $176 for a city view; standard rates are $313 or $345, respectively. Overseas, the Pan Pacific Bangkok has senior rates as low as $99 (versus $225 standard rates) through Dec. 31. For a full listing of hotels and rates: (800) 327-8585 or www.panpac.com .

title: 10 Folders or 2? Some Tips for Organizing E-Mail
description: IT really doesn't take long to learn about and set up folders and filtering," said Catherine M. Beise, who teaches about computer systems at Florida Gulf Coast University in Fort Myers. "Every decent program has them." The Help features in your e-mail program usually tell you all you need to know to set them up. But keep in mind:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on June 27 about a music licensing agreement between Napster and two British trade associations, the Association of Independent Musicians and the Independent Music Companies Association, erroneously included one band among those covered by the agreement. Garbage is not represented by either group.
