description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Optimistic Before G-7 Address
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that he would carry a message of optimism about the United States economy to a meeting with his counterparts from the other big industrial nations on Saturday in Rome, where the main topic will be the faltering world economy.

title: Preparing for the Tour
description: DUNKIRK, France, July 5  Lance Armstrong is riding high, yes, indeed. His wife, Kristin, is four months' pregnant with twins, he won the Tour of Switzerland impressively last week, he has just been elevated to the top spot in rankings of the world's professional bicycle racers and, on Saturday, he sets off as the overwhelming favorite to win his third successive Tour de France.

title: Found in Clutter, a Relic of Lincoln's Death
description: It was there, neatly folded in a glass-topped black box, on a steel shelf in the poorly lighted back corner of the Connecticut Historical Society's cluttered storage area, obscured by other Civil War relics and about 76 years of dust.

title: Student Privacy Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: In First Start in Majors, Wilson Is King for a Day
description: The first four times he was called to the big leagues, Vance Wilson logged a total of one inning on the field. He caught the bottom of the eighth inning at Wrigley Field on April 24, 1999. He was the Mets' Moonlight Graham -- one career game, no plate appearances.

title: The Graduation of Ms. Moffett
description: To the Editor:

title: The Graduation of Ms. Moffett
description: To the Editor:

title: Black and White Create a Standout Backdrop
description: SAY ''neutral color'' and most people will think gray or beige. But black-and-white wallpaper (from stripes reminiscent of men's shirting to a flock of wacky birds) can also provide a neutral background for colorful upholstery and bright accessories. ''Black-and-white wallpaper is chiaroscuro,'' said Mario Buatta, the New York decorator. ''You don't see it too often, but I think it's great.'' And crisp black-and-white wallpaper won't fight with the colors in a room.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Advertising Club of Greater Boston was renamed the Boston Idea Group.

title: Less Than A Laptop, And More
description: Max parks his hoverbike in front of his housing pod's acrylic dome; the artificial-intelligence sentry scans his retinas, then waves him inside. After switching on the hologram player, Max unloads his laptop, a $200 tablet that weighs one pound, contains no moving parts and can be dropped without damage. Its batteries are half depleted -- only 350 hours of power left. He points the machine at his home computer and presses the Send button; the words he wrote on the road are silently beamed to the desktop machine, where they appear as though being typed by a secretary high on caffeine.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Fatal Stable Fire
description: A pretrial hearing is scheduled this morning in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn for Frank Esposito, a 17-year-old charged with setting a fire in the Bergen Beach Stables in June 2000 that killed 21 horses.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Fast Food Company Stalls
description: Ranch 1 Inc., the parent company of the popular chain of chicken-sandwich restaurants, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, according to court documents. The company, which owns four of the Ranch 1 restaurants and franchises the rest, had planned to finance its rapid expansion with stock sales, which fell through, the company said. In addition, Ranch 1 said, it has suffered from ''adverse notoriety'' from criminal allegations made about one of the company's officers. In June 2000, a federal indictment linked the company's former chief executive to the Colombo crime family; the company was not accused of any wrongdoing. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Henman Gives a Nation Blood, Sweat and Tears
description: OUR guy, Andre Agassi, was actually down a set when I decided to abandon my national duty and join the British happening yesterday on Center Court. After I had declared myself an honorary Englishman on America's Independence Day, the ingenious woman whose tennis reporting appears in this newspaper dubbed me Sir Whines-a-Lot and bid me farewell.

title: Israel Affirms Policy of Assassinating Militants
description: Israel's security cabinet decided today to press ahead with a policy of assassinating suspected Palestinian militants in an effort to stop persistent killings of Israelis, officials said.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From France's Mediterranean coast to Boston's waterfront restaurants, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: The Graduation of Ms. Moffett
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANNETT, EMANUEL
description: DANNETT - Emanuel. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Kenneth and Wendy. Dear brother of Herbert and the late Leo. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Zachary and Jacob. Services today, 12:15, at Bet-Am Shalom, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Accounts Put Darker Cloud Over Camp
description: As the investigation continued today into the death of a 14-year-old boy at a desert boot camp for troubled youth, other campers told of abusive treatment they said they had suffered at the hands of counselors who were not much older than the children they were supervising.

title: Golf Hand-Helds For the Gallery, If Not the Links
description: ROB LABRITZ, a professional golfer struggling to make the PGA Tour, was finishing his second round at the Buick Classic in June. He was already 12 over par when he came to the 18th green at the Westchester Country Club and lined up a slick 25-foot downhill putt for birdie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ISAAC D.
description: FREEDMAN-Isaac D., 75 years. Died peacefully in Delray Beach, FL after a valiant battle against cancer. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Howard (Liann), Amy (John) and Jona (Jim). Brother to the late Leo and Marvin. Wise, sageful and loving grandfather to Justin, Kyle, Tiana, Andrew, Dyllan and Christopher. The world was a better place because of you. You really cared about people and your kind and generous spirit will live forever in the hearts of those who knew you. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Love Me Tender: Life in the Animal Kingdom
description: To the Editor:

title: Pearson Names a New Editor For The Financial Times
description: LONDON, July 5  After 10 years as editor of The Financial Times, Richard Lambert announced today that he would step down in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ANN (NEE ZEILER)
description: COHEN-Ann (nee Zeiler). On Wednesday, July 4, 2001. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late David B. Cohen. Loving mother of Vivian Cohen Olshen. Cherished grandmother of Lisa Olshen Adelsohn and Dr. Andrew Olshen. Devoted mother-inlaw of Paul Olshen. Funeral services will be held Friday, July 6, at 11:30 AM, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Union, NJ. Internment at the Knollwood Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Battle Scarred and in Demand
description: By several accounts, Edward J. Zander is a man in demand.

title: Borrowing Others' Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Together in 20 Minutes, They Say, With Nary a Part Left Over
description: Herman Miller, the furniture manufacturer known for classics like the Eames lounge chair and ottoman ($3,060), will open its first retail store ever on July 17 in Chelsea. The store will sell a lower-price (and friskier) Red line of office furniture, whose pieces come disassembled and can be put together in 20 minutes or so by one person.

title: Essay; Stem Cell Hard Sell
description: In the unfamiliar company of bioethicists, George W. Bush is wrestling with a decision about stem cell research that could define his presidency.

title: While Economy Boomed, Money for Lobbyists Soared
description: Last year's surging economy and the related jump in major construction projects in New York fueled the largest increase in spending on lobbyists in at least a decade, as developers turned to lawyers and other well-connected professionals to urge city officials to give them permits needed before any shovels could hit the ground.

title: In China Labor Camp, Deaths Are Disputed
description: Chinese officials today confirmed reports that followers of the banned spiritual movement Falun Gong had died in a northeastern Chinese labor camp, but information about the circumstances remained contradictory. The government said the followers died in a mass suicide, while Falun Gong members in the United States insisted they were tortured to death.

title: Extortion Case Explores Rifts in Korean Enclave in Queens
description: Last fall, Soon Hee Park, who as a waitress had scraped together her tips and her life's savings to open her own restaurant in Flushing, decided she wanted to run advertisements in The Korea Tribune, a weekly newspaper aimed at the Queens neighborhood's Korean residents. For $100, the newspaper was to publish four ads and design a Web page promoting Mrs. Park's broiled salmon and her sushi, the publisher told her.

title: Untangling the Online Gaming Web
description: AS often as five times a week, Thomas Hazzard, 42, a manager at Boeing in Seattle, sits down at his home computer a few hours before he heads to his graveyard shift. He pops in his favorite CD-ROM game, Combat Flight Simulator, and logs on to Microsoft's Gaming Zone site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, THEODORE R.
description: SCHLESINGER-Theodore R. On July 2, 2001. Devoted and adoring husband of Alma for over 66 years. Loving father of Albert, Susan, Donald and Charles. Dear brother of Sig and Belle. Cherished grandfather to Kim and Jill and great grandfather to Emily, Douglas and Jane. Mr. Schlesinger was born in Manhattan on October 27, 1908. He was a graduate of CCNY and Fordham Law School. Mr. Schlesinger spent his 46-year career with the Allied Stores Corporation, before retiring as CEO in 1973. He served as a Director on many boards, including Mutual of New York, American Broadcasting Company, Marine Midland Bank and Eli Lilly. Mr. Schlesinger's philanthropic service to the National Jewish Hospital at Denver was recognized when the organization named him ''Man of the Year'' in 1963. Teddy will be remembered for his quiet, dignified manner, his loyal and honest business conduct, and, most importantly, his unabashed love for his dear wife and best friend, Alma. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 1230 South Tuttle Avenue, Sarasota, FL. 34239.

title: Portable Keyboards Let You Process Words Anywhere
description: Max parks his hoverbike in front of his housing pod's acrylic dome; the artificial-intelligence sentry scans his retinas, then waves him inside. After switching on the hologram player, Max unloads his laptop, a $200 tablet that weighs one pound, contains no moving parts and can be dropped without damage. Its batteries are half depleted  only 350 hours of power left. He points the machine at his home computer and presses the Send button; the words he wrote on the road are silently beamed to the desktop machine, where they appear as though being typed by a secretary high on caffeine.

title: Inside the Virtual Laboratory, Ideas Percolate Faster Than Rivalries
description: ONE might imagine that uniting scientists in different cities through Web-based laboratories could be a daunting technical challenge. But surprisingly, Dr. Stephanie Teasley, a cognitive psychologist who helped establish such an effort for AIDS research about three years ago, freely acknowledges a lack of advanced computer skills.

title: Germany Ponders Opening Door, Just a Crack, to Immigration
description: More than two decades ago, Germany closed its doors to ''guest workers,'' the laborers from Turkey and elsewhere who fueled the postwar economic miracle. Today, a high-level committee proposed opening the door once again to immigrants seeking jobs.

title: Federated Cuts Earnings Outlook Amid Slow Sales
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, slashed its profit forecast today, citing slow sales and steep markdowns.

title: Mexico's Growing Trade Advantage
description: President Bush has now repackaged ''fast track'' authority as ''trade promotion'' authority, hoping that a little marketing might push the legislation through Congress.

title: Companies are developing brand messages as a way to inspire loyalty among employees.
description: TIMES are tough these days in the employment market. But that does not mean that companies are not hiring. Despite cutbacks and layoffs, many firms are still searching for top-rate talent. And to lure and keep these employees they are using advertising to find them -- and not just plain old classified advertising.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Politician Set Free
description: Jayalalitha Jayaram, chief minister of Tamil Nadu, released from jail her archrival, Muthuvel Karunanidhi, 77, former chief minister and head of the regional Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam party, whose arrest last weekend triggered widespread protests. Mr. Karunanidhi's arrest was widely seen as part of a vendetta by Jayalalitha. The government will continue its move to prosecute Mr. Karunanidhi over alleged corruption involving a construction contract, a state government spokesman said. Mr. Karunanidhi's regional party is an important member of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's coalition government. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: Muslims in U.S. Seek Financing; Pursing the American Dream While Following the Koran
description: After moving his growing young family into rental apartments, his in-laws' house and then again into a rented condominium, Sal Spiteri scraped together the money for a down payment last year and bought his first home. It is a milestone that brings joy to most people, but it pained Mr. Spiteri, and he said that it tormented him still.

title: The Reichstag's Done. Time to Wash Up.
description: Norman Foster, above, the English master builder of such technological triumphs as the Hongkong Shanghai Bank, the renovation of the German Reichstag and the steel and glass courtyard of the British Museum, has taken on a new challenge: toilets and bathtubs. Why hire a design senior statesman for the appointments in a room so sequestered and often overlooked?

title: Macedonia Peace Talks Are Revived, but the Fighting Rages On
description: Talks to resolve the crisis in Macedonia are back on track, President Boris Trajkovski said today, even though shelling and shooting continued around the northern mountains, where government troops and Albanian rebels have been fighting for four months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, FRED C., JR.
description: SMITH-Fred C., Jr. On Wednesday, July 4, 2001, of South Orange, NJ. Beloved husband of Margaret McCarron Smith. Devoted father of Michael J., Paul G., Peter M., Christopher D., Stephen F., Monica C., and Timothy J. Smith. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from ''The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home,'' 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, NJ on Saturday, July 7 at 8:30AM thence to Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 217 Prospect Street, South Orange, where a funeral Mass will be offered at 9:30AM. Interment private. Visiting hours Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Torre Picks 7 Yankees, And Says All Earned It
description: Major League Baseball is chartering a plane for the Yankee All-Stars to go to Seattle on Sunday night, and it better be a jumbo jet, considering that Joe Torre picked seven of his own players as at-large selections. It is the most Yankees chosen for the All-Star team since 1962.

title: Henin Upsets Capriati; Venus Williams Beats Davenport
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5  Out of faith or foolishness, the splinter-sized Justine Henin kept coming at the ominous Jennifer Capriati today, swiping through her one-handed backhand as if flinging open a curtain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: South Glens Falls: Complaints About Wages
description: A group representing nonunion construction companies has lodged complaints with the State Labor Department, urging it to investigate whether unionized builders doing work for the South Glens Falls Central School District were paying improperly low wages to their construction workers. The group, Associated Builders and Contractors of Albany, asserts that the unionized contractors doing renovations on the senior high school are not paying their workers the rate required by the state's prevailing-wage laws. State officials said they would investigate the charges. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Bush Will Nominate Mueller to Head F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Robert S. Mueller 3d, a former Justice Department executive and veteran prosecutor, has been picked by President Bush to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation, senior White House officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENBERG, MURRAY
description: LICHTENBERG-Murray, on July 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Sandra. Devoted father of Joan and Lawrence Zombek and Joseph and Susyn Lichtenberg. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Ethan. Dearest brother of Manes, Max and the late Lee. You are beautiful and strong and kind, and will live in our hearts forever. We love you. Services Friday, 1PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made in his memory to the ALS Association, 27001 Agoura Road, Suite 150, Calabasas Hills, CA 91301.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Metro Matters; Fourth Try. Long Odds. It's Badillo.
description: SOMETIMES, the most conspicuous questions in politics can be answered only by searching the most personal of human emotions. One such question this year is, why is Herman doing it?

title: Sports of The Times; Loyalty Goes Only So Far With 'Stars'
description: FOR Joe Torre and Bobby Valentine, filling the All-Star Game rosters wasn't that much different from Forrest Gump's philosophy: Life is like a box of chocolates; you never know what you're going to get. But no matter which ballplayers the managers did or didn't select, they knew they would be criticized.

title: Giving Diabetics (and Their Sore Fingers) a Break
description: IT is one of the most painful and inconvenient tasks for those suffering from diabetes: frequent finger pricks to check blood sugar levels. As a result, many patients draw blood once daily, on average, not the four to seven times a day suggested by doctors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, DOROTHY K.
description: CONNOLLY-Dorothy K. Of Jersey City on Tuesday, July 3, 2001. Dear daughter of the late Mary A. (nee Burke) and Patrick Connolly. Dear sister of Howard Connolly of Vero Beach, Florida. Dear aunt of Margaret Fisher of Columbus, Ohio and Lauren Connolly of Vero Beach, Florida. Relatives and friends are invited to meet for the Funeral Mass at Saint John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church, on Friday at 9:30 AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mount Pleasant, New York. Visitation Thursday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Parking opposite funeral home.

title: Cardinals Developing a Speedy Throwback
description: More than a decade before the St. Louis Cardinals switched to a grass field and a lineup with names like Mark McGwire, Jim Edmonds and Albert Pujols, their symbols were Vince Coleman, Willie McGee and Ozzie Smith flying over the artificial turf.

title: LACK OF LAWYERS HINDERS APPEALS IN CAPITAL CASES
description: Dozens of inmates on death row lack lawyers for their appeals, in part because private law firms are increasingly unwilling to take on burdensome, expensive and emotionally wrenching capital cases, death penalty lawyers say.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronxville: Union Seeks Another Election
description: A union seeking to organize workers at Lawrence Hospital plans to present a petition today to hospital management calling on the hospital to allow a new vote on forming a union and not campaign against it. In March, the hospital's workers voted 124 to 119 against joining the union, 1199/SEIU, after management argued strenuously against a union. Union officials said they would also give hospital managers 150 postcards in which Bronxville residents ask the hospital to stop using antiunion consultants. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Justice O'Connor on Executions
description: An anti-death-penalty activist could not have put it more pointedly: ''If statistics are any indication, the system may well be allowing some innocent defendants to be executed.'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's remarkable statement on Monday to a group of women lawyers in Minnesota should further energize the nation's continuing re-examination of capital punishment. Justice O'Connor, whose support of the death penalty dates back to her days as an Arizona legislator, has provided the swing vote to the Supreme Court's conservative majority in a number of death penalty cases. If she is having qualms about the system, other death penalty advocates need to take another look too.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Truck Driver Dies In Crash
description: A tractor-trailer skidded out of control on wet pavement, hit a traffic barrier and burst into flames on the Pearl Harbor Bridge on Interstate 95 yesterday, killing the driver, the state police said. The police were still trying to identify the driver, who died at the scene, through records at Jevic Transportation of Delanco, N.J., the trailer's owner. The crash occurred around 7 a.m. near Exit 48 in New Haven, shutting down both sides of the I-95 bridge for more than seven hours, in part because the trailer carried swimming pool chemicals that were possibly toxic. The trailer's burning cab hung over the edge of the bridge, then fell, crushing the driver.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in Sunday Styles this week about the rise of Michael R. Bloomberg in New York society misspelled the surname of an actress shown with him at one of the many social events he has been attending. She is Liv Ullmann, not Ullman.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: MaryAnn Capritti was named to the new post of executive vice president and managing partner at Adient, Wayne, N.J., part of the CommonHealth unit of the WPP Group. She had been freelancing for the pharmaceutical marketing industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGIN, STUART
description: DOLGIN-Stuart. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend Stu, a man of great wisdom and infinite compassion, of uncompromising principles and boundless love. He graced our lives with his friendship for over 50 years. Humanity has suffered a deep and abiding loss with his passing. Stu, wherever we are and wherever we go, one of the things of which we will always be most proud, is to be included in the ranks of your friends. Harvey and Ellen Sanders Ricky and Susan Etra Kenny and Karen Etra Jay and Jill Bernstein

title: College, or the N.B.A.?
description: To the Editor:

title: European Parliament Rejects Measure to Ease Takeovers
description: By a single vote, the European Parliament today rejected a ground-breaking measure designed to help consolidate Europe's fragmented industrial base.

title: Article 2001070592590894145 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Article 2001070593027626596 -- No Title
description: This flag was there when Lincoln was shot.

title: John Trubin, Political Insider And Aide to Javits, Dies at 83
description: John Trubin, a prominent New York lawyer and quintessential political insider who spent much of his time working in state and city government, died Tuesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 83 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Writing of Intelligence: Academic, Artificial and Amorous
description: David Lodge regards his fiction as ''a kind of DNA of the imagination.'' As he said in a recent interview, ''There must be a signature in everything you do, a family resemblance.'' He was in his London pied--terre, having come from his home in Birmingham, England. ''The same preoccupations come up in whatever form you use, but I do like to vary the form,'' he added. For him, each novel has to have a new playing field and angle of vision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLIGAN, WILLIAM R., III
description: HOLLIGAN-William R., III. Of Darien, CT, July 2, 2001. Husband of Pamela C. Holligan. Father of William R. Holligan, IV and Kristin C. Holligan. Brother of Kathleen Maher. Friends may call at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, on Thursday, July 5th, from 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, Darien, on Friday, July 6th, 10:30 AM. Interment will follow at Spring Grove Cemetery, Darien. Memorials may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021 or Rumsey Hall School, Washington Depot, CT 06794.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, ROBERT M.
description: SILVER-Robert M. The Officers and Board of Directors of Camp Sussex, Inc. extend our deepest condolences to our past president, Robert E. Silver on the loss of his beloved father. Our deepest sympathy to Carol and the entire family. May your memories be an everlasting source of comfort. Board of Directors Victor Ozeri, President

title: Club Master Has His Eye On Brooklyn
description: About once a week, outside some Manhattan concert, Steve Weitzman can be found handing out fliers in an attempt to lure the audience to a West Village music club called the Village Underground. Most concert halls and promoters hire high school and college students to do this work. But Mr. Weitzman is neither: he is 51 and happens to book, promote and run music at the Village Underground. And this man, who can next be spotted in the midst of a carpet of discarded fliers outside a show by the Algerian rai singer Cheb Mami, has his sites on changing the face of concert-going in New York irrevocably.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARGIULO, EMILY ANNE
description: GARGIULO-Emily Anne (nee Emily Anne Black of Dallas, Texas). Died Monday, July 1, St. Vincent's Hospital, New York City. She was the daughter of the late Dr. James Harvey Black & Alleen Patton of Dallas, Texas. Mrs. Gargiulo was a graduate of Southern Methodist University and received a MSW from Columbia University School of Social Work, where she was also an Alumni Trustee and past President of the Alumni Association. Mrs. Gargiulo was a founding member and former President of the New York Freudian Society and a member of the Council of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapists, Society of Clinical Social Work Psychotherapists and Coalition of Social Work Psychoanalysts. She was also a devoted gardener and longtime resident of Greenwich Village, where she settled and raised her family. Mrs. Gargiulo remained an active member of the community. A great believer in the value of education, she was an original founder of the Village Community School on Geenwich Street. She married the late Armand Gargiulo, a fellow psychologist and psychotherapist in New York in 1957. She was the beloved mother of the late Anthony Patton and Lois Christina Korsupsin of New York, the darling grandmother of Sasha Antonia, Christina Annette and Justin Armand and the devoted mother-in-law of Charan Korsupsin. In addition to her daughter, son-in-law and grandchildren, she is survived by her sister Lois Black Crosland of Dallas, Texas. Graveside services in Sherman, Conn. For further info call Frank E. Campbell,-The Funeral Chapel 212-288-3500. Contributions in her memory may be made to AMFAR or GMHC.

title: Borrowing Others' Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Abroad: Not Exactly New, Not Exactly Circus, But a Magical Mix; A Popular Nouveau Cirque Troupe Leaps Into the Lincoln Center Festival
description: It is probably no coincidence that, for all the government money poured into theater, music, opera and dance in France every year, nouveau cirque, or new circus, the art form that receives the smallest subsidy, is arguably the most original. Put differently, in order to survive, new circus companies have to be good. And the challenge seems to have stirred their Gallic flair.

title: Aftershocks of Racial Tension on a Paris Street
description: The Mtro scene in ''Code Inconnu'' feels uncomfortably real. A Parisian actress (Juliette Binoche) is on her way home after a hard day of rerecording film dialogue. A man (Arab) begins to harass her. (''Don't talk to commoners?'' he asks. ''How can you be so beautiful yet so arrogant?'') She moves to the other end of the subway car. He follows (''What will you do now?'' ''Do I smell?'') and sits down beside her. Then he spits in her face. The man (European) sitting opposite her confronts the harasser, who backs down but tries to frighten them both as he leaves the train.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, RICHARD
description: ARMSTRONG-Richard. Of Old Tappan, NJ, died on Friday, June 29. He is survived by his wife, Virginia, his stepdaughter Jean Rettig-Carr & her husband Daniel Carr, and his granddaughter, Jessica. Burial services were private. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Pius Church, Old Tappan, July 7, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Christophers, 12 East 48th St., NY, NY 10107, or the Hospice Program of Hackensack University Medical Center, 30 Prospect Ave., Hackensack, NJ 07601 or to a charity of your choice. Mr. Armstrong was a writer and fundraiser. He is a former director of The Christophers, and the author of ''Out to Change the World,'' a biography of James Keller, M.M., the founder of The Christophers.

title: Puccini Arias Alfresco Can Be Yours for a Song
description: There were cries of ''Mommy,'' baseballs flying back and forth and even a cricket game in progress; not a typical night at the opera. But then this was not the Metropolitan Opera House. It was Marine Park in Brooklyn, where the Met presented a concert version of Puccini's ''Tosca'' on Wednesday night as part of its 35th summer of free performances.

title: Romancing the Suburbs
description: They say you know you're a real New Yorker when you stop talking about leaving. If that's the case, the closest I came to the real thing was when we bought our apartment on the Upper West Side in 1995. But even then, leaving lurked at the edges, always palpable, like the smell of cooked meat that never quite vented from the stairwell. Eleven hundred square feet was just too small for the family we planned, and though our second bedroom was a luxury to our friends, it reminded us of the inevitable.

title: Woman Is Fatally Shot Through Window
description: A 26-year-old woman died in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday from a gunshot that may have been fired randomly as part of an early Fourth of July celebration nearby.

title: Shares of Marconi Plummet After It Projects Profit Shortfall
description: LONDON, July 5  Shares of Marconi P.L.C., Britain's biggest telephone equipment maker, fell by more than half today in a vivid display of the spiraling decline in Europe's telecommunications industry.

title: You've Got Maelstrom: Dealing With Too Much E-Mail
description: Jed Horovitz considers himself a fairly spare and organized person. At Video Pipeline, the New Jersey-based video promotion company of which he is president, he keeps a clean desktop, both real and virtual.

title: Man Dies After Swim Off Pelham Bay Park
description: A 61-year-old man on a Fourth of July holiday outing with family members died after swimming in what the police said was an unauthorized area off Hunter Island, in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx.

title: Lax Security Blamed in Guard's Knifing
description: High in the federal jail in Lower Manhattan is a kind of fortress within a fortress called 10 South, where six cells are reserved for prisoners awaiting trial for the most violent crimes, like terrorism.

title: Article 2001070592059364163 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: 'Soprano,' 16, Charged in East Side Street Robbery
description: In the spring, the young actor who plays the dispirited adolescent son of a mob boss on ''The Sopranos'' saw the scriptwriters edge his character toward the path taken by his father, Tony Soprano. Vandalism and the theft of a geometry test got him expelled from high school, and the awkward youngster, slump-shouldered and slightly overweight, began suffering from panic attacks, like his gangster father.

title: Stalemate Over Iraq
description: Faced with intractable Russian opposition, Washington has sensibly postponed its efforts to reconfigure sanctions against Iraq till a later date and accepted an extension of existing arrangements for five more months. That gives the Bush administration time to work out a satisfactory compromise with Moscow. Iraq policy should be high on the list of subjects President Bush discusses when he meets again with President Vladimir Putin of Russia later this month.

title: Golf Hand-Helds for the Gallery, if Not the Links
description: HARRISON N.Y. -- ROB LABRITZ, a professional golfer struggling to make the PGA Tour, was finishing his second round at the Buick Classic in June. He was already 12 over par when he came to the 18th green at the Westchester Country Club and lined up a slick 25-foot downhill putt for birdie.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This flag was there when Lincoln was shot.''

title: Keeping Children And Guns Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place to Sit While on Hold For the Next Available Agent
description: Hello, MUrray Hill! The architect and scholar Robert A. M. Stern recently unveiled his EXchange Collection of six new upholstery fabrics, with classic architectural patterns and fanciful names based on old telephone exchanges in New York City. The collection combines Mr. Stern's longstanding love affair with old New York and the decorative arts.

title: Seven Workers Scurry as Fireworks Barge Ignites
description: A fireworks barge caught fire off Atlantic City last evening, igniting an unintended display of shooting flames and wildly careering rockets and sending seven pyrotechnicians on board diving into the ocean for safety.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Talks With Uganda Leader
description: President Joseph Kabila and the Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, met to discuss the three-year-old war in Central Africa, holding private talks in Tanzania. They did not disclose the outcome of their discussions, which were to focus on revitalizing a stalled two-year peace program, but said they would meet again. Mr. Kabila has yet to meet Paul Kagame, the president of Rwanda, the other country backing rebels in the Congo. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, DONALD, M.D.
description: COLE-Donald, M.D. Died accidentally on June 8th at age 74. Survived by 3 children, Jonathan Cole of San Francisco, Deborah Cole of Palm Beach, FL & Alyson Cole-Frankel of Ann Arbor, MI. Dr. Cole was one of the leading specialists in cancer research and Chief of Surgical Oncology at St. Vincent's 1960-1975 and the author of numerous articles and books. He was a lifelong art collector and in his youth, was a professional woodwind musician in several big bands. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Y-Me Foundation, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: Agency Protests Rental Company's Fines on Speeding Drivers
description: The Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection filed a complaint this week against a car rental company in New Haven that uses satellite technology to track drivers and debit their bank or credit card accounts whenever the drivers exceed a certain limit.

title: Torre Begins Tryouts For Roles in the Bullpen
description: Manager Joe Torre met with the members of the Yankee bullpen a few days ago and informed them that while he tries to determine their various strengths and weaknesses, they may be used in a variety of roles, long relief or short relief. Sure enough, Torre experimented today with the newly acquired Mark Wohlers.

title: Digital Recorder Can Blend MP3s With the Office Memos
description: The two latest digital recorders from Olympus are intended for very different users. The $349 DM-1 allows users to listen to MP3 or Windows Media Audio music files when they are not busy dictating memos to the head office. The DW-90 is a bare-bones business model that sells for just $129.

title: Contract Makes N.F.L. Oasis of Labor Peace
description: The wounds of the last strike have only recently healed, but baseball is already dreading the possibility of more labor strife after this season. For pro basketball fans, the lockout that shortened the 1998-99 season is still fresh, and hockey faces the possibility of dark nights and canceled games after its collective bargaining agreement expires in 2004.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Borrowing Others' Ideas

title: Foes Fail to Drown Out White Supremacist
description: Only a few people heard what Robert Barrett, a white supremacist, said at a rally here today, after protesters damaged his sound system.

description: Tightening Noose in Bosnia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSLER, WILLIAM L.
description: WEISSLER-William L. Died July 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Mark (Nancy) and Eric (Cindy). Cherished grandfather of Emily, Adam, Elizabeth and Benjamin. Dear brother of Jack.

title: Editing Your Home Memories
description: I'm getting to be a pretty good liar.

title: Leveling the Playing Field, but for Whom?
description: WASHINGTON  A NEW freshman class is about to enter the University of California, a class in which the percentage of Hispanic students leaped by 18.2 percent and the percentage of Asian-American students rose by 8.7 percent.

title: The Graduation of Ms. Moffett
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Die Hard' DVD Puts Viewer In the Film Editor's Chair
description: With millions of DVD movies pouring into retail outlets annually, movie studios have tried to distinguish new titles with features like alternative endings and soundtracks, trailers and commentary from directors. But executives with Fox Home Entertainment say they have struck on something entirely new in the special-edition release of the 1988 hit film ''Die Hard,'' starring Bruce Willis. Besides watching the usual add-ons, viewers can re-edit specific scenes in the movie using the DVD player's remote control.

title: Ivanisevic Leads the Revival Act at Wimbledon
description: A proud Goran Ivanisevic landed in Australia after a numbing 24-hour flight from Croatia in January, touching down only to bottom out.

title: Both Sides in Macedonia Approve NATO Truce Plan
description: TETOVO, Macedonia, July 5 -- Under heavy pressure from Western powers, the Macedonian government and Albanian rebels signed a formal cease-fire agreement today as a first concrete step toward heading off another ethnic war in the Balkans.

title: Tycoon Ends Online Venture In Hong Kong
description: For Richard Li, the brash tycoon once celebrated as an Asian Internet visionary, it has come to this: He announced today that his telephone company, Pacific Century Cyberworks, had all but shelved its most ambitious venture in cyberspace -- and the company's shares soared nearly 8 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLS, BRIAN SCOTT
description: WALLS-Brian Scott. On July 3rd, 2001, of Manhattan, age 46. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Dearest son of Catherine V. Walls and the late Gerard F. Walls. Dear brother of Gerard, Catherine and Thomas Walls. Loving uncle of Will, Jesse, Andrew, Mary Elizabeth, Scott, Eric, Bennett and Nora. Memorial visitation today at Mangano Funeral Home Inc., 1701 Deer Park Avenue, Deer Park, NY between the hours of 3-5 and 79:30PM. Memorial Mass, Friday, July 6th at 11 AM, Sts. Cyril and Methodius R.C. Church, Deer Park, New York.

title: Public Lives: No Affinity for Trees, but a Nature Crusader Nonetheless
description: WASHINGTON  HE was never exactly Mr. Outdoors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Charred Body Is Found
description: A decomposed body was found yesterday in a weeded area near Kennedy International Airport, the police said. The person appeared to have suffered a crushing blow to the right side of the head, and the body also seemed to be badly charred, the police said. It was discovered about 4 p.m. where the Belt Parkway and Van Wyck Expressway intersect. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: A Canvas the Artist Curls Up In
description: DRE WAPENAAR, a Dutch artist who is practically unknown in the United States, believes that a properly designed tent can alter human behavior. It can do so, he says, by making people feel secure, calm and friendly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOOF, DEBRA
description: DOOF-Debra. Of Closter, on July 2, 2001. Beloved wife of Melvin. Devoted mother of Karen A. and Suzanne Doof. Beloved aunt of Gary J. Bobker. Services Friday, 2PM at ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ. Contributions to the Closter Volunteer Ambulence Corps, Boro Hall, Closter, New Jersey 07624.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARCAN, ARTHUR
description: BARCAN-Arthur. Loving husband of Edyth; father of Sharon Elswit, Reina, Myra, and son-in-law Michael; grandfather of Kate; and brother of Rosalyn Pincus. Died peacefully on July 4, 2001. He loved life, and we will miss him. The memorial service will take place on Friday, July 6 at 3PM at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: A Risk Is Found In Natural Birth After Caesarean
description: More than a decade after doctors declared it safe for women to give birth vaginally after having had a Caesarean section, a new study has found that doing so is riskier to both mother and child than a second surgical delivery, especially if hormones are used to induce labor.

title: Gee Whiz. Must I Keep Slaughtering?
description: ZONE OF THE ENDERS

title: Accounts
description: * Minnesota Office of Tourism, St. Paul, Minnesota, to Colle & McVoy, Minneapolis, majority owned by the Maxxcom unit of the MDC Corporation, to handle its account, which had been at Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $3 million. The tourism office is a division of the Minnesota Department of Trade and Economic Development.

title: Bosnian Serbs Are 'Ready' To Seize Men For Tribunal
description: The Bosnian Serb government, which has until now refused all cooperation with the international war crimes tribunal here, said today that it was willing to arrest indicted suspects, though some legal hurdles have to be surmounted.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about plans in Miami to deal with turmoil there when President Fidel Castro dies misstated the distance between Miami and Havana. It is about 225 miles, not 90.

title: Archivist Par Excellence
description: To the Editor:

title: A MOVEMENT IN HIDING: A special report.; Sect Clings to the Web in the Face of Beijing's Ban
description: Tapping away at one of his computers in a cramped two-room apartment in western Beijing, Lloyd Zhao is engaged in an extraordinarily dangerous endeavor -- searching through the night for holes in the electronic wall that the government has built to keep Chinese from seeing Web sites of Falun Gong, the outlawed spiritual movement.

title: Dialing Up AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAOR, ELIAHU
description: LAOR-Eliahu. Beloved husband of Judith. Adored father of Rauiv, Laurent, Julien and Leann. Loving son of Klara. Devoted brother of Eytan and Ilana Silverstein. He was a dedicated physician and friend. Services Friday 10 AM, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 Street and Madison Ave. For information call the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: The Reel World
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Rene Huey-Lipton was named marketplace planning director at GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. She had been vice president and planning director at the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Lambasting The State Flag
description: Comparing the Confederate battle emblem in the state flag to a swastika, the president of the N.A.A.C.P., Kweisi Mfume, warned Mississippi political leaders to redesign the banner and protect the state's economy. Mr. Mfume, left, did not rule out a resolution calling for an economic boycott of the state, which may come up at the group's annual meeting this weekend in New Orleans, but said the matter was up to state N.A.A.C.P. members. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, who supported changing the flag, said the referendum in April in which voters chose to keep the current flag settled the issue for now.

title: For Coaches of Politics, Business Is Booming; Candidates in Crowded Primary Field Want Their Own Personal Trainers
description: Forget the big-league political consultants like David Garth, James Carville and Roger Ailes, who have become almost as famous as the candidates they shape and reshape to run for the presidency and other high offices.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Wins Contract
description: Lucent Technologies said Telesp Clular, Brazil's largest mobile telecommunications provider, had agreed to buy $130 million of Lucent equipment to build its third-generation high-speed network. Telesp Clular, a subsidiary of Portugal Telecom with 4.5 million customers, said it would use Lucent's switches, base stations and software to improve the speed of data transmission over its mobile network by nearly 10 times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RABBI BENJAMIN M.
description: KAHN-Rabbi Benjamin M. The Hillel family mourns the passing of Rabbi Benjamin M. Kahn, z''l, a pioneer and leader of the Hillel movement. Rabbi Kahn served as Hillel Director at Penn State University from 1940-1959, and as International Director of Hillel from 1959-1971. His work inspired generations of Jewish leaders. He is survived by companion, Lillian T. Shevitz, daughter Jeanette Kahn, son Si Kahn and daughter-in-law Elizabeth Minnich, and grandsons Simon, Jesse and Gabe Kahn. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Charles Newman, Chairman Hillel Board of Directors Richard M. Joel, President and International Director

title: U.S. Urges Use of Blood From Military
description: As it moves to restrict blood donations from people who might have been exposed to mad cow disease in Europe, the federal government is shaping a compromise plan to alleviate any blood shortages that the new donor restrictions might cause in the New York City area.

title: A Colossus Lurks on the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Ely Callaway, Golf Club Maker, Dies at 82
description: Ely Callaway, a versatile and charismatic business leader who founded the Callaway Golf Company, the world's largest maker of golf clubs, died yesterday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 82.

title: Article 2001070693627623808 -- No Title
description: July 2, 2001

title: Boeing to Review Worldwide Account
description: The Boeing Company, which recently announced that it would move its corporate headquarters to Chicago from Seattle, said yesterday that it would begin a review for its worldwide account, considering agencies with full-service offices in Chicago. Billings were estimated at more than $50 million.

title: A Colossus Lurks on the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Utopia Jefferson Founded
description: While everyone else lolled on the beach or barbecued in the backyard, 75 people from 34 countries celebrated Independence Day this week in Charlottesville, Va., by taking the oath of citizenship on the west lawn of Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson. This year, the annual ceremony was held on the 225th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence, drafted by Jefferson, and also recalled his own death exactly 50 years later on July 4, 1826.

title: Procedure, Sources and Amendments
description: QPresently the Supreme Court rejects some cases without comment. Do you think it would be reasonable to expect that the court explains, however briefly, the reasons for rejection in all cases?

title: Album of the Week: Basement Jaxx's "Rooty"
description: BASEMENT JAXX: "Rooty" (Astralwerks). "Rooty" begins with a shiny sound collage that suggests the sliding doors of a spaceship opening to let in the blue rays of heaven. Then a breathy voice dripping with innuendo whispers, "Basement Jaxx," as if it meant something dirty, and you know you're actually stepping into a much more earthy daydream. The psychological world of "Rooty" is hedonism, but disco style as opposed to hip-hop style. Inasmuch as this album is about sex  and it is  it's fabulous sex: nobody is denigrated.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 24 about two Franciscan nuns who were sentenced to prison for trespassing at the School of the Americas, a United States military school, erroneously included a former Haitian military dictator among men trained there. Raoul Cedras did not attend the school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPKA, ROBERT
description: HUPKA-Robert. July 3, 2001. Robert was a renowned photographer known for his photo essays of Arturo Toscanini and Michaelango's Pieta. Robert was also a lifelong friend to Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY. He is survived by his sister Marie Parkinson of Devon, England, and nephews, cousins and many dear friends. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 79 PM, at The John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St, NYC. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30 AM, St. Paul The Apostle RC Church. Interment Manhattanville College Cemetery, Purchase, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to The Cabrini Medical Center, Cardiac Unit, 227 E. 19 St, NYC 10003; or The St Paul Apostle Church, Homeless Shelter Program, 405 W. 59 St, NYC 10019.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Pleads Guilty to Spying
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 6 -- Robert P. Hanssen, the former F.B.I. agent, pleaded guilty today to charges that he had spied for Moscow since 1985 and had handed over many of the nation's most sensitive secrets. The plea resolves a bizarre espionage case that shook the bureau and increased tensions between the United States and Russia.

title: On the Legal Front Lines
description: The nominee for F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, is a longtime prosecutor who has shown impatience with critics of law enforcement. Man in the News, Page A15.

title: Toru Hayashi
description: Ise Foundation

title: Argentina in Quandary as Protest by Jobless Gets Nasty
description: The 200 unemployed workers occupying the central plaza of this squalid oil town may look harmless in their makeshift tents sipping an herbal beverage through metal straws to while away the hours.

title: Residential Real Estate; Troubled Yonkers Co-op Finances a Fresh Start
description: An 89-apartment co-op in Yonkers has emerged from bankruptcy after years of financial struggle that included damages it was assessed in a racial discrimination lawsuit.

title: India's Market Is Roiled By Freeze on Fund Group
description: India's stock market, rocked earlier this year by corruption scandals, has been further roiled by a move to ban selling and buying in the flagship fund of the country's largest mutual fund group.

title: In a Tough Spot in Paris? Fight Your Way Out, Limbs Flying
description: The compact, agile martial-arts cynosure Jet Li has made an impact in the two English-language films that have featured him (though ''Lethal Weapon 4'' doesn't count because even Mel Gibson has probably deleted that one from his rsum). And in the newest, ''Kiss of the Dragon,'' his action sequences are like an oil fire, spilling from one room into the next and lighting the interiors with heat and wreckage. Mr. Li and his fisticuffs choreographer, Corey Yuen, have set a new standard for action here. (Mr. Yuen also worked the battles for Mr. Li's Hong Kong high-water mark, ''Fist of Legend.'')

title: Freelancers Suing Again On Copyright
description: When the Supreme Court ruled on June 25 that three major publishers had violated copyright law by using freelance material in electronic databases without the authors' explicit permission, it suggested that there were many workable models for compensating authors for digital rights.

title: Federated Cuts Profit Forecasts Sharply for Quarter and Year
description: Federated Department Stores, the owner of the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, cut its profit forecast sharply yesterday, citing slow sales and steep markdowns.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Kosher  La Cart
description: A cart devoted to kosher food has opened at the World Trade Center. The cart, which sells hot dogs and other foods, conforms to the standards of the Orthodox Union, a kosher food arbiter. The cart is a patented, sealed, temperature-controlled cubicle in which the server handles food with long, attached plastic gloves, much the way workers would handle materials at a nuclear power plant. Until such a cart was invented, it was difficult for food servers to claim they were kosher, said Councilman Noach Dear, whose committee oversees New York's food carts. Fast Food Factory, the cart's operator, hopes to expand to ballparks and other locations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Americas: Mexico: Banamex Sale Approved
description: The regulatory authorities in Mexico have approved Citigroup's $12.5 billion purchase of Banamex, Mexico's second-largest bank. The acquisition will be the largest banking merger in Latin American history. The Finance Ministry authorized the deal late after consulting Mexico's Central Bank and the National Banking and Securities Commission. In a separate announcement, the Federal Antitrust Commission approved the purchase but said the two banks would have to merge their local pension fund units. The deal still requires the approval of regulators in the United States. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGIN, STUART
description: DOLGIN-Stuart. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend Stu, a man of great wisdom and infinite compassion, of uncompromising principles and boundless love. He graced our lives with his friendship for over 50 years. Humanity has suffered a deep and abiding loss with his passing. Stu, wherever we are and wherever we go, one of the things of which we will always be most proud, is to be included in the ranks of your friends. Harvey and Ellen Sanders Ricky and Susan Etra Kenny and Karen Etra Jay and Jill Bernstein

title: Court Case Seeks to Define a Catholic Priest's Family
description: While the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a Roman Catholic priest, was held by Islamic radicals for nearly 19 months in Lebanon in the 1980's, his relatives back home in Joliet, Ill., felt the anxieties shared by all the hostages' families.

title: Article 2001070694145717632 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Reports Profit
description: Gazprom, Russia's giant energy company, reported its financial results for 2000 audited to international accounting standards, showing a profit of $9.8 billion, compared with a loss the previous year. But the profit was inflated because of a deferred tax provision, which the audit counted as a one-time benefit to Gazprom last year. According to the United Financial Group, a Moscow investment bank that analyzed the audit by PricewaterhouseCoopers, Gazprom's actual profit was $3 billion, just below the United Financial's expectations of $3.3 billion. Increased earnings in 2000 were driven by higher gas prices.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Summit Meeting Next Week
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, will hold a two-day summit meeting beginning Monday with political leaders from Northern Ireland to push for resolution of an impasse over Irish Republican Army disarmament that threatens continuation of the power-sharing Catholic-Protestant government in Belfast. The talks will be held in a secluded mansion in the English Midlands at a time when Ulster faces heightened tensions brought on by the flash point Protestant marching season. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Colossus Lurks on the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH CALLS JIANG, VOICING CONCERNS OVER DETENTIONS
description: President Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China talked to each other today for the first time, and Mr. Bush brought up the recent arrests of American citizens and green-card holders by Chinese security forces, administration officials said.

title: Ada Gilmore -- 'The Summer of 1915: Watercolors From Provincetown'
description: Mary Ryan

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Risk From Animal Pyres
description: The Food Standards Agency said the levels of dioxins found across Britain from the fires set this spring to dispose of farm animals slaughtered in the food and mouth disease epidemic did not pose health hazards. The dioxins, which in higher levels can cause deadly illness and birth defects, were released from the pyres, set on coal, fuel and old railway ties, used to dispose of the almost 3.5 million animals culled. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Says It Missed Forecasts
description: Advanced Micro Devices, the world's second-largest maker of chips for personal computers, warned that its quarterly sales and earnings badly missed Wall Street's expectations because of weak demand for flash memory and pricing pressure from its rival, Intel. Advanced Micro said revenue for the second quarter, ended July 1, had fallen 17 percent from the year before, to $985 million, a sharper decline than the 10 percent drop the company forecast in April. The chip maker, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said earnings would be 3 to 5 cents a share, compared with the 27 cents anticipated by analysts. Its shares were off $1.12, or 3.7 percent, to close at $28.64, and slid nearly $4 more in after-hours trading. Advanced Micro reports its earnings on next Thursday.

title: A Constellation of All-Stars Awaits the Mets at Yankee Stadium
description: As if the season hasn't been horrendous enough for the Mets, they learned in midweek that their schedule was wrong. They thought they were playing the Yankees this weekend, but now they discover they are playing the American League All-Stars.

title: Charges Dropped, Woman Alleges Strip Search and Plans Suit
description: Criminal charges were dismissed yesterday against an 82-year-old Brooklyn woman who said she was strip-searched after being arrested on a complaint that she played rap music so loud that it disturbed her neighbors.

title: BRITAIN APPROVES REED'S PURCHASE OF HARCOURT GENERAL
description: The bid by Reed Elsevier, the British-Dutch publisher, for Harcourt General was approved yesterday by British regulators, clearing the way for Reed to complete the $5.65 billion acquisition. The company also extended its offer for Harcourt shares until July 11, and the acquisition may be concluded by that date, a Reed spokeswoman said. The British regulator did not force Reed Elsevier to sell parts of the business, as some analysts had expected. The bid has already received regulatory clearance in Austria, Germany, Ireland and the United States. The acquisition of Harcourt will make Reed Elsevier one of the biggest companies in the American textbook market.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Hussein Replaces Top Aide
description: President Saddam Hussein, who is also prime minister, replaced one of his three deputy prime ministers after a shuffle last month in the ruling Baath Party, government-controlled Iraqi television reported. Ahmed Hussein Khudayyir, head of the presidential office, joins Tariq Aziz, who is also acting foreign minister, and Hikmat Mezban Ibrahim al-Azzawi, the finance minister. The move comes as Iraq is reported near a decision to accept an extended ''oil for food'' program and to resume exporting oil now that changes in the United Nations program have been shelved for the time being. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: A Hobbled Army Casts A Cloud in Macedonia
description: When the firing began on Wednesday night, the police officers in this ruin of a town received another object lesson in why Macedonia does not have a military solution in its struggle with ethnic Albanian rebels.

title: Violence in the School
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: On Stage and Off

title: MAF BANCORP AGREES TO BUY CLOSELY HELD CHICAGO BANK
description: MAF Bancorp, the parent of Mid America Bank, has agreed to buy the closely held Mid Town Bancorp for $69 million. MAF will pay 80 percent in cash and 20 percent in stock. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter, MAF said. Mid Town, which is based in Chicago and has four locations in the Chicago area, had assets of $322 million, MAF said. MAF operates 27 retail banking offices, mainly in Chicago and its western suburbs. The company, based in Clarendon Hills, Ill., had assets of $5.3 billion as of March 31.

title: Scientists Are Baffled by Loss Of Marsh From Jamaica Bay
description: Thousands of acres of marshy islands in Jamaica Bay, which provide nesting and feeding areas for vast populations of birds and other wildlife, are rapidly, mysteriously vanishing.

title: Officer Is Beaten at Neighbors' July 4 Party
description: An off-duty police officer attending an Independence Day celebration here was beaten unconscious with lead pipes after he intervened in a dispute over fireworks at a party next door, the police said today.

title: The Supreme Court: Consistency Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing to Review Worldwide Account
description: The Boeing Company, which recently announced that it would move its corporate headquarters to Chicago from Seattle, said yesterday that it would begin a review for its worldwide account, considering agencies with full-service offices in Chicago. Billings were estimated at more than $50 million.

title: Article 2001070691843749921 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Metro Business Briefing | Merchandising Officer Named
description: Audrey Schlaepfer was named executive vice president and chief merchandising officer at Linens 'n Things, based in Clifton, N.J. She succeeds Steven Silverstein, who became president in February. Ms. Schlaepfer had been executive vice president for merchandising at Warner Brothers, part of AOL Time Warner. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: AUTO RACING; Harder Tires Putting the Brakes on Several Winston Cup Drivers
description: Jeff Burton summed it up.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 'Sopranos' Actor Answers Charge
description: Robert Iler, the 16-year-old ''Sopranos'' actor arrested on Wednesday and charged with robbery, said in a brief statement released yesterday, ''I never would or did rob anyone in my life.'' Mr. Iler and three other teenagers were charged with second-degree robbery after, the police said, they robbed two other youths on the Upper East Side on Wednesday. The actor also said, ''I know that the events of the past two days have been extremely difficult for my family and friends, and for that I am sorry.'' David Chase, the television show's creator and executive producer, also released a statement saying, ''I'd be proud to have him as my son.''

title: Before Hollywood's 'Traffic' Came the Elegant 'Traffik'
description: Sometimes it's better not to take a second look. This seems to hold especially true for dresses, men and movies. Dazzling first impressions often fade on closer scrutiny.

title: Leveling the Playing Field, but for Whom?
description: WASHINGTON  A NEW freshman class is about to enter the University of California, a class in which the percentage of Hispanic students leaped by 18.2 percent and the percentage of Asian-American students rose by 8.7 percent.

title: Princeton Men Survive Tight Finish in Henley Regatta
description: The Princeton men's heavyweight varsity provided a cliffhanger finish in the opening heat of the Ladies' Challenge Plate at the Henley Royal Regatta at Henley-on-Thames, England, yesterday, winning in the final strokes. The Tigers beat the Mosley Boat Club, a British crew, by three feet.

title: Article 2001070693964508510 -- No Title

title: YELLOW SAYS IT WILL RAISE SOME TRUCKING RATES 4.9%
description: The Yellow Corporation has announced plans to raise trucking rates 4.9 percent on Aug. 1 at its largest unit to increase revenue during the peak shipping season. The increase applies to the Yellow Freight System unit, which accounted for 77 percent of the company's first-quarter sales of $832 million. The move affects customers whose rates are not set by contract, or about half of the total, a Yellow spokesman said. Yellow's first-quarter profit fell 49 percent from year-earlier earnings, while sales declined 5.7 percent. Analysts expect the company, based in Overland Park, Kan., to report second-quarter profit of 31 cents a share, down 52 percent from a year ago. The company's shares fell 14 cents to $19.40.

title: Testimony at Bombing Trial Outlines Recipe for Mayhem
description: An Algerian terrorist who has been convicted of taking part in a plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport during the millennium celebrations laid out in court yesterday how he made explosives from recipes he learned in a training camp, fashioned timing devices from inexpensive wristwatches and even burglarized a store to get the chemicals he needed.

title: This Time, Lilly Pockets The Victory
description: Ted Lilly has the body of an uncooked spaghetti strand and a wooden, awkward delivery in which he appears to step toward first while throwing to the plate. Not much to look at, and apparently, pretty tough to hit.

title: Stem Cell Debate Revives an Old Ideological Battle
description: As the debate over whether to approve stem cell research continues in the White House, President Bush would be well advised to learn from history -- specifically, from the mistakes of his own father.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Wednesday by the author Richard Brookhiser, about Thomas Jefferson, John Adams and the Sedition Act, misstated a word in a Jefferson quotation. Jefferson wrote that ''a few prosecutions of the most prominent [Federalist] offenders would have a wholesome effect in restoring the integrity of the presses,'' not ''process.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Resort At Hitler's 'Nest'
description: Construction work to transform the Eagle's Nest, Hitler's Alpine command center, into a hotel and golf course is due to start today. The 140-bed luxury hotel at Berchtesgaden will cost $30 million to build and will be on the site of Hermann Gring's summer residence. The hotel operators will be contractually bound not to allow any Nazi-related activities on the site. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, SEYMOUR
description: BLOCK-Seymour. The Young Israel of West Hempstead mourns the loss of its beloved member, Seymour Block, husband of Margot, father and father-in-law of Beverly and Michael Rosenbaum, and grandfather of Adam and Ilana. May the family be comforted the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yehuda Kelemer Alan J. Eisenman, President

title: A Girl With Too Much to Say to Worry About Punctuation
description: SCHOOLING

title: City Requests $160 Million To Fix Up Homes in Scandal
description: City officials have urged the federal government to spend $160 million -- twice as much as it had planned -- to rehabilitate hundreds of brownstones and other properties caught up in a home mortgage scandal that has hobbled revitalization efforts in Harlem, Brooklyn and elsewhere.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Officer's Community Service Rebuffed
description: Mark Conway, the New York City police officer ordered this week to perform community service for negligently shooting an unarmed Bronx youth, is seeking another place where he can carry out his sentence, his lawyer said yesterday. The Gloria Wise Boys and Girls Club in the Bronx, where Officer Conway was ordered to report for service next week, asked that Mr. Conway be sent elsewhere, said a spokesman for the Office of Court Administration. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: If You Aim to Revisit the Analog World, Try Hitching a Ride on an Arrow
description: I'm in the middle of carving a longbow. This will be my third one made of yew. I made my first at a workshop about a year ago, tipped with horn nocks at either end that Robin Hood would have recognized. I made another, very light one on my own and started a third but put it aside. That's the one I've picked up again.

title: WATER BOTTLER AGREES NOT TO USE JACK DANIEL'S NAME
description: The bottling company Aubryn International said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the maker of Jack Daniel's whiskey and would not use a similar name on its bottled spring water. Jack E. Daniels is the name of the chief executive of Gorman Properties, which has a water-bottling agreement with Aubryn, based in Upland, Calif. Jack Daniel's Properties, which makes the whiskey, said Aubryn had agreed not to sell its water under the Jack Daniel's name until a trial could be held on the whiskey maker's lawsuit claiming trademark infringement. The whiskey maker is a unit of the Brown-Forman Corporation.

title: Respect for Dolphins
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Brooklyn outpost of the Blue Ribbon empire feels like many things at once. It's part saloon, part oyster bar, part bistro, part diner and part Jewish deli, if matzo ball soup is anything to go by. The extensive menu hops and skips from herring to clam stew to hummus to a fried catfish hero. This is home cooking no matter where home happens to be.

title: Armstrong Says He Is Expecting an Uphill Fight
description: Lance Armstrong is riding high, yes, indeed. His wife, Kristin, is four months' pregnant with twins, he won the Tour of Switzerland impressively last week, he has just been elevated to the top spot in the world ranking and, on Saturday, he sets off as the overwhelming favorite to win his third successive Tour de France.

title: Terpsichore Taps to Town
description: New York becomes Tap City for nine days starting tomorrow, when Tap City 2001: The New York City Tap Festival opens at studios and performance spaces around Manhattan. The roster of more than 90 performers from all over the world includes well-known tapsters like Jimmy Slyde, Prince Spender of the Four Step Brothers, Brenda Bufalino, Jane Goldberg, Lynn Dally, the Silver Belles and Gregory Hines. Many of the performers will also teach classes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Changes At Sulzer Medica
description: Sulzer Medica has revamped its orthopedics division after a major recall of faulty hip and knee implants that has left the company facing a number of lawsuits in the United States. The head of the orthopedics unit, Gary Sabins, was fired, and the unit is being split in two, the company said. The new structure provides that business in Europe, Asia and Latin America will be run from Switzerland, while United States operations will be run from Texas. The company, which is slated to be spun off from its parent company, Sulzer, is facing some 800 lawsuits, and 2,100 patients have undergone corrective surgery.

title: After the Debt Is Paid
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001070692304112448 -- No Title
description: For two days, it was like thunder rumbling in our backyard.

title: Across China, New Economy Folds Into Old
description: A little more than a year ago, China's young Internet entrepreneurs were fending off investors, sniffing derisively at ''dumb money'' while browsing among potential ''strategic partners'' like so many ripe melons.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about religious groups that perform social services misspelled the surname of the executive director of Americans United for Separation of Church and State. He is the Rev. Barry Lynn, not Lynne.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Another Anatomy Lesson

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about food labeling misstated the actions of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. The group petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to require that food labels state the amount of trans fats, which have been linked to heart disease. It did not urge food manufacturers to increase their use of trans fats.

title: Femmes Fatales Who Take the Term Literally
description: At one point in ''Baise-Moi'' a character remarks -- in words that like so much of the dialogue in this movie cannot be quoted directly here -- that the more sex you have, the less you think and the better you sleep. Certainly the film itself, whose title has been translated printably, though not accurately, as ''Rape Me,'' does little to contradict this thesis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBARD, JEFFREY JOHN
description: HUBBARD-Jeffrey John. On July 3, of NYC and Brookville, NY. Beloved husband of Marie Corbett Hubbard. Son of John A. Hubbard and the late Jeannette R. Hubbard, and brother of Sarah M. Conk. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Friday 3-5 and 79 PM. Interment Saturday, 10:30 AM, Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Article 2001070692344831059 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Sociologist Offers New Estimates Of City Hispanic Census Groups
description: A sociologist said yesterday that he had come up with new estimates of the numbers of Dominicans, Colombians and other Hispanics in New York City, estimates that he and planners for the city believe are much closer to the truth than the 2000 census figures released by the Census Bureau last week.

title: A Lasting Imprint On Fabrics
description: Provence may be touted as France's choicest playground, but in 2,500 years it has been attacked by Greeks, Romans, Goths, Franks, Vandals and Saracens. ''Every variety of invader seems to have subjected it to the extremes of pillage, destruction, naked war,'' Lawrence Durrell wrote. ''It was as if its beauty was too much for them and they went berserk.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bloomfield: Church Is Sued For Taxes
description: Using a new state law that allows churches to be taxed for profit-making ventures, township attorneys have filed suit against a Roman Catholic church in an effort to share in revenues generated by six cellular towers that are mounted inside its steeple. Bloomfield tax officials are seeking to claim part of the money that St. Thomas the Apostle Church earns from the towers, all of them owned by VoiceStream Wireless. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Bad Turns Into Worse for Mets And Trachsel
description: One batter into last night's game, Timo Perez stumbled as he started to dive for a sinking liner by the Cubs' Eric Young. As the ball fell in front of Perez and rolled behind him, Steve Trachsel stood flat-footed on the mound, staring into right field.

title: A Colossus Lurks on the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Photographing Drivers On The Road
description: The Department of Motor Vehicles will soon install security cameras on Colorado roads that digitally record facial data. Old driver's license photos will be scanned into a computer database, and new photographs of drivers on the road will be compared with those on file. Proponents say the system will help prevent driver's license fraud; opponents fear invasion of privacy. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: More Software Layoffs
description: The Irish security software developer Baltimore Technologies announced plans for a ''significant reduction in head count,'' even after cutting 250 jobs since a revamping effort began in May. The company has already saved 14.4 million ($20 million), but its savings goal of an annualized 30 million ($42 million) now appears inadequate. ''We now see we have to make radical decisions,'' the chief executive, Fran Rooney told Bloomberg News. In a statement, Baltimore indicated that revenues for the quarter ended June 30 would reach 15.5 million ($22 miilion), below earlier forecasts as customers delayed orders. Shares in Baltimore lost more than 30 percent, to 17.4 pence, on the London Stock Exchange.

title: A Dangerous Life for 2 Aspiring Rappers in the Bronx
description: Poverty, capable of stunting lives, can also blight films. A case in point is the earnest and heartfelt but undernourished and plodding ''Off the Hook.''

title: Home Video: Crisis Control? Click Here
description: With two-hour documentaries about making movies and other extras  deleted scenes, filmmaker interviews and the like  piling up on DVD, a new tactic has emerged: chop up the extra material into short pieces and spread it throughout the film.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: INSIDE ART
description: An Old Master Out of Hiding

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about lobbying in New York City misidentified the firm employed last year by the State Association of Adult Homes and Assisted Living Facilities. It was Coppola Ryan McHugh, not Cooperman Levitt Winikoff Lester & Newman.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Equipment Maker Forecasts Loss
description: ASML Holding, the biggest maker of machines that etch circuits onto computer chips, said it would have a first-half loss of as much as 105 million euros ($89 million) as a result of canceled orders. The loss will stem mainly from the recently purchased Silicon Valley Group Inc. in the United States, ASML said. In Europe, ASML at least broke even for the half, excluding one-time charges, the company said. As recently as May 23, the company had said it expected a break-even result for the first half of 2001, compared with the year-earlier period, when profit rose 36 times to 144 million euros.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEIDMAN, SEYMOUR
description: SCHNEIDMAN-Seymour. It has been 16 years since you left us, and you've missed many happy celebrations and more to come. You are always remembered in spirit and will forever be in our hearts, Happy Birthday. Lorraine and family.

title: U.S. Envoy to Yemen Reportedly Barred F.B.I.
