description: The United States ambassador to Yemen has barred the leader of the F.B.I. team investigating the bombing of the destroyer Cole from returning to the country, following a personal feud and a turf battle between the agency and the State Department over how the investigation should be handled, according to several American officials.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: After Violence, Population Falls
description: The United Nations said a new census shows the population of East Timor at 737,811, about 60,000 fewer than before a rampage by Indonesian-backed local militias two years ago that killed about 1,000 people and drove many thousands more into exile. Of those counted, about 380,000 people over the age of 17 will be eligible to vote next month for an assembly that will draft a constitution for the fledgling nation. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Reckonings; Red Tide Rising
description: During the debate over George W. Bush's tax cut, administration officials told wavering supporters not to worry. The Congressional Budget Office, they insisted, was underestimating future surpluses; in fact there would be plenty of money, even after the tax cut, for other priorities.

title: PACCAR PLANS TO INCREASE PRODUCTION OF SOME TRUCKS
description: The truck manufacturer Paccar Inc. said yesterday that it would increase production of some heavy- and medium-duty vehicles. Production rates will increase 8 percent starting July 16 for the Peterbilt division's heavy-duty trucks and 22 percent as of Aug. 6 for medium-duty trucks, Paccar said. ''I wouldn't call this a market turnaround,'' the company treasurer, Ron Ranheim, said. ''We're just responding to some pieces of the market here. The overall truck market is weak, and we expect that to continue for at least the next 6 to 12 months.'' The company, based in Bellevue, Wash., said earlier that its first-quarter production of heavy-duty trucks fell about 20 percent from the previous three months. Paccar makes Kenworth, Peterbilt, DAF and Foden trucks.

title: Farmers Force Open Canal In Fight With U.S. Over Water
description: With the sheriff's department here refusing to intervene, federal officials asked for help today from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and United States marshals after farmers, angry about being cut off from irrigation water, opened an irrigation canal's headgate three times in the past week.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Suit Filed To Stop Financing College Production
description: A group of 21 legislators and residents has sued to stop the use of tax dollars for a university production of the Terrence McNally play ''Corpus Christi,'' which portrays a Jesus-like character and his apostles as gay. The production is scheduled for Aug. 10 and 11 at Indiana University-Purdue University in Fort Wayne. The plaintiffs contend that performing the play at a state-supported university violates the separation of church and state, but a lawyer for the university said the show would go on. The play, set in Texas, has drawn protests since opening Off Broadway in 1998. Bill Dedman (NYT)

title: Underdog Status Suits Leija
description: Jesse James Leija is sure that everyone will be rooting against him in his boxing match tomorrow night. Leija's opponent will be fighting in his hometown, is undefeated and has a name associated with boxing glitz and glamour.

title: Sow the Seeds of the Fourth, Before We Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Procedure, Sources and Amendments
description: QPresently the Supreme Court rejects some cases without comment. Do you think it would be reasonable to expect that the court explains, however briefly, the reasons for rejection in all cases?

title: U.S. and Japan Discuss Transfer of American Rape Suspect
description: The United States and Japan are close to defining legal guarantees for an American Air Force sergeant suspected of raping a Japanese woman on Okinawa, an agreement that could clear the way for him to be handed over to local authorities before an indictment, the United States ambassador to Japan said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the growth of online travel reservations misstated the company affiliation for an executive who noted that the elaborate computer systems built to serve travel agents eased the way for airlines to adapt to the Internet. Craig S. Kreeger is a vice president for sales at American Airlines , not America Online.

title: Bush Plan Allows States to Give 'Unborn Child' Medical Coverage
description: The Bush administration has drafted a new policy that would allow states to define ''an unborn child'' as a person eligible for medical coverage under the Children's Health Insurance Program.

title: Crisis Control? Click Here
description: With two-hour documentaries about making movies and other extras -- deleted scenes, filmmaker interviews and the like -- piling up on DVD, a new tactic has emerged: chop up the extra material into short pieces and spread it throughout the film.

title: The Great Alaska TourSaver
description: Coupon books are potential money savers everywhere, even in Alaska. The Great Alaska TourSaver, which costs $99.95, has coupons good for a McKinley Explorer rail tour from Anchorage to Denali (normally $280), an Alaskon Express bus fare between two Alaska cities (up to $215), a Portage Glacier Cruise from Portage ($25) and many other deals. For information, call up www.toursaver.com .

title: Proustian Idylls Of the Good Life
description: BEYOND THE EASEL: Decorative Painting by Bonnard, Vuillard, Denis and Roussel, 1890-1930'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is, for better and for worse, just the show for a New York City summer.

title: Let Us Remember the Dear, Departed Plymouth
description: WITH little fanfare, the final Plymouth rolled off a Chrysler assembly line last week.

title: Knicks Meet With Houston About Rich Deal
description: Allan Houston, an All-Star shooting guard who led the Knicks in scoring last season, is believed to be on the verge of agreeing to a long-term contract that will make him the richest player in franchise history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADDOCK, J. JOSEPH
description: RADDOCK-J. Joseph. The Officers, Directors, Administration, and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center express their heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Jay Raddock, a founding Board member and Honorary Vice President. He will long be remembered for his leadership in our construction and development, and for his commitment to our Center. We extend our sincere condolences to the family. Joseph Gurwin, Chairman Lawrence J. Simon, President Herbert H. Friedman Executive Vice President

title: Judah and Brother Robbed
description: Zab Judah, the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion from Brooklyn, and one of his brothers were robbed of jewelry and cash by five men early Wednesday outside the Van Dyke Houses in Brownsville, the police said.

title: Public Lives: No Affinity for Trees, but a Nature Crusader Nonetheless
description: WASHINGTON  HE was never exactly Mr. Outdoors.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Says Profit Fell Short
description: BMC Software Inc., a maker of software for managing corporate computer systems, said fiscal first-quarter profit fell short of its forecasts because of weaker-than-expected sales. Profit for the quarter ended June 30 was 6 cents to 8 cents a share, excluding amortization of good will and charges, less than the 11 cents to 14 cents the company forecast in April, a spokeswoman said. Revenue was $338 million to $345 million, compared with BMC's earlier forecast of $355 million to $365 million. Some sales fell through at the end of the quarter because of the economic slowdown, the Houston-based company said. Earlier this week, the Compuware Corporation, a BMC rival, said its first-quarter sales fell short because it failed to close some European contracts.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Exxon Developing Fields
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Malaysia's state oil company will spend $1.7 billion to develop three oil and gas projects to meet rising demand in Asia, an official said. Exxon is the largest oil producer in the country. It supplies 70 percent of natural gas needs of the Malaysian peninsula. The three projects off Malaysia's east coast will be able to produce 133,000 barrels a day of oil, and 345 million cubic feet a day of gas, offsetting a decline in output from existing projects. The projects are ventures with Petronas Carigali, a unit of Petroliam Nasional, the state oil and gas company of Malaysia.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Terror Jury Deliberates
description: A federal jury in Manhattan completed its first day of deliberations yesterday without reaching a verdict on whether to impose the death penalty on Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, who had been found guilty of bombing the American Embassy in Tanzania, killing 11 people. The jury sent a note early in the day to the trial judge, asking to review more than two dozen items of evidence. Deliberations are to resume on Monday. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Artificial Heart Patient Speaks With His Family and Doctors
description: The man who is living with the first fully implantable artificial heart talked with his family on Wednesday night during nine hours when a breathing tube in his windpipe was removed and he was disconnected from a mechanical ventilator, his doctors said here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULVIHILL, FRANK J.
description: MULVIHILL-Frank J. Of Staten Island, on July 5, 2001. Loving father of Hollis Petrozza, Mari-Alyssa Ferrero, Francis Craig and Donald Mulvihill. Dear brother of Donald J. Mulvihill. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Ave, Staten Island, on Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Sylvester's Church, 10 AM. Private committal to follow. Friends will be received Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital would be greatly appreciated.

title: Finding a Will and a Way, Henin Overcomes Capriati
description: Out of faith or foolishness, the splinter-sized Justine Henin kept coming at the ominous Jennifer Capriati today, swiping through her one-handed backhand as if flinging open a curtain.

title: European Central Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: Despite continued signs of a significant economic slowdown in Europe, the European Central Bank declined again today to lower interest rates and made it clear that it would not relax its grip on monetary policy any time soon.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Hearing In Bombing Case Is Delayed
description: A hearing scheduled for Wednesday on whether there is enough evidence to try Terry L. Nichols on state murder charges in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing has been delayed until Judge Ray Dean Linder of District Court can hear a defense motion on Aug. 22. Mr. Nichols, 46, was sentenced to life in prison after conviction on federal charges of conspiracy and manslaughter for helping Timothy J. McVeigh prepare the truck bomb that killed 168 people. Oklahoma prosecutors have vowed to seek the death penalty. Jo Thomas (NYT)

title: Franks Will Head Pharmaceutical Trade Group
description: Former Representative Bob Franks, fresh from his second straight defeat in a statewide race, is about to embark on a campaign of a different sort, as the chief lobbyist for the pharmaceutical industry in New Jersey.

title: Leading Colleges Adopt New Guidelines for Awarding Financial Aid
description: Yale, Cornell, Stanford and 25 other leading colleges and universities will announce today that they have agreed on new guidelines for determining who is eligible for financial aid.

title: A marketing blitz is aimed at promoting a 'living brand' from Britain for the U.S.
description: EVER hear of Anne McKevitt? Chances are, no, unless you are a devotee of doyennes of domesticity. But you are soon likely to be bombarded with an ambitious marketing blitz on her behalf in an attempt to promote her into being the latest ''living brand.''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUBIN, JOHN
description: TRUBIN-John. On July 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna (Glassman) and loving father of Priscilla and Andrew Trubin, their devoted spouses Richard Lewis & Virginie de Haugoubart; four grandchildren: Beatrice and Judd Lewis and Paul and Edouard Trubin. Beneficiary of kind and caring friends. Funeral services Friday 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment to follow at Knollwood Park Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Jimmy Wright -- 'Recent Paintings and Pastels'
description: D. C. Moore Gallery

title: A Nominee for the F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, shaken in recent years by a series of management failures, needs a director with prosecutorial and administrative experience and a zest for reform. In nominating Robert S. Mueller III for the post yesterday, President Bush chose a seasoned, non-ideological prosecutor thoroughly familiar with the F.B.I. and its parent agency, the Justice Department. It is less clear whether Mr. Mueller has the management skills and determination to bring the burgeoning yet insular organization under control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAOR, ELIAHU
description: LAOR-Eliahu. Beloved husband of Judith. Adored father of Raviv, Laurent, Julien and Leanna. Loving son of Klara and the late Israel. Devoted brother of Eytan (Holly) Laor and Ilana (Evan) Silberstein. He was a dedicated physician and friend. Services today at 10 AM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 St and Madison Ave. For information call the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Rafter Giving Everything to Win It All
description: Once the season ends, Patrick Rafter will take some time to relax, create his own think tank and ponder what will become of his career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDY, RAE P.
description: BONDY-Rae P. Passed away on July 2, 2001, at her home in Carefree, AZ. Beloved wife of the late Philip L. Bondy. Born August 21, 1919, in Chicago, IL. Former resident of North Salem and Waccabuc, NY. Served as a volunteer for the Northern Westchester Hospital and the Carefree Arizona Public Library. Mourned by children: Sally Herndon, Susan Willoughby, Richard Bondy and Sandra Kelley; brother, Richard Parish, step-sister Diana McKissock; seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Private interment. Memorial services at 2 PM, July 12, at St. James Episcopal Church, North Salem, NY. Memorial donations may be made to: The Seeing Eye, PO Box 375, Morristown, NJ 07963-0375.

title: Stem Cell Politics
description: The Bush administration is divided over whether to bar federal funding for research on stem cells derived from human embryos. President Bush is said to be listening carefully to the opinion of Roman Catholics and other religious groups that such research destroys human life. On the other hand, most scientists and many conservatives in the administration and Congress take the more sensible view that these microscopic clumps of cells are not the same as a fetus and that research on them can bring major medical breakthroughs. Whatever Mr. Bush decides, he will be sending an important signal on whether his political ties to religious conservatives will sway decisions on social and scientific policy.

title: African Music Is Here, And It's Now
description: AFTER decades of cultivation, New York City's theaters, arts institutions and concertgoers are at the point where they can accommodate African music of all kinds. This summer's African performers -- in the Africa Out Loud series of Lincoln Center Festival 2001, in the Africa Fte concert at Central Park Summerstage and in one-shot performances around the city -- are showing old and new music from all corners of the continent, from the biggest international acts to the newcomers.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Girl Hit By Stray Bullet
description: A 7-year-old girl was in critical condition yesterday, a day after being shot in the face by a stray bullet as she stood on a North End sidewalk celebrating the Fourth of July. The bullet, which was possibly fired during a drug-related quarrel that had nothing to do with the girl or her family, the police said, passed through the girl's cheeks. The child, Takira Gaston, was taken first to St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center and later transferred to Yale-New Haven Hospital for reconstructive surgery on her jaw.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIRSCH, MURRAY H.
description: KIRSCH-Murray H. 7/6/77. Dear Dad, no matter how many years pass by, you remain deep in my heart and always on my mind. You set a great example of love and caring that I will try to always follow. Love, Arthur

title: Cats, Dogs And Balance
description: Lawrence Guterman sat on a couch in an editing room on the Warner Brothers lot, watching a replay of the opening sequence of his new, half-animated family film, ''Cats and Dogs.'' A lovable-looking hound is lured out of his suburban yard by a taunting cat and captured by a mysterious van.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lowest Welfare Levels Since 1966
description: The city's welfare rolls have dropped below 500,000, the lowest level since July 1966, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. As of June, he said, 497,113 people were on the rolls, a 57.2 percent decrease since the peak of more than one million in March 1995. The mayor credited the Human Resources Administration's use of performance-based contracts with sharply increasing the number of job placements. Human Resources said it was working to ensure that the nearly 46,000 welfare recipients approaching the five-year federal limit for collecting benefits would be placed in jobs or moved into a ''safety net'' program. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Chekhovian Complication For 3 Sisters In Hanoi
description: The Vietnamese director Tran Anh Hung's first two features, ''The Scent of Green Papaya'' and ''Cyclo,'' were partly inspired by the lives of his parents. The first, shot entirely on a soundstage in France, conjured an elusive dream of Saigon in the twilight of French colonial rule. The second, filmed in present-day Ho Chi Minh City, was a brutal, surreal nightmare of third-world urban life.

title: Torre Puts New Relievers to Work
description: The Yankees have a full stable of power relievers now, and every night Manager Joe Torre seems to be trying different rotations and different matchups. He turned to the newcomers Jay Witasick and Mark Wohlers tonight, with some success and some trouble in the Yankees' 6-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: A Rising Long Island Voice in Immigration Debate
description: It began as a group of homemakers concerned about crowds of migrant workers waiting for work on the streets in Farmingville, on Long Island. But after gaining increasing momentum and membership, the Sachem Quality of Life Organization, which now claims 800 to 1,000 members, has grown into an unlikely national opponent of illegal immigration.

title: Narcotics Detective Is Shot in Staten Island
description: A narcotics detective working undercover in a tough Staten Island housing project was shot in the hand yesterday as he and a suspect grappled for his service revolver, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a rally in Morristown, N.J., misstated the given name of a white supremacist who spoke. He is Richard Barrett, not Robert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTERSTOCK, GERTRUDE
description: FENSTERSTOCK-Gertrude. We extend heartfelt condolences to Blair and Jason Fensterstock on the loss of their beloved mother. Gertrude combined an inner strength, love of life and keen intellect, with an intense devotion to Israel and the Jewish people. As a Platinum Founder and a generous supporter of the Jesselson Heart Center and the Nuclear Medicine Institute, her outstretched hand of kindness and warm smile helped to provide ultra-modern and compassionate healing to thousands. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Ctr. in Jerusalem

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIN, JOHN A., M.D.
description: REIN-John A., M.D. A friend and colleague for 44 years. He will be missed. Deepest sympathy to Inger, Jonathan and family. Dr. G. Nonas and Staff

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: LOWER EXPECTATIONS Multex.com Inc. , a New York online financial services company that had been profitable for three straight quarters, said this week that its second-quarter revenues would be lower than forecast and that it planned to reduce its payroll by 15 percent through eliminating jobs and cutting executives' salaries. Multex expects second- quarter revenues of $24 million, 15 percent lower than the company had predicted. The company, which provides research and job listings, forecasts a net loss of $1 million, excluding noncash charges, versus the $3.3 million to $3.8 million predicted. Including charges, Multex expects to lose $8 million. Revenues are expected to remain mostly flat for the rest of the year, officials said. Multex announced the lower expectations Tuesday night; quarterly results are to be announced on July 19. Until this quarter, Multex seemed to be weathering the dot-com sector's crash. Gregory Smith, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase, wrote in a research report that the news "signifies a serious deterioration in the company's existing business, let alone growth prospects over the coming quarters."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLUM, HARRY
description: GOLDBLUM-Harry. On July 4, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Sydell. Loving father of Barbara and Matthew. Devoted grandfather of Elizabeth and Sarah. Dear brother of Ruth and Anna. Services Friday, 10 AM, Levayah-Garlick Funeral Home, Yonkers, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Truck Accident Snarls Traffic
description: A tractor-trailer flipped and caught fire yesterday in a westbound lane of the Long Island Expressway near Bayside, snarling traffic for more than eight hours. Seven people were injured, the authorities said. More than 60 firefighters responded to the accident, which occurred around noon, a Fire Department spokesman said. Last night, a ramp from the westbound L.I.E. to the northbound Cross Island Expressway was closed. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about changes at the New York Academy of Sciences misstated the background of its president and chief executive, Rodney W. Nichols; he does not have a doctorate and he became the group's leader in 1992, not 1995. The article also misidentified the organization that asked the academy to study pollution in New York Harbor; it was a regional office of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, not the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey (which is helping to finance the work). The article also misstated the source of the academy's income; it gets most of its income from a combination of members' dues and sales of publications, not from dues alone.

title: A War Widow's Battle for the Truth
description: A ''Rashomon''-like mystery opens the door into a far-reaching examination of war and national and individual behavior in the Japanese film ''Under the Fluttering Military Flag.''

title: Donations Made to Hevesi's Campaign Prompt Demotion of Housing Supervisor
description: A city housing official is being removed from his post while officials investigate whether any of the $61,040 in contributions he delivered to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's mayoral campaign came from city employees he supervises or contractors who do business with his agency.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the growth of online travel reservations misstated the company affiliation for an executive who noted that the elaborate computer systems built to serve travel agents eased the way for airlines to adapt to the Internet. Craig S. Kreeger is a vice president for sales at American Airlines, not America Online.

title: Sports of The Times; Old Enough To Handle The Losses
description: BOUNCE, bounce, serve, winner. Ball, please. Jennifer Capriati was clearly in a hurry yesterday on Center Court, and it was all going her way, at sub-hour speed. ''I was such an early starter and prodigy, but I feel like a late bloomer,'' she would say, perhaps guilty on this day of trying too hard to make up for lost time.

title: 'Superimposition'
description: Caren Golden Fine Art

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Options Board Looks At HotJobs
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange is looking into a jump in trading of HotJobs.com Ltd. options before the June 29 announcement that the Internet job recruiter would be acquired by TMP Worldwide Inc. for about $460 million in stock. The inquiry, which a spokeswoman for the options board called ''a routine investigation into unusual trading,'' began on Monday. TMP, operator of the Monster.com Internet job site, agreed to pay with shares then worth 21 percent more than the HotJobs closing price of $10.88. The prior day, investors traded 255 contracts for options carrying the right to buy 100 shares of HotJobs stock for $10 apiece through the third week of July. That was more than twice the 125 contracts that had changed hands on all trading days combined before that point. On June 29, 250 more HotJobs July $10 call option contracts changed hands before HotJobs disclosed the purchase after the close of regular trading. A HotJobs spokeswoman declined to comment and TMP officials could not be reached.

title: European Journal Selects Scholz
description: The European edition of The Wall Street Journal has named the London office of Scholz & Friends, part of the Cordiant Communications Group, to handle its account. Spending was estimated at less than $2 million.

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR IS BUSH'S NOMINEE TO LEAD THE F.B.I.
description: President Bush today nominated a seasoned criminal prosecutor, Robert S. Mueller III, to be the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, an agency buffeted in recent months by accusations that it has been undisciplined, mistake-prone and poorly managed.

title: Judi Werthein and Leandro Erlich -- 'Tourismo'
description: Kent Gallery

title: Toe Injury May Keep Piazza Out of All-Star Game
description: Unless Mike Piazza's fractured left big toe heals enough to allow him to catch on Sunday, Piazza is very likely to skip Tuesday's All-Star Game in Seattle. Piazza was elected to start for the National League, but the Mets do not want him to go to the game if he is not on the active roster.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Cuts Overnight Rate
description: Responding to concerns about the sluggish economy, the Bank of Korea cut its overnight interbank call rate by 25 basis points, to 4.75 percent from 5 percent. The factors behind the decision included the slowdown in Korea's economic growth, inflation and a drop in exports and investment. The governor of the bank, Chon Chol Hwan, said the slowing global economy was another reason for easing terms for corporate borrowing and investing. Semiconductor prices, falling to 92 cents a chip from $9 a year ago, have accounted for much of the decline in export earnings. As a result, a general strike called by the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions had limited support. Workers at most major companies did not participate. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAM, NATHAN
description: SCHLAM-Nathan. Of New Rochelle. Died July 5, 2001. He was the devoted husband of the late Margaret Schlam, survived by his daughters Ruth Katz and Edythe Asher, his sister Rebecca Lutto and his three grand children and four great-grandchildren. A 1 PM graveside service is scheduled for Sunday in the Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALANT, HARRY
description: SALANT-Harry. Dear brother of Morris, Benjamin, Samuel, Eileen and the late George. Brother-inlaw of Marilyn and the late Rida and the late Florence. Beloved husband of Claire. His children and grandchildren will carry on his kindness and compassion, as will his many nieces and nephews. The Family Circle

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From Cabrios to car covers, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Julio Galn
description: Robert Miller Gallery

title: Taking The Leap Into Love
description: The sweetness at the core of the raggedy low-budget romantic comedy ''Jump Tomorrow'' is hard to resist, because its beats of small-scale intimacy reflect the geeky yet winning persona of the lead character, the stoic George (Tunde Adebimpe). Gangly, with a slightly at-sea expression frozen on his face, he couldn't be less adept at expressing his emotions and even has trouble watching a romantic tableau unfold before him. He is also totally oblivious to his leading-man good looks, and his humility makes his awkward diffidence all the more touching; it's as if someone mounted a camera inside a tortoise's shell so we could see its marrow-deep doubts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, ANNA
description: SINGER-Anna. The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany (Claims Conference) records with profound sorrow the passing of Anna Singer, the mother of Dr. Israel Singer, our VicePresident and Chairman of the Claims Conference Negotiating Committee. She was a woman of valor and kindness who brought her family through the Holocaust to rekindle Jewish life in a new land. We extend heartfelt condolences to her children Israel Singer and Barbara Tacobowitz and their families. Rabbi Israel Miller, President Gideon Taylor Executive Vice President Saul Kagan Executive Vice President Emeritus

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWAREBMC SAYS PROFIT FELL SHORT

title: Jobs Data and Earnings Warnings Send Stocks Reeling
description: Stocks fell sharply today as profit warnings from technology companies, accompanied by a weak employment report, undermined investors' confidence that the underlying economy, if not profits, would be recovering by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, DAVID
description: COHEN-David. My beloved grandfather, I miss you every day. You are the light of my life. Freya

title: Shares of Marconi Tumble and Technology Follows
description: Shares of Marconi, Britain's biggest telephone equipment maker, fell by more than half today in a vivid display of the spiraling decline in Europe's telecommunications industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, FRED C., JR.
description: SMITH-Fred C., Jr. On Wednesday, July 4, 2001, resident of South Orange, NJ. Cherished husband of Margaret McCarron Smith. Much adored father of Michael, Paul, Peter, Christopher, Stephen, Monica, and Timothy Smith. Proud and loving grandfather to Gabrielle, Samantha, Alexis, Jordan, Brendan, Griffin, Nolan, Erin, Kelly and Grace. Fred was born in Brooklyn, NY, in 1924 and served in the U.S. Navy 1942-1946. He graduated Fordham College in 1949. Fred achieved distinction as a Health Care Administrator working with the New York Medical Group P.C., Medical Group Council, Brooklyn Medical Group and the Kings Highway Medical Group. He served as a Fellow for the American College of Medical Practice Executives, as Chairman of the Advisory Council School of Health Related Professions and President of the Medical Group Management Association -Eastern Section. He also served as a Director on the Board of Directors for the Medical Group Management Association and as a Director for the Group Council Mutual Insurance Company. Fred was President of the South Orange Board of Health. Fred also taught as a Guest Lecturer at the Cornell University School of Medicine and the School of Health Related Professions at the University of Medicine and Dentistry in NJ. Da was an avid historian, a lover of the Jersey Shore, a family chronicler of treasured stories and knowledge, appreciated everything Irish and most of all, was an individual who always placed family and friends above all else. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, NJ, on Saturday, July 7, at 8:30 AM, thence to Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 217 Prospect St., South Orange, where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 9:30 AM. Interment private. Visiting hours Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUITERMAN, RICHARD L. COLONEL RETIRED, (USAF)
description: GUITERMAN-Richard L. Colonel Retired, (USAF), of Park Avenue, New York. Died at St. Luke's Hospital on July 2, 2001. Survived by his dear wife Eleanor, her daughter Sara, son-in-law Scott Moyer, daughter Susan Robie, grandchildren Robie Moyer and K. Arden Moyer and by his sister, Marjorie Morris of West Lafayette, Indiana. Colonel Guiterman retired from the U.S. Air Force in November 1978, after serving more than 37 years on active and reserve duty. He was a Vice President of Chemical Bank in the Corporate Banking Division and also a Vice President of Amercian Express Bank and Director of International Corporate Banking. Colonel Guiterman was a Director of the New York's Finest Foundation and a member of the University Club. A memorial service will be held at the 7th Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, New York City, on Wednesday, July 11, 2001, at 12 noon. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Virginia, on July 25, 2001, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the University of Wisconsin in memory of the deceased.

title: An Unhappy Henley for Yale
description: Yale entered six crews in this year's Henley Royal Regatta as part of the university's 300th anniversary celebration, but the university's alumni, packing the Stewards Enclosure, had little to cheer about yesterday as Yale entries went one for four in qualifying on the Thames River.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Governor Makes It Official
description: Gov. Jeb Bush officially began his re-election campaign, filing paperwork with the State Division of Elections that will allow him to raise and spend political contributions. Two Democrats filed their paperwork earlier this week to run next year, Daryl L. Jones, a state senator from Miami, and Bill McBride, a Tampa lawyer. Other possible challengers to Mr. Bush, a Republican, include Janet Reno, the attorney general in the Clinton administration. Lloyd Dunkelberger (NYT)

title: Standing Tall Along the Comeback Trail
description: REBECCA LOBO is practicing with her New York Liberty teammates, tearing up and down the gleaming basketball court in the Brearley School Field House on the Upper East Side. The 6-foot-4-inch power forward waves her arms wide. Now, she's dribbling. She shoots and misses. At one point, she falls down hard and is helped up by a teammate.

title: Some Motivation for MetroStars
description: After his team's short-handed victory last week over Columbus, Coach Ray Hudson was practically salivating about the Miami Fusion's next home match. ``I can't wait to get stinkin' New York down here at the Orange Bowl,'' Hudson said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Owner of Macy's Lowers Profit Forecast for Quarter

title: Metro Business Briefing | Lower Expectations
description: Multex.com Inc., a New York online financial services company that had been profitable for three straight quarters, said this week that its second-quarter revenues would be lower than forecast and that it planned to reduce its payroll by 15 percent through eliminating jobs and cutting executives' salaries. Multex expects second-quarter revenues of $24 million, 15 percent lower than the company had predicted. The company, which provides research and job listings, forecasts a net loss of $1 million, excluding noncash charges, versus the $3.3 million to $3.8 million predicted. Including charges, Multex expects to lose $8 million. Revenues are expected to remain mostly flat for the rest of the year, officials said. Multex announced the lower expectations Tuesday night; quarterly results are to be announced on July 19. Until this quarter, Multex seemed to be weathering the dot-com sector's crash. Gregory Smith, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase, wrote in a research report that the news ''signifies a serious deterioration in the company's existing business, let alone growth prospects over the coming quarters.'' Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A headline with a report in the Company News column of Business Day on June 28 about divestitures that the Thomson Corporation of Canada is required to make to resolve antitrust concerns over its proposed acquisition of some assets of Harcourt General Inc. misstated the properties that Thomson needs to sell. Thomson must divest itself of textbooks used in 38 college courses and invite bids for a national testing business that it will acquire as part of the deal, not sell a textbook unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, BENJAMIN
description: RUBINSTEIN-Benjamin. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dr. Benjamin Rubinstein, a cherished friend of the Jewish community who expressed his commitment to humanitarian causes through his dedicated service on behalf of our beneficiary agencies. Dr. Rubinstein's sons embrace their father's devotion to our community through their extraordinary support of, and leadership in, UJA-Federation. His son, Laurence, has served on many of our boards and is currently the president of Surprise Lake Camp, a beneficiary of UJA-Federation. His son Rabbi Peter Rubinstein, currently serves on our Board of Directors. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Rubinstein's wife, Irene; to his sons Laurence, Peter, and John; to his eight grandchildren; to his great-grandson; and to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP and CEO

title: Angel Investors Fill Void Left By Risk Capital; Impressing Private Financiers Becomes Crucial to Start-Ups
description: Even in a gathering of some 70 people, spotting the money seekers was easy. They were the younger men huddled off to the sides, clutching glasses of mineral water and trying not to look anxious.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Executive Named In Fire Inquiry
description: The chairman of the French company that helps operate the Mont Blanc tunnel was notified that he is under investigation in connection with the fire in the tunnel in 1999 that left 39 people dead. Remy Chardon is the 12th official of the French and Italian companies that run the tunnel to be put under investigation. The fire erupted as a truck carrying flour and margarine burst into flames in the 7.5-mile-long tunnel, which pierces the Mont Blanc massif to connect Italy and France. Investigators are trying to learn if company officials were criminally negligent. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Mideast Peace Can Only Be Made in America
description: This spring, at the height of the Palestinian intifada, pollsters asked Israelis if they wanted the United States to ''impose a solution'' to the Palestinian conflict; 48 percent said yes. This sentiment was a product of desperation rather than diplomatic logic. But it does indicate that many Israelis accept the truth that should be shouted from the rooftops of Jerusalem, Ramallah and Washington: There is no possibility of ending the nightmare we share with the Palestinians unless the United States takes on an active role as even-handed mediator.

title: In Bucolic Normandy, the Earth Is Plunging
description: Sbastien Elerbach was finishing dinner at his sister's renovated Norman farmhouse when a thunderous crash erupted in the backyard. Dashing out the door to investigate, he plunged into oblivion.

title: Valentine's Latest Feud Is With Floyd of Marlins
description: As manager of the Mets, Bobby Valentine has managed to become embroiled in a series of disputes with some of his own players, most recently Darryl Hamilton. Now, as manager of the National League All-Star team, he has landed in a major argument with a player from another team, Cliff Floyd of the Florida Marlins.

title: Ronald Monchak, 65, Advertising Executive
description: Ronald Monchak, a longtime creative executive in the Detroit advertising industry, died on June 26. He was 65 and lived in Rochester, Mich.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Brownfield Grants
description: The New Jersey Economic Development Authority announced yesterday that it had awarded $328,000 in grants to seven municipalities for investigation or cleanup of so-called brownfields, moderately contaminated former industrial sites that can be redeveloped for commercial or residential use. Through its Hazardous Discharge Site Remediation Fund, the agency has given away $2 million this year for brownfield cleanups, and a total of $41 million to date, the agency said. Yesterday's recipients were Egg Harbor City, Elizabeth, Livingston, North Wildwood, Rahway, Trenton and West Deptford.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NATHAN, HENRY
description: NATHAN-Henry. To you, from me.

title: Companies in U.S. Profiting From Surge In Internet Gambling
description: While it is illegal to offer wagers over the Internet in most states, a growing number of American companies are profiting from a boom in online gambling and from business relationships with virtual casinos based overseas whose games can be played here.

title: Tough-Talking Flyers Dig In On Making Lindros a Ranger
description: If the Rangers get Eric Lindros in a trade with the Philadelphia Flyers, they must deal with Flyers General Manager Bob Clarke. And Clarke indicated yesterday that the negotiations might be difficult. ''We don't care if Eric plays in New York, and we don't care if he ever plays again,'' Clarke said in a statement released by the team.

title: In Another Bronx, Everybody Knew His Name and His Party
description: Under a punishing noontime sun, made tolerable only by a gentle breeze blowing from the river, Herman Badillo came out of his car yesterday, took off his navy suit jacket, rolled up the sleeves of his blue shirt and began walking, alone, the streets of the South Bronx.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: 7 Sentenced For Abusing Disabled Man
description: Seven of eight people found responsible for abusing a mentally disabled man were sentenced yesterday to prison. The defendants admitted that in 1999 they persuaded the victim to join them at a party where they tied him to a chair, shaved his head and forced him to wear women's clothes. They later beat him and made him drink urine, they admitted. The three defendants described by prosecutors as ringleaders received sentences of 15 to 20 years. The others received sentences of 5 to 8 years. The eighth person charged in the case, who is also mentally disabled, is under court-supervised probation.

title: Cardinals Developing Throwback
description: More than a decade before the St. Louis Cardinals switched to a grass field and a lineup with names like Mark McGwire, Jim Edmonds and Albert Pujols, their symbols were Vince Coleman, Willie McGee and Ozzie Smith flying over the artificial turf.

title: Article 2001070692903944491 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: An Old and New Skill
description: Archery has evolved a bit since the days of Robin Hood. Today archers often draw part-magnesium bows and shoot carbon fiber arrows (above). But there is still room for traditionalists who not only favor the old wooden variety, but also carve their own from a stave.

title: Article 2001070693681389960 -- No Title
description: Untangling the Online Gaming Web

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BON, VINKO
description: BON-Vinko. On July 3, 2001. (Former member of Local 806 Structural Steel Painters Union). Beloved husband of the late Aika. Devoted father of Vinko, Jack and Barbara Kaczmar. Dear father-inlaw of Elissa Bon, Holly Bon and Donald Kaczmar. Cherished grandfather of Nadia, Elizabeth and Alaina Bon and Matthew Kaczmar. Funeral Monday, 10 AM, from the Andrew Torregrossa & Sons Funeral Home, 1305 79 St, Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Guadalupe Church. Interment Fairview Cemetery, Red Bank, NJ. Visiting Saturady and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: They Come In Peace

title: In Rome, O'Neill Plans To Laud U.S. Economy
description: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that he would carry a message of optimism about the United States economy to a meeting with his counterparts from the other big industrial nations on Saturday in Rome, where the main topic will be the faltering world economy.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SETS DATE FOR SPINOFF OF ORTHOPEDIC UNIT
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it planned to spin off its Zimmer orthopedic business to shareholders on Aug. 6, letting the company focus on sales of prescription drugs. Shares in the business, Zimmer Holdings, will begin trading on Aug. 7 on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol ZMH. Bristol-Myers, based in New York, said it would give one share of Zimmer common stock for every 10 shares of Bristol-Myers common stock owned. Last year, Bristol-Myers announced a plan to shed the orthopedics business and said in February that it would spin off the unit to shareholders.

title: Western's Early Leader Is Unfamiliar
description: Davis Love III and Phil Mickelson are used to being on the leader board, but Mark Wiebe often goes months without being in contention in a golf tournament.

title: Police Focusing on Voluntary Absence or Foul Play in Intern Case
description: Nine weeks after a Washington intern, Chandra Ann Levy, disappeared, the police are no closer to solving the case and are still treating it as a missing-person investigation, not a homicide, the chief of the Metropolitan Police Department said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETTLE, GLORIA R.
description: SETTLE-Gloria R. Age 80, died July 5. Beloved, devoted and loving partner of Stas Pyka for over twenty years. Loving and proud mother of Joan. A fun, heel-kicking grandmother of Meagan, Heather, Michael and Cathy. Great-grandmother of Taylor, Alison, Caitlin and Jake. Loved and respected mother-in-law to Ernie. Grandmother-in-law to Jim, Bruce and Steve. Loved by the Pyka and Dillon families. She was a joy called GoGo. She was loved and respected by her co-workers throughout her thirty years of service with NBC-TV as manager of the Design and Art Dept. She was the best and my one and only. Stas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROCKET, PHILIP
description: CROCKET-Philip. With reverence and respect, we mourn the passing of Philip Crocket, a former commander in the American Navy stationed in England during WWII, a Rhodes Scholar, former Wall Street broker, the second husband of the late Ruth Dill Johnson who was the former wife of the late Seward Johnson. Mr. and Mrs. Crocket were married for 50 years before she passed away at the age of 84. Philip Crocket was born Memorial Day, 1898, and died July 4th, 2001, at the age of 103, at the Parker Nursing Home which was built on land donated by Ruth Dill Johnson Crocket and where Mr. Crocket lived until 1999, when he himself moved into the Parker Home. He leaves behind three step-children and their families.

title: INSIDE
description: Capriati Out at Wimbledon

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bookseller Sells Distributor
description: The British bookseller, the W. H. Smith Group said that it would sell its distribution unit for 215 million ($300 million) to ABN Amro Private Equity Ltd. to focus on its retail and publishing businesses. The unit, which is the Britain's biggest wholesaler of magazines and newspapers, has annual sales of 1.05 billion. W. H. Smith has been expanding its retail business through acquisitions and store openings. The company has been weighed down by rising costs at the news-distribution arm, where first-half profit fell 33 percent. ''It improves the perceived quality of the business because there's been rather erratic earnings from distribution,'' said Richard Ratner, an analyst at Seymour Pierce Group.

title: U.N. May Delay Climate Treaty's Target Date
description: The chairman of a United Nations conference negotiating a climate treaty said on Thursday that he was willing to delay the target date that countries would have to start cutting emissions of heat-trapping gases. His offer of such a compromise was widely seen as a bid to gain Japan's support for the treaty, known as the Kyoto Protocol.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ex-Officer Admits To Tax Charges
description: A former city police officer pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to neglecting to pay taxes on about $11,000 he earned by working as a bouncer at a massage parlor and gambling den that catered mainly to Chinese-speaking patrons in Flushing, Queens. The former officer, Jay Zhao, was charged in November with providing protection for the massage parlor. According to federal prosecutors, Mr. Zhao, who resigned from the department on Tuesday, faces up to three years in prison. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Shares Decline For Two in Europe
description: Shares of two European agency companies fell yesterday after each made announcements that reflected the slowing economy.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Corruption Charges In Arms Deals
description: Prosecutors charged nine retired naval officers, including a former navy commander in chief, with corruption in arms deals involving France and Germany. The prosecutors recommended sentences of 10 to 14 years for six officers who were accused of buying six French-made Lafayette frigates in 1991 at inflated prices. President Chen Shui-bian reopened the case last year after he defeated the long-ruling Nationalist Party on an anti-corruption platform. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: The Other War Crimes Tribunal
description: Now that Slobodan Milosevic is in custody of the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, the proceedings of another international war crimes court should be coming under stricter scrutiny. The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, based in Arusha, Tanzania, has been making only fitful progress in bringing to justice officials responsible for the genocide in 1994 in which half a million Rwandan Tutsi were slaughtered. The tribunal has long held many of the top accused conspirators in custody, yet precious few have so far been tried. With the world's attention newly focused on the importance of international justice, the Rwanda tribunal deserves the resources and the oversight it needs to complete its mission.

title: Drilling Under Great Lakes Muddies Political Allegiances
description: About a quarter-mile inland from the cattail-covered shore of Lake Huron, squared in by trees and reachable only by rutted gravel road, lies one of the latest beachheads in the escalating battle between environmentalists and energy hunters.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSAK, FREDA
description: HUSAK-Freda. On July 5, 2001, of Lakehurst, formerly of NYC. Sister of the late Elizabeth Gould and Louise Husak. Grandaunt of Elizabeth Smith, Alyson Mickelson and Jennifer Greco. Also survived by many other great-great-nieces and nephews and her dear friend Lillian Paul of Kearny. Visiting at the Wilfred Armitage Funeral Home, 596 Belgrove Drive, Kearny, on Sunday 7-9 PM. Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Stephens Church in Kearny. Interment Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ. In lieu of flowers please make donations to St. Johns, 619 Chestnut St, Lakehurst, NJ 08733.

title: Editor of The Financial Times Will Step Down
description: After 10 years as editor of The Financial Times, Richard Lambert announced today that he would step down in September.

title: Sow the Seeds of the Fourth, Before We Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Parametric Warns On Outlook
description: Parametric Technology, whose software helps engineers design products, said fiscal third-quarter profit and sales trailed forecasts because demand for its customers' products fell. Its shares tumbled $2.24, or 18.1 percent, to to $10.13. Demand for Parametric's computer-aided drafting programs has stalled because its manufacturing clients, which include Lucent Technologies, are facing slower sales of products like networking gear and aircraft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOTWIN, ROSEMARIE
description: LOTWIN-Rosemarie. Forever present in our thoughts. Your family misses you. Lovingly remembered, Sean, Kelle, Dakota, Autumn Rose.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Silencing The Pollsters
description: Parliament took steps to ban the publication of opinion polls in the week before all elections, with penalties of up to two years in prison and a $107,000 fine. The dominant political party, Fianna Fail, proposed the ban after its poor showing in a parliamentary by-election last Saturday; it said voters were unduly influenced by an opinion poll. The Irish government considered such a ban in 1991 but rejected the idea as unconstitutional. The new plan is part of an electoral reform bill that is due to be signed into law shortly. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: At The Hague, Bosnian Serbs Are Castigated Over Fugitives
description: The chief prosecutor of the United Nations war crimes tribunal demanded action, not ''hollow promises or excuses,'' from the Bosnian Serb republic today and openly accused its government of sheltering two fugitive war-crimes suspects, Dr. Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic.

title: All He Wants Is His Mother, But She Doesn't Want Him
description: A.I.

title: U.S. Hands Over Rape Suspect to Japanese
description: TOKYO, July 6 -- The United States today handed over to Japanese authorities an American serviceman accused of raping a woman on June 29 in Okinawa.

title: Indian Celebrates Its Centennial
description: THE reconstituted Indian Motorcycle Company celebrated its centennial by sponsoring a cross-country road trip for owners that started from Indian's original headquarters in Springfield, Mass., in mid-June and ended two days ago at its new factory here.

title: Health and Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News; A Man Made for Law Enforcement -- Robert Swan Mueller III
description: In 1995, Eric H. Holder Jr., the chief federal prosecutor in Washington, received a surprising phone call. It was from Robert S. Mueller III, who not long before had been assistant attorney general of the United States in charge of the criminal division, a post several rungs above Mr. Holder's.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. (Some galleries may be closed this weekend because of the Fourth of July holiday.) Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Dawn Kelly, Jaredd Mooney, Jessie Kremidas and Nate Peterkin, Perkins School for the Blind, Watertown, Mass., June 7, 2001

title: Article 2001070693288168900 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Quick as a Shutter, Group Shows Shatter Conventional Wisdom
description: Artists are rarely single-vocation types. They almost all have a second calling or two. Many excel at collecting, teaching or writing. Some have a flair for interior arrangement or architecture; others for music, gardening or cooking.

title: State's Death Penalty Law Passes Test
description: Wrestling with a constitutional flaw in the state's death penalty law, the Court of Appeals today upheld the guilty plea of a confessed killer and ruled that a plea bargain did not violate his rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, FANNY U.
description: STERNBERG-Fanny U. Of Palm Coast, FL. Beloved wife of the late Fred. Devoted mother of Sandra Sternberg, Linda S. Theos and Deborah J. Sternberg. Loving grandmother of Michelle and Lauren Theos. Services Friday, 1:30 PM, at ''Gutterman-Muslcant,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TENNECO AUTOMOTIVE, Lake Forest, Ill., a maker of automotive shock absorbers, said it had reached an agreement to supply its Monroe shocks and struts to 1,051 United States automotive stores run by Sears, Roebuck.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Arrests In Land Conflict
description: Saying they would not tolerate land invasions, the authorities arrested dozens of squatters who had erected shacks on vacant land just outside Johannesburg. The plots, which include government-owned and privately owned land, were said to have been sold to the poor by local members of the Pan Africanist Congress, a political party that strongly advocates land reform. The police action followed warnings from government officials that South Africa would not allow the kind of illegal land seizures that have swept neighboring Zimbabwe. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Harder Tires Putting the Brakes on Several Winston Cup Drivers
description: New York Times Regional Newspapers

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Funds Stopped for Legal Programs Helping Illegal Immigrants
description: A governor-appointed board has stopped financing four programs at law schools that offer free legal assistance primarily to poor illegal immigrants, drawing complaints from immigration rights advocates who fear that hundreds of people will be left in the lurch.

title: Article 2001070691078259988 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Mount Kaya Journal; A Monument to Peace Has Korean Monks at War
description: The narrow road winds tightly up the mountainside, past lotus-filled ponds and waterworks that cascade gracefully from terrace to landscaped terrace.

title: How to Train -- and Retain -- Teachers
description: For some time now, the nation has been warned that our schools will need up to 2.5 million new teachers over the next decade. Indeed, school officials from New York, Atlanta, Houston, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and other cities are actively seeking teachers from India, the West Indies, South Africa, Europe and anywhere else where good teachers can be found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, ELIZABETH R.
description: BENJAMIN-Elizabeth R. The Boards of Trustees of Monmouth Medical Center and Monmouth Health Care Foundation express sadness at the passing of a very special benefactor, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends.

title: Indian Women, Revered and Reviled
description: ''Woman/Goddess,'' at the India Center of Art and Culture in Chelsea, tackles an impossibly complex subject. Organized by Gayatri Sinha, an art critic in New Delhi, the exhibition aims to explore India's perfervid worship of mythical goddesses and its profound disdain for women in everyday life. To that end, Ms. Sinha draws on the work of 27 photographers -- most of them Indian, three of them women -- and groups the images in eight sections.

title: Sow the Seeds of the Fourth, Before We Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: Courtship Follies From Chekhov, Shaw and Feydeau
description: ''Don't Make Me Laugh,'' an evening of three classic one-act farces at the Westport Country Playhouse through July 14, is summer frippery of a distinguished order. The three plays -- ''The Proposal'' by Anton Chekhov (1888-89), ''The Music Cure'' by George Bernard Shaw (1913) and ''Caught With His Trance Down'' by Georges Feydeau (1897) -- share a general time period, an attitude of fond appreciation for human weakness, and a subject: marriage plans.

title: Our Own Sun King?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Emergency Number Sought
description: Public Advocate Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for mayor, yesterday proposed a 311 telephone line to help New Yorkers through the maze of city government and to relieve pressure on the 911 emergency line. Calling 311 a ''one-stop shop,'' Mr. Green said the number could be used to report potholes or find emergency shelter. A spokesman for the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, another Democratic candidate for mayor, dismissed the proposal as an old idea proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and discussed by the City Council.

title: In Florida, Fraud Doesn't Matter. Will Congress Object?
description: LET'S consider two people who are bankrupt.

title: Canada Vote May Bring First Union to Japan Carmaker
description: Only last month, J. D. Power & Associates named the Toyota plant here the best car factory in North America -- for the fourth time. The Harbour Report, by another industry consultant, ranked it the continent's most efficient producer of subcompact cars.

title: Business Survey Adds to Evidence of a Rebound
description: Business other than manufacturing expanded in June for the first time in three months, an industry survey showed today, adding to evidence that the economy may have begun to pull out of a slowdown.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: Love in a Girls' School, And How It Goes Awry
description: The camera fell in love with Piper Perabo in her first screen appearance, in the hip-hop comedy ''White Boys.'' She had only a couple of scenes playing a fly-girl manqu living in the corn-as-high-as-an-elephant's-eye Midwest, but her insolence made her seem to be daring you to look away. Having squandered her talents in ''The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle'' and ''Coyote Ugly,'' Ms. Perabo displays more of her potential in ''Lost and Delirious'' and adds a new wrinkle. At moments of excitement or embarrassment, she gets flushed just under her eyes; her skin goes dark, indicating an emotional transparency she doesn't overdo.

title: Jobless Rate Rises to 4.5 Percent as Economy Remains Weak
description: The nation's employers cut 114,000 jobs in June, mostly in manufacturing but in other sectors as well, the Labor Department said yesterday, throwing cold water on recent reports suggesting that the economy was beginning to recover.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For two days, it was like thunder rumbling in our backyard.''

title: CEASE-FIRE EASES MACEDONIA CLASH
description: Under heavy pressure from Western powers, the Macedonian government and Albanian rebels signed a formal cease-fire agreement today as a first concrete step toward heading off another ethnic war in the Balkans.

title: Promotional Counterpunch
description: Lennox Lewis's promoters have drawn up a contract agreeing to give Don King the rights to promote a Lewis-Hasim Rahman rematch for $12.5 million, a spokesman for Main Events, which represents Lewis in the United States, said yesterday. But King said he would not sign an agreement written by Lewis's lawyers because he made the original offer and wanted to dictate conditions.

title: Richard Hamilton
Everywhere, Fuel For a Fresh Debate Over Glass's Music
description: LIKE SOME AMAZING POP-UP doll, Philip Glass is everywhere these days. In recent months there have been releases of his music on three different labels, including Point, which he set up with Philips chiefly to record music by others. Now Elektra Nonesuch, the master of hip marketing, has begun to release a slew of Mr. Glass's own music, including Glassian classics in new recordings, early compositions in old recordings and pieces previously unavailable on disk.

title: Leonard Pines, 90, Businessman Who Owned Hebrew National
description: Leonard Pines, who expanded his father's business selling deli meats from a wagon on Manhattan's Lower East Side into Hebrew National Kosher Foods, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 90.

title: Social Warming: Japan's Disabled Gain New Status
description: The strip of studded, egg-yolk-yellow tiles that leads up the stairs and through the entrance of the main building of Tokyo University's Research Center for Advanced Science and Technology is an unlikely gauge of social change.

title: United Airlines Searches for Direction After Proposed Merger Fails
description: It seemed like a corporate fairy tale when James E. Goodwin was named chief executive of United Airlines in 1999, 32 years after joining the carrier as a management trainee. But the last two years, Mr. Goodwin, a tall, taciturn West Virginian, has seemed to be laboring under a curse.

title: Houston and Knicks Are Ready to Sign Deal
description: After Allan Houston and his agent, Bill Strickland, met with Knicks officials in Manhattan on Thursday night to negotiate Houston's long-term contract, both sides were satisfied that the deal would be formalized July 18.

title: Mr. Bush's Fiscal Gaffe
description: No sooner had George W. Bush become president than he began warning of an impending recession and campaigning for a huge tax cut. But he forgot -- or perhaps did not know -- that a slowing economy, with lower corporate profits and personal earnings, would automatically result in lower tax collections and throw his knife-edged fiscal plan into imbalance. So instead of residing peacefully in ''lockboxes'' for the next decade, the trust funds collected to cover baby boomers' Social Security and Medicare benefits may be tapped as early as this year. Mr. Bush gave up long-term fiscal discipline for short-term political gain, and the salad days of surpluses have transmogrified into the bad old days of budget bickering.

title: INSIDE
description: Rafter Eliminates Agassi

title: Jenna Bush Fined for Alcohol Use
description: President Bush's daughter Jenna was ordered today to pay $600 in fines and perform 36 hours of community service for under-age drinking and using false identification.

title: Family of Beaten Police Officer Decides to End Life Support
description: Officials said today that a police officer who was severely beaten on July 4 was brain dead and would be removed from life support.

title: Coca-Cola Still Faces Suits In Race Discrimination Case
description: Despite reaching the largest settlement ever in a racial bias case, the Coca-Cola Company will continue to face lawsuits from current and former black employees, a Florida law firm representing some of the workers said yesterday.

title: The Mideast Deadlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Motivation For MetroStars
description: After his team's short-handed victory last week over Columbus, Coach Ray Hudson was practically salivating about the Miami Fusion's next home match. ''I can't wait to get stinkin' New York down here at the Orange Bowl,'' Hudson said.

title: Editors' Note
description: COMING ON SUNDAY: LOST IN CHECHNYA

title: D-Day Isn't a Metaphor
description: To the Editor:

title: IMMUNE RESPONSE STOCK FALLS AFTER PFIZER ENDS DEAL
description: Stock in the biotechnology company the Immune Response Corporation dropped 44 percent yesterday after the drug maker Pfizer Inc. cut its ties to the joint development of the biotechnology company's most advanced drug candidate. Shares of Immune Response fell $2.01, to $2.58. In the last 12 months, the company, based in Carlsbad, Calif., has lost $17.62 million on revenue of $5.10 million. ''Our decision was based on review of the data from several clinical trials,'' a Pfizer spokesman, Kim Simon, said. Immune Response had been working with Agouron Pharmaceuticals, a unit of Pfizer, to develop and test an immune-based H.I.V. therapy called Remune. An Immune Response spokeswoman, Laura Hansen, said the notice did not explain why Pfizer was ending the relationship.

title: When Politics Clash With Card-Playing
description: A quarter of a century ago, politics was a major issue on the international bridge scene, and some players were caught in the middle. Teams entering a world championship were required to give a pledge that they would play against any designated opponent. A few signed on the line, but nevertheless arrived under orders from their governments to default against South Africa, or Taiwan, or Israel.

title: Article 2001070791642212203 -- No Title
description: July 2, 2001

title: Burial Ground or Ball Field? Past May Clash With Future
description: For as long as anyone can remember, farmers have grown hay and corn on 35 acres of fertile flatland by the Black Creek in northwestern New Jersey. But a court fight is now focusing on a time far beyond memory. Was the site an Indian burial ground centuries before white settlers arrived? Or was it a village, or simply a busy hunting ground?

title: A Second Life For Historic Pipe Organs
description: John Bishop doesn't look like Superman.

title: Kennedy Gets Noted Defense, And 30 Days
description: Mario Cuomo had been quiet most of the day today, sitting near the front of a crowded courtroom here, his role as a defense lawyer for Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Dennis Rivera, the labor leader, promising a rare glimpse of a former governor practicing law.

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the postponement of an International Monetary Fund review of economic progress in Turkey misstated the size of the next installment of I.M.F. funds to Turkey. It is about $1.6 billion, not $1.6 million.

title: CONAGRA IN JOINT VENTURE WITH MAKER OF FROZEN FOOD
description: ConAgra Foods has formed a joint venture with Alfa of Mexico in an effort to expand distribution for both companies' products in the United States, Mexico and Central America. ConAgra, based in Omaha, has bought 50 percent of Sigma Alimentos Congelados, a unit of Alfa that makes frozen Mexican food under the brand names El Cazo Mexicano and Men del Sol. Terms were not disclosed. The joint venture will sell frozen food in the United States and Canada as well as distribute several of ConAgra's frozen food brands, including Healthy Choice, in Mexico and Central America.

title: A Bitter Scent of Loss for Mexican Party
description: For the party that ruled Mexico for seven decades, until last year's devastating presidential election, the mayor's race in Ciudad Jurez was the chance for a new start. It was there that the party that unseated the entrenched Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) last year scored its first electoral victory 20 years ago, spawning a conservative movement that eventually cost the PRI the presidency.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Fund Gets Loan To Pay Investors
description: The country's biggest mutual fund group, Unit Trust of India, said it had received a loan of $318 million to pay investors who hold units in its flagship fund. The loan from State Bank of India comes four days after Unit Trust froze the sale and buyback of units in its flagship fund, the US-64 plan, for six months to stem a $700 million exodus by some of its 20 million investors. The ban was aimed at stopping a sharp rise in withdrawals after a declining performance. The fund has said it is working on plans to allow investors to redeem part of their holdings.

title: World Business Briefing
description: GLOBAL TRADE

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Former Allies Hold Talks
description: President Paul Kagame, left, and his Ugandan counterpart, Yoweri Museveni, met near the border between their countries, vowing to improve relations between the former allies. Many Rwandan Tutsis, including Mr. Kagame, helped Mr. Museveni gain power in Uganda. But relations became strained after they invaded Congo in 1998.

title: Mellon Is Said to Seek Buyer For Consumer Banking Arm
description: The Mellon Financial Corporation is in negotiations to sell its $14 billion in consumer banking deposits to the Citizens Financial Group, a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland, an executive close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Torre Goes Right
description: With the left-hander Al Leiter pitching for the Mets last night, Yankees Manager Joe Torre went to a right-handed lineup, resting the left-handed hitters Paul O'Neill and Tino Martinez and inserting Gerald Williams in right field and Luis Sojo at first base. Williams has hit well in his career against Leiter, but went 0 for 4 last night. Sojo, who had the game-winning hit off Leiter in Game 5 of the World Series last year, went 1 for 2 and scored a run. Martinez pinch-hit for Sojo in the eighth inning and hit a solo home run off Turk Wendell.

title: Article 2001070793094015950 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Beliefs; Speaking in tongues, performing miracles: A look at Pentecostalism from a former insider.
description: Pentecostal Christianity began a century ago with a handful of evangelical Christians for whom simply being born again did not suffice.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: An Airport Named Armstrong
description: New Orleans International Airport will be renamed after Louis Armstrong under a proposal by Mayor Marc Morial that was approved by the New Orleans City Council. The retitling, to the Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport, will be made on Aug. 2, two days before what would have been the trumpeter's 100th birthday. Many Armstrong fans have said he never received proper recognition in New Orleans, his hometown. David Firestone (NYT)

title: The Storm Over Embryo Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Loosing the Logjam in the Sky; Private Sector Is Promoting Its Solutions
description: As air traffic delays have become noticeably worse the last few years, Congress, aviation experts and the public have wondered how the job could be done better. And some airline executives have talked about whether the job should be taken away from the Federal Aviation Administration and given to a private company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBEIN, LOTTA
description: FISHBEIN-Lotta. Age 92. Died July 6, 2001. Wife of the late Arthur L. Fishbein. Mother of Peter and Richard. Mother-in-law of Bette and Estelle. Grandmother of Stephen, Bruce, Gregory and Melissa. Grandmother-in-law of Sara and Jennifer. Great-grandmother of Maggie and Daniel. Funeral Sunday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about changes at the New York Academy of Sciences misspelled the surname of the chairwoman of the academy's section on women in science. She is Dr. Nancy Tooney, not Toomey.

title: Brazil Hits Record Low On Currency
description: Brazil's currency touched a record low yesterday, and some analysts said they did not expect the fall would stop until the country's central bank pushed interest rates even higher than they already are.

title: Millar Eagerly Awaits Opportunity in Prologue
description: David Millar's sister Fran had T-shirts made before the start of last year's Tour de France and gave them to a few family members. On the front, it asked ''What time is it?'' and on the back, echoing a commercial for a beer with a slightly different spelling, it answered ''Millar time.''

title: Evolving Reality TV Tests The Audience's Endurance
description: ''I believe television is going to be the test of the modern world, and that in this new opportunity to see beyond the range of our vision we shall discover either a new and unbearable disturbance of the general peace or a saving radiance in the sky,'' E. B. White wrote in 1938, in ''Removal,'' the opening essay in ''One Man's Meat.'' ''We shall stand or fall by television -- of that I am quite sure.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARCAN, ARTHUR
description: BARCAN-Arthur. The Directors and staff of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York mourn the passing of our former President, Arthur Barcan. May him memory be for a blessing. Avrom I. Doft, President Philip Schatten, Board Chairman Chaim Lauer, Exec Vice President

title: The Storm Over Embryo Research
description: To the Editor:

title: In Building a Charter School, The Hard Job Is Getting It Built
description: Now that its first year of classes is complete, all the Bronx Preparatory Charter School has to do is raise $15 million.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You cannot spin this report to make it sound positive; there is nothing positive about it.''

title: Asian Electronics Slump, Hurting Market Indexes
description: Shares of Asian electronics manufacturers tumbled today as Hitachi of Japan announced it was halting production at a new plant that produces chips for cellular phones, the latest sign of the global squeeze in the semiconductor industry.

title: CALPINE AND PG&E IN ACCORD ON CONTRACTS
description: The Calpine Corporation, the energy supplier, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Pacific Gas and Electric unit of the PG&E Corporation to preserve power-supply contracts between the companies and resolve past-due bills. Under the agreement filed in bankruptcy court in San Francisco, Pacific Gas will pay the more than $267 million that it owes Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif. Pacific Gas filed for protection from creditors in April. Pacific Gas will modify and assume contracts covering 11 Calpine plants, which provide enough power to light about 450,000 homes. Judge Dennis J. Montali is expected to approve the deal on July 12, Calpine said.

title: Telecom Italia Inquiry
description: Investment bankers who helped arrange Telecom Italia's $25 billion acquisition last year of Seat Pagine Gialle are under investigation, along with Roberto Colaninno, the chief executive of the telephone company, a prosecutor said today.

title: Princeton Men Survive Tight Finish
description: The Princeton men's heavyweight varsity provided a cliffhanger finish in the opening heat of the Ladies' Challenge Plate at the Henley Royal Regatta at Henley-on-Thames, England, yesterday, winning in the final strokes. The Tigers beat the Mosley Boat Club, a British crew, by three feet.

title: In Lyme Disease Debate, Some Patients Feel Lost
description: Sandy Samelson could barely lift her head from her husband's shoulder when it was her turn to speak at a Lyme disease support group here in Dutchess County, where per capita incidence of the tick-borne infection is among the highest in the world.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Companies Settle Suit
