description: Five multinational pharmaceutical companies, including Armour, Baxter Healthcare and Bayer, have agreed to settle a long legal battle by compensating 60 hemophiliacs who were infected with H.I.V. and hepatitis C in contaminated blood products in the 1980's. Details of settlement were not announced, but the compensation is thought to be more than $5.6 million, or almost $94,000 each, according to the Irish broadcaster, RTE. A government investigation found that 252 hemophiliacs were infected with H.I.V., hepatitis C, or both; many were not told until years later. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST</B

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMERLER, SYBIL LAMB
description: SCHMERLER-Sybil Lamb. On July 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Joseph Schmerler. Devoted mother of Charles Schmerler and Julie Harrison. Loving grandmother of Sabrina and Sydney Harrison, Jessica and Justin Schmerler. Funeral service Sunday, 11 AM, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery. In her memory, memorial contributions to National Women's Division, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1165 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461 (please designate for cardiac research).

title: Desperate Parents and Dangerous Choices
description: Many parents are understandably shocked and horrified by the death of a 14-year-old boy at a desert boot camp this week. Tony Haynes, a troubled boy whose parents sent him to the camp in Arizona to instill some discipline, died there under suspicious circumstances. According to witnesses, he had been beaten and forced to eat mud. Many will wonder: How could people treat children this way? How could parents send their children to a place where such things could happen? But others, like me, will read this news with grim recognition and the sad realization: ''That could have been my kid.''

title: Administration Clarifies New U.S. Rules Guarding Privacy of Patients
description: Trying to calm the fears of the health care industry, the Bush administration today clarified new federal rules that protect the privacy of medical records.

title: Piazza Plans to Play for N.L. in Seattle
description: Mike Piazza had never missed an All-Star Game in his career until last July, when a concussion resulting from Roger Clemens's beanball kept him from going to the game in Atlanta. Piazza does not want to miss Tuesday's All-Star Game, and he apparently will not let his fractured left big toe stop him.

title: The Storm Over Embryo Research
description: To the Editor:

title: They, Too, Enjoyed Watching Violence And Death
description: How did the gladiatorial contests start?

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Report On Defectors To U.S.
description: A press service run by Iraqi exiles said one of two Iraqi diplomats who were reported to have defected in New York last week may have had files on the cases of Kuwaitis still missing after the Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait in 1990. The Internet news service of the exile organization, the Coalition for Justice in Iraq, said it was the fourth-ranking diplomat at Iraq's United Nations mission, Fela Hesan Al-Rubaie, who had information on the missing Kuwaitis. The Iraqi mission's second-ranking diplomat, Muhammad al-Humaimidi, also defected on June 29.

title: Article 2001070790921167444 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Management page of Business Day on Wednesday about the career path of David Dyer to chief executive of Lands' End misspelled the name of the Paraguayan city in which he once taught at the American School. It is Asuncin, not Ascensin.

title: Youth Camp's Founder No Stranger to Scrutiny
description: Charles F. Long II, who served in Vietnam as a marine, was so proud of the black cavalrymen who fought in the Indian wars that he founded a camping organization for troubled youth in their name, calling it the America's Buffalo Soldiers Re-enactors Association.

title: Fighting AIDS: A New War Is Killing Cambodians
description: Just as Cambodia is emerging from three decades of war and mass killings, it finds itself swept by the beginnings of a new scourge: AIDS. Cambodia is the sickest country in Asia now, at risk for a devastating spread of the disease.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Lifer Has a Quest To Fulfill
description: WILLIE RANDOLPH celebrated his 47th birthday yesterday. The Yankees helped by winning their ninth straight game last night, vanquishing the hapless Mets, 8-3, in the first game of their series.

title: Excerpts From Comments On Hanssen's Guilty Plea
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in Alexandria, Va., at which federal prosecutors announced that the former F.B.I. agent Robert P. Hanssen had entered a guilty plea to charges of spying for Moscow, as recorded by the Federal News Service. Speakers included Larry Thompson, the deputy attorney general, and Ken Melson, United States attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia:

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Sale Of Execution Drugs To End
description: For 18 years, the McAlester Regional Health Center has sold sodium thiopental, pancuronium bromide and potassium chloride for use in executions at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary's death chamber. But no more, said Stephen Cushing, a spokesman for the hospital 100 miles south of Tulsa. ''This just didn't seem consistent with our mission,'' Mr. Cushing said. ''We're involved in caring for people, not killing them.'' Mr. Cushing said that the current directors of the hospital became aware of the sales only after inquiries by a group opposed to the death penalty, Human Rights Watch. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: Counting the Fetus as an Unborn Child
description: A backdoor effort to undermine abortion rights has emerged in a proposal circulated by the Federal Department of Health and Human Services to expand the availability of prenatal care. While the goal is unassailable, the method surely is not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CAROLE
description: KLEIN-Carole. The Board of Trustees of Goddard College mourn the passing of Carole Klein, our colleague, friend, teacher, alumna. She was a great friend and a light in all our lives.

title: Article 2001070793676431075 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Theft of Painkiller Reflects Its Popularity on the Street
description: On the afternoon of the Fourth of July, a slow business day, a young man walked into the Walgreen's on this town's main thoroughfare and said he had a gun. He did not want money. All he wanted was OxyContin, 1,100 pills of the powerful prescription painkiller, which would be worth tens of thousands of dollars on the street.

title: While Waiting for a War
description: There is a new truce, and long may it last. The space between the two main ethnic populations of Macedonia has, over the past weeks, seemed vast one moment and inconsequential or absurd the next -- particularly here in the capital city, where the two ''sides'' are divided by the Vardar River.

title: Staten Island Residents Fight Relocated Power Plant's Start
description: The New York Power Authority is coming under intense criticism from some Staten Island residents as it prepares to turn on a mini-power plant in their neighborhood this weekend.

title: See the City, All at Once, In Queens; Official Guide Offers Some Offbeat Sights
description: It's high season for tourists in New York City. Sure, most of the 116,000 or so visitors slowly wandering the streets right now are here for the museums, the shopping and the night life. But NYC & Company, the city's conventions and visitors bureau, wants even more.

title: Stocks Fall on Warnings by Key Technology Companies
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday as profit warnings from technology companies, accompanied by a weak employment report, undermined investors' confidence that the economy would be recovering by the end of the year.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Eunice Shriver Injured
description: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, the sister of President John F. Kennedy and the founder of the Special Olympics, was injured in a car accident on Cape Cod. Mrs. Shriver, 79, fractured a leg and underwent an operation at Cape Cod Hospital on Thursday. Hospital officials said she was in good condition. Police said a man in a pickup truck pulled out suddenly from a side road and Mrs. Shriver's Jeep Cherokee hit the truck. The man was cited for making an illegal turn; Mrs. Shriver was cited for having an expired registration and failing to wear a seat belt. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: New Car, Old Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about political consultants working for candidates this year in New York City misspelled the surname of one of them. He is Scott Levenson, not Levinson.

title: A Sacred Commitment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANSTERN, ROSALIE ARLENE (NEE MARCUS)
description: MORGANSTERN-Rosalie Arlene (nee Marcus). Age 71, died on July 6, 2001, with her family by her side. Joyfully married for 47 years to her soulmate, Kennard. Cherished and adored by her children Priya (Shari), Bhavani (Mindy), David and Julie; her grandchildren Saisha, Harper, Elana, Cayla, Daria, Dustin, Melody and Eve; her children-in-law Tom, Joe, Carolyn and Scott; and her sister-in-law Myrna Cohen. Beloved by many more. Services Sunday, July 8, 2001, at 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, LI; 516-487-9600. Memorial contributions in her name may be made to North Shore University Hospital Auxilliary-Stroke Club, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY 11030; 516-562-4947. The family will receive visitors at The Morganstern/Jaroff Homestead through Thursday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: Bush Banters, Works and Plays on Birthday With His Family
description: Eighteen holes of golf at a breakneck pace. A game of horseshoes on the lawn. A sunny spell of fishing. A 10-minute phone conversation with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Television Networks Merge
description: Two media companies, Vivendi Universal and the News Corporation, have agreed to merge their Italian pay-television units, both unprofitable. Telepi, owned by Vivendi, will merge with the smaller Stream S.p.A., owned by the News Corporation. Vivendi will own 75 percent of the new entity. The merger will help the companies negotiate for rights to European soccer, and seals an accord between Jean-Marie Messier, above, Vivendi's chief executive, and Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, who have been unable to agree on other combinations.

title: Smithsonian Official's Artifacts Investigated
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is investigating whether the private collection of Amazonian artifacts owned by Lawrence M. Small, the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, contains feathers and other items taken from endangered species, a senior official at the service said today.

title: Fight Night Follows Minor League Baseball to Brooklyn
description: ''This is one of the most famous roller coasters in the world,'' Lou DiBella said, pointing at the 74-year-old Cyclone at Coney Island a few days ago. ''Doesn't it look beat up to you? This neighborhood is beaten up. It's a depressing thing. Sort of like a crying clown.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Artificial-Heart Patient 'Looks Good'
description: The first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart was alert and doing well, said Dr. Laman H. Gray Jr., one of his surgeons in Louisville, Ky. ''He looks good,'' Dr. Gray said of his patient, identified only as a man in his mid- to late-50's. Doctors said the patient communicated with his hands because he could not speak with a breathing tube in his windpipe. The doctors hope to take the man off the ventilator early next week. But Dr. Gray cautioned that his team expected complications.

title: Ernie K-Doe, 65, Who Sang 'Mother-in-Law'
description: Ernie K-Doe, the eccentric rhythm-and-blues singer best known for his 1961 No. 1 hit ''Mother-in-Law,'' died on Thursday at a New Orleans hospital. He was 65.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Israel To See Kidnapping Tape
description: The United Nations said it would allow Israel to see a videotape that the Israelis say could provide clues to the kidnapping of three Israeli soldiers by Hezbollah guerrillas on the Lebanese border in October. The videotape was made by United Nations forces in southern Lebanon a day after the kidnapping. The United Nations had said that it did not have such a videotape, but it acknowledged on Thursday that it did.

title: Schundler Seeks To Shift Debate On Abortion
description: The New Jersey governor's race veered off into the charged territory of religion today, as Bret D. Schundler accused James E. McGreevey, his Democratic rival, of being intolerant of Roman Catholics and others who, like Mr. Schundler, oppose abortion even in cases of rape and incest.

title: New President at Princeton Names Woman as Her No. 2
description: Princeton University yesterday named Amy Gutmann, a professor of politics and former dean of its faculty, as provost, the university's second-ranking official.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Reliant Profit in California
description: Reliant Energy Inc., one of the electricity generators California officials have accused of overcharging, said today that its profit from the state rose more than four-fold last year but that it made less money per megawatt hour than in some past periods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADDOCK, J. JOSEPH
description: RADDOCK-J. Joseph. The administration, faculty and students of Florida Atlantic University and the Board of Directors of the FAU Foundation express their deepest sympathy to the family of Dr. J. Joseph Raddock, a member of the Board of Directors since 1990. An enthusiastic supporter of FAU, he and his wife Sharon provided funds for FAU's Raddock Eminent Scholar Chair for Holocaust Studies, The Sharon Phillips Raddock Professorship in Holistic Nursing and a scholarship endowment for the Honors College. We are greatful for his leadership and commitment to FAU, and his untiring efforts on behalf of higher education. Anthony James Catanese President, FAU Howard Guggenheim Chairmain, FAU Foundation

title: Leo C. Beebe, 83, Led Industrial Equipment Maker
description: Leo Clair Beebe, the former chairman and chief executive of K-Tron International, which makes equipment used in processing for industries ranging from food to chemicals, died on June 30 at a hospital near his home in Jacksonville Beach, Fla. He was 83.

title: S.U.V. Chic: The Rugged and the Reckless
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Card on the Chancellor
description: With more than a million students and 137,000 employees spread over 1,100 buildings, the New York City school system is more complicated than most cities are. In his first 17 months, Schools Chancellor Harold Levy managed the system well and avoided political land mines. The climate changed just recently, however, when the City Council accused him of tolerating administrative bloat at 110 Livingston Street and City Hall attacked him for allowing the school construction budget to rise unchecked.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Busy Executioners
description: China executed more people in the last three months than the rest of the world did in the last three years, Amnesty International reported. The human rights group counts executions reported publicly; many are not reported beyond notices on bulletin boards outside local courts and so are not included in the group's numbers. It said it had counted 1,781 executions and 2,960 death sentences since the most recent anticrime campaign began in April, and 1,751 executions in the rest of the world in the last three years. The numbers on China tally closely with those compiled by at least one Western embassy in Beijing.

title: Yankees Heap More Dirt on the Mets' Season
description: It is the Subway Series and it feels like one-sided softball at a wake, the Mets donned in black and mourning a lost season, the Yankees going about the grim burial like joyless gravediggers. Sedate fans observed the proceedings from the Yankee Stadium aisles, reacting with reserve; to do otherwise would not be appropriate in the face of such woe.

title: How to Make A Pied Piper Obsolete
description: A SMALL company upstate is trying to produce a genetically modified cat.

title: Journal; It's Good To Be the King
description: ''What does the Fourth mean to you, Mr. President?'' was the hardball question thrown at George W. Bush this week, as he visited the Jefferson Memorial in search of ordinary citizens and a photo op. The answer: ''Well, it's an unimaginable honor to be the president during the Fourth of July of this country.'' Or, as Mel Brooks might put it (and has): ''It's good to be the king.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RABBI BENJAMIN
description: KAHN-Rabbi Benjamin. We record with sorrow the passing of our revered colleague, who dedicated three decades of his rabbinate to working with young men and women on campuses, beginning in 1940 as rabbi of the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation at Penn State University and later assuming executive directorship of the Hillel system, directing the work of Hillel on an increasing number of campuses in the United States and abroad. In 1971 he was asked by B'nai B'rith International to become its executive vice president, a post held until his retirement. We extend our condolences to his family and to all whose lives were touched by his rabbinate. His memory is a blessing for his life was a blessing. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. V.P. The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the postponement of an International Monetary Fund review of economic progress in Turkey misstated the size of the next installment of I.M.F. funds to Turkey. It is about $1.6 billion, not $1.6 million.

title: The Storm Over Embryo Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sports of The Times; An American's Stunning Exit Turns Ugly
description: ONLY the uninitiated tennis fan or the head of an American television network could really be saddened by Patrick Rafter's fifth-set reversal of fortune against Andre Agassi here yesterday, considering the gentleman who won the right to move on and the retro Agassi who petulantly stormed home.

title: Sex Offender on Roster Of Arena League Team
description: Basil Proctor is a little-known backup player for the New York Dragons, the Arena Football League team based in Long Island, but he is the focus of a debate about whether it is appropriate for a sex offender to play professional sports.

title: News of New Military Work Is Welcomed in South Jersey
description: Like other mayors, Thalia C. Kay worries about zoning and recycling and sprawl. But today she was also busy calculating the construction schedule for the C-17 Globemaster, the Air Force's newest transport.

title: Among Nuptial Agreements, Post- Has Now Joined Pre-
description: Not so long ago, prenuptial agreements raised eyebrows. What hope was there for a marriage, the thinking went, if even before the wedding the couple were specifying who gets what in case of divorce?

title: Aunt of Missing Intern Says Lawmaker Is Impeding Search
description: The aunt of Chandra Ann Levy, a 24-year-old federal intern who was last seen on April 30, said today that her niece had a romantic relationship with Representative Gary A. Condit, whom she criticized as hindering the search for her niece.

title: The Storm Over Embryo Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTENSTEIN, CHESTER, D.V.M.
description: HARTENSTEIN-Chester, D.V.M. Beloved husband of Florrie. Loving father of Steve and Jane, Bob and Deb and the late Rick. Proud grandfather of Sarah and Leah. Devoted brother of the late Anita and Bernie Levy. Caring brotherin-law of Arnold and Naomi Sherman. Cherished uncle of Karen and Gail, Bill and Jane, Patty and Rick, and Joey and Lisa. Adored great-uncle. He will be deeply missed by all who loved and knew him. Graveside service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY. For information, contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 718-377-7300.

title: The Mideast Deadlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Error and a Grimace, And Ventura Departs
description: When Al Leiter is at his best, his slider breaks late and sharply, in on the hands of right-handed hitters, breaking their bats or forcing them to ground weakly to third base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURITZKY, JANICE ANN
description: KURITZKY-Janice Ann. Died July 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Jay. Devoted mother of Alexander, Brian and Alyson. Loving daughter of Jerome. Dear sister of Nancy Schneer and Ellyn Brinley. Service Sunday, 11 AM, at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Miami's Ex-City Manager Sentenced
description: Miami's former city manager, Donald Warshaw, was sentenced to a year in prison for stealing nearly $70,000 from a children's charity. Judge Federico Moreno of Federal District Court also fined Mr. Warshaw $30,000 and ordered him to pay $51,000 in restitution. Mr. Warshaw, 58, served on the board of the Do the Right Thing charity and admitted spending $69,788 of the charity's money on personal items. Mr. Warshaw was fired by Mayor Joe Carollo last year for refusing to dismiss the police chief, who had assisted federal agents in the raid that seized the Cuban refugee Elin Gonzlez from his relatives' home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSMAN, LILLIAN
description: GLICKSMAN-Lillian. On July 5, 2001, at the age of 96. Wife of the late Charles. She is survived by her sons Sam (Elaine), Hal (Janet), grandsons Richie (Cynthia) and Charlie, sisters Ruth Newman, Emily Fine and Helen Landsman, as well as numerous nephews and nieces. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave (Ave J), Brooklyn. She found purpose and joy in helping others.

title: A Week on the Riviera
description: Star Clippers is offering two-for-one rates on selected one-week cruises along the Riviera out of Rome. The cruises, on board the line's modern versions of tall ships, leave from Civitavecchia, Rome's port, and stop in Monte Carlo, Portofino, Livorno, Bonifacio, Corsica and Portoferraio on Elba. The dates are July 28, Aug. 11 and 25, Sept. 8 and 22 and Oct. 6. Rates start at $1,695 for two, with the discount. Port charges and air fare are extra. Information: (800) 442-0551 or www.starclippers.com . Availability is limited.

title: New York City Schools Chancellor Warns Superintendents of Layoffs and Other Cuts
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy warned the Board of Education's district superintendents yesterday to prepare for layoffs and other cuts if City Hall fails to provide adequate funding for schools.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: More Refugees From North
description: The National Intelligence Service said 25 more North Korean refugees have come to Seoul in the last few days, raising to 250 the number so far this year, compared with 312 in all of last year. The refugees fled through China to third countries, including Mongolia, where they contacted South Korean embassies. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: I.B.M. WINS $100 MILLION CONTRACT FROM SHELL
description: I.B.M. has won a five-year, $100 million contract to help the Royal Dutch/Shell Group consolidate its global computing at three data centers. I.B.M. will supply servers, data storage units and other services, the companies said. Shell is expected to save at least $30 million under the consolidation plan, said an I.B.M. spokesman, John Buscemi. Shell is building the data centers in Kuala Lumpur, The Hague and Houston to consolidate computers and host software used to manage the company's internal processes.

title: Southwest Blocks Orbitz on Fare Data
description: Southwest Airlines, the largest low-fare carrier, blocked the Orbitz travel Web site from displaying its fares and flight information by refusing to file the data with an airline-industry clearinghouse.

title: Williams Finally Finds An Attention-Grabber
description: In the contrary existence of Venus Williams, there is a love for the big stage but a disdain for the process of developing the kind of tennis that leads her there.

title: Witness in Bombing Trial Says He Withheld Names of Friends
description: An Algerian convicted in a millennium bombing plot in Los Angeles finished his testimony yesterday against a man being tried as a co-conspirator in the plot. The witness, Ahmed Ressam, was himself accused of lying to federal investigators to protect others who supported a global Islamic terrorist network.

title: SAT's and Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Group To Expand Its Holdings Across Europe
description: Martin Ebner, the financier whose stakes in Swiss companies have often led to corporate shake-ups, said today that his BZ Group Holding was reaching outside Switzerland to buy shares in some European banks.

title: Article 2001070792876904784 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Japan Arrests Rape Suspect Handed Over by U.S. Base
description: The United States today handed over to Japanese authorities an American serviceman accused of raping a woman on June 29 in Okinawa.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Trademark Challenge Rejected
description: The World Trade Organization in Geneva has rejected the European Union's challenge to an American law barring registration of confiscated trademarks. At issue was the 1998 American law intended to protect Bacardi's rights to the Havana Club rum label, which Bacardi had acquired from the owners who fled Cuba after the 1959 revolution. The law was challenged by Pernod Ricard of France, which had started manufacturing Havana Club rum under an agreement with a Cuban company. A three-member panel of the trade organization ruled that the United States had the right to establish its criteria for registering trademarks. Brussels has not said whether it will appeal the ruling. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, ELIZABETH R.
description: BENJAMIN-Elizabeth R. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend Elizabeth Benjamin. Her father, William I. Rosenfeld, was a founding member of the Ocean Beach Club and its President for many years. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family. Sandy Paskin, President Nancy Lobell, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULVIHILL, FRANK J.
description: MULVIHILL-Frank J. The officers, members and staff of New York Electrical Contractors Association are saddened by the loss of their friend and associate, Frank J. Mulvihill. For many years Frank was an important part of our electrical industry. His counsel and wisdom will be missed by all. We express our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Edward A. Dougherty, President Joseph D'Angelo, Exec Secy

title: Democratic Donations Reach a Record for a Nonelection Year
description: Fund-raisers for the Democratic National Committee and for the party's Senate campaign committee said today that they had raised record donations in the first six months of the year, an accomplishment that they attributed to outrage over early policy moves by the Bush administration.

title: Tony Leswick, 78, the Rangers' Mighty Mouse
description: Tony Leswick, a wing for the Rangers, the Detroit Red Wings and the Chicago Blackhawks whose fluke goal in overtime of Game 7 gave Detroit the 1954 Stanley Cup championship, died last Sunday at a hospital in New Westminster, British Columbia. He was 78.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil prices rose 4.4 percent on expectations OPEC countries would leave production targets unchanged for the rest of the year. In New York, crude oil for August delivery rose $1.19, to $28.21.

title: Bush v. Gore: The Fateful Rulings
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unemployment Up to 4.5% As 114,000 Jobs Are Cut

title: What Schundler Said
description: Bret D. Schundler's remarks at a news conference in Trenton yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Foe Of Governing Party Slain
description: A politician who quit the governing party several weeks ago was shot dead yesterday, the day he was to testify in a corruption inquiry. Paul Tembo, who had been a close aide to President Frederick Chiluba, was to appear before a tribunal that is trying to determine whether government money was used to finance a campaign to change the Constitution to allow Mr. Chiluba to run for a third term. Mr. Tembo and other senior party members quit to protest the third-term bid, which the president abandoned in May.

title: Patients in Turmoil Over Debate on Lyme
description: Patients who believe they are suffering from chronic Lyme disease suddenly find themselves caught in the middle of a medical debate.

title: What Is The Next Big Idea? The Buzz Is Growing
description: It comes along only once every decade or so, typically arriving without much fanfare. But soon it is everywhere: dominating conferences, echoing in lecture halls, flooding scholarly journals. Every graduate student dreams of being the one to think it up: the Next Big Idea.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Investigation Sought On Auto Financing
description: Representative Harold Ford Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, has asked the House Financial Services Committee to investigate how the Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation and other auto lenders treat black consumers. Mr. Ford said a Vanderbilt professor's study showing that blacks financing cars through Nissan dealers paid higher dealer-imposed finance costs than whites was disturbing. Like other lenders, the Nissan operation allows dealers to add extra points to the credit-based rate it sets for borrowers and to share in the resulting revenues.

title: Sony to Take Charge to Pay For Cellular Phone Recall
description: The Sony Corporation said today that it would take a charge of about 12 billion yen, or $95 million, to pay for the recall of 1.1 million cellular phones.

title: Article 2001070793418662682 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: EX-AGENT PLEADS GUILTY IN SPY CASE
description: Robert P. Hanssen, the former F.B.I. agent, pleaded guilty today to charges that he had spied for Moscow since 1985 and had handed over many of the nation's most sensitive secrets. The plea resolves a bizarre espionage case that shook the bureau and increased tensions between the United States and Russia.

title: Stephen Ailes Is Dead at 89; Former Secretary of Army
description: Stephen Ailes, a retired antitrust lawyer and government official who served as civilian head of the Army during the early buildup of American forces in South Vietnam, died on June 30 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 89.

title: Love Appears Healthy And So Does His Lead
description: For the past two months, Davis Love III has thought more about getting healthy than about winning golf tournaments.

title: New York Ranks City's Private Foster Home Programs
description: City child welfare officials said yesterday that they had completed an unsparing performance evaluation of all private foster home programs and vowed to send fewer children to the worst performing ones.

title: White House Wants to Bury Pact Banning Tests of Nuclear Arms
description: In its first six months, the Bush administration has been examining ways to escape permanently from an unratified international agreement banning nuclear tests, just as it has moved to scrap the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and has rebelled against a global warming pact that it believes would cripple American industry.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: English Name Provokes Bomber
description: A man associated with the Quebec separatist movement 30 years ago has been sentenced for trying to firebomb three Second Cup coffee shops in Montreal last October because of their English name. Rhal Mathieu, 53, received a one-month sentence for the botched firebombings, in which no one was injured, and six months on related weapons charges. In 1967 Mr. Mathieu was sentenced to nine years in prison for two bombing deaths. The Separatist party now governs Quebec and strictly enforces laws intended to preserve French and reduce the use of English.

title: Andy Warhol's Montauk Estate Is on the Market for $50 Million
description: The sprawling Montauk compound that Andy Warhol at times called home is up for sale for $50 million. If the asking price is met, the sale would make history in Long Island's pricey East End market.

title: Investigating Woman's Killing, Police Release a Man's Picture
description: The police released a photograph yesterday of a man they want to question in connection with the killing of a young Brooklyn woman who was shot as she stood by her apartment window, apparently by someone randomly firing a gun on the street below.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Gucci Expands Again
description: The luxury goods maker, the Gucci Group, has agreed to buy 91 percent of its rival Balenciaga for an undisclosed amount, adding a line of fashion, fragrances and accessories. Nicolas Ghesquiere, the creative director of Balenciaga, will own the other 9 percent. Balenciaga plans to open stores in several cities in an effort to increase sales. Revenue last year was $20 million. Gucci, based in Amsterdam, has been buying brands like Yves Saint Laurent and Bottega Veneta. Two-thirds of Balenciaga's sales came from fragrance.

title: The Mideast Deadlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Artists Use Art to Fight Eviction Threats
description: ''It's probably the most dangerous piece I've done,'' Eric Legacy said of his latest sculpture. ''It really works, and it's man-sized. You could potentially get killed.''

title: Let Death Be Humane
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURFEIN, BARBARA J. (NEE JACOBS)
description: GURFEIN-Barbara J. (nee Jacobs). 700 Park Avenue NYC, West Hampton Beach, NY, and Weston, FL, passed away July 5, 2001, peacefully after suffering a stroke a year and a half ago. Beloved wife of the late Sidney B. Gurfein. Beloved mother of the late Patricia Hope Gurfein, Leslie Gurfein Sands (husband) Franklin Sands, Ronnie Gurfein (wife) Susan Gurfein, wonderful loving grandmother to Robert Louis Heckler, Stephanie Blair Gomez (husband) Angel Gomez, Alexander Patrick Heckler, Jacqueline Jacobs Sands, Lauren Ashley Gurfein, Blake Taylor Gurfein, and great-granddaughter, beautiful Samantha Madison Gomez. The family mourns the passing of a special woman, both beautiful and bright. A pre-med graduate from New York University. Warm, kind, sensitive practicing therapist to all she knew. After her father's death, she took over his company. The Approved Equipment Manufacturing Co. (aka Blaze Guard), a manufacturer and supplier of fire hoses to the US government and many municipalities. The company was subsequently sold to Figgie Industries. To her grandchildren, she was a loving, giving and gentle teacher. She will be greatly missed. The funeral services were held Friday, July 6, 2001, in NYC.

title: BROAD JOB LOSSES LAST MONTH SHOW SLUMP IS LINGERING
description: The nation's employers cut 114,000 jobs in June, mostly in manufacturing but in other sectors as well, the Labor Department said yesterday, throwing cold water on recent reports suggesting that the economy was beginning to recover.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Making A Profit
description: Cardinal Sergio Sebastiani announced that the Holy See's 2000 budget, which covers papal activities and some other Vatican expenses, was in the black for the eighth year in a row, boasting a tidy $8.5 million profit on revenues of $182 million. Cardinal Sebastiani said he received a $2,300 monthly salary (the Holy See pays his and other cardinals' expenses). He said the pope also received a paycheck, but said he did not know how much. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Waltrip Will Use Daytona Victory as Inspiration
description: Michael Waltrip was asked if he dreaded going back to Daytona, back to the famous racetrack where his friend and former boss Dale Earnhardt was killed just seconds before Waltrip posted his greatest racing triumph.

description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Warning Already Given To Nominee as Labor Solicitor
description: Eugene Scalia, a Washington lawyer who has specialized in representing management in labor disputes, may face serious obstacles in his effort to be confirmed as solicitor of the Labor Department, congressional and administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEITZ, GEORGE E.
description: LEITZ-George E. The Transport Workers Union of America, AFLCIO mourns the loss of our International President Emeritus, George E. Leitz, of cancer, on July 5, 2001. Brother Leitz had served our union with energy and dedication since 1948, first as President of TWU Local 225 in Hackensack, NJ, and later as International Representative, Secretary Treasurer, Executive Vice President and President of the national TWU. He succeeded the late John E. Lawe as International President in January, 1989 and served until his retirement in November, 1993. Our union has lost a courageous fighter for the rights and dignity of all transportation workers here and abroad. He was a lifelong resident of New Jersey until moving to Leesburg, FL, after retirement. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Dorothy; son Robert, and daughter Georgia. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Hospice of Lake and Sumter, 12300 Lane Park Rd., Tavares, FL 32778. Viewing Sunday, July 8, 7-9 PM, and Monday, July 9, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM, at A. K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, NJ (201-945-7100). Services Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Francis R.C. Church, 114 Mt. Vernon St, Ridgefield Park, NJ. Sonny Hall, TWU Int'l President Frank McCann, Exec. Vice Pres. John J. Kerrigan, Secy Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUDNOVSKY, MALKA B.
description: CHUDNOVSKY-Malka B. On July 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Volf, loving mother and grandmother. Services Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Quick Climb Up the Los Angeles Political Ladder
description: ALEX PADILLA grew up poor in Pacoima, which was pretty much the norm in that distressed section of the San Fernando Valley.

title: Tiny Discovery May Answer a Question About the Big Bang
description: By observing millions of subatomic particles called B mesons, a team of scientists working at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center in California has found new evidence of a basic but subtle lopsidedness in nature that may explain why the universe contains mostly matter, rather than being virtually empty and devoid of stars, planets and people.

title: Cease-Fire in Macedonia Stops the Guns but Not the Ethnic Distrust and Bitterness
description: ''For the moment, it's quiet,'' Rexhep Rexhepi, 45, an ethnic Albanian taxi driver, said in this village today. But he would not put it past the other side to stir up trouble.

title: Report Card for Foster Home Programs
description: The maximum possible score is 100.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Sheriff Dies In Shootout
description: The sheriff of Lee County, a cousin of Elvis Presley, was shot to death in a gun battle with a man who tried to escape a police roadblock near Tupelo. The gunman, Billy Ray Stone, who had abducted a woman from a local hospital, was also killed, the authorities said. The sheriff, Harold Ray Presley, 53, above, was the son of a brother of Elvis Presley's grandfather. He was first elected sheriff in 1993. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Man Found Guilty in Killings at Muffin Shop in Manhattan
description: A 24-year-old Brooklyn man was found guilty yesterday of fatally shooting two men and injuring two others in the botched robbery of a downtown Manhattan muffin shop two years ago.

title: Agassi Lets His Emotions, and Rafter, Get the Best of Him
description: Andre Agassi was decorating the court with passing shots that had the loops and curves of expert penmanship, all in gorgeous contrast to the grace of Patrick Rafter's leaning and twisting to react at the net.

title: Echoes of a Vanished Brazil In the Subtle Bossa Nova
description: When Mrcio Faraco left Brazil for Paris in 1992, he brought with him the light-fingered grace of the bossa nova. His early set at the Blue Note on Monday night, as he led a quintet that was four-fifths Brazilian with a French guitarist, whispered through his songs with meticulous syncopations. The music was tinged with nostalgia, both geographic and temporal, for the Brazil he left behind and for an era of Brazilian music before he was born, when subtlety was cherished.

title: At Home Abroad; Bush: Sign of A Shift
description: George W. Bush is moving, at least incrementally, to avoid his father's most grievous mistake as president: the decision to wash his hands of conflict in the Balkans.

title: Pentagon Sets Fourth Test Of Missile For July 14
description: For the first time since a failed missile defense test a year ago, the Pentagon will try to shoot down a mock warhead high over the Pacific on July 14 using a prototype interceptor, officials said today.

title: All-Star Brouhaha Still Dogs Valentine
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine said yesterday that the job he did in selecting the National League All-Star team was the best and most thorough of any job he had ever done. Now one decision has morphed into a mess that continues to rankle him.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about companies that package music selections for retail stores to sell to their customers misidentified the producer of compact discs for Victoria's Secret. The company produced its own CD's; they were not produced by Billy Straus of Rock River Communications, who has compiled CD's for other companies.

title: German Loggers to Leave 'African Eden' Untouched
description: In a move that wildlife biologists say has spared an African Eden, a German logging company said yesterday that it had given up its lease on a tract of swamp-fringed rain forest in the Congo Republic. The Congo government said the land, the 100-square-mile Goualogo Triangle, would be added to the adjacent Nouabal-Ndoki National Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, IRVING
description: SCHAEFFER-Irving. Age 82, of Lakewood, NJ, on July 6, 2001. Predeceased by Angela and Muriel. Cherished father of Bernard Schaeffer. Dear grandfather of Katharine, Christine and Charlotte. Treasured companion of Gwen Misuerella. Devoted friend of Ollie Williams. The funeral service will be held at 7 PM, Saturday, from the D'Elia Funeral Home of Lakewood, State Highway 70 and Vermont Avenue. The funeral service will be offered at graveside, 11 AM, at Wellwood Cemetery, Long Island, NY, on Sunday. Memorial contributions can be made to American Cancer Society.

title: Sins Are a Fine Way To Attract Dancers
description: ONE Friday, ''Anger'' took shape to the strains of a particularly fierce Astor Piazzolla tango. The next Tuesday, various aspects of ''Envy'' were explored to the accompaniment of Bach and Britten. A few days later, ''Greed'' had its turn as five women evocatively muttered, laughed and sang much of their own accompaniment over an array of coveted decorative objects.

title: Corrections
description: A short article in the Postings column last Sunday about the redevelopment of two loft buildings on the Lower East Side misstated the leasing arrangements for the project. Leasing of the retail spaces is being handled by Newmark New Spectrum. The Halstead Property Company is leasing only the apartments, not the stores. In addition, a headline with the article misstated the number of stores in the project. There are three retail spaces, as the article said, not two.

title: Hotel Problem
description: To the Editor: Based on the April 29 article ''Exploring Baltimore's Inner Harbor,'' my sister made a reservation at the Pier 5 Hotel for the Amazon Family package and the Port Discovery package for May 14 and 15. When we arrived we were told that our reservation was ''at our other facility, around the bend.'' Needless to say, we were disappointed to find we had been booked, without our knowledge, at the Brookshire Suites.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUITERMAN, RICHARD L. COLONEL RETIRED, (USAF)
description: GUITERMAN-Richard L. Colonel Retired, (USAF), of Park Avenue, New York. Died at St. Luke's Hospital on July 2, 2001. Survived by his dear wife Eleanor, her daughter Sara, son-in-law Scott Moyer, daughter Susan Robie, grandchildren Robie Moyer and K. Arden Moyer and by his sister, Marjorie Morris of West Lafayette, Indiana. Colonel Guiterman retired from the U.S. Air Force in November 1978, after serving more than 37 years on active and reserve duty. He was a Vice President of Chemical Bank in the Corporate Banking Division and also a Vice President of Amercian Express Bank and Director of International Corporate Banking. Colonel Guiterman was a Director of the New York's Finest Foundation and a member of the University Club. A memorial service will be held at the 7th Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, New York City, on Wednesday, July 11, 2001, at 12 noon. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Virginia, on July 25, 2001, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the University of Wisconsin in memory of the deceased.

description: TEDDI-ANNE KOSTKOWICZ, a sales assistant at an investment banking firm in Manhattan, used to hate smiling for photographs, and she says she sometimes felt very self-conscious when she met with new clients.

title: A School Auditorium Is a Top-Flight Venue
description: THIS is not the kind of school auditorium your parents had assemblies in. The Washington Township Center for the Performing Arts is unlike any high school auditorium most people have ever seen, even though on any given school day it can be the setting for an all-class lecture or a school play.

title: Do Funds Charge Investors For Negative Value Added?
description: IT may be no surprise that many investors have been generous in judging the performance of mutual funds that have loads, or sales charges. But they are not alone. Most finance professors, despite their much-vaunted skepticism, have been kind, too.

description: SINGER-Anna. It is with deep regret that the Maimonides Medical Center family notes the passing of Anna Singer. To her children, Dr. Israel Singer, a friend of our Medical Center, and Barbara Jacobowitz, and their families, we extend our sincere sympathy. Martin D. Payson, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff, President

title: Jean Taylor, William Golden
description: Dr. Jean E. Taylor, a professor of mathematics, and William T. Golden, the emeritus chairman of the American Museum of Natural History, are to be married today by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: Light White, Savoie Joy
description: Spritzy, dry 2000 Paul Boniface Apremont from Savoie -- bottled joie de vivre -- is a find. Francophiles will relish this simple Alpine white's floral scent, grapefruity flavor and weightlessness. Inquisitive palates will discover pleasures in its unknown grape, called Jacqure. Heights Chateau, 131 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street), Brooklyn, asks $11. (Distributed by House of Burgundy.) HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Watching Her Weight
description: Anamarie Regino, her nails painted pink to match the tiny butterfly barrettes in her hair, sits on the floor of her family's modest Albuquerque home, playing tea party. For most girls this would be a quiet respite of a game, but for Ana it is a struggle. Raising her arm to offer an imaginary cup of tea is, for her, like lifting weights. Standing up leaves her breathless. A short walk across the room is a hike. At 4 years old, standing four and a half feet tall, she weighs just over 110 pounds -- meaning she is three times heavier and 50 percent taller than an average child her age.

title: Seda Yalcinkaya, Joseph Hughes
description: Seda Yalcinkaya, the daughter of Naci and Sevda Yalcinkaya of Istanbul, was married there yesterday to Joseph Dana Cainaeach Hughes, the son of Faith M. Brouillard Hughes of Centerville, Mass., and Paul Hughes of Sparta, N.J. Tayfun Ergin, a magistrate in Beykoz, Turkey, officiated at Cubuklu 29, a reception hall.

title: Wall Cracks Are Just a Hint Of a Revered Church's Woes
description: The Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, which has been closed for seven months, recently announced that it was preparing to reopen. But while the 154-year-old national historic landmark on Montague Street has long been covered in scaffolding, it has also been mired in dissent, and church officials do not agree on whether it is safe to open at all.

title: Earnhardt Jr. Wins In Return to Daytona
description: In Nascar's first race at Daytona since Dale Earnhardt was killed there in February, his son brought a crowd of 197,000 to its feet by winning the Pepsi 400. Dale Earnhardt Jr. celebrated by spinning his car in a triumphant tribute to his father.

title: July 1-7; Hurray From Hollywood
description: Negotiators for actors and producers called it a wrap after reaching a tentative agreement on a three-year contract. The settlement brings an end to months of anxiety about the possibility of a strike that could have shut down movie and television production. Barbara Whitaker
