title: Army Builds Defenses for Ulster Parade Today
description: Every July, a tiny piece of quiet countryside here is transformed into a militarized zone.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE most spectacular moment in THE PERFECT STORM (2000) is the sight of that 90-foot wave. It's very bad news for the men on the Andrea Gail, a 72-foot swordfishing boat from Gloucester, Mass., whose catch has been light this year. The captain (George Clooney) can't afford to sit out the weather and let the fish spoil (the ice machine has just broken), so he tries to head home. The film is based on Sebastian Junger's book about tragic real-life events in October 1991 when three huge storm systems collided in the Atlantic. This film didn't receive any acting awards (although Cherry Jones is outstanding in a small part); it's about action (meteorologial) and effects. But, as others have pointed out, this is a story about fighting for your life; nuanced human interaction isn't always involved -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:50 a.m. on HBO.

title: Driving Vintage Models Can Cure Nostalgia
description: EVERYONE knows you can't turn back the clock, but that doesn't keep automakers from trying. With Ford's reborn Thunderbird due to arrive in dealerships later this summer, and with BMW's new Mini and Nissan's reincarnated Z car set to appear next year, it is easy to get all mushy about the past.

title: P.S.
description: My Ultra-Secret Spy Stuff is the summer camp accessory for kids who want to chronicle their tween angst -- and avoid the gaze of nosy bunkmates and priggish counselors. The kit ($19.95 at E.A.T. Gifts or www.Swingsetpress.com) contains a lockable diary and a Spy Pen -- with ink visible only under the glow of a hand-held black light, a k a Ultra-Secret Spy Light.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-08-01: Questions for Jean-Paul Gaultier; An Artist? Moi?
description: Q: You designed the costumes for Madonna's Blond Ambition tour in 1990 and now, again, for her tour this summer. How does that collaboration work?

title: This Summer, Sale Britannia
description: IF President Bush had included Britain on his European itinerary last month, he might have saved enough to cover some tax-rebate checks. With weak bookings for summer, hotels, tour operators and other related businesses all over Britain are cutting prices. ''I think there are a lot of them, particularly this summer,'' said Tim Lovell, vice president for the British Tourist Authority in the United States, referring to the deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSE, FRED W., M.D.
description: BUSE-Fred W., M.D. Formerly of Manhasset, NY, at age 93, on June 27, 2001. Veteran of WWII, graduate of Yale Medical School and known for his innovative treatment for catastrophic burn victims. Loving father of Isabel Abdirkin and Beverly Weisman. Grandfather of Jessica, Jared, Daniel, Carrie and Alexis. Survived by three nieces and one nephew. Companion of Feli and Suzi. Dr. Buse will be buried at sea. A celebration of his life will take place Saturday, July 14th, at 10 AM, at The First Presbyterian Church, Smithtown. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts or Nassau Suffolk Law Services.

title: Accountability in Argentina
description: The indictment last week of Carlos Menem, the former president of Argentina, by a federal judge there is an encouraging advance for legal accountability in a country where the powerful have too often enjoyed impunity from prosecution for their misdeeds. Mr. Menem, who wants to run for a Senate seat this fall, insists that he is not guilty of approving and concealing illegal arms sales to Croatia and Ecuador while he was president during the early and mid-1990's. That is now for the courts to determine, on the basis of evidence, not political influence.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-08-01; Beginning And End
description: This is what happens, once the placenta is expelled: estrogen, that lubricating elixir, plummets in the minutes, the hours, after birth. Progesterone, too, takes a tumble while the anterior pituitary gland, responsible for lactation, swells to twice its normal size. Meanwhile, of course, you are lying in your hospital bed, babe to the breast, your Caesarean scar still fresh, your episiotomy not yet beginning to burn. Or maybe you've gone ''natural''; no matter. How you had the baby is not at issue, only that you had the baby, and in expelling it, expelled the royal purple parachute that floated you and yours through the nine months. Suddenly it's gone. And you come crashing down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, ELIZABETH R.
description: BENJAMIN-Elizabeth R. One hundred one, of Elberon, NJ, died July 5, at home. Mrs. Benjamin was married in 1940 to Barets O. Benjamin, a stock broker who predeceased her. A memorial service will be held in August. For further information please contact Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, Ocean, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREIB, SEYMOUR L.
description: TREIB-Seymour L. On July 1, of Safety Habor, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Survived by his spouse Patricia K. Treib, daughter Elinor Treib Sikes, and sister Blanche Treib Beckerman.

title: After Stocks Slump, Fund Fees Cause More Pain
description: JOHN C. BOGLE has been preaching against the evils of high fees and expenses in the mutual fund business for 50 years, and the message, he thinks, may finally be reaching the skeptics in the farthest pews.

title: Love Hangs On to Lead After Late Run by Hoch
description: A dramatic finish today by Scott Hoch put more drama into the Western Open.

title: Bonnie Watson, Julian Underwood
description: Bonnie Field Watson, a daughter of Margaret P. Watson of Lincolnville, Me., and Thomas J. Watson III of Wilton, Conn., was married on Friday to Julian Rowan Underwood, a son of Charlotte and William J. Underwood Jr. of Westport, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Pike, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Old German Meeting House in Waldoboro, Me.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on Lyme disease prompted a flood of protests from readers who said the condition is not ''in their mind.'' Andrew Sullivan drew mail from ''M*A*S*H'' fans asserting that Corporal Klinger's cross-dressing was a bid for a Section 8 discharge, not a statement of sexual orientation.

title: Brut Force
description: When Macari Vineyards says brut on the label of its sparkling wine, it indeed means brut -- dry. In fact, very dry.

title: A Peninsula Hotel For Chicago
description: Peninsula, the luxury lodgings group based in Asia, has opened its third American hotel, this one in Chicago, and like the ones in New York and Beverly Hills it is conveniently situated for shoppers. The Peninsula Chicago opened last month at East Superior Street and North Michigan Avenue, rising 20 floors above Tiffany, Ralph Lauren and Banana Republic on the Magnificent Mile.

title: Mary Reidy, Robert Masella
description: Mary Elizabeth Clare Reidy and Robert Frederick Masella, corporate lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Boston. The Rev. James F. Rafferty performed the ceremony.

title: The Conservation G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: July 1-7; Iraq's Ups and Downs
description: Russia, more solidly intransigent than ever on Iraq, blocked an American and British plan to revamp rules on trade with the Iraqis, to allow them to buy any consumer goods that could not be proved to have military uses. The new ''oil for food'' plan would also have introduced measures to stop Iraq from smuggling oil. But if Iraq won one round, it lost another: two of its top diplomats defected in New York.

title: Taking a Taxi
description: To the Editor: I sincerely appreciated Lisa Anne Abend's ''Shedding a Backpack for a Back Seat,'' (June 24).

title: If Goldilocks Drove a Car
description: BELOVED readers, I have sad news. I know that you have come to depend on me for wit, erudition and wisdom, but owing to the fact that I can't turn a profit, I will be leaving the state of New Jersey.

title: A Few More Twists At Lombard Street
description: San Francisco visitors looking to take a joy ride down ''the crookedest street in the world'' may have a hard time even getting there. City officials have announced a plan to deal with summer traffic on the 1000 block of Lombard Street, which snakes downhill one way from Hyde to Leavenworth Street. Under the plan, the most popular approach -- the eastbound portion of Lombard between Van Ness Avenue and Polk Street -- will be closed from noon to 9 p.m. on the Labor Day and Columbus Day weekends, and when traffic is so heavy that residents have trouble getting home.

title: The Irish and Europe: A Time for Soul-Searching
description: One month ago, Irish voters stunned Europe by rejecting the European Union treaty that was to pave the way for 12 new members. French and German leaders have been quick to voice their concern over the ability of fewer than a million Irish voters to hold up a process that will affect 500 million people across the continent.

title: Talk-to-Yourself Radio
description: After reading about Phil Hendrie's bad-faith radio show, I would advise you to ask your resident ethicist to weigh in on the moral consequences of this form of bear-baiting. This is entertainment at its most dubious and dangerous. While the joke may be funny, the cynicism it engenders is bad for the nation's mental health. And as for ventriloquism, Anna Deveare Smith does it much better.

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: Dr. Steere read a letter from a patient who said she suffers from some 20 different symptoms of a physiological, or potentially physiological, nature. In response, he concludes that she is mentally ill. Is it any wonder that such people feel put down by the medical establishment? Regardless of whether chronic Lyme disease is or is not the ultimate cause of the woman's sickness, patients like this deserve better treatment.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: Letters
description: NINA SIMONE

title: Kristie Kisner, Aaron Simon
description: Kristie Marie Kisner, a daughter of Karen and Karl Kisner of Wilbraham, Mass., was married yesterday to Aaron Jack Simon, a son of Toby Simon and Dr. Peter Simon of Providence, R.I., and New York. The Rev. Janet Cooper Nelson, the chaplain of Brown University and a United Church of Christ minister, performed a ceremony at the Blithewold Mansion, Gardens and Arboretum, a house museum in Bristol, R.I., that combined Christian and Jewish traditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLANSKY, SUSAN
description: KAPLANSKY-Susan. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff at the Hospital for Joint Diseases are deeply saddened by the loss of Susan Kaplansky, devoted daughter of our good friends Dr. and Mrs. Alfred D. Grant. Dr. Grant is a long standing member of our medical staff, who has served with distinction for many years. Susan leaves a grieving family and many friends who will remember her for her kindness, grace and her dedication to her family. Our heartfelt condoleneces are extended to her husband, Eyal, their children, her parents and to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth Chairman of the Board John N. Kastanis, FACHE President and CEO Victor H. Frankel, M.D. President Emeritus Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief

title: Parallels
description: In September 1999, when Lise Krywy's husband walked out four weeks after their son's birth, she turned to her parents, who lived nearby, for support. Only five months later, Lise's father left her mother, Ruth DuBois. At first, mother and daughter talked about their dissolving marriages and particularly about Lise's hopes for a reconciliation with her husband. But eventually their pending divorces became the one thing they didn't discuss. The photographer Doug DuBois, Ruth's son and Lise's brother, documented this tumultuous period in their lives.

title: A Kosher Pizza Bagel, Frozen, and Just for Kids
description: Bob Silverman, president of Macabee Foods of West Nyack, remembers how difficult it was to find kosher after-school snacks for his daughter and her friends. So Mr. Silverman, who took over the 33-year-old kosher foods company last year, started a new frozen mini pizza bagel aimed entirely at kids.

title: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, KAPLANSKY, SUSAN
description: GRANT - KAPLANSKY - Susan. With unbearable sorrow, we announce the passing of our beloved daughter, Susan, on June 28th, 2001, in Jerusalem, Israel. She had just turned 38, and leaves behind her four children: Edon, 15; Tamir, 13; Gil, 9; Eliya, 3; her husband, Eyal; her siblings, Michele Grant, Laura and Eyal Dagan. Our hearts are broken. We will be at home Sunday, July 15th. Ellen and Al Grant

title: Can Retailers Rebound? Only the Consumer Knows
description: CONSUMERS have done more than their fair share to bolster the economy, but now there are signs of sputtering.

title: Henman-Ivanisevic Match Stretches to a Third Day
description: Only 51 minutes of tennis were played during one reprieve from a steady drizzle over Wimbledon today, leading to the postponement of the women's final between Venus Williams and Justine Henin and another semifinal cliffhanger for Tim Henman and Goran Ivanisevic.

title: "The Cooperative Gene: How Mendel's Demon Explains the Evolution of Complex Beings"
description: When the extraterrestrial visitors land on Earth in their space-saucer, they will be excited to see that ours is one of those rare planets where complex life has evolved. They will have found microbes, like our viruses and bacteria, on every life-bearing planet. Naked biological molecules and simple single cells will be so familiar that they will need only some box-ticking on the extraterrestrials' report: 'they are carbon-based; they use DNA; they are fuelled by electromagnetic radiation and chemical resources; they copy themselves.' But only a few planets will have complex life — creatures like us, with our supercomputing brains; or like swans, with their great wings beating out on either side; or like roses, with their symmetric flowers, delicate petals and seductive perfumes. Complex life forms are built from many cells, and each individual grows up from a single cell to an adult that has an organic form and may be capable of intelligent behaviour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTENSTEIN, CHESTER, D.V.M.
description: HARTENSTEIN-Chester, D.V.M. Beloved husband of Florrie. Loving father of Steve and Jane, Bob and Deb and the late Rick. Proud grandfather of Sarah and Leah. Devoted brother of the late Anita and Bernie Levy. Caring brotherin-law of Arnold and Naomi Sherman. Cherished uncle of Karen and Gail, Bill and Jane, Patty and Rick, and Joey and Lisa. Adored great-uncle. He will be deeply missed by all who loved and knew him. Graveside service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY. For information, contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 718-377-7300.

title: Article 2001070892000712174 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: On the Charts
description: FOR decades, determining the nation's most popular records resembled a free-for-all. Record stores, relying on the honor system, reported top-selling titles but did not provide sales figures, and there was little incentive for accuracy, since record labels and distributors routinely used strong-arm tactics and bribery to sway the process in their favor.

title: Inequality in the AIDS Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWING, EMMA MAI (THOMPSON)
description: EWING-Emma Mai (Thompson). Died June 22, 2001 at her home in Jackson, TN. A resident of NYC, she was a feature writer for The New York Times and in press relations with the American Bible Society and CARE. A memorial service is planned for August 11, 2001 at 2 PM for family and friends at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Nashville, TN.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-08-01; What They Were Thinking: Back From The Front
description: A portfolio of young Russian soldiers returning from service in Chechnya.

title: Going a Mile High and Back Over an Unwanted Nickname
description: Pop quiz: You are the chief executive of a major financial company. You commit $60 million over 20 years to have your company's name on the new stadium of the Denver Broncos of the National Football League. One of your subordinates tells a local sports columnist that company wags have nicknamed the stadium "the Diaphragm." As in the birth control device. The columnist prints it.

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: Dr. Allen Steere is depicted, in David Grann's article (June 17), as something of a martyr to the cause of scientific research -- a gentle fellow, a former ''violin virtuoso,'' who put it all aside to become a researcher. The fact is, for the past several years, he has dominated the discussion on Lyme disease with rhetoric that largely dismisses the existence of chronic cases and broadcasts the dangers of overdiagnosis to the point that many doctors will not even test for Lyme.

title: Changes at the Top
description: Guests at the Four Seasons New York will have to look straight up to appreciate the hotel's latest changes. I. M. Pei has redesigned the top of the 52-story building, at 57 East 57th Street, with enlarged windows for the suites on the top three floors, and crenellations and a ring of lights on the exterior. The redesign, an enhancement of Pei's original design, should be complete by March. Until then, guests who use the Presidential Suite must make do with a three-bedroom suite on the 32nd floor, to be ready Sept. 30.

title: Kathleen Goldberger, Charles Santangelo
description: Kathleen Ann Goldberger and Charles Alfred Santangelo were married yesterday by the Rev. William Bergen at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: Oye, Oye! The Board Is in Session
description: TO speed the rejection process, the Dartmoor Arms Co-Op Board requires that you complete and return this quiz before your application to appear in person can be refused. Note: Withdraw your bid NOW if you have not yet sent your child or children to an out-of-state boarding school.

title: Great Expectations
description: Two years ago, I walked up to an airline ticket counter at J.F.K., reached for my wallet with my ID and realized I had left it in the taxi (Lives, Roxana Robinson, June 17). I did not have the cab's medallion number, nor did I have the driver's name. I talked my way onto the flight, and after returning to California, I got a call from a New York cabdriver saying he had found my wallet and would Express Mail it to me. I sent a thank-you card and a $50 tip to cover the mailing fee and to show my appreciation. I don't know whether he had ''great expectations'' of a reward. I am simply writing to say that he didn't ''just take the money and throw the wallet away.''

title: Early Civilizations On View in Delaware
description: Artifacts dating back to the earliest evidence of civilization will be on display in Wilmington, Del., starting Saturday. The exhibition, ''Syria: Land of Civilizations,'' through Oct. 21 at the First U.S.A. Riverfront Arts Center, includes 385 pieces, most of which have never been shown in the United States.

title: Business & Investing; Is Healthy Fast Food Leaving a Slow Profit Lane?
description: HOW about some low-fat sweet potato fries with that?

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Who Done It? The Campers, Following the Script
description: There has been a murder. And it may be the best thing that ever happened to Tippo, Ga., a sleepy town so down and out its only hope for revival is to hold the trial of the century.

title: A Market Rebound Is Their Springboard
description: AFTER dragging its heels for months, the stock market bounced back smartly during the spring, as domestic diversified stock funds rose 7.9 percent in the second quarter. They narrowly edged out the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which rose 5.9 percent.

title: In Vitro Fertilization Services Available in County
description: To the Editor:

title: Inequality in the AIDS Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: An Advocacy Business Grew From Frustration
description: Like many other people, Robert Clydesdale of Newburgh, N.Y., has had his share of frustrations with managed health care. Now he is hoping to use his experiences to help other consumers, and maybe make a profit in the process.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIERSH, BETTY
description: KIERSH-Betty. We are always thinking of you. You are in our hearts forever. The Kiersh Family

title: Transcript of Buster Olney's Visit to the Yankees Forum
description: Buster Olney, who covers the Yankees for The Times, visited the forum on Thursday, July 5, to discuss the team. Here is a transcript.

title: When Disney Winked, Florida Swooned
description: IN the summer of 1965, central Florida was buzzing with rumors about mystery land buyers who were snatching up thousands of acres of old citrus groves. A local television station, swept up in the excitement, issued a bulletin with a scoop: the station had received a telegram from Detroit confirming the Ford Motor Company as the buyer. Pity the reporter bamboozled by that hoax -- a second telegram arrived later saying Ford wanted the land to grow hay for its Mustangs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, MARGARET ''MAGGIE.''
description: NICHOLS - Margaret ''Maggie.'' Born June 9, 1931, died July 1. Graduated Antioch, masters at University of New Mexico. First woman editor for ''Field and Stream'' magazine. Inspired photographer. Author of ''Wild, Wild Woman: A Complete Woman's Guide to Enjoying the Great Outdoors.'' Longtime member of the Society of Women Geographers. Graduate professor at Pace. Invaluable consultant and mentor to collegaues and literary friends. Maggie and her late husband Mike traveled extensively but loved NYC, especially Greenwich Village, their home since 1964. They actively supported the arts, especially live jazz and theater. A gathering of the Nichols tribe will be held in Maggie's honor in mid September. Friends may call 212-544-2210 for details.

title: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001070891477073102 -- No Title
description: Untangling the Online Gaming Web

title: They Also Served
description: Sullivan may be invoking Corporal Klinger to serve the interests of his article, but Klinger was never portrayed as a homosexual on ''M*A*S*H.'' The show did raise the issue of homosexuality in the ranks, in an episode in which a wounded soldier, Private Weston, was threatened with a dishonorable discharge. This would have served as a far more accurate example, if a less flashy one.

title: A First Line of Defense, Armed With Headsets
description: THE man from Missouri was calling to inquire about index funds, a Vanguard specialty, and William Zinno patiently explained that the company's biggest such fund closely tracks the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The cost of this instant diversification, he noted, is just $1.80 a year for each $1,000 invested.

title: "The Fourth Hand"
description: Imagine a young man on his way to a less-than-thirty-second event—the loss of his left hand, long before he reached middle age.

title: The Picnic Papers
description: There is a great scene in Robert Lewis Taylor's biography ''W.C. Fields: His Follies and Fortunes'' in which Fields gets it in his head to organize a picnic for his secretary, Magda Michael; his companion, Carlotta Monti; her sister, Susie; and himself. He orders the chauffeur to ''tune up the big Lincoln,'' the one with the silver-plated engine and built-in refrigerator. He himself unlocks his liquor room, secured by two iron bars and four padlocks. (Fields forever thought people were stealing from him.) He brings out a case of Lanson '28 Champagne, six bottles of good Burgundy, six bottles of Sauternes, several bottles of gin and a case of beer. He then takes the girls to the Vendme, a Los Angeles gourmet shop, where he buys caviar, pt de foie gras, anchovies, smoked oysters, baby shrimps, crab meat, tinned lobster, potted chicken and turkey, several cheeses, a big bottle of Greek olives and three or four jars of glazed fruit. Back home, his cook, Dell, has made an angel food cake, a devil's-food cake and sandwiches (watercress, tongue, peanut butter and strawberry jam, chopped olives and nuts, deviled egg and spiced ham). When the food has been packed in wicker hampers and the booze has been loaded into the fridge with many extra ice buckets, Fields ushers his passengers into the car. ''What we've missed,'' he says, ''we'll pick up on the road.''

title: Private Sector; Thanks but No Thanks, Workers Say
description: Most people would be pleased if the boss promised them a soft leather jacket for a job well done. But some workers at Toyota Motor Manufacturing Canada booed their president and chief executive, Takanori Sakaue, when he displayed the planned gift at a ceremony at the Toyota plant in Cambridge, Ontario.

title: BackTalk; I.O.C. Should Reject China for 2008
description: On Friday, delegates of the International Olympic Committee will assemble in Moscow to vote to determine which city -- Toronto, Paris or Beijing -- will have the privilege of being host to the 2008 Summer Games. China's leaders have argued that politics should not taint the delegates' deliberations and that each finalist should be subject only to technical review to determine which city has the best sports facilities, transportation systems, hotels and other material resources needed to carry out a successful Olympics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, NANCY DINGMAN ''DINGY.''
description: WATSON-Nancy Dingman ''Dingy.'' Of Truro, MA, and formerly of Putney, VT, died on June 28, 2001, in Truro, MA. Her parents were Dr. Norman and Ann Bauer Dingman of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ. Her grandparents were Dr. James and Jeannette Beveridge Dingman of Spring Valley, NY. Burial and graveside services in Spring Valley, NY, will be held at a later date.

title: Crime
description: Sex and money. Sex and social status. Sex and political power. Sex and . . . opera? People kill for all sorts of reasons in mystery stories, but it takes a prodigious conjurer, as Barbara Hambly proves to be in DIE UPON A KISS (Bantam, $23.95), the fifth book in a ravishing series set in antebellum New Orleans, to recall a time when angry men burned down theaters and fought to the death over a new opera. Cultural war is declared between rival American and Creole opera houses when an Italian company attempts to open the season for the upstart Americans with an original and provocative version of ''Othello.'' The composer is knifed in the alley, the lead soprano is poisoned, a prominent opera patron is murdered, and -- oh, yes, the theater is torched.

title: How to Submit a Wedding Announcement
description: To submit news of your wedding to The New York Times, please pay careful attention to the information that follows:

title: Asoka Roy, 85, a Pioneer In Nurse-Midwifery, Is Dead
description: Asoka Roy, a nurse-midwife who used the skills she learned abroad to help establish the field as a profession in the United States, died on June 22 in Valhalla, N.Y. She was 85.

title: July 1-7; A New Kind of Artificial Heart
description: An unidentified diabetic man in his 50's became the first human to live with a self-contained artificial heart. Doctors said that before the device was implanted, at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky., the man was suffering terminal heart failure, moderate kidney failure, wasting and other problems. Afterward, during a nine-hour period when he was able to manage without a breathing tube, he was able to talk with his family. The doctors remain extremely cautious: the artificial heart is a bold experiment in which complications can arise at any time. Lawrence K. Altman

title: U.S. Crews Make but 2 Finals
description: After four days of elimination heats, the United States, with a record 42 boats entered in the 19 cup events this year, will compete in only two finals in the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Fictions About the Failure At Camp David
description: A year ago this week, President Bill Clinton, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat gathered at Camp David for what, in retrospect, many consider a turning point in Israeli-Palestinian relations. From right to left, hawks to doves, comes unusual harmony of opinion both here and in Israel: Camp David is said to have been a test that Mr. Barak passed and Mr. Arafat failed. Offered close to 99 percent of their dreams, the thinking goes, the Palestinians said no and chose to hold out for more. Worse, they did not present any concession of their own, adopting a no-compromise attitude that unmasked their unwillingness to live peacefully with a Jewish state by their side.

title: Pari Berk, Geoffrey Chang
description: Pari Ellen Berk, a daughter of Terry and William Berk of Marlboro, N.J., is to be married this evening to Geoffrey Sun Chang, the son of Dr. Julius Chang of Niskayuna, N.Y., and the late Yi Chang. Rabbi Morton M. Rosenthal will officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

description: I agree that homosexuals deserve the same recognition that is bestowed on heterosexual soldiers. However, Sullivan's idea of creating a monument that would depict a homosexual soldier would be difficult if not impossible.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Siemens Plans $120 Million Redevelopment in Iselin
description: OVER the next five years, the Siemens Corporation, the American arm of Siemens A.G., the German conglomerate, plans to replace its 30-year-old 350,000-square-foot complex here with a newer and bigger version.

title: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-08-01: Salient Facts: Beach Hazards; In Deep
description: BACKWASHJust when you thought beaches were safe from syringes, there's fecal matter to worry about. According to a recent E.P.A. survey of 1,891 beaches, 24 percent had at least one advisory or closing, largely because of unsafe levels of fecal bacteria in the water. On Memorial Day weekend alone, swimming bans were in effect at three Staten Island beaches. Beachgoers aren't to blame. Heavy rains heighten sewage runoff and urban street runoff, contaminating the water. Fecal bacteria is, no surprise, nasty stuff, causing ear, nose and throat infections, stomachaches and staph on open cuts. Bill Clinton's beach bill, signed last October, requires nationwide standards for beach-water-quality monitoring and public notification of unsafe conditions. But you can test the waters yourself if you've got $25 and at least 24 hours with a kit that will give you a coliform bacterial count, offered by the environmental group Surfrider.

title: Betty Abebe, Geoffrey Chapin
description: Bethlehem Abebe, a daughter of Freweini Abebe and Dr. Loolseged Abebe of New York, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Stark Chapin, the son of Diane and Peter Chapin of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. James G. Amos performed a Lutheran ceremony that combined Ethiopian and Eritrean traditions at the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church in New York.

title: Body Painting Without All the Mess
description: Summer prints are coming on strong in bold motifs. On the street and at parties, they are replacing timid blossoms. Top row, sprays on skirts worn with solid tops; tributes to Surrealism (a lobster), Pop Art and Op Art (optical illusion courtesy of two fabrics moving against each other); and two 1950's-style Scandinavian Modern prints.

title: Sports of The Times; Throwback Reliever An Unusual All-Star
description: In sports, nobody uses the term throwback to refer to an incompetent. It's always a compliment, a term of endearment for somebody who's a reminder of another old pro.

title: Kilmer Park Is Prettier, but for How Long?
description: After decades of deterioration and vandalism, Joyce Kilmer Park and its Lorelei Fountain, opposite Borough Hall, have been almost completely refurbished thanks to a $5 million project.

title: Earnhardts Dominate The Night At Daytona
description: In an almost supernatural second act to Nascar's most dramatic race of the year, Dale Earnhardt Jr. roared to the lead in the final laps of the Pepsi 400 tonight to win on the racetrack where his father was killed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Seeking To Map Brando's Island
description: IT'S JUNE 27, 2000, and I am in Montreal, on location for ''The Score,'' an elegant little heist movie directed by Frank Oz. The producer, Gary Foster, has asked me to watch the stars at work -- the stars being Robert De Niro, Ed Norton and Marlon Brando.

title: Legal Citations on Trial In Innovation v. Tradition
description: For a couple of centuries, judges and lawyers have been including arcane numbers smack in the middle of their writing. They call them sentence citations, see, e.g., Bush v. Gore, 531 U.S. 98, 121 S. Ct. 525, 148 L. Ed. 2d 388 (2000).

description: WHEN Miss Fio visited Dr. Richard Mitchell two years ago, her status as a world-class athlete was in jeopardy.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: WHO lives in a pineapple under the sea?/ Absorbent and yellow and porous is he!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWSON, THOMAS DAVID
description: LAWSON-Thomas David. Age 57, died Sunday, July 1, with his family by his side. Beloved husband of thirty-three years to the love of his life, Fay. Adoring father of Allysa & Benjamin Goldman and Steffie and Andrew Gorenstein. Loving grandfather known to all as ''Bobo'' to Justin, Harris & Dylan. Devoted son-in-law to Leon & Estere Milchikier. There never has been nor ever will be a man like Tom Lawson. Donations in his memory can be made to the T. J. Martell Foundation, care of Dr. James Holland, 555 Madison Ave, NYC 10022.

title: Kristin Kellogg, Warren Valdmanis
description: Kristin Elisabeth Kellogg, the daughter of Cynthia and Norman H. Kellogg of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Warren Gundars Valdmanis, the son of Sandra Warren Valdmanis of Scarborough, Me., and Gundars Valdmanis of Riga, Latvia. The Rev. Dr. David Johnson Rowe performed the ceremony at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: Fireworks And Footwork
GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Ellison Seems to Be Steering for a Cup Role
description: The wealthy men who underwrite America's Cup campaigns fall into two distinct categories: the ones who are content to watch the action from a regal superyacht in the spectator fleet, and those who feel compelled to throw themselves into the fray.

title: Two Playwrights Who Listened to Their Elders
description: CHRISTOPHER SHINN had wanted to be a playwright from the age of 15, when he took a trip to New York, fell in love with another boy, then went home to Connecticut and wrote a play about it. But in his four years in the dramatic writing program at New York University, not one of his plays was ever selected for production. When he was 20, he wrote a four-character play about two teenagers separately seeking out their first sexual encounters on the Fourth of July. He titled it ''Four.'' It, too, was rejected, not just by the writing program but by several regional and New York theaters.

title: Last-Minute Jaunt to Biltmore And the Blue Ridge
description: CHRISTMAS and New Year's, Thanksgiving, the Fourth of July, Memorial Day. These are times when it can be impossible to get a flight or a hotel room, period -- forget about discounts. From a frugal traveler's perspective, one should probably spend those days curled up with a good book, or be safely tucked away in a corner of the world that's out of sync with the rhythms of the American workplace.

title: Agony Over Kashmir Echoes in Indian Courtroom
description: For one of its most controversial courts-martial in 50 years, the Indian Army has chosen a setting that seems like a stage set from the colonial past.

title: New York State of Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: BackTalk; The Yea and Nay of Beijing's Olympic Bid
description: It's time the Olympics went to China.

title: Elizabeth Crouch, Nelson Fitts
description: Elizabeth Alice Crouch, a graduate music student, and Nelson Orus Fitts, a lawyer in New York, were married yesterday evening at Christ Episcopal Church in Bowling Green, Ky. The Rev. Mark Linder, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Don't Take Boswell to the Beach
description: THERE are probably as many ways to ruin a vacation as there are destinations. You can spend your entire trip -- this is one of my specialties -- worrying about whether that leak you never got fixed in the downstairs plumbing has metastasized into a fissure in your foundation. Or you can spend your vacation time, as my in-laws tend to do, arguing about what to do next year. But in my experience, the best route to vacation failure is to take the wrong book, particularly if the point of your vacations, like mine, is to sit around in the shade all day reading, completely ignoring your children.

title: Other Pro Teams Hope to Walk Like Ducks
description: ONE humid mid-June evening, as the sun began to dip, some 3,300 fans passed through the turnstiles of EAB Park in Central Islip and sat down to watch the hometown Long Island Lizards take on the Boston Cannons in what the fledgling Major League Lacrosse association said was the second professional lacrosse game to be contested on Long Island. The first was seven days earlier, when the Lizards defeated the Rochester Rattlers at Hofstra Stadium, their back-up venue when EAB Park is otherwise in use.

title: Ideas & Trends: Dear World; Loose Lips Sink More Than Ships
description: ''WADE -- I love you, I really do,'' wrote a University of Tennessee administrator, Pamela S. Reed, to J. Wade Gilley, the school's president, in a May 27 e-mail, ''and I will never make a statement to the press or anyone else that could harm you about our relationship.''

title: New Jersey Students Star at NJPAC
description: The production of ''Once on This Island'' that opens this week at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center may look something like an All-Star Game for New Jersey young people interested in theater. The musical will feature dozens of young people from throughout the state, drawn together through the Westfield Young Artists Cooperative Theater, a nonprofit group that promotes education in the theatrical arts.

title: Wah Chen, Edward Renwick
description: Dehua Chen, a daughter of Margaret Chen and Dr. Thomas Chen of Millburn, N.J., was married yesterday in Stanford, Calif., to Edward Rainey Renwick, a son of Gloria Rainey Renwick and Edward Shield Renwick of Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. James Oberle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Stanford University.

title: Amy-Beth Bachmann, Gregory Katz
description: Amy-Beth Bachmann, the daughter of Karen and Steven Bachmann of Merrick, N.Y., was married last evening to Gregory Adam Katz, a son of Dayle and Michael Katz of Old Westbury, N.Y. Cantor Jacob Merlis officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Intellectual Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: Exasperated Arafat Says U.S. Should Do More
description: ''So, tell me, where are the Americans?'' Yasir Arafat's cabinet secretary, Ahmed Abdel Rahman, asked in his office in the Palestinian leader's compound here.

title: Rate Cuts Translate Into Gains for Bank Sector Funds
description: INVESTORS in bank stocks owe a lot to Alan Greenspan. Despite a gloomy stock market, banks are showing positive returns in the last few months, thanks to repeated cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.

title: Where Mosquitoes And Tires Breed
description: Mosquitoes are particular about their habitats. One breed prefers standing water full of decaying leaves, a soup of dark pungent moisture in which to lay its eggs. Another breed requires a dry nest for its young. Water is needed only near the end of the egg's life cycle to hatch the next generation of pests.

title: His Success, Like His Music, Keeps Repeating
description: IF the perennially controversial Philip Glass were any other living composer, one could observe with a straight face that his music is suddenly everywhere. His recent chamber setting of Kafka's ''In the Penal Colony'' -- a ''pocket opera,'' he calls it -- is winding up its five-week New York premiere run at the Classic Stage Company (with the final performance on Saturday) just as Lincoln Center Festival 2001 begins a Glass celebration that includes the American premiere of ''White Raven,'' his 1991 operatic collaboration with Robert Wilson, as well as four concerts of old and new works.

title: INSIDE
description: Arafat Asks More of U.S.

title: An Old Game Played the Very Old Way
description: IN early June, several pastors attending a retreat at St. Thomas Seminary in Bloomfield decided to stretch their legs. They strolled into the field behind the seminary classrooms and strayed into the past. What they saw were two baseball diamonds and several players attired in uniforms from the late 19th century playing baseball without gloves.

description: This

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LEE
description: KAPLAN-Lee. The Jewish Braille Institute of America (JBI) is saddened by the passing of the mother of our esteemed Vice President, Myron Kaplan. Our heartfelt thoughts and condolences are with the family during this time of sorrow. We pray that her memory will endure as a continuing blessing and inspiration to the entire family. Barbara B. Friedman, President Dr. Ellen Isler, Executive V.P.

title: Christina Flint, Jeffrey Grossman
description: Christina Flint, the daughter of Aili and Austin Flint of New York, was married on Cape Cod yesterday to Jeffrey Grossman, a son of Raphael Grossman of New Port Richey, Fla., and the late Helen Brenneman Grossman. The bridegroom's father, who was appointed as a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day, officiated at the Orleans Inn in Orleans.

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: A number of the symptoms people complain of are not unlike the side effects of antibiotics. Is it possible that the culprit is the applied cure itself?

title: A Beautiful Paean
description: To the Editor:

title: The Legal History of the Flip Tax
description: Q: Back in 1986, when I sold a co-op apartment on East 96th Street, I paid a flip tax of $16,000, representing a percentage of the appreciation in price. Since then, however, I understand that flip taxes have been ruled illegal. In fact, I believe a neighbor won a refund after threatening to sue the co-op. Am I also entitled to a refund after all these years? . . . Alex Taylor III, Manhattan.

title: Piazza's Improvement
description: Mike Piazza said his fractured left big toe was feeling much better, and he expected to be ready to catch tonight. Even if Manager Bobby Valentine does not use him as a catcher, Piazza said, if he feels he can catch, he will go to the All-Star Game and be the National League's starting catcher.

title: Wicket Good
description: Rhys Thomas, a top U.S. croquet official, caught his first glimpse of the sport's future at a tournament in San Francisco in 1993. Thomas himself had just executed an impressive run of shots that he remembers as ''one of the best turns of my career.'' Expecting a warm ripple of applause from the spectators, Thomas looked up to see a hundred backsides. ''Everyone,'' he says, ''was watching Jacques Fournier on the adjacent court.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, ZAPHRIRAH J.
description: BAUMAN-Zaphrirah J. Died at home July 1, 2001 in her 84th year. A devoted teacher & courageous union activist, she was also a lifelong advocate for tenants rights & other progressive political causes. She is survived by her husband Joseph Bauman; her brother Joseph Kremen; her sons Ellis and Richard Bauman; grandsons Mark and Andrew Bauman; granddaughters Gretchen and Rachael Stoeltje; great-grandchildren Matthew, Morgan, Madisen Bauman, Alexandra Bauman & Calvin and Nicholas Anderson. We will miss her loving heart and her indomitable spirit. A memorial service will be announced later in the Fall.

title: Doing Battle to Stay in High School
description: When Wan Shan Hu was introduced as Lafayette High School's valedictorian at graduation last month, some parents in the the audience grumbled that it was always an immigrant who got the award. Others booed outright. Unfazed, Ms. Hu finished her valedictory speech in her accented English, a shy smile the only sign of how happy she was even to be at the ceremony.

title: Beaten Jersey City Officer Dies After Life Support is Shut Off
description: The Jersey City police officer who was severely beaten during an argument on the Fourth of July died after doctors removed him from life-support equipment, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.

title: Morgan Hellmold, John Stafford
description: Morgan Emily Hellmold, a daughter of Ralph Hellmold of Englewood, N.J., and the late Margaret Trudgian Hellmold, was married yesterday to Lt. John Everett Stafford, the son of Jean and Joe Stafford of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Richard E. Spalding, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Pleasantdale Chteau in West Orange, N.J.

title: From Asian Needles, a Wonder of Stitches
description: SAVVY world travelers collected exotic embroidered wearables before the collapse of China's Qing Dynasty in 1911. Some of these costumes and textiles, including lavish dragon robes and lotus foot slippers shipped home to Hartford between 1860 and 1910, are the subjects of ''The Forbidden Stitch: Chinese Embroidery'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art through Sept. 9.

title: Asking, and Answering, Some of the Big Questions
description: CHAWKY FRENN is a painter who has nailed down the figurative mode, and this accomplishment gives him the license to convey anything he wants, including the grand theme: the elusive meaning of human existence.

title: WASPs' War Effort Gets Due Recognition
description: Long Island has begun to take stock of its strategic role in the Arsenal of Democracy during World War II. But all too often we are mesmerized by the machines built here and ignore the men and women who represent the region's real strength.

title: Midnight Hour: Road Repair Time
description: In an old joke, a car mechanic tells a surgeon that their jobs are much the same. ''That would be true,'' says the surgeon, ''if you kept the motor running while repairing the car.''

title: An Opera Just as Unconventional as Its (Anti)Hero
description: NOW 54, the Sicilian-born Salvatore Sciarrino is widely considered one of Europe's most original contemporary composers, a man whose musical explorations have led him, if not actually to silence, at least to the breathing, rustling, whispering, knocking and scratching sounds that precede silence. He believes, quite simply, that music is more audible when it is almost inaudible. And nowhere is this truer for him than in opera.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the moral and ethical quandaries of medical research on stem cells taken from human embryos misquoted David J. Garrow, a historian at Emory University. Dr. Garrow said the political calculation required of the Bush administration on this issue was one of ''quantity versus intensity,'' not ''quantity versus quantity.''

title: Letters
description: Our article on Lyme disease prompted a flood of protests from readers who said the condition is not "in their mind." Andrew Sullivan drew mail from "M*A*S*H" fans asserting that Corporal Klinger's cross-dressing was a bid for a Section 8 discharge, not a statement of sexual orientation.

title: Alaska Gets Tougher On Cruise Ship Pollution
description: ON a typical summer day in Alaska, the number of people aboard cruise ships along the Inside Passage, from Ketchikan in the south up to Juneau, reaches nearly 50,000 -- enough to constitute the third largest community in Alaska, behind only Anchorage and Fairbanks.

title: A State Story on Two Wheels
description: FOLLOWING the horse, the bicycle presented a revolutionary mode of traveling. And who would guess that it all started in Connecticut?

title: Taiwan's Hard Times Rekindle 'One China' Debate
description: For a 78-year-old pensioner with heart trouble, Lee Teng-hui is not easing up. When Mr. Lee, the former president of Taiwan, came home from a visit to the United States this week, he greeted well-wishers by grabbing a megaphone and bellowing, ''Let's all have confidence in our Taiwan.''

title: Sohee Song, Pierre Kim
description: Sohee Song, the daughter of Jung Nam Song and Sung Kyu Song of Hickory Creek, Tex., was married yesterday evening to Pierre Kim, a son of Yong Hi Kim and Samuel Kim of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Robert Applestone performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Maximus V, the Patriarch of Greek Catholics, Dies at 93
description: Patriarch Maximus V Hakim, who for more than 30 years was spiritual leader of the small Greek Catholic Church and who sought better relations with the larger Eastern Orthodox Church, died on June 29 in a hospital in Beirut. He was 93.

title: William J. Mouton, 70, Engineer and Professor
description: William Joseph Mouton Jr., a structural engineer and emeritus professor of architecture at Tulane University who provided the physical underpinnings for the growth of the New Orleans skyline, died June 30 at a New Orleans hospital. He was 70 and lived in Harahan, La., a suburb of New Orleans.

title: GUN PERMITS INCREASE
description: New Jersey is one of only three states of the 19 that require background checks for gun purchases that reported an increase last year in the number of applications for gun permits. During 2000, 77,211 applications to buy handguns or rifles were submitted to state or local law enforcement agencies, a 1.1 percent increase over 1999, according to a study released last week by the federal Bureau of Justice Statistics. Colorado and Maryland also reported increases. In the other states, the F.B.I. rather than state officials does background checks and statistics are not released on a state-by-state basis. Nationally, requests to buy guns dropped 11 percent from 8.6 million to 7.7 million between 1999 and 2000. The number of applications rejected also declined from 204,000 to 153,000. Karen DeMasters

title: American With French and Italian Spins
description: EVERY town should have a restaurant like Bay & Main in Greenport. Although it's not a tony gourmet palace and neither the food nor the service is flawless, Bay & Main boasts a charming, whimsical style of its own, an accommodating, concerned staff and generally commendable, contemporary American food with Italian and French spins.

title: Article 2001070890715853466 -- No Title
description: July 8, 2001

title: 'The Fourth Hand'
description: Imagine a young man on his way to a less-than-thirty-second eventthe loss of his left hand, long before he reached middle age.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: ECSTASY DATABASE
description: The New Jersey division of the federal Drug Enforcement Administration is compiling a statewide database to track trafficking in the club drug Ecstasy, the first of its kind in the nation. The database, to be used to coordinate local enforcement efforts, may include biographical and vehicle information. Drug officials say that New Jersey does not have a particularly bad Ecstasy problem, though the age of first use has been dropping, but say that the database is a proactive measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHALOW, LOUISE E. K.
description: SCHALOW-Louise E. K. On July 2, 2001, in New York City, after a brief illness. She was predeceased by her brother, Rev. Frederick M. Schalow. She will be deeply missed by her sister, Katherine Hubbard of Los Angeles, CA, her niece and six nephews, their spouses and children. Born in New York City on June 17, 1918, she received her degree in nursing from Hartwick College in 1952, and subsequently worked for the American Red Cross, including assignments in the Far East. She was a gifted and dedicated teacher of nursing in the New York City Public High Schools until her retirement in 1985. A memorial service will be held at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 88th St and Lexington Ave, Manhattan, on Saturday, July 14, 2001, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that donations be made in her memory to a charity of your choice.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Shirts of Paradise
description: You don't have to be Hawaiian to love Hawaiian shirts. You don't even have to wear one to enjoy THE ALOHA SHIRT: Spirit of the Islands (Beyond Words, $45). Dale Hope and Gregory Tozian write, ''Aloha puts into one word the warm sense of greeting, love and playfulness for which Hawaii is well known,'' a spirit evoked through the tropical colors and Polynesian patterns emblazoned on the classic Hawaiian or Aloha shirt. It began as a novelty souvenir, selling for 95 cents during the early 1930's, when Hawaii was emerging as a tourist paradise. Soon the shirt grew into a major industry with its own master textile designers and printmakers. Profusely illustrated with photographs, drawings, advertisements, tags and labels, the book is a history of the shirt's designers and manufacturers. The illustrations are delightful. Film posters and record covers feature celebrity poster boys like Elvis Presley, Bing Crosby (who lent his name to a shirt label) and Montgomery Clift, who in the 1953 movie ''From Here to Eternity'' takes a fatal bullet in his lovely Aloha. There is also a section on the varieties of coconut buttons sewn onto vintage garments. But the real treat is reproductions of the shirts themselves, more than 100 of them, spread out like wallpaper swatches, with lyrical, weird or kitschy designs like palm trees, sailboats, flying fish, surfboards, exploding volcanoes, hula girls and night-blooming cereus patterns. One favorite, from 1959, is the ''Okole Maluna'' or ''Bottoms Up.'' Steven Heller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CAROLE
description: KLEIN-Carole. The Board of Trustees of Goddard College mourn the passing of Carole Klein, our colleague, friend, teacher, alumna. She was a great friend and a light in all our lives.

title: July 1-7; Lincoln Relic Recovered
description: Forgotten since 1922, one of the flags that was standing in President Lincoln's theater box when he was assassinated was shown publicly for the first time. An employee of the Connecticut Historical Society stumbled across the decayed silk Treasury Guard flag in 1998; three subsequent years of research have proved the flag's authenticity. Paul Zielbauer

title: A Pole Is 85 Feet High, With No Flag in Sight
description: An 85-foot-tall pole for a billboard stands forlorn in the backyard of a building on the Bowery, caught in legal limbo between old and new rules restricting outdoor advertising.

title: Larry Clark, Moralist, In the Florida Suburbs
description: ''BULLY,'' the new film by Larry Clark that opens Friday, is like a cancer drug: powerful, hard to take, necessary. A faithful retelling of an ugly murder of a nasty punk by a bunch of troubled, amoral teenagers that took place in Florida in 1993, ''Bully'' is a ''Lord of the Flies'' for our time, except that the kids who lose their tenuous grip on morality here are not lost in some distant jungle but in the tract houses and strip malls and Pizza Huts of suburbia. A movie filled with nudity, sex scenes and acts of violence large and small, ''Bully'' is in fact a deeply conservative film, one that right-wing radio hosts could chew on for weeks, if they could bring themselves to see it.

title: Taking a Taxi
description: To the Editor: This article took me back 20 years, to when my husband and I traveled to Italy. Mostly we wanted to revisit Urbino, where we'd been in our early 20's and got to know each other in the spring of 1965, but we also yearned to see Rome again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPE, SUSAN (NEE NOLAN)
description: LIPE-Susan (nee Nolan). 48 of Indian Rock Beach, FL, and formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. Died July 5, 2001, in Tampa, FL. Beloved wife of Wayne. Cherished daughter of James and Catherine Nolan of Rockville Centre. Beloved sister of James (Debbie), Dr. Patricia (Peter) McAleer, Barbara (Edward) Murphy, Denis (Joan). Beloved aunt of Nicole and Peter James. Susan was a flight attendant for TWA and a graduate of Malloy College School of Nursing. Viewing hours will be today at Moss-Feaster Funeral Home, Serenity Gardens Chapel, Largo, FL, with Mass of Christian Burial, 10AM Monday at St. Jerome Catholic Church, Largo. Burial will follow in Serenity Gardens Memorial Park, Largo. A memorial Mass will be held at a later date at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. For more info call MossFeaster Funeral Home, 727446-2375.

title: DataBank; Profit Warnings Dampen the Holiday
description: The shortened Fourth of July week might have been a nice break for Wall Street, but it offered no relief to investors waiting for corporate earnings to revive. Stocks tumbled across the board, with technology stocks hit the hardest.

title: Divya Gugnani, Pankaj Gupta
description: Divya Gugnani, a daughter of Kavita and Vinay Gugnani of Port Washington, N.Y., was married on Friday to Pankaj Gupta, a son of Neelima and Kamlesh Gupta of Barrington, Ill. Kirat Singh Sethi, a Sikh officiant, performed a ceremony that combined Sikh and Hindu traditions at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANSTERN, ROSALIE ARLENE (NEE MARCUS)
description: MORGANSTERN-Rosalie Arlene (nee Marcus). Age 71, died on July 6, 2001, with her family by her side. Joyfully married for 47 years to her soulmate, Kennard. Cherished and adored by her children Priya (Shari), Bhavani (Mindy), David and Julie; her grandchildren Saisha, Harper, Elana, Cayla, Daria, Dustin, Melody and Eve; her children-in-law Tom, Joe, Carolyn and Scott; and her sister-in-law Myrna Cohen. Beloved by many more. Services Sunday, July 8, 2001, at 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, LI; 516-487-9600. Memorial contributions in her name may be made to North Shore University Hospital Auxilliary-Stroke Club, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY 11030; 516-562-4947. The family will receive visitors at The Morganstern/Jaroff Homestead through Thursday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, MORGAN O'BRIEN
description: JAMES-Morgan O'Brien. Of New York, NY, died June 11, 2001, after a brief illness. Born Sept 24, 1917, in South Hampton, NY. Son of the late Dr. Henry and Rosalie James. Mr. James had leading roles in Broadway and summer stock productions. He is survived by three brothers, Henry James Jr., Daniel and Philip, and was pre-deceased by a brother Walter.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; Close-to-Home Cooking
description: When we moved to Upper Montclair, we found ourselves spending a large amount of time at the Char-Broil, the diner that has been in its Valley Road home since 1912 -- long before we trudged in nightly, weary from a long day of packing and unpacking, balancing books in one arm and baby in the other. With that baby, my husband and our 7-year-old son, we set upon the Char-Broil as only the hungry can. The food, bountiful as the waitresses' generous greetings, never failed to be satisfying. I nearly sank into the huge Greek salad ($6.75), ripe with chunks of feta and fine slivers of anchovies. Alan, a meat-and-potatoes man, went from burgers ($3.40) to pork chops ($9.95) to pot roast ($9.45). There were enough crayons, too, to keep a boy happy. Paul found delights in the children's menu, choosing the Penguin (hot dog, French fries, ice cream ($5.75). And when Miles wasn't asleep in my arms, he delighted in the scenery, inside and out. The large picture windows on Valley Road were perfect, and we smiled and sighed happily as we ate, watching the families outside as they walked, talked, laughed. After we were more settled in our home, we began to neglect the Char-Broil, treating it like a friend to whom we'd revealed one too many intimacies only to regret our indiscretion. When we thought of the Broil, if we did at all, it was only during our family's evening walks around town. But then the faces of the families in the diner's windows -- smiling, happy -- reminded us of our internship, and lured us back, again and again, smiling and happy as well.

title: When She Was Just 16, It Was a Very Bad Year
description: Annus horribilis, indeed. Nik Faulkner can't imagine the year getting any worse. Too many nights she finds herself at home baby-sitting her twin brothers while her parents work double shifts. Her favorite uncle has recently died. And although her mother seems not to notice, Nik thinks her father is spending entirely too much time at her widowed Aunt Marion's house being, as he says, ''helpful.''

title: The Uses of Enchantment
description: DANGEROUS MUSE

title: A Car That Helped Redefine Datsun
description: IN 1969, driving enthusiasts who normally looked to Europe for sports cars found themselves beguiled by the 240Z, sold by a little-known company named Datsun.

title: Move to Curb Biotech Crops Ignores Poor, U.N. Finds
description: Opposition in richer countries to genetically modified crops may set back the ability of the poorest nations to feed growing populations, according to a new United Nations survey.

title: Egypt on Trial
description: Weaver claims that Saad Eddin Ibrahim, chairman of Ibn Khaldun Center, and his co-defendants were held under ''Egypt's draconian emergency laws'' and that they were tried by an ''extraordinary court.'' This is erroneous. The fact is that the case was tried by a High Security Court whose judges are members of Cairo's Court of Appeal and apply the regular codes of law.

title: "Russia and the Russians: A History"
description: The north Eurasian plain is not only Russia's geographical setting, but also her fate. From the Carpathians in the west to the Greater Khingan range in the east, a huge expanse of flat, open territory dominates the Eurasian continent. It divides into four bands of terrain, running from west to east. In the south is desert, broken only by oases along the rivers which run off the mountains along the southern and eastern rims. Then comes steppe, lightly watered country with a thin and variable covering of grasses and scrub, again broken intermittently by oases, gullies, and river valleys. Farther north is a belt of coniferous forest, interspersed toward its southern edge with deciduous trees; only to the west of the Urals does this deciduous belt broaden to become a large and independent ecological zone. Finally comes the tundra: frozen wastelands and swamp, with broad rivers flowing through them to the Arctic Ocean, itself frozen for much of the year.

title: Glass With the Glistening Lure of Silver
description: CHANGING taste is a basic factor in American material culture. Vases, curtain pins, doorknobs, gazing balls, Christmas ornaments and sundry household accessories in silvered glass, which is often mistakenly called mercury glass, have gone in and out of fashion. They have been seen as either beautiful embellishment or sheer kitsch.

description: To the Editor:

description: Audiovox Reports Second Quarter Loss

title: A Bully Moves In
description: TURN over almost any rock uncovered by low tide in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut and you probably will uncover a small, purplish-black alien with six colorfully banded legs and two nimble claws -- a Pacific shore crab.

title: 'Merchant' at Boscobel Restoration
description: SURPRISE is what we've come to expect from the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, even after all these years. In all its splendor here on the Boscobel Restoration grounds, the one-of-a-kind company, blessed with a vibrant gift for discovery, or perhaps more aptly, rediscovery, almost seems to be working on a dare. Tell the director it can't be done and it's a safe bet that it will be done. Forget safety after that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRIGUE, SHEILA KATHLEEN
description: GARRIGUE-Sheila Kathleen. Died peacefully June 9, 2001, at her home in Chappaqua after a long battle with cancer. She was born December 30, 1931, in England, to Kathleen Norah and Edward Donaldson Hogg. At age seven, she was evacuated to Canada to escape the German air raids of World War II. At the war's end, she returned to parents and a home she barely remembered. At eighteen, she took her first job as secretary to the colorful Ian Robert Maxwell. Six years later she left England to work her way around the world, working for KCBS in San Francisco before becoming Executive Assistant to Edward R. Murrow at CBS News in New York. On March 14, 1959, she married Paul Garrigue, whom she had met aboard the ship that brought her from England to the United States. Mrs. Garrigue published three acclaimed children's novels, each of which was translated into several languages: ''All the Children Were Sent Away,'' ''Between Friends'' and ''The Eternal Spring of Mr. Ito.'' The first and third books were based on her own wartime experiences. She was a sought-after speaker at schools throughout the eastern U.S., and corresponded with many children who had read her books. She spent many happy hours over more than two decades with the Chappaqua Drama Group, performing every function from acting and producing to selecting plays and serving as the group's president. An accomplished linguist, she loved reading, writing poetry, telling stories, painting and gardening, and was known for her creativity and dry wit. Above all, she was devoted to her family. Mrs. Garrigue is survived by her husband Paul, her children Matthew, Andrew and Elizabeth, and her granddaughter Madeleine. Contributions in Mrs. Garrigue's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021; or A-Home, 241 Lexington Ave, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALOUSTIAN, ARSHAG ''ARCHIE.''
description: CALOUSTIAN-Arshag ''Archie.'' On July 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Marilou, and Gabrielle and Raymond Frigon. Loving grandfather of Camille. Dear brother of Marie Kakoyan. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Edward D. Jamie Funeral Chapel, 141-26 Northern Blvd, Flushing. Funeral service Monday, 10 AM, at the Armenian Church of the Holy Martyrs, Bayside. Interment Cedar Grove Cemetery.

title: Egypt on Trial
description: Reading Mary Anne Weaver's article on the tribulations of Saad Eddin Ibrahim (June 17), I realized that we have learned little since the waning days of the former shah of Iran. Then, as now, we supported an autocratic and increasingly brutal regime that was unresponsive to the needs of the people and their growing frustrations. The path of this regime, aided by America's blind support, culminated in the Islamic revolution.

What are the odds New Yorkers who have not yet rounded the clubhouse turn of middle age would consider the track a fun, hip destination?

description: COHEN-Louis. Beloved husband of Molly for 76 years. Loving father of Richard and the late Stanley. Devoted grandfather, greatgrandfather and dear uncle. Services at Boulevard-Hewlett, Sunday, 11:30 AM.

title: On Writers and Writing; We Are All Tourists
description: ONE afternoon, when I had been reading Elizabeth Bishop for several hours, I wrote two words down on a piece of paper: ''birthright'' and ''sightlines.'' What was her birthright? Well, she was born in Worcester, Mass.; her father died when she was 8 months old, and when she was 5, her mother entered a mental institution. She was reared by two sets of grandparents: the first, more loving ones were in Nova Scotia; the second, both wealthier and chillier, took her back to Massachusetts.

She and her husband, Sam, suspected their friend's heart was being held captive, but not by the rollicking musical about sleazy celebrity in the Chicago of the Roaring Twenties. No, it was the actress Marcia Lewis, a k a Matron (Mama) Morton, who plays the tough-talking countess of the Cook County Jail in the musical.

description: FLAHERTY-Kevin F. This warm, witty, charitable and well respected young man died July 3, age 45, of cancer. Kevin leaves behind two brothers, Tim and Mike Flaherty, a sister, Sue Huggans, and his companion of ten years, Greg Grimes, who will miss him greatly, as will many friends. Private services were held in Oneonta, NY. A memorial service will be held. For information call the Bookhout Funeral Home of Oneonta, NY.

description: Bobby Valentine obsessed in the visitors' dugout for almost four hours yesterday, pacing, shouting, spitting, encouraging, cajoling, calming, chewing, inciting -- and winning, in the end.

description: LET me dispense with the platitudes up front: I'm into yoga. I think it's great for the city's alpha set. But at the moment yoga fever is out of control.

title: July 1-7; U.S. Soldier in Japan's Hands
description: After the rape of a 12-year-old Japanese girl in 1995, the United States promised to consider handing over military personnel suspected in serious crimes, like murder or rape, even before indictment. So, a week after Air Force Senior Staff Sgt. Timothy Woodland, 24, was accused of the parking-lot rape of a Japanese woman, he was given to the Japanese authorities. His defense: the sex was consensual.

title: Where the View Surpasses the Fare
description: THE Chart House here is one of a national chain of more than 40 Chart House restaurants that share a common theme: Almost all of them border a body of water, and all take full advantage of their extraordinary natural prospects.

title: Paying Heed To the Mysteries Of Trisha Brown
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago I was rehearsing with Trisha Brown and three other dancers in a former sheep fold in a wooded area near Aix-en-Provence, in the south of France. We were creating ''Line Up,'' which we made by improvising for maybe 20 seconds at a time, and then trying to recall, edit and set our improvisation. (This was before anyone used video to record the rehearsal process.) The instructions were to create lines in space while relating to one another and the environment, so there was lots of interaction among the five of us.

title: Lucite and Metal
description: Los Angeles's latest hot spot is an unlikely hybrid of modernist architecture and gritty rock 'n' roll. The Standard Lounge, on the ground level of the Standard Hotel on Sunset Boulevard, is reminiscent of the Danish designer Verner Panton's playful 1960's period, with potato-chip-shaped hammocks, spaceship chrome and walls lined with undulating purple Lucite rods. The waitresses, wearing Courrges-style red minidresses, match the dcor perfectly. But the music, instead of ambient lounge, is hard-rock party anthems by metal groups like Black Sabbath and Van Halen. Already the womblike space has become a must-squeeze-into for Hollywood's tattooed and spiked elite -- among them Tommy Lee, Limp Bizkit's Fred Durst, the band Korn and youth pop stars like Britney Spears and the Backstreet Boys.

title: Seeking the Ultimate Hard-Core Massage When Spa Pummeling Turns Tedious
description: BACK in the early 1990's, when I had no money and men were not yet vain, getting a real therapeutic massage was a special event for me. It involved blas nudity and strange tinkly music. It was Swedish -- which meant it was sexy yet unsexy, something like a meatball but so much more hedonistic. Most of all, it left me woozily indifferent to my all-too-modern life.

title: When New Homes Drive Out Old Jobs
description: ON the northwest edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant -- bordering the bodegas and housing projects of DeKalb Avenue, but only three blocks from the Italianate brownstones and Victorian mansions of Clinton Hill -- six former factories built on a street called Taaffe Place at the turn of the last century have been reincarnated as beautifully renovated residential lofts with rents of up to $3,300 a month.

title: At 76, a Buy-and-Hold Manager Is Learning to Let Go, Bit by Bit
description: MARTIN J. WHITMAN hardly thought about slowing down when he turned 66. Instead, he started a mutual fund.

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: In evaluating a patient's numerous symptoms, Steere says, ''What I suspect is that she doesn't have Lyme disease but some kind of psychiatric illness.'' It cannot be emphasized enough that a psychiatric illness is not a diagnosis of exclusion. In the absence of an adequate and comprehensive psychiatric examination, the more appropriate conclusion would have been to say, ''I simply don't know what the patient has.''

title: 'Every Seat's a Good Seat'
description: NOT too long ago, Croton Point Park was a destination only for moldy coffee grounds, broken windows and whatever filth could be trucked to a county dump, which is what it was for 59 years.

title: Well, It Used to Be Just a Part of Manahatta Island
description: To real estate brokers, NoLIta is synonymous with fashion.

title: "Up in the Air"
description: To know me you have to fly with me. Sit down. I'm the aisle, you're the window—trapped. You crack your paperback, last spring's big legal thriller, convinced that what you want is solitude, though I know otherwise: you need to talk. The jaunty male flight attendant brings our drinks: a two percent milk with one ice cube for me, a Wild Turkey for you. It's wet outside, the runways streaked and dark. Late afternoon. The first-class cabin fills with other businessmen who switch on their laptops and call up lengthy spreadsheets or use the last few moments before takeoff to punch in cell-phone calls to wives and clients. Their voices are bright but shallow, no diaphragms, their sentences kept short to save on tolls, and when they hang up they face the windows, sigh, and reset their watches from Central time to Mountain. For some of them this means a longer day, for others it means eating supper before they're hungry. One fellow lowers his plastic window shade and wedges his head between two skimpy pillows, while another unlatches his briefcase, looks inside, then shuts his eyes and rubs his jaw, exhausted.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COCA, IMOGENE
description: COCA-Imogene. (1908-2001). Whose rare artistry, charm and endearing wistfulness have entertained untold millions and left an indelible imprint on all of television. Board of Governors, March 31, 1979. Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. The Imogene Coca Charitable Foundation. A not-for-profit foundation dedicated to supporting human rights, the fair and good treatment of animals and furthering the artistic spirit of the theatre. At Miss Coca's request, there will not be a funeral or memorial service. Donations in her memory may be made to The Imogene Coca Charitable Foundation C/O Price Financial Group, 37 North Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06851.

description: MULVIHILL-Frank J. The officers, members and staff of New York Electrical Contractors Association are saddened by the loss of their friend and associate, Frank J. Mulvihill. For many years Frank was an important part of our electrical industry. His counsel and wisdom will be missed by all. We express our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Edward A. Dougherty, President Joseph D'Angelo, Exec Secy

title: Inequality in the AIDS Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORGIA, BETTY
description: BORGIA-Betty. She was a special person who possessed sparkle, self-confidence, intelligence and compassion. Though a Nurse Practitioner by trade and choice, she wore many hats and all of them fit her to perfection. Her dedication and loyalty to her patients was part of her legacy. She was the epitome...the paragon of a healer. We will all miss her profoundly. The staff at Jacobi Medical Center

title: All-Star Rivera Replaced By Nelson
description: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera will bypass the All-Star Game because of tendinitis in his right ankle, and the former Yankee reliever Jeff Nelson is going to be an All-Star, after all, as a replacement for Rivera on Tuesday in Seattle.

title: POSTINGS: First of Three Middle-Income Buildings; A New Co-op Going Up in East Harlem
description: Ground was broken on Monday for the first of three middle-income co-op buildings on Madison Avenue in East Harlem. To be named Madison Park Apartments, the nine-story, 129-unit building that will span what is now a vacant lot between 119th and 120th Streets will be what Donald Capoccia, managing principal of the development company, called ''a standard old-fashioned co-op.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERN, CHRISTOPHER JAMES
description: KERN-Christopher James. Of Chestnut Hill, MA, and NYC, died suddenly after a fatal hit-and-run accident, July 4, in New York City, at age 21. Precious son of Anne (Fallon) and Harold George Kern. Wonderful brother of Gregory and Elizabeth. Godson of Mark Lawless and Gail Audet. Much loved by caring aunts and uncles, cousins and friends. Chris had happy times at many schools, including Natick and Brookline Public, Park, Belmont Hill, BB&N class of '99. Sophomore at Hamilton College, classes at NYU. Chris had fond memories of all teammates and coaches, including the Natick Comets, The South Shore Kings, Boston Junior Terriers, Park, Belmont Hill, BB&N and Hamilton. Most recently he was working as a paralegal for the New York City Law Department. Funeral from the William J. Gormley Funeral Home, 2055 Centre St, West Roxbury, on Monday, July 9, at 10:30 AM, followed by a Funeral Mass in St. Lawrence Church, 774 Boylston St, Chestnut Hill, at 11:30 AM. Relatives and friends invited. Visiting hours Sunday, 1-4 and 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers send remembrances to the Christopher James Kern Scholarship Fund, at BB&N, c/o Joe Gill, Gerry's Landing Rd, Cambridge, MA 02138.
