description: MARC COHODES, the highest-profile short-seller on Wall Street, is getting bored.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: GERTRUDE AND CLAUDIUS, by John Updike. (Ballantine, $12.95.) Far more than a pastiche, this prequel to ''Hamlet,'' chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, invents sumptuous, deep lives for Hamlet's mother; her first husband, the king of Denmark; and his younger brother, Claudius, who seduces the queen and usurps the throne. (Hamlet shows up as an arrogant brat.) Drawing on both Shakespeare and older accounts to conjure its rich medieval world, the result is a ''pleasurable and wonderfully dexterous novel about three figures in complex interplay with their public state, their private longings and one another,'' Richard Eder wrote here.

title: D.C. Police Call Answers By Condit Satisfactory
description: The District of Columbia police said today that Representative Gary A. Condit had satisfactorily answered all their questions on Friday night and reiterated that he is not a suspect in the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy, a federal intern who has not been seen since April 30.

title: July 1-7; Saudis Reject Extradition
description: Saudi-U.S. relations hit periodic rocky patches, especially when they touch on the more opaque patches of Saudi Arabian society, like its criminal justice system. This time, the country's interior minister, Prince Nayef, made it clear that the kingdom has no interest in extraditing 11 citizens imprisoned on suspicion of carrying out the deadly 1996 attack on the Khobar apartments, where American military personnel were housed; 19 airmen died. ''Maybe what has been published matters to the United States, but it does not concern us in any way at all,'' the prince said of the indictments. Neil MacFarquhar

title: Architect of Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Stars Fear Inroads By Upstart Digital Actors
description: Aki Ross, a versatile young actress who stars in a movie to be released this week, rakes slender fingers through wind-rippled hair. The light contracts her pupils and glistens on sweat-streaked cheeks, as her eyes sparkle with the eerie illusion of intelligence.

title: Rate Cuts Translate Into Gains for Bank Sector Funds

Funeral Tuesday, 9AM from M.J. Smith Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:30 AM, St. Francis Xavier Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

description: For the second straight summer, Delta Air Lines has decided not to allow pets to travel as checked baggage on passenger flights. But earlier this year it started a program allowing travelers to check in Bruiser under strict supervision.

description: The outcome of the federal government's antitrust case against Microsoft will likely be several years down the road. But a recent independent survey shows that many Americans who are following the case have already made up their minds about what should happen to the company.

Previously, he served as managing editor from 1997 to September 2001 after having been the newspapers foreign editor from June 1995 to 1997. He was the chief of The Times bureau in Johannesburg from April 1992 until May 1995.

title: Moby, With European Influence
description: In his desire to emulate the eclectic kinds of music festivals found in Europe, the unlikely cutting-edge rock star, Moby, has put together the ''Area: One'' festival featuring a wide array of performers, including the hip-hop outfit The Roots, electronica acts like DJ Paul Oakenfold and Orb, the French dance pop act Rinocerose and the Canadian singer Nelly Furtado. Also on board is the spaced-out funk rap of Outkast and the alternative metal sound of Incubus. The festival definitely has an electronic-techno bias, but it is much more encompassing than that. The festival starts at 4 p.m. Saturday at the Tweeter Center, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden. Robbie Woliver

title: The Nation; How Many Poor Children Is Too Many?
description: IN 1999, after nearly a decade of unprecedented economic growth and well into the latest overhaul of the nation's welfare system, one in six American children -- over 12 million youngsters -- lived in poverty, according to the latest available figures from the Census Bureau.

title: Gasoline Prices Down From Last Month
description: Motorists planning summer trips this month will find gasoline prices have dropped since May. In its survey of gasoline prices on June 28, the Westchester County Department of Consumer Protection found that the average price for regular gasoline was $1.861, down three cents from May. Many stations, the survey also found, are selling regular gasoline below $1.80. The lowest price for regular gasoline on June 28 was $1.699 in Cortlandt; the highest price was found in Bedford at $2.14.

description: MORGAN-Edwin D. Died June 28. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 AM, Wednesday, July 11, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave, at 51 St. Eddie served with the 1st Marine Divison in Guadalcanal, New Guinea, New Britain and Peleliu. He founded Holographics, Inc., which developed useful laser technologies. In lieu of flowers send donations to City Parks Foundation, Monuments Conservation Program, Attn: Jonathan Kuhn, Parks and Recreation, Arsenal, Central Park, NY.

title: URBAN TACTICS; At Rikers, Growing Melons, Herbs, Hope and Pride
description: THE reminders of Nina Xheraj's confinement are everywhere -- the fences draped with razor wire, the low-slung jail buildings, the roar of jets from La Guardia Airport -- but she appears not to notice. There is work to be done in the medieval herb and vegetable garden. The rest is just distraction.

title: Was He Crazy? If So, It Was Like a Genius
description: NEARLY a century ago, George E. Ohr was mostly criticized for his innovative ceramics, paper-thin vases and jugs that he ruffled, pleated, pummeled and twisted. Some he gave colorful glistening surfaces; others he left unglazed, looking like cookies, good enough to eat. Critics either ignored his work or derided it, labeling him the ''Mad Potter of Biloxi'' for his unorthodox, frequently erotic pots, as well as for his egocentricity and his bizarre appearance: he sported an 18-inch mustache, tip to tip, and a ragged goatee. Even when Ohr won a silver medal at the Louisiana Purchase International Exposition in St. Louis in 1904, the award was not publicized and he failed to make a single sale.

title: Agbayani Flies Home
description: Mets left fielder Benny Agbayani took a 6 a.m. flight to Hawaii yesterday to be with his wife, Niela, who is due to deliver their first child today. Agbayani will return after the All-Star Game break on Thursday.

title: July 1-7; They Don't Just Kidnap Americans
description: In much of Latin America, the former Soviet Union and parts of Asia, employees of American companies face an increasing risk of being kidnapped. But the danger is far greater for wealthy local business people.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Diary column on the Personal Business page last Sunday, about baby boomers' responses to survey questions about their long-term health care, misstated an affiliation of Christopher Hayes, a gerontologist. He is an advisory board member of the General Electric Center for Financial Learning, which commissioned the survey, and co-director of the Center for Aging Research and Education, which conducted it. He is not an advisory board member of the General Electric Center for Aging Research and Care.

title: ROUTE 80 EMERGENCY
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week declared a state of emergency for Route 80 in Morris County, enabling the state to apply for federal financing for repairs. Interstate 80 was damaged when a June 22 accident ignited 8,200 gallons of gasoline, permanently damaging part of the roadway and a bridge. Mr. DiFrancesco authorized the state Department of Transportation to take any measure necessary to repair the damage and to apply for financing from the Federal Highway Administration. Anne Ruderman

title: Iran's Reformers Set Out to Save the Economy
description: Iran's reformers, fresh from a thumping victory in presidential elections last month, have quickly set their sights on prying open an economy virtually sealed shut since the 1979 Islamic revolution.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 8, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Private Sector; Be Patient, for Grandpa's Sake
description: Gary C. Wendt has been in the public spotlight more for his contested 1997 divorce than for his stewardship of Conseco, the once-ailing insurance and finance company based in Carmel, Ind. The divorce, in which he paid his first wife, Lorna, $20 million after she argued that she had contributed to his success, made national headlines. That hasn't stopped Mr. Wendt from talking about personal matters in official correspondence with shareholders.

title: Inequality in the AIDS Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Creating a Mood
description: To the Editor:

title: New York State of Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Only You Can Save Your Sons'
description: On a hot night last August in a small Russian town on the banks of the Volga River, Yelena Arefieva heard a knocking and someone crying: Mama. Mama. Mama. ''I jumped like a cat to the door,'' she said, but there were only mosquitoes buzzing in the stairwell, for the cries were in her dreams. A few days later, Yelena received a letter from a young police investigator just back from serving three months in Chechnya. It was about her son, Denis, a 19-year-old junior sergeant with an artillery unit who had been sent to Chechnya in June. ''I've been thinking for a long time how to write you and decided to write everything that I know, although this letter will not bring you joy. Your son and another boy from his unit, Aleksandr Chernikov, are in captivity. The Chechens want to exchange them for two relatives of their field commander D. . . .''

title: Transcript of Buster Olney's Visit to the Yankees Forum
description: Buster Olney, who covers the Yankees for The Times, visited the forum on Thursday, July 5, to discuss the team. Here is a transcript.

title: Greenport Gentrifies: A Waterfront Facelift
description: WITH a ribbon-cutting ceremony attended by Governor Pataki, Mitchell Park opened in the heart of downtown Greenport on June 29, capping a six-year effort spearheaded by Mayor David E. Kapell.

title: The Rich Aren't That Different: Their Funds Can Plummet, Too
description: IN 1999, the Nicholas-Applegate Global Technology fund soared 493 percent, making it that year's hottest performer. At the time, it seemed testimony to the adage: ''the rich get richer.''

title: A Longtime Star Hopes It's a Short-Term Slump
description: Thomas F. Marsico, a star stock picker who had a knack for spotting small technology companies on the verge of becoming big hits, had become used to highflying returns  but now he has seen his large-capitalization growth funds take a nose dive.

title: Travel Advisory
description: High Above Niagara's Waters

title: SOAPBOX; The Land of the Free
description: I LIKE free stuff. I think. I mean it's easy to come by, but most of it is supplied by some marketing department that wants to make me an offer -- not an offer I can't refuse, but one I can't use. There are plenty of examples of this pale generosity:

title: White House Asks Court for Voucher Ruling
description: In the first sign that a new legal team is shaping the government's advocacy before the Supreme Court, the Bush administration is asking the justices to uphold an Ohio program that offers Cleveland parents tuition assistance to send their children to private schools, including religious schools.

title: Casino to Hire From Puerto Rico, Prompting Concerns Over Influx
description: Local officials in eastern Connecticut are worried that a casino's plan to hire more than 170 card dealers from Puerto Rico will overtax housing and education resources.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVIN, MELVIN R.
description: LEVIN-Melvin R. Always remembered. Wife, son, daughter, granddaughters, grandsons, and great grandson Mel.

title: BEACH SMOKING
description: Belmar became the only New Jersey beach community and one of the few in the nation to limit smoking on the beach and boardwalk. Yet the police are simply issuing warnings rather than summonses this summer; violators could receive fines of up to $100 and two days of community service picking up cigarette butts. Belmar's police chief, Richard Lynch, said ''There has been a little grumbling, but so far everyone is cooperating.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIRD, ROBERT W., M.D.
description: BAIRD-Robert W., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Robert W. Baird, M.D., a longtime member of the medical staff at the hospital's Singer Division and a philanthropic supporter of many of Beth Israel's programs and initiatives. Dr. Baird forever will be remembered for his selfless generosity, gregarious personality and, above all else, his commitment to quality patient care. To his family, friends and loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President, Medical Board Martin M. Feuer, M.D. Associate Chairman, Department of Medicine-Singer Division Robert L. Salant, M.D., President Doctors Alumni Association

title: Private Sector; Going a Mile High and Back Over an Unwanted Nickname
description: Pop quiz: You are the chief executive of a major financial company. You commit $60 million over 20 years to have your company's name on the new stadium of the Denver Broncos of the National Football League. One of your subordinates tells a local sports columnist that company wags have nicknamed the stadium ''the Diaphragm.'' As in the birth control device. The columnist prints it.

title: Is It the Traffic Or the Orthodox Jews?
description: The self-hating Jews of the Peninsula Environmental Conservancy should listen to the following words: they think that they are hiding behind the curtain of environmentalism, but their underlying agenda ist as clear as a windowpane.

title: F.Y.I.
description: An Elephant's Demise

title: Death Penalty Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A roundup of music events last week misstated the date of a concert by the New York Philharmonic at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. The concert, which begins at 8 p.m., will be on Saturday July 14, not July 24.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Premiere at White Barn

title: Hedi Slimane Puts the Sexy in Suit
description: Just when the French men's shows were beginning to seem old hat, along came Hedi Slimane with a springtime collection for Dior that was a tabula rasa of sexy manhood on the march.

title: The Power Of Choice
description: AT sparsely attended committee hearings in the State House this spring, senators concerned about the blackouts rolling through California peppered state regulators with questions about electric power.

title: The World: Disarm, or Else; In Northern Ireland, Saving the Toughest Issue for Last
description: THE negotiators responsible for building a government here that can withstand the buffeting of Northern Ireland's fractious and violent society have tried a risky construction technique. They filled in the higher floors initially and hoped the confidence-building measures they installed there would become the bricks and mortar needed to build the foundation later.

title: Streetscapes/Fifth Avenue in the East 80's; On Met Museum's Facade, the Sculptures That Aren't
description: FINALLY, last month, it looked for a moment as if the carving had started. A worker high above the main entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art brought out mallet and chisel and began taking fist-sized chunks off four groups of stone blocks that for almost a century have remained uncarved above the columns at the museum's main entrance. But it was not to be. The Met said it was only routine maintenance undertaken every spring, chipping away loose stone.

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: Would you describe people who are afflicted with H.I.V., epilepsy, diabetes, heart disease or cancer as ''stalkers'' if they protested the loss of their medication? Dr. Steere's influence has already translated into a rationale allowing insurance companies to reject treatment claims.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the changing nature of affirmative action misstated the principal finding of the Supreme Court's 1978 Bakke decision. The court did not uphold the racial quota system used by the University of California at Davis; it struck it down as unconstitutional. However, the court's controlling opinion, written by Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., said that campus diversity could be weighed as one factor among many in admissions.

title: Islanders Sign Bates, A Former Bruin
description: The Islanders signed the free-agent forward Shawn Bates to a two-year contract, the team said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGANN, GEORGE
description: MCGANN-George. Age 88 at his home in San Miguel De Allende, June 28. Retired editor & manager of the New York office of Australian Consolidated Press. A tennis authority, he covered tennis and other news, and wrote ''Court on Court'' with Margaret Smith Court and ''Court Hustler'' with Bobby Riggs. Survived by his wife Louise, brother Gerald, sister Marie Fletcher, daughter Pat McGann, three granddaughters and two great-grandsons. Address, APDO 109, San Miguel De Allende, GTO., Mexico 37700.

title: A High School Class Tries to Restore the Elm
description: EVERY few minutes, the crow of a nearby rooster screeches through the silence. Five students, caked with mud, stay on task despite the racket, digging hole after hole to plant their elm trees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDEL, REV. JOHN W., JR.
description: HANDEL-Rev. John W., Jr. On July 2nd, 2001, of Newport, RI, former resident of Sovereign, E. 58th St., Manhattan. Beloved husband of the late Peta Paul. Fond cousin of James A. Young and family. Veteran of U.S. Navy, serving proudly both W.W. II and Korean War. Graduated with honors from Dartmouth University, completing his graduate studies at the University of Heidelberg, Germany. Longtime member of NY Yacht Club. Crew member of ''Constellation,'' winning America's Cup in 1964. Worked on Wall Street-Financial District many years. Loved to ski, sail and travel, making many friends across the U.S. and around the globe. Reposing at Krauss Funeral Home, Inc., 1097 Hempstead Turnpike, Franklin Square, Monday, July 9th, 2-5, 7-10 PM. Funeral Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Bush Weighs a Decision on Stem Cell Research Amid Reminders of Suffering
description: As President Bush inches closer to a decision about federal support for embryonic stem cell research, he is surrounded by reminders -- in Republican circles, in his White House and even in his family's past -- of the lives diminished by afflictions that the research might help fight.

title: Arms Shipments Sent to Iran Via Queens Company, U.S. Says
description: A German businessman has been arrested by United States Customs agents in Arizona and accused of exporting parts for military aircraft to Iran using a Queens-based freight company.

title: Sports of The Times; Remember Virginia Wade's Championship? The British Don't Seem To
description: TIM HENMAN was 3 years old when Virginia Wade held the championship plate that Venus Williams or Justine Henin will loft today, weather permitting. Wade, the last British Wimbledon champion, has been an overlooked phenomenon here in the madness of a possible end to a 65-year male drought.

title: It's Only Rhyming Quatrains, But I Like It
description: In the last days of the Beatles, as things were starting to come apart, the band formed a record label called Zapple. The idea -- or lark, really -- was to record experimental music and spoken word, starting with the poets who had become the band's friends. The orbits of rock and poetry were pushing at each other: musicians like Bob Dylan or Joni Mitchell were starting to claim the mantle of poets, and the Beats were hanging with rock stars, enjoying a small piece of the reflected adulation. Why not merge the two in one grand goof? It got off to a promising start. Allen Ginsberg, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Richard Brautigan and Charles Olson put themselves on tape, and Michael McClure, the West Coast poet, volunteered to play his autoharp -- a gift from Bob Dylan -- behind the verses of a Hell's Angel named Freewheelin' Frank. But Zapple folded after just two albums, and within a year, the Beatles disbanded.

title: Budget Battle in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: No Boardwalk or Top Hat, But It Does Have a Small Cap
description: MUTUAL MANIA. The very name seemed an oxymoron as I peeled off the shrink-wrapped plastic and prepared to put what I must hope is the world's only board game about mutual funds through its paces. ''Play it . . . for love of the gain!'' the box chirped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOD, DALE L.
description: GOOD-Dale L. On June 17, 2001, in Evanston, IL. University of Chicago and University of London graduate. Last served as editorial director at Compton's Encyclopedia. Formerly at Funk & Wagnalls and Random House. Survived by children Aaron and Julia, whose mother is Sharon Lieberman.

title: Lack of Coverage
description: To the editor:

title: Word for Word/The Long Gray Line; For Tomorrow's Army, Cadets Full of Questions
description: THERE is the reassuring sense of a permanent Fourth of July here: of deeply rooted national purpose and pride, of courage, optimism. Wholesome cadets in vintage gray tunics snap salutes and hold seminars on the ''warrior ethic,'' with the stirring words of Douglas MacArthur etched into their souls as firmly as they are in the granite pedestal of his monument: ''Your mission remains fixed, determined, inviolable -- it is to win our wars. All other public purposes will find others for their accomplishment. Yours is the profession of arms -- the will to win, the sure knowledge that in war there is no substitute for victory, that the very obsession of your public service must be duty, honor, country.''

title: His Job Is to Keep the Legend Going
description: IT used to be a given at Wal-Mart's annual shareholder meeting: A country music band would take the stage as a kind of seventh-inning diversion for everyone packed into the Bud Walton Arena in Fayetteville, Ark., named for the brother of Wal-Mart's founder and a short hop from the company's headquarters in Bentonville.

title: Making the Cut
description: Gardeners who have fought the battle of the dandelion in their own backyards could probably use some motivation. For them, Briggs & Stratton, which manufactures lawnmower engines, has come up with a listing of the top 10 lawns in the United States, as selected by garden writers, turf experts and company officials. This year's honorees include the Boston Public Garden, Grant Park in Chicago, the Kentucky Horse Park in Lexington and the Texas State Capitol in Austin. For the complete listing, call up www.toptenlawns.com.

title: Economic Cooperation Planned
description: Finance ministers of the seven leading industrial nations appeared uncertain at a meeting in Rome today about whether the worst of the world's faltering economy has been reached, but agreed to draw back from sharpening differences and focus on greater cooperation.

title: Letters: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, BETTY
description: LEIBOWITZ-Betty. Beloved wife of the late George, died July 5, 2001, in Boca Raton, FL. Adored sister of Eleanor Ruda, Richard and Barbara Marks, treasured aunt of Nancy and Samantha Liebowitz, Jay, Stuart and Meryl Ruda, and Leslie, and great-aunt to their dear children. Betty will be remembered in our hearts forever. A graveside service is scheduled for 1 PM, Sunday, in the Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. Susan and Sol

title: Johnson Wins Unanimous Decision as Part of Lively Card in Brooklyn
description: In the shadows of the Cyclone and Astroland, lit by a full moon nearly hidden by the neon green Nathan's sign, boxing arrived in Coney Island last night.

title: Daniela Gil, Avi Rosenblatt
description: Daniela Simone Gil, a daughter of Regina Keller Gil and Joseph Gil of Great Neck, N.Y., was married on Wednesday to Andrew Seth Rosenblatt, a son of Judith Turk Rosenblatt and Gary S. Rosenblatt of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Yosef Adler performed the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Making Poetic Riffs To the Rhythm of Bombs
description: IN an outdoor cafe overlooking the spot where the muddy Sava River flows into the blue Danube, Maja Mitic, an actress in Belgrade's most prominent theater troupe, Dah Teatar, tells a story that mixes the sweetness of childhood memory with the brutality of Yugoslavia's war-plagued past.

title: Rotterdam
description: When German bombers circled over the Netherlands on May 14, 1940, they left Rotterdam devastated. And that was just the beginning of five years of war and occupation. No wonder that some see the choice of Rotterdam as Cultural Capital of Europe this year, with Oporto in Portugal, as entirely fitting. The city has succeeded not only in rebuilding itself physically but also in resuscitating a lively cultural climate in which experiment is welcomed.

title: The Week in Review: July 1-7
description: Milosevic Faces Tribunal

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle on June 24 gave an incorrect clue for 88 Across, ''2000 Heisman Trophy winner Dayne.'' The diagram called for ''Ron.'' But in fact the winner of the 2000 Heisman Trophy was Chris Weinke; Ron Dayne won it in 1999.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Michael Useem, 58

title: Our Towns; Don't Go in the Water, or the Sun, or the Shade, Or . . .
description: AH, summertime.

title: Great Outdoor Games, Part 2
description: The Great Outdoor Games, a four-day skills and strength competition created and organized by ESPN, will return for its second year, beginning Thursday in Lake Placid, N.Y. More than 300 of the world's best competitors will vie in 21 events in four sport categories -- fishing, timber events, sporting dogs and target sports. Nineteen hours of the competition will be telecast from July 26-Aug. 3. on ESPN.

title: Who's Minding the Rides?; Accidents at Amusement Parks Raise Questions About Safety
description: WILLIAM CALOVINE had just arrived at Lake Compounce on a steamy June morning when he spotted the Zoomerang, a steel roller coaster with the kind of twists and loops that appealed to this coaster lover. So the Bridgeport resident, who was chaperoning his daughter's class trip to the park, escorted a handful of fifth-grade students onto the ride, expecting a few seconds worth of thrills.

title: Life Lessons Via Brooklyn
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Finding Jazz's Soul In Africa's Music
description: IN 1934, Paul Robeson wrote of his desire to study West African ''folk song and folklore.'' Already a legend of stage and screen, Robeson was less interested in celebrity than in introducing the world to the beauty and power of African art. ''I am convinced that there lies a wealth of unchartered musical material in that source which I hope, one day, will evoke the response in English and American audiences which my Negro spirituals have done.'' Robeson's unfulfilled dream of collecting and interpreting the ''unchartered musical material'' of Africa has been taken up by the pianist and composer Randy Weston.

title: July 1-7; Price-Gouging by Race
description: Blacks consistently paid more than whites to finance a car through a Nissan dealership, according to a study of more than 300,000 car loans made since 1993. Lenders like the financing unit of Nissan, which are careful not to discriminate when quoting their own rate, allow dealers to quietly raise it by up to five percentage points and to keep most of the money that dealer markup generates. The study, done for plaintiffs suing the Nissan unit in Nashville, found that blacks paid a higher markup than whites, even when their credit histories were the same. Diana B. Henriques

title: Playing Hide and Seek With the Monster Bluefish
description: By the time the captain, David Blinken, turned the stubby nose of his 17-foot flats skiff into the sheltered cove where we hoped to fish, it was clear that if a day can be described in psychiatric terms, this one was manic-depressive. Just hours earlier, under bright and balmy June skies, Blinken had been poling me and the photographer Richard Franklin along the open, shallow flats of Napeague Bay as we made delicate presentations with small, feathery flies to visible striped bass in the 6- to 10-pound class.

title: Q and A
description: Cognac Tours

title: The Cult and Monster Magnet
description: The Cult has been chugging out its heavy brand of muscular rock 'n' roll for over a decade. Predating such bands as Nirvana and Soundgarden, the Cult is often credited with setting the scene for the grunge phenomenon. Whether the band's mood is melodic, pummeling or psychedelic, it is always heavy. Joining the Cult is Monster Magnet, a heavy-metal band that is slowly, but surely, becoming one of New Jersey's most popular rock groups. They perform at 7:30 p.m. Friday at Convention Hall, 1306 Ocean Avenue, Asbury Park.

title: Bin Hu, Erik Laurence
description: Bin Hu and Erik Jonathan Laurence were married yesterday at the de Seversky Culinary Arts Center at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y. The Rev. Karl Gillmeister, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPPELL, LYDIA HATFIELD
description: CHAPPELL-Lydia Hatfield. Lydia Hatfield Chappell, widow of the artist, illustrator, book designer and author Warren Chappell, died June 25, 2001, at her home in Charlottesville, Virginia. She was 93. The Chappells lived in New York City and Norwalk, Connecticut for many years before moving to Charlottesville in 1978, where Warren Chappell was an Artist-in-Residence at the University of Virginia. Mrs. Chappell is survived by her brother, Weston P. Hatfield of Winston-Salem, North Carolina and Washington, D.C. A service will be held for both Lydia and Warren Chappell in the McGregor Room of the Alderman Libary at the University of Virginia on Friday, July 27, at 1 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Hatfield/Chappell Library Fund, Alderman Library, University of Virginia, P.O. Box 40014, Charlottesville, VA 22904-0014. Andrea Hatfield (202) 363-4294

title: Tajik Journalist Is Held in Moscow
description: In a move denounced by human rights advocates Friday, the Russian authorities have detained a dissident Tajik journalist at the request of Tajikistan's government, which is charging the journalist with insulting the president, a crime in the Central Asian country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORRIGAN, PAUL
description: CORRIGAN-Paul. In loving memory into eternity.

title: Talk-to-Yourself Radio
description: Jack Hitt (June 17) captured the hilarity of Phil Hendrie's show with the voices of its wacky guests. But he described the humorless listeners who don't realize it's shtick as ''the kind of people who regularly call up Rush Limbaugh.'' Believe me, when Hendrie had as a ''guest'' a man who had joined N.O.W. because ''it's a great place to meet chicks,'' the angry women who called in were not Rush fans.

title: A Historic Lamp Is Lost. Fingers Are Pointed Everywhere.
description: Where is the handsome turn-of-the-century lamp that once stood with its mate on the Queensboro Bridge? That's a tricky question.

title: An Indoor Family Goes Outdoors
description: THE key moment in our trip to Lake Tahoe occurred very early, just minutes after our arrival at the Sunnyside Resort, when my wife and two daughters walked to the window of our lakefront room, peeled back the curtains to reveal the roiling, mountain-ringed waters and saw, a few yards away, a sign that read in block letters: ''Water Ski Lessons.''

title: Mercury and Jupiter
description: It will be worth losing some sleep this week to arise around 4:30 a.m. At that hour, very low to the east-northeast, the planets Mercury and Jupiter may be visible.

title: July 1-7; Cease-fire in Macedonia
description: The Macedonian government and Albanian rebels signed a cease-fire to halt four months of fighting that many feared could erupt into another war in the Balkans. But the cease-fire was only the first, and perhaps the simplest, step toward peace. The next is negotiating a political settlement -- a proposal was drafted at the end of the week by experts from the U.S. and Europe -- to expand the rights of ethnic Albanians, who make up about a third of the population. If it succeeds, 3,000 NATO troops will arrive soon to disarm the rebels. If it fails, more fighting is expected. Ian Fisher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVI, LOUIS H.
description: LEVI-Louis H. Age 76, beloved Columbia University teacher and jazz musician; husband of Martee; father of Claudia Levi, and stepfather of Lane Coggin.

title: Making Exceptions
description: Renaissance Cruises has eased two of its rules: its no-smoking and no-children policies. Beginning with departures on Dec. 1, limited areas on its ships will be designated for smokers; the line says 98 percent of the ships will remain smoke-free. And children 2 or older will be allowed.

title: American Independence
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article and a listing of accommodations on June 24 about Lord Howe Island, off Australia, inaccurately described a Web site and misstated its affiliation. The site, www.lordhowe/com.au, is a private site, not a government one, and it is not a source for information about Capella Lodge. (It is, in fact, the site for another hotel.) The lodge's site is www.lordhowe.com. (There is no ''au'' at the end of the address.)

title: July 1-7; Nominee for F.B.I. Director
description: After a two-month search, President Bush named a veteran prosecutor, Robert S. Mueller III, to succeed Louis J. Freeh as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Mueller, if confirmed by the Senate, will be charged with overhauling an agency that has been under fire for managerial lapses and mistakes, like the belated discovery of investigative reports in the Oklahoma City bombing case that forced a month's delay in the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh. Associates say he is up to the task.

title: Private Sector; An Outsider Takes On the Swiss
description: ASHER B. EDELMAN has long thought of himself as an activist investor who buys stakes in undervalued companies, hoping to make them more efficient and valuable. But Mr. Edelman's most recent target, a venerable and sleepy Swiss paper company, has thrust him into a struggle for change in Swiss banking and business.

title: 'Shot Heard Round the World' Echoes, 50 Years Later
description: Nearly two weeks ago, a few days after the death of his son, Bobby Thomson stood at the podium of HBO's theater in Manhattan, praising ''Shot Heard Round the World,' the network's new documentary about the former New York Giants third baseman's historic playoff home run against Brooklyn in 1951.

title: Bush's Warm Embrace Could Cool Schundler Voters
description: In the days since his stunning victory in New Jersey's Republican gubernatorial primary, it has at times appeared that Bret D. Schundler might be running for Governor of Washington, D.C.

title: Smokes Fan the Flames
description: IT was midafternoon on a recent Sunday and more than 100 members of the Unkechaug Indian nation gathered on the pow-wow grounds at their tiny reservation in a corner of Mastic to celebrate the abundance of nature.

title: City Honors Its Home Run King
description: ON Saturday, June 30, some 100 devotees of baseball and local history gathered at the grave of Roger Connor, a slugging left-handed first baseman from Waterbury and one of four baseball Hall of Famers born in Connecticut. (The others are Jim O'Rourke of East Bridgeport, Ned Hanlon of Montville and Morgan Bulkeley of East Haddam.)

title: Serving It Up, With Ladle and Lip
description: A SUMMER squall has rushed in, and it doesn't seem like a good business day for Pat Tirotta, who has been behind the counter since 3 a.m. except for the hour he spent at church on this Sunday morning.

title: A Civil Ending?
description: AN HONORABLE DEFEAT The Last Days of the Confederate Government. By William C. Davis. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: Harcourt. $30.

title: UPDATES: Western Queens, New Yorkl Close-Up
description: WESTERN QUEENS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ELLIOT
description: BERNSTEIN-Elliot. 78, on July 6, 2001, of Glencove, NY. Loving husband of Sybil. Father of Alexander, Steven, Daniel and Adam. Beloved brother of Howard Bernstein and Serina Bardell. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Sarah, Anna Rose, Douglas and Drew Bernstein. Contact Guttermans Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, NY, for services on Monday, July 9, 516-764-9400 Consideration can be made to the Andrew J. Bernstein Foundation.

title: The View From/Bridgeport; Diving Into What Was Once Only a Man's World
description: DURING the more than 25 years since she became the first deep-sea diver in the United States Navy, Donna Tobias did not talk much about her pioneering achievements.

title: July 1-7; Bush Calls Beijing
description: As the much-disputed remains of an American spy plane left China en route back to the United States, President Bush and President Jiang Zemin spoke for the first time. Mr. Bush telephoned to say he hoped to start a new, open dialogue with Beijing, but first China must resolve the cases of two American citizens and several permanent residents who have been arrested on spying charges. There are signs that trials may begin soon, and upon conviction -- of which, given the Chinese criminal system, there is little doubt -- the defendants may be expelled. David E. Sanger

title: Too Idealistic
description: To the Editor:

title: July 1-7; Russian Air Crash Kills 145
description: A Tupolev-154 airliner crashed into a Siberian meadow, killing all 145 on board. The accident was the worst since the mid-1990's, when another Tupolev carrying Russian and Ukrainian miners to a Norwegian island crashed, killing the same number. Russian authorities have ruled out early theories of a bomb. Sabrina Tavernise

title: The World; Where a Little Coca Is as Good as Gold
description: THE DRUG CENTER, the only pharmacy in the stiflingly hot jungle town of Camelias, deep in southern Colombia, looks ordinary, with wide glass counters and shelves stacked high with medicines. Then the customer pays the bill.

title: Reckonings; A Leap In the Dark
description: In a way, I wish that I had more negative things to say about the Japanese executives and officials I spoke to over the last few days. If the executives had been obviously out of touch with the realities of modern business, if the officials had been obstinate and foolish, it would be easy to dismiss Japan's economic malaise as the product of a deeply flawed social and political system -- something that couldn't happen in America.

title: Still Thriving and Living Up to the Billing
description: FROM time to time we revisit restaurants that were previously reviewed. Things change, perhaps nowhere so often as at restaurants.

title: Filling Up On Irish Hospitality
description: WHENEVER possible, I like to reinvent the wheel, so I avoid travel packages. But my wonderful travel agent, Nella, said, ''There are great bed-and-breakfast and car rental packages in Ireland,'' naming a price that seemed way too good to pass up.

title: JANITORS' AGREEMENT
description: The Service Employees International janitorial workers union, announced last week that it reached an agreement with 23 janitorial firms in Hudson County to increase the wages for close to 500 workers from $5.25 an hour to $10.75 over three years. In addition, some employees will receive health benefits for the first time. The contract, which goes into effect on Sept. 1, will be available to custodial workers who sign with the service employees union, which as part of a national campaign to unionize janitors, is working on similar deals with Bergen, Morris, Essex and Middlesex Counties. John Holl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTTER, DR. RUDOLF G.E.
description: HUTTER-Dr. Rudolf G.E. A retired physicist, is listed in the ''Who's Who of America.'' He died in Palm Beach, FL. He lived at 445 E. 80th St, in Manhattan. His first wife, Ruth Hutter, now deceased, was a math teacher at the Chapin School on Manhattan's east side. He graduated with a Ph.D. in physics from Stanford University. He was a Professor at Stanford and The Polythecnic Institute of New York in Brooklyn. He worked at Sylvania and retired as Chief Engineer at G.T.E. He authored the book ''Beam And Wave Electronics In Microwave Tubes.'' He was a member of Sigma Xi, RESA, and Fellow, Institute of Radio Engineers. He will be remembered as a mathematical genius and he was one of Albert Einstein's students in his native Germany. He leaves behind his wife Mrs. Pamela Hutter and family, and his daughter Mrs. Barbara Manford and family of Hopkinton, MA. A memorial service will be held for him in his honor at the Church of the Advent Hope. He was a lovely man and will be sorely missed.

title: STYLE; Out There
description: Standing at the border of one of the last divided capitals in the world, Hussein Chalayan is momentarily at a loss for words. Even his cell phone has given up. The chain-link fence we are peering through staggers under the weight of its floral bouquet. Just on the other side lies the buffer zone, where garlands of barbed wire festoon bullet-pocked concrete and rusty oil drums. Beyond that, a space of suspended imagination.

title: Michelle Steindecker, William Spielfogel
description: Michelle Dena Steindecker and Dr. William David Spielfogel were married on Tuesday by Rabbi Jacob J. Greenberg at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: Money Is Withdrawn For Pesticide Testing
description: YEARS after they were banned for use on farm fields in Suffolk County, agricultural pesticides continue to contaminate drinking water consumed by thousands of East End residents, testing of water samples by county health officials has revealed.

title: Corrections
description: Aclassical music listing on Page 35 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the time for a piano recital by Anne Queffelec at the Frick Collection on Thursday. It is at 5:45 p.m., not 4:45.

title: Here's to a Really Useful Machine
description: STEVEN SPIELBERG'S latest movie, ''A.I.,'' depicts the futuristic concept of a robot boy with artificial intelligence. The reality of a truly emotive robot seems a long way off (possibly even longer than the movie itself). In the interim, we should focus on some things that are less daunting -- and more easily attainable -- that capitalize on existing technology:

title: NEW YORK UP CLOSE
description: A federal judge in Washington last week dismissed a lawsuit filed by animal rights groups against Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey.

title: To Withstand The Surf
description: Even the most serious handbag devotees need a vacation from Prada and Gucci. To this end, retailers are pitching rubber -- in the form of tote bags and accessories, chic enough for city use but rugged enough for beachside outings. Beach bags by Claudia Rapisarda (center; $58 at Henri Bendel) are rubber through and through, as are similar bags by Furla at Saks Fifth Avenue ($90) -- all the easier to hose down after a sandy day. At Banana Republic, rectangular jellies market bags (above left) come in an array of solid candy colors, with sturdy leather shoulder straps ($24). Taking a more whimsical approach, Noir has designed a bright green pocketbook that resembles an old-time bathing cap, complete with a floppy flower ornaments and handles made of clear rubber tubing (above right; $89 at Barneys New York).

title: The Forecast Follies
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTERN QUEENS
description: Our World Neighborhood Charter School will not open this fall as anticipated, because plans for a location fell through. The school had received a state charter, and about 400 students from District 30, which covers much of western Queens, entered a lottery for admission; 250 were admitted.

title: Full Night, But Not Fulfilling
description: NOTHING familiar. A new way of looking at the old and the obscure. Such are the ways of the new artistic regime at the Westport Country Playhouse.

title: The Reproducers
description: THE COOPERATIVE GENE How Mendel's Demon Explains the Evolution of Complex Beings. By Mark Ridley. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York: The Free Press. $26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHTER, MARY S.
description: LEICHTER-Mary S. Helped by many doctors, especially those at New York Cornell, Mary waged a courageous and gracious fight for three and a half years, but the end came on July 7. Loving wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Pamela, Adam, Christopher and Adrian, and daughters-in-law Emily and Charlene. Cherished sister of Ann and the late Andrew. Services at Krtil F.H., 1297 1st Ave (70th St), Tuesday, July 10, at 7 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Cancer Care would be appreciated.

title: Evoking the Season
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fighter Is Hired to Protect the Abused
description: MARYELLEN MARTIRANO'S office was, by her own admission, a mess. She had just finished prosecuting a lengthy child abuse trial in which the suspect was accused of repeatedly sodomizing and raping a young girl. The trial, she said, ''consumed'' her.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Advancing Election Reform
description: Americans are still waiting for the federal government to step in to fix the numerous deficiencies in the nation's electoral process that were uncovered by last year's close presidential race. Members of Congress and President Bush will be politically foolish, not to mention neglectful in their duties, if they duck the problem and simply allow America's patchwork of thousands of underfinanced electoral jurisdictions to continue carrying on as if nothing had happened. Americans' right to vote, and the chances of having their ballots accurately tabulated, must not be diluted by their local government's neglect. There is a clear need for national standards governing how presidential elections are administered.

title: Rafter Is at Ease as He Faces His Best Last Chance
description: In a pocket of Brisbane, Australia, eight of the nine Rafter children jockeyed for bunk space inside a home with a limited number of rooms.

title: Some Chimps Are Too Smart for Their Own Good
description: When Hugo Archibaold (Lance Guest), an anthropoligist, returns home from his most recent trip to Africa, his luggage contains an unwelcome guest: Jennie, a baby chimp whose mother has been killed by poachers. Jennie becomes part of the dysfunctional Archibald family, but when she begins to show almost-human traits, like a knack for sign languauge, she ends up in a chimpanzee research program -- and the Archibalds, including 12-year-old Andrew (Alex D. Linz, below), soon discover how much they want her back.

title: July 1-7; Milosevic Faces Tribunal
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, made his first appearance before the United Nations war crimes tribunal after having been spirited to The Hague from his Belgrade prison cell. Calling the court ''illegal,'' he refused to enter a plea on charges of war crimes linked to the 1999 war in Kosovo and tried to use the moment to denounce NATO. But the imperturbable presiding judge, Richard May of Britain, cut off his microphone and entered a plea of not guilty for him. Marlise Simons

title: Ventura Will Rest
description: Mets third baseman Robin Ventura, who jammed his right shoulder diving for a ground ball on Friday, will not play tonight. Ventura said he hoped to be able to play Thursday, after the three-day All-Star Game break, but he was not sure if he could. Ventura, who said he is having trouble raising his right hand over his head, will not have an M.R.I. test, he said. Tyler Kepner

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CLEAN NEW WORLD

title: A Slip-On Computer For the Masses
description: READY to have access to your computer from your belt?

title: Rachel Rubenstein, John Demeny
description: Rachel Miriam Rubenstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Rubenstein of Westfield, N.J., was married last evening to John Demeny, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Demeny of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Nadia E. Gold officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Hahnah Kasowski, Robert Seminara
description: Dr. Hahnah Jean Kasowski, a daughter of Dr. Elaine M. Kasowski and Dr. Robert V. Kasowski of West Chester, Pa., was married last evening to Robert Vito Seminara, a son of Marie M. Seminara and Vincent F. Seminara of Tappan, N.Y. The Rev. Francis Maione, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del., with Rabbi Bernard Perelmuter taking part.

title: The Selection of a Poet Laureate Brings Lehman Into the Limelight
description: Bill Aguado, director of the Bronx Council of the Arts, has long admired the work of the poet Billy Collins. But until Mr. Collins was named poet laureate of the United States three weeks ago, he did not realize that Mr. Collins had worked for more than 30 years at Lehman College, 10 minutes from his office.

title: SOAPBOX; The Great Escape
description: I ROLL up my garage door. It makes the sound of a cranky old man being awakened unexpectedly from a sound sleep. There before me, in its eclectic splendor, lies my garage. A big boy's toy box. A place of infinite possibilities, reflecting years of acquisitions and years of refusal to discard even the most inconsequential items.

title: I.R.A. Guns and the Irish Impasse
description: To take up arms brings a sea of troubles, as the conflict in Northern Ireland bears witness. But deciding what to do with arms once the battles have ended has dangers of its own.

title: Tanger Steps Up to Lure Asian Customers
description: HANGING out at the mall is usually not on the agenda for the ambassador and consul general of China, Zhang Hongxi. A busy diplomat, he leaves that to his wife, Gong Zhanrong. ''I seldom go to shop,'' Mr. Zhang said. ''Shopping is a waste of time.''

title: Disappointing Damon Has Yet to Benefit Athletics
description: This was the trade that would catapult the Oakland Athletics to the top. But not just to the top of their division. To the top of the league. If anyone could topple the Yankees this season, it would be the Athletics because now they had Johnny Damon. Johnny Damon was the man.

title: Is There Room for Hot Dogs On This Crowded Corner?
description: The northeast corner of 79th Street and Fifth Avenue has a tall apartment building and the Steiner School, where children are dropped off and picked up mornings and afternoons. It has brontosaurus-size articulated buses, often two at a time, lingering at a bus stop. It has an egress from Central Park. It has telephone, electric and cable workers excavating the street for new lines. And it has one lone hot-dog vendor with a silver cart.

title: Instant Green Card
description: I GOT off the 7 train on Roosevelt Avenue on the border of Elmhurst and Jackson Heights, Queens, and roamed around. A man in his 50's stood in front of a store.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Living with Music

title: In G.E.'s Wake, PCB's in the River
description: To the Editor:

title: As California Thirsts, Dams Make Comeback
description: At a photo opportunity three years ago, the Clinton administration's interior secretary, Bruce Babbitt, took a sledge hammer to the soon-to-be-dismantled McPherrin Dam in California's Central Valley and declared that the era of great dam building in the West was over. Environmentalists had long argued that many dams did more harm than good, and after years of battling, the government agreed.

title: Guthrie Birchfield, Peter Schweitzer
description: Guthrie Kathryn Birchfield and Peter Harry Schweitzer were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Kermit Birchfield Jr. of Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Fayette Severance, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: In Santa Fe, Searching for the Meaning of Beauty
description: DAVE HICKEY has a recurring nightmare. He's sitting in an Eastside restaurant at an interminable dinner with Karl Marx (now a tenured professor at Duke) and Montesquieu (recently uplifted from a down period by receipt of a MacArthur Foundation ''genius'' award and a stipend from the French government). These two enjoy fine wines and bemoan the current state of art while Mr. Hickey sits off to the side cracking breadsticks and trying to conjure up an idea for an article that some magazine might buy so he can afford more breadsticks.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; A Hulking Factory Is Given New Life in Norwalk
description: FOR half a century a hulking 140,000-square-foot brick building loomed half-vacant and deteriorating over the corner of Marshall and North Water Streets in South Norwalk. In recent years it became a pariah amid its historic neighbors: the Maritime Aquarium across the street, the shops and restaurants around the corner on Washington Street, and the spreading development of the waterfront under urban renewal.

title: The Nation: Look Sharp; Trying to Run a Country Like a Corporation
description: WHEN President Bush was sworn in nearly six months ago, Washington was awash with loose talk of a ''C.E.O. presidency.'' The first president with an M.B.A. to his name, from Harvard Business School no less, would be the chairman of the board of the world's biggest conglomerate, his aides boasted, a leader who delegated to his cabinet of experienced C.E.O.'s.

title: A Beach to Some, It's Home to Others
description: WHO needs the Hamptons? Who needs hours stuck on the L.I.E. when you can cruise over the Atlantic Beach Bridge at the foot of Doughty Boulevard, pay a miserly $1.25 toll and be in downtown Atlantic Beach, yards from a 1.5-mile strip of gentle Atlantic Ocean frontage?

title: A Pompeii in Slow Motion
description: ON the boggy coastal moors of County Mayo in northwest Ireland lies one of the largest Stone Age sites in the world -- though it might not seem obvious at first glance.

title: A Genre of the Intellect With Little Use for Ideas
description: EVEN though film rights to Octavia Butler's 1979 novel ''Kindred'' have been under option almost continuously since the book was published, a screen version will not be at the multiplex any time soon. ''They just can't raise the money'' for a film adaptation, says Ms. Butler, the only science fiction writer to win a MacArthur Foundation genius grant.

title: July 1-7; A Confession of Spying
description: Robert P. Hanssen, the former F.B.I. counterintelligence expert, pleaded guilty to charges that he had spied for Moscow since 1985, handing over many of the nation's most sensitive secrets. In return, the government will not seek the death penalty; the sentence will be life without parole. But first he must undergo extensive debriefings on the full extent of his espionage. James Risen

title: Plants That Foil Fickle Weather
description: MUCH to their dismay, gardeners in many parts of the country have seen their plants devastated by weather extremes in the past few years. Through sheer serendipity, many of my perennials have not been affected by watering restrictions and record droughts, weeks of unrelenting high heat and humidity, and the flooding downpours of hurricanes. They have boldly flowered on. Their only requirements are good drainage and reasonably fertile soil.

title: Samantha McGill, Thomas McKevitt
description: Samantha Wainwright McGill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McGill of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas McKevitt Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McKevitt of East Meadow, N.Y. Msgr. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, JEFFREY
description: MEYER-Jeffrey. A classical music expert who represented various recording labels such as Delos International, Albany Music, and Qualiton, died Saturday, June 30, 2001, at his home in Marietta, Georgia, after a long and courageus battle with cancer. Mr. Meyer, also a fine and rare antique jewelry broker of fine jewelry was key in providing law enforcement with breakthrough information leading to the return of millions of dollars of jewelry taken from the home of a prominent Palm Beach socialite. His life partner, Peter Bathhaung, his parents Samuel and Hermoine Meyer of Springfield, IL, brother Dr. Jon Meyer and wife Eleanor Meyer of Milwaukee, WI, a nephew David Meyer of Honolulu and niece Laura Meyer of Durham, NC, survive him. For further informaton, contact H. M. Patterson & Son Canton Hill, Marietta, Georgia.

title: "The Girl From Purple Mountain: Love, Honor, War, and One Family's Journey From China to America"
description: My mother was buried alone, surrounded by strangers, the way she wished, in a New York mausoleum auspiciously bearing the name of her college dorm. Ferncliff. She had changed her burial plans secretly, with the help of my youngest brother. A decade earlier, my parents had bought side-by-side plots. My father had thought the matter was all settled.

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: I am a pediatrician in southern New Jersey, where Lyme disease is indigenous. I have great respect for Dr. Steere. We have seen many parents of children treated by local ''Lymeologists'' who have made treating Lyme disease a cottage industry and have mistreated many adult patients by using long-term intravenous antibiotics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, NAT
description: GREENBAUM-Nat. On July 1, 2001. In his 94th year. An honest, caring, giving human being. Beloved husband of Min, father of Elliot and grandfather of Sara and Andrew. Rest in peace.

title: One's Pet Is Another's Livestock
description: On freezing winter nights, James Montanye thinks nothing of bringing Bella, Maisy, Isabella and Rimanie into the house. So what if they are pygmy goats? They're his pets.

title: A STRONG DOLLAR CLOUDS PROSPECTS FOR QUICK REBOUND
description: More than six months after the Federal Reserve began battling to reverse the economic slowdown in the United States, economists and business executives say an unexpected rise in the value of the dollar is complicating the prospects for a rebound.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Sean Campion and Conleth Hill; A Glass for the Old Sod
description: THERE may be no worse place in the world to learn something about America than on Broadway.

title: African Music and African-American Audiences
description: FROM Irving Plaza to Lincoln Center Festival 2001 to the Central Park Summerstage to Celebrate Brooklyn, fans of African pop music have much to cheer about in New York this summer. But just who are those fans?

title: Motorola, With Self-Run Health Plan, Is Wary of Rights Bill
description: Motorola, the cell phone maker, provides health benefits to 230,000 workers, retirees and dependents around the country. For 40 years, in an effort to control the quality of its health plan, the company has reviewed and paid claims itself.

title: Caroline Jones, 59, Founder Of Black-Run Ad Companies
description: Caroline R. Jones, who broke race and sex barriers in advertising to become one of the most prominent black women among agency executives, died on June 28 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Getaway Drill: Check Watch; Sip Beer; Repeat
description: The North Jersey Coast Line to Bay Head was leaving soon, and Penn Station was choked with sun bunnies and chinless summer renters. It was the eve of Independence Day. At Houlihan's, in the New Jersey Transit concourse, drinkers hoisted their bottles with their left hands and checked their watches with their right.

title: Vespa Fans Say You Can't Keep a Good Scooter Down
description: Stian Nilsen squinted at the makeshift ramp, held tightly to the handlebars of his black and blue Italian scooter and gunned its little two-stroke engine.

title: The Way We Live Now: 07-08-01: The Ethicist; Charity Bytes
description: When the Dave Matthews Band decided not to release certain recordings, these coveted songs were leaked without permission via the Internet. To assuage their guilt, some fans who downloaded the songs began a campaign to donate money to the band's charitable foundation. Is it right to make such a donation if it is a self-imposed punishment for unethical conduct toward the band? Andrew Bonavia, Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Now and Again
description: WHEN a bite of my friend's dinner is still on my mind days later, I you know it's a meal worth having for myself. As restaurant dinners go, it was fairly simple: Frenched pork loin, slightly salty, grilled and resting on a bed of black-eyed peas with bacon and sprinkled with fresh tarragon. It was a compelling combination, one that made my friend reminisce about tarragon and its part in wooing his wife. The entree needed only a little less cooking and some sauted greens or maybe grilled apples to replace a Dali-style drape of a goat-cheese crepe, and it would have been a meal suitable for reminiscing, too.

title: Ideas & Trends; It Was a Dark and Stormy Life . . .
description: THE emissary from the hereafter rode out from the city. His subject, Bette Davis, served him lunch. He was writing a newspaper article about her coming made-for-television movie -- at least that was his pretext. It was the truth, but not the whole truth.

title: Letters on Travel
description: Taking a Taxi

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TISCHLER, DAVID
description: TISCHLER-David. Beloved husband of Leslie. Devoted and loving father to Sarra and Alison, Katy and Daniel. Loving son to Ed and Sara. Brother to Susan. Forever missed, forever loved. The Famil

title: The Post Reinvents Itself Again in the War of the Tabloids
description: Most people may not have noticed that the front-page nameplate is higher, or that the articles inside are more numerous and much shorter. But even the most casual reader could tell that changes were afoot at The New York Post when its newest columnist recently wrote a tribute to a dad who could not be with her on Father's Day.

title: Substance Lacking
description: To the Editor:

title: Surplus Magic: It Works Both Ways
description: NO one ever quite figured out why the strong economy of the 1990's generated so much more tax revenue than anticipated, wiping out the federal budget deficit and creating substantial surpluses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, NETTY
description: LEFKOWITZ-Netty. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the passing of Netty, mother-in-law of our fellow member and Secretary of the Board of Governors, Harvey L. Radler. We extend our sincere condolences and heartfelt sympathy to his wife and Netty's daughter Pauline and their family. Robert E. Morrow, President

title: To Be a Railbird, or Just Look Like One
description: SO you want to be a horse player? Beyond an expert's knowledge of jockey logic and equine psychology, you're going to need a few other things. Namely many, many ill-fitting clothes.

title: The Heavyweight Goes In-House
description: BENEATH a sign that asks ''What have you done for you lately?'' the cosmetics section of the Wal-Mart store here is a hard-working shrine to eye shadow, face powder, nail polish, mascara and all the other products that help highlight, conceal, enhance and perfume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, SABINE L.
description: MOSES-Sabine L. Died July 7, 2001. Mother of Cathy and Neil Rose. Grandmother of Melissa and Richard Rose. Sister of Madeline Bernstein. Aunt of many nieces and nephews.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 8, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Article 2001070892824123015 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Willing to Share, but Only With the Sea Gulls
description: BEYOND the S.U.V.'s and the hot asphalt; beyond the sea spray and the forest of masts in Milton Harbor; and beyond the briny air and screeching gulls is a small grove of trees off the coast of Rye from which slapdash bungalows peek out like shy mermaids.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINES, LEONARD
description: PINES-Leonard. Founder of Hebrew National Kosher Foods, the company that promises to ''answer to a higher authority,'' died on Wednesday, July 4th. He was 90. Pines' father, Isadore Pinkowitz, a Romanian immigrant, founded the Hebrew National Kosher Sausage Factory in 1905, producing kosher frankfurters and selling them from a wagon on Manhattan's Lower East Side until his death in 1936. Pinkowitz's eldest son, Leonard, took over the company and built it into the largest kosher brand in America, whose many famous products included hot dogs, salami, corned beef, pastrami, and deli condiments. The company's success proved there was a market for kosher beyond Jewish consumers. Pines was married for 48 years to Mary Zucker, who died in 1981. He lost his second wife, Jeanette Weinstein, in 1999. Pines is survived by four children: Myrna, Isadore (''Skip''), Paula, and Kenneth. He has 13 grandchildren and 10 greatgrandchildren. His is also survived by a sister Pauline Goldstein and brother Max Pines, and sister-inlaw Dottie Pines and his favorite girls Virginia and Sybil. Funeral services will be held on Sunday July 8th, at 11:45 AM, at Star of David, 7701 Bailey Rd, Tamarac, FL, 1-800-456-5252. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the International Myleoma Foundation, 12650 Riverside Drive, Suite 206, North Hollywood, CA 91607-3421.

title: Sufis Remember Arrested Leader in Prayers
description: It was business as usual at a former warehouse near Times Square on Friday night, with men sitting on one side under pointed turbans and women on the other in head scarves. More than two dozen Sufi Muslims had gathered for their weekly prayer session, which would last until dawn.

title: Chamblee Keeps Focus After Painful Year
description: LEMONT, Ill., July 7  To say that Brandel Chamblee would be a popular winner this weekend would be an understatement.

title: Yard Work
description: LAST Fourth of July, the day throngs of spectators flocked to the New York waterfront to watch giant ships glide in from around the world, 200 white-clad sailors and 400 civilians caroused on the roof of a building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard overlooking the docks. Some twirled dance partners to a swing band. Others feasted on strawberries and focaccia. After a hazy sunset, the revelers crowded along the railings to watch red, white and blue fireworks burst over the harbor's black waters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYNE, RUBY (NEE BROWN)
description: PAYNE-Ruby (nee Brown). Of Englewood, NJ on May 24, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Albert Edward Payne. Devoted mother of Thea Payne, Richard Payne, Jeane Ryan & Susan Gato. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth Greco, Christine Perillo, Julie Greco, Christopher Payne, Laura Payne, Susan Ryan-Gunter, Kelly Ryan, Andrew Ryan, Lisa Robinson-Cronin, Allison Gato and the late Dina Greco. Cherished great-grandmother of Tyler Perillo, Alex Perillo, Samantha Cronin, Evelyn Ryan-Gunter and Clementine Ryan-Gunter, and Amelia Ryan Danko. She was a member of SAG, AFTRA and AEA. Memorial Services will be Saturday, September 29, 2001 12 noon at the Actor Fund Home, 155-175 West Hudson Avenue Englewood, NJ. Donations to Employees Fund at the Actors Fund Home would be appreciated. For information, call ''Wien and Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: A Quarter Of Gains, But Doubt Persists
description: AFTER several rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, months of corporate cost-cutting and layoffs, news that tax refund checks would soon be in the mail, and four quarters of tumbling markets, the second quarter brought a bit of a respite from the gloom.

title: A Car Crash, a Tango Instructor: A Novel Look at Scarsdale
description: MARLENE FANTA SHYER'S new novel, ''Second Chances,'' is being promoted as a romance. But the paperback, published in June by Kensington Books, is in fact more a tragi-comedy of suburban manners, set in Scarsdale, circa 2001.

title: July 1-7; Merge? Yes and Non
description: After weeks of buildup, European regulators formally vetoed General Electric's $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International, a deal the Justice Department had approved last month.

title: Summer Camps For Big Kids
description: ELLISA CASSUTO, a special-education teacher in Manhattan, grew up going to sleep-away camp all summer, every summer. When she got too old to be a camper, she became a counselor. Then she became a grown-up and, except for the occasional camp reunion, gave it all up: the campfires, the color wars, eating in a mess hall.

title: Uneasily Evoking an Outdated Past
description: New York's diverse racial and ethnic groups celebrate their presence with place names like African Square in Harlem, Chinatown and Little Italy. But many New Yorkers might be surprised to learn that the antiquated word Negro still holds currency for mariners in the East River.

title: Summer Dreams, Firmly Rooted in Reality
description: FOR the first 50 years or so of television history, the only people who used the words ''hit'' and ''summer'' in the same sentence were baseball announcers.

title: Ideas & Trends: Designated Demon; The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Hitter
description: BARRY BONDS laughs. The brooding San Francisco Giants slugger with what is often portrayed as a permanent case of bitter-beer face does get in a few yuks every now and then -- particularly when he is reminded of a commercial he did for Franklin Batting Gloves five years ago.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT
Wisteria, Uninvited, Still Needs to Be Pruned
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories of 45 'Just Magical' Summers
description: WE'D go to a dark spot where all you could see was the pink glow of the jellyfish, and we'd swim right in the middle of them with the lights trailing behind us in the water. We'd pretend we were mermaids in a fairy dance. It was magical, just magical.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, RUBEN AND WILLIAM
description: BERNSTEIN-Ruben and William. Lovingly remembered. Barbara

title: Loan Disparities
description: To the Editor:

title: One Hand Clapping
description: THE FOURTH HAND

title: They Also Served
description: I appreciate that Andrew Sullivan (The Way We Live Now, June 17) was writing about how our society has done nothing to acknowledge gay people who have served our country in past wars. However, I think it was a mistake to hold up Corporal Klinger and ''M*A*S*H'' as an example of anything positive about the depiction of gays in the military in popular culture.

title: Merrill Horenstein, Brian McGarity
description: Merrill Horenstein, a daughter of Marcia and Sidney Horenstein of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Brian McGarity, the son of Jane McGarity of Old Mill Basin, N.Y., and Donald McGarity of Tamworth, N.H. The Rev. Robert Swain, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the W New York-Union Square hotel in Manhattan.

title: An Innovative Solution To Front-Seat Battles
description: To the Editor:

title: Plaid Squared
description: Segueing from spring's neo-preppy riff, patchwork plaid has become the cool pattern on the block for men and boys this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JULIA, TAISSA
description: JULIA-Taissa. Age 82, of New York City, died on June 2, 2001 after a brief illness. Her absence is deeply felt by her family and friends who miss her wit, intelligence, enthusiasm and beauty. A memorial will be held in New York City in the fall.

title: Icy Outside, But Inside It's Heated
description: EMPATHY is the key to the two great shows on Ludwig Mies van der Rohe on view this summer at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art. An architect often belittled as too cool for human comfort turns out to be a figure possessed by desires of nearly unbearable intensity. These desires also happen to be shared by many who are drawn to city life. His buildings are animated by a universal dream: the lure of the big city, the craving to be accepted there on one's own terms.

title: Like Historic English Castles? Then This Kitchen Is for You
description: Recently upgraded to a Range Rover from an Explorer and still have some money to burn? Take a drive to Christians of Greenwich and consider investing in one of the pinnacles of conspicuous consumption: the six-figure kitchen.

title: N.F.L. Enjoys Stability, But Problems Remain
description: While the economy waffles, and sports organizations like Major League Baseball ponder the possibility of a work stoppage, the National Football League has undoubtedly entered what some league officials are calling a second golden age.

title: Eat, Bark, Be Merry
description: For people, the social calendar doesn't start until September. For party-hopping dogs it's well under way. Two weeks ago Fetch, a pet supply store at 43 Greenwich Avenue, held its second annual Doggie Ice Cream Social. More than 100 dogs cooled off with cups of Frosty Paws chicken-flavored soy ice cream served on the sidewalk, which was festooned with balloons. (Humans snacked on ice cream sandwiches.)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Uniondale, N.Y. included an outdated reference to the location of a federal courthouse. The federal courts for the Eastern District of New York that had been in Uniondale are now at a new courthouse in Central Islip.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Although I have the highest respect for the Justices of the U.S. Supreme Court, most of their opinions cannot be held up as literary models by any means.''

title: "Empire: The Russian Empire and Its Rivals"
description: Over the last two millennia the word `empire' has meant many different things to different people from different countries at different times. Indeed it has often had different meanings to people from the same country at the same time. Statesmen and political thinkers have on occasion noted the word's ambiguity, themselves deliberately using it in different contexts to convey a variety of meanings.

title: Article 2001070892821936697 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Is This Why Gregory Peck Was So Cool?
description: CONNECTICUT residents should be warned that if they see a sporty little Italian motor scooter zip by them along the state's back roads this summer -- and they will see one -- please, don't call it a moped. Otherwise, they will not only offend its very particular owner (there just may be a movie star under that helmet), they will also unwittingly label themselves as tragically un-hip.

title: Good Storyteller
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the World War II Memorial Really Necessary?
description: WMost readers of The New York Times Magazine on the Web agreed that it is important to remember the veterans of World War II, but just as many felt that another memorial on the Mall in Washington D.C. would do have a negative effect on the area's aesthetics. Many felt that a memorial would be better suited for another location in Washington or somewhere else in the country. hat the readers wrote:

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for HARRY J. PEARCE; An Honesty Policy on Executive Illness
description: IN business, as in politics, the health of a boss cannot be kept secret. But when and how much to disclose is a gray area. Vice President Dick Cheney's surgery last weekend to implant a sophisticated pacemaker and defibrillator device in his chest has raised questions about how such an event would be handled in corporate America

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the table of contents of The Times Magazine today misstates the weight of Anamarie Regino, a child whose weight became a custody issue. As the article points out, she weighed 130 pounds at age 3, not 30 pounds.

title: Susan Sperling, Bruce Baiter
description: Susan Kelz Sperling and Bruce Anthony Baiter, both writers, were married on Tuesday at their home in Stamford, Conn. Cantor Kerry Ben-David officiated at the ceremony in which the Rev. Thomas E. Nicoll, an Episcopal priest, took part.

title: Lacrosse Goalie Wins Honors as Rookie
description: TO get first-team all-county honors in a high school sport is impressive. To do so in one's first year playing that sport raises the adjective several notches to astounding.

title: Red Scare Over Newark
description: I WAS a red-diaper baby. Born in 1947, the year the House Un-American Activities Committee unleashed its vengeance on the film industry, I learned secrecy at my mother's knee.

title: A Bully Moves In
description: Turn over almost any rock uncovered by low tide in New Jersey and you will probably uncover a small, purplish-black alien with six colorfully banded legs and two nimble claws -- a Pacific shore crab.

title: Suspect Is Arrested in Woman's Shooting Death in Brooklyn
description: A construction worker was arrested yesterday in the Fourth of July shooting death of a 26-year-old Brooklyn woman killed by a bullet fired through her apartment window, the police said.

title: All-Star Game Revival
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Resisting Yankees' Lure
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, GERALD L.
description: BUTLER-Gerald L. Of Florham Park, NJ, former Director of Labor Relations for Allied-Signal, on July 4. Beloved husband of Nancy, devoted father of Gerald Jr., Jeffrey and Michelle, brother of Marie Lauria and William. 41 year career in labor relations, recognized for his integrity, compassion and fairness. Born Newark 1933, Sergeant, US Marine Corps, 1959 graduate Seton Hall, Nutley resident before moving to Florham Park. Mass: Monday, 11 AM, St. Vincent's, Madison, NJ. Visitation: Sunday, 2-4, 7-9, Burroughs, Kohr, Dangler, Madison. Contributions to American Diabetes Association Research Foundation.

title: When a School Loses A Reality Check
description: How could anyone in their right mind give a vote of confidence to the Ross School [''Conferring Diplomas, Receiving Validation,'' June 17]? The Ross School is exclusive, we-group education. An education like this has nothing to do with the real world. It is four years of living in the world of make-believe, an educational Disneyland.

title: A Die-Off in the Sound: More Theories Than Lobsters
description: City Island can be so easily located in a fog by the aromas from its many seafood restaurants that kayakers call its southern tip ''Finger-Licking Point.'' But a major lobster die-off in western Long Island Sound two years ago has gutted a local industry and made the island's restaurants rely on far-off sources for a staple of their cuisine.

title: OUT THERE/Milan; The Sons of Hercules Again Flex Their Muscles
