description: FIT FOR FUN is an Italian magazine about bodies and keeping them in shape, though a glance at the July cover suggests it isn't likely to get bogged down in facts about basal metabolic rates. Over a cover line that promises ''Belli in Sette Giorni!'' -- Beautiful in Seven Days! -- stand a man and woman, entwined and waist-high in water, who do not appear to be thinking about Cybex machines. One imagines that the couple is on vacation and that their luggage fell victim to some mishap at Alitalia because bathing suits are nowhere in evidence.

title: Victory in Prologue Brings Joy and Bad Memories
description: Starting the 88th Tour de France with a shocker, Christophe Moreau, a 30-year-old Frenchman, easily won the prologue here today before a big, enthusiastic crowd.

title: Castles in the Belmar Sand
description: Who hasn't sat on the beach in summer at dusk, gazed out across the enigmatic water and felt a visceral connection to that unknown primitive human who first tried to form damp sand into the shape of a castle?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE BATTLE OF BRITAIN

title: Lee McGill, William Jennings
description: Lee Carroll McGill, a daughter of Carole M. McGill of Baltimore and Charles C. D. McGill of Upperco, Md., was married yesterday to William Bryan Jennings, the son of Judith and William C. Jennings of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Philip B. Roulette performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Glyndon, Md.

title: Easing the Way
description: Travelers who have limited mobility can find out where to rent wheelchairs, electric scooters and other mobility-assistance machines in hundreds of locations in North America at www.scootaround.com. The site is operated by ScootAround, whose prices vary by city and by features requested. A standard-size electric scooter, for example, rents for $130 a week in Las Vegas and $200 a week in Orlando. A standard wheelchair is $100 a week in Las Vegas, $105 in Orlando. Call (888) 441-7575. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Bronx Loyalists, Manhattan Luminaries
description: NAMING NEW YORK:

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing on Page 35 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the time for a piano recital by Anne Quefflec at the Frick Collection on Thursday. It is at 5:45 p.m., not 4:45.

title: Liberty's Hammon Uses Determination to Offset Her Size Disadvantage
description: At the Liberty training camp in 1999, much of the buzz was about Michele VanGorp, the 6-foot-6 center from Duke and the team's second-round draft pick. Big things were expected of the talented young all-American who that season had led Duke to the national final, where it lost to Purdue.

title: Habitats/Lower Manhattan; A Street Artist Finds A Room With a View
description: EIGHT years ago, Roustam Nour moved to New York from Moscow with $1,000 to his name, disembarking at Kennedy International Airport into a city where he had no friends or relatives. He had been an artist and art teacher in Moscow, and he intended to continue the same career.

title: Valentine Assigns Mets Failing Grades in a Pregame Meeting
description: Too often this season, catcher Todd Pratt said, there has been a feeling on the Mets' bench that no matter how a game is going, something is bound to go wrong. There is ample evidence for that belief, spelled out daily in the National League standing. But yesterday was different, Pratt said, and not just because the Mets beat the Yankees, 3-0, in 10 innings.

title: The Care and Feeding of Managers
description: MARIO GABELLI earned $45.5 million last year. William H. Gross, the nation's best-known bond manager, is in the middle of a five-year, $200 million contract. Charles B. Johnson, chief executive of Franklin Resources and co-manager of the Franklin Income fund, made $1 million last year and holds $2.1 billion of Franklin stock.

title: 'How Milton Works'
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC; Presenting An Epic As Vikings Might Have Heard It
description: ANDVARI, a dwarf, gives the god Loki a hoard of gold and, most reluctantly, a magic ring. Two brothers, Fafnir and Regin, quarrel over the gold, and Fafnir transforms himself into a dragon. Regin forges a magic sword for the warrior Sigurd, who slays the dragon. Suddenly able to understand the speech of birds, Sigurd is warned to kill Regin. Sigurd then rides his horse, Grani, to find the valkyrie Brynhild, who is surrounded by a ring of fire.

title: Our Cotton-Candy Past, at Coney Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Bush's 'Faith Based' Agenda
description: From the start of his presidential campaign, President Bush has spoken fervently of his religious faith and embraced the role of religion in helping the needy. Yet Mr. Bush's effort to expand federal funding to religious groups for certain charitable activities has run into understandable trouble in Congress. Mr. Bush has lately intensified his campaign for aid to ''faith based'' groups, most recently in Philadelphia on Independence Day. He has tried to reassure critics that it would not unduly subsidize religious activities and has accepted some modest changes in the legislation. But as currently drafted, the ''faith based'' initiative still raises concerns about possible violations of the separation between church and state.

title: The Young Faces of Poverty
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Patriarch Maximus V, 93; Led Greek Catholic Church
description: Patriarch Maximus V Hakim, who for more than 30 years was spiritual leader of the small Greek Catholic Church and who sought better relations with the larger Eastern Orthodox Church, died on June 29 in a hospital in Beirut. He was 93.

title: Capitalists in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001070994156149124 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Compressed Data; Painting Some Pictures Of the Online Shopper
description: For Internet retailers trying to understand why some consumers eagerly shop online, while others rarely click the ''buy'' button, a new study aims to offer insight into the attitudes underlying their behavior.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: LightSurf Piggybacks a Tiny Camera on a Cell Phone
description: For millions of Americans today, the cellular phone is simply a convenient way to make calls on the go. But if Philippe Kahn's vision plays out, consumers will soon be using their cell phones to take digital photographs that can be instantly transmitted over wireless networks to other cell phones.

title: Compressed Data; A College Paper's Role In the Microsoft Appeal
description: The Financial Times. The New Yorker. The New York Times. The Washington Post. The Wall Street Journal.

title: Playing A.I. on the Internet
description: Some players of an ambitious Internet game that is part of the marketing push for the film ''A.I.'' say it is a more absorbing experience than watching the much-anticipated movie by Steven Spielberg, on the set above with the actors Haley Joel Osment and Jude Law. The core of the online game -- which has attracted several hundred thousand players, according to Elan Lee, a Microsoft game designer -- is an elaborate sprawl of Web sites for fictitious people and companies, peppered with clues to a murder. The game's obscurity, like that of a nightclub with no sign outside, seems only to increase its appeal. C1

title: A Familiar Mural Finds Itself Without a Wall
description: For years, as they crossed the lobby of the MetLife Building on Park Avenue on their way to Grand Central Terminal, tens of thousands of people a day passed a giant red, white and black mural that the German-born artist and colorist Josef Albers designed as his homage to New York, the city to which he immigrated in 1933.

title: Microsoft Sees Clear Victory On 'Bundling'
description: To Microsoft, its long-running antitrust battle against the government has always been about freedom -- the unfettered freedom to design its products as the company sees fit. Even if, as Microsoft once colorfully argued, that meant bundling a ''ham sandwich,'' or anything else, in its flagship Windows operating system.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: E-Zpass Speeding Penalties
description: Beginning Sunday, motorists who exceed five miles per hour through E-ZPass lanes will face suspension or revocation of their pass, state highway officials have announced. The penalties are intended to reduce accidents at toll plazas. Drivers on the Garden State Parkway, New Jersey Turnpike and Atlantic City Expressway who do not slow down will receive warnings for their first two offenses; 60-day license suspensions for the third violation; 180-day suspensions for the fourth violation; and one-year revocations after a fifth violation.

title: Needed: 35 Good Candidates
description: The most lampooned institution in New York City government — the 51-member City Council — is about to get a huge facelift. Because of term limits taking effect this year, 35 members must go.

title: Publicist's Wayward S.U.V. Hit Clubgoers, Police Say
description: The nightclubs of the Hamptons have long been the playground of the rich and the well connected, where 21-year-olds drive $80,000 sports cars and scoff at $800 bar tabs, and the sweet smell of success lingers in the air.

title: Some Shops Enter New Partnerships
description: Several agencies are making deals for undisclosed terms.

title: Barry Bonds Chases a Record
description: It took Roger Maris 34 years to break Babe Ruth's record for most home runs in a season, and 37 years for Mark McGwire to break Maris's mark, with his 70 home runs in 1998. Now, just three seasons later, this most venerated of baseball records is again under siege, this time by Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants.

title: Tough on North Korea
description: Tough on North Korea To the Editor:

title: MediaTalk; St. Louis Paper Ends Readers' Advocate
description: Who speaks for the reader? At about 40 newspapers around the country, the job is handled by an ombudsman, or readers' advocate. But that number decreased last week when the St. Louis Post-Dispatch eliminated that job.

title: Direct Deutsch Unit Names New Official
description: Deutsch Inc. in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies ( news/quote ), has named Ian Baer to the new post of executive vice president and director for the Playa del Rey, Calif., operations of Direct Deutsch, the agency's direct marketing division. Mr. Baer, 34, had been president at the Chicago office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ); Rapp Collins announced in May that the Chicago office would be reduced to a support operation from a full-service office.

title: Williams Turns On Her Power, And Charm
description: The instant flicker of flashbulbs against the leaden sky created a disco-ball effect on championship point this afternoon, but the moment did not move Venus Williams to spin, twirl or trip the light fantastic.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: AccuWeather.com, State College, Pa., is opening two regional offices: one in Atlanta, to be led by Vincent Desmond Wallace as regional account manager, and one in San Francisco, to be led by Tim Kelly as regional account manager. Mr. Wallace had been business development manager at the Nexchange Corporation, Atlanta. Mr. Kelly had been an account manager at Winstar Interactive Media, San Francisco, a division of Winstar Communications.

title: Pursuing a New Line In Optical Research
description: Each week seems to bring more bad news from the fiber-optics network business, where a rash of over-construction in the late 1990's has created a glut of installed but unused fiber.

title: Valentine, Still Smarting, Adds Floyd
description: After all of the attention the topic brought him, Bobby Valentine said it was a simple decision to add the Marlins' Cliff Floyd to the National League All-Star team yesterday.

title: Officials Loath to Act as Water Meant for Endangered Fish Flows to Dry Western Farms
description: The sheriff will not arrest. The prosecutor will not prosecute. The local irrigation district has turned a blind eye.

title: The Myst Mystique Continues
description: Myst, the top-selling PC game since the data has been tracked, is far from becoming history. Its latest sequel, Myst III: Exile, has been a top-selling title since its release in early May.

title: PROTECTING THE PRODUCT: A special report.; Company's Silence Countered Safety Fears About Asbestos
description: When asbestos was labeled a killer 30 years ago, one company moved to cash in.

title: Ex-Ruling Party Challenges Result in Jurez Vote
description: Pressing ahead with its fight for political control of Mexico's largest city on the northern border, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, the PRI, has filed a complaint to have the mayoral election of last week overturned.

title: E Dubai Speeds Over Slop to Win Dwyer
description: Hero's Tribute towered over his three rivals in the Belmont paddock yesterday before the 84th running of the $150,000 Dwyer Stakes. But over a sloppy track, he proved no match for E Dubai, who cruised to a front-running victory by five-and-three-quarters lengths over Windsor Castle.

title: How Rossini Interpreted Shakespeare
description: The reason usually given for the rarity of performances of Rossini's ''Otello'' is that Francesco Maria Berio di Salsa's libretto is a hack job that makes hash of Shakespeare. If the characters were called by names other than Otello, Iago and Desdemona, audiences would have no idea that they were watching an operatic retelling of the drama. Another charge is that only the third act, when Desdemona meets her fate in the one segment that hews closely to Shakespeare, is truly inspired music. This judgment is unfair, for the first two acts have long stretches that are lyrically beguiling and imaginative.

title: Some Prefer Online Tie-In to the Movie
description: Many a moviegoer has had the experience of seeing a preview that turned out to be more entertaining than the film it was meant to promote. Now some players of an ambitious Internet game that is part of the marketing push for the film "A.I." say it is a more absorbing experience than watching the much-anticipated movie.

title: Isaacson to Head CNN
description: Walter Isaacson, the editorial director of Time, Inc. and one-time managing editor of Time magazine, will take the reins of CNN.

title: A Drive to End The Death Penalty
description: ADrive to End The Death Penalty To the Editor:

title: The Facts of a Man Who Lived a Monstrous Fiction
description: On Jan. 9, 1993, in a small French town, a respected doctor named Jean-Claude Romand killed his wife and their two children and then drove a few miles to his parents' home and killed them.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Sports of The Times; Hitting the Lottery as a Junior?
description: A STELLAR array of basketball cognoscenti that included scouts from almost every N.B.A. team and college coaches -- pads and pencils at the ready, projected mental insights awhirl -- flocked yesterday to see some 220 of the best high school players in the world showcased at Fairleigh Dickinson's Rothman Athletic Center. One player in particular, however, caught much of their attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLALOUF, SAM
description: ALLALOUF-Sam, 73. Of NYC. Died Saturday, July 7, 2001, after weeks of complications following heart surgery. Beloved brother of Pauline and Maury (and wife Jenny) and uncle to Robert, Felice, Gary and Francine. Retired Public Relations Officer and News Editor, formerly of Roosevelt Hospital and St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken, among others. He will be missed by his family and friends. Memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM, on Tuesday, July 10, at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, Inc, 1625 Coney Island Ave (corner Ave M), Brooklyn; 718-377-2700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, ROSE
description: STEINBERG-Rose. The World Jewish Congress participates in the mourning of its Executive Director, Elan Steinberg, on the death of his mother. Services Monday, July 9, at 9:30 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. Edgar M. Bronfman, President Israel Singer, Secretary General Evelyn Sommer, Chairman American Section

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Senator's Associate Pleads Guilty
description: A business associate of State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. has pleaded guilty to filing a false document to secure public money for a nonprofit group. The associate, Sandra Love, the president of Information Networking and Community Assistance, agreed to pay $20,000 to the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. The offense, a misdemeanor, took place in February 1995, prosecutors said. In an indictment, prosecutors alleged that Ms. Love illegally diverted the bulk of a $95,100 state grant, earmarked to revive the Teatro de Puerto Rico in the Bronx, to the Soundview Health Center, where Ms. Love is senior vice president. Senator Espada, who was not charged, is the president of Soundview Health Center. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: CHILDREN TRAPPED BY MENTAL ILLNESS
description: The 16-year-old girl had needed help, no question. She was throwing chairs, she was taking rides from strangers, she was acting suicidal. Finally, she ended up in a psychiatric hospital, where, her mother says, the staff effectively saved her life, stabilized her, worked on her bipolar disorder.

title: A Rival Is Offering $44.5 Billion For AT&T's Cable TV Business
description: Seeking to become the nation's biggest cable television company, the Comcast Corporation made an unsolicited offer yesterday to acquire AT&T's cable operation for $44.5 billion in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, RICHARD J.
description: MALONEY-Richard J. Age 76 of Yonkers, NY, a retired captain of the NYC Fire Department for 40 years, died on July 8, 2001. Richard served in the Navy during WWII and was wounded during the Invasion of Normandy. Loving and devoted husband of Margaret (nee Carrig), proud father of Arthur T., Maureen Andariese, Margaret Ann Kelly and Kathryn Maloney, cherished brother of Mary Murray, John J. Maloney and the late Arthur and Edward. Beloved grandfather of nine. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Paul the Apostle Church, McLean Ave, Yonkers. Interment at Gate of Heavan Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461. The family will be present Monday 7-9 PM, and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at F. Ruggiero & Sons Inc, 732 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, NY; 914-375-1400.

title: Brave New World of Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You could be stupid in the last 10 years and make a lot of money. Now you've got to buckle down and start learning all over again.''

title: Still Finding Joy in a Broken Heart
description: On the Fourth of July, 15,000 people gathered in Battery Park to watch Emmylou Harris perform with her regular backing trio, Spyboy. For many, the view was obstructed by trees, distance or glaring sun, and the sound mingled with the noise of the city. But for those who found their way to the area in front of the stage, this was a diverse and spellbinding concert.

title: Needed: 35 Good Candidates
description: The most lampooned institution in New York City government -- the 51-member City Council -- is about to get a huge facelift. Because of term limits taking effect this year, 35 members must go.

title: Last Push on Campaign Finance
description: For years every obstacle overcome by campaign finance reform in Washington has led to more obstacles in the next phase. Now at last the process has reached a culmination. The House will this week take up the Shays-Meehan ban on open-ended soft-money donations to political parties. House passage can lead quickly to final legislative approval in the Senate. The bill would ban the donations that have eroded public confidence in the political system while placing stringent curbs on the use of soft money by independent groups. A fraudulent measure backed by some Republicans is competing for votes. But the Shays-Meehan bill is the only one that can be labeled reform.

title: Army and Police Keep Order at Protestant March in Ulster
description: British troops and police officers in riot gear mounted a huge security presence in this most volatile of all Ulster towns today, and marching Orangemen limited their procession from Drumcree Church to a token protest.

title: House Critics Call McCain A Bully On Campaign Bill
description: With the House preparing to open what may be a climactic debate on overhauling the nation's campaign finance system, House Republican leaders stepped up their attacks today on the chief Republican sponsor of the overhaul legislation in the Senate, John McCain of Arizona.

title: Museum Says Coffee Chain Is Violating Its Trademark
description: The sandwich and coffee chain Xando Cos Inc., based in Manhattan, has met with an unexpected challenge to its effort to become the next Starbucks. Just as it was preparing to open its first Ohio cafe, in Columbus, an Ohio museum accused the company of trademark infringement.

title: Online Tie-In Outshines Film It Was Pushing, Some Fans Say
description: Many a moviegoer has had the experience of seeing a preview that turned out to be more entertaining than the film it was meant to promote. Now some players of an ambitious Internet game that is part of the marketing push for the film ''A.I.'' say it is a more absorbing experience than watching the much-anticipated movie.

title: The Numbers Tell the Story
description: The Numbers Tell the Story: AIDS Discriminates To the Editor:

title: Honors
description: The Promotion Marketing Association, New York, named Robert E. Balzer chairman and president for a one-year term. He succeeds Robert W. Fallon, who becomes chairman emeritus. Mr. Balzer is president at REB Associates, Towaco, N.J.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: River Edge: Fatal House Fire
description: A house fire left a man dead and his wife injured yesterday, the Bergen County police said. The man, Rajkumar Naik, was pronounced dead at Hackensack Medical Center, and his wife, whose name was not released, was reported in good condition there last night. The authorities received a call reporting the fire in Mr. Naik's home on Seventh Avenue shortly after 3:45 p.m. The cause of the fire is under investigation, the police said. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: Marlow Foods, North Yorkshire, England, owned by AstraZeneca, to Decker, Glastonbury, Conn., to handle the account for the United States introduction of the Quorn Foods brand of meatless frozen entrees. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Brave New World of Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 401(K) ACCOUNTS ARE LOSING MONEY FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: For the first time in the 20-year history of the popular 401(k) retirement savings plan, the average account lost money last year, even after thousands of dollars of new contributions. And despite some strengthening of stock prices in the last couple of months, recent estimates show, the declines persisted in the first half of this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREINDEL, JOSEPH H., M.D.
description: BREINDEL-Joseph H., M.D. Born 1909, in Zablotow, Poland, and graduated medical school in Italy, then immigrated to the US and established a private practice in Obstetrics and Gynecology for over 50 years until his retirement in 1989. Full attending at Beth Israel for many years and former Chief of Obstetrics at New York Infirmary. A leader in Obstetrics, beloved by his patients and adored by his family, Dr. Breindel is survived by his wife Sonia, his daughter Dr. Monique Breindel, son-in-law Jonathan Oberman and his adoring grandchildren Hannah, Naomi and Sarah Rose. Predeceased by his son Eric. Services Monday, 12:45, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Drive to End The Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Hernndez Is Progressing
description: Orlando Hernndez's rehabilitation from foot surgery is going well.

title: Hoch Proves His Best Is Better Than Love's
description: They dueled until the final hole, challenging each other with birdie after birdie. Through the first 17 holes of their memorable final-round tussle today, Scott Hoch and Davis Love III combined for 16 birdies and only one bogey. For quality golf, it was the best head-to-head clash on the PGA Tour this year. And when they reached the final hole of the Advil Western Open, both men were 21 under par, far ahead of the field but unable to shake each other.

title: H. S. Grossbardt, 85, Record Store Founder
description: Harold S. Grossbardt, a founder of Colony Records, the famed collector's store now on Broadway at 49th Street in Manhattan, died on June 10 at his home in Aventura, Fla. He was 85.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Summer Savings in Washington DC
description: The Willard Inter-Continental, two blocks from the White House at 1401 Pennsylvania Avenue, was recently renovated and is marking the occasion with its Summer Options program. Through Sept. 4, a standard room is $179 a night (versus the usual $425), and includes 1,500 frequent-flier miles. There's also a choice of one of the following: full breakfast for two, a second room at half price, an upgrade to a deluxe room, 500 more frequent-flier miles or free parking. Information: (202) 628-9100 or www.washington.interconti.com .

title: Harlem Journal; Generations Sound Off In a Brassy Gospel Jam
description: It's Sunday morning and churches all over Harlem are filled with the sounds of organs and full-throated gospel choirs.

title: A Boxer's Tale: Dreams of Fame End in Death
description: The gym called Round One Boxing is home to a certain breed of men. They are fit and disciplined and used to talking with their fists. They spend more time with a punching bag than they do with the women in their lives. Above all, they are hungry.

title: Pesky Bug Buildup
description: The use of wind power to generate electricity is increasing around the world, particularly in California and Northern Europe. The industry's growth has been spurred in part by the development of huge wind turbines, with rotor blades up to 240 feet in diameter, that can generate enough electricity for about 2,000 homes.

title: Online Grocer Webvan to File for Chapter 11
description: Webvan Group Inc., the online grocer that epitomized the buoyant optimism that the Internet could revolutionize even the most entrenched industries, died today. The immediate cause of death was insolvency, said Bud Grebey, a company spokesman. The company had been suffering from accelerating losses and a source for a cash infusion could not be found.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Dawn Kelly, Jaredd Mooney, Jessie Kremidas and Nate Peterkin, Perkins School for the Blind, Watertown, Mass., June 7, 2001

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARAZEN, RICHARD ALLEN
description: SARAZEN-Richard Allen. Of Windham, NY, died peacefully on July 6, 2001, in Boston. He was 68 years old. Mr. Sarazen was born June 27, 1933, in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by a brother, a sister, two former spouses, eight children and 12 grandchildren. Mr. Sarazen was a Member of the Board and Senior Executive Vice President of the News Corp., retiring in 1998. He held a number of accounting and other positions and spent time as a professional musician previously. He will be greatly missed and remembered by all those he loved and who loved him dearly. Calling hours at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Monday, July 9, 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial will be at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, 65 East 89th St., on Tuesday at 10 AM. Private burial will take place at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in memory of Richard A. Sarazen to the Wellness Community, Santa Monica, CA; and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Tour Riders Make an Unscheduled Stop
description: Computers, cell phones, two-way radios the Tour de France these days is up to its eyebrows in high-tech equipment. But today, the page was turned back many decades: a freight train stopped the race.

title: Fighters Keep Up Verbal Jabbing
description: As the fighters lined up along a table for the postfight press conference at KeySpan Park in Coney Island early yesterday morning, Hector Camacho Jr. wore a pair of oversized glasses and a bandage over his right eye, Jesse James Leija's left eyebrow was covered by a large bandage and, once again, the credibility of boxing sported the biggest scars.

title: MediaTalk; Setting New Frontiers in the Autobiography
description: Susanna Kaysen, an author who helped create a vogue for publishing intimate, confessional autobiographies, is once again testing cultural taboos, this time by chronicling her quest for relief from vaginal pain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Cancer Tests Urged
description: The city and state should increase to seven from two the number of vans outfitted with equipment to perform mammograms, Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday, so that more uninsured women can have access to free screenings for breast cancer, a key step in treatment. Mr. Hevesi, the city comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor, said his program could provide up to 50,000 more mammograms a year and would not cost more than $2 million in its first year. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; Art, Life And the Gap In Between
description: IT'S a good thing it's summer. Timing is everything, they say -- including an excuse, as convenient as any other, for our current celebrity eruption. It has been, to put it mildly, over the top.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEITZ, GEORGE E.
description: LEITZ-George E. The Transport Workers Union of America, AFLCIO mourns the loss of our International President Emeritus, George E. Leitz, of cancer, on July 5, 2001. Brother Leitz had served our union with energy and dedication since 1948, first as President of TWU Local 225 in Hackensack, NJ, and later as International Representative, Secretary Treasurer, Executive Vice President and President of the national TWU. He succeeded the late John E. Lawe as International President in January, 1989 and served until his retirement in November, 1993. Our union has lost a courageous fighter for the rights and dignity of all transportation workers here and abroad. He was a lifelong resident of New Jersey until moving to Leesburg, FL, after retirement. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Dorothy; son Robert, and daughter Georgia. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Hospice of Lake and Sumter, 12300 Lane Park Rd., Tavares, FL 32778. Viewing Sunday, July 8, 7-9 PM, and Monday, July 9, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM, at A. K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, NJ (201-945-7100). Services Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Francis R.C. Church, 114 Mt. Vernon St, Ridgefield Park, NJ. Sonny Hall, TWU Int'l President Frank McCann, Exec. Vice Pres. John J. Kerrigan, Secy Treasurer

title: Study Finds Ballot Problems Are More Likely for Poor
description: A Congressional study has found that the votes of poor people and members of minorities were more than three times as likely to go uncounted in the 2000 presidential election than the votes of more affluent people.

title: Sports of The Times; Now Venus Williams Clearly Stands Alone
description: ''COME on, Serena,'' the feisty spectator cried out from somewhere behind Venus Williams after one game was completed in the third set. Williams had just held serve at love but Justine Henin, after taking the second set, seemed to have momentum and unquestionably had the crowd firmly on her side.

title: Suggestions Of Doping Still Dog Armstrong
description: Responding to new suggestions that he may have used banned performance-enhancing substances, Lance Armstrong denied today that he had ever used the drug EPO and defended his relations with a doctor who has supported its use.

title: The Numbers Tell the Story: AIDS Discriminates
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Prefer Online 'A.I.' Tie-In to the Movie
description: Many a moviegoer has had the experience of seeing a preview that turned out to be more entertaining than the film it was meant to promote. Now some players of an ambitious Internet game that is part of the marketing push for the film "A.I." say it is a more absorbing experience than watching the much-anticipated movie.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Medical Journals Plan to Offer Far Lower Rates in Poor Nations
description: Six major publishers of medical journals are expected to announce today that they have agreed to give researchers in developing countries online access to their publications free or at sharply discounted prices.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLINS, SARA GOLDMAN
description: WOLLINS-Sara Goldman. Died peacefully in Lauderhill, FL, on July 7, 2001, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Goldman. She is survived by her children Howard, Eugene, Alan and Harriet, daughters-in-law Beth, Judy and Fran, 10 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren. Private family service, Tuesday

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Vehicle Kills Pedestrian
description: A 17-year-old girl was killed Saturday night when a sport-utility vehicle struck her as she tried to cross a marked intersection in Brooklyn, the police said. The girl, Golde Shif, was walking across Ocean Avenue at the corner of Kings Highway just before 10 p.m. when she was struck by a 1999 Lexus. Ms. Shif was taken to New York Community Hospital, where she died from her injuries about an hour later, the police said. The police were still investigating last night and said they had not decided whether to charge the driver. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: But for Givenchy, No Lightning Bolts Strike : Dior's Fashion Thunder Steals Season Opening
description: PARIS  In France's storm-tossed weekend, John Galliano stole the fashion thunder with a magnificent and romantic show for Dior  flooded with color and with lightning bolts of imagination. Rajasthan gypsies, Wall Street pinstripes, Arab nomads and Tibetan folklore were melded with refinement and joie de vivre.

title: Breakfast As a Career's First Course
description: Most opera singers find it terribly difficult to sing early in the morning. The entire physical apparatus of the voice seems to shut down during sleep. It usually takes hours of warming up to get the voice going again.

title: INSIDE
description: Croatia's Tough Call

title: E-Commerce Report; Online retail profits have not materialized, so sites are offering information as a substitute for sales.
description: THE Internet divisions of traditional retailers have amends to make for the misery they have visited on their respective corporations.

title: Saudis Offer Veiled Welcome To Tourists of a Certain Age
description: With its bleak deserts and its moral code that makes the Pilgrims seem louche, Saudi Arabia has never exactly been one of those dreamed-about destinations whispering in the ear of every world traveler.

title: Some Lawmakers Urging U.S. to Speed Exports of Satellites
description: Prodded by the satellite industry, members of Congress who demanded a tougher review of satellite sales around the globe just three years ago are now trying to speed up the process.

title: Article 2001070993196649745 -- No Title
description: July 8, 2001

title: Q & A / John Kufuor : Ghana's Chief Works Toward a Recovery
description: President John Kufuor of Ghana, who recently returned from meetings with President George W. Bush and administration officials in Washington, took over the reins of power in the West African country six months ago. Since then, he has been busying himself with the task of helping Ghana recover from the effects of the previous regime, led by former President Jerry Rawlings. Left with a country burdened by economic turmoil and the ravages of social injustices, Mr. Kufuor spoke with Barbra Murray of the International Herald Tribune about his plans to lead Ghana out of its troubles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, ANITA
description: SALTZ-Anita. On July 8, 2001. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Leonard, Susan, Ronald and Gary. Happy grandmother of Emily, Kimberly, Victoria, Arthur and Allison. Loving sister of Selma and Lawrence Ruben, and Robert and Renee Belfer. Services will be held at 12 noon, on Monday, July 9, 2001, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation or the Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHTER, MARY S.
description: LEICHTER-Mary S. Helped by many doctors, especially those at New York Cornell, Mary waged a courageous and gracious fight for three and a half years, but the end came on July 7. Loving wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Pamela, Adam, Christopher and Adrian, and daughters-in-law Emily and Charlene. Cherished sister of Ann and the late Andrew. Services at Krtil F.H., 1297 1st Ave (70th St), Tuesday, July 10, at 7 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Cancer Care would be appreciated.

title: A Drive to End The Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: A Good Swift Chomp
description: Everyone knows a co-worker or two who could use the occasional swift kick to get their work done. The wasp P. occidentalis is the same way  though it employs biting, rather than kicking, to get its fellow workers going.

title: Article 2001070993177841632 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Rivera's Injury
description: One day after Mariano Rivera was scratched from the American League All-Star Game because of a sore ankle, he pitched the ninth inning against the Mets and picked up his 29th save. His fastball was clocked at 96 miles an hour.

title: Hitachi Unit Is Said to Be Buying Consulting Firm
description: Experio Solutions, the consulting division of Hitachi Ltd., the global electronic and industrial products company, plans to announce today that it will acquire WaveBend Solutions, a consulting firm based in Los Angeles, for $17.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, EDRA F.
description: BLOOM-Edra F. On July 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Jeffrey Kitt. Devoted daughter of Norton A. and the late Bilha Bloom and Gisela. Loving niece of Don and Arlena Bloom of Atlanta, GA, and Harold Cowen. Services at 12 noon, Tuesday, at I. J. Morris Inc, 46 Greenwich St, Hemstead, NY.

title: Dartmouth Nips Princeton in Ladies' Plate
description: Dartmouth's men's varsity eight surprised everyone but itself today by winning the Ladies' Challenge Plate in the closest and most exciting of the 19 finals at this year's Henley Royal Regatta.

title: A Drive to End The Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: That Guy From Seattle Enjoys His New Direction; Daniel Sullivan, the Toast of Broadway, Unveils His Latest Effort, a Shaw Revival
description: Pick a handful of the acclaimed plays of the last four years, and chances are Daniel Sullivan directed them: ''Proof,'' winner of this year's Pulitzer Prize, for which he just collected his first Tony Award; ''10 Unknowns,'' which is due to come to Broadway next season; ''Dinner With Friends,'' which won last year's Pulitzer; ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' which was nominated for best play revival last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, EDWIN D.
description: MORGAN-Edwin D. Died June 28. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 AM, Wednesday, July 11, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave, at 51 St. Eddie served with the 1st Marine Divison in Guadalcanal, New Guinea, New Britain and Peleliu. He founded Holographics, Inc., which developed useful laser technologies. In lieu of flowers send donations to City Parks Foundation, Monuments Conservation Program, Attn: Jonathan Kuhn, Parks and Recreation, Arsenal, Central Park, NY.

title: Tove Jansson, Who Created Universe of Trolls, Dies at 86
description: Tove Jansson, a Finnish author and artist whose tales for children about a family of trolls called the Moomins have been popular in many countries, died on June 27 in Helsinki. She was 86 and lived much of her later life on a rocky Finnish island.

title: `Shot Heard Round the World' Is Still Echoing
description: Nearly two weeks ago, a few days after the death of his son, Bobby Thomson stood at the podium of HBO's theater in Manhattan, praising "Shot Heard Round the World," the network's new documentary about the former New York Giants third baseman's historic playoff home run against Brooklyn in 1951.

title: A Tough Texas Senator Is a Crusader Against Cancer
description: SENATOR KAY BAILEY HUTCHISON, the perfectly poised, consummately coiffed Texas Republican, found herself so overwhelmed at a recent Congressional hearing that she could barely finish her sentence.

title: Wendell Faltering Under Heavy Load
description: When Tom Martin was with the Mets earlier this season, he got up in the bullpen almost as often as Turk Wendell. Within a month, Martin had injured his shoulder. A knee condition contributed to Martin's injury, but the constant throwing did not help.

title: New Cautions Over a Plant With a Buzz
description: An obscure hallucinogenic herb from Mexico is gaining a toehold in the world of recreational drugs, prompting law enforcement officials to increase their scrutiny of the plant, which is legal, and moving health experts to issue cautions about the drug, whose jarring effects are not fully understood.

title: Last Days for Brooklyn's Giants; Twin Tanks Carry a Love-Hate Reputation to the End
description: It won't be long now. The explosives arrived on Friday.

title: On Television; Two contenders of 'reality TV' size each other up as their genre matures.
description: THE reigning lion king of reality television, Mark Burnett, is prowling a plain in Africa this week, preparing production for a third edition of ''Survivor,'' the show that conquered the television world a year ago.

title: Croatia in Turmoil After Agreeing to Send 2 to Tribunal
description: Croatia's Western-leaning government found itself confronting collapse and potential civil unrest today after it decided this weekend to send two of its citizens to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

title: 'The Call' Is Answered in Earnhardt's Pepsi 400 Victory
description: Emotionally hung over, blinking and stumbling into the jagged sunlight, the citizens of NascarNation offered three totally acceptable reactions, sometimes all at once, to Junior's thrilling victory last night on the racetrack where Dale Earnhardt Sr. had died for their fandom.

title: Lawyer Defends Congressman's Public Silence About Intern
description: Representative Gary A. Condit, the California Democrat who has been drawn into the case of a missing federal intern, will not talk about what he has told the police because he wants to protect his privacy while cooperating with the investigation, his lawyer said today.

title: El Duque Rehabilitation Is Ahead of Schedule
description: Orlando Hernandez's rehabilitation from foot surgery is going well.

title: People
description: Sue Nixon, director for sales and marketing at the Leonhardt Group, Seattle, part of the Cordiant Communications Group, was named president and chief executive. She succeeds Ted Leonhardt, who was named to the new post of chief creative officer at the branding and design division of Cordiant, based in London. Also at Leonhardt, Ray Ueno, creative director, was promoted to chief creative officer, a new post.

title: There'll Always Be an England (Till the Rules Change Again)
description: It is surprising but true that England has just won its first major international title in the history of the game. There is of course a trick to that statement. Until a year ago English players represented Britain. Now England, Scotland and Wales go out to battle, the bridge authorities having accepted devolution.

description: MONDAY: Consumer Borrowing, May

title: Finance Chiefs Show Concern About Faltering Economies
description: Finance ministers from the big industrial nations who met here this weekend showed concern over the prospect that their economies could continue to lose steam. The bright side was that they agreed that steps could be taken to restore growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERTZER, GEORGE E.
description: SHERTZER-George E. Age 73, died July 7, at Norwalk, CT. A graduate of Yale College, Class of 1950, Columbia Law School, 1953. Served as General Counsel of GTE Corporation from 1972-1983. Survived by his wife Dee, his children John and Anne, and seven grandchildren. Memorial Service later.

title: Me-Zine Journalism for Fun and (Sometimes) Profit
description: Mickey Kaus, a former reporter for Newsweek, works out of his home off the beach in Santa Monica, Calif., looking at a blue sliver of ocean, drawing in the balmy beach air, his usual work attire a mismatched, rumpled sweatsuit.

title: A Miami Boatlift?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsi 400 Broadcast Leaps in the Ratings
description: NBC's coverage of the Pepsi 400 on Saturday night generated a 5.8 Nielsen overnight rating, a 41 percent jump over the 4.1 rating when the race was carried by CBS last year.

title: Patents; New software is intended to help put one's affairs in order and keep them that way until death.
description: PREPARING for death is a fact of life that most people put off while they are young and healthy. It is hard enough to face the need for a will, much less to plan a detailed settlement of journals, documents and photos, or to write letters to loved ones or an autobiography for descendants.

title: Direct Deutsch Unit Names New Official
description: Deutsch Inc. in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has named Ian Baer to the new post of executive vice president and director for the Playa del Rey, Calif., operations of Direct Deutsch, the agency's direct marketing division. Mr. Baer, 34, had been president at the Chicago office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group; Rapp Collins announced in May that the Chicago office would be reduced to a support operation from a full-service office.

description: MARY GEORGE OF ALLNORTHOVER

description: Suddenly, the ball was as heavy as a shot-put in Goran Ivanisevic's hand, and his service arm felt as if it were weighted by sandbags.

title: John F. Hotchkin, 66, a Leader Of Catholic Ecumenical Efforts
description: The Rev. John F. Hotchkin, widely considered a guiding spirit in the Roman Catholic Church's ecumenical efforts in the United States, died on June 24 at his home in Washington. He was 66.

title: The Ichiro Effect
description: It was six o'clock on the morning of July 3 in Toyko when the Japanese press broke the news that Ichiro Suzuki, the Japanese rookie right fielder for the Seattle Mariners, had gotten the most votes to play on the American League team in tomorrow's All-Star game. By evening, the good news was being touted all over Japanese television and on the front pages of the evening editions of respected national papers. Suzuki's success in America has fundamentally changed baseball in Japan -- but perhaps not for the better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDEN, ARTHUR A.
description: RUDEN-Arthur A. Beloved husband of Rachel. Loving father of Beth, Steven, Ronald and Alan. Cherished grandfather of Jacob, Madi, Jordan, Ryan and Jamie. Devoted brother of Eli. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, MICHAEL JOHN
description: O'REILLY-Michael John. On July 7, 2001, of Larchmont, NY. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving father of Michael, Eileen, Anne. Much loved father-in-law of Breege and Brendan. Adoring grandfather of Liam, Ciaran, Aiden and Nolan. Wake at Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, NY, Monday and Tuesday, July 9 and 10, 7-9 PM. Funeral service Sts. John and Paul Church, Wednesday, July 11, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Our Lady of Mercy, c/o Dr. Peter H. Wiernik, 600 East 233rd St, Bronx, NY 10466.

title: White House Memo; Amazing Amazement in Bush at Play
description: Reporters learned many things about President Bush on his first summer vacation. Perhaps the most interesting was his amazing capacity for amazement.

description: To the Editor:

title: Phnom Penh Journal; An Artist Preserving Life's Little Moments
description: So far, there have been 128 events in Svay Ken's life, almost all of them unremarkable.

title: Editorial Observer; A National Newspaper Searches for its Nation
description: On Aug. 25, 1999, Bosnia's Nezavisne Novine newspaper published the first in a series of articles about a 1992 massacre of more than 200 Bosnian Muslims. Based on interviews with survivors of the massacre and former and current Serbian officials, the articles alleged that a group of Bosnian Serb policemen killed the Muslims, and that Bosnian Serb authorities covered up the crime. The newspaper also published the names and birth dates of those murdered.

title: Essay; The C.I.A.'s China Tilt
description: ''New Beijing, Great Olympics'' is the slogan entrancing the International Olympic Committee. If I.O.C. boss Juan Antonio Samaranch prevails, Beijing will be the site of the 2008 Games; thus will the I.O.C.'s financial corruption find its soulmate in China's savage political corruption.

title: Deep in the Red, Indie Film Force Fades to Black
description: If there was one movie that defined New York's independent film scene of the early 90's, it was ''Laws of Gravity,'' a gritty tale of three Brooklyn pals that was made for the astonishingly low cost of $38,000. The movie, which inspired comparisons to Martin Scorsese's early work, was produced by a company with a style as swaggering as its name -- the Shooting Gallery.

title: Taxable and Tax-Exempt Debt Offerings Scheduled This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's sale of 10-year Treasury inflation-protected securities, commonly referred to as TIPS.

title: Market Place; As AT&T Wireless strikes out on its own, the other bits and pieces of AT&T remain in play.
description: THE complex breakup of AT&T could become a bit less complicated today when the company plans to complete its spinoff of AT&T Wireless to shareholders.

title: The Weight on the World
description: Snow may sometimes seem as light as fluff, but when it accumulates it can be quite heavy, as many a homeowner with a wrenched back from shoveling can attest. Architects and engineers know that snow buildup on a poorly designed roof can cause it to buckle.

title: Learning From Mistakes, Peacemakers May Have Got It Right : Early Signs of Success in Macedonia
description: PARIS  Western diplomacy seems close to success in heading off civil war in Macedonia, the last potential battleground of the former Yugoslavia. This time the West may have got it right.

title: In America; Death-Penalty Dissenters
description: Harry A. Blackmun was 85 years old and near the end of his tenure on the Supreme Court when he declared in 1994 that he could no longer support the imposition of the death penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORF, MITCHELL LANE
description: DORF-Mitchell Lane. Age 42, of Freehold Township, died Tuesday, July 3, 2001, at Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, after a long illness while awaiting transplant surgery. Mr. Dorf is survived by his father and law partner, Gerald L. Dorf, his mother Evelyn S. Dorf, an interior designer, and his brother Brian K. Dorf, a public relations consultant, all of Freehold. Funeral services were held Sunday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mitchell Lane Dorf Memorial Fund, c/o Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Ithaca, NY 14850.

title: Lack of Financing May End Trial of an AIDS Vaccine
description: Jonas Salk died in 1995, but executives say his spirit lives at the Immune Response Corporation. The company was started by Dr. Salk to conquer AIDS with a vaccine, just as he had done for polio.

title: The Numbers Tell the Story: AIDS Discriminates
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing a Bit of Wagner Sets Off an Uproar in Israel
description: The conductor Daniel Barenboim caused an uproar here today by leading a German orchestra in a piece by Richard Wagner, Hitler's favorite composer, during a concert Saturday at Israel's most prestigious arts festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, KAPLANSKY, SUSAN
description: GRANT - KAPLANSKY - Susan. With unbearable sorrow, we announce the passing of our beloved daughter, Susan, on June 28th, 2001, in Jerusalem, Israel. She had just turned 38, and leaves behind her four children: Edon, 15; Tamir, 13; Gil, 9; Eliya, 3; her husband, Eyal; her siblings, Michele Grant, Laura and Eyal Dagan. Our hearts are broken. We will be at home Sunday, July 15th. Ellen and Al Grant

title: Race Riot in Another City in Northern England Is Worst So Far
description: It was the worst race riot so far in what has been a tense summer in Britain's restive north. And today, hours after the end of a rampage in Bradford that injured 120 police officers, community leaders and government officials said they were bracing for further unrest.

title: Hamas Threatens 10 Suicide Bombs After Boy's Death
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, July 9 (AP)  A Palestinian who was apparently a suicide bomber was killed in a car bomb in the Gaza Strip today, and an Israeli died from head wounds suffered a few hours after a roadside bomb exploded near his vehicle along a West Bank road, the army said.

title: A No-Hitter in 6th, but Mets Hit the Wall
description: Another game was all but lost in the Mets' lost season, and Turk Wendell plunged into the visitors' dugout in a rage at Yankee Stadium last night and kicked the cement steps with his right foot with enough force to frighten a podiatrist.

title: I'm O.K., You're O.K., the Yanks Are O.K.
description: There is calmness in the kingdom again because the Yankees have regained their swagger. It took less than two weeks and it happened against the lousy teams they are supposed to beat, but, suddenly, the Yankees made more than two months of inconsistency seem as inconsequential as a pair of soiled socks. Throw them away and start fresh. That is what the Yankees have done.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Drop in Average 401(k) Plan Clouds Future of Nest Eggs

title: A natural marketing alliance finally takes some tentative steps: gays and sports.
description: FOR decades, advertisers and agencies have used sports to appeal to the mass consumer market. For a far shorter time, advertisers and agencies have run campaigns aimed at the gay and lesbian market.

title: So Is It or Isn't It a Museum? Only the Web Suffix Knows
description: This is a tale about what it means to be a museum in the age of cyberspace. The Tigertail Virtual Museum is a Web site containing 5,000 famous works of art that Robert Uzgalis, the museum's director, has ''virtually restored.'' The works now look as he imagines they did at the time of their creation. Using software to alter images he has pulled from the Internet, Mr. Uzgalis intensifies colors on faded paintings and replaces body parts on chipped statues. He has even straightened the Leaning Tower of Pisa. ''Some of the restorations are outrageous,'' he admitted.

title: Out on a Limb
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In Big Revamping, Interpublic Regroups Its Ad Agency Units
description: In what may well be the largest reorganization ever on Madison Avenue, the Interpublic Group of Companies is being made over as it becomes the world's biggest agency company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, LAWRENCE I.
description: WOLFSON-Lawrence I. on July 8, 2001 of Westbury, LI. Beloved husband of Iris. Devoted father of Glen and Lisa Wolfson and Ilene and Louis Meister. Cherished grandfather of Brian and Anna. Services Wednesday 1pm at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Doctor's License Restored In Bronx Mammogram Case
description: The owner of a radiology clinic in the Bronx who was accused of failing to diagnose breast cancer because of faulty tests has regained his medical license, but must undergo retraining before practicing mammography.

title: XEROX ELIMINATES DIVIDEND TO SAVE $140 MILLION A YEAR
description: Xerox eliminated its common-stock dividend yesterday to save $140 million a year. It was the latest in a series of cost reductions and assets sales designed to return the company to profitability. The quarterly dividend was reduced to 5 cents from 20 cents a share in October, generating another $400 million in annual savings. The savings are in addition to the $1 billion in cost reductions planned this year by the company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., a spokeswoman, Christa Carone, said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOBELMAN, SHERRY
description: SOBELMAN-Sherry. If tears were a path and memories a road, I'd climb the stairs to heaven to bring you home again. Alan

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in the special Men's Health section on June 24 summarizing experts' advice on controlling anger misstated the opinion of Dr. Robert Allan of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Dr Allan, a psychologist, urges patients not to express their anger directly, but to ''discover and fill the need underlying the anger''; he does not say the anger fills an ''emotional need.''

title: Embracing the World With a Perky Beat
description: Celebration and suffering are never far apart in the songs of Manu Chao, who played for a hugely overflowing crowd at Summerstage in Central Park on Saturday afternoon. As fans waved their arms and shouted along, Mr. Chao sang about marijuana, soccer, love and dancing. He also sang about nuclear war, the C.I.A. in Latin America, hiding from the police and slaughtering cattle exposed to mad cow disease. But as his band jumped into peppy ska or the pop-flamenco that the French call rhumba, the party never stopped.

title: Time Inc. Picks Fortune Editor to Be Its Editorial Director
description: John Huey, the editor of the Fortune group of magazines, was named editorial director of Time Inc. today, replacing Walter Isaacson, who was named chairman and chief executive of CNN on Monday.

title: Closing La Scala To Open It Up
description: Europe's opera houses seem to have a way of creating high drama off the stage as well as on, whether it is the recurrent strikes at the Paris National Opera or the 1994 fire in Barcelona that destroyed the Liceu Theater, now rebuilt. Or the disarray in Venice's plans to reconstruct the Fenice Theater, which burned down in 1996. Or the infighting that recently accompanied reconstruction of the Royal Opera House in London.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Xbox Set To Acquire Youpowered
description: Xbox Technologies, a small technology holding company based in Boca Raton, Fla., has agreed to buy the software maker YouPowered for nearly $4 million, company officials said. Xbox requested clearance from the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Under terms of the merger, Xbox would acquire the company's cash and other assets, including its software. In June, Xbox gave up its name so Microsoft could use it for its new video game console. Xbox Technologies filed applications with the Patent and Trademark Office to use the Xbox name in the spring of 1999, more than six months before Microsoft made its first Xbox filing. John Files (NYT)

title: Clemens and Piazza: Prime-Time Special And Awaited Sequel
description: This is the All-Star Game, Jorge Posada said today. ''It's not Piazza against Clemens.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, LEO J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Leo J. July 8, 2001. Survived by his wife, Cecille; sons, Roger and Jeffrey; grandchildren, Brian, Jill and Jason. Graveside funeral at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Wednesday, July 11, 11AM.

title: African Migrants Risk All on Passage to Spain
description: High on a dusty hill in this tiny Spanish enclave on the north coast of Africa, penned in by wire fencing, are some of those who survived. They were rescued from broken-down boats bobbing a few miles away in the Strait of Gibraltar as they tried unsuccessfully to reach the coast of Spain.

title: G.O.P. Devotees Pay Honor To Whittaker Chambers
description: The passion for Whittaker Chambers burns brightly in the Bush White House.

title: Bush Strikes a Positive Tone On a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: President Bush implored Congress today to pass and send him a patients' bill of rights that addresses his concern for limiting lawsuits, portraying himself as a proponent of -- and not an obstacle to -- legislation that most Americans support.

title: Allen, Giants' Top Pick, Is Robbery Victim
description: Will Allen, the Syracuse cornerback who was the Giants' first-round pick in the draft, was robbed at gunpoint early Sunday morning of jewelry and valuables worth more than $100,000, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, WILLIAM
description: ALPER-William. On July 7, 2001. Beloved and devoted husband and best friend to Janet. Dear brother of Mae Haesler. Cherished uncle. Services to be announced at a later date.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Japan's core machinery orders fell 2.1 percent in May from a month earlier, a smaller decline than had been expected. The decline reflected continued weakness in capital spending by businesses but helped the Tokyo stock market recoup losses posted earlier in the day because of high-technology earnings worries. The benchmark Nikkei average closed down 0.54 percent, at 12,239.68. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Bergen Officials Call for Ambitious Rail Service Expansion
description: Bergen County officials called today for creation of an expanded multibillion-dollar rail system that would include three new train lines in the county and links between them and three existing commuter lines.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 1 about a fuel truck that caused the collapse of a floor in a parking garage in Queens misstated the truck's capacity. It was a 5,000-gallon tanker, not 50,000-gallon.

title: More Samples Urged in Prostate Testing
description: Doctors testing patients for prostate cancer can significantly increase the number of cases they spot by taking more tissue samples, a recent study found.

title: Insure the Born
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Urged to Uphold Pledge on Justice Reforms
description: In the basement of a federal police barracks in Mexico City nine years ago, a dozen officers nearly beat the life out of Alfonso Martn del Campo, according to the officer who led the questioning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, ANNA
description: SINGER-Anna. We mourn the passing of Anna Singer, mother of Dr. Israel Singer, Secretary General of the World Jewish Congress. May her memory be a source of eternal blessing for the family and the world Jewish community. Rabbi Henry I. Sobel Amanda and Alisha Ronaldo Heilbut, President Congregacao Israelita Paulista Sao Paulo, Brazil

title: Effort by U.N. To Cut Traffic In Arms Meets A U.S. Rebuff
description: The Bush administration, which has already pulled away from a range of international treaties, warned today that it would not join a pact to curtail the international flow of illegal small arms if it infringed on the American right to own guns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRICK, CECILE ''COOKIE.''
description: HERRICK-Cecile ''Cookie.'' On July 9, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Edwin. Loving mother of Jayne and Donna. Dear sister of Gloria Kaplan and her husband Shelly. Cherished aunt. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Get NYToday on Vindigo!
description: Filler --> Wish you could take NYTodays restaurant and nightlife reviews with you when youre on the go? Now you can, with a mobile handheld device and Vindigo 2.0, software thats updated with our reviews whenever you sync!

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Son Arraigned In Death
description: A 14-year-old boy was arraigned in juvenile court yesterday in the shooting death of his father. The police said the victim, Gregory Wright, 37, was shot by his son after a domestic dispute Sunday night. The teenager, whose complete name was withheld because of his age, was arrested at his home and charged with murder, unlawful discharge of a firearm and carrying a pistol without a permit. According to state law, he may be charged as an adult, but it is unclear whether the case will be transferred to criminal court.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't even care if I ever play a match in my life again. If I don't want to play, I don't play again. This is it. This is the end of the world.''

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Story Hours for Grown-Ups; Introducing Urbanites to the Lure of a Well-Told Tale
description: Storytelling as an urban art form has come a long way since 1997. That was the year that George Green, a novelist, first invited friends to his Manhattan apartment for an evening of swapping stories, in hopes of replicating the moth-infested, Jack Daniels-soaked yarns of his youth in Georgia.

title: Second Embassy Bomber to Be Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: Aterrorist convicted of 11 counts of murder in the 1998 bombing of the American embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, will be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole, a federal jury in Manhattan decided today in the penalty phase of the trial.

title: Quick Trial for Milosevic
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, Ivanisevic Catches Up to Wimbledon Destiny
description: LONDON  Destiny? Who believes in destiny anymore? But as the aces and the victories started to pile up during the last two weeks at Wimbledon, Goran Ivanisevic, for one and for once, certainly began to believe that it was finally meant to be.

title: National Briefing | West: California: End Of An Era
description: After years of eviction threats, residents of 46 historic bungalows in Crystal Cove State Park in Orange County have left them, in keeping with an agreement with the landlord, the State of California. Many of the bungalows date from the 1920's, and some had been leased by the same families for generations. The state, which bought the area in 1979, wants to restore the historic district and make the park and its coastline more accessible to the public. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: If Comcast Buys AT&T Cable, Efficiency Is Likely to Improve
description: AT&T cable subscribers would probably see a more efficient operation if Comcast acquires AT&T's cable operation, analysts said yesterday. But those efficiencies might not translate into lower prices or enhanced programming.

title: A Ravaged Musical Prodigy At a Crossroads With Drugs
description: The judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan stared sternly through her glasses at the defendant, whose body trembled. ''You have been around this planet for a long time, and you've been using drugs for a fairly substantial amount of time as well,'' she said. ''What I want is for you to go and get some help with this problem.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: New Manager For Shubert
description: A nonprofit theater management company from Ohio will take over the troubled operations of the historic Shubert Theater, Mayor John DeStefano Jr. announced yesterday. The company, CAPA, based in Columbus, manages theaters and produces live music and theater events in Columbus, Cleveland and Chicago. The city owns the theater in downtown New Haven but refused a bailout of the operations when the deficit grew to an estimated $1.5 million. In April, Caroline Werth, the theater's president, resigned. The theater's board is scheduled to meet today. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: CHILE COURT BARS TRIAL OF PINOCHET
description: A Chilean appeals court ruled yesterday that Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's former dictator, is not well enough to stand trial on charges that he covered up the killings of political opponents by a death squad shortly after he seized power in 1973.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERMENT, NATHAN
description: SCHERMENT-Nathan. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Virginia (nee Arochas) of 71 years. Devoted father of Ann June Bernstein-Scherment. Loving grandfather of Richard Craig Bernstein, Deborah Joy Wetreich, Dr. Clifford Scott Bernstein. Also survived by five great-grandchildren. Services Wednesday at Noon at ''Gutterman - Musicant,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Shiva will be observed at the Scherment residence, Fort Lee, NJ.

title: Term Limits Take a Twist When the Speaker's Son Runs
description: George Delis has clawed his way to the middle. He has made a career as a blue-collar government functionary.

title: Indonesia's President Threatens Parliament Over Its Effort to Remove Him
description: As the political endgame intensifies in Indonesia, President Abdurrahman Wahid threatened today to declare a state of emergency and call new elections unless Parliament dropped plans to begin proceedings next month to remove him from office.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Stephen Ailes, a retired antitrust lawyer and former secretary of the Army, misstated the name of an organization of which he was vice chairman. It is the Atlantic Council of the United States, not Athletic Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, IRENE MANNE (NEE SCHWARTZ)
description: GELLER-Irene Manne (nee Schwartz). Died at home in Portland, OR, July 6, 2001, at the age of 89. Widow of Leon Manne and Leon Geller. Beloved mother of Steven (Frances) and William (Kristen). Grandmother of Sandra, Deborah and Eric. Sister of the late Helen Rapport Sheinberg. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Layoffs Planned By The Journal
description: The Wall Street Journal is laying off 16 journalists from its staff of 636, most of them connected to the specialized coverage of small business and entrepreneurship, according to Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for Dow Jones & Company.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Big Gain For Drug Tester
description: Shares of EPS jumped 87 percent as it became the first manager of clinical drug trials in Japan to go public. EPS, founded 10 years ago, rose 1.57 million yen ($12,490), to 3.37 million yen ($26,810), from its issue price of 1.80 million yen ($14,320) in its debut on Japan's Jasdaq market. The shares earlier gained as much as 92 percent, to 3.45 million yen ($27,446).

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Unofficial Commission Acts to Ease Turkish-Armenian Enmity
description: A group of prominent people from Armenia and Turkey put the final touches today on a reconciliation commission intended to open the way for a new era in relations between two neighbors divided by nearly a century of conflict and hatred.

title: Article 2001071093440948645 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Article 2001071092664001856 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Rolim A. Amaro, 58, Dies; Built Up Brazil's TAM Airline
description: Rolim Adolfo Amaro, a pioneering airline executive who played an important role in the modernization of Brazil's aviation industry, died on Sunday when the helicopter he was flying crashed in a deserted stretch of countryside near the border of Brazil and Paraguay. He was 58.

title: The (Mostly Late) Greats, in New Circulation
description: THIS country does a crummy job as guardian of great books by its dead authors. Or it used to. Edmund Wilson voiced that criticism 40 years ago, crankily and accurately. And Cheryl J. Hurley, the blond-coiffed, high-heeled, ladies-who-lunch look-alike (the resemblance ends there) who is chief executive of the Library of America, is relieved that he did.

title: A National Deficit, of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZER, DAVID
description: MINTZER-David 91. Beloved husband of Lenore (nee Gerstein). Father of Ellen Starr, Alice Adler and Andrew; grandfather of Sofia, Olivia and Myles. Graveside service Tuesday, July 10, at 1:30 PM, at the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: City Plans Home Health Contract For Company Renamed After Fraud
description: The Giuliani administration plans to grant a home health care contract to a company that paid $61 million in fines to settle Medicare fraud charges while operating under a different name two years ago.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: No Talks Soon With U.S.
description: Far from engaging in dialogue with the United States, North Korea plans to strengthen its armed forces if Washington sets conditions for talks, a party newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, said. It said the North would never accept the demand of President Bush for ''verifiable constraints'' as a precondition for negotiating an end to the production, testing and export of missiles. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRESE, ELIZABETH B.
description: FRESE-Elizabeth B. Of Jamestown, R.I., died July 6, 2001. She was 72. Born in NYC, daughter of the late Gwendolin Evans and A. Prentiss Butler of Scarsdale, NY. She was employed by Bank of Newport from 1975 until 1995. Wife of the late Calvin W. Survived by four children, Lynda A. Frese, Calvin W. Frese Jr., Catherine E. IanFrese and Robert P. Frese. Sister Ann B. Brown and 6 grandchildren. Service at Saint Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jamestown, R.I., on July 13th, 2001 at 11:00am.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: National Briefing | Washington: Follow-Up To Osprey Inquiry
description: The commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. James L. Jones, ordered the general whose command includes the service's V-22 Osprey squadron to review for possible disciplinary action the final Pentagon report into falsified Osprey maintenance records. The move indicates that senior Marine officers were not implicated by the Defense Department's inspector general, who investigated the case. The Pentagon report has not been made public, but senior officials say it found that the Osprey squadron's commanding officer falsified records because he felt pressure from his superiors to make the Osprey, an innovative but crash-plagued aircraft, appear ready for full production. James Dao (NYT)

title: Article 2001071090346780520 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, LEONARD
description: BECKER-Leonard. The Board of Directors and staff of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service mourn the loss of former Assistant to the Executive Director, Leonard Becker, age 78, who died on July 7, 2001, at Huntington Hospital following a brief illness. A native of Chicago and a veteran and recipient of the Bronze Star for his service in World War II, Mr. Becker graduated from the University of Chicago in 1949 and went on to study for several years at the Sorbonne in Paris. In 1965 he joined the Brooklyn Bureau as Director of Information and was later promoted to Assistant to the Executive Director. He continued to be actively involved until his death, providing valuable contributions to the Bureau and to the children, families and disabled men and women helped by the agency. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Joan (Holliday) Becker and their family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the St. Paul's Lutheran School Scholarship Fund, 106 Vernon Valley Road, East Northport, NY 11731. Viewing Tuesday, July 10, 2 to 5 PM and 7 to 9 PM at Nolan Taylor Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, NY (631754-2400). Memorial service Thursday, July 12, 7:30 PM at St. Paul's Lutheran Church, 120 Vernon Valley Rd, East Northport, NY (631754-4422). Wesley D. Ratcliff, Chairman Donna A. Santarsiero, Executive Director

title: Autodesk Is Planning to Reacquire Its Spinoff, Buzzsaw.com
description: Plucking its former spinoff from the shark-infested waters of Internet start-ups, Autodesk Inc. on Tuesday intends to announce that it will reacquire Buzzsaw.com, a provider of Internet services to help manage construction projects. The move comes less than two years after Autodesk sent the company out on its own.

title: Front Row: New Star at Gucci
description: On Friday in Paris, the Gucci Group closed the deal on the acquisition of another fashion star, Nicolas Ghesquiere, and the legendary house of Balenciaga. Gucci, which in the last year has added Alexander McQueen and Stella McCartney to its roster of emerging young talent, had negotiated with Mr. Ghesquiere and Balenciaga's owner, Groupe Jacques Bogart, for several months.

title: INSIDE
description: Uncertainty for Consumers

title: Article 2001071090392314076 -- No Title
description: Untangling the Online Gaming Web

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Blair and Ahern Meet
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, far left, and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, began two days of talks with leaders from Northern Ireland to push for resolution of an impasse over Irish Republican Army disarmament that threatens the power-sharing government in Belfast. The talks are being held at a secluded hotel near Weston-under-Lizard, in the English Midlands, to shield them from media attention and remove them from Northern Ireland, where marches this week by militant Protestants may heighten sectarian tensions. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: U.S. Farmers Look Back...; ...and See Soy Growers In Brazil Shadowing Them
description: The blazing midday sun dances off the long line of bright gold barges preparing to disgorge their cargo, Asia-bound soybeans, at this tiny but up-to-date Amazon River port. The barges, lashed nine tight, made the uneventful 600-mile journey down the Madeira River from the heart of Brazil's soybean country in less than 48 hours, cutting almost a week off the traditional overland route. That translates into a considerable savings that can be passed along to the beans' buyers.

title: Judge Considering Ex-Klansman's Competency to Stand Trial
description: Confronted with conflicting psychiatric evaluations, a Birmingham judge began hearing evidence today on whether Bobby Frank Cherry, a former Ku Klux Klansman, is competent to stand trial as the final defendant in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, MARK
description: COLE-Mark. On July 8. Survived by his beloved wife, Cecilia Cole; cherished brother-in-law of Min Suskowitz; loving uncle of Saundra and Kenneth Newman. We will all miss him and his sense of humor. Services were private.

title: A National Deficit, of Teachers
