description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ROBERT S.
description: LEVY-Robert S. On July 8, 2001 of Huntington, LI. Beloved husband of Rene, devoted father of Michele Adelman, and Lewis Levy. Dear brother of Marion Levy. Cherished grandfather of Samuel, Laura, Murray, and Rachel. Services today 3 P.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Sports of The Times; First Pick or Last, They Are All-Stars Forever
description: IN alphabetical order, the National League All-Stars were listed on a red banner hanging from the upper deck of Safeco Field on the third-base side. The names ranged from Alou to Walker -- and there at the end was Floyd.

title: Corrections
description: An ''Arts Abroad'' article on Wednesday about the 30th anniversary of the death of the rock star Jim Morrison in Paris misstated the cause of his death. No autopsy was performed, but a French coroner ruled that Morrison had died of natural causes due to heart problems, not of an overdose of alcohol and drugs.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Microsoft Forms Privacy Venture
description: Microsoft and VeriSign, an Internet security company, said they would work together to make Microsoft's .Net Internet services safer for the privacy of users. Consumer advocates have criticized the part of Microsoft's new .Net initiative known as Hailstorm, which would collect large amounts of users' personal information within one computer system. Microsoft said it would use VeriSign's technology to improve the security of the personal information collected by .Net, and VeriSign said it began using computer servers based on Microsoft's Windows 2000 operating system as a host for Internet domain names and Web sites. Financial terms were not announced.

title: Summertime and the Swimming is Easy
description: It's a sweltering summer Friday night but you're not on a train to the Jersey Shore, a jitney to the Hamptons or a water taxi to Fire Island. Instead, you're sprawled out in front of a rickety old fan convinced that there must be a better way to stay cool. You're right: The city's beaches and pools, all within easy reach for a $1.50 MTA fare. The salty, soothing breeze blowing off the ocean at Rockaway Beach or a refreshing dip at the Asphalt Green pool can lower your temperature.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Container Law Revoked
description: The New Orleans City Council repealed the city's open-container law, which for 29 years made it illegal to walk the streets with any beverage, whether or not alcoholic, in an open metal or glass container. Opponents of the law said it was used for racial profiling, and the mayor's office said 80 percent of those charged with violating it were black. In November, a black man was shot to death by the police in a confrontation that began with his being stopped for carrying an open container of beer.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS LUCENT GETS OPTICAL FIBER ORDER

title: Visitors From Another Plane (if Not Exactly From Another Planet)
description: When the German experimental electronic act Mouse on Mars ended its United States tour last Tuesday night at Irving Plaza, its drummer, Dodo Nkishi, stopped the show to reel off a long list of thank yous to the people who made the tour possible, ''even though we didn't make any money.'' Right after, the band's electronics whiz, Jan St. Werner, apologized: ''We are not going soft or anything. It was just an emotional eruption.''

title: Brothers Arraigned In Death of Officer
description: Two brothers accused of fatally beating an off-duty Jersey City police officer with metal pipes during a fight over fireworks on the Fourth of July were arraigned on murder charges today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, MARVIN MD.
description: KELLER-Marvin MD. The Medical Staff of the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens grieve the loss of its distinguished colleague and extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family. Marvin Leder, M.D, President Talat Addasi, M.D. Vice Pres Gabriel DeAngelis, M.D. Secretary, Treasurer

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Token-Booth Clerks
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's plan to replace some token-booth clerks with automatic ticketing machines. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 633-9400.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about drilling for oil and gas under the Great Lakes misstated a part of the Bush administration's plan for energy exploration. The administration is not "calling for increased domestic drilling everywhere." Its recent energy plan calls for the Interior Department to identify suitable public lands for new oil and gas exploration. Drilling in the Great Lakes is not a part of the plan.

title: I.M.F. Official Warns Asia About Barriers to Recovery
description: A senior official for the International Monetary Fund warned today that the structural reforms demanded by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan could undermine long-term regional efforts to recover from the economic crisis of 1997 and 1998.

title: Ensemble Pluckily Confronts Rush Hour
description: The annual Summergarden concerts at the Museum of Modern Art had to be approached with a certain degree of hope, for though the music might be well chosen and the performances lively, there was always the traffic noise to contend with. Now that, because of construction at the museum, the series has moved 11 blocks south to Bryant Park and begins two hours earlier, at 6 p.m., auditors are going to need to be not just hopeful but desperate.

title: A Full Life As Lived And Invented
description: There's a reason biographies often run 700 pages or more. A life fully lived is a complex thing, one not easily summarized even with an open-ended page count. So those who would try the same feat in a two-hour play had better be prepared to discipline themselves, impose limits, choose a point of view and slice of time and stay on target.

title: House Passage Of Finance Bill Seems in Doubt
description: In the final hours before a decisive House debate on a broad bill to rewrite the campaign finance laws, the bill's sponsors said they were uncertain whether they could hold together a fragile coalition to pass a total ban on the unlimited, unregulated political donations known as soft money.

title: Article 2001071090406687116 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about changes at the New York Academy of Sciences misidentified Dr. Constance Sutton. She is a former chairwoman of the academy's anthropology section, not the current chairwoman.

title: Politics of Bush v. Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Neider, 86, Writer And Scholar of Mark Twain
description: Charles Neider, a prolific essayist, novelist, nature writer and Mark Twain scholar, died on Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 86.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Zimmer Returning To Washington
description: Richard A. Zimmer, who left the House of Representatives to run unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1996, then failed to win back his House seat in November, is returning to Washington to lobby his old colleagues. Mr. Zimmer, 56, a Republican, is joining the Washington law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, the firm said yesterday. Mr. Zimmer, of Delaware Township, N.J., represented the 12th Congressional District from 1991 to 1997, serving on the Ways and Means Committee and its subcommittees on trade and oversight. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUERTH, NORMAN
description: FUERTH-Norman. We always will love and always will miss you. Joanee, Glenn, Tommy, Elyse and your Grandchildren

title: Energy Talks Fail
description: A federal mediator ended two weeks of negotiations about California's demands for electricity refunds, seemingly with the state and power suppliers no closer to a settlement than when the talks began. The burden of resolving the dispute now shifts to federal energy regulators.

title: AT&T Splits Off Wireless Subsidiary
description: AT&T split off its wireless unit, the AT&T Wireless Group, into a separate, independent company yesterday, marking a major step in the telephone and cable company's restructuring.

title: Young Writers And Players Trade Energy And Ideas
description: Bringing composers and performers together is clearly a priority at the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, run by the Yale Summer School of Music in this bucolic town in northwestern Connecticut.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Denial On Papal Salary
description: The Vatican spokesman, Joaqun Navarro-Valls, ended speculation about the Pope's salary, saying, ''The Pope does not and has never received a salary.'' An ambiguous statement by Cardinal Sergio Sebastiani had suggested that the Pope did receive a salary. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: Transcript of Keith Stroup's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Monday, July 9, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Keith Stroup, founder of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, NORML . This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Dangerous Complication of Pregnancy Becomes More Common
description: Terry Coffey was 27 weeks pregnant when she was admitted to the hospital for observation because her blood pressure had shot up and her obstetrician worried that her life might be in danger.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Legalizing Abuses in Colombia
description: The human rights record of Colombia's army has improved somewhat in recent years. In part this is because its abuses have been privatized -- paramilitary groups with close links to many members of the armed forces are now committing the bulk of the murders of civilians. But a new law that has passed Colombia's Congress and awaits the signature of President Andrs Pastrana would give the military dangerous new powers over civilians and lessen the possibility that officers would be held accountable for abusing them.

title: Excluded From Comcast Talks, Malone Resigns AT&T Board
description: John Malone, the cable television magnate who is one of the AT&T Corporation's largest individual shareholders, resigned today from the company's board earlier than planned after he was excluded from talks related to the Comcast Corporation's offer to buy AT&T's cable systems.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline on Friday about an 82-year-old Park Slope woman who contends that she was wrongfully arrested and strip-searched referred incompletely to the disposition of criminal charges against her and in one reference misidentified the agency that handled her arrest. A judge dismissed a charge that the woman, Mary Novak, had violated an order of protection by playing a radio loudly, but she still faces trial on charges of harassment, stalking and criminal contempt, and remains under court order to stay away from her neighbors. Her arrest and search were handled by the New York Police Department, not the district attorney's office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Producer Prices Flat
description: British producer prices barely budged in June, growing at their slowest annual pace in more than two years, as manufacturers struggled to cope with growing competition at home and weaker economic growth abroad. Prices for goods leaving factories, utilities and mines rose 0.1 percent after a revised 0.4 percent gain in May. Growth from June 2000 slowed to 0.4 percent, the smallest rise since February 1999, from a revised 0.7 percent.

title: Corning and Alcatel Announce Large Cutbacks
description: Corning and Alcatel, two companies that had flourished in recent years making the building blocks of the communications industry, announced severe cutbacks yesterday, including plant closings, new layoffs totaling 3,500 workers and, in the case of Corning, the suspension of dividend payments.

title: Article 2001071090959710821 -- No Title
description: sustenance .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} Back to Main Student Connections News Summaries Daily News Quiz Word of the Day Test Prep Question of the Day Web Explorer Science Q & A Letters to the Editor Ask a Reporter On This Day in History Weekly News Quiz Resources on the Web Facts About the Times Specials

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Program For Iraq Extended Unchanged
description: Iraq formally agreed to a five-month extension of the existing ''oil for food'' program after the United States and Britain were blocked by Russia from making the program more generous for the civilian population while tightening controls on Iraqi smuggling outside United Nations supervision. Iraq, which stopped exporting oil in early June to protest possible changes in the program -- but failed to push oil prices way up -- may resume exports in a matter of days. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Safeway Posts 9.4% Gain In Earnings For Quarter
description: Fiscal second-quarter profit at Safeway rose 9.4 percent, helped by cost cutting, the company said today. Sales at supermarkets open at least a year rose less than expected, sending its shares down as much as 8.2 percent.

title: Tracking Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, ANITA
description: SALTZ-Anita. We are profoundly grieved by the passing of a devoted friend and Benefactor, whose dedication to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and compassion for others is both a legacy and an inspiration. With her beloved husband, Jack, she established a professorial chair in diabetes and a diabetes research center at our College of Medicine. In recognition of her deep commitment to research and education at our medical school, she was awarded an honorary degree from Yeshiva University in 1992. Her dedication carried forward a family tradition first established by her late father, Arthur Belfer; carried on by her brother, Robert A. Belfer, chairperson of our Board of Overseers; and the other members of the Belfer family who have played such a vital role in the life of our institution. To Jack; to their children Leonard, Susan, Ronald and Gary; to her brother and sister-in-law, Robert A. and Renee Belfer; to her sister and brother-in-law, Selma and Lawrence Ruben, members of our Society of Founders; and to all the members of the Saltz and Belfer families, we offer our deepest and most heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Emeritus Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Hawaiian Resort Discounts
description: Two luxury resorts on the Hawaiian island of Lanai are celebrating 10th anniversaries with offers of free nights. The oceanside Manele Bay Hotel will provide seven nights for the price of five, and the upcountry Lodge at Koele will provide four nights for the price of three. The stay must be completed by Dec. 26, and the deal applies to standard resort rates; availability is limited. Information: (800) 321-4666 or www.islandoflanai.com .

title: Decaying Depots On the Tracks to Freedom; New Interest in the Underground Railroad Inspires an Effort to Preserve Its Landmarks
description: In a bathroom stall in the basement of the oldest black church here, Bishop William Henderson pulls away a framed poster and pokes his head into a dank, musty hole, revealing a crawl space. He breathes in the air and pulls out the history.

title: A National Deficit, of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Mixed Verdict For Major
description: A major in the Indian Army being court-martialed for his role in a conflict in Kashmir two years ago was dismissed from the army and convicted on a charge of ''improperly'' telling his superiors that his troops were unfit for attack. But Maj. Manish Bhatnagar, whose supporters saw him as a scapegoat for the failings of the army's top officers, was acquitted on the most serious charge that he had disobeyed an order to attack Pakistani troops who had occupied a peak in an area of Kashmir held by India. The case drew attention to embarrassing accusations that the Indian military had failed to heed intelligence warnings that Pakistani soldiers disguised as Islamic militants had infiltrated Indian territory and had sent its men to fight a frigid battle with inadequate supplies.

title: Lawmaker Promises Full Aid, Even DNA Test, in Intern Case
description: Trying to deflect intense public scrutiny, the lawyer for Representative Gary A. Condit said tonight that the congressman would provide the police with any information or material they seek, including DNA evidence, in their investigation of the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy.

title: Quality of Herbal Sleep Aid Is Criticized
description: People who buy valerian, an increasingly popular herbal supplement used as a sleep aid, may not be getting what they are paying for.

title: Reform's 'Killer Amendments'
description: By all accounts the vote will be close as campaign finance reform comes before the House this week. The sham alternative put forward by opponents to try to defeat the Shays-Meehan ''soft money'' ban is only one hazard lying ahead. Today we urge lawmakers to watch out for another danger, which is the effort by opponents to try amending the bill to death. Some of the amendments to be offered may even sound appealing. But House members need to be sure that any changes to the underlying bill, however well intentioned, do not drive away more supporters than they bring on board or force a House-Senate conference at which campaign reform could be buried.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Water Shutoffs
description: Rotating cutoffs of water have begun in the Kennewick Irrigation District, in southeastern Washington, prompting complaints from surprised residents and farmers. The brief cutoffs are intended to conserve water in the drought-stricken area by restricting flow on a rotating basis to the district's 10 zones, which serve 15,000 residential customers and 400 farmers.

title: Giving In to the Urge To Do Bad in the South
description: YONDER STANDS

title: Ex-President of Philippines Arraigned on Plunder Charge
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10  Under heavy guard against possible street protests, former President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines was arraigned in Manila today on a charge of plunder.

title: Rodents and Rabies
description: Q. If the rabies virus can be transmitted by any mammal, why do we not hear of its being spread by rats in the United States?

title: Certainty and Uncertainty in Treatment of Lyme Disease
description: A study to be reported on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine is fueling a running disagreement among medical researchers over the unresolved issues in Lyme disease, a tick-borne illness that is endemic in much of the Northeast and in other pockets around the nation.

title: Cathay Pacific Fires 49 Pilots in a Union Dispute
description: A labor dispute here abruptly escalated today as Cathay Pacific Airways dismissed 49 pilots a week after the pilots' union began a work slowdown against the carrier.

title: AOL Selects Time Executive To Take Over As CNN Chief
description: Walter Isaacson, the editorial director of Time Inc. and one-time managing editor of Time magazine, is taking the reins of CNN, which is struggling to stave off competition from the Fox News Channel, MSNBC and CNBC.

title: Racial Gap Found in Asthma Treatments
description: Differences in the care given to black and white asthma patients may help explain why blacks suffer more severe symptoms and generally fare worse with the disease, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Rights Group Lists Abuses By Guerrillas In Colombia
description: The largest rebel group here regularly violates the rights of noncombatants by attacking civilians, kidnapping for ransom, recruiting children and focusing on medical workers, all in spite of the group's occasional pledges to abide by some international rights norms, Human Rights Watch says in a new report.

title: DELTA WILL END ITS WASHINGTON-BOSTON SHUTTLE FLIGHTS
description: Delta Air Lines plans to stop making Delta Shuttle flights between Washington and Boston and will scale back some international service as demand slows. Delta said yesterday that it would replace its nine daily shuttle flights between Boston and Washington with four Delta Connection flights on smaller planes through its commuter partner, Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings. Delta will cut some service to Philadelphia and Newark, as it adds flights through Salt Lake City and to Texas, among other changes. Atlantic Coast will start the new Boston-to-Washington service by Sept. 1, and make eight daily flights by Oct. 1. The carrier will still offer Delta Shuttle service between New York and Washington and New York and Boston.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Terror Trial Sentencing
description: A federal jury in Manhattan completed its second day of deliberations yesterday without deciding whether to impose the death penalty on a terrorist who was convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania, which killed 11 people. The bomber, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, a Tanzanian, was also found guilty of participating in a global conspiracy to kill Americans. If the jury does not vote unanimously in favor of the death penalty, Mr. Mohamed will be sentenced to life imprisonment. The jury will resume deliberations today. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Front Row: New Star at Gucci
description: On Friday in Paris, the Gucci Group closed the deal on the acquisition of another fashion star, Nicolas Ghesquiere, and the legendary house of Balenciaga. Gucci, which in the last year has added Alexander McQueen and Stella McCartney to its roster of emerging young talent, had negotiated with Mr. Ghesquiere and Balenciaga's owner, Groupe Jacques Bogart, for several months.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Growth Seen In Server Market
description: The application server market is growing much faster than expected despite the slowdown in corporate technology spending, concluded a study released yesterday by the International Data Corporation, a research firm. Companies spent almost $2.2 billion worldwide on application server software in 2000, compared with $957 million in 1999. Such software serves as a foundation on which programmers build their applications. ''It's difficult to overstate the significance of this growth rate,'' said Steve Garone, the International Data vice president who led the study.

title: Article 2001071093459591072 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES, Murray Hill, N.J., said it had signed a one-year, $90 million contract to provide optical networking systems to the undersea fiber optic cable provider TyCom, Pembroke, Bermuda.

title: Vallone Urges Schools to Start New Program On Values
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, saying that Democrats have for too long wrongly shied away from frank talk about morals, called yesterday for the establishment of a formal ''values education'' program in all of New York City's public schools.

title: Summer in the City
description: The summer months are notoriously sticky ones in New York, but they're also the best time to take advantage of local recreation and entertainment, most of it free  or very close to it. So rather than hybernating in the cool of the nearest air-conditioned room, get out there and have a drink, see a concert, or tackle a trail in the great outdoors. For the next few months, the sun is out and the price is right.

title: LTV SAYS IT HAS REACHED AGREEMENT WITH STEELWORKERS
description: LTV said yesterday that it had reached a labor agreement with the United Steelworkers of America that will help the company, the nation's No. 2 steelmaker, avoid liquidation. Under the tentative agreement, which is to expire in 2006, LTV will lay off 1,300 workers, halt some raises, reduce costs for pension and health benefits and make employees part owners of the company. It clears the way for LTV to seek a $250 million loan under a federal program for ailing steel producers. LTV threatened last month to stop making steel and to eliminate 7,700 jobs if the union did not agree to cost cuts. The union and LTV's creditors came up with an agreement on Friday that the company approved over the weekend. LTV is reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law.

title: Suzuki's Adventure Continues
description: Ichiro Suzuki, as expected, was a big hit today at the American League workout for Tuesday night's All-Star Game.

title: Tough on North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, ROSE
description: STEINBERG-Rose. The Foundation for Ethnic Understanding mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our distinguished colleague and activist for the strengthening of intergroup relations, Elan Steinberg. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier, President Lawrence D. Kopp, Exec Director

title: Who Is in Charge, President or C.E.O.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunnel Vision; The Texan Who Rides Herd on the City's Subways
description: He is not a long tall Texan. He is more of a square, substantial one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHNEIDER, IRMA
description: GOLDSCHNEIDER-Irma. 96, June 7, after a long illness. Sister of the late Teresa Kenner, Helen Ross, Stanley and Harold Gold, aunt of Ruth Shiff, Phyllis Robinson, Dorothy Broh and the late Marjorie Cabot, great-aunt of Ann Jacobson, Margery Cantor and Nancy Thompson, grand-aunt of Adam, Robert and Ina Jacobson. Former Assistant Probate Clerk of the Surrogate's Court of NY. Service on Wednesday at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions may be sent to Alzheimer's Association, 316 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10017.

title: A National Deficit, of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Users Want a Greater Say on How the Internet Runs
description: If the American public could elect a governing body for the Internet, candidates would include the Pope, William H. Gates, Oprah Winfrey, teachers, ex-hackers and ''regular folks,'' according to the first major study of public attitudes about accountability on the Internet, to be released today by the Markle Foundation, a nonprofit group that focuses on public policy and technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNDEN, IDA
description: HARNDEN-Ida. Dancer. Devoted wife of the late artist William Hershel Harnden. Loving mother of Bonnie and Danny. Will finally play The Palace. Cherished sister of Pauline Bloom and affectionate aunt to many nieces and nephews. She was a tireless senior advocate, loved and admired by all who knew her. Friends may call at Riverside Chapel 180 W. 76 St., NYC, Tuesday July 10th 7pm-9pm. Services Wednesday 11:15am.

title: Ammirati Executives Open New Agency
description: Four top executives at Ammirati Puris in Toronto said yesterday that they had left to open John Street in Toronto as a unit of the Envoy Communications Group.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: A Move as Catalyst
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Miners' Protest
description: Thousands of unpaid miners blocked a rail line in Jishu, in Jilin Province, vowing not to leave without three years' back pay owed them by state-owned mines. The tracks link the province's second biggest city, also called Jilin, with Harbin. Such protests have become common as the government pushes money-losing state enterprises to fend for themselves.

title: Sports of The Times; Extra Day Turns Into Special Day
description: If ever there was a time for Goran Ivanisevic to be a Wimbledon champion, it was on what had to be the most frenzied and unconventional Wimbledon day of all. And to think, some of us thought the gentlemen who preside over the world's grandest tournament had drunk a little too much tea when they decided to extend it an extra day.

title: Article 2001071093709932333 -- No Title
description: July 8, 2001

title: Summertime and the Swimming is Easy
description: It's a sweltering summer Friday night but you're not on a train to the Jersey Shore, a jitney to the Hamptons or a water taxi to Fire Island. Instead, you're sprawled out in front of a rickety old fan convinced that there must be a better way to stay cool. You're right: The city's beaches and pools, all within easy reach for a $1.50 MTA fare. The salty, soothing breeze blowing off the ocean at Rockaway Beach or a refreshing dip at the Asphalt Green pool can lower your temperature.

title: Review/Fashion; Nostalgia Tripping to the Mysterious East and Psychedelia
description: Showing between such a hothouse pair as John Galliano of Dior and Julien Macdonald, the new designer at Givenchy, Jean Paul Gaultier, demonstrated on Sunday why he may be the most accomplished couturier of his generation.

title: Japan Rejects Calls To Revise Textbooks
description: The Japanese government announced that it would order no further revisions of school textbooks that many critics say whitewash the country's record of imperial-era atrocities in Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILE, STERLING JR.
description: PILE-Sterling Jr. Age 86, of Brookville, L.I., died July 8, 2001, after complications following surgery. Beloved husband of Leila; loving father of Leila, Marjorie, Sterling and Laurie, and the fabulous Pop to eight grandchildren. Services will be held at 11:00 AM on July 14, 2001, at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pasquaney Trust, 5 So. State St, Concord, NH 03301.

title: GAMBLING COMPANIES MERGE IN $1.36 BILLION DEAL
description: International Game Technology is acquiring Anchor Gaming in a $1.1 billion stock swap, creating the largest public company in Nevada. International Game, based in Reno, is a large manufacturer of slot machines. Anchor, based in Las Vegas, also makes slot machines. It owns casinos in Cripple Creek and Black Hawk, Colo., and a slot machine network in Nevada. The deal was announced late on Sunday. The companies put its value at $1.36 billion. It includes a one-to-one stock swap worth $1.1 billion, with International Game assuming $430 million in Anchor debt, minus the value of assets. The companies said the merger would create a company with greater stock market value than MGM Mirage, now Nevada's largest public company.

title: No-Trade Clause Stalls the Knicks Contract Talks With Houston
description: Last week's late-night meeting between Allan Houston and Knicks officials was fruitful and encouraging. But two people with knowledge of the negotiations said the two sides had not reached an agreement in principle that would make Houston the highest-paid player in franchise history.

title: Mating Dances Go On and On
description: Fairy tales never reveal exactly what happens once the prince and princess have shaken the rice from their hair, but here's a sample of how other coupled creatures interpret the phrase, ''And they lived happily ever after'':

title: Article 2001071091078648345 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: When Third Parties Dispense Second Opinions
description: Who owns your body? Why, you do, of course. Like your first vote and first legal drink, your first time alone in the doctor's office was a rite of passage, the moment you were finally acknowledged sovereign of your own flesh and bone, chief operating officer of your bowels and sole spokesman for your pores, while your former regent, now deposed, leafed through magazines in the waiting room.

title: Real Religious Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Amerada Hess Agrees to Buy Triton Energy for $2.6 Billion
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation will buy Triton Energy Limited for about $2.6 billion in cash, the companies said today.

title: Japan's Refusal to Revise Textbooks Angers Its Neighbors
description: The Japanese government announced today that it would order no further revisions of school textbooks that many critics say whitewash the country's record of imperial-era atrocities in Asia.

title: Puppets And People Tell Tales Of Antiquity
description: Confused kings and queens, three spoiled princes and a death-dealing beggar were among the vivid characters who came to life in Jodi Liss's ''Tales From the Ocean of the Sea of Stories'' on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Effort To Save Whale
description: Rescuers plan to try today to save a rare right whale that became entangled in a fishing line about 95 miles off the coast. The whale has a jaw infection that could kill it, caused by the fishing line. The effort will be the second to save the whale, a 50-ton male. Right whales are near extinction, with some 300 left. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOTTY, ROBERT, M.D.
description: KOTTY-Robert, M.D. July 24, 1909 -July 10, 2000. Gifted psychiatrist, beloved friend. Always remembered, Norma and Sally.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Gets Optical Fiber Order
description: Lucent Technologies, the biggest American maker of phone equipment, said it had received a multimillion-dollar order for optical fiber from Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest phone company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: REAL GAINS. Brazil's real strengthened after the central bank sold an undisclosed sum of dollars to help prop it up. In New York, the currency settled at 2.454 reais to the dollar from 2.522 reais on Friday.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From a recipe for white gazpacho to wine touring in Oregon, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Victory For National Action Party
description: In an election marred by apathy, the conservative National Action Party, the PAN, dominated the contest for governor on Sunday in Baja California. Voters in the state, a PAN stronghold for more than 15 years, were the first to oust the long ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, the PRI, from the governor's office, and their support for the PAN was no surprise. With more than 92 percent of the ballots counted, the PAN's Eugenio Elorduy was winning by more than 10 percent over Daniel Quintero Pea of the PRI. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: New York Business Briefing
description: MERCEDES DEALERSHIP EXPANDING Hotels, restaurants and travel agents may be feeling the economic slowdown, but Mercedes-Benz Manhattan is not. The dealership is tripling the size of its showroom at 430 Park Avenue, on 56th Street, to 10,107 square feet. The company needs more room because sales have tripled since 1998, said Ralph Risher, general manager for the dealership. The showroom, a satellite of the Mercedes-Benz dealership on West 41st Street, occupies a rare commercial space designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. "This was a unique opportunity to create one of the most magnificent automobile showrooms in Midtown," said David Hoffman Jr., the broker at Colliers ABR, the real estate company, who represented Mercedes-Benz.

title: NCR Says Quarterly Results Were Weaker Than Forecast
description: The NCR Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings and sales missed forecasts.

title: Samaranch's Complex Legacy
description: A day short of his 81st birthday, Juan Antonio Samaranch will retire Monday after 21 years as president of the International Olympic Committee. His stewardship has been as complicated as it has been long, and the Olympic Games have never been so prosperous or so compromised.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROHN, RUTH
description: TROHN-Ruth. Age 90. On July 8, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Dear sister of Marie Cassen and the late Meyer Kowaloff. Loving and devoted aunt, great-aunt and great great-aunt. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: New Jersey Official Resigns Over Plans for the Meadowlands
description: The chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority resigned yesterday over his objections to a proposal to redevelop the Meadowlands sports complex into a mixture of offices and retail space.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Pesky Bug Buildup

title: An Ambitious Internet Grocer Is Out of Both Cash and Ideas
description: Webvan, the online grocer that epitomized the buoyant optimism that the Internet could revolutionize even the most entrenched industries, closed yesterday and said it would seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Restored to the Canon, Plus Funny Bits
description: Is anything new to be learned about Shakespeare from the Hope Theater Company's production of ''Edward III'' at the Bank Street Theater? Hardly; we knew all along he was capable of clogged lines and frayed plots, and this performance creates problems of its own. The play as printed reveals little about Edward III, which is too bad, since he was king of England for 50 years in the 14th century, and his children and their families formed both sides in the War of the Roses, about which Shakespeare wrote good plays.

title: Welcome to New York, Mr. President
description: In his first six months in office, President Bush has visited 32 states, including four trips to Florida and one to South Dakota, which has fewer people than Staten Island. New York has been nowhere on the presidential map. Today, however, Mr. Bush will at last pay a visit. It will be a quick, low-risk exercise -- he will speak about immigration on Ellis Island and honor the late Cardinal John O'Connor at St. Patrick's Cathedral in a bid to woo particular voting blocs. Nobody expects him to dally.

title: Letters: Party Affiliation Unimportant
description: To the Editor:

title: Limping Liberty Holds Off The Fever
description: Vickie Johnson made her exit at halftime. She took a seat on the bench, experiencing cramping in her right hamstring.

title: The Declining Terrorist Threat
description: Judging from news reports and the portrayal of villains in our popular entertainment, Americans are bedeviled by fantasies about terrorism. They seem to believe that terrorism is the greatest threat to the United States and that it is becoming more widespread and lethal. They are likely to think that the United States is the most popular target of terrorists. And they almost certainly have the impression that extremist Islamic groups cause most terrorism.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about drilling for oil and gas under the Great Lakes misstated a part of the Bush administration's plan for energy exploration. The administration is not ''calling for increased domestic drilling everywhere.'' Its recent energy plan calls for the Interior Department to identify suitable public lands for new oil and gas exploration. Drilling in the Great Lakes is not a part of the plan.

title: Mars Expected to Buy Part of Pet Food Maker
description: Mars Inc., the pet food and candy company, is expected to announce today that it is buying at least part of Royal Canin, the French pet food maker, according to executives close to the deal.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the New York State Consumer Protection Board's investigation of telemarketers that offer costly antifraud packages misattributed a statement. It was Edward Langoria, the president of the Senior Advisory Council, which sells an antifraud package, who acknowledged that some of the steps could be ''done solely by the consumer'' but said that since few of them took the trouble, his group was filling a need. The statement was not made by Jon Sorensen, the board's spokesman.

title: California and Generators Still Split After 2-Week Talks
description: A federal mediator ended two weeks of negotiations about California's demands for electricity refunds today, with the state and power suppliers seemingly no closer to a settlement than when the talks began.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: North Bellmore: Robbery Is Thwarted
description: A gas station attendant who is a former corrections officer fatally shot a man yesterday who tried to rob him, the Nassau County police said. The would-be robber, whom police would not identify because his relatives had not been told, entered the Mobil gas station at 871 Newbridge Road here around noon and asked to use the phone. The attendant, Bruce W. Longley, 64, sent him to the pay phone outside. The robber came back with what the police said appeared to be a semiautomatic handgun and ordered Mr. Longley to hand over the money in the cash register. After taking the cash, the robber demanded more. Mr. Longley said there was no more, pulled out a licensed .40-caliber handgun and shot the robber, the police said. A police official said the robber's weapon was a BB gun that looked like an automatic pistol. No charges are expected to be filed against Mr. Longley, who retired from the New York City Department of Correction 22 years ago. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Century 21 Heading West
description: The discount retailer Century 21 will open its first New Jersey store next March in Morristown, in a three-story building on the Morristown Green that has been unoccupied since a Macy's store closed in 1993. Under the 20-year lease, Century 21 will pay $5 million to $7 million of the cost of renovations, and the building's owner, Morristown Green, will pay up to $8 million, said Raymond Gindi, the vice president of the family-owned retailer. Century 21's flagship store is on Cortlandt Street in Lower Manhattan, and it has other stores in Brooklyn and in Westbury on Long Island. The stores sell designer merchandise at 25 percent to 75 percent off retail prices. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: An Urban Childhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rejects A Plea to Shut A Power Plant
description: A state judge in Staten Island refused yesterday to halt the operation of a new mini-power plant in the borough. The ruling means that the plant and nine others at the heart of the Pataki administration's plan to prevent blackouts in New York City this summer will be used, at least for now.

title: LVMH's Shares Rise Sharply As It Reports Sales Gains
description: Despite faltering growth in its major markets, the luxury goods conglomerate LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported unexpectedly encouraging revenues for the first half of the year, largely a result of continued strong sales in its fashion and cosmetic businesses, the company said.

title: Clearing the Air for Children of Smokers
description: Doctors hoping to reduce the exposure of smokers' children to secondhand smoke have found that putting nicotine monitors in the home seems to help persuade parents to smoke less around their children.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Alloy Online To Buy Cass
description: Alloy Online in New York, a media and direct marketing company that focuses on the market for teenagers, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire CASS Communications in Chicago, which offers integrated advertising and marketing services to connect national advertisers and their agencies with the college and high school markets. Under the terms of the agreement, Alloy has issued approximately 1.7 million shares of stock, valued at about $23 million, and paid $9.7 million in cash and future performance-based consideration to complete the acquisition. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: A Note of Caution on Bee Sting Allergies
description: Anyone with a history of bee sting allergies shouldn't put too much faith in a skin test that shows the danger has gone away, researchers have found.

title: Yellow Jersey Is No Fashion Statement
description: To some teams in the Tour de France, the leader's yellow jersey in the early days is a prize beyond belief, and to others it is a sugarcoated bullet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAVROPOULOS, NANCY
description: STAVROPOULOS-Nancy. On July 8, 2001, at age 74. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Peter and his wife Cally. Adoring grandmother of George. Dear brother of Peter and James. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, July 10, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 337 East 74th Street, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at New Cemetery, Somerville, NJ. Contributions in her memory may be made to the George Stavropoulos Academic Chair at Kent State University or St. Michael's Home for the Aged.

title: Other Side of Monticello
description: To the Editor:

title: Reserved Scientist Creates an Uproar With His Work on Stem Cells
description: When Jonas Salk discovered the polio vaccine, he granted the journalist Edward R. Murrow an interview, appeared in a photo spread in Life magazine, and became an American hero virtually overnight. When Dolly the sheep was cloned, her creator, Ian Wilmut, was featured in news magazines and on television programs around the globe.

title: Effects of the Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Real World Record:$64.5 Million for Zidane
description: LONDON  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Wednesday July 11th, 2001:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Border Crossing Eased
description: The government plans to ease travel between India and Pakistan by making it possible to get a visa at the border, another in a series of goodwill gestures that have included freeing 400 Pakistani prisoners. Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee is to be the host for Pakistan's military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, at summit talks this weekend.

title: No Endorsements From Sharpton Until His Release
description: Saying he did not want to divert attention from the cause behind the protests against the Navy bombing exercises in Vieques, P.R., the Rev. Al Sharpton indicated yesterday that he would wait until after he was released from federal prison before making any political endorsements.

title: Hopkins Content to Be the Bad Guy
description: For Bernard Hopkins, it is a short ride from his home in Philadelphia to New York City -- ''give me two days, and I'll jog it'' -- but the proximity to Madison Square Garden does not fool him.

title: A Move as Catalyst
description: To the Editor:

title: London Journal; 5 Characters in Search of an Office
description: One Michael, the son of an immigrant, is on a quest for self-discovery. Another Michael, an earl married to the daughter of a duke, knows exactly who he is. Ken is comfortable with his paunch, Iain is unbothered by his baldness and David is hoping to create a public persona.

title: Front Row; New Star at Gucci
description: On Friday in Paris, the Gucci Group closed the deal on the acquisition of another fashion star, Nicolas Ghesquiere, and the legendary house of Balenciaga. Gucci, which in the last year has added Alexander McQueen and Stella McCartney to its roster of emerging young talent, had negotiated with Mr. Ghesquiere and Balenciaga's owner, Groupe Jacques Bogart, for several months.

title: Zidane to Real Madrid In Record Transfer Fee
description: ZINEDINE ZIDANE, the son of Algerian immigrants, who led France to the World Cup title in 1998 and the European Championship last year, became the world's most expensive player yesterday. Zidane was transferred from Juventus of Italy to Real Madrid of Spain for a $64.5 million transfer fee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, ABBING, MSGR. JOHN PATRICK
description: CARROLL-ABBING-Msgr. John Patrick. Died July 9, 2001. Founder of Boys' Towns of Italy, Inc., and other relief organizations in Italy. Funeral 4 PM, Wednesday, July 11th, at Boys' Town, Rome. Memorial contributions to the Msgr. J.P. Carroll-Abbing Scholarship Fund, c/o Boys' Towns of Italy, Inc. 250 East 63 St, NY, NY 10021.

title: Easing Parents' Anxiety Over a Child's Fever
description: Despite many attempts to ease parents' fears about fever, many are still overly concerned about it, often to the potential detriment of their children.

title: Who Is in Charge, President or C.E.O.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Physicists Unite, Sort of, on Next Collider
description: The directors of major physics laboratories in Europe, the United States and Japan gathered at this mountain resort this week to make plans for a new particle accelerator they all agreed would be so large, powerful and expensive that it could be built only if they all cooperated on a scale without parallel in scientific history.

title: Violence Breaks Out Amid Camden Corruption Inquiry
description: A corruption scandal in the Camden Parking Authority erupted in violence today when the former executive director of the authority, facing criminal corruption charges, died, apparently in a suicide, after shooting and severely injuring a former employee and accuser.

title: S.U.V. Crash Becomes the Talk of the Hamptons
description: It took Claudia Hunt one word to sum up her feelings on Topic A in the Hamptons. But that word was unprintable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECTER, LANI
description: SCHECTER-Lani. On July 8, 2001. Beloved wife of Philip. Devoted mother of Robyn Schecter-Park. Mother-in-law of James Park. Cherished grandmother of Gunner. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: PENTAGON TO SEEK MONEY FOR TESTING OF MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Pentagon is preparing to ask Congress for money to build a missile defense test site in Alaska that could also become the command center for a working antimissile system as early as 2004, military officials said.

title: Financial Magazine Closes
description: Jonathan Steinberg, the chief executive of the Individual Investor Group, said yesterday that he would shut Individual Investor magazine and lay off 90 percent of the company's staff, or about 50 employees.

title: SILICON GRAPHICS POSTS A LOSS, AND AN EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: Silicon Graphics, whose computer workstations are used to create movie effects, said yesterday that it had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of as much as $80 million and that its chief financial officer, Hal Covert, resigned. The loss before charges for the quarter ended June 30 was $70 million to $80 million on revenue of $430 million to $440 million. Mr. Covert, who joined the company in July 2000, will be succeeded by Jeffrey Zellmer, the controller. Bookings for the coming fiscal year are disappointing, Bob Bishop, the chairman and chief executive, said on a conference call. In April, Silicon Graphics said it would dismiss 1,000 workers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officer Charged In Beating
description: A corrections officer, on leave because of a medical disability, was charged yesterday with attempted murder, accused of hitting her sister over the head Sunday with a piece of a metal pipe, the police said. The officer, Renee Dasque, 36, is also being investigated in the killing of her 63-year-old father, whose bludgeoned body was found later on Sunday in the basement of their Rosedale home, the police said. Ms. Dasque was initially charged with assault, but the police added the attempted murder charge yesterday. The sister, Jeanine Dasque, was treated at Franklin Hospital Medical Center in Valley Stream for a head cut and released, the police said. Ms. Dasque She had worked at a maximum-security prison on Rikers Island before going on medical leave this spring, the authorities said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: A Wild Card, a Wild Crowd, a Wild Wimbledon Finish
description: On the last changeover of a Wimbledon final destined to become a folk tale, Goran Ivanisevic threw a towel over his head to block out the Aussies clutching their inflatable kangaroos and to seal off the chants from the face-painted Croatians.

title: Cities and Their Suburbs Are Seen Growing as Units
description: The vast majority of new jobs and economic wealth created in the United States over the past decade were generated within metropolitan areas, a new analysis for the nation's mayors shows.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Something a Little Different

title: For Heart Surgeons, Many Careful Steps
description: When Dr. Laman A. Gray Jr. and Dr. Robert D. Dowling implanted the first self-contained, battery-powered artificial heart in a patient at Jewish Hospital here last week, it was the second time in 16 years that Louisville had been vaulted into the news by experiments with an artificial heart.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Asset Seizure For Drug Offense
description: In one of Nassau County's largest asset seizures for a drug-related offense, the Nassau County district attorney's office has seized $750,000 from the estate of a man who committed suicide after being arrested for dealing drugs. The man, Robert Vorbeck of Queens, was arrested in July 1999 on charges of selling cocaine in Nassau, Queens and Suffolk Counties. Two weeks later, he committed suicide in jail. Under state law, a prosecutor can seek forfeiture of any asset obtained during criminal activity. Denis Dillon, the district attorney, had sought all of Mr. Vorbeck's assets, but settled with the estate administrator for drug-related assets. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Who Is in Charge, President or C.E.O.?
description: To the Editor:

title: A National Deficit, of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: A campaign for an online brokerage firm promises to eliminate the 'middleman.'
description: AT a time when online trading volume is contracting and most Web-based brokerage firms are cutting their advertising budgets, a new online brokerage firm is seeking to generate awareness among and business from potential customers with a television, print and online campaign.

title: Armstrong Says Doctor Never Talked About Drugs
description: ''It's rip Lance time,'' Lance Armstrong said pleasantly and cryptically in a conversation just before the start of this 88th Tour de France. Now his meaning is becoming clear.

title: No Whistle as Players and Refs Talk
description: Scottie Pippen had been waiting two months to ask the question. The veteran Trail Blazers forward wondered why a certain superstar got away with physical contact he believed other players could not.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Roger Clinton Gets A Trial Date
description: An Aug. 7 trial was scheduled for Roger Clinton, former President Bill Clinton's half-brother, who was arrested in February in Hermosa Beach, Calif., on charges of driving under the influence and disturbing the peace. The judge ordered the prosecution to turn over by July 23 police cell phone records requested by the defense. Mark Geragos, Mr. Clinton's lawyer, says the authorities made a target of him. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESHAMKIN, OLIVER M., M.D.
description: NESHAMKIN-Oliver M., M.D. July 8, 2001, peacefully in his home in Manhattan. Beloved husband of Lucy. Devoted father of Paul and his wife, Ruth, and Linda and her husband John W. French. Proud grandfather of Alexandra and Jennifer French. Staunton Military Academy '31, Columbia College '35, Anderson College of Medicine, Glasgow, Scotland '42. Combat surgeon in European Theater of WWII. Dedicated physician. Former staff of Midtown and St. Clare's Hospitals. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Columbia College Alumni Fund. Memorial service later. Call Paul Neshamkin at 201-714-4881 for information.

title: Board Makes Push to Fill City Summer School Seats
description: Aura D. Rivera, the principal of Intermediate School 195 in West Harlem, hustled in at 7 a.m. yesterday to welcome the 344 students assigned to the school's summer program.

title: Tracking Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001071092808767895 -- No Title
description: Wimbledon champion. .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} Back to Main   Daily Lesson Plan Lesson Plan Archive News Snapshot Crossword Puzzle Affiliate Program Advisory Board Quote of the Day Campus Weblines Education News Newspaper in Education (NIE) Teacher Resources Classroom Subscriptions   News Summaries Daily News Quiz Word of the Day Test Prep Question of the Day Web Explorer Science Q & A Letters to the Editor Ask a Reporter   Conversation Starters Family Movie Guide Site of the Day Discussion topics Product Reviews Vacation Donation Plan Educational Products On This Day in History Weekly News Quiz Monthly Calendar Resources on the Web Facts About The Times Specials

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Inmate On Hunger Strike Dies
description: The death toll from a hunger strike over prison conditions rose to 28 with the death of Ali Koc, 30, an inmate serving 12 years for membership in a left-wing organization, human rights officials said. Hundreds of radical leftist prisoners and their relatives have conducted a hunger strike since the inmates were transferred from dormitory-style prisons to jails with cells, where, inmates say, they are vulnerable to abuse. The government says the smaller cells are necessary to regain control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREINDEL, JOSEPH H., M.D.
description: BREINDEL-Joseph H., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians, nurses and staff in the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Joseph H. Breindel, M.D., a dedicated member of the hospital's Ob/Gyn medical staff, who retired in 1989. To his beloved wife, Sonia, his family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President, Medical Board Arnold J. Friedman, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Ob/Gyn Robert L. Salant, M.D., President Doctors Alumni Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIMES, KENNETH
description: GRIMES-Kenneth. The Board and staff of Citymeals-on-Wheels express sympathy to our Vice President, Robert Grimes, on the loss of his father, Kenneth-a loving, courageous and righteous gentleman for all his 91 years. Preston Robert Tisch, President Gael Greene, Founder and Chair Marcia Stein, Executive Director

title: Metro Business Briefing | Satellite Radio Studio
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings has opened a broadcasting studio in New York, about nine blocks from its sole rival, Sirius Satellite Radio. XM is leasing 5,000 square feet at 111 West 57th Street in Midtown's Steinway Building. XM plans to begin broadcasting as many as 100 channels of news and music from two satellites to car radios in the United States for $9.95 a month by the end of September. Sirius has said it will start selling radio service for $12.95 a month in the fourth quarter.

title: Mission Will Add New Portal to Space Station
description: The next addition to the International Space Station will be a porch and a doorway that will make it easier for astronauts to go outside for spacewalks.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Mercedes Dealership Expanding
description: Hotels, restaurants and travel agents may be feeling the economic slowdown, but Mercedes-Benz Manhattan is not. The dealership is tripling the size of its showroom at 430 Park Avenue, on 56th Street, to 10,107 square feet. The company needs more room because sales have tripled since 1998, said Ralph Risher, general manager for the dealership. The showroom, a satellite of the Mercedes-Benz dealership on West 41st Street, occupies a rare commercial space designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. ''This was a unique opportunity to create one of the most magnificent automobile showrooms in Midtown,'' said David Hoffman Jr., the broker at Colliers ABR, the real estate company, who represented Mercedes-Benz. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, LOUIS JOSEPH
description: FINKELSTEIN-Louis Joseph, on July 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Rosalynde Finkelstein (nee Kleinberg). Dearest father of Karen Orenstein of Washington, DC and the late Robert Z. Finkelstein. Adoring grandfather of Joshua (Jacqueline) and Abigail Orenstein and Jeremy and Jared Finkelstein. Loving father-in-law of Jan Orenstein and Harriet Finkelstein. Devoted brother of Sol Finkelstein and the late Julius Finkelstein and Ethel Tanser. Caring brother-inlaw of Martin and Eleanor Kleinberg, Seymour and Gloria Kleinberg and Sylvia Finkelstein. Graveside service to be held at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ on Tuesday, July 10. Memorial contributions may be made to Hebrew Home of Greater Washington, 6121 Montrose Rd., Rockville, MD 20852 or Alzheimer's Association. Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Inc., Rockville, MD, 800-217-9403

title: Mars Gets Its Close-Up
description: WEATHERING THE STORMS -- Clouds of ice and swirling orange dust storms are visible above Mars in a picture taken by the Hubble Space Telescope on June 26, when the planet was about 43 million miles from Earth -- the closest it had been to Earth since 1988.

title: Party Affiliation Unimportant
description: To the Editor:

title: All-Star Games: Indifferent Players Meet Blas Viewers
description: If form holds during tonight's baseball All-Star Game in Seattle, few players will come to bat more than twice, no one will play every inning, almost every pitcher will get into the game and managerial strategy will be discarded in order to let every player participate.

title: Aventis Is Said to Be Ready to Sell Agrochemicals Business
description: Aventis, the French-German pharmaceutical company, has entered into exclusive negotiations to sell its agrochemicals business to Bayer, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Galileo Sale Is Approved
description: The Cendant Corporation's $3.5 billion purchase of Galileo International Inc. received clearance from the Federal Trade Commission today. The F.T.C. granted the New York-based company's request for an early end to a waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Act, Cendant said in a statement. Galileo is the second-largest reservations system for travel agents behind the Sabre Holdings Corporation. Cendant's purchase is still subject to the approval of regulatory authorities outside the United States and Galileo's shareholders.

title: A Tree Project Helps the Genes of Champions Live On
description: As a bald eagle wheels overhead against a crystalline blue sky, Martin Flanagan walks toward a grove of towering cottonwood trees beside the Yellowstone River, which is the color of chocolate milk as the spring runoff rushes past.

title: Superior Data On Mice DNA Is Being Cited As Attraction
description: Celera Genomics said yesterday that it had signed up its first customer from the inner ranks of its rival in the race to decode the human genome. The National Cancer Institute, part of the National Institutes of Health, has signed an agreement to allow its researchers access to Celera's genome database.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Online Grocer Calls It Quits After Running Out of Money

title: Needy Workers Wait for a Kansas Plant to Reopen
description: The cluster of white buildings and steel bins rises above these cattle-covered plains like a miniature city of skyscrapers. But the giant Con Agra beef processing plant here is still these days. Gone are the rows of workers' cars that used to fill its parking lots, and gone, too, is the bustle of business from sunrise to sundown.

title: Public's Chance to Inspect Emissions-Test Contracting
description: In the year and a half since its disastrous debut left drivers fuming in long lines, New Jersey's problem-plagued emissions-testing system has spawned an equally long trail of investigations, reports and recriminations. And on Tuesday, the line will grow a little longer, as state investigators begin the public part of a look that has taken months into the awarding of the contract to build and operate the system.

title: A National Deficit, of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Destroy 14 Homes Of Palestinian Refugees
description: Israeli wrecking crews protected by hundreds of riot police officers destroyed 14 homes at the edge of a Palestinian refugee camp in East Jerusalem today in the biggest demolition campaign in the city's Arab neighborhoods in recent years.

title: Bush Seems to Ease His Stance On the Accountability of Schools
description: With a joint committee yet to tackle differences in the House and Senate education bills requiring annual nationwide testing of public school students, the White House appears to be favoring the Senate's weaker demands for state accountability for educating poor, black and Hispanic children.

title: For AT&T, Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, may be wondering just how Vision No. 3 would suit him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, KENNETH
description: WOLFE-Kenneth. The New York Metropolitan Region of The United Synagogue of Conservative Judiasm mourns the untimely passing of our Board Member. Our condolences to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Marsha Shlefstein, President Bruce F. Greenfield, Exec. Dir.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Alliance Negotiations
description: Alitalia said it had agreed to hold exclusive talks with Air France and Delta Air Lines on partnerships that could help profitability and give its passengers easier access to European and United States flights. Alitalia said the talks would probably be completed by October and the accords would go into effect in April 2002. The carriers said the agreements could lead to Alitalia joining Air France's and Delta's SkyTeam alliance, and Alitalia's chief executive, Francesco Mengozzi, said such an alliance might eventually lead to a merger.

title: A Move as Catalyst
description: To the Editor:

title: Destiny Revisits the Great Plains
description: As the Fourth of July holiday week began, I was stuck with driving through Yellowstone National Park, because the most direct route to Wyoming is through the park. I don't normally visit Yellowstone by choice. Montanans don't suffer traffic well, but I am even more vexed by the sight of American tourists videotaping museum-piece megafauna. Confining bison to a park is an admission of defeat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEMBERTON, CATHERINE WATJEN
description: PEMBERTON-Catherine Watjen. Died peacefully at home on July 6th 2001 at the age of 99. Widow of the late John C. Pemberton, she was born in New York City on April 26, 1902, graduated from Chapin School with the Class of 1920, attended the Art Students League, and started a fifty-seven year career as interior decorator in 1933. ''Cottie'' was a prominent professional, numbering among her clients Mayor John Lindsay and his wife Mary for whom she decorated Gracie Mansion. She was a member of the Colony and Cosmopolitan clubs, and for almost 50 years maintained a summer home on Norton Farm, Lambert's Cove Road, Martha's Vineyard. Her restored dwelling was built by Captain Nathan Smith in 1740. She is survived by a son, Louis Watjen Pemberton of New York and his four children Christine, Anne, Julia and Andrea, and the four grandchildren by her late son John C. Pemberton, Jr. of Philadelphia; Mary Murdock, Frances Tyler, Catherine Pemberton and John C. Pemberton IV, as well as seven great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at the Congregational Church of West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard at 3:00 on Sunday July 29th; a memorial service will be held in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave at 51st, at 4:00, October 3rd. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, Central Park Conservancy or the Vineyard Conservation Society.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Hip Implant Lawsuits
description: Sulzer Medica, Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic products, now faces about 1,000 lawsuits over a recalled hip implant. The company, based in Winterthur, Switzerland, said insurance probably would not cover all the related costs. The number of lawsuits has jumped from the last report of about 800. Meanwhile, about 2,200 patients have had surgery to replace the implants, the company said. Sulzer Medica's chairman, Max Link, said he expected the figure to rise to 2,500.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Chris Byrnes, senior editor and graphics director at Charlex, New York, was named president. He succeeds Alex Weil, who continues as chief executive and executive creative director. Also at Charlex, nine executives were named vice presidents: Steve Chiarello, senior producer; Tom Ferguson, business manager; Marc Goldfine, senior flame artist; Donna Herman, financial controller; Amy Kindred, executive producer; David Langley, corporate affairs; Grey Oyen, senior flame artist and technical director; Harry Skopas, director for engineering; and John Zawisha, senior editor.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Caviar Smuggling Sentence
description: A Russian citizen was sentenced on Friday to 27 months in federal prison for attempting to smuggle more than $1 million worth of caviar into the United States, the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn said. Grigori Oudovenko, president of MNA Atlantic, a caviar-exporting company with offices in Russia and New York City, had pleaded guilty to falsely packaging 1,760 pounds of sevruga and osetra caviar in a container labeled as dried fish, said Julie Myers, an assistant United States attorney. Investigators confiscated the shipment in the Port of Newark last summer, in what officials of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service called the largest seizure of caviar since trade controls took effect three years ago. Mr. Oudovenko, who was sentenced by Judge John Gleeson of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, faced up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Foreign Affairs; Policy by Obituary
description: Let's do a quick test. I'll mention a name and you tell me what comes to mind. Ready? Secretary of State Colin Powell . . . Quick -- what comes to mind? Well, actually nothing.

title: Front Row; Just Plain Egon
description: Those too young to have been cavorting in wrap dresses to the song ''Lady Marmalade'' might not know that once, long ago, Diane Von Furstenberg used to be Diane Someone Else. The designer came by her surname in 1969 when she married Prince Egon Von Furstenberg, a bon vivant she met as a student in Geneva.

title: Market Place; As Comcast moves to acquire AT&T's cable business, investors worry about the price.
description: SHARES of the Comcast Corporation dropped sharply yesterday as investors absorbed its unsolicited $44.5 billion offer for the cable business of AT&T. Stock analysts said the decline was touched off by fears that Comcast was offering a high price and might be forced to sweeten the bid to win the approval of AT&T.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Pet Food Purchase
description: Mars Inc. said it would acquire the French pet-food maker Royal Canin in a deal worth $1.3 billion. Mars agreed to pay 825 million euros, or 145 euros a share, for the 56.4 percent stake in Royal Canin that is now owned by Paribas Affaires Industrielles, the private equity arm of the French bank BNP Paribas. Mars said it would offer the same amount for the remainder of Royal Canin, valuing the company at 1.5 billion euros, or about $1.3 billion.

title: Managing the Masai Mara
description: Kenya's Masai Mara is one of the world's most famous and lucrative game reserves. Thousands of khaki-clad tourists bearing large amounts of hard currency visit the Mara each year to savor its unspoiled savanna and a breathtaking array of wildlife. They thrill to the elemental drama of predatory lions, leopards and cheetahs in perpetual hunt among grazing flocks of giraffes, zebras, elephants, impalas, Thomson's gazelles, sable antelopes. Unfortunately, behind this shimmering natural spectacle lies a darker human tradition of exploitation and corruption that has impoverished the Kenyan people to whom the reserve actually belongs, a tribe of nomadic cattle herders known as the Masai. But now a plan is afoot that, if successful, could bring long-overdue change to this sorry condition.

title: SCIENTISTS CREATE SCORES OF EMBRYOS TO HARVEST CELLS
description: Breaking a taboo against creating human embryos expressly for medical experiments, scientists at a Virginia fertility clinic have mixed donated eggs and sperm to derive embryonic stem cells, the primordial cells at the crux of a national debate over federal research funding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, ANITA
description: SALTZ-Anita. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem deeply mourn the passing of Anita Saltz. She, along with her brother AFHU Council of Trustees Member and Member of The Hebrew University Board of Governors, Robert Belfer and her sister Selma Ruben, all of whom are Hebrew University Benefactors, established the ''From the Laboratory to the Patient-Cancer Research Program'' through the Arthur and Rochelle Belfer Foundation, to help in the battle against cancer. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Jack; children Leonard, Susan, Ronald, and Gary; brother and sister-in-law Robert and Renee Belfer; sister and brother-in-law Selma and Lawrence Ruben; and the rest of the Saltz and Belfer families. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President

title: 2 Are Killed In Plane Crash In Bean Field In New Jersey
description: A pilot and a passenger were killed yesterday afternoon when their two-seat plane crashed into a soybean field just short of the runway at a regional airport in Burlington County, N.J., police and aviation officials said.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Jersey Loses Fourth Insurer
description: New Jersey has let go of the fourth auto insurance carrier in a month, after regulators permitted the Providence Washington Insurance Company to drop all of its 2,200 policyholders in the state by September 2002. The New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance approved the departure of the company on June 29, said William Heine, a department spokesman, after it turned down the company's application for a 48 percent rate increase in April. The department had already agreed to let American International and State Farm Indemnity Company, the state's largest car insurer, pull out, and permitted the Newark Insurance Company to stop selling new policies. Mr. Heine insisted that New Jersey was still a viable market for insurers, suggesting that companies have not yet benefited from savings that will result from changes intended to limit lawsuits. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREED, WILLIAM C.
description: BREED-William C. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of William C. Breed, father of Michael Breed, Head Golf Professional. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Rebecca, his children, Giff, Alan, Michael and Becky, and to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Richard J. Bronstein, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHMEELK, GARRETT
description: SCHMEELK - Garrett. Beloved son, brother, uncle and dear friend. You are in our hearts forever. The Schmeelk Famil

title: A Bit of Tuscany, All Over the World
description: THIS is the time of year when cooks from Crete to Catalonia and from Damascus to Nice hoard stale bread, an essential ingredient in their variations on panzanella, the classic bread and tomato salad from Tuscany. But this combination of summer-ripened tomatoes, basil, extra virgin olive oil and red wine vinegar is only the beginning of the bread salad glossary. Who knew?

title: FedEx Freight Rates to Rise
description: The FedEx Corporation's freight companies are planning to increase rates 5.9 percent next month, amid higher costs for service centers, safety programs and World Wide Web based data systems. The move, effective Aug. 6, comes one week after Yellow Freight System, a unit of the Yellow Corporation, said it would raise trucking rates 4.9 percent on Aug. 1, defying the nation's slow economy. FedEx said the rates will increase at its less-than-truckload carriers Viking Freight, based in San Jose, Calif., and American Freightways, based in Harrison, Ark., which FedEx acquired in February for about $1.2 billion.

title: TV NOTES
description: Internal Tension On 'Big Brother'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENN, MYRON
description: PENN-Myron. Beloved husband of Laura. Devoted father of Stewart and Joan, Erica and Larry Epstein. Loving grandfather. Services were held. For information call 1-800-556-7799.

title: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Newark Building To Be Renovated
description: Newark's 76-year-old Military Park Building is trying to get back in fighting shape, with a $5 million restoration announced yesterday by its owner, the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, N.J. Restoration of the 21-story Art Deco skyscraper at 60 Park Place, which stands opposite Military Park and features reliefs of military figures on its brown brick exterior, was hailed by Mayor Sharpe James as yet another breath in what he called Newark's renaissance, akin to restoration of the National Newark Building a few blocks away. Richard Stadtmauer, Kushner's managing partner, said that the overhaul of the 220,000-square-foot building's windows and its electrical, heating and fire-suppression systems and windows, along with new lighting to dramatize its exterior, fit the company's pattern of ''repositioning'' aging properties. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Israel Bulldozes Houses in a Refugee Camp in the Gaza Strip
description: Israeli Army bulldozers rumbled into a Palestinian refugee camp in the Gaza Strip early today and leveled houses and shops, leaving scores of people homeless and igniting a fierce gun battle.

title: House Approves Mail-Order Purchases of Foreign Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The House voted today to make it easier for individuals to import low-cost prescription drugs for their own use, after rejecting a more sweeping proposal to allow such imports by drug wholesalers and distributors.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Market Place; Despite cost-cutting, Compaq is facing declining earnings and sales.
