description: THE Compaq Computer Corporation, the world's second-largest personal computer maker, said yesterday that it expected to report lower-than-projected earnings and sales for the second quarter and that it would eliminate 1,500 more jobs than previously announced.

title: The Interpublic Group will revamp now that it is the world's largest agency company.
description: IN what may be the largest reorganization on Madison Avenue, the Interpublic Group of Companies is being made over as it becomes the world's biggest agency company.

title: Singapore Says Economy Is in Recession
description: Singapore said today that its economy had slipped into recession, becoming the first of what economists predict will be a long list of export-dependent Asian countries that will suffer from the economic slump in the United States.

title: Can't Say Sandwich in Hindi? Just Order Paneer on Paratha
description: A tearoom should be serene with elegance, a description that fits Tamarind's new next-door cafe at 43 East 22nd Street. With a mere nine seats, it is a lovely spot for Indian-style sandwiches rolled in flaky paratha breads ($4.75 to $7.50), like yogurt-marinated lamb; garlic-and-spice-infused paneer (resembling cottage cheese) with spinach, served by Radhika Khanna; and tandoori salmon. There are Indian sweets, savory Indian biscuits and Western pastries ($1 to $4.95) to nibble with teas, which include some of this city's best iced tea: muscat-scented darjeeling and floral nantou oolong ($2.50, iced; $3.75, hot).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, LAWRENCE I.
description: WOLFSON-Lawrence I. On July 8, 2001. Of Westbury, LI. Beloved husband of Iris, devoted father of Glenn and Lisa Wolfson, and Ilene and Louis Meister, cherished grandfather of Brian, Anna and Neil. Services today 1PM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Birth After Caesarean
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Leader's Warning
description: Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, said make-or-break talks aimed at achieving I. R. A. disarmament would fail if they continued ''making all other issues secondary to the issue of I.R.A. arms.'' Mr. Adams spoke before the negotiations, being conducted at a secluded English Midlands hotel by Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, adjourned after a second night. The Northern Ireland peace accord has been in crisis since the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, resigned as first minister last week , forcing Britain and Ireland to press for quick arms action or consider suspension of the power-sharing government in Belfast. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Keeping the Band Together
description: The toughest crisis I have ever faced was the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993. Our offices were on the top five floors. Normally I parked in the underground lot where the bomb exploded, but by coincidence, my car was in the shop that day so I rode with someone else. I arrived around noon, sat down to a lunch meeting at 12:15, and the bomb exploded at 12:18.

title: New Gambits for Masters of the Cheese Board
description: Mezzo Secco, a silky textured cow's milk cheese with a scent of nuts and herbs, was made until the late 1930's, when its popularity waned. But tastes change, and Vella Cheese in Sonoma, Calif., famous for its dry jack, is again making this cheese with a pepper-rubbed rind. Mezzo Secco (back, left) costs around $10 a pound at Murray's Cheese Shop, $8 at Fairway. Another new cheese in town is Nocturne (front, right), an ash-covered soft-ripening cow's milk cheese from Andante Dairy in Santa Rosa, Calif. It is both buttery and tangy; $6.99 at Murray's. Andante is owned by Soyoung Scanlan, a biochemist and amateur musician, hence the musical names. California is the top cheese state, unseating Wisconsin, which now has fine artisanal cheeses like Pleasant Ridge Reserve (back, right), with a complex fruity and nutty flavor. It is made by Uplands Cheese in Dodgeville, Wis., with summer milk from grass-fed cows. It is $21.99 a pound at Murray's and $19.94 a pound at Fairway. And from Quebec comes Chaput vacherin (front, left), a runny pungent cheese: scoop, don't slice. A small wheel is $13.99 at Fairway; $7.99 for half. Chaput also makes a piquant aged goat's milk pyramid (front, center), $6.69 at Fairway.

title: AN INVESTMENT FIRM OFFERS TO BUY ZANY BRAINY'S ASSETS
description: A Los Angeles investment firm has agreed to buy the assets of Zany Brainy, a bankrupt specialty toy retailer, for $115 million, its chief executive said yesterday. The executive, Thomas G. Vellios, said the purchase by the firm, Waterton Management, would be completed in August if it is approved by a Delaware bankruptcy court and that Zany Brainy would be rebuilt as a private company, with Mr. Vellios remaining chief executive. Zany's creditors, including Mattel and Lego, will receive about 20 cents on the dollar of the $60 million they are owed and Zany's shareholders will receive nothing. Zany was forced into bankruptcy in May. Julian E. Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BEATRICE (BEA)
description: COHEN-Beatrice (Bea). On July 7, 2001. My beautiful and loving aunt, my inspiration and my guiding light. You clothed yourself with style, fashion and grace, but the garments of your soul were kindness, generosity and friendship. You touched the lives of all who knew you and you will be missed more than you could ever imagine. Who's my favorite aunt? Isabel Balson

title: Arms and Irish Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Charities Are Denied Bias Law Exemption
description: The Bush administration declined a request from the Salvation Army to exempt religious charities that receive federal money from local laws that bar discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Ousted Philippines President Officially Charged With Plunder
description: Under heavy guard against possible street protests, the former president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, was arraigned today on a charge of plundering the country while in office.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about treatment for people with Lyme disease misstated certain details about the case of Sandy Samelson of Dutchess County, N.Y. Ms. Samelson did see a tick when she was bitten in 1993 and developed a rash. A test at that time was negative; seven years later, other tests confirmed that she had Lyme disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, EDWARD L.
description: BLAU-Edward L. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Robert and Charles, dear brother of Nancy Lasser, loving grandfather of Eric, Thomas & Rachel. Services Cong B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, NJ, Thursday 11:00AM. For information, call Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, New Jersey.

title: Auction Case Takes Turn To Documents
description: In the continuing legal battles involving Christie's and Sotheby's, a storm has erupted over four confidential documents from Christie's that have mistakenly wound up in the hands of lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's who is facing criminal antitrust charges. The case is part of the long investigation into price-fixing by the two auction houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENHAM, WILLIAM HAIG
description: DENHAM-William Haig. Age 83. Loving father of Stacey Denham and the late Lisa Ahn, proud grandfather of Boris and Naomi, devoted brother of June McDonald and Leonard Denham and the late Gloria Cubbin, uncle to Michelle and Denise. Died July 9, 2001. Dir. of Manpower & Training NIMH, professor of social work Howard Univ, Ph.D. Florence Heller Brandeis University, MS Columbia School of Social Work. As a young man he played pro baseball in the Negro Leagues. He was a music connoisseur with a special love for jazz and played a mean jazz piano. Memorial service 7/14. Call for info 212-627-2612.

title: Drivers Stand By Earnhardt's Victory
description: Bobby Labonte, the defending Nascar Winston Cup champion, waded yesterday into the debate percolating over the validity of Dale Earnhardt Jr.'s rousing, bittersweet and storybook victory Saturday night in the Pepsi 400 at Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: France Feels the Heat of the Competition
description: FRENCH wine exports are in trouble. High prices, overproduction and stiff competition, particularly from what Europeans still quaintly refer to as ''the New World,'' have seriously diminished, if not ended, France's role as the leader in wine exports.

title: Commander Says His Troops Committed Crimes in Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, July 11 — The commander of Russian military forces in Chechnya said today that his troops had committed "widespread crimes" in two days of terror they inflicted on civilians in Chechnya. Fifteen hundred residents of two villages were arrested, subjected to beatings and electric shocks and saw their homes looted after mine blasts killed Russian soldiers nearby.

title: Russians Terrorize 2 Villages After Chechen Mines Kill 4
description: Hundreds of Russian Interior Ministry troops backed by helicopter gunships swept into this Chechen village and a neighboring one on July 3 and 4.

title: Charity Is Told It Must Abide By Antidiscrimination Laws
description: The Bush administration declined a request today from the Salvation Army, the nation's largest charity, to exempt religious charities that receive federal money from local laws that bar discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Teenager May Be Tried As Adult
description: A 14-year-old boy arraigned Monday in the shooting death of his father will be tried as an adult. The police said the teenager, Gregory Wright Jr., killed his father, Gregory Wright, 37, Sunday night after watching him strike his mother in the face. The state prosecutor's office has 10 days to consider returning the case to juvenile court, said a Hartford police spokesman, Sgt. Neil Dryf. Otherwise, the teenager will be tried in criminal court and may face life in prison.

title: Top 2 US Airways Executives Oppose Breakup
description: Facing growing pressure from employees, the top executives of US Airways said yesterday that they would not recommend breaking up the carrier when the airline's board meets next week.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Autotrader In Deal With Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company's FordDirect.com Internet sales venture with dealers will use the classified advertising Web site AutoTrader .com to manage its used car database. FordDirect.com, which includes new Ford cars and trucks, will use AutoTrader.com to make a database to list Ford's used models on the Internet, the companies said in a statement. In exchange, AutoTrader.com will add FordDirect.com vehicles to its 1.5 million listings on its site.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Milestone For Parliament
description: The ruling Awami League proclaimed a nine-day ''victory celebration'' to mark the completion of a five-year term of Parliament for the first time in the nation's 30-year history. A neutral caretaker government will now assume power as campaigning begins for fall elections. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Hartford Report Details Financial Abuses by County Sheriffs
description: Connecticut's attorney general and public auditors issued a detailed report today on what they called the ''out of control and unprofessional'' financial record keeping that pervaded the state's recently abolished county sheriff system.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Vasogen Wins U.S. Patent
description: Vasogen Inc. said it had secured a United States patent for its bone marrow transplant cancer treatment. Tony Bolton, Vasogen's research director, said that about half of all bone marrow tissue transplants result in rejections by the new host. He said that Vasogen's process involves treating T-cells in the host's immune system in a way that leaves them strong enough for the graft to succeed while reducing the likelihood of rejection. Shares of Vasogen rose 12 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $5.85 on the Toronto stock exchange. Vasogen's president, David Elsley, above, said the company was currently negotiating a strategic partnership with another company. Robert M. Frank (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNKLAU, DOROTHY RISS
description: BERNKLAU-Dorothy Riss. Departed from us ten years ago (29 Tammuz 5751) today, but remembered fondly throughout by Her children, David and Renee, with seven-year-old granddaughter Danielle.

title: Playtime for Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberty Has 2 Tough Games Before Players Can Rest
description: Less than a week before the Women's National Basketball Association's All-Star Game break, the Liberty's players are hobbled and in need of time off.

title: Nassau G.O.P. Figure Is Reported Missing
description: The Nassau County police are searching for Karan Kumar, a businessman, prominent Republican fund-raiser and Indian-American leader, who has been missing since Sunday night. He was last seen leaving a diner off Jericho Turnpike in Syosset, officials said yesterday.

title: Where to Cool Both Soul and Heels
description: CLASS=seriftext> ONE weekday a few years ago, a pedestrian walked into Bryant Park, behind the New York Public Library at 42d Street, west of Fifth Avenue. The park was swarming with visitors that afternoon, and you'd never have picked this woman out of the crowd if she hadn't been bone pale, tear-stained and trembling. She took a seat on one of the stone benches at the park's east end, closest to the library. The weather was so temperate that people were doffing their jackets, but she continued to shake.

title: Helping Top Athletes Meet Minimum Standards
description: The 200 students gathered in makeshift classrooms at the hotel here today are among the country's best high school basketball players, and almost all are being offered the chance to attend some of the country's most elite schools.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Minority Graduates at CUNY Colleges

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Warning Issued On False Drug Prescriptions
description: The state pharmacy board said hospitals, clinics and pharmacies should be on ''high alert'' for fraudulent OxyContin prescriptions and asked that the local police monitor places that stock the painkiller. The board released the guidelines after calls from pharmacists concerned about their safety in the wake of a string of OxyContin thefts. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: SAKS SAYS IT WILL CLOSE ITS PALM SPRINGS STORE
description: Saks plans to close its store in Palm Springs, Calif., and has offered the 60 store employees transfers to other branches. The retailer said the 50,000 square-foot Saks Fifth Avenue store, based in the Desert Fashion Plaza in Palm Springs, will close on Saturday. Saks also operates a 50,000-square-foot store in nearby Palm Desert, which will remain open. Saks, the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and regional department stores, said separately that it had bought two stores formerly operated by Montgomery Ward, the General Electric unit that said in December it would file for bankruptcy and close its 250 stores. Saks is based in Birmingham, Ala.

title: The Yin And Yang Of Adam And Eve
description: ''Symbiosis'' seems like a fancy title for a duet that is the latest premiere in Pilobolus Dance Theater's season at the Joyce Theater.

title: Rock Hard and Tasteless: You Call These Heirlooms?
description: HEIRLOOMS seem destined to bring out the worst in people. Just about every family with anything worth handing down winds up fighting from the death over who really deserved Grandma's diamond brooch or Dad's gold watch. Some of my siblings are still squabbling over a $100 rifle.

title: Mrs. Clinton Backs Giving Mayor Control of New York Schools
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that the movement to abolish the New York City Board of Education was gaining momentum, and that there might soon be ''critical mass in the city and Albany to make the change.''

title: Beijing Stages War Games, Mostly for Taiwan
description: China's latest and largest war games have been described in unusual detail by an official Chinese magazine, apparently to reinforce the exercises' message to the 23 million people on Taiwan that they should not be complacent about peace.

title: Alternative Bill Attracts Some Minority Support
description: To its supporters, a bill offered by the House Republican leadership to rewrite the nation's campaign finance laws is a common-sense alternative to legislation that would ban unrestricted soft-money donations to the national parties.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's logical that at some point their conditions would have to change from the days of the Old Testament.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JUNE PLEHN
description: GREEN-June Plehn. Of Las Vegas and New York. Beloved wife of Joel. Loving mother of Debra. Proud grandmother of Jennifer and Gregory. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her for her warmth, wit and caring nature. Graveside service Thursday 11:00 A.M. at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Myrtle Ave, Queens, NY.

title: N.F.L.'s Internet Deal Will Be Largest Ever
description: The National Football League, which has the largest television deal in sports, will announce the biggest league Internet rights deal today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Disaster Designation Sought
description: Gov. Gary Locke requested that the federal government designate 13 counties in the southeastern part of the state agricultural disaster areas after severe thunderstorms last week damaged more than 30 percent of some crops, especially fruits like cherries, peaches and apples. Mr. Locke made the request in a letter to Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman. The designation would provide emergency low-interest loans as well as livestock assistance to cover production and property losses to farmers and ranchers in those areas.

title: TRENDS; What Horace Greeley Said Still Rings True
description: Looking for work? Utah may not be the first area that comes to mind, but according to a new study, areas in Utah ranked high for concentrations of fast-growing companies based on employment during the 1990's, while the New York area was low on the list.

title: Legislator Can Sue Pataki Over Legality of Vetoes
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver can sue Gov. George E. Pataki over his budget vetoes, the state's high court ruled today, touching on an issue that has influenced recent budget fights, including this year's.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the plans of Autodesk Inc. to reacquire Buzzsaw.com, a provider of Internet services, misstated which company reported sales of $5.3 million in its first year. It was Buzzsaw, not Autodesk.

title: Ferrer Opposes Surtax Cut, Saying City Needs Revenues
description: Taking a politically tricky step in his campaign for mayor, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx continued yesterday to promote the repeal of a recent city tax cut -- an idea that is setting him apart from his rivals.

title: S.E.C.'s Chief Of Enforcement To Step Down
description: Richard Walker, who ran the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission in a period when the commission cracked down on accounting manipulations, said yesterday that he would leave the S.E.C. soon after the new chairman, Harvey Pitt, takes office.

title: Unprepared for Class
description: About 10 years ago, I got a job at a state university training undergraduates who were studying to become social studies teachers. Fresh from graduate school, where I had received a Ph.D. in history, I implored these prospective junior high school and high school teachers to engage their own students in the timeless debates of the discipline: What is history? Does it move in a linear direction, a cyclical one or neither? What makes one version of history better than another? I quickly realized, however, that many of my students had never addressed these questions themselves. ''What's all this business about debate?'' one puzzled student asked me. ''History is about facts. Either they happened or they didn't.''

title: Jury Rejects Death Penalty For Terrorist
description: A federal jury in Manhattan deadlocked yesterday on whether to impose the death penalty on a terrorist convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania, which killed 11 people. As a result, the bomber will be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Dead Man Named In Indictment
description: A stock promoter shot to death in New Jersey in 1999 has been named as a conspirator in a stock fraud indictment filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the United States attorney's office announced yesterday. The promoter, Alan Chalem, who was also known as Albert Alain Chalem, was involved in manipulating the initial public offering of an Idaho company called T.J.T. Inc. in 1995 and 1996, prosecutors said. Mr. Chalem was killed, along with an associate, Maier Lehmann, in his house in Colts Neck; no one has been charged with those murders. The federal indictment charged Paul Fiorini, the former president of the Toluca Pacific Securities Corporation, with orchestrating the scheme. He pleaded not guilty to the charges yesterday. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Point Pleasant Beach: Beach Fees Dispute
description: A town that makes children pay a fee to use its beaches may be sued by the state attorney general. The town, Point Pleasant Beach, is in violation of a state statute banning fees for beach access to children under 12, a spokesman for the attorney general's office said yesterday, citing a letter sent Friday. But the mayor, John Pasola, said the town dropped the fees on Friday. A private company manages the beach and charged the fee, $1.50 a day or $45 for the season for children aged 5 to 11, he said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: 2 Companies Get Bad News From F.D.A. On New Drug
description: Genentech and Novartis said that approval of their drug for asthma and hay fever would be delayed significantly because the Food and Drug Administration had requested more data about potential side effects. The announcement sent the stocks of the companies, as well as some other biotechnology companies, down sharply.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Lynette Harrison was named publisher at InStyle magazine, New York, part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. She succeeds Louis Cona, who became publisher at Vanity Fair, New York, part of the Condé Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications. Also at InStyle, Kevin M. Belden was named associate publisher marketing, succeeding Hope Hening, who also left for Vanity Fair, as associate publisher.

title: Second Look Backs Doubts On Finding Key Particle
description: What seemed to be hints last year that physicists at the CERN laboratory in Geneva had discovered one of the most coveted prizes in all of science -- a particle believed to be the source of mass and weight in the universe -- may have been a statistical mirage, the mathematical equivalent of seeing mythical beasts in a grainy photograph, scientists said yesterday.

title: Shh! There's No Talking In the Papyrus Section
description: LIBRARIES IN THE ANCIENT WORLD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPPS, LILLIAN J.
description: EPPS-Lillian J., 85. On July 9, 2001. Widow of Gerald J. Epps, M.D., much loved mother of Helen Epps, cherished aunt, and devoted sister to the late Bernice Raskin. Her strength, spirit and generosity will be missed. Memorial service: Congregation Beth Elohim, Garfield Place and 8th Avenue, Bklyn, New York, July 13th, at 1:30 P.M. Family at home Wednesday thru Friday, 3-8 P.M. Donations to Cancer Care would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | West: California: H.M.O. Coverage For Viagra Is Rejected
description: A Sacramento Superior Court judge, Lloyd Connelly, ruled that state regulators cannot force California's largest health maintenance organization, Kaiser-Permanente, to pay for Viagra, a decision that could affect prescription coverage at other H.M.O.'s in the state. The ruling allows health plans to exclude sexual dysfunction drugs from prescription benefits. It applies only to Viagra but could affect coverage for other drugs that treat conditions like baldness, where medical necessity is sometimes unclear. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Try Milosevic at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Redesign to Fill Vacancies in Rockefeller Houses
description: With stone carvings on the ornate facade and elaborately detailed woodwork throughout the interiors, the Rockefeller town houses at 13 and 15 West 54th Street are among the city's most unusual office buildings. Built in 1896 with a common front entryway, the houses are now part of a small office complex whose new owners have begun a remodeling program to fill in persistent vacancies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, ILSE (CIERER)
description: HAAS-Ilse (Cierer). At Isabella Nursing Home, on July 10, 2001. Most beloved daughter of Josef and Henriette. Beloved wife of Erich and cherished mother of Anita. Memorial service Thursday, 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Ilse will be remembered for her gentle ways and great intelligence and will be missed by her friends, especially Miriam Roldan, a close friend for eight years.

title: More Banter, Please, and Pass the Emotional Indigestion
description: The dinner party at the center of ''Blue Window,'' Craig Lucas's achy comedy from 1984, is a deliciously credible rendition of a well-meaning disaster, the sort of oil-and-water gathering that many New Yorkers will recognize and hope never to attend again. In the discomfiting but finally touching revival of the play that opened yesterday at the 28th Street Theater and was directed by Julia Gibson, the result for the audience is a ''there but for the grace of God go I'' experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPELOV, BEATRICE
description: KAPELOV-Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Dudley and mother-inlaw of the late Harriet. Cherished grandmother of Steven, Susan and Danny Buch. Great grandmother of Andy and Hayley. Services Thursday, July 12, 1PM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Summer Shopping: Part 2 - Beach Gear
description: When NYC lost Woolworths we lost neighborhood stores that could be relied on for seasonal merchandise. Bed, Bath and Beyond (620 Avenue of the Americas, at19th, 212-255-3550) fills that bill, but so far there is just the one location. Its huge selling floor has a large seasonal area that right now is filled with summer and outdoor merchandise. Check out the low-to-the-ground beach chairs with tubular metal frames, fabric seats and backs that can be adjusted into 5 positions. They are $29.99.

title: Judges' Political Stripes
description: To the Editor:

title: At Site of Massacre, Polish Leader Asks Jews for Forgiveness
description: Sixty years after as many as 1,600 Jews were killed in eight hours in a village in northeast Poland, the nation's president offered a strong apology today: it was not Nazi soldiers, he affirmed, but ordinary Poles who beat, stabbed and, finally, burned their fellow villagers alive in a barn.

title: Bush Drug Plan Calls for Using Discount Cards
description: President Bush will call later this week for major changes in Medicare, and as an interim step wants to encourage the elderly to acquire drug discount cards so they can immediately get lower prices at pharmacies, federal officials said today.

title: NYT Text Version
description: This page provides links to the text versions of certain areas of NYTimes.com

title: Bush Fills a Third Fed Seat, Selecting a Former Banker
description: President Bush filled another vacancy at the Federal Reserve today, saying he would nominate Mark W. Olson, a former president of the American Bankers Association, to the central bank's governing board.

title: State Rushed Emissions Test System Into Use, Witnesses Say
description: State officials pushed through a poorly conceived plan to let a private company run New Jersey's auto emissions testing program and then failed to provide enough time and supervision for the inexperienced contractor to do the job, witnesses said today at a hearing on the program.

title: Circuit City Lowers Threshold on Takeovers
description: The board at Circuit City Stores has lowered the threshold at which a plan to prevent hostile takeovers would be enacted, saying it was following other companies that had taken similar action.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro rose against the dollar on concern that the dollar has gained too much strength this year, hindering a U.S. recovery. In New York, the euro climbed to 85.70 cents, from 84.78 cents on Monday.

title: Judge Rules Random House Can't Stop Electronic Books
description: AFederal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the term "book" in book contracts does not automatically include electronic books. The decision goes to the heart of a battle over who controls the right to sell digital editions of the great majority of work published in the last century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, MILLIE
description: STEINBERG-Millie. Civic leader and county legislator for the Setauket-Stony Brook area during the 1970's died peacefully on July 9 at age 91 in Bethesda, MD. She is survived by her children Charles, Julie and Laura and grandchildren Alison and Robin. Memorial service on Thursday July 12 at 11:30 am at Washington Memorial Park, Mt. Sinai; visitation 2-6PM, 110 Spring St., Port Jefferson. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Victims Information Bureau of Suffolk County, POB 5483 Hauppauge NY or Emily's List.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDLAY, HARRIET LINDSAY
description: FINDLAY-Harriet Lindsay. Died unexpectedly in her Manhattan apartment on July 5th, 2001. Known as Lindsay, she was born on August 16, 1935, in Kansas City, MO, and grew up in New Canaan, CT. A graduate of Dana Hall School, Goucher College and the Harvard-Radcliffe Business Program, she initially worked for The Putnam Fund in Boston, MA. In 1958 she joined her father, David B. Findlay Sr., in his Manhattan art business, David Findlay Galleries. The original Findlay Galleries was founded in Kansas City, MO, 1870. Lindsay was a member of the fourth generation of the family to be involved with the gallery. In 1989 her father died, and Lindsay assumed control of the gallery. She is survived by her mother, Harriet Jonew Findlay, two brothers, David B. Findlay Jr. and H. Peter Findlay, and numerous nieces and nephews. Each of the brothers has his own eponymous art gallery in Manhattan. A memorial service will be held at the Congregational -United Church of Christ, 23 Park Street, New Canaan, CT, on Tuesday, July 17th at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Humane Society of Manhattan in memory of the deceased.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Authority To Grow For Justice Dept. Inspector General
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft is expected to sign an order today expanding the authority of the Justice Department's inspector general to investigate the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration, officials said. Such investigations cannot now begin without the attorney general's approval, a rule that some lawmakers say limits the office's independence. David Johnston (NYT)

title: Twists, Turns and Triple Jumps
description: Yuliana Perez is only 19, but she has already endured the killing of her mother, two years in foster care and relocation to Cuba to live with her father's family. If not for a fateful journey on a wrong bus here in Tucson last year, Perez might not be preparing to enter the rarefied company of track and field's elite at the world championships in Edmonton, Alberta, next month.

title: Article 2001071191716138099 -- No Title
description: Japan's Refusal to Revise Textbooks Angers Neighbors .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} Back to Main   Daily Lesson Plan Lesson Plan Archive News Snapshot Crossword Puzzle Affiliate Program Advisory Board Quote of the Day Campus Weblines Education News Newspaper in Education (NIE) Teacher Resources Classroom Subscriptions   News Summaries Daily News Quiz Word of the Day Test Prep Question of the Day Web Explorer Science Q & A Letters to the Editor Ask a Reporter   Conversation Starters Family Movie Guide Site of the Day Discussion topics Product Reviews Vacation Donation Plan Educational Products On This Day in History Weekly News Quiz Monthly Calendar Resources on the Web Facts About The Times Specials

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Contract At Automaker
description: Korea's second-largest automaker, the Kia Motors Corporation, said it had reached an agreement with union representatives on a wage increase for this year. The terms included a 7.6 percent increase in monthly wages and extra incentives.

title: In Tampa, Big Brother Is Watching You
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSHLAND, JOAN POSNER
description: KOSHLAND-Joan Posner. Formerly of NYC. Died in Foster City, CA. July 9, 2001. Survived by daughters Peggy, Linda and Mary, seven grandchildren and her sister Evelyn Weber. Preceded in death by her beloved husband Richard.

title: Judge Dismisses Ex-Troopers' Bias Lawsuit
description: Ruling in favor of the New York State Police, a federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit in which three former state troopers alleged that they were the victims of discrimination when they were fired for misconduct in 1993.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NTT DoCoMo Recalls Handsets
description: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's biggest mobile-phone company, said defects were found in 100,000 handsets from the Matsushita Communication Industrial Company, the latest in a string of glitches to affect Japanese handset makers. The Matsushita handsets, which are compatible with the Java computer language developed by Sun Microsystems, contain a flaw in the way the software interacts with the central processing unit, causing delays in voice transmissions, DoCoMo said. The defect is the second problem with Matsushita's P503i handset model. In February, DoCoMo announced the recall of 230,000 P503i handsets because of software problems. And on July 6, Sony said it would take a $95 million charge to cover the cost of recalling 1.1 million of its handsets this year because of software flaws.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Oracle Japan Profit Jumps
description: Oracle Japan's annual profit rose 64 percent, lifted by database sales to Japanese companies using its computer software to improve the efficiency of accounting systems, online purchases and other operations. Parent net income at the Japanese unit of the biggest database software developer was 18.3 billion yen ($145 million), or 142.95 yen a share, in the year ended May 31, up from 11.2 billion yen, or 131.08 yen, in the year-earlier period.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARSTENS, GREG R.
description: CARSTENS-Greg R. Devoted son of Ina (nee Riney). Loving brother of Gary. Dear uncle of Shawn and Shawna. Loving partner to Tom DeFina. Beloved companion of Rick Pascual. Reposing Perazzo Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Visiting Wed 2:00-5:00PM, 7:00-9:30 PM. Services Thu, 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston Street, New York, NY 10014 would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Mixed Report On Children's Health
description: A new study of the health of Newark's children has found favorable trends in teenage pregnancy, child abuse and juvenile arrests but disturbing ones in sexually transmitted diseases, infant mortality and asthma. The study, ''Kids Count,'' by the Association for Children of New Jersey, says reports of venereal diseases rose 31.4 percent in 1999, the most recent year for which data are available, or more than double the 13 percent statewide increase, while infant mortality was 13.5 deaths per 1,000 births in 1999, and 6.4 statewide. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Criticism and Support for Rules on Clean Air
description: Energy companies complained today that they could barely replace a turbine blade or boiler pipe without inciting regulatory scrutiny so onerous that it threatened their ability to light homes and fuel automobiles.

title: Brokerage Puts Limit on Stocks Analysts Hold
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday barred its stock analysts from buying shares of the companies they cover, going a step further than the industry standard to remove a potential conflict of interest.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Vote For Tory Leader
description: Michael Portillo won the first round of a runoff among five candidates by Conservative members of Parliament to choose two finalists for the party leadership vote by party members later this summer. But a new vote was scheduled for Thursday when a last-place tie meant that no one was eliminated. The results were Mr. Portillo, 49 votes; Iain Duncan Smith, 39; Kenneth Clarke, 36; and both David Davis and Michael Ancram, 21. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Seoul Defends Itself Against I.M.F. Criticism
description: The official charged with overseeing Korea's financial industry defended the government's record today against criticism that it unwisely pressured Korean banks to extend credit to troubled companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDSBERGER, LILLY
description: LANDSBERGER-Lilly. Resident of Spring Moor Retirement Home, Raleigh. N.C. On July 10, 2001 at age 89. A native of Czech Republic, she lived in Moravska Ostrava, Prague, London and New York prior to moving to Raleigh. Lilly was one of the first women to graduate law school in Czechoslovakia. She was an ardent Zionist, proud British subject with keen intelligence, a wonderful sense of humor and a warm heart. Lilly was preceded in death by her husband Leopold S. Landsberger of Vienna, Austria and New York. Her sister-in-law Frances Snow of Delray Beach, Fl., a niece and nephew, Barbara and Jim Maass of Raleigh as well as six grand nieces and nephews and a great grand niece survive her. Funeral services will be held in New Jersey.

title: OPPENHEIMERFUNDS WILL BUY A HEDGE FUND CONSULTANT
description: OppenheimerFunds, a unit of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, agreed to buy the hedge fund consultant Tremont Advisers for about $133 million in cash to add hedge funds to its product line. OppenheimerFunds, which manages assets of $127 billion, said it will pay $19 a share for Tremont, which is based in Rye, N.Y. ''Tremont fits perfectly with our goal of extending both our product line and our client base,'' said Kurt Wolfgruber, head of the domestic equity mutual fund business at OppenheimerFunds. ''Our clients have been asking for hedge funds more frequently.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MIRIAM SPIEGEL
description: KAUFMAN-Miriam Spiegel, age 85 of Somers, NY on Saturday, July 7, 2001. Mrs. Kaufman was a teacher for the public school systems in Hicksville, NY. She is survived by a daughter and son-inlaw, Hermine and Arthur Blumenfeld, a son and daughter-in-law, Ira and Maria Kaufman, nine grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Services Thursday, July 12 at 10:00 from The Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT.

title: STORM LOSSES WILL PARE CHUBB'S QUARTERLY EARNINGS
description: The Chubb Corporation, a leading insurer of businesses, said it had $80 million of storm-related losses in the second quarter that will cut earnings per share by as much as 31 percent. The company, based in Warren, N.J., said it expected to post second-quarter earnings of 75 cents to 80 cents a share, less than the $1.08 expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Chubb said most of the losses were related to damaged caused by tropical storm Allison, which swept through Texas in June.

title: Estrada Is Arraigned in Plunder Case
description: MANILA  Defiant and angry, Joseph Estrada refused to enter a plea Tuesday on charges that he plundered tens of millions of dollars of government money during his two and a half years as president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, RABBI DAVID L.
description: SILVER-Rabbi David L. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of one of the oldest rabbinic alumni, who was spiritual leader of Kesher Israel Congregation, Harrisburg, PA, for 50 years until his retirement in 1983 and remained active in the community until last year. An internationally admired scholar and rabbinic leader, he received an honorary doctorate from YU in 1960. He was deeply devoted to his alma mater, working tirelessly to advance its various scholarship programs. The Rabbinic Alumni honored him in 1997 for his dedicated efforts. A man of both great charm and integrity, he was widely beloved and respected. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Rabbi Ahron (and Shoshana) Silver, Basya (and Larry) Zucker, Malka (and Joel L.) Morris, and Adina (and Rabbi Dovid) Cohen; sister, Yetta Izenstein, a YU Guardian with her late husband, Dr. Louis Izenstein; grandchildren; greatgrandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer Unit Spun Off
description: Shares in Sulzer Medica, Europe's largest orthopedic company, fell 9 percent, to 85 Swiss francs ($47.34), after the company was formally split off from its parent company, Sulzer. The spinoff of Sulzer Medica, which is facing a growing number of lawsuits in the United States related to faulty replacement hip and knee joints, was approved by Sulzer's shareholders on Monday. The shareholders received two shares for each Sulzer share they owned.

title: Moving This Heron Required a Crane (And a Nasty 3-Year Court Battle)
description: This much was clear: the heron was 40 feet tall. It weighed two tons and was made of welded steel. Its eyes were shrouded in black bunting today as it awaited its exile from its perch on the pebbly sands of Jim and Barbara Miller's waterfront backyard here.

title: First You Munch One, Then Another . . .
description: LIKE so many addictions, this one started innocently enough. A small, slender box of chocolate wafers seemed to beckon from a shelf near the cash register at the Greek market near my apartment.

title: Rhone Whites' Delights
description: A FEW weeks ago, I expressed disappointment with California viogniers. Those fashionable white wines, made from grapes that are rare even in their home territory, the northern Rhone Valley, are most noticeable for their extravagantly perfumed aromas. Too often, though, they are heavy and hotly alcoholic. Essentially they are fun to sniff but not to swallow.

title: Geoffrey Zakarian
description: THERE'S a point of no return when you're cooking tomatoes. A little too much heat, a little too long in the pot, and you lose that sense of fresh ripeness that makes tomatoes so great. The problem is the water content, the juices, even in a dead-ripe, dense-fleshed beefsteak tomato. If you cook chopped tomatoes with all of their juices, it takes a long time for the sauce to reach the right consistency. By then the freshness is gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOMER, JUDGE ALAN
description: BROOMER-Judge Alan. After a long illness, retired Judge Alan Broomer succumbed to cancer yesterday. His brilliant judicial career in Kings County Superior Court spanned over a decade. He began his legal career in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, rising to the position of Bureau Chief before his appointment to the bench by Mayor Koch. He is survived by a sister Doris Kaplan and a brother Brian Broomer, both of Long Island as well as loving in-laws and nieces and nephews. A great man has passedlet it be noted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about battles over Colorado's waterways included a miscalculation of how much water a court recently permitted the city of Golden to divert for recreational use in its Clear Creek Whitewater Park. It is 1,000 cubic feet of water per second, which is about 7,480 gallons, not more than 600,000 gallons.

title: Beijing Must Wait, Worry, and Not Mess Up
description: Having arrived here as strong favorites to secure the 2008 Summer Games, leaders of the Beijing bid must now survive a peculiar 72-hour Olympic malady -- the agony of the front-runner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, SEYMOUR
description: CANTOR-Seymour. Age 86, of Riverdale, NY and Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Adeline. Devoted father of Mark, and grandfather of Fara, Carrie and Justin. Services are today, at 1:15 PM at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Reckonings; Outside the Box
description: During last year's campaign, George W. Bush solemnly pledged that his tax cuts would not come at the expense of future retirees, that the reserve the Social Security system was accumulating to help it pay benefits to the baby boomers would be kept in a ''lockbox'' -- that is, that Social Security surpluses would not be used to cover deficits in the rest of the budget.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Squatters Ordered Out
description: A high court judge told black squatters who have built shacks on vacant land near Johannesburg to leave within 48 hours or face forcible eviction. The judge was granting a petition filed by government officials, who said the squatters were illegally occupying the land, which is owned by two government agencies and a local farmer. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Vive la Marshmallow In Five Toastable Flavors
description: The French have pushed marshmallows into a new and more colorful realm. Pastel marshmallows, called ptes de guimauve, are a foot long and flavored with lemon, raspberry, anise, violet and orange. Cut them with scissors and toast them (for Bastille Day, of course) and the inside color will intensify; 99 cents each at Citarella stores.

title: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Transcript of Tyler Kepner's Visit to the Mets Forum
description: Tylerkepner (Tyler Kepner, Mets Beat Writer for The Times) Hey everyone. I'm ready to talk about those lovable Mets.

title: An American Retreat on Small Arms
description: The Bush administration might as well have sent Charlton Heston, president of the National Rifle Association, to deliver its opening address to a United Nations conference on small arms earlier this week. In a shameless subordination of diplomacy to domestic political pandering, John R. Bolton, the under secretary of state for arms control and international security, told the gathering that Washington would not support an agreement to curb the international flow of illicit small arms if it infringed on the right of Americans to bear arms.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Saturday Postal Delivery To Continue
description: The United States Postal Service said it would continue to deliver mail six days a week, after having considered eliminating Saturday delivery as a way of saving money. The proposed service reduction was criticized by members of Congress who said it would inconvenience customers and threaten the economy.

title: A Top Editor Is Appointed At Time Inc.
description: John Huey, a rambunctious Atlanta native and former Navy intelligence officer, was named editorial director of Time Inc. yesterday, in a newly expanded role that gives him direct daily control over more magazines than any other editor in Time Inc. history.

title: Eugene Cronkite, 86; Found Cancer's Links to Radiation Exposure
description: Dr. Eugene P. Cronkite, an expert in radiation biology who was among the first to recognize and report on links between cancer and exposure to sublethal levels of radiation, died on June 23 at his home in Setauket, N.Y. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANIER, GEORGE I.
description: TANIER-George I. October 17, 1917-July 6, 2001. Importer of Danish furniture for half a century and founder of Design Selections International, Inc. Survived by his wife Inger-Marie Tanier of CrotonOn-Hudson, New York, son Jeffrey Tanier Berg of Cambridge, MA, daughter Nanna Tanier of Malverne, NY, and his sisters Eva Hindus of Newton, MA. and Roma Konefsky of Brooklyn, New York.

title: Rustic Italian, Breathlessly Translated
description: THE concrete floor and the brushed-aluminum chairs send off warning signals. Is Peasant, despite the name, going to be an exercise in deprivation chic? The whitewashed brick walls and bare wood tables don't offer much hope. But closer inspection suggests that all is not as it seems. At the far end of the room, a brick pizza oven radiates heat. On a counter in front of the open kitchen, apricots, tomatoes and grapes have been massed in abundant display.

title: Rise in Wholesale Inventories In May Was Biggest in Months
description: Sales at wholesalers fell in May and inventories rose more than at any time in the last six months, a sign that businesses may be reluctant to order more goods until the economy picks up.

title: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: In Population Ranks, An Ascent of Asians
description: Nearly one in every 10 New York City residents describe themselves as Asian, up from one in 14 in 1990, according to the 2000 census. Their numbers grew at a faster rate than those of any other racial or ethnic group. The growth was especially striking in Queens, a place being reinvented by immigration, where one in every six residents are Asian.

title: G.E. to Give Dishwasher Refunds As Product Recall Is Questioned
description: Up to 5,000 New York State residents could qualify for refunds from the General Electric Company under a court finding that G.E. engaged in deceptive conduct in recalling potentially unsafe dishwashers, a state official said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Compaq to Miss Forecasts And to Cut 1,500 More Jobs

title: Restaurant Crawl Through London
description: Here are some of the distinctive new restaurants in London. Prices are for a three-course dinner for one, not including wine.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Albania: Muted Fund-Raising Effort
description: Two weeks after President Bush drew attention to war-related fund-raising by Albanians in America and Europe, the main group raising money for the fighters in Macedonia has gone underground, according to Ilir Zherka, president of the National Albanian-American Council. The presidential order, made on June 26, has chilled Albanian fund-raising in the United States, he said, ''but I don't think it will stop people who are committed.'' American-Albanians number about 400,000. David Binder (NYT)

title: Zabel Discovers It's Easy Being Green
description: That fellow with the broad smile and arms in the air in a victory gesture today was Erik Zabel, the star German sprinter who, when he looks over his rivals in the Tour de France, must feel like a wolf inspecting a flock of grazing sheep.

title: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Hull Is Atop Rangers' Shopping List
description: The Rangers' plan this summer is to nurture a youth movement after years of trading prospects for aging veterans.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Diamond Courier Attacked
description: A 68-year-old courier was robbed of $80,000 in diamonds and jewelry outside the Essex House yesterday in Midtown by two men who struck her in the face and shocked her with a stun gun, the authorities said. The men fled as hotel guards chased them onto Central Park South. A police officer, Thomas Fitzpatrick, joined the chase and caught one suspect. Officials said Fabio Casas, 30, of 94-17 37th Avenue, Queens, was charged with robbery and weapons possession. The courier, Batia Miller, lost a tooth and was burned by the stun gun. The jewelry was recovered. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the effect of the downturn in the high-tech industry on Austin, Tex., incorrectly described John Thornton, who commented on the city's accomplishments. He is a general partner in Austin Ventures, a venture capital firm, not its head.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Many Left Homeless By Monsoon Rains
description: Monsoon rains have forced 500,000 people to flee their homes in the state of Orissa. Boats have been pressed into service for the delivery of food. The army has been placed on alert. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 27 in some copies about how Bret D. Schundler harnessed conservatism to win the Republican primary for governor of New Jersey misstated the year that he worked in Gary Hart's campaign for president. It was 1984, not 1980.

title: Compressed Data: A College Paper's Role in the Microsoft Appeal
description: The Financial Times. The New Yorker. The New York Times . The Washington Post . The Wall Street Journal.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: French, After Jazz

title: It's Johnson Starting, Not Schilling
description: In an unusual development for an All-Star Game, Curt Schilling was scratched as the starting pitcher for the National League today and replaced by his Arizona Diamondbacks teammate Randy Johnson.

title: F.A.A. Denies Airline Plea on Pilot Rest
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday denied a request from major airlines to suspend its enforcement of the rule limiting how many hours each day a commercial pilot can work.

title: A Squash Steals the Show From Zucchini
description: Lita squashes, originally from India, have that zucchini look, but are sweeter in flavor, paler in color and a bit more bulbous, with dense flesh. Trim them, slice them very thin and saut them with onions in some butter. Salt, pepper and a generous dash of curry powder are all you need for seasoning, though some heavy cream at the end adds a smooth note. The squashes are also excellent to stuff. They are $1 to $1.60 a pound in the Union Square Greenmarket from farms like Migliorelli in Tivoli, N.Y.; Cherry Lane in Bridgeton, N.J.; and S.&S.O. Produce in Goshen, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAVROPOULOS, NANCY
description: STAVROPOULOS-Nancy. On July 8, 2001, at age 74. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Peter and his wife Cally. Adoring grandmother of George. Dear brother of Peter and James. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, July 10, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 337 East 74th Street, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at New Cemetery, Somerville, NJ. Contributions in her memory may be made to the George Stavropoulos Academic Chair at Kent State University or St. Michael's Home for the Aged.

title: Classic Japanese, With a Western Touch
description: WITH her first compilation of recipes, Hiroko Shimbo proves that you can't always judge a cookbook by its title. ''The Japanese Kitchen'' (Harvard Common Press, $29.95 hardcover, $16.95 paperback) is an exceptionally clear guide to Japan's most classic dishes. But it is also a surprising exploration of the flavors that can be achieved when a chef weaned on green tea starts dabbling in sun-dried tomatoes and feta cheese.

title: Isles Re-Sign Czerkawski
description: The Islanders agreed yesterday to a three-year deal with the restricted free agent Mariusz Czerkawski, the team's leading scorer the past two seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, ABBING, MONSIGNOR JOHN PATRICK
description: CARROLL - ABBING - Monsignor John Patrick. The directors and staff of Boys' Towns of Italy, Inc. mourn the passing of our beloved founder, Monsignor John Patrick Carroll-Abbing. He was ordained a priest in Rome in 1935 and named a Monsignor shortly thereafter. He served in the Papal Household under Pope Pius XI and Pope Pius the XII until the outbreak of World War II. Pope Pius XII gave Monsignor permission to leave the Household and to assist the refugee population of Italy. He began by starting ''Shoeshine Hotels'' for the young street population of Italy and thereafter devoted his life to caring for children whose lives have been shattered by war, poverty, and natural disaster. His mission of unconditional love and acceptance have stood for decades as a shining beacon offering a ''second chance in life'' to lost and abandoned boys and girls of many nationalities. Monsignor Carroll-Abbing was the founder and leader of the residential facilities Boys' Towns of Rome and Girls' Towns of Rome, as well as Boys Towns of Italy, Inc., the oldest American charity working abroad, and was an internationally respected advocate for child welfare. We miss him dearly and will always strive to keep his spirit and mission alive. Brother A.E. D'Adamo, CFC, Executive Vice President Mauro C. Romita, Secretary/Treasurer

title: A Woman With Everything, or Maybe Nothing
description: For anyone who's ever run into an old friend on the street, caught up over a cup of coffee and left feeling suicidal because the friend's life was obviously turning out so much better, there is solace in John Patrick Shanley's new play, ''Where's My Money?,'' which opened on Monday night at Center Stage/NY.

title: Schundler Backtracks on Restricting Medicaid Abortion Payments
description: For the second time in less than a week, Bret D. Schundler's stance against abortion was the focus of the New Jersey governor's race yesterday, as his campaign sought to clarify statements in which Mr. Schundler said he opposed the use of federal money, including Medicaid, for abortion procedures.

title: Police Call for Polygraph Test And Search Condit's Home
description: The Washington police said today that they wanted Representative Gary A. Condit to take a polygraph test and give samples of his DNA as part of their investigation into the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy, a federal intern. Hours later, the authorities took up an offer by Mr. Condit's lawyer and began a search of the congressman's apartment.

title: Zero-Tolerance Policy Is Challenged
description: In a lawsuit that could affect subsidized-housing policies nationwide, several civil rights and women's rights groups yesterday challenged, as a form of sex discrimination, an Oregon zero-tolerance policy allowing the eviction of the entire household after a domestic assault.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Animal Cruelty Charged
description: As part of a four-month investigation into conditions at a 30-horse boarding stable in Lindenwood, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals yesterday made its second arrest of a horse owner at Linden Stables on 78th Street, charging him with cruelty to animals, a misdemeanor. The society, which employs agents with arrest powers, said it had seized four horses at the stable in its investigation, including a malnourished horse named Kenya removed on June 27. Yesterday, the agents arrested the horse's owner, Rossano Case-Irwin, 42, of Brooklyn, and turned him over to the Queens district attorney's office. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEMBERTON, CATHERINE WATJEN
description: PEMBERTON-Catherine Watjen. Died peacefully at home on July 6th, 2001, at the age of 99. Widow of the late John C. Pemberton, she was born in New York City on April 26, 1902, graduated from Chapin School with the Class of 1920, attended the Art Students League, and started a fifty-seven year career as interior decorator in 1933. ''Cotty'' was a prominent professional, numbering among her clients Mayor John Lindsay and his wife Mary for whom she decorated Gracie Mansion. She was a member of the Colony and Cosmopolitan clubs, and for almost 50 years maintained a summer home on Norton Farm, Lambert's Cove Road, Martha's Vineyard. Her restored dwelling was built by Captain Nathan Smith in 1740. She is survived by a son, Louis Watjen Pemberton of New York and his four children Christine, Anne, Julia and Andrea, and the four grandchildren by her late son John C. Pemberton, Jr. of Philadelphia; Mary Murdoch, Frances Tyler, Catherine Pemberton and John C. Pemberton IV, as well as seven great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at the Congregational Church of West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard at 3:00 on Sunday July 29th; a memorial service will be held in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave at 51st, at 4:00, October 3rd. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, Central Park Conservancy or the Vineyard Conservation Society.

title: In New York, Bush Visits Sites Evocative of His Philosophy
description: One hundred and seventy-one days after he was sworn in, George W. Bush paid his first visit as president to New York State yesterday, proposing ways to ease immigration and paying tribute to Cardinal John O'Connor. But Mr. Bush expressed something short of pure delight at being back in the state that he lost by nearly 25 percentage points last November and that his advisers view as politically out of reach for 2004.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Monday misstated in some copies the penalty that will be imposed for a third violation of the five mile-an-hour speed limit through E-ZPass lanes on New Jersey toll roads. Violators will have their E-ZPass privileges -- not their driver's licenses -- suspended for 60 days.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travel Site Reports 2 Million Visitors
description: Orbitz.com, the Web travel site backed by five major airlines, said it had attracted 2.1 million at-home visitors in its first full month and that travel sales since its June opening had topped $100 million. Orbitz now has more than one million registered users, the company said in a statement. Including computers at home and work, Orbitz reported 3.7 million visitors, an increase of 1.9 million from its May testing period. The Chicago-based company, owned by the United Airlines unit of UAL, the American Airlines subsidiary of AMR, Delta Air Lines Inc., Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines, was created to cut ticket distribution costs. The site also also provides information about flight delays and weather.

title: No Altered Corn Found in Allergy Samples
description: Virtually all the food samples collected from consumers who complained of allergic reactions to StarLink corn did not contain the genetically modified corn at all, government tests have found. The results could further allay concerns that StarLink had caused the reactions.

title: INSIDE
description: Doubts on Campaign Bill

title: 'Big Brother' Ejects Contestant Who Held a Knife to a Woman
description: One of the contestants on the CBS reality television show "Big Brother" was thrown off the show late Tuesday night for taking a kitchen knife and holding it against the throat of another contestant.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Insurance Purchase
description: The Dutch financial services company Fortis agreed to buy a dental-benefits division from Protective Life of Birmingham, Ala., for $300 million. The acquisition will make Fortis the fourth-largest provider of dental benefits in the United States, while allowing Protective Life, which recently acquired two insurance companies, to focus on its core life insurance, retirement savings and credit businesses. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Democrats Say Bush's Tax Cuts Jeopardize Military Spending
description: Three of the Senate's most powerful Democrats warned today that President Bush's tax cut had made it virtually impossible to increase military spending significantly in 2002 without slashing other programs or dipping into surplus Medicare funds.

title: Soft Money's Scanty Leftovers
description: If politicians really cared about efforts to get out the vote in America, they would stand up on the House floor this week and support real campaign finance reform: the ban on soft money in the Shays-Meehan bill.

title: French Twist For Steak
description: GRILLED steak is one of the original convenience foods, and in many ways it remains the champion. What else offers so much flavor and satisfaction with so little work? The best cuts of the best beef are so delicious that most attempts to improve them are pointless.

title: Britannia, When She Basked in Midday Sun
description: The title of ''Queen Victoria's Empire'' is the point. Although this four-hour, four-part PBS documentary begins with descriptions of a little princess growing up lonely in a big palace, it is not the story of Victoria the woman or of her reign. ''Queen Victoria's Empire,'' which begins tonight on Channel 13 and concludes on Aug. 1, is a history lesson. Its real stars are William Gladstone, Benjamin Disraeli, Dr. David Livingstone, Gen. Charles George Gordon, Cecil Rhodes, the potato famine, international free trade, the Sudan, Crimea, the Boer War, India, the African interior and the Suez Canal.

title: Air Miles From Park Hyatt Hotels
description: By booking a stay at selected Park Hyatt Hotels online, travelers can earn 5,000 United Mileage Plus frequent-flier miles through Aug. 31. The participating Park Hyatts are in Chicago, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Toronto, Washington and the Stanhope in New York. Reservations must be made at www.parkhyatt.com or www.hyatt.com .

title: U.S. Won't Block China's Bid for Olympics
description: The Bush administration, uncertain that it could effectively oppose China's bid for the 2008 Olympics, has decided to remain silent on the issue. But in doing so, it has come to believe that there could be advantages for the United States if Beijing prevails, officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Forum On Better Education
description: The New York Legislature is holding a public forum seeking advice on how to improve the education system in response to a a court ruling making a ''sound, basic education'' mandatory. Room 1923, Assembly Hearing Room, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 298-5585.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. A heat spell in the East and Texas helped lift natural gas prices. In New York, natural gas for August delivery rose 12.9 cents, or 4.09 percent, to $3.282 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Report Looks at a Generation, And Caring for Young and Old
description: Anyone juggling the needs of young children and aging parents can identify with Beth Ann Roth of Fairfax, Va., who is wondering this week whether to fly to Florida, where her father is in the hospital, and -- if she goes -- which of the seven children in her blended family might need what.

title: Business Travel; Most car rental customers can relax. The top companies have no plans to monitor speeders.
description: ABOUT eight months ago, you might have seen some ranting and raving in this space over the increasing use of hidden cameras on streets and highways to nab unsuspecting speeders.

title: Van Gundy Has a Surprisingly Optimistic Outlook
description: Jeff Van Gundy is aware that he will only coach Chris Webber in his dreams. The Knicks are so far above the salary cap that a major free-agent acquisition is impossible and a blockbuster trade that would land the Knicks their coveted frontcourt star is most unlikely.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From a recipe for white gazpacho to wine touring in Oregon, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about ''Don't Make Me Laugh'' in Westport, Conn., referred incorrectly to Gilda Radner, the comedian. She was the second wife of Gene Wilder, who is in the show, not his first wife.

title: She's Lovely, But Alas, She's Only Software
description: Sitting through the latest animated science-fiction film, ''Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within,'' may send you hurtling back to the future and the 1982 megabyte hype of ''Tron'' for the last instance when a movie's electronically fashioned special effects, synergized with video-game appeal, were so widely trumpeted. And as was true of ''Tron,'' you may find yourself staring at this film's special effects to gauge their realism -- a much more diverting endeavor than following the story line.

title: It's the Fizz This Summer (And It's Not Champagne)
description: JUST a few years ago, had you mentioned the word prosecco to a wine snob, the response would have been predictable: a sagging of the lower lip, a vacant stare. Its reputation was hardly one to revere. Prosecco then was what you might have called a cheapo trattoria drink. Wedding bubbly. Poor man's Champagne.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Calls for Change in an Ancient Occupation
description: The shepherd was deep in the desert, eight miles from the nearest road and more than four miles of rocky brush past the closest sign of civilization, a landfill. It was midafternoon, 110 degrees, and the 500 sheep he tends 24 hours a day, seven days a week were sleeping. But with nothing else to do, he was watching them anyway, pacing the parched earth with two panting border collies by his side.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Insurer Corrects Error
description: A major New York health insurer has agreed to reimburse customers $35,000 after failing to pay for emergency room services that should have been covered by their plans, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, announced yesterday. Because of a technical error, Group Health Inc. classified 195 emergency room claims as nonemergency treatment, said Ilene Margolin, a company spokeswoman. Customers had to pay those charges themselves, Mr. Spitzer's office said. The company, which processes more than 17 million claims a year for 2.6 million participants, will also pay $1,000 in penalties and $4,000 in costs, Mr. Spitzer said. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLAIN, GERTRUDE G.
description: CHAMBERLAIN-Gertrude G. On May 9, beloved wife of the late Thomas G. Chamberlain, devoted Aunt of Gail Hammond of Houston, Texas, devoted Great Aunt of Sandra Hoag of Alexandria, Virginia. Memorial service at St. Bartholomew's Church July 24 at 10 AM.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS CUBA: A GLIMPSE OF THE LITTLE HERO Elián González, the famously repatriated Cuban boy, made a rare public appearance exchanging an affectionate greeting with Fidel Castro at a children's rally. Elián and his father, Juan Miguel González, were in the front row with Mr. Castro and other senior leaders at the event in Havana. Mr. Castro gave Elián a kiss on the cheek and a paternal pat on the shoulder.    (Reuters) MEXICO: DRUG-CARTEL ARREST Mexican officials said they had arrested a man suspected of being the chief assassin of one of Mexico's most notorious drug cartels. Jorge Humberto Rodríguez, alias The Frog, had been detained since March, but he had falsely identified himself upon arrest. Officials said Mr. Rodríguez had undergone plastic surgery to alter his appearance. Mr. Rodríguez is believed to have worked for the Tijuana- based Arellano Félix drug cartel, Mexico's most violent criminal organization.    Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: State Chided For Lack Of Asthma Data
description: A report faults the state, which has the nation's highest rate of asthma, for not tracking the disease. The study, by the Trust for America's Health, a nonprofit group in Baltimore, found that Nevada was one of 12 states with high levels of air pollution but no way to track asthma, which state officials say has killed 330 residents since 1990. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has estimated that, based on patients' reports, up to 7.2 percent of Nevada residents have asthma. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Bettor's Delight Is Early Favorite in the Meadowlands Pace
description: Mike Lachance will probably drive the favorite in the $1 million Meadowlands Pace on Saturday night for the first time in his illustrious career. Lachance, 50, will guide Bettor's Delight, who was made the 6-5 early favorite today in the post position draw for the Pace, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary.

title: Sports of The Times; Another Epic Night In Seattle
description: THERE they were, Seattle's past and present, converging on first base. Both of them wore No. 51, and the man who goes by the single name of Ichiro was quite aware of the symbolism.

title: U.S. Professor to Be Tried In Beijing on Spying Charge
description: The Chinese government confirmed today that an American business professor accused of spying for Taiwan would go on trial in Beijing on Saturday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Arraigned In St. John's Shooting
description: A man arrested in March after a shooting at St. John's University wounded two men pleaded not guilty yesterday to multiple charges of attempted murder and assault, the Queens district attorney's office said. The suspect, Christopher Prince, 22, of Elmont, was accused of pulling out a gun near a cluster of dormitories and shooting Cory Mitchell, a St. John's senior on leave from school, in the back, and Rashan Fray, 19, who is not a St. John's student, in the leg. Mr. Prince, who was released in March on $100,000 bail, faces up to 25 years in prison for each of the three attempted-murder charges. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Tracking Sales and the Cashiers; Retail Software Monitors Inventory But Also Watches For Employee Theft
description: The manager at a Beall's Outlet store in the Southeast was stealing money in small amounts -- $50 here, $90 there.

title: Summertime and the Swimming Is Easy
description: It's a sweltering summer Friday night but you're not on a train to the Jersey Shore, a jitney to the Hamptons or a water taxi to Fire Island. Instead, you're sprawled out in front of a rickety old fan convinced that there must be a better way to stay cool. You're right: The city's beaches and pools, all within easy reach for a $1.50 MTA fare. The salty, soothing breeze blowing off the ocean at Rockaway Beach or a refreshing dip at the Asphalt Green pool can lower your temperature.

title: Teacher Shortage Is Hurting Students, Union Says
description: Students seeking summer remedial classes to help them pass high-school graduation examinations in math are being turned away from some Brooklyn schools because of a shortage of qualified teachers, the New York City teachers' union said yesterday.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Suit Seeks Fee in Looted Art's Recovery
description: Hector Feliciano, the author of a book that focused international attention on artworks looted by the Nazis, has sued the estate of the Parisian art dealer Paul Rosenberg, saying he was deprived of a finder's fee for helping the family recover paintings by Matisse, Monet, Lger and Bonnard.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAIL-WELL INC., Englewood, Colo., the largest maker of envelopes, said it had received an order from the United States Treasury Department to produce more than 47 million envelopes that will be used to mail tax rebate checks to taxpayers.

title: Financing the Straphangers Campaign
description: The Straphangers Campaign was born in the dark days of the New York City subway system -- remember the graffiti-smothered trains and routine breakdowns of the late 1970's? -- when a group of riders banded together to lobby for better service. Today, it has an annual budget of $250,000 and five full- and part-time staff members.

title: Wine Grapes Rerouted Into Grown-Up Juice
description: Chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon grape juices are for grown-ups who may want a juice that is less sweet. They are delicious with sparkling water or iced tea or even mixed with spirits. The chardonnay suggests tropical fruit and apple, while the cabernet is more winelike. The juices, from Napa Style, are $9 for 25.3 ounces (or $90 a case), plus shipping, from (866) 776-6272.

title: Berkman Sitting at the Bats of the Masters
description: Twenty-two players, 11 on each team, invaded Safeco Field tonight as first-time members of the National and American League All-Star squads. Only one of them was hitting .365.

title: Critic's Notebook; Isaac Babel May Yet Have The Last Word
description: Along with other secrets about spies and agents and assassinations and conspiracies, the archives of the former Soviet Union may contain a literary secret: an unpublished novel by the Russian writer Isaac Babel.

title: Front Row Seat on the Road of Life
description: Awhile back, I was supposed to drive a bunch of middle school students from Battery Park to the United Nations for a 3:30 tour. The teacher let them run around and didn't get them back on the bus until 3:26. When I told him the time, he said, ''So what? We have four minutes to get there.'' I guess he had never heard of rush-hour traffic in Manhattan. We missed the tour, and the teacher had to be content with walking the students around the building.

title: 'Faith Based' Plan Holds a Pitfall
description: To the Editor:

title: London's Bad Boys Grow Up, and the Scene Does, Too
description: IT'S easy, looking across the ocean, to see London as a distorted reflection of New York. The key industries are the same, the fashions and the slang overlap, and the dining scene, to an uncanny degree, seems to follow the same script: all boom, no bust. The pound is weak, financial markets are unsettled, but nothing seems to slow down the food economy. Restaurants keep opening, diners keep filling them, and no one can figure out how long the boom can continue, what the next food trend will be or who all these people are.

title: Bank Deal Is Blocked By Britain
description: After a four-month inquiry, Britain's competition regulator today blocked Lloyds TSB's $26 billion bid for Abbey National. The move stymied expansion plans by Lloyds along with any obvious prospect for further cost-cutting deals among Britain's Main Street giants.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Police Search Condit's Home for 3 Hours for Clues on Intern
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The police spent three hours into the early morning today searching the four-room apartment of Representative Gary A. Condit, seeking information that might help solve the mystery of what happened to Chandra Ann Levy, the federal intern who disappeared more than two months ago.

title: Fragola
