description: Adapted from the Red Cat

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Autonomy Slips
description: Shares in the Autonomy Corporation fell 7 percent on concerns that orders for its information management software would be delayed as large corporations cut back on spending. Autonomy said late on Monday that a pattern of deferred spending by its biggest customers that dented first-quarter results were repeated in the second quarter. The company also said that it expected to earn 1 to 2 cents in the three months ended June 30, slightly more than analysts had expected.

title: Artful Sushi and an Engaging Chef, in the East Village
description: SOMEONE asked me recently how to discern decent sushi from great sushi, and, at a momentary loss for words, I fell back on paraphrasing that old Supreme Court platitude, ''You'll know it when you taste it.''

title: Our Towns; Relearning, Sadly, to Duck And Cover
description: THE shots rang out without warning on Independence Day.

title: Punt E Mes Fizz
description: Adapted from the Tonic

title: Gap Found in Funeral Home Inspections
description: The discovery of five decomposing bodies in a funeral home's garage here last month has led to yet another finding: Connecticut has not had an inspector for funeral homes for more than a decade.

title: Community of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADDOCK, J. JOSEPH
description: RADDOCK-J. Joseph. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed Board Member, Chai Founder and cherished member of our extended family, Jay Raddock. Together with his wife, Sharon, the Raddocks' generous support enabled Boys Town to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Michael J. Scharf, President Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Josh S. Weston Honorary Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTHERLAND, EDWARD M.
description: SUTHERLAND - Edward M. Passed away July 10, 2001, after a long illness. Survived by his wife, Barbara, two brothers, and cousins, Gail and John. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. No service, no flowers, please. Contributions to The Volunteer Referral Center, Star Learning Center, or Help Line.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about battles over Colorado's waterways included a miscalculation of how much water a court recently permitted the city of Golden to divert for recreational use in its Clear Creek Whitewater Park. It is 1,000 cubic feet of water per second, which is about 7,480 gallons, not more than 600,000 gallons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILE, STERLING JR.
description: PILE-Sterling Jr. Age 86, of Brookville, L.I., died July 8, 2001, after complications following surgery. Beloved husband of Leila; loving father of Leila, Marjorie, Sterling and Laurie, and the fabulous Pop to eight grandchildren. Services will be held at 11:00 AM on July 14, 2001, at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pasquaney Trust, 5 So. State St, Concord, NH 03301.

title: War-Weary Kashmiris Contemplate the Price of Peace
description: Before dawn each day, Nazir Ahmed, bone-thin and stubble-bearded, rises, dons heavily patched trousers and a sweat-stained shirt, and faces Mecca for his prayers. Then, under the fading glimmer of the stars, he sets out with a rickety handcart, his route framed by a silvery lake, distant Himalayan peaks and centuries-old high-domed mosques.

title: Summer Shopping: Part 1 - Picnics
description: In a city overrun with take-out food shops, there are many that will attend to the specific needs of a picnicker. Call ahead and have your order waiting before heading off to your picnic place.

title: What Produces a Voter? Seemingly Not Civics Class
description: ONLY about half of voting-age Americans went to the polls in November. Can schools do anything to spur future graduates to improve on that sorry performance?

title: Sorting Out a Future After Dot-Com
description: When Rebecca Bregman was laid off from an Internet company in March for the second time in a little over a year, she decided to put the turmoil of the technology industry behind her.

title: Article 2001071191191122009 -- No Title
description: state assemblyman, on his proposal to set work rules for California's shepherds. .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} Back to Main   Daily Lesson Plan Lesson Plan Archive News Snapshot Crossword Puzzle Affiliate Program Advisory Board Quote of the Day Campus Weblines Education News Newspaper in Education (NIE) Teacher Resources Classroom Subscriptions   News Summaries Daily News Quiz Word of the Day Test Prep Question of the Day Web Explorer Science Q & A Letters to the Editor Ask a Reporter   Conversation Starters Family Movie Guide Site of the Day Discussion topics Product Reviews Vacation Donation Plan Educational Products On This Day in History Weekly News Quiz Monthly Calendar Resources on the Web Facts About The Times Specials

title: Rights Leaders Urge Powell to Attend U.N. Racism Conference
description: A group of American civil rights leaders is pressing Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to go to a United Nations conference on racism and discrimination this summer to make a strong showing for the United States at a time when the Bush administration has been withdrawing from some international activities.

title: Countdown Time for Reform
description: After years of trying to bury campaign finance reform with delaying tactics, Speaker Dennis Hastert has shifted course and started pressing for an almost immediate vote. The Shays-Meehan soft-money ban is now due to come up in the House tomorrow, leaving proponents only another day to round up support. Though the bill has passed twice in the House, the danger is that defection by only a couple of dozen lawmakers in each party could defeat it. That is why we again urge wavering Republicans and members of the Black and Hispanic Caucuses to stand by the cause for which they have voted, and pledged to vote, in the past.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about battles over Colorado's waterways included a miscalculation of how much water a court recently permitted the city of Golden to divert for recreational use in its Clear Creek Whitewater Park. It is 1,000 cubic feet of water per second, which is about 7,480 gallons, not more than 600,000 gallons.

title: Mental Health Experts Clash Over Competency of Defendant in 1963 Church Bombing Case
description: Two experts are convinced that Bobby Frank Cherry is not mentally competent to stand trial for murder in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church here. Two other experts are just as convinced that he is competent. Now it is up to Judge James Garrett to decide.

title: Economic Troubles Worsen in Argentina
description: Argentina's financial troubles deepened yesterday as the government had to offer 14.01 percent interest to attract investors to its three-month Treasury bills.

title: Africans Making Slaves of Africans
description: The historic drama ''Adanggaman,'' which starts a two-week run at Film Forum today, is about an African whose village is captured and its inhabitants forced into slavery by the African collaborator Adanggaman (Rasmane Ouedraogo). Traitorous and arbitrary, Adanggaman has a round face that constantly calls out for the rum the Dutch traders ply him with.

title: Liberties; The Lost Girls
description: I went to Barnes & Noble one Saturday a couple of months ago and asked the young guy behind the counter to help me find a book. ''I can't remember the title,'' I told him. ''But it's a collection of true stories in which love affairs end with a horrible crime.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGREEN, MORRIS H.
description: BERGREEN-Morris H. Beloved husband of Adele, adored father of Laurence and the late John, cherished father-in-law of Betsy and Natasha, loving grandfather of Nicholas and Sara. Remarkable, brilliant, and unforgettable, a truly generous spirit. Services on Thursday, July 12, 2001 at 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: In a Shift, an H.M.O. Rewards Doctors for Quality Care
description: Blue Cross of California, one of the nation's largest health insurers, announced yesterday that it would pay bonuses to doctors serving its health maintenance organization members based on patient satisfaction and other quality standards. It will also stop paying extra to physicians with the best cost-cutting records.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cheektowaga: No Hazard Detected In Landfill
description: State officials reported that they had detected no major environmental hazards in a quarry and three landfills near Cheektowaga, near Buffalo, despite residents' concerns about higher cancer rates. According to the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, the landfills either have no detectable contamination or are off-limits to residents and therefore considered safe. But the Cheektowaga town supervisor, Dennis Gabryszak, said that residents were still concerned and that he planned a meeting next week between the Town Board and the department. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Mixing a Nasty Real Estate Deal With Love: Must Be a Musical
description: Manhattan of the mid-1980's, when hostile takeovers were business as usual and real estate prices went crazy, when greed was good and the homeless multiplied, is the setting for ''Once Around the City,'' the hapless new musical that opened at Second Stage Theater last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGENSTERN, HELEN
description: MORGENSTERN-Helen. Devoted wife of the late William. Loving mother of Gail Fried (Burton). Cherished grandmother of Marsha Bainnson (Drew), Howard Fried (Samantha), Shari Dembin (Matthew), Laurie Stone (Bradley), Lisa Held (Richard) and Alan Morgenstern (Jennifer). Adoring great grandmother of Joshua, Alexis, Michael, Kyle, Trevor, Chelsea, Shannon, and Jeffrey. Services Wednesday 9:45 AM at ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Democrats Maneuver on Soft Money as Vote Nears
description: Fearing that House Republican leaders were making headway against a broad measure to overhaul the campaign finance law, the leaders of the effort to cut down on money in politics struggled today to find a last-minute formula that would consolidate Democratic support for their bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, ANNE
description: FINKELSTEIN-Anne. On July 10, 2001. Died in Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of Paul. Devoted mother of Larry and Ellen. Proud grandmother of David & Mallory. She was a true woman of valor, dedicated to all human beings. Her family and friends will miss her as a symbol of courage and compassion. Services Thursday, July 12 at 2PM, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ZACHARY
description: WILSON-Zachary, 51. In loving memory of the family who mourns with heartfelt sorrow the loss of their beloved Zach. Son of the late Ami. He is survived by his beloved mother, Eunice, his children Adam and Alexis. Brother to Joel and Suzi, and Lana and Bob Morgan. Uncle to Michael & Stacy, & to Austin and Brandon Morgan. Nephew to Ronnie and Claire Levene. Loving companion to Geislyn Turcotte and dear friend to Franny Wilson. He is also survived by his devoted cousin Zvi Shoshan and his family in Israel. We will miss and love you with all our hearts. Rest in peace. Suzi, Joel, Michael and Stacy Wilson

title: Corrections
description: An Outdoors column in SportsSunday about fishing off Long Island misidentified the steel instrument used to help pull a fish into a boat and subdue it. It is a BogaGrip, not a boca grip.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Architecture and Sex

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Drug-Cartel Arrest
description: Mexican officials said they had arrested a man suspected of being the chief assassin of one of Mexico's most notorious drug cartels. Jorge Humberto Rodrguez, alias The Frog, had been detained since March, but he had falsely identified himself upon arrest. Officials said Mr. Rodrguez had undergone plastic surgery to alter his appearance. Mr. Rodrguez is believed to have worked for the Tijuana-based Arellano Flix drug cartel, Mexico's most violent criminal organization. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Hess to Buy Triton Energy For $2.6 Billion in Cash
description: Amerada Hess will buy Triton Energy for about $2.6 billion in cash, the companies said yesterday.

title: Ripken Signs Off as an All-Star in Indelible Style
description: The All-Star Game was supposed to be a homefest for Seattle's Mariners, the game's high-flying hosts, and it was, lovingly. It was going to be the night on which Mike Piazza finally faced Roger Clemens again, and he did, uneventfully. But the game overwhelmingly became the latest tribute to Cal Ripken of the Baltimore Orioles, who upstaged everyone else at Safeco Field tonight, incredibly.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Radio Stories, With an Edge and on the Edge
description: MIKE FEDER has been through three marriages. He has spent thousands of dollars on shrinks. He has been in a couple of mental institutions. His allergies preclude long periods of time outside walls of concrete. He feels guilty about, well, everything. And he thinks a lot about death. All this, and he loves to talk about it, a lot, 20 years of talk, although this is not, he will tell you, enough.

title: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Restructuring Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: John Carroll-Abbing, 88, Dies; Founded Italian Boys' Town
description: Msgr. John Patrick Carroll-Abbing, a priest who founded Boys' Town and Girls' Town of Italy 56 years ago for the waifs left after World War II, died on Monday at Boys' Town of Rome. He was 88.

title: Trivia: The Best on the Mound for the '77 Mets
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DoubleClick Loss Widens
description: The big online advertising agency DoubleClick Inc. said its second-quarter loss widened as revenue fell 20 percent from a year earlier. The company also expects to cut an undisclosed number of jobs. The loss was $37.9 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with a loss of $22.1 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $101.9 million from $128.1 million. DoubleClick's shares fell 74 cents, or 5.8 percent, to $12.02. DoubleClick, which reduced its 2001 revenue forecast in April and predicted losses for the rest of the year, confirmed that forecast yesterday.

title: City's Subway Service Is Improving, Group's Report Says
description: Attention all No. 7 train passengers: Please step aside.

title: Otto Rosenberg, 74, Gypsy Who Survived Auschwitz
description: Otto Rosenberg, a German Gypsy who survived Nazi persecution and described it in a volume of memoirs, ''A Gypsy in Auschwitz,'' died last Thursday in Berlin, the German newspaper Berliner Zeitung has reported. He was 74.

title: Malone Leaves AT&T Board a Month Early
description: John C. Malone, the cable television magnate who is one of AT&T's largest individual shareholders, resigned yesterday from the company's board earlier than planned after he was excluded from talks related to Comcast's offer to buy AT&T's cable systems.

title: Founder Is Forced to Resign At Irish Software Developer
description: Fran Rooney, the founder of the Irish security software developer Baltimore Technologies, resigned today as chief executive and deputy chairman. Shareholders had been pressuring Mr. Rooney to resign after a series of bungled announcements and missed financial goals the last six months.

title: Homeowners' Suit Says They Are Victims in Deceptive Sales Scheme
description: They are nurses and police officers, minority couples and families, most of them from working-class New York City neighborhoods. And they say they listened avidly to the offers of affordable suburban houses on tree-lined streets near country clubs, beaches, lakes and good schools for their children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSLAND, HELEN ''NICKY'' NELSON
description: BOSLAND-Helen ''Nicky'' Nelson, of Amelia Island, died Monday (July 9th) of pancreatic cancer at age 67. Nicky, as she was known to everyone, formerly resided in Short Hills, New Jersey and summered in Stowe, Vermont. She was a graduate of The Beard School and Wheaton College. In New Jersey, Nicky was a life member of the Millburn-Short Hills First Aid Squad, Chairman of the Millburn-Short Hills Red Cross and a member of the Short Hills Garden Club. She was immediate past Chairman of the Amelia Arts Academy, an active volunteer at the Amelia Island Museum and a member of the Jacksonville Women's Golf Association. An avid golfer, she was also a founder of The Country Club of Vermont. Nicky leaves her husband of 45 years, Paul, of Amelia Island; two sons, Richard of Summit, New Jersey and James of Wellesley, Massachusetts; four granddaughters, and a sister, Susan Marshall of Darien, Connecticut. A memorial service will be held at The Amelia Plantation Chapel on Saturday, July 14 at 4:00PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Amelia Arts Academy, Post Office Box 222 Fernandina Beach, Florida 32035, or the American Cancer Society.

title: Undeterred by Crises, So Paulo Biennial Celebrates at 50
description: Trends come and go, and government cultural policies are always subject to change. In the perpetually unstable world of Brazilian art, the only constant is this: The So Paulo Biennial will be held, though not necessarily in alternate years, and it will be bathed in controversy.

title: Spirited Recall Effort Draws a Yawn From McCain
description: For many of them, the last straw was his vote against President Bush's tax cut package. Yet while some Arizona Republicans were content to complain in letters to local newspapers, others decided more forceful action was necessary.

title: New Jersey Man Accused of Repeatedly Molesting Six Girls
description: An architect from Woodbridge, N.J., was arrested yesterday and accused of molesting six young girls, including the daughter of a local police officer. The case prompted charges by the man's lawyer that the police were engaged in a witch hunt.

title: Light Covers, Warm Colors
In the Wee Hours
Light Covers, Warm Colors
Japans Textbook Case
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Public Candor and Gary Condit
description: It's time for the Democratic House leadership, and indeed, leading Democrats at the national and state party level, to express serious concern about the conduct of Representative Gary Condit. The House Democrats, in fact, should press Mr. Condit to give a full public account of his friendship with Chandra Levy and anything he may know about her activities in the days before she disappeared.

title: Bush Offers Lawmakers a Wish List on Medicare Revamp
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Five big health care companies promised today to work with President Bush to help Medicare beneficiaries obtain discounts on prescription drugs through a voluntary private program starting Jan. 1. But Democrats in Congress ridiculed the president's proposal as a trivial step to solve a huge problem.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Plea In Drug Case
description: A 31-year-old Israeli man pleaded guilty yesterday to running an international smuggling ring for the drug Ecstasy by using Hasidic couriers. The Israeli, Sean Erez, admitted in Federal District Court to using Hasidim from Williamsburg and Monsey. For $1,500 per trip, the couriers smuggled more than one million Ecstasy tablets from Europe to the United States in 1998 and 1999. Mr. Erez used Hasidim in religious garb because they drew less scrutiny in customs, prosecutors said. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Great Fanfare, Then No Deal In Louima Case
description: Shortly before 5 p.m. yesterday, the city announced that it and the main police union would pay Abner Louima $8.75 million to settle his civil rights lawsuit.

title: CALENDAR
description: Road Shows

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, CAROL G.
description: STERN-Carol G. Of Hollywood, FL. Passed away on Tuesday, July 10, 2001. She was born in New Haven, CT and resided for many years in Greensboro, N.C., until the death of her husband, Henry J. Lavietes. She then married the late Julian Stern and moved to Hollywood, Florida. She was active in many charitable organizations. She will be remembered as a woman of remarkable beauty, grace, taste, and graciousness by all of those who were fortunate enough to know her. She leaves behind family, friends and most of all, admirers. We miss her already. Funeral arrangements entrusted to: Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 2230 Hollywood Blvd, Hollywood, FL. 33020 954-921-1776.

title: No Defense This Year For the Mets' Offense
description: Moments after his team's first half ended with another punchless defeat Sunday night, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine thought ahead to the All-Star Game, where he would manage a team of sluggers chosen mostly by him. ''Hopefully, we'll score some runs,'' Valentine said.

title: CBS Expels Reality Show Contestant Over Threats
description: A male contestant on the CBS reality television show ''Big Brother'' was dismissed from the program late on Tuesday night for holding a kitchen knife against the throat of a female contestant, the show's executive producer said yesterday.

title: Judge Grants Authors a Victory In Fight Over Digital-Book Rights
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the term ''book'' in book contracts does not automatically include electronic books. The decision goes to the heart of a battle over who controls the right to sell digital editions of the great majority of work published the last century.

title: Summer, the Silicon Season
description: DURING the summer my family splits into two factions. Some members like to frolic in the sand. Others think of it as wallowing in a special kind of dirt.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST HAWAII: SEXUAL CONSENT AGE RAISED The Legislature overrode a veto for the first time since statehood, upholding a bill to raise the age of sexual consent from 14 to 16. The governor, Benjamin J. Cayetanos, a Democrat, had opposed the measure on the grounds that it was poorly drafted and was inconsistent. He accused Republicans in the Legislature of manipulating the issue for political advantage and the Democrats of giving in for fear that it would be used against them in next year's elections.    Todd S. Purdum (NYT) PLAINS OKLAHOMA: DEATH PENALTY CASES REVIEWED Evidence will be retested in at least three of 14 death penalty convictions that are being reviewed because the F.B.I. criticized the forensics work of a police laboratory chemist, the state attorney general's office said. The 14 reviews are expected to be completed by next week. Joyce Gilchrist, the chemist whose work was questioned, is on administrative leave.   (Reuters) SOUTH ALABAMA: SCHOOL DRUG TESTS Students at the Alabama School of Mathematics and Science could face mandatory drug testing if the school's board of directors approves a policy proposed by a committee of educators. Under the new policy, the school would become the first public school in the state to administer the tests.    Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT) MISSISSIPPI: TRAVEL BOYCOTT URGED Delegates at the N.A.A.C.P. convention in New Orleans adopted a resolution asking members to discontinue travel to Mississippi in an unofficial boycott over the state's refusal to rid its flag of the Confederate emblem. In a referendum last April, voters overwhelmingly supported keeping the emblem.   Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT) LOUISIANA: SHIPYARD TOLD TO SHAPE UP An administrative law judge with the National Labor Relations Board has ordered the Northrop Grumman Avondale shipyard near New Orleans to reinstate 22 workers whom the judge found were dismissed illegally from 1994 to 1997 for trying to unionize the shipyard's 4,000 workers. The judge, Philip McLeod, also ordered Avondale to repay $5.4 million in legal fees, saying the company was wrong to ask the Navy to pay for defending the yard.    Steven Greenhouse (NYT) NEW ENGLAND MASSACHUSETTS: DISTRICT WOULD DISAPPEAR While Representative Martin T. Meehan, a Democrat, has been lobbying for a campaign finance overhaul in Washington, the Democratic speaker of the state House has unveiled a redistricting plan that would pull Mr. Meehan's district out from under him. The speaker, Thomas M. Finneran, left, whom Mr. Meehan recently accused of trying to weaken state campaign finance laws, would divide Mr. Meehan's Fifth District among several others, though the state is not losing a Congressional seat. Mr. Finneran said he was trying to create more coherent districts and give minorities a stronger voice.    Julie Flaherty (NYT) MASSACHUSETTS: BAD WEATHER FOR WHALE Choppy seas and poor visibility thwarted marine scientists' effort to aid a rare North Atlantic right whale with rope entangled in its jaw about 45 miles east of Cape Cod. A spokeswoman for the National Marine Fisheries Services said scientists found the whale on Tuesday but did not try to remove the line because of weather.    (AP) RHODE ISLAND: UNIVERSITY NAMES PRESIDENT Roger Williams University in Bristol has appointed Roy J. Nirschel, a longtime college administrator and accomplished fund-raiser, as its eighth president. Dr. Nirschel, who earned his Ph.D. in public administration at the University of Miami, is the president of Newbury College in Brookline, Mass.    Jodi Wilgoren (NYT) WASHINGTON LESS FOR CHARITIES The House Ways and Means Committee approved a scaled-down version of President Bush's program to funnel federal money to religions for their charitable works. The proposal for the administration's "faith-based initiative" will provide $13 billion in tax breaks over 10 years, down from the $98 billion requested by Mr. Bush. The bill also would allow taxpayers who did not itemize to deduct charitable contributions of no more than $100. A House vote is expected next week.   Elizabeth Becker (NYT) TEACHERS UNIONS JOIN HANDS The nation's two major teachers unions are forming a joint council for lobbying and legal action and to coordinate activities. The National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers represent a total of 2.5 million teachers.    Jodi Wilgoren (NYT) SCIENCE AND HEALTH COCAINE CRAVINGS RECUR Cocaine addicts may have a tough time kicking the habit because cravings for the drug increase long after they have stopped taking it, scientists have found. "This phenomenon helps explain why addiction is a chronic, relapsing disease," said Dr. Alan Leshner, the director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse.   (Reuters)

title: Gracie Mansion Needs Attention, But Whose?; Mayor's Marital Dispute Extends to Peeling Paint
description: The paint is peeling, balcony railings are rotting and the lawn is worn down to a bare spot. Gracie Mansion, the 200-year-old official residence of the mayor of New York, has grown, in a word, shabby.

title: Facing Crisis, The President Of Sri Lanka Calls a Vote
description: The suspension of Parliament on Tuesday night by the president of Sri Lanka -- which analysts say she undertook to avoid a no-confidence vote she feared she would lose -- was constitutional but was condemned by the political opposition as undemocratic.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Petals, Fruit, Sequins And a Fudgeable Fit
description: I HAVE restrained myself from talking about shoes for long enough. I laid low for months, creating cover by pretending to care about other things: art, politics, the state of the economy. But I was living a lie.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: UBS Postpones Spinoff
description: Switzerland's largest banking group, UBS, said it would postpone the spinoff of UBS Capital, its $3.2 billion private equity business, because of weak financial markets. The Zurich-based group also said the unit's chief executive, Pierre de Weck, was leaving by the end of July but gave no other details. UBS Capital had a $165 million loss in the first quarter after a $7 million profit the previous three months. The unit will remain part of UBS Warburg, headed by Markus Granziol, above, but a management shift is planned. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Disturbed Children, Lacking Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Work to Begin on Site for Testing Missile Defense
description: The Pentagon will notify Congress on Monday that it plans to begin preparatory work in mid-August on a new missile-defense test site at Fort Greely, in Alaska, the first step in a more aggressive testing program.

title: Bugs Bunny Is Losing His Times Square Home in October
description: The Warner Brothers studio store, which was a symbol of a resurgent Times Square when it opened four years ago, is closing in October.

title: A Quick Way to Search For Images on the Web
description: Is there anything Google can't find? In February the popular search engine announced that it had started indexing millions of portable document format files (identifiable by the suffix .pdf). Now the company has launched Google Image Search, a nifty new tool that lets you search for the pictures embedded in Web pages.

title: A New Jersey Sensibility: So?
description: Perhaps it's simply that it's summer, but readers are no doubt aware that there doesn't seem to be any remarkable literary question these days of the sort that ignites fiery clashes in journals and reviews among book people.

title: Marks & Spencer Reports Another Loss
description: Angry shareholders criticized the chief executive of Marks & Spencer, the British retailer, today after the company reported its 12th successive quarterly slide in sales but asked investors to give its directors larger rewards.

title: Virtual Hollywood
description: With the rise of digitized leading characters in movies like ''Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within,'' it was only a matter of time before Hollywood producers, agents and executives would be supplanted by a computer-generated horde of swaggering, cutthroat, Armani-clad pixels. According to the latest Hollywood power list, the six most influential people in the business today are not, technically speaking, people:

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from July 10.

title: To Expand Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Telephone Privatization
description: South Africa announced that the long-planned public offering for Telkom South Africa would be in November. South Africa is undertaking a sweeping effort to sell significant stakes in its biggest state-owned companies, but with labor balking at the scope of the effort, progress has been slow. The global downturn in technology and telecommunication stocks has made the government more circumspect about taking Telkom public. Telkom Malaysia and SBC Communications, which together own 30 percent of Telkom South Africa, are in talks with the government, which owns the remaining 70 percent, over which will sell shares and how much of the company will go public. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: 'Faith Based' Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Hell on Wheels, With a Few Creaky Parts
description: They came roaring into town this afternoon, 10 miles or more of chrome, leather and thunder headed for this dusty locale that calls itself the birthplace of the American biker and sets aside one weekend in July to keep that place in cultural history.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: In a Shift, Microsoft to Give PC Makers More Freedom

title: Banks Give Polaroid Time to Renegotiate Millions in Loans
description: The Polaroid Corporation won a reprieve from its banks yesterday, receiving a waiver that will keep it from defaulting on $367 million in loans. The waiver was Polaroid's third this year.

title: Cyclones Take Aim At Yankees
description: The Subway Series, it's not. But the Bridge Series might prove to be a little more competitive.

title: MICROSOFT TO GIVE COMPUTER MAKERS GREATER FREEDOM
description: Acknowledging that it must change its business practices, Microsoft announced yesterday that it would give personal computer makers more freedom to choose what software and services they offer on the machines they sell.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit At Software Concerns
description: Two of India's leading software exporters, Infosys Technologies and Satyam Computer Services reported strong increases in quarterly profits but warned that the global economic slowdown was putting pressure on prices. Infosys said on Tuesday that its profit rose 49 percent, to 1.9 billion rupees ($40.4 million), and Satyam said yesterday that its profit rose 141 percent, to 1.2 billion rupees ($25.7 million). Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Conservatives Pressure Bush In Cell Debate
description: For all the talk of a compromise on embryonic stem cell research, many leaders in the anti-abortion movement say they are counting on President Bush to abide by his campaign promises and hold the line against federal financing for such research.

title: Don't Be Cruel: Tales of Two Lives
description: ELVIS IN THE MORNING

title: Union Leader Will Propose Total Access To Head Start
description: Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, is scheduled to call today for universal access to high-quality preschool programs for every child in the nation age 3 and over.

title: New Surplus Numbers
description: The White House said the weakening economy might reduce the federal surplus this year but there is no risk ''at present'' of having to use Social Security surpluses in coming years.

title: For Better Mousing, A Better Mousetrap
description: In the struggle to prevent computer-related injuries, the shoulder sometimes gets short shrift. But moving the arm from the keyboard to the mouse, then moving the mouse, then moving back to the keyboard, can lead to a sore shoulder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHRACH, YVONNE
description: BACHRACH-Yvonne. On July 11, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Richard Jay. Loving father of Daniel and Lewis. Funeral services will be held on Friday, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. In lieu of flowers a contribution to Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 St., NYC 10021 in her memory would be appreciated.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Paul Benjou was named director for client services at the New York office of Mediaplex, succeeding Jen Bauer, who left, the company said, to move to Atlanta. Mr. Benjou had been senior vice president and group media director at Draft Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Ford Is Changing the Way It Rates Work of Managers
description: The Ford Motor Company told employees on Tuesday that it was changing a performance ranking system for managers that had become the subject of a growing number of lawsuits.

title: Toronto Journal; Shedding a Bit More Than Its Image
description: When Carmen Russo goes to work, she routinely does something that just a few years ago would have been unthinkable in a city so conservative about so many things that it was known throughout Canada as Toronto the Good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGREEN, MORRIS H.
description: BERGREEN-Morris H. The President, Chancellor Emeritus Boards of Governors and Overseers, Faculty Administration and Students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Morris H. Bergreen, generous benefactor and devoted friend of the College-Institute. Mr. Bergreen, a member of the Board of Governors for more than three decades, served as a member of the Executive Committee, Chair of the Library, Museum and Archives Committee and was deeply committed and involved in the life of the College-Institute. He helped guide all HUC-JIR during a period of far-reaching decisions and he offered his wise counsel and his astute perspective with unstinting zeal. We offer our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Adele and family whose loss we profoundly share. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, Pres. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Rabbi Norman J. Cohen, Provost Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors.

title: Notes of a Housewares King
description: WHEN Joel Dean and Giorgio G. DeLuca started Dean & DeLuca in 1977, Mr. Dean specialized in the store's line of fine housewares. It's no wonder then that he had firm ideas about what went into the kitchen of his 2,400-square-foot house in East Hampton.

title: Voyages of Discovery, Myth and Murder at Lincoln Center
description: Over the years the composer Philip Glass has taken a lot of criticism for repeating himself, and not just in his music. After all, repetition of rhythmic patterns and melodic figurations is the whole point of Minimalism (a term Mr. Glass has never much liked). It's his repetition of subject matter and themes, especially in his operas, that has also come in for criticism.

title: Drop in Profit At Emerson For First Time In 43 Years
description: Emerson Electric said today that its annual profit would drop for the first time in 43 years, dragged down by a plunge in spending by telecommunications companies.

title: Ensnared on the Web? How to File a Complaint
description: Q. Where can I report an incident of online consumer fraud?

title: Track Body Criticized But Cleared
description: An independent commission said yesterday that it had found no evidence that USA Track & Field willfully covered up any positive drug tests, but said the organization failed to follow its procedures ''for assuring that no doping cases were ignored or suppressed.''

title: The Sale of a Lifetime
description: SUE BLAIR began buying antiques at 10 and never stopped. Her career and marriage led her to prime places for collecting: Paris, London, Geneva, Jerusalem, New York City and this hamlet in Putnam County.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Warning On Revising Borders
description: President Vojislav Kostunica warned against any redrawing of borders in Yugoslavia, saying in a newspaper interview that revisions could increase instability in the region and in particular harm neighboring Macedonia. A day earlier, the Montenegrin government set March 2002 as the date for a referendum on Montenegro's independence from Yugoslavia. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, ROSE
description: STEINBERG-Rose. WIZO extends its deepest sympathies to Elan Steinberg on the loss of his mother Rose. May the cherished memories of her love and devotion be a source of consolation to the family Evelyn Sommer, President, WIZO USA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, STOKELY
description: WEBSTER-Stokely. Age 88, on June 29, 2001. Renowned Impressionist painter. Beloved husband of Audrey. Father of Stephanie Brooks, Dr. Jane Ramsay, Norman J. Coutant, Elizabeth Howell, Sandra Kelly. Memorial Service will be Saturday, July 14, at 11 AM, the First Church Congregational, 148 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT

title: Witnesses Say Auto Test Company Got Inside Data
description: In violation of a rule prohibiting state officials from meeting with potential bidders, the one company that bid on New Jersey's $500 million auto emissions testing system in 1998 was given advance information on the program, witnesses disclosed today.

title: Mixed Messages
description: President Jiang Zemin of China is scheduled to make a state visit here on Sunday, but Olympic decisions made before he arrives will determine whether his visit will occur in splendid triumph or in bitter defeat.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Judge Won't Free Youths In Beating
description: A State Superior Court judge ruled yesterday that 11 of the 12 teenagers accused last month of beating and killing a homeless man in Paterson would not be released from custody. The status of the 12th teenager will be decided later. The court refused to grant the youths home detention on the grounds that they represented a serious danger to the public, said Michael O'Shea, the acting chief assistant prosecutor. The youths face murder, felony murder and robbery charges in the fatal beating of Hector Robles, 42. The prosecutor's office has not decided whether they will be tried as adults.

title: A Little Slam Fails Where A Big One Would Not
description: The diagramed deal caused some heartache in Turkey recently. Consider what contract you would choose to play in looking at just the North-South hands. East has shown at least 5-5 distribution in the minor suits. Then answer the same question looking at all four hands.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Forlorn Lots, Seeking Proposals
description: The Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it would accept proposals for the development of 300,000 square feet of city-owned property at seven locations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The sites, which include lots in Washington Heights, Downtown Brooklyn, and the South Street Seaport, are suitable for commercial, industrial, or retail uses. The largest is a 101,700-square-foot retail strip in East New York. In making its selections, the city's Economic Development Corporation will consider financial feasibility, design, developers' qualifications, and economic, environmental and community effects. Proposals are due Sept. 26.

title: Yahoo, Reporting a Loss, Looks for Joint Ventures
description: Yahoo, which was once one of the few money-making Internet companies, said yesterday that it lost $48.5 million in the second quarter. It nonetheless modestly beat its financial goals, which it had drastically reduced earlier this year as demand for Internet advertising began to plummet.

title: Just Divorced, Gone Shopping
description: LEILA MESGHALI, a psychologist in Los Angeles, didn't look back. When she walked out of her marriage of three years, she took only her clothes and some heirloom dishes. ''It felt cleaner that way,'' Ms. Mesghali, 30, said. ''Some of our clashes had to do with decorating.'' A few months after she separated from her husband, the decorating urge kicked in. Even on a limited budget, she spent $6,000 on a dark teak armoire, sofa and bedroom set. ''I had a lot of motivation to fill my apartment up quickly,'' she said. ''It was an opportunity to do my own thing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDLAY, HARRIET LINDSAY
description: FINDLAY-Harriet Lindsay. Died unexpectedly in her Manhattan apartment on July 5th, 2001. Known as Lindsay, she was born on August 16, 1935, in Kansas City, MO, and grew up in New Canaan, CT. A graduate of Dana Hall School, Goucher College and the Harvard-Radcliffe Business Program, she initially worked for The Putnam Fund in Boston, MA. In 1958 she joined her father, David B. Findlay Sr., in his Manhattan art business, David Findlay Galleries. The original Findlay Galleries was founded in Kansas City, MO, 1870. Lindsay was a member of the fourth generation of the family to be involved with the gallery. In 1989 her father died, and Lindsay assumed control of the gallery. She is survived by her mother, Harriet Jones Findlay, two brothers, David B. Findlay Jr. and H. Peter Findlay, and numerous nieces & nephews. Each of the brothers has his own eponymous art gallery in Manhattan. A memorial service will be held at the Congregational Church, 23 Park St, New Canaan, CT, on Tuesday, July 17th at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Humane Society of Manhattan and New Canaan Nature Center in memory of the deceased.

title: Now Batting for Boston: John Adams
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts At Psion
description: The British computer equipment maker Psion said it would take a charge of 29 million ($41 million) and cut 250 jobs, a fifth of its staff, as it abandons plans to make hand-held computers. Psion, which has lost market share to Palm Inc., the leader in hand-held computers, will focus on software and services for mobile phones. It said sales in its Teklogix unit were likely to slow in the second half of the year, as companies cut back on information technology outlays. The unit's sales rose nearly three-fold in the first half to 63 million ($91.8 million). Sales at the company's digital unit, which made the hand-held computers, fell more than 50 percent in the first six months of the year, to 36 million ($50.8 million). Total sales grew 5 percent, to 99 million ($139.8 million). Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: U.S. Sets Missile Defense Plan, Threatening 1972 ABM Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 — The Pentagon wants to start construction in April of facilities for a missile-defense shield that could put the United States in violation of a 1972 treaty banning such defenses, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz told lawmakers today.

title: In a Flash, Flood Leaves Town's Future in Question
description: It was the long-dreaded hundred-year flood, roaring down right on schedule by Mayor Jack Premo's reckoning. It swept through the mountain hollow like a tidal wave, upending homes and cars and smashing ruinously through the dozen simple stores that underpin the tax base in this impoverished Appalachian town.

title: Corporate Plagiarism
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Bush administration's view of China's bid for the 2008 Olympics misstated the stance of Amnesty International. It is not opposed to the Olympics being held there; it takes no position on the question.

title: Isbister and Isles Reach Deal
description: The Islanders have come to terms on a two-year contract with the 24-year-old power forward Brad Isbister.

title: A Little Hangar in the Hamptons
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. -- DEAN & DELUCA, the luxury food store, helped establish the aesthetic of industrially inspired retail minimalism when it opened 24 years ago. So it is no surprise that when Joel B. Dean, one of the founders of Dean & DeLuca, decided to build a home on a secluded wooded lot by the Long Island Rail Road tracks in East Hampton, he would pick rough-and-tumble metal parts for a house off the shelf from an Ohio company that builds barns, airplane hangars and chicken coops. Mr. Dean's weekend getaway was designed by Jack Ceglik, of the Manhattan design firm Ceglik, who had previously done Mr. Dean's whitewashed loft on Wooster Street in New York.

title: Kidd Adds His Act To Nets' Showtime
description: Byron Scott first gained fame as a member of Showtime, filling the lanes for layups or hitting open jumpers off no-look passes from Magic Johnson in Los Angeles. Now, as the Nets' coach, Scott believes Jason Kidd can bring Showtime excitement and success to New Jersey.

title: Take the Party Out of the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMPUCOM SYSTEMS INC., Dallas, a provider of network products and integration services and a unit of Safeguard Scientifics has agreed to buy certain assets of Excell Data Corp., Bellevue, Wash., a developer of online business software and Web sites for the information-technology industry, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Durand's Spots Vanish, Erased by Topography
description: The king is dead, long live the king. No, that would not be Albert II of the Belgians but Jacky Durand of the mountains.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From Turkey to Tuscany, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: On the Trains And in Your Pocket
description: Not only does Philippe Starck, right, reign over hotel chains, bathroom fixtures and citrus squeezers, he is taking on mass transportation and the money supply. Eurostar, which operates the trains linking Paris and London, has hired him to oversee a $55 million refurbishment of its train interiors, terminals, graphics and uniforms. And numismatists take note: Mr. Starck has been asked to design France's last one-franc coin. Available in September, the limited edition of 50,000 coins (with an outsize ''1'') will have a short life. Euro currency is being introduced in January, and will replace the franc next July 1.

title: Beyond Borders, Without Boundaries
description: Around midnight on Monday night, the crowd of dancers at the Bowery Ballroom formed a circle, wrapped their arms over one another's shoulders and sang along with a tearful Mexican-style waltz about lost love, accompanied by the button accordion from the band onstage. Moments later the drums charged in, the tempo was jacked up, and the fans went back to slam-dancing.

title: Father Owing Child Support Loses a Right To Procreate
description: In an unusual action against a ''deadbeat dad,'' the Wisconsin Supreme Court has upheld a probation order that bars a man convicted of failure to pay child support from having more children unless he shows that he can support all his offspring.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Bouncer at Strip Club Is Accused Of Killing Man After Argument
description: A bouncer at an Atlantic City strip club was charged with murder yesterday in the beating death of an investment banker from London who had been attending a bachelor party early Sunday morning, the Atlantic County prosecutor announced.

title: A Little Hangar In the Hamptons
description: DEAN & DELUCA, the luxury food store, helped establish the aesthetic of industrially inspired retail minimalism when it opened 24 years ago. So it is no surprise that when Joel B. Dean, one of the founders of Dean & DeLuca, decided to build a home on a secluded wooded lot by the Long Island Rail Road tracks in East Hampton, he would pick rough-and-tumble metal parts for a house off the shelf from an Ohio company that builds barns, airplane hangars and chicken coops. Mr. Dean's weekend getaway was designed by Jack Ceglik, of the Manhattan design firm Ceglik, who had previously done Mr. Dean's whitewashed loft on Wooster Street in New York.

title: Measure Easing Drug Imports Passes in House
description: The House voted today to make it easier for people to import low-cost prescription drugs for their own use, after rejecting a more sweeping proposal to allow such imports by drug wholesalers and pharmacies.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Class Materials
description: A Congressional panel approved legislation that would permit colleges and universities to put copyrighted material for classes online. The bill, passed unanimously by the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Courts, the Internet and Intellectual Property, would allow students taking courses remotely to have access to texts and recordings for assignments using the Internet. The schools would be required to protect the files from being viewed or copied without permission. The Senate passed similar legislation last month; House approval would send the bill to President Bush.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about plans to destroy two natural gas tanks in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the age of one neighborhood resident, Annette Lamatto. She is 43, not 49.

title: Ice Cream Makers Ask Washington to Help Cut Rising Costs
description: Scoopers in hand, lids peeled off their 3-gallon tubs, the nation's ice cream makers massed in Washington yesterday, complaining that the government has driven them to charge prices that even summer-struck consumers do not want to pay.

title: Fund-Raiser Is Found Unhurt And Says He Was Kidnapped
description: Forty-eight hours after he mysteriously vanished, Karan Kumar, a prominent Republican fund-raiser on Long Island and a luminary in some Indian-American circles, has just as curiously reappeared.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea, Vietnam: A Friend In Need
description: Kim Yong Nam, North Korea's second in command, began a mission to Vietnam in hopes that Hanoi would show its gratitude for past favors by donating rice and other aid. Mr. Kim, greeted by Vietnam's No. 2 official, President Tran Duc Luong, planned to visit a cemetery containing bodies of North Korean pilots shot down in the Vietnam War. Hanoi upset Pyongyang by opening ties in 1992 with South Korea, now a big investor and trading partner.

title: Light Covers, Warm Colors
description: A QUILT sounds like a strange bedfellow during the summer, but not when the air-conditioner is turned to high or when country nights are cool.

title: In America; Get Well, George
description: Nineteen-sixty-four was the year the 60's really began. The earliest years of the decade were for the most part an extension of the conventional, cold-war, black-and-white 50's. Dwight Eisenhower was president through 1960, which was the year the U-2 reconnaissance pilot Francis Gary Powers was shot down over Soviet territory. When John F. Kennedy was inaugurated in 1961, the men participating in the ceremony wore morning coats and top hats.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Bush administration's view of China's bid for the 2008 Olympics misstated the stance of Amnesty International. It is not opposed to the Olympics being held there; it takes no position on the question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VATIS, JOHN D.
description: VATIS-John D. On July 10, 2001. Beloved husband of Kalipso (Kay). Cherished father of Harriet and Robert Gardner. Funeral Friday 10:30am Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 319 East 74 St. Friends may call Thursday 2-4 and 7-9, Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: South Africa Confronts Landless Poor, and a Court Sends Them Packing
description: The invaders came to the wasteland by the hundreds two weeks ago, dragging splintering planks, rusting metal sheets and wilting squares of cardboard.

title: Who Needs the Suburbs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Batting for Boston: John Adams
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Remember Forgotten 'Yankees'
description: OUT beyond left field in Yankee Stadium are Monument Park's 5 monuments and 17 plaques symbolizing much of Yankee history.

title: From Captain to Coach: Ex-Goodfella's New Life
description: Having watched youth-league coaches across the United States make news for behavior ranging from assaulting umpires to molesting children, the Encino Little League decided this spring to require all prospective managers to submit to a background check, even going so far as to have each of them fingerprinted.

title: Tennis association tries to make the United States Open even more successful.
description: IT may seem a bit early -- after all, the rain-delayed finals at Wimbledon just ended on Monday. But though the United States Open at Flushing Meadows is still nearly seven weeks away, the United States Tennis Association and some of its sponsors have already begun their push to make the tournament bigger -- and more commercially successful -- than ever before.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Convicted Of Five Murders
description: A federal jury yesterday convicted Elvis Irizarry, 30, an amateur boxer nicknamed the Little Bull, on federal racketeering charges that included loan-sharking, arson and five murders in New York and New Jersey. Mr. Irizarry, according to trial testimony, committed his crimes on orders from the Luchese and Gambino crime families. He faces five life terms, plus 240 years, when sentenced. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Knoblauch Must Hit To Remain A Yankee
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, does not second-guess the rationale behind the 1998 trade for Chuck Knoblauch, because the team has won the World Series in every year Knoblauch has been with the team. ''And how can you question that?'' Steinbrenner asked, rhetorically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREED, WILLIAM CONSTABLE III
description: BREED-William Constable III, 66, died Monday July 9, 2001 following complications after a courageous battle with Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Breed was co-founder and president of Edgewood Management Company in New York and lived in Greenwich, Connecticut. Prior to founding Edgewood Management Company in 1974, Mr. Breed was a vice president of Channing Management Corporation, responsible for the firm's New York investment office. He joined Channing in 1970 from his previous position as President of the investment advisory firm of Cannell, Breed & Musser, Inc. Before that, he had formed and supervised the Investment Advisory Department of F. Eberstadt & Company. Mr. Breed began his investment career in 1962 as a portfolio manager at the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York. Mr. Breed also served as a company commander in the United States Army at Fort Bliss, Texas and was honorably discharged as a first lieutenant in 1961. Mr. Breed was a well-known amateur athlete. His championship victories spanned a period of four decades from 1964 to 1991. Included in this time were twelve tennis titles, four club championships in golf and he was a finalist in the United States National Paddle Tennis Championship in 1969. Mr. Breed was active in many charitable and civic endeavors and served on a number of boards of directors, including Junior Achievement, The International Peace Academy, Manhattan Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat Hospital, The Round Hill Club in Greenwich, and the Stony WoldHerbert Foundation. He was also a former finance committee member of the Committee on Trust Funds for the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States. Mr. Breed was born and raised in New York City. He was a graduate of the Buckley Country Day School in New York, St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, and Middlebury College. He did graduate work in business at The Business School of New York University. He was the son of the late William C. Breed, Jr. and Ellen Whitman Breed. Mr. Breed was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Rebecca, and four children: William C. Breed IV of Richmond, VA, and Alan W. Breed, Michael S. Breed, and Rebecca B. Richardson, all of Greenwich. Eleven grandchildren and a sister, Mrs. Foye Staniford of New York, also survive him. A celebration of his life will be held at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, Connecticut on Friday, July 13, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family would greatly appreciate contributions to: The Mayo Foundation for Alzheimer's Disease Research, 200 First Street Southwest, Rochester, Minnesota 55905.

title: Now Batting for Boston: John Adams
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUKAS, CHRISTOPHER
description: SOUKAS-Christopher. On July 10, 2001. Loving husband of Alexandra. Devoted father of Thomas and his wife Barbara, Anthony and his wife Diane, Christopher and his wife Catherine. Dear grandfather of Matthew, Heather, Nicholas, Alexandra Chloe, Gerald, James and Thomas. Dear brother of Vasiliki V. Viangos. Survived by his nieces and nephews. Reposing Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, Bronx NY on Thursday & Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Religious services will be conducted at Prophet Elias Greek Orthodox Church, 15 Leroy Avenue, Yonkers, NY on Saturday, at 10 AM. Interment will follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Basil's Academy, 79 St. Basil Road, Route 9D, Garrison, NY 10524, or Ronald McDonald House, Greek Division, 405 East 73rd Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Medicaid To Be Restored For Thousands
description: New York City and State have agreed to pay back the medical expenses and restore the health care coverage of thousands of poor city families who were wrongly cut from Medicaid when they were dropped from the welfare rolls.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Sexual Consent Age Raised
description: The Legislature overrode a veto for the first time since statehood, upholding a bill to raise the age of sexual consent from 14 to 16. The governor, Benjamin J. Cayetanos, a Democrat, had opposed the measure on the grounds that it was poorly drafted and was inconsistent. He accused Republicans in the Legislature of manipulating the issue for political advantage and the Democrats of giving in for fear that it would be used against them in next year's elections.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Legal Eagle Surveys Prey

title: It's Physical but Not Close As Liberty Thumps Storm
description: Coach Richie Adubato of the Liberty said he would remind his players before last night's game with the Seattle Storm what Lauren Jackson had said last spring.

title: Bernstein Is Signed, Sealed, Postmarked and Delivered With Exuberance
description: Weather often provides a measure of drama in the free outdoor performances that the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera and other ensembles offer through the summer, and on Tuesday, when the Philharmonic opened its 37th season of concerts in the parks, it looked unpromising just before curtain time. A thunderstorm warning was in effect, and listeners picnicking in Central Park were rained on briefly.

title: Through the Looking Glass, to Holographic Data Storage
description: STORAGE space is tight these days, and not just in cramped New York apartments. Home dwellers anywhere might be delighted to stow the 10 years' worth of receipts, canceled checks and tax records clogging their files in a space no bigger than an ice cube. Hospitals, insurance companies, banks and department stores might also appreciate storage that compact for their vast databases.

title: Nissan Says It Can Refute Report of Bias In Car Loans
description: The Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation yesterday released a report that it said ''strongly refuted'' two recent studies indicating that black customers had paid more than whites to finance cars through Nissan dealerships.

title: A Bigger Hard-Disk Drive For Those With Room to Grow
description: A new hard drive from the Maxtor Corporation may make digital video storage problems a thing of the past. Maxtor recently released the DiamondMax 536DX, a hard drive that stores a whopping 100 gigabytes of data.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: School Drug Tests
description: Students at the Alabama School of Mathematics and Science could face mandatory drug testing if the school's board of directors approves a policy proposed by a committee of educators. Under the new policy, the school would become the first public school in the state to administer the tests. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Beach Blanket Bibliophiles; From Serious to Steamy: E-Books for the Shore
description: Five writers were asked to name some electronic books that they would be interested in reading this summer, and why. All are available in at least one of three e-book formats: Microsoft Reader, Adobe Acrobat Reader or Gemstar eBook.

title: Coming Soon to Les Halles, Via the Biennale
description: When Gilbert and Jean-Louis Costes planned a new restaurant near Les Halles they handed the designing to Gilbert's 26-year-old son, Thierry. The young Mr. Costes turned to friends like the French artists Pierre Huyghe and Philippe Parreno, and the graphic art team M&M. The group's luminous treelike lamp with opalescent bulbs, above, will be installed in the Les Halles restaurant when it opens in November; it was part of the three-room French Pavilion created by Mr. Huyghe at the recent Venice Biennale, where he was commended for his blending of art, architecture and design.

title: Disturbed Children, Lacking Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on July 3 about using microbicides to protect women against sexually transmitted diseases misidentified the company that is testing a gel called Savvy. It is Biosyn, not Biosys.

title: Metro Business Briefing | 13 Plus Digital Equals 61
description: WNET in New York began broadcasting digital television yesterday, becoming one of the first nonprofit stations in the country do do so. The digital arm of the station, WNET-DT, will broadcast on Channel 61, offering a mix of shows from the Public Broadcasting Service and WNET's own local programming. The station's analog broadcasts will continue on Channel 13. To view high-definition broadcasts, which feature clearer images and better sound quality, viewers must have a high definition television, a cable box and a special encoder. The transition at WNET was made possible through contributions to the station's $27 million digital campaign. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Chancellor to Scrutinize School Building Costs
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy outlined a series of reporting procedures to the Board of Education yesterday that will help his staff keep tighter control on spending under the system's five-year construction plan.

title: Corrections
description: A group of pictures with an article last week about the renovation of Jenna Lyons's loft on lower Broadway carried a credit that misidentified some of the photographers. A picture of the loft's dining area and another of its doorbell should have been credited to Stuart Tyson, not Antoine Bootz. None of the pictures were by Fred R. Conrad.

title: Energy Commission Divides Control of Eastern Power Grid
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ordered yesterday that the electricity transmission grid for the eastern United States be put under control of two regional authorities. One group would oversee New England and the Middle Atlantic states, and the other would be responsible for the Southeast.

title: Hold the Phone: A Final Freebie
description: BEFORE the Internet bubble burst, the dot-com era was really getting to be a lot of fun. By giving up a little personal information you could get Internet service, toothpaste or even dog food, all of it free. And now, almost all of it's gone, nothing more than a crazy fad that we'll describe to our grandchildren with a bittersweet chuckle. Psychiatrists had better gear up for a new class of mental affliction: Dot-Com Consumer Bereavement.

title: Campaign Finance's Crucial Vote
description: As they take up campaign finance legislation today, House members must not forget the underlying abuses that led to this moment. The current drive for reform sprang from the 1996 fund-raising scandals, including the foreign money and other abuses of former President Bill Clinton's re-election campaign and the Republicans' own six-figure excesses. It is no surprise that as issue after issue in Washington gets decided less by voters than by wealthy special interests, Americans have grown more weary of and disconnected from politics.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: University Names President
description: Roger Williams University in Bristol has appointed Roy J. Nirschel, a longtime college administrator and accomplished fund-raiser, as its eighth president. Dr. Nirschel, who earned his Ph.D. in public administration at the University of Miami, is the president of Newbury College in Brookline, Mass. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Artificial Heart Recipient Has Another Procedure
description: The first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart had a surgical procedure this week for a buildup of fluid around the device and was reported to be resting comfortably today, officials of Jewish Hospital said in a statement.

title: A Software Patch Brightens the Palm M505
description: With a color screen in a sleek metal case, the Palm m505 sounded like the palmtop of a user's dreams. But for many palmtop fans, excitement turned to dismay as they discovered that the m505's screen was so dim that it was difficult to read indoors. Palm says the screen was the only one that would fit in a super-slim case without sacrificing battery life; yet the company did not include a brightness control that would have left the brightness/battery tradeoff to the customer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOESCHEN, FRANCIS BURKE
description: MOESCHEN-Francis Burke. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Francis Burke Moeschen, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Rhythms Of Africa Plink, Snap And Rock
description: If a perpetual-motion machine is ever invented, it will probably have a six-cylinder engine. Or so it seemed at Africa Fte on Sunday afternoon at Central Park Summerstage, with a double bill of bands whose six-beat rhythms generated limitless energy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBANK, HELEN HORN
description: MILBANK-Helen Horn, age 87, died July 9, 2001. Beloved wife of Robert Milbank. Cherished mother of Mary Day Bodenstein of Morristown, NJ, Robert Jr. of Dallas, and Anne Mell of Summit, NJ. Devoted grandmother of Barbara, Meredith, Elizabeth, John, Stephen and Caitlin. Loving sister of Louise Riker and Nancy Norris, both of Chatham, NJ. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 14, 2001, at 11 AM, at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Avenue, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Junior League of Summit, NJ, or the Overlook Hospital Women's Auxiliary Twig #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRICKS, MARY
description: BARRICKS-Mary. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member, Dr. Norman Adler upon the loss of his mother. May the families be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, C. NICHOLAS
description: POTTER-C. Nicholas. Of Mill Neck, NY died peacefully at home on July 10th after a courageous battle with cancer. He was 62 years old. Loving and devoted husband of Clare; proud father of Cary Nicholas Jr. & his wife Alison, Christopher Kingsland & Jennifer; grandfather of Macy Lockheart, Nina Webb and Nicholas Alonzo; son of Julia M. Thompson; and brother of Charles, Dickie and Frances Thieriot. Until his retirement in 1997, Mr. Potter was a Senior Executive at J.P. Morgan & Co. A graduate of Yale University, he joined Morgan in 1965 after destroyer service in the U.S. Navy. Over the course of his 32-year career, he held a variety of senior positions with Morgan, all in the investment management area. In 1974 he started the firm's international investment management business in London putting Morgan at the forefront of one of the world's most rapidly growing financial services businesses. In 1984, he was appointed President and Chief Executive of J.P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. with overall responsibility for investment management. Under his leadership, J.P. Morgan became one of the largest and most successful global investment managers in the world. Mr. Potter was a director of Phoenix House, a trustee of The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation and a trustee of The Hospital for Special Surgery. From 1981 to 1997, when it merged with American Reinsurance Company, he was a director, Chairman of the Finance Committee and member of the Executive Committee of Munich American Reinsurance Company. From 1985 to 1996, he served as a trustee of St. Mark's School, Southborough, Massachusetts. Services will be held on Monday, July 16, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church in Locust Valley, L.I. at 11:30AM. Memorial contributions may be made to Phoenix House Development Fund, 164 W 74th St, NY, NY 10023.

title: 2 GROUPS IN HOUSE ARE AT FOCAL POINT ON CAMPAIGN BILL
description: Representative Shelley Moore Capito believes too much money is pouring into politics. She campaigned last fall with Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, at her side.

title: Nationalists On Taiwan Try to Regroup
description: When Taiwan's Nationalist Party was swept out of the presidency last year after 55 years, its leaders spent months in the political wilderness licking their wounds and falling out among themselves about who should take the blame for the defeat.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hamden: Pollution Cleanup Ordered
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection has ordered the town of Hamden and three other entities to clean up polluted soil in the neighborhood of Hamden Middle School. The order was directed at the town, the South Central Regional Water Authority, the State Education Department and the Olin Corporation, a maker of ammunition. The environmental agency said the four were probably responsible for the contamination, which includes lead and arsenic. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Corporate Plagiarism
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Come Up Empty On Mutombo and Davis
description: Two of the Knicks' pipe dreams ended this week when Dikembe Mutombo and Antonio Davis agreed to stay with their current teams. Mutombo is set to sign a five-year deal worth more than $13 million a year with the Philadelphia 76ers, and yesterday Davis accepted a five-year offer for more than $60 million from the Toronto Raptors.

title: To Cash In on a Lifestyle, Apple Hits the Mall
description: THE store is so self-aware that it doesn't even have its name on a sign. Instead, a glowing white apple with an iconic bite beckons shoppers in an upscale mall in this affluent Washington suburb.

title: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Beachcombing
description: High-powered binoculars bring the world closer. Unfortunately for people not blessed with steady hands, they can also make the world seem as though it is undergoing a constant earthquake. Canon's 10x30 IS binoculars ($699) use electronics and a special optical system to create steady, magnified images. The system can even eliminate the vibrations of the moving car, making the binoculars ideal for drive-by birdwatching.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Hong Kong's Bow To Beijing
description: Legislators in Hong Kong gave preliminary approval to a bill that would allow the Chinese government to dismiss Hong Kong's chief executive. The law, which Hong Kong authorities drafted after consulting with Beijing, provides for the chief executive to be elected by an 800-member committee. Pro-democracy leaders said the leader should be chosen in a direct election. The current chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, is widely expected to win a second term next year. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Poetic License
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, BETTY FRIED SILVER
description: COHN-Betty Fried Silver. Beautiful, vivacious, caring, beloved mother of Nanci Alderman and Larry Fried. Loving mother-in-law of Carolyn. Proud and adoring grandma of Jenny and Joey. Lifelong friend to many. The blonde bombshell has gone to join her Joe. Services ''Gutterman Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, Friday 11AM (1-800-378-1892).

title: Marathoner Aims For Championships
description: Despite tightness in his back, Khalid Khannouchi, the fastest marathoner, is trying to get healthy enough to represent the United States in the world championships Aug. 3 in Edmonton, Alberta. In the Boilermaker 15-kilometer road race Sunday in Utica, N.Y., Khannouchi had back spasms and dropped out after 10 kilometers. Twice this week he has been treated by a physical therapist and yesterday he ran for 45 minutes near his home in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODENCE, LOIS (BECKER)
description: ODENCE-Lois (Becker), on Monday, July 9, of Clearwater, FL and Brookline, MA. Beloved wife of Charles L. Odence. Loving mother of Barbara Lawrence Alfond and Theodore Alfond of Weston, MA, Ruth Lawrence duPont and Thomas duPont of Belleair, FL, Susan and Jeffrey Odence of Brockton, MA and Joanne Odence Flackett and John Flackett of Stratham, NH. Her son, John Odence predeceased her in 1986. Her thirteen grandchildren, five great-grandchildren and her nephews adored her and will treasure her memory. Services at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, MA, on Friday, July 13 at 10:00 AM. Memorial observance at the home of Barbara and Ted Alfond on Friday, after the interment, Saturday evening, Sunday and Monday. A memorial service will be held in Clearwater in the fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Lois Odence's memory may be made to the Library Work Scholar Fund, c/o BUNWC, P.O. Box 549110 MS 132, Waltham, MA 02454, or The Planters Nursing Scholarship Fund, c/o Morton Plant Mease Foundation, 1220 Druid Road South, Clearwater, FL 33756.

title: Traders Find Little Comfort In Dollar as Crises Deepen
description: PARIS  It is an axiom in the currency markets that when tremors rattle the global economy, investors seek safety in the dollar.

title: To Prosecutors, He's a Terrorist; to Defenders, a Con Man
description: As his case went to the jury yesterday, an Algerian man accused of conspiring in a plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport was alternately depicted as a small-time con artist unknowingly caught up in the terror plan and as a would-be guerrilla eager to join a holy war against America.

title: AT&T to Weigh Comcast Offer For Cable Unit
description: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, offered a spirited defense of his tenure and strategy today, even as he said that his company would carefully consider the Comcast Corporation's unsolicited bid to acquire AT&T's cable television unit.

title: Four Not-So-Spooky Summertime Minidramas
description: ''Night Visions,'' an anthology of tepid terror stories, begins tonight on Fox with four minidramas. One, about a nasty radio host who gets his comeuppance, concludes with an epilogue from the series's host-narrator, Henry Rollins. In language a bit more blunt, he says that for all the thorns in the side watching, ''remember, you can only irritate so many people before you'' infuriate ''the wrong one.''

title: Black Caucus Members Find Themselves Courted Heavily in Soft Money Fight
description: Few groups have heard as many kind words as the Congressional Black Caucus has heard this week from advocates of various versions of campaign finance legislation.

title: So, Who's the Pro?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Missile Defense Test for Congress
description: The Pentagon has not yet developed any technology that can reliably shoot down enemy missiles. Yet the Bush administration seems determined to sidestep Congressional and European misgivings and the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty and start building a rudimentary missile shield during its first term. Its latest gambit is a plan for a new test site in Alaska, with a few interceptor rockets stored nearby for possible emergency use.
