Some details remain unclear, but the arrangement could dangerously blur the distinction between testing and the fielding of an operational system.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEELER, VIVIAN M. (NEE MURPHY)
description: KEELER-Vivian M. (nee Murphy). On July 11, 2001. Devoted wife of the late William. Beloved sister of John and Joan Murphy and the late Vincent. Loving stepmother of Robert and Regina Keeler and Pamela and Joseph Imholz. Loving aunt of Robert, Thomas, Raymond, Mary, Jane, William, John and Kate; and 26 great nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Friday, July 13, 2PM to 5PM and 7PM to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, July 14, 9:00 AM at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: A Fatal Battle Worsens in Colombia: The War on Journalists
description: Oscar Vsquez had warned his brother, the news director of a radio station in a violent town, Florencia, to tone down his reporting. But the newscaster, Jos Dubiel Vsquez, continued disseminating news about local corruption and the conflict between rebels and paramilitary groups.

title: Republican Asks to See Rivals' Petitions
description: As the major candidates for mayor prepared to submit hundreds of thousands of petition signatures to the Board of Elections today, the campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg was requesting copies of them.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: District Would Disappear
description: While Representative Martin T. Meehan, a Democrat, has been lobbying for a campaign finance overhaul in Washington, the Democratic speaker of the state House has unveiled a redistricting plan that would pull Mr. Meehan's district out from under him. The speaker, Thomas M. Finneran, left, whom Mr. Meehan recently accused of trying to weaken state campaign finance laws, would divide Mr. Meehan's Fifth District among several others, though the state is not losing a Congressional seat. Mr. Finneran said he was trying to create more coherent districts and give minorities a stronger voice. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Legacy of Poison in Twice-Excavated Yards
description: Tom Harrington's backyard in Queensbury, N.Y., looks much as it used to, except for a few telltale signs: the maple tree is smaller, the swing set is in a different place, and the lawn has strange lines running through it, like a bad hair implant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 28 about grants by the Pew Charitable Trusts to environmental causes misstated the restrictions on political activity by non-profit groups. They are permitted to spend limited amounts of money on lobbying. They are not prohibited from doing so.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I refuse to carry an AARP card. Not as long as I ride a Harley.''

title: Addenda: Whitehall Parts Ways With Young & Rubicam
description: The Whitehall-Robins Healthcare division of the American Home Products Corporation ( news/quote ) said yesterday that it had unexpectedly ended its relationship with the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group ( news/quote ), by parting ways with the agency on the domestic accounts for its Advil pain reliever and Dimetapp cold and sinus brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, ANNA
description: SINGER-Anna. WIZO mourns the passing of Anna Singer who inspired her son Israel Singer to become a great leader of the Jewish people. Evelyn Sommer, President, WIZO USA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, LIONEL M.
description: ROGERS-Lionel M. of Darien, CT on June 22. Father of Susan F. Rogers and N. Pendleton Rogers. Memorial service will be held at noon on Saturday, July 21 at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to The Rector's Discretionary Fund, Christ Church, 254 E. Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830 or to The Endowment Fund, University of the South, Sewanee, TN 37375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, ABBING, MONSIGNOR JOHN PATRICK
description: CARROLL - ABBING - Monsignor John Patrick. The directors and staff of Boys' Towns of Italy, Inc. mourn the passing of our beloved founder, Monsignor John Patrick Carroll-Abbing. He was ordained a priest in Rome in 1935 and named a Monsignor shortly thereafter. He served in the Papal Household under Pope Pius XI and Pope Pius the XII until the outbreak of World War II. Pope Pius XII gave Monsignor permission to leave the Household and to assist the refugee population of Italy. He began by starting ''Shoeshine Hotels'' for the young street population of Italy and thereafter devoted his life to caring for children whose lives have been shattered by war, poverty, and natural disaster. His mission of unconditional love and acceptance have stood for decades as a shining beacon offering a ''second chance in life'' to lost and abandoned boys and girls of many nationalities. Monsignor Carroll-Abbing was the founder and leader of the residential facilities Boys' Towns of Rome and Girls' Towns of Rome, as well as Boys Towns of Italy, Inc., the oldest American charity working abroad, and was an internationally respected advocate for child welfare. We miss him dearly and will always strive to keep his spirit and mission alive. Brother A.E. D'Adamo, CFC, Executive Vice President Mauro C. Romita, Secretary/Treasurer

description: South Korean aviation authorities tried to demonstrate their desire to improve safety standards today, less than a week before a Federal Aviation Administration deadline for South Korea to show it had corrected practices that the F.A.A. said were in ''noncompliance'' with its regulations.

title: For Clinic, Stem Cell Test Is Rebirth Of Old Debate
description: When the United States' first test tube baby was born in 1981, the Jones Institute for Reproductive Medicine, where she was conceived, found itself at the center of an intense debate over whether scientists should tamper with the beginnings of human life.

title: Violence Subsides in Jamaica, but Wounds Still Fester
description: The violence in which 21 civilians have died in the West Kingston slums since the weekend has subsided. The corpses that had been festering in the streets have been removed.

title: Tips for the Era Of Constant Connection
description: A typical computer security notice issued by the CERT Coordination Center, a federally financed research and development center at Carnegie Mellon University, is titled ''Buffer Overflow in IIS Indexing Service DLL'' and is aimed at software engineers and corporate network administrators. But now the security clearinghouse has developed a list of tips written in lay terms and has posted them on the Web at www.cert.org

description: MOROZE-Lewis M. Of Bergenfield, NJ, on July 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Dora (nee Wolberg). Devoted father of Esther Moroze. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, EDWARD L.
description: BLAU-Edward L. The American Jewish Committee is profoundly saddened by the death of Edward Blau, a treasured friend and devoted member for nearly 50 years. Bud served AJC as a member of our National Board of Governors, Budget Committee, Domestic Policy Committee and as past president of our Metro New Jersey Chapter. His indefatigable humanity, generosity, wisdom and love for the Jewish community guided him in support of AJC's bold and innovative efforts to bring people of different faiths and ethnicities together in a bond of mutual respect and understanding. He was an inspired and gifted leader, and we were proud to honor him with our National Human Relations Award in 1995. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara, his sons Charles and Robert and his entire family. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Executive Dir. Shulamith Bahat, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Matthew Della Croce was named to the new post of senior vice president for financial communications in the corporate practice at Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide, New York, part of the WPP Group. He had been a vice president at the financial communications practice and headed the investor relations group at Fleishman-Hillard, New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: In Election Year, Vallone Is Criticized for Prominence in Tax-Financed Mailings
description: They have been dropped into mailboxes by the tens of thousands: letters from the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, extolling his work with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the last decade to improve the quality of life by cracking down on crime, squeegee men, and even sex shops and topless bars.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus fell to 252.1 billion yen ($2 million) in May, 65 percent below the figure for the corresponding month last year. Exports slowed, reflecting weaker demand abroad, while higher oil prices and the depreciating yen helped imports expand, leading the country to post a decline in trade surplus for the sixth consecutive month. The Finance Ministry, however, said that the diminishing surplus in trade reflected a global business cycle and currency movements. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about assertions by Senate Democrats that President Bush's tax cut jeopardizes military spending referred incorrectly in some copies to the surplus Medicare and Social Security funds that Democrats say the government would have to spend in 2002 to pay for the administration's proposed budget. It is $42 billion, not $62 billion.

title: Fossils May Be Earliest Human Link
description: An Ethiopian fossil hunter has found the bones and teeth of forest-dwelling creatures who lived as much as 5.8 million years ago, a discovery that appears to challenge some assumptions of early human evolution and extend knowledge of the family tree back close to its roots.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Family Friendly Programming Forum, a coalition of advertisers interested in stimulating production of prime-time TV programs to appeal to broader, multigenerational audiences, will hold its third annual Family Program Awards luncheon on Aug. 2. The awards will be televised on CBS on Aug. 10.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

description: To the Editor:

title: Dark-Age Obscurities Pulled Into the Light
description: Listen. This is how the story begins: ''Listen.'' And the audience -- at the Lincoln Center Festival show ''Edda,'' which opened on Tuesday night at John Jay College Theater -- can do no less, as the story unfolds.

title: Aetna to Close Some Unprofitable H.M.O.'s
description: Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, said yesterday that it would close or sell numerous unprofitable H.M.O.'s and expand its business with self-insured companies and medium-size employers in an attempt to improve profitability.

title: African Bloc Hoping to Do Better as the 'African Union'
description: Nearly four decades after Africa's newly independent nations created the Organization of African Unity in an effort to give a strong voice to the world's poorest lands, the continent's current leaders began burying that body today and creating a new one that they pledged would redeem the failures of its predecessor.

title: Cappellini Comes to Town, With a French Accent
description: Cappellini, the Italian furniture manufacturer, has become an international force by collaborating with designers like Marc Newson, Shiro Kuramata and Jasper Morrison. But until last month, when it opened a store in the Marais, top, Cappellini had no outpost in Paris. (The Three Sofa de Luxe by Mr. Morrison is $2,680.) ''Paris is strategic for both a local and international market, and there is powerful talent here in young French design,'' said Giulio Cappellini, inset, the head of the company. Cappellini has work by the French designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, Patrick Norguet and Christophe Pillet. Ora-to, the renegade graphic designer, did its latest ad campaign. ''The French are not a catalog culture,'' said Arnaud Aquizerate, the store's manager. ''Once they can actually see and touch, they are sold.'' Florence Fabiani-Baudoux, a Paris interior architect, says the big trend is to add contemporary furniture to traditional interiors. ''It's not just being talked about in design magazines,'' she said. ''It's what my clients are asking for.'' The Italian manufacturers Kartell and Maxalto recently opened showrooms in St.-Germain-des-Prs. Cappellini is at 4, rue des Rosiers 75004; (011) 33-1-42-78-39-39.

title: Don't Reward Dictators
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Vote Further Limits Bush Drilling Options in Monuments
description: In a new limit on the White House's energy options, the Senate today approved a measure barring the Bush administration from developing new sites to extract oil, gas or coal in lands designated as national monuments.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Comverse Cuts Earnings Forecast
description: Comverse Technology, a maker of software and systems for wireless communications and Internet services, said its second-quarter earnings would be 28 cents a share, falling short of analysts' consensus forecast of 45 cents a share. In a statement, Kobi Alexander, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the downturn was attributable in part to delays in the introduction of next-generation wireless networks and customers' postponement of discretionary purchases. He said deteriorating market conditions, particularly in the developing world, also contributed to the reduced expectations. Shares of Comverse Technology, which is based in Woodbury, N.Y., fell $13.07, or 33.5 percent, to $25.95 a share. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Yankees Keeping Their Eyes On October
description: The teenage batboys cleaning the Yankees' clubhouse last Saturday evening worked unencumbered, gathering laundry and straightening chairs without having to maneuver around players after the Mets won in extra innings. It was the Yankees' only loss this month and most of them dressed and departed quickly, rushing from Yankee Stadium as if it were newly condemned.

title: Conflating Cause and Effect, And Reducing All to Bare Lines
description: Salvatore Sciarrino's ''Luci Mie Traditrici'' is apprehended by the ear just as it retreats into silence. The peeps and hushed implosions of its orchestra and the short, brittle fragments assigned to the four singers onstage are specks set against a blank plane cleared of all other intrusion. The sounds -- and often the loudest of them is the rustle of a conductor turning pages -- are like a violation of the emptiness toward which Mr. Sciarrino's opera is seemingly drawn.

description: In percent

title: A Guide to Gadgets For Sun, Sand and Sea
description: From music to books to beachcombing, almost every seaside pursuit now has its own digital devices and accessories, like the watch that measures ultraviolet exposure. A roundup is on Page 7.

title: The Beijing Olympic Bid
description: As the International Olympic Committee gathers in Moscow this week to select a host nation for the 2008 Summer Games, there is no mystery about the human rights record of China, the heavily favored contender. It is abysmal. As a matter of principle, China's human rights abuses and suppression of dissent should disqualify it from holding the Olympics.

title: Books for the Blind Go Digital
description: SINCE 1951, Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic, a nonprofit organization based in Princeton, has recorded thousands of textbooks, from kindergarten- to graduate-level, on cassette tapes that it makes available to schools and to blind and dyslexic students.

description: BERLINER-Dolores. Aged 90, departed this life on July 11, 2001. Devoted wife of the late Henry (Howard) Berliner, loving mother of Martin (Gail), Joan (David), Robert and Bruce (Deborah). Devoted grandmother of David, Seth, Mark, Brett, Amanda, Jason, Joel and Russell. Graveside services at Mount Hebron Cemetery, July 12, 2001 at 11:00 A.M.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Buys Maker Of Network Chips
description: Cisco Systems said it would acquire AuroraNetics Inc., a privately held networking company, for $150 million in stock. With the purchase, Cisco hopes to improve its routing technology for metropolitan areas, where data traffic through communications networks is heaviest. Cisco said it expects to complete the acquisition during the coming quarter and to take a charge of no more than a penny a share. AuroraNetics, founded last year in San Jose, Calif., makes chips for 10-gigabit-per-second communications networks. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Me-Zine Journalism for Fun and (Sometimes) Profit
description: Mickey Kaus, a former reporter for Newsweek, works out of his home off the beach in Santa Monica, Calif., looking at a blue sliver of ocean, drawing in the balmy beach air, his usual work attire a mismatched, rumpled sweatsuit.

title: Gephardt Sways Foes On Money For Contests
description: When Democrats controlled the House of Representatives in the early 1990's, Representative Richard A. Gephardt often found himself described as something other than a champion of campaign finance reform.

title: In Asia, Alcohol Laws Are Unevenly Enforced
description: BANGKOK  Age limits on alcohol consumption exist in countries across Asia, but enforcement is lax and drinking is curbed more by social custom and religion than by law.

title: A Furniture Boutique As Extreme Yoga
description: Csar Pape, 32, is the much talked about new kid on the block in Paris. His reputation as a hip guy about town is unusual for a gallery owner selling home decorating items. Opening night at his St.-Germain-des-Prs boutique ended with a late party at the nightclub Castel. Among his shop's offerings are a green 1950 lacquer table by Jacques Quinet ($15,500), a set of four Christophe Pillet chairs from the 1980's ($3,200 for the four) and contemporary photography from $250 to $20,000. Mr. Pape, below, raised in a family of collectors, sees dealing furniture as a natural progression from his years of studying yoga. ''The physical rapport between an object and an emotion fascinates me,'' he said. Ah, to be dashing and supple. Csar Pape, 6-8, rue de Seine 75006; (011) 33-1-43-26-16-20.

description: Here are eight key numbers for the Mets heading into the second half of the season, most of them depressing.

description: STAGGER the line. Elyssa, step forward. That looks good.'' Ben Thompson never raises his voice as he guides the four dancers into their opening positions. Without videoconferencing equipment, however, he would need to bellow, since he is in Los Angeles and the dancers are in New York.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: JUST TOYS, AND DEBTS Just Toys , a New York-based company that sells toys under the Spalding and Louisville Slugger names, has filed for bankruptcy protection after losing money in each of the past four years. Just Toys filed for Chapter 11 protection in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, listing $57,000 in assets and $2.7 million in debts. The company revealed in March that it was unable to pay its creditors and vendors. It said it had fired most employees not needed to fill orders and was discussing selling its assets. Calls seeking comment from company officials were not immediately returned. Founded in 1988 by Allan Rigberg and Rose Evangelista, Just Toys went public in 1992, raising about $13.6 million. By 1993, its shares, initially offered at $10.50, had risen to $42.78. In 1995, Just Toys settled a lawsuit filed by Mr. Rigberg and Ms. Evangelista after they were fired. They said the company had violated their employment contracts and made them scapegoats for its financial troubles. Company sales peaked in 1997 at $23.2 million and have fallen steadily since. Shares of Just Toys were unchanged at 1 cent. The shares fell 87 percent in 2000 and have fallen more than 98 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEANEY, BERTHA I.
description: BEANEY-Bertha I. A lifelong resident of New York City, died in her sleep on Tuesday, July 10, 2001, of natural causes. She was 90. Born on November 17, 1910, in Washington, D.C., she was the daughter of William Beaney and Mary O'Dea Beaney. Miss Beaney served in Europe during World War II in the Women's Army Corps as a Staff Sergeant and was honorably discharged on April 25, 1946. After the war she worked for McKinnon & Company and Ray Temporary Staffing in various capacities. She was a lifelong New York Yankees fan and golf enthusiast. She was affectionately known to her family as ''Aunt Buddy'' and to her friends as ''Betty.'' Miss Beaney was the third of four sisters, Mrs. Jane Beaney Patterson, Mrs. Gertrude Coleman Butler, and Mrs. Agnes Beaney Woods. Calling hours will be from 7 PM to 9 PM on Thursday, July 12, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on July 13 at 10 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. and 84 St. Burial services will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADISH, MAX
description: KADISH-Max. On July 11, 2001. Loving husband of Mildred, devoted and loving father of Barbara Kadish, Ronnie Accordino and Abbe Kadish. Cherished father-inlaw of Anthony Accordino and Judy Kadish. Adored grandfather of Robert, Michael, Chelsea and Molly. Services Friday July 13, 2001, 2 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RISES. The yen rose as debt and currency markets in Latin America were in turmoil, traders said. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.36 yen, down from 125.37 on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Arab League Gets New Voice
description: Hanan Ashrawi, a prominent spokeswoman for the Palestinians, has been appointed to the new post of media commissioner for the Arab League. In announcing the appointment, Amr Moussa, the league's secretary general, said Ms. Ashrawi would continue to focus on Palestinian issues. Ms. Ashrawi, 54, said she would still live in the Palestinian territories. Mr. Moussa took over the league two months ago, promising to revitalize a pan-Arab organization widely viewed as ineffective. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

description: On Aug. 6, 1930, Joseph Force Cra ter a ''playboy judge'' who socialized with racketeers -- cashed two checks for large sums, bought a ticket to a Broadway show, hailed a taxi, and vanished forever.

description: JEREMY JACOB is a true connoisseur of summer camps. Over the years, this boy, a slight, sandy-haired 11-year-old, has been to sailing camp, soccer camp, tennis camp, art camp and ''fun'' camp.

The sad stories emanating from Washington -- the degrading conduct of Monica Lewinsky and the former president, and now the case of Chandra Levy and Congressman Gary A. Condit -- suggest we have a way to go in reaching male-female equality in government and politics.

description: Two major biopharmaceutical companies faced off in court today, as Biogen of Cambridge, Mass., sought to convince a panel of judges here that Serono's claims of a superior multiple sclerosis drug were misleading and should not be publicized.
