title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMLIN, GEORGE
description: CHAMLIN-George. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, George Chamlin. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. Paul M. Weltz, President Samuel Laufer, Secretary

title: Translating Union Into Khmer; The A.F.L.-C.I.O. Organizes in Cambodia
description: The black clouds of an early monsoon were piling up outside as Jason Judd of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. paced before a classroom of local union leaders and labor organizers, lecturing on what it takes to force garment factory managers to the negotiating table.

title: Muse Creative To Offer Shares
description: Muse Creative Holdings in New York, an agency company specializing in multicultural marketing, said yesterday that it had filed for an initial public offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLADDEN, ELSPETH
description: SLADDEN-Elspeth at home in Sag Harbor, New York, July 3rd, after a long battle with Multiple Myeloma. Adored wife of Michael, much loved mother of Mark & Chloe, cherished sister of Glynn, and devoted educator. Funeral July 14th at Christ Episcopal Church, Sag Harbor, New York. No flowers please, but donations, if desired, to The Elspeth Sladden Teacher Education Fund, C/O Center for Applied Special Technology, 39 Cross Street, Peabody, MA. 01960 (978/531.8555)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Adding Flights . . .
description: JetBlue Airways will add six daily flights to Florida from Kennedy International Airport this winter, the company said this week. JetBlue, a low-fare carrier, said that the new service, to Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach and Fort Myers, would raise its winter flight schedule to 22 daily flights from Kennedy to five Florida airports. Some flights will be added on Nov. 1, others on Dec. 1 and Dec. 20. JetBlue also has daily flights to Orlando and Tampa.

title: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Taking Pictures
description: The beach is one place you can't take an underexposed shot; digital image sensors adore bright sunlight, and the bright, vivid colors of summer make sensational subjects. It's just too bad that surf, sand and spray can mean instant death to your expensive gear.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Teachers Unions Join Hands
description: The nation's two major teachers unions are forming a joint council for lobbying and legal action and to coordinate activities. The National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers represent a total of 2.5 million teachers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor Named For Commerce Post
description: Michael J. Garcia, a veteran prosecutor in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan, has been nominated by President Bush to be assistant secretary of commerce for export enforcement. Mr. Garcia, 39, participated in major prosecutions of terrorism cases, most recently the successful prosecution of four men charged with conspiring with the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Chechnya Abuses Admitted

title: Natural gas prices are falling, but there may be some good buys for patient investors.
description: ONE glance at the steep downward trajectory of the natural gas market, and the impulse is to ditch shares of oil and gas exploration companies, fast.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Redback Networks Loss Widens
description: Redback Networks, a maker of equipment for phone and fiber optic networks, reported a steeper second-quarter loss as telecommunications customers continued to delay projects and cancel orders. Redback said it lost 26 cents a share, excluding special items, for the three-month period ended June 30, a sharp increase from the 5-cent loss during the comparable period last year. Including charges related to acquisitions, restructuring and other special items, Redback lost $460 million, or $3.26 a share. Revenue increased 22 percent to $59.4 million from $48.7 million. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., said it anticipated no recovery in telecommunications spending this year. Its shares fell 49 cents, or 7 percent, to $6.53. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Judge Orders Napster to Remain Off Line
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- A federal judge today ordered that the Napster music-sharing service must remain off line until it can prove that it can more effectively filter copyrighted material, signifying the first time a judge has mandated the shut down of the Internet service.

title: Man Accused of Hitting Woman And Shoving Stroller Into Street
description: Elizabeth Garcia was pushing her 18-month-old daughter in a stroller toward a park near the United Nations building yesterday when a violent attack left her unconscious on the sidewalk and the stroller in the middle of the street, the police said.

title: Where the City Is Horizons Away
description: ONE cold Monday this spring, the day I realized I wasn't the person I thought I was, a dozen white jack rabbits crisscrossed my drive as I left my ranch for town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, JANE GERMAN
description: IRWIN-Jane German, 74. The directors and staff of the Henry Luce Foundation deeply mourn the loss of their colleague and friend who served on the foundation's board with distinction from 1990 to 2001 and was chairman of its compensation and new programs and major grants committees. We will remember her exceptional warmth, grace and wisdom, and extend deepest sympathy to her family. Henry Luce III, Chairman John W. Cook, President

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Meriden: City May Pay $17 Million Tax Refund
description: The city of Meriden may pay two utility companies nearly $17 million. A court ruled in April that the city had overtaxed the companies, and the City Council's Finance Committee yesterday recommended payment. The city is appealing the ruling and negotiating with the utilities, Yankee Gas Services and Connecticut Light and Power Company, to reach a settlement.

title: Gerald L. Geison, 58, Historian Who Found a Flawed Pasteur
description: Dr. Gerald L. Geison, a biographer of Louis Pasteur and an expert on the history of medicine, died July 3 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 58.

title: City and Police Union Reach Settlement Deal With Abner Louima
description: Four years after being tortured with a broken broomstick while under police custody in a Brooklyn station house, Abner Louima agreed yesterday to settle his civil lawsuit against New York City and its main police union.

title: Report Cites 23 Countries in Human Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The State Department today criticized several of this country's closest allies, including Saudi Arabia, Israel, Greece and South Korea, for making insufficient efforts to stop the trafficking of slaves within their borders.

title: JUDGE SHARPLY CUTS JURY AWARD IN DIET-DRUG SUIT
description: A state district court judge in Texas has cut $47.3 million, or 84 percent, from the $56.5 million awarded to a woman who claimed her heart had been damaged by the fen-phen diet-drug combination, the woman's lawyer said yesterday. The judge, Terry Canales, of Jim Wells County District Court in Alice, Tex., ruled that the state's limits on punitive damage awards required him to reduce the judgment against American Home Products Corporation, said Kathryn Snapka, the lawyer for the woman who won in the suit, Gloria Lopez. The ruling came as American Home, based in Madison, N.J., was pushing to settle the remaining lawsuits accusing it of hiding the health rises of the diet drug. An estimated 10,000 claims are outstanding.

title: Risky Caesarean Section
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTEL, LEAH
description: AMSTEL-Leah. Passed away peacefully on July 11, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Felix Amstel. Loving mother of Jeri Meltzer and her husband Steven. Adoring grandmother of Stephen, Scott and Wendy Schechter, and best friend of Laurel Kettle. Private funeral services will be held on Friday.

title: Add Betrayal and Death to the Political Saga in Camden
description: In the rough-and-tumble world of Camden politics, Anthony Scarduzio held dear to the notion of personal loyalty. A tireless foot soldier for the Camden County Democrats and chief of the city's Parking Authority, Mr. Scarduzio, 47, enjoyed a devoted network of friends who helped him during his 25-year climb from his first job as a meter maintenance man.

title: Blues With a Scratch
description: Chris Whitley ran his pick along the low strings of his National guitar during his Tuesday set at the Bowery Ballroom, making a buzz that sounded like a record being scratched. It wasn't a showy move, but an act of integration. With DJ Logic pulling similar rhythms from his turntables, and Etienne Lytel providing ambient, Kraftwerk-style keyboard lines, Mr. Whitley lured the blues into a new matrix.

title: Airline Pact Reached
description: American Airlines and union leaders for its flight attendants reached a tentative agreement today.

title: Economic Scene; Can good looks really guarantee a product's success?
description: LAST week brought bad news for people who like their products with at least as much style as substance. Apple Computer said it was canceling its beautiful Power Mac G4 Cube, barely a year after it introduced the machine it called ''the coolest computer ever.''

title: New York Area Transit
description: Traveling in and around New York City can be costly, frustrating and stressful, but a savvy traveler can circumvent local transit nightmares with proper planning and a little know-how. Check out these official websites for information on transportation means, costs, routes, and times, and make your trips in, out and around the city a little easier.

title: Summer at the Chateau With the Designers
description: On the grounds of a romantic chateau near Poitiers, France, the Vitra Design Museum and the Pompidou Center offer workshops for lovers of art, architecture and design. From now through Sept. 9, instruction is available from experts who will share their crafts and most certainly a glass of good wine or two. Instructors include the Swedish architects Marten Claesson, Eero Koivisto and Ola Rune; the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban (on paper architecture); and the designers Matali Crasset, Andr Dubreuil, and Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. The cost for courses, dormitory lodging (below), meals and materials is about $636 a week (students, $500). Information from the museum at (011) 49-7621-702-3574 or at www.design-museum.com/workshops.

title: Motorola Has Operating Loss of $232 Million in Quarter
description: Confirming expectations that business was dismal in its recently completed second quarter, Motorola reported late yesterday that it had lost $232 million, or 11 cents a share, from operations, compared with a profit of $551 million during the comparable three months in 2000.

title: Analysts' Fuzzy Math
description: Talk about bad-hair days: Palm Computing had one that lasted the entire month of March. As though the tech-industry slowdown weren't enough, the company shot itself in the foot, the knee and the belly button by announcing its 2001 palmtop models months before they were available. Sales of the existing models tanked, forcing Palm to slash prices and announce two waves of layoffs. I'll be the first to admit that the company's got some issues; too many talented employees have left for sunnier corporate pastures.

title: House Shelves Campaign Finance Bill After a Fierce Rules Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The effort to overhaul the campaign finance law collapsed in the House today in a bitter procedural battle, with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert saying he has no plan to resurrect the legislation any time soon.

title: Elegance and Grace, On Order From Paris
description: Muriel Grateau, far left, is known in decorating circles as the doyenne of simple, elegant and beautifully made cutlery, linens, glasses, plates and vessels in blown glass, porcelain, ceramic and crystal. She is an advocate of plain tableware. ''If you have a rich interior, you don't want your table to be in competition with paintings, furniture or rugs,'' she said. Simple tableware, she added, looks better the more of it you put on a table. Until recently, Americans had to visit one of her two Paris shops to buy her subtle shades of table linens and her porcelain, left, top and bottom. Now, a mail-order catalog is available on request for about $32, with the cost deducted from the first order. Muriel Grateau, Jardins du Palais-Royal, 130, galerie du Valois, 75001; telephone, (011) 33-1-49-21-20-90, or fax, (011) 33-1-49-21-20-91.

title: Case of the Missing Intern Echoes Loudly Back Home
description: In this once-sleepy city in California's lush farm belt, the case of the missing young woman and the local congressman is taking a profound toll.

title: Napster Is Told to Remain Shut
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 _ A federal judge today ordered that the Napster music-sharing service must remain off line until it can prove that it can more effectively filter copyrighted material, signifying the first time a judge has mandated the shut down of the Internet service.

title: Whitehall Parts Ways With Young & Rubicam
description: The Whitehall-Robins Healthcare division of the American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it had unexpectedly ended its relationship with the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, by parting ways with the agency on the domestic accounts for its Advil pain reliever and Dimetapp cold and sinus brands.

title: Compressed Data: A College Paper's Role in the Microsoft Appeal
description: The Financial Times. The New Yorker. The New York Times . The Washington Post . The Wall Street Journal.

title: Corporate Plagiarism
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Towns Renowned For Small Pleasures
description: A world away from Wall Street in New York or Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, Calif., are the Dandelion Capital of the World (also known as Vineland, N.J.) and the Fire Hydrant Capital of the World (Albertville, Ala., of course). America's small towns and cities are celebrated, in all their history and fame, at ePodunk (www.epodunk.com).

title: Lou Kusserow, 73, Is Dead; Led Football Upset of Army
description: Lou Kusserow, an outstanding back who ran for two touchdowns in Columbia's monumental football upset of Army in 1947 and later became a producer for NBC Sports, died June 30 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, ANITA BELFER
description: SALTZ-Anita Belfer. The Hillel family mourns the passing of our dear friend, Anita Belfer Saltz. Anita was a pioneer in opening the Jewish community to young adults through Hillel's Belfer Initiative, a program that continues to touch the lives of young Jews across North America. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Saltz and Belfer families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman International Board of Governors Lynn Schusterman, Co-Chair Michael Steinhardt, Co-Chair Charles Newman, Chairman, Board of Directors Richard M. Joel, President and International Director

title: Jamaica Clash Ends, But Anger Remains
description: The violence in which 25 people have died in Kingston since last weekend, when the police entered a neighborhood to stop a simmering war between politically connected gangs, has subsided. But the bullet holes, sandbags and the squads of soldiers carrying assault rifles remain as reminders that Jamaica has been shaken by its deadliest clashes in decades.

title: Bush Offers Lawmakers a Wish List on Medicare Revamp
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Five big companies promised today to work with President Bush to help Medicare beneficiaries secure discounts on prescription drugs through a voluntary private program starting Jan. 1. But Democrats in Congress ridiculed the president's proposal as a trivial step to solve a huge problem.

title: French Circus Performers Injured on Opening Night
description: Cirque Plume, the French new-circus troupe, canceled last night's performance at Lincoln Center Festival 2001 after two members of its company were injured toward the end of the opening-night performance on Tuesday.

title: Microsoft Leads Stock Rally; Nasdaq Surges 5.3 Percent
description: Stock prices surged in a powerful rally today, sending the Nasdaq composite index up more than 5 percent, after Microsoft ( news/quote ) said its second-quarter revenue would exceed Wall Street's forecasts, giving investors some hope that the worst might be over for corporate profits.

title: Those Were the Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Declining Surplus Renews Debate Over the Budget Outlook
description: The Bush administration said today that the weakening of the economy might push the federal budget surplus this year down to a level that, Democrats said, would portend a return to fiscal difficulties in the years ahead.

title: Art Appreciation in a New Light
description: ART uses light to convey its message, but far too many beautiful rooms are filled with badly lighted art.

title: So, Who's the Pro?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK BROOKLYN: PLEA IN DRUG CASE A 31-year-old Israeli man pleaded guilty yesterday to running an international smuggling ring for the drug Ecstasy by using Hasidic couriers. The Israeli, Sean Erez, admitted in Federal District Court to using Hasidim from Williamsburg and Monsey. For $1,500 per trip, the couriers smuggled more than one million Ecstasy tablets from Europe to the United States in 1998 and 1999. Mr. Erez used Hasidim in religious garb because they drew less scrutiny in customs, prosecutors said.   Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Audio and Video
description: When most people think of music on the beach, they are reminded of the dreaded boombox, scourge of peaceful vacations everywhere. Boomboxes are the audio equivalent of Mutually Assured Destruction: each side is armed to the teeth, and nobody wins.

title: Lawmaker's Apartment Searched in Intern Case
description: The police spent three hours early today searching the four-room apartment of Representative Gary A. Condit, seeking information that might help solve the mystery of what happened to Chandra Ann Levy, the federal intern who disappeared more than two months ago.

title: Russian General Admits 'Crimes' in Chechnya
description: The commander of Russian military forces in Chechnya said today that his troops had committed ''widespread crimes'' in two days of terror they inflicted on civilians in Chechnya. Fifteen hundred residents of two villages were arrested, subjected to beatings and electric shocks and saw their homes looted after mine blasts killed Russian soldiers nearby.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Shipyard Told To Shape Up
description: An administrative law judge with the National Labor Relations Board has ordered the Northrop Grumman Avondale shipyard near New Orleans to reinstate 22 workers whom the judge found were dismissed illegally from 1994 to 1997 for trying to unionize the shipyard's 4,000 workers. The judge, Philip McLeod, also ordered Avondale to repay $5.4 million in legal fees, saying the company was wrong to ask the Navy to pay for defending the yard. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: First Place at Stake For Power and Beat
description: The next 10 days could determine the top two spots in the Women's United Soccer Association playoffs. The Atlanta Beat and the New York Power, first and second in the eight-team league, will meet twice in the next month, starting with a game here Thursday night.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: More Job Cuts At I.B.M.
description: I.B.M. is laying off about 500 employees from its PC and sales and distribution businesses in addition to the almost 1,500 workers it said it would let go last week. An I.B.M. spokesman said the job cuts were the result of a routine skills evaluation. ''It's a skills rebalancing we do on a consistent basis, year after year,'' the spokesman, John Bukovinsky, said. ''The most significant fact is that we expect our employee population to be higher this year.'' I.B.M. said last week that it was cutting nearly 1 percent of the 150,000 workers in its Global Services consulting arm. It had added 10,000 workers in that unit this year. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Two Can Play This Game
description: The hard-line judiciary has set up a court to handle lawsuits against foreign countries, notably the United States, a Justice Department spokesman said. The decision is a response to a U.S. law that lets Americans claim compensation from Iran as victims of terrorist attacks backed by Iran. However, the spokesman said the court would not rule against the United States merely as a retaliatory measure. An American court ruled last month that Iran owed $323 million to a citizen taken hostage in Lebanon by groups that Iran supported. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Democrats Do an About-Face on School Board
description: With Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani preparing to leave office, Democrats are suddenly lining up behind an idea they reviled for most of his term: mayoral control of the Board of Education.

title: Cell Phone Companies Are Raided
description: European regulators raided the offices of Vodafone and eight other mobile phone operators today and combed through documents they believed would offer evidence that the companies had set artificially high prices for some services.

title: Bloomberg Makes a Pledge To Travel via Mass Transit
description: Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he will do his part to alleviate congestion if elected mayor by using mass transit every day. Mr. Bloomberg, a wealthy Republican businessman who is accustomed to traveling by limousine, said that would include commuting to City Hall by taxi as well as by bus or subway.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Internet Defamation Suit
description: A state appeals panel ruled yesterday that a company filing a defamation suit against an anonymous critic on the Internet must establish that the criticism harmed the company before the critic's identity can be revealed. The case involves four people who questioned accounting practices at Dendrite International, a software company in Morristown. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Let's Keep Talking to Arafat, Peres Says
description: Despite mounting Israeli hostility toward Yasir Arafat, Israel should continue dealing directly with the Palestinian leader in an effort to bring violence under control and get both sides back to the negotiating table, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said in an interview today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: So, Who's the Pro? To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The ''Hot and Cold'' table in Business Day yesterday, listing stocks with large percentage gains and losses on Tuesday, misstated the change for the Cintas Corporation. Its shares rose $3.16, or 7.2 percent. They did not fall by that amount.

title: Napster Is Told To Remain Shut
description: A federal judge today ordered that the Napster music-sharing service remain shut down until it can prove that it can more effectively filter copyrighted material.

title: After Three Unavailing Days, Ulster Negotiators Take a Breather
description: Efforts to rescue the faltering Northern Ireland peace accord were put on hold tonight after three days of intensive talks led by Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, failed to make progress on the central issue of Irish Republican Army weapons.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tajik Journalist Freed
description: An effort by Tajikistan's government to seize a dissident journalist, Dododjon Atovulloyev, in Moscow was blocked by the prosecutor general. Mr. Atovulloyev, detained at a Moscow airport last week, is wanted on charges of insulting or criticizing the Tajik president, Emomali Rahmonov, under whose rule dozens of journalists have been killed or exiled. A spokesman for the prosecutor general said he had found no grounds for extraditing the dissident.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Goshen: Inquiry Into Nursing Home Death
description: A 94-year-old woman suffered serious burns and died days later after being scalded by 140-degree water as an attendant bathed her at her nursing home, a spokesman for the Orange County district attorney said yesterday. The spokesman did not identify the woman, who died July 4, but The Middletown Times Herald-Record reported that she was Frances Thein, a resident at the Orange County Residential Health Facility. The death is being investigated by the attorney general's office and the state police. ''We don't know whether this was a mechanical difficulty or a problem with the staff,'' said the Orange county executive, Joseph Rampe. Nursing home officials did not return calls seeking comment.

title: Disturbed Children, Lacking Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Gives the House G.O.P. a Boost, and Hopes for One, Too
description: President Bush went to Capitol Hill today to reinvigorate his relationship with House Republicans, including anxious moderates, and to spark action on his agenda.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Just Toys, and Debts
description: Just Toys, a New York-based company that sells toys under the Spalding and Louisville Slugger names, has filed for bankruptcy protection after losing money in each of the past four years. Just Toys filed for Chapter 11 protection in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, listing $57,000 in assets and $2.7 million in debts. The company revealed in March that it was unable to pay its creditors and vendors. It said it had fired most employees not needed to fill orders and was discussing selling its assets. Calls seeking comment from company officials were not immediately returned. Founded in 1988 by Allan Rigberg and Rose Evangelista, Just Toys went public in 1992, raising about $13.6 million. By 1993, its shares, initially offered at $10.50, had risen to $42.78. In 1995, Just Toys settled a lawsuit filed by Mr. Rigberg and Ms. Evangelista after they were fired. They said the company had violated their employment contracts and made them scapegoats for its financial troubles. Company sales peaked in 1997 at $23.2 million and have fallen steadily since. Shares of Just Toys were unchanged at 1 cent. The shares fell 87 percent in 2000 and have fallen more than 98 percent this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about the economy of Singapore slipping into recession misstated the gross domestic product for the second quarter compared with the first quarter. It declined 10.1 percent, at an annualized rate, not 0.8 percent.

title: Another Lender to Stop Sales Of Single-Premium Coverage
description: Household International said yesterday that it, too, would yield to pressure from consumer groups and stop selling a type of mortgage insurance that has been criticized as predatory.

title: Transportation Hurdles Cited in Children's Health Care
description: One out of five poor children miss routine doctors' appointments because their parents cannot get them there, according to a national survey scheduled to be released today by the Children's Health Fund, a nonprofit agency based in New York that provides health care for children in low-income families.

title: A Diva of the Spoken Word Who Irritates the F.C.C.
description: SARAH JONES has a mouth on her. She's a spoken word diva, after all. She's the performance artist whose protest lyrics got a radio station smacked with a federal indecency fine for playing her hip-hop song ''Your Revolution.'' She has just arrived home after a flight from Los Angeles. A big suitcase is plopped down, unopened, on the floor.

title: A Patriarch of the Blues Burnishes His Own Legend
description: A combination of exuberance and awe spread through the crowd at a nightclub here on July 6 when Pinetop Perkins, one of the last survivors of the generation that invented electric blues, sat down behind the piano and began to play.

title: Corrections
description: Sunday Styles on June 10 erroneously reported the marriage of Virginia Marie DeFina and Stephen Robert Scott. In fact, as Mr. Scott informed The Times yesterday, the wedding never took place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERBERG, ELEANOR
description: SILBERBERG-Eleanor. 92 years old. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Dear mother to Ann and Judy. Grandmother to Peter and Bonnie, Bob and Kim, Robyn and Gael. Beloved (Elly) to great-grandchildren Alex, Jessica, Jake and Tess. May she rest in peace.

title: Argentine Debt Creates Fallout That Is Wide
description: The fallout from the financial crisis in Argentina was felt outside Latin America yesterday as the dollar fell and the stocks of some American and Spanish banks with exposure there dropped.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Bush administration's view of China's bid for the 2008 Olympics misstated the stance of Amnesty International. It is not opposed to the Olympics being held there; it takes no position on the question.

title: Left Uninspired by Mayor's Race, Democrats Put Off Endorsements
description: In what is emerging as a clear and not particularly kind verdict on the field of New York mayoral candidates, powerful players in Democratic politics -- including unions and elected officials -- have decided to hold back their endorsements in this year's primary contest. They said none of the candidates had yet presented compelling reasons to take sides, and that voters seemed persistently uninterested in a contest just eight weeks away from a vote.

title: Senate Backs Offshore Florida Oil Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Senate signaled its clear support today for a compromise White House plan for new oil and gas drilling in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, turning aside a Democrat-backed measure that would have blocked exploration in the area.

title: Back When Oddballs Roamed the Earth
description: Eccentricity has become more difficult to define since 1962, when Murray Burns, the childish renegade at the center of ''A Thousand Clowns,'' first made his appearance on Broadway in the person of Jason Robards. Herb Gardner's precious, middle-of-the-road comedy about Murray, an unemployed television writer who is forced, with a lot of literal and psychological kicking and screaming, to return to work so he can retain custody of his young nephew, was, in large part, a paean to idiosyncrasy and the value of not going along to get along.

title: SAFECO REVISES ITS FORECAST, CITING STORM CLAIMS
description: The Safeco Corporation said yesterday that it expected a second-quarter operating loss of 25 cents to 30 cents a share, worse that analysts had forecast, citing rising claims from storm-related losses. The insurer, based in Seattle, was expected to report a loss of 18 cents a share, revised from 19 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. The company had earnings of $12 million, or 77 cents a share, in last year's second quarter. Safeco said its financial results were hurt by an April hailstorm in St. Louis, a tropical storm in the Houston area and a series of Midwest storms. Safeco was the third insurer in two days to warn that storms would hurt results.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit At Daewoo
description: The South Korean automaker Daewoo Motor reported an operating profit of $17 million in the second quarter after losing $35 million in the first quarter. The company reported a pretax profit of $1.3 million in June, giving it three consecutive months in the black. But profit in June was $9 million less than the profit in May. Daewoo's creditors believed the figures would raise the stakes in talks on selling the company to General Motors, which has reportedly offered less than the creditors who took over the company nearly two years ago are determined to receive. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Travel Boycott Urged
description: Delegates at the N.A.A.C.P. convention in New Orleans adopted a resolution asking members to discontinue travel to Mississippi in an unofficial boycott over the state's refusal to rid its flag of the Confederate emblem. In a referendum last April, voters overwhelmingly supported keeping the emblem. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Less For Charities
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a scaled-down version of President Bush's program to funnel federal money to religions for their charitable works. The proposal for the administration's ''faith-based initiative'' will provide $13 billion in tax breaks over 10 years, down from the $98 billion requested by Mr. Bush. The bill also would allow taxpayers who did not itemize to deduct charitable contributions of no more than $100. A House vote is expected next week. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Work (if You Must)
description: Although vacation usually means leaving the office behind for a week or two, you can take it with you. But be warned: dragging a laptop computer to the beach is not a good idea, as the sun and sand can do horrible things to your machine.

title: Pulling Punches? Jones Says Perhaps
description: Roy Jones Jr. has one of the most devastating punches in boxing, but to listen to Jones talk -- and he loves to do that -- he has been holding back, taking pity on his opponents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Weather Watching
description: Gone are the days when checking the temperature at the shore meant twisting your neck to see the rusty Hires Root Beer thermometer on the boardwalk.

title: Booting Up for Summer
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RABBI BENJAMIN
description: KAHN-Rabbi Benjamin. B'Nai B'rith International mourns the passing of Rabbi Benjamin Kahn. Leader, Teacher, Role Model. Richard Heideman, International President Daniel Mariaschin, Exec. Vice President

title: American History, Sliced to Order
description: For centuries, history painting was an exalted genre. Almost nobody makes a career of it now. Its time-honored ingredients -- didacticism, idealism, rhetorical flair -- are out of fashion, as is history itself, the idea that certain things happened in a certain way. Postmodernism put the kibosh on all that.

title: Scurry and Hooper Lead Atlanta Past the Power
description: Coach Pat Farmer's fear that his Power would have its hands full with Atlanta's Charmaine Hooper and Cindy Parlow tonight was nothing to sneeze at. Sure enough, Hooper scored two second-half goals with help from Parlow and that propelled the Atlanta Beat to a 3-0 triumph at Mitchel Field in a battle for first place in the Women's United Soccer Association.

title: ESPN Plays Games With Its Digital Ads
description: Since its inception in 1995, ESPN Classic (n Classic Sports Network) has served as the guardian of oldies. Archival games from nearly every sport, largely ignored in storage, have received new life on the network, which has added fresh programming like the marvelous ''SportsCentury'' biography series.

title: More Arrests in Fatal Attack Outside Atlantic City Club
description: He was bright and ambitious, a young investment banker with a new job in London who had come back to America for the wedding of a close friend. But early Sunday morning, after a weekend of raunch and revelry in Atlantic City, Peter Westra was kicked to death as he lay on the pavement outside a go-go club, moments after he had been ejected from a college friend's bachelor party.

title: She's Got Bette Davis Eyes. Or Does She?
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Democrats Raise Enough To Reach Spending Cap
description: The four main Democrats running for mayor have each already raised more than they can legally spend for the Sept. 11 primary, with Public Advocate Mark Green bringing in the most money during the last six months, campaign officials said yesterday.

title: Glass That Glowed In the Dark Ages
description: In Europe, the Dark Ages were a period of decline that did not end until A.D. 1000. But from 600 to 1000 it was anything but dark in the Middle East. ''It was a flourishing time,'' said David Whitehouse, the executive director of the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y.

title: On Top in Bulgaria: New Premier Is the Old King
description: Bulgaria got its deposed king back, albeit as prime minister, when Simeon II of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha announced today that he would accept the position.

title: Basquiat And Friends, In Creative Serendipity
description: Shot as ''New York Beat'' in 1980-81 but completed for release only last year, ''Downtown 81'' emerges as a nostalgic portrait of pre-Giuliani Manhattan, an unruly place full of garbage, graffiti, rubble-strewn lots, unlicensed after-hours clubs and highly idealistic kids eager to make their mark as avant-garde artists and musicians.

title: Sports of The Times; Others Need to Do Dirty Work
description: THERE was encouraging news for Red Sox fans yesterday: the return of shortstop Nomar Garciaparra, pitcher Pedro Martnez and outfielder Carl Everett is on the horizon.

title: 'Monitor: Volume 1' Susan Hiller -- 'Psi Girls'
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: Deadpan Decadence, With a Sneer of Disgust
description: ''Bully'' is based on the true story of a murder in South Florida, and it purports to be a raw and honest examination of the violent, hedonistic, amoral lives of America's youth, or at least a particularly decadent and photogenic cross-section of it. The film's director, Larry Clark, has visited this territory before, in the disquieting ''Kids,'' which looks like mid-period Woody Allen compared to ''Bully.''

title: MALONE PLANS TO SELL 5 MILLION AT&T SHARES
description: John C. Malone, who resigned this week from AT&T's board earlier than planned, has filed to sell five million shares in the company. Mr. Malone, chairman of the Liberty Media Corporation, disclosed his intent to sell the shares, valued at $107 million at today's prices, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Malone, 60, resigned on Tuesday after he was excluded from talks related to Comcast's unsolicited $44.5 billion bid for AT&T's cable-television unit. Mr. Malone acquired the AT&T stock earmarked for sale when the company bought Tele-Communications, Liberty Media's parent, in 1999. Mr. Malone held 26.4 million AT&T common shares as of Jan. 1, according to the company's latest proxy statement. That represents less than 1 percent of AT&T's 3.4 billion outstanding shares.

title: Manufacturer of Artificial Heart Forbids Doctors to Talk About Patient's Condition
description: In the 10 days since the first self-contained artificial heart was implanted here, the device's manufacturer, Abiomed, and officials of Jewish Hospital have severely restricted news about the recipient's progress, in a policy that is drawing harsh criticism from leading medical ethicists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, ABBING, MONSIGNOR JOHN PATRICK
description: CARROLL - ABBING - Monsignor John Patrick. The directors and staff of Boys' Towns of Italy, Inc. mourn the passing of our beloved founder, Monsignor John Patrick Carroll-Abbing. He was ordained a priest in Rome in 1935 and named a Monsignor shortly thereafter. He served in the Papal Household under Pope Pius XI and Pope Pius the XII until the outbreak of World War II. Pope Pius XII gave Monsignor permission to leave the Household and to assist the refugee population of Italy. He began by starting ''Shoeshine Hotels'' for the young street population of Italy and thereafter devoted his life to caring for children whose lives have been shattered by war, poverty, and natural disaster. His mission of unconditional love and acceptance have stood for decades as a shining beacon offering a ''second chance in life'' to lost and abandoned boys and girls of many nationalities. Monsignor Carroll-Abbing was the founder and leader of the residential facilities Boys' Towns of Rome and Girls' Towns of Rome, as well as Boys Towns of Italy, Inc., the oldest American charity working abroad, and was an internationally respected advocate for child welfare. We miss him dearly and will always strive to keep his spirit and mission alive. Brother A.E. D'Adamo, CFC, Executive Vice President Mauro C. Romita, Secretary/Treasurer

title: Musicians, Drugs And Gil Scott-Heron
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Vote Signals That Compromise Is Likely on Gulf Drilling
description: The Senate signaled its clear support today for a compromise White House plan for new oil and gas drilling in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, turning aside a Democrat-backed measure that would have blocked exploration in the area.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Outrage Over Japanese Textbook
description: Seoul canceled military exchanges with Japan and decided not to move ahead with a program to tear down cultural barriers after Japan again refused to revise new textbooks that Koreans say gloss over wartime atrocities. President Kim Dae Jung called on Japan to follow the German example and recount the facts of history in its schoolbooks. Donald Kirk (NYT)

title: Abbott Told to Reduce Supply of Unapproved Thyroid Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that Abbott Laboratories must gradually reduce its distribution of a highly prescribed thyroid drug while it applies for regulatory approval of the medication.

title: G.E. Reports 15% Increase In 2nd-Quarter Earnings
description: The General Electric Company, despite its first quarterly decline in revenues since 1988, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were up 15 percent from the same quarter last year.

title: CITY SETTLES SUIT IN LOUIMA TORTURE
description: Four years after being tortured with a broken broomstick while under police custody in a Brooklyn station house, Abner Louima agreed yesterday to settle his civil lawsuit against New York City and its main police union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTON, MARGARITA H.
description: BUTTON-Margarita H., 90. Of 40 Stevens Camp Road, North Hero, VT, died in Buenos Aires on July 3, 2001, after a brief illness. Her beloved husband, Dr. William H. Button, Jr., died in 1982. They spent winters in New York City and each summer in North Hero. Mrs. Button was a member of the Colony Club and the City Gardens Club of New York. She leaves her stepdaughter, Judith Button (Mrs. Jonathan M.) Keyes; six grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren; a nephew, Edward Macrae Moir of Buenos Aires; and four children of her other nephew, the late Victor Macrae Moir. Her stepson William H. Button III died in 1999. A memorial service will be held at the Button Cemetery in Clarendon, VT. on August 18, at 2:30PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Friends of North Hero Library, North Hero, VT 05474. Tossing Funeral Home, 39 Washington St., Rutland, VT 05701 is coodinating services.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Two Roles, One Secret

title: Can Suffering Be Too Beautiful?
description: SENTIMENTAL voyeurism'' is the latest jab, this one from Jean-Franois Chevrier, a French art professor, in Le Monde. Clearly it's tough being the world's most famous photojournalist.

title: Album of the Week
description: BASEMENT JAXX: -- ''Rooty'' (Astralwerks). ''Rooty'' begins with a shiny sound collage that suggests the sliding doors of a spaceship opening to let in the blue rays of heaven. Then a breathy voice dripping with innuendo whispers, ''Basement Jaxx,'' as if it meant something dirty, and you know you're actually stepping into a much more earthy daydream. The psychological world of ''Rooty'' is hedonism, but disco style as opposed to hip-hop style. Inasmuch as this album is about sex -- and it is -- it's fabulous sex: nobody is denigrated.

title: A Scramble, As Usual, At Deadline For Petitions
description: It was the day they'd all been waiting for, the hard-and-fast, no-excuses, no-exceptions-granted deadline for candidates to file petitions to get on the ballot for the Sept. 11 primary.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sale Canceled
description: Deutsche Bank canceled plans to sell its Morgan Grenfell Private Equity unit to a management group after a disagreement over terms of the transaction. Graham Hutton, the chief executive of Morgan Grenfell, quit when the negotiations ended, said Sir Robert Smith, who is succeeding Mr. Hutton.

title: 'Voyages' -- A Smithsonian Libraries Exhibition
description: Grolier Club

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEON, DANIEL MANNING
description: McKEON-Daniel Manning, 94. Of Ridgefield, CT, July 11, 2001. Retired stockbroker of the NY Stock Exchange (1929-1953), Ridgefield community leader for the past six decades and recipient of the Papal ''Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice'' decoration, a Knight of Malta and of St. Gregory and graduate of Yale University. Husband of the late Louise (nee Hoguet) McKeon, father of Louise Belt, Katherine Bailly, Jessie Cosnard, Sheila Schwartzburg, Daniel McKeon, Jr., John McKeon and Denis McKeon, grandfather of 21 and great grandfather of 25. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10 AM, St. Elizabeth Seton Church, Ridgefield, CT. Burial to follow. Visiting hours at the Kane Funeral Home, 41 Catoonah St., Ridgefield on Sunday from 5PM-8PM. Contributions to the Ridgefield Historical Society, 400 Main Street, Ridgefield, 06877 or to the St. Thomas More Chapel, Yale University, 268 Park Avenue, New Haven, CT. 06511, would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRADER, ABRAHAM
description: SCHRADER-Abraham. On July 12, 2001 at age 100. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Mort and his wife Miquette & Steve and his wife Lucy. Grandfather of Jacob, David and Eliza. Services today, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Company Using Cloning to Yield Stem Cells
description: In another example of how stem cell research is running ahead of public policy, a Massachusetts company is trying to use cloning technology to create human embryos that would yield the cells, which in turn might give rise to tissues that were a perfect match for patients.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Court Supports Back Pay
description: In a ruling that supported the awarding of back pay, the State Supreme Court yesterday struck down the state's 1859 ''no work, no pay'' law. In a case involving prison guards, a labor arbitrator awarded back pay to union members who did not receive overtime as stipulated in their contract. The state resisted, citing the ''no work, no pay'' law. In the majority opinion, Justice James R. Zazzali, left, called the law an ''outdated and outmoded anachronism.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Milford: Prayer Meeting Ruling Criticized
description: The town of New Milford is considering appealing a federal judge's ruling that struck down its rule limiting the attendance of non-family members to 24 at Sunday prayer meetings at private homes. The town said it regarded the measure as regulating traffic congestion. But a judge found last week that it violated the constitutionally protected exercise of religion.

title: M.L.S. Announces All-Star Starters
description: Three teenagers -- Bobby Convey of D.C. United, Landon Donovan of San Jose and DaMaracus Beasley of Chicago -- were among the 22 players voted as starters for Major League Soccer's sixth All-Star Game, to be be played July 28 at Spartan Stadium in San Jose, Calif. The league named the starters for both teams yesterday and will name the substitutes July 24.

title: Brando and De Niro Chill Over Ice
description: The best thing about Frank Oz's film ''The Score'' is, well, the score. If you close your eyes, Howard Shore's suave, moody music, with its Miles Davis-ish muted trumpets floating over cushions of bass, might create an impression of cool, elegant precision. Frustratingly brief snippets of performances by Cassandra Wilson and Mose Allison certainly enhance the effect. And, to be fair, if you open your eyes at the right moments, like when Ms. Wilson and Mr. Allison are onscreen in the lacquered, dim Montreal jazz club where much of the action takes place, you might mistake ''The Score'' for a stylish film-noir chamber piece.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gay Community Center Reopens
description: After nearly three years and $12 million of renovations, the former Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center reopened yesterday. The center, at 208 West 13th Street, was founded in 1983 and is home to more than 300 community and other groups. The complex has been renamed the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center. Denny Lee (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Redistricting Begins
description: The Legislature began a politically charged debate over two new Congressional seats for the state. House and Senate members held the first of 20 public hearings, as lawmakers prepare to draw new district lines. Democrats are already complaining that they have been shut out by the Republican-dominated Legislature. Speaker Tom Feeney, a House Republican and a potential candidate for one of the seats, said the process would be open and fair. But he cautioned: ''Redistricting is a political process. You can't take the politics out of politics.'' Lloyd Dunkelberger (NYT)

title: Police Search Abandoned Buildings for Intern
description: As part of their search for Chandra Ann Levy, the intern who disappeared more than two months ago, the police began combing abandoned buildings today. Police officials said the search could continue for several days and would use dogs trained to find cadavers.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Jobs Leader Adds Scholarships
description: TMP Worldwide, the parent of Monster.com, the largest job-search Web site, said it had acquired FastWeb, the nation's largest scholarship Web site. Terms were not disclosed. FastWeb, based in Skokie, Ill., has 11 million users and lists more than 600,000 scholarship opportunities representing about $1 billion in capital, TMP Worldwide said. Jeff Taylor, chief executive of Monster.com, said the deal was another step toward building a ''comprehensive college and career information site for students.'' Last month, Monster.com acquired CollegeLink.com, a Web site that offers help in the admissions process, and Monster's largest rival, HotJobs.com. TMP shares rose $3.25, or 6.3 percent, to $54.82. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 6 Injured In Crash
description: A van collided with another vehicle in Astoria yesterday, injuring a woman, her two children and passengers in both vehicles, the authorities said. The mother, Suli Perreira, 36, suffered a leg fracture and was taken to Elmhurst General Hospital. The children suffered minor injuries, the police said, as did two passengers in the van and the driver of the other car. The collision occurred about noon at 48th Street and 30th Avenue. The police issued no summonses and said the investigation was continuing. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: New Video Releases
description: Down to Earth

title: Oil High on Agenda as Bush Meets Algerian Leader
description: President Bush met today with the leader of oil-rich Algeria, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, the first visit of an Algerian head of state to the White House in 16 years.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Navy Rules Out Training Range
description: The Navy will not use 222,000 acres in South Texas as a replacement site for military training exercises now being conducted on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, Navy Secretary Gordon England said Wednesday. Instead, the military will explore moving the exercises to existing facilities. Economic development officials in thinly populated Kenedy County had proposed land near the Padre Island National Seashore as an alternative to Vieques, prompting an outcry from environmentalists.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Parliament Urged To Reopen
description: After President Chandrika Kumaratunga's suspension of Parliament, opposition leaders urged Anura Bandaranaike, the House speaker, to defy her and call Parliament back in session. He said he would decide today. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: In a Shift, United Renews Its Bid to Acquire US Airways
description: At the insistence of US Airways and under an implied threat of litigation, United Airlines has reluctantly agreed to move forward with its proposed $4.3 billion bid to buy US Airways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARINELLA, JOEY
description: FARINELLA-Joey. Age 41, Member of Local 15, Operating Engineers. Died July 11th at St Lukes/Roosevelt Hospital due to cancer. Spiritually, Joey could not be beaten. Loving son of Diane & Sonny; five brothers, Randy, Francis, Gus, Sonny Jr, & Thomas; loving sister in-law Helen; niece Amanda; God child Alexa; nephew Danny; aunts Tina, Joan, Sue & Carol; uncles Gus, Bob & Al. Viewing at James Funeral Home, 540 Broadway, Massapequa (516541-4000) Friday 8:30AM-9:30PM, Saturday 8:30AM-10:30AM. Funeral mass at St Kilians, Massapequa, Saturday 11:00AM. In lieu of flowers, donations sent to ''Joey Farinella Chemo Laboratory Fund'' 516-293-6118

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From the New Beetle to singing the catalytic converter blues, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTEL, LEAH
description: AMSTEL-Leah. Devoted mother of Jeraldine Meltzer. Cherished and loving grandmother of Stephen, Scott and Wendy Schechter. Graveside service to be held Friday, July 13 at 10AM, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMOVICI, HENRY
description: HAIMOVICI-Henry. Died at his home in New York City on July 10, 2001 at 93 years of age. He is survived by his brother Avram Haimovici, his nephew Yaacov Haimovitch and his niece Sara H. Hirsch, all in Israel; and a niece Marta H. Albulescu in Romania; and several grand-nephews and grand-nieces. His wife, Nelicia, predeceased him several years ago. Henry Haimovici was born in rural Romania in 1907 and, after graduating from college, attended and graduated from the Marseille Medical School in France in 1937 and became a French citizen. He was awarded a Rockefeller Fellowship at Harvard Medical School in 1938-1939. Although World War II had already started in Europe, Henry Haimovici returned to France and was drafted into the French army in 1940 as an army surgeon in Montpellier, but by July, 1940, with the war escalating, he thought he should try to return to the United States, which he was able to do with the help of Marshal Petain. It took two years for him to get an exit visa out of France to North Africa and into the U.S. Practicing medicine in the U.S. since 1942, Dr. Haimovici was with Mt. Sinai Hospital from 1944-1954, was Chief of Vascular Surgery at Montefiore Hospital from 1945-1972 and Chief of Surgery Emeritus thereafter. Dr. Haimovici was a member of various medical societies and was considered one of the true pioneers in the field of vascular surgery. He held honorary degrees from medical schools in Ireland, Italy, Argentina, Brazil, Japan, France, Israel and Cuba and lectured at symposia all over the world. He was the founder in 1950 of the International Society of Cardiovascular Surgery and published over 200 articles and books in French and English, including his book The Metabolic Complications of Acute Arterial Occlusions and Related Conditions in 1988 and his treatise, Haimovici's Vascular Surgery, Principles and Technologies, which is currently in its fourth edition. At the request of his family, the funeral and burial will be private.

title: The Ice (Cream) Age
description: There's little better on a warm summer day than a cool, smooth ice cream. Here are a few of New York's top spots for a scoop or two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANINGA, DILSUKH, MD.
description: RANINGA-Dilsukh, MD. With great sadness the family, friends and colleagues of Dilsukh Raninga mourn his passing and celebrate his life of service and achievements. Beloved husband of Irene DeLizzo and father of Steven, Amit and Christina, Dr. Raninga is also survived by his father Vasanji Raninga of Dhanka, India, mother and father-in-law Diane and Frank DeLizzo, daughter-in-law Chila and granddaughter Bianca, four sisters and three brothers. Born in Dhank, Dr. Raninga received his medical degree from Baroda Medical School. While maintaining his cardiology practice in Brooklyn, NY, Dr. Raninga also served as Chief of Cardiology and Physician in charge of the intensive care unit at New York Community Hospital. He was also attending cardiologist at Beth Israel Hospital. Wake to be held at Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Place, Brooklyn, NY. Hindu funeral rite to be celebrated at Green-Wood cemetery on Saturday, July 14, 2001 at 9:30 AM.

title: Reporter's Notebook; For McCain and the House, A Day of Twists and Turmoil
description: The Speaker of the House lost on a procedural vote, a rare occurrence and the first time that it had happened to J. Dennis Hastert. One of the cardinal principles of the operations of the House is that the rank and file follow the party leader on procedures. Today, 19 Republicans voted against Mr. Hastert.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Diversity Grant For University
description: The Ford Foundation has given the University of Michigan a $600,000 grant to promote diversity in higher education. The grant is intended to finance outreach and research efforts in connection with two federal lawsuits challenging the university's affirmative action policies in undergraduate and law school admissions, which are pending appeal. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGREEN, MORRIS
description: BERGREEN-Morris. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of one of our staunchest advocates and friends whose sensitivity and encouragement spurred the Theater's efforts to identify and nurture American playwrights We will miss his wise and generous counsel and convey our condolences and warm affection to Adele. Lincoln Center Theater Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman John Chalsty, President Joan Straus Cullman, Vice Chair Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Exec. Producer

title: Disaster At Corning: At Least the Balance Sheet Is Strong
description: REMEMBER Rutherford B. Hayes?

title: Evidence Was Suppressed In Murder Case, Court Rules
description: A federal appeals court said yesterday that the Brooklyn district attorney's office kept crucial evidence from lawyers defending a man serving 20 years to life in prison for murder, and ordered a new trial.

title: Introduction
description: When the corn is high and plentiful, all anyone has to do is steam or boil it, add a little salt, maybe some butter -- and there's nothing better on earth. In fact, many of us just keep on eating it exactly that way, as often as possible, eating fast and furiously in the full knowledge that soon the season will be over and the sweet corn will be gone again.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Cold Corn Soup
description: This cold soup is in the puree style. It is not meant to be very liquidy -- but still a true soup rather than a vegetable. It would be quite bland if we failed to garnish it, but the dollop of yogurt, the chopped chives and the strips of red pepper added after the soup is chilled will give it an appealing touch of sharpness and surprising complexity. It gains its thickness, it's rich texture, not from cream but from bread cooked with soup, which then becomes a thickening agent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, GERTRUDE
description: WEISS-Gertrude. On July 12, 2001. Beloved wife and indispensable business partner of the late Max Weiss. Loving step-mother and adoring aunt. Funeral services will be held Sunday, July 15, 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: 'Pandaemonium'
description: Directed by Julien Temple

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GMELIN, STEPHAN
description: GMELIN-Stephan on July 11, 2001 of Cranford, NJ. Beloved husband of Alice C. Gmelin, father of Elisabeth G. Hunsinger and Robert C. Gmelin. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral Services Saturday July 14th, 2001 at Trinity Episcopal Church, Cranford, NJ at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Permanent Endowment Fund, Trinity Episcopal Church, Cranford, NJ 07016, or the Crane Phillips House Restoration, C/O Cranford Historical Society, 38 Springfield Ave, Cranford, NJ 07016. Services coordinated by Gray Funeral Home, Cranford, NJ.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Strike Opposes Security Law
description: A one-day strike called by Maoist rebels to protest a new security law caused businesses and schools in Katmandu to shut down. The law gives district administrators new powers to detain people on suspicion that they threaten the nation's sovereignty. The rebels have increased their attacks since the massacre of most members of the royal family on June 1. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Markets Disapprove Of Argentina's Plan To Rescue Economy
description: Political leaders and investors turned a disapproving cold shoulder today to a new round of austerity measures offered by the government, sending local financial markets plummeting and a chill through some markets abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIBOSIAN, GEORGE
description: PHILIBOSIAN-George. The Board of Trustees of Englewood Hospital and Medical Center records with sorrow the passing of our esteemed colleague and benefactor, George Philibosian. His devotion to our Medical Center and so many other institutions in the greater Englewood Community will long be remembered and serve as a testament to his life and work. Our thoughts and prayers are with his beloved wife Alice and his children Emil, Alan, Charles, Stephen and Anita and their families. Andrew F. Durkin, Chairman Daniel A. Kane, President

title: Heinz Prechter, Car Customizer and Bush Booster, Dies at 59
description: Heinz Prechter, who as an exchange student from Bavaria brought the concept of car sunroofs to the United States and who went on to become a major manufacturer of automotive products and a leading contributor to the campaigns of both President Bush and his father, died on July 6 at a guest house next to his home in Grosse Ile, Mich., a suburb of Detroit. He was 59.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 30 about Modjadji V, a rain queen and tribal ruler in South Africa, misidentified the member of her family who died a few days before she did. It was her daughter, Mmakheala, not her granddaughter, Makobo.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a stalled agreement in the Abner Louima civil rights lawsuit misstated the nature and the time of a planned announcement by the city. The city had prepared a statement, but did not officially release it Wednesday night because the deal was not formalized.

title: With All Those Chairs, Who Stood in the 80's?
description: Like the three other shows that preceded it in the series, the Metropolitan Museum's ''Century of Design, Part 4: 1975-2000'' will give you only a tantalizing glimpse of its chunk of the bustling century.

title: Swissair to Sell $1.7 Billion in Assets to Cut Debt
description: The Swissair Group says it will sell more than $1.7 billion of assets, including its stakes in the Galileo reservations service and the Equant data network, as well as aircraft, as it tries to reduce a crushing debt load.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Tkachuk Stays With the Blues
description: Keith Tkachuk, the All-Star left wing acquired by the St. Louis Blues in a March 13 trade with the Phoenix Coyotes, signed a one-year, $8.3 million qualifying offer to remain with the Blues.

title: Twombly Shows a Side of Tactile Eloquence
description: Cy Twombly is known for paintings in which febrile clusters of lines, words and symbols scatter like startled graffiti across planes of faint color or bare canvas. Influenced by the seismographic brushwork of Soutine and early Dubuffet, and the further liberties of Surrealism, automatism and Abstract Expressionism, these scrawled traceries mix intimations of light-drenched Mediterranean landscapes with references to the events and personages of Greek myth and poetry.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Rumsfeld Defense
description: Fuzzy math, meet fuzzy strategy.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Health Care Purchase
description: Mayne Nickless Ltd., the country's largest health-care company, will buy the biggest domestic drug distributor, F. H. Faulding & Company, after raising its bid by almost 25 percent. The cash or stock alternatives value Faulding at up to 2.5 billion Australian ($1.27 billion).

title: The I.M.F. Representative to Palestine
description: A delegation of European diplomats was being quizzed in Israel recently about European financial support for the Palestinian Authority, which was supposed to be delayed until the Palestinians adopted strict new spending guidelines and put a stop to off-the-books business deals.

title: AFFILIATED COMPUTER IS BUYING NATIONAL PROCESSING UNIT
description: Affiliated Computer Services said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a unit of National Processing for $43 million. The unit processes health care claims, credit card applications and airline tickets. Affiliated Computer, a Dallas-based company that helps clients process and analyze documents, will get National Processing operations in Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and Barbados and about 75 percent of the company's Mexican operations, the companies said. National Processing, based in Louisville, Ky., will take a fiscal second-quarter charge of $6 million from the sale. National Processing said it planned to focus on its business that settles electronic payments, like credit card transactions.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Senator May Have Tough Opponent
description: A new poll indicates that Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat seeking a third term, may be vulnerable, particularly if his Republican opponent is Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul. The poll, conducted last week by Mason-Dixon Research, has Mr. Wellstone holding only a four-point edge over Mr. Coleman. Mr. Coleman has indicated he will probably run. He is being heavily pressured to do so by top Republican leaders, among them President Bush.

title: Orlando Looks Like Ewing's Next Stop
description: While in the Bahamas this past week, Patrick Ewing got into an argument he couldn't win with a middle-aged Houston Rockets fan, who agitated the former Knick center by bringing up a sore subject.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Mental Health Care Expansion
description: Massachusetts officials say they plan to expand the treatment offered mentally ill children outside psychiatric hospitals. Details of the plan are under negotiation. Advocates have long been demanding such services, and they say those details will determine whether they file a class-action suit. At issue are hundreds of ''stuck kids,'' mentally ill children and teenagers who spend weeks or months in psychiatric hospitals for lack of community-based treatment. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFANDARI, ALBERT
description: ALFANDARI-Albert. Died peacefully at home on July 11, 2001. Loving father of Jacqueline Alfandari and Sandra Alfandari Murphy. Adoring grandfather of Jason M. Nelson and Rachel Nelson. He will be warmly remembered by his family for his kindness and wisdom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, KARYN
description: REYNOLDS - Karyn. Devoted mother of Dr. Harmony and mother-in-law of Dr. Albert Nejat. Cherished daughter of Harriette. Services Sunday at 11:15 AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the financial collapse of the Shooting Gallery, an independent film production company, misstated the occupation of one of the investors, Donald C. Carter. Mr. Carter is a private investor living in Palm Beach, Fla., not the former owner of the Dallas Mavericks, who is Donald J. Carter. The article also misidentified the person who a Miramax spokesman denied had bluffed Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax, into paying $10 million for the movie ''Sling Blade.'' He is Larry Meistrich, not Larry Russo.

title: Wu Shan Zhuan and Inga Svala Thorsdottir
description: Ethan Cohen Fine Arts

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: 3rd Woman Stoned To Death
description: The hard-line court in Tehran executed a third woman in three months. Maryam Ayoubi, 32, buried up to her neck, was stoned in Evin prison, the daily Entekhab reported. She had been found guilty of adultery and murdering her husband with the help of her lover, who will be executed by hanging. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Amid Grief, And Insults, South Africa Evicts Poor
description: The armored trucks rumbled into the illegal shantytown at 12:44 p.m. today, carrying riot police with rifles and demolition workers with crowbars.

title: Martnez's Injury Keeps Red Sox Guessing About His Return
description: There were Red Sox in and around the batting cage, Red Sox in the outfield, Red Sox in the bullpen, Red Sox everywhere. It was four hours before last night's game with the Mets, and the Red Sox, the battered, resilient Red Sox, already had about 15 players in uniform who looked ready and able to grind through the second half of the season.

title: How Dowdy Old Baltimore Turned Fashionable
description: Yes, you can go home again. Just don't expect it to look the same.

title: There's Interest in the Bronx as Giambi and the A's Break Off Negotiations
description: Jason Giambi's contract negotiations with Oakland appear to have broken off, and there will inevitably be speculation about a possible deal between the Yankees and the Athletics. There are, however, many reasons the Yankees are unlikely to trade for Giambi:

description: TEICHMAN-Murray. Of Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Devoted father of Harvey and Helen, Stewart and Sue, and Anita and Pat. Adored grandfather of Heather, Ben, Matthew, Eric, Ashley and Andrew. Dear brother of Bernice and Lillian. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, at 9:30 AM.

title: From Nancy Reagan, a Nod Toward Embryonic Stem Cell Research
description: Nancy Reagan has privately indicated her support for research on embryonic stem cells, and two of her husband's closest former aides have conveyed her position to senior White House officials, people familiar with Mrs. Reagan's feelings said today.

title: The Real Test of Welfare Reform Still Lies Ahead
description: In some circles, America's welfare reform has already been declared a success. Five years after Congress approved a time limit and work requirements for welfare, the number of people on the rolls has fallen by half, to six million, and many former recipients, including single mothers, have found at least part-time employment. But heartening as these facts are, it is premature to assume from them that the 1996 law has been a successful experiment. Five years is a short time for testing a substantively new social policy -- and these particular five years have not been ordinary ones.

description: Directed by Patrick Hasson

description: TELECOMMUNICATIONSMORE LAYOFFS COMING AT LUCENT

title: Beijing Is Preparing to Celebrate
description: China began tentative preparations for a national celebration today as it waited for the International Olympic Committee's decision Friday on whether Beijing will play host to the 2008 Summer Games.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bid For Bottler
description: The San Miguel Corporation, the largest Philippine food and drinks maker, said it was in talks to buy the Cosmos Bottling Corporation from its nearest rival, the RFM Corporation, a move that would give it a near monopoly in soft drinks. RFM also has interests in flour, meat and poultry.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Research Firm Cuts Staff
description: The market research and consulting firm Forrester Research said it would cut 111 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, but added that it still expected to meet its second-quarter earnings forecast. The company has seen demand for its technology consulting services diminish with the economic slowdown. George F. Colony, its chief executive, said Forrester's sales force would shift its focus to more specialized market niches. The company confirmed expectations for revenue of $46 million, or 24 cents a share. Forrester shares jumped $2.06, or 10.6 percent, to close at $21.46. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Benjamin M. Kahn -- B'nai B'rith Official, 87
description: Rabbi Benjamin M. Kahn, executive vice president of B'nai B'rith International from 1971 to 1976, died on July 4 at a hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 87 and lived in Silver Spring.
