title: Biology Teacher at Bronx Science Is New Principal
description: The national search for a new principal of the Bronx High School of Science, one of New York City's most prestigious public schools, has ended where it began: at home.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Spy's Wife Calls Punishment 'Appropriate'
description: The wife of Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent who spied for Moscow for more than 15 years, said she regretted the damage he had caused and called his life sentence ''appropriate.'' In her first public statement since her husband's arrest in February, Bonnie Hanssen, described herself as ''an innocent victim'' who was ''very appreciative of the government's recognition that she had played no role in and received no benefit from her husband's activities.'' Mr. Hanssen pleaded guilty last week to espionage. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

title: Art in Review
description: Voyages '

title: Ford Changes Some Managers In Its North American Division
description: The Ford Motor Company, buffeted by lower auto sales and the continuing dispute over the failure of Firestone tires on its Explorer sports utility vehicles, announced a series of management changes today to shore up its operations in North America.

title: EARL SCHEIB SAYS IT WILL CLOSE 41 OF ITS AUTO BODY SHOPS
description: Earl Scheib Inc., owner of a chain of auto body shops, plans to close 26 percent of its stores in the next three years as part of an effort to reduce costs. The company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., will close 41 of its 155 stores to concentrate on business in California, Arizona and other states where winter weather does not keep customers from seeking new paint jobs. The step could eliminate as many as 328 jobs, or 33 percent of its staff, the company said.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: French Models Looking for Love In New York City
description: THIS Sunday, don a beret, grab a baguette, crank up the 2CV and make a hard right at the Left Bank. If you make it to 86th Street and Riverside by noon, you can join a parade of French cars through the streets of New York.

title: Small Power Plants Planned in Nassau County
description: As part of efforts to stave off California-like blackouts on Long Island next summer, the Long Island Power Authority and the KeySpan Energy Corporation announced plans today to build two small power plants here on Nassau County's North Shore.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT IS UP. Wheat rose on expectations that a heat wave will damage crops in the Midwest and northern Great Plains. The September contract jumped 6 percent, or 16.5 cents, to $2.8925 a bushel.

title: Rights Group Says Taliban Aren't Solely to Blame for the Afghan Disaster
description: Breaking ranks with most human rights groups and the American government, Human Rights Watch said in a report today that the Taliban alone were not responsible for a deepening disaster in Afghanistan.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: More Layoffs Coming At Lucent
description: The Lucent Technologies chief executive, Henry B. Schacht, citing weakness in the economy, told the company's employees yesterday to expect further layoffs. In addition, Lucent said that 8,500 managers had accepted buyout offers. Lucent will reveal the full financial impact of the buyouts, which could potentially save the company more than $800 million a year, late this month. The buyouts were offered to about 13,000 midlevel managers as part of a cost-savings plan that could result in as many as 20,000 layoffs. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Windsor Locks: Inquiry At Tax Collector's Office
description: The police have begun an investigation into a report of missing money and other irregularities in the tax collector's office. An audit released in May said the tax office was short at least $4,200 from November 2000 to March. John T. Suchocki, the police chief, said officers on Tuesday removed boxes of payment receipts, balance books and statements, but declined to give more details about the investigation.

title: Diageo Says Nonliquor Units Continued to Underperform
description: Diageo, which is trying to focus on its strength as the world's biggest liquor company, said today that its other businesses continued to stumble, including the Burger King fast-food chain, which was hit by worries in Europe over mad cow disease and foot-and-mouth disease.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loan For Hyundai
description: Creditors authorized new loans of $478 million to Hyundai Petrochemical after Hyundai Engineering and Construction agreed to join other units of the struggling Hyundai Group and give up their shares in the chemical concern. The new credit line will allow Hyundai Petrochemical to continue buying naphtha, which is used in making ethylene, a component of plastics, and avoid shutting down its naphtha cracking plant. The move by Hyundai Engineering gave the creditors control of more than two-thirds of Hyundai Petrochemical, a condition that they insisted on before extending the new credit. Hyundai Engineering asked the lenders for a new loan of about $55 million to cover its loss Don Kirk (NYT)

title: An Emmy Turf War
description: ''The Sopranos,'' the HBO series starring James Gandolfini, above right, with Robert Iler, and ''The West Wing,'' from NBC, are squaring off for an Emmy-night battle. ''The Sopranos'' led in nominations, 22 to 18.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Political Party Limits
description: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a law requiring that political parties have national membership and providing for federal financing for election campaigns. Critics have warned that the law is too restrictive in limiting the number of parties, which was more than 50 last year. The Kremlin argued that the law would prevent oligarchs and criminals from financing parties and abusing immunity provisions by purchasing seats in Parliament. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: The Ice (Cream) Age
description: There's little better on a warm summer day than a cool, smooth ice cream. Here are a few of New York's top spots for a scoop or two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEIL, MARY HUBBARD
description: O'NEIL-Mary Hubbard, 80. Formerly of New York City died after a brief illness July 9 at St. Francis Hospital of Hartford. Mrs. O'Neil is survived by her eight children and twelve grandchildren and is predeceased by her husband George W. O'Neil. Mrs. O'Neil graduated from Our Lady of Lord and Manhattanville College in 1943.

title: CAMPAIGN MEASURE SHELVED AFTER FIERCE FIGHT ON RULES
description: The effort to overhaul the campaign finance law collapsed in the House today in a bitter procedural battle, with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert saying he has no plan to resurrect the legislation any time soon.

title: Battle Under Way Over Arts Chairman
description: The first culture war of the Bush administration does not involve homoerotic photographs, holy images and waste products or a performance artist clad only in chocolate.

title: She's Got Bette Davis Eyes. Or Does She?
description: To the Editor:

title: MILITARY SCUTTLES STRATEGY REQUIRING '2-WAR' CAPABILITY
description: The United States is abandoning requirements that its military be prepared to fight two major wars simultaneously, according to a classified strategy document. Instead, the new strategy will order the armed forces to ''win decisively'' in a single major conflict, defend American territory against new threats and, at the same time, conduct a number of holding actions elsewhere around the globe.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: House Panel Looks At Online Gambling
description: The head of a Congressional panel said lawmakers must address the issue of Internet gambling. Representative Sue W. Kelly, Republican of New York and chairwoman of the Financial Services Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, said during a hearing that she planned to support legislation in the coming months. Last summer, the House failed to approve a bill that would have banned most forms of betting online. She said Internet gambling posed a particular threat to children and college students. Representative James A. Leach, above, Republican of Iowa and a member of the Financial Services committee, said Congress had ignored online gambling ''at society's peril.'' The industry, he said, is one in which ''the odds are clearly stacked against consumers.''

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Getting The Picture

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 30 about Modjadji V, a rain queen and tribal ruler in South Africa, misidentified the member of her family who died a few days before she did. It was her daughter, Mmakheala, not her granddaughter, Makobo.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: New Police Chief For Detroit
description: Detroit's fire commissioner, Charles Wilson, was named chief of police, replacing Benny N. Napoleon, a 26-year veteran who announced his resignation in May. Mayor Dennis W. Archer named Mr. Wilson, left, 54, to lead the department, which is under investigation by the Justice Department for police shootings and mistreatment of witnesses and prisoners. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: The Big City; A New Deal For Tenant And Landlord
description: THE mayoral candidates are promising to spend billions to ease New York's housing crisis, but even their most ambitious plans won't make much difference anytime soon, if ever. Meanwhile, they're all overlooking a cheap, simple way to provide a dramatic number of new homes immediately.

title: Appraiser Examines a Newfound Treasure: Fame
description: SUDDENLY, bafflingly, and thanks to PBS, it is hip to be John A. Hays. A jolly, Columbo-esque stalker of antiques, he has an eclectic office that is equal parts paper scraps and auction-bound treasures in the Christie's empire at Rockefeller Center. The snazzy zebra-wood door is, he admits, ''only a veneer.'' But the somber Wyeth on the wall is the real thing, even if he can't recall its title, and as for that ''tough little Thomas Tuft Philadelphia dressing table'' (tough is apparently the standing ovation of cabinetry adjectives), get those bids in now.

title: Hitler and the Olympics
description: To the Editor:

title: Napster Appeals an Order To Remain Closed Down
description: Lawyers for the Napster Internet music service today asked a federal appeals court here to set aside a judge's order that it remain offline until it has shown it has made ''every effort'' to prevent the exchange of copyrighted audio files not permitted for use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZMAN, ALLAN H.
description: KURTZMAN-Allan H. The Hunter College community mourns the loss of our distinguished alumnus and loyal supporter, Allan H. Kurtzman. A member of the Hunter College Hall of Fame, former Chair of the Hunter College Foundation Board of Trustees and former President and Chief Operating Officer of the Neutrogena Corporation, he was a tireless and dedicated supporter of Hunter College and its mission of education, research and service. We will miss his energy, his wise counsel and his concern for the students, faculty & staff of Hunter College. We extend our deepest sympathy to his devoted wife, Maxine, and his loving daughters. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College Eileen Caulfield Schwab, Chair, Hunter College Foundation, Board of Trustees

title: Musicians, Drugs And Gil Scott-Heron
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KINDER MORGAN INC., Houston, said its pipeline venture, Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, had bought four storage terminals from Royal Vopak, Houston, for $44 million.

title: A Rivalry Across the Narrows; First, the Subway Series; Now, Fans Take the Ferry
description: Dave Jorn, the stony-faced manager of the defending champion Yankees, claims not to see what the fuss is about. ''We're in first place and they're in first place,'' he said after batting practice. ''Other than that, there's no significance in it. It's just like playing another team.''

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; If You Simply Must Call From a Car
description: IT was an accident that was barely avoided. I cut left into the Sears parking lot, across the bow of a car whose driver's hand seemed to be waving me by. But the approaching car didn't slow down: the upraised hand held a cellular phone, and the driver's eyes were focused not on me, but on the faraway place he was calling. I stomped on the accelerator and squeaked past before he awoke enough to use his horn. (There was no sign, though, that he ever hit his brakes.)

title: Editors' Note
description: On Stage and Off

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDLAY, HARRIET LINDSAY
description: FINDLAY-Harriet Lindsay. Died unexpectedly in her Manhattan apartment on July 5th, 2001. Known as Lindsay, she was born on August 16, 1935, in Kansas City, MO, and grew up in New Canaan, CT. A graduate of Dana Hall School, Goucher College and the Harvard-Radcliffe Business Program, she initially worked for The Putnam Fund in Boston, MA. In 1958 she joined her father, David B. Findlay Sr., in his Manhattan art business, David Findlay Galleries. The original Findlay Galleries was founded in Kansas City, MO, 1870. Lindsay was a member of the fourth generation of the family to be involved with the gallery. In 1989 her father died, and Lindsay assumed control of the gallery. She is survived by her mother, Harriet Jones Findlay, two brothers, David B. Findlay Jr. and H. Peter Findlay, and numerous nieces & nephews. Each of the brothers has his own eponymous art gallery in Manhattan. A memorial service will be held at the Congregational Church, 23 Park St, New Canaan, CT, on Tuesday, July 17th at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Humane Society of Manhattan and New Canaan Nature Center in memory of the deceased.

title: Credit Suisse Shakes Up First Boston
description: John J. Mack wanted to be a Wall Street chief executive, and yesterday he suddenly got his wish when he was named to run Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: BRITISH REGULATORS EXTEND REVIEW OF P.& G. PURCHASE
description: Procter & Gamble's proposed $4.95 billion acquisition of the Clairol hair care unit from Bristol-Myers Squibb will get a longer-than-expected review by Britain's antitrust regulator. The regulator, the British Office of Fair Trading, will complete its review by Aug. 13, three weeks later than scheduled, the agency said in a statement. A spokeswoman for the British agency declined to say what prompted the decision. Antitrust officials in the United States and overseas were expected to focus on the addition of Clairol's Herbal Essences shampoo products to Procter & Gamble's Pantene and Head & Shoulders lines, analysts have said.

title: FLORIDA ROCK IN DEAL FOR SOME ASSETS OF U.S. AGGREGATES
description: Florida Rock Industries, a leading provider of concrete products in the Southeast, has agreed to buy the Southeastern operations of U.S. Aggregates for $105 million. Florida Rock will pay $105 million in cash, and assume debt and equipment operating leases valued at about $45 million for seven stone quarries, two sand plants and a cement-mixing plant. The plants crush stone, sand and other materials used in construction. The new markets will complement areas in Florida and Georgia that Florida Rock serves, the company said.

title: Pentagon Sets Ambitious Tests Of Missile Plan
description: Senior Pentagon officials announced details today of an ambitious missile-testing plan that they said could lead to a working system of land-based, sea-launched and airborne weapons in four years. Senate Democrats immediately attacked the proposal, saying it was highly likely to violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty within a year.

title: Sather's Rebuilding Plan Won't Sacrifice Prospects
description: From his home in the Czech Republic, Jaromir Jagr said yesterday that he was shocked when he learned the Pittsburgh Penguins traded him to the Washington Capitals on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBANK, HELEN HORN
description: MILBANK-Helen Horn, age 87, died July 9, 2001. Beloved wife of Robert Milbank. Cherished mother of Mary Day Bodenstein of Morristown, NJ, Robert Jr. of Dallas, and Anne Mell of Summit, NJ. Devoted grandmother of Barbara, Nancy, Meredith, Elizabeth, John, Stephen and Caitlin. Loving sister of Louise Riker and Nancy Norris, both of Chatham, NJ. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 14, 2001, at 11 AM, at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Avenue, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Junior League of Summit, NJ, or the Overlook Hospital Women's Auxiliary Twig #

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Since that day almost four years ago, I have vowed to do everything I can to ensure that the torture and cover-up I suffered will not be inflicted on my children or anyone else's children in the future.''

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Discovering the Inner Child

title: The Ice (Cream) Age
description: There's little better on a warm summer day than a cool, smooth ice cream. Here are a few of New York's top spots for a scoop or two.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Accused In Auto Scheme
description: Two men were arrested and accused of tampering with odometers on dozens of used cars and then selling or leasing the cars at inflated prices, the Brooklyn district attorney said yesterday. The men, Gaby Dahan, 41, and Jerry Strzebala, 38, both of Brooklyn, each face four years in prison if convicted. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: DiFrancesco Seeks Options On Emissions Test Contract
description: A day after hearings ended on a widely criticized $392 million contract for emissions-testing for automobiles, New Jersey's acting governor, Donald T. DiFrancesco, told members of his cabinet yesterday to draw up a list of options that would include the possible cancellation of the 1998 contract.

title: Corn and Tomato Salad
description: One of our favorite ways of serving salads is in a hollowed-out tomato, and that's what we'll use today. An interesting twist is that the tomato flesh removed during the hollowing process will be salvaged and cut into chunks to be added to the salad.

title: You Can't Recall Senators
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: She's Got Bette Davis Eyes. Or Does She?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Criticizes Major Allies For Inaction In Slave Trade
description: The State Department today criticized several of the United States' closest allies, including Saudi Arabia, Israel, Greece and South Korea, saying they had not made sufficient efforts to stop the trafficking of slaves within their borders.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In descending order of ambition, and price, Daniel Boulud now offers three package tours for serious diners. There's Daniel for the no-holds-barred, all-out splurge and Caf Boulud for high-level food in a more casual neigborhood setting. To these two Mr. Boulud has added DB Bistro Moderne, a snappier, more energetic version of the Boulud style. The menu is short, the atmosphere is informal and on Saturdays the plat du jour is hamburger, scheduled to migrate to the main menu.

title: Chinese Officials Avoid Tough Questions
description: Beijing officials took no chances on being blindsided by potentially embarrassing questions today as they met with the 1,500 members of the news media gathered for Friday's vote for the host city of the 2008 Summer Olympics.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Investors React Negatively To Argentine Austerity Plan

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Joint Auto Venture
description: Two automakers, Toyota Motor of Japan and PSA Peugeot Citron of France have formed a joint venture to develop and build a compact car in Europe, the companies said. At a news conference in Brussels, Fujio Cho, president of Toyota, and Jean-Martin Folz, left, chief executive of Peugeot, said the 1.5 billion euro ($1.3 billion) project would produce 300,000 vehicles a year. Two-thirds of them will have the Peugeot nameplate and the rest Toyota.

title: Last-Ditch Effort Failed For 4 in Washington Fire
description: Firefighters call them ''shake and bakes'' or ''tinfoil coffins.'' They are thin, aluminum-and-fiberglass tents designed to withstand heat of up to 600 degrees and work as a last refuge for a person fleeing a wall of flames. Curling up inside one is the ultimate fear of anyone who battles wildfires.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: No Delay To Tanks' Destruction
description: A suit seeking to delay the implosion of two 400-foot-high empty natural-gas storage tanks in Greenpoint was rejected by a civil court judge yesterday. The tanks, owned by the KeySpan Energy Corporation, are to be demolished Sunday. The suit, filed yesterday by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez and community groups, argued that KeySpan had not given proper notice to the community or responded to concerns about health and safety problems. But Mr. Lopez said the judge held that with the tank already wired with explosives, it would be more dangerous to halt the demolition than to go through with it. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, ANITA
description: SALTZ-Anita. Midori & Friends Board and Staff mourn the passing of Anita Saltz, a wonderful friend and benefactor of our Foundation, whose generosity greatly benefited many children throughout the city. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jack and their family.

title: Small Arms in a Big, Brutal World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEASON, JAMES FRANCIS
description: GLEASON-James Francis. Of Scotch Plains, NJ and Stuart, Fl. Formerly of Point Lookout and Brooklyn. Husband of the late Eileen (Moore) Gleason. Father of Maryellen Kincade, Jane Kenda, Jennifer Perrotta, Gregory J. F. Gleason and the late Janet Gleason. Brother of Ann Regis (Nancy) G. O'Neil, the late Mary Alice Sullivan, Virginia Kiernan, Elizabeth Gleason, Joseph T. Gleason and Dolores McDougal. Also surviving are nine grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the Higgins & Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Ave., Westfield, NJ on Monday, July 16 at 9 A.M., thence a funeral mass will be offered at St. Helen R.C. Church, Westfield at 10 A.M. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. Friends may call Saturday 7-9 and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Helping Hands and Hearts of St. Helen's Parish Center, 1600 Rahway Avenue, Westfield, NJ 07090, would be appreciated.

title: The Immigrant Journey Gets No Easier in Britain
description: The hulking textile mill that dominates the skyline in the Manningham neighborhood here used to operate around the clock.

title: More Changes Made At Interpublic Group
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York continued to make changes yesterday, just days after the agency company announced it was reorganizing into four principal divisions.

title: Study Breaks New Ground On Variations In Genome
description: A large-scale study of the variability in the human genome has shown that each human gene may come in 12 different versions on average. The authors also say their findings cast doubt on the way that a large government and industry program is mining the genome for the genetic basis of common human diseases.

title: Leiter, Wanting to Stay, Shows Why He's a Keeper
description: Al Leiter thought carefully last winter while preparing his partial no-trade list. The Mets' left-hander tried to predict which teams would be most likely to deal for him. He designed the list to block trades to those clubs.

title: With New School Year Looming, City Needs 3,300 Teachers
description: Largely because of a wave of retirements, the Board of Education needs to hire 8,000 teachers before school reopens in September -- 2,000 more than last fall -- and with eight weeks left it is still 3,300 teachers short of that goal, school officials say.

title: That Beautiful Rhapsody of Love and Youth and Spring
description: EASY TO REMEMBER

title: School Leaders Contend Laws May Cause Lower Standards
description: The superintendents of the nation's two largest city school systems warned today that the toughened testing and accountability measures passed by the House and Senate recently could drive down educational standards, rather than raising student achievement.

title: Small Arms in a Big, Brutal World
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler to Speed Process For Designing New Vehicles
description: Chrysler announced a plan today aimed at both speeding the introduction of new vehicles and encouraging its staff to embrace innovative thinking.

title: A Couple of Chumps Mess Up the Big Deal
description: Who knew that Jon Favreau wanted to be John Cassavetes all along? In ''Made,'' his directorial debut and another guys' guys misfit comedy in the vein of ''Swingers,'' which he wrote and co-starred in, he pushes on through to the other side. ''Made'' is the work of a man who's probably sick of having people come up to him and repeat lines from ''Swingers'' while probably missing the point of that movie's last scene, which explodes the characters' self-absorption.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK ALBANY: RULING IN CITY CONTRACT TALKS In a ruling that police and firefighters' unions hope will win them larger pay raises, a state appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling that a state board can arbitrate contract disputes involving New York City police officers and firefighters. The ruling, by a five-judge panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, takes the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association further toward its goal of having its contract dispute with the city arbitrated by the State Public Employment Relations Board rather than the city's Office of Collective Bargaining. The state board takes into account the salaries of officers and firefighters in suburban communities, which pay as much as 35 percent more than the city does. The city said it would appeal.   William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, JANE GERMAN
description: IRWIN-Jane German. Widow of former US Ambassador to France and Manhattan lawyer, John N. Irwin II died on July 11 of Cancer. She was 74. Mrs. Irwin who lived in New Canaan, CT. was a loving mother and grandmother with a generous giving spirit. She was active in charitable endeavors having particular involvement in matters related to theology and theological institutions. At the time of her death she was a Board Member of The Princeton Theological Seminary, The Henry Luce Foundation and The Asia Foundation. Mrs. Irwin was also active in, and in many cases a Board Member of, The Friends of the Museum of Princeton University where she was one of the first Docents, The Girl Scouts of Greater NY, The Center of Theological Inquiry in Princeton, NJ and The Hoover Institution in Stanford, CA. Mrs. Irwin was born in Archer City, TX, married Watkins W. Reynolds, Jr., a Fort Worth rancher and businessman with whom she had two children both of whom survive her and are living in Fort Worth, Watkins W. Reynolds III and Thomas B. Reynolds. Mr. Reynolds died in 1957. After Mr. Reynolds' death, Mrs. Irwin married Carl D. Reimers, Jr., a Presbyterian Minister who was Assistant Dean of Princeton University Chapel. They had one child Carl D. Reimers III who lives in Greenwich, CT. In 1976 Jane married John N. Irwin II and was the stepmother to his children, Jane W. I. Droppa of Ellicott City, MD and John N. Irwin III of Greenwich, CT. In addition to her three children and two stepchildren, Mrs. Irwin is survived by her mother, Mrs. R. T. German of Midland, TX, 12 grandchildren, Watkins Reynolds IV, Ellen Reynolds, Thomas Reynolds, Jr., William Reynolds, Grace Reynolds, Grace Reimers, Charles Reimers, Anna Irwin, Genevieve Irwin, Jack Droppa, Daniel Droppa and Katherine Droppa. Mrs. Irwin will be remembered by her family and many friends for her wit, personal warmth and lively intelligence. The family interment will be in Fort Worth, TX on Saturday. A memorial service will be held in NY at The Brick Presbyterian Church on Friday, July 27. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: Princeton Theological Seminary or to The Girl Scout Council of Greater NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: $1 Billion Transit Plan Approved
description: The board of New Jersey Transit approved a $1.14 billion budget for its commuter rail and bus lines for 2002, up $138 million from last year. Jeffrey Warsh, executive director of the agency, said it would receive only one-third of the increase in state aid that it had requested, but it would avoid fare increases. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline in Business Day yesterday about financial results at Yahoo Inc. referred incorrectly in some copies to the quarter for which the company was reporting. It was the second quarter, not the first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, VERONICA AGNES (NEE CORKEY)
description: CARROLL-Veronica Agnes (nee Corkey). Age 93. Formerly of Woodside, N.Y. Daughter of the late Joseph and Phoebe Folke Corkey. Died on July 10, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. Carroll. Devoted mother of Patricia Baxter (John), Eileen Bronzino (Donato), PeggyAnn Klein (William) and Thomas J. Carroll. Beloved sister of the late Eleanor O'Toole (William) and the late Joseph Corkey. Loving grandmother of 14 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. Associated with Tiffany and Company for over 50 years. A memorial Mass will be held at 10:15AM on Monday, July 16, 2001 at St. Teresa's Church, 50th Avenue at 44th Street, Woodside, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Gilbert residence, 203 South Huron Street, Ypsilanti, Michigan 48197, would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Subway Passenger Dies
description: A 39-year-old man was found unconscious on the E train early yesterday and was later pronounced dead, possibly from a heart attack, the police said. The man, identified as Kevin Bland, was found at the end of the E line in Queens about 2:10 a.m. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Bush and Health Care Companies Promise Medicare Drug Discounts
description: Five big health care companies promised today to work with President Bush to help Medicare beneficiaries obtain discounts on prescription drugs through a voluntary private program starting Jan. 1. But Democrats in Congress ridiculed the president's proposal as a trivial step to solve a huge problem.

title: User Agreements and a 'Timeless Issue'
description: Finding that "the timeless issue of assent" has continuing vitality in the realm of cyberspace, a federal judge has ruled that Internet users who downloaded free software from a Web site were not bound by the terms of a software licensing agreement because they never consented to it.

title: The Chandra Levy Story
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Hardware Acquisition
description: An Australian building supplies company, Wesfarmers Ltd., will acquire a rival, Howard Smith Ltd., for 2.65 billion Australian dollars ($1.35 billion) and become the country's leading hardware retailer. Wesfarmers, which is based in Perth and owns the Bunnings hardware store chain, will get access to Howard Smith's BBC Hardware stores, which serve Sydney and other large domestic markets in the eastern part of the country.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Panel Calls for Higher Mileage Standards
description: A pivotal House panel voted tonight to require carmakers to raise the fuel economy of sport-utility vehicles and minivans, setting the stage for the first congressionally mandated increase in auto efficiency standards in a generation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVENE, RICKY
description: LEVENE-Ricky. So dearly loved, so deeply missed, so much too soon. Our constant love, Mom and your Family

title: 2 Big Projects Deregulating Vacant Units
description: After half a century as a bulwark of middle-income housing in New York City, Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village are removing their vacant apartments from rent regulation and turning them into luxury rentals.

title: 'Inbred Rednecks'
description: Directed by Joshua P. Warren

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Ex-Schools Chief Weighs Governor Bid
description: Paul Vallas, the former chief executive of the Chicago public schools, is considering running for governor of Illinois next year. Mr. Vallas, who resigned in June after overseeing the city's schools for six years, said he was meeting with Democratic Party leaders. A crowded field of Democratic candidates is likely. Gov. George Ryan, a Republican whose popularity in polls has been hurt by, among other things, a federal bribery investigation, has not said whether he will seek a second term.

title: Even Unfried, They're So Easy to Love
description: On a placid, saltwater farm in Maine, an elderly woman named Janet Bonney lovingly tended her chickens. She called them the ''girls'' and spoke with appreciation about their personality quirks.

title: Elliott Abrams's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Bribery Charge For Exile
description: The police say they have enough evidence to charge Akezhan Kazhegeldin with taking bribes and abusing his authority while he was the prime minister of Kazakhstan from 1994 to 1997, according to the Interfax news agency. Mr. Kazhegeldin lives in self-imposed exile. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Shavian Artillery Levels Hypocrisy
description: Judging by his rsum Daniel Sullivan doesn't have much interest in musicals. But as a theater director he seems to work with a baton and a tuning fork, as if a script were a score and the cast a chamber orchestra. He's interested in instrumentation. Mr. Sullivan has proven his nuanced ear in recent productions like David Auburn's ''Proof,'' Jon Robin Baitz's ''10 Unknowns'' and Donald Margulies's ''Dinner With Friends,'' ensemble works whose language creates fugues of harmony and discord rather than lyrical solos, and in Eugene O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten,'' with the howlingly painful aria of James Tyrone at its center. Mr. Sullivan's gift is for locating and sharpening the dramatic pitch of a playwright's work, as a respectful conductor would do for a composer.

title: Experiments in the Vineyard; Some Fear Modified Plants Will Hurt Sales and Mystique
description: Some of the world's most tradition-minded manufacturers are confronting one of its most modern technologies. Genetic engineering is coming to the wine business.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on July 5 described the fireworks display on the East River incompletely. The display is put on by Macy's, which hires two companies, Fireworks by Grucci and Pyro Spectaculars by Souza, to produce the display. Also, the fireworks were launched from four barges, not one.

title: Emmy Award Nominations Favor Established Hits
description: Will the mob series ''The Sopranos'' finally exact revenge on the White House drama ''The West Wing''?

description: CORN FLAN

title: Eneas -- 'Thriller'
description: Esso

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a report by Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, on abuses in the county sheriff's system erroneously rendered as a direct quotation what was in fact a paraphrase of Mr. Blumenthal's remarks. It said that most of the abuses the auditors found were unethical and could indicate criminal behavior, though very few incidents could be immediately deemed illegal.

title: Guests Drink Free
description: This one should appeal to the thirsty: the Wyndham Aruba Beach Resort and Casino has a Bed and Breakfast and Beverage rate available through Dec. 15 that includes unlimited alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages, plus breakfast. Rates for three nights start at $149 a person, based on double occupancy, and include tax and tips. Information: (800) 996-3426 or www.wyndham.com

title: Neil Farber -- New Drawings
description: Clementine Gallery

title: Second Night of Rioting Rocks Northern Ireland
description: LONDON, July 13 — Rioters went on a rampage in Northern Ireland for the second straight night, injuring more than 100 police officers and casting gloom over last-ditch high level negotiations resuming today to get Catholic and Protestant politicians to revive peace efforts.

title: Accounts
description: J.D. Edwards, Denver, a software company, is beginning a review for an agency to handle creative and media duties, after two years of working with neoBrands, Costa Mesa, Calif. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Judge Criticizes Documents In Revamping by an Insurer
description: Documents that are to go out today seeking policyholder approval of a reorganization of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company into a hybrid insurer ''may not be fraudulent,'' but they heavily accentuate the positive and gloss over the negative, a judge in Boston said this week.

title: Fire Forces Evacuations at Rainbow Room
description: A smoky fire at the Rainbow Room forced about 30 patrons to be evacuated from an adjacent restaurant 65 floors over Manhattan last evening. No injuries were reported.

title: Contradicting Ethics Ruling, Judge Orders Payment of Fees
description: A Connecticut state judge this week threw into doubt a settlement between an investment company and the State Ethics Commission, which had fined the firm for ethics violations.

title: Nuclear Testing and National Honor
description: Last weekend, The New York Times reported the latest attack by the Bush administration on a major international agreement -- the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, banning all test explosions of nuclear weapons. Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz recently raised the possibility of circumstances ''where you would have to contemplate'' nuclear testing, and an administration official told Agence France-Presse that the treaty ''has no support within the administration.'' Meanwhile, General John Gordon, head of the National Nuclear Security Administration, recently informed Congress that he is looking hard at ''improving test site readiness.''

title: Trying Time Trial for the U.S. Team
description: Protecting the yellow jersey of the Tour de France's leader, the underrated Crdit Agricole riders stunned everybody but themselves today by finishing first in a long team time trial and taking over the top three places in the race.

title: Nominee for F.B.I. Director Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 — Robert S. Mueller III, the prosecutor chosen by President Bush to be the director of the F.B.I., has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, according to a letter from Mr. Mueller's doctor that was disclosed today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Musicians, Drugs And Gil Scott-Heron
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, PEARL
description: GOLD-Pearl. On July 11, 2001. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Joan. Dear sister of Alvin and the late Edmund Preiss. Services Friday 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ATLAS AIR IS BUYING CARGO COMPANY FROM G.E. AFFILIATE
description: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings, a leading carrier of freight for other airlines, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Polar Air Cargo for $84 million to expand into Japan. Polar has routes in key international markets, including Japan, which ''we have sought to enter since Atlas Air's inception,'' Atlas said. Atlas, based in Purchase, N.Y., said it might be able to reduce the purchase cost by as much as $30 million by restructuring leases and selling some Polar aircraft and parts. The seller is an affiliate of GE Capital Aviation Services, a unit of General Electric. The acquisition comes as Atlas and Polar struggle with a drop in demand for shipping services that has led to layoffs in the last few months.

title: INSIDE
description: Fire Procedures Questioned

title: A Cleaner Jamaica Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Police Resist Wahid's Order
description: Struggling with diminishing success to assert his leadership in advance of a parliamentary impeachment session, President Abdurrahman Wahid demanded legal action against the national police chief, Gen. Suroyo Bimantoro, after he refused to step aside when the president fired him. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: United Resurrects Bid
description: At the insistence of US Airways and under an implied threat of litigation, United Airlines has reluctantly agreed to continue its proposed $4.3 billion bid to buy US Airways. The decision forces the hand of the Bush administration's Justice Department, which must take formal action if it wants to block the deal.

title: Abe Schrader, 100, a King Of Seventh Avenue Fashion
description: Abraham Schrader, a garment manufacturer who cut a wide swath in the Seventh Avenue ready-to-wear trade, died yesterday on the Abe Schrader Floor of Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 100.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Enron Net Rose 40% in Quarter
description: The Enron Corporation, an energy trader, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 40 percent as its sales of natural gas and electricity surged in the United States and Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAYNE, LORETTA (NEE SHAUGHNESSY)
description: WAYNE-Loretta (nee Shaughnessy). On July 9, 2001. Retired social worker in public service for 50 years, first on Long Island, later New York Medical College, then Bellevue Hospital Psychiatric Department. She was a loving and devoted wife to her husband, Martin Wayne, M.D., who survives her. She is also survived by her sister, Helen Ullman. She was known as Sis to her large family. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 at St. John of God Church, 84 Carlton Avenue, Central Islip, Long Island.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Office Complex Gains Approval
description: Rutherford, N.J., has approved the construction of Highland Cross, a complex of two 12-story office buildings, a 216-room Marriott SpringHill Suites hotel and two parking garages, the developer, Lincoln Equities Group, announced yesterday. The project is still subject to a decision by the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, which is waiting for the results of a traffic study, a spokeswoman for the commission said. If the $175 million project is approved, construction will begin in early 2002, said Joel Bergstein, the executive vice president of Lincoln Equities in Rutherford. The buildings would be at the junction of Routes 3 and 17. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Bowl Series Changes Formula
description: It came a year too late for Miami, but college football's Bowl Championship Series made two major changes yesterday in the way it selects teams for its annual championship game. Had those changes been in effect last season, Miami, and not Florida State, would have played Oklahoma in the title game in the Orange Bowl.

title: Corn Flan
description: The trick to making this dish -- at least the most prominent and interesting one -- is to roast the corn first. That gives it a pleasant nutty flavor, but also dries out the kernels somewhat so they will hold their shape better and retain their identity when cooked in what is essentially a cheese-topped custard.

title: Nets' Kittles Is Back, With a Healthy Knee and Outlook
description: Kerry Kittles took the floor tonight in a Nets uniform, albeit a practice uniform, lining up on the Champion Center court with rookie hopefuls and an assortment of players whose only purpose is to fill out the Nets' summer league roster.

title: Hanover Says Painting Mansion Is a Good Idea, if City Hall Helps
description: Donna Hanover, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's estranged wife, said in a statement issued yesterday that she would welcome the support of City Hall in repainting Gracie Mansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, MARSHALL
description: ABRAHAM-Marshall. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Marshall Abraham, and extends sincere sympathy to his family and friends. David S. Mack, President Michael Stein, Secretary

title: Players Must Give Back 10 Percent of Their Pay
description: The golf tournament ended Wednesday afternoon, followed by the Versace fashion show at 8 p.m. and a mandatory union meeting this morning.

title: So Nice To Have You Back Where You Belong
description: The gay romantic fantasy ''Big Eden'' takes its title from the small Montana town where the principal character, the New York artist Henry Hart (Arye Gross), was reared by his crusty but loving grandfather (George Coe). When word reaches Henry that his grandfather has suffered a stroke, he abandons his big Chelsea gallery opening and takes the next flight home.

title: Franois-Xavier Seren -- 'Noblesse Oblige . . .: Intimate Portraits of European Nobility, 1985-2000'
description: M.Y. Art Prospects

title: G.M.-DAEWOO TALKS IN FINAL STAGE, KOREAN OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Talks for the sale of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor to General Motors are in the final stage, according to Korea's finance minister, Jin Nyum. Mr. Nyum said that General Motors and its creditors, led by the government-owned Korea Development Bank, were ''trimming each other's offers.'' A spokesman for the bank denied, however, that General Motors had offered $610 million for the best Daewoo facilities while attempting not to have to buy the entire company, including an aging plant in Inchon. The two sides have been negotiating intermittently since early last month. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Ashcroft Orders U.S. Marshals To Protect an Abortion Doctor
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has ordered the United States Marshals Service to protect a doctor in Kansas who has been singled out as a subject of anti-abortion protests expected in the coming week, Justice Department officials said today.

title: Jewelry Store Owner Is Slain in Queens
description: A 51-year-old jewelry store owner was fatally shot yesterday in a robbery attempt at his shop in the Woodhaven section of Queens, the police said.

title: Seeing Red, or Not
description: Whatever happened to the budget surplus?

title: Rethinking Extras on DVD
description: As DVD spreads, some video axioms are taking a bit of adjusting. For example, in the disc's beginning it was generally held that the extra features on many DVD's would primarily interest only movie buffs. ''The average Joe who buys at Wal-Mart -- you wouldn't think they'd care,'' said Corie Tappin, senior vice president of marketing at MGM Home Entertainment. ''But according to our research, even they are interested in some of them.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar rose against the euro on optimism U.S. stock gains and better-than-expected company earnings may herald a rebound in economic growth. In New York, the euro fell to 85.34 cents, from 85.91 cents.

title: Rethinking Extras on DVD
description: As DVD spreads, some video axioms are taking a bit of adjusting. For example, in the disc's beginning it was generally held that the extra features on many DVD's would primarily interest only movie buffs. "The average Joe who buys at Wal- Mart  you wouldn't think they'd care," said Corie Tappin, senior vice president of marketing at MGM Home Entertainment. "But according to our research, even they are interested in some of them."

title: Overcome by Slavery
description: On January 1, 1863, Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation declaring slaves forever free, but the subject remains very much alive. On the big screen we have had ''Glory,'' ''Amistad,'' ''Shadrach'' and ''Beloved.'' On television, the four-part series ''Africans in America'' was followed by Henry Louis Gates Jr.'s controversial sojourn through Africa, during which he confronted African complicity in the slave trade. Such programs have come hard on the heels of new monuments and miles of freedom trails, dozens of exhibitions and the building of museums dedicated to slavery.

title: Optimistic Outlook From Microsoft Lifts Shares Sharply
description: Stock prices surged in a powerful rally yesterday, sending the Nasdaq up 5.26 percent.

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: Motorola Says It Expects Loss In 3rd Quarter
description: Motorola said yesterday that it would lose money in the third quarter and that it planned to cut 4,000 more jobs than it had previously announced. But it also told analysts that its cell phone business was beginning to rebound and that it expected to return to profitability before the end of the year.

title: After Lawsuit and 3 Trials, Louima Points to Reforms
description: Following is a transcript of Abner Louima's statement on the settlement of his civil lawsuit against the city and its main police union, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: Juniper Earnings Beat Sharply Reduced Forecasts for Quarter
description: Juniper Networks, the smaller rival of Cisco Systems in the market for Internet routers, today reported second-quarter earnings that edged past Wall Street's already diminished expectations.

title: Republicans Report Record In Donations And Cite Bush
description: As the House carried on a rancorous debate on whether to limit fund-raising by national political parties, Republican Party committees announced today that they raised record sums in the first half of the year.

title: Dow Jones Second-Quarter Profit Fell 51%
description: Second-quarter profit at Dow Jones & Company fell 51 percent because of lower advertising sales, the company said yesterday. The publisher of The Wall Street Journal said that third-quarter earnings might be less than half analysts' estimates.

title: White House Bomb Scare
description: A false alarm prompted the evacuation of parts of the White House and the Eisenhower Executive Office Building for about an hour this morning after a bomb-sniffing dog was attracted to a car parked in the driveway.

title: Capriati Takes It Easy
description: Jennifer Capriati says she has not hit a tennis ball since Justine Henin of Belgium upset her a week ago in the Wimbledon semifinals. She isn't angry or depressed, she says, just taking a little vacation.

title: Small Arms in a Big, Brutal World
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Is Selected as 2008 Host City
description: MOSCOW, July 13 -- Saying that the world's most populous country deserved to stage the world's most extravagant sporting event, the International Olympic Committee awarded the 2008 Summer Games to Beijing today.

title: She's Got Bette Davis Eyes. Or Does She?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Ruling In City Contract Talks
description: In a ruling that police and firefighters' unions hope will win them larger pay raises, a state appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling that a state board can arbitrate contract disputes involving New York City police officers and firefighters. The ruling, by a five-judge panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, takes the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association further toward its goal of having its contract dispute with the city arbitrated by the State Public Employment Relations Board rather than the city's Office of Collective Bargaining. The state board takes into account the salaries of officers and firefighters in suburban communities, which pay as much as 35 percent more than the city does. The city said it would appeal. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Teun Hocks
description: P.P.O.W.

title: Yanks Lose Knoblauch and Are Pounded Early
description: The 97-mile-an-hour fastball smashed into Chuck Knoblauch's left elbow tonight, and he did not flip his bat away casually and jog to first, as he had done on most of the other 130 occasions he has been hit by pitches in his career. Knoblauch spun away from the plate, and tilted forward, his agony obvious, and he was soon led off the field, his arm cradled in the hands of the Yankees' trainer, Gene Monahan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Down At Chip Maker
description: Europe's biggest chip maker, STMicroelectronics, said its second-quarter sales fell 15 percent from the comparable period a year ago, to $1.59 billion, and net income dropped 54 percent, to $155 million, reflecting declining demand for chips used in cellular phones. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Terrorizing Civilians in Chechnya
description: So brutal and indefensible was the rampage carried out by Russian troops in two Chechen villages earlier this month that Moscow's political and military officials in the region have openly condemned the attacks. Their criticism is amply justified. But more decisive action is needed. Leaders of the assault should be identified and prosecuted. Beyond that, President Vladimir Putin must impose professional discipline on Russian military forces.

title: A Rich Ditz Has Both Brains and the Last Laugh
description: ''Legally Blonde,'' a fluffy new fish-out-of-water, believe-in-yourself romantic comedy, includes one line that made me and some of my dyspeptic colleagues laugh giddily and helplessly. It's a throwaway bit of repartee, which I wouldn't give away even if the mildly vulgar punch line were suitable here. But then again I might, since the movie doesn't offer enough occasions for real spontaneous laughter to justify the cost of a full-price ticket.

title: Masters Who Put Thought On Paper
description: In an increasingly machine-made world, a world that inundates us with digitally generated images and messages, in which success often means enslavement to electrical devices, where photography trumps painting, music is composed by software and entirely pixilated movie stars wait in the wings, what good is looking at hand-made drawings?

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Soldiers Held On Rape Charges
description: The army said it had arrested two soldiers for raping a woman from the Tamil ethnic minority on the northern Jaffna Peninsula. The army had earlier maintained that separatist Tamil rebels had committed the crime. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Plum To Sotheby's

title: CASCADES AGREES TO BUY 2 TISSUE MILLS FROM PLAINWELL
description: Cascades Inc. has agreed to buy two tissue mills from Plainwell Inc. for $64.2 million to expand production of private-label toilet paper, napkins and facial tissue. The purchase will make Cascades, of Kingsey Falls, Quebec, one of the leading tissue producers in North America, said Suzanne Blanchet, the chief executive of the company's Perkins Papers unit, which will acquire the plants. The mills, which are in Eau Claire, Wis., and Ransom, Pa., can produce a combined 110,000 tons of tissue a year. Plainwell, based in Wilmington, Del., filed for bankruptcy protection in October. The sale requires the approval of the Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington.

title: Mr. Hastert's Debacle
description: After hours of bluster and threats, the House speaker, Dennis Hastert, resorted yesterday to the old-fashioned way of trying to kill campaign finance reform. Unable to get his way on the parliamentary ground rules for considering the Shays-Meehan bill, he simply abandoned his promise of a fair vote and yanked it from the floor. There is no telling when, or if, the speaker might allow it to come before the House again. Now the supporters of reform have no choice but to mount a loud protest against Mr. Hastert's thuggish tactics and demand immediate action next week on the bill. If the speaker refuses, lawmakers should sign a petition demanding a vote, just as they did successfully in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, C. NICHOLAS
description: POTTER-C. Nicholas. His fellow trustees and the administrative staff of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation mourn the untimely passing of a beloved colleague and wonderful friend. An engaging man of thoughtfully chosen words, all of them incisive, Nick Potter brought an informed and steady voice to the Foundation's deliberations, playing an especially crucial role on its finance committee. Introduced to the board by former trustee and chairman, Robert V. Lindsey, his colleague at J. P. Morgan & Co., Nick Potter for years shared not only his generosity of spirit but a profound understanding of the Foundation's investments. His unflagging concern for the well-being of the artists, scholars, and scientists who received fellowships spoke volumes about his values. All of us conncected with the Foundation feel fortunate to have had the privilege of knowing and working with this collegial, quietly eloquent man. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Clare, and to the members of their family. Joseph A. Rice, Chairman Board of Trustees Joel Conarroe, President Coleen Higgins-Jacob CFO and Treasurer

title: Longley Has Not Yet Made It Official, but It Looks Like the End of the Line
description: For Luc Longley, the telltale moment came Feb. 1 when Todd MacCulloch, the Philadelphia 76ers' slow-moving center, beat him on a backdoor cut for a layup.

title: AT&T Wireless shifts its big account to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide from Foote, Cone & Belding.
description: IN one of the largest changes by a big advertiser in recent memory, AT&T Wireless said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, to handle its advertising account. The move ended a three-year relationship between AT&T Wireless and Foote, Cone & Belding, now part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $400 million.

title: In the Flux of Reality Recomposed
description: AT the beginning of Alfred Leslie's ''Cedar Bar,'' the abstract painter Barnett Newman muses on the irreconcilably opposed interests of artists and the critics who analyze their work. He thinks about those who traffic in aesthetics, he says, the way a bird thinks about ornithologists. It seems at first that Mr. Leslie is offering a bird's-eye view of his subject, since Mr. Newman's wise words, gleaned from a black-and-white television interview of unspecified vintage, are followed by the image of a vaudeville mountebank spouting German-sounding gibberish translated via subtitles into the prose of Hilton Kramer, always a convenient straw man for attacks on critical arrogance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEHMHOEFER, RUTH M.
description: WEHMHOEFER-Ruth M. On July 11, 2001. Loving sister of Robert Wehmhoefer. Dear aunt of Tara Dill and Kevin Wehmhoefer. Resposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Avenue (corner Lefferts Boulevard) Richmond Hill. Service Sunday 5PM, St.Peter's Lutheran Church. Funeral Monday 10AM from church. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Visiting Saturday 2:30-5 and 7-9:30PM and Sunday, 10AM-2PM; 4PM-5PM St. Peter's Lutheran Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 105 Highland Place, Brooklyn, NY 11208, would be appreciated.

title: Residential Real Estate; A Building for Families With Low Incomes: It Took Perseverance
description: Perseverance, a six-story, 30-apartment building for very low-income residents on the Lower East Side, officially opened this week, a little more than a year after the leader of the nonprofit group that sponsored the building seized on the name during an airline flight.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWERS, MARCIA (PERGAMENT)
description: POWERS-Marcia (Pergament). Devoted mother of Garry and Mel; loving mother-in-law of Michael and Mary; cherished grandmother of Alicia and Paul, Holly, Lauren, Melissa and Dr. Michael Levine, and great-grandmother of Benjamin. Still sadly missed and remembered with great love and affection

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Rochelle: Body Found In Parking Lot
description: The decomposed body of a woman was found in a car at a Stop & Shop parking lot, the police said yesterday. The body was discovered Wednesday inside an Oldsmobile. A police officer said the woman could have been dead for two months. The discovery came two months after an Ansonia, Conn., woman named Maria Viglione disappeared. She was last seen driving an Oldsmobile. The police would not say whether they thought the body was her remains. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: The Next Microsoft Windows
description: With the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia affirming last month that Microsoft is a monopolist that has violated the nation's antitrust laws, the company by all logic should rein in its ambitions for the next version of its Windows operating system. Its competitors now have the upper hand legally to insist on it, and the Bush administration must do the same in any settlement talks with the software giant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, BERNARD D.
description: FISCHMAN-Bernard D. Age 86. On July 11, 2001. Adored husband of Hilda. Devoted & loving father of Judith (Harmer) and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Jesse, Joanna and Eliza. Brother of the late Ruth Rackman and Mervyn Fischman. Funeral service Friday, July 13th, 11 AM at The Riverside Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights, 333 7th Ave, 13th Floor, New York, New York 10001-5004.

title: Calling for Modest Rents In Trade for Tax Breaks
description: Thousands of tenants of the Waterside Plaza housing complex would be spared from having their rents raised suddenly to market levels under an agreement in principle reached earlier this month with the landlord. The owner, Richard Ravitch, would get a multimillion-dollar tax break for agreeing to more modest annual increases.

title: Running Rings Around the Competition
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Cows vs. Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANINGA, DILSUKH, M.D.
description: RANINGA-Dilsukh, M.D. The staff of the New York-Presbyterian Healthcare System acknowledges with sadness the passing of Dilsukh Raninga, MD, Chief of Cardiology at Community Hospital of Brooklyn. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Arthur A. Klein, MD, Sr. VP and Chief Operating Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, GERTRUDE
description: WEISS-Gertrude. On July 11, 2001. Beloved wife and indispensable business partner of the late Max Weiss. Loving step-mother and adoring aunt. Funeral services will be held Sunday, July 15, 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: An Uncertain Cure For the Bleak Side Of Niagara Falls; Plan to Introduce Gambling Evokes Hope and Skepticism
description: From Prospect Point, next to the giant cascade of white water, the lit-up Canadian skyline sparkles with new luxury hotels. A white tower emblazoned with the word ''casino'' in red taunts this side of the border.

title: The New Laws of Nations
description: As economic interconnections increase among countries around the world, critics protest that this globalization is eroding the ability of governments to protect the interests of their citizens against those of multinational corporations. But the European Commission's recent blocking of the proposed merger of two American companies, General Electric and Honeywell, suggests otherwise. Since the merged company would have operated on both sides of the Atlantic, the merger hinged on the consent of not just one but two sets of regulators, each with its own legal tradition and its own interpretation of the public interest. And despite public relations campaigns by both companies, attempts at personal persuasion by G.E.'s formidable outgoing chief executive, Jack Welch, and the threat of retaliation by Congress, the European antitrust authorities rejected this merger, which had easily won approval from the United States Justice Department.

title: From Beachside Mansions to Cold Jail
description: Vladimiro L. Montesinos, the former spy chief who dominated Peru from the shadows for a decade and lived a life gilded with beachside mansions and diamond-crusted watches, is now spending his nights on a skimpy foam mattress over a cold slab of concrete.

title: Lindsay Findlay, 65, Art Gallery President
description: Lindsay Findlay, president of the David Findlay Galleries in Manhattan, was found dead on July 5 at her home in Manhattan. She was 65.

title: Policy of Jailing Protesters On Minor Crimes Is Revoked
description: Facing two civil rights lawsuits, the New York Police Department yesterday rescinded a two-year-old policy under which people arrested for minor offenses at protests were jailed overnight rather than given summonses to appear in court later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, BERNARD D.
description: FISCHMAN-Bernard D. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, L.L.P., mourns with sorrow the July 11, 2001 passing of our beloved counsel and sage, Bernard D. Fischman. Known to all as Bernie, he was an extremely dedicated attorney, and at the time of his death was still active on behalf of many of his clients. Bernie joined LeBoeuf in 1994 as counsel, and his career as a lawyer spanned more than 64 years. Bernie was a truly altruistic human being, always looking for and finding ways to help everyone with whom he came in contact. He will be missed by all who knew him. We extend deepest condolences to his wife, Hilda, their children, Judith and Robert, and their grandchildren, Jesse, Joanna and Eliza.

title: Planting a Fatal Delusion In the Mind of a Declarer
description: Courtesy, civility and friendliness are of great importance to the bridge community but are seldom discussed. Among the top players, who should set an example, many behave with perfect correctness but unfortunately a few do not.

title: Misguided Sanctions
description: Next week the White House and Congress will consider whether the United States should punish foreign companies that do business with Cuba, Iran and Libya. Laws already prohibit American businesses from trading with these countries, but the Helms-Burton Act and the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act, both passed in 1996, go even further. They try to haul foreign companies into American courts and bar the companies' executives from entering the United States. These laws only irritate American allies. President Bush and the House Financial Services Committee should act to neutralize the laws and seek other ways to promote democratic change in partnership with other nations.

title: Fighting Wildfires and the Lessons of Experience
description: Until the investigation is finished, no one will really know what happened during the tragic Thirty Mile Fire Tuesday in the Cascade Mountains. But as someone who worked fighting forest fires for 34 years, what strikes me is the role that a lack of experience may have played.

title: Man Gets 3-Year Term for Dog's Death
description: A man who threw a small dog to its death in a fit of road rage was sentenced today to three years in prison, the maximum penalty for felony animal cruelty.

title: Call More Strikes, Umpires Are Told
description: The borders of this season's strike zone seem to be causing more conflict between the umpires and Major League Baseball officials than between umpires and players.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Foreign Minister Shimon Peres's views on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict misstated the extent of recent violence by Palestinians. There had in fact been a fatal attack by Palestinians on an Israeli in the previous several days; an Israeli officer died after a bomb exploded under his vehicle on Sunday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Moth, a loosely organized company that holds storytelling shows at bars and cafes, misstated the birthplace of the writer Frank McCourt, who participated in a show on the theme ''Going Home.'' He was born in Brooklyn, not Ireland.

title: A Summit Meeting of Old Foes: India and Pakistan
description: In the more than two years since India and Pakistan fought a brutal little war in the frigid, lifeless reaches of the Himalayas, the leaders of the two nuclear-armed foes have not sat down to talk about how to live in peace.

title: Free Throws Give Liberty A Hard-Fought Victory
description: After last night's game, Liberty Coach Richie Adubato walked down the hallway outside the visitors' locker room at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRADER, ABE
description: SCHRADER-Abe. We are saddened by the loss of our dear friend & neighbor, Abe Schrader. Abe showed all of us how to live life to its fullest. We extend condolences to his sons, Steven and Morton. Arthur Sarnoff, President Kenilworth Apts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, ANNETTE
description: BLOCH-Annette. On July 12, 2001 in her 95th year. Loving mother of Judy Ringel. Cherished grandmother of Jill and Jennifer and her husband Luciano. Devoted friend of Herb Behrens and caring companions ''Ragane'', Josie and Patricia. Longtime dedicated teacher and supervisor in the NYC public schools. Positive, strong, young in mind and outlook. Graveside service Sunday 10AM Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: INSURANCE.COM STARTS SELLING ONLINE AUTO COVERAGE
description: Insurance.com, a unit of Fidelity Investments, began offering streamlined Internet sales of auto insurance in two states, Florida and Georgia, yesterday. Instead of the four or five days that it has taken to close an Internet deal, Louis Geremia, the president of Insurance.com said drivers can get coverage through his system in a few hours. Customers begin by answering more than 50 questions about themselves and their driving history. The computer responds with a price for coverage from five companies: Progressive, Liberty Mutual, Travelers, the Hartford and Allmerica Financial. The customer chooses one and receives a phone number to dial to close the transaction. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Lincoln Center Festival 2001 events in Weekend yesterday included two performance dates erroneously. There is no performance of ''Edda: Viking Tales of Lust, Revenge and Family'' tonight at 8 at the John Jay College Theater, and no performance of the opera ''Luci Mie Traditrici'' tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. at the La Guardia Drama Theater.

title: Beijing Wins Bid for 2008 Olympic Games
description: Saying that the world's most populous country deserved to stage the world's most extravagant sporting event, the International Olympic Committee awarded the 2008 Summer Games to Beijing today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's good for China even if it's bad for me.''

title: Stay on Guard Against Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Supports Torricelli With More Than Words
description: In the weeks since the Democrats regained control of the United States Senate, Senator Robert G. Torricelli has received more than just words of support from his Democratic colleagues. He has been given tens of thousands of dollars to pay legal bills as he defends himself in a criminal investigation by federal prosecutors.

title: Woman Struck by Car Dies
description: A pregnant woman was killed yesterday in what the police said was a hit and run at Columbus Avenue and West 100th Street in Manhattan.

title: Morris H. Bergreen, 83; Led Philanthropic Group
description: Morris H. Bergreen, a lawyer, businessman and administrator who as president of the Skirball Foundation oversaw the donation of millions of dollars to New York University, the Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles and other recipients, died on Monday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Captain, Once a Scapegoat, Is Absolved
description: Fifty-six years after the sinking of the cruiser Indianapolis in one of the most horrific events in American naval history, the ship's captain has won a measure of vindication.

title: Man Is Guilty In Bomb Plot At Millennium
description: An Algerian-born shopkeeper was convicted in federal court yesterday of conspiring to provide support for a plan by an Algerian terrorist to enter the United States from Canada and set off a bomb at Los Angeles International Airport in December 1999.

title: Sports of The Times; The Sticky Wicket of Caddies and Carts
description: EITHER P. G. Wodehouse, the humorist, or Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court justice, I felt certain, wrote about this incident involving a caddie: ''Mitchell addressed his ball. He swung up, and then, from immediately behind him came a sudden sharp crunching sound. I looked quickly in the direction whence it came. Mitchell's caddie, with a glassy look in his eyes, was gnawing a large apple. Even as I breathed a silent prayer, down came the driver and the ball, with a terrible slice on it, hit the side of the hill and bounded into the ravine.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MURPHY, NEIL J.
description: MURPHY-Neil J. 5/16/51-7/14/00. Dearest son, we will always miss you. You are in our hearts and prayers. You were the Marine's son, Semper Fi. Love Mom, Dad

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Campaign Bill: A Bitter Aftertaste
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, DAVID NOYES
description: JACKSON-David Noyes. Who, with his companion, the late poet James Merrill, resided in Key West for nearly 25 years, passed away peacefully in his sleep at his home in the early morning of July 13, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Doris Sewell Jackson. A remembrance of his life will be scheduled later in the year.

title: Russia Negotiating to Help Impoverished Nation With Reactor Project : Burma Seeks Nuclear Research Plant
description: RANGOON  In a bid to join the world's atomic nations, Burma is negotiating to build a nuclear reactor with Russian financial and technical help.

title: YankeeNets Eyes Ex-Cable Official
description: Leo J. Hindery, a former cable television executive, is the leading candidate to run the Yankees' proposed TV network and to be an investor, an executive involved in the negotiations said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALK, SUE ROSENBERG
description: ZALK-Sue Rosenberg, age 56, of NYC. Passed away July 11th while visiting in Florida. Sue was Vice President of Student Services, Graduate School, CUNY. She is survived by her father, Dr. Samuel Rosenberg; husband, Richard Zalk; partner, Joel Lyons; sister, Frances (Richard) Tesser; brother, Dr. George (Jessica) Rosenberg. A memorial service will be held in NYC at a later time. For more information, please call Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Campaign Bill: A Bitter Aftertaste
description: To the Editor:

title: A Suite That Softly Evokes The Venice of Henry James
description: Salvatore Sciarrino's reductive style was taken up by the New Juilliard Ensemble on Wednesday night. As his opera ''Luci Mie Traditrici'' took a night off from its run at the La Guardia Drama Theater down the street, two pieces -- the Piano Sonata No. 2 and the ''Aspern Suite'' -- were giving listeners at Paul Recital Hall a less visual kind of theater. The Italian composer, who is in town for both events, is a major constituent of the current Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Of Democrats, Vallone Has Most Cash Left
description: He may not be the leader in collecting donations, or in recent polls. But the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, will have more money to spend on his mayoral campaign between now and the Sept. 11 primary than any of his Democratic opponents, according to estimates provided yesterday by the candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  URBANO, ARMAND P., D.D.S.
description: URBANO-Armand P., D.D.S. July 14, 1916-June 21, 1993. Daddy would be 85 today. We miss you so much. Jeanette, Georgia and Richard Paula, Natalie, Julia and Petey

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOTMAN, PAUL FREUD
description: WOTMAN-Paul Freud. Darling Paul, today is your 50th birthday, as long as we live, you shall live in our hearts, minds and deeds. Mom, Dad and brother

title: Unexpected Priority: Stem Cell Research's Rise as a Test for Bush
description: The debate about research on embryonic stem cells has traveled in just a month's time from relative obscurity to magazine-cover ubiquity, and, many political analysts and lawmakers say it has become a defining issue of President Bush's first year in office.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Foreign Minister Shimon Peres's views on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict misstated the extent of recent violence by Palestinians. There had in fact been a fatal attack by Palestinians on an Israeli in the previous several days; an Israeli officer died after a bomb exploded under his vehicle on Sunday night.

title: Left at the Altar; Jilted Merger Partners Increasingly Turn to the Courts
description: When a big merger broke down in years past, as they often did, the last thing corporate managers wanted was costly, distracting, time-consuming, risky litigation.

title: Cows vs. Dogs; Dictating Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAGNER, NORMAN WILLIAM
description: WAGNER-Norman William. Dear Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Love, Your Family

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the baseball series between the Staten Island Yankees and the Brooklyn Cyclones misstated the teams' won-lost records. The Yankees were 14-7 and the Cyclones were 15-8 after their victories Thursday night, not before them.

title: Pardon, What Did You Say? A Cleansing Blast of Noise
description: Ian Astbury declared himself a punk rocker during the Cult's eardrum-threatening show at Roseland Wednesday, although for the most part he didn't behave like one. The singer is very dedicated to the notion of rock as a purifying force, and since punk was a giant dose of ipecac, his desire to align himself with it made sense.

title: Farmland Battle Tests South African Leaders
