description: As the demolition of illegal shacks continued today, some businessmen, white farmers and politicians praised South Africa's resolve.

title: Companies on Long Island Pledge To Help Employees Buy Homes
description: Eight companies on Long Island recently signed on to a program intended to help their employees buy homes near their work places, the Long Island Housing Partnership and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced today.

title: You'll Be Looking Live At Some Morning Events
description: The choice of Beijing to be the host city for the 2008 Summer Olympics might initially appear to give NBC the time zone problem it had last year in Sydney when 15 hours separated Australia from the Eastern time zone of the United States. NBC showed only one Olympic event live in prime time.

title: A Fund Manager Who Had It Right on Energy Stocks
description: Near the end of a life cut short at 61 by Lou Gehrig's disease, Stephen C. Johnes made an investing bet that struck many as foolhardy. Mr. Johnes, the Merrill Lynch manager of what was one of the biggest and most successful mutual funds around, argued that demand for energy, especially for natural gas, would soon soar.

title: Troubled Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERWIN, SYLVIA NEWBURY
description: MERWIN-Sylvia Newbury, 72, died July 12 in Charlestown, R.I. Mother of Jay G., Jr. and Jeffrey V. of Baltimore and Alexander N. of Reading, PA. Grandmother of nine. Memorial service July 15, 2PM at Stanwich Congregational Church, Greenwich, CT.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Anger At U.S. 'Slavery' Report
description: Saying a State Department report that accused South Korea of ignoring trafficking in women ''negatively depicts our country without sufficient analysis,'' the Foreign Ministry urged Washington ''to make immediate changes so the report can reflect conditions accurately.'' The report listed 23 countries that the State Department said did not meet minimum standards for trying to stop the trafficking in people, mostly women and children exploited as prostitutes or put into low-paying jobs by abusive employers. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Editors' Note
description: COMING ON SUNDAY

title: Religion Journal; A Unique Portrait of Jesus by Jefferson
description: Thanks to the publication of new biographies, John Adams is enjoying a great renaissance, 175 years after his death. It has reached the point that some historians even caution that enthusiasm for Adams, the nation's second president, shouldn't be allowed to diminish respect accorded his successor, Thomas Jefferson.

title: Mixed Results When Wealth Is an Issue
description: When millionaires or billionaires have run for public office -- as has happened with increasing frequency in recent years -- the candidates have often been shy about releasing details of the depth and breadth of their wealth.

title: Campaign Bill: A Bitter Aftertaste
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicare's Drug Problem
description: For once, Congress and President Bush can agree: Medicare needs an outpatient prescription drug benefit. The federal program, begun in 1965, comes from an era when drug therapies were fewer and not as widely applied as they are today. This week Mr. Bush offered the most minimal way to follow through on his campaign promise of immediate relief for the elderly. His action makes Congress's task -- instituting a permanent benefit -- all the more urgent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Asset Sales
description: The Italian government will speed the sale of stakes it owns in companies, including its remaining 2.2 billion euro ($1.87 billion) holding in Telecom Italia, to lower debt and cut interest payments. Italy will try to sell its 3.95 percent of Telecom Italia this year, as well as stakes in Enel, the country's dominant power utility, and Eni, Europe's fourth-largest oil company, the deputy economy minister, Mario Baldassarri, said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP., Plano, Tex., said it received a 15-year, $469 million contract from Franklin Covey Co., Salt Lake City, to provide customer relationship management and I.T. services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, DOROTHY STRASSBURGER (NEE LAMB)
description: REYNOLDS-Dorothy Strassburger (nee Lamb). Born in Buffalo, N.Y. on November 18, 1913. Died at home on July 12, 2001 of congestive heart failure. Her parents were J. Walter Lamb and Mabel Halberstadt Lamb. She received a BA degree from Hunter College and a Master of Arts degree from Columbia University. She is survived by her husband W. Arnold Reynolds, her children Raymond L. Strassburger, Lynn Strassburger Brady and Walter A. Reynolds III, Richard E. Reynolds and Marjory Reynolds Rode, as well as numerous grandchildren. Her first husband Dr. Raymond C. Strassburger died in January, 1968. Visiting hours will be at the Whalen & Ball Funeral Home on Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial in Christ the King Church on Monday, July 16 at 11AM. Whalen & Ball 168 Park Avenue, Yonkers, 914-965-5488.

title: Panel Says Steel Imports Undercut U.S. Companies
description: A United States trade panel said today that unfairly priced imports of steel used in construction from China, South Korea and three other nations were hurting American companies, setting the stage for punitive tariffs of up to 232 percent.

title: Manhattan Journal; Camera Owners Mourn a Departed Repair Shop
description: There was genuine sadness on both sides of the sales counter as the camera repairman, Herb Zimmerman, and the woman who wanted her camera repaired, Donna Janis, realized that their meeting was going to be futile.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about the Emmy Award nominations referred incorrectly to the status of Allison Janney, who plays the president's press secretary in ''The West Wing.'' She was indeed nominated this year -- for best supporting actress in a drama series; she was not absent from the list. The article also misstated the category in which Ms. Janney won an Emmy last year. It was best supporting actress in a drama series, not best dramatic actress.

title: Corrections
description: The Floyd Norris column in Business Day yesterday, about financial troubles at Corning Inc., misidentified a $2 billion security issued by the company. It is a convertible bond that might have to be repaid in 2005, not a convertible preferred that might have to be paid off in 2004.

title: Louima Case One Factor In Changes For the Police
description: The 1997 station house torture of Abner Louima played a pivotal role in prompting New York City to confront the question of excessive force used by its police officers. But it was not the only thing.

title: How Bush Took Florida: Mining the Overseas Absentee Vote (cont.)
description: Devising a Complex Approach to Challenging Ballots

title: Pataki Campaign Raised $9 Million Over Six Months
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is already raising money at a ferocious pace for his re-election, collecting almost $9 million in the last six months, his campaign said today, far more than his two Democratic rivals combined.

title: U.S. Trust Is Fined $10 Million in Bank Secrecy-Law Case
description: Federal and New York regulators ordered the U.S. Trust Corporation yesterday to pay $10 million in fines to settle accusations that it violated bank secrecy laws and failed to keep complete records in a special trading unit.

title: Environmental and Transportation Improvements Could Send Price Soaring
description: Now that Beijing has won its long-coveted Olympics, it must confront the costs of staging the Games. The real numbers may never be fully disclosed, but the vote today by the International Olympic Committee is likely to be remembered more as a political victory than as an economic windfall.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: The Politics Of Dog Food
description: The head of the United Nations ''oil for food'' program in Iraq has done some unusual accounting. Benon Sevan, angry at Iraqi accusations two weeks ago that the organization's mine-sniffer dogs eat better than Iraqi people, told the sanctions committee that feeding each dog, on imported dog food and chicken and animal fats, cost $408 a year, not $1,248, as an Iraqi minister told the Security Council last month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. On your birthday & indeed every day the precious and wonderful memories linger on. Love, Harry

title: Sirince Journal; Will Success Spoil a Historic Village?
description: Sevan Nisanyan, a feisty intellectual with a talent for trouble, stopped and turned to face the bulky village woman who had hailed him from the step of her house.

title: Campaign Bill's Allies Vow to Return Issue to House
description: A day after the drive to overhaul the nation's campaign finance law collapsed in bitter recriminations, its supporters vowed today to bring the issue back to the House floor even if it required further confrontation with the Republican leadership.

title: HONEYWELL CONSOLIDATING SOME DIVISIONS
description: Honeywell International will consolidate operations into four units, as the chief executive Lawrence Bossidy moves to reduce costs after General Electric's planned purchase of Honeywell collapsed. A spokesman, Tom Crane, said eight existing divisions would be consolidated into four: aerospace; automation and controls; specialty materials; and transportation and power units. In addition, the chief operating officer, Giannantonio Ferrari, 61, will retire immediately, Mr. Crane said. The realignment may be a precursor to breaking up the company, based in Morris Township, N.J., and selling the parts, analysts said.

title: 4th Guilty Plea In Investigation Of Corruption
description: An asbestos removal contractor pleaded guilty today to a single charge of mail fraud, saying he had defrauded this city of nearly $80,000 by inflating fees for his services. The contractor, Brian Bannon, 34, of Milford, was the fourth person to plead guilty in connection with a continuing federal investigation into municipal corruption in Bridgeport.

title: Glittering Bits and Pieces, Hobbling, Frisky or Fishy
description: Dances whizzed by in ''What Limbs May Come,'' the program of short works the Notario Dance Company offered on Wednesday night at the Kitchen as a benefit for the Breast Examination Center of Harlem. The choreography of Brook Notary, the troupe's director, abounded with ingenious effects, and some of the dances were enhanced by live music.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Complaints About Workplace Forums
description: Three Democratic senators wrote to Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao to voice concerns that three forums she is holding on workplace injuries will not include speakers from several major health care organizations and dozens of people who had suffered from work-related ergonomics injuries. The senators, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, called on Ms. Chao to include the witnesses at the forums, which begin on Monday. Labor Department officials said Ms. Chao wanted to have a wide variety of witnesses so she would hear all views. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Being the Host Keeps the Pressure on China
description: There is a place in sports for politically inspired boycotts and exclusion. It is extremely limited, but it exists.

title: No Alfresco Handel, but a Smiling Oboe
description: Holding a concert outdoors is liberating; moving the same concert back indoors is like retranslating from a foreign language back into the original. A bit of ease is lost along the way. But because of an untimely shower, the Washington Square Summer Music Festival gamely moved its opening concert on Tuesday night into the dark Frederick Lowe Theater on West Fourth Street, where the air-conditioner did its best to evoke the lost ambience with buffeting gusts of cold air and a steady whirring sound not unlike rain on a roof or the surface noise on a 78-r.p.m. recording.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Ex-Governor's Son Joins Race
description: Tim James, left, the son of former Gov. Fob James, said he would seek the Republican nomination for governor next year. Mr. James, a former Greenville businessman, has never run for public office. His father was first elected as a Democrat in 1978 and then ran successfully as a Republican in 1994; he lost his 1998 re-election bid to the current governor, Donald Siegelman, a Democrat who is planning to run again. Mr. James is likely to face several primary opponents, including Representative Bob Riley and Lt. Gov. Steve Windom. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Ex-Congressman Fights the Hand That Overfeeds Him
description: THE picture window in the little cottage with gray shingle siding offers a spectacular view of the rich blue waters of Buzzard's Bay on the western side of Cape Cod. But the man of the house, former Representative Hastings Keith, sits with his back to this serene scene as he works on his one cause: saving America from overly rich COLA's.

title: Ulster Talks Resume, but Riots Dim Hopes
description: Last-ditch high-level talks on Northern Ireland were to continue today in an atmosphere of tension and gloom after rioting in the province left more than 100 police officers injured and hope for peacemaking by the province's Roman Catholic and Protestant politicians fading.

title: UNITED AIRLINES WINS A CASE IN TAX COURT
description: The United States Tax Court overturned a $111 million tax bill from the 1980's for United Airlines, saying the airline was entitled to deduct fringe benefits paid to pilots and flight attendants. The tax court ruled 10 to 3 that the airline was entitled to take the deduction for paying a per diem, worth $36 a day, to the 12,000 flight attendants and 6,150 pilots who worked for the airline at the time. The ruling affects tax years 1983, 1984, 1986, and 1987. The Internal Revenue Service argued the per diem was limited to $14 a day and said the airline was not entitled to deduct anything over that because the payments were not explicitly described compensation. The airline is awaiting another decision in the dispute from the United States Court of Federal Claims, where the I.R.S. argued that United's parent, UAL, must pay employment taxes on the money.

title: Campaign Bill: A Bitter Aftertaste
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Insurance Office
description: In another sign of American enthusiasm for the insurance business in China, the GAB Robins Group of Companies of Parsippany, N.J., which specializes in managing and adjusting insurance claims, has opened a representative office in Beijing. GAB works with insurance companies in processing claims. Joseph Zubretsky, chief executive of GAB Robins, said the company hoped to capitalize on an expected annual growth in insurance in China of 40 percent a year as foreign investment and international trade grow there. About a dozen American and other foreign insurers are now doing business in China and several dozen other foreign insurers have been allowed to open representatives offices, like the one GAB Robins opened on June 8, in hopes of eventually receiving an operating license. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: State Primaries Closed
description: Gov. Tony Knowles allowed a bill that would create closed primary elections to become law without his signature. Most Alaskans are nonpartisan or undeclared voters, a spokesman for the Democratic governor said, but the bill followed a United States Supreme Court decision invalidating open primaries in states where political parties objected to them. Closed primaries permit only registered party members to vote, and only in their own party's primary. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Rates Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan's policy board decided unanimously to hold monetary policy steady, resisting government pressure for further monetary easing. While the bank had been widely expected to keep its policy unchanged, pressure to increase outright purchases of bonds or introduce other monetary easing may mount as the government goes ahead with a program for structural reform that could bankrupt many concerns and put hundreds of thousands out of work. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: U.S. Opposition to Tribunal Worries European Supporters
description: The European Union, whose 15 members support a permanent International Criminal Court, fears that the Bush administration's active opposition could undermine a campaign to get enough ratifications over the next year to get the tribunal up and running, diplomats say.

title: A Month After Court Victory, Immigrant Is Let Out of Prison
description: Enrico St. Cyr, the Haitian immigrant whose victory before the United States Supreme Court last month changed the fate of thousands of legal immigrants facing deportation proceedings, has been released from prison.

title: Time Inc. Says It Is in Talks To Acquire British Publisher
description: Time Inc., the magazine arm of AOL Time Warner, is in talks to buy IPC Media, a British magazine publisher, the companies confirmed today.

title: Two Are Charged in Money-Laundering Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn announced money-laundering conspiracy charges yesterday against a man they identified as the former acting boss of the Genovese crime family.

title: Rainbow Room Fire Deemed 'Suspicious'
description: Afire at the Rainbow Room on Thursday night that forced the evacuation of an adjacent restaurant has been deemed suspicious, fire officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Gold Project
description: Placer Dome, a leading gold mining company, said it would sell its interest in a company developing Venezuela's largest gold deposits to Vannessa Ventures. Terms were not released. The sale came just hours after Venezuela said it had dropped Placer Dome from the project, which was to develop the Las Cristinas tract in Venezuela's southeastern state of Bolvar. Placer Dome, based in Vancouver, said it would retain an interest in the gold and copper revenues generated by Las Cristinas.

title: How 'White Raven' Echoes 'Einstein' but Breaks Its Own New Ground
description: In the middle of the classic operatic work ''Einstein on the Beach'' (1976), a moment of high drama occurs when, against a field of darkness, a horizontal fluorescent rod slowly rotates into a vertical shaft of light. The churning intensity of Philip Glass's Minimalist patter and the simplicity of Robert Wilson's design -- the sense of stasis in sound and sight -- turn every angle change into an event as pungent as an unexpected harmonic modulation.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in World Business yesterday about an International Monetary Fund representative in the Middle East referred incorrectly to the Palestinian governing body in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. It is the Palestinian Authority, not ''Palestine.''

title: U.S. and 18 States Agree To Accept Microsoft Ruling
description: The federal government and 18 states said today that they would not appeal the recent decision by a federal appeals court in the Microsoft antitrust case that reversed an order to break up the company, and they asked instead that the court accelerate the remaining proceedings.

title: Soul-Shaking Power Of a Cuban Wonder
description: A ''drama with music'' is the way the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater bills ''La Lupe: My Life, My Destiny.'' But for the audience the experience is a concert by an infectiously passionate singer whose gift for comic innovation is unpredictable and dangerous -- with occasional dialogue laced in to supply a narrative theme.

title: Mideast Bottom Line
description: To the Editor:

title: State Rethinks Deal to Provide Extended Welfare via A.T.M.
description: Pataki administration officials have withdrawn a proposed $30 million contract with Citigroup to produce a network of special debit cards for the state's poorest families. The cards were to usher in a virtually cashless world for people who reached their five-year lifetime limit on federal welfare; instead of cash, they would spend state aid electronically at stores across New York.

title: How Bush Took Florida: Mining the Overseas Absentee Vote (cont.)
description: Devising a Complex Approach to Challenging Ballots

title: At Home Abroad; Homage To Balanchine
description: George Balanchine left his home in Russia at the age of 20, in 1924, escaping the Stalinist repression that would surely have crushed him as it crushed (or destroyed) so many other creative geniuses. He did not return until 1962, when he brought his great company, the New York City Ballet, to Russia.

title: Stay on Guard Against Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Never Told Jeter There'd Be Games Like This
description: A fine rendition of the Bronx cheer has been transplanted here, and when Derek Jeter squeezed an easy pop-up in the fifth inning tonight, the crowd let him have it. The fans roared facetiously, an unsubtle reminder of all the mistakes he had made. Jeter touched the bill of his cap in acknowledgment and grinned at his own expense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, C. NICHOLAS
description: POTTER-C. Nicholas. Of Mill Neck, NY died peacefully at home on July 10th after a courageous battle with cancer. He was 62 years old. Loving and devoted husband of Clare; proud father of Cary Nicholas Jr. & his wife Alison, Christopher Kingsland & Jennifer; grandfather of Macy Lockheart, Nina Webb and Nicholas Alonzo; son of Julia M. Thompson; and brother of Charles, Dickie and Frances Thieriot. Until his retirement in 1997, Mr. Potter was a Senior Executive at J.P. Morgan & Co. A graduate of Yale University, he joined Morgan in 1965 after destroyer service in the U.S. Navy. Over the course of his 32-year career, he held a variety of senior positions with Morgan, all in the investment management area. In 1974 he started the firm's international investment management business in London putting Morgan at the forefront of one of the world's most rapidly growing financial services businesses. In 1984, he was appointed President and Chief Executive of J.P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. with overall responsibility for investment management. Under his leadership, J.P. Morgan became one of the largest and most successful global investment managers in the world. Mr. Potter was a director of Phoenix House, a trustee of The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation and a trustee of The Hospital for Special Surgery. From 1981 to 1997, when it merged with American Reinsurance Company, he was a director, Chairman of the Finance Committee and member of the Executive Committee of Munich American Reinsurance Company. From 1985 to 1996, he served as a trustee of St. Mark's School, Southborough, Massachusetts. Services will be held on Monday, July 16, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church in Locust Valley, L.I. at 11:30AM. Memorial contributions may be made to Phoenix House Development Fund, 164 W 74th St, NY, NY 10023.

title: A Small Victory That Could Mean Defeat
description: Those who want to rewrite the nation's campaign finance laws won a battle on Thursday, but may have lost the war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCELLINO, FRED
description: MARCELLINO-Fred. July 12, 2001. Husband of Jean. Father of Nico and his wife Elizabeth. Brother of Marie Marcellino Allen. He was a noted illustrator and author of children's books after an illustrious career as both a book jacket and record album cover designer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday, July 16, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service on Tuesday, July 17, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYU Medical Center, Deptartment of Oncology, or the Cabrini Hospice. In tribute to Fred's love of gardening, flowers are welcomed and appreciated.

title: Again, Many Empty Seats In Summer School Classes
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy revealed yesterday that only about 55 percent of high school students and 76 percent of elementary and middle school students ordered to attend summer school have reported to class.

title: American Cities Upbeat After Toronto's Loss
description: The selection yesterday of Beijing to stage the 2008 Olympic Games was greeted warmly by American cities trying to become the Olympic host in 2012.

title: Aspen's Hotel Jerome
description: One suggestion on overcoming summer's heat: start thinking about Aspen, Colo., in the fall. The Hotel Jerome, a 92-room resort listed in the National Register of Historic Places, makes it easy to think ahead. From Sept. 2 to Oct. 14, it is offering rooms for $95 a night Sunday through Wednesday. And from Oct. 15 to Nov. 15, the $95 rate is good all week. But it is subject to availability. Call (800) 331-7213 or visit www.hoteljerome.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, THE REVEREND PROTOPRESBYTER BASIL S
description: GREGORY-The Reverend Protopresbyter Basil S, a priest of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese and President of Latsis U.S.A. Inc/ SETE Consultants & Services (USA) Inc, reposed on July 12 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Father Basil was a priest for over five decades, serving Greek Orthodox Communities in Scranton, Chicago, Pittsburgh, Brooklyn and Manhattan, where he served St. George Tropsoforos Church for 25 years until his retirement in 1998. From 1964 to 1970, he was the Director of Economic Development of the Greek Orthdox Archdiocese, and later served as the Director of the Office of Press and Information. In addition to his ecclesiastical service, in 1970, he established the U.S. office of the Greek shipping magnate, John S. Latsis, where he served as its president until his passing. He was a 1948 graduate of Holy Cross Greek Orthodox School of Theology in Brookline, MA, and in 1964 earned an MBA from the University of Pittsburgh. He had served on the Boards of the St Michael's Home for the Aged(in Yonkers), Atlantic Bank of New York, the Manhattan School of Music, the American Symphony Orchestra, Hellenic American Chamber of Commerce, and was the President of the American Associates of the St Catherine Foundation(the trust for the conservation of the Library at the St Catherine Monastery in the Sinai Desert). He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Anne, his children Andre and Maria, and Nicholas and Athena and his grandchildren Christina, Marianna, Alexander, Anastasia and Vasiliki. Visiting hours will commence Sunday at 4PM at St George Greek Orthodox Church, 307 West 54 Street. Funeral Monday. Liturgy will commence at 9:30AM at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East 74 St, NYC. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to New York Hospital Pediatric Hematology/Oncology, 525 East 69th St, Room P695, NY, NY 10021. The American Associates of the St Catherine Foundation, 712 Fifth Ave, Suite 9-D, NY, NY 10019.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Infineon Raises Cash
description: Infineon Technologies raised 1.3 billion euros ($1.1 billion) in a share sale to finance production and pay debt, about 12 percent less than what the company hoped for earlier this month. Infineon, a unit of Seimens that makes chips used in mobile phones and computers, sold 52.2 million new shares at 25 euros a share, the Goldman Sachs Group said. An Infineon spokesman, Achim Schneider, said he expected an additional 7.8 million shares to be sold, which would bring the total proceeds to about 1.5 billion euros. Infineon has lost more than a third of its value since the beginning of June after computer-memory chip prices fell and the company said it would report a 600 million euro operating loss in its fiscal third quarter.

title: Milwaukee Cathedral Plan Draws Ecclesiastical Ire
description: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Milwaukee, Rembert G. Weakland, has told a high-ranking Vatican official that a $4.5 million renovation of Milwaukee's cathedral will proceed largely as planned, despite the official's recent criticism of the project and a campaign by a group of conservative lay Catholics to halt it.

title: Correcting Her Idea of Politically Correct
description: In France, Julia Kristeva is best known as the wife of Philippe Sollers, a high profile French novelist. In the United States, by contrast, it is Ms. Kristeva who has long enjoyed both recognition and notoriety, admired by many for her teachings and writings on linguistics, sexuality and psychoanalysis, criticized by others for stimulating the rise of multiculturalism.

title: U.S. Law on Trade Fines Is Challenged Overseas
description: The European Union and eight nonmember countries have asked the World Trade Organization to rule on a United States law allowing fines from antidumping cases to be paid to the American companies that started the complaints.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: President Repeats Threat
description: One day after the authorities refused to meet his demand for the arrest of the national police chief, President Abdurrahman Wahid repeated his assertion that he would declare a state of emergency and dissolve Parliament on Friday if Parliament did not cancel plans for an impeachment session. He said he would replace Parliament with a ruling council to govern until elections are held in a year's time. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Near the Top, Julich Plans to Stay
description: Two lean years later, Bobby Julich is back where he once belonged: in third place in the Tour de France. The mobs of photographers and interviewers are back too, as they were at the start of the sixth stage this morning in the village of Commercy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, HARRY
description: WEISS-Harry. Not a day goes by. Dearly loved, deeply missed. Your ever loving Jeannie

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPEVACK, EDMUND
description: SPEVACK-Edmund. 7/14/63-7/2/01 We celebrate his life. For us he will never die. Diane, Elaine, Eunice and Witold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGREEN, MORRIS H.
description: BERGREEN-Morris H. Beloved husband of Adele, adored father of Laurence and the late John, cherished father-in-law of Betsy and Natasha, loving grandfather of Nicholas and Sara. Remarkable, brilliant, and unforgettable, a truly generous spirit. Services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, JOSEPH
description: KAUFMAN-Joseph. Of Pound Ridge, NY, died unexpectedly at home. Beloved husband of Arlene. Cherished father of Gabrielle Shanin, Jacqueline Kaufman and Ellen Orkin. Adoring grandfather of Daniel and Julia Shanin, and Danielle & Jamie Orkin. Services 1:00 PM Sunday at the King David Memorial Chapel, 288 Main St., Mt. Kisco, New York (914-241-7100).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPER, LOIS MAY (NEE GUTERMAN)
description: JASPER-Lois May (nee Guterman). Loving wife of the late Julius. Beloved mother of Steve and Nancy, Richard and Millie, Barbara & Stuart Aferiat. Adored grandmother of Kyle, Ben, Robert, Lily, Alex and Corey. Dear sister of Elaine Kaufman. After a courageous battle with cancer. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. Service Sunday, July 15th, 10AM at Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Despite Worries Over Rights, It Wins on 2d Round of Voting : Beijing Is Awarded 2008 Summer Olympics
description: MOSCOW  Beijing was awarded the 2008 Summer Olympics on Friday by the International Olympic Committee, despite China's relatively short Olympic history and lingering questions about its approach to human rights.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tory Candidate Withdraws
description: David Davis withdrew his candidacy for leader of the Conservatives and threw his support to a fellow right-winger, Iain Duncan Smith, in Tuesday's vote among the 166 Tory members of Parliament. That ballot will decide the two finalists for the post in September, when all 330,000 members of the party vote. In the first-round vote, Mr. Davis had 18 votes, behind Michael Portillo (50), Mr. Duncan Smith (42) and Kenneth Clarke (39).

title: Joyous Vindication and a Sleepless Night
description: There was a collective shout, then silence from the thousands of people gathered at the Millennium Monument shortly after 10 p.m. Friday as the image of the International Olympic Committee president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, broadcast from Moscow, flashed onto two massive video screens.

title: John Holdridge, Ambassador And Asian Affairs Expert, 76
description: John H. Holdridge, a longtime Foreign Service official who accompanied President Richard M. Nixon on his historic visit to Beijing in 1972, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 76 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: E-Z Grousing On Speed Limit In Toll Plazas
description: While New Jersey drivers prepare to slow to a crawl when using their E-ZPass cards at state-highway tolls, critics of the system are revving up protests that new guidelines that go into effect tomorrow are defeating the purpose of the program.

title: Maceo Anderson, 90, Tap Dancer, Is Dead
description: Maceo Anderson, the last surviving founding member of the Four Step Brothers, one of the world's most celebrated and enduring tap acts, died on July 4 at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 90 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Army Accused Of Desecrations
description: The president of Ingushetia said the Russian Army had profaned monuments of medieval history and architecture in the Dzheirakh region. The president, Ruslan Aushev, said a military helicopter had destroyed a burial site and troops of the 58th Army had ''set up a latrine'' in the 12th-century Tkhaba-Yerdy Church.

title: Stay on Guard Against Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: The Many Veils Of Meaning Left by Leonardo
description: A parody of Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' shows Jesus delivering this message to his astonished disciples: ''Separate checks.'' Heretical, yes. But the cartoon parody shares something with what most interpreters, particularly modern interpreters, have seen in the ''Last Supper'': a single emotional moment, a frozen picture of expressions and gestures, a narrative full of clear meaning.

title: Cone Making the Most Of Latest Last Chance
description: David Cone is living in a hotel in Boston while playing the role of a baseball survivor with the Red Sox. Sure, it is a four-star place where coffee, orange juice and waffles cost about $20 and where they leave enough chocolates on your pillow to satisfy a class of first graders. Still, living out of a suitcase is a way for Cone to keep this phase of his career, maybe the final phase, simple.

title: Norton Rejects Call to Have Panel Review Water Cutoff
description: In a blow to farmers along the Oregon-California border, Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton refused to accept a petition today that sought reversal of a decision that has shut off irrigation water to about 200,000 acres of farmland.

title: Ah, Romance! Our Love, My Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Lyme Disease Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese-American Pride Swells After Decision
description: To Grace Ho, a practitioner of Chinese medicine, the awarding of the 2008 Summer Olympic Games to Beijing yesterday was like giving China a strong whiff of curative herbs.

title: A Private Lie Detector Test Clears Condit, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for Representative Gary A. Condit said today that a privately administered polygraph test showed that his client was not deceptive in denying knowledge of what happened to Chandra Ann Levy, the federal intern who disappeared on April 30.

title: Doubleday Discusses Split With Wilpon
description: The strained relations that have marked the partnership of the Mets' co-owners, Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon, have made a split inevitable, Doubleday said last night.

title: U.S. Reports Retail Sales Grew Less Than Expected
description: New evidence of a weak economy appeared yesterday in the latest reports on retail sales, inflation and consumer confidence, suggesting that a much anticipated upturn will not materialize until the fall, if then.

title: President, With a Variety of Steps, Addresses Climate Change
description: President Bush today promoted a number of studies and other measures intended to address the impact of greenhouse gases, including a $120 million NASA research project to examine more thoroughly the relationship between them and climate changes.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the At the Movies column in Weekend yesterday omitted the screenwriter who, along with Billy Crystal, wrote Joe Roth's new film, ''America's Sweethearts.'' He is Peter Tolan.

title: Prosecutor Nominated to Lead the F.B.I. Has Prostate Cancer
description: Robert S. Mueller III, the prosecutor chosen by President Bush to be the director of the F.B.I., has prostate cancer, said a letter from Mr. Mueller's doctor that was disclosed today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: CORN SYRUP PRICE-FIXING SUIT TO BE DISMISSED
description: A federal judge said he intended to dismiss a class-action lawsuit that accused Archer Daniels Midland, Cargill, Tate & Lyle and Cerestar of conspiring to fix prices in the $2 billion market for high-fructose corn syrup. Judge Michael M. Mihm of United States District Court in Peoria, Ill., told lawyers on Wednesday that he planned to dismiss the lawsuit, which was filed in September 1995 by PepsiCo , Coca-Cola and 24 other food companies, according to Holly Williams, chief deputy of the court. The suit said that the companies colluded as far back as 1991 over the price of high-fructose corn syrup, a sweetener used in soft drinks and candy. The litigation stemmed from a 1995 F.B.I. raid on the headquarters of Archer Daniels in Decatur, Ill. That raid resulted in conspiracy convictions and prison sentences for three company executives.

title: Can Communism Compete With the Olympics?
description: I was deeply involved in the decision that President Jimmy Carter made to boycott the Olympics in Moscow in 1980. In 2001, were I on the Olympic Committee, I would have voted to award the Olympics to Beijing as the committee did yesterday, though with serious reservations.

title: Added Rights For Indians Are Ratified In Mexico
description: With the approval of more than half its 31 state legislatures, Mexico ratified landmark constitutional changes on Thursday aimed at granting 10 million Indians new rights and protections against discrimination.

title: No Bailout Is Planned For Argentina
description: The Bush administration and the International Monetary Fund said yesterday that there was no special assistance in the works for Argentina, putting a damper on an early stock and bond rally in Argentina and other emerging markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, GERALD FIRTH, JR.
description: LEWIS-Gerald Firth, Jr. Died on July 10, 2001, peacefully at home after a brief illness. Beloved husband for forty-eight years of Harriette (nee Campbell), devoted father of Tish, Daphne and Larry, adoring grandfather to Jennifer, Christopher, Lindsay, Elizabeth and Lauren, and loving brother to Lindsay Catron & the late Daphne Scott. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA on July 4, 1919 and attended Shadyside Academy, St. Paul's School, Concord, New Hampshire before graduating from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After serving in the Navy Special Services for Anti-Submarine Warfare, he settled in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. where he worked as a consulting engineer in water distribution systems for the Bristol Company. He travelled around the world consulting on the development of water control systems from Borneo to Brazil. After moving to Brazil in 1975 on assignment from Montgomery Consulting, he lived in Pasadena, California, before retiring to Cape Ann, MA. Memorial Services will be held on Friday, August 3, 2001, at 11 AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, Roslyn, L.I. Donations in lieu of flowers to The Hospice of North Shore, 10 Elm St, Danvers, MA, 01923, or The World Wildlife Fund, 1250 Twenty-fourth St, N.W. Washington, DC 20037. For further information, contact The Campbell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot Street, Beverly, MA.

title: Safety Issue Assessed as Congress Considers Raising Mileage Standards
description: For the first time in years, Congress appears willing to raise gasoline mileage standards, giving new importance to a longstanding question a scientific committee is struggling with: Would doing so cause more deaths?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMLINSON, HENRY P.
description: TOMLINSON-Henry P., 81. Of Vero Beach, FL died July 10, 2001, at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach after a brief illness. Mr. Tomlinson was born September 29, 1919 in Princeton, NJ and moved to Vero Beach in 1984 from Mantoloking, NJ. He was a member of the Ivy Club of Princeton University from which he graduated in 1941. He served in the U.S. Army as Captain during World War II. Surviving are his wife of sixty years, Anne J. Tomlinson of Vero Beach, FL; a son, Henry Prout Tomlinson, Jr. of Albuquerque, NM; daughters, Melissa Tomlinson of Vero Beach, Sarah Roberts Fuller of Oakland, CA and Anne J. Tomlinson of Frederick, MD; sister Ann T. Reed of Princeton, NJ and nine grandchildren. For further information, contact Strunk Funeral Home in Vero Beach, FL.

title: Op-Art
Drought Dictated Attack on Fire, Officials Say
description: The map covering the war zone of fire that nearly 600 people are trying to contain here in the North Cascades also designates the towering firs, ancient pines and thick brush above the Chewuch River Valley as an area that is supposed to be left to nature, with minimal human interference.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, LESTER
description: ROBBINS-Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep and abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila

title: Cows vs. Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: In Rural Areas, Interstates Build Their Own Economy
description: Night and day, 18-wheelers roll on and off the scale outside the one-room yellow brick weigh station beside Interstate 40, just west of Oklahoma City. One afternoon, they were hauling lettuce and two-by-fours, frozen turkeys, cars and paper towels, just about all the things that Americans use and consume.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: 17 Charged With Smuggling
description: Seventeen men were charged with smuggling more than 200 pounds of cocaine from Haiti into the United States last year. The men were also indicted on charges of smuggling illegal immigrants. Gov. Jeb Bush joined United States Attorney Guy Lewis in announcing the indictments.

title: Septuplets Born in Capital Are Third Set in the World
description: The world's third set of septuplets five boys and two girls, each so tiny they could fit in the palm of a man's hand- -- were born at Georgetown University Hospital late Thursday, delivered by a team of doctors and nurses who had spent weeks running through practice drills.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Corporate Bond Issue
description: Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company, Kaztransoil, has issued $150 million of Eurobonds in the country's first corporate bond issue. The bonds, which have a face value of 8.5 percent and yield 8.67 percent, mature in 2006. The lead manager for the issue, which was oversubscribed, was J. P. Morgan. It was sold to more than 30 investors, split evenly in the United States and Europe. J. P. Morgan's managing director, Richard Luddington, said the issue was an important step in the development of a capital market in Kazakhstan, the major issuer of government bonds in the former Soviet Union. Kaztransoil will use the proceeds for a pipeline in western Kazakhstan. Birgit Brauer (NYT)

title: U.S. Set to Oppose International Plan For Cleaner Energy
description: The Bush administration plans to oppose an international drive to phase out fossil fuel subsidies and increase financing for nonpolluting energy sources worldwide, administration officials said today.

title: McGreevey Attacks Rival's Outsider Status
description: James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, tried today to dent the outsider status cultivated by his Republican rival, Bret D. Schundler, by tying him to the unfolding controversy over the state's auto emission testing program.

title: Powell and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

description: BASSOFF-Horace H. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Dubin). Much loved father of Caron and Eddie Rabinowitz and Scott Bassoff. Dearest Grandpa of Lauren and Jason Rabinowitz, Allison and Lindsay Bassoff. Son of the late Charles and Anna Bassoff and brother of the late Harold. ''The Legend'' will live on in all our hearts forever. Services Sunday 10:00 A.M. at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made in his memory to North Shore-Long Island Jewish Hospital.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. and 18 States Request Accelerated Microsoft Case

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: A Visually Elegant 'Orfeo ed Euridice'
description: ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' is known as a reform opera -- which is to say that Christoph Willibald Gluck, writing it in 1762, was trying to do away with the excesses of contemporary operatic practice. With only three characters, a simple story and straightforward melodies, ''Orfeo'' was a far cry from the opera-seria norm, with its convoluted, many-figured plots and elaborate vocal ornaments. But Gluck himself, as sensitive to the demands of his audience as the next composer, revised the piece extensively for its Paris premiere in 1774, adapting it to French tastes by eliminating the castrato, beefing up the ballets, and adding an Act I aria for Orfeo featuring the kind of florid singing he purported to be reacting against in the first place.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Offer Raised For Eircom
description: The Irish entrepreneur Denis O'Brien extended a nine-month bidding war for Eircom, the former state phone company, with an all-cash offer of $2.6 billion. The latest offer from Mr. O'Brien's eIsland consortium of $1.16 a share surpasses the $2.47 billion, or $1.12 a share, bid of cash and warrants from a rival consortium, Valentia, which is led by Ireland's wealthiest person, Sir Anthony O'Reilly, and is backed by the financier George Soros. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: The Disappearance of Chandra Levy
description: Every parent who has lost track of a child for even a few moments on the playground or at the supermarket knows the crippling panic that persists until the child is found. Susan and Robert Levy have been living with a variant of this panic for 10 weeks, ever since their 24-year-old daughter, Chandra, disappeared from her apartment in Washington, D.C. Watching the police search for Ms. Levy with corpse-sniffing dogs this week was wrenching enough for the family. But Representative Gary Condit of California has substantially worsened this ordeal by failing to cooperate fully with law officers investigating the case when they first interviewed him about the young woman's disappearance nearly two months ago.

title: The Old Tap and the New Team Up With Affection
description: Tap, like the rest of the world, has changed since the days of the great solo dancers. That was one message of ''Tap City,'' the central program of the inspired New York City Tap Festival, on Thursday night at the Duke on 42nd Street. Another message was that this peculiarly American, peculiarly lovable art form is still a lot of fun to watch and even, occasionally, as exalted as those earlier tapsters, though in a different way.

title: Bloomberg Discloses He's Rich, But He's Frugal With the Details
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the businessman who is running for mayor, revealed information yesterday about his financial holdings as required by the city's election law. The financial information, the first to be disclosed by Mr. Bloomberg, showed him to be very rich, to have a daughter who wins equestrian prizes and to have a former wife who owes him a lot of money.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Charges Dropped Against Ex-President
description: The Supreme Court dropped all corruption charges against a former president, Alan Garca, saying that any corrupt acts committed during his rule, from 1985 to 1990, had already passed the statute of limitations. Mr. Garca, who ran a strong second in the May presidential election runoff, was accused of taking kickbacks related to the building of an unfinished rail line in Lima and to the purchase of arms. Mr. Garca has always denied the charges. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Political Prisoners Freed
description: The government said it had released seven political prisoners, including the last three of the 203 elected representatives of the opposition National League for Democracy who had been detained three years ago. The other four were members of a comedy troupe jailed five years ago for mocking the regime. The government has released 140 prisoners since January in a good-will campaign as it holds talks with the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: In percent

title: Warning on Internet Stocks
description: Warren E. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, said today that a 50 percent decline in Internet stocks in the last year had not made them more attractive as investments.

title: Cone Returns To Haunt The Mets
description: When the Mets traded David Cone to Toronto in the late summer of 1992, it was a clear signal that an era was ending. The brash, victorious team Cone had joined in 1987 had deteriorated, and things at Shea Stadium would have to get worse before they improved.

description: KELLMAN-Claire. On July 12, 2001. Beloved mother of David and Denise. Dear sister of Marvin Kaplan. Adored grandmother of Samantha.

title: A Fierce Music From Mali, Via a Small Railroad Cafe
description: The Super Rail Band's concert on Wednesday night at La Guardia Concert Hall was a spellbinding display of how African tradition reconquers its colonizers. The band, an institution in Mali since the late 1960's that is starting its first United States tour, used electric guitars, trap drums and Caribbean congas to create music that sounded Malian in every kinetic detail. It set a high standard for the Lincoln Center Festival's Africa Out Loud series, which continues through Thursday.

title: Airlines Are Cutting Back on Some International Flights
description: United Airlines' decision two weeks ago to abruptly drop its nonstop service between New York and Hong Kong after only three months could be the harbinger of similar moves by other United States carriers, industry analysts say.

title: Nets Look to Sixers for Center
description: Todd MacCulloch played fewer than 10 minutes a game last season, averaging only 4.1 points and 2.7 rebounds for the 76ers. He also blocked shots about as frequently as a small point guard.

description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. REJECTS INJECTABLE PAINKILLER FROM PHARMACIA
description: Pharmacia said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had rejected its application for an injectable painkiller designed to reduce the need for morphine. The F.D.A. cited deficiencies in the company's application for approval of the drug, which would have been used to treat hospitalized patients with severe pain and those who have had surgery, a Pharmacia spokesman, Craig Buchholz, said. The company said it would conduct new studies within 18 months to collect an unspecified amount of data the F.D.A. requested. The drug, parecoxib sodium, would be the first injectable form of the powerful Cox-2 inhibitor class of painkillers.

title: Christine Stanley, Michael Preston
description: Christine Campbell Stanley, a daughter of Judith E. Campbell of Madison, N.J., and Thomas A. Stanley of Kirkland, Wash., was married yesterday to Michael David Preston, the son of Carol A. Preston, also of Madison, and the late David B. Preston. The Right Rev. Gerard P. Lair, the abbot emeritus of St. Mary's Abbey in Morristown, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

description: On the morning after Election Day, George W. Bush held an unofficial lead of 1,784 votes in Florida, but to his campaign strategists the margin felt perilously slim. They were right to worry. Within a week, recounts would erode Mr. Bush's unofficial lead to just 300 votes.

description: Comverse Technology Warns of Weak Quarter

description: Two police officers shot and killed a man on a Harlem street corner yesterday morning as the man repeatedly stabbed his girlfriend and refused the officers' orders to drop a knife, the authorities said.

description: In its 25-year history, the Meadowlands Pace has been the test of champions for pacers, and Real Desire proved tonight that he is the champion for 3-year-olds.
