description: Call it a lesson in unintended consequences.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-15-01: On Language; Compassion
description: In the case of P.G.A. Tour v. Martin, the Supreme Court held (7-2) that the game of golf would not be fundamentally altered if a handicapped contestant in a tournament was allowed to ride in a golf cart. Because the game was played in a place of public accommodation, the Americans With Disabilities Act applied, and the court upheld judges who directed the Professional Golfers Association to let the golfer Casey Martin ride.

title: Nuclear Arms Still Keep the Peace
description: In recent statements, Bush administration officials have called for the United States to cast aside so-called relics of the cold war. On Thursday, for example, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz told a Senate committee that the administration's missile-defense program will ''inevitably bump up against'' the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty ''in months.'' Even the concept of nuclear deterrence is not immune to this desire to clean house. In mid-June President Bush stated his intention to move away from the logic of mutually assured destruction -- ''the capacity of each of us, each country, to blow each other up,'' as he said -- in favor of a new framework based on some combination of strategic offensive and defensive systems.

title: In the Region/Westchester; As Complaints Rise, Advice on Hiring a Contractor
description: THIS summer, based on the number of formal complaints filed, more Westchester residents than before have fallen prey to what Richard J. Linkowski, the county's deputy director of consumer protection, calls ''the fly-by-night contractors out there -- the guys who are here today and gone tomorrow.''

title: Untattoo You
description: Covermark's Tattoo Cover Kit is a set of concealers for illustrated men and women who need temporary camouflage for job interviews, weddings, meetings with potential in-laws and other diplomatically delicate situations. (The makeup was developed for models who wanted to mask their tattoos during go-sees.) The tin contains a coverup primer, two shades of foundation, finishing powder, moisturizer and a sponge and brush.

title: Counting Noses of Fish and Those Who Catch Them
description: It would have been unimaginable some years ago: a census of Hudson River fishermen.

title: From Dressing Down to Suiting Up
description: AS recently as April, Gary Kaplan of Larchmont still bore the sartorial signs of a dot-com employee for whom nearly every day had lapsed into dress-down Friday. Selling software from home, he wore shorts, slippers and T-shirts emblazoned with dot-com names. Shaving was optional. ''Why bother when you are working virtually?'' Mr. Kaplan said.

title: The Nation; The Lost Privacy of Gary Condit
description: VIEWERS of CNN had a chance to spend quite a few seconds Thursday morning looking at the door of Susan and Robert Levy's home in Modesto, Calif. Eventually it would open, and the parents of Chandra Levy would make another statement, adding film, if not facts, to the ongoing coverage of the missing Federal Bureau of Prisons intern.

title: When Cell Phone Users Step on Others' Toes
description: Arrogant cell phone users like Carol Scibelli [''Cell Phones, and Other Diversions,'' Opinion, July 8] are the reason we need laws banning cell phones from cars in the first place. Cell phones appear to be the new smoking. They are annoying and sometimes dangerous for the user and those around her.

title: Doing (Reverse) Splits To Avoid Delisting
description: Just before Webvan announced last week that it had ceased operations, directors of the company tried to use a popular tactic to shore up its stock price and avoid losing a listing on the Nasdaq National Market.

title: Ideas & Trends: Curtains!; How to Avoid Being Attacked in the Shower
description: LIKE millions, perhaps even billions, of people, David Schmidt of Amherst, Mass., takes a shower every morning. For the last few years, between first spritz and final drain, a question has vexed him: why does the shower curtain suck in?

title: Photographer's Journal
description: Broadway and 107th Street, 5 P.M.

title: Oregon's Water War
description: In spirit, the Endangered Species Act is the noblest of the landmark environmental statutes passed during the Nixon era. In practice, it has been by far the most controversial. It is the act right-wing property-rights advocates love to hate, and once again it is under fire for allegedly protecting animals at the expense of human economic needs -- this time in Oregon's Klamath Basin, where the federal Bureau of Reclamation has shut off irrigation water in order to save the endangered suckerfish and the threatened coho salmon. The action, coming on top of the worst drought the Pacific Northwest has seen in many years, has left 1,400 farmers without water, ruined crops on about 200,000 acres and inspired isolated acts of civil disobedience in which angry farmers have tried to reopen headgates blocking the water. It has also become the latest rallying cry for opponents of the Endangered Species Act.

title: Face to Face With Edison
description: The Menlo Park Museum in Edison has statues of Thomas A. Edison as a youth and as an elderly man. Now the museum has an image of him in death. Making death masks -- plaster masks of famous people at the time of death -- was a common practice for centuries, said Jack Stanley, director of the museum, but it was not known until 1991 that a death mask of Edison had been created by James Earle Fraser, a sculptor who also created the buffalo head nickel and the bronze work known as ''End of the Trail'' of a defeated Indian warrior slumped on his tired pony. Some detective work eventually turned up the mask in a collection in Northern California. Of 12 copies that were made, two were sold to Ron Rohrenbacher of Pomona, Calif., who in turn donated one to the museum last week. The museum at 37 Christie Street, Edison, is open Wednesdays through Sundays 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

title: Thanks for Coming. Now Go.
description: THEY wrote many of today's computer codes, set up networks spanning millions of miles, designed and built Web sites and databases. The role of Indian immigrants in the development of the Internet has been likened to the contribution made by earlier waves of immigrants who built the nation's railroads and subway systems.

title: Ideas & Trends; Virtual Revenge and the Decline of the Dot-Coms
description: THE hooting and jeering began the moment Webvan, the online grocer that was once a Wall Street darling, shut its doors last week, laying off its 2,000 employees and saying it would seek bankruptcy protection.

title: For Co-ops, Bad Income And Good
description: IS there ever such a thing as too much money? For some co-ops, the answer is yes. ''It's the old 'good news/bad news' routine,'' said Marc Shernicoff, a Manhattan accountant who specializes in co-ops and condominiums. ''In some co-op buildings with commercial tenants, the good news is that those tenants produce a significant amount of income for the co-op. The bad news is that if a co-op gets too much of its money from commercial tenants or other outside sources, its shareholders can lose the tax benefits of owning a co-op.''

title: Reporter's Notebook; Opinions on Death Penalty Spoken But Not Heard
description: When Judith Mwila testified last month in the death-penalty hearing for a terrorist convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania, she described how hard her life had been since the death of her husband. He was an embassy guard, the family breadwinner, and one of 11 people killed in the attack.

title: One Year and Five Visits to India Later, a Wedding
description: SMITA MICKEY PATEL had the time, money, inclination and willing participants.

title: What He Did (on Crutches) on Vacation
description: SUMMER vacation was only days away, but Jonathan Lowenstein suddenly felt as if someone had cast a spell on him. There he stood at home plate, his sandy-blond curls tucked under his helmet, living any preteenage boy's nightmare. Two out in the final inning of the final game of the entire Little League season. Make an out, kid, and the season ends on your shoulders.

title: A School's Racial Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: I Beg Your Pardon
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASKY, CHARLES AND ESTELLE
description: LASKY-Charles and Estelle. July 18th and July 20th. On their birthdays and everyday, always loved and the wonderous memories linger on. George, Joyce and Family

title: At Work, With All the Comforts of a Family
description: ALMOST exactly four years ago, the Drama Dept. staged Douglas Carter Beane's ''As Bees in Honey Drown'' at its usual haunt, the Greenwich House Theater in Greenwich Village. Only the third production by the company -- a collective of actors, writers, directors, designers, musical directors and stage managers conceived in 1994 -- it beguiled audiences and critics, transferring to a long run at the Lucille Lortel Theater. The first hit play for Mr. Beane, the company's artistic director, it solidified Mark Brokaw's status as a rising director, gave J. Smith-Cameron perhaps her most memorable role in the scheming social butterfly Alexa Vere de Vere and remains the Drama Dept.'s biggest commercial success to date.

title: Foes Fear New Chairwoman Will Just Toe the Party Line
description: Community Board 2, which covers Greenwich Village, SoHo and Little Italy, is among the city's most active boards. Debates over the finer points of city proposals and block disputes can extend well into the evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUNG, RANDOLPH CHENG, YU
description: TUNG-Randolph Cheng-Yu. Of New Rochelle, NY. On July 12. Beloved husband of Suetse Li. Survived by his brothers Z.Y. of Brooklyn, W.Y. of Chicago, L.Y. of Queens, K.Y. of Oakland and sisters Angela Woo of South Bend, May Wong of San Francisco and Y.N. Lowe of Mountain View. Visitation at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY, on Friday, July 20, 6-8 PM. Funeral service at Bennett on Saturday, July 21, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Duck in Beijing
description: To the Editor: As someone who lived in Beijing from 1992 to 1994, I thoroughly enjoyed Florence Fabricant's article ''In Beijing, Duck Is Just the Beginning'' (Choice Tables, May 6).

title: After Conquering the Hill, A Super Bowl Sounds Easy
description: It is just before 7 a.m. and Tiki Barber and Greg Comella are at Ramapo Valley County Reservation, stretching and chatting about Comella's recent marriage when Barber breaks into a hypnotic smile and stares at the towering trees as the morning sun tries to peek through.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 15, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Reckonings; A Latin Tragedy
description: In the 1990's Argentina staged a dramatic recovery from decades of economic mismanagement, and in the process became an icon of the new world order. But last week the Argentine government found that it could roll over short-term debt only by offering a 14 percent interest rate, five points higher than a month earlier. And the buzz on Wall Street is that the question about an eventual Argentine debt default is no longer whether, but when.

title: Lab Seeks Leader for Post-Marburger Era
description: IT could have been the cheerleaders and pom-poms at the official opening of Brookhaven National Laboratory's new particle accelerator last year, or maybe the public tours that scientists gave to explain how the machine works, or more likely the monthly meetings with environmental groups and concerned citizens that so endeared John Marburger, the laboratory's director, to people on and off its 5,265-acre campus.

title: Old Sounds From the New World
description: A CENTURY ago New York's leading musicians, including the visiting composer Antonin Dvorak and the immigrant conductor Anton Seidl, confidently anticipated the creation of an American canon. An acknowledged body of esteemed symphonies and operas, sonatas and concertos, steeped in plantation song and other folk strains, would anchor a distinctive New World musical high culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCHINS, MARGARET MANDON
description: WILCHINS-Margaret Mandon. Of Rockville, MD. On Friday, July 13, 2001. Age 53. Beloved wife of Howard Wilchins. Devoted mother of Julie and Dan Wilchins. Loving daughter of Gay and Morris Mandon. Services will be held at Tikvat Israel Congregation, Rockville, MD. Interment at Judean Memorial Gardens. Family will observe shivah through Saturday evening at the family residence. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Hillel Greater Washington, Jewish Education Service of North America, Charles E. Smith Jewish Day School; Mazon or the cancer charity of your choice.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-15-01: Five From Sebastiao Salgado; Moments in Time
description: ''A photo is great when you need no more information than just the picture,'' says Sebastiao Salgado, the award-winning photojournalist whose recent book, ''Migrations: Humanity in Transition,'' is the subject of both an exhibit at the International Center of Photography through Sept. 9 and a Cinemax documentary, ''Salgado: The Spectre of Hope,'' which will be aired on Aug. 8. Unlike other photographic forms, photojournalism done well needs no explanation. ''The photo tells a story,'' Salgado says, ''that everyone feels.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, LADY SHELAGH JOCELYN MORRISON, BELL MOORE
description: CAMPBELL-Lady Shelagh Jocelyn Morrison-Bell Moore, age 87, formerly of New York, died April 21, 2001 in England. Journalist and author of Resident Alien. Survived by her son David A. C. Moore, daughter-in-law Christiane Citron & granddaughter Cornelia, of Denver, CO. The Memorial service England August 3. Contact David Moore tele. 303.777.2242.

title: The Embryo Taboos
description: Scientists at a fertility clinic in Virginia have crossed a previously taboo line by creating and then immediately destroying human embryos to obtain stem cells for research purposes, and a small biotechnology company in Massachusetts may soon break another barrier by doing the same thing through controversial cloning procedures. All previous work in this field has used stem cells derived from surplus embryos that would have been discarded at fertility clinics. That work is controversial in itself, but there is something about the notion of scientists creating and destroying embryos solely for research purposes that arouses particularly intense opposition.

title: SOAPBOX; In Traffic and Not Dropping a Stitch
description: NEW YORK STATE has become the first state in the country to legislate a total ban on the use of a handheld cellular phone while driving. I applaud our state legislators, who cannot get a budget passed on time (again), but were able to control this insidious menace on the road.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Fashionistas, Ecofriendly And All-Natural
description: I HAD my first tofu birthday cake when I was 9,'' reminisced Natane Adcock, an actress and model, who grew up with a mother who was a charter member of the health-food movement. Mealtimes, she confided, used to make her cringe. ''At school I got made fun of,'' she said. ''Finally, I stopped using anything that had the word 'whole' in it.''

title: A Tiny Island, but a Cause So Clbre; From New York to Hollywood, Vieques Has Issues for Everyone
description: A small island off the coast of Puerto Rico has captured the national, if not global, stage and provoked a surprising degree of activism. Remember when most people couldn't even pronounce Vieques, much less point it out on a map?

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SPINACH DAYS

title: Victoria Caspar, Matthew Eichler
description: Victoria Marie Caspar, a daughter of Frances and George J. Caspar III of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Aaron Eichler, a son of Susan and Thomas Eichler of Bear, Del. The Rev. Percival L. D'Silva performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington.

title: Harvard's Hoard
description: 'There's something good about hunger,'' a dean at Harvard says. ''It is important for our students to be co-investors in their own education.'' Harvard, the hotbed of liberalism? To me, this sounds more like George W. Bush's compassionate conservatism.

title: African Sculpture Taught in St. Louis
description: Visitors to the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis are being offered an unusual opportunity this summer: workshops in which they can shape a 60-pound chunk of native Zimbabwean stone into forms inspired by traditional African culture. The five-day classes, taught by artists from Zimbabwe, will be offered through September.

title: The World: War Crimes in Africa; Where Justice Takes a Back Seat to Just Ending War
description: AFRICA is where most of world's warfare is now. Since civilians are often the targets there, it stands to reason that Africa may also be fertile ground in this new era of international justice. So: what signal did the delivery of Slobodan Milosevic to the Hague in exchange for $1.3 billion in assistance to Serbia send to Africa and its often appalling leaders?

title: The Red-State Network
description: Sella tips his hand at the end of his grudgingly favorable article on Fox News, i.e., two paragraphs for Dan Rather to respond to a comment by Brit Hume on Rather's bias.

title: You've Got Mail, at Last; The Carrier Stole It in '96
description: Kathleen DeGuilme was confused five years ago when several neighbors did not show up for a Christmas party held by her family at their home in Rutherford, N.J. But last week, her confusion was cleared up when two of the invitations were returned in the mail, along with a letter from the United States Postal Service explaining what had happened.

title: Three Seats in Coach, For Armchair Travelers
description: Looking for some bargain airline seats? Three coach seats from Trans World Airlines are now for sale on eBay, the online auction site.

title: A Marriage Without Subtitles
description: COLIN NUTLEY so liked Sweden that he decided to make Swedish movies, which was perhaps a tad strange for an English television director who was already working in the lingua franca of modern cinema. But the move served him well, not least because 11 years ago he met a rising Swedish stage and screen actress, Helena Bergstrom, who soon became both his wife and his muse. She has appeared in all eight movies he has made since then.

title: Harvard's Hoard
description: As a cog in the augmentation of the Harvard endowment (I was co-chairman this year of the medical school's 50th class-reunion gift), I offer a word about alumni motivation in giving.

title: Atheism Isn't a 'Faith'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Jackie Robinson's Daughter Continues Job of Conquering Obstacles
description: SHARON ROBINSON sat in an uptown coffee shop recently, enthusiastically describing the in-school education program she started along with Major League Baseball in 1997. The Breaking Barriers in Sports, in Life program, which is in 26 major league cities including New York, teaches adolescents the principles of confronting obstacles and ultimately clearing them. Robinson, 51, said that after rearing her son and serving as a midwife for more than two decades, her involvement with this program is the most invigorating undertaking of her life.

title: A Flickering Candle for the Independent Inventor
description: THE members of the New York Society of Professional Inventors last met in May, convening at the state university campus in Farmingdale for a lively discussion about patent protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, DAVID NOYES
description: JACKSON-David Noyes. Who, with his companion, the late poet James Merrill, resided in Key West for nearly 25 years, passed away peacefully in his sleep at his home in the early morning of July 13, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Doris Sewell Jackson. A remembrance of his life will be scheduled later in the year.

title: July 8-14; Louima Wins $8.75 Million
description: Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant tortured by police officers in a station house bathroom in 1997, settled a civil lawsuit against New York City and its main police union for a total of $8.75 million. It represents the most the city has ever paid to settle a claim of police brutality and is believed to be the first time a police union anywhere in the country has paid to settle a brutality case. Alan Feuer

title: Federal Suit Accuses City of Not Acting on Harassment Complaints in Workfare Jobs
description: The federal government has sued the Giuliani administration, charging it with doing too little to protect women in workfare jobs from sexual and racial harassment by their supervisors.

title: States Pressed As 3 Boys Die At Boot Camps
description: The death of Tony Haynes, a 14-year-old, in the Arizona desert this month is increasing calls for stronger regulation of outdoor camps for troubled youths, an industry that has grown substantially over the last 20 years.

title: A Place for Fresh Fish, Evoking Full Sails
description: AS the heat of the season intensifies and respite at the shore seems weeks away, those of us detained on shimmering pavements can get a taste of the sea on main street here at Caffe Regatta. This new kid in town has arrived not a moment too soon. Its very name evokes full sails, swift boats and cool breezes; but more than that, anyone with a hankering for fresh fish will be accommodated here. Arrive hungry. Most portions are huge and easily shared.

title: Stephanie Kwei, David Greer
description: Dr. Stephanie Lynn Kwei, the daughter of Amy and Thomas Kwei of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., and Aspen, Colo., was married yesterday to Dr. David Matthew Greer, a son of Arline Greer and Dr. Melvin Greer of Gainesville, Fla. Louis H. Pressman, the chaplain of the Hotchkiss School in Connecticut, from which the bride graduated, and a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day, performed the ceremony at Castle Hill, an estate in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Asher B. Edelman, an American takeover investor who is trying to buy Baumgartner Papiers, a Swiss paper company, misstated the per-share equivalent of an estimated 349.5 million Swiss francs in Baumgartner reserves not reflected on the company's balance sheet. It is 2,688 Swiss francs per share, not 2.68.

title: A Touch of the Soothsayer In the Big City
description: IN the 1930's, the story goes, the renowned Danish nuclear physicist Niels Bohr kept a horseshoe on his laboratory wall. One day a distinguished visitor said to Bohr, a Nobel Prize-winning father of quantum physics, ''Surely a great scientist like yourself doesn't believe in such silly superstitions?''

title: Behind a Masterpiece May Be Another Masterpiece
description: IT'S the kind of discovery that makes an art historian's day. In 1521, Michelangelo did a sketch of scowling monsters and the head of a gargoyle. To the side, more faintly, he drew a robed woman. In the 1980's, scholars questioned whether the woman was linked to the tombs Michelangelo designed in the Medici Chapel. Then, 11 years ago, conservators removed the picture from its mount and discovered, on the back, a drawing of a sarcophagus.

title: AUTHORITY CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: Raymond H. Bateman resigned last week as chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, citing his opposition to a plan backed by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco to turn the Meadowlands sports complex into a shopping mall and family sports center. Mr. Bateman has said he will fight that plan as it is considered in the Assembly. Mr. Bateman will remain on the authority as a member.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about the use of digital images to replace actors in Hollywood films, and a picture caption with it, referred incorrectly to the status of the 1982 film ''Tron.'' It was the first feature film to use computer-generated images in entire sequences, not the first to contain such images.

title: Bonds Receives Support From Mr. October
description: When Barry Bonds hit 39 home runs before the All-Star Game, he surpassed Reggie Jackson and Mark McGwire as the player who hit the most home runs at that juncture of the season. Now Jackson is pulling for Bonds to pass McGwire as the player who hits the most home runs in an entire season.

title: Hardcover Fiction
description: This

title: The Last Knockout May Loom at a Popular Boxing Center
description: In a 1999 Oscar-nominated documentary called ''On the Ropes,'' a young woman overcomes homelessness and imprisonment to train at the New Bedford-Stuyvesant Boxing Center, from which she hopes one day to begin a professional boxing career.

title: The Reality Of Recovery, Unadorned
description: IF you've ever encountered Bob Dey while channel surfing, you may have had cause to rethink your definition of reality television. His on-screen world -- one without tribal warfare, $1 million prizes or more-than-minimal production values -- is about as real as it gets.

title: POSTINGS: $8 Million for Natural History Museum; For Theater, A New Name, A New Look
description: So it's not the traditional diamond. (Anyway, this place already has plenty of those.)

title: Private Sector; A Famous $35 Emblem, Put to Charitable Use
description: In 1971, Carolyn Davidson, then 29 and a graphic design student at Portland State University in Oregon, was asked by a shoe salesman and accounting professor named Philip H. Knight to create a logo for an athletic shoe company he was trying to start. She provided Mr. Knight with several ideas. ''They were going to print shoeboxes the next morning, so a decision had to be made,'' Ms. Davidson recalled. ''They decided on this swoosh and he said, 'Well, I don't love it but it'll grow on me.' '' After he chose one, she charged him $35, which covered the cost of her supplies.

title: The Red-State Network
description: Sella states that Fox viewers typically live in ''red states.'' But this doesn't take into account many, many of us in the East whose cable companies don't carry Fox.

title: July 8-14; Pinochet Wins Crucial Case
description: Augusto Pinochet won a legal battle that is likely to end his three years of arrests and captivity on human rights charges, first in Britain and then in Chile. An appeals court ruled that the former dictator was not mentally competent to defend himself against charges that he covered up for a death squad held responsible for kidnappings and executions of dissidents in 1973. Most legal scholars believe that there is now little chance General Pinochet will ever stand trial for his alleged involvement in the deaths and torture of thousands during his 17-year rule. Clifford Krauss

title: The Old World's New World
description: ONCE, Europeans traveled to the New World and named the places they colonized after home. More recently, Americans returned the favor. Thus, in February, my family was able to travel from our home in New York City to Disneyland Paris and stay in a hotel named Newport, dine at a restaurant named Manhattan and stroll along Main Street USA, to a place called Frontierland.

title: A Company Credo, as Applied or Not
description: RALPH S. LARSEN, chief executive of Johnson & Johnson, clearly remembers his whereabouts on Tuesday, March 31, 1998. ''I was at a speaking engagement in Phoenix,'' he said. ''I got a phone call that said: 'Ralph, you're not going to believe this, but we just had a raid at our LifeScan headquarters by 30 or 40 armed federal agents. They've cordoned off the building and are serving a search warrant.' '' Mr. Larsen thought that the call might be an early April Fool's joke.

title: 2004 Buzz: Bradley, Kerry, Gore and More
description: Action is picking up on the Election 2004 front.

title: Chimp Change
description: ''Planet of the Apes'' may not invade earth for another two weeks, but simian chic already has. In honor of Curious George's 60th birthday this fall, Universal Studios has released a crop of merchandise. Snug T-shirts and cotton and silk boxer shorts, (above center; from $12 to $20 at www. universalstudios.com) will bring out anyone's inner child -- or chimp.

title: A Rich Past, Imperiled by an Affluent Present
description: It could hardly be likened to the destruction of the giant Buddhas carved into the cliff faces in Afghanistan by the fanatical Taliban. But to historic preservationists here, removal of the brick facade of an 1840 row house was sacrilege enough.

title: The Last Mayor of Fun City
description: THE UNGOVERNABLE CITY

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MURPHY, NEIL J.
description: MURPHY-Neil J. 5/16/51-7/14/00. Dearest son, we will always miss you. You are in our hearts and prayers. You were the Marine's son, Semper Fi. Love Mom, Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLADDEN, ELSPETH
description: SLADDEN-Elspeth at home in Sag Harbor, New York, July 3rd, after a long battle with Multiple Myeloma. Adored wife of Michael, much loved mother of Mark & Chloe, cherished sister of Glynn, and devoted educator. Funeral July 14th at Christ Episcopal Church, Sag Harbor, New York. No flowers please, but donations, if desired, to The Elspeth Sladden Teacher Education Fund, C/O Center for Applied Special Technology, 39 Cross Street, Peabody, MA. 01960 (978/531.8555)

title: In Scarsdale, It's a New Ballgame
description: IN his four seasons as a Little League parent in Scarsdale, Mark Gompertz says he has ''seen some real doozies'' on the baseball field.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KASS, MITCHEL
description: KASS-Mitchel. July 15, 1992. Dearest dad, we miss you. Love, children, grandchildren and great-granddaughters

title: Are 'Fake' Pornographic Images Protected by First Amendment?
description: LAST year, District Attorney Jeanine Pirro's investigators were assembling evidence in a child pornography case when they came across something unusual: one of the images was fake. A photograph of a real child had been superimposed onto a sex scene, so skillfully that only an expert could tell the difference.

title: Political Briefing; 2004 Buzz: Bradley, Kerry, Gore and More
description: Action is picking up on the Election 2004 front.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: DOGHOUSE ROSES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANSELL, HANK
description: ANSELL-Hank. On Tuesday, June 26, 2001. Funeral service and interment were held on June 27, 2001 in Baltimore, Maryland.

title: Political Briefing; San Francisco Mayor Looks to Sacramento
description: Speaking of radio interviews. . . .

title: Set for Takeoff
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''J.F.K. Becoming a Bit Friendlier'' (Practical Traveler, June 17): An imaginative choice of restaurants? Free Internet access? I'm on my way! Oops, it's an airport terminal. But Terminal 4 sounds like a worthwhile destination itself.

title: The Shyness Syndrome
description: Margaret Talbot's article did much to trivialize what can be a debilitating condition (The Way We Live Now, June 24). I wish she had included some interviews with people who have been treated for social phobia.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: Fighting Sex Harassment, and Stigma, in Japan
description: For women all over this country, Moeko Tanaka, a former campaign worker who successfully sued the governor of this prefecture for sexually molesting her and won, remains a heroine without a face.

title: A Star's Cure For a Classic: Tough Love
description: GIVEN the raw star power that allows Sylvie Guillem to do much as she pleases, it is perhaps odd that the idolized French dancer is launching her career as a choreographer with a work that has long irritated her. ''Giselle,'' she feels, is simply unconvincing as a narrative, at least in the traditional versions that she has frequently danced. And yet, when approached in the mid-1990's to make a ballet movie of her choice, she proposed ''Giselle'' as best suited to the screen.

title: Enchanted Places
"The Dearly Departed"
description: Sunny met Fletcher for the first time at their parents’ funeral, a huge graveside affair where bagpipes wailed and strangers wept. It was a humid, mosquito-plagued June day, and the grass was spongy from a midnight thunderstorm. They had stayed on the fringes of the crowd until both were rounded up and bossed into the prime mourners’ seats by the funeral director. Sunny wore white—picture hat, dress, wet shoes—and an expression that layered anger over grief: Who is he? How dare he? Are any of these gawkers friends?

title: Colleen Carey, Justin Boyd
description: Colleen Marie Carey, a daughter of Barbara H. Carey and Thomas H. Carey of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Justin Shepard Boyd, a son of Anne S. Boyd and Dr. Alvin T. Boyd of Chappaqua, N.Y. Msgr. Christopher DiLella performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Martyr Church in Madison.

title: No Stethoscope: A (Legit) Safecracker Defies the Stereotype
description: THE safe was unusual but not particularly challenging for Phil Mortillaro, who was contemplating how to break in. Built by the Lowrie Safe and Lock Company, it had a small round door covered with chipped silver paint. The safe was attached to the bedroom wall of a pre-World War I co-op on West End Avenue.

title: You Can Call Her A Cat Person
description: KAY ROSAIRE is afraid of heights and highway traffic, but put her in a ring surrounded by six snarling tigers and she's cool as ice.

title: Dance This Mess Around
description: You could argue that the greatest contribution the French have made to fashion is precision. And that the greatest contribution everyone else then made was imprecision. The French are like Felix to the rest of the world's Oscar, and designers -- from the Italians to the Belgians to the Americans to the Brits -- have made their biggest mark by unmaking the corner-tucked, coin-bouncing bed of French fashion.

title: Dana Kazlow, Andrew Stern
description: Dana Wylie Kazlow, the daughter of Dr. Carole Kazlow and Dr. Alan Kazlow of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Andrew Lane Stern, a son of Nancy Z. Lane of New York and the late Mark G. Stern. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRADER, ABRAHAM
description: SCHRADER-Abraham. Abe, we will miss you. You have been an inspiration and guiding hand for all of us. Your advice, philosophy and humor was unmatched. Mort, Miquette, Steve and all the family, our love is always with you. George Kaufman Kaufman Management Company

title: A Legal Debate Over a Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Talks Fail to Solve Problem of I.R.A. Weapons
description: Five days of crisis talks aimed at rescuing the failing Northern Ireland peace accord ended today without a breakthrough in the impasse over Irish Republican Army weapons that threatens the province's Catholic-Protestant power-sharing government.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: TOBY, WHAT ARE YOU? By William Steig. Illustrated by Teryl Euvremer. Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins. $14.95. (Ages 2 to 6) Some domestic games that toddlers and preschoolers adore adapt perfectly as stories. Toby, the same weasel who played with his parents in ''Toby, Where Are You?,'' has returned with a related game. Father comes home and guesses (or fails to) that Toby is a doormat, a bridge, a pair of scissors, a banana sandwich and so on. Delicious fun and perhaps inspiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMICKLE, LIZA MORROW
description: McMICKLE-Liza Morrow. Bigband era vocalist, died Sunday, June 24 at her home in North Hollywood after a brief illness. She was 87. Born in Brooklyn, she began her career in the entertainment business while still a teenager, working as a publicist for Universal Pictures in Manhattan. She came to the attention of others through her promotional activities. NBC signed her to her own morning show, ''Lyrics by Liza''. After leaving NBC she went on to sing with the bands of Benny Goodman and George Paxton. It was while she was with Goodman that she recorded her hit ''My Guy's Come Back''. She also sang with Eddie Condon, Bobby Hackett, Ben Pollack and Freddie Slack, among others. Although semi-retired for many years, she sang occassionally with the bands of Noni Bernardi, Ray Charles and Tommy King. She as a member of the Society of Singers, an avid golfer, and the widow of Dale McMickle, a lead trumpet player with the Glenn Miller Band and copyist. She is survived by her daughter Cristy. In lieu of flowers, it is suggested that donations be made to the Society of Singers. A wake will be held at her home in North Hollywood on Saturday, August 4, 2001 at 4PM.

title: Ideas & Trends: Divided They Stand; The High Court and The Triumph of Discord
description: TWO federal courthouses here provided scenes of stark contrast on the last Thursday in June. At the Supreme Court, the justices concluded their term by announcing decisions in four cases, all by votes of 5 to 4, while almost simultaneously, less than a mile down Constitution Avenue, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit announced its unanimous decision in the Microsoft case.

title: Ambitions Delivered
description: NICHOLAS HARARY is a force of nature, one of those people who descend on the planet out of nowhere and set off earthquakes. He entered the Culinary Institute of America at 15, excelled in the study of wine before he was even allowed to drink it, and became the sommelier of a four-star Manhattan restaurant at 25.

title: Investing; An Online Auctioneer That Helps Cut Costs
description: FREEMARKETS INC. is doing its best impression of Lance Armstrong cycling in the Pyrenees.

title: Vivian Chang, Andrew Hua

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, THE REVEREND PROTOPRESBYTER BASIL S
description: GREGORY-The Reverend Protopresbyter Basil S, a priest of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese and President of Latsis U.S.A. Inc/ SETE Consultants & Services (USA) Inc, reposed on July 12 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Father Basil was a priest for over five decades, serving Greek Orthodox Communities in Scranton, Chicago, Pittsburgh, Brooklyn and Manhattan, where he served St. George Tropsoforos Church for 25 years until his retirement in 1998. From 1964 to 1970, he was the Director of Economic Development of the Greek Orthdox Archdiocese, and later served as the Director of the Office of Press and Information. In addition to his ecclesiastical service, in 1970, he established the U.S. office of the Greek shipping magnate, John S. Latsis, where he served as its president until his passing. He was a 1948 graduate of Holy Cross Greek Orthodox School of Theology in Brookline, MA, and in 1964 earned an MBA from the University of Pittsburgh. He had served on the Boards of the St Michael's Home for the Aged(in Yonkers), Atlantic Bank of New York, the Manhattan School of Music, the American Symphony Orchestra, Hellenic American Chamber of Commerce, and was the President of the American Associates of the St Catherine Foundation(the trust for the conservation of the Library at the St Catherine Monastery in the Sinai Desert). He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Anne, his children Andre and Maria, and Nicholas and Athena and his grandchildren Christina, Marianna, Alexander, Anastasia and Vasiliki. Visiting hours will commence Sunday at 4PM at St George Greek Orthodox Church, 307 West 54 Street. Funeral Monday. Liturgy will commence at 9:30AM at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East 74 St, NYC. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to New York Hospital Pediatric Hematology/Oncology, 525 East 69th St, Room P695, NY, NY 10021. The American Associates of the St Catherine Foundation, 712 Fifth Ave, Suite 9-D, NY, NY 10019.

title: Personal Business; As Rules Ease, More Citizens Choose to Fly 2 Flags
description: ORAZIO GIGLI was a teenager in 1972, when he and his family left behind the orange-scented hills of his native Capaci, outside Palermo, Sicily, in search of greater economic opportunity in the United States. When he became an American citizen five years later, he had to renounce his Italian citizenship, but he never let go of his memories of playing street soccer with a ball made of rags or of the close-knit community of family and neighbors that shared his life.

title: Beethoven, Mozart and . . . Hummel?
description: IN his day, the composer, pianist and pedagogue Johann Nepomuk Hummel was considered as sure a bet for immortality as Beethoven, maybe surer. After all, Beethoven, born eight years earlier, was controversial. Hummel was widely admired, even by Chopin, an effete type not prone to praising other composers. In an 1840 letter to the pianist Anna Caroline de Belleville, Chopin complimented her for her marvelous performances of ''such great masters as Mozart, Beethoven and Hummel, the masters of us all.''

title: China and Kids
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from China, my wife and I read with some apprehension the request for information about visiting China with children ages 3 and 7 (''Family Trip to China,'' Q & A, June 17). We want tourists to be warned, because we weren't prepared for some circumstances that affected even the small group on our luxury tour.

title: Coming Next Year, A Truck de Ville
description: The Escalade EXT is definitely not your grandfather's Cadillac, or his pickup. Due to go on sale in January, the EXT is a plush version of the Chevrolet Avalanche, a four-door truck whose 5-foot cargo bed can be extended to 8 feet by folding the back seats and opening a ``midgate'' at the rear of the cabin.

title: Commercial Property/Hotels; Offering Business Travelers Less-Fancy Quarters

What executives traveling to the nation's core cities really need, he says, are the equivalent of a bed-and-breakfast with high-tech connections to keep them in contact with the rest of the world.

description: To the Editor:

title: July 8-14; Higgs, Still Missing
description: Particle physicists want the world to know that the origin of mass and weight in the universe is not chocolate, as some wags have had it. The physicists thought they had clinched their point last year when an experiment at CERN, in Geneva, apparently saw traces of a long-sought particle, the Higgs boson. Theoretically, matter would be weightless unless the energy of the Higgs fills space like a sort of invisible mousse. But CERN physicists have concluded that they may have mistaken ordinary particles for the Higgs. An experiment at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory near Chicago, home of the Midwest's beloved Frango chocolates, now takes over the search. James Glanz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEMBERTON, CATHERINE WATJEN
description: PEMBERTON-Catherine Watjen. Died peacefully at home on July 6th, 2001, at the age of 99. Widow of the late John C. Pemberton, she was born in New York City on April 26, 1902, graduated from Chapin School with the Class of 1920, attended the Art Students League, and started a fifty-seven year career as interior decorator in 1933. ''Cotty'' was a prominent professional, numbering among her clients Mayor John Lindsay and his wife Mary for whom she decorated Gracie Mansion. She was a member of the Colony and Cosmopolitan clubs, and for almost 50 years maintained a summer home on Norton Farm, Lambert's Cove Road, Martha's Vineyard. Her restored dwelling was built by Captain Nathan Smith in 1740. She is survived by a son, Louis Watjen Pemberton of New York and his four children Christine, Anne, Julia and Andrea, and the four grandchildren by her late son John C. Pemberton, Jr. of Philadelphia; Mary Murdoch, Frances Tyler, Catherine Pemberton and John C. Pemberton IV, as well as seven great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at the Congregational Church of West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard at 3:00 on Sunday July 29th; a memorial service will be held in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave at 51st, at 4:00, October 3rd. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, Central Park Conservancy or the Vineyard Conservation Society.

title: When Dino's Playing, Fold Early and Save Time
description: There are two schools of thought regarding addiction to gambling. One is the insatiable thrill of winning. The other is the insatiable thrill of losing.

title: "The Imitation Factor: Evolution Beyond the Gene"
description: Aristotle raised all the best questions scientists are raising in laboratories today. That might be an overstatement, but if it is, it isn't a grand overstatement; it holds true for the basic questions that we address in my lab, as well as in the labs of many of my colleagues. But Aristotle was wrong, at least for the most part, about the ability of nonhuman animals to imitate. It was a big oversight. Nearly two and a half thousand years later, we discovered nature's blueprints — genes — but still remained almost blind to nature's way of transmitting information across the generations outside the genome. We tend to think we are the only animals able to do the trick of passing down the wisdom of our forebears. That trick is known as culture. Surprisingly, even guppies can do it.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bedford, N.Y.; Peace and Quiet, Even for the Famous

''Spurling is able to convey the speed and mystery of Humbert's rise and fall,'' Alice Kaplan wrote in these pages last year. ''We're left, like her victims, seduced and astounded.''

title: July 8-14; Estrada Arraigned
description: It has not been a good year for Joseph Estrada. In January he was driven out of office as president of the Philippines by a public uprising and military defection. Then he was imprisoned. Now he has been arraigned on a charge of plunder, which, in theory, could bring a death sentence. Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos had better luck. After being forced from office in 1986, he lived in a Hawaii mansion until he died three years later. Mr. Estrada is accused of stealing $76 million, while Mr. Marcos stole billions. Seth Mydans

title: She Adapts A Science Of Illusion To Her Art
description: HARRIET CASDIN-SILVER doesn't look the part of a high-tech pioneer. Now in her mid-70's, she is a small woman with a short-cropped brush of red hair, wire-rimmed glasses and a hearing aid she makes no attempt to conceal. It is one of her few concessions to age. In conversation, she is spirited and often funny, recalling past controversies with relish and bubbling over with ideas for future projects, creating an impression of youthfulness at odds with her years. Such energy and ambition have been conspicuous throughout her 30-year career as one of the country's leading holographers, sustaining her in a profession that falls uncomfortably in the gap between art and science.

title: "Andrew Jackson and His Indian Wars"
description: The great Shawnee chief Tecumseh let out a terrifying whoop. Six Shawnees, six Kickapoos, and six Winnebagos responded with similar cries. Together, with two Creek warriors as guides, they boarded canoes and headed down the Wabash to the Ohio River on their way south to the country of the Five Civilized Nations: Creeks, Cherokees, Chickasaws, Choctaws, and Seminoles. They were beginning a momentous journey that would change the course of American history in ways they never intended. Tecumseh expected to persuade the southern tribes into joining a stupendous confederation of Native Americans reaching from the Canadian frontier to the Gulf of Mexico with which he would launch a massive Indian attack against white settlements. With such an alliance he expected to sweep the white devils back into the ocean whence they had come and restore the continent to its rightful owners.

title: "The Algeria Hotel: France, Memory, and the Second World War"
description: The Sewing Room

title: The Silence of the Earps
description: Wyatt Earp might be the best known of Old West lawmen, but despite his frequent depiction in movies he's appeared somewhat rarely in novels. Maybe the problem has been deciding whether Earp was a hero or a villain. Robert B. Parker, the creator of the Spenser detective series, has taken the refreshing view that Earp was a man long before he was a symbol and has written GUNMAN'S RHAPSODY (Putnam, $22.95), a swift-moving, satisfying novel about Earp's controversial two years in Arizona. It's a novel that shows surprising fidelity to most of the known facts without letting them get in the way of a good story. Parker's strengths here, as in his crime novels, are plot and dialogue. In ''Gunman's Rhapsody'' he has a terrific ready-made story in the events that led to the gunfight at the O.K. Corral and its bloody aftermath of revenge, and he creates a spare Western vernacular that gets to the truth in a hurry. Wyatt and his older brother Virgil converse in a kind of shorthand in which silences are as meaningful as words. ''She ain't much,'' Virgil says of Wyatt's common-law wife, the doomed, alcoholic Mattie. ''No,'' Wyatt says, ''she ain't.'' ''Still, you took up with her.'' ''Yep.'' Parker's Wyatt knows more than he says and seldom says all he knows; only Josephine Marcus, the beautiful young Jewish actress from San Francisco (and Sheriff John Behan's fiance) has his number. ''Did you plan to collar me?'' asks the seductive Josephine when Wyatt drops by, ostensibly looking for suspects. ''Well, yes,'' replies Wyatt, ''in a manner of speaking.'' Then, we read, ''She walked right up to him and put her body against his and raised her face and said in the softest voice imaginable, 'I'll go peacefully.' '' Allen Barra

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHLEY, CHARLES ALLEN, M.D.
description: ASHLEY-Charles Allen, M.D. The Trustees and staff of Bassett Healthcare mourn the loss of our former Director, Charles Allen Ashley, M.D. Under Dr. Ashley's leadership (1967-1984), Bassett experienced significant growth in terms of the number of patients served, expanded medical education programs and innovative research initiatives. Dr. Ashley also founded Bassett's philanthropic support organization, The Friends of Bassett. Dr. Ashley originally joined Bassett in 1947 as an intern. He returned in 1955 as an Associate Pathologist. He conducted considerable research, which generated numerous publications. Following his retirement, Dr. Ashley continued as a consultant until 1988. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Audrey, and his entire family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Friends of Bassett, One Atwell Road, Cooperstown, New York 13326; Cornell University, 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850; or Cornell University Medical College, 1300 York Ave., Box 61, New York, NY 10021. title: Harvard's Hoard
description: I read with interest Johanna Berkman's article on Harvard's endowment (June 24). My interest in the unprofitable side of life earned me Harvard Medical School's first Kurt Isselbacher Humanitarian Award. However, my pursuit of primary care in an urban, medically underserved neighborhood, coupled with the federal government's abrupt cancellation of its loan-relief program, has left me scrounging to meet my monthly $1,363 student-loan payments. Numerous phone calls to Harvard for assistance in renegotiating my $100,000 debt (one-third owed directly to Harvard at the ''subsidized'' rate of 9 percent) gets me rapidly transferred to the collections department.

title: QUICK BITE/Stone Harbor; A Professor's Summer Job Scooping Ice Cream
description: For the last 27 years, as the college classes he's taught have wound down, Neil Humphreys has the same itch as many of his students: to head to the beach. But for Mr. Humphreys, summer days at the Jersey Shore have been a busboy's holiday. The business management professor becomes a businessman, the owner of Springer's Homemade Ice Cream in Stone Harbor. The lines along Third Avenue into the clapboard building jammed between a convenience store and an Italian restaurant sometimes stretch for a block. But few complain, since the end result is the ice cream Mr. Humphreys, his wife, Barbara, and their three adult children make by hand daily. From recipes for 65 flavors, the Humphreys choose as many as four dozen to offer each day. For $2 a generous scoop, the creamy Springer's version is a bit lighter than the ultra-butterfatted vogue of recent years. The Humphreys all live the rest of the year in Virginia, where Mr. Humphreys has taught at Virginia Commonwealth University and Longwood College. ''But we're here in Stone Harbor by choice,'' said Mary Humphreys, who has scooped at Springer's since age 7, when her parents bought Springer's and its recipes from Jack Fitzpatrick. ''Dad constantly said he wanted to buy it if he was selling, and finally, he did.'' The business, they believe, started during Prohibition, as one proprietor's change from the bar trade. A favorite flavor, Springer Chip, comes from the Fitzpatrick's era. ''Oh, that was a mistake,'' Mary Humphreys said. ''Someone put chocolate chips in coffee instead of vanilla. But it's been a huge hit ever since, so we don't change back.'' Robert Strauss

title: A Wandering Radio Station Finds a Home at Mercy College
description: FOR 33 of his 43 years, Marc Sophos has wanted basically one thing: to be able to devote all his time to WDFH-FM (90.3), a radio station he started in his home here when he was 10. Now his dream is about to be realized.

title: Faking It
description: When Internet stocks began their free fall in March 2000, the Internet was finally put in its proper place. It was nothing more than a fast delivery service for information -- that was what serious people who had either lost a lot of money in the late stages of the Internet boom or, more likely, failed to make money began to say now. The profit-making potential of the Internet had been overrated, and so the social effects of the Internet were presumed to be overrated. But they weren't. Speeding up information was not the only thing the Internet had done. The Internet had made it possible for people to thwart all sorts of rules and conventions. It wasn't just the commercial order that was in flux. Many forms of authority were secured by locks waiting to be picked. The technology and money-making potential of the Internet were far less interesting than the effects people were allowing it to have on their lives and what these, in turn, said about those lives.

The students, staff, and faculty at the CUNY Graduate Center mourn the sudden and untimely death of Sue Rosenberg Zalk, Vice President for Student Affairs and pioneer in the study of women and society. She will be remembered for her unfailing committment to students, to CUNY, and to The Graduate Center, for her outstanding work as Editor of ''Sex Roles'', and for her always being a thoughtful colleague, a consummate professional, a passionate advocate, mentor, counselor, and friend. Devoted husband of Dorothy, beloved father of Carol Brown, Valerie Schechter & Leslie Bagon. Cherished grandfather of Courtney, Eric, Nathaniel, Dana & Sarah. Proud greatgrandfather of Jonas & Maia.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on June 24 about the film ''The Warriors'' misspelled the surname of the author of the novel on which it was based. He is Sol Yurick, not Yuris.

title: Cash Advances Are Under Scrutiny
description: After the police said that the Giants' rookie cornerback Will Allen had been robbed of more than $150,000 worth of jewelry, almost everyone in the Giants' organization had the same two thoughts.

title: The Greatest?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Long Arm of the Law Reaches Into the Gallery
description: DESPITE its title, ''Art at the Edge of the Law'' at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, is more earnest than sensational. According to Richard Klein, the museum's assistant director, the show was previewed by several lawyers and members of the Ridgefield police department. They found it to be this side of illicit and recommended it to their colleagues to boot.

title: Chicken-Hearted
description: In ''The Natural History of the Chicken'' (today at 2 p.m. on Channel 13), Mark Lewis, the director, goes beyond the dinner table to prove that one person's Fido may be another person's Valerie. Consider the case of Janet Bonney's feathered friend, whom she found in a Maine snowstorm, legs extended in the air like a couple of Popsicle sticks. ''I did what I had to do,'' Ms.Bonney said: she performed C.P.R. and brought Valerie back to life. And then there is Karin Estrada of West Palm Beach, who routinely bathes and blow-dries her favorite fowl, Cotton, before sitting her down in front of the television for her daily dose of opera. Finally, Mr. Lewis lionizes the chicken who valiantly tried to save her brood of chicks from an attacking hawk. ''I wanted to show how you could never call a chicken a coward,'' said Mr. Lewis, who grew up on a farm in Australia. ''In spite of the fact that the chicken has been domesticated, it still has a natural history like any other animal. It's just as valid as a house pet as in a meat-processing plant.''

title: Relocation Specialist
description: ANDREW JACKSON

title: Saint Laurent Sets It Right in Paris
description: The Americans who arrive here each summer after their Fourth of July barbecues and leave just before the Bastille Day playing of the ''Marseillaise'' constitute one of the more hearty minorities still going. They are the couture customers, those well-heeled ladies of the front row, and in good times or bad, they are here -- living out the dream of owning exquisite clothes while quietly contemplating how they're going to break it to their husbands that the dress they want costs $50,000.

title: July 8-14; Switch on Military Strategy
description: The military has new marching orders. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and senior commanders agreed that the strategy set in 1993 of remaining ready for two major wars at one time will be replaced by requirements to maintain four broad capabilities: win in a single major conflict, defend U.S. territory, deter hostilities through global deployments and conduct small-scale actions of limited duration -- all at once. Contained in a classified document called ''terms of reference,'' the guidelines will be used in drafting future strategy and budgets. Thom Shanker

title: By Adding Weatherspoon, The Knicks Are Near a Wrap
description: Three days remain before the Knicks can officially sign players, but almost all of their off-season work is done. On Friday Allan Houston waived his request for a no-trade clause and accepted the Knicks' offer of a six-year, $100 million contract, a person who knows of the negotiations said. The deal will make Houston the highest-paid player in franchise history.

title: The Red-State Network
description: I will believe the claims of ''balance'' when I see Michael Moore on Fox News as often as Bill O'Reilly. The myth of the liberal news media is conservatism's version of the Big Lie -- say it often enough and people begin to believe it. The only authentically liberal voices in broadcast journalism work for small, listener-supported radio stations.

title: Private Sector; Fast Cars, Harleys and Cheesecake
description: THE muscular and dapper chief executive of the Sara Lee Corporation, C. Steven McMillan, used to drive Formula 2000 race cars as a hobby. He also took to riding Harley-Davidson motorcycles to relax. And legend has it that he once stuck his head in a tiger's mouth on a dare.

title: Perks for Pets
description: Loyalty is prized in pets, and hotels value it in their customers. So it's only natural that the Metropolitan Hotel, at Lexington and 51st Street in Manhattan, has developed a Privileged Paws frequent-stay program for pets. After five nights, for example, a pet receives a free room-service meal and bowl of fluoride-enriched water; after 30 nights, pets get an Emre collar from Henri Bendel and an hourlong session with a pet psychic and animal communicator; (866) 638-7669 or www.metropolitanhotelnyc.com.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Short, Troubled Life Prompts Reflections
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ICCHOK IGNACY
description: GOLDBERG-Icchok Ignacy. 85, Professor Emeritus of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, died June 2.

title: Political Briefing; Taking Another Stab At State's Term Limits
description: In the 11 years since California voters approved term limits for state legislators -- six years for Assembly members and eight years for senators -- a number of efforts have been made to repeal or soften the limits, none successful. But opponents of limits keep trying, not just in California but also in the 18 other states with limits. They argue that while some turnover of entrenched lawmakers may be healthy, the downside of term limits is that the terms tend to be so restrictive that legislatures often end up being run by amateurs and career lobbyists.

title: The Fabled No. 7, Not So Lucky These Days
description: SUBWAY riders in the city need a strategy. For many riders of the No. 7 train, whose sassy red cars shuttle between Times Square and Flushing, Queens, the big decision in the past year has been whether to squeeze onto a crowded morning rush-hour car or wait several minutes for another train that might be a beat less packed.

title: 2004 Buzz: Bradley, Kerry, Gore and More
description: Action is picking up on the Election 2004 front.

title: Rebecca Patterson, Robert Frank
description: Rebecca Hope Patterson and Robert Louis Frank were married yesterday by the Rev. Ginger Grab, who performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist in Barrytown, N.Y.

title: Our Budget Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, NAHUM
description: GRAY-Nahum. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nahum Gray, associated with The Times from 1951 until 1980.

title: Finding a New Way At an Old Theater
description: EVEN when Lucille Lortel conceded, she had her way.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-15-01: The Ethicist; Firm Commitments
description: A senior manager with a consulting firm, I often interview job candidates. My role is both to evaluate them and to ''sell'' them on our firm, a place I've grown less enamored of. In fact, I'm seeking other employment. What do I tell candidates who ask my opinion of the firm? If I tell the truth, I harm my firm's chance to land them; but a lie is unfair to the candidate. And I can't avoid doing the interview. Anonymous, Mass.

title: THE GUIDE
description: DuMond in Spotlight

description: To the Editor:

title: The Cheapest Seats in the House
description: Most people paid between $15 and $68 apiece to watch the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater perform ''Revelations'' and other works at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center's Prudential Hall on May 12. But more than 200 people paid just $5 each -- and some of them even sat in the orchestra section -- thanks to the Bildner Ticket Fund, which provides cut-rate seats to community groups.

title: Hold the Homogeneity. Hot Dogs Stay Local.
description: AS yet, the food-manufacturing behemoths of America have been unable to take over the $1.7 billion supermarket hot-dog market, and the reason was abundantly clear here on a recent day. Not far from the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, during high season for the great American pastime, more than 1,100 frankfurter worshipers queued up enthusiastically under a party tent at the Farmers' Museum to sample 11 brands of regional wieners.

title: With Zest the Deceased Once Had, Town Recalls Its Flight 800 Victims
description: The graves of the teenagers are no longer raw like the grief of family survivors and friends who journey up to touch the headstones and stare out quietly from the hillside burial ground.

description:
Document is not available.

title: To Get to Be Mr. Insider, It Helps to Be an Outsider
description: The candidates for governor have been slamming Trenton and its corrupt ways, and Trenton is obliging them by serving up the last week's news about the way the firm chosen by the state to test auto emissions used lobbyists to get inside information on the contract they eventually won, and then had so much trouble getting right.

title: For Housing Plan, Landscape Is the Priority
description: WHAT distinguishes Mooreland Glen, a development of upscale houses to be built in Kensington, is everything it is not. The houses will be modern, not faux historic, and manageable in size rather than starter castles.

title: Mysteries of the Wild Beasts of India
description: 'So far as I am able to judge,'' Mark Twain once wrote, ''nothing has been left undone, either by man or Nature, to make India the most extraordinary country that the sun visits on his round.'' It is ''the Land of the Thug,'' he continued, ''the land of Famine . . . the Land of Giant Illusions, the Land of Stupendous Mountains'' and ''by an unapproachable supremacy the land of Murderous Wild Creatures.'' India's wild creatures are no more or less intrinsically ''murderous'' than animals elsewhere, but they do come in closer contact with human beings and, as two new books for children attest, that continuing clash yields compelling stories.

title: The King and I
description: ELVIS IN THE MORNING

title: The Red-State Network
description: The Fox News Channel says that it is ''fair and balanced'' and that ''we report, you decide.'' If that were true, Fox would not have to remind viewers of this so often. The stories would speak for themselves.

title: Welcome to the Capital of Wacky Laws
description: I HAVE not left the house in 146 days because of the Lists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, PAUL
description: MARKS-Paul. On July 2, 2001. Loving son of Irving H. Marks and Mindy Wexler Marks. A friend and brother to Daniel, Anna, and Alexis Marks.

title: A Beach Assault In Full Metal
description: For those wearied by the frivolous fruit patterns of this summer's swimwear, the season's collections also offer a more serious alternative: swimsuits trimmed with all manner of hardware.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UBALDI, GIACOMO ''JACK'' M.
description: UBALDI-Giacomo ''Jack'' M. On July 14. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Richard, Augustine and Joan Costello. Beloved grandfather of ten. WWII Navy veteran. Former owner of the Florence Meat Market in Greenwich Village, NY, and cooking instructor at the New School and the Peter Kump School of Culinary Arts. Author of ''Jack Ubaldi's Meat Book.'' Visitation Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at the Morisco Funeral Home, Inc, 30-12 Astoria Blvd, Astoria. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday, Mt. Carmel Church, Astoria. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Shrine of St. Jude would be appreciated.

title: Vintage Knowledge
description: Rhone Valley wines are the liquid curriculum for a pair of seven-night courses at the Universit du Vin, in the 12th-century Chteau de Suze, in Suze-la-Rousse in the Rhone Valley in France. The English-language courses, Sept. 23 to 30 and Oct. 21 to 28, include three seminars followed by lunches that match wines with regional dishes. There will also be visits to vineyards. Accommodations are in the Chteau de Rochegude and the Place de l'Horloge in Avignon. The cost is $2,460 a person, double occupancy, and does not include air fare or dinner wines. Information: (800) 639-3331.

title: Lieberman Put Democrats In Retreat on Military Vote
description: For many Democrats immersed in Florida's disputed presidential election, there was no worse moment than the one on Sunday, Nov. 19, when Senator Joseph I. Lieberman appeared on national television and said that election officials should give the ''benefit of the doubt'' to military voters.

title: Tracking Radiohead
description: To the Editor:

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: He's Too Busy To Call It Retirement

title: The Track's Quite Springy
description: To the Editor:

title: July 8-14; Slave Report Widens Blame
description: The State Department issued its first report on the worldwide trafficking in slaves and faulted 23 countries for failing to make much effort to stop the trade. Such reports usually criticize Burma, North Korea, Iran and Afghanistan -- countries that care little what Washington thinks. But this one slapped at Israel, Russia, Greece and Turkey, among other countries important to Washington. All are potentially subject to sanctions, if they don't improve. But the sanctions don't take effect until 2003 -- which may be one reason the department chose to be so direct this year. Joel Brinkley

title: Habitats/Forest Hills, Queens; In This Co-op Apartment, Murals Are Wall to Wall
description: NEW YORK CITY may be the white-wall capital of the world. White is supposed to make spaces seem larger, and most apartments in the city could benefit from feeling a bit grander.

description: STALIN'S SECRET POGROM The Postwar Inquisition of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee. Edited by Joshua Rubenstein and Vladimir P. Naumov. Translated by Laura Esther Wolfson. Illustrated. 527 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.
