O'Byrne of Rye. The Most Rev. James McCarthy, an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: After 85 Years, Texas Air Base Closes
description: SAN ANTONIO, July 14 (AP) — Kelly Air Force Base has become history, closing 85 years after it opened at the height of World War I.

title: Business; An American Directs Mexico City's Cinema Revival
description: EIGHT years ago, without knowing a word of Spanish, a ponytailed Harvard Business School student named Matthew D. Heyman came here to seek his fortune. He surveyed the city's aging movie theaters and gave himself five years to become a millionaire.

title: Nationalism in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPER, LOIS MAY (NEE GUTERMAN)
description: JASPER-Lois May (nee Guterman). Loving wife of the late Julius. Beloved mother of Steve and Nancy, Richard and Millie, Barbara & Stuart Aferiat. Adored grandmother of Kyle, Ben, Robert, Lily, Alex and Corey. Dear sister of Elaine Kaufman. After a courageous battle with cancer. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. Service Sunday, July 15th, 10AM at Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MITCHELL
description: KAUFMAN-Mitchell, 93. On July 12, 2001. Beloved husband of Loretta, father of Seth (Patricia), grandfather of David and Robert, brother of Jess and the late Howard Kaufman.

title: Geography Is Destiny
description: THE BOSTONS

title: Public Universities and Private Money
description: If public university presidents could have more training in any area, their top choice would not be greater experience in administrative or faculty posts. Instead, more than half wish they had had more training in fund-raising, according to the American Council on Education.

title: In a Tight Transpac, Pegasus Pulls Through
description: In years past, the glorified stars of the biennial Transpac Race from Los Angeles to Honolulu were the navigators. On their shoulders lay the critical job of interpreting the weather, poring over the charts and finding the fastest -- if not necessarily the shortest -- route to the islands.

title: Hotel Rates Advance While Occupancy Drops
description: WHEN preliminary figures were released last month showing that nationwide occupancy rates at hotels had fallen 4 to 5 percent in May from the same month last year, it would have been logical to assume that room rates had also fallen. After all, the national economy continues to sputter, hotels are adding energy surcharges to bills, and -- until recently -- near-record gasoline prices presumably were a deterrent to travel. This would hardly seem a propitious time for rate increases.

title: July 8-14; Ireland's Hopes Fading
description: The British and Irish governments want the Irish Republican Army to put its guns far away, but it's balking until Britain acts to remove its troops from Ulster -- and on that all-too-familiar note of impasse, peace talks stalled yet again. Negotiators reconvened -- after riots broke out in Belfast -- but the British prime minister, Tony Blair, warned that it might be the last chance to make the power-sharing government from the 1998 peace accord a reality. Hubert B. Herring

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, CATHERINE A.
description: HIGGINS-Catherine A. On July 13, 2001. Of Rye, NY, formerly of Manhasset, NY, and Charlestown, RI. Widow of the late George B. Higgins. Mother of Catherine Higgins, Helen Minetti and George Higgins. Grandmother of Sean Higgins and Michael Minetti. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Sunday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Emerging Artists, Emerging Visions
description: Emerging Artists

title: BUSH AIDES WEIGH LEGALIZING STATUS OF MEXICANS IN U.S.
description: President Bush's top immigration advisers are weighing plans to allow the more than three million Mexicans living illegally in the United States to earn permanent legal residency, officials involved in the deliberations said today.

title: Numbers And Pain Add Up For Piazza
description: Mike Piazza had a typical experience when he woke up yesterday morning. Open your eyes and then feel the tightness in your lower back. Sometimes, there is a variation. Feel the tightness in your lower back and then open your eyes. Piazza has endured the pain for about a month.

title: Extra Oil, Please
description: To the Editor: For those who cannot get to Edirne to see the olive oil wrestlers (''Turkey's Version of Wrestlemania,'' June 24), there is that wonderful caper movie ''Topkapi,'' with a sequence that puts you in the middle of the festival, both inside the stadium and the surrounding camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, ANITA BELFER
description: SALTZ-Anita Belfer. We mourn the loss of Anita Belfer Saltz and extend our condolences to the entire family. Eli Zborowski, Chairman American and International Societies for Yad Vashem

title: Victoria Gilbert, Christopher Maksymowicz
description: Victoria Elizabeth Gilbert and Christopher Anthony Maksymowicz were married last evening by the Rev. Philippa A. Turner at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

title: Maureen Marsh, Christopher Abularrage
description: Maureen Siobhan Marsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Marsh of Rhinebeck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Christopher Joseph Abularrage, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Abularrage of Douglas Manor, Queens. The Rev. James Lee Dugan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the chapel at the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Buying Groups of Buildings to Create Campuses
description: TWO companies with longtime roots on Long Island are contributing to the changing face of the island's commercial and industrial community by buying groups of buildings in an area and renovating and unifying them in campuslike settings.

title: LIVES; On the Edge
description: You could tell by the guy's voice something was going on. It was May of '91. I was a covering lieutenant in Rescue 1 in Manhattan. We were ordered to respond to Seventh Avenue and 48th Street. They're starting to say on the radio that there's a bad fire -- people are trapped. We make a right onto 45th Street, and there was a garbage truck there. Instead of waiting for him to clear, we backed out and went around. So we get there, and two people are hanging out different windows. We started charging up the stairs. It was a 12-story building. I was so pumped I don't even remember that being a hindrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANFORD, CHARLES H. ''BUD.''
description: SANFORD-Charles H. ''Bud.'' Of Southport, CT, died on July 12, 2001. Survived by two sons, Samuel C. Sanford of Manlius, NY, Charles H. ''Tim'' Sanford of Greenwood Village, CO; two daughters, Polly Sosnowski of Wadmalaw Island, SC, and Sally Sanford of Concord, MA; a stepdaughter, Suzette King of Tucson, AZ; a step-son, Horton Spitzer, of Jackson, WY; fourteen grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 661 Old Post Rd, Fairfield, CT, on Thursday, August 9, 2001, at 10 AM. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to: The Anthony Trust Association, PO Box 205471, New Haven, CT 06520 or to Yale University, 265 Church St, New Haven, CT 06510-7003.

title: Cures From Abroad?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bit of Sheer, A Bit of History
description: When Hubert de Givenchy showed his first collection, in 1952, the hit of the show was the white Bettina blouse, named for the model who wore it. Givenchy arrived when Paris couture had very set rules. He showed separates cut from cheap cottons because he couldn't afford luxury fabrics. The store buyers dismissed his offering as a flash in the pan, when in fact it was a visionary look at what would happen 40 years later. Givenchy soon fell under the spell of Balenciaga and Audrey Hepburn, and abandoned his separates. Today, designers have revived variations on the Bettina blouse, often in diaphanous organdy. There are street versions, bottom far right, and luncheon versions, above and bottom far left. Two sheer beauties, below and top left, are from Saint Laurent couture.

title: Art and Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,000th Victory for Valentine, Single Blemish for Rusch
description: The news release was already being prepared in the third inning. The headline was ''A Grand Day for Bobby V,'' and it was in anticipation of Bobby Valentine's 1,000th victory as a manager. Glendon Rusch was coasting against the Boston Red Sox and Mark Johnson had hit a homer, so the Mets were cautiously confident.

title: Young One Is Too Restless, So the Old Fox Gains a Point
description: When taking on a talented youth, one has to be careful. Above all, do not get into a wild tactical melee. This opponent won't get calculation fatigue; he'll love it and give it his best. This stricture was nicely followed by the American grandmaster Boris Gulko, sometimes called the Old Fox, in his game with Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, a 14-year-old grandmaster, who last year set a record by achieving his rank at 13. They met in the second round of the Sigeman & Company International Tournament in Malmo, Sweden.

title: You Can't Get Here From There With That Bridge, M.T.A. Says
description: Maspeth's new 58th Street Bridge is nowhere near 58th Street. It's stuck in Albany, where it was built and where it will stay until the State Department of Transportation can figure out how to get it to Queens.

title: Cuomo Is Catching Up to McCall In Money-Raising Marathon
description: Just five months into his campaign for governor, Andrew M. Cuomo's fund-raising has nearly matched that of his rival for the Democratic nomination, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, the Cuomo campaign reported today, with $4.6 million raised and $4 million in cash on hand.

title: Private Sector; Pirate of Prague, or Comeback Kid?
description: Times are tough for Viktor Kozeny, an migr Czech financier who became known as the Pirate of Prague over accusations of defrauding investors in the Czech Republic and the oil-rich Caspian nation of Azerbaijan. Creditors have repossessed his London home, his wife has left him, and the Czech police are investigating where the assets of his Czech investment funds have gone. Courts have frozen nearly all of Mr. Kozeny's property in America and Britain.

title: The Water's Fine, but the Rental Costs Leave People Cold
description: The rich get richer and the poorer go to Wildwood.

title: Past Scandal Could Haunt I.O.C. Candidate
description: Now that Beijing has been awarded the 2008 Summer Games, delegates of the International Olympic Committee have turned their attention to a vote they consider more important, electing a replacement for the president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, on Monday.

title: A Good Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, C. NICHOLAS
description: POTTER-C. Nicholas. Of Mill Neck, NY died peacefully at home on July 10th after a courageous battle with cancer. He was 62 years old. Loving and devoted husband of Clare; proud father of Cary Nicholas Jr. & his wife Alison, Christopher Kingsland & Jennifer; grandfather of Macy Lockheart, Nina Webb and Nicholas Alonzo; son of Julia M. Thompson; and brother of Charles, Dickie and Frances Thieriot. Until his retirement in 1997, Mr. Potter was a Senior Executive at J.P. Morgan & Co. A graduate of Yale University, he joined Morgan in 1965 after destroyer service in the U.S. Navy. Over the course of his 32-year career, he held a variety of senior positions with Morgan, all in the investment management area. In 1974 he started the firm's international investment management business in London putting Morgan at the forefront of one of the world's most rapidly growing financial services businesses. In 1984, he was appointed President and Chief Executive of J.P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. with overall responsibility for investment management. Under his leadership, J.P. Morgan became one of the largest and most successful global investment managers in the world. Mr. Potter was a director of Phoenix House, a trustee of The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation and a trustee of The Hospital for Special Surgery. From 1981 to 1997, when it merged with American Reinsurance Company, he was a director, Chairman of the Finance Committee and member of the Executive Committee of Munich American Reinsurance Company. From 1985 to 1996, he served as a trustee of St. Mark's School, Southborough, Massachusetts. Services will be held on Monday, July 16, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church in Locust Valley, L.I. at 11:30AM. Memorial contributions may be made to Phoenix House Development Fund, 164 W 74th St, NY, NY 10023.

title: July 8-14; Verdict for Embassy Bomber
description: A second terrorist in the embassy bombings case will be sentenced to life without parole after a federal jury in Manhattan deadlocked on whether to impose the death penalty. The terrorist, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, was convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania, which killed 11. The jury did not say how it divided, but reported that 7 of 12 jurors concluded that if Mr. Mohamed were executed, ''he will be seen as a martyr and his death may be exploited by others to justify future terrorist acts.'' The same jury deadlocked last month in the case of Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24, who was convicted in the nearly simultaneous attack on the embassy in Kenya, which killed 213. Benjamin Weiser

title: Laura Morsman, John Thorsen
description: Laura Winston Morsman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Morsman III of Deerfield, Mass., was married yesterday to John Chaffee Thorsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Thorsen of Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Gordon McClellan, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Deerfield.

title: Jobless Rates Don't Convey A Key Aspect: Does It Last?
description: FOR the last six months, American companies have been laying off tens of thousands of workers, while their counterparts in Europe have been adding to their payrolls. Yet unemployment in the United States -- 4.5 percent in June -- remains lower than it is across the Atlantic.

title: Continental and United Forge E-Ticket Link
description: Continental Airlines and United Airlines have made their electronic tickets compatible. This means either airline can issue an electronic ticket for a trip that involves a connection to the other. It also means that if a passenger holding an e-ticket on one line must be transferred to the other line because of a flight cancellation or labor dispute, the process of turning the original ticket into a paper ticket for endorsement won't be necessary.

title: After All That, Webber Is Likely to Stay
description: After all the innuendo and speculation, Chris Webber is about to stay put.

title: Jamaica Station Project: Making Train-Changing More Pleasant (by 2005)
description: THE construction detours that went up last month at the Jamaica station of the Long Island Rail Road -- not to mention the noise of jackhammers and timetable changes -- will be around for the next four years.

title: Family-Run Theater Still Draws Audiences

Stanley of Kirkland, Wash., was married yesterday to Michael David Preston, the son of Carol A. Preston, also of Madison, and the late David B. Preston. The Right Rev. Gerard P. title: Corrections

She was Jacqueline Asbury, not Margaret Jayne Bryan, a granddaughter of the bridegroom, who was a flower girl.

title: Keeping Two Talents In Balance
description: THE first time the installation artist Ann Hamilton heard Meredith Monk, it was 1981 and Ms. Hamilton was just out of college. ''It was an incredibly modest affair -- just Meredith and her voice,'' she recalled. ''But I actually said to myself, 'If I can ever make work that feels like this sounds' -- you felt your own volume in what you were hearing; it made you sit up, expectant -- 'I'd be very happy.' ''

description: To the Editor:

title: Critics at Home Surfacing in Wake of China's Successful Bid for the Games
description: The ink had hardly dried on the gushing headlines celebrating this city's winning bid to stage the 2008 Summer Olympic Games before some Chinese started questioning the euphoria.

title: Vacancy Rate Falls In Commercial Office Space
description: About 283,692 square feet of commercial office space in Westchester County were leased in the second quarter of 2001, causing the vacancy rate to fall to 6.8 percent from 7.9 percent in the first quarter, according to figures from CB Richard Ellis, a real estate services company with an office in Stamford that tracks about 411 properties, each containing 10,000 square feet or more of rentable area.

title: Fresh Seafood With Creative Touches
description: THE food has not been this good at 2468 Main Street in Bridgehampton since the days when C. J. Thorne was there. The most recent restaurants at this address were best known for their stylish late-night bar scenes.

title: Maria Chabot, 87, Dies; Began Indian Market and Was an O'Keeffe Associate
description: Maria Chabot, who in the 1930's began the popular Indian markets on the Plaza in Santa Fe, N.M., and later became a close associate of the painter Georgia O'Keeffe, died on Monday in an Albuquerque hospital. She was 87.

title: GAS PRICES FALL
description: Gasoline prices in New Jersey have fallen about 10 cents a gallon over the last month, according to the American Automobile Association's New Jersey chapter. Surveys by the chapter showed unleaded regular gas at $1.57 a gallon last week and $1.67 a month earlier; it was $1.58 a year ago. Premium was $1.75 last week and $1.86 a month earlier. An A.A.A. spokeswoman attributed the decreases to lower demand as a result of conservation by drivers. John Holl

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: I have known Allen Steere for almost 40 years; he is an ethical, gentle, humble human being who happens to be an outstanding physician. As a parent of a child who has suffered an illness -- initially misdiagnosed as Lyme disease -- I can appreciate the frustration voiced by some of the patients quoted in David Grann's article (June 17). But shame on those who would threaten Dr. Steere. The very diagnosis they seek would have been unavailable, if not for him.

title: When Life Was Spending Time on the Roof
description: THE heat wave and heavy, polluted air that rolled in with July were the perfect weather conditions for ''Up on the Roof: The Culture of New York City Rooftops,'' which opened recently at The New-York Historical Society, on Central Park West at 77th Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the lack of privacy in e-mail communications misstated the date of an announcement by the University of Tennessee that an administrator, Pamela S. Reed, had falsified her rsum. The announcement occurred on June 13, not June 14.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Art Nurtured In Communism Has Advocate
description: ON a gray, rainy Saturday with a decidedly Eastern European grimness about it, Marsha Child cheerfully prepared her art gallery in Princeton for an opening party. The mostly earth-toned paintings of Natalya Zaloznaya, a Byelorussian artist who recently relocated to Belgium, were arranged in the gallery, and an industrial-size jug of white wine cooled in the refrigerator.

title: Just the Spot When Weather Is Spotty
description: July is a wonderful time to explore Cape May and the surrounding environment, when one is taking a break from the beach, the sand and the sun. But what to do when it rains?

title: The Name Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Winner on Bastille Day Is From the Right Country
description: Laurent Jalabert, that old and skillful warrior, knows what it is like to be a French rider who wins the Tour de France's daily stage on July 14, the national holiday.

title: Belt Tightening Is Called Threat To the Economy
description: Like many other American consumers, Steven Saint-George has suddenly gone from being a source of the economy's strength to a reason to fret about its future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLANSKY, SUSAN GRANT
description: KAPLANSKY-Susan Grant. On June 28, Susan Grant-Kaplansky lost her heroic battle for life. The Lehmans, who knew Susan from birth, were devastated by her sickness, and now her passing. Susan was a wonderful daughter to Dr. Alfred and Ellen Grant, sister to Michelle and Laura, sister-in-law to Eyal Dagan, wife to Eyal, and loving mother to Edon, Tamir, Gil, & Eliya. She was a remarkable and idealistic woman who chose to live in Israel and raise a large family. We were all very proud of her and feel fortunate that we knew such a ''wonder.'' Our hearts are broken. May the family never know any more sorrow. Wally & Sheila Lehman & Family

title: Nile Virus in Florida Bird Raises Concern About Fast Spread
description: The West Nile virus that first appeared in North America when it struck New York two years ago has now reached as far south as Florida, federal and state health officials say.

title: Harvard's Hoard
description: If Harvard does not spend its enormous income for its exempt purpose, its excess should be taxed, like that of the rest of American businesses.

title: When Doctors Feel Disposable
description: THE doctor on the line is very angry. What they don't understand, she says, is how hard she works, how many lives she has saved and how much it costs her to run an office. If they did, she said, her voice shaking with anger, they would never make the choices they do.

title: Jaime Chapin and Timothy Miller
description: SARAH JAMES CHAPIN and Timothy Breese Miller were known among friends for being socially and politically aware, but neither was having much luck with relationships. So, when a mutual friend asked Ms. Chapin if she could give her number to Mr. Miller, she said she was intrigued but skeptical.

title: Gauging Analysts' Ratings
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-15-01; I Oughta Be In Pictures
description: History made on celluloid might as well be history written in sand. In the old Soviet Union, movies could be strategically re-edited to eliminate actors or historical figures fallen from favor; in the new Hollywood, the reasons are seldom so straightforward.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Friday about Larry Clark's film ''Bully'' misstated a previous credit for the actor Nick Stahl, who appears in the film. He did not appear in Mr. Clark's film ''Kids.''

title: Bank Jobs Lead To Odd Jobs
description: Few people who call the state Division of Travel and Tourism to find out where they can pick strawberries or locate the best campground realize that the woman answering their questions is serving time.

title: Wells's Surgery May End Season
description: CHICAGO, July 14 (Bloomberg News) — White Sox pitcher David Wells is scheduled to have surgery on a herniated disk in his back on Wednesday and will probably miss the rest of the season.

title: Knoblauch Helps Yanks Avoid Sweep In Florida
description: A tarp protected the field from a drenching rain this morning and the Yankees took batting practice in an indoor cage. Chuck Knoblauch tested his badly bruised left elbow for the first time in two days, his first swings tentative.

title: A Short, Troubled Life Prompts Reflections

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUERRERO, ANTONIA
description: GUERRERO-Antonia. July 13, 2001. Alumna and Professor of Spanish at Brooklyn College for 32 years. Loving sister of Frank, Marie and Eleanor. Loving aunt and great-aunt.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption with the Vows column last week (June 8), about the marriage of Marcia Lewis and Fred Bryan, misidentified a child who was a guest at the wedding and referred incorrectly to her role. She was Jacqueline Asbury, not Margaret Jayne Bryan, a granddaughter of the bridegroom, who was a flower girl.

title: Target Said to Be Hit In an Antimissile Test
description: The Pentagon said its first attempt in a year to shoot down an intercontinental ballistic missile succeeded late last night when a prototype interceptor launched from the Marshall Islands hit a mock warhead 140 miles over the Pacific. The mock warhead was launched in California, 4,800 miles from the Marshalls. The test provided a political lift to the costly missile defense program.

title: Eight Artists Cross the Border
description: MITCHE KUNZMAN and Alex McFarlane, curators who both live here near the border of Connecticut, see the geographical boundary line between Westchester County and Western Connecticut as unnecessary, especially when considering the rich and diverse cultural makeup the areas share.

title: Both Sides of the Hyphen
description: TALKING IN THE DARK

title: Manchester
description: To the Editor: Mr. Cowell's article omitted a fascinating institution, the Pumphouse People's History Museum, which focuses on ordinary people and the labor movement. It is appropriately situated on the Left Bank, Bridge Street, (44-1618) 396061.

title: A Legal Debate Over a Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: July 8-14; Gun Battles in Jamaica
description: In the worst spate of violence in Jamaica in decades, more than 25 people -- most civilians -- were killed in gun battles in the slums of West Kingston. The fighting, accompanied by tensions between the government and its opposition, started after officers went into a neighborhood looking for guns; they said they were fired upon by snipers lurking inside housing projects. David Gonzalez

title: A Publicist Scorched By Fires She Fanned
description: YOU'RE dead, son,'' Burt Lancaster snaps coolly at Tony Curtis. ''Now get yourself buried.''

title: Romanced by the Stone
description: A FEW months ago, I found myself crouching in a sandstone cave beneath a small church in Pienza, in Tuscany. At one time, the cave was an Etruscan temple, and I was drawn to one of its ancient relief carvings: a faceless woman riddled with pockmarks, her legs impossibly splayed outward, like wings. A leaflet told me she was ''a mermaid with two tails.'' The evidence said, ''fertility goddess.''

title: The Week in Review: July 8-14
description: Stem Cells in Private Labs

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: CLAY'S QUILT By Silas House. Algonquin, $21.95.

title: Sit. Stay. And if the Super Comes Asking Questions, Hide.
description: Pet owners who live in Lawrence Towers have been facing a decision worthy of King Solomon -- whether to part with their animals or find new homes.

title: Pride of Place
description: WHEN it comes to assigning wedding guests to their tables at the reception, a simple, elegant and legible place card will do for most couples.

title: The Red-State Network
description: Your article dissecting Fox News was fascinating. I would be equally fascinated with an investigation of the way in which the mainstream news channels put together their shows.

title: The Shyness Syndrome
description: Bravo to Margaret Talbot. It is time we confronted the advocates of psychotropic drugs. By taking pills, we weaken the will to combat social anxiety.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on Fox News stirred debate on its claim of ''fair and balanced'' coverage, prompting some readers to ask: Is CNN fair? Is The Times? And ''Harvard's Hoard'' drew mail suggesting that the college should use its hefty endowment for scholarships, etc., or lose it to the taxman.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Next Up for Newtown: A Plan for the Land
description: WHEN Ursula Goebel of Newtown lived with her two children and husband, a doctor at Fairfield Hills Hospital, in a staff house there during the 1960's and 70's, she never dreamed the sprawling state psychiatric center would one day release all its patients and close its doors forever.

title: At Road's End, a Taste of Rural Norway
description: I'M a New Yorker born and bred, someone whose idea of rural adventure is taking the M86 bus across Central Park. But in Norway, where I now live -- and where the No. 1 recreational activity is walking in the woods -- even the most thoroughgoing urbanites will confess to feeling an almost mystical affinity for the countryside. So when the idea of spending a couple of nights on a farm presented itself, I figured it was time for me to get into the act.

title: Williams Redux
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: To Adopt: Cute 2-Lane Blacktop. Has Papers.
description: THE sign on Middle Country Road, ''In Memory of Christopher J. Kalamaras,'' was placed by a grieving family to honor a 20-year-old college junior who died there in an automobile accident in August 1998. It also marks the beginning of a one-mile stretch of the road that the family has pledged to clean up at least four times a year under the Adopt-a-Highway program run by the state Department of Transportation.

title: Mix, Patch, Promote and Lift; A Showman Speeds the Makeover of Ted Turner's Empire
description: JAMIE KELLNER sat back and gazed out the window as the Gulfstream V corporate jet began its gentle glide into this city, his new home. Down below, a billowy carpet of green trees and brush was broken up by a glassy lake. ''I didn't know there was water there,'' he said. Mr. Kellner, who was looking for a place to live, paused, then added, ''I wonder how I get a piece of that.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Cadillac Escalade; A Mammoth Appetite And Creature Comforts
description: WHEN the six blind men of Indostan approached the elephant of the Hindu fable, their perceptions were colored by where they stood. Certainly, if you grasped the tail of the beast, you might think you held a rope; the ear could indeed be mistaken for a fan; and the trunk was very like a snake. But each man missed the big picture. In its totality, the elephant, with its versatility and cargo capacity, its voracious appetite and its high center of gravity -- not to mention its natural-hide upholstery -- quite resembled a sport utility vehicle.

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

description: Tracy Liorah Brown, the daughter of Margaret and Stanley Brown of Southold, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Perry Gardiner, a son of Virginia Gardiner and Gilbert Gardiner, both of North Kingstown, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Forrest Church, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated in the Chapel at Camp Quinipet, on Shelter Island, N.Y.

Cavallo, the Argentine economy minister, and Mrs. Cavallo of Buenos Aires, was married there last evening to Daniel FitzGerald Runde, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Runde of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Howard V. O'Shea officiated with the Rev. Rafael Braun at Our Lady of Pilar Roman Catholic Basilica.

Harry Cronin, a retired town justice in Lake Luzerne, N.Y., officiated at the Saratoga Rose Inn in Hadley, N.Y.

title: Confessions of Workers At Play on the Computer
description: When your colleagues at work aren't looking, maybe you play a game or two of computer solitaire. Or perhaps you fire off a few e-mail messages to friends or make an online purchase on company time.

title: Yale to Make Sunday Debut
description: For the first time in its 129-year football history, Yale will play a game on a Sunday, against Dartmouth in the Yale Bowl at 1 p.m. on Oct. 7.

title: The Nation: The Color of Money; Is Green the One That Counts the Most?
description: WHEN the advocates of campaign finance overhaul rail against the evils of big-money politics, they often point to anonymous lobbyists for oil or tobacco or insurance companies who buy millions of dollars in television time before an election to air slick corporate pitches masquerading as voter education.

title: CHINATOWN
description: The demolition of a municipal parking lot was delayed on Monday by State Supreme Court Justice Edward H. Lehner, pending a hearing next month on a lawsuit filed by Borough President C. Virginia Fields and Community Board 1. The suit says the city failed to consult local officials before closing the Manhattan Civic Center Parking Garage, located under Police Plaza, to build a new 911 emergency call center. DENNY LEE

description: This

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCELLINO, FRED
description: MARCELLINO-Fred. July 12, 2001. Husband of Jean. Father of Nico and his wife Elizabeth. Brother of Marie Marcellino Allen. He was a noted illustrator and author of children's books after an illustrious career as both a book jacket and record album cover designer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday, July 16, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service on Tuesday, July 17, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYU Medical Center, Deptartment of Oncology, or the Cabrini Hospice. In tribute to Fred's love of gardening, flowers are welcomed and appreciated.

description: IT was a formidable challenge to create a craft show that did not home in on one subject or technique, formidable on many levels.

description: THE sudden shakeout in Connecticut's discount retail market over the last two years surprised and puzzled Jesse Moldavsky of West Hartford, a longtime customer of Caldor and Bradlees.

title: Hamptons Players In a Lower Key
description: THE Sag Harbor Community Band was getting ready to give its first free outdoor concert of the summer last Tuesday evening. Everything was as it has been for years. Volunteers set up chairs and music stands on the front patio of the American Legion hall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about the views of cadets at the United States Military Academy misstated the date in some copies for fighting in which 18 American soldiers were killed in Somalia. The fighting took place in October 1993, not 1998.

title: Laura Clark, Mark Sirota
description: Laura Ann Clark and Mark Avery Sirota are to be married today by Rabbi Michael Strassfeld at Congregation Ansche Chesed in Manhattan.

title: For the Traveler Short of Tempo, Some Presto Courses in Italian
description: Their taxis aren't double-parked outside Parliamo Italiano en route to the Alitalia terminal at Kennedy International Airport. But many New Yorkers who have signed up for lessons at the Italian language school on East 65th Street will have to be sharp students to be fluent by the time their flights leave.

title: Honeymoon's Over
description: GRAND AMBITION By Lisa Michaels. 274 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95.

title: A Judge's Work Isn't Easy When No One Is Guilty
description: IMAGINE a moral continuum that extends downward from Categorical Imperatives to Impractical Ideals. Somewhere toward the middle, you'll find my not-so-firm opinion of musical competitions: I'm against them -- unless I'm one of the judges.

title: Letters
description: Our article on Fox News stirred debate on its claim of "fair and balanced" coverage, prompting some readers to ask: Is CNN fair? Is The Times? And "Harvard's Hoard" drew mail suggesting that the college should use its hefty endowment for scholarships, etc., or lose it to the taxman.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 4 about the funeral of Chet Atkins, the Nashville musician and producer, misidentified the manufacturer of one of his guitars, which was onstage during the service. It was made by the Gibson Guitar Company, not by the Gretsch Company.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm worried about the consumer -- not putting away their wallets but using them a little less. It wouldn't take much downward movement in consumer spending to cause a recession.''

title: Sounds of the 60's
description: In what might be the summer's dream concert for grownups, Brian Wilson and Paul Simon will perform together in a performance that is only missing a Beatle for pedigree. In the 1960's, both men spoke for their generation, with Simon and Garfunkel expressing the angst of moody New York folk-rockers and Mr. Wilson's Beach Boys speaking for happy-go-lucky California surfers. These premiere songwriters are currently riding career highs (Mr. Simon's recent ''You're the One,'' is a simmering gem), and this is a concert of such depth, it will be difficult to match. They perform Wednesday at the Tweeter Center, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden. Robbie Woliver

title: Toe Cozies for Bohemians
description: Since sarongs and Indian blouses have become the uniform for dharma beach bums, hipper hippie chicks need a new way to stand out.

title: Meridith Corcoran and Ronan O'Byrne
description: Meridith Mangan Corcoran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy McKee Corcoran of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday in Rye, N.Y., to Ronan Michael O'Byrne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian J. O'Byrne of Rye. The Most Rev. James McCarthy, an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Suzan Lori Parks; The Playwright Bride
description: I WONDERED who was scratching away back there.'' That's how the dancer Judith Jamison introduced herself to Suzan-Lori Parks at the intermission of the play ''Top Dog/Underdog'' on Wednesday night. Ms. Parks, its author, had been noisily taking notes on a yellow legal pad during a preview performance at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: A Bounty From Uneven Terrain
description: ABOUT 15 years ago, I received a letter from a reader in the United States asking for names of country inns where she and a friend, both of them great walkers, could stay in Sicily. After some thought and with considerable surprise I had to answer that there weren't any.

title: A Miracle, and Yet
description: It is midafternoon on a Wednesday in early January, and Operating Room No. 5 at Vanderbilt University Medical Center is a backdrop of blue: blue scrubs on the 10 nurses and doctors who crowd around the O.R. table; blue sterile sheets on 28-year-old Kelly Hasten, who is about to undergo experimental surgery. The procedure will put her at risk for infections, hemorrhages and death. But Kelly will receive no physical benefits. Her body is simply the gatekeeper for the main event: an operation on a 24-week-old, one-pound fetus nestled inside her.

title: Beijing Convicts Professor; Orders Expulsion
description: China convicted an American business professor today of spying for Taiwan and ordered him expelled.

title: Transportation for 2020: A Plan Bound to Fail
description: A more realistic approach to our traffic problems is to to build a tunnel under Long Island Sound similar to the Chunnel between England and France and to immediatly begin construction of a high-speed light-rail system to deliver people to the major airports, shopping centers, sports stadiums and to key points in Manhattan, where they will have access to the subway system. Unless government implements these two plans, the economy of Long Island will eventually lead to the same dead end that traffic comes to when it reaches Montauk Point.

title: Riots Point Out Jamaican Fault Line
description: With a heart hastily cut out of black cloth pinned to her dress, Evelyn Ruddock stood outside Madden's Funeral Home and patted her bulging belly to soothe the child waiting to be born. Her husband, Humphrey, the father that child will never know, was on a metal gurney inside.

title: Manchester
description: To the Editor: ''Manchester Rising,'' by Alan Cowell (June 24), exhibits the very prejudice against those from northern England that it describes. The article is sprinkled with references to ''the grimy textile center,'' the ''damp northwest,'' and the city's supposed ''dour northern traditions.'' Well, one may perhaps note that the London area has not been without its own problems: its slums, its crime, its high cost of living.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, BERNARD D.
description: FISCHMAN-Bernard D. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, L.L.P., mourns with sorrow the July 11, 2001 passing of our beloved counsel and sage, Bernard D. Fischman. Known to all as Bernie, he was an extremely dedicated attorney, and at the time of his death was still active on behalf of many of his clients. Bernie joined LeBoeuf in 1994 as counsel, and his career as a lawyer spanned more than 64 years. Bernie was a truly altruistic human being, always looking for and finding ways to help everyone with whom he came in contact. He will be missed by all who knew him. We extend deepest condolences to his wife, Hilda, their children, Judith and Robert, and their grandchildren, Jesse, Joanna and Eliza.

title: EMISSIONS CONTRACT HEARINGS
description: Testimony before a state investigative commission last week described state officials violating contract procurement rules in awarding a 1998 auto-inspection contract to Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group of California. In a two-day hearing, the last step in a 15-month investigation of the $500 million, seven-year auto inspection contract, accountants and other analysts said that the state grossly underestimated costs in order to give Parsons an opportunity to get the contract. A manager at the Division of Motor Vehicles said the Parsons deal was costing the state at least $10 million more a year than a state-operated program would have. Anne Ruderman

title: A List With a Waiting List
description: In many states, people can put their names on lists to stop pesky telemarketers from calling them. Wisconsin currently does not have such a list, but as state lawmakers there found last week, there is demand for one.

title: Failure of Compromise On Jewish Center
description: In her July 8 letter defending a proposed Chabad Lubavitch center in Kings Point and calling its critics ''self-hating Jews,'' Pamela Hoenig seems to think that Chabad's way is the only way of ''doing it right.'' The Crusaders, the Inquisitors, the Holocaust perpetrators, the Taliban, Ayatollah Khomeini, Muslim, Christian and Jewish extremists all thought that they were ''doing it right.'' What Ms. Hoenig is telling her fellow Jews is that it is her way or no way.

title: Liberties; I'm Still Here
description: He looks like Sydney Greenstreet in ''The Maltese Falcon,'' as described by Dashiell Hammett, a ''fat man flabbily fat with bulbous pink cheeks and lips and chins and neck, with a great soft egg of a belly that was all his torso, and pendant cones for arms and legs. . . . his voice was a throaty purr.''

title: "Yellow"
description: THE PRICE OF EGGS IN CHINA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAVIS, MINA
description: TRAVIS-Mina. On July 15, 1998. Remembering a special mother, grandmother and great-grandmother for years of love and fun. Claire, Marvin, Jeff and Lee

title: What Government Gives, It Can Take Away
description: SOME 92 million American taxpayers will begin receiving tax-cut rebates this month in the mail. But as they await their $41 billion windfall, some may be surprised to learn that a sizable tax increase is headed their way.

title: Slaveholding Past: Burden for Present
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Your Data, Yourself; A Protective Path Paved in Granola
description: TO understand the state of play for privacy in the digital age, it helps to look at environmentalism as it was taking shape in the late 1960's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, TOBI EVELYN (NEE NOVIS)
description: KRAUSS-Tobi Evelyn (nee Novis). July 10, 2001. Of the Bronx and Delray Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Ira Krauss, mother of Maxine Hilliard and Joanne Krauss, mother-in-law of Vincent Hilliard and Robert Nowicki, grandmother of James, Robert and Richard Hilliard, and Jessica and Robert Nowicki.

title: July 8-14; Memorial to Shamed War Dead
description: More than 300 soldiers, many of them shell-shocked and heartbreakingly young, were executed by the British Army for desertion in World War I. They have never been pardoned, although the killings have come to be widely seen as a shameful piece of Britain's past.

title: The Inmates of 'Oz' Move Into a New Emerald City
description: TOM FONTANA, creator of the HBO prison drama ''Oz,'' had no choice but to end the series' fourth season in February with a bang, blowing up the fictitious Oswald Correctional Facility. The show was being booted from the 60,000-square-foot space in Chelsea Market where its annual eight episodes had always been filmed, and viewers would need to know why the set looked different when they tune in next year.

title: Elizabeth Leyden, Danny Hakim
description: Elizabeth Rose Leyden, a daughter of Rose and Brian Leyden of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married last evening to Danny Hakim, a son of Joy and Sam Hakim of Virginia Beach. The Rev. John Kirwin, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Saratoga National Golf Club in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., with Rabbi Monte Sugarman taking part.

title: Saved by Books
description: It's bad news for a boy named Herb when the Big Bad Wolf and a little not-so-bad wolf fall out of a storybook, drooling and hungry. Thank goodness for fairy godmothers. After all, who else can bring the big wolf down to size and turn the little wolf into a fashion plate? If all that sounds silly, it is. It's meant to be, in BEWARE OF THE STORYBOOK WOLVES (Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic, $15.95; ages 4 to 8). With a sly wit and a handful of evocative characters, Lauren Child takes the familiar ''once upon a time'' story, shakes it and then spins it for a giggle. Imagine Mother Goose meeting Roald Dahl's ''Enormous Crocodile.'' The result is a smile-provoking yarn full of fairy-tale twists.

title: "Stalin's Secret Pogrom: The Postwar Inquisition of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee"
description: Late on the night of January 12, 1948, the renowned Yiddish actor and theater director Solomon Mikhoels was murdered in Minsk on the direct orders of Joseph Stalin. This was not an ordinary operation. As director of Moscow's State Jewish Theater and chairman of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee (JAC), which played a prominent role in Soviet propaganda efforts against Hitler during World War II, Mikhoels had earned an international reputation. But with the onset of the Cold War and the impending creation of Israel, Stalin came to suspect Mikhoels's loyalties. Dispatched to Minsk ostensibly to review a play for the Stalin Prize, Mikhoels was lured from his hotel and taken to the country house of Lavrenti Tsanava, head of the Belorussian security services, where he was summarily killed. His body was left in the snow along a quiet street, where, in the morning, workers discovered him. Mikhoels's death was declared the result of a traffic accident. To complete the camouflage, he was honored with a state funeral.

title: Modern Baseball Began in 1845
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stylish Whites From Upstate
description: Anthony Road, spurred by a new German winemaker, is a comer among Finger Lakes wineries. Its brisk 2000 dry riesling ($11), redolent of peaches and apricots, and its fruity 2000 pinot gris ($13), which is spritzy and offers a long finish, show how stylish the region's whites have become. John Martini, an owner, sells these food-friendly wines Saturdays at the Union Square Greenmarket.

title: Child's Death Spotlights Culture Shock Among Yemeni Jews
description: In 1994, Yahia and Lauza Jaradi left Yemen for a stab at life in America. As devout Jews in a Muslim land, they were eager to practice their religion freely. As poor teenagers with little education, they were grateful that their Hasidic sponsors, the ultra-Orthodox Satmars, had promised a nurturing environment.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; A New Building in Montclair in a 19th-Century Style
description: THERE will be a marriage on Union Street here this summer, a May-December affair -- or maybe January-December.

title: July 8-14; In the Beginning
description: Fossil bones and teeth uncovered in Africa extend knowledge of human origins back to near their beginnings, scientists say. An Ethiopian paleontologist has reported that the fossils belonged to a hominid who lived as much as 5.8 million years ago -- tantalizingly near the time the human line diverged from the one that produced chimpanzees. Scientists say the hominids -- designated a subspecies of Ardipithecus ramidus -- lived in a forest in what is now Ethiopia, challenging the belief that human ancestors emerged in grasslands.

title: Candidates Hoping to Replace Samaranch
description: Alook at the candidates in the running to replace the departing I.O.C. president, Juan Antonio Samaranch.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Easton, Conn., rendered the names of two stores incompletely and misstated the location of a restaurant. It is the Easton Village Store, not the Village Store, and Greizer's Country Store, not the Country Store. Bill's Bistro is behind the Easton Village Store, not behind Greizer's Country Store. A photo caption with the article repeated the error about Bill's Bistro; it is not in the building shown, which is Greizer's Country Store.

title: Pardon My Dust? Neighbors of a College Project Say No
description: For the past month, life has been pretty heated for Yougeng Sun. Mr. Sun is upset because his co-op apartment, at 605 West 111th Street, overlooks the empty playground behind the Bank Street College of Education, at the southwest corner of West 112th Street and Broadway, where the college is about to build an eight-story tower with classrooms.

title: Nay on Lantos

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 4 about the funeral of Chet Atkins, the Nashville musician and producer, misidentified the manufacturer of one of his guitars, which was onstage during the service. It was made by the Gibson Guitar Company, not by the Gretsch Company.

title: NEWARK LAGS
description: The birth rate among teenagers in Newark has decreased in recent years at a rate faster than the rest of the state, but by almost every other measure, the children in Newark are worse off than those living elsewhere in New Jersey, according to Kids Count 2000, a survey of children's welfare released last week by the Association for Children of New Jersey. The birth rate for girls 15 to 19 years of age in Newark declined 21.1 percent between 1994 and 1998 compared with a decline of 7.2 percent statewide, according to the report by the Newark-based association. However, infant mortality in Newark was 13.5 deaths for each 1,000 live births in 1998, the most recent figures available, against the 6.4 deaths per 1,000 births statewide. Likewise, sexually transmitted diseases among children under 19 years of age increased 31.4 percent between 1996 and 1999 in Newark compared with a 13 percent increase statewide. Karen DeMasters

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-15-01: Phenomenon; (Buy Me)
description: The young people grouped at the end of the bar resemble Gap models. They are facially attractive, in that asymmetrical sort of way, and they wear the new uniform of the Internet cast-aside who still has money to carouse with: tight dark blue jeans, T-shirts a bit too small and hair slightly greased. It's a Wednesday night at a small bar on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

title: Jessica Greene, Jeep Post
description: Jessica Alexis Greene, a daughter of Alanna and Thomas Greene of Weston, Vt., was married yesterday to John Sparks Post, a son of Tania Clark of Greenwich, Conn., and Allen Cookman Post of Bonita Springs, Fla. The Rev. Reid Curtis Mayo performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in Rutland, Vt.

title: "Free Flight: From Airline Hell to a New Age of Travel"
description: When I was growing up in Southern California in the fifties and sixties, I had no more or less than the typical boy's interest in airplanes. My brother and I made and painted Revell models of the great bombers of World War II. I snapped together balsa-wood gliders and went to the park to watch them fly. I was thrilled when, as a ten-year-old going to Philadelphia from my home in California for a summer visit with my grandparents, I got to take a ride back on what I remember as having been the first jet departure from the Philadelphia airport, a TWA liner that went nonstop to Los Angeles International. In Boy Scouts, I worked for a merit badge that involved going to the local air force base and getting a lecture on thrust-to-weight and lift-to-drag.

title: Milosevic's Abode: 10 by 17 Feet but No Dungeon
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the newest inmate at the United Nations cellblock here, has been informed of the prison rules.

description: Glen Sather has vowed to rebuild the Rangers through youth. He reaffirmed that strategy just last week with his refusal to part with any of the Rangers' top prospects in a deal for Jaromir Jagr before Pittsburgh dealt the star player to Washington.

title: Dead-Drift Casting Lures the Bass
description: For more than a week in late June, my youngest son, Jeff, and I reveled in the best fly-fishing for striped bass we had experienced in many years.

description: Dr. Andrew Wiles, who has rarely appeared in public since solving one of the most famous mathematical problems of the ages, was greeted like a rock star by the current generation of young math stars at the close of their global competition.

title: DataBank; A Rally Before the Checks Arrive
description: Despite uncertainty about whether the American economy has managed to halt its decline, the stock market rallied at the end of last week. The surge began with positive sales reports from Microsoft and Motorola and came after the Dow Jones industrial average nearly slipped below 10,000 and the Nasdaq composite closed below 2,000 for the first time in four weeks.

title: Night's Light Dims Stars and Irks Residents
description: AT a distance of 43 million miles from Earth, about as close as it ever comes, Mars appeared as a shimmering, red-tinged dot last weekend through the 13-inch diameter telescope at the Custer Institute observatory in Southold, where public viewing is a Saturday night tradition.

title: The Senior Guy
description: IT was a party for Frank Corino and three others who were celebrating their 10th anniversaries with the Fire Department. Firefighters who weren't on duty stopped by the East Harlem firehouse of Engine 53 and Ladder 43 at Third Avenue and 102nd Street to offer congratulations. The smoke of cigarettes and cigars hung in the air. Men told jokes and stories, and their voices echoed off the cement walls.

title: Relief Is in Sight
description: It is not the sort of thing one might expect to undermine a great art institution, but the exterior stonework at the base of the National Gallery in Trafalgar Square has been suffering from erosion caused by London's nighttime revelers who cannot be bothered to seek out a more traditional restroom. To combat this problem, the Westminster City Council is placing open-air urinals on the streets on Friday and Saturday nights starting this month in the West End, home of the National Gallery.

title: Lovin' Spoonfuls
description: Mr. Latte does not talk much in the morning. He might mumble a few cryptic fragments before we get to Xando, his favored cafe, but it isn't until after his coffee that he forms full and coherent sentences.

title: Correspondence/Europe's Trials; From Bosnia to Berlin to The Hague, On a Road Toward a Continent's Future
description: BY making the presence of the past palpable, the Balkans were a useful preparation for Germany, where I took up residence a few years after covering the Bosnian war. In Belgrade, Slobodan Milosevic used the undigested history of World War II to help whip up a frenzied Serbian nationalism that would wreak havoc across the region. In Berlin, I discovered another country struggling to digest bad history. But Germany, unlike Serbia, turned its back on the very notion of national pride after 1945, even as it wrestled with how to come to terms with the acts of the Third Reich and how to define a viable modern German identity. ''Hitler has a long shadow,'' Der Spiegel wrote recently.

title: The World; For the Newest Nuclear Powers, a Little Chat
description: UNTIL another nation tests the tools of apocalypse, India and Pakistan will remain known as the world's two newest nuclear powers. In May 1998, these hostile neighbors set off tit-for-tat underground explosions. Given their bloody history -- having fought three all-out wars and then sustaining a lethal ritual of cross-border artillery fire -- they immediately seemed the nuclear gunslingers with the planet's itchiest trigger fingers. The world again thought the unthinkable.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, MAX
description: COHEN -Max. July 17, 1959. In cherished and loving memory of dearly beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Sadly missed. Always in our heart. Lucille Richard, Hope & their daughters Lindsey and Ashley

title: When a 'Late Style' Gets an Early Start
description: THE location of old age has been moving further along life's timeline, but a beast still lurks in the territory. A few photographers, back when people fell into the old-age category earlier, stared the monster down; others have ended up defeated and blushing. Eugne Atget, who lived to 70, was both more daring and more lyrical in his last years than he had ever been, and he had been both. Alfred Stieglitz could make the sky speak eloquently on photographic paper when he was in his 60's. Imogen Cunningham may not have outdone her earlier self during her ninth decade, but could still make a picture whistle and hum.

title: A 26-Year Dispute Over a Tower, With No End in Sight
description: The Cathedral Parkway Towers loom over Morningside Drive and dwarf Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine across the street, but they are not much to look at these days. The two splotchy brown towers at 424 West 110th Street, built in 1975 with 309 low-income apartments, are rimmed now with red scaffolding because bricks keep falling off.

title: Jeanine Pirro's Sting: Visiting Chat Rooms To Chase Pedophiles
description: ON the fourth floor of the District Attorney's office in White Plains is a small, windowless room, where two heavily built, middle-aged investigators sit with pistols in their holsters and pictures of their children over their desks. Here they spend the day -- and often, the night -- logging onto Internet chat rooms and pretending to be gullible 14-year-old boys.

Just five years ago, Center City after work was a quiet and gloomy terrain, however rich in history and colonial charm. Energized by a brawny economy and some forward thinking entrepreneurs, things began to change. And, as is often the case, restaurateurs led the charge.

title: The Alchemy of Stem Cell Research
description: As a biologist involved in stem cell research for over a decade, I find the current debate over human embryonic stem cells increasingly detached from scientific reality. Embryonic stem cells are primitive cells with a broad potential to differentiate into any specialized cell type in the body -- liver cells, for example, or insulin-producing cells, or specific types of neural cells. They are infant cells that have not yet chosen a profession.

title: July 8-14; Stem Cells in Private Labs
description: Medical research raced ahead of public policy, with two reports that scientists are creating human embryos to extract stem cells, the primordial cells that may yield treatments and cures. Instead of using frozen embryos, a Virginia fertility center used donated eggs and sperm to make fresh embryos, while a Massachusetts biotechnology company is trying a different tack: cloning. The reports outraged abortion opponents and inflamed the already heated debate over whether President Bush should permit federal funding for stem cell research. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: The Wound and the Historian
description: The historian Joseph J. Ellis's chief accomplishment to date is restoring John Adams to his rightful status as America's most human founding father. Adams, before Ellis, had been relegated for nearly two centuries to the sidelines, a fat and unlikable conservative overshadowed by George Washington, a god; Benjamin Franklin, a wit; and Thomas Jefferson, a visionary. The fault was largely Adams's. As Ellis explains in ''Passionate Sage: The Character and Legacy of John Adams'' (1993), our second president was a man of enormous wisdom and ingrained skepticism who grasped better than any other American the need for checks and balances in government and the likely horrors of the French Revolution. He was also abrasive, tempestuous, candid to the point of obnoxiousness, touchy about his place in history, paranoid and unstatesmanlike. He had a way of undercutting his presidential persona with sarcastic self-deprecation or temper tantrums. A proud descendant of Puritans, he thought public relations were corrupt, so instead he did himself harm. But Ellis managed to dig Adams most of the way out from under dirt he'd heaped upon his own head -- enough, anyway, so that David McCullough, America's best-selling presidential hagiographer, read ''Passionate Sage'' and was moved to write his own Adams book.

description: BY the time 9-year-old Dorothy Johnson walked into the Scarsdale Plaza in the late 90's, the movie theater had seen better days. The film wasn't much (''Air Bud,'' about a dog that plays sports), but the interior of the Plaza, the elegant ceiling and chandeliers, the plush cathedral-size screening room, left a lasting impression on her. ''I don't know why, but I love that movie theater,'' said Dorothy, now 12. ''It gave me a feeling that I don't get at other theaters, like I was in a special place.''

title: Lake Placid

But the number of summer visitors here -- more than a million each year -- exceeds those of winter, and an estimated 65 percent of the local economy is generated from May through October, much of it from sports tourism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, JANE GERMAN
description: IRWIN-Jane German. Widow of former US Ambassador to France and Manhattan lawyer, John N. Irwin II died on July 11 of Cancer. She was 74. Mrs. Irwin who lived in New Canaan, CT. was a loving mother and grandmother with a generous giving spirit. She was active in charitable endeavors having particular involvement in matters related to theology and theological institutions. At the time of her death she was a Board Member of The Princeton Theological Seminary, The Henry Luce Foundation and The Asia Foundation. Mrs. Irwin was also active in, and in many cases a Board Member of, The Friends of the Museum of Princeton University where she was one of the first Docents, The Girl Scouts of Greater NY, The Center of Theological Inquiry in Princeton, NJ and The Hoover Institution in Stanford, CA. Mrs. Irwin was born in Archer City, TX, married Watkins W. Reynolds, Jr., a Fort Worth rancher and businessman with whom she had two children both of whom survive her and are living in Fort Worth, Watkins W. Reynolds III and Thomas B. Reynolds. Mr. Reynolds died in 1957. After Mr. Reynolds' death, Mrs. Irwin married Carl D. Reimers, Jr., a Presbyterian Minister who was Assistant Dean of Princeton University Chapel. They had one child Carl D. Reimers III who lives in Greenwich, CT. In 1976 Jane married John N. Irwin II and was the stepmother to his children, Jane W. I. Droppa of Ellicott City, MD and John N. Irwin III of Greenwich, CT. In addition to her three children and two stepchildren, Mrs. Irwin is survived by her mother, Mrs. R. T. German of Midland, TX, 12 grandchildren, Watkins Reynolds IV, Ellen Reynolds, Thomas Reynolds, Jr., William Reynolds, Grace Reynolds, Grace Reimers, Charles Reimers, Anna Irwin, Genevieve Irwin, Jack Droppa, Daniel Droppa and Katherine Droppa. Mrs. Irwin will be remembered by her family and many friends for her wit, personal warmth and lively intelligence. The family interment will be in Fort Worth, TX on Saturday. A memorial service will be held in NY at The Brick Presbyterian Church on Friday, July 27. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: Princeton Theological Seminary or to The Girl Scout Council of Greater NY.

title: When QWERTYUIOP was High-Tech
description: Universities often take pride in their high-tech capacities. Rider University in Lawrenceville has the opposite to offer in its ''typewriter cluster,'' a collection of 25 typewriters, on three shelves in Riderana, the Rider University archives at Franklin F. Moore Library. The collection also includes a couple of stenograph machines, a dictaphone, an unusual adding machine, typewriter advertisements and photographs from a time when Rider arranged its 200 students into classes of 60 or 70 to learn the new skill of typing. The university archivist, Lynn Livingston, recenty talked about the collection.

Visitors can also try their hand at moviemaking, with special effects by fashioning their own wax molds, dubbing in sound effects, and setting up a scene with their families and videotaping it.

title: A Famous $35 Emblem Put to Charitable Use
description: In 1971, Carolyn Davidson, then 29 and a graphic design student at Portland State University in Oregon, was asked by a shoe salesman and accounting professor named Philip H. Knight to create a logo for an athletic shoe company he was trying to start. She provided Mr. Knight with several ideas. "They were going to print shoeboxes the next morning, so a decision had to be made," Ms. Davidson recalled. "They decided on this swoosh and he said, `Well, I don't love it but it'll grow on me.' " After he chose one, she charged him $35, which covered the cost of her supplies.

title: Jamie Simon, Douglas Brookman

title: A Majority of One
description: When Jeffrey Rosen (June 3) contrasts Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's contextual and particularized approach to judicial decision-making with Justice Scalia's more rulebound approach, he echoes observations I made in ''In a Different Voice.'' But when Rosen questions the validity of Justice O'Connor's approach, he edges toward equating difference and deficiency. Like Rosen, I have disagreed with Justice O'Connor's (and Justice Scalia's) conclusions in many important cases. But like Justice O'Connor, I am disturbed when women are tarred with negative, gender-related stereotypes.

title: Failure of Compromise On Jewish Center
description: In 25 years I have seen my community maligned and misrepresented by non-residents, ignorant of the essence that is Great Neck. That is hurtful enough. But I find it personally repugnant to be unfairly repudiated by a fellow Great Necker.

title: Pakistani's Day 1 in India: Busyness, but Little Business

Drivers on the Garden State Parkway, the turnpike and the Atlantic City Expressway will receive warnings for their first two offenses; a 60-day E-ZPass suspension for the third violation; a 180-day suspension for the fourth violation; and one-year revocation after a fifth. John Holl

The average unemployment level in the region during the first quarter of 2001 was 3.3 percent, below the New York City, New York State and national rates.

title: Corrections

title: Running From Office
description: The Next Kennedy was sitting in an upholstered chair in a brownstone just off Kenmore Square in Boston, getting ready to run. Max, 36, the ninth child of Robert and Ethel Kennedy, had come to the office of his media consultant, Doug Hattaway, to prepare for his impending Congressional campaign. Most Massachusetts insiders assumed he couldn't be stopped. He had the most famous name in American politics, as much a part of Boston's 20th century as Fenway Park. He had assembled the best -- or at least the best-known -- political consultants in the country. He had fund-raisers ready to go in Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia and New York. Unions were lining up behind Kennedy, as were longtime aides to Joe Moakley, the revered congressman whose death from leukemia triggered a special election. Kennedy had just closed on a $550,000, five-bedroom colonial in West Roxbury, in the heart of Moakley's Congressional district, a few short blocks from the Irish social hall and the local pub. All that remained now was for him to officially announce his candidacy, and then to win.

title: Roughing It In Romania
description: SINCE it has very few tourist facilities, Romania is trying to make a strength of its weakness. Not blessed with great hotels or famous museums, it sends tourists out into remote rural areas where they can get away from museums and hotels. The name for this program is ''rural tourism,'' which often translates into romance without plumbing. (For plumbing without romance, stay in Bucharest.)

description: CHICAGO -- For years, the chance of the historic, but rundown, Uptown neighborhood receiving substantial investment seemed about as remote as the odds of the Cubs making it to the World Series.

title: Florida Revisits Laws
description: As part of an overhaul of state election rules that Gov. Jeb Bush signed into law in May, Florida changed the standard that election officials will apply when judging the legality of overseas absentee ballots. Postmarks will no longer be necessary. Under the new law, overseas ballots that arrive in Florida without a postmark, or even a late postmark, must be counted if the voter has provided the date the ballot was signed.

title: The Red-State Network
description: Sella cleverly morphs the Fox News slogan into a ''sound . . . like a German policy initiative: Fairenbalinst.'' I don't expect television journalism to grow up anytime soon, but I hoped The Times would.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: LIKE the latter part of this year's World War II blockbuster, ''Pearl Harbor,'' the 1944 film THIRTY SECONDS OVER TOKYO depicts James Doolittle's morale-boosting raid on Japan in April 1942. Van Johnson is Ted Lawson, the real-life flier whose book was the basis for the film, and Spencer Tracy is Doolittle. Trivia buffs can dissect factual differences between the movies - did crews desperately jettison cargo, includng their planes' guns, to lighten the aircraft for shipboard takeoff (as in ''Pearl''), or did they climb aboard their plans with suitcases in hand (as in ''Tokyo'')? More compelling are the differences in sensibilities: the romance so much more restrained, the hero completely without roguishness. And smokers, be prepared to wince: in one scene, Lawson buys 12 cartons of cigarettes for $7.20 - Tuesday at 10:30 p.m. on TCM.

title: July 8-14; 2008 Olympics for China
description: China beat Paris, Toronto, Osaka and Istanbul to win the right to host the 2008 Summer Olympic Games, in voting by the 119-member International Olympic Committee in Moscow. It will be China's first chance to host the games, and the country has promised to spend billions to lower pollution and build new roads and stadiums in Beijing. Many people hope that the international focus the games bring will pressure China's government to improve its human rights record. Others fear that Beijing will use the games to validate its often repressive governing style. Craig S. Smith

title: Wait Till Next Year For Wells to Return
description: David Wells's season is apparently over, now that he has decided to have back surgery that will end any chance of the Yankees trading for him this summer. In a roundabout way, however, his back problem increases the likelihood that Wells will end up with the Yankees next season.

title: Lendl's Desire to Succeed Puts Him in Hall of Fame
description: Ivan Lendl's long sporting journey from the crowded courts of his youth in Czechoslovakia to his rise as the most dominant tennis player of his era came to a triumphant conclusion here today when he was enshrined in the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: OPINION; Same Old Unwise Ideas on Energy
description: RICHARD KESSEL'S push to build numerous fossil-fuel power plants in the LIPA service area is misguided. To understand how out-of-date the Long Island Power Authority chairman's proposals are, one only need consult the recent report on global warming published by the National Academy of Sciences. This study concludes that global warming is indeed a problem and getting worse, and its primary cause is the burning of fossil fuels. Building more fossil-fuel plants is obviously not a responsible answer to our energy needs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLANE, G. WARREN
description: McCLANE-G. Warren. 81. Manager of the Booth Theatre died on June 25, 2001 at Lenox Hill Hospital from cancer. During four decades in the theater he was considered the consummate company manager (''Beyond The Fringe'', ''Irene'', ''Dancin''', ''Woman Of The Year'') before becoming a theater manager for the Shubert Organization. He is survived by four nieces, Farrell Gonsalves of MA, Barbara Jean McClane, Sharon McClane and Dana McClane of CA., and three nephews, Kenneth an English Professor at Cornell, Walter and Duncan of CA. A memorial service will be held after Labor Day.

title: For Him/Her, the Film Version Is/Isn't the Same
description: IT comes as a bit of a shock, seeing Phyllis Stein in the flesh. In the stage version of ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch,'' the cult-hit musical that ran for more than two years in the West Village, Phyllis was never seen. She was conjured only in the cutting remarks of Hedwig, an embittered drag queen who longs for glam-rock stardom and a sexual identity to call his own.

title: Benefits of Prepaying a Mortgage
description: Q. I understand that if I make prepayments on my mortgage, I will save money because the prepayments shorten the term of the loan. But how do I know what the new ending date will be? Also, how do I know that the additional payments are being correctly credited? . . . Paul Warren, Manhattan.

title: Looking Back: 14 Years of Tips
description: WHEN Paul Grimes, the originator of the Practical Traveler column, turned it over to me 14 years ago, he said the most important task was to read the fine print on everything -- tickets, insurance fliers, tour brochures, guarantees. In the big type, he said, everyone fibs. Typical is the ''nine night'' tour that the small type clearly shows includes one night in an airline seat.

title: Patents; A 'black box' for cars to determine the cause of an accident and a device to detect drowsy drivers.
description: EVERYONE is familiar with the ''black box'' technology tucked away inside aircraft and often dramatically retrieved from the wreckage of an airplane. Investigators and survivors rely on the data collection boxes to reconstruct air accidents and help explain the cause of a plane crash.

title: Florida's Flawed Ballots
description: History can now add another inequity to the long list of problems that distorted the balloting for president in Florida and threw last year's election into doubt for more than a month. Overseas ballots were judged by vastly different standards depending on where they were counted. The Democrats were clearly outhustled and outmaneuvered in the scramble for a small but vital batch of these ballots, the only votes that could legally be received and counted after Election Day. The Republicans pursued these votes with aggressive precision, tailoring their legal arguments to suit the different political leanings of various counties, while the Democrats were hobbled by indecision and contradictory strategies.

title: Paper? Plastic? Profits?

More than half of Webvan's customers never placed a second order -- apparently because grocery shopping online requires more planning and more time than many consumers find worth the effort.

She will be remembered by her family and friends for her warmth, enthusiasm and kindness. A memorial mass will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, 184 East 76th Street, New York 10021, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROHS, BELLE
description: GROHS-Belle. 89, of NYC, died July 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Arnold Grohs, devoted sister of the late Gertrude Busch and Lillian Blum, cherished aunt of Elizabeth Busch-Le Ne, Margaret Busch and Charles Busch and loving great-aunt of James Stull. A woman of great spirit, born in Cincinatti, OH, in 1911, she was a veteran of WWII and Korea. She was for many years dietitian and head of Home Economics for both Childrens Center and Jennings Hall for Boys. Her commitment to public service and volunteer work through her support of Roosevelt Hospital, and particularly their AIDS ward, made her a true role model for all senior citizens. Services Tuesday, July 17, at 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., with interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Volunteer Fund, care of Volunteer Department, 1000 10th Ave., NYC 10019 would be appreciated.

title: Ardor, Elegance and Trees On a Midsummer Night
description: It was Shakespeare's job to shrink the Forest of Arden to a fantasy, sized to fit within a theatergoer's mind. There through the suggestive power of words it could grow again: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' localized within four walls and yet set free in the imagination of every individual inside them.

title: DROP IN FUEL PRICE MAY WEAKEN PUSH FOR ENERGY PLANS
description: As the Bush administration begins a campaign-style push to drum up support for its energy plan this week, the sense of crisis that had propelled the plan forward has receded while energy shortages ease and fuel prices fall, at least for now.

title: Accused, Armstrong Defends His Honor
description: In a vigorous defense of his integrity, Lance Armstrong rejected suggestions that he uses illegal performance-enhancing drugs, reaffirmed his relationship with a controversial doctor who has been accused of prescribing them and denounced ''all the innuendo, all the speculation, all the critics.''

Retired former International Medical Director for Mobil Corp. For more information, call Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY 914-337-6770.

title: Masius Is Enlarging Its New York Shop
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of the Bcom3 Group, is expanding the New York office of Masius, its marketing unit for corporate, business-to-business and financial services that was introduced last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTERMAN, RORI
description: ATTERMAN-Rori. On July 11, 2001. With great sorrow we mourn the passing of our dear friend. She will be remembered for her beauty, intelligence and kindness. We will miss her greatly. A funeral service was held on July 15 in Miami, FL. A memorial gathering will be held Tuesday, July 17, in NYC.
