Former owner of the Florence Meat Market in Greenwich Village, NY, and cooking instructor at the New School and the Peter Kump School of Culinary Arts. Author of ''Jack Ubaldi's Meat Book.'' In lieu of flowers, donations to the Shrine of St. Jude would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Shot To Death
description: A man was shot to death and a woman wounded yesterday morning when someone entered a Brooklyn apartment and fired several rounds, the police said. There are no suspects. Timothy Bumbury, 16, of 526 Bainbridge Street in Brooklyn, and Luevinnie Miles, 42, apparently a resident, were shot at about 6:20 a.m. inside a second-floor apartment at 765 McDonough Street in Stuyvesant Heights, the police said. The victims, whose relationship was not specified, were taken to St. Mary's Hospital, where Mr. Bumbury was pronounced dead. Ms. Miles, whose head was grazed in the shooting, was treated and released yesterday. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: 2 Mayoral Candidates Forming Education Parties
description: In an effort to capitalize on widespread concern about the quality of New York City's public schools, two of the six major mayoral candidates are collecting signatures to create new education-oriented political parties, which could give them additional lines on the November ballot.

title: Metropolitan Diary

title: A Fight for Survival in British Network TV
description: When Charles Allen, chief executive of Granada Media, sent a letter recently to Prime Minister Tony Blair, warning that his company would be at a disadvantage to foreign competitors if the government did not lift restrictions on media ownership soon, he unleashed a salvo of criticism from compatriots.

title: USA Networks to Buy Stake in Expedia
description: The Microsoft Corporation agreed to sell its controlling interest in Expedia Inc., an online travel reservation company, to USA Networks for stock and other securities with an estimated value of $1.5 billion, USA Networks said today.

title: Power Finally Scores a Goal But Can't Snap Losing Streak
description: New York Power Coach Pat Farmer could not restrain himself this time. After watching the Power's offense get blanked for its 260th consecutive minute, Farmer decided he needed a no-holds-barred halftime tirade to get his team in motion today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Stem Cell Genie
description: The stem-cell genie is out of the research bottle. If we command it sensibly, this unexpected servant will help us lead much healthier, longer lives. But if we fail to force the genie to conform to our ethical sense, this future regenerator of tissue and rebuilder of organs and brains could brutalize and demoralize mankind.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Bush, After Gaining Tax Cut, Is Taking Aim at Tax Code
description: Having achieved its initial economic goal of a substantial tax cut, the Bush administration is making plans to address an even more ambitious and divisive issue: overhauling or replacing the entire federal tax code.

title: Promotions to Revive The Dancing Raisins
description: The California raisins will hit the dance floor again this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALK, SUE ROSENBERG
description: ZALK-Sue Rosenberg. I lost one of my dearest friends. For over 30 years Sue consistently exemplified loyalty, commitment, tolerance and love. She will remain in my heart forever. Marilyn Sohn Birke

description: GLAZER-Simon. Tim, dear, I miss you more with every passing year. Love, Val

description: Havas Advertising, Levallois, France, acquired Noonan/Russo Communications, New York, a biotechnology public relations agency. Terms were not disclosed.

title: New Links in Khmer Rouge Chain of Death
description: During their first year in power a quarter of a century ago, senior Khmer Rouge leaders ordered the arrest and execution of thousands of Cambodians who they were convinced would undermine their brutal revolution, and demanded detailed secret reports to show that the orders had been carried out.

title: E-Commerce Report; As the shakeout proceeds, some business-to-business marketplaces show their staying power.
description: EARLIER this year, Forrester Research, the Internet consulting firm, predicted that the universe of business-to-business e-marketplaces would shrink to a mere 180 in the next two years, from 1,000 or more today. It was a bleak forecast, but one that surprised few who had watched such sites search in vain for customers in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINVILLE, CLARENCE EDWIN
description: LINVILLE-Clarence Edwin. Of Rye, New York, died Friday, July 13, 2001, on the day of his 92nd birthday at the Osborn Pavilion. Ed was born in State College, PA, on July 13, 1909. He grew up in Elizabeth, New Jersey, graduated in 1930 from Princeton University and received a master's degree in history from Rutgers University. He spent most of his career as an educator and administrator in the New York City public school system. From 1963 through 1972 he served as the principal of the Taft High School in the Bronx. As with many of his generation, his career was interrupted by World War II. He served four years with the army, teaching military intelligence and attaining the rank of Major. Ed lived with his family for over 50 years in Scarsdale, New York. After retiring in 1972, he continued his active participation in community affairs, serving in leadership roles with the Greenburgh Nature Center, the Scarsdale Baptist Church, the Schepp Foundation, the Scarsdale Historical Society and the St. Christopher-Jennie Clarkson Home. Ed is survived by his wife of 58 years, Susanne Gay Linville; his sons, John Evans Linville of New York City and James Coker Linville of Rowayton, Connecticut; and four grandsons. Friends are welcome to attend a memorial service Tuesday, 4 PM, at the Scarsdale Community Baptist Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583. For additional information please contact Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home at 914-698-5968.

title: India's Top Mutual Fund Group To Ease Freeze on Flagship Unit
description: Unit Trust of India, the country's largest mutual fund group, said today that it would partly lift the freeze on the sale and purchase of units of its flagship fund, US-64, on Aug. 1, permitting almost half of the plan's investors an exit.

title: The New Pentagon War Strategy
description: It is heartening to learn that the Pentagon is ready to set aside its outdated plan to fight two major wars simultaneously. The purpose of such broad strategies is to determine the size, shape and weaponry of the Army, Navy and Air Force. The two-war requirement, in place since 1993, was straining the Pentagon budget and distorting the three services. It took insufficient account of the weakening of the conventional military threat from Iraq in recent years and ignored the most common military operations Washington has actually had to face, like Balkan peacekeeping.

title: Israeli Cabinet Rules Out Idea Of Exchange Of Territory
description: Israel's government today formally buried the idea of land exchanges with the Palestinians, a concept that was raised during the peace talks at Camp David a year ago.

title: The Coming AIDS Crisis in China
description: At the United Nations summit on AIDS last month in New York, the Chinese minister of health, Zhang Wenkang, made an astonishing announcement: 600,000 people in China have AIDS or are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes it. The Chinese government had never before admitted to large numbers of H.I.V. cases. And what this estimate shows -- given the conditions fostering the spread of H.I.V. in China -- is that a major explosion of H.I.V. and AIDS will happen there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANFORD, CHARLES H. ''BUD.''
description: SANFORD-Charles H. ''Bud.'' Of Southport, CT, died on July 12, 2001. Survived by two sons, Samuel C. Sanford of Manlius, NY, Charles H. ''Tim'' Sanford of Greenwood Village, CO; two daughters, Polly Sosnowski of Wadmalaw Island, SC, and Sally Sanford of Concord, MA; a stepdaughter, Suzette King of Tucson, AZ; a step-son, Horton Spitzer, of Jackson, WY; fourteen grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 661 Old Post Rd, Fairfield, CT, on Thursday, August 9, 2001, at 10 AM. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to: The Anthony Trust Association, PO Box 205471, New Haven, CT 06520 or to Yale University, 265 Church St, New Haven, CT 06510-7003.

description: LEIFSCHUTZ-Theodore. On July 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Sophie for 59 years. Cherished father of Marcia, Bashie and Sashie. Devoted father-in-law of Harold, Nick and Paula. Loving grandfather of Steven, Howard, Aaron and Gerald. Great-granddad of Rachel. Caring brother of Esther Greenwald. We will always love you. Services today, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S. Envoy, A Bridge To Vietnam, Ends Tenure
description: If anybody personified the maturing new relationship between the United States and Vietnam, it was Ambassador Pete Peterson, a former prisoner there who almost never talked about the war.

title: North Cypriot Editor Speaks His Mind
description: Any attempt to understand north Cyprus is complicated by the emotive claims of the Greek Cypriots and by the uncanny ability of the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, to skew any argument in his favor. Both his critics and his supporters admit Mr. Denktash's skills as a lawyer have been central to his durability as a politician.

description: Anne Queffélec

title: In Cable TV, Programmers Provide a Power Balance
description: To grasp one of the most important developments in the cable television industry did not necessarily require being at the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan last week for Comcast's briefing on its $44.5 billion bid for AT&T's cable unit.

title: Russia Tries To Catch Up
description: With its vast distances, highly educated population and desperate need of a modern communications system, Russia would seem the perfect place for the Internet to take hold. But while much of the Western world jumped online in the 1990's, Russia, embroiled in political turmoil and growing poverty, missed the revolution.

title: Uncle Held After Boy Dies In Shooting
description: A 32-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with criminal possession of a weapon and tampering with evidence after his 4-year-old nephew apparently shot himself in the man's home and later died, the police said.

title: Making Herself at Home In an All-Star Fashion
description: Vickie Johnson never wanted to come to New York. Big city, strange people, different atmosphere -- it was not a place that she expected or wanted to call home.

description: With last week's $8.75 million settlement of the lawsuit by police torture victim Abner Louima, and with two cops serving long prison terms for the attack on Mr. Louima, you would think this case that both convulsed and shamed the city would finally be over.

description: In the latest unseemly episode associated with reality television, a male contestant was dismissed from the CBS show ''Big Brother 2'' last week for taking a knife to the throat of a female contestant.

title: Yankees Look Within, and It's a Frightful Sight
description: The players could see the anger in their manager building as the Yankees' mistakes multiplied today, and like meteorologists, the veterans who know the rhythms of Joe Torre's mostly stable moods could have predicted the postgame outpouring.

title: Compressed Data; For a Tiny Pacific Nation, Its Domain Is Its Treasure
description: The tiny South Pacific country of Tuvalu, despite being strung with so few phone lines that international callers hear busy signals more often than voices, has buttressed its economy with cash from the Internet. And to celebrate, Tuvalu (pronounced too-vah-LOO) is using a more traditional network: the postal service.

title: Now Even Umpires Are Arguing Over Number of Balls and Strikes
description: The number of pitches in a major league baseball game has become the center of a heated dispute between umpires and Major League Baseball officials. The dispute has prompted a grievance by the umpires' union against baseball, and the resignation of a supervisor who wanted no part of telling umpires they had to call more strikes when they worked behind home plate.

description: SALERNO-Mary. Died peacefully, on July 14, 2001, at an age we have long since forgotten. A caring and independent woman who was devoted to family and friends. She is survived by a sister, Tina, and a brother, Fred, and many nieces and nephews. An accomplished professional who was a pioneer for women in commercial real estate. Contributions may be made in her memory to the American Cancer Society or the cancer charity of your choice. A service in celebration of her life will be scheduled at a later date.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Internet Caution Urged
description: Internet sites that offer auctions, travel, vacation deals and online investing sites, while often legitimate, are sometimes run by disreputable companies or individuals trying to bilk users, Jane S. Hoffman, the city's consumer affairs commissioner, said yesterday. She listed several sites that she called confusing and misleading. Ms. Hoffman also offered suggestions for doing business over the Internet. When providing credit card information, she said, consumers should make sure the information is sent to a secure server. They should also check that the company has a phone number and a physical address, she said.

title: Memories Rise As Tanks Fall In Brooklyn
description: When the explosives went off and the big KeySpan natural-gas storage tanks came tumbling down in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, hundreds of people watched, but each saw something different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARNELL, JULES E.
description: YARNELL-Jules E. Of Rye Brook, NY, and Lakeville, CT, passed away at age 82, on July 14, 2001. He endured an extended illness with courage and dignity. Born NYC, June 12, 1919. Graduated Townsend Harris and CCNY. Received J.D. from St. John's University and Masters of Law from NYU. During WWII served as captain in the Army Air Corps in the European Theater. Trial lawyer Antitrust Division of Department of Justice. Partner in NYC law firm. Founded Anti-Piracy Division of the Recording Industry Association of America. Instrumental in passage of federal legislation and laws in 48 states making counterfeiting illegal. World's preeminent authority on recording piracy. Beloved husband of Marilyn (Oshman) for 50 years. Cherished father of Marcie Dodson, Janet and William Yarnell, and Michael and Ellen Zimmer. Devoted grandfather of James, Steven and Daniel Dodson. Loving brother of Rose and Ben Yarnell. Services Wednesday, July 18, 2 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBERT F.
description: SMITH-Robert F. Of Brooklyn, NY, died June 26, 2001. Son of Peter P. and Edythe Read Smith. Manhattan College 1933, numerous track records, competed for NY Athletic Club, US Olympic Team 1932. Staff Sergeant US Army Intelligence, D-Day landing, Bronze Star. 15 RKO movies, including ''Call Out the Marines,'' ''An Obliging Young Lady.'' Originated role of Beauregard Burnside opposite Rosalind Russell in ''Auntie Mame'' on Broadway. Starred in ''Brigadoon,'' ''One For the Money,'' ''Gramercy Ghost'' opposite Sara Churchill. Owned Coat of Arms restaurant in east midtown. Survived by sister Mrs. E. Vincent Curtayne and dozen of nieces and nephews and their progeny. Actor, runner, soldier, spy. War hero, Olympian, bubble gum king, candlelighter, movie star, Broadway leading man, brother, uncle, friend. We mourn the passing but celebrate the life of Robert F. Smith. You represented your country in the Olympics. You served your country on D-Day and in Normandy. You entertained us, loved us, provided us an example of religious faith, and surely died in a state of grace. Our nation thanked you with the Bronze Star. We probably never thanked you enough. We know you are in heaven, loving your mother, and Clare and your seven other siblings and arguing with Pa. Pray for us, Bob. Love, Grace and all your nieces, nephews, grand-nieces, grand - nephews, great - grand nieces and great-grand-nephews. Buried at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Memorial Mass, Holy Family Church, Fairfield, CT, July 18.

description: A caption in Business Day on Friday about efforts by the UAL Corporation to acquire US Airways misstated when the chairmen of the two airlines appeared at a news conference to announce the initial deal. It was May 2000, not last May.

description: China's Communist Party celebrated its 80th anniversary this month as the gap widens between its increasingly anachronistic pronouncements and the reality those words struggle to describe.

title: Guardian Honors Mall by Curbing Number of Memorials
description: JOHN G. PARSONS is Washington's ultimate power ranger. As the landscape architect in charge of land use for the National Park Service here, he has drawn a line in the sand -- the grass, really -- to stave off what he sees as an invasion of the remaining open spaces on the Mall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCELLINO, FRED
description: MARCELLINO-Fred. July 12, 2001. Husband of Jean. Father of Nico and his wife Elizabeth. Brother of Marie Marcellino Allen. He was a noted illustrator and author of children's books after an illustrious career as both a book jacket and record album cover designer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday, July 16, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service on Tuesday, July 17, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYU Medical Center, Deptartment of Oncology, or the Cabrini Hospice. In tribute to Fred's love of gardening, flowers are welcomed and appreciated.

title: Ending the Slave Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, C. NICHOLAS
description: POTTER-C. Nicholas. The Board of Directors, Senior Management and Staff at J.P. Morgan mourn the loss of our dear and wise friend, C. Nicholas Potter. Mr. Potter spent over 30 years with the firm and his contributions were numerous and far-reaching. Nick began his career with J.P. Morgan in 1965 headquartered in New York, following service in the U.S. Navy. He was transferred to London in 1974 to create the firm's first ever international investment management unit. Nick returned to New York in 1979 to head investment research and in 1980, his responsibilities were expanded to lead investment policy. Nick was appointed Chief Investment Officer of Morgan's Trust and Investment business in 1981. He was named President of J.P. Morgan Investment Management upon its creation in 1984. Nick retired from the firm in 1997 and for the two years following, he served as a strategic advisor to the business. Mr. Potter was a leader in every way. He is widely recognized both by his colleagues and within the industry, as one of the early visionaries for our investment management business. He set the standard for both personal and professional integrity as well as fiduciary responsibility. We will miss him as a friend and colleague. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Clare and family.

title: India-Pakistan Talks: Many Hopes, No Details
description: India's prime minister and Pakistan's military ruler, leaders of nuclear-armed adversaries, had never even met until Saturday. At a summit meeting here today, they had their first face-to-face negotiations. The two men talked alone for an hour and a half about their most intractable disagreements.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, named two executives to head the organization for 2001-2002. David A. Park, chief executive at the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, becomes chairman. He succeeds Arthur C. Liebler, who until his recent retirement was senior vice president for global brand marketing at the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler, Auburn Hills, Mich. And Paul C. Atkinson, vice president for integrated sales at AOL Time Warner, New York, becomes vice chairman of the organization. He will become chairman for 2002-2003, succeeding Mr. Park.

title: Series of Treasury Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a nine-day cash management bill.

title: Farmers Return to Roots of Cotton
description: For all the seasons of debt and drought, all the years when cotton betrayed them and their families, Mississippi farmers never forgot the fiber that bound them to the past. Even after the banks forced them to abandon low-priced cotton for the despised soybean in the 1960's and 70's, they waited, hoping that some unseen market force would one day provide the excuse they needed to go back.

title: 3 Russian Officers Disciplined for Roles in Chechen Assault
description: MOSCOW, July 16 — The Russian Army commander for Chechnya relieved a deputy of his duties today and suspended two others in the wake of "mopping up" operations in two Chechen villages west of Grozny, the capital.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: John Claybrooks, vice president for business transformation and integration at LeasePlan USA, Atlanta, was promoted to senior vice president for sales and chief marketing officer. He succeeds Gary Scanlon, who left, the company said. LeasePlan USA is owned by ABN Amro Lease Holding, a unit of ABN AMRO Bank.

title: Europe's Chance in the Mideast
description: On a range of issues from global warming to the small arms trade, the policy gulf between Europe and America is noticeably widening. But one potentially important area of divergence is among the least noticed: the Middle East conflict, where Europe and America have sharp differences and where, at the same time, Europe may be set to play an increasingly prominent part.

title: U.S. Review on Russia Urges Keeping Most Arms Controls
description: A Bush administration review of American assistance to Russia has concluded that most of the programs aimed at helping Russia stop the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons are vital to American security and should be continued, a senior administration official says. Some may even be expanded.

title: Movie Made for Russia Roils Brighton Beach
description: The day begins calmly enough. An elegantly plump Russian grandmother strolls with her gentleman friend along the boardwalk in Brighton Beach, reminiscing about the old country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMER, YVONNE
description: SOMMER-Yvonne. Beloved wife of the late Georges M. Loving mother of Francine and Philippe, mother-in-law of Carolyn (Setlow) and Robert Batscha, and grandmother of Eric Batscha, Alexander and Daniel Sommer. Devoted sister of Jean-Pierre (Janine) Metzger of La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland; and Claude (Clio) Metzger of New Rochelle, NY. Services Monday, July 16, at 11:45 AM, at Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the National Neurofibromatosis Foundation, 95 Pine St, NYC 10005.

title: The Bulls, the Bears and 401(k)'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Focusing on Bozell, Interpublic Retools
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York continued to make decisions on the details of its reorganization last week, centering on what had been the Bozell Group. The most recent changes mainly involve account shifts and merging agencies at what became units of the new Partnership division of Interpublic.

title: He's in Charge, in Demand and in Prison
description: When union leaders went to prison in years past, often for embezzlement or worse, they were usually shunned by everyone but their utmost loyalists. But that certainly has not happened to Dennis Rivera, president of New York City's giant health care union.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Sharp Drop in Sales Expected for Chip Equipment Makers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 — Semiconductor equipment makers will see their sales decline by more than a third this year, and they will not surpass last year's sales levels until 2004, an industry trade association predicted today.

title: Jupiter Media Hires Chief From Infosis
description: Jupiter Media Metrix, the Internet rating and research firm, has hired Robert Becker as its new chief executive, the company said on Friday.

title: INSIDE
description: Clues on Missing Americans

title: Frustrated Europeans Set to Battle U.S. on Climate
description: This used to be a gritty and dirty little town, surrounded by coal mines and factories and overshadowed by a power plant that spewed soot everywhere.

title: True Crimes, Famous and Forgotten
description: A COLD CASE

title: Russia, China Sign Treaty Amid Concerns About U.S.
description: MOSCOW, July 16 -- Russia and China signed a treaty of "friendship and cooperation" today, binding the two giants closer in the next 20 years and also committing them to oppose jointly much of the framework for international security that the United States is seeking to erect after the cold war.

title: Suspect Held In 3 Killings Above Deli
description: The second man sought in the execution-style killing of three people in a robbery above the Carnegie Deli in May was arrested yesterday after the authorities tracked him to a homeless shelter in Miami based on calls to the ''America's Most Wanted'' television program.

title: THE INCOMPLETE RSUM: A special report.; An Executive's Missing Years: Papering Over Past Problems
description: For the young executive, it must have appeared that his world was falling apart. He had landed a job running a company despite being fired by his previous employer. But then he was fired again, with the company's board accusing him of overseeing a huge accounting fraud.

title: Ashcroft Says Trust in F.B.I. Has Been Eroded by Missteps
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 — Attorney General John Ashcroft said in a speech at F.B.I. headquarters today that the public trust in the law enforcement agency had been eroded by recent missteps, among them a case in which an F.B.I. agent pleaded guilty to spying for Russian and another in which the bureau failed to turn over thousands of pages of investigative reports to defense lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case.

title: Friends Help Valentine Savor Victory Milestone
description: Bobby Valentine was relaxing in his office at Shea Stadium yesterday when the telephone rang. The official-sounding voice told Valentine that it was Camp David calling to locate him and that another call would be placed in five minutes because President Bush wanted to speak to him. Valentine hung up, a little anxious and a little wary.

title: Better H.M.O.'s?
description: To the Editor:

title: Easy on the Adverbs, Exclamation Points and Especially Hooptedoodle
description: These are rules I've picked up along the way to help me remain invisible when I'm writing a book, to help me show rather than tell what's taking place in the story. If you have a facility for language and imagery and the sound of your voice pleases you, invisibility is not what you are after, and you can skip the rules. Still, you might look them over.

title: A 60's Shakespeare  Go-Go, Flavored With Hints of James Bond
description: It's a good sign when the audience breaks into a collective smile during the first minute of a production. That happened on Thursday night at the opening performance of the Aquila Theater Company's gleefully engaging ''Much Ado About Nothing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, ANN MARIE
description: HERZ-Ann Marie. Passed away at home on July 14, 2001. Beloved wife of Charles. Loving mother of Meg and her husband Bill FloydJones. Cherished grandmother of Charles and Laura. Visitation Monday, 2-5, 7-9 PM, McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:15 AM, Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church.

title: Equity Offerings
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Nauvoo Journal; Mormons Rebuild a Temple on Hallowed Ground
description: Sometime in September, a construction crane will hoist a seven-foot statue of an angel atop a spire, about 150 feet above the ground. Striking though it will be, with a skin of gold leaf and a trumpet raised to its lips, the statue is but a detail of a larger structure, a reconstruction of the elaborate temple built by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, back when this Mississippi River village stood at the faith's geographic center.

title: Internet Music Start-Up to Obtain Licenses
description: Internet music start-ups, angling to take the lead in the race to sell music online, have made big news recently by obtaining licenses from major record companies. But these licenses have largely addressed only a portion of the complicated set of rights used in the music business.

title: Democrats Seek Inquiry on Florida Vote Count
description: Several leading Democrats said today that the Bush campaign acted improperly in pressing for counting overseas absentee ballots in Florida after last year's presidential election. And some said they would probably call upon Congressional investigators to open an inquiry into efforts by Republicans to involve the Pentagon to help them contact military personnel.

title: How to Lose a Cold Contract By Outsmarting Yourself
description: In the 1960's and 70's Canada had one of the world's best partnerships. Eric Murray and Sami Kehela never won a world title, but they may be the best partnership that never did. They came close on several occasions but have been in virtual retirement for two decades. Toronto, their home town, is the site of the Summer Nationals this year, and on Thursday, the eve of the tournament, they will be inducted into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame. Many of those who remember them with affection and respect will be there to cheer.

title: U.S. Reassures Iraqi Kurds on Protection From Baghdad
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 — The Pentagon has assured Iraqi opposition leaders that it will not let Saddam Hussein use Iraqi airspace to attack the Kurds or to threaten Baghdad's neighbors, a Defense Department official said.

title: New I.O.C. President Named
description: MOSCOW, July 16 — Jacques Rogge, an urbane 59-year-old orthopedic surgeon from Belgium, succeeded Juan Antonio Samaranch today as president of the International Olympic Committee, as the most visible and important position in sports administration changed hands for the first time in two decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPARTLAND, ANNE
description: McPARTLAND-Anne. On July 14, 2001. Retired executive secretary, W.R. Grace Co. Beloved daughter of the late Michael and Helen. Dear sister of the late Bernard and Michael, and survived by her sister-in-law Josephine. Loving aunt of Michael, Bernard, Ellen Higgins and Moira Byrnes, and the late Mary Ann Cunniffe. Great-aunt of 13 nieces and nephews and one great-grandniece. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. at 20th St., NYC, Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th St., Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Immaculate Conception Church would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRADER, ABE
description: SCHRADER-Abe. Hineni International Outreach extends heartfelt sympathy to Mort, Miquette, and David Schrader on the passing of their beloved Abe who left a legacy of a joyous spirit. Rebbetzin Esther Jungreis, Pres. Barbara Janov, Exec. Director Rabbi Yisroel Jungreis Rabbi Osher Jungreis

title: On Television; Stringing Together Taut Episodes, Not Codas, on 'The Sopranos'
description: As ''The Sopranos'' ended its third season this spring, accompanied by a torrent of attention, David Chase, the show's creator and executive producer, was far away, secluded in France on vacation, unaware, he says, of the intensity of passion that attended the final episodes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENDLER, DORA KLEIMAN
description: TENDLER-Dora Kleiman. Born Rokitno, Poland. Devoted wife of Mayer. Beloved mother of Mark and Carol, Ellen and Peter. Cherished grandmother of Lori, Jodi and Doug, Rachel and Bertie, Tara, Hilary, David, Joseph and Benjamin. Great-grandmother of Joshua and Noa. Dear sister of Chana, Dov and Ruth. Services today at 12 noon at The Riverside, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGREEN, MORRIS H.
description: BERGREEN-Morris H. Beloved husband of Adele, adored father of Laurence and the late John, cherished father-in-law of Betsy and Natasha, loving grandfather of Nicholas and Sara. Remarkable, brilliant, and unforgettable, a truly generous spirit. Services were held.

title: When Site Sponsorship Threatens Credibility
description: Say you are a celebrity intellectual and an occasional magnet for controversy.

title: Tour's Also-Rans Enjoy Their Day in the Rain
description: A cold rain fell all day, the Alps are coming up Tuesday and the first week of the Tour de France has been rapid, nervous and wearying, so a revolt of the bottom feeders -- riders far behind the leaders -- succeeded stupendously today and added an unexpected contender to the race.

title: From Africa to Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Takes Skill, as Well as Smarts
description: To the Editor:

title: Potential Mergers Face a Foreign Hurdle
description: Trust-busting is alive and well.

title: A Rocky Road for AT&T
description: When AT&T made C. Michael Armstrong its chief executive in October 1997, he promised to revive the struggling company by turning it into an information-services behemoth. Three years later, however, the company changed its path unexpectedly, announcing that it would split into four different businesses. Mr. Armstrong has tried to make the best of a new game plan he admits he did not foresee. Last week he chalked up a small win and a potential draw, but bigger challenges lie ahead.

title: Gimmicks and Games To Create Dancegoers; People Aren't Born Loving Pas de Deux, So the Art of Persuasion Grows Complex
description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater is not known for its program notes. The company tends to let its freewheeling, often surrealistic dances stand on their own. But audiences at the Joyce Theater, where Pilobolus is performing through July 28, will find not one but two substantial notes accompanying the credits for ''Davenen,'' a new piece by Robby Barnett and Jonathan Wolken that explores the nature of prayer.

title: Rangers Put Prospects on Display
description: Glen Sather has vowed to rebuild the Rangers through youth. He reaffirmed that strategy just last week with his refusal to part with any of the Rangers' top prospects in a deal for Jaromir Jagr before Pittsburgh dealt the star player to Washington.

title: Manhattan Past, Queens Present; City Hall Park Artifacts Are Returned From Obscurity
description: Men in a moving truck drove down to Virginia three months ago to collect some stuff belonging to the City of New York. They pulled up in front of a warehouse in Fairfax, loaded box after box into the truck's hold, and headed north, back to the city.

title: A Long Road Ahead For Missile Program
description: After the United States military succeeded for only the second time in shooting down a mock intercontinental ballistic missile, Pentagon officials played down the significance of the test, warning that scientists would need weeks or even months to finish analyzing the results and that much more development would be required before the technology could be reliably used.

title: Suspect Held in 3 Killings Above Deli
description: The second man sought in the execution- style killing of three people in a robbery above the Carnegie Deli in May was arrested yesterday after the authorities tracked him to a homeless shelter in Miami based on calls to the "America's Most Wanted" television program.

title: Piazza Shows Jays The Back Of His Hand
description: Mike Piazza has thick forearms, bulging biceps, sturdy shoulders and a large chest. He could stroll into a professional football locker room tomorrow and feel as if he belonged. He could moonlight as a bouncer at any club in Manhattan if he ever wanted to supplement his $13 million-a-year salary. He is big, strong and athletic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASSOFF, HORACE
description: BASSOFF-Horace. To our dear friend Horace, may you rest in peace. Our heartfelt sympathies to dearest Phyllis and the family. Ralph and Frankie Friedlander

title: North Korean and Vietnamese Trade Compliments
description: SEOUL  North Korea's second-in-command won words of praise but no promises of rice for his hungry country as he concluded a three-day visit to Vietnam.

title: Private Suits Put Microsoft At Little Risk
description: The recent appeals court decision upholding a lower court's ruling that Microsoft had violated antitrust law aided the dozens of private antitrust lawsuits customers have filed against the company.

title: The Good Times of Way Down Yonder, Complete With the Rakish Growl
description: Any excuse that brings top New Orleans musicians to New York City is good. The concert in the courtyard of Aaron Davis Hall on Saturday afternoon featured regulars on the New Orleans club circuit who too rarely come north: the trumpeter Kermit Ruffins with his band, the Barbecue Swingers; the singer John Boutt; the trumpeter James Andrews; and the Rebirth Brass Band, who brought with them a dancing auxiliary, the Original Lady Buck Jumpers.

title: Cashing In on Black Readers; Book Niche Is Seen Keeping Writers Outside the Mainstream
description: An advertising campaign for Strivers Row, a new line of books from Random House aimed at black readers, is creating a stir among black authors and agents. The reason is that the advertisements double as plugs for Pine-Sol, the household cleanser.

title: Ulster Disarmament: One More Last-Chance Strategy
description: In the struggle to bring political stability to Northern Ireland, the presence of guerrilla arms has been the elephant in the room that people pretended they didn't see. Now it has become an impassable beast that no one can ignore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRENT, TERESE
description: TRENT-Terese. On July 11, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Edwin. Loving mother of Walter, Paul & the late Richard. Fond mother-inlaw of Alice, Sandy and Florence. Dear grandmother of Nancy Trent Jakubik, Patricia Trent Saidenberg, Adrien Trent and Evan Trent. Cherished greatgrandmother of Scooter, Charlie and Harry Jakubik and Robin Saidenberg. Graveside services were held at Salem Fields Cemetery Sunday, July 15, 2001. For more information please call The Universal Funeral Chapel, 212753-5300.

title: Angst and Ambivalence From 2 Young Companies
description: Tom Pearson and Eva Silverstein, two very different choreographers who have founded companies in the last three years, shared the program presented on Saturday night by the Bridge for Dance, an attractive studio theater at 2726 Broadway near 104th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, KATE (NEE FISHER)
description: GREENBERG-Kate (nee Fisher). Of Riverdale, NY, on July 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Aaron. Devoted mother of Herbert Greenberg and Rona Ziskin. Cherished mother-in-law of Carole. Loving grandmother of five and great-grandmother of seven. Services will be held at GuttermanMusicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, July 17, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USDAN, BEATRICE F.
description: USDAN-Beatrice F. Age 94, on July 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Israel Usdan. Loving mother of Judith Kassover and Michael Usdan. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Memorial contributions may be made to Hadassah, 50 West 58th St., NYC 10019.

title: Compressed Data; Amazon's Chief Agrees To Play Barbecue Chef
description: So why is Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon.com, throwing a barbecue today in New York for Modern Humorist, a tiny Brooklyn publishing company and Web site operator?

title: Amid Applause, Caution Urged on Missile Defense
description: The United States military has succeeded for only the second time in shooting down an intercontinental ballistic missile, but Pentagon officials warned today that much more development would be needed before the technology could reliably destroy real weapons.

title: Hotel Savings in Hong Kong
description: Through Sept. 10, the five-star Great Eagle Hotel in Hong Kong is reducing rates more than 45 percent. A courtyard-view room is $142 a night; a harborview room, $180 (prices may vary because of exchange-rate fluctuations). Rates on the Club Floor, with breakfast, evening cocktails, use of a health club and a fruit basket, are $205 to $244. Information: (800) 457-4000 or www.gehotel.com .

title: Delta Dawn
description: Afamiliar name in home improvement is making what executives hope will be some well-received improvements of its own -- remodeling its corporate identity and refurbishing its advertising.

title: Team Says Morales Lied About Age
description: The Yankees have cut their contractual ties with the Cuban defector Andy Morales, arguing that he misrepresented his age to the team, and Morales now faces immigration complications.

title: Sports of The Times; Stay Clear of the Dreaded Lytham Bunkers
description: IN the glow of winning last year's British Open at St. Andrews by an elegant eight strokes, Tiger Woods was informed, mistakenly, of having been in a bunker on the seventh hole in Friday's second round.

title: China and Russia Draw Closer, With Ceremony Today
description: President Jiang Zemin of China arrived in the Russian capital today for a state visit that is to culminate Monday in the signing of a treaty on friendship and cooperation. It will be the first such pact since 1950, when Moscow and Beijing allied themselves against the West.

title: New Economy; A dot-com editor sheds his five-year 'cocoon,' and looks at how journalism has changed in the age of the Internet.
description: EVEN as dot-coms continue to crash around us, it is easy to lose sight of the Internet's impact. After five years inside the cocoon of an intense start-up, TheStreet.com, I have emerged to find common activities transformed by electronic connection. Not least of these, journalism has swiftly evolved to handle the rapid emergence of a new medium.

title: Joint Effort to Investigate Gene Functions
description: Celera Genomics and Isis Pharmaceuticals are expected to announce today that Isis will try to determine the functions of more than 200 genes supplied by Celera.

title: Studies in a Bleakness The Composer Knew
description: The important modernist composer Luigi Dallapiccola was born in 1904 in a disputed region of Italy then under Austrian control. When he was 13 his family, suspected of Italian nationalism, was interned at Graz, Austria. His early experiences fostered a lifelong fervor for liberty in Dallapiccola. Yet like many Italians during the 1930's, he initially fell for Mussolini's nationalistic propaganda. He soon became a committed anti-Fascist (his wife was Jewish), who was periodically forced into hiding during World War II.

title: Brooklyn Dominating New Rival
description: Give them some time. Maybe a few more games. Maybe a few more years, but the Brooklyn Cyclones and the Staten Island Yankees have yet to establish a rivalry to match that of their parent organizations. For now, the Borough Series, the Ferry Series, or whatever name sticks until the next time, is for the fans.

title: Masius Is Enlarging Its New York Shop
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of the Bcom3 Group, is expanding the New York office of Masius, its marketing unit for corporate, business-to-business and financial services that was introduced last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, RUTH COHEN
description: JACOBSON-Ruth Cohen. Age 60, on July 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Jerry. Stepmother of Sue Center and Cathy Monaco, both of Nyack. Also survived by five grandchildren. Services Monday 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, NORMAN
description: SINGER-Norman. Died peacefully July 14, leaving Geoffrey Charlesworth, his beloved companion of 56 years, niece Linda Parker, nephew Duke Lechtman and niece Judi Meyersfield. No funeral. Contributions to American Civil Liberties Union or Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: Sports of The Times; This Olympic Hurdle May Be Set Too High
description: FROM her hotel room in Moscow yesterday evening, Anita DeFrantz, first vice president of the International Olympic Committee, spoke alternately with the deftness of a politician and the candor of an activist-pioneer.

title: Shepherds' Labor Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Adversary to Become F.T.C. Official
description: Susan A. Creighton, a Silicon Valley lawyer who has dogged Microsoft for years and only last month wrote a ''white paper'' assessing the antitrust issues raised by the company's new Windows XP operating system, is abandoning the chase. She is joining the Bush administration as an antitrust watchdog.

title: Bodies of 3 New Yorkers Believed Found in a Serbian Grave
description: The Serbian authorities have found what may be the remains of three Albanian-American brothers from New York who were arrested and apparently executed under Slobodan Milosevic's government shortly after NATO's war against Yugoslavia ended.

title: test slideshow july 16
description: this is another test slideshow done on monday, july 16

title: Private Matters
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Refiner Courts California Over Pending Merger
description: A week before the Valero Energy Corporation announced plans to buy the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation, William E. Greehey, Valero's chief executive, sat down with California's attorney general, Bill Lockyer, to discuss Valero's track record.

title: White House Unconcerned About China-Russia Accord
description: The Bush administration played down the importance of a friendship pact between Moscow and Beijing today, saying it represented short-term interests rather than a long-term strategy that should concern the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about free software to adjust the backlighting on the Palm m505 hand-held computer misstated the Web address at which the software is available. It is www.palm.com/support/m505 /backlight_utility.html.

title: 7 Choreographers Pick a Sin and Run With It
description: A good time was had by nearly all on Sunday afternoon when ''The Seven Deadly Sins'' spilled out across the stage of the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. Many in the audience rose in a standing ovation. And the performers and choreographers seemed to have had a lot of fun putting this oddity together. But the parts amounted to less than one might have expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JEROME DONALD (JERRY)
description: SMITH-Jerome Donald (Jerry). Beloved husband of Janet. After a long illness. Funeral service at 10 AM, Tuesday, July 17 at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 250th Street and Henry Hudson Parkway. For more information 718-543-8400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, BERNARD D.
description: FISCHMAN - Bernard D. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend and fellow director of the Elie Wiesel Foundation, Bernie Fischman. We shall miss the warmth of his presence, his wise counsel, his integrity, his commitment to all that is noble in man and all that allows hope for the future. Dear Hilda, Judy and Bobwe share your pride in his legacy, as we share in your sorrow. Elie Wiesel, President Marion Wiesel, Vice President Arnold Thaler, Vice President

title: Labor and Industry Debate Workplace Safety
description: At a forum to discuss workplace safety rules, union leaders accused Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao today of favoring industry as the Bush administration considered whether new rules were needed to replace those announced by President Bill Clinton, which Congress repealed in March.

title: A Missile Shield Road Map
description: The flight data must still be fully evaluated, but the Pentagon reports that last weekend's missile defense test was a success, giving a modest but timely advance to a troubled program. For the second time in four tries, the Pentagon said, a prototype interceptor hit and destroyed a dummy warhead far above the Pacific. Many more tests will be needed before a reliable ground-based system is ready for use. These must include tests under more realistic conditions, with the dummy warhead surrounded by multiple decoys designed to draw the interceptor away from the target. Saturday's test used a single decoy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBANDOS, JIM
description: AMBANDOS-Jim. Wonderful loving husband of Francine and dear father of Andrea-our own private internet! Professor Emeritus of Communications, Temple U. Noted writer of TV's Golden Age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIT, JULIUS
description: MAIT-Julius. We mourn the loss of our first cousin Jules who was more like our brother. Jules celebrated life every day. He shared joyfully with Doris for 62 years, with his three sons and daughters-in-law, his two sisters, his eight grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren, and with each person who knew and adored him as we did. The Justin and Charles Israel Families

title: Continental Airlines Reports a 72% Drop in Quarterly Profit
description: Kicking off what promises to be a depressing series of second-quarter earnings reports from the major airlines this week, Continental Airlines surpassed Wall Street expectations yesterday.

title: Yanks Shake Off Missed Chances to Cling to First
description: Joe Torre demanded more from his team after a brutal loss Sunday and what he got for 13 innings tonight were more mistakes -- another passed ball, another infield error, flubbed bunts, a base-running blunder, and 19 consecutive hitless at-bats from the first four hitters in his lineup.

title: Sea Lions and Their Prey
description: To the Editor:

title: Shielding Women From H.I.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Troubled Comdisco Sells Unit
description: Comdisco Inc., whose stock price has steadily tumbled since last year, said yesterday that it would sell its technology services business to the Hewlett-Packard Company for $610 million and file for bankruptcy protection. The business acquired by Hewlett-Packard focuses on ''availability services,'' such as contingency planning services and disaster recovery. Comdisco, whose primary focus is leasing computer equipment, said that 50 of its United States subsidiaries have filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter 11, adding that it hopes to emerge from bankruptcy early next year. The company, based in Rosemont, Ill., also announced it would lay off about 200 employees, representing less than 10 percent of its North American work force, and said it had received commitments for $600 million in financing. The business units acquired by Hewlett-Packard employ roughly 1,300 employees worldwide and last year had $440 million in revenues.

title: PGA Tour's Shotgun Approach Hits All the Targets
description: The PGA Tour is a most unfathomable organization, and not only because it opposes Casey Martin's right to use a cart. Unlike other sports organizations eager to trumpet how much money the networks are paying them, the PGA Tour is shy about detailing its deals, including the agreements it announced yesterday with CBS, ABC, NBC, ESPN and USA Network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, RICHARD E., ESQ.
description: BAUMAN-Richard E., Esq. On July 14, 2001, at age 77. Devoted companion of Jose R. Vega. Also survived by his grandchildren Maria Rodriguez, Robert Vega and four great-grandchildren; sisters Reva Hildum and Blanca Rodriguez; brothers-in-law Ramon and Carmen Rodriguez. Interment private. Memorial service Wednesday, July 18, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., 4:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, PAUL
description: SINGER-Paul. Beloved husband of Martha. Loving father of Larry (Gail) and Andre. Cherished grandfather of Emily. Born in Munkacs, Hungary. Survivor of the Holocaust. Services today, 2PM, at Congregation Mt. Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn.

title: A Remolded Grant To Return Saturday
description: Teddy Atlas, a trainer, said yesterday that Michael Grant, a once promising heavyweight, was a fighter in search of an identity. One minute the 6-7, 250 pound Grant fought with the agility of Muhammad Ali; the next he was a brawler like Jake LaMotta.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Panel Backed by Bush Urges Higher Car Fuel Efficiency

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRANE, EUGENE WILLIAM
description: McGRANE-Eugene William, 78. Graduate of Manhattan College, died July 14, 2001 at Memorial Hospital, Ormond Beach, FL. He is survived by his wife, Gail, four step-children and eight step-grandchildren. He is also survived by his former wife, Grace, nine children and 12 grandchildren.

title: 2 Minneapolis Agencies Say They Will Combine
description: Two agencies in Minneapolis said yesterday that they would combine.

title: Umpires Might Unite On Strike-Zone Issue
description: Major league umpires do not have to be told that in unity there is strength; they learned that fact of labor life long ago. They have also learned from their experience of the past couple of years what the absence of unity can mean. Their problem is they don't know how to regain the unity they had before the Richie Phillips war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the National Football League's sale of its Internet rights misstated the number of vistors to Major League Baseball's Web site last October as determined by Jupiter Media Metrix, an Internet research firm. It was 542,000, not 6.1 million.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: EIGHT MILES OF BOOK LINKS The Strand Book Store in Manhattan has signed a deal to sell its merchandise on eBay's online marketplace Half.com. A portion of Strand's famed eight miles of new, used and rare titles went on sale on the site about three weeks ago, but officials waited until yesterday to announce the agreement in order to work out any kinks, said Kristin Keyes, a spokeswoman for Half.com. Founded in 1927, the Strand has two retail locations — 828 Broadway, at 12th Street, and 95 Fulton Street in the seaport district — and a Web site, www.strandbooks.com, that also sells books.    Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A RAILROAD COMPANY SAYS ITS PROFIT WILL BEAT FORECASTS
description: Genesee and Wyoming Inc., which operates railroads in five countries, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings would beat forecasts because of American coal and salt shipments, cost reductions and the performance of an Australian unit. Profit will be about 59 cents a share, compared with the Thomson Financial/First Call average estimate of 52 cents, the company said. Profit from operations in the year-earlier quarter was 34 cents. In June, Genesee and Wyoming, based in Greenwich, Conn., started shipments from the American Rock Salt Company near Rochester. The company operates six short-line railroads in Oregon, Louisiana, Illinois, New York and Pennsylvania, and trains in Australia, Bolivia, Canada and Mexico.

title: VITAL SIGNS: REMEDIES; Thalidomide Validated as Cancer Fighter
description: A new study has confirmed earlier reports that the drug thalidomide can significantly extend the lives of people with advanced multiple myeloma, a cancer of the blood.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Hearings Start On Soccer Deaths
description: Three months after a stampede killed 43 fans at a soccer match in Johannesburg, a commission of inquiry opened public hearings and was told by the general manager of the stadium where the calamity unfolded that extra measures had been taken to accommodate the large crowd expected for the match. The victims of the worst accident in the country's sports history died as thousands of fans tried to make their way into the already crowded stadium for the start of one of the season's biggest games. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Clever Wiring Harnesses Tiny Switches
description: In the emerging field of molecular electronics, researchers have already constructed the tiniest of components -- molecules that act as switches -- and they are now starting to tackle the harder problem: how to wire the tiny switches together into useful devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUE, SHYH, JONG, M.D.
description: YUE-Shyh-Jong, M.D. The American College of Acupuncture mourns the loss of a colleague, mentor and friend, Jack, who over the past three decades trained hundreds of physicians and dentists in the practice of acupuncture. His wisdom and guidance helped formulate the New York State Educational Standards. He was awarded registration number 002, the second person certified to practice acupuncture in New York State. Giving his time unselfishly, he was the founding President of the American College of Acupuncture. He helped establish the New York Society of Acupuncture for Physicians and Dentists, presided as its President, and guided the Society in educational tours to Taiwan, France, Australia and China. Trained as both an orthopaedic surgeon and rehabilitation specialist, Dr. Yue was the Director of Rehabilitation Medicine at Saint Luke's and Clinical Associate Professor in Rehabilitation Medicine at Columbia P&S. Condolences to his wife Nai Gi, an accomplished artist, and to his son David and family. Sung Liao, M.D. Alfred Peng, M.D., Peter Teng, D.D.S. Mathew Lee, M.D. Board of Directors

title: Business Inventories Were Unchanged in May
description: Business inventories were unchanged in May as sales rose more than in any month since March of last year, the government reported today, a sign a pickup in the economy may lift production months from now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, MARION (NEE WEISS)
description: WALLACE-Marion (nee Weiss). Devoted mother of Martin and mother-in-law of Doris. Last member of a unique family.

title: Boxer's Biggest Fight Is for Attention
description: He may be The Best Fighter You've Never Heard Of. And Vassiliy Jirov wants that to change, if only someone with credentials will agree to fight him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, RALPH
description: FRIEDLANDER-Ralph. Of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of Frankie Spinoza Friedlander. Devoted father of Vivien Konsker. Stepfather of Debra Liberman and Vicki Reynolds. Cherished brother of Hannah Erlich. Loving grandfather of Joshua Konsker, Laura and Melissa Reynolds. Fond brother-in-law of Marilyn and Robert Weinberg. Dear uncle of Bambi, Mickey and Yossi. Graveside services 2 PM, Tuesday, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions in Ralph's memory to North ShoreLIJ Health Systems. For additional information call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Dutch Phone Company Still in Merger Talks
description: In an attempt to defray speculation that merger discussions with a Belgian phone company had stalled, Royal KPN, the large Dutch telecommunications group, said today that talks were continuing, but had not progressed to an advanced stage.

title: Katharine Graham, Former Publisher of Washington Post, Dies at 84
description: Katharine Graham, who transformed The Washington Post from a mediocre newspaper into an American institution and, in the process, transformed herself from a lonely widow into a publishing legend, died today in Boise, Idaho, where she had been hospitalized since being injured in a fall over the weekend. She was 84.

title: NURSING HOME OWNER TO SELL SOME OPERATIONS IN FLORIDA
description: An operator of skilled-care nursing homes, Beverly Enterprises, has agreed to sell 49 skilled nursing sites and four assisted living centers in Florida for $165 million in cash to pay down debt. NMC of Florida, an affiliate of Vantage Medical and Formation Capital, will buy the centers, the company said. Beverly, of Fort Smith, Ark., will have a second-quarter charge of $6 million to $10 million for additional asset impairments in Florida. The Florida operations represented about 10 percent of Beverly's $2.6 billion in 2000 revenue, but accounted for about 70 percent of the company's liability costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEER, NETTIE
description: SCHNEER-Nettie, 96. Formerly of E. 10th St. died July 15, 2001. Wife of the late Max R. Schneer, mother of Stephen Schneer and the late Anita Simpson. Memorial contributions may be directed to The New School For Social research, 66 West 12th St., N.Y.,N.Y.10011

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Viruses
description: Q. Unlike bacteria, which can be useful in many ways, there don't seem to be any ''good'' viruses. Do any play a positive role?

title: Full Count in the Elysian Fields of Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Murtagh, 57, Brookhaven Physicist
description: Michael Murtagh, chairman of the physics department at Brookhaven National Laboratory and an expert on high-energy physics, died on Thursday at John T. Mather Hospital in Port Jefferson, N.Y. He was 57 and lived in Shoreham, N.Y.

title: Johns Hopkins Admits Fault in Fatal Experiment
description: Johns Hopkins University said today that it accepted full responsibility for the recent death of a volunteer in an experiment. In a report on its investigation into the death, the university said the researcher who conducted the experiment and the ethics committee that approved it had failed to take adequate precautions to protect research subjects.

title: A Sandinista Who Renounced the Sword for the Pen
description: When Sergio Ramrez published a book this spring about his experiences as a leader of the Sandinista revolution, he called it ''Adis, Muchachos,'' or ''Goodbye, Boys.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLMAN, GERALD S.
description: COLMAN-Gerald S. July 17, 2000. You are in our hearts forever. We love you, we miss you. Your devoted family and friends.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Saving The Caspian Sturgeon
description: Responding to warnings that stocks of sturgeon are perilously low in the Caspian Sea, the largest reservoir for the fish that is the main source of black caviar, Russia will suspend commercial fishing for sturgeon on Friday. The decision followed the recommendation of the United Nations body that regulates trade in endangered species. Scientists say pollution, oil drilling and poaching are threatening the sturgeon. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Front Row
description: Sensible Shoes

title: The Recount Is In, and the Supreme Court Loses
description: The recounts by the news media of Florida's ballots in the 2000 presidential election are coming in. And so far they're proving to be inconclusive.

title: Candidates Scurry for Money In the Campaign for Governor
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall has raised $5 million for his run for governor next year and has $3.8 million cash on hand, his campaign reported today, putting him on a par with his Democratic rival, Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Study Says 2000 Election Missed Millions of Votes
description: A new study of the 2000 presidential election has found that 4 million to 6 million votes of the 100 million cast last November were not counted. The survey cited faulty voting equipment, confusing ballots, voter error and problems at polling places, including long lines, short hours and inconvenient locations.

title: Bush Forgoes Trying to Bar Cuba Deals By Foreigners
description: In a setback for the Cuban exile lobby and its Congressional allies, President Bush said today that he would not activate the harshest sanction of a law that seeks to punish foreigners for investing in property in Cuba that was confiscated by the Havana government.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Bank Raises A Key Rate
description: Turkey's central bank raised its overnight borrowing rate four percentage points yesterday, an effort to control inflation and strengthen the country's currency, which has lost half its value since February. The bank lifted the overnight rate to 67 percent, the first increase since the rate rose to 6,200 percent in February as investors pulled $4.5 billion out of the country in three days. Turkey abandoned the defense of its currency, the lira, on Feb. 22, setting off a devaluation and spurring price increases. The lira has been driven lower by bickering among leaders of Turkey's ruling coalition, which delayed $3.2 billion of loans from international lenders, and by concern that Argentina will default on its debt.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Thursday about Microsoft 's relaxing of some contract restrictions on personal computer makers incompletely described a federal appeals court ruling on June 28 about the company's bundling of its Internet browser with its Windows operating system. The court ruled that Microsoft had bundled the browsing software with Windows in a way that violated antitrust laws on two counts. But the court also said that bundling of software was not inherently illegal. It vacated that finding by a lower court and sent the issue back for reconsideration by a new judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALK, SUE ROSENBERG
description: ZALK-Sue Rosenberg. We'll never be a full house again without our Sue, a wonderful friend. We'll miss her. The Poker Game

title: Russia and China Sign 'Friendship' Pact
description: Russia and China signed a treaty of ''friendship and cooperation'' today, binding the two giants closer in the next 20 years and also committing them to oppose jointly much of the framework for international security that the United States is seeking to erect after the cold war.

title: Like Politics, Except the 400-Pound Gorilla Is Real
description: STEVEN E. SANDERSON is a people person. Specifically, he is a poor-people person, as in Mexican and Brazilian peasants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRITER, LUCY KATT
description: FERRITER-Lucy Katt. A longtime resident of Manhattan, died July 13, in Alexandria, VA, following a short illness. She was 84. Ms. Ferriter was born Lucy Erwin Katt in Scarsdale, NY, in 1916 to Margaret and John Katt. She attended the Masters School and graduated from Wellesley College in 1939. During and after World War II, Ms. Ferriter worked as an executive assistant to the President of the American Hardware Association and the Chancellor of New York University. In 1955, she married Joseph Ferriter, a securities analyst, and worked as a homemaker and mother. Following her husband's retirement, she traveled widely and maintained residences in Charlestown, RI and Naples, FL. Ms. Ferriter is survived by a son, John, of Alexandria; a sister, Jean Balzerit, of Portola Valley, CA; and two grandchildren, Matthew and William. Joseph Ferriter died in September, 2000.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Before Summit, A Letter Bomb
description: A letter bomb went off at a police station in Genoa, where the Group of 8 summit meeting begins on Friday, wounding one officer and heightening preconference jitters. The police destroyed a suspicious van that had been parked for days in front of another police station. With tens of thousands of antiglobalization protesters expected, Italy plans to close airports, deploy thousands of soldiers and police officers and install a missile defense to secure the city. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Sara Lee Apparel Unit Selects a New Agency
description: The Sara Lee Branded Apparel division of the Sara Lee Corporation ( news/quote ) said yesterday that it had named the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., to handle United States advertising for its Hanes and Hanes Her Way lines. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUTTAL, CLARICE
description: BLUTTAL-Clarice passed away on July 15, 2001. She was 77. She is survived by two children, Steven and Joan Bluttal, brother Milton Wind, sister Ruth Dworin, and granddaughter Jaquelin Bluttal. For information: Zion Memorial Chapel. 914-381-1809.

title: Treatments: A Closer Look at Medical Marijuana
description: Two studies of the accumulated data on marijuana's medical value have found mixed results: the drug had some advantages over standard treatments for severe nausea, but no advantage in reducing severe pain. Both papers were published this month in The British Medical Journal.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a strong possibility that we will go through all this agony and it will end up changing nothing.''

title: Letters: A Matter of Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: 5-Term Birmingham Mayor Considers 6th
description: Richard Arrington Jr., the former mayor of Birmingham, has announced that he is leaning toward running for his old job in 2003. Mr. Arrington, who served five terms before resigning in 1999, told The Birmingham News on Sunday that ''as of today, the answer is yes.'' But he also said he was ''keeping his options open because we're two and a half years away.'' Mr. Arrington, 66, was Birmingham's first black mayor. His successor, Bernard Kincaid, has been handicapped by contentious relations with the City Council. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Anti-Semitic Graffiti
description: The police said yesterday that they were investigating the spray-painting of swastikas on a synagogue, several homes, a car and the rooftop of an apartment building, mostly on a single block in Brooklyn. Large black swastikas were painted on the doors of seven homes along East 12th Street between Avenue K and Avenue L in Midwood, where many Orthodox Jews live, the police said. The graffiti painted on the synagogue, Congregation Yeshuous Chaim at 1167 East 13th Street, included anti-Semitic remarks, the police said. A passer-by discovered the graffiti at 1:45 a.m. and alerted the authorities. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: British Open Requires Precise Shots, Not Power
description: The skies were clear, the course was crowded and practice for this week's British Open began in full force today.

title: Remedies: Thalidomide Validated as Cancer Fighter
description: Anew study has confirmed earlier reports that the drug thalidomide can significantly extend the lives of people with advanced multiple myeloma, a cancer of the blood.

title: Passed Balls Still Perplexing Posada
description: Jorge Posada went to dinner Sunday night and did his best to forget about all the passed balls he had in the afternoon game against the Phillies. ''I'm glad that game's over,'' Posada said before tonight's game, in which he had one passed ball but hit a two-run homer as the Yankees won, 6-3.

title: Threats to Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympics Ignite a New Battle of Marathon
description: The Greeks have a second Battle of Marathon on their hands.

title: American Style From the 60's Captures New Imaginations
description: ''I hate chic,'' the American modeling agent said, staring glumly from the window of his chauffeured Mercedes as it inched through traffic on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honor. Along the length of this luxury goods rialto were strollers, presumably Parisians, dressed according to the certified standards of taste that the French treat like trust fund principal, something one never invades.

title: Cheney Calls on Navy to Pay Rising Bill to Light His Home
description: Millions of Americans are struggling to cope with sky-high electricity bills for their homes. Among them, it turns out, is Vice President Dick Cheney, the Bush administration's point man on energy policy, whose home is a 33-room mansion on the leafy grounds of the Washington Naval Observatory.

title: Instead of Summer Break, Some Keyboard Calisthenics
description: It has been a busy summer at the Mannes College of Music. Last month the school devoted five days to the New York Guitar Seminar, and last week there was a Beethoven Institute that included master classes, faculty recitals and a student marathon.

title: Sara Lee Apparel Unit Selects a New Agency
description: The Sara Lee Branded Apparel division of the Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it had named the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., to handle United States advertising for its Hanes and Hanes Her Way lines. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'DONNELL, JOSEPH P.
description: O'DONNELL-Joseph P. July 17, 2000. Rest in peace. J. and R.

title: The Best Investment in Helping Poor Nations
description: With more than 1.2 billion of the world's people still living on less than $1 a day, there is no more important challenge than improving living standards and eliminating poverty. The World Bank and other multilateral development banks have a crucial role to play in meeting this challenge. To do so, they need to change their ways of doing business.

title: A Regional Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Journalist Sent To Prison
description: A court sentenced a journalist to six years in prison, overruling the verdict of an appeals court that had reduced the original 10-year prison term to six months. The court found Akbar Ganji, 45, who has already served a year in prison, guilty of ''propagating against the regime'' for taking part in a conference in Berlin last year on possible reforms in Iran. Mr. Ganji has written several books critical of the government and has accused former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani of being linked to the killing of Iranian dissidents. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen declined after the Bank of Japan signaled the outlook for the economy was dimming. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.47 yen, down from 124.83 on Friday.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Third Time Around

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALERNO, MARY
description: SALERNO-Mary. Died peacefully, on July 14, 2001, at an age we have long since forgotten. A caring and independent woman who was devoted to family and friends. She is survived by a sister, Tina, and a brother, Fred, and many nieces and nephews. An accomplished professional who was a pioneer for women in commercial real estate. Contributions may be made in her memory to the American Cancer Society or the cancer charity of your choice. A service in celebration of her life will be scheduled at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MARTIN C.
description: KLEIN-Martin C. On July 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Jim and his wife Jane. Adored grandfather of Elizabeth. Devoted brother of the late Jerome. Dear uncle of Dan and Dona. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, 5-7 PM, with service Tuesday 11:30 AM.

title: Salomon Settles Lawsuit on Discrimination
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the investment firm Salomon Smith Barney have settled a lawsuit filed in September that accused the firm of discriminating against some Haitian, Nigerian and West Indian employees at its data center in New York.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Millions Are Hungry
description: Five million Afghans -- one-fifth of the population -- ''have little or no access to food'' because of prolonged drought and civil war, according to a statement from the World Food Program, a United Nations agency. Some 75 tons of American wheat are expected to arrive soon but that will still leave a 1.4 million ton shortfall for predicted needs. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Florence: Search For Woman Resumes
description: Burlington County officials yesterday resumed their search of a Florence landfill for a missing Cinnaminson woman who they believe was killed, according to Robert D. Bernardi, the county prosecutor. The woman, Kimberly Szumski, missing since May 8, called the police to her house the night before to report a domestic dispute with her estranged husband, Thomas Szumski. He died of a heroin overdose on July 4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, LILA
description: BAUM-Lila, 73. Of Lake Worth, Florida, passed away on July 12, 2001. Mrs. Baum was born in Brooklyn, New York. She will be remembered as brilliant, funny, caring & the best wife and mother. Mrs. Baum is survived by her son Jonathan Baum of Lake Worth, Florida. She was predeceased by her husband of 50 years Jess Baum in August of 2000. The Funeral services will be private and are entrusted to Dorsey Funeral Home, 3525 S. Congress Ave, Lake Worth, Florida 33461.

title: Market Place; Nurse Shortage Puts a Premium on Staff Agencies
description: HOSPITALS across the country are struggling with an acute shortage of nurses, but the hospitals' problem is a big opportunity for a handful of nurse staffing companies.

title: Players Might Join Umpires In Dispute Over Pitch Count
description: Umpires may not be the only group that files a formal objection to the pitch-count practices of Major League Baseball. The players association is looking into the issue as well, the players' labor leader said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about potential deals involving the cable business of AT&T misstated the relationship of two top executives at AOL Time Warner, one of the companies with which AT&T is considering a deal. Gerald M. Levin, the company's chief executive, reports to the board, not to Stephen M. Case, the chairman.

title: Why the Other Guy Should Pay
description: Following is an excerpt from a response by the White House Office of Administration to an inquiry by the House Appropriations Committee on some proposed changes to how to pay the electric bills for the vice president's residence:

title: State School Chiefs Fret Over U.S. Plan To Require Testing
description: State education officials across the country complain that the imminent federal requirement for annual reading and math tests threatens to undermine the testing systems virtually every state has fashioned over the last decade.

title: Canadian Aluminum Producer's Earnings Take a Tumble
description: Alcan, an aluminum producer based in Montreal, reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were well below estimates.

title: How a Shooting Suspect Stayed Free: Odd Jobs and Dumb Luck
