description: For nearly 10 weeks on the run, Joseph Sean Salley kept a step ahead of one of New York City's biggest manhunts through a combination of odd jobs, scattered crimes and dumb luck, the authorities said.

title: No Yoga Studio Nearby? Your Chair Will Do
description: ''Seated Yoga,'' with Carol Dickman, Yoga Enterprises, $19.95 for VHS (43 minutes), (888) 937-9642 or www.stretch.com. ''Sitting Fit Anytime,'' with Susan Winter Ward, Yoga for the Young at Heart, $19.95 for VHS (43 minutes), (800) 558-9642 or www.yogaheart.com.

title: Drawn to Foreign War, 3 Brothers Find Death
description: They were like so many other young men in this beach town -- washing dishes in a local diner, dancing on summer nights in crowded clubs by the shore, shooting pool and talking about the future.

title: 4 Salt Lake City Charges Dismissed
description: A federal judge threw out 4 of 15 felony charges in the Salt Lake City Olympics bribery case yesterday and indefinitely postponed the July 30 trial of Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson, who were indicted last year in the vote-buying scandal that had threatened the future of the Olympic Games.

title: Lucent Seeks One.Tel Payment
description: Lucent Technologies says it is owed at least $488 million by the insolvent telecommunications company One.Tel, but Lucent is unlikely to collect even half the money, according to a report made public today.

title: Church Bombing Figure Found to Be Incompetent
description: An Alabama judge all but ended the prosecution of the 1963 Birmingham church bombing case today by ruling that the sole remaining defendant, Bobby Frank Cherry, was mentally incompetent to stand trial.

title: New Man at the Olympic Helm
description: At the International Olympic Committee meeting in Moscow yesterday, Dr. Jacques Rogge, a Belgian physician and Olympic sailor, was elected to serve an eight-year term as president. This was as important a decision, in its own way, as the granting of the 2008 Summer Olympics to Beijing on Friday. Dr. Rogge faces immense challenges in eliminating all remaining vestiges of corrupt practices within the I.O.C. and in ensuring that the Beijing Olympics lives up to the movement's professed ideals.

title: Compressed Data: A College Paper's Role in the Microsoft Appeal
description: The Financial Times. The New Yorker. The New York Times . The Washington Post . The Wall Street Journal.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Storm Kills Dozens
description: The worst storm to hit South Korea in 37 years left 40 people dead and 14 missing over the weekend, officials said. More than 34,000 people were left homeless in Seoul and the surrounding province, and 69,000 were sent to shelters. Nineteen of the victims were electrocuted when they touched light poles or wires that fell as they walked through flooded streets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VISCUSI, MILDRED
description: VISCUSI-Mildred. Eighth anniversary, July 23, 1993. Our thoughts are always with you and we miss you every day. Love, Fred, Laura, Stephen and Casey

title: VITAL SIGNS: NUTRITION; Choosing the Right Fat for Heart Health
description: A monthlong diet heavy in so-called trans fats had bad effects on two markers of cardiac health, a study from the Netherlands has found.

title: Ex-Alcoa Boss May Become A Man of Steel; Paul O'Neill Leads Effort For Bush Administration As It Weighs Trade Curbs
description: When Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill was chief executive of Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum company, a glut of aluminum had flooded the market and profits were falling. His solution? In 1994, he almost single-handedly persuaded the major aluminum-making nations to produce less. Aluminum prices rose and have remained high, and Mr. O'Neill is seen as the savior of that industry.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From veal piccata to visiting wineries in Australia, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Israeli Strike Kills 4 in Bethlehem
description: JERUSALEM, July 17 — The month-old cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians, more a concept than a reality from the start, seemed shakier than ever today with new violence that included the first Palestinian mortar attack against a Jewish neighborhood on Jerusalem's southern rim.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Jamaica: Inquiry Into Killings
description: Prime Minister P. J. Patterson announced that an inquiry would be held into the recent clashes between the police and gunmen that left more than 25 people, mostly civilians, dead in four days of violence in West Kingston. The police said they were only defending themselves after they were fired upon while sweeping through the community looking for guns; opponents of the government said the police had fired indiscriminately. ''Jamaica and the whole world must know exactly what happened,'' Mr. Patterson said in an address to the nation on Sunday night. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROHS, BELLE
description: GROHS-Belle. 89, of NYC, died July 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Arnold Grohs, devoted sister of the late Gertrude Busch and Lillian Blum, cherished aunt of Elizabeth Busch-Le Ne, Margaret Busch and Charles Busch and loving great-aunt of James Stull. A woman of great spirit, born in Cincinatti, OH, in 1911, she was a veteran of WWII and Korea. She was for many years dietitian and head of Home Economics for both Childrens Center and Jennings Hall for Boys. Her commitment to public service and volunteer work through her support of Roosevelt Hospital, and particularly their AIDS ward, made her a true role model for all senior citizens. Services Tuesday, July 17, at 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., with interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Volunteer Fund, care of Volunteer Department, 1000 10th Ave., NYC 10019 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWEN, ARTHUR S.
description: COWEN-Arthur S. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Riverdale, NY, died peacefully at home at the age of 93 on July 15th, 2001. Loving husband of the late Elsie Smerling Cowen and the late Pauline Boxer Cowen and brother of Fanny Spencer. Devoted father of Janice and Dr. Michael Tannenbaum, Philip and Gloria Perlo Cowen, Robert and Ann Cowen, Susan and Morris Klein and Lenore and Joel Martin. Proud grandfather of Dr. Darryl and Suzanne Tannenbaum, Jill Tannenbaum, Amy and Michael Denker, Dr. David Cowen, Andrew and Alison Cowen, Ellen Cowen, Elizabeth, Alexandra and Joanna Cowen, Mitchell Klein and Valerie Coffin, Melissa Klein, Dr. Michael Waxman, Marc Waxman and Gianna Cassetta and Nicole Martin. Dear great-grandfather of Nicholas and Brendan Tannenbaum and Jake Denker. Services Tuesday, July 17th, at 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about Microsoft's relaxing of some contract restrictions on personal computer makers incompletely described a federal appeals court ruling on June 28 about the company's bundling of its Internet browser with its Windows operating system. The court ruled that Microsoft had bundled the browsing software with Windows in a way that violated antitrust laws on two counts. But the court also said that bundling of software was not inherently illegal. It vacated that finding by a lower court and sent the issue back for reconsideration by a new judge.

title: Demanding a Vote on Reform
description: Campaign finance reform is a cause whose obituary gets written repeatedly by the experts in Washington. Opponents of the Shays-Meehan soft-money ban in the House were at it again over the weekend. They declared once more that there would not be a vote any time soon on reform because the House speaker, Dennis Hastert, was under no pressure to schedule one. But Mr. Hastert must know that in reneging last week on his promise to allow for a fair vote, and then pulling the bill from the House floor, he is further dramatizing the issue. Indeed, popular discontent is bound to accelerate as both Democrats and Republicans intensify their campaign fund-raising this summer.

title: Government Ends Homestore.com Inquiry
description: Homestore.com, which controls more than 90 percent of the home-sale listings on the Internet, said today that the Justice Department had ended an investigation into the company and that no enforcement action would be taken.

title: India and Pakistan End Talks Over Kashmir in Bitterness
description: The leaders of India and Pakistan, nuclear-armed adversaries, abruptly broke off two days of marathon negotiations on Monday night. They failed to make any substantive progress on their intractable conflict over Kashmir, a land claimed by both nations, or on reducing the risks of a nuclear exchange.

title: Woman Found Slain in Brooklyn Apartment
description: Investigators want to question former boyfriends of a 32-year-old Brooklyn woman who was found stabbed to death Sunday night in the bedroom of her condominium in Bath Beach, the police said yesterday. They also want to speak to a man the woman may have gone out with Saturday night, the police added.

title: Upon Closer Inspection, Icons of Science Show Their Age; Evolution
description: Parts per million.

title: For G.I.'s, a Balkan Road of Neither War Nor Peace
description: When a column of American soldiers found their way blocked by a Macedonian mob last month, Col. Anthony J. Tata initially thought that it was too risky to turn back.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Marine Motion Detectors

title: E.P.A. Delays Further Rules Of Clinton Era
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it intended to wait until at least 2003 before requiring states to adopt strict new water-pollution guidelines that were to have taken effect last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGREEN, MORRIS H.
description: BERGREEN-Morris H. The President, Board of Governors, Fellows and staff of the Oxford Centre for Hebrew and Jewish Studies, Oxford, England, as well as the American Friends of the Centre, are profoundly saddened by the death of their colleague, supporter and friend, Morris H. Bergreen. As President of the Skirball Foundation he made an enormous contribution to the academic development and international reach of the Oxford Centre, strengthening in particular its graduate student and research links with the United States. His wise counsel and unwavering commitment to scholarly excellence will be immeasurably missed. We send our deep sympathy to his wife Adele and to all his family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New City: Vote On Detectors
description: The Rockland County Legislature is scheduled to vote today on a bill that would require apartments, hotels, college dormitories and other residential housing to be equipped with carbon monoxide detectors. New construction would need the detectors by Jan. 1, and existing structures by April 1. The measure was set aside last September because of concerns that the detectors would lead to an increase in false alarms. The bill would require the police to respond to each alarm. The measure was reintroduced after eight Rockland County residents were hospitalized in December because of a carbon monoxide leak. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Ad Federation Plans Multiculturalism Center
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington, in another effort to encourage more multicultural initiatives in advertising and marketing, will announce plans tomorrow that are to include the formation of a Center on Multiculturalism.

title: Shinjo Is Up, And Perez Is Down
description: The Mets made an anticipated decision in activating outfielder Tsuyoshi Shinjo from the disabled list yesterday. But they also made a surprising move, optioning outfielder Timo Perez to Class AAA Norfolk. Perez was an offensive force late last season and in the first two rounds of the postseason, but, for now, he has become expendable.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Corel To Acquire Micrografx
description: The Corel Corporation, the Canadian software company that owns WordPerfect, has agreed to acquire the graphics software maker Micrografx Inc. for about $32 million of stock, the companies said. The deal is subject to approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission and from Micrografx shareholders. Corel officials said the merger was an ''important milestone'' in the company's long-term growth and profitability. The company said it was seeking to strengthen its position in the graphics market, develop new Web-based products and move into emerging markets like wireless and Internet services. ''This is clearly a strategic opportunity for both Corel and Micrografx,'' said Derek Burney, chief executive of Corel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEON, DANIEL MANNING
description: McKEON-Daniel Manning. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers notes with deep regret the passing of Daniel Manning McKeon who faithfully served on the Board over 50 years. Mr. McKeon was Secretary of the Board of Managers and served on the Executive, Finance and Buildings & Grounds Committees. His expertise in finance and advocacy of the youth in Lincoln Hall's care made him an invaluable asset to the agency. The Board and staff extend sincere condolences to Mr. McKeon's family on their loss. James G. Nugent, President Douglas W. Wyatt, Vice President & Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sharpton To Sue Navy
description: Lawyers for the Rev. Al Sharpton announced yesterday that he planned a $1 million lawsuit against the United States Navy for the ''physical and psychological injuries'' suffered during his arrest on May 1 while protesting the naval bombing of the Puerto Rican island of Vieques. Mr. Sharpton, who has served nearly two-thirds of his 90-day prison sentence for trespassing, contends that he was strip-searched, forced to sit in mud and made to lie on a wet floor handcuffed. Cmdr. Greg Smith, a spokesman for the Navy, said there were no irregularities in Mr. Sharpton's arrest.

title: Andrew Gibson, 79, an Official In the Nixon Commerce Dept.
description: Andrew E. Gibson, a shipping executive who was an assistant secretary of commerce in the Nixon administration, died on July 8 at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 79.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENTS; A Closer Look at Medical Marijuana
description: Two studies of the accumulated data on marijuana's medical value have found mixed results: the drug had some advantages over standard treatments for severe nausea, but no advantage in reducing severe pain. Both papers were published this month in The British Medical Journal.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Less Crime For 6th Straight Year
description: Crime levels fell last year for the sixth year in a row, according to figures released by the state police. The number of reported crimes dropped 2.7 percent last year, and 19.7 percent since 1990. The statistics come from about 900 police agencies. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: A Matter of Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Multiple Partners May Imperil Prostate
description: The more women a man has sex with, the higher his risk of developing prostate cancer in middle age, a new study reported in The American Journal of Epidemiology suggests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANSFIELD, SUSAN P.
description: STANSFIELD-Susan P. Widow of Dr. John B. Stansfield, on July 12. Beloved mother of Lindsey Stansfield Pryor and the late John Bradley Stansfield, Jr. Cherished grandmother of Christina, Antonia, Sam and Jack Pryor. She will be remembered by her family and friends for her warmth, enthusiasm and kindness. A memorial mass will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, 184 East 76th Street, New York 10021, would be appreciated.

title: Great American Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News; Experienced Helmsman -- Jacques Rogge
description: It seems fitting that Jacques Rogge was elected president of the International Olympic Committee today in the same city where he had taken the most important stand of his own sporting career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUELLER, REVEREND ANTHONY E.
description: MUELLER-Reverend Anthony E. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the Parochial Vicar of St. Thomas-More-St. Edmund Church, Rockaway Point, on July 14. Reposing at Queen of Peace Residence, 110-30 221 St, Queens Village, Tuesday, July 17 from 2 to 9PM. Vigil Service at Our Lady Queen of Peace, Tuesday, July 17 at 7:30PM. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, July 18 at 10:30AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the spread of the West Nile virus to Florida omitted one state from a listing of those affected by the virus last year and included another in error. Vermont was affected; South Carolina was not. The article also misstated the given name of the coordinator for the virus at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. He is Dr. Stephen Ostroff, not David.

title: The Big City; $25,000? I'm Leaving Today
description: THE modest proposal in last week's column for easing New York's housing crisis -- use a computerized system like Priceline.com to arrange buyouts of rent-regulated tenants -- provoked a deluge of mail, mostly enthusiastic. ''I would leave in a New York minute if offered a buyout,'' wrote one of the many tenants willing to leave town for the right price. Landlords rhapsodized about getting rid of rich tenants paying low rents. A developer in the Poconos wrote to tell New Yorkers that a $25,000 buyout would make a fine down payment on one of his spacious homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKWELL, ALAN WESSON
description: ROCKWELL-Alan Wesson. At the age of 82 Alan passed away due to heart complications on Thursday, July 12, 2001 in Marin General Hospital. He graduated from the St. Mark's School in 1936 and later from Harvard College in 1940. During World War II Alan served as a Lieutenant in both the Atlantic and Pacific theatres, receiving a Silver Star medal for his heroism during a Japanese Kamikaze attack. After a career in marketing and advertising, including Benton and Bowles in New York, he relocated to Tiburon, Calif. He is survived by his two brothers, David and Stuart.

title: Compaq to Place More Emphasis on Computer Services
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation will announce a change today in the way it sells its products to large corporations, emphasizing the company's increasing reliance on its services division to improve profits.

title: Lifelong Mating Rituals
description: To the Editor:

title: An Enriching Change for Infant Formulas
description: By early next year, infant formulas sold in this country may have had an important change in their ingredients. The Food and Drug Administration has just approved the addition of two fatty acids that can enhance the neurological and visual development of children who are not breast-fed.

title: Lawyer Joins First Boston as Vice Chairman
description: Speculation abounded last week on Wall Street about which former colleagues John J. Mack would lure from his former employer, Morgan Stanley, to his new firm, Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: For Some, Insulin Without Needles
description: Kathleen DeSormier, a 39-year-old woman from Tiverton, R.I., has had diabetes since she was 22, and for many years she needed three shots of insulin a day to control her blood sugar. Although she got used to the injections, the routine was still tiresome.

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hoboken Water Deal
description: United Water Resources in Harrington Park, N.J., said yesterday that it would pay Hoboken $2.7 million and invest $3.8 million in metering and infrastructure improvements to operate the city's water supply system for 10 more years. The company said rates would not change.

title: The Many Veils of Meaning Left by Leonardo
description: Aparody of Leonardo's "Last Supper" shows Jesus delivering this message to his astonished disciples: "Separate checks." Heretical, yes. But the cartoon parody shares something with what most interpreters, particularly modern interpreters, have seen in the "Last Supper": a single emotional moment, a frozen picture of expressions and gestures, a narrative full of clear meaning.

title: 'Sopranos' Creator Expected To Remain for a Fifth Season
description: David Chase, the creator and executive producer of ''The Sopranos,'' the hit HBO program that spawned both critical acclaim for quality writing and acting and heated criticism for excessive violence, has agreed to extend his contract to produce the show by an additional year.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday about trade sanctions incorrectly identified the Congressional committee that will take up the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act tomorrow. It is the Senate Banking Committee, not the House Financial Services Committee.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK MINEOLA: CANDIDATE RAISES $1.7 MILLION Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove, a Democratic candidate for Nassau county executive, has raised $1.7 million for his campaign, about 50 percent more than his opponent in the primary, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli. In submissions to the County Board of Elections, Mr. Suozzi also disclosed that he had spent about $500,000. Mr. Suozzi faces a September primary against Mr. DiNapoli, who won the Democratic Party's backing and who has raised about $1.1 million, about $400,000 of which has been spent. The Democratic victor will face the sole Republican candidate, Bruce R. Bent, a multimillionaire financier who said he had donated $100,000 to his campaign, $60,000 of which has been spent.   Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Lifelong Mating Rituals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBB EVAN
description: SMITH-Robb Evan. Of Washington, DC, on July 12th, 2001. Beloved husband of Joan Kerrigan, father of Evan Smith and Brooke Smith of Washington, DC, brother of Dan Franklin Smith of NYC. Services will be held Wednesday, July 18, at 12:30 PM, in Washington at the Shrine of the Blessed Sacrament, Western Avenue at Quesada St., N.W. Memorial contributions may be made to the School of Advanced International Studies, Johns Hopkins University, Washington, D.C.

title: A Panel Backed by Bush Urges Higher Fuel Efficiency for Cars
description: A federal panel that President Bush has said will help him decide whether and how much to increase fuel economy standards has recommended in a draft report that the government require automakers to improve the mileage of new vehicles.

title: Moderate Democrats Seek Unity and a Leader
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, was so eager to appeal to moderate Democrats meeting here today that he made special mention of his role in persuading Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont to defect from the Republican Party, a move that shifted control of the Senate to the Democrats.

title: Foreign Affairs; Don't Look Back
description: Nearly six years ago I attended the Arab-Israeli economic summit in Jordan. (Remember? They used to do that.) I was seated in the press gallery just above the Israeli delegation, and as I looked down I saw a Kuwaiti businessman, in traditional Arab kaffiyeh headdress, mistakenly take a seat in the Israeli row, next to an Israeli delegate wearing a yarmulke. So as I looked down I saw this kaffiyeh next to this yarmulke. Nice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLED, HARRY
description: SOLED-Harry. Of Wellington, Fla. Passed away July 16, 2001. Loving husband of Risa. Adored father of Teri Soled-Harper and Martin Soled. Cherished grandfather of Marla. Beloved brother of Alex Soled. Mr. Soled was an architect and past president of A.I.A. Brooklyn chapter. Interment services Tuesday 1:30PM July 17, 2001 at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I. For further information contact Gutterman's Rockville Centre, L.I. 516-764-9400.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Redistricting Panel Names Chief
description: The commission that will redraw the state's Congressional districts unanimously picked Alan Rosenthal, a professor of public policy and political science at Rutgers University, as its chairman and 13th member. Mr. Rosenthal will serve as a tie-breaker if the commission's six Democrats and six Republicans are deadlocked on a new map. Mr. Rosenthal, who has written extensively on state legislatures around the country, served on the earlier commission that created today's districts. Panel officials said they would study a redistricting map the state's Congressional delegation has unanimously approved.

title: Art Dealer Faces Charges In Trading Of Antiquities
description: An influential East Side art dealer was indicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan on charges that he conspired to receive and possess ancient artworks that had been stolen and illegally removed from Egypt.

title: Power, Once a Sure Bet, Losing Sight of Playoffs
description: After losing only once in its first 12 games, the Power has not won in three weeks in the Women's United Soccer Association. With six games left on its regular-season schedule, the Power is in danger of missing the playoffs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Patent Appeal
description: The Swiss digital televi sion technology group, Kudelski, said that it would appeal a Delaware court ruling requiring it to pay $15 million to IPPV Enterprises for violating its patent rights. The court said Nagravision, a Kudelski unit, and NagraStar, its joint venture with EchoStar Communications, had infringed a patent owned by IPPV. Kudelski, based in Lausanne, one of the largest suppliers of pay-television systems, said the patent was to expire in a few months, and that it had avoided using technology that would have infringed IPPV's patent. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Upon Closer Inspection, Icons of Science Show Their Age; Atoms
description: Parts per million.

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Upon Closer Inspection, Icons of Science Show Their Age; Neanderthals
description: Parts per million.

title: Ashcroft Says F.B.I.'s Failings Have Led Public to Lose Trust
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today in a speech at F.B.I. headquarters that public trust in the agency had been eroded by recent humiliations, among them a case in which an agent pleaded guilty to spying for Russia and another in which the bureau failed to turn over thousands of pages of investigative reports to defense lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case.

title: New Heart at Work: An X-Ray View
description: Doctors yesterday released an x-ray of the first recipient of the first self-contained artificial heart. They said the patient had shown signs of improvement. Page A12.

title: Bush Calls for World Bank to Increase Grants
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Calling for "compassionate conservatism at an international level," President Bush urged the World Bank and other development banks today to significantly increase their grants of money, as opposed to loans, to poor nations.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Most Wanted'' chart in Business Day yesterday mislabeled the data for magazines, ranked by advertising revenue. The data were from June 2001, not May 2001.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Seeking Ethics Inquiry Over Vote
description: Representative Peter Deutsch, Democrat of Florida, filed an ethics complaint asking for a House investigation into whether Representative Steve Buyer, Republican of Indiana, used government resources to help George W. Bush in the presidential race in Florida. Mr. Deutsch submitted the complaint after The New York Times reported that Mr. Buyer, then a member of the House Armed Services Committee, asked the Pentagon in November for telephone numbers and e-mail addresses of military personnel, including some whose absentee ballots had been disqualified in Florida. Alison Mitchell (NYT)

title: 2 Energy Giants Shuffle Stakes in Europe's Markets
description: In a further sign of how Europe's energy companies are trying to carve up territories among themselves, E.ON of Germany announced a $5.6 billion deal to trade its oil and gasoline business for BP of Britain's stake in Ruhrgas, a big German natural gas distributor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK GRIFFITH, DOROTHY
description: WEINSTOCK GRIFFITH-Dorothy. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the mother of its esteemed member, Mrs. Marcia Reiter and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: Even Trachsel Helps to Spur Awakening
description: The Mets want to believe that the rest of their trying season can still be meaningful. They despise the notion that they could be finished in July. They know it is useless to speculate about what could happen because they have so much to accomplish before they can even claim to be a respectable team.

title: Family Blames Tax Inquiry for Her Death : News Executive's Wife Killed in Fall in Seoul
description: SEOUL  The wife of the top executive of one of South Korea's leading newspapers, who died in a fall from her sister's 13th-floor apartment on Sunday, was portrayed by her family on Monday as a victim of a government tax investigation.

title: Tunnel Vision; Getting Rubbed, or Maybe Tickled, All for the Price of a Token
description: If you keep an eye on other subways around the world, you'll detect what could be a strange new trend in public transit.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Negotiating Gas Tax And Farm Aid
description: The Legislature convened for its third special session, then promptly recessed to allow Gov. Gary Locke and legislative leaders to discuss a transportation package and relief for farmers hurt by recent storms. The meetings are expected to take at least two days, with separate votes in the House and Senate concluded within the week. The Democratic governor and Republican negotiators are deciding on the size of a gasoline tax and revenue sources. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEENSTOCK, GLADYS LAMPERT
description: BEENSTOCK-Gladys Lampert. On July 15th, 2001, in Rye, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Barbara Mann and Edward Beenstock Jr. Cherished grandmother of John and Anthony Mann, Margaret Mann Berenblum, Jeffrey and Steven Beenstock. Loving great-grandmother of Joshua, Arielle, Rachel, Alexandra, Isabelle, and Strauss Mann, Samantha and Julie Berenblum & Samuel Beenstock. Special aunt of Ellin Rosenzweig. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Gladys Lampert '28 and Edward Beenstock Fund, C/O Advancement Office, Smith College, Northampton, MA. 01063.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Dim Outlook By Central Bank
description: The Bank of Japan lowered its assessment of the country's economy yesterday, raising speculation that the central bank may be forced to further ease monetary policy, which it decided to hold steady last week. The central bank issued its view of the economy for July and said that economic adjustments -- considered a euphemism for slowdown -- were intensifying, ''amid sharply falling production due mainly to a slowdown in exports.'' The bank also said that capital spending was decreasing and corporate earnings were deteriorating, especially in manufacturing. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Officials Are Still Wary About West Nile Virus
description: Lucy York recently saw a few dead crows around her home in Piscataway, N.J., she said, but she did not think much of it.

title: Lifelong Mating Rituals
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith's Name Has Not Caught Up to Her Game
description: Katie Smith leads the Women's National Basketball Association in scoring and is an accomplished defender. She is also the Western Conference's leading 3-point and free-throw shooter. Yet Smith did not start for the West, which won tonight's W.N.B.A. All-Star Game by 80-72 over the East at the TD Waterhouse Center.

title: Patterns: Multiple Partners May Imperil Prostate
description: The more women a man has sex with, the higher his risk of prostate cancer, a new study reported in the American Journal of Epidemiology suggests.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Live by the Pen, Die by the Sword
description: At the height of the Maya civilization, the only literate society in pre-Columbian America, kings fervently, perhaps desperately, believed in the power of the pen. Whether they thought it mightier than the sword is doubtful, but a growing body of evidence from Maya writing and art shows that scribes played a central role in magnifying their king's reputation and solidifying his political hold on the realm.

title: Patients Define M.S. in Their Own Words
description: ''When the Road Turns: Inspirational Stories About People With MS,'' by Margot Russell. Health Communications Inc. $12.95.

title: Nutrition: Choosing the Right Fat for Heart Health
description: Amonthlong diet heavy in so-called trans fats had bad effects on two markers of cardiac health, a study from the Netherlands has found.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 2 Israeli Soldiers; 3rd Is Badly Wounded
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up near a train station in the northern Israeli town of Binyamina today, killing two soldiers, critically wounding a third, and injuring several other people.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Ex-Lawmaker Planning Return
description: A year after he became the only House Republican incumbent to lose a primary, Merrill Cook is considering another run in 2002. Questions over his temper and treatment of his staff led Second District Republicans to choose another candidate to oppose Jim Matheson, the Democrat who won the general election. Mr. Cook, who served two terms, said a recent visit with Republican leaders in Washington convinced him he could regain his seat, an assertion disputed by Winston Wilkinson, a Republican on the Salt Lake County Council who intends to run himself. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Court Urged To Hear Skakel Case
description: Prosecutors and the defense lawyer for Michael C. Skakel, who is accused of killing Martha Moxley in 1975, have asked the State Supreme Court to hasten Mr. Skakel's appeal of a juvenile court judge's decision that transferred his case to adult court. Mr. Skakel, 40, was initially charged as a juvenile because he was 15 at the time of Miss Moxley's death. The Supreme Court, the state's highest court, can agree to consider appeals directly, skipping over lower courts and thus speeding cases likely to be appealed to the court anyway.

title: A Floridian, Not a New Yorker, Will Be the Ambassador to Rome
description: President Bush has decided to appoint a Florida developer and major Republican Party fund-raiser as ambassador to Italy, New York State and Republican officials said yesterday. It was a rebuff to Gov. George E. Pataki and Italian-Americans who had pushed for Mr. Pataki's economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DOROTHY M.
description: COLLINS-Dorothy M. Of Staten Island, on July 15, 2001. Beloved wife of the late John. Loving mother of John P. Collins Esq. of Manhattan. Dear sister of Joan Mulligan. Reposing Harmon Funeral Home, 571 Forest Ave., Staten Island, NY Tuesday 2-4 & 79 PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Peter's Church Wednesday 10 AM. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Grievance to Be Filed On Behalf of Morales
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association is most likely to file a grievance on behalf of Andy Morales, after the Yankees' efforts to void his contract because of alleged age discrepancies.

title: TURBODYNE REPLACES ITS BOARD WITH 3 GERMAN INVESTORS
description: A developer of auto engine systems, Turbodyne Technologies, said yesterday that its 11-member board had resigned and was replaced by three German investors as the company tried to turn around its business. The new board consists of Dieter Neujeffski, Lars Neujeffski and Albert Wierz. Turbodyne also said it was choosing a new chief executive and chief financial officer. The company, based in Carpinteria, Calif., has been pressured by Honeywell International over a 1999 agreement to develop an electronic system that improves the performance of engine turbochargers. Turbodyne said Honeywell recently began an arbitration process to end the agreement because of Turbodyne's financial, management and operating problems.

title: Local School Districts Hindered by Budget Delays
description: Pressure to resolve the budget standoff heated up today, as attention from local and state officials homed in on the main sticking point in talks: money for education.

title: Germany Urges the Czechs To Close a Nuclear Plant
description: The German government confirmed today that it has called on its neighbor, the Czech Republic, to shut a nuclear power plant near the German and Austrian borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UBALDI, JACK
description: UBALDI-Jack. The many students, customers, readers and friends of Jack Ubaldi mourn his death on Saturday, July 14, at the age of 90. He loved people, food, and cooking, and whether in his store, the Florence Meat Market on Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village, or in his classrooms at the New School, The New York Restaturant School, and Peter Kump's Cooking Schol, he endeared himself to all who came in touch with him. His many students remember that every class ended with a meal, usually with a glass of wine, and always with a sense of warm fellowship. He was a true New Yorker, born in Italy, but loving this city, and he spent his working life and an active retirement as a vital part of it. Elizabeth Crossman Carol Durst

title: Building Worker Survives Plunge
description: A 21-year-old construction worker lost his footing while working on a building ledge in Chinatown yesterday afternoon and survived after plunging 10 stories, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRITZER, ARTHUR ROY
description: KRITZER-Arthur Roy. Died after a brief illness at Peninsula General Hospital. He was 47 years old. He resided at Surfside Manor in Rockaway Park. The funeral was on July 15th, 2001 at Beth David Cemetery. His family and all his friends will miss him.

title: In an economic slowdown, a new push for accountability among account planners.
description: AGENCY employees who are responsible for gaining insights into the behavior of consumers -- the better to sell them stuff, natch -- are seeking to become more accountable as the continuing sluggishness of the economy leads clients to demand more efficient and effective advertising.

title: Judge Demands Resolution to Talks in Turnpike Shooting Case
description: A New Jersey judge expressed impatience today with the pace of plea-bargain talks in the case of two state troopers charged in the 1998 shooting that thrust the state into a tumultuous three-year debate over racial profiling.

title: Richards Group Leader Shares Some Power
description: Stan Richards, president and creative director at the Richards Group in Dallas -- one of the last large independent agencies -- said yesterday that he would address succession issues by forming a creative leadership council whose members would share what has been his sole authority over creative development and operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RENEE
description: BERGER-Renee. On July 15. Beloved wife of 43 years of Jack H. Adored friend and godmother, kind and beneficient patron of civic and educational causes of New York City. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. on July 17th at 1:30 PM. Private burial. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Mrs. Berger's name to the League of Women Voters of the City of New York, 45 East 33rd St., Room 309, NY, NY 10016, telephone 212677-5050, fax 212-725-3443.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Closing the Rich-Poor Gap
description: Getting more cellular phones into the hands of the developing world's poverty-stricken populations may not top the agenda of the Group of Eight meeting in Genoa, Italy later this week. But the G-8 leaders are expected to endorse broad goals aimed at closing the technology gap between rich and poor countries. And a report released yesterday by a group called the Digital Opportunity Initiative proposes specific strategies for raising the living standards in poor countries by building wireless communications networks and training workers to use the Internet. The report, to be presented to the G-8 leaders at the summit, was financed by the nonprofit Markle Foundation, the management consulting firm Accenture and the United Nations. Amy Harmon(NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWLETT, SELINA RICHARDS WOOD GREW
description: HEWLETT-Selina Richards Wood Grew. Of Old Lyme, CT, on July 15, 2001, in her 91st year. Widow of Henry Sturgis Grew, Jr. and Roger Sanderson Hewlett. Survived by her daughters Selina G. (Mrs. W. Allen) Rossiter of Lincoln, MA; three sons, Henry S. Grew of Newport, RI; Rt. Rev. J. Clark Grew, II of Cleveland, OH; Dr. Robert S. Grew of Raleigh, NC; step daughter Sandra H. (Mrs. Robert) Johnson of Burlingame, CA; step son Peter S. Hewlett of Sebastopol, CA; 13 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 21, 2001, at 11:30 AM, in St. Ann's Episcopal Church, 82 Shore Road (Rte. 156) Old Lyme, CT 06371. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in her memory to St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL MEDICO, BILLYE WATERSTONE (NEE STRAUSBERG)
description: DEL MEDICO-Billye Waterstone (nee Strausberg). Devoted mother of Stephen Waterstone and Sharon K. Lieblich. Cherished motherin-law of Phyllis Waterstone and Robert Lieblich. Dear sister of Rosa Pieofsky. Loving grandmother of Benjamin Lieblich, Rebecca Lieblich, Roberta Waterstone-Albert and Melissa Waterstone, M.D. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon, ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St, Hackensack, N.J.

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: All Languages, All the Time, And All Over the Suburban Dial
description: At daybreak in central New Jersey, Indian professionals wake up to live Hindi prayers on the radio. At midday on Long Island, lonely Chinese immigrants confide in the host of a popular radio program called ''Happy Family.'' At dusk in the Hudson Valley, Polish-Americans absorb the latest news from Warsaw on Rockland County's only talk-radio station, which is all Polish, all the time.

title: VITAL SIGNS: REACTIONS; Some Brains Act Faster to Attack Pain
description: The reason some people seem to feel pain less than others may be that their brains counteract it more aggressively, according to a study that involved putting volunteers in a brain-scanning machine and making their jaws ache.

title: Sports of The Times; New Leader Represents Old Order
description: IT'S good for Athens -- and, in reverse, it's good for New York and every other United States city flirting with the financial burden of holding the 2012 Summer Games.

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning To Treat, Not Judge
description: Physicians, like most human beings, often judge people based on fleeting or even mistaken impressions. But in medical practice this habit can have decidedly negative effects on diagnosis and treatment.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Fire Destroys Abortion Clinic
description: An early morning fire destroyed Baton Rouge's only abortion clinic on Sunday. Law enforcement officials have not commented on a possible cause. No one was injured, but the fire destroyed most of the building housing the Delta Women's Clinic. In 1987, four men were convicted on federal charges in connection with the firebombing of the same clinic. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Reactions: Some Brains Act Faster to Attack Pain
description: The reason some people seem to feel pain less may be that their brains respond to counteract it more aggressively, according to a study that involved putting volunteers in a brain-scanning machine and making their jaws ache.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, SHIRLEY
description: LEVIN-Shirley. On July 16, 2001. Dear sister of Ralph and Douglas, and sisters-in-law Diane and Elaine. Also survived by her nieces, nephews, great nieces and great nephews. Services, officiated by her nephew Rabbi Harry Levin, will be Wednesday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Doctors Say Artificial-Heart Patient Is Improving
description: The unidentified man who became the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart two weeks ago has a positive mental outlook and has shown some signs of improvement, his surgeons said here today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS 5.6%. Natural gas declined on expectations that mild weather will curb demand. The August contract fell 18.2 cents, to $3.068 for a million B.T.U.'s on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARBISH, RITA
description: FARBISH-Rita. 1926-1995. Never forgotten, always missed. Your husband, Alfred.

title: A Marker for Mad Cow Disease May Be Found in Urine
description: In a discovery that is capturing the attention of experts on mad cow disease, an Israeli scientist has reported finding a unique substance in the urine of people and animals afflicted with various forms of the malady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHENGORN, RALINE BERGER
description: GERSHENGORN-Raline Berger July 14, 2001. Dear beloved mother of devoted and kind daughter Linda Grayson. Sister to the late Howard C. Berger, M.D. Also survived by her son Cary Skolnick, M.D.

title: Invercreran Journal; Fish Farms Spawn Trouble for Salmon Anglers
description: In the home of the Scottish salmon a source of delights from the lox on the bagel to the saumon in the crote -- is the king of fish in jeopardy? Surveying his ancestral lands below the Grampian Mountains, David Stewart thinks it most certainly is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMER, YVONNE
description: SOMMER-Yvonne. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of our devoted member, Yvonne Sommer. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her beloved children Philippe and Carolyn Sommer, Francine Sommer, grandchildren Daniel, Alexander and Eric, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODGES, SHIRLEY
description: HODGES-Shirley. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our devoted member Diane Hodges. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: A Vision of Choreography That Includes a Wheelchair
description: Disabled dancers and dancers without disabilities gathered together onstage when the Infinity Dance Theater performed on Friday night at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Candidate Raises $1.7 Million
description: Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove, a Democratic candidate for Nassau county executive, has raised $1.7 million for his campaign, about 50 percent more than his opponent in the primary, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli. In submissions to the County Board of Elections, Mr. Suozzi also disclosed that he had spent about $500,000. Mr. Suozzi faces a September primary against Mr. DiNapoli, who won the Democratic Party's backing and who has raised about $1.1 million, about $400,000 of which has been spent. The Democratic victor will face the sole Republican candidate, Bruce R. Bent, a multimillionaire financier who said he had donated $100,000 to his campaign, $60,000 of which has been spent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IRENE
description: COHEN-Irene. We regret to inform you of the passing of a beloved member of our temple family, Irene Cohen, on July 15. Our deepest condolences to her daughters Barbara and Lynne. May God comfort all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Leonard B. Austin, President

title: NASD Fines 10 Companies For Violations
description: The brokerage units of Deutsche Bank, Merrill Lynch and the Goldman Sachs Group were among 10 firms settling regulators' charges that they violated a market rule that is supposed to provide an orderly start to trading of shares in initial public offerings, regulators said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Hospital Fined In Surgery Case
description: The State Health Department has levied a $32,000 fine against Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens, for failing to prevent two urologists from using what state investigators called ''assembly-line techniques to mass-produce surgery.'' The hospital did not return calls seeking comment. The urologists planned and performed prostate surgeries on men who lived at a residence for the mentally ill called the Leben Home for Adults. The department earlier punished the doctors for operating on 24 residents of the home. The department said there was a ''lack of valid evidence to suggest that any of the patients were in need of the surgeries performed.''

title: SPECIALTY PAPER MAKER TO QUIT PART OF BRAZIL BUSINESS
description: A maker of specialty papers, Schweitzer-Mauduit International, is leaving the uncoated-papers business in Brazil because of poor market conditions. Schweitzer-Mauduit said a slowdown in the Brazilian printing and writing papers market and a recently started electricity rationing program had hurt sales and forced a scaling back of production. The company, based in Alpharetta, Ga., which had annual revenue of $497 million last year, said the business is its least profitable line in Brazil yet its biggest user of electricity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADEL, ELLYN
description: RADEL-Ellyn. July 15, 2001. Family and friends mourn the sudden and untimely death of Ellyn, daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. Phillip Goldsmith. She was a loving mother to Deborah and Liane, a caring sister to Lynda and a devoted friend to many. Ellyn was a person of courage and family values. She will be dearly missed. Services 11 AM Tuesday, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST WASHINGTON: NEGOTIATING GAS TAX AND FARM AID The Legislature convened for its third special session, then promptly recessed to allow Gov. Gary Locke and legislative leaders to discuss a transportation package and relief for farmers hurt by recent storms. The meetings are expected to take at least two days, with separate votes in the House and Senate concluded within the week. The Democratic governor and Republican negotiators are deciding on the size of a gasoline tax and revenue sources.    Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Compensation Deadline Extended
description: Parliament has extended the deadline for Nazi-era slave laborers to apply for compensation from a $4.4 billion fund set up by the government and industry. The extension, from Aug. 11 to the end of the year, was requested by victims' organizations. Up to 1.5 million surviving laborers, most in Central and Eastern Europe, are expected to be eligible; more than a million have filed claims for payments up to $6,550 each. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Rodney Kirk, 67, Director Of Manhattan Plaza, Is Dead
description: The Rev. Rodney Kirk, an Episcopal priest who became a guiding spirit behind Manhattan Plaza, the Midtown Manhattan housing complex for artists and writers, which he directed for many years, died Thursday at his home in St. Croix, V.I. He was 67 and had moved to St. Croix after retiring four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRELL, ALAN S.
description: PRELL-Alan S. Age 73, of Wyckoff, NJ, and Boynton Beach, FL. A retired Paper Merchant. Predeceased by his granddaughter, Robyn Prell. Survived by his wife of forty-five years, Nicky; son, Michael & Andrea; daughters, Cyndee and Andrew, and Genie and Andrew; grandchildren, Scott, Josh, Brittany, Sara, Jake, Rebecca, Brandi and Spencer; sisters, Shirley and Eleanor. Services are today, 12 Noon, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: 2 Large Banks Beat Estimates For Earnings; Another Slips
description: Lower interest rates bolstered second-quarter results at Citigroup and Bank of America even as their businesses showed some weakness from the softer economy. But Bank of New York, which has comparatively little exposure to lending, surprised investors with lower-than-expected earnings.

title: 3 Soldiers Are Punished For Abuses In Chechnya
description: The Russian Army commander for Chechnya relieved a deputy of his duties today and suspended two others in the wake of ''mopping up'' operations in two Chechen villages west of Grozny, the capital. Soldiers were accused of widespread looting, beating and administering electric shocks during interrogations of villagers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTWIN, RUTH W.
description: LITTWIN-Ruth W. Of Teaneck, NJ on July 14, 2001. Wife of the late Charles Littwin, MD. Stepmother of C. Stuart Littwin, MD. Grandmother of Carolyn, Charles, Daniel and K. Deborah. Great-grandmother of Rachel and Jack.

title: From N.B.A. Courts to the Halls of Politics; A Life That Started in Caribbean Poverty Turns Toward Albany Lobbying
description: In 1990, Adonal Foyle saw his future and dreaded it. With an eighth-grade education, living on a tiny Caribbean island that had neither electricity nor running water, his likeliest fate was to become a fisherman.

title: Ready for Double Trouble In the Big City of Galway
description: JUNO & JULIET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEAVEY, ESSIE, MATRIARCH
description: SEAVEY-Essie, Matriarch. July 12, 1905-July 14, 2001. Mourned by her devoted sons Robert and Gilbert, her daughters-in-law, grandchildren, great - grandchildren, nieces and nephews and extended family. Intelligent, warm and witty, Essie enjoyed a rich life, a happy marriage, many close friends and a large, loving family. Proud of her family's accomplishments, she contributed her unfailing love and support as she urged all to their goals. We will all deeply miss Grandma Essie and will strive to emulate her long and wonderful life. Her family

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: China's Entry Into W.T.O.
description: Fresh from winning its bid for the 2008 Olympics, China began final talks yesterday in Geneva on its membership in the World Trade Organization. ''There aren't many issues left,'' China's chief negotiator, Long Yongtu, told The Associated Press. Talks to iron out the remaining issues, most of them technical, before China can be admitted to the trade group are expected to last a week. Among the issues is whether overseas companies already operating in China will be treated as new businesses requiring 50 percent Chinese ownership. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Fighting For The Forest
description: Hoping to preserve the largest privately held swath of land in New Hampshire, a national conservation group is working on a deal to buy 171,000 acres of forest from the International Paper Company. While the group, the Trust for Public Land, intends to resell the property, taking it off the market will allow time to raise money to buy easements, which would limit development. Some estimate the land is worth $40 million. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS FORD OFFERS PHONE SYSTEM The Ford Motor Company ( news/quote ), the No. 2 automaker, will begin offering a hands-free, voice-activated system in some vehicles this year to enable drivers to use cellular phones more safely. Cellport Systems Inc. of Boulder, Colo., will supply the system, the Cellport 3000 with Voice Command, under a $48 million contract, said Ralph Poplansky, Cellport's vice president of product development. Last month, New York became the first state to ban the use of cell phones by drivers unless they use headsets or hands-free devices such as Cellport's. The Cellport 3000 will first be sold as a dealer- installed option on Taurus sedans and Windstar minivans and will be offered in most Ford vehicles by mid-2002, a Ford spokeswoman, Della DiPietro, said.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Several Rough Years Are Seen for Semiconductor Industry
description: Semiconductor equipment makers will see their industry decline by more than a third this year and will not surpass last year's sales levels until 2004, an industry trade association predicted today.

title: On the Stage Or in the Tent, Sound in Spin
description: Turntables were at the core of Area: One, the seven-hour event that sold out the Jones Beach Theater on Sunday, its first of two nights there. Moby, the headliner, borrowed an idea from European rock festivals, where live bands often perform on one stage while disc jockeys pump out dance beats in a nearby tent. Area: One put five bands on the amphitheater stage and five electronica acts in a tent where the dancing crowd soon overwhelmed the air-conditioning.

title: Cheney, on the Road, Seeks Support for Energy Program
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that falling fuel prices in no way diminished a need for more domestic energy supplies, arguing that America was becoming overly dependent on foreign oil exporters, some of whom ''do not wish us well.''

title: Media Executives Ask Senate Not to Limit Ownership Growth
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  As Federal regulators prepare to loosen or eliminate the rules that have restricted the largest broadcasters from growing bigger and owning newspapers, senior executives from Viacom Inc. and the Tribune Company asked the Senate today not to intervene.

title: Condit Facing Inquiry Bills That Stretch His Resources
description: Representative Gary A. Condit, the California Democrat caught in the middle of the controversy surrounding the disappearance of the government intern Chandra Ann Levy, has few financial resources with which to deal with the personal and political crisis building around him, his Congressional financial disclosure records show.

title: Stroll Around the Grounds, Mindful of the Sprinklers
description: Sara Pearson/Patrik Widrig and Company devised fun and games for performers and spectators alike when they presented ''A Curious Invasion'' on Sunday afternoon on the grounds of Wave Hill, a public garden in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Body Shop Buys Partner
description: The Body Shop, the retailer of beauty and hair products based on natural materials, said it had agreed to buy the Bellamy Retail Group, its United States venture partner, for $11.6 million in cash and stock to regain control of the business in America. The Body Shop said it would issue 7.5 million new shares to finance most of the deal. Adrian Bellamy, the chairman of the Bellamy Retail Group, will continue as chairman of American operations, the Body Shop said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: THE NEW BATTLE OF MARATHON
description: Plans to build an Olympic water sports complex on a historic battlefield in Greece prompt American archaeologists to join those who oppose it. Science Times, Page F3.

title: BERKSHIRE PARTNERS TO ACQUIRE CLOTHING MAKER
description: A private investment firm in Boston, Berkshire Partners, said yesterday that it would buy the William Carter Companies, a children's clothing maker and retailer, from the private investment fund Investcorp for $450 million. Berkshire Partners will have an equity stake of about $130 million in Carter's, based in Morrow, Ga., which makes children's underwear, pajamas and other clothes, and operates 149 retail outlets. In the four years since Investcorp owned the clothing company, net sales have climbed almost 50 percent, to $471.4 million in 2000.

title: A Rainbow of Differences in Gays' Children
description: Does growing up with parents who are gay or lesbian make a difference? A host of studies published over the last two decades would argue that it does not.

title: Norman Singer, 80, Executive Who Led Arts Organizations
description: Norman Singer, a teacher and arts executive who directed several music organizations in New York City, where he also presented major dance troupes, died on Saturday in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 80 and lived in Sandisfield, Mass.

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Revisited: The Election and the Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, LOUISE STUBBS
description: WILLIAMS-Louise Stubbs, 70, died Monday, July 16, 2001. Funeral services will be Thursday, July 19, 2001, at 10:00 AM, at the D'Esopo Funeral Chapel, 277 Folly Brook Blvd., Wethersfield, CT. Friends may call at the chapel on Wednesday, July 18, from 4:00 to 8:00 PM.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, named two executives to head the organization for 2001-2002. David A. Park, chief executive at the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, becomes chairman. He succeeds Arthur C. Liebler, who until his recent retirement was senior vice president for global brand marketing at the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler, Auburn Hills, Mich. And Paul C. Atkinson, vice president for integrated sales at AOL Time Warner, New York, becomes vice chairman of the organization. He will become chairman for 2002-2003, succeeding Mr. Park.

title: Whimsical, Dreamy and Outright Wacky
description: ''Mlanges,'' the title of the show put on by Cirque Plume, the little French circus playing through Saturday under the yellow big top in Damrosch Park as part of the Lincoln Center Festival 2001, is one of those designations that merit an accolade for truth in advertising.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Earnings Double For Yahoo
description: Yahoo Japan, a unit of the Softbank Corporation, reported yesterday that its earnings for the April-June period more than doubled to 1.1 billion yen while sales soared 84 percent, to 4.9 billion yen ($39.3 million), from the level a year earlier. The start of its high-speed Internet service lifted Yahoo Japan's performance as it recorded sales of broadband equipment to BB Technologies, a Softbank company, which will in turn sell the kit to subscribers to its asymmetric digital line. Yahoo Japan also said it began charging users of its auction services -- 280 yen ($2.25) a month -- in May, helping the company raise its profits. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: La Guardia Flight Curbs Are a Help, Official Says
description: The rationing of flights to La Guardia Airport in recent months has helped to untangle air traffic, and similar plans should be considered for other busy airports around the country, said the chairman of a House aviation subcommittee that met in New York City yesterday.

title: BLOOMBERG TOPS COMBINED SPENDING OF ALL OPPONENTS
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire businessman who is making his first foray into politics, has already spent a little more than $8 million of his own money in his bid for mayor. That is more than the combined expenditures of all four of the Democrats and one Republican vying against him.

title: Bush Calls for World Bank to Increase Grants
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Calling for "compassionate conservatism at an international level," President Bush urged the World Bank and other development banks today to significantly increase their grants of money, as opposed to loans, to poor nations.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on Friday about a reorganization of the Interpublic Group of Companies misstated the amount of national television spending that will be the initial focus for the Magna Global USA unit of Magna Global, a new media negotiations agency. The figure is about $8.6 billion, not close to $35 billion. The entry also misstated which office of the Bozell Group, now owned by Interpublic, handles the account of the National Fluid Milk Processor Promotion Board. It is the New York office, not the Chicago office.

title: Rogge Takes Olympic Reins From Samaranch
description: Jacques Rogge, an urbane 59-year-old orthopedic surgeon from Belgium, succeeded Juan Antonio Samaranch today as president of the International Olympic Committee as the most visible and important position in sports administration changed hands for the first time in two decades.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Theater Fund Files Suit To Protect TKTS Name
description: The Theater Development Fund, which runs the TKTS discount ticket booths in Times Square and downtown Manhattan, filed suit yesterday in London over the use of the booths' name.

title: Selling a Book With More Than Guesswork
description: The book publishing business prides itself on being a unique enterprise run by quaint eccentrics for whom a calculator is an exotic implement. Who buys books? Does advertising work? How many copies should be printed? Publishers pose these questions almost as an afterthought; their answers tend to be highly conjectural. ''You throw the book out into the world, and it's hit or miss after that,'' says Jason Epstein, former editorial director of Random House.

title: Beijing and Taipei
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Ford Offers Phone System
description: The Ford Motor Company, the No. 2 automaker, will begin offering a hands-free, voice-activated system in some vehicles this year to enable drivers to use cellular phones more safely. Cellport Systems Inc. of Boulder, Colo., will supply the system, the Cellport 3000 with Voice Command, under a $48 million contract, said Ralph Poplansky, Cellport's vice president of product development. Last month, New York became the first state to ban the use of cell phones by drivers unless they use headsets or hands-free devices such as Cellport's. The Cellport 3000 will first be sold as a dealer-installed option on Taurus sedans and Windstar minivans and will be offered in most Ford vehicles by mid-2002, a Ford spokeswoman, Della DiPietro, said.

title: Medicare Patients Who Tell of Poor Doctor Care Win Right to Learn of Findings
description: A federal judge has ordered Medicare officials to disclose their findings whenever they investigate a consumer's complaint that a doctor or a hospital provided poor-quality care or committed medical errors that injured the patient.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, NORMAN
description: SINGER-Norman. The Board of Directors, Artist Members and Staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center are saddened by the passing of Norman Singer, Executive Director from 1975 to 1982. His love of music and inspired leadership contributed greatly to the Society's growth and advancement during its formative years. We extend our most sincere condolences to his companion, Geoffrey Charlesworth, and their family and friends. Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Chairman Peter Frelinghuysen, President David Shifrin, Artistic Director Norma Hurlburt, Exec. Director

title: Riders Have Miles to Go and Mountains to Climb
description: Another long breakaway animated the Tour de France today, but what everybody talked about was the one the day before.

title: INSIDE
description: E.P.A. Stalls Waterway Plan

title: USA Networks To Buy 75% Of Expedia
description: USA Networks agreed yesterday to buy the 75 percent of the Expedia travel agency owned by the Microsoft Corporation with the goal of creating a vacation shopping channel -- bridging television and the Internet -- to mirror its Home Shopping Channel.

title: U.S. Plan to Halt Blood Imports Worries Europe
description: An American proposal to ban blood imports from Europe has alarmed European suppliers, who say it would upset a decades-old trans-Atlantic system that provides blood to New York City and would cast a pall of suspicion on the safety of European blood.

title: ST. PAUL SAYS COURT REVERSES SUSPENSION OF ITS LICENSE
description: The insurer St. Paul Companies said that a Georgia state court judge had thrown out an order suspending its license in the state over efforts to cut losses in its medical-malpractice liability business. The company said the judge, Gail S. Tusan of the Fulton County Superior Court, overturned the suspension ordered by the Georgia insurance commissioner, John Oxendine. The suspension came after St. Paul said it would not renew more than 1,200 policies up for renewal in June. St. Paul said its medical-malpractice business in Georgia pays out $1.79 in claims for every $1 in premiums it collects, compared with a nationwide claim payout of $1.40 for every $1.

title: In the Treaty's Words: 'International Stability'
description: Following are excerpts from the Treaty on Good Neighborly Friendship and Cooperation Between the Russian Federation and the People's Republic of China, as translated from the official Russian text by The New York Times:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Metro Business Briefing | Eight Miles Of Book Links
description: The Strand Book Store in Manhattan has signed a deal to sell its merchandise on eBay's online marketplace Half.com. A portion of Strand's famed eight miles of new, used and rare titles went on sale on the site about three weeks ago, but officials waited until yesterday to announce the agreement in order to work out any kinks, said Kristin Keyes, a spokeswoman for Half.com. Founded in 1927, the Strand has two retail locations -- 828 Broadway, at 12th Street, and 95 Fulton Street in the seaport district -- and a Web site, www.strandbooks.com, that also sells books.

title: Agencies Are Reducing Energy Use, Energy Department Says
description: Federal agencies have cut energy use this year and have begun to use a variety of creative conservation programs, a Department of Energy report has found.

title: The Land Rush To Reality Island; Overcrowded? Yes, But Showing No Signs of Sinking
description: For many who work in television -- and many who watch it -- the onslaught of reality shows and game shows that began invading network television last summer presents a threat akin to the Vandal horde pounding on the gates of Rome.

title: In Court, a Priest Reveals a Secret He Carried for 12 Years
description: On a winter afternoon in 1989, a Jesuit priest named Joseph Towle was called to the home of a teenager in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx. Jesus Fornes, a young man Father Towle had guided toward his first communion, had something awful to tell the priest: he had killed a man in Kelly Park.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GEN-X SPORTS INC., Toronto, which makes snowboards and golf accessories, said it would buy First Team Sports Inc., Anoka, Minn., which manufactures in-line skates and hockey equipment, for $10.4 million.

title: 10-Day Tour of Botswana
description: Two can fly to Africa for the price of one with a deal from African Travel Inc., a division of Far & Wide Travel. From November 2001 through June 2002, the 10-day Last Refuge tour to Botswana includes stops in the Okavango Delta, Moremi Reserve and Chobe National Park. The price, without air fare, starts at $2,995 a person, based on double occupancy. When two book together, only one traveler pays for an airline ticket. The tour price includes accommodations, all meals, daily game viewing, small-plane flights from camp to camp, park fees, transfers and taxes. The free air-fare offer does not apply to all departure dates. Information: (800) 722-7755 or www.africantravelinc.com .

title: A Monumental Race
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Slaying Suspects Arrested
description: Two cousins captured after a chase in Brooklyn were arrested in connection with a shooting in Harlem, and investigators have linked them to bludgeoning deaths in Florida and Connecticut, the police said yesterday. The men, Tyrone Blash, 25, and Anthony Bryant, 23, were spotted Monday night driving a car that had been linked to a July 14 killing in Oakland Park, Fla., near Fort Lauderdale. The suspects are also wanted in a slaying in New Haven on June 27, the police said. The victim in Harlem, John Wisdom, is believed to be Mr. Blash's uncle, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIGHTMAN, IRMA SHORELL
description: LIGHTMAN-Irma Shorell. 7/18/94 ''You were an original... a very special person who made everyone feel happier! The world is a sadder place without you.'' Hal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RENEE
description: BERGER-Renee. Beloved, dedicated and committed Life Member of the League of Women Voters of the City of New York will be greatly missed by all its members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUZOW, STANLEY
description: RUZOW-Stanley, 89. Passed away at home on July 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Rosabelle. Devoted father of Steve and Sue. Dear father-in-law of Miriam. Loving grandfather of Elyse, Liora, Danny and Limor. Cherished greatgrandfather of Jordyn, Brooke and Jon. Services Wednesday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: U.S. Arrests Russian Cryptographer as Copyright Violator
description: In one of the first cases of criminal prosecution under a 1998 federal digital copyright law, a 27-year-old Russian cryptographer was arrested at a Las Vegas hotel on Monday morning, a day after giving a presentation to a large convention of computer hackers on decrypting the software used to protect electronic books.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, HYMAN
description: RULNICK-Hyman. July 18, 1993. Miss you. Your loving daughter, Joyce

title: WELLS FARGO REPORTS LOSS ON HEAVY CHARGES
description: The country's fourth-largest bank, Wells Fargo & Company, reported a second-quarter loss yesterday after taking $1.16 billion in charges, mainly tied to losses in technology and telecommunications investments. The bank, based in San Francisco, had a loss of $87 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with earnings of $1.04 billion, or 61 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2000. Most of Wells Fargo's portfolio loss is from the declining value of its shares in Redback Networks and Cisco Systems. The shares rose $1.47, to $47.50.

title: Clark Expected In New York City
description: Christine Clark, the only American woman to compete in the marathon in the 2000 Olympics, will run in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 4.

title: Pfizer's Profit in Second Quarter Rose 31%
description: Second-quarter profit at Pfizer Inc. rose 31 percent as it cut costs and benefited from sales of Lipitor, Viagra and other medicines, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY,
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: The First Generation
description: The generally cerebral and curious fans of ''Star Trek'' have been waiting with great anticipation for its next television incarnation. They have to wait no longer.

title: Violence That Shook Asbury Park Leaves Police Searching for Clues
description: Except for a drying puddle of blood and a swarm of investigators, there was little sign today of the violence that shook this broken-down resort town Sunday night as a pack of armed young men rampaged through a crowd of revelers. Three men were shot, and more than a dozen people were arrested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIG, JERRY A.
description: DANZIG-Jerry A. Of Manhattan, died on July 16. The retired management consultant (Chester Burger & Co.) and pioneering broadcast executive served for 12 years as special assistant for communications to Governors Rockefeller and Wilson of NY. Before entering government service, he worked for CBS television and NBC's television & radio networks. During WW II, he was awarded the Bronze Star as a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy for valor during the Normandy invasion. Mr. Danzig, a graduate of Dartmouth College, is survived by his son, Jerry P. of Manhattan, his step-daughter, Diana C. Dupont of New Hampshire, and his sister, Evelyn D. Haas of San Francisco. He was married to the late Sarah Palfrey, former National Tennis Singles Champion. His brother, Frank, formerly of Los Angeles, also preceded him in death. The gathering for family and friends will be held at 11AM on Friday, July 20, at the Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Dartmouth College or the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOEING, Seattle, won an order for nine 767-300 aircraft from Hawaiian Airlines, Honolulu, valued at about $1.1 billion.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Governor Brings In Mediator
description: Gov. Gary Locke has hired a mediator to help resolve disagreements on a transportation package that has brought House and Senate members back for a third special session. The mediator, Jerry Cormick, is trying to forge an agreement on sticking points like spending on roads and public transportation. A spokesman for Mr. Locke, a Democrat, said the mediator's services could cost up to $10,000. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Senators Angered After F.B.I. Says Weapons Are Missing
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senators from both political parties expressed outrage and dismay today over an F.B.I. equipment inventory that found that hundreds of firearms and laptop computers were missing.

title: Protesters at Bay, Rich Nations' Chiefs to Meet in Genoa
description: Multiple checkpoints, bomb-sniffing dogs and 13-foot iron gratings put up across cobbled alleys to seal off secure zones have given the medieval port city of Genoa the look of pre-1989 East Berlin.
