title: William C. Breed III; Investment Executive, 66
description: William C. Breed III, a financial executive active in charitable and civic affairs, died in Greenwich, Conn., on July 9. He was 66 and lived in Greenwich.

title: Stem Cells and Delicate Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, MARTIN
description: SLATER-Martin. July 17, 2001. Brother of Ruth and her husband Julie. Uncle of Joan and her husband Peter, Alan and his wife Fern. Devoted partner of Gerald. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Wednesday, July 18th, 6-9PM. Service on Thursday, July 19th, at 11 AM at the Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, N.Y.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 47 Killed By Explosives
description: A blast in northwest China caused by illegal explosives stored in a house killed 47 people and injured 85, state news media reported. The police were searching for the owner of the explosives. In April, officials shut down an illegal Shaanxi Province explosives factory and its owner moved the materials to the house, officials said. Illegal explosives sold to mines and quarries are cheaper than state-licensed products. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Suspect Says He Will Fight Extradition In 3 Killings
description: Joseph Sean Salley said yesterday that he would contest extradition to New York on charges that he killed three people above the Carnegie Delicatessen on May 10 during a bungled robbery.

title: Governor Is Silent On U.S. Drilling Plan In the Finger Lakes
description: A federal proposal to drill for oil and gas under the Finger Lakes, part of the state's only national forest preserve, has met with unusual silence from Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: 'Gershwin' to Close
description: ''George Gershwin Alone,'' a one-man play written and performed by Hershey Felder with music and lyrics by George and Ira Gershwin, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Directed by Joel Zwick, the show will have run for 96 regular performances and 16 previews.

title: No Failure at Talks
description: India and Pakistan, longtime foes, emerged from two days of talks without even a joint news release to show for it. Yet ministers from both countries said that the meeting had not failed, but had helped them better understand each other.

title: Medicare Drug Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Midtown Snacking Of the Sweet And Gooey Kind
description: The Cipriani restaurants are best known for their creations for the cocktail hour (the bellini) and the appetizer course (carpaccio). But their desserts -- dark chocolate cake, cream-filled layers of puff pastry, silky cheese cakes and tart lemon meringue pies -- are also attention-getters, and now they are being sold in the new Cipriani Le Specialit shop at 110 East 42nd Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USDAN, BEATRICE
description: USDAN-Beatrice. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Beatrice Usdan, our esteemed colleague, a member of The National Board and a former National Vice President. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, Nat'l Pres

title: Police See Nothing to Link Missing Intern and Dead Women
description: Washington police investigating the disappearance of the government intern Chandra Ann Levy have found no evidence that would link her case to other recent missing-person cases involving young women in the capital, law enforcement officials said today.

title: A Law Firm In Australia Sues 3 Airlines Over an Illness
description: An Australian law firm has begun legal proceedings against the country's aviation safety authority and three international airlines on behalf of passengers who contend that they developed blood clots and related complications on long flights.

title: Our Towns; Stripped And Searched, Even at Age 13
description: THE 13-year-old girl was frightened. She was on her way to juvenile detention, after refusing repeated orders from a judge to attend her seventh-grade classes.

title: Pentagon Revisits a Space Defense Plan
description: A defense official announced today that the Pentagon planned to renew research on a highly contentious element of the Strategic Defense Initiative called Brilliant Pebbles, a plan to base thousands of missile interceptors in space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWLETT, SELINA RICHARDS WOOD GREW
description: HEWLETT-Selina Richards Wood Grew. Of Old Lyme, CT, on July 15, 2001, in her 91st year. Widow of Henry Sturgis Grew, Jr. and Roger Sanderson Hewlett. Survived by her daughters Selina G. (Mrs. W. Allen) Rossiter of Lincoln, MA; three sons, Henry S. Grew of Newport, RI; Rt. Rev. J. Clark Grew, II of Cleveland, OH; Dr. Robert S. Grew of Raleigh, NC; step daughter Sandra H. (Mrs. Robert) Johnson of Burlingame, CA; step son Peter S. Hewlett of Sebastopol, CA; 13 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 21, 2001, at 11:30 AM, in St. Ann's Episcopal Church, 82 Shore Road (Rte. 156) Old Lyme, CT 06371. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in her memory to St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: Abused and Evicted
description: To the Editor:

title: In Japan, A Steak Secret To Rival Kobe
description: I WASN'T sure whether to be insulted or impressed when, seconds after I had stepped out of his barn here, Mikichi Kubo took out a dustpan and broom and swept up after me. The barn is home to six large black cows. Shouldn't I be scraping my shoes instead?

title: Richard Rogers, Harvard Film Teacher, 57
description: Richard P. Rogers, director of the Film Study Center at Harvard University, and a filmmaker, died on Saturday at his home in Wainscott, N.Y. He was 57 and also had homes in Manhattan and Cambridge, Mass.

title: They're Just Barrels, Not Crystal Balls
description: HAVE you bought your 2000 Haut-Brion yet? Or your 2000 Le Pin? Better hurry, before the prices go up or, worse, the wines run out. You can still grab a case of Chteau Haut-Brion for $4,000 or a bit more. Le Pin, from the rustic little winery of the same name in Pomerol, is a bit pricier, $9,600 a case, but then, what's money when it comes to wine?

title: Metro Business Briefing | Apartment Costs Rise; Sales Fall
description: Despite the softening economy, the average selling price of a Manhattan apartment in the past three months was a record $894,617, an increase of 2 percent over the previous quarter, according to the latest Douglas Elliman Manhattan market overview. In a more striking change, the number of sales declined by 19 percent -- from 2,257 apartments during the second quarter of last year to 1,829 last quarter. ''The market was surprisingly stable,'' said Jonathan J. Miller, the president of Miller Samuel, an appraisal company, which prepared the report. ''The only cause for concern is the decline in volume.'' He said sales were down because fewer apartments were on the market and many people were waiting to see what happens to the economy. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Merger Specialist Sentenced
description: A mergers and acquisition specialist was sentenced yesterday to one year and one day in prison for failing to report $670,828 in income to the Internal Revenue Service. The specialist, Frederick Roa, 64, pleaded guilty in April to evading $255,557 in taxes for his firm, Telesis Mergers and Acquisitions Inc. of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Mr. Roa cheated the government from 1995 to 1998 to pay for personal expenses, including a house renovation, his lawyer, Larry Horn, told Judge William H. Walls of United States District Court in Newark.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A British Invasion, With Mayo
description: The British sandwich chain Pret A Manger, which opened its first overseas store in New York last year, plans to open three more in the city this summer and expand to 30 Manhattan locations in the next two years. The company, which recently sold a 33 percent stake to the McDonald's Corporation to finance international expansion, plans to open at 530 Seventh Avenue next week, at 287 Madison Avenue in August and at 1350 Sixth Avenue in September. It has 113 locations in Britain and one at 60 Broad Street in the financial district, where the menu has been adjusted slightly to reflect American tastes. The company is also considering expanding to Hong Kong.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Union And State Set More Talks
description: Negotiators for the state and the Oregon Public Employees Union will hold a final mediation session on Friday in an effort to avoid a strike in a contract dispute. The union is seeking a 2 percent (or $40 per month) salary increase next year and 3 percent the next year, compared with a total 4 percent increase proposed by the state. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, KATHARINE
description: GRAHAM-Katharine. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University are saddened by the loss of our esteemed friend, Katharine Graham, a former member of The Rockefeller University Council. Her loyal friendship to the University will be missed. We greatly admire her tremendous professional accomplishments as one of this nation's legendary leaders in journalism. Her devotion to the pursuit of truth helped to transform not only a newspaper but the business of news in the United States, and her personal courage profoundly affected the lives of women both in the U.S. and abroad. Her keen intelligence and astute insight into the world of government and politics have inspired generations of journalists. The Rockefeller University community will treasure the memory of her caring and gracious nature, and the generous way in which she embraced those around her. With heartfelt sympathy, we extend our deepest condolences to her family. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard B. Fisher, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman, The Rockefeller University Council, and Chairman Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHEL, ROSALIE ON JULY 17, 2001
description: REICHEL-Rosalie on July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Fredric and his wife Beverley, Enid and her husband Edwin Kammin. Dear sister of Dorothy. Adoring grandmother of John and Suzanne. Graveside services on Friday, July 20th, 11AM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: The Subcontinent Summit Meeting
description: Hard by the Taj Mahal in the northern Indian city of Agra, the leaders of India and Pakistan have concluded three days of talks that were widely but perhaps unfairly described as a disappointment. Distrust is so great that it would have been a miracle for Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India to narrow differences extending back to independence and partition more than 50 years ago. But though there was squabbling that prevented a joint statement at the end of the talks, both sides reported progress. Even a minor step forward is a welcome relief in a region shadowed by the danger of nuclear conflict.

title: Miami Police Face Investigations Over Their Handling of Suspects
description: Stung by accusations of abuse, corruption and cover-ups, the Miami Police Department is under intense scrutiny by federal prosecutors and the department's own investigators, who are reviewing a string of police shootings in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DOROTHY ''GOLDIE''.
description: GOLDMAN-Dorothy ''Goldie''. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Mildred Grant and Irma Millard. Dear grandmother of Staci Bird. Great grandmother of Hayden & Kenna Bird. Visiting on Wednesday 7-9PM. Service Thursday 11:30AM at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Panel Says U.S. Spending On Energy Is Paying Off
description: Money that the federal government has put into research and development for energy efficiency and fossil fuel production during the last 22 years has generally been well spent, a National Academy of Sciences committee said today.

title: According to The Times...
description: To demonstrate how deadly alternating current could be, Thomas Edison helped electrocute an elephant named Topsy before an audience on Coney Island in 1903.

title: INSIDE
description: F.B.I. Property Missing

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: No Dancing, No Surfing. (Surfing?)
description: The ruling Taliban, who have banned music and dancing, have now banned use of the Internet to prevent un-Islamic influences, according to Agence France-Presse, which quoted Foreign Minister Wakil Ahmed Mutawakel. Not many people would be affected by the prohibition. Very few citizens have telephones. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Meriden: Tax Dispute Settled
description: Meriden and two utilities have settled a 1995 dispute over millions of dollars in tax refunds owed to the utilities. In a settlement reached Monday, the city agreed to drop its appeal of an April ruling that it had overtaxed the utilities $16.4 million, including interest. The utilities -- Northeast Utilities, the parent company of Yankee Gas Services Company, and Connecticut Light and Power Company -- agreed to accept $14.9 million. The City Council will issue municipal bonds to help pay for the refunds.

title: Mexico's New Anti-Drug Team Wins the Trust of U.S. Officials
description: After five years of failure, American and Mexican officials fighting the war on drugs say they have created a trusted group of undercover Mexican investigators who are arresting long-sought suspects and attacking all the big drug cartels, instead of selling out to them as in the past.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on July 6 about efforts by the Colorado Department of Motor Vehicles to prevent fraud misstated the department's plan for collecting and comparing digital images of drivers' faces. The department will compare old and new license photographs taken in its offices. It will not collect images with security cameras on Colorado roads.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Adam S. Bauman was named chairman and chief executive at IsoSpace, New York, succeeding Abbas Shah, who becomes vice chairman. Mr. Bauman had been chief global e-commerce officer at Deloitte Consulting, New York, a unit of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu.

title: Market Place; Intel Reports Earnings Beat Estimates by 2 cents
description: The Intel Corporation, offering hope that the worst days of the semiconductor slump may be behind it, said today that its second-quarter earnings beat Wall Street's estimates on the strength of renewed growth in sales of microprocessors.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEINSTEIN, HARRY
description: FEINSTEIN-Harry. 6/24/26 to 7/18/80. Your essence shines brightly all these 21 years. Francine, Nina, Beth and David

title: Lawmaker Wants Review of Bush Aide
description: The ranking Democrat on the House Government Reform Committee asked the White House today to refer questions about possible conflicts of interests involving Karl Rove, President Bush's senior adviser, to the Justice Department for further review.

title: Mike Saltzstein, 60, Coney Island's Carousel Man, Dies
description: Mike Saltzstein, who for more than a quarter-century kept Coney Island's last historic carousel spinning through sunlit summers, ice-cold winters and lurching changes in the famed amusement area, died on July 4 in his Brooklyn apartment. He was 60.

title: Bodies of New Yorkers Are Identified by Belgrade
description: The Serbian government confirmed today that three bodies found in a mass grave in eastern Serbia were those of Albanian-American brothers from New York whose family name is Bytyqi. The men were in police hands when they disappeared, said senior officials, calling their killings an ''extraordinarily serious crime.''

title: Winston Sponsor Stays
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said yesterday that it would continue sponsoring the Nascar Winston Cup series through at least next season, its 32nd as a sponsor. But Rick Sanders, a company executive, said it was hardly a simple, painless or joyful business decision.

title: Washington Talk; House, in Ritual Vote, Opposes Flag Burning
description: The House voted today, as it has regularly in recent years, to amend the Constitution to allow Congress to pass laws against flag burning and other types of desecration of the American flag.

title: The Roman Empire Without the Plebeians
description: Between ''tantalizingly prehistoric'' and ''recent enough to be relevant'' lies a black hole that is eager to swallow up makers of historical documentaries. The earnest folks who made ''The Roman Empire in the First Century,'' which begins tonight on PBS, find this out the hard way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, BENJAMIN
description: WEINTRAUB-Benjamin. Staten Island, NY. Benjamin Weintraub died suddenly on July 16, 2001. He was 88 years old. Beloved husband for 16 years of Rae Wasserman. Devoted father of Josy Ingersoll of Landenberg, PA, and Kathy Puckett of Shelburne Falls, MA. Fond stepfather of Steve Wasserman of Yonkers, NY, Ira Wasserman of Brooklyn, NY, Becca Gelfand of Newburyport, MA, and Jacqueline Gilbert of Berkley, CA. Proud grandfather of Michael, Jamie, Tad, Cassidy, Christoph and Gilbert. Adoring great-grandfather of Lucien. Loving brother of David, Arthur and the late Phil Weintraub. He was a widower of Anita Solomon Weintraub. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, on July 11, 1913. He attended City College of New York before he enlisted in the Army in WWII, serving as a combat photographer in the 10th Combat Camera Unit in the China-Burma-India Theater. He continued his career as a photographer in civilian life, and worked as a builder/ realtor. His lifelong passion was political activism for world peace. He served as a non-governmental delegate to the United Nations until his death, organized anti-war photographic exhibits, monitored elections in Nicaragua as a volunteer for President Carter, traveled to Bosnia to raise funds for war victims, and was honored in Moscow for his participation in WWII. He was active in VFW Post #

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN, MICHAEL
description: ROSEN-Michael. July 18, 1980. In loving memory, never forgotten. Your Family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Transit Worker Electrocuted
description: A transit worker died early yesterday after he tripped and fell onto the electrified third rail of a subway track in Queens, New York City Transit said. The worker, Samuel McPhaul, 49, a nine-year city transit employee, was working on the track for the E and F lines north of the Grand Avenue station in Queens when he fell onto the rail, which remains electrified during routine maintenance work. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Putin Says Russia Won't Join China in Countering U.S. Shield
description: MOSCOW, July 18  President Vladimir V. Putin used his first formal news conference today to temper Russian criticism of Washington's plans for a limited missile defense, saying Moscow would not act jointly with China to counter an American missile shield should it be built.

title: G.M. Registers 73% Decline In Net Income For Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation posted a sharp decline in profits yesterday because of rising competition from Asian carmakers, cooling demand for cars in the United States and disappointing sales in Europe.

title: News Corp. Intends to Shed Its Magazine Unit
description: The downturn in the magazine industry has beaten back one of the giants of worldwide media.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Changing The Death Penalty
description: The House approved a bill that would ban the execution of mentally retarded people. The bill, a revised version of one already approved by the Senate, will now go back to the Senate. Among the changes in the House bill is language that would allow defendants to ask a judge to declare them mentally retarded only with approval from the prosecutor. Lino R. Rodriguez JR. (NYT)

title: Senator Says Most Americans Want Controls on Light Arms
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein said today that a majority of Americans would not approve of efforts by the United States to derail the talks here on an international agreement to tighten controls on light weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHURRE, GILAH AKA GOLDIE GORDON.
description: SCHURRE-Gilah aka Goldie Gordon. Beloved wife of the late Morris Gordon and Jacques Schurre. Devoted mother of Sandy Stiebel Field, Judy Gussin, Barbara Bluhm Kaul, Robert and Alan Gordon. Loving sister of Pearl Mosak. Cherished grandmother of 12 and great-grandmother of 16. Services were held Monday in New York and interment in Jerusalem.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Diphtheria Vaccine Shortage
description: A shortage of the tetanus-diphtheria vaccine has state officials asking hospitals to ration the vaccine to those with a serious risk of contracting either disease, including pregnant women. Only a handful of diphtheria cases across the country are reported in a year. Doctors are delaying routine vaccinations for groups like high school sophomores, who receive a tetanus-diphtheria booster as part of an annual examination, said LeeAnn Thayer, a clinical specialist at Yale-New Haven Hospital.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the disputed renovation of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist in Milwaukee carried an outdated artist's rendering of the interior. Later changes have placed a crucifix above the altar and moved the pulpit and the bishop's seat forward into the church.

title: Key N.B.A. Players Who Are Staying Home
description: Major personnel shifts were supposed to color the N.B.A.s off-season, but it didnt happen. Here are key players who have agreed in principle to stay put, although contracts cannot be signed until July 18.

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: Keeping Heads, and Hair, in Game; Teachers' Ongoing Training Includes DNA Lessons
description: The teachers were pulling out their hair.

title: Interstate Competition for Teachers From Abroad
description: New York City did not realize just how hot the market for foreign teachers had become until Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy sent recruiters to Madrid in the spring. There, the astonished New Yorkers ran into school officials from Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts and Washington -- all eager to lure teachers to the United States from Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, MARGA
description: OPPENHEIMER-Marga. Beloved widow of P. Hans Oppenheimer, died peacefully on July 16, 2001. She will be deeply missed by both family and friends. Funeral services Friday, July 20, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY LUCAS
description: SMITH-Mary Lucas. Suddenly on July 16, 2001. Longtime resident of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of William A. Smith. Loving mother of David W. Smith. Grandmother of Lucas and Nicolas. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Wednesday and Thursday 3-5 & 79PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10AM, St. Mary's RC Church Manhasset with interment to follow at Mt. St. Mary's. Donations in her memory may be made to The United Cerebral Palsy Association 110-35 164th Place, Jamaica, NY 11433.

title: Greenspan Says More Action May Be Needed on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the economy remained weak and susceptible to more bad news, and he suggested that the central bank might cut interest rates at least once more this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Kearny: Death On The Tracks
description: The last car of a New Jersey Transit train struck and killed a man who was seen standing yesterday afternoon alongside the tracks here, the railroad said. The man was not immediately identified, and the reason for the accident was unclear, said Penny Bassett Hackett, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit. The man was killed just as the Boonton-line train was moving past the Arlington station, bound for Dover. The accident caused minor delays on the line. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, RICHARD E., ESQ.
description: BAUMAN-Richard E., Esq. On July 14, 2001, at age 77. Devoted companion of Jose R. Vega. Also survived by his grandchildren Maria Rodriguez, Robert Vega and four great-grandchildren; sisters Reva Hildum and Blanca Rodriguez; brothers-in-law Ramon and Carmen Rodriguez. Interment private. Memorial service on Wednesday, July 18, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, 4:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Goosen Getting Used to the Spotlight
description: In the span of one month, Retief Goosen has won two tournaments, including a major championship, while watching his fame and fortune increase faster than he ever imagined.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Diana Zerka and Penny Weill, Manolo Blahnik boutique, New York, May 4, 2001

title: It's Risky Crashing a Raptor Convention
description: ''Do you remember the sounds they made?'' Dr. Alan Grant (Sam Neill) asks a colleague in an awe-inspired whisper in ''Jurassic Park 3,'' the cruel-to-be-kind sequel that's a lot more fun than the previous ''Park'' excursions. Grant is talking about raptors, and given the miraculous season the Toronto Raptors had in the N.B.A., that could be what he is marveling about. But Grant is referring to the quick, fierce prehistoric creatures better known as velociraptors. He has learned that the raptors can speak and communicate, and adds, ''They were smarter than primates.''

title: Argentine With a Headache: The Economy
description: Things could be going smoother for Domingo Cavallo since he returned as economy minister in March, widely viewed as the knight in shining armor who would lift Argentina out of its three-year recession much as he quelled the hyperinflation that tormented the country a decade ago.

title: Two Weeks in Prague
description: Sometimes a good deal requires you to put together the pieces yourself. For example, an Untour two-week land package in Prague, available for Wednesday departures through Aug. 15, costs $899 a person (marked down from $1,020) for travelers who can make their own flight arrangements. That price is based on double occupancy and includes an apartment in Prague, a metro pass and airport transfers. Availability is limited. Information: (888) 868-6871 or www.untours.com .

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: On Her Own List, One Big Wish
description: Emilie Schindler, 94, widow of the German industrialist Oskar Schindler, returned to Germany to live after more than half a century in Argentina. Several towns offered nursing-home care after she said it was her ''greatest and last wish'' to spend her final years in Germany. The Schindlers' story of saving many Jews from the Nazis was told in the movie ''Schindler's List.'' Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Mets Sign Top Draft Pick
description: The Mets signed the right-handed pitcher Aaron Heilman yesterday, six weeks after they made him their first-round pick in the amateur draft.

title: Liberties; Kay's Amazing Grace
description: At dinner with Kay Graham and some friends at Kinkead's, a Washington restaurant, a few months ago, I told Mrs. Graham that C-Span radio, which has been broadcasting Lyndon Johnson's phone tapes from the Oval Office on Saturdays, had just played the one where L.B.J. flirted with her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEERY, DONALD R.
description: GEERY-Donald R. Of NYC, died on July 3, 2001, survived by his nephews, Saleem A. Pernath, Tucker R. Geery & Scott T. Geery. A memorial service will be held at Greenwood Cemetery at 11 AM on Saturday, July 21. Donations in Mr. Geery's memory may be made to Cornell University, Ithaca, New York, for the Cornell Fund.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Union Organizer Set Free
description: Cao Maobing, a union organizer at a silk-factory in eastern Jiangsu Province, has been released from a psychiatric hospital where he was held for 210 days, according to China Labor Watch, a New York-based human rights and labor advocacy group. Mr. Cao was put in the hospital, medicated and forced to undergo electroshock therapy, his relatives said, after he tried to organize an independent labor union at the Funing Silk Factory near the city of Yancheng. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Recipe: Tomato, Watermelon and Goat Cheese Salad
description: Time: 15 minutes 2 cups tiny ripe cherry tomatoes (halved if larger than a grape)

title: Not All Lost In the Talks Between India And Pakistan
description: India and Pakistan, foes from way back, did not emerge from an intensive two days of talks here with even a jointly issued, garden-variety press release to show for it. Yet ministers from both countries said today in separate news conferences that the summit had not failed, but helped them better understand each other.

title: A Spirited Cafe Reaches for the Next Decade
description: AT the upper end of the market, popular Manhattan restaurants tend to live through three stages. At the outset, they make their mark with innovative, high-quality cooking. They bask in the warm glow of flattering reviews. The chef becomes famous. The crowds line up.

title: House Committee Approves Bush's Plan for Drilling in Alaskan Refuge
description: House Republicans moved swiftly today to transform President Bush's energy plan into legislation as a committee for the first time endorsed the White House plan to drill for oil in an Arctic wildlife refuge.

title: Bubbles, but Not Champagne
description: IN a country where the most popular beverages are soda and beer, you would think that the lure of carbonation would draw more people toward sparkling wines. But no. Americans seem to lump all sparkling wines together as Champagne, which they've consigned to a pedestal and consume only for ceremonies and celebrations.

title: A Bet on Bulgaria Pays Dividends; Plants Like American Standard's Bolster the Economy
description: Much like a Martian spacecraft, a huge new factory that makes porcelain bathroom fixtures is a startling sight on the farmland outside this worn-down city of 25,000 in a remote corner of the Balkans.

title: Revenues Rise And Legislators Debate Impact
description: State revenues were strong in the first quarter of the fiscal year, but that was mostly an echo of last year's still-booming economy, officials said today, as all sides said that the new data supported their positions in the state budget fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMBS, MASON
description: COMBS-Mason. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Mason Combs. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Education at the Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Disney To Supply Content For Cars
description: The Disney Internet Group said yesterday that it would provide content from ESPN.com, Disney.com and ABCnews.com to automobile stereos through the OnStar system of General Motors. Users of OnStar, which has 1.3 million subscribers, can get information using voice-activation and voice-synthesis technology. The companies said the Web-based information from Disney would be personalized but that only audio would be available. Disney will provide ESPN.com's Sports Center update, the audio track of ''World News Tonight'' and Bill Diehl's Entertainment News and other programming to subscribers. OnStar has been seeking localized services for its Virtual Advisor -- an automated, cellular-based service that has been offered as an option on most G.M. vehicles since the beginning of the year. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST WASHINGTON: GOVERNOR BRINGS IN MEDIATOR Gov. Gary Locke has hired a mediator to help resolve disagreements on a transportation package that has brought House and Senate members back for a third special session. The mediator, Jerry Cormick, is trying to forge an agreement on sticking points like spending on roads and public transportation. A spokesman for Mr. Locke, a Democrat, said the mediator's services could cost up to $10,000. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: My Indirect Career Path
description: AROUND a campfire at Camp Laughing Waters in Gilbertsville, Pa., two weeks ago, a group of established, successful -- let's just say it: older -- women talked wistfully yet contentedly to a circle of their former selves. Their listeners were Girl Scouts, ages 13 through 17, and they had gathered for three days in the woods with 20 potential role models to learn how to build a dream and make it come true.

title: Yankees Extend Their Stay At the Expense of the Phillies
description: The Yankees played 25 innings in two nights here and they have at least 18 innings to play in Detroit on Wednesday, and it is all starting to run together, Derek Jeter said. But they keep winning, improbably, and nobody's tired.

title: What Dad (the Boss) Says, Goes: His Rules Say So
description: Last November, Robert B. McKinley grounded his 17-year-old son for drinking on a trip away from home. Then he suspended him from work without pay.

title: In-Season Additions Fail to Add A Spark
description: The Yankees won the World Series last year after being jump-started by midseason acquisitions like David Justice, Denny Neagle and Jose Vizcaino. The players brought in by General Manager Brian Cashman, like Glenallen Hill, Luis Sojo and Dwight Gooden, gave the team an immediate burst of production.

title: Data Become Ammunition In the Race to Win City Hall
description: The race for City Hall took a hostile turn yesterday, as thousands of pages worth of newly disclosed financial reports and petitions became ammunition for attacks and counterattacks by the Democrats who want to be mayor.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: State Sues Check-Cashing Company
description: The state attorney general's office announced that it was suing the nation's largest check-cashing company, which the attorney general, Ken Salazar, accused of violating state law and charging excessively high interest to mostly low-income clients. The defendant, ACE Cash Express of Irving, Tex., has about 50 stores in Colorado and operates in more than 30 states. The company surrendered its Colorado lending license last year but said it could still operate because of its affiliation with a federally chartered bank. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Spy Trial in China Likely for U.S. Resident
description: Gao Zhan, a permanent United States resident accused of spying for Taiwan, has been indicted and will probably stand trial this month in Beijing, one of her lawyers said today.

title: In the Silk Stocking District, a Real Shoestring Candidacy
description: It's hard being nobody. Especially in politics. Especially when you're running for office on the Upper East Side.

title: Merrill and Schwab Say Earnings Show Steep Declines
description: Two big brokerage companies reported sharply lower earnings for the second quarter yesterday, setting the stage for another round of layoffs and cost-cutting on Wall Street.

title: Katharine Graham of Washington Post Dies at 84
description: Katharine Graham, who transformed The Washington Post from a mediocre newspaper into an American institution and, in the process, transformed herself from a shy widow into a publishing legend, died yesterday after suffering head injuries in a fall on a sidewalk on Saturday in Idaho. She was 84.

title: Bush Ally Supports Financing Limited Stem Cell Research
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 — In a hint of how President Bush might resolve the divisive debate over embryonic stem cell experiments, Senator Bill Frist, a transplant surgeon and close ally of the president, today announced his qualified support of federal financing for the research "within a very carefully regulated, fully transparent framework."

title: Me-Zine Journalism for Fun and (Sometimes) Profit
description: Mickey Kaus, a former reporter for Newsweek, works out of his home off the beach in Santa Monica, Calif., looking at a blue sliver of ocean, drawing in the balmy beach air, his usual work attire a mismatched, rumpled sweatsuit.

title: Anxiety Rises After Attacks In West Bank And Israel
description: The month-old cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians, more a concept than a reality from the start, seemed shakier than ever today with new violence that included the first Palestinian mortar attack against a Jewish neighborhood on Jerusalem's southern rim.

title: Reckonings; Other People's Money
description: It wasn't true when Richard Nixon said it, but it is true today: We are all Keynesians now -- at least when we look at our own economy. We give anti-Keynesian advice only to other countries.

title: SOVEREIGN BANCORP AGREES TO BUY MAIN STREET BANCORP
description: Sovereign Bancorp, which operates 527 branches in six states, has agreed to buy the Main Street Bancorp for about $170 million in stock and cash to expand in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Sovereign will exchange $16.10 in a combination of Sovereign stock and cash for each share of Main Street, Sovereign said. That is a 50 percent premium above Main Street's closing price on Monday. Shareholders of Main Street, which has 42 offices in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, can elect to receive as much as 30 percent of the amount in cash. The shares of Sovereign, based in Philadelphia, closed unchanged at $12.92. Main Street shares rose $4.58 to $15.33.

title: Stem Cells and Delicate Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEF
description: I DON'T have much use for recipes. They give you a formula, but they don't tell you how something is supposed to taste, and they're not foolproof either.

title: In From the Fields, An Elegant Partner
description: THERE are few foods as splendid as a perfectly ripe watermelon in its most natural state, sliced in wedges and served outdoors, so you can spit out the seeds and let the juice run in streams down your arms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, RALPH D.
description: FRIEDLANDER-Ralph D. Beloved brother-in-law to Marilyn and Bob; wonderful uncle to Eileen and Larry; a responsible, respected, charitable, warm human being who has been devoted to his extended family and will be sadly missed by all of us. Our sincerest condolences to his wonderful wife Francine and loving daughter Vivian. Marilyn and Robert Weinberg Eileen and Larry Toulouse

title: Stocks Fall on Earnings Reports and Greenspan Comments
description: Stock prices fell today as investors digested another round of bleak corporate earnings reports along with downbeat comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, about the economy's continuing weakness.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: APARTMENT COSTS RISE; SALES FALL Despite the softening economy, the average selling price of a Manhattan apartment in the past three months was a record $894,617, an increase of 2 percent over the previous quarter, according to the latest Douglas Elliman Manhattan market overview. In a more striking change, the number of sales declined by 19 percent — from 2,257 apartments during the second quarter of last year to 1,829 last quarter. "The market was surprisingly stable," said Jonathan J. Miller, the president of Miller Samuel, an appraisal company, which prepared the report. "The only cause for concern is the decline in volume." He said sales were down because fewer apartments were on the market and many people were waiting to see what happens to the economy.   Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Building Bridges With Buoyant Spirits Under the Stars
description: There were thousands of people on and around the Great Lawn of Central Park on Monday night, enjoying the music being played by the New York Philharmonic, enjoying the temperate evening, enjoying being in New York. These may not be occasions for close listening, but they most certainly are occasions. Some highly skilled professionals come out of their natural habitat to meet the crowd. And the crowd quietly attends. Bridges are being formed in each measure: people who would probably never dream of entering the glass foyer of Avery Fisher Hall are listening, possibly for the first time, to live orchestral music. The fireworks at the end are celebrating what has been achieved: a moment of contact.

title: Coke Bottler To Eliminate 2,000 Jobs
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises, the bottling company responsible for about 80 percent of Coca-Cola's soft drink sales in North America, will cut 2,000 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, the company said yesterday.

title: 5 Years Later, Flight 800 Victims Still Mourned
description: Five years after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 fell from the sky in fiery bits that landed in the ocean near here, the relatives of some of the 230 people who died in the crash made their annual pilgrimage to the East End of Long Island for prayer and remembrance.

title: Recipe: Watermelon, Fennel and Arugula Salad
description: Adapted from Aureole

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTTER, DR. RUDOLF G.
description: HUTTER-Dr. Rudolf G. On July 5th, 2001, of 445 E. 80th St. Beloved husband of Pamela. Cherished father of Barbara Manford and father-in-law of David. Loving grandfather of Jonathan and stepfather of two. Predeceased by his first wife, Ruth Hutter, who was Head of the Math Department of the Chapin School on the Upper Eastside of Manhattan. Memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 19th, 6 PM, at Church of Advent Hope, 111 E. 87th St., NYC. For further info, contact John Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: Two Shot to Death On a Brooklyn Street
description: Two teenagers were shot and killed yesterday afternoon on a crowded street in Flatbush, Brooklyn, in what may have been a gang-related fight, the police said.

title: Cagey Armstrong Goes Up, Up And Away as Tour Hits Alps
description: Speeding up the last of three daunting climbs in the Alps and shattering his rivals, Lance Armstrong took a big step today toward his third consecutive victory in the Tour de France. He did it by bluffing.

title: Tobacco Giant's Analysis Says Premature Deaths Cut Costs in Pensions and Health Care : Critics Assail Philip Morris Report on Smoking
description: The tobacco giant Philip Morris was flayed Tuesday for an economic analysis concluding that smoking is good for government coffers because it causes people to die prematurely, thereby saving pension and health care costs.

title: Corrections
description: A rock review yesterday about ''Area: One,'' an event at Jones Beach, misidentified the label of the 1999 album ''Play'' by Moby, a band that performed. It was V2 Records, not Elektra.

title: AT&T Rejects Comcast's $40 Billion Offer for Broadband Unit
description: NEW YORK (Reuters) - AT&T Corp. T.N said on Wednesday its board unanimously rejected Comcast Corp.'s unsolicited bid to purchase its AT&T Broadband unit, saying the $40 billion stock offer did not reflect the full value of the No. 1 U.S. cable-television company.

title: Court Orders State to Release Lead Paint Health Data
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered the city's Department of Health yesterday to release electronic data to a watchdog group that had been denied the material on the ground that certain information in its computers was exempt from the state's Freedom of Information Law.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: High-Speed Wireless In Seattle
description: AT&T Wireless began offering advanced wireless services in Seattle yesterday, making it one of the first companies to allow customers to send and receive data on cell phones at speeds that are much faster than those available on most wireless networks. AT&T Wireless, which recently became independent from AT&T, plans to extend the services to 40 percent of its customers this year and to all by the end of 2002. The move puts AT&T at the forefront of wireless carriers in the United States that are seeking to profit from risky plans to sell services like e-mail and access to corporate databases on wireless devices. In Europe, some of the world's largest wireless carriers are reeling from debt after spending billions to acquire licenses for the communications spectrum needed to provide similar services. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: History From a Major Player

title: Trivia Question: Mets All-Time Great Pitchers
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Stem Cell Debate in House Has Two Faces, Both Young
description: Nine months old and fidgeting in their parents' arms, Luke and Mark Borden, twins from California who were adopted when they were still embryos in frozen storage at a fertility clinic, came to the Capitol today to help in a campaign urging President Bush not to permit federal financing of stem cell research that destroys human embryos.

title: Who Puts the Standards Into Standardized Tests?
description: IN Ohio this spring, 98 percent of students who took the state's graduation exam passed. In California, less than half passed a similar test.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Parametric Planning Layoffs
description: The Parametric Technology Corporation, an engineering software maker, said it would cut 400 to 500 jobs, or 8 to 10 percent of its work force, in response to slow growth in sales. The company, based in Needham, Mass., said its third-quarter net income, excluding amortization and charges, was $6.7 million, or 3 cents a share, down from $7.1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales were $229.1 million, up from $227.3 million in the year-earlier quarter. The company will take a charge of $20 million to $30 million in the fourth quarter to cover the cost of the job cuts. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Robert Frazer Rushmer, 86; Developed Heart Monitoring
description: Dr. Robert F. Rushmer, a pediatrician and physiologist who used bioengineering to monitor living hearts and track fetal cardiac function, died on Friday at home at a retirement community in a Seattle suburb. He was 86.

title: N.B.A. Unveils Its Minor League
description: The National Basketball Association announced the team names and coaches today for its minor league venture, the National Basketball Development League, with news conferences in each of the eight cities and then a gathering in Boston to unveil the team colors and names.

title: Blurring Borders in the New World
description: HERE

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE /> BRITAIN: AN INCREASE IN PRICES

title: Plan to Shift Utility Costs For Cheney Gains Ground
description: The House Appropriations Committee voted along party lines today to support a White House plan that would have the Navy pay all the electricity bills for the official residence of Vice President Dick Cheney, the administration's energy point man.

title: DeVito/Verdi, on its 10th anniversary, makes some changes.
description: A NEW YORK agency that flourished during tough times is hoping history can repeat itself.

title: Royal Philips Plans to Cut 4,000 Jobs
description: In a further sign of the slowdown cascading over Europe from the United States, Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands, the Continent's leading electronics manufacturer, said today that it would shed a further 4,000 jobs, bringing its total for the year to more than 10,000.

title: Political Climate Complicates Food Shortage in Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe faces a food shortage in the coming months, and while such shortages are not unknown in the country, this time the reasons behind it -- and the ways out of it -- are especially complex, aid officials say.

title: Filming the Comic and the Absurd in Czech History
description: PRAGUE  Try as he might, Jan Hrebejk could never conjure up the time machine that he had longed for as a child, but decades later he has found a better way to bend time to his will. Using a filmmaker's wizardry, he is resurrecting memories buried by the enforced forgetting of the Soviet years, filming the stories of a nation finally able to reclaim its history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEAVEY, ESSIE, MATRIARCH
description: SEAVEY-Essie, Matriarch. July 12, 1905-July 14, 2001. Mourned by her devoted sons Robert and Gilbert, her daughters-in-law, grandchildren, great - grandchildren, nieces and nephews and extended family. Intelligent, warm and witty, Essie enjoyed a rich life, a happy marriage, many close friends and a large, loving family. Proud of her family's accomplishments, she contributed her unfailing love and support as she urged all to their goals. We will all deeply miss Grandma Essie and will strive to emulate her long and wonderful life. Her family

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: South Brunswick: Stolen Parts Sold On Ebay
description: A worker at the Volkswagen warehouse here told the police that he had stolen parts and then sold them on eBay, the police said yesterday. The worker, Glenn Feigenbaum, 43, was charged with theft and fencing on Monday after he sold stolen parts on the auction Web site to an undercover detective, the police said. The police were searching warehouse records yesterday to determine how much had been stolen but said that at least $20,000 in parts so far had been sold. A woman who answered the telephone yesterday at Mr. Feigenbaum's house refused to comment.

title: Democrats Stand on Both Sides of Faith Bill
description: Flanked by religious and civil rights leaders, Democratic members of Congress made a final plea today against legislation to funnel more federal money to religious groups for social services, warning that the measure would undermine the rights of minorities and women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCCHIO, DAVID SCOTT
description: ROCCHIO-David Scott, 37. Of Bedford Hills, NY, died on July 17, 2001 at home. Graduate of the School of Visual Arts. Son of Thomas and Joanne of Bedford Hills. Brother of Paul C. of Alexandria, VA and Matthew L. of Goldens Bridge, NY. Uncle of Zoe C. Rocchio of Alexandria, VA. Grandson of Bettina Rocchio of Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY on Wednesday and Thursday from 24 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, Mt. Kisco, NY Friday at 10:00 AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cancer Research Foundation of America, 1600 Duke Street, Alexandria, VA. 22314, ''in memory of David Rocchio.''

title: An Arrest in 6 Attacks on Women in Brooklyn
description: A 30-year-old man was arrested yesterday in connection with six attacks since 1999, including rapes, attempted rapes and robberies. The victims were women in their 20's in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Greenpoint and Williamsburg, investigators said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Bearing Maker Cuts Jobs
description: A maker of roller bearings, SKF, plans to cut more jobs and drop production about 10 percent this quarter. The outlook eclipsed a 22 percent increase in second-quarter income. Net income rose to 520 million kronor, or $48 million, from 427 million kronor a year earlier. Sales climbed 11 percent, to 11.5 billion kronor.

title: A Set of Chinoiserie for Everyday
description: A fresh, more casual look in chinoiserie dinnerware seems just right with this summer's renewed interest in the style. Canton, a new red and blue pattern, also happens to be less expensive than the familiar formal blue and white. It depicts a farmer of yore in his field, an appropriate enough scene for backyard entertaining. A five-piece place setting is $42. A teapot, sugar bowl and creamer set is $70. Canton is made in China and is sold at Homenature, 255 Main Street, Amagansett, N.Y., (631) 267-6647.

title: Microsoft Asks Court for Rehearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Three weeks after claiming to be victorious in its antitrust appeal, the Microsoft Corporation asked a federal appeals court today to reconsider an important part of its decision about product design that could have significant implications for the new operating system that the giant software company plans to begin selling soon.

title: Webber Plays Hamlet, And Kings Must Wait
description: Most National Basketball Association executives had given up hope of landing Chris Webber, figuring the All-Star forward was on the brink of re-signing with the Sacramento Kings for the second-largest contract in league history -- an estimated $123 million over seven years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Ultimatum For The Rev. Newlywed
description: The Vatican is giving Emanuel Milingo -- the 71-year-old Zambian archbishop who was married to a Korean doctor in a Manhattan ceremony by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon last May -- until Aug. 20 to renounce his marriage and new faith or be excommunicated. In another edict, also signed by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger on Monday, the Roman Catholic Church announced that owing to deep doctrinal differences, it no longer considered Mormon baptisms valid. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Immigration Nominee Could Face Firestorm at Hearing Today
description: With Capitol Hill roiling over the possibility that President Bush will back a plan to let millions of illegal Mexican immigrants earn legal residency, the first official target for lawmakers' queries and criticisms will be an untested player in an unfolding geopolitical drama.

title: Follow That Watermelon!
description: WHILE we have become familiar with things like blueberries from Maine and tomatoes from New Jersey, there is some produce, like watermelon, that seems to have no origin. They are just something that you know will be there, piled high in your grocery store throughout the summer. Every day, tons and tons of them arrive in the city, just hours out of the field, and as they disperse to grocery stores, markets and bodegas, all traces of where they came from disappear.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Keating's Wife Is Front-Runner
description: A new poll shows that Cathy Keating, the wife of Gov. Frank Keating, is the early leader for the Republican nomination for a Congressional seat from Tulsa. The poll, commissioned by The Tulsa World, showed Ms. Keating as the choice of 34 percent compared with 17 percent for her closest rival, State Representative John Sullivan, a Tulsa Republican. The poll of 403 registered voters had a margin of error of seven percentage points. The incumbent, Steve Largent, a Republican, plans to resign on Nov. 29 to run for governor. Mr. Keating is barred from seeking a third term. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Business Travel; The long-term market for corporate jets continues to look up.
description: AIRPLANE makers will produce about 775 corporate jets in 2001, a record. From this year through 2010, the production of corporate jets will increase 80 percent over the previous 10 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the disputed renovation of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist in Milwaukee carried an outdated artist's rendering of the interior. Later changes have placed a crucifix above the altar and moved the pulpit and the bishop's seat forward into the church.

title: Former State Worker Is Charged in $100,000 Identity Theft Plot
description: A former employee of the State Insurance Fund has been accused of stealing the identities of thousands of people, identities that the authorities say she and others used to order at least $100,000 worth of goods.

title: Eugene Brooks, 80, a Lawyer and Poet
description: Eugene Brooks, a lawyer and writer who gave frequent readings with his brother, the poet Allen Ginsberg, died on Wednesday. He was 80.

title: Preschool for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: E-Books In Library Of Congress
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies has submitted the first e-books for electronic copyright registration to the United States Copyright Office, a spokesman for the Library of Congress said yesterday. The two e-books, ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Wireless Web'' and ''The Business Week Guide to the Best Business Schools,'' were the first full-length electronic books transmitted over the Internet and processed for copyright approval entirely in digital format. In addition to administering the copyright law, the copyright office creates and maintains the public record of copyright registrations and recorded documents and obtains copies of works for the collections of the Library of Congress; the authenticity and integrity of the digital submissions are checked through digital signatures, officials said. Robert Bolick, director of new business development at McGraw-Hill, praised the copyright office and the Library of Congress for ''farsightedness'' in its effort to build digital collections. ''Readers and publishers should be applauding,'' Mr. Bolick said.

title: Free Trade Has to Be Managed
description: As the presidents and prime ministers of the seven industrialized nations prepare to gather later this week in Genoa, Italy, the global economy has come to resemble a balloon rapidly losing air. The world's three largest economies -- in the United States, the European Union and Japan -- are slumping, and the financial and trading connections among them are reinforcing the downward spiral. Emerging markets from Argentina to Turkey to Indonesia have serious financial problems, too, all of which are made worse by the slowing of the world's major economies. Corporate profits everywhere are evaporating, and stock markets are weakening.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK MINEOLA: EVICTION CODE LIKELY TO BE SOFTENED The Nassau County Legislature has approved a bill that would soften what critics say is an overly harsh eviction code. In the past, landlords placed evicted tenants' possessions on the sidewalk, a practice that the village of Hempstead challenged on the ground that it violated a local anti-littering law. The new bill, which the Legislature passed Monday and which the county executive is expected to sign, would require that landlords move tenants' belongings into storage and pay for 30 days of storage. Martin A. Shlufman, a lawyer for the Apartment House Council of Nassau County, a coalition of apartment building owners, said many of his members were unhappy with the measure but were not likely to fight it.   Elissa Gootman (NYT) ALBANY: PESTICIDE USE DECLINES The use of chemicals by businesses, excluding farms, to kill insects and weeds was down significantly in New York State in 1999, according to final figures for the year released by the State Department of Environmental Conservation. About 20.9 million pounds and 2.4 million gallons of pesticides and herbicides were applied in 1999, down from 23.9 million pounds and 3.6 million gallons in 1998. Leading users were Suffolk County, with 2.1 million pounds and 373,000 gallons, and Brooklyn, with nearly 2.1 million pounds and 97,000 gallons. The state health commissioner, Dr. Antonia Novello, said the reduction would help protect drinking-water supplies.   (AP) QUEENS: TRANSIT WORKER ELECTROCUTED A transit worker died early yesterday after he tripped and fell onto the electrified third rail of a subway track in Queens, New York City Transit said. The worker, Samuel McPhaul, 49, a nine-year city transit employee, was working on the track for the E and F lines north of the Grand Avenue station in Queens when he fell onto the rail, which remains electrified during routine maintenance work.   Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Lazard Hires Executive
description: The international investment bank Lazard L.L.C. announced yesterday that it had hired Laurence Grafstein to run its global telecommunications practice. The bank said that Mr. Grafstein, 40, had also become a managing director. Previously, Mr. Grafstein ran the telecommunications, media and technology group at Wasserstein Perella & Company and the global telecommunications group at Credit Suisse First Boston. Most recently, Mr. Grafstein was a managing director at Gramercy Communications Partners, a private investment firm in Manhattan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A world where some live in comfort and plenty, while half of the human race lives on less than $2 a day, is neither just, nor stable.''

title: F.B.I. Check Finds Laptops And Weapons Are Missing
description: An internal F.B.I. inventory has found that 449 firearms and 184 laptop computers, including one containing classified data, are missing or have been stolen, bureau officials said today, acknowledging what appears to be another lapse at an agency already battered by criticism of its managerial practices.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Official Resigns
description: The transport minister, Enis Oksuz, whose opposition to the sale of the state phone company helped undermine confidence in the government, resigned after the currency had its biggest one-day decline in four months. Mr. Oksuz had stalled efforts to replace political appointees on the board of the utility Turk Telekomunikasyon, as demanded by the International Monetary Fund. That contributed to decisions by the I.M.F. and the World Bank to hold up $3.2 billion in loans. While the money was released this week, confidence in the government has dwindled. The lira fell 7.7 percent yesterday, to 1.5 million to the dollar.

title: In France, It's Finally Time for Tea
description: THIS is the summer France discovered th glac parfum or flavored iced tea, if you please.

title: 3 Routes to the Heart of Africa Out Loud; Squeals Show the Winner
description: Musicians face new audiences with hope and calculation, eager to recruit new fans. The concerts on Friday and Monday nights at La Guardia High School in the Lincoln Center Festival's Africa Out Loud series tested three strategies: on Friday night, folklore-style explanations from the South African group Amampondo and an effort to meet pop partway from Cheikh L (who was born in Burkina Faso but plays Senegalese rock via Paris), and on Monday, two hours of home-style rump-shaking from Koffi Olomide's Quartier Latin, from Congo. Both concerts sparked rare behavior from an indoor audience at Lincoln Center: dancing from the seats onto the stage.

title: At Cheney's House, 186,000 Points of Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Encores Arent Easy at the British Open
description: There has not been a back-to-back winner of the British Open since Tom Watson won in 1982 and 83, the longest current span that any major has gone without a repeat winner. Here is a list of British Open winners since 1983, and how they fared in the Open the following year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Levy Warns Budget Cuts May Threaten Bilingual Plan
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy warned members of the Board of Education yesterday that their recently approved overhaul of bilingual education programs might have to be postponed because City Hall has not allocated enough money to pay for the changes.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suit Fights Bush Drug Plan
description: Two national organizations representing drugstores and pharmacists filed suit in federal court to block President Bush's plan to endorse drug discount cards issued to Medicare beneficiaries by private companies. The plaintiffs, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores and the National Community Pharmacists Association, said the government devised the program in secret meetings with private industry in violation of federal law. Robert Pear (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: On To Cambodia
description: Kim Yong Nam, North Korea's No. 2 leader, got a hero's welcome to Cambodia, the last stop in a tour that took him to Vietnam and Laos. King Norodom Sihanouk, who lived in exile in Pyongyang in the 1970's, and his son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, welcomed Mr. Kim at the airport in Phnom Penh. Both Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Hark, Golden Lads and Girls, Was That a Helicopter?
description: Here is a rarity: a ''Cymbeline'' in which all the tangled plotlines are clear. Since he started Gorilla Rep nine years ago to perform free classics in parks and other public spaces, Christopher Carter Sanderson has insisted that company members performing Shakespeare forget modern psychology and literary criticism and find characters and action solely in the playwright's words. The company's ''Cymbeline'' in Riverside Park vindicates that approach impressively.

title: Stem Cells and Delicate Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data: A College Paper's Role in the Microsoft Appeal
description: The Financial Times. The New Yorker. The New York Times . The Washington Post . The Wall Street Journal.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: No More Trash Burning At Home
description: State residents will no longer have the freedom to burn trash in their yards, under a measure signed into law by Gov. Jeanne Shaheen. Governor Shaneen, a Democrat, said that items like PVC plastic and treated wood burned in low-temperature fires released 17 percent of dioxins, chemicals linked to cancer, in the state. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Johnson Is Not Retiring, According to His Agent
description: George Bass, the agent for Larry Johnson, thought the Knicks acted wisely in acquiring Clarence Weatherspoon last weekend.

title: Bush's Words: 'To Build This Better World'
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks today to the World Bank, as provided by the White House press office:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Casino Talks Continue
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that no agreement was imminent between his administration and the St. Regis Mohawks to establish a casino in the Catskills, but that talks were continuing. ''I certainly have supported having a casino or two casinos in the Catskills and we'll continue to negotiate and try to reach agreement,'' he said. In addition, the Seneca Indians want to build as many as three casinos in western New York. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, ALAN STUART
description: GRAHAM-Alan Stuart. 77 years old. Born in New York, has lived in Paris, France for over 50 years, worked as a designer and interior decorator. Loving son of the late Arthur and Sara (Nee Cohen) Goldman. Beloved cousin of Elaine Udelsohn of Memphis, TN., Malcolm Cohen of San Antonio, TX. and many more generations of cousins. Funeral services and interment will be at the Baltimore Hebrew cemetery, Baltimore, MD. on Thursday, July 19 at 12 noon. For more information call Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc., 800-338-1701

title: State Open: The Black Course Gets Test Drive
description: It is called the Black Course, and it has achieved an almost mythic status. The most challenging of five public courses at Bethpage State Park, which will be the site of the United States Open next year, gave a hint of things to come for the players who teed off today in the Mony New York State Open.

title: One Agency Closes; Two Others Merge
description: A small New York agency is closing after losing its biggest account and two agencies in New England have agreed to merge.

title: No Prosecution For Teenagers In Fatal Blaze
description: One of the deadliest fires ever for New York City firefighters, a raging blaze at a hardware store in Queens that killed three firefighters last month, was ruled an accident yesterday. Law enforcement and Fire Department officials said the two teenagers whose horseplay led to the fire would not face criminal charges.

title: Oilers Said to Have Gotten Rights to Flyers' Lindros; Rangers Sign Ciger
description: While the Rangers announced a signing yesterday that they had completed Saturday, of the 32-year-old left wing Zdeno Ciger, who played the last five seasons in his native Slovakia, word of a potential blockbuster deal circulated through the N.H.L.

title: Molinari Rides Into the Sunset as Bloomberg's Sidekick
description: Michael R. Bloomberg logged his 12th campaign appearance in Staten Island on Saturday night, taking in a fireworks display and a Beatlemania concert on South Beach. And once again, Guy V. Molinari, who is retiring as Staten Island borough president, was there at Mr. Bloomberg's side, escorting him through the closest thing there is to a Republican stronghold in New York City.

title: Triangular Diplomacy
description: The new treaty of ''friendship and cooperation'' between Russia and China, signed Monday by Presidents Vladimir Putin and Jiang Zemin, does not signal a return to cold-war tensions with the United States. But it does represent an effort by the Russians and Chinese to strengthen their hands in future diplomatic dealings with Washington. Triangular diplomacy is back, in a new form and with diminished strategic significance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAY, GEORGE
description: SHAY-George. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved father of our devoted member Scott Shay. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Pequots Withdraw Casino Plan
description: The Eastern Pequot Indians have withdrawn their plans to build a $500 million waterfront casino here after the City Council voted Monday night to oppose the project. The federal Bureau of Indian Affairs has granted preliminary tribal recognition to the Eastern Pequots. They hope to receive full recognition by year's end, giving them the right to pursue casino gambling projects. The City Council unanimously passed a resolution opposing the Pequots' plan for a casino complex at City Pier. Nancy Tyler, a Pequot spokeswoman, said the Eastern Pequots were studying other potential sites. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: U.S.-Based Scholar To Be Tried in China
description: Gao Zhan, a permanent United States resident accused of spying for Taiwan, has been indicted and will probably stand trial this month in Beijing, one of her lawyers said.

title: Learning to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Stem Cells and Delicate Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: A New African Union
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Hearing On Articulated Buses
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on possible dangers to pedestrians and vehicles from articulated buses, which are 60 feet long -- 20 feet longer than most buses -- and in two sections. Second-floor committee room, City Hall, Manhattan, 11 a.m. Information: (718) 633-9400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLEY, REVEREND BROTHER JOSEPH J., C.F.C.
description: HANLEY - Reverend Brother Joseph J., C.F.C. on July 16, 2001. Devoted son of the late Joseph J. and Mary Irene (nee Curley) Hanley. Loving brother of Kate Healy, John J. Hanley, R. Patrick Hanley, Cecilia Greco and Peggy Ann Mastropietro. Nephew, cousin, uncle, grand-Uncle and brother-inlaw; Adopted relation and devoted friend to ''Treasured Multitudes'' Member of the Congregation of Christian Brothers (formerly, the Brothers of the Christian Schools of Ireland). Calling hours are Thursday, July, 19, 2001 at Sacred Heart of Jesus Church, 457 West 51st Street, NYC from 3-5PM & 79PM. And on Friday, July 20, 2001 at St. Joseph's Residence, 30 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle, NY from 3-5PM & 7-9PM. Mass of the Resurrection will be Saturday, July 21, 2001, 10AM at Holy Family Church, Mayflower Ave. New Rochelle, NY. Interment to follow at Christian Brothers Cemetery, West Park, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Joseph's Care Center, 30 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle, New York 10804.

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Former Hotel Is Being Reborn as Small Offices
description: The owner of the 15-story former Knickerbocker Hotel in Times Square is thinking small: it wants to turn the top seven floors into office space for small tenants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, MILDRED ELLIS
description: REYNOLDS-Mildred Ellis. Of Bridgeport, CT, formerly of New York City and Washington, CT, died July 15 at the age of 101. She is survived by her son David C. Reynolds, two grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the First Congregational Church, 6 Kirby Road, Washington, CT., on Monday, July 23, 2001 at 2:00 PM. Interment will follow at Washington Green Cemetery.

title: Crispy Chops Grilled to a T
description: LAMB chops are among the best meats to grill. Although they tend to catch fire, they cook so quickly -- three minutes a side is usually more than enough -- that there is no time for them to char, and the fire makes the exterior extra crisp. Team them with a cool, refreshing cucumber salad and you have the centerpiece of a meal that needs little more than a good piece of bread to make it complete.

title: THE BOSS; Taking Charge in the Huddle
description: My father was a player and coach in the N.F.L. for more than 40 years. In 1957, when he first started coaching, I was 8, and I used to get so emotionally involved that I'd get sick to my stomach before games.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARBER, ROBERT D.
description: FARBER-Robert D. July 18, 1948December 23, 1995. Every minute of every day I am so proud you are my brother. With never ending love, Lindy and your family.

title: Kentucky Breeding Industry Lifted by Keeneland Sale
description: Kentucky's thoroughbred breeding industry, severely affected by the deaths of an estimated 2,500 foals and fetuses this past spring, received a boost Monday night and last night when 89 horses brought a gross of more than $63.2 million at the 58th edition of Keeneland's annual July Yearling Sale.

title: COMCAST BID MAY BE TOPIC AT BOARD MEETING OF AT&T
description: AT&T directors began their monthly meeting last night in Denver, home to the cable television operation, AT&T Broadband, that is the target of a $44.5 billion unsolicited acquisition bid by the Comcast Corporation, people close to AT&T said. The meeting, which was scheduled for Denver before Comcast made its bid on July 8, is supposed to run through today, the people said. It is possible that the board will authorize a response to Comcast's offer at the meeting. It is also possible that the board will consider potential deals with other companies, including AOL Time Warner. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Trade With China
description: Six of Taiwan's most powerful executives, including the chairman of Compal Electronics, one of the world's largest laptop computer makers, urged the government to relax restrictions on trade with China in an effort to bolster Taiwan's economy. The executives asked the government to lift curbs on investment in China and allow tourists from the mainland. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Official Defends Her Conduct In the Vote Counting in Florida
description: Responding to an article in The New York Times about the treatment of absentee ballots last November in the presidential election in Florida, Secretary of State Katherine Harris has defended her role in the election, saying she acted properly and without bias.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 2 Tory Finalists Chosen
description: Conservative members of Parliament chose Kenneth Clarke and Iain Duncan Smith as the two candidates from whom the 330,000 party members will select a leader in September to replace William Hague, who is stepping down after the party's election loss last month. Eliminated in a final knockout vote was the original front-runner in a five-man field, Michael Portillo, with 53 votes, to Mr. Duncan Smith's 54 and Mr. Clarke's 59. The new contest offers a choice between a moderate in favor of Britain's adopting the European common currency, Mr. Clarke, and a right-winger deeply opposed to exchanging the pound for the euro, Mr. Duncan Smith. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, MOLLIE
description: PLOTKIN-Mollie, 90. Of NYC, on July 16th, 2001. Devoted mother of Carol and son-in-law, Ken, grandmother of Rhona, Larry and Kris, great-grandmother of Morgan, Ashton and Cassidy, sister of Jules Miller and sister-in-law of Gertrude Miller, Blanche Weiskopf, Betty Markson and Goldie Miller. Her love, wit and intellect will be sorely missed.

title: 2 Drop Out of Democratic Primary in the Bronx
description: The field of candidates for the Democratic nomination for Bronx borough president diminished yesterday, as two candidates said they would not run in the primary.

title: Publisher to Appeal Digital-Rights Ruling
description: The book publishing giant Random House said yesterday that it would appeal a district court's decision that a book contract does not automatically include the exclusive right to publish digital editions of the same text.

title: ARTS ABROAD; Filming the Comic and the Absurd in Czech History
description: Try as he might, Jan Hrebejk could never conjure up the time machine that he had longed for as a child, but decades later he has found a better way to bend time to his will. Using a filmmaker's wizardry, he is resurrecting memories buried by the enforced forgetting of the Soviet years, filming the stories of a nation finally able to reclaim its history.

title: A Filmmaker and a Castle, Both With a View
description: A SEASIDE Shangri-La that costs an immodest $50 million, a potentially record price even for the greed-is-good-glutted Hamptons, must be hard to miss. But unless you're boating in from the Atlantic -- if so, watch out: those underwater rocks from the glacial deposit this estate straddles are murder on boat bellies -- forget that silly selling point the real estate agents call curb appeal. This is Montauk, the final frontier, and occasionally the spurner, of Hamptons affectation. There are no curbs. There is, however, cliff appeal.

title: Knife Maker Prefers To Step Back Into the Past
description: A FEW decades ago, knife manufacturers introduced home cooks to stainless steel, seducing them with its resistance to rust and its ability to hold a respectable edge. The traditional carbon steel knife didn't stand a chance. Weighed against stainless, it seemed a relic of a more primitive age.

title: Mob Soldier Faces a Return To Jail for Parole Violations
description: A mobster who shot his way into the annals of organized-crime history more than 20 years ago by taking part in one of the most storied of mob executions is in trouble once again.

title: A Mideast Broker: U.S., Not Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: An Increase In Prices
description: Consumer prices in Britain rose in June for the second consecutive month, reaching a two-year high and surprising economists who had expected a smaller increase. The jump fanned speculation that the Bank of England would raise interest rates.
