The increase in prices, attributed to higher food costs resulting from poor harvests and foot-and-mouth disease, meant that retail prices excluding home-loan interest were 2.4 percent higher than they were a year ago, just shy of the Bank of England's 2.5 percent inflation target. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; The Poison Threatening The Umpires
description: IT'S one of baseball's oldest stories. Bill Klem, the legendary umpire who originated thrusting a right arm upward to denote a strike nearly a century ago, was being razzed by a female fan. ''Klem,'' she yelled, ''if you were my husband, I'd put poison in your coffee.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALMON, SAMUEL ALTER
description: ALMON-Samuel Alter. Of West New York, New Jersey. Companion of Jerry Belitz. Son of Dorothy Glassberg Almon. Brother of Renee and Charles Almon. Many nieces and nephews. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J. Thursday, 11AM. (1-800-378-1892).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENSER, SIDNEY AND RUTH
description: GENSER-Sidney and Ruth. On this anniversary and always, you are thought of and missed. Enjoy dancing in the stars. Love, Barbara

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Higher Bid For Montedison
description: Italenergia, a holding company controlled by Fiat and lectricit de France, has increased its offer for Montedison to 3.07 euros a share, or $2.61, from 2.82 euros, valuing Montedison at 5.35 billion euros, or $4.5 billion, up from 4.92 billion euros under an earlier offer. The new bid leaves unchanged the terms of a secondary bid by Italenergia for Montedison's energy subsidiary, Edison. Last week, Montedison set a shareholders' meeting for Aug. 9 to replace the board but gave itself a month to block Italenergia. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Sunday with an obituary of Fred Marcellino, a book jacket designer and children's book author, was published in error. The picture, of a jacket for ''The Handmaid's Tale'' by Margaret Atwood, showed Mr. Marcellino's illustration but not his typography.

title: A Bad Call
description: Back in the 60's, John Rice, an American League umpire, was having a bad night behind the plate. He missed a few calls on balls and strikes and then, like many umpires, he tried to make up for it by calling a few the other way. But the more he tried to even things up, the worse it got. After a few innings, Mickey Mantle hollered, ''Hey, John, what's this next one going to be?''

title: Apple Offers Improvements and Price Cuts on Computers
description: Apple Computer Inc. announced a series of aggressive performance improvements and price cuts today on its desktop computers for consumers and professionals, and it previewed the first upgrade of its new OS X operating system.

title: Jerome A. Danzig, 88, Rockefeller Adviser
description: Jerome A. Danzig, whose early work in broadcasting as a reporter and a producer led to his appointment as a top adviser to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, died on Sunday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 88.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Holocaust Memorial Campaign
description: ''The Holocaust never happened'' is the provocative slogan to appear in newspaper advertisements and on billboards starting Thursday seeking donations of $2 million for the Berlin Holocaust Memorial. Under the slogan and a picture of a serene mountain lake and snow-capped mountain will be smaller type saying: ''There are still many people who make this claim. In 20 years there could be even more.'' Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Prosecutor Asks For Grand Jury In Seton Hall Fire
description: The acting Essex County prosecutor asked a judge today to convene a special grand jury to hear evidence in the Seton Hall fire that killed three freshmen in their dormitory last year.

title: Stem Cells and Delicate Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Places It Didn't Go; How a Small Success Was Puffed Into a Big Flop
description: t is one of the more confounding casualties of any Broadway season in recent memory. How could ''Seussical: The Musical,'' a show that moved producers to tears at a Toronto workshop, wind up limping its way to Broadway from a Boston tryout last fall, dismissed by critics, begging for audiences (''Mother's Day Offer! Bring Your Mom for Free!'') and shut out of the Tony Awards? Ultimately, it closed in less than six months, at a loss of $10.5 million.

title: Democrats Are Warned on Missile Stance
description: Buoyed by a successful antimissile test on Saturday, the Pentagon warned Senate Democrats today that a protracted fight over the administration's ambitious missile defense plans would undermine President Bush's effort to overhaul the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty in coming talks with Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, SHIRLEY
description: LEVIN-Shirley. On July 16, 2001. Dear sister of Ralph and Douglas, and sisters-in-law Diane and Elaine. Also survived by her nieces, nephews, great nieces and great nephews. Services, officiated by her nephew Rabbi Harry Levin, will be Wednesday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Swissair and Belgium Reach Accord on Sabena Finances
description: The financially ailing Swissair Group reached agreement today with the Belgian government to give a financial lifeline to Sabena in return for a release from Swissair's commitment to raise its ownership stake in the airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HARVEY (DR. GIZMO).
description: ROSENBERG-Harvey (Dr. Gizmo). Son of the late Helene and Henry Rosenberg. Died suddenly on July 16th. Survived by Phyllis and Paul Tobin, Mitch Tobin, Jill, Todd, Eli and Andrew Tsakiris, and Melissa Tobin. We will all miss this fascinating Renaissance man. Graveside services on Thursday, July 19th, at Mt. Judah Cemetery. Call Gutterman Chapels 516764-9400 for exact time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINK, PAUL
description: PINK-Paul. Beloved husband of Estelle. Father of Judith Goldin & Joanne Goetz. Brother of Sylvia Gelfand. Grandfather of five. Died July 15, 2001, at home in Cocoa Beach, FL. Donations may be made to Temple Israel, 7350 Lake Andrew Drive, Melbourne, Florida 32940, or United Order of True Sisters, 541 Summerset Court, Indian Harbor Beach, FL 32937, or Hospice of Wuestoff Hospital, PO Box 565002, 185 Barton Blvd, Suite C, Rockledge, Florida 32956-5002.

title: Powered By Pitching, Mets Record First Sweep
description: In hindsight, it was fun, Al Leiter said last night. He was too worked up to enjoy himself during the humid evening at Shea Stadium.

title: As Sweet as a Mango, and a Whole Lot Tidier
description: THE best way to eat a ripe mango, according to the old saying, is alone in a bathtub. Carefully ripened mango nectarines are the discreet alternative -- they might not deliver quite the same messy bliss, but they're much easier to enjoy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, NORMAN
description: SINGER-Norman. The Board and Staff of City Center are saddened by the death of Norman Singer, whose vision kept this theater alive during a critical period in its history. His commitment to the arts helped insure that City Center thrives today as a home for theater, music and dance. Judith E. Daykin, President and Executive Director City Center

title: From France, for the Berries
description: Leave it to the French to bury Reddi-wip under a swirly pouf of whipped cream. One of France's finest creameries, Isigny Ste.-Mre, has created Crme  la vanille de Madagascar (cream with Madagascar vanilla) in a spray can. Shake and squirt, and you have instant topping for summer's fresh berries, ice cream and cakes. And it lasts for months without spoiling. A 9-ounce can is $4.99 at Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street).

title: A Credible Soy Stand-In for Caviar
description: The tiny black and gray beads glistening invitingly atop squares of toast could fool the eye  but the price tag would not trick any true lover of caviar. Royal Caviar's Kaviar, made in Glendale, Calif., from soybeans, costs under $15 for 4.4 ounces, compared with $100 or so an ounce for the best Caspian Sea sturgeon eggs.

title: A Credible Soy Stand-In for Caviar
description: The tiny black and gray beads glistening invitingly atop squares of toast could fool the eye -- but the price tag would not trick any true lover of caviar. Royal Caviar's Kaviar, made in Glendale, Calif., from soybeans, costs under $15 for 4.4 ounces, compared with $100 or so an ounce for the best Caspian Sea sturgeon eggs.

title: Bristol-Myers To Take Stake In Exelixis Inc.
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb will take a small stake in Exelixis Inc., a genomics company, and work with it to develop a new class of cancer drugs, the companies are expected to announce today.

title: Earnings at Apple Beat Expectations; Sales Miss Target
description: Apple Computer Inc. reported quarterly earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations, but its sales were slightly below analysts' estimates.

title: Woods's Arsenal Honed For Blustery Conditions
description: By 6:15 local time today, Tiger Woods was already on the golf course at Royal Lytham and St. Annes, playing a practice round with Mark O'Meara, Thomas Bjorn and Adam Scott.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: A Raise For Women On Faculties
description: The University of Maine system is planning to give raises to about 200 female faculty members because a two-year study found a gap in salaries between the sexes. The study compared paychecks, taking into account tenure, degrees, rank and the like. It found the greatest gap at the University of Maine at Augusta: men earned on average $3,079 more than women. The raises are retroactive to July, 1, 2000. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Eviction Code Likely To Be Softened
description: The Nassau County Legislature has approved a bill that would soften what critics say is an overly harsh eviction code. In the past, landlords placed evicted tenants' possessions on the sidewalk, a practice that the village of Hempstead challenged on the ground that it violated a local anti-littering law. The new bill, which the Legislature passed Monday and which the county executive is expected to sign, would require that landlords move tenants' belongings into storage and pay for 30 days of storage. Martin A. Shlufman, a lawyer for the Apartment House Council of Nassau County, a coalition of apartment building owners, said many of his members were unhappy with the measure but were not likely to fight it. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: No Wiseguys For 'X-Files'
description: Fox executives, hoping to squeeze one more year out of what has been the network's biggest drama hit, ''The X-Files,'' emitted two long sighs of relief yesterday.

title: A Real Estate Mystery On Proper Nantucket
description: All the other houses on Main Street present perfect faces to the world, their trim flawless, their shingles tastefully weathered, their clematis climbing and their roses profuse. This, after all, is the heart of the historic district on this most proudly historic of islands.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Veritas Cuts Outlook
description: Citing the weak economy, Veritas Software, the leading independent vendor of data storage software, said yesterday that it expected revenue to grow 25 percent to 35 percent during the rest of the year, not 35 percent to 50 percent as previously projected. The cautionary note came as Veritas, based in Mountain View, Calif., reported a second-quarter loss of $129 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenue of $390 million, up 42 percent from a year earlier. Pro forma income, as Veritas calls profits before accounting costs for acquisitions and other items not related to its business operations, reached $80 million, up 41 percent from a year earlier. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Cold Dinners

title: Recipe: Watermelon Gazpacho
description: Time: 10 minutes, plus 2 hours' chilling time 3 very ripe tomatoes, cored and seeded

title: China Reports 7.8% Growth in Economy
description: China's economy grew 7.8 percent in the second quarter, making it an island of economic strength in a region again facing recession after recovering only briefly from a devastating economic crisis four years ago.

title: MAYTAG REPORTS THAT QUARTERLY PROFITS FELL 71%
description: The Maytag Corporation said second-quarter profit fell 71 percent as sales of its Hoover vacuum cleaners slowed. Net income for Maytag, which makes Maytag, Jenn-Air and Magic Chef appliances, fell to $21.8 million from $75.7 million a year ago, said the company, based in Newton, Iowa. Net income rose to $1.08 a share from 92 cents because of an accounting change, the company said. Sales fell to $1.07 billion from $1.1 billion. The company said its profit was hurt when retailers like Wal-Mart Stores and the Kmart Corporation ordered cheaper vacuums and delayed orders for higher-priced machines. The chief executive, Ralph F. Hake, said Maytag expected new products to help sales. Shares rose 69 cents, to $31.90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALK, SUE ROSENBERG
description: ZALK-Sue Rosenberg. The Board of Directors and staff of the Feminist Press at CUNY mourn the sudden loss of our colleague, collaborator and friend, Sue Rosenberg Zalk. Sue served for a decade as a member & secretary of our board and chaired our transition and search committees. Her energy, intelligence, leadership, and stalwart support have made an incalculable contribution to our work and will be deeply missed.

title: Europeans Doubt U.S. Can Replace Blood Imports
description: European blood-bank officials told a top American official on blood safety today that they were skeptical that the United States could easily replace blood imports from Europe if a proposed ban goes into place. The Europeans warned that an interruption in the supply would be impossible to reverse in the foreseeable future.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Strong Rally in Stocks On Positive Profit Reports

title: EXCEPTION RULED IN SEX CRIME LAW
description: New Jersey's highest court ruled today that children who are found guilty of sexual offenses before age 14 are not automatically subject to decades of public warnings about them and their crimes.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Netzero Founders Resign
description: Just weeks after agreeing to merge with its rival, Juno Online, NetZero said four of its founders -- including the company's president -- had resigned to start another company. The four -- Ronald Burr, NetZero's president; Stacy Haitsuka, senior vice president for technology; Harold McKenzie, vice president for software; and Marwan Zebian, vice president for networking and communications -- are leaving to form Layer2Networks, a broadband networking company. Mark R. Goldston, chairman and chief executive, will hold those posts at United Online, which was formed by the NetZero-Juno merger last month. The NetZero service, started in 1998, was one of the first advertising-supported free Internet service providers. In recent months, however, both NetZero and Juno have suffered as a result of the contracting online advertising market. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Math Teacher Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: A Movable Chef Stirs Things Up in Park Slope
description: THE subtle blue storefront of Bistro St. Mark's sits on a nondescript block on the fringe of Park Slope. It blends so inconspicuously with the surroundings that on my first visit I walked by twice before realizing, with a double take, that I was right at the door. A look at the menu provokes a double take, too, because this is no simple bistro fare. Like al di l in Park Slope and the Grocery in Carroll Gardens, two other leaders in the Brooklyn dining revolution, Bistro St. Mark's uses the guise of neighborhood conviviality to cloak serious and creative cooking.

title: Upper Vedeno Journal; Chechen Warlord Fights Rebels for Mother Russia
description: Raybek Tovzayev is a Chechen warlord who fights on the side of Mother Russia against the rebels of his homeland whom he calls bandits.

title: Tupperware to Sell Products in SuperTarget Stores
description: Tupperware, the storage- and serving- container company that has sought to expand its business beyond the traditional party by selling goods in mall kiosks, on the Internet and on the Home Shopping Network, has entered into its first agreement with a national retail chain.

title: Percentage of Minority Drivers Stopped on Turnpike Rises Again
description: The percentage of minorities arrested during traffic stops on the New Jersey Turnpike by the state police is back up to the levels of 1997 and 1998, before state authorities admitted that troopers had engaged in racial profiling, according to a report released yesterday. But overall, the percentage of minorities stopped and arrested statewide rose only slightly in the period covered by the report.

title: Vallone Would Aid City Riders By Adding Suburban Train Stops
description: Saying that New York was alone among large cities in having decreased its train track mileage since the 1940's, Peter F. Vallone outlined a plan yesterday to expand city train service using existing tracks and stations.

title: Debating Who Controls Holocaust Artifacts
description: As the years lengthen and survivors die off, the memory of the Holocaust is increasingly embodied in written accounts and artifacts. But who owns this physical evidence?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITTLESON, MARIANNE
description: ITTLESON-Marianne. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Henry Anthony. Loving mother of Philip and his wife Margot, Christina and her husband Sean and Stephanie. Cherished grandmother of Carlin, Henry and Fayre. Devoted sister of Nina, Cecilia, Agneta and Christian. Loving daughter of Alfhild Sundby. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC, on Sunday, July 22, 2001, 5-8 PM. Service Monday, July 23, 2001 at 11 AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., NYC. Cemetery arrangements private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 or Hollings Cancer Center, Medical University of South Carolina.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Revealed: The Answer to Question 27

title: Stem Cells and Delicate Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Kittles Enrolls In Summer School
description: Midway through the first quarter of an otherwise meaningless summer league game at UMass-Boston, Kerry Kittles, the Nets guard, drove the baseline and cocked his arm to attempt a dunk this afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLSOM, MRS. PATRICIA C.
description: FOLSOM-Mrs. Patricia C. A gracious and great lady has been lost. The Board of Trustees of the Optometric Center of New York join with the College community of the SUNY College of Optometry in mourning the loss of Pat Folsom, devoted wife of Dr. William Folsom. She was intimately associated with the activities of our Foundation and with the students of the College for more than forty years. She believed deeply in the talents of young women to pursue a professional career in the profession of optometry and devoted most of her life to furthering the profession. We extend to Dr. Folsom, our esteemed colleague and fellow Trustee, our profound coldolences at this difficult time. Ms. Kim Eierman, President, Board of Trustees Optometric Center of New York and Dr. Alden N. Haffner, President, SUNY College of Optometry 33 West 42 Street New York, N.Y. 10036-8003

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: New Government For Montenegro
description: President Vojislav Kostunica has asked a former Montenegro finance minister, Dragisa Pesic, to form a new federal government, ending the political uncertainty since the government collapsed after Slobodan Milosevic's transfer to The Hague last month. Mr. Kostunica gave the new government to the end of August to define new relations between Serbia and Montenegro within the Yugoslav Federation. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Tagliabue Rejects Appeal of Fine By Ravens' Lewis
description: The saga of Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis, who went from murder suspect to Super Bowl most valuable player, has come to a close with a recent ruling by Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League. Tagliabue has denied Lewis's appeal of a six-figure fine imposed on him by the league, an N.F.L. official confirmed yesterday.

title: Katharine Graham
description: In the annals of journalism, Katharine Graham, who died yesterday at 84, will be best known for supporting her reporters' and editors' aggressive pursuit of the Watergate scandal in The Washington Post, which led to the resignation of President Richard Nixon. The Post earned a Pulitzer Prize, and Mrs. Graham and her team helped foster a generation of investigative reporters. Even before playing this central role in the century's iconic political saga, Mrs. Graham had proved her mettle as a publisher by overruling her lawyers and supporting The New York Times in the historic confrontation with the government over the publication of the Pentagon Papers.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Rate Lowered
description: The Bank of Canada has lowered its target for overnight interest rates a quarter percentage point, to 4.25 percent, citing a slowdown in the economy. Commercial banks responded by cutting the prime lending rate by a similar margin, to 6 percent, effective today. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: BUSH URGES SHIFT TO DIRECT GRANTS FOR POOR NATIONS
description: President Bush called today for a major change in the way rich nations help poorer countries, proposing that up to 50 percent of aid to those countries from the World Bank and similar institutions be given as direct grants rather than loans for needs like education and health.

title: At Cheney's House, 186,000 Points of Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadcasters Ask Senate To Let F.C.C. Loosen Rules
description: As federal regulators prepare to loosen or eliminate the rules that have restricted the largest broadcasters from growing bigger and owning newspapers, senior executives from Viacom and the Tribune Company asked the Senate today to let regulators proceed without intervention.

title: Apple Offers Improvements and Price Cuts on Computers
description: Apple Computer Inc. announced a series of aggressive performance improvements and price cuts today on its desktop computers for consumers and professionals, and it previewed the first upgrade of its new OS X operating system.

title: Emmys Under Fire
description: WB showed a few programs last year that were beloved by the television critics, ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' and ''Gilmore Girls'' chief among them.

title: Minimum Wage Can Be Bumped Above Minimal
description: Another exhausting eight-hour shift had ended for Mussie Habetezion, a garage attendant, but his workday was far from over. He still had to endure an eight-hour overnight shift at the local 7-Eleven. On the days he didn't work at the 7-Eleven, he held a third job at a CVS Pharmacy.

title: Mexico Plans Limited Release of Secret Intelligence Files
description: In a move aimed at uncovering the truth about one of the most painful periods in Mexico's history, Interior Minister Santiago Creel has announced that he will allow human rights investigators to review a cache of files that had been kept secret by the federal intelligence agency.

title: Friend or Foe?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: You Have Entered The Strike Zone
description: Welcome to the strike zone, the mysterious, 17-inch-wide rectangle that was codified long ago, yet is interpreted by its paid arbiters as widely as those who love and hate Adam Sandler movies.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Profit Down 71%
description: The EMC Corporation said its earnings fell 71 percent in the second quarter after its customers cut back on spending. EMC, the leading maker of data-storage systems for businesses, said it had net income of $109 million, or 5 cents a share, including a 1-cent charge to cover the cost of staff reductions, in the second quarter. ''I cannot recall a more difficult environment in terms of technology spending than the one that has unfolded over the past few months,'' said Michael C. Ruettgers, above, EMC's chairman. The results met the scaled-back forecast the company issued on July 6, but were down sharply from $429 million, or 19 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales declined 6 percent to $2.02 billion from $2.15 billion in the year-earlier quarter. EMC's shares fell $2.18, or 10.7 percent, to $18.21. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: For the British, Bivouacking Had a Whole Other Meaning
description: Wherever British soldiers fought, they carried shrewdly engineered furniture that looked luxurious, yet the mahogany frames collapsed, horsehair-upholstered seats retracted, carved feet came off. One officer slept on a gilt-brass canopied bed (above left, and dismantled, right) with rope-twist posts and lion-paw feet. Entire dining suites fitted into footlocker-size crates. ''Britain's Portable Empire: Campaign Furniture of the Georgian, Victorian and Edwardian Periods,'' at the Katonah Museum of Art in Katonah, N.Y., until Sept. 30, shows 60 pieces. It is ''the largest agglomeration of British campaign furniture in one place probably since the Battle of Waterloo,'' said the show's curator, Nicholas A. Brawer. Adults, $3; those under 12, free. Route 22 at Jay Street; (914) 232-9555. EVE M. KAHN

title: Bush Choice Pledges Kinder, Gentler I.N.S.
description: President Bush's choice to be the nation's top immigration official distanced himself today from a 1996 Republican-sponsored law that required foreigners entering the United States without proper documents to be detained, often alongside criminals in local jails.

title: Mendoza, With Sinker, Excels as Middle Man
description: Ramiro Mendoza wears down when he works as a starter and when he throws daily as a short reliever. But Mendoza has settled into a comfortable niche in which he pitches a couple of innings every other day, and he is dominating at it.

title: Ex-Chief Of I.O.C. Remains In Hospital
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch remained hospitalized yesterday after collapsing Tuesday night in Lausanne, Switzerland, a day after he was succeeded as president of the International Olympic Committee, Olympic officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: New BMW Site Selected
description: The luxury carmaker BMW said it had selected Leipzig in eastern Germany as the site of a factory to build the 3-Series, its best-selling car. The plant will open in 2005. BMW said it was looking for a site with good transportation connections and inexpensive land. It also said that it could receive at least 280 million euros in subsidies for its investment of 1 billion euros ($860 million).

title: I.B.M. Earnings Meet Expectations
description: Underscoring its relatively strong position in the turbulent information technology sector, I.B.M. reported yesterday that it earned $1.15 a diluted share in the three months ended June 30, an 8.4 percent increase from a year earlier and a gain that was right in line with Wall Street's projections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEAVEY, ESSIE, MATRIARCH
description: SEAVEY-Essie, Matriarch. July 12, 1905-July 14, 2001. Mourned by her devoted sons Robert and Gilbert, her daughters-in-law, grandchildren, great - grandchildren, nieces and nephews and extended family. Intelligent, warm and witty, Essie enjoyed a rich life, a happy marriage, many close friends and a large, loving family. Proud of her family's accomplishments, she contributed her unfailing love and support as she urged all to their goals. We will all deeply miss Grandma Essie and will strive to emulate her long and wonderful life. Her family

title: Clemens Gives His All, Then the Yankees Give Out
description: The lingering effects of a collision with a pillow were evident on Roger Clemens's face when he walked into the visitors' clubhouse here this morning -- puffiness around the eyes, vertical hair, a semicomatose stare, all common symptoms among the travel-weary Yankees. Expecting a day off, Clemens had slept in, but his adrenaline began flowing when he heard his Yankee teammates mention that the rookie Adrian Hernndez had the flu and could not pitch the game scheduled to start in 90 minutes.

title: Drama Kings of the Wild Frontier
description: In 1803 the Louisiana Purchase opened up the American West in fact and in imagination. As settlements grew into towns and cities, performers toured them with plays, music, songs and dance. A virtual version the New York Public Library's exhibition ''Touring West'' at the library's Web site offers a look at life onstage and on the road (www.nypl.org/west/tw_subhome.shtml).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Vladimiro L. Montesinos, the former spy chief of Peru who is a subject of criminal investigations, misstated the given name of a major Colombian cocaine trafficker who was said to have made campaign contributions to Alberto K. Fujimori when he was president and Mr. Montesinos was in power. The trafficker was Pablo Escobar, not Carlos.

title: Continent's Inflation Rate Eases
description: Europe's inflation rate fell in June, and the decline, the first in five months, should pave the way for the European Central Bank to lower interest rates in the months ahead.

title: David E. Babcock, 86, Ex-Chief Of May Department Store Chain
description: David E. Babcock, a former chairman and chief executive of May Department Stores, died last Friday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 86.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Iran's W.T.O Bid Blocked
description: Iran's bid to become a member of the World Trade Organization has been blocked by the United States. Iran began its quest to be admitted to the global trade body six years ago, but its application was formally considered for the first time this year. Its application can go forward only if all 141 member countries agree. The United States trade negotiator said Washington was reviewing the matter. The United States government views Iran as a state sponsor of terrorism. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pharmacy In Trial With Grocer
description: The pharmacy chain Boots P.L.C., will begin selling products at six outlets owned by the supermarket chain J Sainsbury P.L.C. next year as part of a trial. As many as 10,000 Boots pharmaceutical and health-and-beauty products will replace Sainsbury's own lines in suburban stores. Boots has said that it is looking for ways to stay ahead of supermarkets like Tesco P.L.C., which are selling more health-and-beauty goods.

title: Microsoft Asks Court For Review
description: Three weeks after claiming to be victorious in its antitrust appeal, the Microsoft Corporation asked the appeals court today to reconsider an important part of its decision about product design that could have significant implications for the new operating system the company plans to begin selling soon.

title: Condos on the Rise, by Architectural Stars
description: TREVOR DAVIS, a New York City developer, brashly predicts that his 67-story condominium skyscraper, now rising four blocks north of the Empire State Building on Fifth Avenue, will change the Manhattan skyline forever.

title: Painting the Pictures Of a Perfect Vacation; A Vision of Lake George as a Tourist Spot, Marketed With Striking Postcard Imagery
description: The artist Martin Johnson Heade came here in 1862, checked into the finest hotel in what was already a bustling resort, strolled down to the shore and painted a scene that made it look as if he had trekked to the ragged edge of the frontier. The manicured lawns, colonnaded verandas and parasol-carrying ladies that were the hallmarks of Victorian-era tourism here were all carefully omitted. A soft bed awaited at the end of a day of arduous wilderness art.

title: Punishing Plagiarists
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers Pass on Lindros; Islanders Eye Allison
description: While Kevin Lowe, the general manager of the Edmonton Oilers, was announcing yesterday that his team had apparently failed in its attempt to acquire Eric Lindros from the Philadelphia Flyers, the Islanders were stepping up their own efforts to obtain yet another marquee center, one the Rangers have expressed interest in as well.

title: Article 2001071994008405157 -- No Title
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); }

title: 2 Agencies Selected For Drug Campaigns
description: Two drug makers have made decisions on two big assignments to handle advertising for prescription drugs aimed at consumers, with total spending estimated at $175 million to $180 million.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST HAWAII: JUDGE BLOCKS ARMY TRAINING A federal judge, siding with a group of Native Hawaiians, temporarily blocked the Army's planned live-ammunition training in a remote valley. The group contends that the training could harm endangered species and ancient Hawaiian cultural sites in the Makua Valley on Oahu. The judge, Susan Oki Mollway of Federal District Court, issued a preliminary injunction blocking the training pending an Oct. 29 hearing. (AP)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Cracking the Code Of Online Filtering
description: EVERY year the Electronic Frontier Foundation hands out its Pioneer Awards to people who have played crucial roles in the history of technology. Recipients have included visionaries like Ivan Sutherland, creator of some of the first computer graphics programs; Douglas C. Engelbart, an inventor of the mouse; and Linus Torvalds, inventor of the popular Linux operating system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESWICK, SERENA, PH.D.
description: RESWICK-Serena, Ph.D. A resident of New York for 75 years, Serena W. Reswick, Ph.D. (nee Weissmann), died at home in Lower Merion, PA, on July 15th, following a long illness. She will be remembered as a gifted and compassionate psychologist and as a loving and much loved wife, mother, sister and grandmother. She is survived by her husband, Joseph Reswick of Lower Merion, PA; her brother, Bernard Weissmann of Evanston, IL, and her daughter, Janet Reswick Long, and grandson, Daniel Joseph Long of Moylan, PA. Was also beloved sister of the late Gertrude Snelwar. Memorial service and interment will be private. Donations may be made to the research arm of the International Myeloma Foundation, www.myeloma.org, at 12650 Riverside Drive, North Hollywood, CA. 91607.

title: Vehicles That Left Telltale Evidence Behind
description: Here are a few investigations in which forensic evidence from vehicles was crucial:

title: Why Isn't the U.S. Making Friends?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Egypt, With a Pager as Your Guide
description: FORGET sending e-mail messages and checking stock quotations. The latest application for wireless hand-held devices is as a personal tour guide at a children's museum.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about Congressional debate over stem cell research gave an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a woman shown with Alyssa Thomas, a child with Rett syndrome whose parents say she could benefit from the research. The woman was Representative Constance A. Morella, Republican of Maryland, not Alyssa's mother, Daphne Thomas.

title: Twice Stolen, Twice Found: A Case of Art On the Lam
description: A Rembrandt and two rare Drer ink drawings stashed in a castle in Nazi Germany, stolen by Soviet troops and handed over to the K.G.B. only to be stolen again from an Azerbaijani museum and offered for sale by a doomed Japanese ex-wrestler trying to raise $12 million for a kidney transplant and . . .

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Suggests Fed May Reduce Rates Again

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a petition to seat a special grand jury to investigate the fatal dormitory fire last year at Seton Hall University misstated the name of the New Jersey court where the petition was filed. It was State Superior Court, not Supreme Court.

title: Belgrade Journal; Rakish City of the Serbs, Fighting Back the Tears
description: ''Blaywatch'' is among the fancier of the elaborate constructs that the Belgraders call ''rafts'' -- floating restaurants and bars that bob on the edge of the Danube as it meanders near some striking reminders of NATO's bombing: the Chinese Embassy; the casino where the late warlord Arkan once held sway; the blasted ruin of the party headquarters of first Tito's, and then Slobodan Milosevic's, Yugoslavia.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Position At Brokerage Firm
description: Hall F. Willkie, an executive vice president of Brown Harris Stevens, the real estate brokerage firm, has been named president of the company's residential-sales division. The position, a new one, was created after a reorganization that followed Brown Harris's purchase of the Halstead Property Company in January. The acquisition made Brown Harris the second-largest real estate brokerage firm in New York, behind Douglas Elliman and ahead of the Corcoran Group in both number of agents and sales volume. Mr. Willkie will oversee the company's 190 residential-sales agents in three offices in Manhattan and two in Palm Beach County, Fla. Mr. Willkie was a senior vice president and director of residential sales at Douglas Elliman and a manager at Sotheby's International Realty before joining Brown Harris Stevens in 1988.

title: Cash-for-Tickets Case Haunts Chirac as Report Raises the Figure
description: Three days after President Jacques Chirac said on national television that allegations that he had paid $300,000 in cash for airplane tickets for himself, his wife and his entourage were exaggerated, a new report has found that he spent even more than that.

title: Clueless on Global Warming
description: For the second time in six weeks, President Bush, having rejected the Kyoto Protocol on climate change, is headed to Europe without a strategy on global warming, an issue of deep concern to America's allies. European leaders will try to use the forthcoming Group of Eight summit meeting of industrialized nations in Genoa to persuade Mr. Bush to relax his opposition to Kyoto. Meanwhile, environmental ministers from a wider array of countries will be making the same case to Paula Dobriansky, the assistant secretary of state representing the administration at climate change talks in Bonn. The Europeans should not get their hopes up. Mr. Bush described Kyoto last month as ''fatally flawed'' because it would damage the American economy, and he has not changed his mind.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Pressure On Japan
description: The campaign against Japan's new middle-school textbooks, which critics say gloss over wartime atrocities, continued with the National Assembly unanimously passing a resolution asking the government to block Japan's campaign for a seat on the United Nations Security Council. The action came a day after the Foreign Ministry said it would ask Japan to act on a request by families to remove from the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo the names of more than 21,000 Koreans on the list of those who died fighting for Japan in World War II. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rapper Sentenced On Drug Charges
description: The hip-hop performer known as O.D.B. was sentenced yesterday to two to four years in prison on drug charges, the Queens district attorney said. The performer, whose real name is Russell Jones, was arrested in Queens in July 1999 on charges of possession of cocaine and marijuana. Mr. Jones, now 32, pleaded guilty to possession of a controlled substance, and prosecutors agreed not to charge him with violating bail. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: The Quest Goes On To Win A Major
description: Colin Montgomerie held an entertaining news conference today, loaded with self-deprecating humor about his failure to win a major championship, and the British Open in particular. In his last six British Opens, Montgomerie's best finish is a tie for 15th; he has missed the cut three times.

title: CUNY Pleased by Results Of New Universitywide Test
description: The City University of New York said yesterday that it had received promising results from a new test to determine whether to allow students to graduate from its community colleges or to move beyond their sophomore years in their senior colleges.

title: Missile Interception Test Was Hit-and-Miss, Pentagon Reports
description: A prototype missile defense radar had a malfunction after a successful interception test on Saturday and was unable to confirm that a mock warhead had been destroyed, the Pentagon said today.

title: After All the Dinner Guests Have Agreed, What More Is There to Say?
description: Before Jeff Greenfield's nightly CNN show made its debut on June 4, its executive producer, Shelley Lewis, explained its premise: ''What if we could have a great dinner party and invite really cool people?''

title: Article 2001071991257155266 -- No Title
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); }

title: Times Co. Operating Profit Fell 73% in Second Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that operating profit fell 73 percent in the second quarter, as declines in advertising sales more than offset increases in circulation revenue and reductions in expenses.

title: Of Cycles and Scriptures: Chafing Against Rituals
description: The bed sits in the semidark in the Ann Loeb Bronfman Gallery at the District of Columbia Jewish Community Center, where it is illuminated by a spotlight and covered with white handkerchiefs.

title: In Brooklyn, 3 Candidates Battle in Close Race for Borough President
description: On a sultry evening this week, a candidate for Brooklyn borough president, Jeannette Gadson, greeted a seemingly endless stream of people entering Wingate Park for a concert by Teena Marie, the rhythm-and-blues singer of 1980's fame. With a broad smile and a firm handshake, Ms. Gadson, who served as deputy borough president for eight years, urged hundreds of concertgoers to ''remember me on Primary Day.''

title: Webber Stays A Very Big Fish In Sacramento
description: The drama played out much longer than the Sacramento Kings and their legions wanted. Yet, at the end of the day, Chris Webber spurned the rest of the N.B.A. to play out his prime in a small market with very big dollars.

title: Article 2001071993836590453 -- No Title
description: A Sandinista Who Renounced the Sword for the Pen .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;}

title: Always at the Ready, A Front-Row Seat
description: Good things can come in small packages. The Tri-Lite aluminum and nylon canvas stool, below, weighs 18 ounces, holds 250 pounds and opens in 10 seconds. ''I personally tested it,'' said Jay Shields, who weighs 241 pounds and is the president of Byer of Maine, which makes outdoor furniture in Orono, Me., and distributes the stool in the United States. The stool, made by Deproc of Germany, has a green seat, 16 1/2 inches wide and 8 inches deep, and a red frame, 17 1/2 inches high. It is suitable for everything from sitting at a Little League game to waiting in line for tickets to ''The Producers''; $19.95. Information, (800) 338-0580. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Ford Says $752 Million Loss Is Mostly From Tire Costs
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it had lost $752 million, or 41 cents a share, in the second quarter, mostly because of costs associated with replacing 13 million Firestone tires as well as reorganization charges at the Mazda Motor Corporation.

title: Why Isn't the U.S. Making Friends?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Budget Enforcer Defies Fiscal Conservatives in House
description: The Bush administration's hopes of stopping Congress from declaring budget emergencies to ignore spending caps is being threatened by a powerful Republican lawmaker who is usually one of its most reliable allies on Capitol Hill: Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip.

title: Marco Zanuso, 85, Innovative Designer
description: Marco Zanuso, one of the leading designers of furniture, appliances, buildings and more to emerge from postwar Italy, died on July 11 at his home in Milan. He was 85.

title: Punishing Plagiarists
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Casino Announces Layoffs
description: Harrah's New Orleans Casino announced on Tuesday that it was laying off 148 employees, 5 percent of its work force. Harrah's, the state's only land-based casino, opened to fanfare in 1999. The decision comes just four months after the state granted a $50 million tax break to help sustain the struggling casino. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Fugitive Fujimori Relative is Shielded by Japan
description: The Japanese government said today that it had granted citizenship to former Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori's brother-in-law, who is wanted in Peru on suspicion of embezzling public funds.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial production rose in May for the first time in three months, led by cars. But the rebound might be short-lived. An index measuring production of goods ranging from energy to consumer goods rose 0.3 percent, after April's revised 0.4 percent drop, the statistics office Insee said.

title: Microsoft Earnings Rise, Excluding Charge
description: Leaning heavily on desktop computer products designed to help businesses use the Internet, the Microsoft Corporation reported strong quarterly revenue growth today, but the software company sharply reduced its profit forecast for the coming months.

title: Dredge the Hudson
description: The Bush administration is facing a critical public health and environmental choice about the future of the Hudson River. It must decide whether to embrace the proposal made by the Environmental Protection Agency in December 2000 -- after 11 years of study -- to get polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, out of the river by dredging and removing contaminated sediments from the upper Hudson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWLETT, SELINA RICHARDS WOOD GREW
description: HEWLETT-Selina Richards Wood Grew. Of Old Lyme, CT, on July 15, 2001, in her 91st year. Widow of Henry Sturgis Grew, Jr. and Roger Sanderson Hewlett. Survived by her daughters Selina G. (Mrs. W. Allen) Rossiter of Lincoln, MA; three sons, Henry S. Grew of Newport, RI; Rt. Rev. J. Clark Grew, II of Cleveland, OH; Dr. Robert S. Grew of Raleigh, NC; step daughter Sandra H. (Mrs. Robert) Johnson of Burlingame, CA; step son Peter S. Hewlett of Sebastopol, CA; 13 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 21, 2001, at 11:30 AM, in St. Ann's Episcopal Church, 82 Shore Road (Rte. 156) Old Lyme, CT 06371. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in her memory to St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: It's Christmas in July (Click on 'Clearance')
description: I FELT relatively safe when I believed that my GE Profile refrigerator was the only inanimate object plotting against me. But I had underestimated my enemy's ability to forge alliances.

title: G.O.P. MODERATES DEAL NEW SETBACK TO HOUSE LEADERS
description: Faced with a threatened rebellion by Republican moderates, House Republican leaders today abruptly delayed voting on President Bush's initiative to funnel more federal money to religious groups to deliver social services.

title: Hynix to Shut Chip Plant In Oregon for 6 Months
description: Hynix Semiconductor said today that it would suspend operations for six months at its plant in Eugene, Ore., as a result of what it called ''the worst year ever for the global semiconductor industry.''

title: CURRENTS: PRODUCTS; Building a House With Broken Glass
description: Tim McCarthy, a businessman, spent seven years developing Ice Stone, a terrazzolike product made with recycled glass (inset). He plans to manufacture it at his Great Harbor Design Center at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Last Friday, Mr. McCarthy received a permit from the New York City Department of Business Services to begin building a $1.3 million, 65,000-square-foot manufacturing facility (above, a model of the research center) inside three cavernous 19th-century structures at the yard. The design by Gary Shoemaker Architects of Manhattan calls for walls of luminous channel glass. Mr. McCarthy's company will join 200 businesses, 52 of them design related, at the yard. Ice Stone will be produced in polished panels that are as large as 4 by 8 feet, or in smaller tile sizes. It is made of bits of glass that have been reclaimed from the tons of glass destined for landfills each year in this country. They are then added to a cement-based mixture engineered not to crack. A computer-controlled pigment system offers thousands of colors. Mr. McCarthy expects Ice Stone to be available this fall starting at $25 a square foot. ''New York developers will be very keen on this,'' he said. ''Building with locally manufactured, sustainable materials gets them tax credits from the state.'' He is also negotiating with Home Depot to develop kitchen and bath countertops. Mr. McCarthy is at (718) 596-5829. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

title: Accounting Office Demands Energy Task Force Records
description: After two months of unsuccessful requests, the General Accounting Office demanded today that Vice President Dick Cheney turn over records relating to how his energy task force developed its policies.

title: Police in Cincinnati Pull Back in Wake of Riots
description: Three months after this city was traumatized by street clashes and vandalism, the police have retreated from ''proactive'' patrols in black neighborhoods, saying they fear fresh charges of racism.

title: Fire Forces Shutdown of Parts of Baltimore
description: A freight train carrying toxic chemicals derailed and caught fire in a tunnel in downtown Baltimore this afternoon, bringing much of the city's commercial center to a standstill.

title: Looking For Clues In Junior's Keystrokes
description: IT was in the spring of last year when a divorced mother of two teenagers in Livingston, N.J., realized that her 14-year-old son's online habits called for drastic steps.

title: A Pattern In the Dots: Film's Rival Is Gaining
description: IN the olden days, those of us in the geek industry had an understanding about digital cameras: they were cool because you could see the photo before you took it (by watching the screen on the back), you could instantly delete a bad shot you'd just taken, and you could touch up the pictures once you transferred them to your computer. But for quality, went the standard thinking, even the best digicam can't touch the cheapest film camera.

title: In U.S. Unions, Mexico Finds Unlikely Ally on Immigration
description: It is rare for foreign officials to address labor conventions, much less raise their fist in solidarity with the union members.

title: Ernst Baier, 95, Skating Star And Founder of Berlin Ice Revue
description: Ernst Baier, a German figure-skating star of the 1930's, died on July 8 at a hospital in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, a winter resort in southern Germany. He was 95 and lived in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, the site of the 1936 Winter Olympics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHEL, ROSALIE
description: REICHEL-Rosalie on July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Fredric and his wife Beverley, Enid and her husband Edwin Kammin. Dear sister of Dorothy. Adoring grandmother of John and Suzanne. Graveside services on Friday, July 20th, 11AM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Few Missile Defense Details Emerge After Powell Talks
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, played a guessing game today over what each side intended on the sensitive issue of missile defense. Mr. Ivanov said that Russia would keep talking to the United States but conceded little else. Secretary Powell, who said the time had come to be more specific with the Russians, appeared at least in public to have few details to offer.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Dave Chapman was named to head a new New York office of Wolfe/Doyle Advertising as vice president and director for client services. He had been vice president and account director at Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Charged After Child's Death
description: A Bronx man was charged Tuesday with hiding an unlicensed gun atop a kitchen cabinet, where his 9-year-old grand niece found it on July 1 and fatally shot herself by accident, the police said yesterday. The man, Johnny Ledbetter, 48, was charged with criminal possession of a weapon and endangering the welfare of a child. The girl, Taniqua Hall, discovered the gun while she and a friend were looking for peanut butter in her grandmother's apartment, officials said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | World: Dutch Approve International Court
description: The Netherlands became the 37th country to ratify the treaty of the International Criminal Court. Another 23 ratifications are now needed to allow the court -- the first permanent tribunal created to try individuals charged with genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity -- to begin operating. It will be based in The Hague, the Dutch capital. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Crossing the Ocean, Sampling the Outdoors
description: Clubland's denizens happily faced daylight on Saturday afternoon when Basement Jaxx, from England, headlined Central Park Summerstage for a crowd that far overflowed Rumsey Playfield. The double bill also included a kind of premiere: Bongo Maffin, a South African band, gave the first live American performance of kwaito, the dance music that now dominates South African pop.

title: Bush, in Britain, Enjoys the Calm Before the Storm
description: AYLESBURY, England, July 19 -- President Bush basked today in the least problematic of his administration's foreign relationships, visiting the bunker where Churchill weathered World War II, lunching with Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace and spending the night here at Chequers, the official country retreat, as a guest of Prime Minister Tony Blair, who did everything he could to minimize his differences with Washington.

title: French Linens, A Traditional Touch
description: Looking for Provenal cotton prints or toile de Jouy at bargain prices? Toto has 80 shops in France (and now one in New York), selling prints from the South of France for $5 to $7 a yard. (Comparable fabrics can cost as much as $45 a yard on Madison Avenue.) Tablecloths are $15 for a 70-inch square to $22 for a 65-by-96-inch rectangle; napkins, $2 each. White or ecru Matelass bedcovers in 80 percent cotton, 20 percent polyester, made in France, are $25 for twin size; $35 for queen or king. Cotton toile de Jouy in yellow, blue or green is $12 a yard. Toto of Paris, 667 Lexington Avenue (56th Street), (212) 588-8979. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Wearable, Wireless Appliance That Will Keep the Net at Hand
description: Wearable computers have been around for years in industrial settings, military complexes and futuristic television commercials. But hard-core technology lovers who wanted wearables had to cobble them together from disparate parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, FLORENCE
description: AXELROD-Florence. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Leon. Adored mother of Felicia Porges and Alice Chaikin. Cherished grandmother of Melissa Chaikin, Eric Chaikin, John Porges and Vicki Porges Eisner, and greatgrandmother of Dylan Porges. Service today, July 19, at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her memory to the Dysautonomia Foundation, 633 3rd Ave., NY NY 10017.

title: Mining a Dot-Com Disaster for EBay Sales
description: INTERNET stocks remain pariahs on Wall Street, but on eBay, the smart money is moving into beleaguered dot-coms. Take Webvan, the online grocery service, for example. Last week, it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and ended operation after spending almost $1.2 billion in startup capital.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Opposition Ready For Showdown
description: Despite a ban on rallies, opposition parties vowed to go ahead with a huge demonstration in Colombo today to protest President Chandrika Kumaratunga's decision to suspend Parliament. The president halted the session last week to avoid a no-confidence vote after her party fell into a minority. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Pushing Agenda for ABM's, Bush Prepares to Meet Putin
description: As President Bush prepares for meetings this weekend with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and other world leaders, the White House has stressed its desire to work out a new understanding with Moscow to replace the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Windsor Locks: Tax Official Charged With Larceny
description: The town's tax collector has been charged with second-degree larceny as part of an investigation of missing money in her office. The collector, Mary M. Damotta, 32, was arrested Friday and released on $25,000 bond, Police Chief John Suchocki said. Ms. Damotta did not return phone calls made to her home yesterday.

title: Study Shows Extra-Long Buses Have More Mishaps Than Others
description: Articulated buses, the road giants with extra-long bodies and accordion midsections that began appearing in Europe many years ago and have now come to New York, have been prone to more accidents than regular buses on two of Manhattan's busiest routes, a City Council committee said yesterday.

title: Sentimental Favorite Montgomerie Leads British Open
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 19 - In the stellar career of Colin Montgomerie, his failure to win a major championship is a painful void, and his dreadful performance in the British Open is baffling.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Psssst. Store That E-Mail. To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; Human Touch Is Common in Heade's Landscapes
description: Martin Johnson Heade has been called the Vermeer of 19th-century American painting. To be sure, his luminous, awesomely spacious landscapes may seem a far cry from the Delft master's intimate interiors, but like the latter's, Heade's paintings have a magical lucidity and an enigmatic psychology that continue to captivate the eyes and haunt the minds of modern viewers.

title: Creating an Inner Sanctum For That Secure Feeling
description: The new A3 workstation, designed by Lise Anne Couture and Hani Rashid of Asymptote Architecture, has curvilinear wings covered in stretch-knit mesh. Mr. Rashid says the shape is based on ''the womblike enclosure that you feel on an airplane.'' The mesh, which creates the illusion of privacy, comes in white, yellow, orange or blue, and the desk, movable storage unit and overhead bin have corresponding silver-gray, orange, yellow or blue accents. Accessories will include pencil cups, file folders and shelves, all within easy reach. The system can be configured to line up in conventional rows or organic clusters. The A3, $1,000 to $2,000, will be available in March from Knoll. Information, (800) 445-5045. MELISSA FELDMAN

title: Earnings Decline by 63% at J. P. Morgan Chase
description: J. P. Morgan Chase & Company reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were 63 percent below last year's, largely because of a reduction of more than $1 billion in the value of its private equity investments. The company said that further layoffs were likely, in addition to those announced following the merger of J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan last year.

title: Everything but the Minibar
description: IS there an ideal guest? Perhaps there can be, if you provide the ideal guest room. A properly furnished room makes a guest feel comfortable and self-sufficient. The accouterments include a first-aid kit equipped with Band-Aids and insect repellent, among other things; toothbrushes and an electric fan for a heat wave. Of course, an ideal guest takes a hint: once the clean towels are used up, it's time to go home.

title: Recapturing A Partnership That Was Lost
description: For soul fans, the work of Jerry Ragovoy and Howard Tate holds its own against the best of Otis Redding, Wilson Pickett and Joe Tex, thanks in part to Mr. Tate's melting falsetto and Mr. Ragovoy's mix of classic gospel and pop orchestration.

title: California's New Problem: Sudden Surplus of Energy
description: After months of warnings about power shortages and forced blackouts, an unusually cool July and surprisingly effective conservation efforts have put California in a stunning position: it has so much electricity on its hands that it is selling its surplus into a glutted market.

title: Transcript of Murray Chass' Visit to the Major League Baseball Forum
description: Murray Chass, national baseball writer for The Times, visited the forum on Tuesday, July 17. Here is a transcript.

title: The Education of a Millionaire
description: The $12 million man, the 6-foot-11, 250-pound, $12 million teenager, to be more specific, found himself in Brasserie Jo, one of the better French restaurants in Boston and the first French restaurant he had ever knowingly patronized.

title: Toll Booths Should Be a Distant Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Unemployment fell in June for the fourth consecutive month, reaching its lowest level since December 1997, the National Statistics Office said. All told, 745,000 workers, 3.3 percent of the work force, were out of jobs last month, a decline of 35,000, or 4.5 percent, from May. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITTLESON, MARIANNE
description: ITTLESON-Marianne. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Henry Anthony. Loving mother of Philip and his wife Margot, Christina and her husband Sean and Stephanie. Cherished grandmother of Carlin, Henry and Fayre. Devoted sister of Nina, Cecilia, Agneta and Christian. Loving daughter of Alfhild Sundby. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC, on Sunday, July 22, 2001, 5-8 PM. Service Monday, July 23, 2001 at 11 AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., NYC. Cemetery arrangements private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 or Hollings Cancer Center, Medical University of South Carolina.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: More Prisoners Freed
description: The military government said it had released 11 more political prisoners including a leading journalist, Daw San San Nwe, 56, who was imprisoned in 1994 after being accused of ''causing misunderstanding of the government'' in her news reports. A member of the opposition National League for Democracy, she has been recognized by foreign press associations for her work. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Drinking and Eating In the Lap of Art
description: Starting tomorrow, visitors to the cafe of the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, can perch on 150 chairs, some of them below, covered in fabrics with African designs. Franz West, an Austrian artist who designed the chairs, said he chose the fabrics ''because they are some kind of wild.'' He donated the chairs, worth $30,000, to the museum. ''A project should not be made based on how much you get paid,'' he said. ''And I'm not so poor.'' Carlos Basualdo, chief curator of exhibitions, said the chairs may be in the permanent installation when the show, called ''Notations,'' ends next spring. The cafe is at 1871 North High Street. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Overzealous Prosecutors
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Joining the Hall of Fame, 2 for Near Wins
description: As the Summer National Championships begin here tonight, eight players will be inducted into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame. Two of them in the living player category are Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., who won the World Pairs Championship in 1982, the Bermuda Bowl in 1985 and 1987 and the Rosenblum Teams in 1994; and Richard Freeman of Atlanta, Ga., who won the Bermuda Bowl in 1995 and 2000. Both have won a string of national titles.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Wins A Stay
description: A federal court of appeals granted an emergency stay of a lower court ruling, issued last week, that required the Internet music service Napster to remain offline until it proved it could more effectively filter copyrighted content. Yesterday's ruling, by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, clears the way for Napster to resume service, but people close to the company said it had not yet decided when to go back online. The Redwood City, Calif., company took the service down on July 1 to upgrade technology used to filter files of copyrighted music. Napster had planned to resume service last week, asserting in court that it could filter at 99 percent effectiveness, but Judge Marilyn Patel of the Federal District Court in San Francisco ruled that the service must remain down until it proved it could be more effective still. In appealing the ruling, Napster asserted that the standard set by Judge Patel was impossible to meet. The Ninth Circuit granted a temporary stay, and said it would review Napster's appeal further before issuing a final order later, meaning the court could still uphold Judge Patel's ruling. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Miscellany
description: * KPMG Consulting, McLean, Va., will run its first television commercials since it became a public company. The spots, by Gaylord Sports, Scottsdale, Ariz., feature the golfer Phil Mickelson, who is sponsored by KPMG. The spots will run this weekend on ABC during the British Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DR. NANCY
description: LEWIS-Dr. Nancy. Nancy Hara Lewis, died July 17, in a tragic airplane accident near Fairbanks, Alaska. Loved, admired and adored by all who knew her. She will be deeply missed by her husband Hugh Rose, her parents Harriet and Dick Lewis of Great Neck, New York, her beloved sisters, Tracy Nause and Amy Tabor, brother-in-laws Bob Tabor and Peter Nause. Cherished niece of Ruth Swaback, Rosaline Simon, Leanore Fox, and by her many cousins. She was of superior intelligence, a kind and caring young doctor who lived life to the utmost climbing mountains, and rafting rivers the world over. She cared deeply about the environment and the beauty of Alaska. She died at 48, but lived 100 years.

title: Britannica Still Rules the Web But It Will No Longer Be Free
description: In another sign that the Web of the free is fading, Britannica.com announced yesterday that it would no longer offer its entire encyclopedia available online at no cost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEER, ANN (NEE) DAVENPORT
description: GEER-Ann (nee) Davenport. On July 13, 2001. Husband Walter H. Geer, daughter Susan Davenport Geer of Swarthmore, PA. Employee of Swarthmore College Alumni, Swarthmore, PA. Funeral service and interment private. James M. Brower Funeral Home, Wallingford, PA.

title: Essay; Nights of The Round Table
description: After Richard Nixon's landslide re-election in 1972, as hostility rose in the White House at The Washington Post's apparently fruitless pursuit of the Watergate affair, the courageous publisher Katharine Graham horrified her editors by offering a Nixon speechwriter a coveted job as columnist.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ASML Reports A Loss
description: ASML Holding, a Dutch manufacturer of chip-making tools, reported a first-half loss and warned that it expected no recovery in its slumping industry for at least a year. ASML, which acquired the American equipment maker Silicon Valley Group in May, said it sold 250 of its multimillion-dollar systems, 72 fewer than during the comparable period a year earlier, as demand continued to wane and customers canceled orders. The company, based in Veldhoven, the Netherlands, said it lost 96 million euros, or $83.9 million, on revenue of 1.02 billion euros, or $891.3 million. For the year-earlier period, ASML reported a profit of 149 million euros, or $130.2 million, on revenue of 1.34 billion euros, or $1.17 billion. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Slavs and Albanians at Odds In Peace Talks in Macedonia
description: After nearly two weeks of intensive Western-brokered negotiations, Macedonian Albanian and Slav leaders still appear unable to reach a political agreement to end the five-month-old conflict and set the stage for the deployment of a NATO task force to disarm Albanian rebels.

title: From Outfields to Art, One Blade at a Time
description: UNDER a friendly sky here a few weeks back, David R. Mellor toed the third-base line in Fenway Park, calling instructions to a man pushing a heavy iron roller. ''Go over the heel one more time,'' Mr. Mellor instructed, ''and then you're done.''

title: The Tuberculosis Threat
description: The London neighborhood of Newham is a good illustration of the perils of complacency about tuberculosis. That East End borough now has 108 cases of tuberculosis per 100,000 inhabitants -- double that of India and on a par with Russia. Many of those sick are immigrants from Asia and Africa, a reminder that tuberculosis anywhere can mean tuberculosis everywhere. But Newham is also suffering because London needs to spend more on public health. There are not enough nurses and specialists in the worst-hit areas to control the disease.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Another Internet Bankruptcy
description: Phase2Media Inc., a New York advertising and marketing Internet company, announced yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection. The move came four months after the company withdrew its plans for an initial public offering of $57.5 million in stock, citing the falling stock markets. The company listed $18 million in assets and $19.6 million in debts in the papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: The Florida Vote: Rearguing the Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Punishing Plagiarists
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers in Cambodia
description: To the Editor:

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Profit Is Down Sharply at Knight Trading
description: The large Nasdaq share dealer, the Knight Trading Group, said today that second-quarter profit dropped as the conversion to decimal pricing reduced income from trading.

title: Beach Closed
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Thought Police
description: The thought police have arrived. An Ohio man has been sentenced to seven years in prison for thinking bad thoughts about children and writing them down in his private journal. In Ohio, that's against the law.

title: Greenspan Warns of Serious Risk But Says Rebound May Be in Sight
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the economy remained weak and susceptible to more bad news, and he suggested that the central bank might cut interest rates at least once more this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Doctor Is Shot
description: Detectives yesterday were investigating a report by a Bellevue Hospital Center emergency room doctor that she had been shot on a Brooklyn street. The doctor, Denise Tyler, 37, drove herself to the Bellevue emergency room about 2 a.m. yesterday. She was treated for a gunshot wound to her left side and listed in stable condition. Dr. Tyler told the police that she had been shot outside the car on Atlantic Avenue. But investigators found a spent shell casing inside the car, leading them to believe that she had been shot inside the car, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, BERNARD D.
description: FISCHMAN-Bernard D. For your countless acts of kindness, thoughtfulness, and decency; for your passionate curiosity, wise counsel, and penetrating intellect; for your fierce loyalty and your boundless generosity of spirit, we who knew you will miss you and remember you always, Bernie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMERVILLE, DURWARD
description: SOMERVILLE-Durward. On July 17, 2001. Funeral service Friday, July 20, 2001, at 9 AM, at St James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street. Also, a memorial service will be held at a later date

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Health Official Censured
description: A senior official of the State Health Department violated the state code of ethics by securing a job for his wife at a company that did business with his office, reviewing matters she was working on, and lying to the department about her involvement in those matters, the State Ethics Commission ruled yesterday. The official, Charles F. Murphy, has been suspended without pay and the Health Department said that it planned to dismiss him. Mr. Murphy's office reviewed applications from nursing homes seeking state aid. His wife worked at a consulting firm that helped make such applications. Mr. Murphy could not be reached for comment yesterday.

title: Europe Moves to Speed Up Approval of New Drugs
description: The European Commission today proposed an acceleration in the approval of new drugs that could reduce by up to half the time it takes for new medication to reach markets and patients.

title: The Reign of a Great Publisher
description: The term ''publisher,'' as used in the news business, is unique. Its equivalents elsewhere, chief executive officer or chairman, do not bear the same weight or convey the same authority. A publisher has the responsibility of a skipper on the bridge of a vessel, mindful always of the rigging, the weather, the course, the morale below decks and, not least, the safe delivery of the cargo, the news, good and bad. The news business has its own amendment of the Constitution of the United States, which gives the cargo a special value and the skipper a special duty.

title: Prudential Is Challenged Over Plans To Revamp
description: When Richard Ciocca awoke this morning, he said, it was to the ringing of an alarm clock bearing the logo of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. He drank his coffee from a mug with the same logo.

title: Taking On the Curmudgeons
description: For 23 years, curmudgeon Andy Rooney has wrapped up each week's "60 Minutes" broadcast with his hilarious, pointed commentary, "A Few Minutes with Andy Rooney." It's not hard to guess what his slant is going to be on a given topic -- they put less coffee into coffee cans these days, there's too much junk mail -- but it's often laugh-out-loud funny.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Phone Maker Is Moving
description: An Avaya customer-service center in Parsippany, N.J., and the 348 people who work there are among the latest victims of the telecommunications industry's continued contraction. Avaya, a spinoff of Lucent Technologies that makes office-phone equipment, said yesterday that it would close the center and move the jobs there to Atlanta and Oklahoma City. The shift is part of a restructuring announced last month that will trim 3,000 jobs within a year because of declining orders for telephones. Paula Horii, a spokeswoman for Avaya, said some of the workers in Parsippany would be offered jobs elsewhere, and others can opt for early retirement or buyouts. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York State's revenues for the three months ended on June 30 misstated the amount by which total revenues exceeded Gov. George E. Pataki's projection. The excess was $285 million, according to the governor's budget office; $495 million was the amount by which just one source of revenue, personal income tax collections, exceeded the projection.

title: Doubts Cast On U.S. Effort For the Safety Of Shellfish
description: The Food and Drug Administration collects so little information on the safety of shellfish that it cannot tell whether its efforts to improve inspections and reduce illnesses among people who eat them have yielded any significant results, according to a study to be released today.

title: Why Isn't the U.S. Making Friends?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Sees Discord on Size of Military
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that sharp disagreements remained among some in the armed services over how large the American military must be to carry out new strategic guidelines he recently negotiated with the nation's most senior officers.

title: A Sleek Aerie Atop the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel
description: AN 800-square-foot apartment that sits practically on top of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and around the corner from an entrance to the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel may not be everyone's idea of an urban oasis. But for Avi Adler and David Stark, a renovated one-bedroom home on the roof of a nondescript 1940's Brooklyn building is paradise found.

title: Elmer Henderson, 88, Dies; Father of Major Rights Case
description: Elmer W. Henderson, a retired government lawyer who helped make civil rights history after enduring an insult on a 1942 train trip, died on Tuesday at a nursing home here. He was 88 and lived in Washington.

title: People
description: * Mel Korn, chief executive at the Collaborative Marketing unit of Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, was named chief executive at a new collaborative marketing service division of Publicis, Collaborative Marketing Worldwide. At the Saatchi & Saatchi unit, Margaret Somers, who was executive vice president and general manager, will succeed Mr. Korn.

title: Panel Nears Vote to Raise Fuel Economy of S.U.V.'s Slightly
description: A House committee moved today toward requiring slightly higher fuel economy from sport utility vehicles, minivans and other light trucks for the first time since the mid-1980's. But it voted against calls for major increases, and environmentalists vowed to take the fight to the floor.

title: World Business Briefing
description: GLOBAL TRADE

title: Ailing Statue: Symbol of Industry or Pork Barrel?
description: With his body sliced into pieces and spread ignominiously over an asphalt parking lot, Vulcan looks as if he has already been laid low by Senator John McCain's flashing, budget-cutting sword.
