title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHTA, CAROLE A.
description: MEHTA-Carole A. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Dilip. Dear mother of Nina and Diane. Sister of Joan Fuhrer. Adored and loving daughter of the late Sidney S. and Lila Leonard. Services Friday, July 20, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From restaurants in Amsterdam to ATMs in Italy, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the impact of falling fuel prices on the Bush administration's energy plan misstated comments by Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham about gasoline prices. Mr. Abraham testified to Congress that news reports about inflated prices could become a ''self-fulfilling prophecy'' and raise prices to $3 a gallon in the summer, but he did not warn that prices could go that high, and he said his information did not support predictions of so steep an increase.

title: Clergy to Ask Minority Voters To Weigh Stances on Profiling
description: A prominent black New Jersey clergyman said today that he and fellow pastors would urge black and Hispanic voters to withhold their support for any candidate for governor who does not endorse measures to counter racial profiling.

title: 2 Men Arrested As Police Seize One Million Ecstasy Tablets
description: Narcotics detectives raided a studio apartment on the edge of the financial district on Tuesday night and discovered more than a million tablets of the popular club drug Ecstasy, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the announcement by the former king of Bulgaria, Simeon II, that he would accept the position of prime minister misstated the number of his sons. There are four, not three.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Pentagon Gave Out Personnel Contact Information
description: The Department of Defense routinely honored requests from members of Congress for addresses of service personnel to contact constituents or conduct similar business, a Pentagon spokesman said. The spokesman, Rear Adm. Craig R. Quigley, said the department had no formal policy for such requests and did not comment on the actions of Representative Stephen E. Buyer, Republican of Indiana, above. Mr. Buyer was described in a New York Times report as having asked the Pentagon last November for telephone numbers and e-mail addresses of military personnel, including some whose absentee ballots had been disqualified in Florida. Mr. Buyer has said he did not forward the voter contact information to anyone. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Israelis Send In Tanks for a Show of Force in the West Bank
description: Israeli tanks were stationed north and south of this city today after a flare-up of violence touched off by the killing of four Palestinians here on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIG, JERRY A.
description: DANZIG-Jerry A. Of Manhattan, died on July 16. The retired management consultant (Chester Burger & Co.) and pioneering broadcast executive served for 12 years as special assistant for communications to Governors Rockefeller and Wilson of NY. Before entering government service, he worked for CBS television and NBC's television & radio networks. During WW II, he was awarded the Bronze Star as a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy for valor during the Normandy invasion. Mr. Danzig, a graduate of Dartmouth College, is survived by his son, Jerry P. of Manhattan, his step-daughter, Diana C. Dupont of New Hampshire, and his sister, Evelyn D. Haas of San Francisco. He was married to the late Sarah Palfrey, former National Tennis Singles Champion. His brother, Frank, formerly of Los Angeles, also preceded him in death. The gathering for family and friends will be held at 11AM on Friday, July 20, at the Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Dartmouth College or the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP., New York, a maker of flight simulators and military testing systems, said it was awarded a contract by the Air Force to provide training systems. Terms were not disclosed.

title: My $1 Windfall
description: To the Editor:

title: Staying Online Without Cutting Off the Rest of the World
description: IN an age when broadband Internet services offer speedy and constant connections, computer users who still dial a phone number to go on the Internet may be considered an endangered breed.

title: Israeli Leader Pardons Friend of Rabin's Assassin
description: Israel's political, social and religious fault lines were exposed about as starkly as they had ever been with the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995. Today, they suddenly re-emerged when the country's president pardoned a young woman imprisoned for having failed to tell the police what she knew about the killer's intentions.

title: The Times Company Names Financial Officer
description: Leonard P. Forman, a senior vice president of The New York Times Company, will become chief financial officer at the end of the year, the company announced yesterday. He succeeds John M. O'Brien, who will retire then.

title: The Line Score: 3 Games, 2 Cities, No Sleep
description: The Yankees schedule after leaving Philadelphia just past midnight.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Water Compromise Offered
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber released a proposed compromise on water allocations in the Klamath Basin that he hoped would be acceptable to farmers, fisherman, Indian tribes and environmentalists. The governor's plan, one of many being considered, sets minimum irrigation flows based on this year's drought but leaves water levels in Upper Klamath Lake below levels mandated by a Fish and Wildlife Service decision. The state severely limited irrigation water for farmers in the basin this year to protect endangered fish. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Fortress Genoa Awaits G-8 Leaders and Foes
description: Scrubbed, freshly painted and sealed off with metal fences, the harbor where a summit meeting for the world's major industrial nations will begin on Friday is quite calm -- the shuttered-down silence that enveloped the western frontier town before the shootout in ''High Noon.''

title: Key Bush Ally Suggests a Deal On Cell Studies
description: In a hint of how President Bush might resolve the debate over embryonic stem cell experiments, Senator Bill Frist, a transplant surgeon and close ally of the president, announced today that he supported federal financing for the research ''within a very carefully regulated, fully transparent framework.''

title: Attached to Juno
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not What It Used to Be
description: The speed of the buzz. A manuscript, a book proposal, a debut short story is out there and everyone knows about it and if you want to buy it and publish it you better get the cash there quick quick quick, ballistic fast. Or so it seems. And this need for snap and steam is very likely the most important and certainly one of the most interesting evolutions in book publishing in recent years.

title: Daschle Defends His Critique of Bush's Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  The Senate majority leader said today that he stood by a charge that President Bush had weakened the United States standing in the world. But he said that he "probably would have chosen a different time" to offer such criticism if he had focused on the fact that the president was heading to an international summit.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a United Nations conference that seeks to tighten international controls on light weapons omitted the given name and title of an American official who addressed the conference earlier. He is John R. Bolton, under secretary of state for arms control.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about new ways to treat diabetes misstated the name of a manufacturer of inhaled insulin. It is Inhale Therapeutic Systems, not Inhaled Therapeutics System.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, EVELYN
description: FELDMAN-Evelyn. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, N.Y. mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Jeffrey Sinensky, President

title: Golfers begin a $5 million campaign to catch up to the boom in other professional sports for women.
description: THE Ladies Professional Golf Association will introduce a new advertising campaign on Saturday to raise its profile in the highly competitive field of women's sports.

title: Airlines, Led by United, Show Big Losses
description: Whipsawed by a plunge in high-priced corporate travel and rising labor and fuel costs, several major airlines, led by United Airlines, reported steep second-quarter losses yesterday, a downturn that several managers described as among the worst in a generation.

title: City Says Inmate Care Fails In Most Contract Categories
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that the health care company that was awarded a $314 million contract to care for inmates had failed to provide adequate service in more than two dozen categories, from H.I.V. testing to infection control, during its first three months on the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, ALAN STUART
description: GRAHAM-Alan Stuart. Died suddenly, while lunching with friends, on Monday, 16 July, in New York City. An elegant man with superb taste he was a well-known fashion designer in the late forties and early fifties in Manhattan. A protege of Norman Norell and then, under his own label, he was a favorite of Lord & Taylor where he enjoyed coverage in ''Vouge'' and ''Glamour.'' In 1952 he moved to Paris continuing his career in the atelier of Jacques Fath and with the firm Tricot. Later, as a respected and knowledgeable antiquarian, he assisted American and French friends in acquiring furniture and treasures through his sources there. A man of strong opinions, great charm, and personal style, he is mourned by his many friends on both continents. Devoted Friends

title: Officer Kills Man in Self-Defense, the Police Say
description: A plainclothes police officer intervening in a fight yesterday morning fatally shot a man who had struck him from behind with a bat, the police said.

title: AOL Time Warner Posts Mixed Results in Quarter
description: In an economic storm, AOL Time Warner Inc. has labored mightily to remain on course. But for all of its helmsmanship, it may be difficult for the company to reach its desired financial destination for this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKMAN, AUDREY PEART
description: DICKMAN-Audrey Peart. Of Middletown, NJ and New York City died Monday at home. She was coordinating producer of Saturday Night Live from its inception, for 18 years. She also worked on Kraft Music Hall and several other productions and received numerous Emmy citations. Audrey was born in London, England and is survived by her husband Bernie, her sisters Florence Ferguson and Doris Notley and several nieces and nephews. A graveside service will be held Tuesday 10:00 A.M. at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Donations to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

title: SAFECO TO ELIMINATE 10% OF ITS JOBS BY THE END OF 2003
description: The property and casualty insurer Safeco Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate the jobs of 1,200 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, as it reorganizes its auto and home insurance unit. Safeco, based in Seattle, said it expected to take restructuring charges of $60 million through 2003. The cuts, combined with previously announced plans to reorganize its commercial insurance lines, will reduce expenses by about $100 million and bring total planned job reductions to 1,650, Safeco said. Half the job cuts will occur this year. Its shares rose 2 cents, to $28.83.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Crackdown On Press
description: The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists said there had been ''a deplorable upsurge'' in recent weeks in government attacks on the news media in Angola. Journalists are being detained and interrogated in provincial cities as well as in the capital, Luanda, where a BBC reporter and Rafael Marques, a well-known writer, were prevented from reporting on the forced evacuation of a city neighborhood. A church radio station, Radio Ecclesia, is also under attack. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Senators Criticize F.B.I. for Its Security Failures
description: Senators from both political parties expressed outrage and dismay today over an F.B.I. equipment inventory that determined that hundreds of firearms and laptop computers were missing. Lawmakers said the latest lapse indicated that the bureau could no longer reliably manage its basic operations.

title: A Virtual Slide Show On a SmartPhone
description: While real-time picture phones are still unavailable in the United States, you can have a phone that at least displays real photos. The free Album to Go software developed by ClubPhoto

title: Sports of The Times; Too Shrewd To Dwell On a Feud
description: WHO knew about Cliff Floyd before all this happened?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a United Nations conference that seeks to tighten international controls on light weapons omitted the given name and title of an American official who addressed the conference earlier. He is John R. Bolton, under secretary of state for arms control.

title: Workers in Cambodia
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal Is Set for OTB Parlors
description: The Giuliani administration intends to announce today the selection of a partnership created by Magna Entertainment Corporation of Aurora, Ontario, and Greenwood Racing Inc. of Pennsylvania as the winning bidder for the city's Off-Track Betting parlors, an official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUIMBY, TOD
description: QUIMBY-Tod. Suddenly on July 16, 2001. Will be missed by all. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Epilepsy Foundation will be appreciated.

title: Shares Decline on Bleak Earnings Reports
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as investors digested another round of bleak corporate earnings reports along with downbeat comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, about the economy's continuing weakness.

title: The Inner Lives of Garden Paths
description: IF a garden is a world in itself, the path is a journey through it. You need a path so you can push the wheelbarrow to the compost pile. And lead guests to the wooded glade where Southern magnolias bloom over a carpet of golden euonymous. And tempt the eye around the next bend.

title: Nepal's Royal Deaths Give Life to Swirl of Theories
description: For ordinary Nepalese, there has been little healing in the weeks since thin gray smoke spiraled into the sky from the cremation of this mountain kingdom's murdered king, queen and seven other members of the royal family.

title: Polaroid Reports a Loss Greater Than Expected
description: Polaroid reported a second-quarter loss yesterday that was far worse than Wall Street expected, but the company said that it could become profitable again sometime next year.

title: Psssst. Store That E-Mail.
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Cheney Records Are Sought

title: Turning the Tables On Software That Spies
description: Q. If I download a free program from the Web and install it on my computer, how can I make sure it is not secretly installing other software that tracks my Web surfing habits?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABLER, MILDRED GATES
description: ABLER-Mildred Gates, 82. On July 18th. Beloved wife of Morton. Cherished mother of Michelle and Madeleine. Dear mother-in-law of Charles H. Elliott, Jr. and Kent S. Calhoun, loving grandmother of Charles (Skip), Jonathan, Naomi and Alexander. Services at Chapel in the Woods, Congregation Kol Ami, 50 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY, Friday, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Alzheimer's Association of Westchester, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York 10605.

title: Bush Scolds Protesters at Genoa Talks
description: President Bush arrived here tonight to begin a weeklong trip to Britain, Italy and Kosovo, and in an interview with foreign reporters released tonight he said the thousands of people gathering in Genoa, Italy, to protest a meeting of leaders of industrialized nations had ''hurt the case of the poor.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Immigrants are in every workplace in the United States, and they're not leaving. We have to make it clear to immigrant workers that we're on their side.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAY, GEORGE
description: SHAY-George. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of George Shay, who was deeply devoted to the Jewish community. Mr. Shay's beloved son, Scott Shay, is a true leader of UJA-Federation who serves on our Commission for Jewish Identity and Renewal, & on the executive committee of our Wall Street Division. We extend our deepest sympathies to Scott & his wife, Susan; to Mr. Shay's beloved wife, Helene; to his 4 grandchildren; & to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Pocket-Size U.S.B. Hard Drive Goes Along for the Ride
description: Wallet? Check. Keys? Check. Q drive?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Pilots' Slowdown
description: Pilots have voted to extend indefinitely a work slowdown against Cathay Pacific Airways. In their first meeting since the carrier dismissed 49 pilots, the 1,300 pilots repeated demands for higher pay and changes in work schedules. John Findlay, the head of the Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association, said the airline's tactics ''are driving further downward the good will of the pilots.'' Cathay Pacific, which has delayed or canceled dozens of flights, said its operations were almost back to normal. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: And Now a Word From Their Cool College Sponsor
description: Chris Barrett and Luke McCabe emerge from the surf, studded with the logos of a credit card company, and begin to work their way across the beach toward a coterie of publicists and a photographer there to capture the moment.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Turnpike Project Examined
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority and two of its former officials misled investors about additional costs for the Big Dig construction project in Boston. The turnpike chairman, James J. Kerasiotes, and his deputy, Patrick Moynihan, were asked to resign last year after the project ran $1.4 billion over budget. The project will move Boston's downtown Interstate 93 underground.

title: Workers in Cambodia
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleaning Up Stock Market Research
description: Investment banks, whose analysts were touting stocks with overwhelming zeal even as the stock market started crashing, are now trying to rehabilitate their images. Last week Merrill Lynch, by some measures the world's biggest investment bank, declared that except under strictly monitored circumstances, its analysts would be prohibited from holding shares in the companies they research. The goal is to remove any incentive for them to boost a stock to ensure their own enrichment. But this novel policy will not entirely prevent conflicts of interest from arising. It should be regarded as a springboard to a more complete revamping of the relationship between publicly available research and investment banking.

title: MERCK GAINS EXTENSION FOR SALES OF CHOLESTEROL DRUG
description: The drug maker Merck & Company said yesterday that it had received an additional six months of exclusive sales rights for its cholesterol-lowering drug Mevacor after federal regulators reversed a decision that would have allowed immediate generic competition. The regulators, at the Food and Drug Administration, said Merck's test on the drug in girls was sufficient to warrant the extension until Dec. 15. That reversed an earlier decision by the agency to reject Merck's pediatric studies because they did not include enough girls. Merck submitted additional data after Federal District Judge James Robertson of Washington demanded a reconsideration of the agency's original decision. Merck shares jumped $3.07, to $67.55.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, MARTIN
description: SLATER-Martin. The Kips Bay Towers Condominium Board mourns the loss of their past member, Martin Slater. Our sympathies to Jerry and the rest of the family.

title: State Commission Reviewing Fight
description: The New York State Athletic Commission is reviewing the Brooklyn bout on July 7 in which Hector Camacho Jr. was awarded a disputed victory over Jesse James Lejia, a commission spokesman said yesterday.

title: Egypt Tries 52 Men Suspected of Being Gay
description: In a high-profile crackdown on suspected homosexual activity that has been condemned by some legal activists and human rights groups, 52 men were charged today in a state security court with engaging in immoral acts or religious offenses.

title: 'Guys in White Coats'
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Upholds Gay Marriages
description: The Constitutional Court rejected a move by the states of Bavaria and Saxony to block a law granting same-sex couples the right to marry. The ruling means that as of Aug. 1 gays and lesbians will be allowed to marry in state registry offices and share common surnames. They will also receive rights given heterosexual spouses in areas like inheritance and health insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, MARGA
description: OPPENHEIMER-Marga. Beloved widow of P. Hans Oppenheimer, died peacefully on July 16, 2001. She will be deeply missed by both family and friends. Funeral services Friday, July 20, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Officers Acquitted Of Assault Charges
description: Two Newark police officers were acquitted on charges of assaulting a suspect and then encouraging other prisoners to beat the suspect. Sgt. Anthony Caruso, an 11-year veteran, and Officer Wendell Harper, a 9-year veteran, were accused of beating Emmanuel Aldea, 26, who was suspected of molesting a 10-year-old boy, in June 1999.

title: Serving Roasted Author, Preferably au Jus
description: LIT LIFE

title: Learning to Speak Their Minds
description: ANDREW GANAT graduated from high school in May and is looking forward to college in the fall. While that is an important milestone in anyone's life, reaching it is especially sweet for Mr. Ganat, 18. In the second grade, he was found to have the learning disability dyslexia.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: New Bosnia Genocide Charge
description: The prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal has revealed that a so-far secret indictment exists against a former head of the Bosnian Serb security services. Stojan Zupljanin, 49, has been charged with the tribunal's gravest crimes, including genocide, torture, persecution and deportation. The prosecutor's office did not say why it decided to disclose the 1999 indictment now, but it could be a means to increase pressure on Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian leader, who is still at large. The two men were close collaborators during the Bosnian war.

title: The Florida Vote: Rearguing the Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonkers for Music, Cheer and Glory; For Britons, It's Time for the Proms, That Exhilarating Feast
description: You never know from the weather if summer has arrived in Britain, but you have no doubt it's here once music starts pouring nightly over throngs in the Royal Albert Hall and out to millions more on the radio.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New City: Carbon-Monoxide Detector Bill Rejected
description: Wary of an increase in false alarms, the Rockland County Legislature rejected a bill that would have required carbon-monoxide detectors in all residential housing. On Tuesday night, the Legislature voted 8 to 7 against the requirement, with all six Republicans and two Democrats voting no, and seven Democrats voting yes. The bill was set aside last September, then reintroduced after eight county residents were hospitalized for carbon monoxide poisoning. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Sets Sights On Server Market
description: Dell said yesterday that it would begin marketing switching equipment this fall for the kinds of computer networks used by the small and medium-sized businesses. Dell estimated that such switches accounted for about $5.3 billion of the $19.5 billion market for all network switches, including those sold to phone companies. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Pinter the Actor Meets Pinter the Writer
description: The alarm sirens should be screaming at Lincoln Center. Evil has arrived there in a sleek, fleshy package with a baritone purr. That famous ambiguous sense of menace that has always haunted Harold Pinter's plays has at last been given a human face, and its name is -- take a breath -- Harold Pinter.

title: Parents of 7 Teenage Suspects Apologize in Beating Death
description: On the eve of learning whether their children would be charged as adults in the beating death last month of a homeless man, parents of some of the teenagers apologized today to the dead man's family.

title: A Club Pro Gives Himself Some Good Advice
description: It was early in the day, only the fifth hole of the interminably long Black Course in the Mony New York State Open at Bethpage State Park, and now John Nieporte was talking to himself.

title: Armstrong Pierces the Sky and Keeps Going
description: Lance Armstrong need not have worried about paying the bill today for his winning climb to L'Alpe d'Huez the day before.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer Shows Increase
description: The retailer PinaultPrintemps-Redoute reported a 16 percent increase in second-quarter sales after it opened stores in Europe that outweighed declines at some American divisions. Sales for Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the owner of Printemps department stores and the Fnac chain, rose to 6.7 billion euros ($5.8 billion) from 5.8 billion euros a year earlier, Bloomberg calculations show. In the first six months, sales rose 20 percent.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Political Strange Bedfellows

title: L.P.G.A. Goes From Tee to Shining Tee
description: With 79 players from 20 countries this year, the L.P.G.A. is a global tour. The women have seven tournaments outside the United States this season, and international players, who have captured their share of events over the years, have dominated the L.P.G.A. Tour this year.

title: British Open Concerns: Weather, Wind, Woods
description: During his first practice round this week, Davis Love III quickly discovered how difficult the British Open will be this year. On the 14th hole, Love hit a drive that sailed left and landed in knee-high rough. Love never found his ball. And it will not be the last ball to disappear.

title: Accounts
description: * Sara Lee Coffee and Tea Consumer Brands, Harrison, N.Y., a unit of the Sara Lee Corporation, to Christy MacDougall Mitchell, New York, as the agency of record for two coffee brands, Chock Full o' Nuts and Hills Brothers. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. The unit also sells the Chase & Sanborn and MJB coffee brands. Sara Lee acquired Hills Brothers and the two other brands from Nestl in 1999 after buying Chock Full o' Nuts.

title: New Opinion Editor at Wall St. Journal
description: Paul A. Gigot, a Washington columnist for The Wall Street Journal, will take the reins of the newspaper's opinion pages, assuming the title of editorial page editor this fall and all the duties of Robert L. Bartley, the current opinions editor, next year, Dow Jones & Company, the newspaper's owner, announced today.

title: Washington Stayed Here, but Here Is on the Move
description: If the walls of Rockingham could talk, they would probably cry out for a stable home. In a little more than a century, the 20-room mansion where George Washington spent the final months of the Revolutionary War has been moved twice, each time to escape an encroaching quarry that threatened to swallow its foundation. After each move, the promise of permanence has been elusive.

title: Treasury Chief: Tax Evasion Is on the Rise
description: Tax evasion by Americans using offshore accounts is rising and will increase, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill testified today as he tried to persuade a skeptical Democratic senator that he was committed to vigorously pursuing tax cheats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUVANE, REV. JAMES A.
description: HUVANE-Rev. James A., formerly of the Bronx, July 18, 2001. Beloved brother of John Huvane and wife, Veronica; beloved uncle of 3 nephews. Calling hours, 2-4 & 6-9 PM, Thurs and 2-5 PM Fri, at Regina Coeli Church, Rte. 9, Hyde Park, NY. A Mass of Eucharist, 7:30 PM Fri, and a Mass of Christian Burial, 9:30 AM, Sat. with Edward Cardinal Egan officiating, at Regina Coeli Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Regina Coeli School, 2 Harvey St., Hyde Park, NY 12538. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne. Sweet's Funeral Home, Hyde Park.

title: Using the Internet to Cut Phone Calls Down to Size
description: FOR most of the last century ''the phone company'' was a source of much consumer frustration and countless complaints. These days, however, anyone with a computer and an Internet connection can try to do better, by placing calls over the Web.

title: Economic Scene; There are fewer summer jobs for teenagers, but that might not hurt long term.
description: SUMMERTIME and the living is supposed to be easy. But for many teenagers looking for work, this summer is shaping up as a disappointment. As Ira Gershwin might have put it: the fish are not jumping and the cotton is not quite so high.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Steel Bands Plan Boycott of Brooklyn's West Indian Parade
description: By the calendar, it is pan time in Brooklyn, the annual rite of summer when hundreds of Caribbean immigrants and their American-born children turn sidewalks, vacant lots -- any sliver of concrete they can find -- into late-night practice yards for Panorama, the popular steel band showdown that begins the West Indian American Labor Day weekend carnival.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Loss Widens At Level 3
description: The broadband communications services provider Level 3 Communications said yesterday that its loss in the second quarter widened to $731 million, or $1.99 a share, from $281 million, or 77 cents, in the period last year. The company, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., said its customer roster declined by 24 percent, to 2,275, in the second quarter from 2,975 in the first. Level 3, which operates a large fiber optic network in North America and Europe, has been hurt by a drought in financing for communications companies and other companies that could lease capacity on its system. Level 3 shares dropped 23 cents, or 5.7 percent, to $3.78. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Says Education Can Prevent Illness
description: Campaigning in the shadow of City Hall yesterday, Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican candidate for mayor, said the city should do more to prevent diseases like diabetes and asthma by educating residents about proper diet and cleanliness.

title: Hevesi Leads in Money From, and Returned to, Intermediaries
description: Money bundled in large chunks by prominent city lawyers, business executives and bankers is continuing to pour into Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's campaign at a rate that far exceeds those of his Democratic rivals for mayor.

title: A De La Hoya Rematch Is Not on Mosley's Mind
description: Shane Mosley, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, has been closely linked to Oscar De La Hoya.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Strike Ends At 3 Buildings
description: Cleaning workers at three downtown office buildings returned to work on Tuesday after being on strike for three months against the buildings' cleaning contractor, Planned Building Services. The 30 workers returned after the managers of the buildings, 32 Broadway, 39 Broadway and 42 Broadway, canceled their contracts with the company and hired One Source, a union cleaning contractor. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: The Florida Vote: Rearguing the Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTERMAN, RORI
description: ATTERMAN-Rori. The oldest cousin in my family. Apart most of our lives, I'll never forget our childhood. You'll always be that sweet, funny, confident, beautiful, tall blond girl ready for adventure. I was always proud to talk about your accomplishments. You'll always have a place in my heart. I.G.

title: Metro Matters; Happy Voters Are the Stuff Of Dull Races
description: FOR just over an hour yesterday morning, Alan G. Hevesi stood at the subway entrance on 23rd Street and Eighth Avenue and shook the hands of everyone coming and going.

title: Sentimental Favorite Montgomerie Leads British Open
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 19 - In the stellar career of Colin Montgomerie, his failure to win a major championship is a painful void, and his dreadful performance in the British Open is baffling.

title: AT&T Rejects Comcast Offer On Cable Unit; Halts Spinoff
description: No thanks, Mr. Roberts and Mr. Roberts. Anyone else?

title: A Creative Partner Leaves Ground Zero
description: Kirk Souder, creative partner at Ground Zero in Marina del Rey, Calif., is leaving the agency to spend more time with his family and travel, said Jim Smith, chairman.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Florida Bound
description: JetBlue Airways, the low-fare airline that began operating last year, is offering $59 one-way fares between New York and Florida. The fares are available for some seats on flights from Kennedy International Airport to Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach, Orlando, Tampa and Fort Myers, Fla., the airline said. Tickets must be purchased by Aug. 8, for travel between Sept. 4 and Oct. 31.

title: Parole for 11-Year-Old's Murderer And Other Killers Could Come Early
description: The State Supreme Court today denied the attorney general's request for a rehearing on a ruling that overturned a 70-year jail sentence for Samuel A. Manzie, the teenager who confessed to murdering an 11-year-old boy who was selling candy door to door for a school fund-raiser.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: 4 O'Clock and All's Abloom

title: Silver Picks Group to Study School Control
description: In a sign that the State Assembly's opposition to mayoral control of New York City schools may be softening, Speaker Sheldon Silver has appointed a committee to study the issue and make recommendations.

title: Why Isn't the U.S. Making Friends?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jia Lanpo, 92, Archaeologist Who Led Work on Peking Man
description: Jia Lanpo, one of China's leading archaeologists and a director of the Peking man excavation, died on July 8 at his home in Beijing. He was 92.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Nuclear Stance
description: The Czech government rejected a call by Germany to shut the $2.5 billion Temelin nuclear power plant, which is about 37 miles from the German and Austrian borders. The reactor has been plagued with problems since it began operating in October. Both Germany and Austria say that Temelin's twin Soviet-designed reactors are unsafe, despite the installation of Western-built control systems. ''The government has no reason to doubt the nuclear and environmental safety of the Temelin plant,'' the Czech prime minister, Milos Zeman, said. Mr. Zeman said he would talk with the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schuessel, after a recently completed report on Temelin is published, but he gave no date. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKEER, BARBARA
description: SKEER-Barbara. Beloved wife of Frederick. Devoted mother of Jeffrey and Kenneth. Dear sister of Phyllis Morse. Services Friday 12 noon at Gutterman's Funeral Home (Parkside Building) 98-60 Queens Blvd., Rego Park, Queens.

title: Addenda: Agencies Close Unit and Make Layoffs
description: One agency is closing its design unit and another agency is laying people off.

title: Transcript of Steve and Michele Kubby's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, July 17, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted medical marijuana activists Steve and Michele Kubby . This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; American Express to Cut Jobs As Junk Bond Losses Mount
description: American Express surprised investors yesterday by saying that it would eliminate as many as 5,000 jobs and take more than $1 billion in charges against its earnings by the end of this quarter.

title: CALENDAR
description: Harbor Tour

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HELEN S.
description: ROSENBERG-Helen S. On July 15, 2001. Beloved mother of Hillary Volper, cherished grandmother of Erik and Mandy. Funeral at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI, on July 19, 10:30 AM.

title: Smithsonian Museum Close To Naming a Hall for G.M.
description: The Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History has offered General Motors the right to name a new 20,000-square-foot hall of transportation in exchange for a $10 million gift, museum officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Suspect In Huge Blast Surrenders
description: A man suspected of illegally storing explosives that accidentally detonated early Monday, killing 47 people in northern Shaanxi Province, surrendered to the police, state news media said. Ma Shigui was said to have moved the explosives to his brother's home after safety inspectors shut his illegal explosives factory in April. Mr. Ma faces a potential death sentence for the accident.

title: Agencies Close Unit And Make Layoffs
description: One agency is closing its design unit and another agency is laying people off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMDHANIE, BASDEO ''TAN''
description: RAMDHANIE-Basdeo ''Tan''. On July 4, 2001. Husband of Ena. Father of Randolph, Keith, Sue-Lynn, Kelvin and Michele.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALISTA, BARBARA F.
description: KALISTA-Barbara F. Died on July 17 in Port Washington, NY. Sister of Phyllis Kalista Scobbo of Port Washington. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, July 20 at 9:30 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Chinese Citizen Files Human-Rights Suit
description: A Chinese citizen is suing a Chinese government official in a federal court in Manhattan, accusing the official of torturing him and murdering his brother and mother in China. Lawyers for the Chinese citizen, Peng Liang, served legal papers Tuesday night on the official, Zhao Zhifei. Under the Torture Victim Protection Act of 1992, human rights victims, even if they are nonresident foreigners, can file for claims in federal court as long as the defendant is served on American soil. Mr. Peng alleges that Mr. Zhao, head of public security in Hubei Province, had acted against him because Mr. Peng is a member of the Falun Gong spiritual movement.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: PHONE MAKER IS MOVING An Avaya customer-service center in Parsippany, N.J., and the 348 people who work there are among the latest victims of the telecommunications industry's continued contraction. Avaya, a spinoff of Lucent Technologies that makes office-phone equipment, said yesterday that it would close the center and move the jobs there to Atlanta and Oklahoma City. The shift is part of a restructuring announced last month that will trim 3,000 jobs within a year because of declining orders for telephones. Paula Horii, a spokeswoman for Avaya, said some of the workers in Parsippany would be offered jobs elsewhere, and others can opt for early retirement or buyouts.

title: Wreaking Havoc Behind the Wheel
description: TWISTED METAL: BLACK

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a house built for Joel B. Dean in East Hampton, N.Y., misspelled the name of its designer and of his firm. He is Jack Ceglic, not Ceglik.

title: Apple Announces Price Cuts And Product Improvements
description: Apple Computer Inc. announced yesterday a series of aggressive performance improvements and price cuts on its desktop computers for consumers and professionals, and previewed the first upgrade of its new OS X operating system.

title: Pataki Objects to U.S. Plan For Drilling in Finger Lakes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's administration came out today against a Bush administration proposal for oil and gas drilling in the Finger Lakes National Forest, after the governor came under fire for refusing to take a position on the issue.

title: Amateur Night at Shea: Who's on Third? Zeile Is, and Mets Make It Count
description: Bobby Valentine was honored before last night's game at Shea Stadium with a lengthy ceremony that included video tributes, his family by his side, a gift from the Mets and another gift from his players. It took him just four innings to make himself the centerpiece of the game.

title: Call Him Ahab. And That Boat Shed? The Pequod.
description: IT was another muggy day in the Consolidated Yachts boatyard on City Island. Robert D. Simmons, his 32-foot sloop moored at a slip, was watching workers hose down the asphalt floor of a boat shed in preparation for a staging of Orson Welles's two-hour version of ''Moby Dick.''

title: G-8 Leaders Call for 'Third-Party' Monitors for Mideast
description: ROME, July 19  Responding to the increasing fury of violence in the Middle East, the foreign ministers of the major industrialized countries told the Israelis and Palestinians today that they should agree to "third-party" monitors as the most assured way of halting the deteriorating situation.

title: Father and Son Facing Charges In Theft of Gas And Electricity
description: A father and son who distribute petroleum products on Long Island have been charged with stealing other forms of energy: thousands of dollars' worth of electricity and natural gas, Nassau County prosecutors said today.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Old-Media Rights In the Digital Age; Book Business Is Latest Battleground Over Contracts and Copyrights
description: Is this man a thief, and just what is he making off with?

title: Why Isn't the U.S. Making Friends?
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking On the Curmudgeons
description: For 23 years, curmudgeon Andy Rooney has wrapped up each week's "60 Minutes" broadcast with his hilarious, pointed commentary, "A Few Minutes with Andy Rooney." It's not hard to guess what his slant is going to be on a given topic -- they put less coffee into coffee cans these days, there's too much junk mail -- but it's often laugh-out-loud funny.

title: Baseball Retreats in Dispute Over Umpires' Pitch Counts
description: The latest development in the pitch-count caper can be summed up in two words: Never mind.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Transgender Discrimination Banned
description: The state has become the second in the country to ban discrimination against transsexuals, cross-dressers and others who cross sex boundaries. The law, which became effective without the governor's signature, prohibits discrimination based on ''gender identity or expression'' in housing, employment and credit. Gay rights advocates say the law will ensure that a worker cannot be fired for having ''sex reassignment'' surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, KATHARINE
description: GRAHAM-Katharine. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board and Members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note the death of our dedicated friend and generous supporter, Kay Graham. Her vision and civic endeavors were an inspiration to us all. In 1993, UCP was proud to bestow the Annual Humanitarian Award upon her. The many individuals at UCP/NYC who have benefited from her generosity join us in extending our heartfelt condolences to her family. Leo Hausman, Chairman Martin C. Hausman, President UCP/NYC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, LOUIS S.
description: BLOCH-Louis S. Husband of Emily (nee Brooks), father of Amy, brother of Robert (Nancy). Services July 19, in Cleveland, OH. Funeral services are at BerkowitzKumin-Bookatz, 1-800-448-2210.

title: Child Well-Being Improves, U.S. Says
description: By many social, financial, educational and health measures, the well-being of America's children has been improving, according to a new report from the federal government.

title: A PowerPad Laptop Battery That May Be a Better Wallet Fit
description: Electrofuel, the company that managed to make a laptop battery that looks like a mouse pad, has come out with a new version of its signature product, the PowerPad external lithium-ion battery. And while the new model packs less of a charge than the original, it also has less of a price tag.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Ex-Ambassador Urged To Run For Governor
description: Pete Peterson, a Democrat who ended his four-year tenure as the nation's first postwar ambassador to Vietnam on Sunday, was greeted as he returned to Tallahassee by 50 supporters who want him to run for governor against the incumbent Republican, Jeb Bush. Mr. Peterson, 66, who represented North Florida in Congress for six years, said he had not decided whether to run, but he told supporters to keep their ''Run, Pete, Run'' signs. Other possible Democratic candidates include former Attorney General Janet Reno. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Oil Company Sales
description: The country's second-largest oil company, Woodside Petroleum Ltd., said sales in the second quarter rose 9.7 percent, helped in part by the lower Australian dollar. Revenue increased to 552.3 million dollars ($283.3 million) in the three months ended June 30, from 503.5 million dollars ($259 million) a year earlier. Domestic gas production was higher than planned because of strong demand, the company said. Oil production fell over all last quarter. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Woods Discovers Some Sand in His Carburetor
description: Forget about thoughts that Tiger Woods will avoid all the bunkers at the British Open this year. And forget about seeing him cruise to a comfortable victory.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Montgomerie Is Off to a Flying Start
description: Whether he was splitting fairways with tee shots, or throwing dartlike approach shots into greens, Colin Montgomerie had the feeling that all golfers treasure: his ball would do what he wanted.

title: Gunther Gebel-Williams, Circus Animal Trainer, Dies at 66
description: Gunther Gebel-Williams, who taught lions to ride on the backs of skittish horses, leopards to jump through flaming hoops held by the gleaming teeth of tigers, and elephants to take calm, leisurely walks through roaring traffic in the nation's busiest cities, died yesterday at his home in Venice, Fla. He was 66.

title: P. Diddy and the Bad Boy Family's 'The Saga Continues'
description: P. DIDDY AND THE BAD BOY FAMILY: "The Saga Continues . . ." (Bad Boy/Arista). What if Sean (Puffy) Combs looked like Suge Knight? What if, instead of prancing around the Hamptons in a pink Oxford shirt, dating celebrities, cozying up to Regis and rapping gangsta lite in an effete mumble, he was a huge, intimidating ex-bodyguard who flaunted gang affiliations and a beyond- the-law hard-core-rap empire? Chances are that Mr. Combs wouldn't be flaunting the survival skills and not-guilty verdicts that he does on his third album. That he calls himself P. Diddy these days is just one more example of his slipperiness. Who is he? Is he good or evil? Gentle or brutal?

title: EchoStar Earns $2.25 Million
description: EchoStar Communications, the television satellite broadcaster, said today that it had an unexpected second-quarter profit, though it also warned that it might add fewer subscribers this year than previously forecast.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: School Cost Overruns No Secret, Official Says
description: Members of the Board of Education howled in protest earlier this month when they learned that the cost of building new schools and repairing old ones was running far above estimates -- so far above that the school system now faces a $1.9 billion shortfall in its current $7 billion capital budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, FERN W. (NEE WEST)
description: JAFFE-Fern W. (nee West). In her 76th year. Extraordinary mother of Carl. Special & devoted friend and cousin of many throughout the country. A proud veteran and devoted social worker. She was a giving and devoted person to all, while always remaining true to her principles. While she will be greatly missed, her legacy will live on through the lives she touched. Funeral service Sunday, July 22nd, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made in Fern's memory to Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, N.Y., New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCHINGER, BRIAN
description: ASCHINGER-Brian. The American Musical and Dramatic Academy mourns the loss of its beloved teacher, director, conductor, colleague, and friend, who passed away on July 18. A memorial celebration to be held in tribute in late September. David Martin and Jan Martin The Faculty and Staff of AMDA

title: Among Neighbors of MX Missiles, Little Neutrality
description: The small cement slab on Ed Weppner's ranch is surrounded by a barbed wire fence bearing a sign warning that deadly force will be used against intruders. Mr. Weppner's home is less than a mile away.

title: 'Massless Medium' -- 'Explorations in Sensory Immersion'
description: Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage

title: Forget the Tour Bus; Stay a Night; Hotels Are Signing Up to Join the Harlem Renaissance
description: When the Hotel Theresa, known as the Waldorf of Harlem, closed its doors in 1966, the idea of out-of-town visitors staying in the heritage-rich but harrowed neighborhood faded into history. Over subsequent decades, a few pioneers opened hostels or bed-and-breakfasts, mostly to serve venturesome Europeans. By and large, however, most visitors confined their time in Harlem to a few hours, and their vista to a tour bus window.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Big Loss At Chip Maker
description: Hynix Semiconductor said that it had a pretax loss of $976 million for the second quarter, compared with a pretax loss of $360 million in the first quarter. The company also reported an operating loss of $203 million in the second quarter after posting a profit of $52 million for the first quarter. The results sent the company's stock tumbling 10.4 percent, closing at a record low of 1,515 won on the Korea Stock Exchange. Hynix's chairman, Park Chong Sup, said the company, after suspending operations at its Eugene, Ore., plant on Wednesday, might have to reduce production at its three plants in Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARO, MARGHERITA SHIELDS
description: KARO-Margherita Shields. Died at her home in NYC July 9, 2001. Known as Nan, she was born July 7, 1939 in Dublin, Ireland, but spent the bulk of her life in New York. She was a 1961 graduate of Radcliffe College. Nan was an esteemed Wall Street securities analyst for over 30 years. She leaves behind many loving friends and is survived by her brother, Frank Shields. She was the aunt of Clodagh Coghlan, Henrietta, Oliver and Alexander Shields. For many years, she was the loving wife of Tamas A. Karo. Services will be held on July 25th at 2PM at St. John the Martyr, E. 72 St. betw. 3rd & 2nd Avenue, where Nan was an active member. A reception following the service will take place at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66 St. Contributions in Nan's memory may be made to St. John the Martyr (212-744-4880).

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Stake Sale
description: China's fifth-largest bank, the Bank of Communications, said it had received approval to sell a minority stake to foreign investors to increase its capital and improve its management skills. The bank said it planned to sell about 15 percent of its equity to at least two foreign financial institutions, Reuters reported. A few of China's smaller banks, including the Bank of Shanghai and Xiamen International Bank, have already sold minority stakes to foreign investors. Craig S. Smith

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Sister Sent To Labor Camp
description: The sister of a labor activist has been charged with subversion and sentenced to three years in a labor camp, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said. Li Wangling is apparently being punished for talking to foreign reporters after her brother Li Wangyang staged a hunger strike earlier this year to demand that a prison in which he had been incarcerated pay his medical bills. He was arrested again in May and charged with subversion. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Company Receives Rent Break
description: Eyebeam Atelier, a nonprofit arts and technology company in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, has been approved for rent abatement from the New York City Economic Development Corporation. Eyebeam is the first company to receive rent abatement as part of the E.D.C.'s commercial expansion program. Eyebeam Atelier will receive $11,275 in rent abatement for each of the next three years, with a phaseout in the fourth and fifth years of the program, officials said yesterday. New tenants in Dumbo are eligible to save up to $15 per square foot per year through the program, meant to encourage businesses to expand or relocate outside the most crowded sections of Manhattan. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: As the World Warms: More Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivane Neuenschwander and Iran do Esprito Santo
description: The Americas Society

title: U.S. at Odds With Europe Over Rules on World Drug Pricing
description: Before the United Nations has even raised up to $10 billion for its new fund to fight AIDS, the Bush administration and the European Union are engaged in a behind-the-scenes struggle over how that money will be spent, particularly on pharmaceutical drugs.

title: INSIDE
description: Genome Project Views Race

title: A Grown-Up La Scala Ballet Shows Off Its Edge
description: In the late 19th century, the ballet company of La Scala opera house in Milan produced the best dancers in the world. Russians adored them. Every version today of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' ''The Nutcracker'' and ''Swan Lake'' harks back to the Italian ballerinas who starred in these works' earliest productions in St. Petersburg.

title: National Team to Play at Area Parks
description: The United States national baseball team, which won the gold medal at the Sydney Olympics last year, will face Taiwan in a series of exhibition games at minor league parks in the New York metropolitan area. The first game is tomorrow at EAB Park, in Central Islip, N.Y., the home of the minor league Long Island Ducks.

title: Green's Tactic For Support: Slight Changes In the Message
description: Mark Green won endorsements yesterday from black ministers and a group of Hasidic Jews as he hop-scotched around Manhattan in what his advisers said was an attempt to demonstrate the ideological and ethnic breadth of his political support.

title: Board's Opinion Allows 2 Sides To Claim Victory
description: Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's mayoral campaign must pay the full market value for services it receives from its political consultants, but individual consultants can volunteer for him, a statement from the Campaign Finance Board yesterday suggested.

title: Saved By a Sequel?
description: The summer has been an uneasy one for the Hollywood movie machine. Hampered at first by threats of writers' and actors' strikes that never materialized, it kicked off like gangbust ers at the box office in May with hits like ''Shrek'' and ''The Mummy Returns'' that promised record-setting lucre before Labor Day cooled the flames.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRAFESA, JOHN, SR.
description: PETRAFESA-John, Sr. Disney Theatricals honors the life and memory of John Petrafesa, Sr. who died suddenly on July 18, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Millicent, his son and daughter-inlaw John, Jr. and Melissa, his daughter and son-in-law Jennifer and Brian McLaughlin and two grandchildren Aidan, Patrick McLaughlin and Katie Petrafesa. Wake today 3-8PM at Redgate Hennessy Funeral Parlor, Trumbull, CT. Funeral on Saturday, July 21st, 1 PM, St. Thomas Church, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers donations to Dominican Sisters of Hope, 299 N. Highland Ave., Ossining, N.Y. 10562 or Assumption School, 591 Stratfield Road, Fairfield, CT. 06432.

title: False Claims From Fake Crashes Leads to Charges Against 172
description: Capping a 19-month investigation, prosecutors today announced the indictment of 172 people in New Jersey, including a medical doctor, a lawyer and two chiropractors, charging them with staging 19 automobile accidents and filing false medical claims totaling more than $5 million.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: LIBERTY MUTUAL TO ACQUIRE 3 ROYAL AND SUN BUSINESSES
description: Liberty Mutual Insurance of Boston has agreed to buy three Spanish subsidiaries from the Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group of London for 134 million ($190 million). Liberty Mutual will buy Royal and Sun Alliance S.A., Royal and Sun Alliance Vida y Pensiones and Regal Insurance Club, the company said. This is Liberty Mutual's second purchase in Spain this year. In the first quarter, the company bought Hartford Seguros, a life and auto insurer, from Hartford Financial Services. Royal and Sun has been selling unprofitable businesses to focus on units giving at least a 10 percent return.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PEERCE, STUART B.
description: PEERCE-Stuart B. The six years have passed so quickly. You are in our thoughts and our hearts. Rest in peace. Love All Of Us.

title: Jeffrey Archer, Guilty of Perjury, Is Jailed for Four Years
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire author and member of the House of Lords with a roguish past of surviving repeated brushes with scandal, was convicted on perjury charges today and jailed for four years.

title: After Last Year's Bacchanal, a Quieter Webby Party
description: The fourth annual Webby Awards, honoring excellence and innovation on Internet sites, felt more like a bacchanal. Held in Nob Hill, one of the city's ritziest neighborhoods, the event, from the candlelit pre-party at the Grace Cathedral, to the post-party, under white tents at a scrupulously groomed park, was all wild costumes, slinky models, and food, wine and spirits every which way you looked.

title: In a Skirmish Along Party Lines, Daschle Talks of Isolationism and Republicans Fire Back
description: As President Bush began his second trip to Europe since taking office, a partisan battle erupted at home over the direction of his foreign policy -- and the propriety of criticizing a president while he is overseas.

title: SPRINT EARNINGS FALL, BUT SHARES OF WIRELESS UNIT RISE
description: Sprint, the long-distance phone company, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings fell 35 percent as its sales slipped. Its wireless unit, Sprint PCS, signed up more new users than expected, and its shares rose more than 10 percent. Net income for Sprint was $290 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $443 million, or 50 cents, a year ago, the company, of Westwood, Kan., said. Analysts had expected profit of 28 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales slid 3 percent, to $4.31 billion. Sprint shares rose 67 cents, to $22.60; the tracking shares of Sprint PCS climbed $2.45, to $25.49.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Sierra Club Considers a Mutual Fund
description: The Sierra Club, the oldest, largest and most influential environmental advocacy group in the country, wants to start a mutual fund using its well-known name to attract individual investors' money into the shares of companies that meet the club's strict standards for environmental performance.

title: As the World Warms: More Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Stored Artifacts In Peril
description: A report by the state Council of Professional Archaeologists has found that thousands of artifacts in state museums are in peril because of improper storage. Inventory methods and climate controls must meet federal standards. The threatened collections include Indian artifacts, and some museums have stopped accepting artifacts because of a lack of money and space. Without storage arrangements, some future archaeological digs may have to be canceled. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Knoblauch Not Starting As Team Ponders Trades
description: Chuck Knoblauch was dropped from the starting lineup tonight as club officials considered trades for players who could replace him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESCH, CARL W.
description: DESCH-Carl W. On July 18, 2001 of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of the late Katharine W. Loving father of Carol, Carl Jr. and Barbara and grandfather of 7 grandchildren. Also survived by his sister Margaret Hanft. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 & 7-9 PM Friday. Religious service Garden City Community Church, 9AM Saturday. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Red Cross appreciated.

title: The Murderers and Robbers Next Door
description: The lurid stories may be dated, but ''Murder They Wrote'' feels right on the news in this tabloid summer of Andrea P. Yates (the Houston mother accused of drowning her five children) and Chandra Ann Levy (the missing Washington intern).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, LOUIS S.
description: BLOCH-Louis S. Husband of Emily (nee Brooks), father of Amy, brother of Robert (Nancy), son of Ann and the late Jerome S. Services July 19, in Cleveland, OH. Funeral services are at BerkowitzKumin-Bookatz, 1-800-448-2210.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHLAG, ELIZABETH G.
description: OSHLAG-Elizabeth G. On July 18. Services Sunday, July 29, Temple Israel, New Rochelle, NY. George T. Davis F.H., New Rochelle.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Aceh Autonomy
description: Indonesia's Parliament passed a bill granting broad autonomy to the rebellious but resource-rich province of Aceh. In addition to allowing the conservatively Muslim province to impose Islamic law, the bill includes handing over 70 percent of the royalties collected from sales of Aceh's oil and natural gas. In March, growing unrest forced Exxon Mobil to suspend operations at natural gas fields in Aceh, a move that cost Indonesia about $400 million in income as troops restored security. Exxon Mobil resumed operations in Aceh this week. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Oklahoma Governor Refuses to Stay Execution of Mexican
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 — Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma refused today to further delay the execution of a Mexican who killed a man he had met in a bar.

title: A Pot Dealer, a Drifter and the Pig That Gets in the Way
description: Christopher Hanson's ''Scrapple'' is a completely uncondescending, nearly letter-perfect re-creation of a late 60's-early 70's stoner comedy. As such, it's a very strange cultural artifact, though not an unappealing one. It opens today for an exclusive run at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater in the East Village.

title: Mets Should Hold On to Rusch
description: The conversation took place in a Port St. Lucie, Fla., hotel last March and lasted about three minutes, but they were three revealing minutes. Dave Stewart had seen Glendon Rusch dominate a spring training game for the Mets and gave an unsolicited glowing scouting report to a reporter. Stewart, the Toronto Blue Jays' assistant general manager and a four-time 20-game winner, sounded as if he would have traded for Rusch immediately.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Minor Surgery For Heart Patient
description: The first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart had minor surgery this week to create an opening in his neck so a breathing tube could be passed into his windpipe and connected to a ventilator. Previously, the tube had been passed through his mouth. The procedure, done to make him more comfortable, allows the recipient, identified only as a man in his 50's, to sit in a chair. The surgeons in Louisville, Ky., plan to take him off the ventilator for short periods until he can breathe on his own. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: 'In an Exuberant and Profuse Manner'
description: Bose Pacia Modern

title: Forecasting Index Registers Third Consecutive Increase
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose for a third month in June, a private research firm said today, suggesting growth may accelerate by the end of the year.

title: Toward Ending Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, SEYMOUR
description: FALK-Seymour. 77. Of Hemlock Farms in Lords Valley, PA and Hillsboro Mile, FL. On July 19 after a long struggle with cancer. Husband of Estelle, father of Barbara Falk Barbour of Allentown, PA and Janet Falk Kessler of Cortlandt Manor, NY, grandfather of Joshua, Jonathan, Samuel, Rebecca and Daniel. Funeral Services, Sunday, July 22, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside, 76th & Amsterdam''.

title: Indictments Charge 4 Racetrack Tellers With Laundering Money at Betting Windows
description: Four racetrack tellers used the flow of cash through betting windows to launder money, law enforcement officials said today, announcing indictments in a widening circle of investigations into the people who run and staff New York's premier tracks.

title: Two Bright Spots in Technology Give Lift to Share Prices
description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday, led by the technology sector, after Nokia reported better-than-expected earnings and Dell Computer stood by its profit forecast.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Officer Accused Of Perjury
description: A Nassau County police officer was charged yesterday with initiating an improper sexual relationship with a woman cooperating as a witness in drug investigations and then lying about the relationship under oath, said county prosecutors. Because of the relationship, alleged to have taken place in 1998, drug possession charges against the woman were dismissed and her credibility as a witness undermined, prosecutors said. The detective, Cleve Frazier, 45, and an 18-year veteran, has been indicted on charges of perjury and official misconduct, said Philip L. Tomich, a senior prosecutor. Mr. Frazier's lawyer denied that his client had had a sexual relationship with the woman. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Early Winner in Online Food; Local and Simple Ways Work for British Grocer
description: John Browett, the chief executive of Tesco.com, the online arm of Britain's largest supermarket chain, is no stranger to the intricacies of home delivery. So when he visited the warehouse of an Internet grocery company in the United States last year, he noticed that it was using a fancy conveyor belt to ferry boxes around a corner, when another gadget would have done the job for half the price.

title: As the World Warms: More Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Adult Trials Are Sought In Man's Death
description: Twelve teenagers charged with beating a homeless man to death during an after-school rampage last month should be tried as adults, prosecutors said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Down the Stretch, Johnson Stops To Promote Track
description: MICHAEL JOHNSON emerged from a side entrance and stepped onto the track at the Armory Track and Field Center in Washington Heights yesterday afternoon. About 50 junior high- and high school-aged runners, seated on the track in front of a podium, applauded.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Prosecutors Hold Soldiers
description: Prosecutors said they had detained six Russian soldiers in an investigation into complaints that scores of civilians were tortured and their homes looted when Russian troops swept through three villages in Chechnya this month. A Chechen prosecutor, Viktor Dakhnov, told the Interfax news service that he now has evidence that the soldiers were goaded into their ''excessively cruel acts'' by unnamed local residents. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALLON, JOHN T. (JACK)
description: FALLON-John T. (Jack) Of Weston, Ma.,Osterville, Ma. and Roslindale, Ma; on July 19, 2001, age 77. Former Chairman and CEO of R. M. Bradley, Inc. Survived by his wife Antoinette (Mayer) Fallon; sister Anne Jones and husband Payson Jones of Falmouth, Ma.; daughter Pamela Jagla and husband Kevin Jagla of Portland, Or., son William and wife Susan of Campton, NH; son John and wife Patrice of Osterville, Ma.; five grandchildren and several nieces. Mass Funeral will be held on Tuesday, July 24th, 11am at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, Osterville, Ma. Family and friends are respectfully invited. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Wianno Senior Class Association, POB 159, Osterville, Ma. 02655. For information John-Lawrence Funeral Home, Marston Mills, Ma.

title: YankeeNets Network Attracts Investors
description: The lineup of investors for the YankeeNets' cable network may be completed by next week, not a moment too soon to hire announcers and production personnel, sell advertising and negotiate with cable systems.

title: Abandon the Olympics
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo in 2019, Paris in 1880
description: Whether by marketing stratagem or plain accident, a week's worth of video releases usually reflects what is playing in movie theaters. For example, amid the novel digital animation in multiplexes this summer comes a DVD special edition of "Akira," Katsuhiro Otomo's violent, groundbreaking animated adventure set in Neo-Tokyo in 2019.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Doubts On Identity Fraud Bill
description: Gov. Bill Owens has indicated doubts about a bill that he signed to allow the Department of Motor Vehicles to buy facial recognition software to be used at driver's license bureaus to prevent people from obtaining multiple identification cards or driver's licenses. The plan, signed into law in the last legislative session, has raised privacy concerns, and in a letter to lawmakers, Governor Owens, a Republican, said he did not think such technology should be used for ''generic fishing expeditions.'' He asked for an extensive review of the new law before it is implemented. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Stock Firm Cuts Staff
description: W. R. Hambrecht & Company, one of the few remaining online investment banks, dismissed 45 employees, or about 20 percent of its staff, this week. The dismissals came as Hambrecht, best known for running online auctions of shares in initial public offerings of stock, decided to stop trading more than 100 stocks. The firm will continue to sell new stocks and bonds through its online auction system. About 30 of the people dismissed were stock traders, said Sharon Smith, a spokeswoman for the three-year-old San Francisco firm. Hambrecht will continue to make markets in stocks it has taken public or that its research analysts cover, she said. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Losses at Delta and Northwest; Southwest Has a Profit
description: Hurt by a slump in business travel, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines reported quarterly losses yesterday and joined other major carriers in announcing cutbacks.

title: Agency Companies Make Acquisitions
description: Deals are being made in direct marketing, advertising and corporate communications.

title: Ticket to Semifinals
description: Janet Lee, a 24-year-old Californian, is ranked 97th in the world. Svetlana Krivencheva, a 27-year-old Bulgarian, is ranked 235th.

title: Los Angeles, Don't Mess With a Tokyo Gangsta
description: It's probably fitting that Takeshi Kitano goes by the nickname Aniki in his yakuza spectacular ''Brother'' because he stirs up some serious anarchy on the Los Angeles crime scene. Mr. Kitano directed, edited and wrote ''Brother'' (aniki is Japanese for brother), and his style of close-to-the-vest brutality travels extremely well.

title: New York Needs a Place to Live
description: Times are still good in New York City, after a long boom coupled with the benefits of a drop in crime. The next mayor, rightly, is expected to focus on fixing the schools. But another slow-motion crisis threatens to undermine the city's progress.

title: Some Letters From I.R.S. Err on Size of Rebate
description: A $33.9 million mass mailing promoted by the White House as a way of heading off confusion about tax rebate checks is instead creating it, especially among the half-million taxpayers who are receiving a government letter this week that promises them a bigger check than they will actually receive.

title: Stocks, Under Pressure From Microsoft, End Lower
description: Stock prices fell today under pressure from Microsoft, which led the three major market indexes lower after it warned that sales and profits in the next quarter would be more sluggish than previously forecast.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMKINS, FREDERICK, JR.
description: TOMKINS-Frederick, Jr. 82. On July 16, 2001, at his home on Seabrook Island, S.C. Survived by his beloved wife of 41 years, Mary; by his children Randolph, Sheridan, Peter, and Victoria; and by 11 grandchildren and one great grandchild.

title: Contractor Is Arrested Over Stairway Removal
description: A contractor was arrested yesterday on charges that he illegally removed three flights of stairs from a 19th-century five-story walk-up building in Manhattan, forcing a rooftop evacuation of dozens of people, the police said.

title: Nortel Posts A Huge Loss For the Quarter
description: The maker of telecommunications equipment Nortel Networks reported a record loss of $19.4 billion, or $6.08 a share, for the second quarter today.

title: For Genome Mappers, the Tricky Terrain of Race Requires Some Careful Navigating
description: Scientists planning the next phase of the human genome project are being forced to confront a treacherous issue: the genetic differences between human races.

title: 8 Months Later, Talks on Climate Treaty Restart, Now in Bonn
description: Nearly eight months after formal talks over a proposed climate treaty fell apart in The Hague, negotiations resumed here today in nearly as tangled and troubled a state.

title: Assembly Speaker Attacks Plan to Expand School Board
description: The speaker of the State Assembly yesterday attacked a proposal by the New York City teachers' union for an expanded Board of Education in which a majority of the members would be appointed by the mayor. With such a structure, Speaker Sheldon Silver said, the mayor would be able to continue shrugging off responsibility for the school system's failures.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: The Yankees Come Home With Plenty to Sort Out
description: The groundskeepers tended to the field after the fifth inning at Comerica Park and Yankees Manager Joe Torre leaned over the dugout railing and looked out, arms folded in front of him. They dragged screening across the infield and raked the dirt, and Torre watched but didn't really see, his mind preoccupied.

title: One Week in London
description: With advance summer reservations to Britain hurt by the reports of the foot-and-mouth epidemic in the spring, many hotels and tour operators are now giving discounts to pick up for lost business. Europe Express has a seven-day package to London, available for selected dates through Aug. 26, starting at $829 a person, based on double occupancy. For that, you get round-trip air fare on Virgin Atlantic from New York or Boston, airport transfers by subway in London, six nights at the tourist-class Queens Park Hotel (nerar Oxford Street), daily Continental breakfast and a coupon book. Upgrading to the Selfridge Hotel brings it to $989 a person; the Howard Hotel is $1,189. Information: (800) 927-3876 or www.europeexpress.com .

title: Nokia Reports 16% Decline In Earnings
