description: Nokia, the world's largest cellular phone maker, reported a decline in second-quarter profit today, its first in five years, and said business would continue to deteriorate in the near future before improving slightly late this year.

title: Across the Hudson Highlands, Sculptures Are Sprouting, Inside and Out
description: Sculpture is the name of the game this summer in the commuting-distance regions of upstate New York. Monumental pieces by Alexander Calder wander across the green acres of the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville. The Paris-born artist Marisol is honored in a modest retrospective at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase. Two bright young talents, Sarah Sze and Tony Feher, commandeer the galleries and grounds of the Center for Curatorial Studies Museum at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Panel Named For Teacher Talks
description: A fact-finding panel has been named to help break the impasse over teachers' pay that has left 110,000 school employees without a contract since November, the Public Employment Relations Board announced yesterday. Daniel G. Collins, professor emeritus of New York University law school, will head the three-member panel. Like Mr. Collins, the other members, Martin F. Scheinman and Rosemary A. Townley, are experienced labor arbitrators, said the employment relations board. Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, the teachers' union, said she welcomed the move. Stephanie Flanders (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba Offers Glum Outlook
description: The software maker Ariba Inc., whose products help companies set up shop on the Web, said its fiscal fourth-quarter sales would be $60 million to $70 million, substantially below the $91.7 million analysts had projected. For its fiscal third quarter, ended June 30, Ariba said that before charges, the company lost $26.1 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with a loss of $11.3 million, or 5 cents, in the period a year earlier. The company also said its chief executive, Larry Mueller, was leaving after three months in the job. Keith Krach, the chairman, would be acting chief executive. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: U.S. May Order Mandatory Recall of Some Firestone Tires
description: The Transportation Department said today that it had asked Bridgestone /Firestone to recall additional tires but the company insisted its tires were safe and said it would state its case at a public hearing and in court.

title: Deal Is Seen Near on Sale of VNU Magazine Unit
description: The Dutch publisher VNU, which recently bought ACNielsen and publishes trade magazines like The Hollywood Reporter and Billboard, is near an agreement to sell its consumer magazine business for about $1.1 billion in cash to Sanoma WSOY of Finland, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: With a Woof and a Meow, The Battle Is Joined Again
description: Cats and Dogs

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Reports Of Phone Sale
description: British Telecommunications has sold its New Zealand unit, Clear Communications, to a consortium of investors and Berkshire Partners of Boston, according to a report by IDG Communications, a provider of information technology news. The consortium includes the investment vehicle of one of New Zealand's richest families, the Todd Corporation, the report said.

title: Arab Landscapes After the Oslo Era
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. Acts to Fine American Over Pilot Rest
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that it was seeking to fine American Airlines $285,000 for violating regulations mandating how many hours pilots can work without rest.

title: Interpreting Jazz for Ears, Eyes and Feet
description: Trisha Brown at her best is poetic rapture shot through with teasing practicality. The ''el'' in ''El Trilogy,'' her latest piece, appears to refer not to fandangos or elevated subways but to the length of the evening-long dance. Presented in its New York premiere by the Lincoln Center Festival on Wednesday night at the La Guardia Concert Hall, ''El Trilogy'' is also the inspired product of a two-year collaboration with the jazz composer and trumpeter Dave Douglas and the painter Terry Winters, who created the sets and costumes

title: British agency companies love it when two big French companies talk media deals with them.
description: THE French are coming! The French are coming!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, MARGA
description: OPPENHEIMER-Marga. Beloved widow of P. Hans Oppenheimer, died peacefully on July 16, 2001. She will be deeply missed by both family and friends. Funeral services Friday, July 20, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Jasper Johns For Philadelphia

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Maker Cuts Back
description: Hitachi Ltd. said it would give workers at its semiconductor plants longer summer holidays to adjust for slumping demand for chips. Workers at its domestic factories will have up to 14 consecutive days of vacation instead of the maximum of 7 days last year. Toshiba and Mitsubishi Electric have announced similar moves while Fujitsu said it would cut production at a plant making flash memory chips in the United States. The cuts reflect a worldwide slowdown in demand for semiconductor chips. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: A Celebrity Couple and the Emptiness of It All
description: Like a bottle of lukewarm Champagne -- an expensive one, judging by the label -- ''America's Sweethearts'' opens with a promising burst of effervescence and quickly goes flat. A voice familiar from countless real-life movie trailers recaps the careers of the fictitious movie stars Eddie Thomas and Gwen Harrison, played by the real-life movie stars John Cusack and Catherine Zeta-Jones.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Anti-Semitic Graffiti
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday and charged with spray-painting anti-Semitic remarks and swastikas on a block in Brooklyn this week, the police said. The boy, Maxim Tcherkassov, was charged with felony criminal mischief, aggravated harassment and making graffiti, the police said. On Monday, large black swastikas were painted on seven homes along East 12th Street between Avenue K and Avenue L in Midwood, where many Orthodox Jews live, the police said. Graffiti was also painted on a synagogue on East 13th Street. The police said they were looking for three others who were with Mr. Tcherkassov. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZINGER, JOHN F.
description: HOLZINGER-John F. Dobbs Ferry, NY, died July 16, 2001. Born in Manhattan January 8, 1911, grew up in Riverdale and graduated from Columbia University in 1931. He served as Lt. Commander in the US Navy, directing landing craft during the WWII invasion at Omaha Beach. John established the real estate firm, Barhite & Holzinger, Inc. in 1935, in Manhattan, moving its headquarters to Bronxville, in 1969. He retired in 1995. On March 4, 1938, John married Claire Heffernan. She survives as does his son John F. Holzinger, his daughter Dana Dyas and four grandchildren. Services will be private. Contributions to Dobbs Ferry Public Library, 153 Main St. Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522 or American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York 10601.

title: Ventura Is Prepared for a Shake-Up
description: Robin Ventura was a member of the Chicago White Sox in 1997 when the team traded many of its top players despite being within striking distance of first place. Unlike the White Sox, the Mets are not within striking distance of anything except last place in the National League East. They, too, may have a drastically new look by the end of the month.

title: In Connecticut, David Smith and Lord Snowdon Reign
description: Whatever its other virtues Connecticut is a fine place to look at art, particularly in the summer when the New York scene goes sleepy. This year the range seems particularly strong, from a Picasso show in Hartford to a David Smith presentation clear across the state in New London. In between one could visit a show about art and the law in Ridgefield; view a vastly entertaining display of photographs by Lord Snowdon, former husband of Princess Margaret, in New Haven; and see what Yale's gallery has been up to since it started collecting in 1832.

title: Residential Real Estate; Draw to Brighton Beach Is by the Sea, by the Sea
description: For buyers at the Oceana condominium development, which is taking shape on 15 acres once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, a major attraction is the same thing that once drew bathers -- the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Argentina's Austerity Plan Provokes Nationwide Strike
description: Several labor confederations began a crippling 24-hour nationwide strike today to protest the Argentine government's new austerity plan, which cuts public wages and pensions by up to 13 percent to avert a default on foreign debt payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, KATHARINE
description: GRAHAM-Katharine. The Board and staff of the Committee to Protect Journalists mourn the passing of Katharine Graham, longtime board member and dedicated press freedom advocate. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the Graham family.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Fatal Car Crash
description: A car careered out of control last evening and crashed into a knot of people on the sidewalk, killing one and sending three others to University Hospital in critical condition, the police said. The car, a black Ford Explorer, was westbound on 12th Avenue toward South Sixth Street when it swerved around another vehicle at an intersection before going out of control about 9:15 p.m., said Detective Eugenio Gonzalez Jr., a Newark police spokesman. He said three occupants of the car were being held for questioning, but had no immediate information on reports from witnesses that the Explorer was being chased by police. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: More Talks With Pakistan
description: A day after Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar, said India and Pakistan had come close to a deal at their summit meeting that would be a foundation for future talks, India announced that Foreign Minister Jaswant Singh would meet Mr. Sattar in Pakistan. No date has been set. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Betwixt, Between On a Glam Frontier
description: Is the world ready for Hedwig? Or more precisely, is the T-shirted, baseball-capped world beyond the Off Broadway milieu where it was a runaway stage success ready for the screen version of ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch''?

title: Stocks, Under Pressure From Microsoft, End Lower
description: Stock prices slipped today under pressure from Microsoft, which led the three major market indexes lower after it warned that sales and profits in the next quarter would be lower than previously forecast.

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL HOLDINGS IS BUYING AMERICAN BANK
description: American Financial Holdings, the bank holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy American Bank of Connecticut for $153 million. The purchase would increase the assets of American Financial Holdings to $2.8 billion from $1.9 billion, and double the number of branches to 34 from 17. Under the agreement, shareholders of American Bank, Waterbury, Conn., can receive either 1.304 American Financial Holdings shares for each American Bank share, $30 in cash, or a combination. American Financial Holdings, based in New Britain, Conn., owns American Savings Bank. Its shares were down 64 cents, to $22.36. American Bank shares rose $4.63, to $28.83.

title: Watching Movies With . . ./Kevin Smith; The Thrill Is Just Talk
description: WORDS, words, words. They come spilling out of ''A Man for All Seasons'' in great torrents that spin and swell into rapids, a furious river of words. And Paul Scofield wraps his dour face and deep-timbred voice around Robert Bolt's dialogue with such satisfying, calculated calibration.

title: Analysts' Group Halts Forums on Companies
description: The New York Society of Security Analysts, one of the nation's largest organizations devoted to advancing the quality of security analysis, has halted its public forums examining management's responsibility to shareholders at public companies.

title: Editorial Observer; The Risks and Rewards of Ranch Diplomacy
description: Act II of the most intriguing and potentially important diplomatic drama of George W. Bush's presidency will unfold this weekend in the Italian seaport of Genoa when Mr. Bush renews his unexpected friendship with President Vladimir Putin of Russia.

title: Senate Confirms Black Judge Whom Clinton Named in Recess
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The Senate confirmed its first federal judges today since the Democrats took control in May, including Roger Gregory, who was initially named to the bench by former President Bill Clinton in a recess appointment after the Republican-run Senate stalled his nomination.

title: House Backs Aid for Charities Operated by Religious Groups
description: The House passed legislation today that would expand government financing of the social work of religious charities, after the Republican leadership beat back a strong challenge from Democrats and Republican moderates over civil rights.

title: Enron Unit in India Asks for Arbitration in Power Dispute
description: BANGALORE, India, July 19  Dabhol Power, the Indian unit of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ), asked the Supreme Court of India today to revive arbitration proceedings in its dispute with a western Indian state utility company that was the sole customer of its $2.9 billion power project.

title: Exchange Ends Rebate Program
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange, in another sign of declining profitability of Wall Street trading, canceled a rebate program today that had helped the exchange compete for options business.

title: Sun Posts Quarterly Loss For First Time in 12 Years
description: Sun Microsystems posted its first quarterly loss in more than a decade yesterday, as orders from customers in Europe and Japan continued to dwindle.

title: S.E.C. Nominee Says Rules Need a Review
description: In his first public appearance since being selected to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey L. Pitt said today that he would undertake a comprehensive review of the agency's rules and regulations with the aim of simplifying and reducing them.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Protesters Defy Ban
description: More than 10,000 people in the political opposition defied a government ban on a rally in Colombo and assembled to protest President Chandrika Kumaratunga's suspension of Parliament. The police used tear gas, rubber bullets and riot sticks to disperse the crowds. Parliament, which was to take a no-confidence vote on the government that Mrs. Kumaratunga feared losing, is to remain suspended until Sept. 7. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Nepal Premier Resigns; Caught in Chaos After Royal Blood Bath
description: Nepal's prime minister, Girija Prasad Koirala, resigned today, succumbing to pressures from a bribery scandal in his government, a Maoist insurgency in the countryside and last month's macabre blood bath in the royal palace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, EDWIN F.
description: POTTER-Edwin F. On July 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Frances. Dear father of Laura and Paul. Loving grandfather of Daniel, John and Emily. Brother of the late Richard and Thomas. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC Friday 4-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 9AM Saint Columba Church.

title: Beck Brewery Up for Sale; Foreign Bids Are Expected
description: More than 125 years after their family began brewing beer, the owners of Beck's, Germany's top-selling export brew, said today that the company was for sale.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Sizing Up Military Might And Mission
description: Pentagon planners went back to work to match the proposed size of the United States' armed forces to the broad strategy guidelines negotiated by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and senior generals and admirals. A review panel led by a civilian and including civilian policymakers and military officers had proposed levels of weapons and personnel that did not match the intent of the guidelines, officials said. Officials said the guidelines, which require the military to prepare concurrently for a major regional war, homeland defense, worldwide deployments and peacekeeping missions, could be interpreted to require a sizable increase in forces. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Washington: More Police Cameras Urged
description: The superintendent of the New Jersey State Police told a Congressional hearing yesterday that federal funding for video cameras in police patrol cars was necessary to discourage racial profiling. The superintendent, Col. Carson J. Dunbar Jr., testified before the House Committee on Government Reform that New Jersey has installed cameras, which cost $3,000 apiece, in more than 80 percent of its 1,700 state patrol cars at a cost of more than $5 million. Congress allocated a total of $2.3 million for cameras this year, down from $7 million last year.

title: Vehicles That Left Telltale Evidence Behind
description: Here are a few investigations in which forensic evidence from vehicles was crucial:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MARION LANGSAN
description: KATZ-Marion Langsan. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Howard Katz, Esq. Loving aunt of Vita, Harvey, Helene, Howard, Susan and Nancy and great aunt of Ariana. Services 1 PM Friday July 20, 2001 at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Sports of The Times; It's Time for a Battle of the Sexes in Golf
description: IT'S time for golf's grander version of the Billie Jean King-Bobby Riggs tennis match nearly three decades ago: a mixed pro tournament with, say, the 50 best men, the 50 best women and one winner.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Transportation Package Advances
description: Members of the Legislature's House and Senate transportation committees tentatively agreed on the specifics of an $8.9 billion transportation package late Wednesday. It would raise the gasoline tax by 9 cents, to 32 cents a gallon, increase the sales tax on cars by 2 percent and impose a 25 percent weight-fee increase for commercial trucks. A spokeswoman for Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat, said a vote might not come until Sunday, if at all. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Apartment Buyouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Nikoloas Birbilis and Amy Roy have joined the Brownstein Group, Philadelphia, as art director and copywriter, respectively. They had been students.

title: Row, Row, Row Your Boat (Gently, Gently)
description: I had my heart set on a Swampscott dory. Of course, I hadn't actually been in one, but I had seen photographs. And it had such a salty New England name, with a sturdy work-boat heritage. I had a clear image of myself on the Hudson River, face lined by long years of wind and sun, hands and muscles hardened by work, pulling on the oars and cleaving the chop on a windy day, pulling in nets full of shad.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Unemployment Rate Up 50%
description: The state's unemployment rate for the first half of 2001 is up 50 percent from the same period last year, officials said. More than 15,000 workers have been laid off this year, 2,500 so far this month. Coca-Cola, Motorola and other companies have had multiple rounds of layoffs in the last six months, and economists say there may be more to come in services and manufacturing. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Arab Landscapes in a Global Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Genoa's Protesters March Peacefully, but Vow Stronger Action
description: On the eve of a meeting of leaders of the industrialized nations, tens of thousands of people marched peacefully today through Genoa to protest the meeting as a symbol of globalization, capitalist exploitation, environmental insensitivity and a host of contemporary ills.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Agency Asks Firestone To Recall Additional Tires

title: SHARES OF ACCENTURE RISE AFTER AN INITIAL OFFERING
description: Shares of Accenture, the consulting and project-management company, rose yesterday after its $1.67 billion initial offering. The gains were capped by concern that Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting, faced slowing revenue growth. Shares rose to $15.17 after the company sold them at $14.50, near the top of its $13 to $15 estimated range. Accenture sold 115 million shares, or 12 percent of the company. It told investors that revenue growth was likely to slow as telecommunications and computer companies reduced their spending on services.

title: Text of G8 Economic Statement
description: Genova, 20 July 2001

title: For Some, It Isn't Easy to Come of Age Before 40
description: In these days of overworked air- conditioners, one should never discount the cooling power of brisk, breezy dialogue. Watching ''Music From a Sparkling Planet,'' Douglas Carter Beane's nimble escapist comedy about escapism, is like sinking into a frozen margarita -- or, to be more precise, one of those pastel-colored margaritas bearing the names of summer fruits.

title: Affidavit Is Said to Back Schwarz's Appeal in Louima Case
description: A police officer, known for the moment simply as Officer F, has come forward to discredit the account of the chief witness in the Abner Louima case, who said that Charles Schwarz was the patrolman who led Mr. Louima toward a station house restroom on the night of the infamous assault.

title: M.T.A. Will Expand Service Near Grand Street Subway
description: Three days before huge changes in subway service that would almost close the busy Grand Street subway station in Chinatown, Gov. George E. Pataki and Speaker Sheldon Silver of the State Assembly announced yesterday that the neighborhood's riders would get a reprieve.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: U.S. Sergeant Charged With Rape
description: Prosecutors in Okinawa indicted an American Air Force senior staff sergeant, Timothy Woodland, on charges of raping a Japanese woman in a parking lot last month. Sergeant Woodland, who said he had consensual sex with the woman, will remain in custody unless he posts bail, which has not been set yet. The case has renewed a debate in Japan over the treatment of American servicemen accused of crimes. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about peace talks on Northern Ireland and riots there misidentified the Protestant king who defeated the Catholic King James II in 1690 in a battle that gave rise to annual commemorations that have fueled Protestant- Catholic tensions. He was William III, not William IV.

title: HEALTH CARE PROPERTY IS BUYING 18 BUILDINGS FROM BOYER
description: Health Care Property Investors, the health care real estate investment trust, is buying 18 medical office and research buildings from the Boyer Company for $126 million. Two-thirds of the buildings are in Utah, mostly at the University of Utah's Research Park Campus, said Health Care Property, based in Newport Beach, Calif. The rest are in Arizona, Colorado, Kansas, Idaho and Wyoming. The acquisition from Boyer, of Salt Lake City, will help Health Care Property diversify into the biotechnology industry. It has more than 400 properties.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Green Thumbprints?

title: BUOYANT ECONOMY OF NEW YORK STATE SHOWS A REVERSAL
description: New York State's economy, which had been bucking the national economic slump, has slammed into a wall, losing jobs in the private sector in May and June, the first such back-to-back job declines since 1995.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS CALL FOR MONITORS FOR MIDEAST TRUCE
description: Responding to the increasing fury of violence in the Middle East, the foreign ministers of the major industrialized countries told the Israelis and Palestinians today that they should agree to ''third party'' monitors as the most assured way of halting the deteriorating situation.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The dining room at the Plaza Athne has always had good bones, but it desperately needed a good face-lift. With the closing of Le Rgence, it got one. The reborn restaurant, Arabelle, is pink, creamy and fresh-looking, still dignified but much less dowdy. It looks good, and diners look good in it, thanks to the very flattering lighting. Now if only someone can figure out how to unplug the soundtrack, a musical voyage into New Age outer space.

title: Official Hints Israel May Allow U.S. Monitors of Mideast Truce
description: JERUSALEM, July 20 -- On a day when the Middle East buried more of its dead, Israel's defense minister seemed to open the door, if just a crack, to the idea of foreigners monitoring the worsening Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But he said the outsiders would have to be Americans.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Leaders Gather By The Sea
description: China's top leaders have begun their annual retreat in Beidaihe, a northeastern seaside resort. The agenda is expected to be dominated by discussions of next year's leadership changes -- when President Jiang Zemin is expected to step down from his post as head of the Communist Party -- and changes in the party's makeup after Mr. Jiang's recent announcement that private businessmen should be allowed to join. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Liechtenstein: Money-Laundering Charges
description: Two financial advisers in the tiny country have been charged with laundering millions of dollars for the Cali drug cartel in Colombia, the chief prosecutor said. Eugen von Hoffen, 49, and Rudolf Ritter, 47, were charged with conspiring to hide revenues from South American drug trafficking over a three-year period beginning in 1997. Liechtenstein began cracking down on illegal money movements last year after it was listed by an international task force as a safe harbor for dirty money. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the arrest of a mobster, Anthony Indelicato, for parole violations referred incorrectly to the meetings with crime figures that caused him to be arrested. Mr. Indelicato was meeting with investigation targets, not victims. The investigations concerned gambling and money-laundering. A picture caption misstated the source of Mr. Indelicato's photograph. It was from his driver's license, not from the Police Department.

title: Icon for Abortion Protesters Is Looking for a Second Act
description: Randall Terry sat at the shiny black piano that dominates his home here in the hills outside Binghamton, singing and playing to a recording of himself singing and playing songs written by Randall Terry.

title: Scout Leader Is Charged In Sex Abuse Of Teenager
description: A Manhattan Boy Scout troop leader was charged yesterday with molesting a boy in his troop on a regular basis between September 1996 and May 1997.

title: As the World Warms: More Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Nikoloas Birbilis and Amy Roy have joined the Brownstein Group, Philadelphia, as art director and copywriter, respectively. They had been students.

title: Future And Past Shock
description: In ''Music From a Sparkling Planet,'' J. Smith-Cameron, right, plays a onetime children's television star who is sought out by three former fans. The Drama Dept. production of Douglas Carter Beane's nimble summer comedy, at the Greenwich House Theater, reunites several veterans of the company, including the director, Mark Brokaw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTER, JANE FAY
description: HARTER-Jane Fay, of Nantucket, 13 July. Widow of Isaac Harter Jr. Mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother.

title: Scranton Leading Big Apple By 2 Shots
description: The wear and tear on Nancy Scranton's left shoulder became so unbearable five years ago that she decided to have reconstructive surgery. Successful surgery and obtaining a new teacher as an outgrowth of her rehabilitation has rejuvenated her career.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Good Swami Named Yami

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Inclusion On Contraceptives
description: The state insurance commissioner, Mike Kreidler, has proposed requiring state-regulated health insurers to include contraceptive coverage in their prescription drug benefits. Mr. Kreidler, a Democrat, says he expects the state to adopt the rule in September and insurers to include contraceptive coverage by January 2002. A Federal District Court decision in June and an Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruling in December forced employers to include contraceptives in their drug plans; Washington would be the 15th state to require the same of insurance companies. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Mentions Prayer, And His Opponents Pounce
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, touching upon the contentious issue of prayer in school for the first time, said yesterday that he favored a moment of silence in public schools but that he would not try to impose the requirement in New York City if elected mayor.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Analog Devices Warns On Sales And Profit
description: Analog Devices Inc., a maker of high-speed communications chips, said it was reducing its estimates for the third quarter because of canceled orders. The company now expects $480 million in sales, or 20 percent below this year's second quarter. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: OBITUARY : Walter Oberreit, 72, Lawyer
description: Walter W. Oberreit, 72, a partner of the New York-based international law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, died on July 15 in Brussels, where he had lived for more than 30 years. He was recognized as the dean of American law practitioners there.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a great white shark on July 8 with the Our Towns column carried an erroneous credit. Though taken by David Doubilet for National Geographic, the picture is owned by Doubilet Photography Inc.

title: Panel Argues for Changing Social Security
description: A commission appointed by the Bush administration set out a rationale today for overhauling Social Security, describing the current system as plagued by financial problems and a crisis of confidence.

title: Role of Private Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Rate Unchanged
description: As widely expected, the European Central Bank held its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4.5 percent despite faltering growth in the 12-nation euro single-currency zone. The Frankfurt-based European bank has reduced its rates only once this year, reflecting its concern that inflation in the euro zone has remained persistently above its annual target of 2 percent for more than a year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Washington Talk; A Behind-the-Scenes Guy on Stage
description: Most people on Congressional staffs walk three paces behind their bosses. Aides are frequently reminded, as one senator's press secretary said she was told on her first day at work, ''Your job is to get my name in the paper, not yours.''

title: Spinning 'Indecency' Into Wholesome Issues
description: This is a new 30-second television commercial called ''Decency'' that the mayoral campaign of Alan G. Hevesi begins broadcasting this evening.

title: Editors' Note
description: On Stage and Off

title: Cuddyer Is Back On Track
description: Listening to the Twins prospect Michael Cuddyer raises a chicken-or-the-egg question: Has the New Britain Rock Cats' reversal of fortune put Cuddyer's career back on track, or have his impressive offensive numbers made the Rock Cats a winner again?

title: Recognition For Biloxi's Mad Potter
description: In Japan, potters are so revered that there are several museums in major cities and small towns dedicated to individual potters. In America, the situation is different. The Ohr-O'Keefe Museum of Art in Biloxi, Miss., is believed to be the only museum in the United States dedicated to a single potter, George E. Ohr (1857-1918), a Mississippi native known as ''the Mad Potter of Biloxi.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOTT, GORDON D.
description: STOTT-Gordon D., youngest son of the late Louis N. and Ethel (Doulton) Stott of Santa Barbara, California died Thursday, July 19, 2001 in the John Dempsey Hospital of the University of Connecticut Medical Center in Farmington, CT, of pneumonia. He was 91. Mr. Stott was born in Los Angeles, CA and attended the Thacher School in Ojai, CA and the Loomis School at Windsor, CT. He entered the brokerage business in the summer of 1929 as a runner for his father's firm of Logan & Bryan. He joined A.G. Edwards and Sons in 1938, and the following year, as partner, became a member of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Stott was inducted in 1942 into the Counter Intelligence Corps, and later transferred to Special Branch, Military Intelligence, stationed in Washington, D.C. After the war and continuing for the next fifty years, Mr. Stott was involved in mineral and real estate activities in the mountain states and joined the Salt Lake Stock Exchange. He served as President of Chief Consolidated Mines and later as Chairman of Park City Consolidated, both Utah companies, and was a member of the Alta Club in Salt Lake City. For almost 20 years beginning in the early 60's, he delivered a popular radio commentary, the ''Human Side of Wall Street'', for WVIP in Mount Kisco, NY, reminiscences of years in the securities business. In the mid 60's, he was instrumental in establishing a brokerage office (now Solomon Smith Barney) in Mount Kisco. Mr. Stott was an active member of the Amateur Chamber Music Players and played cello in Washington, D.C., New York City, Salt Lake City and in Westchester County, NY. He was a founding member of the Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra and played with that organization for many years. Mr. Stott is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Hubbard Stott of Farmington, his son, Peter H. Stott of Paris, France and daughters, Janet Stott Pembleton of Beverly Hills, California and Sarah Stott Noyle of Tampa, Florida. A memorial service will be held at St. Mark's Church, 85 East Main St., Mt. Kisco, New York at 2 PM, Sunday, July 22, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Thacher School, 5025 Thacher Rd, Ojai, CA 93023, or to the Amateur Chamber Music Players, 1123 Broadway, Room 304, NY, NY 10010-2007.

title: Jets Part With Elliott, for Now
description: The Jets released the veteran tackle Jumbo Elliott yesterday to sign some rookies under the salary cap.

title: They Sold the Derivative, but They Didn't Understand It
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS ''did not fully comprehend the risk'' it was taking, explained its chief executive, Kenneth I. Chenault, as he announced corporate America's latest bath, this one for $826 million.

title: Johns Hopkins Death Brings Halt To U.S.-Financed Human Studies
description: After investigating the death of a young, healthy volunteer last month in a research study at Johns Hopkins University, a federal oversight agency yesterday suspended almost all the university's federally financed medical research involving human subjects.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Steel Duties Lifted
description: Canada has lifted four-month-old duties on imports of steel sheet from six countries, quashing the claim by the steel maker Dofasco Inc. of Hamilton, Ontario, that cheap overseas products are hurting domestic producers. The Canadian International Trade Tribunal said imports of the corrosion-resistant sheet do not cause ''material injury or retardation'' to Canadian steel makers and do not threaten to do so. The importers are China, India, Malaysia, Russia South Africa and Taiwan.

title: Profit Soars at German Software Giant
description: Europe's biggest software maker, SAP of Germany, outpaced rivals and broke ranks with the Continent's gloom-laden technology business today, beating analysts' forecasts with a report of a 78 percent rise in second-quarter profit and offering a bullish forecast for the full year.

title: Scott Merrill, 82, Broadway Star; Macheath in 'Threepenny Opera'
description: Scott Merrill, who played Macheath -- Mack the Knife -- in the hit 1954 production of ''The Threepenny Opera'' by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht at the Theater de Lys in Greenwich Village, died on June 28 at a hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 82 and lived in Bristol, Conn.

title: Three Arabs Slain; Jewish Settlers Claim Responsibility
description: Three Palestinians, including a baby, were killed tonight west of the West Bank city of Hebron in a drive-by shooting that the police said was apparently an attack by Jewish gunmen.

title: Abusive Trials in Egypt
description: Tolerance for political dissent or unpopular lifestyles has never been a feature of Hosni Mubarak's 20-year tenure as Egypt's president. But recently Mr. Mubarak's rule seems to be growing more authoritarian and arbitrary. This week, 52 defendants were hauled before a special state security court for alleged homosexual activities. If convicted, they face sentences of three to five years with no right of appeal unless Mr. Mubarak personally intervenes. In May a similar court sentenced Saad Eddin Ibrahim, Egypt's leading human rights advocate, to seven years in prison for his efforts to promote democracy and religious tolerance.

title: Mrs. Clinton Slips From Script on Aspiration
description: The National Press Club was packed today for a policy speech by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York. But it was her slip of the tongue that provoked the biggest response.

title: Sweetness and Light at a Brothel? It Still Sounds Pretty Grim
description: BROTHEL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITTLESON, MARIANNE
description: ITTLESON-Marianne. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Henry Anthony. Loving mother of Philip and his wife Margot, Christina and her husband Sean and Stephanie. Cherished grandmother of Carlin, Henry and Fayre. Devoted sister of Nina, Cecilia, Agneta and Christian. Loving daughter of Alfhild Sundby. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC, on Sunday, July 22, 2001, 5-8 PM. Service Monday, July 23, 2001 at 11 AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., NYC. Cemetery arrangements private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 or Hollings Cancer Center, Medical University of South Carolina.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Royalties For Artists
description: European Union governments agreed to require auctioneers like Sotheby's Holdings Inc. and Christie's International to pay royalties to artists on resold sculptures and paintings, starting in 2006. After five years of talks, the 15 governments and the European Parliament agreed to apply a sliding scale to artists up to a maximum of 12,500 euros ($10,890) on resales of artwork over 3,000 euros.

title: As the World Warms: More Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits on May 31 with an article about the use of Microsoft PowerPoint in schools misspelled the surname of a kindergarten pupil shown. His mother informed The Times by e-mail this week that he is Quentin Carranza, not Czrranza.

title: U.S. Schools Turn More Segregated, a Study Finds
description: As President Bush and Congress wrestle with how to toughen federal law to weed out failing public schools, a Harvard University study has found that classrooms grew more segregated in the 1990's. The trend, reversing desegregation gains from the civil rights era, is undermining the educational prospects of black and Hispanic children, the study says.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK WASHINGTON: DREDGING DECISION SAID TO BE NEAR Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will decide by the end of next week whether to dredge possibly toxic PCB's from the Hudson River, according to a congressman who spoke with her. Her decision will not be made public until mid- September, after New York state officials have had a chance to review it, said the congressman, Representative Maurice Hinchey, Democrat of Saugerties.   (AP)

title: Hamm Pays Personal Price for Soccer
description: For the second time in the league's inaugural season, Mia Hamm has been named player of the week in the Women's United Soccer Association. A recent poll named her the most recognizable and marketable female athlete in the United States. The soccer league exists largely on her name recognition, and twice crowds have swelled beyond 30,000 by her presence on the field.

title: Teenagers' Sad World In a Comic Dimension
description: I have often complained, aloud and in print, about the sorry state of America's youth, at least as they are depicted in movies. A year ago, I wrote an article bewailing the decline of two genres dear to my reluctantly adult heart: the high school or college campus romantic comedy and the coming-of-age melodrama. My despair, happily, was premature. This year has brought, along with a flood of worse-than-average blockbusters, some better-than-average growing-up movies (including ''Save the Last Dance'' and ''Crazy/Beautiful'') as well as two -- Jim McKay's ''Our Song'' and John Singleton's ''Baby Boy'' -- that miraculously transcend the conventions of the subject matter while avoiding cheap laughs and exploitative moralizing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Karl Marx and Lenin, Mark Twain, George W. Bush. From one end of the spectrum to the other.''

title: PEPSICO SAYS SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT ROSE 16 PERCENT
description: Second-quarter profit for PepsiCo rose 16 percent after the company increased sales with new Frito-Lay snacks and with beverages like Mountain Dew Code Red. Net income rose to $652 million, or 44 cents a share, from $563 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. PepsiCo of Purchase, N.Y., was expected to earn 43 cents a share. Sales increased 7.2 percent, to $5.28 billion from $4.93 billion, the company said. Frito-Lay, which generates about 60 percent of PepsiCo's profit, gained market share with snacks like Lay's Bistro potato chips. Shares fell 52 cents, to $46.47.

title: Lush, Staid or Frenetic on Long Island
description: Visitors to Long Island museums this summer can time-travel through the 20th century. Start with the elegant designs of the Art Nouveau and Art Deco periods at the Nassau County Museum of Art.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Interest Rate Increase
description: In an effort to keep consumer prices in check despite a weakening currency, the monetary policy committee of Brazil's Central Bank raised the basic interest rate to 19 percent from 18.25 percent. The committee has raised rates for five consecutive months, as a local energy crisis and the threat of a debt default in neighboring Argentina have caused the real to devalue more than 20 percent this year. If Argentina were forced to declare a debt moratorium, analysts say that the Central Bank could raise rates to as much as 25 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORNE, PHILIP BARRY
description: OSBORNE-Philip Barry, 66. On July 18, at his home in Chappaqua, NY. Mr. Osborne, a former assistant managing editor at Reader's Digest, previously had been an editor/writer for Time, CBS, and Business Week. Beloved husband of Frances Mary Paczka, devoted father and grandfather of Leicia Osborne Milano and Morgan Osborne Milano. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: The ALS Association, 116 John St., New York, NY 10038 or New Castle Historical Society, 100 King Street, Chappaqua, New York 10514.

title: Houston Wants to Score the Easy Way
description: It has become Allan Houston's staple, as predictable as it is unstoppable. He catches the ball on the perimeter and faces up an aggressive defender. He throws a few jab steps, takes a couple of hard dribbles in one direction, uses a quick crossover move to get room, then elevates for a jumper over the lunging and beaten opponent.

title: Batter Up!
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Says PC Business Will Worsen
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported solid gains in quarterly revenues and operating profits yesterday, but the company said that it expected the personal computer business to worsen further in the current quarter.

title: Nieporte Hangs On For Victory
description: It seemed almost follish on a day of torture for most players in the MONY New York State Open at Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEXACO, White Plains, the oil company, and Energy Conversion Devices, Troy, Mich., a designer of batteries, have formed a venture to produce nickel metal hydride batteries for vehicles.

title: In a Crime, a Car May Hold the Clues
description: HAVE strangers been staring at your car? Maybe they are jealous. Or perhaps they are detectives, and the car fits the profile of a vehicle on the lam.

description: The Family Man

title: Art in Review
description: M Medium'

title: Arab Landscapes After the Oslo Era
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Caribbean to Russia, All in New Jersey
description: This summer some ordinarily reliable spots for art in New Jersey, including the Montclair Art Museum, have shut for renovations. But this still leaves the exhibitions below, a good selection despite fewer choices.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From Neon trouble in the mountains to faulty cruise control, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Tokyo in 2019, Paris in 1880
description: Whether by marketing stratagem or plain accident, a week's worth of video releases usually reflects what is playing in movie theaters. For example, amid the novel digital animation in multiplexes this summer comes a DVD special edition of ''Akira,'' Katsuhiro Otomo's violent, groundbreaking animated adventure set in Neo-Tokyo in 2019.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global PC Sales Dip
description: Worldwide sales of personal computers declined during the last quarter for the first time since 1986 as the United States economy's troubles spread to other regions, two market research firms reported. Gartner Dataquest said unit shipments fell 2 percent from the second quarter of last year, to 29.8 million. The International Data Corporation pegged the decline at 1.9 percent, to 30.4 million.

title: Bush, in Britain, Enjoys the Calm Before the Storm
description: President Bush basked today in the least problematic of his administration's foreign relationships, visiting the bunker where Churchill weathered World War II, lunching with Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace and spending the night here at Chequers, the official country retreat, as a guest of Prime Minister Tony Blair, who did everything he could to minimize his differences with Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SOLA, FRANK
description: DE SOLA-Frank, 91. Died June 29 in Beaufort, SC. Mr. De Sola was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and grew up in Brooklyn, NY. In 1946 he succeeded his father as president of the family-founded import/export firm, De Sola Bros. Inc., located on Wall Street in Manhattan. He served as the company's dynamic and successful leader for the next 33 years. After retirement, he and his wife moved to Beaufort. They spent their summers in Savoy, MA. He enjoyed the woods of Savoy and the marshes and birds of Beaufort; he loved good books, good conversation, and good chocolate. He is survived by his wife, Michi Yasumura De Sola, his daughters Anne De Sola Paust of Succasunna, NJ and Linda De Sola Diffily of California and Washington DC, his niece Dolores De Sola Tugwell of Atlanta, GA, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: PEPSI BOTTLING STRIKE ENDS

title: French Sending Fugitive Home to U.S. for New Trial
description: Ira S. Einhorn, the flamboyant counter-culture celebrity who spent the last 20 years fleeing prison for the murder of his girlfriend, was taken into custody by French police yesterday for a flight back to a new trial in the United States.

title: What the Protesters in Genoa Want
description: Genoa, that Renaissance city known for both openness and shrewd political sophistication, is in crisis this weekend. It should have thrown its gates wide for the celebration of this summit of the world's most powerful leaders. But instead Genoa has been transformed into a medieval fortress of barricades with high-tech controls. The ruling ideology about the present form of globalization is that there is no alternative. And strangely, this restricts both the rulers and the ruled.

title: The Battle for Shays-Meehan
description: Friends of campaign finance reform, undeterred by the Republican leadership's obstructionist tactics and last week's failure to secure a floor vote in the House for the Shays-Meehan bill, opened a new front yesterday in the drive to diminish the influence of soft money in American politics. At a news conference on Capitol Hill, a group of moderate House Democrats announced their intention to collect at least 218 signatures -- just over half the membership -- on a discharge petition that would force the bill to the floor for the reckoning it has so far been denied.

title: Foreign Affairs; Evolutionaries
description: Throughout history, successful social protest movements have had one thing in common -- a clear, simple message and objective. Whether it was the women's rights movement or the anti-Vietnam-War movement, the mere uttering of the name immediately conjured up who the protesters were and what their objective was.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about peace talks on Northern Ireland and riots there misidentified the Protestant king who defeated the Catholic King James II in 1690 in a battle that gave rise to annual commemorations that have fueled Protestant-Catholic tensions. He was William III, not William IV.

title: Middle East Politics Add Heat To Campaigns for Governor
description: New Jersey's gubernatorial campaign veered into the thicket of Middle East politics today as the two major candidates started feuding over the same Muslim group that was at the center of a quarrel between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio in the New York Senate race last fall.

title: Making Jury Duty Seem Less Like Incarceration
description: IN the Jury Assembly Room at the New York Criminal Court Building in Manhattan, Walter Schretzman is the clerk behind the open mike. He greets some of the most sullen-looking folks you will ever see on a Monday morning.

title: 'Wendingen' -- Dutch Design, 1918-1932
description: Ubu Gallery

title: Tensions Touch G.O.P. Chief's Tenure
description: Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia says his model as leader of the Republican National Committee is the elder George Bush, whom President Richard M. Nixon appointed chairman in 1973.

title: Summery Homes For Art
description: IN museums around the New York metropolitan area this summer, shows explore, among other themes, the relationship of words and images in modern art. ''Summer Reading'' at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., brings together Mallarm, de Kooning, Duchamp and Ray Johnson, the epistolary artist whose big collages feature anything-goes allusions and daffy graphics, beautifully drawn.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: No Meeting With Powell
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will not get a chance to renew the dialogue between the United States and North Korea next week at a meeting in Hanoi of Asian countries. North Korea's embassy in the Vietnamese capital said Foreign Minister Paek Nam Sun would be too busy to go. American officials had hoped that Secretary Powell and Mr. Paek would exchange at least a handshake. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: National Briefing | Washington: Change Of Heart On Criminals
description: A poll released by the American Civil Liberties Union has found that Americans are softening their views about how to treat criminals. The poll found that a majority of Americans believed that it was possible to rehabilitate nonviolent offenders and that prisons were failing to prepare inmates for their return to society. The poll also found that 61 percent of Americans opposed mandatory sentences for nonviolent crimes and that 75 percent favored treatment and probation for nonviolent drug use. The telephone poll, conducted in January, surveyed 2000 people, with a margin of error of plus or minus two percentage points. Fox Butterfield (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Ferry Service To End
description: SeaStreak America is closing its ferry service from the 58th Street Pier in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, to Pier 11 in Manhattan, on July 27, after about three years. ''It's getting too uneconomical to run the boat,'' said Patty Shrensel, customer service manager for Sea Streak, in Atlantic Highlands, N.J., confirming a report in yesterday's New York Post. Ms. Shrensel said the slowing economy has made fuel and boat upkeep very expensive. Service will continue to Pier 11 and East 34th Street from Atlantic Highlands and Highlands, N.J.

title: Merrill Lynch Settles With Former Client
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a claim by a former client that the investment firm's star Internet analyst, Henry Blodget, recommended a stock without disclosing a conflict of interest.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: Teammate Takes a Few Cuts At the Mets' Feeble Outfield
description: The season-high five-game winning streak had faded into another harsh reminder of 2001 by the time the Mets were packing their bags and making their way to the idling buses beyond right field, not unlike the thousands of young campers who turned out for an early afternoon game yesterday and found there was not much to cheer about.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Unhappy With Japan
description: The government officially protested Japan's decision to grant citizenship to former President Alberto K. Fujimori's brother-in-law, Victor Aritomi. The Peruvian Embassy in Tokyo said that the move was ''an obstacle to the administration of justice in Peru'' and that it threatened to sour normally good relations between the countries. As a Japanese citizen, Mr. Aritomi, who is wanted on corruption charges in Peru, is now protected from extradition. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: Hong Kong Court Rules Boy Can Stay, in Snub to Beijing
description: HONG KONG, July 20  In a bold reassertion of its independence, Hong Kong's highest court ruled today that a 3-year-old boy born here to a mainland Chinese mother has the right to residency.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Chile: Airplanes Seized
description: The authorities grounded six planes owned by a Peruvian carrier, AeroContinente S.A., and arrested executives of the airline on accusations of laundering drug money. Clara Szczaranski, head of the Chilean state prosecutor's office, said four people were arrested for suspected involvement in a conspiracy to launder money. The head of AeroContinente said the accusations were intended to damage its image and stifle competition.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Boy At Boot Camp Drowned
description: The Maricopa County Sheriff's Department has determined that Tony Haynes, the 14-year-old boy who died on July 1 at a boot camp for troubled youths, drowned in a motel bathtub. Investigators said the boy became dehydrated in 114-degree heat after counselors forced him to eat mud, so they took him to a nearby motel and placed him under a shower. When the counselors returned, investigators said, they found the boy face down in the water. They said the boy was then returned to the camp on orders from the owner, Charles Long, who believed he was faking an illness. He was pronounced dead that night in the hospital. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: U.S. and Caribbean Face Era Of More, and Big, Hurricanes
description: The Atlantic Seaboard and the Caribbean face 10 to 40 years of stronger and more frequent hurricanes, a new analysis of weather data shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMERVILLE, DURWARD
description: SOMERVILLE-Durward. On July 17, 2001. Funeral service Friday, July 20, 2001, at 9 AM, at St James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street. Also, a memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Middletown: Riding Instructor Sentenced
description: A top riding coach has been sentenced to nine months in prison for sexual misconduct with a 14-year-old student. The coach, Robert L. Johnson, 44, is the owner of Quarry Town Stables in Portland. He was found guilty of illegal sexual contact with a victim under 16 and fourth-degree sexual assault. Mr. Johnson was arrested in October 1999 on nine charges, including groping the student. Mr. Johnson, sentenced Wednesday, said through his attorney that he would appeal. He is free on $100,000 bond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DR. NANCY HARA
description: LEWIS-Dr. Nancy Hara. Dear sister and aunt. You are our middle and our rock. We will miss you but always remember your love of life and family. Bob, Amy, Kory, Scott and Adam

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on July 12 about Apple Computer's new retail stores misstated the history of the company's relationship with several retailers. Apple's announcement that it would stop selling computers through Best Buy, Circuit City, Of-ficeMax and Sears was made in February 1998, not recently. Circuit City resumed Apple sales last July; sales also resumed for a time at Sears but have again been discontinued.

title: Best Person for the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: With Napster Down, Its Audience Fans Out
description: The record industry's largely successful effort to cripple Napster, the online music site turned social phenomenon, has left it facing something potentially worse: a new generation of music-swapping sites, more numerous and much harder to police.

title: The Big City; Why People Love to Hate Publicists
description: THE Mayans had their ways of dealing with publicists, as you may have seen in an ancient illustration published on Tuesday in these pages. It showed a flack, once the powerful issuer of royal press releases but now obviously out of favor, who was in the process of having his fingernails torn off.

title: Electric Exhibitions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, CHARLES A. JR.
description: WRIGHT-Charles A. Jr. 39. Art Historian and Curator. Died 7/20/01 at Beth Israel Medical Center. Memorial services at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring Street, NYC, Sunday, July 22, 11 AM.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Some Power Rules Are Eased
description: After putting an energy deregulation plan on hold when the power crisis struck this year, the state has taken a step toward easing some regulations for large customers. Gov. Kenny Guinn signed a bill that will allow large consumers like casinos and mines to buy electricity from suppliers other than the state's primary utility, Nevada Power. Sponsors of the bill, which took effect immediately, hope it will permit those big customers to find cheaper rates and ease shortages. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Brother Plays a Part in Capriati's Success
description: They are the only children in the family. He is 21 years old and plays No. 1 for the University of Arizona tennis team. She is 25 and won the Australian and French Opens, the first two Grand Slam tournaments this year.

title: SUNGARD DATA SYSTEMS TO SEEK ASSETS OF COMDISCO
description: SunGard Data Systems Inc., which sells financial services software, said yesterday that it planned to bid on the computer-disaster-recovery assets of Comdisco Inc., which sought bankruptcy protection earlier this month. Comdisco said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its technology-services assets to the Hewlett-Packard Company for $610 million. But yesterday, the chairman of SunGard, James Mann, said that his company also wanted the assets. Comdisco said it would entertain other offers. The Federal Bankruptcy Court in Chicago will open Comdisco's assets to bidders, Mr. Mann said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Exchange Shares Fall
description: The 200-year-old London Stock Exchange, trailing other European exchanges, finally listed its own shares as the Continent's fragmented bourses jostle for dominance in a pan-European market. But the shares fell yesterday by as much as 8 percent. Clara Furse, the chief executive, said that with the offering, the exchange would be transformed from a business owned by its members to one that would be able to ''exploit strategic business opportunities.'' The Deutsche Brse in Germany and the Euronext alliance of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels bourses have already listed their shares. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARACI, VINCENT D.
description: FARACI-Vincent D. A former recording executive for Atlantic Recording Corp. Died July 19, 2001 at the age of 58. He is survived by his daughter Stephanie Faraci of Larchmont, NY & his former wife, Elaine Faraci. He is predeceased by his son Vincent M. Faraci. Visiting on Sunday from 5 to 9 P.M. at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home. (914) 949-7777. Mass Monday 11 A.M. at Sacred Heart in Hartsdale. In lieu of flowers, donations to Gilda's Club in Westchester, 80 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York 10601.

title: Missing-Person Cases: A Balancing Act for Police
description: The number seems horrifying. Last year 876,213 missing-person cases were reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation by local police agencies after calls from frantic families or friends.

title: Rethink the Olympic Bid
description: To the Editor:

title: Stem Cell Research and a Parent's Hopes
description: In October my wife, Laurie, and I will have our third child. Even though all three were conceived naturally, we have about 60 embryos frozen and in storage, courtesy of nine cycles of in vitro fertilization. As far as we know, ours may well be the largest personal cache of embryos anywhere. As we told The New York Times Magazine for an article that was published July 1, we had attempted in vitro fertilization because we were trying to have a child who was free of Fanconi anemia, the deadly genetic disease we had passed to our first son, Henry. The child also had to have the right combination of leukocyte antigen proteins to be a perfectly matched stem cell donor for Henry. Otherwise, Henry would need to have a bone-marrow transplant from a donor whose marrow was less likely to be accepted by Henry's fragile system -- a transplant that could have endangered his life.

title: Congressional Clash on Education
description: George W. Bush's promise to put an end to ''the soft bigotry of low expectations'' that allows poor and minority children to fall permanently behind at school was perhaps the most popular theme of his campaign. Both liberals and conservatives were excited by the prospect that a president would actually fight to ensure that impoverished children get the education they are entitled to under law. But a vital proposal that would require the states to narrow the achievement gap between rich and poor schoolchildren as a condition of receiving federal aid is in danger of being lost in Congress.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Foreign Reinsurance
description: The state-owned insurance company has, for the first time, bought reinsurance against major losses from natural disasters like earthquakes and floods from a foreign insurance group. The coverage, put together through companies in Bermuda, Britain, Germany and Switzerland, by two brokers, Guy Carpenter & Company and Willis Re, will reimburse the Chinese company, People's Insurance Company of China, for losses of up to $725 million, said Sean Mooney, a Guy Carpenter executive in New York. The Chinese company, which provides 80 percent of the country's insurance on homes, cars and businesses, would have to pay the first $150 million in claims. Before the purchase of the reinsurance, the Chinese company had been responsible for all claims, exposing the central government to huge losses.

title: Gathering on the Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense System in Georgia Needs Overhaul, Lawyers Say
description: Some of Georgia's best-known lawyers made a plea today for improving Georgia's system of defending poor people accused of crimes, arguing that the state needed to change one of the lowest-funded and most disorganized defense systems in the nation.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARGAND, GREGORY PAUL
description: ARGAND-Gregory Paul. Beloved son. 12/5/50-7/21/83. Forever in our hearts. Mom and Dad

title: Howard Schomer, 86, Seminary President
description: The Rev. Dr. Howard Schomer, a former president of the Chicago Theological Seminary and activist on behalf of human rights and civil rights, died on June 28 in a hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 86 and moved to Oakland in the 1980's.

title: Warnings Sent to E-ZPass Speeders
description: About one in 1000 E-ZPass users in New Jersey will receive warning letters for exceeding the five-mile-per-hour speed limit at toll booths during the first two days of a new enforcement system that could lead to suspension of E-ZPass privileges, officials said yesterday.

title: Stockbroker Pleads Guilty To Kickbacks In Bridgeport
description: A Connecticut stockbroker who is a longtime friend of Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport pleaded guilty today to a federal conspiracy charge, telling a judge that he had agreed to pay kickbacks to another close friend of Mr. Ganim and to an unnamed elected city official in exchange for winning contracts related to the police and fire department pension funds.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: VNU Sells Magazine Unit
description: The Dutch publisher VNU confirmed yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its consumer magazine business to the Finnish media company Sanoma WSOY for $1.09 billion. VNU's consumer magazine arm, which includes regional editions of Cosmopolitan, Playboy and Home & Garden, is the biggest magazine publisher in the Netherlands, Belgium, the Czech Republic and Hungary. The deal is meant to help VNU pay for its $2.3 billion acquisition of ACNielsen, the United States media and entertainment market research company. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: 61 Senators Call for Stem Cell Research
description: A bipartisan group of 61 senators sent letters to President Bush today that urged him to permit the use of federal dollars for embryonic stem cell research.

title: Protester Is Killed in Genoa; Leaders Upbeat on Economy : Violence Rages at G-8 Talks
description: GENOA  Rampaging protesters turned parts of Genoa into a war zone on Friday as the death of one man together with more than 100 injuries overshadowed the efforts by Group of Eight leaders to talk up the world economy.

title: Hugh Wilbourn Jr., 85, Phone Executive
description: Hugh Randolph Wilbourn Jr., the founder and chairman of the Allied Telephone Company, now known as the Alltel Corporation, died on Thursday. He was 85.

title: Senators Press Bush On Stem Cell Studies
description: President Bush was urged by 61 senators to permit the use of federal dollars for embryonic stem cell research.

title: Artists From Faraway Places With Far-Out Ideas
description: One of the most admirable features of the annual American Dance Festival held on the campus of Duke University here is the International Choreographers evening. Each summer several choreographers from abroad are invited to stage works with casts of students attending the festival school. The way choreographers representing different national traditions use modern dance techniques is always interesting and sometimes startling.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: China and India Face Off in Nepal
description: JAKARTA  Only a present day William Shakespeare could imagine the real life tragedy in Nepal when the Crown Prince eliminated an entire line of a royal dynasty that had ruled that land for more than 200 years.

title: Appeal Pending, Immigrant Mothers-to-Be Crowd Prenatal Clinic
description: It is Thursday, prenatal day at the storefront health clinic on Nostrand Avenue, in the heart of Caribbean Brooklyn. So the narrow, brightly lighted waiting room is packed with round bellies and aching backs, baby strollers and mothers-to-be patiently listening to lectures on the virtues of milk and cheese.

title: Simon Leads, but Armstrong Gains
description: In the first of three days in the Pyrenees, Franois Simon refused to crack and lose any more of his huge lead than expected.

title: Ugly Thoughts, Set Down on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Killer Is Refused Clemency by Oklahoma
description: Acting in a case that was being closely watched by foreign governments and death penalty lawyers around the country, Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma yesterday turned down a request for clemency from a Mexican citizen who at the time of his arrest was not advised of his right under an international treaty to contact his embassy.

title: Ugly Thoughts, Set Down on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: An Israeli Hints At Permitting U.S. Observers
description: On a day when the Middle East buried more of its dead, Israel's defense minister seemed to open the door, if just a crack, to the idea of foreigners monitoring the worsening Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But he said the outsiders would have to be Americans.

title: Senators Confirm 3 Judges, Including Once-Stalled Black
description: The Senate confirmed federal judges today for the first time since the Democrats took control in May, including Roger Gregory, who was initially named to the bench by President Bill Clinton in a recess appointment after the Republican-run Senate stalled his nomination.

title: Damaged Brains and the Death Penalty
description: You don't have to be a psychiatrist, Dr. Dorothy Otnow Lewis says, to know that something was terribly wrong with Ricky Ray Rector, who before his execution in Arkansas ordered his last meal and asked that the pecan pie be set aside so he could have it later.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Chasing Pinochet, Again
description: A federal judge, Rodolfo Canicoba Corral, asked Chile to extradite the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet to Argentina so he can face questions about a conspiracy by South American dictators to execute leftists in the 1970's and 80's. Analysts consider it doubtful that Chile will detain General Pinochet, who is 85 and won a court ruling in Chile this month declaring him mentally unfit for trial on charges there. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Inflammation Causes Rivera's Ankle Pain
description: Mariano Rivera underwent a second M.R.I. exam on his right ankle yesterday and the Yankees reported that he has mild inflammation, nothing more. But despite receiving a report consistent with his first M.R.I., Rivera still seemed worried because the pain has hounded him for about a month.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Electrolux Earnings
description: Reversing a prediction of increased profit for the year, Electrolux, the household appliance maker, joined other European companies bracing for a slowdown. Electrolux posted a 23 percent drop in second-quarter net income, to $109 million, slightly worse than expected, and said full-year profit would also fall. Electrolux cited slowing demand in the United States and problems with new refrigerator plants in America. The chief executive, Michael Treschow, said he expected no second-half improvement in the United States while European sales would grow no more than 0.5 percent, compared with an earlier estimate of 3 percent to 4 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Muslim Consortium to Back Green in the Race for Mayor
description: In the first formal endorsement ever given by a large, organized coalition of Muslim voters in New York City, the Muslim Political Coordinating Committee of New York has said that it will support Mark Green for mayor. The group said it would announce its endorsement, as well as those for borough presidents and council members, tomorrow in Queens.

title: Ugly Thoughts, Set Down on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retail Sales Flat
description: British shoppers eased their spending in June in a sign that the slowdown in the United States and on the Continent was reaching Britain. Spending was unchanged from May, but it was up 5.6 percent from June 2000, the National Statistics Office said. Sales increased 0.8 percent in May from April.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: State Won't Cover Painkiller
description: Gov. Howard Dean said a state welfare program would stop paying for prescriptions for the painkiller OxyContin. Governor Dean, a doctor, said that the drug had too much potential for abuse and that it had created a wave of pharmacy robberies. The decision to cut off OxyContin coverage affects about 70 people, and is the first such action by a state. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Promises of Law and Order, And Some Praise for Giuliani
description: The mayoral campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg began broadcasting two television advertisements about fighting crime this week. This is one.

title: DISNEY SEEN NEAR DEAL FOR FOX FAMILY
description: The Walt Disney Company is close to an agreement to buy Fox Family Worldwide, a cable television network operator, for about $3.3 billion in cash plus the assumption of about $2 billion in debt, executives close to the negotiations said last night. The News Corporation, which owns half of Fox Family, was looking for a buyer for the network after its partner, the children's television producer Haim Saban, exercised an option that otherwise would have forced the News Corporation to buy out his interest. Fox Family Worldwide owns the the Fox Family Channel, which has close to 80 million subscribers but has struggled to compete against Viacom's Nickelodeon and other cable networks.

title: Fatal Shooting in Queens
description: A 26-year-old man was fatally shot in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday, and his father was shot in the arm as he chased the gunman, the police said.

title: No-Names at Open Make Names Known
description: Many fans who looked at some of the names on today's British Open leader board were mystified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, JACQUELINE
description: SCHUMAN-Jacqueline. On July 20, 2001. Beloved mother of Kathy. A woman of great warmth, generosity, strength and style, a supportive friend, and a true artist. Her kind and loving spirit lives on in the hearts of those close to her.

title: Lieberman Joins Bush Bid To Push Aid-to-Charity Bill
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, will meet with President Bush next week in hopes of building support in the Senate for legislation giving religious institutions more federal money for their charitable works.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORTHROP GRUMMAN CORP., Los Angeles, the military contractor, extended its $2.6 billion unsolicited offer for Newport News Shipbuilding Inc., Newport News, Va., to Aug. 2 because antitrust regulators need more time to review the proposal.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a halt in public forums by the New York Society of Security Analysts, examining management's responsibility to shareholders, misstated the composition of pro forma financial results reported by one recent forum subject, Amazon.com. The results do not exclude interest, depreciation or taxes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about AOL Time Warner's second-quarter financial results misstated the increase in the stock price so far this year. Through the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday, the increase was 28.3 percent, not 43 percent.

title: Clinton Office Is Furnished Off the Shelf In Nod to Cost
description: Oval, it's not.

title: Rivals Waging A Media War Over Wachovia
description: With only $200 million separating the bidders, the battle for the Wachovia Corporation is heating up in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Can't Afford Hawaii? Get the Shirt; Fashion Tees Let Shoppers Put on Fictional Identities
description: Times were, a T-shirt really meant something. It broadcast the wearer's alma mater or vacation haunts. It might indicate that the T-shirt's owner had ridden the mechanical bull at Gilley's or visited one of the world's Hard Rock Cafes.

title: Petty Lets the Racing Honor His Son
description: A driver in a red racing suit and a black cap turned a corner and strode briskly onto pit road for his qualifying attempt this afternoon. Those who were scattered in the aluminum stands at New Hampshire International Speedway began to applaud him warmly the instant they spotted his ponytail. Only Kyle Petty has a ponytail on the Winston Cup circuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: Wards Put Long Shot in Oaks
