description: From a victory in the Acorn has grown the idea of trying to win an Oaks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DETRICK, BRUCE
description: DETRICK-Bruce. Age 59, co-founder of the Tamarand Foundation, died June 30, 2001 of cancer. The Municipal Arts Society honored him in 1992 for roof gardens and play gardens created for NYC AIDS care facilities and for the Hope Garden in Battery Park. A composer, poet, teacher, singer and actor, his work appeared in books, on stage, on television and in films. His expansive body of work often met with critical acclaim. Surviving are his mother, Helen, and partner, Joe Mondello. Memorial Saturday, 12:45 PM, Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East 29th St. Contributions to Tamarand Foundation, 202 Riverside Drive, 7D, New York, NY 10025.

title: For Aspiring Americans, New Hope and Concern
description: The old military barracks in this farming town just across the Rio Grande from Mexico are empty except for a room where seven students are studying to become American citizens. The instructor, Vincent Ramirez, moves quickly from the War of 1812 to the Civil War before segueing to a familiar subject, immigration.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Europe Fights U.S. Steel Duties
description: After two months of talks, the European Union now plans to file complaints with the World Trade Organization against American duties on imports from steel companies, including Usinor S.A., Europe's largest steel maker. The Europeans say the W.T.O. found in their favor in a similar case involving British Steel P.L.C., now known as the Corus Group. In that case, the W.T.O. ruled that the United States wrongly imposed duties on the ground that the former state-owned company unfairly benefited from subsidies before it was sold.

title: 1951:Abdullah Slain : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: AMMAN  King Abdullah of Hashemite Jordan was assassinated as he entered the mosque of Omar, in Jerusalem, to pray at his father's tomb. The 69-year-old King, who was considered the West's firmest ally in the Middle East, died almost instantly. His assassin, 21, a Jerusalem tailor and member of the Al Jihad Al Mokadas, which has demanded a separate Palestine Arab state, was killed by the King's bodyguards.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANDARS, PAUL, JR.
description: SANDARS-Paul, Jr. July 21, 2000. There is such a void since you left us a year ago. The children and family have made life bearable. I miss you and will always love you, Conni

title: Two Rookies, Two Paths, One Goal
description: Richard Jefferson and Michael Wright faced each other on the Clark Center court Thursday night for the first time as opponents, the divergent paths that the two had taken since the end of the season at the University of Arizona finally winding back and meeting at the University of Massachusetts at Boston.

title: Stupples Joins Scranton At the Top in Big Apple
description: The small greens firmed up at Wykagyl Country Club today and as a result, the scores were much higher than on opening day. With no rain in the forecast for this weekend, the greens will be even firmer for the final two rounds of the Sybase Big Apple Classic, and that news makes the co-leader Nancy Scranton rather happy.

title: Coming to Blows Over How Valid Science Really Is
description: Sometime in 1962, to paraphrase Virginia Woolf, the world changed. That year a physicist and historian of science, Thomas S. Kuhn, did for conceptions of science what Copernicus and Einstein did for astronomy and physics. He led a revolution, at least if one accepts the analysis in his book, ''The Structure of Scientific Revolutions,'' which has sold over a million copies in 20 languages.

title: AVANT SHARES SLIDE AFTER RULING BY CALIFORNIA JUDGE
description: Shares of the Avant Corporation, a maker of software, fell as much as 39 percent after a California state judge ordered the company to pay $182 million plus interest to Cadence Design Systems Inc. for taking the Cadence computer code to include in its products. The shares fell $4.68, to $10.45, in trading of 3.2 million shares, almost 11 times the three-month daily average. ''People didn't expect the restitution to be so high,'' said Jennifer Jordan, an analyst with Wells Fargo Van Kasper. With interest, the award could exceed $200 million, said the Santa Clara County prosecutor, Julius Finkelstein. The amount of interest will be determined on Monday.

title: The Pas de Deux of Politics and Art
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN PROTESTER IS KILLED BY POLICE AT GENOA MEETING
description: A 23-year-old Italian protester was shot and killed today by a police officer during a riot less than two miles from a gathering of leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations, who were protected by a 13-foot fence that anti-globalization demonstrators had vowed to breach.

title: Similar questions of faith underlie debates over stem cell research and missile defense shields.
description: Is research on stem cells derived from human embryos to liberals what the missile defense system is to conservatives? Well, not quite. There are many conservative supporters of such stem cell research, after all, just as there are some liberals opposed to it.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Monsoons Batter Millions
description: Unusually heavy monsoon rains have forced the evacuation of tens of thousands and have affected an estimated seven million people in the eastern state of Orissa. According to the authorities, floods have cut off 9,000 villages in an area still trying to recover from a devastating cyclone in 1999. So far, the death toll has been put at 42. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Fuel Deal With Libya
description: The government, which has been desperately short of hard currency to pay for fuel imports, has brokered a $360 million deal with oil-rich Libya, according to news reports from the capital, Harare. In exchange for the fuel, Zimbabwe will export local products to Libya. The fuel shortage has heightened discontent in the struggling nation, and easing the problem is a crucial hurdle for the government, which faces national elections early next year. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Ugly Thoughts, Set Down on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, RENEE
description: POWELL-Renee. Age 72, of Oradell, NJ, on July 19, 2001. Predeceased by her husband of fortytwo years, Louis Powell, former President of Alexanders Department Stores. Survived by her loving children Nancy Skulnik, Allan, Michael & Steven, sister of Milton Negrin and Anna Dastris. Adored by six grandchildren. Services are Sunday, 10:00 A.M., at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Cyberworks Cancels Offering
description: Pacific Century CyberWorks, the financially stressed telecommunications company, canceled a planned $1.5 billion bond offering yesterday, citing a poor market. CyberWorks had already scaled back the offering from $2.5 billion; a spokeswoman said the bonds could not be priced at an acceptable level. CyberWorks had planned to use the money to refinance debt from its $28 billion acquisition of Hong Kong's flagship telephone company. The spokeswoman, Joan Wagner, insisted that the company could service its debt of nearly $5 billion. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Earnings Off Sharply At Samsung Electronics
description: The semiconductor crisis caught up with Samsung Electronics, the global leader in memory chips, in the second quarter of this year, though the company's success in other fields staved off the kind of disastrous losses recorded by its competitors, Samsung said yesterday.

title: Grim Reminder On Mental Illness; Detroit Executive's Bouts With Depression
description: Gleaming in the summer sunshine, a long line of black limousines, town cars and sport utilities ferried dignitaries last week to the Grosse Ile Presbyterian Church, on a residential island just south of this city.

title: A Newport Aristocrat Has Fallen for Everyman's Game
description: NEWPORT is known for many things, although baseball is not one of them. Take me out to the ball, perhaps, but not the ballgame.

title: Manhattan Bridge Service Changes
description: Tomorrow the final stage of the Manhattan Bridge rehablitation project will reroute subway lines that cross the bridge.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Holocaust Denier's Appeal Fails
description: A three-judge panel has rejected an appeal by the historian David Irving of a High Court ruling last year that said he could be branded a Holocaust denier. Mr. Irving, 63, unsuccessfully sued an American academic, Deborah Lipstadt, and her publisher, Penguin, over her 1994 book ''Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory,'' which he claimed destroyed his livelihood and generated hatred against him. The judges ruled that the High Court was correct in finding that Mr. Irving had deliberately misrepresented history to portray Hitler in a favorable light. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Problems For Cable And Wireless
description: In another indication of investor discontent with the salaries received by executives, shareholders of the Cable and Wireless communications group challenged a proposal yesterday at the annual meeting to offer the company's 100 most senior managers more generous stock options. Some 28 percent of the shareholders opposed the plan that would give the chief executive, Graham Wallace, options worth up to $6.4 million. The proposal, however, was approved because most of the votes mailed in favored it. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Dissidents Skeptical of Canadian Party Leader's Offer to Resign
description: Banners for the famous Calgary Stampede festival flutter along this city's boulevards, but it is the political Wild West show that is being put on by the Canadian Alliance and its besieged leader, Stockwell Day, that now seems to be attracting the most attention around here.

title: Waning Demand for Handsets Leads to Big Loss at Ericsson
description: Ericsson, the Swedish phone equipment maker, said today that a sharp decline in sales for its handsets contributed to a second-quarter loss and that demand for its network infrastructure was falling.

title: Jets and Moss Are No Closer To a Contract
description: The agent for receiver Santana Moss, the Jets' first-round draft pick, said yesterday that he was still hopeful a deal could be worked out by Wednesday, when rookies report, although he said there had been no recent progress in negotiations.

title: School Board Tightens Reins On Supervisors
description: Board of Education employees being considered for promotion to a supervisory position will undergo a more rigorous review of their personnel records that will include scrutiny of previously unsubstantiated allegations of misconduct, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced yesterday.

title: Ugly Thoughts, Set Down on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Skin Care Deal
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb is in talks to sell its skin products division to Bioglan Pharma, a British drug company, for about $700 million, people close to the talks said yesterday. The deal is expected to close in mid-August, these people said. Bioglan confirmed that it was in discussions to buy some dermatological assets from another company, but declined to identify the seller. Bristol-Myers Squibb's dermatology business had sales of about $240 million in 2000. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Arrest Made in Attack on 'Sopranos' Actress
description: A 40-year-old man was arrested in Jersey City yesterday for an attack on an actress from the television show ''The Sopranos'' that left her with a broken arm and a badly injured leg, the authorities said.

title: Mine Kills 2 Macedonia Monitors and Interpreter as Tensions Rise
description: Two international monitors and their interpreter were killed when their car hit a land mine in western Macedonia, officials said today. The monitors were the first foreign casualties in the five-month-old conflict.

title: The Bloomberg Factor
description: Michael Bloomberg, a Republican candidate for mayor of New York City, has decided that spending $8 million so far of his own money is a form of political charity. Invoking the Rockefellers and Kennedys as others who have dipped into their pockets to become political servants, he noted recently that ''anybody who doesn't think it is a good thing is a very strange person.'' As arguments go, this one can sound very attractive. But such unbridled spending to buy a political seat overturns a social and legislative consensus about how New Yorkers prefer to elect their public officials.

title: Third Insurer to Stop Selling Single-Premium Credit Life Policies
description: American General, seeking approval of its pending $23 billion purchase by the American International Group, has decided to stop selling a type of life insurance that consumer advocates say is merely a tool for stripping the equity out of poor people's homes.

title: INSIDE
description: OPEC May Cut Production

title: Ugly Thoughts, Set Down on Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk About a Reality Show. A Pinter Classic Is It.
description: They are back at their cushioned battle stations, folks, one of the strangest and most familiar, most extraordinary and ordinary bands of combatants ever to assemble in a living room. And oh, what a lovely, frightening and utterly compelling war it is that they are waging at the John Jay College Theater.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Summit Leaders Pledge Money to Fight Diseases

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Referendum On Discrimination Law
description: Opponents of a new state law banning discrimination against gays have forced a referendum on the measure next year, state election officials said. Take Back Maryland, a coalition of religious groups and political conservatives, gathered 47,539 signatures on a petition against the law, which forbids discrimination based on sexual orientation. That is about 1,400 more than needed to put the measure to a vote in November 2002.

title: Junior Celebrity Circuit Welcomes Big Farm Boy
description: Ten months ago, Rulon Gardner performed the unthinkable, bursting from athletic obscurity to upset the forbidding Russian, Aleksandr Karelin, and win the Olympic gold medal in the super heavyweight class of Greco-Roman wrestling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSACCHIO, LUCILLE
description: MUSACCHIO-Lucille. Age 89 of Huntington on July 20, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Thomas. Loving mother of Claire Lucille Pace and Dr. John Hunter. Dear mother-in-law of Dr. Anthony J. Pace and Ann Hunter. Cherished grandmother of Bradley, Adrian, Jonathan, Heather, Todd and Timothy. Adored great grandmother of Naomi and Madison. Reposing Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington Station. Mass Monday, 10 AM at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to YAI, National Institute for People with Disabilities, 96 Willis Avenue, Mineola, New York 11501.

title: Premier Urges Jamaicans To Comply With Police
description: Two weeks after clashes between the police and gunmen claimed the lives of 26 people and prompted a special investigation, Jamaica's prime minister, P. J. Patterson, insisted today that no community was above the law.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I can understand why these situations are so difficult for family members. Every hour must be agony. The good statistics don't bring much comfort to family members.''

title: Istanbul Journal; Great Divide Widens As Economy Worsens
description: A black Porsche Carrera swings to the curb and two doormen in tuxedos rush to open the doors for the driver, who is in wraparound designer sunglasses and his passenger, a young woman wearing a short red silk dress and improbably high heels. Whisked past the paparazzi, they disappear into Laila, a sprawling club on the Bosporus where the city's hip and rich party away the summer nights.

title: Rookie Pitcher Is Rocked Early
description: Brett Jodie ambled into the spacious, bustling Yankees clubhouse yesterday, carrying a duffel bag and looking like a visitor from some small town who had been dumped in Penn Station. He took a few steps across the blue carpet before stopping and waiting. Ten, 20, 30 seconds passed before Jodie was directed to a clubhouse attendant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITTLESON, MARIANNE
description: ITTLESON-Marianne. On July 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Henry Anthony. Loving mother of Philip and his wife Margot, Christina and her husband Sean and Stephanie. Cherished grandmother of Carlin, Henry and Fayre. Devoted sister of Nina, Cecilia, Agneta and Christian. Loving daughter of Alfhild Sundby. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC, on Sunday, July 22, 2001, 5-8 PM. Service Monday, July 23, 2001 at 11 AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St., NYC. Cemetery arrangements private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 or Hollings Cancer Center, Medical University of South Carolina.

title: Indonesia Leader Dodges and Weaves in Threat of Ouster
description: Caught in a political net, President Abdurrahman Wahid flopped and wriggled today as he sought a way to slow momentum for his removal from office in the coming days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALLON, JOHN T. (JACK)
description: FALLON-John T. (Jack) Of Weston, Ma.,Osterville, Ma. and Roslindale, Ma; on July 19, 2001, age 77. Former Chairman and CEO of R. M. Bradley, Inc. Survived by his wife Antoinette (Mayer) Fallon; sister Anne Jones and husband Payson Jones of Falmouth, Ma.; daughter Pamela Jagla and husband Kevin Jagla of Portland, Or., son William and wife Susan of Campton, NH; son John and wife Patrice of Osterville, Ma.; five grandchildren and several nieces. Mass Funeral will be held on Tuesday, July 24th, 11am at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, Osterville, Ma. Family and friends are respectfully invited. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Wianno Senior Class Association, POB 159, Osterville, Ma. 02655. For information John-Lawrence Funeral Home, Marston Mills, Ma.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOW, DON
description: ARONOW-Don. Passed away after a courageous battle with cancer on July 19, 2001 on Cape Cod, surrounded by his loving family. Ithaca College graduate and brilliant founder/chief executive of DNA Creative, a dynamic marketing and graphic design firm in New York City. He is the son of the late Les Aronow and is survived by his beloved wife Jill, mother Gail Aronow Kaufer, stepfather Marshall Kaufer, brothers Rob, James and sister-in-law Trish. Services on Sunday, July 22, 1 P.M., Wanamaker and Carlough Funeral Home, 177 Route 59, Suffern, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hospice of Cape Cod, 923 Route 6A, Yarmouth Port, MA 02675 and/or the Melanoma Research Foundation, 23704-5, El Toro Rd. #

title: Czechs Debate Benefits of Smokers' Dying Prematurely
description: Ever since the Czech Republic sold its state tobacco industry to Philip Morris in the early 1990's, Czechs have been giving the company four-fifths of the domestic cigarette market.

title: Fuel Standards Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Loss Isn't as Deep As Expected
description: DaimlerChrysler said today that its Chrysler unit lost $125 million in the second quarter, a better performance than analysts had predicted because of stronger auto sales and gains from a turnaround plan. Chrysler earned $986 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Thursday incorrectly identified Paula Dobriansky, who is leading the United States delegation at the global warming talks in Bonn. She is the under secretary of state for global affairs, not an assistant secretary. An editorial yesterday incorrectly referred to Representative Sherwood Boehlert of New York as Sherwin.

title: A City Union Gives Nod, But Barely, To Vallone
description: With several major unions standing on the sidelines in the Democratic mayoral campaign, the leaders of District Council 37, the giant union of municipal employees, sought this week to give a resounding endorsement to City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on July 11 about the award of a patent to Vasogen for its bone marrow transplant treatment for cancer misstated a comment by Tony Bolton, the company's research director. He said that about half of all marrow tissue transplants result in rejection of the new host, not by the host. The report also misstated Mr. Bolton's explanation of Vasogen's process. It involves treating T-cells from the donor, not T-cells in the host's immune system.

title: Conflicting Accounts of an Accident in Newark That Left One Dead
description: The police and witnesses gave conflicting accounts today of an accident Thursday night in which a speeding sport utility vehicle that turned out to be stolen careered out of control into a crowd of people in Newark's Central Ward, killing a 17-year-old girl and injuring six other teenagers.

title: Mets' Pratt Is Spared War of Words, for Now
description: Todd Pratt's remarks Thursday about the lack of run production from the Mets' outfielders were met with a mostly muted response inside the team's clubhouse today.

title: Judge to Fine If Alabama Cannot Move Prisoners
description: An Alabama judge declared today that the state corrections commissioner was in contempt of court for failing to move prisoners from county jails to prisons and said the court would begin fining the state for every prisoner not moved out of a jail within 45 days.

title: Leading Indexes Drop as Microsoft Casts Long Shadow
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday under pressure from Microsoft, which led the three major market indexes lower with the warning that its sales and profits in the next quarter would be below previous forecasts.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Judge Strikes Term Limits
description: A Marion County circuit judge stuck down a state law enacted by ballot initiative in 1992 that imposed term limits on statewide office holders and legislators. The judge, Richard Barber cited a 1996 Oregon Supreme Court ruling and said the initiative contained too many dissimilar constitutional amendments and should not have been on the ballot. Former State Representatives Mike Lehman, a Democrat, and Bill Markham, a Republican, brought a suit challenging the law in June; both lost their seats through term limits. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: F.C.C. to Waive Rules for Acquisition by Murdoch
description: The Federal Communications Commission has decided to approve the News Corporation's purchase of Chris-Craft Industries and waive rules that would have forced the combined company to sell either The New York Post, WNYW-TV or WWOR-TV, according to senior government officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, GRACE BORGENICHT
description: BRANDT-Grace Borgenicht. Of NYC, age 86, on July 19, 2001. Beloved wife of Warren, loving mother of Jan Schwartz, Berta B. Kerr, Lois Borgenicht, stepmother of Isabella Brandt Johansen, sister of Shirley Black Kash, grandmother of Kendra, Adam, Regina, Orin, Max, Daven, Nicholas, greatgrandmother of David and Sarah. Her integrity and grace will be remembered. Service Sunday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Museum, 1109 5th Ave., NY, NY 10128.

title: John Marriott, 78, Stamp Master For Britain's Royal Collectors
description: John Brook Marriott, a Briton who for many years watched over the queen's bulging private stamp collection, considered one of the world's richest, died on July 3 at Godalming, Surrey. He was 78.

title: Jamaica's Drug Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: A Woman Is Guaranteed To Win the Grand Nationals
description: A team from the New York metropolitan area contended here today in the semifinal stage of the Grand National Team Championship, the curtain raiser to the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Ethan Stein, Michael Kamil, Rozanne Pollack, William Pollack, Joel Friedberg and Ilya Levitin faced a Californian team consisting of Jill Meyers, Iftikhar Baqai, Mitch Dunitz, John Mohan and Ed Davis.

title: AIR CANADA AND I.B.M. FORM $908 MILLION PARTNERSHIP
description: Air Canada and I.B.M. have agreed to a $908 million partnership to develop information-technology services and products. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will manage the airline's computer and information technology operations, including application development and maintenance, 20,000 workstations, employee help-desk services and network and computer server operations. The two also plan to offer the products and services they develop to other airlines. Air Canada, which carries most of Canada's domestic air travelers, said that it expected to save about $130 million over the seven-year term of the contract.

title: Questioned About Johns Hopkins, Bloomberg Keeps His Counsel
description: During his run for mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg has eagerly promoted his prominent volunteer position at Johns Hopkins University, where he is chairman of the board.

title: Editors' Note
description: COMING ON SUNDAY

title: Miami Beach Ocean Resort
description: The Miami Beach Ocean Resort, on Collins Avenue near the Art Deco District, Ocean Drive and the Lincoln Road Mall, is offering rates starting at $139 a night for two, with a two-night minimum stay, through Sept. 30. Included is a full breakfast each day for two, but not taxes. The 243-room hotel is on the beach. Information: (800) 550-0505.

title: L.I. Millionaire's Newest Venture Was Oldest Profession, Police Say
description: For almost 40 years, Stuart J. Roll has built a business selling mustard, ketchup, jelly and jam that did $10 million in sales last year and made him a multimillionaire.

title: Listen to the Irish
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Entry to Trade Group Stumbles Over Life Insurance
description: China's effort to win entry to the World Trade Organization has stumbled over the access of foreign companies to the country's vast life insurance market. Negotiators appeared to have made no headway on the issue by the end of the session this week as China continued its 15-year quest.

title: States Steer Religious Charities Toward Aid
description: Despite the resistance that President Bush's religion-based initiative has encountered in Washington, the idea is already catching on in many states, where local officials are making unprecedented efforts to encourage religious charities to apply for government money.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Campaign Finance Board ruling on Comptroller Alan Hevesi's spending in his mayoral campaign misstated the average monthly retainer paid to his consultant, Hank Morris, and referred incorrectly to Mr. Morris's comments on the possibility of voluntary services. The retainer has averaged $8,333, not $12,000, since January. And while Mr. Morris says he has the right to volunteer, he will not say whether he is actually doing so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORNE, PHILIP
description: OSBORNE-Philip. We dearly miss you but will always remember your humor and thoughtfulness. Our love and sympathies are with Fran, Leicia, Michael and Morgan. Billie Jean and Patrick, Cyd and Richard, Nancy and Bill

title: New Jersey Is Trying New Way For Witnesses to Say, 'It's Him'
description: Prompted by new insights into the psychology of eyewitnesses to crimes, New Jersey is changing the way it uses witnesses to identify suspects.

title: A Frightful Friday for Mets and Yankees
description: The Mets' only offensive threat, Mike Piazza, did not stay beyond his first at-bat. The Mets' most successful pitcher, Rick Reed, left the field after taking a line drive off a wrist.

title: Abroad at Home; Bush The Radical
description: We are well aware by now of the radical change that George W. Bush has brought to basic domestic policies: his retreat from environment protection, for example, and his effort to breach the separation of church and state. But in fact his changes in national security policy are even more radical, upsetting fundamentals that have defined our international outlook for more than 50 years.

title: Making Time Elastic Enough To Tell a Tale of Generations
description: D. Chase Angier is a fine storyteller, and she turned her audience into the equivalent of children at bedtime with two pieces she presented on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo. In ''Waiting,'' Ms. Angier created a haunting world of women living through decades of time with a few props and six strong performers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: More Gunshots
description: Hooded gunmen from a Protestant paramilitary group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, that last week withdrew its backing for the Northern Ireland peace agreement fired 10 shots into a community center in a Catholic neighborhood in North Belfast that works with children from both communities. None of the children were wounded, but many were treated for shock. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNER, BERNICE ROSNER
description: HORNER-Bernice Rosner. On July 17, 2001. Retired Executive Director, Visiting Nurse Service of Brooklyn. Survived by three sisters, one brother and many nieces and nephews in Hawaii. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial, Monday July 23rd, 10:30AM, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about financial results at Sun Microsystems misstated the company's earnings for the quarter ended June 2000. Excluding special items, the figure was $717 million, not $720 million.

title: A Hong Kong Court Rebuffs Beijing on Residency Issue
description: In a bold reassertion of its judicial independence from Beijing and Hong Kong, the territory's highest court ruled today that a 3-year-old boy born here to a mainland Chinese mother has the right to residency.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel Still Has Tricks Up His Sleeve
description: IN the August issue of Esquire, there are the usual models, actors and other assorted pretty people wearing the latest fashions that cost as much as nuclear submarines. But as you flip through the publication, past the ''Saturday Night Live'' actor Chris Kattan wearing an Armani sport coat, past the music producer Wyclef Jean in black loafers, a face leaps out of the pages, one that causes an instant double-take.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFERS, HAROLD
description: WOLFERS-Harold. Age 94, of Lake Worth, Florida passed away on Thursday, July 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Hilda (Bodeck) Wolfers for sixty-eight years. Cherished father of Joan Wolfers Belkin and loving father-in-law of Steven Belkin. Adored grandfather of Julie Ann & Amy Jill Belkin. A kind, loving man who will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, July 22 at 9:30 AM at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel 5808 West Atlantic Ave, Delray Beach. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: A Cold-War Weapon Disguised as a Place to Spend the Night
description: You may not have thought that dialing up room service or raiding the minibar was striking a blow against communism. But after World War II, when the cold war was being fought on every conceivable front, even luxuriating in a hotel tub could be considered a triumph for democracy.

title: Ashcroft Seeks Return of Criminal Immigrants
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has warned that a recent Supreme Court ruling could result in the release of thousands of immigrants with criminal records into American cities and said he was considering steps to force nations to take them back.

title: Thriving Guatemala Shrimp Farm Sets Off a Conflict
description: In the waist-high estuaries that wind through the mangroves, bare-chested fishermen cast their nets only to haul them back empty. Crab traps with their plump bait lie untouched for hours. The desolate quiet is interrupted just by a few birds and the constant buzz of motorized pumps along the banks.

title: Mosley Set to Defend Title Against Stone
description: Shane Mosley, who will defend his World Boxing Council welterweight title tonight in a scheduled 12-round bout at Caesars Palace, and Adrian Stone of England each weighed in at 147 pounds in Las Vegas yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Amnesty Prompts TB Fears
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma ordered 35,000 prisoners released from prison under an amnesty approved by Parliament, spurring fears that the convicts would carry tuberculosis to the general population. Ukraine's crowded prisons, like those in Russia, are breeding grounds for drug-resistant TB. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Dismisses Condit Polygraph Results
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation dismissed as useless today a privately administered polygraph examination taken by Representative Gary A. Condit in connection with the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, GLORIA
description: WEINSTOCK-Gloria. Sister of Selma and Jack, sister-in-law of Florence, beloved aunt and greataunt.

title: Grace Borgenicht Brandt, 86, New York Art Dealer, Dies
description: Grace Borgenicht Brandt, a longtime New York art dealer, died Thursday in Manhattan. She was 86 and had homes in Manhattan and Watermill, N.Y.

title: Columbia University Hires Star Economist
description: Trying to regain its old glory as a teaching and research center in economics, Columbia University has hired Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Stanford University professor often mentioned as a future Nobel prize winner for his contributions to economic theory.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Jim Lesczynski, a Libertarian candidate for the New York City Council, misstated the number of signatures he had collected on his candidate petitions. By Wednesday, it was roughly 700 -- not 100 -- of the 2,100 he would need by Aug. 21 to get his name on the November ballot.

title: The Rural Life; For Sale
description: A couple of years ago, judging by roadside signs, it looked as though the rural economy of America depended almost entirely on the sale and resale of Beanie Babies. On every country road you passed hand-lettered squares of cardboard, nailed to a fence or tied to a mailbox, announcing the availability of Beanie Babies. If you didn't know what Beanie Babies were, the signs could be confusing -- ''Lambs for Sale'' at one farmstead, ''Piglets'' at another down the road, and ''Beanie Babies'' at a third. As I drove home from the train station the other night over nearly an hour of country roads, I realized I hadn't seen a ''Beanie Babies'' sign in a long time. That sector of the rural economy has moved, I think, to the Internet.

title: The Stem Cell Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: An Egyptian Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Wife Sees Milosevic In Jail
description: Slobodan Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, has visited her husband at the United Nations detention center in The Hague where the former Yugoslav president awaits trial on war crimes charges. Mrs. Milosevic spent most of Thursday and yesterday at the jail and is to return to Belgrade today. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Montgomerie Halfway Home on Road to Title
description: Starting the second round with a three-stroke lead at the British Open, Colin Montgomerie was like the neighborhood kid who had the toy that everyone else wanted. To keep it, Montgomerie was forced to fight for it.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Indians Threaten Blockades
description: The Assembly of First Nations, Canada's largest Indian organization, is threatening to block highways across the country if the federal government continues to bypass Indian leaders with plans to revamp the federal Indian Act. Matthew Coon Come, national chief, gave the government 30 days to change direction or face acts of civil disobedience that could disrupt the economy. In the past, Indian blockades have led to violent confrontations with the police. The government has been meeting with tribe members to promote changes to the Indian Act that it says will improve Indian governance and accountability. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Johnny LoBianco, 85, Referee In Controversial Duran Bout
description: Johnny LoBianco, a boxing referee in New York for three decades who worked a host of championship bouts, most notably Roberto Duran's controversial knockout of Ken Buchanan in 1972, died last Monday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 85.

title: A Great Woman Who Was Everywoman
description: Katharine Graham left us as unexpectedly as she arrived. A woman raised mainly to be the wife of a powerful man, she responded to widowhood by becoming a publisher who helped end a war and bring down a presidency. A resident of a rarefied world of wealth and privilege, she became a wife and worker with whom many women identified because of both her painful lack of confidence and her determination to overcome it.

title: After 8 Years, Republican Leaders Gather to Revel in Their Chance at Praising the President
description: Leaders of the Republican Party who are meeting here did something today that they had not done in eight long years: extolled the president's virtues.

title: OPEC Leaders Indicate They Are Set to Cut Output Again
description: Leaders of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated yesterday that they planned to reduce daily production for the third time this year to shore up flagging crude oil prices. Analysts said the decision could come as early as next week and would probably lead to a decrease of 750,000 to one million barrels a day, or 3 percent to 4 percent of OPEC's current daily output of 24.2 million barrels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, BERNICE BLOCK
description: FRIEDMAN-Bernice Block. Died at 81 on July 20th, 2001 after a heroic 55-year struggle with melanoma. Widow of Charles, mother of Jonathan & Jeremy, Marilyn and Lisa, grandmother of Lindsay, Charlie, Caroline and David, and sister of Aubrey. Beautiful, hopeful and articulate, she was one strong and smart woman. A passionate, vivacious, and intensely dedicated human being, she lives forever in our hearts. Funeral at 12 noon, Sunday, July 22nd, at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York. Contributions in her name to the Skin Cancer Foundation, 245 Fifth Avenue, Suite 1403, New York City 10016.

title: California Legislators Haggle Over Aid for Troubled Utility
description: California legislators worked late tonight to reach a compromise to aid the nearly bankrupt Southern California Edison, the state's second-largest utility. But no deal was reached to help the company pay its debts.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Support For Slavery Reparations
description: Human Rights Watch threw its weight behind demands for reparations and compensation for slavery, a topic likely to inflame debate at the United Nations-sponsored World Conference Against Racism later this summer in Durban, South Africa. The New York-based international human rights organization called for the establishment of panels in countries including the United States, Brazil and South Africa to assess the effects of slavery and colonialism, and look for the broadest ways to compensate the descendants of slaves. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KEEFFE, MARGARET ''PEGGY'', NEE RYAN
description: O'KEEFFE-Margaret ''Peggy'', nee Ryan on July 19, 2001. Emigrated from Thurles, Tipperary, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Michael J. O'Keeffe and the late Stephen Coffey. Cherished mother of Carmel O'Keeffe Judge of California, Michael ''Buzzy'' O'Keeffe, and Barbara O'Keeffe Kennedy of New York. Cherished mother-inlaw to Martin Kennedy. Dearest grandmother to Kevin O'Keeffe Kennedy and Brian O'Keeffe Kennedy of New York and Michael Judge, John Judge, Patricia Ann Williams, Stephen Judge and the late Thomas Judge of California. Also survived by her loving sister Mary Hennessey of Coolcroo, Thurles, Tipperary and her many dear nieces and nephews including David Hennessey, Liam Hennessey, Bernie Lanigan, Tessie Fogarty, and Mattie Bannon of Ireland, and William Ryan of New York. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 E. Tremont Avenue, Bronx, NY until Monday 10:30 AM. Mass of Christian burial St. Frances de Chantal Church, Bronx, NY 11 AM. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting Saturday 7:00-9:30 PM Sunday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:30 PM. James E. McQuade, Dir.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: School Stays Out Of League
description: A predominantly black Roman Catholic grade school that fought to be accepted into a predominantly white athletic league said it would not join after all. The school, St. Sabina, decided to withdraw because league members refused to give written assurance that no coaches would forfeit games rather than go to its South Side neighborhood. In May, citing concerns about the safety of the neighborhood, the league voted not accept the school, but after St. Sabina's priest said that decision reflected racist stereotypes, the league admitted the school. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Merrill Settles a Conflict-of-Interest Dispute
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a claim by a former client that the brokerage company's Internet analyst, Henry Blodget, recommended a stock without disclosing a conflict of interest.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Boot Camp Inquiry
description: Three weeks after a 14-year-old boy died in a Phoenix-area boot camp for troubled youths, Gov. Jane Hull said she intended to appoint a panel to develop new guidelines for camp operators. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Laura Bush Enjoys Globalization's Lighter Side
description: Because her plane had to land in Pisa anyway, Laura Bush took a detour from her duties today to get a close look at the Leaning Tower of Pisa.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a halt in public forums by the New York Society of Security Analysts, examining management's responsibility to shareholders, misstated the composition of pro forma financial results reported by one recent forum subject, Amazon.com. The results do not exclude interest, depreciation or taxes.

title: Think Locally And Rock Globally
description: The first 90 minutes of Youssou N'Dour's concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall were a well-nigh perfect arc: a gradual, sweeping crescendo and a passage from Western-tinged pop to modern African rock. It began calmly, with Mr. N'Dour accompanied by acoustic guitars and hand drums. Then, as new band members arrived for each song, it spiraled into explosive Senegalese mbalax, accelerating with every song, that had the entire audience on its feet and dancing. The snippets of the concert broadcast on ''Live at Lincoln Center'' caught only the upswing of the euphoria.

title: Risky Rewards in Emerging Markets
description: EMERGING-MARKETS investors typically follow one of two styles. The "top-down" school looks at a country's economy and politics before deciding to invest in its stocks, while "bottom-up" advocates shop wherever they find good companies.

title: Bennigan's Settles in Harassment Suit
description: Bennigan's Grill and Tavern, the national restaurant chain, has agreed to pay $160,000 and apologize to nine women who worked at a restaurant here to settle a sexual harassment lawsuit brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: B. D. Fischman, 86, Lawyer and Activist
description: Bernard D. Fischman, a lawyer and civil liberties advocate, died on July 11 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rich Nations Offer a Hand, But the Poor Hope for More
description: After growing protests, world leaders sat down today for the first time to discuss health, debt and the poor -- exactly the topics that demonstrators have complained are ignored by rich countries.

title: Who's in Running For Council Seat? Almost Everybody
description: Dr. Kendall Stewart had a hammertoe waiting. He is a podiatrist by profession. He will fix whatever bothers the foot. He took a bit of time to talk politics, for he is running for City Council in the 45th District in central Brooklyn.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: A Case of Cruelty And Injustice in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Otello' Runs a Lively Leg In La Selva's Verdi Marathon
description: When Vincent La Selva announced, in 1994, that he would perform all 28 of Verdi's operas, in chronological order, as part of Summerstage in Central Park, the task seemed daunting. But the finish line is in sight: on Wednesday evening, just after 11 p.m., Mr. La Selva and his New York Grand Opera company put ''Otello'' behind them, leaving only the production of ''Falstaff'' that is scheduled for Aug. 1 to round out the cycle.

title: Congress Passes $6.5 Billion Spending Bill
description: Both houses of Congress today approved $6.5 billion in additional government spending this year, most of it for the Pentagon, in a bill that was seen as an early test of President Bush's ability to enforce budgetary discipline on lawmakers.

title: New Affidavit Likely Means Louima Case Will Drag On
description: While the new affidavit by the mysterious Officer F submitted two days ago as part of Charles Schwarz's bid to overturn his convictions in the Abner Louima case caught many people by surprise, it does not mean that Mr. Schwarz will be getting out of prison any time soon.

title: Journal; Condit Country Or Bust
description: A.I.'' tanked, ''Pearl Harbor'' is already history, and ''Jurassic Park III'' is getting sub-two-star reviews. The nation yawned at the prospect of a man holding a knife to a woman's throat on ''Big Brother 2,'' and the hottest title that American publishing can come up with for a beach read is ''John Adams.'' The Mrs. Robert Blake mystery had no legs, and New York's own summertime pride and joy, the Lizzie Grubman saga, lacks two essential elements that might make it fly west of the Hudson, sex and death.

title: Beacon Hill
description: To the Editor: What a true gem you led us to in ''Cheery Cosseting on Beacon Hill'' (Travel Advisory, June 3) at the Beacon Hill Hotel and Bistro. This fine restaurant has given Charles Street just the easy yet delicious dining it needed.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-22-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Roque Abalsamo, Regina McConoghy and John Tobin Jr., West Roxbury, Mass., April 22, 2001

title: INVESTING WITH/Bruce L. Bartlett and Christopher M. Leavy; Atlas Growth and Income Fund
description: THE two managers of the $388 million Atlas Growth and Income fund work together, but each follows his own investment discipline.

title: Pillars Party, Too
Anna Blau, Alexander Zay
description: Anna Marika Blau, the daughter of Heide I. Wetmore of Ghent, N.Y., and Dick Blau of Milwaukee, is to be married today to Alexander Oliver Zay, a son of Jean Zay of Great Barrington, Mass., and the late Thorn Zay. The Rev. Ray Wilson will perform the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Great Barrington.

title: With 65, Duval Sits Near Lead Once Again
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 21  With his best round ever at the British Open, David Duval dramatically put himself into contention in today's third round.

title: For Jet Skiers, A Little Less V-r-r-o-o-o-o-m!
description: SOME people, particularly the owners of beachside cottages and the mayors of serene waterfront villages, call Jet Skis and similar craft the motorcycles of the sea and say that they should be be kept as far as possible from waterside Shangri-Las.

title: WEST VILLAGE
description: Neighbors of an empty yard at 600 Washington Street sued the city on July 13 for letting luxury housing on a block zoned for manufacturing. The city's Board of Standards and Appeals had granted the J. D. Carlisle Development Corporation a variance for a 14-story residential building on the site. Tenants at the West Village Houses who filed the suit, argued that the building would jeopardize the area's low-rise, middle-income character.

title: Farm Unrest in Mexico Challenges New President
description: The fields are green with new sugar cane, but the peasant farmers feel that their way of life is withering away.

title: Storytelling Conference in Princeton
description: ''Stories are the fabric of universal life,'' says Gwendolyn Jones, professor emeritus of the College of New Jersey and founder of the Garden State Storytellers' League. ''They embrace all emotions, all times and all places. No other form of art has been accessible to all, and practiced by all, throughout the ages. Storytelling is not a lost art . . . it is an art in a state of exciting re-emergence.''

title: A Literal Addition To Prime-Time Crime
description: IT must be true that death never takes a holiday -- not on television, anyway. Here we are in high summer, and newly minted true-crime shows are still turning up in prime time.

title: The Allergy Prison
description: In response to Susan Dominus's article (June 10) on severe food allergies, a reader from Dallas wrote to the Letters page (July 1) asking for a recipe for an egg-free, butter-free, milk-free cake (and frosting) for her son's birthday. There are lots of wonderful, kid-pleasing recipes in the cookbook put out by the Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Network (www.foodallergy.org).

title: Follow the Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory
description: Science Center With Depth and Height (417 Feet)

title: From Busywork To Opportunity
description: AROUND 1905, my grandfather and great-uncle started McKissack & McKissack Architects in Nashville. I worked there part time during the summers before I went to college.

title: July 15-21; Layering Disagreement
description: The leaders of India and Pakistan, mired in one of the world's most intractable conflicts, met for the first time in more than two years, but their two-day summit meeting ended with no agreement even on what they are willing to negotiate. India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, accepted an invitation to visit Pakistan from Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. But while Pakistan says progress was made on a framework for discussing Kashmir, the Himalayan land both claim, as well as narcotics trafficking and other issues, India maintains the two countries will have to start from scratch. Celia W. Dugger

title: Beating the Bogeyman In Nuclear Power Debate
description: Peter Maniscalco's Opinion piece, ''Same Old Unwise Ideas on Energy'' [July 15], is an interesting collection of opinions and fables. Explaining our recent political climate regarding Shoreham with references to mythology is clever but useless.

title: July 15-21; Shirt Tale
description: The most sought-after tailor in France just now is Stphane Gitton, who works out of the back of a small truck and deals mainly in polyester shirts -- most notably, yellow ones.

title: How to Dress an Evil Dwarf
description: THE DEVIL'S CLOTH

title: Setting Out
description: THE FLIGHT OF THE MAIDENS

title: Paperback Fiction
description: This

title: More Than One Way To Get Into Stuyvesant
description: To the Editor:

title: Vienna: Museum Information
description: House of Music, 30 Seilerstätte, (43-1) 51648, fax (43-1) 512-0315; hausdermusik.at . Open daily 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.

title: More Than One Eden in Cornwall
description: SCI-FI wasps' nests? Giant bubble wrap? Half-buried space ships? When I stood at the edge of the huge crater, once an abandoned china-clay pit near St. Austell, Cornwall, I kept grasping for comparisons. I had never seen anything like the two clusters of curving geodesic domes that nestled snugly into the earth. They form a complex of greenhouses, the largest in the world, called the Eden Project. My husband, James, and I had come to Cornwall for a week in April, only a month after Eden had opened, partly to see these greenhouses, or ''biomes.''

title: Nira Firestone, Christopher Psaltos
description: Nira Suzanne Firestone, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Firestone of Port Jefferson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Dimitrios Psaltos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dimitrios Psaltos of Leonia, N.J. Peter J. Graham, a Port Jefferson village justice, officiated at the Port Jefferson Country Club at Harbor Hills.

title: Progress in Cleaning Chesapeake Bay, but Far to Go
description: Bits of progress abound in the vast cleanup that has been under way for a generation in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, the nation's largest estuary, which stands as the model of a natural treasure haunted by relentless land development and deepening sources of pollution.

title: Comic Book Plots
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Believes He Will Stay As Manager
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre requested and received a one-on-one meeting with George Steinbrenner yesterday at Yankee Stadium, and Torre emerged from the brief session believing he would return to manage the team beyond this season.

title: Preservation Is Goal of Farm Designation
description: NEW YORK STATE has approved an Agricultural District for Westchester, which will enable the county to develop an agricultural and farmland protection plan and become eligible for state money for farmland preservation.

title: From Menu to Setting, It's a Taste of Paris
description: YOU do not have to be French to open a restaurant in the cellar of the 200-year-old building on Big Shop Lane in Ridgefield, but it does seem to be a pattern. Luc's Cafe-Restaurant is the latest in a string of Gallic occupants of this attractive, intimate space, from Le Coq Hardi to Chez Noue.

title: When You're Cooking More Than a Meal
description: Who says too many cooks spoil the broth? Not the 11 office supervisors at the law firm Bingham Dana, who just participated in a ''Corporate Culinary Team Building Workshop'' conducted by Loyalty Factor, a Boston consulting firm.

title: Campaign Danger: Deep Pockets
description: To the Editor:

title: Stem Cells and Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: After 1,900 Years, A Colosseum Face Lift
description: The Colosseum in Rome, completed in A.D. 80, has suffered quite a bit of wear and tear over the centuries; its marble seats and nearly all its rich decorations are gone.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Governor
description: DONALD T. DiFRANCESCO had it all. Not only did he inherit the governor's office -- but by a constitutional quirk -- he controlled half of the State Legislature as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about ''Mercy,'' a new dance-theater work by Ann Hamilton and Meredith Monk, omitted one of the two organizations that commissioned it. The Wexner Center for the Arts at Ohio State University commissioned the work, along with the American Dance Festival.

title: Erika Moravec, Nelson Jaeggli
description: Erika Eugenie Moravec and Nelson Southwell Jaeggli were married yesterday by Peter Awn, who is a Roman Catholic priest and the dean of the School of General Studies at Columbia University, in a nondenomenational ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Gabriele Moravec and Dr. Clayton Moravec, in Owings Mills, Md.

title: Rivera Has Inflammation
description: Mariano Rivera is relieved that a second M.R.I. exam merely showed inflammation in his tender right ankle, and he is hoping that a visit to a foot specialist next week will provide orthotics for his cleat that will help reduce the pain.

title: As Titans Tangle, Every Imp Counts
description: Two California teams, each captained by a top-ranked female player, clashed here today in the final match of the Grand National Teams championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-22-01: On Language; Lounge Act
description: The opening salvo at the phrase foreign service was fired by Secretary of State Colin Powell. He proposed to strike those words from the medal established by Congress in 1999 to honor federal employees killed or injured while serving under chiefs of mission abroad. It was Powell's plan to change the name of ''the Foreign Service Star'' to ''the Thomas Jefferson Star.''

title: The World; As Labor Lost Ideology, U.S. Parties Found It
description: NOBODY can accuse George W. Bush and Tony Blair of neglecting the trans-Atlantic relationship. Mr. Blair was the first European leader to make an official visit to the newly elected Republican. Mr. Bush returned the compliment last week, dropping in on Mr. Blair's country residence. The two have discovered they have so many things in common they even use the same brand of toothpaste.

title: Vestige of the Old Neighborhood Hangs On in a Hipsters' Hangout
description: Tucked between a partly vacant Roman Catholic church and a Vietnamese herbal store, the Beard Cafe, on Elizabeth Street, near Broome, could be mistaken for another downtown bar, priced out of SoHo or the East Village. At night, young urbanites and European tourists mingle to enjoy techno music and imported beer. Leftist literature competes for attention with a video art installation.

title: New Imaging Centers Allow Outpatient X-Rays
description: Why go to the hospital for an X-ray when you can go to an outpatient center? Two new imaging centers, Westchester Imaging in Yorktown Heights and the unrelated Westchester Medical Imaging Services in Hawthorne, now provide services ranging from CAT scans to ultrasounds on an outpatient basis.

title: HOMESTEAD REBATE INCREASE
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week signed legislation that will increase to $750 the maximum property tax rebate for elderly and disabled citizens. The payback, called the Homestead Rebate, had not increased from $500 since 1990. The increase will cost the state an extra $144 million a year. Starting next year, the maximum Homestead Rebate will automatically increase annually to match the rate of inflation. Anne Ruderman

title: Conservatives in Iran, Despite Defeat, Try to Thwart Reformers
description: Iran's hard-line conservatives show little sign of yielding, despite their overwhelming defeat in presidential elections last month; instead they appear to be intensifying their efforts to thwart the reform movement.

title: This Time the Shock Is Her Turn Toward Naturalism
description: SUZAN-LORI PARKS has her own way of doing things. A 38-year-old playwright, she first made her mark on the fringes of Off Broadway with plays that defied virtually every aspect of naturalistic theater. ''Imperceptible Mutabilities in the Third Kingdom'' in 1989 established her as a writer experimenting with poetic repetition, literary wordplay, an irreverent perspective on history and a love for odd titles and wacky names.

title: OUT THERE: Tokyo; Love Birds Seek Discreet Nest
description: THE choices must have seemed endless, from giant neon-dressed pleasure palaces that offer every amenity (color jet baths and karaoke machines) to darker and more discreetly lighted places that rely on romantic-sounding French names like C'est la Vie.

title: Toward a New Skyline
description: TO hear the mayor tell it, Louis R. Cappelli's new building proposal is nothing less than the economic salvation of this long-stagnant city. It is certainly ambitious: the City Center would be a $300 million complex with 560 luxury rental units, a 16-screen cinema and as many as 10 restaurants, to be built on the site of the old Macy's building in the heart of downtown.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Celebrating A Century And More Of Summers
description: As a performer on stilts ambled past him, Kareem Tunstall could not help but lift his eyes from his own balancing act. Two paper plates teetered on his small hands -- on one, a stack of watermelon slices, and on the other, a piece of chocolate cake.

title: The G.O.P.'s Unsung Centrists
description: Last week's brief rebellion by Republican moderates in the House over President Bush's ''faith-based initiative'' ended tamely with vague promises from the White House to review complaints that the bill would override state and local anti-discrimination laws. Still, the grumbling over one of the signature issues in Mr. Bush's domestic agenda was a reminder of the gap between Mr. Bush and the moderate wing of his Congressional party. Republican moderates in Congress, in turn, reflect the feelings of their constituents -- voters who supported Mr. Bush but do not like the policy trends of his administration on certain key issues.

title: Margaret Green, Michael Rauenhorst
description: Margaret Green, who assists refugees, and Michael Rauenhorst, who helps provide loans to low-income entrepreneurs, were married yesterday. Msgr. Richard Albert performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. Archbishop Harry J. Flynn of St. Paul and Minneapolis took part in the ceremony.

title: Reasonable Economic Targets
description: Disappointing earnings reports continued to stream in from some of America's biggest corporations last week. There is no doubt that the economy is in a slump now, and the beginning of its revival may still be months away. But comfort may be drawn from the fact that despite its current weakness, the economy could recapture a historically normal rate of growth as early as next year.

title: A Dog Biscuit for Your Thoughts
description: READING, a 10-year-old white Maltese ball of fluff, arrived at Donna Lozito's apartment barking orders to anyone who'd listen. Dale and David Canner followed like royal courtiers: Ms. Canner with a plastic container of water at the ready, Mr. Canner with a hospital pad to spread on the kitchen floor in case of accidents.

title: From Paris, With Buddhism
description: In the realm of trendy restaurant openings, is there such a thing as too much hype? That seems to be the most whispered question about Man Ray, a Parisian import, which opened in Chelsea two weeks ago. Johnny Depp, Sean Penn and John Malkovich are investors. And at the opening party -- a culinary version of the Oscars -- Warren Beatty, Joan Collins, Francis Ford Coppola and Mark Wahlberg showed up to smile for the paparazzi and to enliven the French-Asian dcor. The owner, Thierry Klemeniuk, part of the fashion and film jet set, is a Buddhist convert, which might explain design elements like a waterfall, a sculpture of a goddess and, behind the bar, two Tibetan murals made of glass. But how much glamour does Man Ray actually deliver with its Eurasian fusion menu (green tea souffl, lobster in sake sauce)?

title: Pressure on Sudan
description: Sudan's 18-year civil war is among the world's worst sustained conflicts since World War II. Until recently, though two million people have died and four million have been displaced, it was also among the most obscure. But now a combination of factors is pushing Sudan's war to the forefront of the Bush administration's agenda. That is to be welcomed. But some of the ideas being urged on the administration are misguided.

title: Jeanette Smith, William Weldon III
description: Jeanette Goodyear Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Gunter Smith of Mobile, Ala., was married last evening to William James Weldon III, a son of Mrs. Francis J. Herel of Old Saybrook, Conn., and the late Mr. Weldon II. The Rev. Santino Titta, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the summer home of the bride's parents in Springfield Center, N.Y.

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
description: This

title: What Are Friends For?
description: What a lovely and eloquent Style section (July 1). I was cheered by the honest and affectionate article by Ken Gross and the accompanying photographs by Geof Kern. I applaud the bravery of the gentlemen who unabashedly revealed genuine affection for their best friends.

title: Clothed Passion
description: To the Editor:

title: Jones Has a 3-Shot Lead, And Local Knowledge
description: Including last year, Rosie Jones has twice finished second at the Sybase Big Apple Classic, the lone L.P.G.A. stop in the New York metropolitan area. Determined to finish one better this time, she is in position to accomplish her goal.

title: Armstrong Finally Wears Yellow Jersey
description: You can't win 'em all, but Lance Armstrong is trying.

title: Elizabeth Hovey, Marc Laibe
description: Elizabeth Bronson Hovey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Hovey of Geneva, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marc William Laibe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Laibe of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. W. James Gerling, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Geneva.

title: Paid Family Leave Would Protect Livelihoods
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: A FABULOUS KINGDOM

title: Potholes Of Common Driveways
description: WHEN Alonso Parra bought a three-bedroom house in Elmhurst, Queens, the fact that he would be sharing a driveway with his next-door neighbor did not seem to be a problem. As long as both owners were not trying to use the driveway at the same time, the seven-foot-wide space between the houses was more than either needed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 1 about young Japanese women who are delaying marriage and still living with their parents and the effects of this on Japan's society and economy misstated the change in the Japanese gross domestic product since the recession there in 1994. It has grown by an average of about 1 percent a year, not shrunk 20 percent over seven years.

title: A Castle in Rye That's Part of a Golf Club
description: IF Whitby Castle here reminds visitors of Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, they're on the right track. The influential 19th-century architect, Alexander Jackson Davis, designed them both in the years when some of the millionaire kings of burgeoning industries thought it only fitting to live in a castle.

title: Ideas & Trends; Fiddle With Baseball's Internal Clock? Good Luck
description: HAVING watched umpires shrink its strike zone to smaller than a bread box, Major League Baseball this month sent a pointed e-mail message urging some umps to call more strikes, leaving the men in blue turning red. The aim is to speed up the proceedings, but baseball seems constitutionally resistant to such forces, its tempo immutable. This is an itch even ballplayers can't scratch.

title: The Week in Review: July 15-21
description: Genoa Talks Open With Death

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 8 about a gardening program at Rikers Island misstated the locations of two scenes. Only the photograph at the bottom, showing a woman, was taken at Rikers. The two others were taken at branch libraries in Brooklyn where inmates did landscaping -- the DeKalb branch. at the top, and the Saratoga branch, in the center.

title: How Can the Theater Make Itself Matter Again?
description: WE all want to feel we're at the center of the culture, and all of us who love theater know that we are not. What I mean, of course, is that theater's not. We cannot imagine ourselves without movies or some kind of popular music; most of us can't imagine ourselves without television. Theater is the only form of art or entertainment that people who consider themselves culturally sophisticated aren't embarrassed to boast about ignoring.

title: 'Three Sisters,' Friends and Relatives With a Summery Air
description: WHY spend three hours of a balmy summer night with Chekhov when there is far lighter, more vacationy fare around? Good acting, for starters.

title: A Decade Spent Shaping Dance In Spain
description: SPAIN'S highly regarded Compaa Nacional de Danza arrives at the Lincoln Center Festival on Wednesday to the rich strains of Bach. The ensemble will present ''Bach: Multiplicity,'' an evening-length work choreographed by Nacho Duato, its artistic director and chief choreographer. The ballet was commissioned for the company in 1999 by the city of Weimar, Germany, and commemorates the 250th anniversary last year of the composer's death.

title: Is Torricelli Radioactive? Democrats Want to Know
description: It is an axiom in American politics that the surest way to drum up enthusiasm on the campaign trail is to have a big-name politician at your side.

title: New Subway Routes Take Effect Today
description: Several subway lines in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens will be rerouted beginning today, because of extensive renovation of the Manhattan Bridge.

title: A Dream Achieved
description: To the Editor:

title: European Papers Doubt Value of Summit Talks
description: PARIS, July 21  As tens of thousands of protesters continued to clash with the police outside the summit meeting of major industrial nations in Genoa, Italy, there was mounting opinion in Europe that such conferences should be dropped in the future.

title: Streetscapes/Long Island City, Queens; After Hard Times, 1910 Auto Factory Gets New Life
description: THE old Brewster automobile factory in Long Island City was remarkable for its central tower, which gave it the feel of a European guild hall facing a ceremonial public plaza. After hard times, including the loss of its central tower and the plaza itself, the 1910 building, where Rolls-Royces and fighter planes were once manufactured, is about to become office space for MetLife.

title: Track Had A Makeover For Today
description: This past week, another Nascar expert took a shot at Bob Bahre's tidy little racetrack in the woods, and Bahre cannot say he enjoyed reading what Darrell Waltrip, the champion driver turned television commentator, had to say.

title: The Invisible Grand Central
description: Grand Central Terminal is celebrated for its Beaux-Arts style, but Kurt C. Schlichting looks behind the facade to see the hidden engineering marvels in GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL: Railroads, Engineering, and Architecture in New York City (Johns Hopkins, $26.50). Completed in 1913 at a cost of about $42 million (the equivalent of more than $750 million today), the terminal had more functions than a Swiss Army knife, seamlessly combining subways, commuter rail and long-distance rail lines. Grand Central's story is also one of cover-ups and conspiracies. William J. Wilgus, the chief engineer of the New York Central Railroad, was responsible for the station's innovative double-level system and for electrifying the trains, but left under a cloud after destroying evidence that the railroad company knew of an engine problem that led to a disastrous crash in the Bronx in 1907, in which 25 passengers were killed. Whitney Warren, the architect who designed Grand Central's celebrated Grand Concourse and facade, schemed to have the commission taken away from the firm of Reed & Stern, which was a partner in the project, and was ultimately booted out of the American Institute of Architects. Schlichting, a sociologist at Fairfield University, has a better feel for the engineering of the station than its architecture, and his prose is often as stultifying as reading a timetable, but the book will deepen anyone's appreciation for New York's most magnificent interior space. Eric P. Nash

title: Navy to Raise Ehime Maru From Depths
description: The Navy has begun an unprecedented three-month operation to raise the Japanese fishing vessel Ehime Maru, which sank Feb. 9 after colliding with the U.S.S. Greeneville, a Navy submarine. Because the ship is about 2,000 feet under water and too deep for divers, it will be lifted and transported using remote controlled machinery. In shallower waters, divers will try to recover the bodies of the five men and four teenagers killed in the sinking and parts of the ship that might be used in a memorial. If successful, the operation will be the first to raise a ship so large from so deep.

title: Broadway to Park South, A Trouper Keeps Trekking
description: THE tiny cabaret stage at Arci's Place on Park Avenue South is not big enough to accommodate everything that the Tony Award-winning dancer and singer Donna McKechnie can do, to say nothing of all the things she has done. Yet it is on Arci's stage that Ms. McKechnie will present a retrospective of her work in the theater -- ''An Evening With Donna McKechnie: My Musical Comedy Life'' -- beginning on Tuesday (through Aug. 11).

title: A Dangerous Muse
description: THE LOOKING GLASS

title: For the Floating Hospital, A Day Without Any Patients
description: The Floating Hospital is probably the only vessel in New York Harbor that can claim four medical examining rooms, hundreds of little life preservers and a constant supply of crayons.

title: A Criminal of the Old School
description: A COLD CASE

title: Armstrong Revises His Buddy System
description: ST. LARY SOULAN, France, July 21  Meet the kinder, gentler Lance Armstrong. Always full of surprises, Armstrong stood up in defense of his pal Marco Pantani last week. Armstrong could afford to be generous; he was hitting a stride in which he would win three of four stages in the mountains, the latest being today's leg from Foix to St. Lary Soulan.

title: July 15-21; Johns Hopkins Rebuked
description: Nearly all medical research involving human subjects has been suspended at Johns Hopkins University. The university, a federal oversight agency said, was lax in its monitoring of a study that led to the death of a healthy 24-year-old woman last month. Hopkins said that the measure was extreme: it is already taking action to correct its deficiencies, it said, and patients with cancer and other serious illnesses could be harmed by the studies' interruption. Gina Kolata

title: Come Home, Jay Gatsby
description: A 21st-century Gatsby scene: the first of this summer's six Saturday Mercedes-Benz Polo Challenge matches evoked polo's 1920's and 30's golden age on Long Island. Sleek ponies, grand cars, pedigree dogs and elegant women and men promenaded within the white picket fences at Two Trees Farm in Bridgehampton. An auction aided the Leary Firefighters Foundation. Admission, $20 a carful, goes to the South Fork Breast Health Coalition.

title: Newcomers Play Big Roles for Astros
description: Gerry Hunsicker likes this season's unbalanced schedule. ''I'm glad they went to it,'' the Houston Astros' general manager said, ''because this is the way it should be, going head to head with your division rivals, especially down the stretch.''

title: Cabbage Fever
description: Next to the turnip, the cabbage is probably the most reviled vegetable in the Western world. This unfortunate spin has more to do with the willful British punishment inflicted on its preparation for 500 years than with anything inherent in the poor misunderstood crucifera itself. With the exceptions of Jane Grigson and Elizabeth David, that nation's approach to the worthy leaf has been to boil it till it's about the feel and flavor of a deflated basketball.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Old-Fashioned Art Works

title: INSIDE
description: Power Struggle in Indonesia

title: Mama's Boy
description: THE DEATH

title: FUJIAN, U.S.A.: A special report; Within Chinatown, a Slice of Another China
description: Bi He Liu rested his head against the sun-baked window of the Happy Travel bus and tried to enjoy the rare sensations of motion and light. Six days out of seven, Mr. Liu works a 3 p.m.-to-3 a.m. shift as a cook in a suburban Philadelphia restaurant. He rarely sees the sun -- or much else beyond the kitchen stove and the two-room apartment he shares with six other men.

title: I Had a Stroke of Luck. Cheever Didn't.
description: I HAD noticed, over the course of the past few summers, that I had begun to know a lot of people with backyard pools. Before that, an invitation to swim at someone's home would have been like being invited to a castle, complete with moat. But it was becoming almost commonplace. My humble New Jersey neighborhood had turned into Beverly Hills. Or at least a sort of Cheever-esque Connecticut.

title: Parasites in Prt--Porter
description: I was delighted by Peggy Orenstein's article (July1) about Japanese women who have decided not to get married. At first, I could not put my finger on what was different about the photos of young women in your article from the young women I knew in Japan as a child. Finally, I realized what it was. They are smiling!

title: Mary Lanzerotti, Robert Wisniewski1
description: Dr. Mary Yvonne Lanzerotti and Dr. Robert William Wisniewski, computer scientists, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph M. McLafferty officiated.

title: Hot Wheels That Are Adult Toys
description: IT is not always easy being a New Yorker in Los Angeles. Sunglasses, watch, shoes, cell phone -- the details matter here, and the code is intricate. There is no more treacherous moment for the visitor than in the driveway of his hotel: All those attractive people slipping into their purring German convertibles, and then his homely little rental car intrudes on the well-groomed scene. If nothing else, what will the valet think?

title: Leon Golub, Brawler In a Cosmic Melee
description: I'M sort of political, sort of metaphysical, sort of wiseacre,'' Leon Golub is saying in his street-smart Chicago cadence. ''When I paint a skull, I don't do it with eyebrows furrowed.''

title: Capriati Gets a Paid Workout, and Advances to an Exhibition Final
description: Jennifer Capriati looked as if she had not played a tennis match in two weeks, and that was so. Svetlana Krivencheva looked as if she had been playing too much tennis, and that was also so.

title: Dana Newbold, Peter Yoon
description: Dana Marie Newbold, a daughter of RoyAnne and Verl Newbold of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday to Peter Yoon, a son of Anna and Lawrence Yoon of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Joseph Deponai performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for J. ROBERT HUNTER; The Big New Word in Insurance
description: A GROWING number of insurance companies -- mostly life insurers -- are overhauling their basic corporate structure, switching from policyholder ownership to shareholder ownership in a change known as demutualization.
