One of the largest, Prudential Financial, has given its 11 million policyholders until the end of this month to vote their preference. In the conversion, billions of dollars would go to the policyholders but their relationship with the company would change.

title: Vancouver
description: For the third year in a row, Vancouver has been voted the world's most livable city by the William M. Mercer Institute, a British consulting firm that bases its decisions on 39 quality-of-life criteria.

title: Only Fair for Chinese
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: No Reading Glasses For the Chief Executive
description: To the Editor:

title: The Making (Or Possible Breaking) Of a Megabrand
description: IN May, a new advertisement began appearing on billboards and aboard subways and buses in New York, Chicago and Philadelphia. In it, black-and-white pictures show a young woman, with dark flowing hair and upraised arms. Beside the picture, a slogan for a deodorant blares: ''Next stop, armpit heaven.''

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: A Family That's Making Its Art Generational
description: WHAT would prompt the ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, the country's largest professional ballet company, to spend his week off choreographing a work for DanceGalaxy, a small, up-and-coming dance troupe?

title: Former Heinz Plants to Hold Apartments
description: PITTSBURGH

title: With 65, Duval Surges to Front Once Again
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 21  With his best round ever at the British Open, David Duval dramatically put himself into contention in today's third round.

title: A Barbour, a Baker, a Chinese Rainmaker
description: In a new meshing of money and politics, the Republican fund-raiser and heavyweight lobbyist Haley Barbour has branched out into Washington's latest twist on the influence game. He has signed up as a senior adviser to Milestone Merchant Partners, a newly formed private equity group. It is modeled after the Carlyle Group, a successful merchant bank based in Washington that has relied on such prominent Republicans as former President George Bush and James Baker 3rd to drum up investment business around the globe. In this case, Mr. Barbour will be opening doors along with James Baker  James Baker 4th, a Washington lawyer and son of the former presidential adviser.

title: In Northport, New Front in a Familiar Battle
description: WHEN the commercial building at 188 Main Street rose in Northport's bustling downtown in 1925, the old guard was giving way and Southern and Eastern European newcomers were beginning to make their presence felt.

title: Miles of Music (and Books)
description: The choice of a soundtrack for road trips can be an important -- and idiosyncratic -- decision. Here are some selections, from James Taylor to Tolstoy:

title: A Mild-Looking Hedgehog Is a Killer at the World Open
description: The 26th running of the World Open Tournament at the Adam's Mark Hotel in Philadelphia, June 30 to July 8, ended in a seven-way tie for first place.

title: 'The Last Empire'
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IN ADAM'S RIB (1949), George Cukor's screwball courtroom comedy, Katharine Hepburn learns an important lesson: women should have equality with men, but that doesn't mean they have the right to shoot their husbands. Ms. Hepburn and Spencer Tracy play husband-and-wife lawyers who end up on opposing sides of the same attempted murder case. And although they play rough (''I am going to cut you into 12 little pieces and feed you to the jury,'' says Tracy), they blow kisses to each other under the courtroom tables. Thank the screenwriters, Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin, who had been married for seven years at the time, for the film's warmly affectionate view of couplehood - Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM.

title: Arthur Davidsen, 57, Johns Hopkins Astrophysicist, Dies
description: Dr. Arthur F. Davidsen, a Johns Hopkins astrophysicist who helped define the density and composition of intergalactic space and was a prime mover in transforming the university into an astronomical powerhouse, died Thursday in a Baltimore hospital. He was 57.

title: Red-Carpet Welcome Has Mayor on the Spot
description: Maybe a red flag should have gone up a couple of weeks ago when Mayor John O. Norquist of Milwaukee learned that the United States branch of the Communist Party was going to hold its 27th national convention in his city. But it didn't.

title: Atlantic Challenge Turns Miserable for Crews
description: One can hardly blame the veteran English sailor Mike Golding if his mood of late is a tad cranky.

title: OPINION; High in the Saddle, High on Life
description: IT might be hard to imagine with bumper-to-bumper traffic on roads like Broadway and West Broadway in the Five Towns today, but in the early 1930's these roads were a haven for horseback riding.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT
description: Unemployment in New Jersey rose to 4.5 percent in June from 4.3 percent in May, as New Jersey lost 5,100 jobs, mostly in manufacturing. Although the state unemployment rate has been at or below the national rate for 19 months, it has increased steadily since the beginning of the year. The only June employment gains were in retail trade and the services industry. Mark Boyd, the state labor commissioner, attributed some of the increase in unemployment to auto industry layoffs and a strike at Pepsi. Anne Ruderman

title: Romper Rock
description: Sometimes you change when you have a kid, even when you're in rock 'n' roll. For instance, going on the road with Dan Zanes, rock-'n'-roll dad, is not like it used to be when Dan Zanes was Dan Zanes, rock-'n'-roll single guy. When he was a rock-'n'-roll single guy, Zanes, 39, was the leader of the Del Fuegos, a band that started out playing at cool clubs and wild parties in Boston and ended up touring the world; when he went on the road in those days there were planes and big tour buses and roadies and groupies and a lot of other people who had never spent their evening hours reading and rereading ''Goodnight Moon.'' That road-tour situation was, to generalize, very classic rock-'n'-roll-guy road tour, very Steven Tyler-esque -- though it should be noted that (a) Steven Tyler is an actual dad, even if he still does those things with his mouth and the microphone that are not terribly dadlike; and that (b) Dan Zanes was always more of a roots-rock pioneer, less Aerosmith and more Buddy Holly, even as a kid. ''I just never understood the glitter, the high-heel shoes,'' Zanes says. ''It just all completely bypassed me.''

title: There's a Catch
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Make-or-Break Time For N.Y. Jets Player
description: IT'S put-up time for Eric Ogbogu of Irvington. When the New York Jets veterans report to summer camp next Saturday, what the defensive end does in the next two months will determine his future in his chosen profession.

title: Liberty Eyes Home Edge As Playoffs Approach
description: In May, many in the Women's National Basketball Association picked the Liberty as the team to beat in the East. The Liberty, as the two-time defending Eastern Conference champions, had everything that was good about last year's team back, and then some.

title: Here Are the New Courses. Now Where Are the Golfers?
description: These should be the glory days of golf.

title: Scull Sessions
description: ON THE WATER

title: Bar Clears Hugh Rodham in Clemency Case
description: The Florida bar has cleared Hugh Rodham of violating legal ethics by accepting $400,000 after successfully lobbying his brother-in-law, President Bill Clinton, for clemency for two felons, The Miami Herald reported today.

title: Daisy Alpert, Kenneth Florin
description: Daisy Isadora Alpert, the daughter of Michael B. Alpert of New York and the late Ellen M. Alpert, was married last evening to Kenneth Ross Florin, a son of Annette and Alan I. Florin of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Dena F. Klein officiated at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Antiques at Sea
description: Experts from the BBC version of the PBS series ''Antiques Roadshow'' will be aboard four cruises on the Crown Odyssey this fall, but passengers shouldn't pack all those heirlooms of questionable provenance (unless they want to toss a few overboard). Instead of doing appraisals, the experts will discuss the culture, art and contemporary collectibles in the ports of call, and how to find a bargain. Either Hilary Kay, formerly of Sotheby's, or Terrence Locket, an expert on pottery, porcelain and glass, will be on board the cruises, which range from 17 to 25 days and stop at ports in Africa, India and Asia. Fares start at $2,995 a person. Information: (800) 333-7300 or www.orientlines .com. JOSEPH SIANO

title: POSTINGS: $13.5 Million Renovation and Restoration for 133-Year-Old Building; Yale Mansion to House Globalization Center
description: You won't find Morticia Addams staring from a dormer window in that great mansard roof. But the 133-year-old Davies Mansion on a New Haven hilltop has been haunted all the same in its decades as a Yale University property; by fire, vandalism and Yale's inability -- some said unwillingness -- to find a new use for an impractically lovely landmark.

title: Note of Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: Staring Out to Sea
description: THE SELECTED POETRY OF ROBINSON JEFFERS

title: The Nation; Dick Cheney, Environmentalist
description: THEY say they've been turning off the lights, and they've modernized the fireplace. Maybe the mild weather has helped, too.

title: A Pugnacious Innovator Looks to a Lively Future
description: THE provocateurs are packing their bags. The conservatives have put away their crash helmets. Goodbye Berio, Ligeti and Messiaen. Hello Richard Strauss. This is Gerard Mortier's last summer as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, and the city looks to become a quieter place. Naming a contemporary composer, Peter Ruzicka, as Mr. Mortier's successor may mean a continued commitment to the new and unusual, or it may be an intelligent public-relations move. No one yet knows for sure. During a recent swing through New York, the soon-to-abdicate director expressed a diplomatic pessimism.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: Unlikely Story as Ordez and Trachsel Lift Mets
description: Rey Ordez hit a home run tonight. Predicting an Ordez home run is like looking out the window, seeing sunshine, and calling for rain.

title: Corrections
description: The On Politics column last Sunday, about New Jersey's history of electing governors who have not held statewide office, misstated the given name and middle initial of a former governor (1947 to 1954). He was Alfred E. Driscoll, not William T.

title: BOOX
CRIME
description: I have learned never to trust the narrators in Minette Walters's subtle psychological mysteries. These complex characters can be cunning, deceitful, even mad -- which is exactly what makes them such absorbing company. M. Ranelagh, the English schoolteacher who tells her harrowing tale in THE SHAPE OF SNAKES (Putnam, $24.95) with the help of newspaper clippings, police reports, personal letters, photos and other records, openly admits to being manipulative, and for much of the story Walters keeps us mystified about her motives.

title: Virtual and Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Kerry Donovan, Sean Byrnes
description: Kerry Lynn Donovan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franey Martin Donovan Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Sean Michael Byrnes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Byrnes of Brooklyn. The Rev. Michael Palmer performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Corrections
description: A review on June 24, about ''The Noonday Demon: An Atlas of Depression,'' by Andrew Solomon, erroneously cited an omission in the book's bibliography. William Styron's ''Darkness Visible'' is indeed in the bibliography; it is not missing.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-22-01: Expert Opinion; Home Improvement
description: Summer is a good time to take care of those much-needed home repairs. The weather is better, and more people take time off from work. Getting into the spirit, the Bushes are reportedly planning some renovations to the White House that will cost about $5.8 million, if Congress approves the project. Now, I certainly don't expect the president and first lady to strap on tool belts and do everything themselves, but this estimate seems a bit high. Four hundred and thirty thousand for the pool area alone? Because the pipes and pumps need work and the walkways are cracked? Would sending a staff member out for some concrete mix and PVC pipe be out of the question? You know, doing a few chores around the house wouldn't kill you. Let's break some of this down, for purposes of comparison, just in case members of Congress are too busy to do so:

title: Eyes Instead of Theories
description: LOOKING FOR HISTORY

title: Hardcover Fiction
description: This

title: Despite High Hopes, Drug Plan May Be Disappointing to Elderly
description: The new Democratic majority in the Senate is struggling to deliver a prescription drug benefit for the nation's elderly. But even the most generous benefits now under consideration will fall far short of what many of the elderly expect, some lawmakers and health policy experts say.

title: Luring Audiences And More Up North
description: GETTING audiences to support regional theater in their home state is tough enough. The lure of Broadway as the hub of theater persists, in defiance of reality. And then there are Off and Off Off Broadway, representing snob appeal of another sort.

title: The 2000 Vote, Cont'd.
description: To the Editor:

title: July 15-21; Arrest Over E-Book Software
description: The publishing industry is aggressively escalating efforts to protect digital media by enlisting the strength of the government. Federal agents, acting on complaints by Adobe Systems, arrested a Russian at a Las Vegas hacker convention in one of the first criminal applications of a controversial 1998 digital copyright law. Dmitri Sklyarov, a 26-year-old cryptographer, was accused of creating a program that circumvents Adobe's e-book reader. Protests against the arrest are being planned in a half-dozen cities, including Moscow.

title: Red-Carpet Welcome Has Mayor on the Spot
description: Maybe a red flag should have gone up a couple of weeks ago when Mayor John O. Norquist of Milwaukee learned that the United States branch of the Communist Party was going to hold its 27th national convention in his city. But it didn't.

title: No Reading Glasses For the Chief Executive
description: To the Editor:

title: Patsy Cline Memorabilia On View in Memphis
description: An exhibition about Patsy Cline at the Rock 'n' Soul Museum in Memphis centers on 48 letters between Cline and her original fan club president, Treva Miller, who died in a car wreck three years before Cline was killed in a plane crash in 1963.

title: A Man of the Cloth
description: Ronald Coleman had just bought what he thought was the perfect Brooks Brothers suit, a black, single-breasted Italian pinstripe, marked down to about $800. Despite its apparent stylishness and superior tailoring, Mr. Coleman, a lawyer, suspected that the suit had one major flaw.

title: Political Briefing; Red-Carpet Welcome Has Mayor on the Spot
description: Maybe a red flag should have gone up a couple of weeks ago when Mayor John O. Norquist of Milwaukee learned that the United States branch of the Communist Party was going to hold its 27th national convention in his city. But it didn't.

title: Word for Word/Neapolitan Hand Gestures; Non Beffeggiare, Please: A Field Guide To Italian Conversation
description: ITALIANS, as every tourist knows, love to talk with their hands. But who knew how much? Andrea de Jorio, a 19th-century Neapolitan cleric-turned-anthropologist, did. In 1832, he wrote a groundbreaking lexicon of Italian hand gestures that was little known outside Italy until Adam Kendon, an anthropologist and expert in gesture communication, translated it into English.

title: Scouring Mexico's Flats for Elusive Gray Ghost
description: BOCA PAILA, Mexico -- "Trip, trip, trip," Lemus Dzul said, yelling frantically at me from his perch atop the stern corner of the flatsboat. He was holding the craft motionless with a long pole he had plunged into the white, silty, sandy bottom of the bay as I cast a fly from its bow.

title: N.F.L. Training Camps: Getting Back to Business
description: The rookie and veteran reporting dates and sites for the 2001 National Football League training camps. Last years records in parentheses.

title: Metamorphosis
description: A 4-year-old girl played on the long lawn with the farm dog. The dog had one blue eye and one brown one. I don't know who fascinated me more: the dog or the child. The grown-ups gathered in the living room by the window, talking about her in hushed tones. Her mother, Valerie, was my father's first cousin, a very pretty, intelligent girl who had gone to Paris to study French. That's a common thing for middle-class Irish girls to do. But she had an affair with a Greek architect who abandoned her when she became pregnant. Ashamed, she had hidden the baby, rearing her alone abroad. Finally one of her brothers visited her and discovered the child. Her name was Lisa.

title: Curious Yellow
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith St.: A Hot Strip With a Storied Past
description: SMITH STREET, Brooklyn's restaurant row, has been called the hottest new hot spot in New York. Newspapers and magazines have been filled with articles about the street in Boerum Hill, as if the strip had sat there its whole life gathering dust until the young and hip arrived a few years ago and put the place on the map. Truth be told, the 14-block artery has a vibrant history and has long been the center of many people's universe.

title: Footlights
description: Teaching Ballet and Talking to Legs

title: Duval Gets His First Major Victory
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 22 - What was expected to be a frantic finish became the defining performance of David Duval's career.

title: July 15-21; The Lastest Archer Headline
description: Over the years, the modifiers before the name of Jeffrey Archer have piled up -- millionaire novelist, Conservative party vice chairman, London mayoral candidate, art collector, hot ticket party host, charming rogue, risk-taking Houdini, serial philanderer and disgraced politician. Now there are three more -- perjurer, convict and inmate. The 61-year-old peer was convicted on two counts of perjury and two of perversion of justice for creating false alibis and forging diaries in a 1987 trial in which he denied knowing a prostitute he had paid $3,500. Thursday, Lord Archer awoke in his Thames-side penthouse; that night he slept in a London jail cell beginning a four-year term.

title: Jenifer Blaxall, Charles Buice
description: Jenifer Sarah Moor Blaxall, a daughter of Martha O. Blaxall of Washington and John G. N. Blaxall of Vienna, Va., was married yesterday to Charles Upchurch Buice, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Buice III of New York. Marion Lyman-Mersereau, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated at Murphy Farm in Quechee, Vt.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: WALKING THE BIBLE

title: New Rules for Bankers
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Tea in Style
description: ANGLERS AND WRITERS

title: The Made-to-Order Savior
description: My heart went out to the Nashes and the Strongin-Goldbergs, whose children are suffering from Fanconi anemia, and I commend them for their strength and courage (Lisa Belkin, July 1). But I found it disturbing that not only had neither set of parents heard of the disease (including Lisa Nash, who was a neonatal I.C.U. nurse), but apparently their doctors also had failed to give them a very simple blood test that would have screened for this genetic disease, along with others like Tay-Sachs.

title: A Winery Changes Its Face
description: The joke about this village in the flat farmland of central Atlantic County is that there are few eggs, no harbor and not much of a city.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Apartment Developer With the Law in Its Toolbox
description: IF it were so inclined, AvalonBay Communities could quote a Yogi Berra bon mot as a mantra for its operations in Connecticut. ''Dj vu all over again'' would be appropriate for the regularity with which Fairfield County's wealthier towns have rejected AvalonBay's applications to build what have become signature luxury rental apartment complexes for more than a decade.

title: If Kenny Were in This Show, He Might Be the First Course
description: THE SETTING: A rainy Saturday night at the Kraine Theater on East Fourth Street. On the sidewalk, a crowd waited to see ''Cannibal!,'' a musical based on a film of the same name by Trey Parker, creator of the ''South Park'' cartoon. The show chronicles the 1874 misadventures of Alferd Packer, who the producers say was the only American convicted of cannibalism.

title: Ideas & Trends: Open Door, Open Questions; This Way Up
description: ALLOWING the more than three million Mexicans living in the United States illegally to earn permanent lawful residency is an idea packed with political, economic and even foreign policy risks for both George W. Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico.

title: The Names Scream 'Value.' But the Portfolios Don't.
description: THE value investor is a lonely hunter.

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
description: This

title: ALLIES TELL BUSH THEY'LL ACT ALONE ON CLIMATE ACCORD
description: As tens of thousands of demonstrators marched toward the center of this ancient city and occasionally clashed with the police, the United States' leading allies told President Bush today that they intended to move ahead and ratify the Kyoto Protocol on global warming by next year, even without American participation.

title: The Courage to Aim Both High and Low
description: GLITTERING high comedy with a burlesque vulgarity -- that's the best way to describe Darren Star's series ''Sex and the City,'' midway through its fourth season on HBO. There's never been anything quite like it on television: at its best, it suggests what Sheridan's ''The Rivals'' or ''The School for Scandal'' might be like set in the Manhattan of the millennium, with a contemporary preference for frankness over euphemism in the discussion of sex.

title: Efforts to Oust Its President Move Ahead In Indonesia
description: Indonesia's legislature began proceedings today that could quickly put an end to the erratic and ineffectual 21-month-old tenure of the country's quirky president, Abdurrahman Wahid.

title: Ferocious Hunters, in Need of a Friend
description: When 600 pounds of growling, salivating grizzly bear is bounding toward you as if you're her next meal, your gut instinct may be to run. But not Joel Sartore (above), a National Geographic magazine photographer who journeyed to Alaska last year to track down these formidable hunters and throw himself, literally, into their paths.

title: Hard Rock Sound From Pittsburgh
description: Joe Grushecky and the Houserockers, Pittsburgh's seminal hard rock band, have been touring the clubs along the New Jersey shore and elsewhere on the East Coast since the 1980's, when they were known as the Iron City Houserockers. Now promoting a live album, ''Down the Road Apiece'' on the Schoolhouse label, Mr. Grushecky and his backing band will play two divergent theaters when they perform at the Sands Casino Hotel in Atlantic City on Friday and at the Stone Pony in Asbury Park the next night.

title: The World: American Way; A World Seeking Security Is Told There's Just One Shield
description: GEOPOLITICS needn't be mind-bending. Think of a centuries-long floating poker game in which the lead keeps changing hands, from Greece to Rome, Spain to Britain, France to Prussia. These days, one player not only holds the chips and a stack of i.o.u.'s; he has most of his rivals' clothes, too.

title: Finding the Blues, and Bringing Them Home
description: BLUES music is flourishing on Long Island, and Toby Walker, a singer-songwriter-guitarist from Oyster Bay who performs as Little Toby Walker, is one of the main reasons.

title: Desserts Without Penalties
description: Fashion-savvy restaurants have taken to matching courses as if they were clothes, offering desserts that echo ingredients used in main dishes. To tempt the calorie-phobic, pastry chefs are leaning almost as heavily on the savory as they are on the sweet -- particularly in the Flatiron district, where throngs of thin and thinner would-be models can be seen dining. (Which is what they want.) Patria offers poached pears with a gazpacho sorbet (above) made of tomato juice, cucumber juice, red wine vinegar and sugar ($9); a stiff goat cheese custard ($9); and a strawberry Basque cake ($10) with red pepper sauce and camomile ice cream. At Beppe, after-dinner brittles made of pork, rosemary and basil are the confection of choice. And Lotus offers a napoleon of almond ice cream, green grapes, honey, lavender and white truffle sauce ($8). ''These days, people tend to be very health conscious,'' said Alex Astenza, the pastry chef at Patria, ''so I try to use sugar as a seasoning rather than as a whole flavor.'' For fall, he intends to add a new savory dessert: an apple empanada served with blue cheese and a toasted bacon salad. Bacon, now that's healthy.

title: Political Briefing; Playing Blame Game In California Crisis
description: Former Governor Pete Wilson of California has mostly avoided the limelight and held his tongue since the state's term limits law forced him back into private life in early 1999. But his name has nevertheless been in the news a lot over the last few months.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What you're seeing in these proposals is how little you can really do with $300 billion when you're trying to reach an elderly and disabled population with high expenditures.''

title: At a 'Crazy Little Theater,' Mixing Bessie Smith and Penguins
description: EVEN if you are not passionate about penguins, it's a safe bet that, at least, you like them and you'd be sad to know they are disappearing.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 22, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Audit Blames Budget Cuts Under Clinton For Lab Errors
description: Cuts in the Energy Department's budget and staff in the Clinton administration contributed to accidents and management errors at several national laboratories, according to an audit by the agency's inspector general, Gregory H. Friedman.

title: It's a Fast, Cheap High With a Big Price Tag
description: Beach parties. Concerts. Sporting events.

title: Mosley Dispatches Stone and Remains Undefeated
description: After two unspectacular rounds in tonight's World Boxing Council welterweight title fight at Caesars Palace, a solitary voice from the crowd issued an impassioned plea for the champion Shane Mosley: ''Come on, Sugar. Hit the guy.''

title: Satisfying an Infatuation With Cranesbills
description: AT heart I am a plant collector. Time and finances do not permit me to attend rare-plant auctions or scale the Himalayas in search of choice specimens, but the Internet gives me access to all kinds of plant societies and nurseries from Manitoba to Miami. As a result, I have a nice menagerie of roses, and an expanding collection of lungwort (Pulmonaria). Some day I may add an assortment of Chinese tree peonies.

title: Reckonings; 2016 And All That
description: I knew that the commission on Social Security reform appointed by George W. Bush would produce a slanted report, one designed to bully Congress into privatizing the system. But the draft report released last week is sheer, mean-spirited nonsense.

title: You Had to Be There, Man
description: Ellis ''misled students at Mount Holyoke College, as well as reporters from The Boston Globe, when he claimed to have spent the 1960's as a combat veteran in Vietnam, a civil rights worker in Mississippi and an antiwar protester at Yale.'' Oshinsky asks: ''Why did he do it? What did he have to gain? And whom, exactly, did he hurt?'' Ellis stole from those who actually did what he says he did, and he hurt those who study history.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In Newark Urban Desert, New Homes Begin to Rise
description: THE rundown blocks in the area off Route 78 near Newark Airport, splotched with boarded-up buildings and lacking such urban amenities as shopping and playgrounds, seem an unlikely nest for dreams of home ownership and community.

title: Doldrums For All Seasons On Wall St.
description: WALL STREET usually slows down in the summer. That is a problem this year, because the pace of business during the winter and spring quarters was also not brisk.

title: Children's Books
description: This

title: Rogge Can Make His Term As President of I.O.C. Count
description: I don't know Jacques Rogge, the new president of the International Olympic Committee, but I like what I see. Judging from his early statements, he has been an astute observer of the brilliance and the shortcomings of his predecessor, Juan Antonio Samaranch. As he assumes the presidency, Rogge has called for unity, while being open to new ideas from all constituencies of the I.O.C. Based on my experience as an athlete, former I.O.C. employee, television commentator and Olympic sports organization executive, I would like to recommend five key initiatives for Rogge:

title: Airline Complaints
description: To the Editor: I read ''Customer Service by E-Mail'' (June 10) by Bob Tedeschi with much interest and, I must say, little dispassion.

title: An Essential Element In the Voice Of Jazz
description: FOR many musicians, the death of J. J. Johnson, who took his own life in February after a long struggle with prostate cancer, was the devastating loss of one of the giants of postwar American music. Johnson's departure was even more of a blow because it came so soon after the Ken Burns documentary ''Jazz,'' which did not even mention Johnson and largely neglected his chosen instrument, the trombone.

title: Letters on Travel
description: Meat to Newcastle

title: Blasts From The Past
description: Twenty-five miles south of Charleston, W. Va., the Appalachians look as they must have a thousand years ago, rapturously folded against each other and densely covered with trees. Down a gently sloping mountainside, a conveyor belt angles toward four coal-storage bins that resemble farm silos. I exit onto a roughly-paved road and arrive at a small white guardhouse near a wooden sign: ''Hobet 21.''

title: He Found The Wave And Rode It
description: THE French filmmaker Jean-Pierre Melville used to tool around Paris at the wheel of a huge Cadillac convertible the size of most Parisian apartments. He liked to sport a wide-brimmed, white Stetson hat, just one degree short of genuine cowboy scale, and a gigantic pair of aviator sunglasses that functioned as a permanent mask. From a distance, he looked more like the Lone Ranger than the balding, tubby intellectual he was -- which was just what he had in mind.

title: Young Lee, Robert Kim
description: Young Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yang Lee of Seoul, South Korea, is to be married this evening to Robert Minsoo Kim, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jong Yule Kim of White Plains. The Rev. Jai-Keun Choi, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted on July 8 for a grouping of pictures of the Sunny Atlantic Beach Club. The photographer was Chris Maynard.

title: Contemporary American With Flair
description: IS George Martin in Southampton a steakhouse, a bistro, a hybrid of the two or something else? It's hard to pigeonhole. The dcor is classic steakhouse: a bold, masculine room with dark mahogany accents, large, framed mirrors, wooden blinds and leather banquettes. The big-beef possibilities on the menu, along with a lineup of 10 side dishes, further the steakhouse image.

title: Railroad Remnant: Some See It as Art, Others as Debris
description: Sagging gently into the Hudson River, at the 64th Street pier, is an undulating steel-beam frame that looks, depending on your perspective, like a sunken roller coaster, a zeppelin that crash-landed, or a skeletal model by the architect Frank Gehry.

title: Human Rights For TV Rights
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Next Generation
description: OUTSIDE the men's room at the New Britain City Hall, politicians are easy to spot because of their blue shirts. They are part-time partisans who happened to come from their day jobs all wearing the same color, and they stand waiting to write city policy, making small talk. The group included Councilman Jason Jakubowski, ideologically and fashionably indistinguishable from his colleagues, but easily identified as a different breed of city official.

title: Dschubba Brightening
description: Last July the familiar head of Scorpius sported a new look as its middle star, Dschubba, suddenly and unexpectedly brightened to magnitude 1.9 from its usual magnitude 2.3.

title: New Cell Phone Trick: It's a Boarding Pass
description: Frequent fliers may soon be able to obtain boarding passes over their cell phones, eliminating the time spent standing in line for an identity check.

title: Looking Ahead
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A 70's Castoff Returns to the Bandstand
description: NOT long ago, straight-ahead jazz musicians tended to dismiss the Fender Rhodes electric piano as a cheesy relic of the 1970's. Some still do. But in the last couple of years, the Rhodes has cropped up on well over a dozen recordings by younger jazz artists. By injecting the vintage sound of the Rhodes into modern acoustic settings, jazz's next generation is pioneering a new sound by means of an old, rusty electric tool.

title: SCHOOL SEGREGATION
description: New Jersey schools are among the country's most segregated, according to a study released last week by Harvard's Civil Rights Project at Harvard Law School. The study ranked New Jersey, which is divided into 617 districts, as having the fourth most segregated schools in the country, after Michigan, Illinois and New York. The study, which found that 70 percent of the nation's black students attend school in districts dominated by minority populations, recommends urban magnet schools and community and foundation efforts to help integrate schools.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Pulse column last week about toe bracelets inspired by Eastern culture misidentified the ones pictured. They were those available from nianewyork.com, not from Barneys New York.

title: Party Time in Rockapulco, Hamptons West
description: The dandies have their Hamptons, but the multitude has the Rockaways, a sandy swath in southern Queens that lays up on the Atlantic.

title: Police Pursuit Under Review After a Fatal S.U.V. Crash
description: Officials said yesterday that a stolen sport utility vehicle was being pursued by the police at high speed when it careered out of control and into a crowd of people in Newark's Central Ward Thursday night, killing a 17-year-old girl and injuring six other teenagers.

title: Dominicans on a Wing, a Prayer and One Suitcase
description: Hilda Coste packed light for her Thursday flight to Santo Domingo on Trans World Airlines, but not by choice. Last month, the airline, one of the major carriers from New York to the Dominican Republic, began restricting passengers traveling to the island to one 70-pound suitcase and one carry-on bag, down from the previous two 70-pound suitcases and one carry-on. That meant that Ms. Coste, who learned about the change shortly before her trip, had to leave some personal items and gifts for relatives at her home in Marble Hill, the Bronx.

title: Growth Stock: Corporate Apartments
description: WHEN the economy soars and corporations bring phalanxes of executives, consultants, associates and trainees to New York, the corporate apartment market thrives.

title: The Secret History of Birth Control
description: DEVICES AND DESIRES

title: Alexandra Cammerman, Alan Hellawell III
description: Alexandra Tal Cammerman, a daughter of Andrea Dasha Reich and Dr. Charles Reich of Tannersville, N.Y., is to be married this evening at the Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco, to G. Alan Hellawell III, the son of Ellen and Alan Hellawell of Gaithersburg, Md. The ceremony is to be performed by John F. Donelan Jr., the bridegroom's uncle, who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner for the day by San Francisco County.

title: Science Center With Depth and Height (417 Feet)
description: Queen Elizabeth officially opened a new science center in Glasgow earlier this month at Pacific Quay, an area of reclaimed docklands in the heart of the city. The Glasgow Science Center is housed in three buildings, the Glasgow Tower, the Science Mall and the IMAX Theater.

title: Calling the Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Grant Amnesty
description: To the Editor:

title: For British Officers Abroad: All the Trappings of Home
description: BRITAIN'S officers and gentlemen, over a 200-year period of empire building, managed to take all the trappings of home along with them to far-flung places. Investing in elegant and fashionable pieces that were also durable and decorative, the officers and their families not only preserved a way of life but also kept from getting homesick. All such possesions were carried by servants, like the ones, right, in ''British Officer in Palanquin With Indian Bearers'' (1830). ''Britain's Portable Empire'' is installed in both of the Katonah Museum of Art's main galleries, one covering the Georgian and Regency periods (1740 to 1830) and the other, the Victorian and Edwardian eras (1837 to 1901).

title: The Poor Man's Capitalist
description: Miller's article artfully combined the satire of Bulgakov, the irony of Gogol and economics high jinks not seen since Brecht's ''Three Penny Novel.'' A less subtle approach might have included the smoky back room where a cabal of world bankers wring their hands over $9 trillion of assets locked up by the world's poor, too ignorant or stubborn to properly demarcate their property lines. But wait! We'll recruit some Panglossian pied piper: he will dress the indigenous dogs in suits; he will lead them them down to the courthouses, to the notaries, to the halls of records. They will howl their testimony. Once the dogs use the paper, as it were, once the property is officially owned . . . and we know the rest.

title: Coolly Carrying the Torch for the Classical Guitar
description: THERE'S something about the guitar that draws composers to local color. For Christopher Rouse, this means a ''Concert de Gaud'' for guitar and orchestra that opens and closes with big flamenco flourishes, with swatches of bright, romantic orchestral color alternating with glissando effects evoking the organic, unexpected curves of the buildings of Antonio Gaud, the great Catalan architect. And for Tan Dun, it means echoes of the pipa, the Chinese lute, in his guitar concerto, Yi2 , which brandishes a panoply of whispering percussion, against which the guitar notes play like the plash of a waterfall in a Chinese garden.

title: Friendly Strangers; Bratislava
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Rediscovering Old Bratislava'' (Nov. 19) by Jill Knight Weinberger was so appealing that I stashed it away, hoping to have the opportunity to visit. I had that pleasure in June.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Tinton Falls, N.J.; An Old Area That Has Bloomed Lately
description: A 13-MILE-LONG, two-mile-wide municipality that straddles the Garden State Parkway, Tinton Falls is struggling to establish its identity.

title: DISTRICTING TIEBREAKER
description: Alan Rosenthal, Rutgers University professor of public policy at the Eagleton Institute of Politics, was named last week as the tie-breaking 13th member of the commission formed to redraw New Jersey's congressional districts, just as he was 10 years ago. The districts, which are revised to balance population after each census, have to be redrawn by mid-January. The commission that does the often politically contentious work, is made up of six Democrats and six Republicans appointed by the state party leadership, and a 13th, nonpartisan, member.

title: Wanted: Director for Cultural Trust
description: The position hasn't been advertised yet -- the job description hasn't even been finalized -- but ever since the New Jersey Legislature created the trust to benefit arts, history and humanities groups last July, potential candidates have voiced their interest, said Carol Cronheim, the secretary of the trust's board of trustees.

title: To Teach Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Rules of the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Shareholders Are Restless, and Starting to Pounce
description: THE proxy season is mostly over. Smoke from boardroom battles is clearing. What do the results mean for investors and top executives?

title: A Jewish Delicatessen True to Its Roots
description: THERE are kosher hot dogs and knishes in the front window, the biggest portions this side of Romania on the plates and wonderfully nostalgic photos of the Lower East Side on the walls at the new Pickles Restaurant-Delicatessen in Port Washington.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Buick Rendezvous; A Glorified Van or a Grand Slam?
description: TREND surfing is not what comes to mind when a Buick motors by. The most staid of General Motors' divisions, Buick sells cars, not trucks. It built its reputation on a soft ride, spacious comfort and smooth power -- its buyers traditionally wanted Roadmasters, not Loadmasters -- and it remains one of the very few car purveyors that do not sell any minivans, pickups or sport utility vehicles.

title: CROP REPORTS
description: Many New Jersey crops are doing exceptionally well this year despite a slow start to the season, according to agriculture agents with the Rutgers University Cooperative Extension Service. Peaches in particular are doing well because of rainfall at the right times, said Win Cowgill, an Extension Service fruit expert. Apples, which are not ripe as yet, also are doing well, he said. For the state's vegetable crops, such as peppers, corn, tomatoes and lima beans, the year started slow with dry, cold weather but has improved since then. The only sour note in the mix is blueberries, which are off normal production levels by 30 percent in some regions , although the reason for the underyield is not known, said Nicholi Vorsa, director of the Philip E. Marucci Center for Blueberry and Cranberry Research with Rutgers. Karen DeMasters

title: Bring Your Biceps, Liniment and a High Pain Threshold
description: At the Rockaway Beach boardwalk last weekend, people were rubbing more than sunscreen on their arms and shoulders.

title: What Do Poor Nations Need Most?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chardonnay Map
description: Long Island wine merchants and restaurateurs recognize the name Paterno Imports, which has a Lake Success office. An importing and national marketing company, Paterno is part of the Terlato Wine Group in Lake Bluff, Ill. Terlato holdings include the Rutherford Hill Winery in the Napa Valley, which is the home of a 1999 chardonnay called Michel Laroche at Rutherford Hill.

title: Go-Anywhere Luxury Yachts Bull Out to Sea
description: IF you stand on the bridge of Dream, a 184-foot yacht capable of circumnavigating the globe on a single tank of fuel, the deck 20-odd-feet below looks like that of some gutsy supply boat, all chunky with steel and gritty gray nonskid paint. You might feel like a tanker captain on the bridge, with its Global Positioning System equipment and its four engine-room video monitors. Dream has smokestacks like a real ship and two cranes, similar to those on a small freighter. The original owner used the cranes to offload two tenders, a 36-foot fishing boat and a submarine.

title: You Had to Be There, Man
description: When I returned from Vietnam, after spending 26 months in an army hospital, I recall very few people asking me to regale them with war stories. In fact, it was quite the opposite. I am proud that I served my country, angry that I was wounded, disappointed that the news media distorted the war. Although I have medals, I don't feel like a hero. Like everyone else I encountered in combat, I was scared. It kept me alert, and perhaps it kept me alive. To those who would choose to lie about their service (or lack thereof) to country, I can only feel pity. Perhaps it will spawn a cottage industry in which veterans can rent their medals and sell their actual Vietnam stories. In retrospect, I'd rather win a Pulitzer than be shot, but then that's just me.

title: Angela Garcia, Daniel O'Shea Jr.
description: Angela Maria Garcia, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Wilson J. Garcia of Fort Worth, was married there last evening to Daniel Patrick O'Shea Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Shea of Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Dennis Smith performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Patrick.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Bedford, N.Y., misstated the location of the Fox Lane Middle School and the Fox Lane High School. Both are in Bedford; the Bedford Central School District, which is on the same campus as the two schools, has a post box address in Mount Kisco.

title: Rivera Toppled as Yankees Lose Fourth Straight
description: The sight of Mariano Rivera trotting in from the bullpen is a welcome one to the fans at Yankee Stadium because it usually means the Yankees are leading in the ninth inning and close to winning another game. Rivera's mere presence causes some fans to stand and scream, a miniature celebration before the eventual victory celebration.

title: July 15-21; 'Faith-Based' Bill Gains
description: The House passed a limited version of the president's plan to expand funding to religious organizations for their charitable work, the core of his promise to practice compassionate conservatism. Democratic lawmakers, who took pains to praise the help the groups give to the needy, said they voted against the measure because it allows the groups to discriminate in hiring. The bill, which faces an uncertain future in the Senate, offers little new money for the poor, only the chance for religious groups to compete with secular organizations for federal funds. Elizabeth Becker

title: Proposal on Council For Wood Recycling
description: Asserting that timber in trees cleared for roads and development is being wasted, a Suffolk County legislator has proposed creation of a county forestry council to promote wood recycling.

title: Another Version of the Girl Scout Promise
description: AS the meeting began, members of Girl Scout Troop 2798 held the three fingers of their right hands together and upright. Then, in a patchy rhythm, they recited the Girl Scout Promise:

title: Isa Catto and Daniel Shaw
description: WHEN Isa Pettus Catto, an abstract painter, married on July 14 in Woody Creek, Colo., the sky looked like one of her intense oil landscapes: patches of turquoise and powder blue mixed with nearly black thunderclouds, some with long, jellyfishlike tentacles hanging down.

title: Wedded to Winston Cup, For Better and for Worse
description: A pretty, blue-eyed cheerleader, Arlene Everett had what amounted to a secret life in 1960's Alachua, Fla., outside Gainesville. She hated all sports, even football, and loved to read Dickens and ancient history, particularly the Greeks and the Romans. She was interested in computers. She wanted to go to a good state college and become an archeologist.

title: State Moves to Inspect Funeral Homes
description: FRED CARMON, who was stabbed to death in 1998, would be turning in his grave if he had one.

title: Victoria Ludwin, Jason Pastorius
description: Victoria Lee Ludwin and Jason Richard Pastorius were married yesterday in Dorset, Vt., by the Rev. Frederick Buechner, a Presbyterian minister, at the United Church of Dorset and East Rupert.

title: Sex and The Purple Prose
description: THE critics haven't been entirely kind to ''Jacqueline Susann's Shadow of the Dolls'' (Crown), the new sequel to ''Valley of the Dolls,'' Ms. Susann's seminal 1966 pulp classic of fame, glamour, pills and promiscuity.

title: A Small-Town Visit For a Very Big Star
description: IN the 19th century, Franz Liszt turned his piano into an orchestra by playing his own transcriptions or arrangements of other composers' orchestral works. He delivered them well: he tossed his legendary mane of hair around, broke pianos, rolled his eyes in ecstasy and made women swoon.

title: Boom in Natural Gas Drilling Can't Match Soaring Demand
description: Over the last six months, Mark Papa's company has drilled more natural gas wells than anyone else in the United States -- about one a day -- and many have been here in the dry plains of South Texas, a dominant source of the country's fastest-growing fuel.

title: Cast of Star Wars Makes Comeback in Bush Plan
description: Twenty years after President Ronald Reagan created an international furor by proposing to place weapons in space, the Pentagon has put nearly every major element of the original program back in the center of its plans as part of a national missile shield.

title: One Investor. Two Brokers. An Account Runs Dry.
description: IT took John Teeples six and a half years as a software salesman at Microsoft to amass the stock options and other assets he felt he needed to take a break from work and spend more time with his wife, Sharon, and their two young sons.

title: More Women Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Brandes, Paul Steiger
description: Wendy Brandes, a vice president and the managing editor for Web sites at Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, and Paul E. Steiger, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, are to be married today. Rabbi Charles Davidson will officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Great Potential
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tabloid Public Is Not the Majority
description: The country has been inundated with news about Chandra Levy, the missing Washington intern. The coverage has seemed almost nonstop on cable television news, and the story has been Topic A on the chat shows. Even Dan Rather, who had resisted covering what he considered a tabloid story, had to give in and let his news show include a summary of the search for Ms. Levy and the initial reluctance of Representative Gary Condit to help Washington police by talking with them about his last meetings with her.

title: July 15-21; Rescuers Stymied
description: The Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown, Mass., has rescued more than 50 whales in a quarter century. So why haven't its experts been able to help a right whale named Churchill that is swimming toward Canadian waters entangled in a nylon rope? Partly, said Joanne Jarzobski, a spokeswoman for the center, because the rescuers have so far been unable to sedate it. The next rescue attempt may come midweek, but the dangerous infection the rope caused may worsen. Hubert B. Herring

title: Suffolk Finds Causes of High Bacteria at Shelter Island Plant
description: HUMAN error at a Shelter Island sewage treatment plant and heavy crowds during the July 4 holiday week are to blame for extremely high levels of bacteria found in effluent from the facility, according to Suffolk County health officials and a private engineering firm.

title: In Tough Spot, Hardy Geraniums to the Rescue
description: AT heart I am a plant collector. Time and finances do not permit me to attend rare-plant auctions or scale the Himalayas in search of choice specimens, but the Internet gives me access to all kinds of plant societies and nurseries from Manitoba to Miami. As a result, I have a nice menagerie of roses, and an expanding collection of lungwort (Pulmonaria). Some day I may add an assortment of Chinese tree peonies.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-22-01: The Ethicist; Nursing School
description: I believe in the benefits of breast-feeding and intend to nurse my second child as I did my first. However, this does keep a mother on a short leash and relegates even the most committed father to a secondary role of diaper-changing and occasional entertainment. Thus, I wonder, If a mother possesses the resources to breast-feed, is she ethically obligated to do so, and for how long? L.W., Staunton, VA.

title: Tweedside Captures Oaks, as the Favored Starrer Unseats Her Jockey
description: Sensitive to history, the New York Racing Association returned the Coaching Club American Oaks to the leg-wobbling distance of a mile and a half in 1998. The $350,000 Grade I race for 3-year-old fillies is the final leg of New York's triple crown for fillies, so it might as well mirror the Belmont Stakes, right?

title: Who Owns a Movie After it is Released, the Viewers or the Director?
description: The majority of readers this week contended that "ownership" of a movies should stay with the director. Implications for the sanctity of intellectual copyright were dire enough to keep the directors prerogative paramount.

title: Beyond Analyzing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kind of Preservation Buildings Don't Need
description: To the Editor:

title: When Noir Means More Than Style
description: ONE of the pleasant surprises in this mostly dreary movie season has been a stylish, inventive British crime thriller. I'm referring to Jonathan Glazer's ''Sexy Beast,'' but I could have written the same sentence a year ago with Mike Hodges's ''Croupier'' in mind. The year before that, fudging the issue of nationality a bit -- the director, Stephen Soderbergh, is American, but the star and the sensibility are unmistakably English -- I might have said something similar about ''The Limey.''

title: Political Briefing; Laura Bush Is Given High Marks In Poll
description: The Harris Poll turned its attention the other day from how President Bush is doing to how Laura Bush is doing. And?

title: Duval Gets His First Major Victory
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 22  What was expected to be a frantic finish became the defining performance of David Duval's career.

title: MINORITY TRAFFIC STOPS
description: The New Jersey State Police continue to arrest minority drivers in higher proportion than white drivers in traffic stops on the New Jersey Turnpike, according to figures released last week in the latest report by an independent monitor appointed by the United States Department of Justice under a 1999 consent decree. In this last reporting period, Nov. 1 through April 30, when troopers stopped a total of 44,177 drivers on the turnpike, 77 percent of the 307 arrests they made were of minority drivers, the highest percentage since 1997-98, before state officials acknowledged that officers engaged in racial profiling.

title: Never Too Tough to Be Softened Up by a Flower
description: JOEL HERSHMAN, who is soft-spoken and candid and at age 40 retains a boyish charm, is the first to acknowledge that had his latest film, ''Greenfingers,'' not been based on actual events, the story might have been too sentimental for him. ''What gives it its meaning and poignancy is that it's true,'' he said recently over tea in New York, where he lives. ''Otherwise, audience reaction would have been, 'Sure, only in Hollywood.' ''

title: SOAPBOX; Harpo Marx, One of Us
description: WE loved Harpo because instinctively we knew he was one of us. But we couldn't have understood that his own life as a child might have been the reason for our recognition. In fact the creative depth of his clowning had to have come from something more profoundly ingrained in his nature than his adult experience in the theater as one of the Marx Brothers about to hit it big in Hollywood.

title: Negotiators Near Accord On Details of Climate Pact
description: Negotiators from 178 countries moved a step closer late Saturday night to agreement on the final details of the Kyoto Protocol, a climate treaty rejected by President Bush.

title: Firefighters Closer to Subduing Train Fire in Baltimore Tunnel
description: After a marathon subterranean battle with a freight train fire that started three days ago, firefighters claimed the upper hand today as they hauled a score of cars from the Howard Street tunnel and moved in on the heart of the fire in three burning cars.

title: July 15-21; Genoa Talks Open With Death
description: In Genoa, Italy, the annual summit meeting of the world's industrialized nations was overshadowed by dismay after a policeman shot and killed a 23-year-old Italian during a demonstration that turned into a riot. It was the first such death since the antiglobalization movement surfaced at a World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in 1999, and it fed a growing sense that such international gatherings, which have attracted vast and often violent protests, cannot go on unchanged.

title: What Do Poor Nations Need Most?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Male Body
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tinkerer's Last Stand, Sold for Pennies on the Streets of Williamsburg
description: In front of a warehouse at South Fourth Street and Wythe Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday, there were thousands of treasures for sale to the highest bidder. The problem was figuring out what, exactly, the treasures were.

title: Court Messages
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Iris Lior, Gary Posternack
description: Iris Hava Lior and Gary Joel Posternack were married on Thursday by Rabbi David J. Gelfand at the Ram's Head Inn on Shelter Island in New York.

title: Measuring Buildings Without a Yardstick
description: EVERY architecture competition has the potential to force a crisis in evaluation. Periodically, the standards by which buildings are judged should themselves be placed on trial. One recent New York competition holds far greater potential than most to compel an appraisal of critical standards. Indeed, it has given us a chance to see that a crisis in evaluation is not a bad thing. Provoking such calamities, and uncovering their causes, is one of the most useful cultural tasks a modern city can perform.

title: Dispute Over Faxed Ads Draws Wide Scrutiny After $12 Million Award
description: Sam G. Nicholson was offended by Hooters restaurant. Mr. Nicholson was not provoked by the skimpy outfits of Hooters' waitresses. It was the restaurant's faxes that got to him.

title: Gazetteer
description: Three-bedroom, 1-bath ranch with no garage at 80 Clinton Place, $159,000.

title: Where Lawn Bowling Once Reigned, Weeds Take Over
description: Tucked away in a corner of the winding Watsessing Park in Bloomfield, near a new children's playground is a large square of ground enclosed by a wire fence. The ground, covered with dandelions and other weeds, is obviously unused. Nearby, a discreet sign above a locked door of a small, white vacant building, proclaims this to be the Essex County Lawn Bowling Club. Until it was closed three years ago, the club was well known worldwide in lawn bowling circles. Skip Arculli, a member of the club and a former international lawn bowling champion, recently talked about the club and the sport.

title: Please Say Who This Book Is About, Please
description: HONEYMOONERS

title: College Saving, by the Numbers
description: IN four years I will know. In four years I will know if all the financial moves I have made over the last 20 years have amounted to anything. In four years we'll see just how smart I have really been.

title: Fortunoff Widow Puts Own Imprint on Company
description: SITTING behind a large oak desk in the expansive, sun-drenched office that once belonged to her husband, Helene Fortunoff looks every bit the woman in charge. The suite in Fortunoff's Uniondale headquarters building is dominated by a wall unit lined with photos of her husband, their six grown children (five of whom work with her) and several grandchildren.

title: Jodi Ginsberg, Robert Zwiebach
description: Jodi Beth Ginsberg, a daughter of Susan Ginsberg and Dr. Stanley A. Ginsberg of Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Robert Cooke Zwiebach, a son of Judy Zwiebach of Westport, Conn., and the late Dr. Melvyn Zwiebach. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: With Eye on Unequal World Wealth, Young Europeans Converge on Genoa
description: Atle Mikkola Kjosen, 25, and his companion, Siv Helen Hesjedal, 22, could well have been headed for the beach on this cloudless and sun-drenched day along the Mediterranean.

title: Pseudo Fairy Tales
description: To the Editor:
