description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); }

title: Gone Fusion
description: NEVER mind that you may or may not find Origin Thai Inc. on anydirectory.com, that the name doesn't sound like a restaurant and that for two days, a computerized voice apologized for not being available and hung up every time I called.

title: Quantum Fizz
description: THE CENTER OF THINGS

title: The Nation: Wrong Number; The Unbearable Lightness of Public Opinion Polls
description: AFTER a week during which one politician or interest group after another brandished a poll to prove conclusively that the public backs federal funding of human embryonic stem cell research, it may come as a surprise to learn that American public opinion on the subject doesn't exist -- at least not yet. The subject is just too new and too complicated.

title: Editors' Note
description: An essay in the Soapbox column on July 8 recounted the experiences of a homeowner in Rye who takes to his garage as a refuge from everyday discipline. The article, ''The Great Escape,'' appeared first in The Rye Record, on May 18.

title: Counting Cowbells
description: EARLY one misty spring morning when I was around 16, my father and I sat on the side of a country lane, listening to cowbells. The swirling fog occasionally parted to reveal a few of the dozens of hot-chocolate-colored brown Swiss cows in the pasture of a small farm in the piney foothills of New Hampshire. Each animal wore a bell around her neck, and as the cows grazed and strolled and ruminated, the bells rang out through the mist -- one note, then another, then a few in a burst of tinkling, rhythmless melody. My father had discovered the bells one day while he was crisscrossing the state as a salesman, and one Saturday he brought me back to hear them.

title: In Tough Spot, Hardy Geraniums to the Rescue
description: AT heart I am a plant collector. Time and finances do not permit me to attend rare- plant auctions or scale the Himalayas in search of choice specimens, but the Internet gives me access to all kinds of plant societies and nurseries from Manitoba to Miami. As a result, I have a nice menagerie of roses, and an expanding collection of lungwort (Pulmonaria). Some day I may add an assortment of Chinese tree peonies.

title: Corrections
description: A program listing on Page 18 of the Television section today and a highlight caption on Page 19, both for 8 p.m. tomorrow on Comedy Central, have become outdated. The film ''Very Bad Things'' is being replaced by ''Half Baked,'' a 1998 comedy starring Dave Chappelle and Jim Breuer.

title: QUICK BITE/Chester; Tea for Two, and Soon for More
description: With English fare served on bone china, afternoon tea served all day and antiques as dcor, Sally Lunn's Tearoom and Restaurant in Chester is one of a kind. Or at least it was. In 1996, the mother-and-daughter team that owns it opened a second on in Princeton. And now the pair plan to franchise Sally Lunn's. ''People were requesting that we go all over the place,'' said Jean Gaffney, the mother, who still travels regularly to England to purchase their antiques. Theresa Gaffney, her daughter, commands the kitchen. She refuses to hire anyone from culinary school, preferring to train dishwashers to become cooks and regularly turns down the likes of Gourmet and Bon Appetit magazines begging for scone recipes. Standards include tea ($2.95), scones with clotted cream and preserves ($3.95), chicken pot pie ($8.95) and a ploughman's lunch ($9.95). The restaurant is named for an Englishwoman who tried to bake a brioche and came up with a new type of bread, a round loaf with a hint of sweetness (Sally Lunn bread, $3.95 a loaf). ''It has taken a lifetime to get the experience and a lifetime to get the collection,'' said Jean Gaffney. So why franchise? As Theresa Gaffney said, ''People want what we've got.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Willa Ford; Twinkle, Little Star
description: SHE'S known more for the star she used to date (Nick Carter of the Backstreet Boys) than for her own accomplishments, but she's out to prove doubters wrong. ''Anti-fan'' sites denounce her as ''skanky'' -- with the logic of teen fandom, any pretty young woman dating your favorite boy pop star is eeeeevil. But she is in fact pretty, talented and kind to animals and parents, not to mention driven.

title: In Suburbs, a Move to Put Bears in Their Place
description: WHEN Celine Zacynski saw a young black bear clawing apart a bird feeder in her back yard last spring in Suffield, she was thrilled.

title: Sara Kropf, Adam Schwartz
description: Sara Elizabeth Kropf and Adam Jeffrey Schwartz are to be married today at the St. Regis Hotel in Washington by Judge Robert A. Katzmann of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York.

title: Guides Finger 'Sopranos' Sites
description: THE bus tour goes up U.S. 1 and 9, one of the ugliest roads in America, passes an old chromium dump and takes in the industrial section of Kearny, N.J. High spots include an auto body shop, a pork store and a sleazy dance joint in Lodi.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.)

title: Fact and Fiction From Airworld
description: TWO new books offer dueling versions of business travel, aimed at roughly the same audience. The first offers sensible shoes for the serious executive whose work takes him or her to another city. The second portrays an air traveler's nether world -- a place with all the heart and soul of a Vegas casino, precisely what the respectable executive hopes to avoid.

title: Hardcover Fiction
description: This

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Changed Forever By a Holiday Massacre

title: UPPER EAST SIDE
description: On Wednesday, Community Board 8 rejected Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's application to rezone part of its campus so it could build a 440-foot research tower on 68th Street between York and First Avenues. More than 400 people showed up for the five-hour debate. Sloan-Kettering emphasized the importance of keeping its research and clinical centers together, but some board members were concerned about setting a precedent for high-density development in the middle of an Upper East Side residential street. ERIKA KINETZ

title: House Votes Dredging For Fire Island Inlet
description: The House of Representatives has approved more than $8.7 million in spending for an Army Corps of Engineers project to dredge Fire Island Inlet and stabilize public beaches on Jones Island, Representative Steve Israel announced last week.

title: L.I.A. at 75: Fighting Off A Challenge From Inside
description: IN the early 90's the Long Island Association was looking for a way to spur economic growth in the aftermath of the aerospace industry's demise. It seized upon the idea of convening a series of meetings it called Project Long Island, beginning in 1995 and concluding in 1999.

title: Paperback Fiction
description: This

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Vengeance Destroys Faces, and Souls, in Cambodia
description: It is a form of revenge that is intended to be worse than murder. Every time the victim looks into the mirror she will know: I am ugly now.

title: Versatile White From Italy
description: San Biagio's '98 Verdicchio di Matelica Vigneto Braccano, made near the Adriatic, displays the hallmarks of the verdicchio renaissance, which began in the 90's. Its bouquet is redolent of honey; its texture, soft; its flavor, applelike. This complex Italian white is versatile at the table.

title: Drag Racing 21st-Century Style
description: Every weekend night, Newman Shiue, 21, an electrical engineering student at U.C.L.A., leaves the apartment he shares with two roommates, a stuffed Winnie-the-Pooh and his Bruce Lee posters, and heads to North Hollywood in his sleek white Acura Integra GSR.

title: The Allergy Prison
description: A reader wrote to say that she needs a recipe for cake and icing that does not contain eggs, butter or milk. She can find recipes in some vegan cookbooks, since vegans eat no animal products of any kind. Also, if she has access to the Web, a search for ''vegan cake recipe'' will provide quite a few choices.

title: The Nation; The Bush Energy Dance
description: DESPITE a bout of laryngitis that had him whispering hoarsely at times, Vice President Dick Cheney finally seemed to find his voice -- politically speaking -- in promoting the Bush administration's energy goals.

title: July 15-21; Kyoto Protocol's Last Gasp
description: In Bonn, Germany, negotiators from 178 countries huddled in a last-ditch effort to complete the Kyoto Protocol, a treaty that would require cuts in gases linked to global warming. The United States, the largest source of warming gases, sent 34 officials. But in the wake of President Bush's rejection of the treaty or any binding reductions, they had strict orders not to offer new ideas. Few participants thought there would be a significant breakthrough in the talks, set to end today. Andrew C. Revkin

title: Last of a Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock in the Park in Hoboken
description: Three different styles of New Jersey rock will be on display when the Summer Enchanted Evening series continues with Southside Johnny, Pat Dinizio of the Smithereens and Bob Delevante, who was part of the Delevantes, a sibling duo. They will perform at 7 p.m. Tuesday at Frank Sinatra Park in Hoboken. Robbie Woliver

title: Mount Kisco Center Offers Order to Day Laborers
description: It is only 7 a.m., but already about 60 men, most from Guatemala, are milling about the parking lot outside a one-story stone building on Columbus Avenue, a dead-end street populated by moving companies and auto body shops. All of the men are dressed in work clothes, waiting to be picked up by contractors, landscapers and local homeowners, so they can spend the next 12 hours or so digging ditches, planting trees, building stone walls and doing other manual labor.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday showing changes in subway service that go into effect today gave an incorrect route for the new Special Shuttle. It will go from the Grand Street station to the West Fourth Street station, with a stop at the Broadway-Lafayette Street station; it will not end at Broadway-Lafayette. An article on the changes appears today, on Page 31.

title: California Coast
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's article ''Meandering Up the California Coast'' (Frugal Traveler, July 1) brought to mind my own dream.

title: A Septet of Car Museums
description: IF your summer vacation entails a driving trip, you might consider a detour down memory lane.

title: Rules a Hot Topic For London Cabdrivers
description: IF there's one sure-fire way to make the driver of a black cab see red, it's to mention the unlicensed minicabs that prowl the West End at around 11 p.m. when crowds from theaters, pubs, clubs and movies cram the streets.

title: The World: Tolerating Falun Gong; Hong Kong Bows to Beijing. Except When It Doesn't.
description: TWO years ago today, the Chinese government outlawed Falun Gong, saying the spiritual movement posed a dire threat to social stability. While Beijing has hounded the sect with escalating fury -- imprisoning and allegedly torturing scores of its adherents -- Hong Kong has quietly backed off its campaign.

title: Restoring Lost Luster
description: ERIN GINSBURG had arrived at Artcraft Silversmiths Inc. here, clutching the collection of window catches, locks, keyhole plates, doorknobs, fasteners, hinges and screws she had stripped from the doors and windows of her home. She had sorted and separated them into dozens of plastic bags, but she was skeptical about what could be done to restore them to their original finish.

title: Hong Kong Court Ruling on Boy Angers China
description: The Chinese government said today that it disapproved of a ruling by Hong Kong's highest court granting residency to a 3-year-old boy born in the territory to a mainland Chinese mother.

title: Investing; When Hidden Fees Erode 401(k)'s
description: ADMINISTRATIVE fees once borne almost universally by employers are chipping away at the returns of many investors in 401(k) retirement plans.

title: Paper Dolls for Grown-Ups
description: If the 1980's revival seems to be lasting longer than the actual 80's. some alternative-decade respite is in sight, at least on paper. This month, Dover Publications is releasing two new collections of paper dolls, which engage in sartorial satire of the 60's and 70's and are intended for grown-ups who never quite kicked the snip-and-fit habit. In ''Rock 'n' Pop Stars of the 60's,'' music and fashion buffs can choose from 16 dolls, including representations of James Brown, Roy Orbison, Joan Baez, Diana Ross, Mick Jagger and Cher (with and without Sonny). Film enthusiasts can slice into ''Glamorous Movie Stars of the 70's,'' outfitting the likes of Faye Dunaway, Goldie Hawn, Ann-Margret, Meryl Streep, Sally Field and Susan Sarandon. Each movie star comes dressed in her skivvies and can be changed into two outfits, plus accessories: for instance, vests and ties for Diane Keaton's ''Annie Hall'' look and a bowler hat for Liza Minnelli's ''Cabaret'' act. The dolls may be slightly more kitschy than chic, but from a fashion standpoint it's hard not to wish that Dover had printed Ms. Dunaway, Ms. Hawn and Ann-Margret, and called it a day (or, for that matter, a decade). The cutout books are $5.95 each at www.doverpublications.com.

title: You Had to Be There, Man
description: I spent 17 months as a marine in Vietnam. I have many friends who were also there. Except for those who were in my platoon, I would have a hard time telling you which units these other friends served in. Why? Because we don't talk about it. We realize that we were lucky to have escaped with our skins. We did not make the ultimate sacrifice, and to beat our chests as if we had would only belittle the memory of those who died. Those who talk about it the most seem to have done the least.

title: Baltimore Is Setting the Bar High
description: This is the time of year when the defending Super Bowl champion Baltimore Ravens should feel a bit nervous. The season is approaching, and so is the realization that their title defense is about to begin. Expectations of a second consecutive championship can be as crushing as a Tony Siragusa tackle.

title: Immigration Critic's New Project: Billboard Lawsuit
description: Nine months after the city removed his last billboard warning against immigration to the United States, the man who put it up has sued for the right to erect his signs in the city.

title: An Older, Wider West vs. Today's More Crowded One
description: AS wide-open space becomes more crowded, images of great American vistas take on new meaning, becoming relics of landscapes that either no longer exist or are changing quickly. Now, in a photographic exhibition called ''The Great Wide Open,'' the Huntington Library here takes us to two such places: to a West of the past that was both real and imagined, offering the hallowed American birthright of starting over in a land of endless possibility; and to a West of the present, which still calls, in a voice that is broken, sad, yet nonetheless beautiful.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: What Are Friends For?
description: In an article about good friends that even features a picture of Barry Levinson, you might have mentioned Levinson's great buddy movie, ''Diner.'' It opened during my senior year at Columbia, and my friends and I saw it at least five times. It has become an annual ritual and required viewing before any of us gets married.

title: A Move-In, Move-Out Fee in a Co-op
description: Q. The board of my co-op recently renovated the hallways by installing new carpeting and wallpaper. They are now imposing a $200 move-in, move-out fee.

title: Kashmir Impasse: India and Pakistan Are Stuck on Semantics
description: Since India and Pakistan's summit meeting ended on Monday without agreement -- and without even the polite formality of a public handshake -- the two nuclear rivals have been alternately upbeat and downcast about each other and their future relations. They act the part of wavering daisy petal pickers: we hate them, we hate them not.

title: A Film Done on a Shoestring Gives Rise to Big Expectations
description: WHEN Bradley Gallo first told his mother that he wanted to be a filmmaker, she dismissed his dream as a whim.

title: Rachel Hartigan, Christopher Shea
description: Rachel Hartigan, an editor, and Christopher Shea, a writer, both for magazines in Washington, are to be married today. The Rev. Catherine Linesch, a Unitarian Universalist minister, will officiate at the West Shore Cafe, a restaurant at Lake Tahoe in California.

title: Our Towns; Waist Deep in a Cleaner Hudson, an Old Folkie Pushes On
description: PETE SEEGER reached down with both hands to hoist his left leg so he could climb onto the bed of his red pickup. He is 82, but the years evaporated once he was standing there, lanky in worn jeans and a straw hat, playing a banjo bearing a peace sign and the words, ''This machine surrounds hate and forces it to surrender.''

title: Slobo Was Here
description: Soon after the war began in Bosnia in April 1992, the landscape came to resemble a scene of madness: roofless houses with baleful black eyes for windows, staircases to nowhere, smashed minarets or chimneys pointing a stone vestige to the sky, entire villages deserted but for stray dogs attacking the carcasses of cows. War is hell, but this was not war in the conventional sense of a battle between armies. The devastation resulted from the overwhelming Serbian onslaught on Muslim civilians, which tried to purge most of Bosnia of any non-Serb in the first months of the war.

title: Stroke of Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: You Had to Be There, Man
description: In his attempt to understand Joseph J. Ellis's classroom deception, David Oshinsky came perilously close to exonerating it (The Way We Live Now, July1). If the 1960's offer ''a special case,'' as Oshinsky suggests, which justifies lying in the name of ''chasing the magic of a very special time,'' then college students should be warned that they take history classes with tenured radical wannabes at their peril.

title: Private Sector; The Marketer From Mexico
description: It has been more than six months since Leticia Navarro Ochoa, once the highest-ranking woman at Gillette, started her new job as Mexico's minister of tourism. But on a working trip to New York last week, Ms. Navarro said she still had not visited all of Mexico's tourism areas because she was so busy. The job, she said, ''is much more than I expected -- a huge challenge.'' Ms. Navarro, 46, has been devising new ways to promote her country, where 90 percent of tourists visit coastal resorts like Acapulco and Cancn. She has developed plans to attract nature lovers, golfers, big-game hunters and chefs. She said Mexico was moving slowly toward development of gambling casinos and was opening a tourist office in Tokyo. ''We are not only sun and beaches,'' she said.

title: Katherine Low, Jonathan Owsley
description: Katherine McKnight Low, the daughter of Candida and David Low of Blairstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Hawkes Owsley, a son of Thomas Owsley of Arlington, Va., and the late Susan M. Hurley. The Rev. Charles Fox, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Old First Church in Old Bennington, Vt. The Rev. James R. Kelley, a United Church of Christ minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Private Sector; He Just Couldn't Stay Away
description: Robert M. Miller, a lawyer who advised bondholders of companies like Macy's and the Trump Taj Mahal during the last wave of corporate bankruptcies a decade ago, is back. After a six-year hiatus from full-time bankruptcy work, Mr. Miller has joined Financo, an advisory firm specializing in the retail industry, as head of its new restructuring practice.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Corrections
description: The Dining Out column on July 1 misstated the hours and prices for Auberge Maxime, in North Salem. At lunch, main dishes are $12.50 to $18; at dinner, main dishes are $25 to $31. A prix fixe dinner on Saturdays is $56. Lunch is served Thursdays through Mondays from noon to 2:30. Dinner is served Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays from 6 to 9:30 p.m.; the hours on Sundays are 3 to 9 p.m. Auberge Maxime is closed Tuesdays and Wednesdays.

title: Online Forums: Tips and Tales
description: EVER return from a trip bursting with knowledge and great experiences, only to meet with the dutifully tolerant interest of hometown friends? (''That sounds fascinating! Now let's talk about me.'') Well, there's an audience out there hungry for your wisdom, in the ever-widening world of online bulletin boards.

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Census Results Are In. Where Is Everybody?
description: FOR some people in Litchfield County, especially the rich and famous who have chosen the area as a second-home haven, a post office box can give much desired anonymity. But last year, many box holders became even more anonymous than they'd intended because when the 2000 census was done, the Federal Government couldn't find them.

title: Commercial Property/430 Park Avenue; Redesigning and Upgrading a Faded Office Building
description: A TIRED office building on Park Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets is being redesigned and renovated to fit in better visually with its neighborhood and become what its managers hope will be a prime location for corporate tenants.

title: An 18th-Century Landmark Faces 21st-Century Problems
description: Behind some bushes on Roosevelt Island's Main Street sits a gray clapboard farmhouse. It was built in 1796 by the Blackwell family, whose name the island bore until 1828, when the city bought the land. In 1976, the city designated the house a landmark.

title: The Poor Man's Capitalist
description: Hernando de Soto has a great idea, one that seems to make sense for both conservatives and liberals (Matthew Miller, July1). His idea of ''titling'' the assets of the impoverished to empower them with economic leverage fulfills the conservatives' advocacy of private property rights and the liberals' advocacy of economic justice. Three cheers to Hernando de Soto and to the leaders who sign on to and implement his idea.

title: Letters: Phillip Glass
description: Last of a Line To the Editor:

title: Does a Plan to Shut Token Booths Turn a Blind Eye to Crime?
description: A plan to reduce staffing and hours at 122 subway token booths citywide, including the permanent closing of 35, has upset riders from Brighton Beach to Bedford Park who worry that the initiative will make those stations less safe and more inconvenient.

title: Emily Kramer, Steven Rubin
description: Emily Elizabeth Kramer, a daughter of Jane and Howard Kramer of Rye, N.Y., is to be married today to Steven Andrew Rubin, the son of Maria Rubin and Dr. Joel Rubin of Valley Forge, Pa. Rabbi Balfour Brickner will officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: July 15-21; Who Added the Yeast?
description: Why are there dinner rolls in Leonardo da Vinci's ''Last Supper''? The supper, after all, was a Passover seder. And Jesus was a Jew. So shouldn't the bread be unleavened?

title: Hide Those Children. A Jersey Guy's on TV.
description: DANNY DeVITO. Jack Nicholson. Bruce Willis. Bruce Springsteen. Frank Sinatra.

title: Logging Plan for West's Burned Forests Incites a Debate
description: It was a year ago that wildfires roared through the forests of the rugged Bitterroot Valley here, consuming 70 homes and more than 355,000 acres of forest. But controversy sparked by the fires still smolders.

title: July 15-21; Cambodian Evidence Found
description: New evidence directly links senior Khmer Rouge leaders to genocide under the Pol Pot regime. Telegrams and documents contained in a new report by the War Crimes Research Office of the American University College of Law and the Coalition of International Justice provide the first proof of the responsibility of seven living leaders for systematic murders that eventually claimed the lives of a million people. The current Cambodian government has resisted United Nations efforts to create an internationally approved tribunal to try the Khmer Rouge. Elizabeth Becker

title: What Do Poor Nations Need Most?
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: July 22, 2001
description: Weeks

title: American Media Mogul Makes News in Moscow
description: When Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, recently celebrated his first year in office, teenagers in Moscow organized a bash for him. Naturally, the party was held in Red Square, and some 10,000 high-school students attended. By all accounts, everyone had a great time. There were bands and balloons and free refreshments for all. Some of the kids even brought skateboards, though the cobblestoned surface outside the Kremlin does not lend itself well to that particular pastime.

title: Sharon Silver, Robert Lichtman
description: Sharon I. Silver, a senior vice president for human resources, and Dr. Robert M. Lichtman, a psychologist, are to be married today by Rabbi Tsurah August at Teviotdale, a house in Livingston, N.Y., originally owned by Robert Fulton, the steamboat builder.

title: What's a Campaign Debt Between Friends?
description: There is no sign in the lobby, and the placard outside the elevator that opens up to the 18th floor of the Madison Avenue building identifies the office that fills the floor simply as Morris, Carrick & Guma, a political consulting firm.

title: Hen Island History And Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: Diane Donovan, Timothy Kiernan
description: Diane Michelle Donovan, a daughter of Dorothy and James Donovan of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there on Friday to Timothy Michael Kiernan, a son of Mary and John Kiernan of Nanuet, N.Y. The Rev. John Rathschmidt performed the ceremony at Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Personal Business; How Much Is That $100 Deductible in the Window?
description: LAST year, before he turned 9, Rocco, a feisty Chinese pug, received a special gift from his owner, one that was intended to last through many more birthdays: enrollment in a pet health insurance plan.

title: Corrections
description: Photographs with the Dining Out column last Sunday appeared in error. They showed The Grill Room at Whitby Castle in Rye, which is reviewed today on page 15, not the Caffe Regatta Oyster Bar & Grill in Pelham, which was reviewed last week.

title: Meat to Newcastle
description: To the Editor: We too prefer villas, cottages or apartments to hotels. We also enjoy shopping at local markets and using the fresh food available. It really does make us feel more like natives than visitors.

title: Heavy Metal
description: JEWELRY TALKS

title: It's by Your Palm She Will Know You
description: DONNA McCUE bustled out of her frame house, scooped up her white poodle, Rocky, and cheerily greeted a visitor to her Springs home without stopping to shake hands. Inside, she quickly retreated to the kitchen to finish preparing a lunch of poached salmon, asparagus and salad.

title: When the Mainstream Takes Over Outsiders' Turf
description: AMONG the many group shows of contemporary art offered by Manhattan galleries this summer was one that trumpeted its own historical significance. It had to. '' 'Pictures' at an Exhibition'' at Artists Space, the nonprofit gallery at 38 Greene Street, recreated part of a 1977 show whose focus on appropriated imagery is said to have signaled the birth of postmodernism.

title: Political Memo; In Slow-Motion Albany, Old Days Look Exciting
description: There is a tradition here that for decades was the pulse of state government, each beat an exercise of power, a clash of adversaries, a piece of deal-making. These days, it is more like a flatline.

title: Russia's Eventual Place in NATO
description: President George W. Bush has been bold in his design for a Europe whole and free. Now he needs to be bolder still. On his first trip to Europe, last month, he made an impressive speech in Warsaw in which he argued that the European Union and NATO, those key institutions of Europe and the West, should grow decisively eastward. How far eastward, of course, remains the question.

title: Friendly Strangers
description: To the Editor: In 1994, my husband and I were touring Dublin and wanted to visit Kilmainham Jail, the location of the incarcerations and executions after the Easter uprising of 1916. At Heuston Station, I asked the information officer for directions, and before he could respond, a female voice behind me asked, ''How many people in your group?'' I answered, ''Just two.''

title: Q & A
description: Along the Silk Road

title: Gaul Divided
description: FRANCE

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 24 about hotels in historic structures misstated the restriction on architectural changes by owners of buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The requirement that changes comply with federal standards takes effect only if a building has received federal tax credits for historic preservation or federal funds. Mere listing on the register does not restrict an owner's ability to change the building.

title: Honolulu Proves Clichs Can Charm
description: AS a child of an era in which plastic hula dolls jiggled on every other dashboard, I approached Honolulu with my traveler's radar on, prepared for a sudden attack of tropical clich. Then, stepping off the jet at Honolulu International Airport into a phalanx of waiting tour guides, their arms dripping with orchid, frangipani and jasmine leis, my defenses melted. The Hawaiian welcome may be one of the most touristy rituals in America, but it's also surely one of the most seductive.

title: State's Plan for a Leaky Landfill Doesn't Go Far Enough, Some Say
description: The Brookfield landfill's 272 acres are dwarfed by the nearby Fresh Kills landfill's 3,000, but they still have a toxic punch. Those 272 acres leak 95,000 gallons of contaminated water every day into the groundwater and Richmond Creek.

title: At Salzburg, The Sting Of a Gadfly May Endure
description: SALZBURG, Austria, best known as the birthplace of Mozart and the site of the Salzburg Festival, is one of the prettiest places on the planet. It has Baroque cathedrals and a medieval fortress and a swift-flowing river and quaint little streets and elegant shops, hotels and restaurants. It is surrounded by craggy Alps, into which are nestled turquoise lakes and softly, intensely green meadows.

title: Glory Road And Its Storied Past
description: NOSTALGIA comes in dozens of forms, some subtle and some not. The least trustworthy kind is always shiny and bright -- think of those overly restored diners whose walls are adorned with 45 r.p.m. records, where sandwiches have names like ''The Big Bopper.'' It's nostalgia as marketing tool, and when someone's trying to sell you something, the sense of place often dies in the sales pitch.

title: Editors' Note
description: The What's Doing column on March 18, about San Antonio, included the Days Inn at 902 East Houston Street in a short list of budget lodgings, described as ''less expensive but not less convenient than some standard hotels.''

title: You Had to Be There, Man
description: Oshinsky says he sees disappointment in his students' eyes when they hear he was neither on the front lines of the war nor on the front lines of the battle against the war. But he has a chance to encourage participation in democracy. Writing a letter or phoning a member of Congress is not a dramatic act of courage, but it does make a difference.

title: BackTalk; Dodger Days Created Memories For All of Brooklyn to Share
description: When I wrote about the Dodgers of My Brooklyn four weeks ago, it inspired readers to write me about Their Brooklyn in those years. One even soothed my disappointment in being stiffed for an autograph by Pete Reiser, who was my favorite Dodger.

title: Middle Village Journal; Sleeping With the Giants of the Mob
description: There is a graveyard in Middle Village, Queens, where the Mafia goes to rest in peace.

title: Crossing Borders, and Not Just in Art
description: MITCHE KUNZMAN and Alex McFarlane, curators who both live in South Salem, N.Y., near the border of Connecticut, see the geographical boundary line between Westchester County and Western Connecticut as unnecessary, especially when considering the rich and diverse cultural makeup the areas share.

title: Duval (65) Has Chance to End Talk of Failure
description: With his best round at a British Open, David Duval put himself into the thick of the drama in today's third round.

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Envisioning a Day When Ferries Abound on City Waters
description: The thunk of the East River against the ferry landing at Pier 11 on Wall Street is the sound of a vast and largely untapped resource for city commuters: water. But by 2004, the jaunty ferry terminal at Pier 11, which opened last fall, may be joined by 14 more landings.

title: STYLE: BEST OF THE COLLECTIONS; Glimmer Twins
description: Who knows what it was like for Dorothy, but for Jeremy Scott, growing up in Kansas (well, actually Kansas City, Mo.) meant reruns of ''The Carol Burnett Show'' and ''Sonny and Cher'' -- they were Jeremy's Oz. Think Carol Burnett as Scarlett O'Hara in her green curtain-rod dress. Think Cher in an over-the-top Indian headdress singing ''Half Breed.'' Just think Cher, period. What Jeremy didn't realize was that the wizard behind all this ''glamour till you die'' was Bob Mackie. ''He has been part of my consciousness for so long I didn't even know it,'' Jeremy says. ''Bob Mackie is such a part of American culture, he's practically in the tap water.''

title: After Day of Extremes, Anything is Possible In Final Round
description: On a day of wild extremes at the British Open, David Duval boldly shot his way into a share of first place. Tiger Woods suffered on the back nine, as his swing shockingly fell apart, sending him into a nose dive that left him five strokes off the lead, with 27 players in front of him. Colin Montgomerie surrendered his lead with shaky putting, raising serious doubt as to whether he will win his first major championship.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: FOUR WINGS AND A PRAYER

title: Sports of The Times; Fond Memories of Maris's Series Homer, No. 62*
description: ROGER MARIS, in that storied, Bambino-surpassing, asterisk-scarred year of 1961, hit not just that famous figure of 61 homers, but 62. I know. I was there when No. 62 was socked -- and to his teammates, it was as important a home run as Maris had hit all that season. In fact, it was the most exciting one of them that I, then a college senior who found himself in the ballpark that day, had witnessed in person -- and the only one.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Small Boutique Hotels Are Seeking to Fill a Niche
description: WHEN Deborah Rivera Pittorino and her husband, William, planned to attend a wedding on the North Fork two years ago, they found there were no available rooms for them to stay overnight. All had been booked months in advance.

title: The Tops in Sous Chefs on the Rise
description: JUST as perfect grapes are essential to making fine wine, a talented sous chef is integral to a successful kitchen. Keeping the kitchen humming, he often creates the menu with the executive chef, oversees the line cooks, keeps inventory, orders the food and, of course, cooks.

title: Political Briefing; White Drops Bid To Join Black Caucus
description: It seemed like a natural enough request to Alderman Thomas Murphy, who represents Chicago's 18th Ward on the city's Southwest Side. The ward is 85 percent black, and so its alderman, Mr. Murphy reasoned, should be a member of the City Council's black caucus.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Sleek New Breed of Hog
description: HARLEY-DAVIDSON will celebrate its 100th birthday in 2003. It rolled out the cake last week, two years early.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-22-01; Sex and This City
description: Like countless other Washingtonians, I came to the capital city as an intern. The place is full of them. Each June and September, a new wave lands ashore, just as fresh and vigorous as the last one. If you catch the G2 bus in the morning as it wends its way from the dorm rooms and group houses toward downtown or if you hop on the Metro toward Union Station and Capitol Hill, you will see them in droves: dozens of former high-school presidents, khakis everywhere, red ties and sensible red dresses, hair still wet from a rushed shower.

title: Phil Lesh and Willie Nelson in Camden
description: In a bill for Deadheads and redheads, Phil Lesh bassist of the Grateful Dead, and Willie Nelson, who is sometimes known as the redheaded stranger, will perform in a concert that will range from jazzy cosmic jams to perfected country-pop songs. Each act likes to perform for hours, so the evening has the potential to be a long and interesting one. They'll appear Saturday at the Tweeter Center, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden. Robbie Woliver

title: Private Sector; A Barbour, a Baker, A Chinese Rainmaker
description: In a new meshing of money and politics, the Republican fund-raiser and heavyweight lobbyist Haley Barbour has branched out into Washington's latest twist on the influence game. He has signed up as a senior adviser to Milestone Merchant Partners, a newly formed private equity group. It is modeled after the Carlyle Group, a successful merchant bank based in Washington that has relied on such prominent Republicans as former President George Bush and James Baker 3rd to drum up investment business around the globe. In this case, Mr. Barbour will be opening doors along with James Baker -- James Baker 4th, a Washington lawyer and son of the former presidential adviser.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-22-01: Questions for Neil Diamond; Diamond Is Forever
description: Q: You turned 60 the same year as Bob Dylan. Did you guys bond?

title: Saxophonist Basks in the Limelight
description: THE jazz saxophonist Joe Lovano is in the midst of a banner year.

title: Con Ed Offers Plans To Cope With Peak Usage
description: Hoping to reduce peak usage this summer by as much as 70 megawatts (the amount of energy needed to power about 70,000 homes), Con Ed has introduced incentive programs for businesses.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Artistic Fury Born of Anger
description: ANGER that swelled ''beyond its usual confines'' drove Elaine Lorenz to create ''Beyond.'' The six-foot-long abstract sculpture made of beeswax, steel mesh, plaster and grapevines suggests a human larva, fleshy and ripe, stretching toward the sun.

title: Here Lies Hollywood: Falling for 'Six Feet Under'
description: AS Fred Allen once remarked, imitation is the sincerest form of television. And if that is the measure, ''Six Feet Under'' -- HBO's new comedy-drama about a family of morticians -- is terribly sincere. It openly borrows from such recent and past successes as ''Ally McBeal'' (the fantasy-hallucination sequences), ''The Singing Detective'' (ditto, mixed with song-and-dance) and ''Sex and the City'' (titillation and lightweight malaise).

title: A Ballet Master
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Washington; A Town Hall That Is for the People, Bowling and All
description: FOR the better part of 70 years, Bryan Memorial Town Hall has seen its share of stories -- and the people who provoked them -- stride past its pillars and through its double doors.

title: Dance Listings
description: AT&T LATINO CULTURAL FESTIVAL — Wed., 7: Ballet Provincial de San Luis from Mexico will perform. Thur., 8: Fusion Tango and the Otero X Tango Quartet will perform "Flores Negras" and other works. Fri., 8: Arthur Aviles Typical Theater will perform "La Mezcla" and the "Five Star Dance." Sat., 3, Free: Sisa Pakari, the New York based Ecuadorian dance troupe will present traditional works. Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows Corona Park, Exit 9E and the Grand Central Pkwy. (718-760-0064).

title: Marcy Reher, Lance Spacek
description: Marcy Jill Reher and Lance Joseph Spacek were married on Friday by the Rev. John Laferrera at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Caldwell, N.J.

title: Music Listings
description: Classical and Opera

title: Missile Defense Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Khadijia Mayo, James Morrow III
description: Khadijia Alanna Mayo and James Anthony Morrow III were married in a nondenominational ceremony yesterday in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Adelle Brown officiated at Wyndham Sugar Bay, a resort in Smith Bay, St. Thomas.

title: MetroStars Get a Break And a Victory Over D.C.
description: D.C. United defender Carey Talley had a fairly amazing day against the MetroStars at Giants Stadium, scoring two goals today. His first tied the score for United. His second won the game for the MetroStars.

title: Reading Up for Road Trips
description: THE approaches that publishers take to road-trip guidebooks are as varied as the kinds of cars they are found in -- from the solid American sedan (the AAA guides) to the European import (the Michelin Green guides). The Michelin series, in fact, has been covering an ever-increasing amount of mileage in the United States in recent years, including guides for Florida, California, New England and New York-New Jersey-Pennsylvania.

title: Meat to Newcastle
description: To the Editor: Lauren Shakely's article ''Leaving Home, Taking the Hearth'' (July 1) reminded me of something I have done. When my husband and I go to England to see his grown daughters and their families, we rent ''self-catering'' cottages, house-sit for friends or do a home exchange.

title: Private Sector; Knowing Where to Eat in New York
description: For Richard A. Grasso, chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, it has become a constant source of opportunity, amusement and frustration: the dinner parties he gives at the exchange for the winners of Chief Executive magazine's chief executive of the year award have lately been honoring people whose companies trade on Nasdaq. ''Any evening,'' he said last Thursday, ''when I can bring Michael Dell and John Chambers to the New York Stock Exchange is a very special event.'' Mr. Chambers (Nasdaq ticker symbol CSCO, for Cisco), last year's winner, was there to introduce Mr. Dell (DELL, of course), this year's winner. ''If anyone who has any good ideas as to where I can go to convince John and Michael that they have one too many letters in their ticker symbols, I'll be glad to depart,'' Mr. Grasso said, leaving his destination unclear.

title: A Hands-On Dig In Colorado
description: For those who hanker to be Indiana Jones or Lara Croft for a day, the Crow Canyon Archaeological Center has recently opened a new dig northwest of Mesa Verde National Park in Colorado. The center, with headquarters in Cortez, is doing long-term archaeological research on the newly dedicated 12-acre Albert Porter Preserve, occupied by Pueblo Indians from A.D. 600 to 1225.

title: Letters
description: Lisa Belkin's cover article on Fanconi anemia prompted mail urging prospective parents to get genetic testing. Responding to the flap over a historian's phony war stories, veterans said that those who served don't talk about it. And a request for an allergy-proof cake drew many recipes.

title: Beate Uhse, 81, Entrepreneur In the Business of Erotic Goods
description: Beate Uhse, who as a destitute war widow sold birth control pamphlets from a bicycle before going on to develop Europe's biggest emporium of erotic goods, died on Monday in a hospital in Switzerland. She was 81.

title: Liberties; Blubber For Breakfast
description: He's got an office by the ocean, even though he hates the ocean. He lives in L.A., even though driving makes him nuts. He goes to dinner parties, even though he can't stand socializing.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Traffic Jam Ties Up British Open
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, July 20  On a day of wild extremes at the British Open, David Duval boldly shot himself into a share of the lead with a 65, while Tiger Woods shockingly fell apart on the back nine, falling five strokes off the lead. Colin Montgomerie surrendered his lead with shaky tee shots and even shakier putting, but so many players made blunders this afternoon, Montgomerie was still among the huge contingent of possible winners.

title: Yes, Yes to Pompoms
description: If summer sightings are anything to go by, fall promises plenty of warm fuzzies in the form of that ever-perky ornament the pompom. So nice they named them twice, pompoms have appeared this season on pseudopunk T-shirts by In Vitro ($25 at Y.R.B.) and thong underwear by Occhi Verdi ($22 at Saks Fifth Avenue). Now, superfueled by their appearance last month in the tresses of those ever-accessorized ''Sex and the City'' girls, pompoms are taking off. At Cynthia Rowley, oversize fake-fur pompoms (above) and more diminutive multicolor-yarn ones adorn hair elastics ($30). Ms. Rowley's circus-themed fall 2001 show was, in fact, the inspiration for Sarah Jessica Parker's latest ponytail preference. At Henri Bendel, hooded sweatshirt jackets in pastel colors have mink pompom accents ($88). For $158, Olive & Bette offers a rainbow selection of cashmere scarves with abundant pompoms on the ends. (Caution: they're likely to snag on the brooches you pinned on your denim jacket.) And those who hanker to customize can buy mixed bags of pompoms at Pearl Paint at a mere $3.99 for a small bag (left) and $15 for a big bag. Hurry now, while supplies last.

title: Same Old Greed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Send in the Kleins
description: ACCORDING to the new census, there are 684,162 more people living in New Jersey than there were 10 years ago. Perhaps you've noticed. For me, it was bad enough that more of you are beating me to parking spaces, standing in front of me at the post office and delaying the deli line at ShopRite. But now more of you have my name.

title: Habitats/10th Avenue and 54th Street; Restaurateur on the Move
description: THOMAS VICARI grew up in Greenwich Village, where his grandfather had a candy store and his father a grocery store, and he has watched the ebb and flow of Manhattan's neighborhoods for many years.

title: A Tribute to Faith
description: An icon titled ''The Crowning of Christ,'' now being readied for the ceiling 120 feet above the nave of the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, is a gift from the Very Rev. Robert V. Wilshire, who served for 20 years as Dean of the Cathedral, seat of the Long Island Episcopal Diocese. Dean Wilshire died on July 22, 1999.

title: Finding Some Way To Disperse The Fog
description: THE economy, if you'll pardon the metaphor, is like a ship inching its way through a thick fog. Until it lifts, the crew cannot increase speed. But there is not enough wind to blow the fog away, or sun to burn it off. So the fog stays and the ship proceeds slowly -- and this is a long-lasting fog.

title: Cejka's Career Path Has a Few Twists
description: Alex Cejka, one of four players tied for first place heading into the final found of the British Open, has one of the most unusual backgrounds of any professional golfer.

title: We're Not in Oz Anymore
description: INSIDE RIKERS

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the jazz singer Mildred Bailey misstated the title of a song that both she and Ella Fitzgerald recorded in 1939. It was ''It's Slumbertime Along the Swanee,'' not ''It's Slumbertime Down South.''

title: An Appalling Silence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Business; Temporary Work Is Sidestepping a Slowdown
description: THE law of gravity has worked on stocks, dot-coms and economic growth rates. But it is having a harder time pulling down the industry that supplies temporary employees to American businesses.

title: Caroline Carlson, William Balz
description: Caroline Birgit Carlson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Carlson of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to William Paul Balz, the son of Alice Balz of Kalamazoo, Mich., and Dr. Gunther Balz of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Henrietta D. Aiello performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Chatham, Mass.

title: Private Sector; Comfortable With the Fast Track
description: AS a 15-year-old racing fanatic, Anne Stevens longed to hang out with the mechanics in the pits at the stock car races near her home in Reading, Pa. But girls weren't allowed.

title: Sona Kumar, Vicente Mata
description: Sona Udiaver Kumar, the daughter of Jean and Mohan Kumar of Lafayette, N.J., is to be married today to Vicente Mata Silva, a son of Elena Silva Sandoval and Vicente Mata Perez of Rio Grande, Mexico. The Rev. Anthony Johnson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, will officiate at the Parsippany Hilton Hotel in New Jersey. The ceremony is to be preceded by a Hindu marriage ceremony conducted at the hotel by Chaitanya Bijoor.

title: Man Dies in Brooklyn Fire
description: A 71-year-old Brooklyn man died in a fire in his apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBACKS
description: NEWJACK: Guarding Sing Sing, by Ted Conover. (Vintage, $14.) The author, a journalist with a reformer's heart, recounts the year he spent under cover as a rookie correction officer, or ''newjack,'' at Sing Sing prison in Ossining, N.Y., where he struggled to maintain order within the anarchic cellblocks while keeping his own psyche and moral code intact. His report, which won a National Book Critics Circle Award, is a ''moving indictment of our ways of punishment,'' Daniel Bergner wrote in the Book Review last year.

title: A Room and a Park Bench of His Own
description: MY uncle died last month. Esophageal cancer took him. The bad cells squeezed the good cells and wrung out his body until he weighed no more than 70 pounds. He was so thin at the end, it seemed a flick of the finger could snap his ribs. You could actually see his heart struggling to beat in his chest.

title: A Vienna Museum For Would-Be Maestros
description: ANYONE who has daydreamed about becoming a famous maestro can fulfill the fantasy at the House of Music, a museum that opened last year in the heart of Vienna.

title: The Secret Society of Caretakers
description: TWO weeks ago, he was in the parking lot of the assisted living community where my mother lives. Last week, in the lobby. Next in the elevator.

title: DataBank; In 1,500 Earnings Reports, Mixed Signals
description: Corporate earnings ruled Wall Street last week, as almost 1,500 companies reported their profits and offered forecasts into their futures. The results left a mixed and murky picture.

title: Christine Guyer, Alexander Barned
description: Christine Marie Guyer, a daughter of Mary Alice Guyer and David Carlin Guyer of Springfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Alexander St. John Barned, the son of Carol Ann Barned and Anthony R. Barned of Colombo, Sri Lanka. The Rev. Laurent R. Laplante, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the service at St. Martha Church in Kennebunk, Me.

title: What Do Poor Nations Need Most?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharp Odor Along Jersey Shore Is a Mystery
description: A strange chemical odor prompted scores of phone calls to emergency service agencies across New Jersey yesterday. Officials who received the complaints said they were baffled and unable to determine the source of the stench.

title: Missile Defense Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Holden's New York
description: THE first thing I did when I got off at Penn Station, I went into this phone booth. I felt like giving somebody a buzz. I left my bags right outside the booth so I could watch them, but as soon as I was inside, I couldn't think of anybody to call up.''

title: Don't Spend That Check: It Won't Be in the Mail
description: About 130 million individual income tax returns will be filed this year, but only about two-thirds of those filers will be receiving tax rebate checks that the Treasury will start mailing this week. And many of the checks will be for only part of the rebate promised earlier this year.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief review on June 24 of ''Libraries in the Ancient World,'' by Lionel Casson, misstated the time and the responsibility for the destruction of the great library of Alexandria, Egypt. According to the book, it was probably destroyed about A.D. 270 in a war between Rome and Palmyra, and could not have been destroyed in the Muslim conquest in A.D. 642.

title: The Next Wave in Computers
description: How's the water? There's no need to dip a toe if you log on to Rutgers University's Coastal Ocean Observation Laboratory (COOL) Web site, www.thecoolroom.org. It provides air and water temperature and wave height at beaches from Sandy Hook to Cape May for swimmers, and information about currents and buoy notices for fishermen and boaters. The site, updated several times a day, is actually part of research being conducted by the Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences that is yielding surprising results for scientists interested in such things as where different types of fish and clams are situated and why they are, or are not, growing, said Dr. J. Frederick Grassle, director of the institute. The information that is being continuously compiled by underwater sensors is used to form models to make predictions about the ocean and underwater weather for both the near and long term.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Fading Shoreline

title: Slowly, Calling the Burbs Home
description: TWENTY years ago this season, I stepped off a train at the Scarsdale station into a life in the suburbs. My family was not happy about the move. We felt like strangers in a strange land, even though we were Americans, for we had lived in Europe for 14 years. None of us had ever lived in a suburb.

title: Missile Defense Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Hen Island History And Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: More Legal Oddities In a State Full of Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Amap yesterday showing changes in subway service that go into effect today gave an incorrect route for the new Special Shuttle. It will go from the Grand Street station to the West Fourth Street station, with a stop at the Broadway-Lafayette Street station; it will not end at Broadway- Lafayette. An article on the changes appears today, on Page 31.

title: Where the Saints March In From
description: WHEN churches around the country are ready to upgrade their Nativity scenes, chances are good they will turn to a Bronx company called Institutional Statuary.

title: M.R.I. Trailer Is No Godsend to Neighbors
description: On Astor Avenue, in front of Bronx Multi-Medical Care, when Mondays come, so does the M.R.I. tractor-trailer.

title: A Fighter in Frilly Pajamas Demands Her Elevator
description: Jane Wood, a sprightly 94-year-old, was getting ready to go to sleep at 8 p.m. on Tuesday. But this was no ordinary bedtime. After brushing her hair, Ms. Wood walked down four flights of stairs to an inflatable mattress in the lobby of her building at 274 West 19th Street.

title: Save Fire Island, A People's Treasure
description: Why is it urgent that the government proceed with a Fire Island Erosion Control Project?

title: No Reading Glasses For the Chief Executive
description: To the Editor:

title: A Director Who Likes To Sit Alone In the Dark
description: TERRY ZWIGOFF admits to what his producer has told him: that when she's pitching one of his movies, it's easier if he doesn't come along. ''Maybe I'm not very good in a pitch meeting,'' he says. ''I come across as rather self-deprecating, and they don't like that at all. My producer warns me: 'Quit knocking yourself. They're not getting it. Go in there and be rather arrogant.' I said, 'I can't do that.' ''

title: July 15-21; Cease-fire Lost in Crossfire
description: The Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire that has not been seems as if it may never be. A Palestinian suicide bomber killed two young Israelis near a train station. The Israeli Army, aiming at a Hamas figure, fired missiles that killed four men. Israeli settlers on the West Bank killed three Palestinians, including a baby, in a drive-by shooting. Hoping to keep matters from spinning utterly out of control, foreign ministers of the major industrialized countries proposed sending in ''third party'' monitors. But Israel, ever wary of outside observers, said no. And the next day, in unclear circumstances, an explosion near the Hebron office of Al Fatah, the party of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, killed a man. Clyde Haberman

title: A Young Star Finds The Personal Touch
description: THE American violinist Joshua Bell has been much praised for his technical assurance and catholic repertory, qualities revealed in concert and in numerous recordings. Until recently, though, his work lacked a personal stamp. Now a series of CD's suggests that a change may be taking place.

title: A Welcome Mat, or a Banana Peel?
description: Yes, a fresh chapter in life can be exciting. And when that new chapter involves new employment, the initiation can prove enlightening, whether it leads -- literally or figuratively -- to a bed of hot coals or a bed of roses.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about quick courses in Italian mispelled the surname of a woman who took one and misstated her age. She is Anna Marguerite McCann, not MacCann; she is 68, not 76. The article also referred incorrectly to a robot she will use in an archaeological expedition off the coast of Italy. It will not collect samples from the sea floor.

title: Musical Tribute to Firefighter
description: A 40-year-old Passaic firefighter, Alberto Tirado, died on May 9 when he was trapped on the third floor of a burning tenement building. Local rock 'n' rollers and the Streets of Fire, a motorcycle club of Newark firefighters, will hold a tribute to the firefighter at the Stone Pony tonight with the proceeds to go to Mr. Tirado's wife and four children. The Nortons, Joe D'Urso, Plug Spark Sonje and Chris Grace are among the musicians who will play for the event starting at 7 p.m. Karen DeMasters

title: Rivera Has Inflammation
description: Mariano Rivera is relieved that a second M.R.I. exam merely showed inflammation in his tender right ankle, and he is hoping that a visit to a foot specialist next week will provide orthotics for his cleat that will help reduce the pain.

title: Heidi Tarshis, John Hornick
description: Dr. Heidi G. Tarshis, a daughter of Marlene and Steven Tarshis of Monroe, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Frederic Hornick, a son of Joanna and Frederic Hornick of Columbia, S.C. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Lyndhurst, the Jay Gould house and museum in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Davidson took part in the ceremony.

title: Widening Racing's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: Her Homework's in the Window at Bendel's
description: THE ''open-see'' at Henri Bendel is legendary; novice designers line up for the chance to show their work to the store's buyers, face to face. Todd Oldham and Anna Sui were discovered there.

title: July 15-21; Another F.B.I. Lapse
description: Already buffeted by a string of embarrassments, F.B.I. officials glumly reported that they could not account for 449 firearms, mostly handguns, and 184 laptop computers, at least one and possibly four of which contained classified information. The disclosure brought fresh groans from lawmakers in both parties, who echoed the sentiments of Richard J. Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, who said, ''How did this great agency fall so far so fast?'' David Johnston

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: REGARDING FILM

title: Investing; A Jolt at Callaway Golf, But a Firm Foundation
description: WHEN a company loses its visionary founder, people on Wall Street usually start asking questions.

title: Truth Serum as Behavior Modification
description: IT is said that the truth will set you free, but for Connie Moutis, it was truth serum.

title: Friendly Strangers
description: To the Editor: Thanks for ''The Help of Strangers'' (June 3). My husband and I have had the pleasure of extensive travel, and we have a lot of warm memories of people helping us when we were lost: the waiter in Florence who walked two blocks in the rain to point us in the right direction; the girl in Athens who climbed into our cab, with her dog, when the cabdriver didn't understand where we wanted to go; the man in Paris who not only pointed us to a specific street in the Marais but also took the time to offer a two-minute history lesson.

title: Lisa Braverman, Scott Yarbrough
description: Lisa Danielle Braverman, an actress, and Scott Manning Yarbrough, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Geva Theater in Rochester. The Rev. Joyce L. Gioia, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Storage Bill to Aid Evicted Tenants
description: Nassau County legislators unanimously approved a bill last week requiring that the possessions of evicted tenants be placed in storage for 30 days at the landlord's expense rather than left on the curb by deputy sheriffs. The law also applies to belongings of homeowners who are foreclosed.

title: Alexandra Wald, Adam Gimbel
description: Alexandra Sarah Wald, the daughter of Ellen Ginsberg of Sands Point, N.Y., and the late Richard Wald, was married yesterday to Adam MacRae Gimbel, a son of Valerie Mary Battine Gimbel and Louis S. Gimbel III of Manhattan. Denny Chin, a judge of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Symbol Anticipates Lower Second Quarter

title: Randy Weston, Still Feeling The Pulse of African Rhythms
description: THOUGH he's a regular on the jazz club and festival circuit, Randy Weston doesn't characterize his music as jazz. He prefers to call it ''African rhythms.''

title: July 15-21; Grading Missile Defense Test
description: In the days preceding the first missile defense test in a year, Pentagon officials played down its significance. Even after the prototype ''kill vehicle'' demolished a mock warhead 140 miles over the Pacific night, the three-star general who oversees missile defense testing warned that the program still had ''a long road ahead.''

title: Introduction
description: Lisa Belkin's cover article on Fanconi anemia prompted mail urging prospective parents to get genetic testing. Responding to the flap over a historian's phony war stories, veterans said that those who served don't talk about it. And a request for an allergy-proof cake drew many recipes.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: LOUIS

title: Human Rights for TV Rights
description: The common perception is that site selection by the International Olympic Committee confers some sort of moral high ground. Not much could be further from the truth.

title: Newspapers Sputter, but Shares Mostly Flourish
description: If this is the summer of anguish over advertising, why, exactly, are the stock prices of some of the biggest newspaper companies floating along at or near their 52-week highs?

title: Rebels Secure a Base in Macedonian Town
description: Ethnic Albanian rebels have taken advantage of a NATO-brokered cease-fire in Macedonia to move into this town and a few villages in this mainly Albanian-populated area of western Macedonia, right under the noses of government forces.

title: A Difficult Financial Future Awaits Midsize Arts Groups, Report Finds
description: Last fall, Ballet Arizona of Phoenix prepared to close after 15 years because it could not meet its $60,000 payroll just six weeks before ticket sales started peaking for its lucrative ''Nutcracker'' season. Frantic executives hoped for miracles and publicly begged for money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISMAN, ALLAN M.
description: DISMAN-Allan M. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member, Allan Disman. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President

title: Case of the Caddie Who Couldn't Count
description: Ian Woosnam could never have anticipated today's nightmare at the British Open, and neither could anyone else.

title: Gillette Hires BBDO for Oral Care Work
description: The Gillette Company ( news/quote ) has expanded its relationship with the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), by naming BBDO New York to handle creative duties for its worldwide oral-care businesses, including the Oral B line of toothbrushes and dental floss along with the Braun line of oral-care appliances. Annual spending was estimated at $100 million.

title: New Economy; The pioneering spirit lives on at Apple Computer, and the industry cannot afford to ignore it.
description: BY the usual yardstick of market share, Apple Computer is a computing pipsqueak. Its slender slice of personal computer sales is less than 4 percent in the United States, and its share of the global market is even slimmer. Yet in terms of industry attention, press coverage and attendance at trade shows like the Macworld Expo in New York last week, Apple still looms pretty large.

title: Gillette Hires BBDO For Oral Care Work
description: The Gillette Company has expanded its relationship with the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by naming BBDO New York to handle creative duties for its worldwide oral-care businesses, including the Oral B line of toothbrushes and dental floss along with the Braun line of oral-care appliances. Annual spending was estimated at $100 million.

title: Lawyers' Study Says States Should Pay for Court Races
description: States should provide public financing for judicial campaigns to limit the growing role of money in judicial politics, a study by the American Bar Association is to recommend this morning.

title: Compressed Data; When the Soundtrack Turns Subliminal
description: At the peak of financial earnings season last week, business reporters spent countless minutes on hold, listening to background music while waiting for corporate quarterly conference calls to begin.

title: A Rare Home Run Off Franco Sinks the Mets
description: As they have navigated their way through this desperate season, the Mets have searched for signs that their troubles are ending. They thought they unearthed several positive omens Saturday, including the first home run by Rey Ordez in two years and a rare victory from Steve Trachsel.

title: Olympic Committee To Begin Campaign
description: The International Olympic Committee has begun a worldwide promotional program for the 2002 Winter Games, to be held in Salt Lake City beginning on Feb. 8. The campaign will continue to use a theme, ''Celebrate humanity,'' that was introduced before the 2000 Summer Games.

title: Memo to Umps: Disregard Previous Memo
description: If it is not balls and strikes, it is warnings and ejections. It seems that it is always something with the umpires. Because of directives from Major League Baseball on how to do their jobs, umpires are attracting so much attention, they may soon be able to demand a pay increase for being stars just like players.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Recession Blues Are Turning Into a Ballad of the Sad Cafes
description: Porteos, as the residents of Buenos Aires call themselves, are in a foul mood these days. Nearly one in five is out of work, crime is on the rise and the only thing to joke about is the bumbling of the government.

title: A Faded Resort Lumbers to Life; Grass-Roots Tourism Revival in a Mineral-Spring Retreat
description: For the old-timers in this historic mineral-spring village, it was more than a little startling when the white elephant came back to life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKER, VICTOR E.
description: MARKER-Victor E. Passed away July 21, 2001. Of Philadelphia, PA. Survived by his wife Beatrice (nee Weissman). Father of Richard A. (Mirele) Marker and Gary J. (Ann) Marker. Brother of Helen Pinsky and Leon Marker. Grandfather of Adam and Joshua. Services and interment will be private. For information, Goldsteins' Funeral Home 1-800-622-6410.

title: The Roots of Conflict In Jamaica
description: During the spasm of violence in Jamaica earlier this month, my wife and I spent a quiet afternoon on the veranda at the home of my 84-year old mother, in a part of Kingston less than three miles from the center of the conflict that, over four days, left more than 25 people dead. We felt about as safe as we would anywhere in New York or Boston.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Matters; If Only All Parks Were Central
description: A SUMMER Friday, and the city is emptying out as those with places at the beaches, lakes and mountains head for their getaways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, ANNETTE
description: OPPENHEIM-Annette. July 20, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Stephen. Loving mother of Steph and his wife Wendy, and Jeffrey and his wife Ellen. Cherished grandmother of Kara and Jesse. A gracious lady who will be deeply missed. Service Monday, July 23, 2001, 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street.

title: Juvenile Sex Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: If you thought rates were down for commercial time on network TV, take a look at cable.
description: ADVERTISERS are agreeing to buy television commercial time ahead of the 2001-2002 season from cable networks and program syndicators at rates even lower than those negotiated last month, when they made plans to buy commercial time in advance of the coming season from the broadcast networks.

title: Washington Not Alone in Cell Debate
description: As President Bush and Congress struggle with the question of regulating embryonic stem cell research, one fact is being overlooked: nearly two dozen states already have laws that govern research on embryos and fetuses, and at least nine ban any experimenting with human embryos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JOHN T. (JACK)
description: GALLAGHER-John T. (Jack). On July 22, 2001. Formerly of John T. Gallagher Funeral Home, Church Ave. Beloved husband of Mary Kay. Devoted father of Katherine, Joanne Oplustil, J. T. Jr, Arthur, Eileen Cullen and Edward. Also survived by nine wonderful grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at their residence, 196 Marlboro Rd, Monday 7-9, and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, Holy Innocence R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers in memoriums to CAMBA, 1720 Church Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11226, deeply appreciated.

title: Guide Proposed for Trials of Rogue Leaders
description: A group of leading international legal scholars and jurists, convinced that more public figures are likely in coming years to face trial for abuses like genocide and crimes against humanity, is proposing the first set of guidelines for such cases.

title: Jarrett's Friendly Bump Opens Path to Victory
description: Dale Jarrett had only one car to pass and only one chance to do it. Ricky Rudd, his teammate, was driving that car, which made a difference in the way Jarrett tried to pass him. But Jarrett was not about to slam on his brakes, either.

title: Treasury Offerings Scheduled for Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a two-year note being auctioned Wednesday.

title: Woods Starts New Streak, Failing to Win 2nd Straight Major
description: Tiger Woods never seriously threatened the leaders and finished tied for 25th at one under par, his worst finish in a major championship since the 1997 P.G.A. Championship, when he tied for 29th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, HERBERT
description: GOODMAN-Herbert. 83, of Riverdale, NY, and Delray Beach on July 21. Devoted husband of Dorothy, loving father of Joan and son-in-law Donald Link, grandfather of Alana, Suzanne and Steven. Services Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, Tuesday, July 24, 12 noon.

title: Dear I.R.S.: Thanks for the Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Found Dead In Midtown
description: A man was found dead yesterday on the roof of a McDonald's restaurant at 688 Eighth Avenue, near 44th Street. At 9:30 a.m., the police were notified of an apparently unconscious man on top of the restaurant. When officers arrived, they discovered that the man was dead. His name was not released pending the notification of family. A preliminary investigation indicated that the death might have been a suicide, but the police did not provide details. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Bush Firm on Missile Shield Despite Treaty Violation
description: ROME, July 23 — President Bush said today that while he hopes to reach an agreement with Russia to reduce nuclear arms and scrap the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, "time is of the essence," and if he cannot reach an accord with President Vladimir Putin he will move ahead with testing missile shield technology.

title: Rules for Writers (1. Don't Rely on Rules)
description: To the Editor:

title: Aiding Dictatorship, Not Democracy
description: SPAIN BETRAYED

title: Determined Jones Wins Big Apple By a Stroke
description: Rosie Jones stood on top of the hill on the last hole at the Wykagyl Country Club and debated which club to use for her approach to the green below. There was a slight wind and the ball was sitting on the first cut, just off the fairway. Moments later, the diminutive Jones raised her arms in triumph as her 8-iron shot from 121 yards landed 4 feet from the hole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, DAPHNE C. (NEE BARSHT)
description: SCHER-Daphne C. (nee Barsht). On July 21, 2001, in Annapolis, MD. Loving wife of the late Meyer Scher, loving mother of Jillian Kanavage of Arnold, MD, beloved mother-in-law of Bernard J. Kanavage, loving grandmother of Anthony and Daniel Kanavage. Funeral services and interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, on Tuesday, July 24, 1:30 PM. Contributions to the charity of choice. For information, Levinson Funeral Home, 800-338-1701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMAN, LEONA
description: PEARLMAN-Leona. On July 22, 2001. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Edmund Pearlman. Cherished mother of Robin Forrest Lefkowitz and her husband Steve, and Michele Rizika. Adored and adoring grandmother of the late Bradley Jon Forrest; loving grandmother of Jeffrey and Richard Rizika. Great-grandmother of Brittany, Brandi and Talia. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Bradley Jon Forrest Foundation.

title: Dear I.R.S.: Thanks for the Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate Talks Stuck
description: For the second time in eight months, the fate of the first treaty to require cuts in gases linked to global warming came down to a marathon all-night session as countries sought to ensure that the agreement did not harm their economies or other interests.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Mark Ganton, a senior account director at Brian J. Ganton & Associates, Cedar Grove, N.J., was named to the new post of director for business development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERSON, J. ROBERT
description: PIERSON-J. Robert. On July 21, 2001, at age 88. Beloved husband of the late Catherine. Loving father of Mary E. Malone, Robert A. Pierson and Kathryn A. Pidgeon. Dear grandfather of Dawn Marie, Tyler, Gregory, Austin and greatgrandfather of Kyle, Kelsey and Brennen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Ave at 54th St, Wednesday. For further information call, 212-288-3500.

title: Rules for Writers (1. Don't Rely on Rules)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Russian Arsenal
description: To the Editor:

title: Never Plead Guilty, Never Plead Aches and Pains; With a Book Just Published and Several in the Works, John Mortimer Remains Tireless
description: Sir John Mortimer has plenty of physical complaints -- his sight is failing, his body is aching, and ''I can't walk properly, which is quite tiresome,'' he said -- but there are unexpected compensations. ''You have hundreds of friends helping you about,'' he said, ''and you get into all sorts of adventures.''

title: A Sweet Young Thing? Nope, She's Very Much in Charge

description: The landscape of the Web has changed. Or maybe not.
