description: A SHIFT is taking place at NBC, and panic is in the air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, J. DORMER
description: CANNON-J. Dormer. Of Lakeville, CT, formerly of NYC, on July 20, 2001, age 81. Son of the late William C. Cannon and Edith Dormer Cannon, of Lakeville, CT, and NYC. Retired partner of Beekman and Bogue. Graduated the Hotchkiss School, Yale University and the University of Virginia Law School. Survived by his wife Jane, sons William C. of Concord, NH, John D. of Rupert, VT, and Joan C. Cassin of Bronxville, NY. Predeceased by wife Marian Hamilton and daughter Jane Cannon Smith. Grandfather of ten and greatgrandfather of two. For service info call Newkirk Funeral Home, Lakeville, CT; 860-824-7350. Donations in his memory may be made to Sharon Hospital, Sharon, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESCH, CARL W.
description: DESCH-Carl W. The Directors of the Columbia University Club Foundation note with sadness the loss of its former President, Carl W. Desch. A member of the Columbia College Class of 1937, he was a great supporter of his Alma Mater. We treasured his leadership, financial acumen and humor. We extend our sincere sympathy to his daughters, Carol & Barbara, son, Carl, Jr., and sister, Margaret Hanft. The Directors of the Columbia University Club Foundation, Inc.

title: Havas Makes Bid For Stake in Tempus
description: Havas Advertising in Paris has bought 3.6 percent of the outstanding shares of the Tempus Group in London after making an offer to acquire Tempus that is being supported by owners of 25 percent of Tempus's stock.

title: Reasonable Economic Targets
description: Disappointing earnings reports continued to stream in from some of America's biggest corporations last week. There is no doubt that the economy is in a slump now, and the beginning of its revival may still be months away. But comfort may be drawn from the fact that despite its current weakness, the economy could recapture a historically normal rate of growth as early as next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOWER, LORRAINE POPPELE
description: FLOWER-Lorraine Poppele. Of Morristown and Lake Mohawk, NJ. On July 20, 2001. Dear daughter of the late Jack Poppele, founder of radio station WOR, and sister of June Poppele and Virginia Endres. Memorial service at Restland Memorial Park Chapel, 77 DeForest Ave, East Hanover, NJ, on Friday, July 27, 2001, at 11:30 AM. For information contact Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, Livingston, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: A McGovern Liberal Who's Content to Stick to the Label
description: THIRTY years ago he was the Tom Daschle of his generation, the Democratic senator from South Dakota talked about as a contender for the White House.

title: Rethinking Mexican Immigration
description: The evolving partnership between George W. Bush and Vicente Fox, the president of Mexico, makes this a favorable moment for both countries to revisit the difficult immigration and border issues that have long vexed relations between the United States and Mexico. Indeed, Mr. Bush and Mr. Fox are working on an ambitious set of proposals that they hope to unveil during Mr. Fox's visit to Washington in September. On the American side, the package under consideration includes legalizing the status of some three million undocumented Mexican workers here and embracing a more ambitious temporary-worker program for future migrants.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Sentencing In Watkins Case
description: The sentencing of Felix Rodriguez in the 1999 murder of Amy Watkins is scheduled in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. In June, Mr. Rodriguez was convicted of second-degree murder for being the lookout when another man plunged a knife into the back of Ms. Watkins, a young social worker from Kansas.

title: Russian Card In Bush Deck
description: When the Bush administration took office it was skeptical of the Russians and openly dismissive of President Clinton's brand of personal diplomacy with Kremlin leaders.

description: BONN, Germany, July 23 -- The world's nations, minus the United States, accepted treaty rules that for the first time would require industrialized countries to cut emissions of waste gases linked to global warming.

title: ''Shrek'' Is the Leader So Far This Summer
description: Bolstered by ever-escalating ticket prices and an incremental rise in the number of movies, the summer movie box-office total is on pace this year to continue its growth of recent years. For the eight weeks from Memorial Day weekend through July 15, the nation's moviegoers spent nearly $1.5 billion on tickets -- slightly above last year's level for the first eight weeks of the summer season.

title: Falun Gong Manages Skimpy Rally; Is Sect Fading?

Dear sister of Anne Elvins, Dr. James W. Wallace, Daniel C. Wallace and the late Dr. Richard C. Wallace. A memorial service will be held at a later day and time. For information call Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA; 617-277-8300.

description: A remarkable turnabout in the final set of deals gave the Grand National Team title here last night to a foursome from Southern California. At the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, victory went to Jill Meyers, who was the world's top-ranked female player two years ago; Ed Davis; Mitch Dunitz; and Iftikhar Baqai. They trailed by 25 imps into the last quarter, but several slam swings helped them surge to an 8-imp win.

title: A Stronger, More Theatrical Role for Female Activists
description: In the Web's early days, the Internet was often described as a place where men were men -- and most of the women were, too. The joke was that the Ann in a chat room was just as likely to be an Andy in the same way that a teenager could pretend to be an adult or a Dane could masquerade as a Pole. Because the Net could be used to conceal one's real identity, anyone with a mind to do so could easily create an alternate online persona, a character performing in the virtual theater of cyberspace.

description: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia agreed today to link discussions of American plans to deploy a missile defense system with the prospect of large cuts in both nuclear arsenals. If an accord was reached quickly, it might take the place of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

description: The Mets do not plan to ask the All-Star catcher Mike Piazza to change positions in the near future, and told him so last week.

The end, which came in the third round, was predictable. Focus instead on a more significant display at Caesars Palace. This one took place about an hour after the fight.

description: Iwas greatly saddened to learn in Elmore Leonard's 10 rules for authors ("Easy on the Adverbs, Exclamation Points and Especially Hooptedoodle," Writers on Writing, July 16) that he once "had to stop reading to get the dictionary."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Home Invasion Assault
description: Four men wearing black clothes and masks forced their way into an apartment in Canarsie early yesterday and sexually assaulted two women inside at gunpoint, the police said. The police answered a call at 2:30 a.m. and were told that the men had stolen money and property from the apartment and fled. The victims were 20 and 24, and a 30-year-old man was also present when the robbers broke in, the police said. The two women were treated at Kings County Hospital Center and released. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONDERO, LISETTE
description: DONDERO-Lisette. Wife of the late John A. Dondero and formerly Vice President of the New York based firm Faurot, Inc., well known to law enforcement agencies throughout the country and abroad, and a longtime member of the International Association of Identification, died on Saturday, July 21. Faurot, Inc., specializes in forensic identification equipment. She is survived by son Dr. John A. Dondero, M.D., of Mendon, MA, and daughter Professor Marilyn L. Picard of White Plains, NY. She is the well loved grandmother of six grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

title: G-8 and Main Protest Groups Concur on Stopping Violence
description: As both sides left Genoa, the leaders of the major industrialized nations who met here and the mainstream protest leaders began reflecting today on how to carry out their goals while avoiding the fatal violence that marred this year's meeting.

description: The Gillette Company ( news/quote ) has expanded its relationship with the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), by naming BBDO New York to handle creative duties for its worldwide oral-care businesses, including the Oral B line of toothbrushes and dental floss along with the Braun line of oral-care appliances. Annual spending was estimated at $100 million.

title: Author Eudora Welty Dies at 92
description: Eudora Welty, whose brilliant short stories, notable for the evocativeness of their imagery and the sharpness of their dialogue and wit, made her the most revered figure in contemporary American letters, died today. She was 92.

title: Motorola to Sell Inner Workings of Cell Phones to Rivals
description: Motorola plans to announce today that it will begin selling its most advanced cell-phone microchip sets, software and production tools to anyone who wants to buy them, including major rivals of its own handset unit.

title: For Riders, Many Riddles, Written in Q's, D's and W's
description: Wearing the fluorescent orange vest that identified her as a subway official there to assist confused riders, Josefina Rivera stood in the Grand Street subway station yesterday and did her best to tell Ngan Hoan Dam how to get where she needed to go. It was no small feat, since there was no one available who spoke Ms. Dam's language.

title: Blunderbuss Approach Hurt ABC's Coverage
description: A bunched-up leader board in a major golf tournament, like the British Open, after three rounds is a chance to milk potential drama on a Sunday as some golfers surge forward and others falter. But ABC's final-round coverage for three of its five and a half hours yesterday was an unnerving, discontinuous botch that could have driven anyone to turn it off.

description: Like a spacecraft breaking free of the rocket it no longer needs to reach its final destination, Intelsat severed its ties last week with the governments that launched it nearly 40 years ago.

description: IRVING-Arthur Paul, Jr. 7/23/25. On what would have been your 76th birthday, we remember you as a loving and attentive husband, father and grandfather. We know you are at rest, of ''good cheer'' and enjoying eternal life, as the result of a life well lived here on Earth. Not a day goes by that we don't think of you and miss you terribly. Happy Birthday! Peggy and Famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABLER, MILTON
description: GABLER-Milton. On July 20, 2001, at age 90. Two time Grammy Award winner, inductee into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, composer of such songs as ''Love,'' and ''Danke Schoen,'' and founder of Commodore Records and head of A and R at Decca Records for over 30 years. Recorded such great artists as Billie Holiday (''Strange Fruit''), Ella Fitzgerald, Louis Armstrong and Bill Haley and the Comets (''Rock Around the Clock''). Beloved husband of Estelle, loving father of Lee, Eileen and Melina Gabler. Cherished grandfather of Jenny, Melissa, Sean, Tina, Andre, and greatgrandfather of two. Surviving siblings: Regina Greenberg, Helen Greenfield and Danny Gabler. Services today, Monday, July 23, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, 12 noon. Interment Riverside Cemetery.

title: Colorado Geologist Fights To Save Dinosaur Fossils
description: A prominent resident of this bedroom community west of Denver recently gave the town a scruffy five-acre strip of abandoned clay pits, once used for making bricks. Local officials are planning to include it in Golden's first public 18-hole golf course.

description: Supporters of ethanol, a fuel made from corn, are gaining in their push to make it a major part of the nation's energy policy, despite persistent doubts about its economic and environmental benefits.

title: Athens Races To Prepare For Olympics
description: International Olympic Committee officials are not ready to abandon their concerns over the pace of preparations for the 2004 Summer Games in Athens, but signs of a turnaround are emerging as local organizers and the Greek government increase their efforts.

title: Unhealthy Cuts for Head Start
description: Buried in President Bush's budget message, released in April, is a plan to dramatically change Head Start, the federal program that promotes literacy as well as healthy and enriched lives for children from disadvantaged backgrounds. The president's strategy already needs rethinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, CECILY B.
description: RYAN-Cecily B. Age 57, on July 21, 2001, of Garden City. Beloved wife of Charles Patrick. Loving mother of Shannon, Elizabeth, Catherine and Margaret and mother-in-law of Kevin O'Donnell and Christian Olivier. Dearest Lovie to Quinn. Cherished daughter of Cecily Blanco Brady and the late Leslie Blanco. Dear sister of Peter. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City, 7-9 PM, Monday, and 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10 AM, Wednesday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society, Garden City Unit, appreciated.

title: Aveline Kushi, 78, Advocate of Macrobiotic Diet for Health
description: Aveline Kushi, who taught and promoted macrobiotic cooking and helped found one of the nation's first natural food stores, died of cancer on July 3 in Brookline, Mass. She was 78 and lived in Brookline and Becket, Mass.

title: The G.O.P.'s Unsung Centrists
description: Last week's brief rebellion by Republican moderates in the House over President Bush's "faith- based initiative" ended tamely with vague promises from the White House to review complaints that the bill would override state and local anti-discrimination laws. Still, the grumbling over one of the signature issues in Mr. Bush's domestic agenda was a reminder of the gap between Mr. Bush and the moderate wing of his Congressional party. Republican moderates in Congress, in turn, reflect the feelings of their constituents  voters who supported Mr. Bush but do not like the policy trends of his administration on certain key issues.

title: Brigadoon Beckoning Turf World
description: John (Old Smoke) Morrissey was a gambler, casino owner, boxing champion and United States congressman, which is not a bad rsum at all. In 1863, however, he did something extraordinary. He held a three-day race meeting in upstate New York that laid the foundation for Saratoga Springs to become a must stop for horsemen, as well as an enchanting Brigadoon for horseplayers.

title: JAKARTA ASSEMBLY MEETS TO REMOVE CHIEF FROM OFFICE
description: Indonesia's legislature began proceedings today aimed at removing President Abdurrahman Wahid from office and ending the short, tempestuous rule of the country's first democratically elected leader in a generation.

description: As a lobbyist in Washington, Haley Barbour contends that the campaign finance system does not need to be overhauled -- and it is not hard to see why.

description: Last week, James Truman, the editorial director of Cond Nast, announced to a handful of the magazine company's editors in chief that he had hired the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas to work for Cond Nast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBROW, HONEY CHANSON
description: DOBROW-Honey Chanson. Of Boca Raton, FL, died July 22, 2001, as gracefully as she lived. She leaves her beloved son Richard Steven and a bevy of adoring nieces, nephews and friends, whose lives her spirit illuminated.

description: The tall, rumpled man made a phone call to Fort Worth to ask about books for sale. ''I'm Larry McMurtry,'' he said by way of introduction. ''I'm a book dealer in Archer City.''

description: BEFORE training camp in other years, Bill Parcells couldn't wait to get started, couldn't wait to coach the Giants, the Patriots or the Jets, or couldn't wait as the Jets' director of football operations to start overseeing the franchise.

title: Corrections

It is the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, not Consular Rights.

title: Patents; One invention will cut hair evenly; another embeds its texture in jewelry.
description: WHEN it comes to hairstyling, precision is as important as fashion. What good is great color, conditioning or cut if the barber or hairdresser doesn't trim evenly or layer consistently? If hair on the left side is shorter than on the right, it can be fixed only with further trims. Uneven hair looks chopped and sloppy, and can be repaired only with time.

description: Following are excerpts from the news conference by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the close of the summit meeting in Genoa, as provided by The Associated Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, RUTH
description: GOLD-Ruth. On July 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Ellen and Evan, Stacey and Isidore, Liz and Ed. Dear sister of Shirley and Seymour. Adoring grandmother of Marjorie, Bennett, Amanda, Jennifer, Daniel, Jessie and David. She will always be in our hearts. Service July 23, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: MediaTalk; Error in Quote Stirs Arguments Over Adams Legacy
description: One hundred and seventy-five years after his death, John Adams may be more popular today than he was while president, thanks to David McCullough's best-selling biography portraying Adams as the underappreciated ''colossus of independence,'' in Thomas Jefferson's memorable phrase.

description: It wasn't the best played or most intense tennis match of Jennifer Capriati's career, but it didn't have to be.

title: 2 Arrested in Fatal Shooting Of Man Who Offered Help
description: Like the good son his family said he was, Rupinder Singh promised his mother that he would come home early to Queens so his brother could use the car. Like the generous man his family also described, he stopped along the way to give a lift to five people with a broken-down vehicle.

title: Dining in the Great Outdoors
description: In the spring and summer, our thoughts turn to the outdoors, and a good way to celebrate the season is to dine al fresco. Here are 12 restaurants that offer pleasant garden spots. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, JUDITH
description: SILVERSTEIN-Judith. July 22, 2001, of Great Neck, NY, age 57. Beloved wife of Bob, loving mother of David, Debbie Silberg and her husband David. Proud grandmother of Rachel, dear sister of Alan Gardner. New York City Public school teacher for 31 years. Funeral services at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Family will be at home until Friday. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Parker Comprehensive Community Hospice, 5 Dakota Dr, Suite 104, Lake Success, NY 11042.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Choice of Top Military Man Weighed as Strategy Changes
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has the opportunity in coming days to put an indelible personal stamp on the American military when he gives President Bush his recommendation for the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILK, DIANE
description: SILK-Diane. Wife and friend of Robert. Devoted and beloved mother of Ilissa Siegel and Jerry Silk, and mother-in-law of Jonathan and Robin. Loving aunt of Helene Smith. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: A Retailer Will Take Its Campaign to TV
description: American Eagle Outfitters, the retail chain that sells casual apparel to younger consumers, is expanding its advertising efforts to add television for the first time to the print campaigns it runs.

title: Bush and Putin Tie Antimissile Talks to Big Arms Cuts
description: GENOA, Italy, July 22 — President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia agreed today to link discussions of American plans to deploy a missile defense system with the prospect of large cuts in both nuclear arsenals. If an accord was reached quickly, it might take the place of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Montedison Accepts Takeover Offer
description: The board of Montedison S.p.A. accepted a sweetened 5.5 billion euro ($4.79 billion) offer from Fiat S.p.A. and lectricit de France today, likely bringing an end to a battle for control of the owner of Italy's second-largest power company.

title: A Soul Singer Reappears, Still Obsessed With Love
description: When Howard Tate's voice leaped into falsetto on his 1967 album ''Get It While You Can'' (Verve), it was the sound of a man driven nearly beyond endurance by love and pain. He sounded just as powerful and just as blue when he sang at the Village Underground on Saturday night, in his first New York performance since he dropped out of music in the 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRWAN, TAYLOR, NANCY
description: KIRWAN - TAYLOR - Nancy. On July 20th in London, peacefully after a long illness endured with great courage. Funeral at Mortlake Crematorium on Friday July 27th at 3:00PM. All inquiries to J.H. Kenyon, London 01144.207.834.4624

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, JAMES JOHN
description: McCAFFREY-James John. Age 79, died July 21, 2001, in Bangor, Maine. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held 10 AM, Friday, July 27, 2001, at Our Lady of Holy Hope Church, Castine, ME.

title: Pressure on Sudan
description: Sudan's 18-year civil war is among the world's worst sustained conflicts since World War II. Until recently, though two million people have died and four million have been displaced, it was also among the most obscure. But now a combination of factors is pushing Sudan's war to the forefront of the Bush administration's agenda. That is to be welcomed. But some of the ideas being urged on the administration are misguided.

title: E-Commerce Report; Internet companies brave the transition from a free service to a business that charges.
description: OFFERING consumers a free service and then converting them to paid customers has long been a retail marketing tactic -- whether through a free issue of a magazine, a short-term fee waiver on a credit card or a shampoo sample handed out in a drugstore.

title: Refusing to Let Go, Property Owners Test Eminent Domain's Limits
description: The owners of the last houses amid the scarred and weedy lots of Fort Trumbull ask only to stay there while the city of New London realizes its dream of office buildings, apartment clusters and other upscale development rising in their neighborhood.

title: Hunt Goes On For Source Of Odd Odor In New Jersey
description: The authorities were still trying yesterday to find the source of a foul odor that wafted across New Jersey on Saturday, prompting dozens of phone calls to the police, environmental agencies and emergency workers.

title: Norwegians, Defying Protests, Will Sell Blubber to Japan
description: Norwegian whalers are preparing to export hundreds of tons of edible minke whale blubber to Japan in the face of widespread condemnation by nations that oppose whaling.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Motorola Plans to Sell Cell Phone Chips to Rivals

title: Dear I.R.S.: Thanks for the Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: Mysteries Of Life, In Images And Music
description: This summer's American Dance Festival concluded with an extraordinary world premiere, ''Mercy,'' a collaboration between Meredith Monk, the composer, choreographer and filmmaker, and Ann Hamilton, an artist known for site-specific installations.

title: Laiseka Wins 14th Stage; Armstrong Can See Paris
description: Basques by the tens of thousands have crossed the border from northern Spain to southwestern France in the last two days, and today they got what they were looking for -- a victory by one of their own in the 88th Tour de France.

title: Mr. Bush's Genoa Diplomacy
description: President Bush spent a busy weekend meeting with seven other world leaders in Genoa, Italy, with mixed results. His session with President Vladimir Putin of Russia brought a promising agreement to coordinate discussions on reducing offensive nuclear weapons and building a limited missile defense. But Mr. Bush's stubborn resistance to international plans to reduce global warming further isolated the United States from most of its leading allies.

title: Italy's Prime Minister Steps Out of the Summit Meeting and Into a Firestorm
description: After three days of compliments from his guests at the protest-besieged Genoa summit meeting, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi was heckled as soon as he set foot beyond the 13-foot-high metal and concrete walls encircling the world leaders.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Disney Is Said To Be Close To Acquisition Of Fox Family
description: In a deal intended to make the Walt Disney Company a stronger force in the lucrative cable programming business, Disney is close to an agreement to buy Fox Family Worldwide from the News Corporation and its partner for $3.2 billion in cash, people close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Better Global Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001072392669881754 -- No Title
description: Colorado Geologist Fights to Save Dinosaur Fossils .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;}

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, SOPHIE
description: SELIGMAN-Sophie. Beloved wife of Alexander. Devoted mother of Richard (Jody), Thomas, Diane and Barbara (Irwin) Bergman. Dear grandmother of Benjamin, Matthew, Sarah, Rachel, Cheryl and Jaclyn. For time of service call Sunset Chapels, 516-482-3600.

title: Dear I.R.S.: Thanks for the Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonus Miles From Shangri-La
description: Through Aug. 31, Shangri-La and Traders hotels is offering quadruple bonus miles when booking their value rate, a non-discounted published rate. The deal is good at 30 city hotels and 7 resorts and applies to 21 participating airlines, including American, British Airways, Japan Air Lines, Northwest, United, Singapore and Cathay Pacific. The value rate also includes the following year-round services: round-trip airport limousine, daily full breakfast, dry cleaning and laundry service and a 6 p.m. checkout; in the resorts, the rates include a buffet dinner, full breakfast, laundry services and a 6 p.m. checkout. Book at www.shangri-la.com or at (800) 942-5050 or a travel agent, and ask for the summer value-rate promotion.

title: Levy Orders A New Review Of School Data
description: Chancellor Harold O. Levy has ordered the New York City public school system's 32 district superintendents to meet with his deputies at least four times a year to analyze reams of data about their students, schools and teachers, and outline strategies for improvement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGRE, JACK H.
description: EGRE-Jack H. Beloved husband of Nettie, devoted father of Janice & Richard Levy, Martin & Faye Egre, Howard & Meryl Egre and Garry & Michele Egre. Dear broher of Gertrude Rothman and Millie Shapiro, cherished grandfather of Michael, Jahnna, Stefani, Jessica, Owen and Samantha. Serivces Tuesday, 2 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woobury, LI.

title: Earnings at 3M Drop 4% as Demand Falters Worldwide
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its second-quarter profit fell 4 percent because of weak demand in North America, Europe and Asia and the effects of the strong dollar.

title: An Alloy of Murder Mystery Game and Musical Chairs
description: Watching ''Murder in Small Town X'' is a little like kibitzing a game of ''Clue.'' You start wondering if Mrs. White performed the murder in the conservatory with the rope, though it would be more fun to play the game yourself.

title: China Sentences Three People to Jail Terms for Spying
description: BEIJING, July 24 - China sentenced three people to jail terms for spying for Taiwan, including two permanent U.S. residents, Gao Zhan and Qin Guangguang, who were both sentenced to 10 years in prison after brief trials Tuesday.

title: Still Around? Oh, How the Ghost of You Clings
description: Little of Harold Pinter's famous savagery is on display in ''Monologue,'' a quiet, pained playlet from 1972, a production of which was presented by the Almeida Theater of London as part of the Lincoln Center Festival's salute to the playwright; it completed its five-performance run at the Clark Studio Theater on Sunday. The title refers not just prosaically to the play's sole actor but also resonantly to its subject, which is not loneliness exactly but more specifically what it feels like to be left irrevocably alone.

title: Craft Will Snap Up Pieces of Sun and Bring Them to Earth
description: Scientists believe that some of the raw material from which the solar system was made more than four billion years ago still exists in the Sun, and they are about to send a spacecraft to snare a sample and bring it back to Earth.

title: Knoblauch Heats Up As Deadline Approaches
description: The Yankees will talk with many teams and explore many trades before the July 31 deadline, because they are the Yankees and will consider just about any productive player, without the constraining binds of fiscal concern that interfere with the planning of most teams. But unless something changes radically in the next week -- Oakland deciding to trade Jason Giambi, for example -- it appears there is a good chance they won't complete any deals.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Loss At Phone Company
description: Sonera, a Finnish phone company, recorded a second-quarter pretax loss, excluding capital gains and nonrecurring items, as spending was high on new products and expansion abroad. The company said it lost 28 million euros ($24 million), before taxes and special items, in contrast to an 85 million euro profit a year earlier. Revenue increased 11 percent, to 557 million euros.

title: Bush Hears Pope Condemn Research in Human Embryos
description: President Bush, facing a decision whether to allow federal financing for research using human embryo cells, heard an appeal today from Pope John Paul II to ''reject practices that devalue and violate human life at any stage from conception until natural death.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Meets With U.S.
description: Microsoft lawyers met yesterday with Justice Department officials for the first time since a federal appeals court set aside an order to break up the company. The two sides discussed procedures for renewed talks in the government's antitrust case, according to a spokeswoman for Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, one of the 18 states suing Microsoft. The participants refused to discuss the meeting. Microsoft's lawyers also met with Charles A. James, the department's antitrust chief, as well as Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, and Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut. Also yesterday, Microsoft said it was making the source code of its Windows CE 3.0 operating system available over the Internet. Windows CE operates in electronic devices like hand-held computers and is increasingly used to power Internet-connected appliances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKER, VICTOR
description: MARKER-Victor. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Jewish Outreach Institute in New York mourn the passing of Victor Marker, the father of our friend and colleague Richard Marker who also serves as the chairman of our Jewish Connection Partnership project. Our deepest sympathy to Richard Marker, his wife Mirele and family. Terrence A. Elkes, President David Sacks, Chairman Dr. Kerry M. Olitzky, Exec. Dir. Dr. Egon Mayer, Founding Dir.

title: British and French to Resume Concorde Flights
description: British Airways will resume flights of its Concorde supersonic jet in September, and Air France will follow a month later, a coalition of French and British transport officials said today.

title: An Architect Of New Coke Is Returning As No. 2 Man
description: When the Coca-Cola Company's president abruptly resigned last March, leaving the company bereft of a second in command, Douglas N. Daft, the chairman and chief executive, said that was precisely the way he wanted it.

title: Experts Unearth a Stormy Past
description: It was an unlikely setting for a hurricane hunt.

title: Pentagon Shuts Down Web Sites to Guard Against Virus
description: Amid concerns that its computers were vulnerable to a type of virus known as the Code Red worm, the Pentagon said tonight that it had shut down parts of its public Web site today to allow technicians to install protective software.

title: Piecing Together Answers From Soot and Ashes
description: BEING a firefighter is the greatest job in the world, a very manly job,'' said Louis F. Garcia. ''You put out a fire, it's a great feeling, very rewarding. You get instant gratification.''

title: Disney Discusses Strategy Behind Buying Fox Family
description: Laying out the goals for their acquisition of Fox Family Worldwide, executives from the Walt Disney Company said yesterday that they intended to create a cable channel built on the model of a broadcast network.

title: Don't Dismiss the Genoa Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: Blasting Off

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about regulation of stem cell research misspelled the given name of a professor of bioethics who said states might end up with varied rules. She is R. Alta Charo, not Alto.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Truce With Maoist Rebels
description: The government and Maoist rebels said they would halt all offensive actions to pave the way for peace talks. The new prime minister, Sher Bahadur Deuba, took office on Sunday and appealed to the rebels to stop their violent uprising. He was chosen by the Nepalese Congress to replace Girija Prasad Koirala, who resigned last week under pressure from the opposition and his own party. The Maoists killed at least 17 policemen in a Sunday attack in Pandusen village in the western reaches of the country.

title: At Katharine Graham Funeral, Parade of Boldface Names
description: Mourned as a friend of the powerful but a foe of the imperial presidency, Katharine Graham was buried today after an eloquent farewell from leaders of the ruling establishment where she had flourished as publisher of The Washington Post.

title: Modern Masters' Works to Be Auctioned for Unicef
description: A $40 million collection of paintings and sculptures by modern masters like Picasso and Mir, Lger and Magritte, is being sold by Christie's in New York on Nov. 6 to benefit Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Virus Outbreak Is Feared
description: State health officials said a man in Madison County, about 45 miles east of Tallahassee, might be infected with the West Nile virus. Test results will not be confirmed until later this week, but positive results would mark the first human infection in Florida. In the last three weeks, health officials have discovered 13 dead birds and a dead horse that had been infected with the mosquito-borne virus in counties that stretch from Jacksonville to Fort Walton Beach. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Cleaning Our Waterways
description: To the Editor:

title: In Testimony, Greenspan Again Hints at Interest-Rate Cut
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 - Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, once again gave calm reassurances about the economy to lawmakers today, and he again indicated that the Fed was prepared to lower interest rates further if needed to revive growth.

title: Jets Talking To Holecek, A Linebacker
description: The Jets met with the former Buffalo starting linebacker John Holecek yesterday, as part of Holecek's tour of teams that might be interested in signing him. Holecek would provide much-needed depth behind the starter Marvin Jones, whose current backup is Doug Colman, signed for his special-teams skills.

title: Family Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Household Announces Changes in Lending Practices
description: Three days before a Senate committee is scheduled to hold hearings on predatory lending, Household International, one of the nation's largest consumer lenders, announced several changes it would make to practices that largely affect the lower-income families that are its main customers.

title: In Testimony, Patrick Ewing Tells of Favors At Strip Club
description: The marathon strip-club trial that promised to embarrass some of the country's best-known athletes and entertainers finally lived up to its billing today when Patrick Ewing, the veteran National Basketball Association star, took the stand and admitted that he received sexual favors on two occasions from dancers at the Gold Club.

title: Basketball Diversity Is Best, Study Says
description: College and professional sports organizations have shown improvements in hiring members of minorities for managerial and front-office jobs, but the hiring of women has slowed and only two professional leagues are near or at true diversity, says a report released yesterday by a research center at Northeastern University in Boston.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From cooking without salt to selecting California cabernets for a wedding, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JULIAN
description: FOX-Julian. September 2, 1926July 18, 2001. Mourned by his devoted family: wife, Suzanne; sons, Ethan and Jonathan; daughters-inlaw, Susan and Nicole; and granddaughters, Sophie and Rachel. Contributions in Julian's memory can be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Republicans Seek Votes Against Bipartisan Patients' Rights Bill
description: As the House moves toward a confrontation this week over managed health care, senior House Republican aides said today that Republicans did not yet have the votes to defeat a bipartisan patients' bill of rights favored by Democrats and opposed by President Bush.

title: Woman in the News; A Daughter of Destiny; Megawati Sukarnoputri
description: When she was still something of a neophyte six years ago, Megawati Sukarnoputri spoke with wonder about the hard work of politics. The most difficult thing to learn, she said, was patience.

title: HCA Reports Strong Results for Quarter
description: NASHVILLE, July 23 (AP)  HCA Inc., the largest United States hospital chain, said today that its second-quarter net income was $263 million, a figure that beat expectations. The turnaround came a year after HCA took a $498 million charge to settle federal fraud allegations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOVELL, HAROLD M., M.D.
description: TOVELL-Harold M., M.D. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the recent death of their Life Fellow, Harold M. Tovell, M.D.

title: Breast-Feeding and Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing
description: ROCKIES

title: Race Under Way to Winnow Down Genetic Data
description: Celera Genomics raced to determine the entire human genetic code. Now it is racing to winnow the information down.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: New York's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Cuts Back Funds for Faith-Based Charities
description: With its huge timber beams and fieldstone spire, the Newtonbrook United Church has long represented a sturdy commitment to community. Lately, it has also become a sign of how the delicate curtain that separates church from state in Canada has been shifting.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Merger Measures
description: The Swiss food giant Nestl said it planned to sell some of its concerns in Europe to win European Union approval of its $10.1 billion purchase of the pet food producer Ralston Purina. The company has notified the European Union Competition Commission that it would either shed some units or sell Ralston Purina's businesses in Spain, Greece and Italy. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: The Big City; Crossroads Of the World, Less the Roads
description: TOMORROW morning, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is scheduled to announce a new era of broader sidewalks in Times Square. This is welcome news to all New Yorkers and tourists who do not wish to be crushed to death.

title: INSIDE
description: Germ Arms Pact Revisited

title: Schumer Announces Support For New L.I. Power Plant
description: In an unusual show of solidarity for a project that some environmentalists and politicians would rather steer clear of, Senator Charles E. Schumer and an economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council announced support today for a proposal to build a 250-megawatt power plant here.

title: Love Story, or Is That Death Story?
description: SUZANNE'S DIARY FOR NICHOLAS

title: 3 Girls, Trapped in Surf at Rockaways, Drown
description: Four cousins wading in knee-deep water at a beach in Far Rockaway, Queens, were swept away yesterday by the fierce currents that have killed so many swimmers there. While their uncle and scores of other people watched helplessly from the shore, a boy struggled back to safety, but three girls were all pulled underwater and drowned.

title: U.S. ONLY LOOKS ON
description: With the Bush administration on the sidelines, the world's leading countries hammered out a compromise agreement today finishing a treaty that for the first time would formally require industrialized countries to cut emissions of gases linked to global warming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEINDLIN, TANIA
description: SHEINDLIN-Tania. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Anita Tore and Judge Jerry Sheindlin. Loving sister of Rose Halpern and cherished grandmother of eleven and greatgrandmother of six. Funeral services Tuesday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Eurotunnel Narrows Its Loss But Sees New Problems Ahead
description: Eurotunnel, which operates the channel tunnel linking Britain and France, said today that it narrowed its loss for the first half of the year, but warned that it might not meet its target of generating enough cash to cover its expenses by next year.

title: A New Indonesian Leader
description: The swearing in of Megawati Sukarnoputri yesterday as Indonesia's fourth president in the last three fractious years brought an abrupt but largely peaceful end to the ineffectual rule of Abdurrahman Wahid. Though Mr. Wahid refused to vacate the presidential palace, his resistance appeared to be futile. With the elevation of Mrs. Megawati, who was vice president, Indonesians must now belatedly address daunting economic and social problems that continue to threaten the stability of the world's fourth-most-populous nation.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper fell after a report of declining business confidence in Germany led to concern about worsening demand. In New York, copper for September delivery fell 1.2 cents, or 1.7 percent, to 68.8 cents a pound.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apartheid Era Aide On Trial
description: Dr. Wouter Basson, the head of chemical warfare under the former apartheid government, took the stand to defend himself against criminal charges of drug dealing, fraud and murder. He testified that he had infiltrated antigovernment groups and traveled abroad in the 80's to acquire information, technology and equipment to build the country's biological warfare arsenal, state radio reported. Dr. Basson, who has been on trial for 22 months, has been accused of injecting poison into prisoners and using government laboratories to make the drug Ecstasy.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen fell as Japanese stocks slumped on concern that attempts to write off bad loans would hurt economic growth. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.24 yen, up from 122.94 on Friday.

title: Letters: Family Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, FRANK
description: SCHWARTZ-Frank. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Loving father of Barbara and Norman Weinberg and Fran and Stewart Bluestone. Cherished grandfather of Sarah. Loving partner and companion of Zelda Groelinger. Dear brother of Millie, Marie and Kitty. Forever in our hearts.

title: American Express Earnings Tumble, as Warned
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its profit fell in the second quarter, even without its $826 million loss on high-yield bonds, as companies tightened travel and entertainment spending.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the debate over the execution of mentally retarded criminals gave an erroneous year in some copies for the death of Mario Marquez, a man with an I.Q. near 65, who was convicted of rape and murder. It was 1995, not 1985.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Twists At Alleycat
description: AlleyCat Information Sciences Inc., a privately held publisher of one of Silicon Alley's two technology magazines, is expected to announce today that it has received an undisclosed round of investments, and the company named Bill Britt, a former media executive and entrepreneur, as its new chief executive officer and publisher. Before joining AlleyCat, Mr. Britt was a vice president of business development at Broadserve, an Internet service provider. Mr. Britt replaces Janet Stites, a founder of the company who served as its publisher and chief executive. Ms. Stites will remain the president of the company. AlleyCat had been publishing 11 issues a year until it was hit by a slowdown in advertising. Officials at the company said they have secured advertising contracts that are sufficient to publish three more issues in 2001 and resume an 11-issue schedule in 2002. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Allison Willing to Wait the Bruins Out
description: Jason Allison is not sitting and waiting to see whether the Boston Bruins will trade his rights this summer. Skating and waiting is more like it.

title: 'And We're Going to Live Forever'
description: 'And We're Going to Live Forever'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, FRANCES M.
description: BRENNAN-Frances M., 80. Fanny died at New York Weill Cornell Center on July 22, 2001. Wife of the late Hank Brennan. Survived by son Christopher and his wife Ellen of Feasterville, PA, son Richard and his wife Elizabeth of New York City, and sister Lee M. Wrenn of Orcas Island, WA. The family wishes to extend its profound gratitude to Fanny's friends, physicians, nurses and attendants for their love and care. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be planned at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56th St, New York, NY 10019-3984.

description: SHIELDS-F. Paul, Jr, twenty five, on July 21, 2001. Devoted son of Frederick and Judy Shields; loving brother of Michael Shields and Emily Shields Allen; beloved uncle of Matthew David Allen; and cherished grandson of Amelia C. Shields. Services Thursday (July 26, 2001) 8:45 am at the funeral home. Funeral mass 9:30 am at St. Helena's RC Church, Edison, NJ. Private cremation to follow. Visitation Wednesday (July 25, 2001) 24 & 7-9 PM at The Gosselin Funeral Home, 660 New Dover Rd, Edison, NJ 08820. (732) 381-5858.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nursing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Jobless In Metropolis
description: Less than half of the women in the New York metropolitan area are employed -- the lowest level of any of the country's urban areas, according to an analysis by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Only 49.2 percent of New York women have paying jobs, well below the national average of 57.4 percent, according to the bureau's analysis of 1999 survey data. The area with the highest proportion of working women was Minneapolis-St. Paul, at 70.7 percent. In general, fewer people of either sex work in New York than in most other metropolitan areas, although the proportion of workers in New York had been rising until recently, according to the city comptroller's office.

title: Strong Gains Are Reported By Vivendi
description: Propelled by box-office hits and strong performance at its telephone unit, Vivendi Universal S.A. of France announced robust second-quarter results for its media and communications divisions yesterday.

title: Bike Seat to Hot Seat As Armstrong Is Grilled
description: Answering a barrage of questions today about whether he used illegal performance-enhancing drugs and his relationship with a controversial doctor who is accused of supplying the drugs to bicycle racers, Lance Armstrong defended his reputation as ''the cleanest of clean riders.''

title: Don't Dismiss the Genoa Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: As Trade Deadline Nears, Contenders Shop for Bargains
description: Randy Johnson is not available in this last week before the nonwaiver trading deadline. Nor is anyone like Randy Johnson available. That is why contending teams seeking a starting pitcher will have to weigh their options and their decisions carefully. Even if they exercise caution, however, some teams will wind up overpaying for a pitcher who will not help them reach the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, MADELEINE D.
description: RYAN-Madeleine D. Formerly of Staten Island, on July 21, 2001. Wife of the late Thomas. Mother of Jill Swartsel, Susan Clow, John, Nancy and Virginia Ryan. Eight grandchildren. Funeral Mass in the chapel at the Shrine of St. Joseph, Stirling, NJ, on Wednesday at 10:30am. Visiting in the Farmer Funeral Home, 45 Roseland Ave., Roseland, NJ, today, 2-4, 7-9.

title: Universal Begins Account Review
description: Universal Studios, owned by Vivendi Universal, said yesterday that it had begun a review for its theme-park advertising account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: Don't Dismiss the Genoa Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROYAL
description: LEVINE-Royal. We note with sorrow the passing of Royal Levine, a long time volunteer. We send our most heartfelt condolences to his family. Pat Roberts, President Volunteer Auxiliary, North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset

title: For Green, Running Comes Down to Shoe Leather
description: Derek Jeter has his stats, and Mark Green has his: number of African-American churches visited, 130; number of schools he has popped in on, 50; 70 town hall meetings in 53 community districts.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Cyberian Outpost plunges toward the abyss, two suitors wait patiently to pick up the pieces.
description: WHEN the stock of an online company drops to 50 cents, you can usually chalk up another one for the dot-com bust. But for Cyberian Outpost, an online seller of computers and electronics, the half-dollar benchmark was precisely when it found itself in the position of having two suitors vying to buy it.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: FORD TO EXPAND PICKUP TRUCK PLANT IN VIRGINIA
description: The Ford Motor Company will invest about $375 million in the next three years and add as many as 200 jobs as it expands a plant in Norfolk, Va., that produces the F-150 pickup truck. The expansion project includes a new 350,000-square-foot body shop, Ford said. The plant, which opened in 1925, has about 2,300 workers and built about 240,000 F-Series pickups last year.

title: Screaming Media to Acquire Stockpoint
description: Online content distributor ScreamingMedia ( news/quote ), whose shares have fallen 83 percent since its initial public offering in August, agreed yesterday to buy Stockpoint, a financial data provider, for $21.6 million in stock, cash and debt.

title: The Federal Reserve Is Now Finding the Limits of Its Power
description: Despite six interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year and the possibility of more to come, analysts say that monetary policy is packing less of a punch so far than expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABLER, MILTON
description: GABLER-Milton. With deep sorrow, we regret the passing of our friend, colleague and long-time Board Member, Milt Gabler. The Officers & Board of Directors Songwriters Hall of Fame

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, LILLIAN
description: ROTHENBERG-Lillian. Passed away July 23, 2001. Dearest and closest friend, we will miss our wonderful Wednesdays together visiting museums, art galleries, theaters, music and dance performances. We will miss her sense of humor, her artistic talent, her generosity of spirit and her always being there to listen. Claire and Paul Finkel

title: Pataki Offers Revised Plan On Drug Laws
description: Reviving moribund efforts to soften New York's Rockefeller-era drug laws, Gov. George E. Pataki is making a new offer, one that would give many more defendants the opportunity to undergo drug treatment rather than long prison terms.

title: Ways to Make Retirement Work for You
description: What are you doing now that you're retired? Or, if you are not yet retired, how are you planning to fill your days when you do? Playing golf? Watching television? Puttering around the house? Riding around in an R.V. spending your children's inheritance, to quote that popular bumper sticker?

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Chris Esposito was named manager for promotions at Raknroll Entertainment, Culver City, Calif., a new agency that offers services like public relations, celebrity management, marketing and special events. He joins Raknroll after being a student.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Think Tank column in Arts & Ideas on Saturday, about the United States government's backing of Hilton hotels during the cold war as a showcase for capitalism, was published in error. It showed the new Berlin Hilton, not the one that opened in 1958 in what was then East Berlin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, DUANE W., M.D.
description: TODD-Duane W., M.D. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the recent death of their Life Fellow and Past President, Duane W. Todd, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, ANNETTE
description: OPPENHEIM-Annette. The National Council of Jewish Women New York Section notes with great sadness the passing of Annette Oppenheim, former Vice President for Community Services, President of our Westchester Chapter and longtime Board member. Her beauty and dedication will long be remembered by the many whose lives she touched. Rita Fishman, President, New York Section NCJW Judith R,.Golub, Executive Director, New York Section NCJW

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSFELD, SUSANNE
description: WOLFSFELD-Susanne of Forest Hills, NY on July 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Rudy, dearest sister of the late Hildegard Grau, and the late Lewis Schloss. Donations in Susanne's memory can be made to the Holocaust Memorial Council, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Plaza, S.W. Washington, D.C. 20024 or Childreach/Plan International, 155 Plan Way, Warwick, R.I. 02886.

description: HEUMANN-Fred J. July 22, 2001, of Somers, NY. Beloved husband of the late Lee. Devoted father of Roger and Mark. Loving grandfather of three granddaughters. Services Tuesday, July 24, at 10am, at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Bedford Corners, NY. Interment Ivandell Cemetery, Somers, NY.

title: With a Week to Go, First Trade
description: The Mets made their first trade of what could be an active week before the July 31 trading deadline today, sending the backup catcher Todd Pratt to the Philadelphia Phillies for catcher Gary Bennett.

title: President's Ouster Grips Indonesia : Military Regains Political Clout
description: SINGAPORE  The Indonesian military, publicly reviled and excluded from power after Suharto resigned the presidency in disgrace in 1998, is returning to center stage and again playing a key political role in the world's fourth most populous nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, ROBERT
description: UNGAR-Robert. Loved and adored son of Paula and Larry Ungar, brother of Pamela Blank, brother-in-law of William Blank and grandson of Johanna Hamburger died on July 22, 2001. Services Wednesday, July 25th 10 AM, Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, send donations to your favorite charity.

description: To the Editor:

title: Breast-Feeding and Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANA, G. MORLEY JR.
description: MORGANA-G. Morley Jr., on July 11, 2001. Most beloved friend, son, brother, cousin and uncle, whose lives his spirit illuminated. He will be profoundly missed. No immediate plans for a memorial. ''Details to follow...''

title: A City Takes a Breath After the Dot-Com Crash; San Francisco's Economy Is Slowing
description: In the two-room flat above the Infusion Bar and Restaurant near Second and Bryant Streets -- a most coveted corner during the dot-com boom -- an Internet start-up came, spent handsomely and closed up shop. Its change of fortune, and that of hundreds of other Internet companies here, was so sudden that perhaps even the new tenant would not have been able to foresee the downfall.

title: Where There's Smoke, There's More
description: Heavy drinking and smoking often go hand in hand. Now researchers are suggesting a possible reason.

title: A Shellfish Caveat
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; MAD Isn't Crazy
description: I sure welcome the news that the Bush team will open missile talks with Russia, because it might bring some clarity to the Bushies' arguments on missile defense, which have been at best incoherent and at worst dishonest.

title: Pitter-Patter of Paws Is Time-Tested Remedy
description: Don't worry so much about the cardiovascular workouts, the oat bran, the diet or the aspirin a day. They may all have benefits, but apparently they're minor compared with one simple thing to do to live longer, heal faster, lower blood pressure and cholesterol and have a better chance of surviving a heart attack.

title: Gotcha! So What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, ADELE (NEE GRUBER)
description: LISMAN-Adele (nee Gruber). Of New York City, on July 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel P., devoted sister of William, Leo, Mamie, Ida, and Martha. Cherished aunt of Marcelyn and Larry, Ronald and Anne, Linda and Maurice, Roger and Ellen, Barbara and Ted, Lee and Simone. Adored great aunt. Her integrity and strength inspired us all. She lives within us forever. Graveside services on Thursday July 26, 2001, at 3 P.M. at The Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, NY. For information contact Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel: 718-892-9400.

title: Vatican Decides to Rebaptize Mormons Who Are Converting
description: The Vatican has decided that Mormons must be rebaptized before converting to Catholicism.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about the likelihood of stronger, more frequent hurricanes misstated part of the name of the agency that oversees the hurricane research center. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not Oceanographic.

title: Publish or Perish
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about subway service changes that took effect over the weekend referred incorrectly to the route for the new Special Shuttle. It will end at Broadway-Lafayette Street; it will not be extended to the West Fourth Street station until November. A correction on Sunday referring to a map of the route was published in error; the map was correct.

title: BellSouth Reports 17% Profit Decline In Second Quarter
description: The BellSouth Corporation, the biggest provider of wireless phone service in Latin America, said today that its second-quarter profit fell 17 percent, partly because of declining currencies in Brazil and Colombia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, HOWARD BERNARD
description: EHRLICH-Howard Bernard. Husband of Lillian. Father of Elizabeth, Carol, and Abraham. Funeral at Old Montefiore, Tuesday 1:30 pm. Shiva at the home of Elizabeth Potok, Mamaroneck, Tuesday-Sunday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: I.M.F. Package
description: The Brazilian central banker Arminio Fraga, along with a team of government economists, is planning to meet with officials from the International Monetary Fund in Washington to discuss a new financing agreement that could be worth as much as $12 billion. The Brazilian government, which was opposed to a new I.M.F. accord earlier this year, has become more receptive recently as worries over a possible debt default in neighboring Argentina have increased borrowing costs and depressed the value of the local currency.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Law On Khmer Rouge Trials Approved
description: The Senate unanimously approved a law that would allow creation of an international tribunal to try surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge, the Communist movement responsible for the deaths of more than a million people from 1975 to 1979. The law needs final approval by the Constitutional Council and King Norodom Sihanouk. It would then be reviewed by the United Nations, which must approve it before agreeing to take part in a Cambodian trial. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Bush Ponders Aid for Only Domestic Supplier of Reactor Fuel
description: With Soviet-era nuclear weapons now providing more than half the uranium that powers American nuclear power plants, the Bush administration is weighing whether to provide support for the only American company that enriches uranium for reactor fuel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBACH, DR. JOSEPH J.
description: MARBACH-Dr. Joseph J. Adoring husband of Judith Marbach. Devoted father of Claudia and Daniel, Emily and Tim, Ezra and Cecily. Dear brother of Lee Smith and Paula Nathan. Loving grandfather of Rachel, Noah, Rebecca, Sam, Akiva, Amos and Alice. Dr. Marbach was a compassionate doctor to his patients in the area of chronic facial pain and fibromyalgia. Dr. Marbach held the Robert and Susan Carmel Professor in Algesiology at University of Medicine and Dentistry of NJ with appointments at both dental school and the Department of Psychiatry. He also held joint appointments as lecturer at Columbia University at the Mailman School of Public Health and College of Physicians and Surgeons. Donations can be made to the NY Chapter of Hadassah. Funeral will be held today, 9:30 AM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam.

title: Hospitals Put Doctors in the Picture
description: Many hospital patients find it hard to figure out who their doctor is, given the bustle of doctors, residents, interns, nurses, technicians and assorted others in and out of their rooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELL, JOHN T.
description: CONNELL-John T., 77, July 22, 2001. He was a lifelong resident of the Bronx, parishioner of St. Brendan's Church, and a U.S. Army veteran, having served during WW II in Europe and the Pacific. An accountant for H.P.D. who was retired in 1985. Beloved husband of the late Mary Connell. Dear father of James J., John T. and his wife Maureen. Brother of Dorothy Connell and the late Eleanor Palmer. Also survived by four nieces and two nephews. Family and friends are invited to call Tuesday and Wednesday, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM at John F.X. McKeon & Son Funeral Home, 3129 Perry Avenue, Bronx. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Thursday at 9:45AM at St. Brendan's Church. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, CECILY B.
description: RYAN-Cecily B. Age 57, on July 21, 2001, of Garden City. Beloved wife of Charles Patrick. Loving mother of Shannon, Elizabeth, Catherine and Margaret and mother-in-law of Kevin O'Donnell and Christian Olivier. Dearest Lovie to Quinn. Cherished daughter of Cecily Blanco Brady and the late Leslie Blanco. Dear sister of Peter. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City, 7-9 PM, Monday, and 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10 AM, Wednesday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society, Garden City Unit, appreciated.

title: Mental Health Care: It's Time for Parity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVE, JOAN
description: BOVE-Joan. On July 21, 2001. 99 years and 9 months of love, laughter, and excitement. The families of Dick and Rusty Gelb, and Bruce and Lueza Gelb, and their children: Larry, Lucy, John, Jody, Jane, Richard, Connie, and Jimmy, and their children: Richard and Emily, Matthew and Andy, Nathaniel and Johnny, Serena, Lueza, and Dora, and baby Daniel, will always remember their wonderful Gigi with loving memories. Contributions in her name may be sent to The Red Cross. Funeral services will be private.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Executive Pessimism
description: German executives were more pessimistic in June than at any time in almost five years, according to a monthly survey. The Ifo institute's index of German business confidence declined for the 12th time in 13 months. The index, one of the most widely watched gauges for Europe's economy, is based on a survey of about 7,000 companies. The index declined to 89.5 from a revised 90.8 in May. Economists had expected a reading of 90.

title: Fast-Forward Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile yesterday, about George S. McGovern, the former senator who is the American representative to the United Nations' food agencies in Rome, referred incorrectly to his World War II service. He was a bomber pilot, not a fighter pilot.

title: 7 Die in Macedonian Clashes as Talks for Cease-Fire Continue
description: Heavy fighting broke out today in the town of Tetovo in western Macedonia between government forces and Macedonian Albanian rebels, killing at least seven villagers and wounding dozens.

title: Caribbean Bargains
description: Until the cold weather hits the Northeast, bargains are available at Caribbean destinations. Island Destinations has a five-night Summer Seclusion package at the Parrot Cay resort on the Turks and Caicos for $1,258 a person, double occupancy, good through Oct. 26. The company says that it represents a 60 percent savings at the resort, which occupies 50 acres on its own private island. The rate includes daily breakfast and dinner, one massage per guest, a beach-hideaway lunch, a fruit bowl replenished daily and all non-motorized water sports. The rate is based on availability and does not include air fare or 19 percent tax. There is also a seven-night package at the CuisinArt Resort and Spa on Anguilla for $1,655 a person, double occupancy. It is good through Nov. 16, but keep in mind that the resort is closed Sept. 4 to Oct. 26. The rate includes a few spa treatments, daily Continental breakfast, one lunch and dinner, nonmotorized water sports and a one-hour personal-training session. Information: (877) 902-2525 or www.islanddestinations.com .

title: Germ Warfare Talks Open in London; U.S. Is the Pariah
description: European nations and other major powers today urged the completion of a draft agreement to enforce the 1972 ban on biological weapons, a move that puts them at odds with the Bush administration.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES TO OPEN TALKS WITH PILOTS
description: American Airlines and the union for its 11,500 pilots plan to open contract negotiations formally today by exchanging initial proposals. The talks follow agreements that American, which is a unit of the AMR Corporation and is the largest airline company in the nation, reached with flight attendants and mechanics. The flight attendants still must vote on their tentative contract. The Allied Pilots Association approved a five-year agreement after the last contract negotiations in 1997.

title: Miscellany
description: * Allstate Corp., Northbrook, Ill., agreed for its Allstate Insurance Company unit to become the ''official'' home and automotive insurance sponsor for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City as well as for the 2002 and 2004 United States Olympic teams. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bush Offers Encouragement to Soldiers Serving in Kosovo
description: CAMP BONDSTEEL, Kosovo, July 24 -- Less than a year after he questioned during his presidential campaign whether American troops should remain in the Balkans, President Bush today told thousands of cheering troops at largest American military camp in Kosovo that "America's contribution is essential, both militarily and politically."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, FRANCES
description: FISCHER-Frances, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Grace Greenhut and Marvin, and Martin Fischer and Susan. Cherished grandmother of Bruce and Ellen Greenhut, Arlyne and Richard Hoffman, Nancy and Frank Levin, Elizabeth Fischer and Michael Fischer. Caring great-grandmother of Taylor Greenhut, Emily Hoffman, and Hannah and Jeremy Levin. May she rest peacefully with Paul. Graveside service Wednesday. Donations in her memory may be made to Hospice-by-the-Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486 or your favorite charity. For information: Plaza Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: At Bridge Championship, Familiar Winners
description: One of the world's most successful partnerships won another major title here on Sunday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, IRVING H.
description: SHERMAN-Irving H., who passed away July 21, 2001, had a front-row seat at many of the pivotal events of the 20th century. Born and raised in NYC, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School and attended Cornell University on scholarship. Mr. Sherman was a key member of A.G. Becker and Co., Inc., where his exacting but supportive leadership created an atmosphere that attracted the best of Wall Street. He was an active member and governor of the NY and American Stock Exchanges. After his retirement in 1967 and until his 100th birthday, he maintained offices at S.G. Cowen and later at Oppenheimer and Close, Inc. His knowledge of the century's best and most important investment banking underwritings demonstrated his intellectual strengths until the end. An expert in the commercial paper field, he led the marketing of German dollar bonds in the 1930's. Contacts Mr. Sherman made during this period provided the base of his aggressive help to the German Jewish community. He was personally involved in helping the escape of innumerable Jews and funneling funds to those in need. He was forced to end these activities in 1939, but his commitment to the Jewish community continued for the balance of his business career. At the start of WWII, he was recruited for the OSS, and after the war was involved in the reestablishment of the German banking system. Irv Sherman is survived by his loving wife of close to 60 years, Marie Vandeputte Sherman; two stepchildren, Richard Barzin of Marco Island, FL and Lora Childs of Spring Island, SC; a niece, Dr. Ruth Pike of State College, PA; a grand-nephew, Dr. Carl Pike; 7 grandchildren; 7 greatgrandchildren; and 2 great greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Cornell Club-NY on July 30 at 5 PM. Gifts may be made to the Sherman Scholarship Fund at Cornell University, 55 Brown Rd., Ithaca, NY 14850, or United Jewish Appeal.

title: Family Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; About Mutual Funds
description: As a result of growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is eliminating entries for some of the smallest ones and making its daily table more concise.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Real Estate Players
description: Prudential Financial's real estate unit and S L Green Realty Corporation, the New York-based property investor, have formed a venture to lend or invest as much as $250 million in Manhattan office buildings. Each company will have a half stake in the venture, said Theresa Miller, a Prudential spokeswoman. The move continues a partnership that Prudential, based in Newark, and S L Green began in 1999, when they paid about $192 million for 100 Park Avenue, an office building near Grand Central Terminal.

title: More to It Than Games
description: With security certain to be a major issue at the 2004 Summer Games, seven countries with extensive counterterrorism experience have joined to offer training and intelligence to Greek law enforcement authorities.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the indictment of a Manhattan Boy Scout leader, Jerrold Schwartz, on charges that he molested a troop member misstated the location of his office and the number of counts against him. It is 36 counts of sodomy, not 38. The office is on East 80th Street, opposite his apartment, not in the same building.

title: Trading Unit on the Move
description: Banc of America Securities, one of the 25 primary dealers that trade directly with the Federal Reserve, is moving its Treasury trading desk to New York from San Francisco.

title: Stocks Slide as Worries Persist on Corporate Earnings
description: Stocks fell across the board today as investors grew increasingly frustrated by weak profit reports and by corporate projections that offered few specifics and fewer positive ones.

title: Spanish Utility to Buy an Italian Generator
description: Endesa, Spain's largest power company, agreed today to buy Elettrogen of Italy for 3.69 billion euros ($3.2 billion) to become the third-largest generator in Italy. It beat 11 rivals in an eight-month auction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODNER, ROSALIE
description: RODNER-Rosalie, ninety, of White Plains, NY on July 22, 2001. Loving wife of the late B. Robert Rodner. Beloved mother of Stephen and Jon Rodner. Devoted grandmother to Jason, Barrie, Robert, Kristine and Peter Rodner. Loving sister of Sylvan Taplinger and Doris Gottlieb.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Fall 31% At Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments, whose chips run two-thirds of the world's cellular phones, reported a second-quarter loss of $197 million, or 11 cents a share, in contrast to income of $1.3 billion, or 72 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 31 percent, to $2.04 billion. The company also forecast a loss for the third quarter.

title: 3rd Suspect Surrenders in Killing Of Driver Who Offered a Ride
description: A 26-year-old Brooklyn man turned himself in to the police yesterday in the shooting death of an Indian immigrant who offered him and four other stranded passengers a ride early Friday morning, the authorities said.

title: Democrats Try to Work Up A Shield Plan of Their Own
description: With the Bush administration moving briskly toward a missile shield, a group of national security experts in the Democratic Party is pushing Congressional Democrats to unite around an alternative that they contend would be less costly and less threatening to arms control agreements.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Anger Over Police Tactics In Genoa
description: The interior minister set off an angry debate in Parliament while seeking to defend police tactics to quell rioting at the summit meeting of industrial nations in Genoa last weekend. Street clashes left one protester dead and hundreds of police officers and demonstrators wounded. Dozens of the foes of globalization were hurt during a Sunday morning raid on a protest organizer's headquarters. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi pledged $6.7 million to Genoa to pay for the damage. Genoa city officials estimated the cost at close to $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOGARTY, GERARD W.
description: HOGARTY-Gerard W. 7/24/91. We continue to celebrate the joy of your life. Mother, Tim, Family and Friend

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, KATHARINE
description: GRAHAM-Katharine. The 52nd Street Project offers its sympathy and best wishes to our dear friend and Board Chair Stephen Graham and to the entire Graham family upon the death of Katharine Graham, whose extraordinary life serves as inspiration to us all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIVNICK, ESTELLE (NEE TUROVITZ)
description: SLIVNICK-Estelle (nee Turovitz). Beloved wife of Dr. Maurice, loving mother of Bruce (Judy), David (Barbara), and Sari (Billy) London. Proud and devoted grandmother of Steven, Ben, Brian, Jeremy, Elyssa, Stephanie, and Ashley. Cherished sister of Toby (Sheldon) Alter, and Barbara (Aaron) Klein. Adored aunt of many nieces and nephews. Funeral services and interment were held in Chicago on Monday July 23rd. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Chicago Symphony Orchestra Adventures in Music, 220 South Michigan Avenue, Chicago, Ill 60604 or Sloan Kettering Cancer Research Foundation, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021. Info: 1-800-288-5701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYKOCINSKI, JOSEPH
description: TYKOCINSKI-Joseph. ''He who saves one life, it is as if he has saved the entire world.'' Righteous ba'al chesed, extraordinary human being, hero of the Shoah and hero to us. He defied the darkness and illuminated many worlds. Our love to Lily, Mark and Judy, Annette and Joseph, and all the grandchildren. Yehi zichro baruch. Tobi, Nessa, Josh, Mattie, Doria

title: Powell Returns to Vietnam
description: HANOI, July 24 — Almost 40 years after he first slogged through the jungles of South Vietnam as an Army officer, Colin L. Powell, arrived as Secretary of State today in the capital of his former enemy, bringing with him memories of American friends who perished in a war he has caustically called "a conspiracy of illusion" and the Vietnamese colleagues who suffered mightily after he left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKWOOD, ELLEN BANKS (BONNIE)
description: ROCKWOOD-Ellen Banks (Bonnie). July 19, 2001. At home in Scituate, MA. Survived by her son David Rockwood III, her mother Marian L.
