Banks, her sister Susan Banks Edmands, her beloved companion Mark Handrahan. Private memorial service. Contributions can be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Boston.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sales Down At Computer Associates
description: Computer Associates International of Islandia, N.Y., whose software manages mainframe and network computers, reported a first-quarter loss yesterday of $342 million, or 59 cents a share, in contrast to profit of $23 million, or 4 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell to $713 million from $1.14 billion. Sam Wyly, a shareholder and Texas billionaire, is waging a proxy fight to replace the board and fire the top executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBNER, IDA
description: GIBNER-Ida. 88 years. Beloved aunt and friend. Last of a kind, Russia to New York. Services were held July 23, 2001.

title: Grappling With the Ethics of Stem Cell Research
description: Can life be preserved at the expense of other life? The use of human embryonic stem cells presents a tight tangle of ethical questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANKEN, SYLVIA RITA
description: PANKEN-Sylvia Rita. Beloved wife, loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Services private. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Recipe for a Refuge in Louisiana: Wetlands, Wading Birds, Oil Wells
description: Louisiana is rich in both wealth-producing and awe-inspiring natural resources, but nearly a fifth of its residents are poor, and politics and pollution often threaten its wild treasures.

title: House Passes Bill to Create New Monitor For the F.B.I.
description: The House of Representatives today approved the creation of a new position within the Justice Department's inspector general's office to watch over the F.B.I., which has been under heavy fire in Congress for a series of investigative mishaps, managerial breakdowns and supervisory lapses.

title: Indonesia Gets A New Leader; Ex-Chief Balks
description: In the most peaceful transfer of power in Indonesia's history, Megawati Sukarnoputri was sworn in as president today, moments after the nation's top legislative body voted to cut short the fractious and rudderless tenure of her predecessor.

title: Isolated on Global Warming
description: A wallflower at what might have been its own victory party, the United States could only watch yesterday as 178 countries agreed on a deal that salvages the 1997 Kyoto Protocol and commits the rest of the industrialized world to orderly, mandatory reductions in the gases that are believed responsible for the warming of the earth's atmosphere. The door was left open for the Bush administration to sign on at any time in the future. But that seems unlikely. President Bush has already called the treaty ''fatally flawed,'' and nothing said yesterday by Paula Dobriansky, the under secretary of state who led an essentially irrelevant American delegation at the talks, suggested any change in Mr. Bush's thinking.

title: LA-Z-BOY CREATES TWO NEW PRODUCT GROUPS
description: La-Z-Boy Inc., the maker of its namesake reclining chairs, created separate groups for its upholstery and casegoods to use manufacturing capacity more effectively and market more products together. The casegoods group makes dressers, chests and other wood furniture for bedrooms, living and dining rooms. La-Z-Boy, based in Monroe, Mich., has increased to 16 operating companies from 8 in 1999, the company said. The upholstery group includes the Bauhaus, Centurion, Clayton Marcus, England, HickoryMark, La-Z-Boy and Sam Moore brands. The casegoods group includes Alexvale, American Drew, Hammary, Kincaid, Lea, Pennsylvania House and Pilliod.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELKIN, LES
description: NELKIN-Les. The Board of Columbia/Barnard Hillel mourns with deepest sorrow the untimely passing of Les Nelkin. As a Founder of the Kraft Center for Jewish Student Life, the Nelkin Family Foundation has been a devoted supporter. Our heartfelt condolences to Les's parents, Ruth and Harold Nelkin, and to his sister, Amy. May his memory be a blessing. Prof. Robert Pollack, President Earle W. Kazis, Chairman Arthur O. Sulzberger, Chairman, Executive Committee Rabbi Charles H. Sheer, Jewish Chaplain Joanne Ben Avi, Director of Development

title: GE CAPITAL TO ACQUIRE DANISH CREDIT CARD BUSINESS
description: GE Capital, the largest nonbank finance company and a unit of the General Electric Company, plans to buy the Danish credit card unit of Gjensidige Nor Sparebank of Norway for about $66.5 million. The credit card business, AcceptFinans, has a total loan portfolio of $151 million, according to GE Capital, which is based in Stamford, Conn. AcceptFinans will become part of GE Capital's Global Consumer Finance unit, which already employs about 400 people in Scandinavia, mostly in Sweden.

title: Bishop of Peoria Is Front-Runner For Newark Job
description: A bishop from a largely rural diocese in Illinois who is known primarily for his orthodox stance on Catholic teachings is expected to become the spiritual leader for 1.3 million Roman Catholics who live in a heavily urban swath of northern New Jersey, according to church leaders.

title: To Be Young and in Search of the Higgs Boson
description: Real estate in this resort town, which cascades down a mountainside a few miles northwest of Aspen, can run over $1,000 a square foot. Compare that with the roughly $6 billion, without furnishings, that senior physicists at a meeting here this month said they needed for a new machine to track down exotic particles weighing about the same as a single silver atom left in the ground from the region's hardscrabble mining past.

title: Lucent Nears A Deal to Sell Optical Unit to Furukawa
description: As part of its long-running effort to raise badly needed cash, Lucent Technologies is close to an agreement to sell its fiber optic business to the Furukawa Electric Company and Corning Inc. for about $2.75 billion, executives close to the talks said last night.

title: Along the 'Death Trap,' a Wariness Born of Past Losses
description: Jennifer Bridgeforth has not dipped as much as a toe in the ocean since the summer of 1974, when the undertow sucked her beneath the water and the riptides began to drag her out to sea after she went for a swim in what the people of Far Rockaway call the death trap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, BERNICE H.
description: ROSNER-Bernice H. The staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York express their deep sorrow at the loss of Bernice H. Rosner, a leading figure in home and community-based health care for more than 50 years. A former Associate Executive Director of VNSNY and, later, CEO of the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, she will be missed for her lifelong commitment to the nursing profession and the highest standards in home care. Carol Raphael, President and CEO, Visiting Nurse Service of New York

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Connecting the Dots

title: An Opera Festival's Homage to the 20th Century
description: As its nod to the centenary of Verdi's death this year, Aix-en-Provence's opera festival has presented ''Falstaff.'' And for its annual tribute to Mozart, it has a new ''Marriage of Figaro'' and a revived ''Magic Flute.'' Yet for the second year running it is a 20th-century opera that has won the most accolades here. Last year, it was Janacek's ''Makropulos Case.'' At this festival, which ends on July 29, it is Britten's ''Turn of the Screw.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Securities Concern Posts Profit
description: Korea's second-largest brokerage firm, the Hyundai Securities Company, said it returned to profit in its fiscal first quarter, after losing money in the 2000 period on bonds sold by companies in the failed Daewoo Group. The company earned 74.3 billion won ($57 million) in the three months through June, in contrast to an 81.8 billion won loss in the period last year, said a spokesman, Kim Hyung Joo.

title: Scientists Are Starting to Add Letters to Life's Alphabet
description: Scientists are taking the first steps toward creating alternative life forms -- organisms that use a genetic code different from the one used by all other creatures on earth.

title: Will U.S. Resume Aid? That Depends on Jakarta
description: In the months leading up to President Abdurrahman Wahid's removal as president yesterday, American State Department officials and the National Security Council developed a contingency plan that calls for the quick resumption of economic aid to Jakarta if his successor, Megawati Sukarnoputri, begins to carry out economic reforms.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Aiming At A Tycoon
description: Malaysia's government offered to pay 3.72 billion ringgit ($979 million) to buy the construction company United Engineers Malaysia, a deal that would give it control of an affiliated conglomerate, the Renong Group, from the tycoon Halim Saad. Renong became a storehouse of ruling-coalition commercial interests two decades ago, and Mr. Saad was installed at its helm as a model of ethnic Malay entrepreneurship. During the Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998, however, Renong emerged as the nation's largest debtor. The government stood by as Mr. Saad shuffled assets rather than sell them, becoming emblematic to disenchanted foreign investors of the country's refusal to make the political sacrifices that accompany economic reform. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I prefer an imperfect agreement that is living than a perfect agreement that doesn't exist.''

title: AOL Invests $100 Million In Amazon.com
description: With sales falling short of expectations, Amazon.com said yesterday that it had received a $100 million investment from AOL Time Warner. That investment was part of a broader deal in which AOL will buy technology from Amazon to operate its online shopping channels.

title: Fourth Condit Interview Is Possible, Washington Police Say
description: Washington police officials may seek to interview Representative Gary A. Condit for a fourth time in their investigation of the disappearance of the government intern Chandra Ann Levy, a police spokesman said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Stock Rises At Next Level
description: Shares of Next Level Communications Inc. rose 41 percent after the company said it had developed enhancements that reduced the cost of residential broadband services, a move the company hoped would lead to higher sales. Shares rose $1.65, to $5.65. The company announced that a breakthrough in the technology for its high-speed digital-subscriber line would reduce the installation cost by 33 percent a subscriber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, DAPHNE
description: SCHER-Daphne. We join in mourning a past President, Daphne Scher, whose memory will hold a special place in all our hearts. For the 45 years she served us, Daphne touched many lives. Services will be held Tuesday, July 24, at 1:30pm at Mt Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale. Pat Roberts, President Volunteer Auxiliary, North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Sex Offense Ruling Is Upheld
description: The State Supreme Court upheld a ruling that would free many sex offenders from parole and state prisons. The state attorney general, Ken Salazar, had asked for a rehearing last month after the court ruled on conflicting legislation concerning the parole of sex offenders. The latest ruling will free 70 sex offenders from prison on Wednesday and hundreds more from parole soon. Sex offenders must still register with the state.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about subway service changes that took effect over the weekend referred incorrectly to the route for the new Special Shuttle. It will end at Broadway-Lafayette Street; it will not be extended to the West Fourth Street station until November. A correction on Sunday referring to a map of the route was published in error; the map was correct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, GRACE BORGENICHT
description: BRANDT-Grace Borgenicht. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their colleague, a founding member of ADAA. A great dealer, a great person, warm and generous, one of a kind, her memory is cherished by us all. Our sympathy and condolences to her husband, Warren; to her children, Jan, Berta, Lois and Isabella; to her sister, her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Richard Gray, President Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin. V.P.

title: Pressure to Pray
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Seeks to Put Japan First, but U.S. May Find Itself Left Out
description: On his trip to Asia, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell insisted that Japan, with which Washington wants to strengthen its ties, would be the first port of call. By going out of his way to put Tokyo at the top of his five-nation list -- if only for seven waking hours -- the secretary wanted to demonstrate Japan's importance to the United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Tour on the Tube: It's Live and Elusive
description: The Tour de France is one of those great sports events that has eluded live coverage in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JOHN T. (JACK)
description: GALLAGHER-John T. (Jack). On July 22, 2001. Formerly of John T. Gallagher Funeral Home, Church Ave. Beloved husband of Mary Kay. Devoted father of Katherine, Joanne Oplustil, J. T. Jr, Arthur, Eileen Cullen and Edward. Also survived by nine wonderful grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at their residence, 196 Marlboro Rd, Monday 7-9, and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, Holy Innocence R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers in memoriums to CAMBA, 1720 Church Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11226, deeply appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chip Maker Surges
description: Shares of ARM Holdings rose 16 percent after the semiconductor maker said its second-quarter profit rose 23 percent. The British company, which makes chips for mobile phones and electronic games like Nintendo's Game Boy Advance, reported net income of 8.3 million ($11.8 million), or 1 pence a share, compared with 6.7 million last year. Revenue climbed 56 percent, to 36 million. Despite the broad economic slowdown, ARM said its customers had continued to place orders for semiconductors as they experimented with new products. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Wal-Mart Assumes Complete Control of Its Online Store
description: In a move that executives described as ''more evolutionary than revolutionary,'' Wal-Mart Stores announced yesterday that it had bought out the minority stake in Walmart.com held by Accel Partners, the California venture capital firm.

title: New Agency Opens in New York
description: Interference Inc., a new agency that specializes in alternatives to traditional advertising, is being opened in New York by Sam Travis Ewen, chief executive, and Michael Glickman, president. Mr. Ewen, 32, had been president at Eisnor Interactive in New York, which closed. Mr. Glickman, 33, had been president at Performance Event Marketing in New York, which is being absorbed into Interference.

title: Houston Gets Big Money And Vows to Justify It
description: Allan Houston was standing before dozens of news media members and Knicks employees yesterday, thanking the many people who played a role in his becoming the highest-paid player in franchise history, when he suddenly sensed a bit of skepticism from the crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADATO, ROBERT K.
description: LADATO-Robert K., real estate broker with Douglas Elliman Inc., NY. Son of Joseph Ladato. Brother of Janice Van Der Veken. Visitation on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Krowicki McCracken Funeral Home, 2124 East St. Georges Avenue, Linden, NJ. Funeral mass Wednesday, Trinity Episcopal Church, Cranford, NJ. 10:30 AM.

title: SARA LEE'S ACQUISITION OF EARTHGRAINS IS APPROVED
description: The Sara Lee Corporation's $2.8 billion acquisition of the Earthgrains Company was cleared by federal regulators. Sara Lee's tender offer of $40.25 for each Earthgrains share will expire at midnight on July 31. The transaction will make Sara Lee, the nation's biggest maker of frozen pies and cakes, the nation's second-largest bread company.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Ruling Expels Flag T-Shirts
description: A federal judge ruled that Seminole County students could not wear T-shirts with the Confederate flag to school, a victory for school officals and parents who feel the shirts are divisive. The judge, W. Louis Sands of United States District Court for the Middle District of Georgia, is expected to issue a final ruling in 60 days. Nine students, some parents and the American Civil Liberties Union sued the county school board, saying a policy that banned anything ''that might be offensive to others'' was arbitrary.

title: A Nervy Russian Soul For Verdian Heroics
description: Months in advance of the Kirov Opera's two-week ''Tribute to Verdi'' engagement at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden, every ticket was sold. Part of the keen interest here was due to the enormously successful London visit by the St. Petersburg company last season, when Valery Gergiev, the charismatic conductor and, since 1996, the general and artistic director of the Mariinsky Theater, as the Kirov Opera and Ballet are formally known, presented four Russian operas, including a critically hailed production of Prokofiev's daunting ''War and Peace.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Blast Kills 38 Coal Miners
description: At least 38 coal miners were killed by an explosion on Sunday at an illegal mine in Jiangsu province and dozens were missing, state news media reported. The mine, near the eastern Chinese city of Xuzhou, had been closed in mid-June because of safety concerns. The reports said the mine owner had been arrested. Thousands of coal miners die in China's mines each year. Earlier this month, 21 miners were killed when a mine flooded in Jilin, a northeastern province. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Official in a Cuban Exile Group Resigns, Exposing a Rift
description: Amid growing tension in the leading organization for Cuban exiles over how hard its anti-Castro stance should be, one of the group's most prominent members has resigned, saying today that the group was being run like the dictatorship it was created to oppose.

title: Webb Pitching In for Spinal-Injury Research
description: With a great deal of help from her friends in the L.P.G.A., Karrie Webb's Celebrity Pro-Am to benefit the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation has grown considerably in just two years. An auction at a dinner reception Sunday night and an invitation-only golf outing here today at Manhattan Woods Golf Club raised about $200,000.

title: New Footprints in 3 Distinct Styles
description: Three promising young choreographers made quiet magic from mostly simple ingredients on Saturday night at the Puffin Room in SoHo.

title: Breast-Feeding and Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Will Not Make City Build Expensive Water Filtration Plant
description: The federal government has offered New York City a way out of having to design a multibillion-dollar water filtration plant in exchange for a promise to improve its water quality in other ways, including a much cheaper ultraviolet treatment plant.

title: Different Stories on Birth Control
description: One thing a married couple might be expected to agree on would be whether to practice birth control. But in many cases, a new study finds, that is not so.

title: U.S. Envoy Takes Up Chinese Post, Seeking to Clear Up Cloudy Ties
description: The new American ambassador to China, Clark T. Randt, took up his post here today, delivering a brief, upbeat statement in Chinese that underscored his past experience in the country.

title: Don't Dismiss the Genoa Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Teacher Raises Are Approved
description: Despite waning tax collections, the Legislature voted overwhelmingly to lock in a package of teacher raises designed to lift average salaries to more than $41,000 by the 2005-2006 school year. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, a Democrat, called lawmakers into the one-day special session to repeal a provision that tied the raises to a 5 percent growth in state tax collections.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Online List Of Sex Offenders
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed a bill yesterday to establish a list of sex offenders to be posted on the Internet. The online registry will list the names, addresses, photographs and vehicle information of what are termed moderate and high-risk sex offenders. ''The registry will still give parents information about sex offenders who live near their homes, but unlike the current community notification program, it will also let them research offenders who may live near the place their children play or go to school,'' said State Senator Joseph F. Vitale, one of the bill's sponsors.

title: When Privacy Is a Credit Risk
description: Spurred by polls showing that the public is concerned about maintaining personal privacy, federal and state legislators have proposed a blizzard of legislation. In Congress, many of these bills would require explicit consent from customers before their financial information could be transferred to a third party. A law like this sounds reasonable to many people, and it would certainly protect privacy, but at great cost to consumers.

title: Adobe Opposes Prosecution in Hacking Case
description: In an unexpected turnaround, Adobe Systems called yesterday for the release of a Russian programmer accused of violating American copyright law after he helped create software that can crack Adobe's security software for electronic books.

title: After 46 Years of Sales, Thyroid Drug Needs F.D.A. Approval
description: On July 12, the Food and Drug Administration told Abbott Laboratories to submit a new drug application by Aug. 14 for its thyroid drug, Synthroid, or begin taking the product off the market.

title: Taking Care of Gracie Mansion
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has given landmark status to more than 22,000 buildings, thus protecting them from demolition or alterations that might destroy their historical uniqueness. One of the most venerable landmarks is Gracie Mansion, the official mayoral residence for more than 60 years, which is now looking shabby. The commission has occasionally sued building owners who failed to keep landmarks in ''sound repair,'' and it must issue a permit before a landmark can get a fresh coat of paint. As of yesterday the commission said it had yet to receive a permit application for painting the mansion, whose peeling paint and rotting balcony railings have become an embarrassment to the city. This vulnerable wood-frame structure deserves more care than Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his estranged wife, Donna Hanover, have been giving it.

title: Rx for War Zone Workers
description: Like many children of the 60's, David Kuhns dreamed of joining the Peace Corps right out of high school. And like most teenagers, he didn't have any skills to offer. So he studied to become a physician assistant, and in 1994 applied to go overseas with the aid group Doctors Without Borders.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Dr. Arthur F. Davidsen, an astrophysicist at Johns Hopkins University, misspelled the given name of his wife. She is Frauke Davidsen, not Krauke.

title: Eudora Welty, a Lyrical Master Of the Short Story, Is Dead at 92
description: Eudora Welty, whose evocative short stories, notable for their imagery, sharp dialogue and fierce wit, made her a revered figure in contemporary American letters, died yesterday at a hospital near her home in Jackson, Miss. She was 92.

title: Stockbrokers in India Go on Strike
description: Stockbrokers across India went on strike for a day today to protest the market regulator's effort to force brokers to settle trades on the day they are made rather than waiting as long as two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTERMANN, BERTHA W. (BERT)
description: HOLTERMANN-Bertha W. (Bert) Of Jamaica Estates, age 97, on July 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Jr., loving mother of the late Eleanor Rehman and Henry J. III, dear sister of Louise Ilse and proud grandmother of Lisa and James Rehman. She brought much joy and laughter to our lives. Services will be private.

title: BUSH PANEL BACKS LEGALIZING STATUS OF SOME MIGRANTS
description: A cabinet-level panel has recommended that President Bush endorse a limited plan allowing some of the estimated three million Mexicans living in the United States illegally to apply for permanent legal status, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Yankees Help Clemens Add to His Milestones
description: David Wells was New York's favorite son when he departed and Roger Clemens was the ugly stepchild when he arrived. Clemens was treated like hired help at Yankee Stadium: appropriate applause when he won, vociferous boos when he struggled, a simple and cold business arrangement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILER, ELIZABETH
description: WEILER-Elizabeth. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Elizabeth Weiler. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Gilbert Klaperman Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Profit Increase At Check Point
description: Check Point Software Technologies, a maker of Internet security software, said yesterday that profits doubled as it continued to gain market share. The company reported revenue of $142.1 million for the second quarter and net income of $86.8 million, or 33 cents a share. It earned $43.7 million, or 17 cents a share, in the period a year ago. It attributed its growth to expanded partnerships, strong attendance at its conferences and demand for its new software. Shares rose $1.15, to $36.57. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Tunnel Vision; A Couple of New Twists Thrown Into the Rat Race
description: Here is a good example of how yesterday morning went for William Finkel, train service supervisor.

title: Redbook Gets An Editor Back
description: The founding editor of O: The Oprah Magazine, Ellen Kunes, is back at Hearst Magazines, this time as editor in chief of Redbook Magazine, which has a circulation of 2.2 million.

title: Pakistan Reckons With a Rising India
description: Earlier this month, in the small north Indian city of Agra, the leaders of India and Pakistan met to discuss the troubled relationship that has led them into four wars in the last five decades. The Taj Mahal, a symbol of eternal love, seemed an appropriate backdrop to their efforts: the marble monument was built by Shah Jehan, the 17th-century Mogul emperor, in memory of his wife, who had died young. There also appeared something reconciliatory in the choice of venue by India's ruling Hindu nationalist party, which is not known for its affection for Muslim-built cities and monuments -- the party rose to power after destroying, in 1992, a 16th-century mosque it thought expressed a Mogul invader's contempt for Hindus.

title: Q & A
description: How Now, Brown Cow?

title: After Years in Navy, Retirement With the Fishes
description: At noon today, the old Navy dormitory barge, a squat, three-story maritime row house known by the inelegant name APL-31, rolled gently at anchor in the Atlantic about 16 miles off Manasquan. Five minutes later, the dull thud of explosives rocked the 261-foot ship, and puffs of gray and brown smoke rose from its bow and stern.

title: Albany Ponders a Bare-Bones Bill to End Budget Gridlock
description: After nearly four months of stalemate over the state's budget, Assembly and Senate leaders are considering passing a stripped-down version of the governor's spending plan and then resolving major disagreements in a supplementary budget later this year.

title: Rebels Attack 2 Crucial Airports In Sri Lanka on Riot Anniversary
description: Separatist Tamil rebels sneaked through a security cordon in the pre-dawn darkness this morning to attack an air force base and the nation's only international airport just 18 miles north of the capital, military officials said.

title: Ties to a Neighborhood At Root of Court Fight
description: Property owners in an old waterfront neighborhood argued today that their lifelong ties to their community would be destroyed if the city proceeded to demolish their buildings as part of a sweeping redevelopment plan.

title: Napster Will Name New Chief Executive
description: Napster, the online song-sharing service and recording industry pariah, will name Konrad Hilbers, a former executive from the media company Bertelsmann, as its chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODGLASS, IRWIN M.
description: GOODGLASS-Irwin M., of Fort Lee, NJ, and Boca Raton, Fla. Beloved husband of Natalie (nee Brown). Devoted father of Steven Goodglass, Scott Weiner, Jed Weiner and Myra Fender. Loving grandfather of Jesse, Lauren, Jessica, Benjamin, Adam, Kyle, Brandon and Shana. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ, on Tuesday at 3 PM. Family to receive family and friends at the residence, Tuesday evening and Wednesday. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Smoking May Reduce Fertility in Women
description: Women who smoke may be reducing their chances of having a baby, a new study finds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERO, ELYSE
description: SPERO-Elyse. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our Board member, Zev Weissberg, upon the untimely passing of his sister. May the families be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Kebran Gabriel Journal; On Monks' and Nuns' Islands, 'You Have Only God'
description: Two decades ago, recalled Brother Gabriel Selassie, he was a 49-year-old farmer with a big family and a big midlife crisis. He was tilling his land one morning, as was his wont, when he threw down his plow, ran away from home and became a monk.

title: What Stinks? Here's a Theory: Rotting Sea Plants
description: Marine scientists at Rutgers University think they have a plausible theory to explain the nose-wrinkling odors that prompted complaints from as far south as Atlantic City and as far north and inland as Morris County over the weekend.

title: 1, 2, 3: Connecticut, New York And New Jersey Lead in Taxes
description: Connecticut, New York and New Jersey rank first, second and third among the 50 states in state and local taxes, and New York is the runaway leader in local taxes, a new Census Bureau study shows.

title: Sports of The Times; The Rule That Haunts Woosnam
description: IT'S rule 4-4, but it doesn't stand for back-to-back par 4's. It's been in ''The Rules of Golf'' since 1938: The player shall start a round with ''not more than 14 clubs.''

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER BUYING 1,200 BARGES
description: The American Electric Power Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 1,200 barges and 30 towboats from Progress Energy Inc. for $270 million, tripling the size of its inland shipping fleet and enlarging its territory. The barges can handle coal, ore, grain or other dry-bulk commodities, said Pat Hemlepp, an American Electric spokesman. The transaction is expected to close in 60 days, immediately adding to earnings, he said. American Electric is buying Memco Barge Line, a St. Louis-based unit of Progress, which is based in Raleigh, N.C. Memco operates on the Mississippi River and its tributaries in Tennessee and Alabama, and along the Gulf of Mexico, Mr. Hemlepp said. Before the acquisition, American Electric owned 605 barges and 15 towboats on the Ohio River.

title: AT&T Reports a Loss; Long-Distance Is Weak
description: AT&T reported a loss in the second quarter yesterday, hampered by the swift erosion of revenue from long-distance operations and a $1-billion-plus plunge in the value of an Internet-related investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAYER, DOROTHY DENNISON
description: NAYER-Dorothy Dennison, who spent most of her life in New York City, died on July 21, in Oakland, CA. She was 90 years old and will be remembered for her contribution to the field of nursing education. As one of nursing's early pioneers, she fought to professionalize the field by advocating for college-based nursing programs. Born in Altoona, PA, on May 2, 1911, she graduated from the Mt. Sinai School of Nursing in 1932, and went on to receive a B.S. and M.A. from Teachers College, Columbia University. Her professional career in nursing included teaching at the University of Michigan and at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, as well as being assistant director of the American Nurses Association. She was Associate Editor of the American Journal of Nursing from 1962-1973. She is survived by Dr. Herman R. Nayer, her husbnd of 59 years, daughters Anne and Louise Nayer, son-inlaw Jim Patten and granddaughers Sarah, Laura and Lily, all of whom reside in California. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date.

title: Tunnel in Baltimore Is Cleared of Train
description: Five days after a freight train derailed and caught fire in a Baltimore tunnel, crews pulled out the last smoldering boxcar. Firefighters had battled the blaze since Wednesday afternoon, when it began on a CSX train 60 feet underground in the 1.7-mile-long tunnel. The fire, billowing black smoke, snarled traffic and forced the cancellation of three Orioles games. The derailment of the train, which was carrying hazardous chemicals, wood and paper, is under investigation. Inspectors went through the tunnel yesterday afternoon, and it will be reopened to traffic on Tuesday morning. Because of safety concerns, part of Howard Street, a main street above the tunnel, remained closed.

title: A Day After Seeing Putin, a Harder-Line Bush Emerges
description: President Bush said today that ''time is of the essence'' in his new arms talks with Moscow and warned that he would move ahead with testing missile shield technology even if he did not reach an agreement that would scrap the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Landmark Hearing
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission will hold a regularly scheduled public session. Public hearing room, 100 Old Slip, Manhattan, 9 a.m. Information: (212) 487-6782.

title: The 2nd Artificial Heart: Patients Are Ready, but Not Surgeons
description: As the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart enters his fourth week with the device, his surgeons say his recovery continues to exceed their expectations. The hopeful news raises a critical question: who will be the next to receive an AbioCor implant?

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Index Of Chip Orders Rises
description: A closely followed measure of demand for chip-making equipment rose in June, the second consecutive increase after hitting its lowest point in a decade. Semiconductor Equipment Materials International, a trade group, said North American manufacturers took in $705 million in June for a book-to-bill ratio of 0.54, which means that equipment makers booked $54 in orders for every $100 in shipments.

title: Don't Dismiss the Genoa Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about subway service changes that took effect over the weekend referred incorrectly to the route for the new Special Shuttle. It will end at Broadway-Lafayette Street; it will not be extended to the West Fourth Street station until November. A correction on Sunday referring to a map of the route was published in error; the map was correct.

title: Judge Grants Couple's Wish For Mercy
description: For perhaps the 20th time, Lawrence Watkins and Gayle Greene Watkins made the journey yesterday from their Upper East Side home to the Brooklyn courthouse where they have watched the wheels of justice do their small part to grind away the grief.

title: Judge Grants Car Insurer a Big Rate Increase
description: In another chapter of the roiling debate over the high cost of auto insurance in New Jersey, a judge has ruled in favor of a substantial rate increase for one of the state's largest insurers.

title: Screaming Media to Acquire Stockpoint
description: ScreamingMedia idsrc="NASDAQ" value="SCRM"/>, whose shares have fallen 83 percent since its initial public offering in August, agreed yesterday to buy Stockpoint, a financial data provider, for $21.6 million in stock, cash and debt.

title: From a Noxious Landfill to a Nurturing Colony for Artisans
description: The lush peaks and valleys of this Blue Ridge community have long been home to some of the nation's finest craft workshops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHOLLAND, REV. H.
description: MULHOLLAND-Rev. H., Charles entered into eternal life, on July 21, 2001. Retired priest of the Diocese of Raleigh, NC. Born in NYC, graduate of Bishop Loughlin Memorial HS, US merchant Marine Academy and Catholic University. Veteran of WWII. Beloved brother of Mary Costabile, Catherine Tessitore, Joseph, Robert, Thomas and Peter. Reposing at William E. Law Funeral Home, Massapequa, NY (516) 541-8070 on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Resurrection on Thursday at 11:00am at Maria Regina RC Church, Seaford, NY. In memory of his passion for justice and peace, donations may be made to PAX Christi, 532 West Eighth Street, Erie, PA 16502-1343.

title: When a Badge Is Seen, Views Vary; After Louima, New Yorkers Are Split on Police Progress
description: It was a little after 4 o'clock last Tuesday afternoon, and two teenagers had just been shot to death at Church Avenue and Raleigh Place in central Brooklyn. As the police descended, the curious gathered behind yellow crime-scene tape.

title: Family Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Not Running For Governor
description: Representative Martin T. Meehan said he had abandoned the idea of running for governor and decided to seek re-election to Congress. Mr. Meehan, a Democrat, is perhaps best known as a sponsor of the Shays-Meehan campaign finance bill, which stalled in the House of Representatives this month. Mr. Meehan, 44, had been considered possibly a front-runner among Democrats in the governor's race. His Fifth District was in danger of being eliminated in redistricting, but state Democratic officials say that could change now. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, RAE P.
description: WESTON-Rae P. In her 91st year. Beloved wife of the late Milton R. Weston. Dearly loved mother of Joyce Engler and Harold Weston. Cherished mother-in-law of Berl Engler and Bernice Weston. Adored grandmother of Pam and Bruce Bieber. Loving great-grandmother of Alec and Harrison Bieber. Devoted sister of Anne P. Lipkind. Gracious, generous, tenderhearted, fun loving and wise. Will forever be remembered.

title: Literary Fishing Hole Gets a For-Sale Sign; Bookshop Seeking Less Chaotic Home
description: The Gotham Book Mart is putting its cluttered West 47th Street townhouse up for sale and plans to move to a new modern home, replacing the cozy jumble that has attracted bibliophiles and browsers for more than 50 years.

title: Guilty Verdicts in Brokerage Fraud Case
description: A jury in New York state court returned guilty verdicts yesterday in the government's stock manipulation case against the A. S. Goldmen & Company brokerage firm, its former owner and several former employees.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Marriages and Baby Carriages

title: Accounts
description: * CHS/Community Health Systems, Brentwood, Tenn., to Doe Anderson, Louisville, to handle its account, which had been at Xor, Tulsa, Okla. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, ERNEST L.
description: FEIN-Ernest L. 88 years. Beloved husband of Jean, devoted father of Robin Elson and Alan and father-in-law of Robert. Cherished grandfather of Zach and Oliver. Survived by his brother Burt and loving nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday, July 24th, 2001 at 10am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave (at 10th St), NY, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Parkinson Foundation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Die In Apartment Fire
description: A man and a woman died of smoke inhalation early yesterday after a fast-moving fire engulfed their Flatbush apartment. The police identified them as Gerald Poitier, 47, and Lisa Ellison, 39, of 1352 New York Avenue. The couple's son, Gerald Jr., 3, was rescued by firefighters and was being treated for smoke inhalation at Kings County Hospital Center. The couple were pronounced dead at the hospital, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: Deflation of an Optimist, by a Young Writer
description: If you're a frequent theatergoer, the sound of a new and singular dramatic voice is the sound you listen for. Hearing it is rare, of course, and you're never expectant but always hopeful, like a bird-watcher attuned to the trill of an endangered bird. The sound is loud and unmistakable, however, here at the Williamstown Theater Festival, where the work of a 25-year-old playwright -- a play called ''The Man Who Had All the Luck'' -- is surely the herald of an important career.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $1.2 Million Hospital Settlement
description: Beth Israel Medical Center has agreed to pay $1.2 million after civil charges that the hospital was overpaid by Medicare because of incorrectly documented claims, Mary Jo White, the United States attorney, announced yesterday. A federal audit found that from 1990 to 1996, the hospital billed Medicare for services that were supposed to be performed by faculty physicians, but was unable to document that those physicians were present. Other claims were not properly coded. As part of the settlement, Beth Israel will also submit to annual reviews of its billing practices. Elizabeth Plowe, a hospital spokeswoman, said the settlement was a small part of the hospital's $260 million in annual billings and that ''no questions were raised'' as to whether patients received the care for which the hospital sought payment. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: John Lindsay Park Urged
description: Nine members of the New York Congressional delegation wrote a letter yesterday to the City Council urging it to rename a Manhattan park after the late Mayor John V. Lindsay. The Council is discussing renaming East River Park, between Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and the East River from East 12th to Montgomery Streets, in honor of the former mayor, who died in December. The letter, initiated by Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, cited Mr. Lindsay's role in closing park drives to traffic during the day and on weekends. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBROW, HONEY CHANSON
description: DOBROW-Honey Chanson. Of Boca Raton, FL, died July 22, 2001, as gracefully as she lived. She leaves her beloved son Richard Steven and a bevy of adoring nieces, nephews and friends, whose lives her spirit illuminated.

title: It's Off to the Races For Stock Car Fashion
description: On Feb. 19, like so many New Yorkers whose music collections contain not a single effort from the Charlie Daniels Band, Stefano Tonchi opened the morning paper and discovered that someone named Dale Earnhardt had come to a catastrophic end. Mr. Tonchi, Esquire's fashion creative director, read that Earnhardt had died the day before after a crash at the Daytona 500. He soon learned that stock car racing was an intoxicant to millions of Americans and moreover, that Earnhardt held the kind of exalted place that Adlai E. Stevenson held among liberals circa 1955.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus posted its biggest decline on record in the first six months of the year as export growth stalled and an 11 percent slide in the yen pushed up the cost of imported oil and gas. The trade surplus fell to 3.2 trillion yen ($25.9 billion) in the six months ended June 30, down 44 percent from the first half of last year, the Ministry of Finance said. It was the biggest decline since records were first kept in 1947.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T Posts Another Loss As Revenue Declines 3%

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Crime Figure Convicted
description: Joseph Watts, a onetime star in the Gambino crime family, was convicted yesterday of conspiring to lie to federal tax agents about his income. But the jury was deadlocked on the question of whether he laundered nearly $2 million in loan-sharking profits through his retirement estate on an island off Florida's Gulf Coast. The government says Mr. Watts was the Gambino family's de facto ambassador to Las Vegas and its liaison to the Westies, an Irish gang that specialized in labor racketeering. He will be retried on the money-laundering charges sometime in the next several months. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONALOY, DR. MORRIS A.
description: MONALOY-Dr. Morris A., of Passaic, NJ on Saturday July 21st. Beloved husband of Florence (nee Perlman), devoted father of Gail Garbin (son-in-law Dr. Melvin D. Garbin) of Clifton, NJ and Stephen Monaloy (daughter-in-law Vicki Chalfin) of Paramus, NJ, loving grandfather of two grandchildren. Services at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ, today at 12 noon. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Children Face Perils of the Playground
description: Children are more likely to be seriously injured on playground equipment than they are in bicycle or car crashes, researchers are reporting today.

title: Diamond in the Rough
description: At 6-foot-7, 19-year-old Oleg Korneyev stands out on the mound, especially when his pitches clock in at 91 miles an hour.

title: Wynalda Rediscovers His Game With Fire
description: Dealing with the right coach in the right environment is all ERIC WYNALDA has wanted in his career. He has gone from college to Germany to the United States national team to four stops in Major League Soccer -- San Jose, Miami, New England and now Chicago. There has been a great deal of success along the way for Wynalda, the national team's career leading scorer (34 goals and 16 assists in 106 matches), but he seems to have found the perfect coach and the right environment in Chicago with the Fire.

title: Mississippi's Teacher Salaries
description: For many years Mississippi has lagged far behind other states in teacher pay, even in the Southeast, making it difficult to hire and keep teachers. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove has been working since he took office last year for a big pay raise for teachers to make it easier to recruit them.

title: Duval Was Pleased Not to Call Woods This Time
description: Whenever Tiger Woods wins a golf tournament, he receives a congratulatory phone call from his friend David Duval.

title: The Smithsonian Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Universal Begins Account Review
description: Universal Studios, owned by Vivendi Universal ( news/quote ), said yesterday that it had begun a review for its theme- park advertising account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARO, MARGHERITA SHIELDS
description: KARO-Margherita Shields. Died at her home in NYC July 9, 2001. Known as Nan, she was born July 7, 1939 in Dublin, Ireland, but spent the bulk of her life in New York. She was a 1961 graduate of Radcliffe College. Nan was an esteemed Wall Street securities analyst for over 30 years. She leaves behind many loving friends and is survived by her brother, Frank Shields. She was the aunt of Clodagh Coghlan, Henrietta, Oliver and Alexander Shields. For many years, she was the loving wife of Tamas A. Karo. Services will be held on July 25th at 2PM at St. John the Martyr, E. 72 St. betw. 3rd & 2nd Avenue, where Nan was an active member. A reception following the service will take place at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66 St. Contributions in Nan's memory may be made to St. John the Martyr (212-744-4880).

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Ferry Project Delayed
description: The developers of a ferry terminal in Stamford say it will take at least another year before commuter ferry service will begin between Stamford and New York City as well as other Connecticut ports. Principals in the development firm, the Strand/BRC Group, said they were still trying to reach an agreement with at least one of five ferry-service companies. The leading contender for a ferry deal in Stamford is Lighthouse Landings Inc., which operates commuter ferries between New Jersey and New York City, including the New York Fast Ferry. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EDO CORP., New York, a maker of military armament systems and components, said it had received a $17.4 million contract from the U.S. Air Force to continue making ''smart'' bomb racks for F-16 Falcon aircraft.

title: Dow Takes 152-Point Drop As Worries Won't Fade
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as more companies reported weak second-quarter earnings.

title: Agency Eases Research Ban At University
description: A federal agency investigating the death of a volunteer in a research study at Johns Hopkins University announced today that it was easing its four-day-old suspension of research experiments involving human subjects at the university.

title: The new president of BBDO North America reflects on life and business in the colonies.
description: WILL the executive recently named to head North American operations for BBDO Worldwide one day have colleagues and clients singing, ''And here's to you, Mr. Robertson''?

title: Front Row
description: Anna Wintour, Vogue's famously reticent editor in chief, was waxing candid. ''I'm 51,'' she said. ''My biggest fashion bellwether is my daughter -- she's the first one to say, 'Mommy, you can't wear that.' ''

title: Ashcroft Wants Thai Boy Used by Smugglers to Stay in U.S.
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft granted ''humanitarian parole'' today to a Thai boy infected with H.I.V. who was used as a decoy in a human trafficking scheme, saying the United States should not deport him.

title: A New World Banquet, Flavored by Africa
Eye on the Storm
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Earning the Shirt
description: To the Editor:

title: McDONALD'S EARNINGS SLIP BECAUSE OF MAD COW FEARS
description: McDonald's said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings fell 16 percent as Europeans bought fewer hamburgers because of fears about mad cow disease. The company, the largest fast food chain, may close 250 restaurants to cut costs and increase profit. Net income fell for the third consecutive quarter, to $440.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from $525.9 million, or 39 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 4.2 percent, to $3.71 billion. McDonald's was hurt by declines in the euro and other currencies, reluctance among Europeans to eat beef and higher costs for food, packaging and labor. The company is headed for its first annual profit decline in at least 10 years.

title: City Auditors Will Examine Hevesi's Costs For Campaign
description: Declaring that the city Campaign Finance Board must determine if Alan G. Hevesi's mayoral campaign is being frugal or fraudulent, city auditors are set today to visit the Madison Avenue offices of his chief political consultant, the board's chairman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELTY, EUDORA
description: WELTY-Eudora. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of literature.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Protests Over A Death At G-8 Summit
description: Tens of thousands of people, many shouting ''Killers! Killers!'' protested in peaceful marches in cities throughout Italy against the use of police force that left one person dead and more than 230 injured at the G-8 summit meeting in Genoa. The protesters demanded the resignation of Interior Minister Claudio Scajola, who was in charge of security for the conservative government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. The opposition center-left Olive Tree bloc, which lost a general election to Mr. Berlusconi last May, put forward a formal no-confidence motion against Mr. Scajola in Parliament. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Culture Clash

title: Happy Clams Take a Plunge In Vinegar Dip
description: For some people, clams or oysters on the half shell demand red cocktail sauce. But for those who prefer a French-style vinegar dip, there is a new seasoned vinegar in a bottle. Made by Domaine des Terres Rouges in south-central France (hours from the nearest oyster beds), it is a cider vinegar with shallots, fleur de sel and seaweed to use as a dip for shellfish, to spoon over freshly grilled fish or to season a seafood salad. It costs $6.99 for 8.5 ounces at Fairway.

title: National Briefing
description: MIDWEST

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Apish Behavior Off Screen, Too

title: Suit Challenges Prudential Plan To Reorganize
description: A New York law firm filed a lawsuit in Superior Court in Newark yesterday seeking to block a plan by Prudential Financial, one of the country's largest life insurers, to reorganize and go public.

title: Traveling 2 Roads In One Life
description: Angela Williams began her speech at a conference for female corporate lawyers in May with an apology. Her assistant had sent over the wrong biography, describing her as a Baptist minister rather than a lawyer. In reality, she said, she was both.

title: McCain Threatens Slowdown on Trucking Bill
description: In a rare moment of solidarity with the White House, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, threatened today to slow the Senate's work on a bill that would sharply restrict Mexican truck travel in the United States.

title: AMERITRADE PROFITS FALL 98% AS ONLINE TRADING DECLINES
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, a leading online brokerage firm, said yesterday that its profit fell 98 percent in its most recent quarter as declines in stocks curbed the appeal of trading over the Internet. The company, based in Omaha, said net income fell to $70,000, or break-even on a per share basis, from $4.6 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the period ended June 30, the third quarter of Ameritrade's fiscal year, fell 26.5 percent, to $112.6 million from the quarter a year earlier and 5 percent from the prior quarter. The average number of trades executed by Ameritrade's clients declined to 109,000 a day from 113,164 in the third quarter of 2000.

title: A Peoria Bishop Plays Well in Newark
description: As a churchman who has spent his entire pastoral life in America's rural heartland, Bishop John J. Myers knew his appointment today as archbishop of Newark might inspire some good-natured jibes about the country priest who finds himself dispatched to the big city.

title: Trivia Question
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: F.C.C. Approves Fox Takeover of 10 Chris-Craft TV Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to approve Fox Television Stations Inc.'s application to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, which owns 10 television stations.

title: How Brazil Lights Fire In a Glass
description: WHEN it comes to cocktails (and most evenings it does, in my case), I'm a martini man -- Tanqueray, if you've got it, up, very dry, with a twist. Have been for 50 years, ever since my grandfather announced one Thanksgiving that it was time I learned to drink ''like a man,'' and handed me a martini. A silver bullet. A see-through.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about an international accord to combat climate change misspelled the name of the under secretary of state for global affairs who represented the United States. She is Paula Dobriansky, not Dobrianksy.

title: Merrill Picks Heir Apparent To Top Job
description: Merrill Lynch & Company moved E. Stanley O'Neal, who grew up poor in rural Alabama and worked his way through college in an auto factory, into position yesterday to be its next chief executive. Mr. O'Neal, who has run Merrill's brokerage business since early last year, could become the first black to lead a major Wall Street securities firm.

title: Getting the Corporate Point Across to Employees
description: In January, General Motors announced an unorthodox plan: its employees in charge of communicating with employees would no longer report to a G.M. executive but to a New York City consultant who specialized in management-employee relations.

title: IN AMAZON'S STOCK SALE TO AOL, A CLAUSE ABOUT TAKEOVER
description: Amazon.com, in agreeing to sell $100 million of stock to America Online, included a provision that lets AOL propose a takeover of the company, the world's largest Internet retailer. The contract, filed with the S.E.C., includes provisions that bar AOL, a unit of AOL Time Warner, from increasing its stake in Amazon.com or seeking board control. Such ''standstill'' provisions are often included in investment agreements. Less common was a caveat to the standstill restrictions that permits AOL to suggest an ''extraordinary transaction'' with Amazon.com, as long as the talks can be kept confidential.

title: A Climate Pact Without America
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CAN TO PAY $2 MILLION TO SETTLE SHAREHOLDER SUIT
description: The U.S. Can Corporation said it had agreed to pay $2.06 million to settle a lawsuit brought by stockholders who contended they did not get enough for their shares in last year's $269 million management-led acquisition. U.S. Can, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said in June 2000 it would be bought by a group formed by Paul Jones, chairman and chief executive, and Berkshire Partners, based in Boston, for $20 a share, a 21 percent premium at the time. The buyout was approved by a shareholders' vote and completed in October. David Addis, a stockholder who sued in Delaware Chancery Court, agreed to settle the class-action suit after the company offered to pay 20 cents more a share.

title: Armstrong: Left Behind, Still Ahead
description: Their plates piled with beets, celery root and tomatoes, the riders of the Crdit Agricole team sat down to a recent dinner looking as diced, sliced and shredded as their first course.

title: China Riled Over Planned Visit to Japanese War Shrine
description: TOKYO, July 25 -- A controversy over a planned prime ministerial visit next month to a Shinto shrine honoring Japan's war dead escalated sharply today with a stern warning by China to call off the ceremony

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVELIS, DR. MARCOS, MD
description: RIVELIS-Dr. Marcos, MD, surviving are his wife Emma, sons Fabian and Daniel, daughter Debora, six grandchildren, two great grandchildren, two brothers and two sisters. Funeral Thursday 12:00pm, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Inc. 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Memorials to Arthritis Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, FRANCES
description: FISCHER-Frances. The Officers, Directors and Staff of Mount Carmel Cemetery deeply mourn the passing of Frances Fischer, the mother of Martin A. Fischer, President of Mount Carmel Cemetery Association. Mark I. Stempa, Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENNERICH, WILLIAM S.
description: GENNERICH-William S. On July 23, 2001 of West Hempstead and Shelter Island, NY. Beloved husband of Kathleen Harrington-Gennerich. Adored father of Kathleen Mazza (Jim), Susan and Kristin Gennerich, and Sean (Jennifer) and Patrick Harrington. Loving grandfather of Caroline and Matthew Mazza. Bill retired as Vice President of Labor Relations for Capital Cities/ABC in 1995 after twenty six years. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday at 10 AM, St Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Mashomack Preserve, PO Box 850, Shelter Island, NY 11964 appreciated.

title: Power Failure Causes Spill Of Raw Sewage Into Hudson
description: An estimated 3.75 million gallons of raw sewage flowed into the Hudson River on Monday afternoon after an electrical power failure here shut down Westchester County's largest pump station, county environmental and health officials said today.

title: Palestinians Angrily Protest Arrest of Militants
description: Hundreds of Palestinians, angered that militants had been arrested by the Palestinian Authority, hurled stones and fired shots at the home of a security chief in Gaza on Monday night, witnesses said. It was one of the worst incidents of internal unrest since an anti-Israeli uprising erupted nearly 10 months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SHEA, MARGARET M. (NEE DRISCOLL)
description: O'SHEA-Margaret M. (nee Driscoll), wife of the late Peter J. O'Shea died on July 23, after a long illness at Gladeview Health Care Center, Old Saybrook, CT. Mrs. O'Shea was 88 years of age and lived most of her life in the Chelsea district of NYC and Jackson Heights, Queens. She is survived by her three children and their spouses, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Sorge of Greensboro, NC, Mr.and Mrs. Peter J. O'Shea of New Canaan CT, and Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. O'Shea of Old Lyme, CT. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Viewing will be held on Thursday, July 26 from 7 to 9PM at the Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home 13 Beckwith Lane, Old Lyme CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Friday, July 27 at 11:30AM at the Christ the King Church in Old Lyme. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday October 21 at 5PM in Guardian Angel Church on 21st St and 10th Avenue NYC. The family requests that donations be made in Mrs. O'Shea's memory to Child and Family Agency of Southeastern Connecticut, 255 Hempstead St, New London CT 06320, Covenant House, 346 West 17 St, NY NY 10011 or St. Jude's Children's Hospital in Memphis, TN.

title: Lifeguards Rescue Girl, 9
description: A 9-year-old girl was rescued from the surf by lifeguards at Coney Island yesterday after she was apparently pulled under the water by a mild undertow, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, WILLIAM
description: BURKE-William of St. Petersburg, FL died July 22, 2001. Survived by his wife Voncile. National Cremation Society, St. Petersburg, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLAR, GUSSIE
description: STOLLAR-Gussie. Loving mother of Carole and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Judith, Kenneth and Deborah. Great-grandmother of Samantha and Daisy. Funeral service today at 11:30 AM at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, JOSEPHBERG SARAH (''SYD'')
description: GREENBLATT - JOSEPHBERG Sarah (''Syd''), at age 94 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Louis Greenblatt and the late Maurice Josephberg. Loving mother of Ira and Linda and Ann and John Cohen; grandmother of David, Margo and Michael, Ellen, Patti and Eric, Stephanie and Richard, and Linda; great-grandmother of Jordan, Alexander, Marc, Myles and Blake. Funeral services will be private.

title: Corn-Based Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Convictions In Prison Deaths
description: A court has convicted two police officers for their part in the deaths of at least 83 prisoners, most of them opposition supporters, who apparently suffocated last November soon after being locked up in a small, poorly ventilated cell in the northern town of Montepuez. One of the officers was sentenced to 18 years in prison, and the other to 17 years. The crackdown last November came as supporters of the Mozambican National Resistance, known as Renamo, clashed with the police around the country over the ruling party's unwillingness to include Renamo in the government, even after it narrowly lost the 1999 national elections. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Busy Signal at the I.R.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, JAMES J.
description: McCAFFREY-James J., 79. Of Blue Hill, ME, a retired advertising agency executive, former weekly newspaper publisher and avid fisherman-not necessarily in that order-died Saturday, July 21, at the Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor of complications from a stroke. He was stricken a month earlier while on a fishing trip to Canada. Jim was born in New York City on May 15, 1922, the son of John and Marie McCaffrey of Scarsdale, N.Y. He was educated at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., & was enrolled at Princeton University when he as stricken with polio at the age of 19. Despite surviving with only limited mobility in his left leg and none at all in his right, McCaffrey nevertheless completed his education at Princeton, graduating with honors in 1944, and was headed for law school at Harvard University when he took a summer job in the mailroom of Young and Rubicam, then the second largest advertising agency in the world. He was bitten by the advertising bug and told Harvard ''the law will have to do without me.'' In 1945, Jim met a young woman named Virginia (''Geegee'') Given on the beach of Fire Island and the two were marrid the following year. While she continued working as an editor for ''Glamour Magazine'' and ''House Garden Magazine'', he quickly worked his way up the advertising ladder to become an account executive, first at Young and Rubicam and then at Ogilvy and Mather. In 1962, he joined forces with David B. McCall to purchase an agency called C.J. LaRoche and Co. Thus was born the firm of McCaffrey and McCall, Inc. The company became one of New York's preeminent advertising agencies over the next two decades. Over his career, Jim worked with such clients as Rolls Royce, J.C. Penney, Bacardi Rum, Helena Rubenstein, Pepperidge Farm, Hathaway Shirt, Norelco and ABC Television. Jim served as the agency's chairman of the board for the next 10 years, also ascending to the presidency of the 4A's (American Association of Advertising Agencies). He retired in 1973 at the age of 50 to move with Geegee to a Castine, ME farm overlooking the Bagaduce River. Once in Castine, Jim quickly became involved in the community. He was an active member of Our Lady of Holy Hope Catholic Church and a founder of the volunteer Bagaduce Ambulance Corps, which continues to serve Castine and surrounding towns today. Jim also played a major role in Castine's ''revolt'' against a state uniform property tax, helping lead a successful statewide effort to repeal the unpopular tax. In 1976, he made an aggressive bid to represent Hancock County in the Main Senate. Opting to run as an independent, without party affiliation or support, Jim nevertheless garnered more than 4,000 votes in a four-way race that was won by the Republican incumbent. In 1980, he embarked on a career as a newspaper publisher, teaming with editor Hugh Bowden to launch the weekly Castine Patriot, serving the towns of Castine, Orland, Penobscot and Brooksville. Jim's strong and thoughtful viewpoints appeared each week in well-crafted editorials, each carefully written in longhand, that became the talk of the community. Though the newspaper has seen several owners since Jim sold it in 1982, it continues to flourish today. Jim had a keen mind and fiery temper and did not suffer fools gladly. But he was also sensitive, articulate and could be loyal almost to a fault. Partner David McCall said of him on his retirement, ''Jim has never hurt a fellow human being in his life. Jim not only treats everyone equally, he literally can't see any difference between the president of General Motors and the window washer-unless one of them is an ass.'' The McCaffrey's sold their Castine farm in 1997 and became residents of Parker Ridge, a retirement community in Blue Hill, ME. For more than 50 years, Jim was an avid fisherman in Maine, Canada and the Bahamas. His fishing partner and 55-year partner in life was always his wife. Regarding his stroke and ultimate death, Geegee commented to friends about their most recent trip to Canada: ''Jim caught a 10pound salmon before he had other things to do.'' And no one knows his no-holds-barred dedication to tomorrow better than she. In addition to his wife, Jim is survived by a daughter, Anne (''Nancy'') McCaffrey Rathmell of Belfast; and three granddaughters, Meghan Rathmell of Hollis, Erin Rathmell of West Tisbury, Mass., and Katharine Rathmell of Exeter, N.H. A funeral mass will be held Friday, July 27, at 10 A.M. at Our Lady of Holy Hope Catholic Church in Castine. Following interment in the Castine Cemetery, a celebration of Jim's life will be held in the dining room at Parker Ridge from noon to 4 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Post Polio Support Group of Maine, 674 HallowellLitchfield Rd, West Gardiner, ME 04345, or to Alzheimer's Disease Research, 15825 Shady Grove Rd, Suite 140, Rockville, MD 20850.

title: The Therapeutic Listener
description: As the only psychologist for 880 patients, I've been warmly received by staff and residents. Not long ago, I asked a middle-aged AIDS patient with a history of sporadic violent outbursts whether he got depressed. His reply was: ''The food in the crazy house is better than here.'' His confusion resulted from psychosis and AIDS-related dementia. He had a perpetually sad expression that reflected how overwhelmed he was from three catastrophic illnesses.

title: Yankees' Comedy of Errors Ends in Victory
description: Jorge Posada turned his back to the plate to chase the stray pitch and, from the screams of Mariano Rivera and thousands of fans, Posada realized instantly that one of the fastest runners in baseball was sprinting home, trying to score the tying run.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fast-Food Prices
description: One of the least expensive places in Manhattan to buy a watch might be Canal Street, but some of the most expensive fast food can also be found there, according to a new survey released by the Department of Consumer Affairs. The survey compared prices of a sample of burgers, French fries and the like across the five boroughs. Among the 50 McDonald's and 45 Burger King restaurants surveyed, the highest prices were in Manhattan. And in Manhattan, the $12.27 paid on Canal Street was 33 percent higher than prices elsewhere in the borough. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about the transfer of the United States government bond trading desk of Banc of America Securities to New York from San Francisco misstated the location of the company's equity trading desk and omitted a city from a list of its trading centers. The equity desk is based in San Francisco, which remains a trading center, not in New York.

title: About Mutual Funds; Editors' Note
description: As a result of growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is eliminating entries for some of the smallest ones and making its daily table more concise.

title: Burlington Northern Profit
description: Burlington Northern Santa Fe said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 22 percent as costs at the second-largest railroad rose and shipments of steel, food and automobiles declined.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ebay Seeks Large Sellers
description: In an effort to attract large sellers, eBay is designating auction software companies to help provide logistical services for high-volume sales. The companies will provide software that will help sellers with the billing, tracking and shipping of items. The program, Preferred Provider Program, will start with a dedicated section on eBay's Web site over the next three to six weeks, eBay said.

title: Honeywell Profits Plunge In Failed Merger's Wake
description: Honeywell International, struggling to regain its footing after the collapse of its merger with General Electric, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings had plunged 92 percent below those of last year.

title: A Continental Tire Is Under Scrutiny
description: One model of tire that the Ford Motor Company is using to replace Firestone Wilderness AT's has a higher rate of damage claims than the Firestones do, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today as it opened a defect inquiry into the tire.

title: A New World Banquet, Flavored by Africa
description: THIS is where the strands came together, where the native Brazilians and the Portuguese settlers and the African slaves whom they shipped across the South Atlantic to harvest sugar began fashioning a vivid new culture.

title: EXXON MISSES FORECAST; CHEVRON TOPS IT
description: Exxon Mobil said yesterday that its second-quarter net income edged lower because of merger-related charges, while Chevron posted an 18 percent increase in profit. Chevron exceeded analysts' expectations but Exxon Mobil fell short of estimates because of lower-than-expected profit from fuel sales in Europe and Asia. Exxon Mobil reported net income of $4.46 billion, or 65 cents a share, compared with $4.53 billion -- also listed as 65 cents a share -- in the period a year earlier. Chevron said second-quarter net income climbed to $1.32 billion, or $2.05 a share, compared with $1.12 billion, or $1.71 a share, in the period a year earlier. Exxon Mobil had exceeded estimates each quarter since it was created by the merger of Exxon and Mobil in November 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, BENJAMIN B., M.D.
description: MOSES-Benjamin B., M.D. On July 24, 2001 in Baltimore, Maryland. Husband of Minna Moses (Zakarin) and the late Frances Moses (Kolodny). Father of Ellen M. Heller, Baltimore, MD, Charlotte M. Fischman, NY, NY, Carol M. Rubin, Newton Center, MA. Grandfather of Dr. William A. and Dr. Lawrence D. Heller, Elihu J. Rubin, Ann F. Fischman, Noam M. Rubin. Great grandfather of Lillian F. Heller. Services at Sol Levinson & Bros. Home, Baltimore, MD (800-338-1701) on Thursday, July 26 at 10:00 AM. Interment Arlington Cemetery-Chizuk Amuno Congregation, Baltimore, MD. Contributions in his memory to the Benjamin B. Moses Scholarship Fund, C/O Central Scholarship Bureau, 1700 Reisterstown Rd., Balimore, MD 21208. In mourning at 807 St. Georges Rd., Baltimore, MD 21210.

title: Leasing of Trade Center May Help Transit Projects, Pataki Says
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, speaking yesterday at the closing of the $3.2 billion deal to lease the World Trade Center, said the money from the deal could help finance the long-stalled Second Avenue subway and plans to provide tunnel access for Long Island Rail Road trains to Grand Central Terminal.

title: G.O.P. in House Faces New Split on Patients' Rights
description: When a revolt by moderate Republicans forced the House leadership last week to delay a vote on President Bush's plan to give religious groups a greater role in social services, Representative Fred Upton of Michigan captured the defiant mood of the rebels by flexing his arm and pointing to his muscle.

title: Stunned Neighbors Mourn 3 Cousins Lost off Far Rockaway
description: Just before sundown today, a pine box bearing the body of Rahela Begum, who drowned in the waters off Far Rockaway on Monday, was laid on a downtown street here for a Muslim funeral.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Soybean Trade Case
description: The Brazilian government plans to ask the World Trade Organization to open an arbitration panel that would challenge subsidies for soybean growers in the United States. Brazilian trade officials contend that the subsidies, which should reach $3.3 billion this year, have prompted an overproduction that has sent world prices falling to 30-year lows. Brazil, the second-largest world soybean grower behind the United States, with $4.5 billion in exports, plans to seek unspecified compensation for lost revenue. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: In Indonesia, Uncertainty Amid Hopes For Stability
description: Currency traders prize stability above all else. By driving the Indonesian rupiah up 13 percent over the last two days, the traders sent a powerful signal that they expect Indonesia's new president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, to restore much-needed ballast to the country's storm-tossed economy.

title: A Climate Pact Without America
description: To the Editor:

title: A, B, Q, Q<diamond=, W: Taste the Alphabet Soup
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Continental Drifts

title: Tom Colicchio
description: BRAISING is a combination of cooking methods: hot and dry, then slow and moist. You don't have to do the steps all at once, so it's very convenient.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm In Deal With Chip Makers
description: In an effort to expand beyond the manufacturing of consumer electronics, Palm Inc. said yesterday that it had signed licensing deals with three chip makers to help developers get Palm OS-enabled devices to market more quickly. Through the initiative, known as the Palm OS Ready Program, the chip makers -- Intel, Motorola and Texas Instruments -- will integrate the Palm operating system into their chip designs. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Ordez Just Wants To Start, Anywhere
description: Wearing headphones, Rey Ordez walked into the Mets' clubhouse and right past the lineup card without giving it a glance. The lineup was the same as it was on Monday when the Mets' game against the Florida Marlins was rained out. Ordez seemed to know his fate.

title: Contrasts in SoHo: Salty, Sweet and Satisfying
description: HAVE you ever taken a bite of something that captured your mood, desires and surroundings perfectly? I had a dish like that on a recent warm evening at Stella, an uncommonly inviting little restaurant in SoHo. It was a special, a chilled cantaloupe soup ($5.50), and with the first spoonful I knew there was nothing else in the world I would rather eat at that moment.

title: Corrections
