description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about President Bush's visit to Italy misstated the title of Silvio Berlusconi. He is Italy's prime minister, not the president.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Saks To Close White Plains Store
description: Saks Inc., operator of Carson Pirie Scott, Proffitt's and its namesake department stores, will close its Saks Fifth Avenue store in White Plains after Christmas and sell the space to the closely held Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware Inc. The store has about 100 workers. Some employees will be offered jobs at other Saks stores, the company, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., said in a statement distributed by Business Wire. Saks said the store, which is 128,000 square feet, had fallen short of the company's performance criteria. Company officials did not immediately return a phone call seeking comment. The shares of Saks rose 10 cents to $11.10 in trading yesterday. They have risen 10 percent this year.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Name Applications
description: The company in charge of Internet addresses in the new .info domain will start accepting applications today from trademark holders who wish to register addresses with the new extension. For 30 days, trademark and service-mark owners can apply through accreditd companies, known as registrars. The applications will be submitted to Afilias, which manages the .info database. The .info extension is one of seven addresses being added in an effort to relieve overcrowding in the .com, .net and .org domains. Open registration for .info addresses is expected to begin Sept. 12.

title: Lindros May Have to Go East Before Going West for Olympics
description: In his role as the executive director of hockey operations for Team Canada in the coming Salt Lake City Winter Olympic Games, Wayne Gretzky yesterday raised the specter of Europe when discussing where Eric Lindros might have to go if he wants to play in his second Olympics.

title: U.S. Explores Other Options On Preventing Germ Warfare
description: A senior administration official said yesterday that although the White House rejects a draft agreement under discussion at talks in Geneva, it remains committed to strengthening a 1972 treaty banning biological weapons and has already begun exploring alternative ways of enforcing the ban and deterring and punishing cheaters.

title: Sports of The Times; Liberian, New Yorker, Altruist
description: ON Sunday, George Weah will socialize with his Nigerian pals in New York, in some cafe or bar where a television satellite dish just might beam in the crucial game from distant Port Harcourt, Nigeria.

title: An Authentic Gelato, Without a Trip to Italy
description: Gelato is the Italian word for ice cream, but the cold, sweet, creamy stuff that Italians scoop is not an exact equivalent of the American version. Gelato is not frozen as hard as American ice cream, and has a lower butterfat content than top-of-the-line American brands. At Il Gelatone, a new ice cream parlor at 397 Third Avenue (28th Street), Saida Tofani, right, serves the real thing, made on the premises the Italian way. There are usually six to eight flavors, which change from day to day (strawberry, lemon, black currant, chocolate-hazelnut, caramel and deeply winy mixed berry are some), and the assortment always includes plain ''milk gelato.'' (The name does not do justice to that unflavored confection.) Cups and cones are $2.80 to $5.75, and sundaes are $10. Il Gelatone is open daily from 3 p.m. to midnight.

title: Drownings at Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Baptist Group Wins Suit
description: In a case with implications for President Bush's proposal to provide federal financing to charities run by religious organizations, a federal court in Kentucky ruled against Alicia Pedreira in a lawsuit accusing the Kentucky Baptist Homes for Children of discrimination. In a termination letter, Ms. Pedreira, a lesbian, was told she was fired in 1998 because the ''homosexual lifestyle is contrary to Kentucky Baptist Homes for Children core values.'' Officials at the American Civil Liberties Union, which joined her in the lawsuit and announced the outcome, said they strongly disagreed with the finding. The home receives financing from Kentucky, and the A.C.L.U. had argued that religious organizations that receive taxpayer financing should not be allowed to discriminate. Mr. Bush's proposal would expand a religion's right to hire within its faith to include federally financed programs. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: According to The Times...
description: The glass-beaded shirts that Neil Diamond wears at most of his concert performances weigh 10 pounds each.

title: A Climate Pact Without America
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the News Corporation's decision to sell Maximum Golf referred incorrectly to the effect on the company's magazine operations. The company will remain in the business through its ownership of The Weekly Standard; it will not leave the business.

title: States Adjust Adult Prisons To Needs of Youth Inmates
description: Shaun Miller was 15 in 1998 when he was arrested for robbing a convenience store in Pahrump, Nev., with three older teenagers. The oldest member of the group, who was 19, planned the crime and used a gun. Shaun, who was unarmed, took the money from the cash register.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Oxford: Show-And-Tell Marijuana
description: A 13-year-old girl has been arrested on drug-possession charges after bringing marijuana to summer school for show and tell. The girl, whose name was not released by the police because she is a minor, was arrested Friday after she brought a half-filled sandwich bag of the drug to show her classmates at Great Oaks Middle School, said Sgt. Paul Vance, a state police spokesman. School officials notified the police, who charged the girl with possession of marijuana.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Peoplesoft's Revenue Increases 27%
description: PeopleSoft, which makes e-business software, posted second-quarter earnings yesterday of 14 cents a share, excluding nonrecurring items, a return that exceeded analysts' estimates by 2 cents a share. Including nonrecurring items, the earnings per share were 15 cents. Peoplesoft, of Pleasanton, Calif., had revenue of $533 million, an increase of 27 percent from the quarter a year earlier. The company said that revenue from licensing its software was $166 million, up 51 percent from the quarter a year earlier, while revenue from services increased 20 percent, to $337 million. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Think Tank column in Arts & Ideas on Saturday, about the United States government's backing of Hilton hotels during the cold war as a showcase for capitalism, was published in error. It showed the new Berlin Hilton, not the one that opened in 1958. A correction in this space yesterday misstated the site of the earlier hotel. It was in West Berlin, not East Berlin.

title: Mandela Is Being Treated for Prostate Cancer
description: Nelson Mandela, South Africa's first black president and revered leader of the anti-apartheid struggle, has been found to have prostate cancer and is undergoing treatment, his office announced today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an international accord to combat climate change misspelled the name of the under secretary of state for global affairs who represented the United States. She is Paula Dobriansky, not Dobrianksy.

title: Jonathan C. Rice, 85; Innovator Of Public TV in San Francisco
description: Jonathan C. Rice, an influential figure in the development of public television in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAY, GEORGE
description: SHAY-George. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of George Shay, beloved husband of Helene and devoted father of Scott (and Susan) Shay, distinguished supporters of NJOP who have played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the entire family. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Change At Hyundai
description: Kim Dong Jin, left, was appointed chief executive of the Hyundai Motor Company, replacing Lee Kye Ahn, in a surprise move. Mr. Kim was president of the company's commercial vehicle division. Mr. Lee, who had overseen the company's recovery from the 1997-1998 economic crisis, was named chairman of the Hyundai Capital Company, its financing unit. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Japanese Artist Goes Global; Far-Flung Helpers Meet Demand for Takashi Murakami's Paintings
description: In a converted garage on a residential street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a small band of Japanese painters were making art. One young woman stood behind a plastic curtain, using a spray gun to apply coat after coat of white paint to a canvas mounted on wood. At a table, another woman was tracing the outlines of a mouselike character onto another canvas. Nearby, a young man painstakingly noted minuscule imperfections in a lustrous moonscape of midnight blue.

title: Just Swashbuckle In and Brandish a Fork
description: EVERY restaurant wants to have a personality. Unfortunately, many of them start from the outside and work in. They concentrate on getting the look and the atmosphere down. Much attention is devoted to the soundtrack. The food is not so much created as curated. It's treated as style. From this frantic activity, like the earth emerging from a cloud of swirling hot gas, something resembling character is supposed to rise. It never does.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, BARBARA
description: FARBER-Barbara. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Torre Awaits Help From Within
description: Other teams are tossing around names like Jermaine Dye and Pedro Astacio in trade talks, while the Yankees are focusing on adding two players, David Justice and Orlando Hernndez, who are making strides in recovering from injuries.

title: Big Steps for Vaccine Industry; Fresh Approaches And Technology Ignite New Interest
description: Una S. Ryan, president and chief executive of Avant Immunotherapeutics, used to tread carefully when describing the cholesterol fighter her company was developing. Facing criticism from numerous skeptics, she started calling it an ''inhibitor,'' not a vaccine.

title: Louima Backs Hevesi, Citing Hope of Halting Police Beatings
description: Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, the Democratic mayoral candidate who has been criticized by some rivals as being less than outspoken on police misconduct, won the endorsement yesterday of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who has become the symbol of police brutality in New York.

title: Qualcomm Calls Off a Spinoff and Realigns Management
description: Qualcomm Inc., the mobile phone technology company, canceled plans yesterday to spin off its semiconductor division and said it would restructure itself under a shuffled management team.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Cultural Leader Leaving

title: INSIDE
description: Attack Stuns Sri Lankans

title: Getting Away From It All, at Least for a Little While
description: It's summertime, and that means the beach and other vacation spots beckon workers away from the office. But with a weak economy, high gasoline prices early in the season and higher costs for meals and lodging, some vacations may be scaled back or shortened this year.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about talks to enforce a ban on biological weapons misstated the location. It is Geneva, not London.

title: One Gadget Does It All, Foil to Cork
description: More compact and cheaper by far than gangly lever-operated wine bottle openers, the new Zyliss model, a translucent plastic cylinder, is a paragon of efficiency. It is about 5 inches high and does it all. You start by placing the gadget over the cork, pressing the small lever near the bottom and turning the whole thing. Inside is a tiny blade that neatly slices off the foil or plastic covering the neck and top of the bottle. Then you remove that covering, replace the opener on the bottle and turn the stubby handles on top. You can see the spiral work its way down into the cork and eventually pull it out of the bottle and into the body of the opener. Remove the opener, turn some more and the cork is released. And you will have a bottle with a clean edge at the opening every time. The Zyliss wine opener with foil cutter is about $20 at Service Hardware, 1338 Lexington Avenue (89th Street) and at some Bed Bath & Beyond and Linens and Things stores.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fence Falls And Injures Man
description: A section of a chain-link fence fell from a roof last night, severely injuring a man who was walking with his father and their wives down West 106th Street about 9 p.m., the police said. The son, Michael Taratuta, 40, was in St. Luke's Hospital in critical condition; his father, Aba Taratuta, suffered a head cut. Both men live across the street from the building, 69 West 106th Street. The cause of the accident was not known. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Eight Fillies and a Comeback to Spice Saratoga
description: Eight precocious 2-year- old fillies at least their owners hope they are precocious -- and a star from last year who is on the comeback trail will headline the opening day of the most prestigious thoroughbred racing meeting in the nation.

title: COURT UPHOLDS $1.1 MILLION JUDGMENT AGAINST WAL-MART
description: Wal-Mart Stores must pay $1.1 million to a customer who slipped on loose cardboard in one of its Sam's Club stores, a court ruled. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit dismissed Wal-Mart's claims that jurors erred in awarding $1.5 million to the customer, William Myers, for a broken hip suffered in a 1997 fall at a Sam's Club in Michigan. The judge overseeing the case later reduced the award to $1.1 million. Mr. Meyers, 65, sued last year after hip-replacement surgery. A Wal-Mart spokesman, Bill Wertz, said, ''We felt the trial court award was out of proportion to the injury Mr. Meyers suffered.''

title: A Climate Pact Without America
description: To the Editor:

title: European Fare, Brazilian Accent
description: SALVADOR DA BAHIA introduced us to the astonishing array of exotic Brazilian fruits, and we rediscovered many of them every morning on the breakfast buffet at our hotel, here, the Caesar Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, EVAN D.
description: DIAMOND-Evan D., 76. Of Norwalk, CT. died July 22, at home. He is survived by two daughters, Amy Diamond Barnes of Hamilton, N.Y., Laura Diamond of Stow, MA, & his loving partner, Eileen Jensen of Norwalk, CT.

title: Albany to Pass Austere Budget, Ending Logjam
description: The leaders of the State Assembly and Senate announced today that they would move to break the four-month deadlock over the state budget by passing an austere spending plan next week that is far smaller than the one Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Global Trade: Steel Ruling
description: The World Trade Organization panel of experts upheld a ruling that the United States government had illegally increased duties on Japanese steel imports. The earlier ruling, issued in February, rejected the June 1999 duties imposed by Washington after American steel companies complained that Japanese hot-rolled steel was being dumped on the United States market at below-market prices. The United States and Japan must now agree on when the duties will be eliminated.

title: Liberties; Obligation Or Temptation
description: I don't understand men.

title: American Airlines Offers Pilots Novel Accord
description: American Airlines yesterday offered its pilots a novel contract proposal intended to avoid the drawn-out negotiating process that has led to threatened strikes at several major airlines this year. But it seemed unlikely that the pilots' union, which has long had strained relations with American management, would endorse the plan.

title: Conservation Bill Benefits Coal Industry, Critics Say
description: A $33.5 billion energy bill in the Republican-controlled House advertises the $3.3 billion in tax credits it includes for ''clean-coal'' technology as a means to promote conservation.

title: Aiming at the over-50 traveler, a Minneapolis agency stresses mystery and avoids stereotypes.
description: THE ads promote exciting sights, exotic locales and romance.

title: Corrections
description: Picture credits last Wednesday with an article about the growing popularity of flavored iced teas in France misspelled the given name of the photographer. He was Jean-Luc Mano, not Lean Luc Mano.

title: Auditors Say Amtrak Unlikely to Meet Deadline for Profitability
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 N Amtrak is unlikley to meet the date Congress set to break even or face the possibility of liquidation, two outside auditors told a House subcommittee today.

title: New York Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lively but Modest White
description: COMPARED with the heartbreaker allure of pinot noir or the vivacious snap of pinot grigio, pinot blanc has an anonymous ring to it. No one would speak of a sassy pinot blanc or a brooding pinot blanc, as he might of a Beaujolais or a Bordeaux. In fact, when speaking of pinot blanc, one may not mean pinot blanc at all: studies have shown that some of the pinot blanc vines in California are actually melon de Bourgogne, the grape of muscadet.

title: Burritos Leave Campus Life
description: COSMOS LYLES has nothing if not nerve. It was not enough for Mr. Lyles, as a senior at Duke University in 1995, to open a burrito restaurant, Cosmic Cantina, near the campus in Durham, N.C. Two years ago, he opened a branch of the cantina, this time braving Chapel Hill, home of Duke's archrival, the University of North Carolina.

title: ABB, Reporting Lower Profit, Will Cut 12,000 Jobs
description: ABB Ltd., Europe's largest electrical engineering group, reported a 21 percent drop today in half-year profit and said it would shed 12,000 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, to try to counter the global economic slowdown.

title: Earnhardt Is Driving, and Learning, Fast
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr. is polite and articulate and speaks softly, his voice barely carrying over the clatter of tools in a garage. The voice, perhaps, is a ruse. Rumbling beneath the facade, like a growling engine under a shiny hood, is a driver who is developing a steely edge and who is capable of holding a grudge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONDEL, MICHAEL LAWRENCE
description: TONDEL-Michael Lawrence. Of Cresskill suddenly on July 22, 2001. Beloved son of Lawrence and Sharyn (nee Smith). Devoted brother of KC. Loving grandson of Jean Basch Tondel and Mr. & Mrs. Francis X. Smith. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home on Wednesday 7 to 9 PM and Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10 AM, Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly. Interment in Brookside Cemetery, Englewood. Memorials to Make A Wish Foundation, 1034 Salem Road, Union, N.J. 07083, would be appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro gained as slowing German inflation reinforced expectations that the European Central Bank will reduce interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 87.64 cents, up from 86.96 cents on Monday.

title: Eudora Welty's Daringly Sheltered Life
description: ''A place that ever was lived in is like a fire that never goes out,'' Eudora Welty once wrote. Miss Welty, who died Monday at 92, knew the feel of that fire better than almost anyone. As a writer, she warmed herself on place. It is ''the stuff of fiction,'' she wrote, ''as close to our living lives as the earth we can pick up and rub between our fingers, something we can feel and smell.'' Who knows whether she would have thought just this way if she hadn't lived her whole long life at home in Jackson, Miss.? But she did, and so anyone who reads her now finds Jackson added to the atlas of places that we know better, through literature, than we know our own towns.

title: OPEC Ministers Agree to Oil Output Cut
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to reduce its daily production by about 4 percent, or one million barrels, to buoy crude oil prices amid fears that worldwide oil demand is weakening.

title: House Democrats Seek to Promote Conservation in Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  House Democrats, joined by moderate Republicans, said today that they would offer amendments to alter the new farm bill this week, seeking to double spending for conservation and to trim direct crop subsidies.

title: Powell Said to Be Dismayed by Beijing Trial
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is scheduled to be in Beijing this weekend, learned of the 10-year sentence imposed on Gao Zhan, a Chinese scholar with United States residency, as he was flying here today from Tokyo. A senior State Department official told reporters that the Bush administration was ''quite dismayed'' by the sentencing, as well as the circumstances of the trial.

title: Survey Shows Few Parents Use TV V-Chip to Limit Children's Viewing
description: Five years ago, in the heat of his re-election campaign, President Clinton urged Congress to require equipment in new television sets that would allow parents to block programs they considered inappropriate for their children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, JACK
description: EPSTEIN-Jack, of Kings Point and Hartsdale, New York, June 1, 1961 -July 15, 2001. Beloved son of Morris and Joan, brother of Sheila and Jeff, uncle, and grandson. Forever in our hearts.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit At Retailer
description: India's largest consumer products company Hindustan Lever said it earned 3.46 billion rupees ($75 million) in its second quarter, a 21 percent increase from the period a year earlier. Sales rose only marginally, to $29.3 billion rupees ($630 million) from 28.8 billion rupees ($619 million). Sales were restrained by competition and by a slowing rural economy, which has been hurt by lack of rain. Hindustan is a subsidiary of Unilever.

title: Lucent to Make Cuts Of 20,000 More Jobs
description: Lucent Technologies, the once-mighty telecommunications equipment giant, announced a large loss and plans to cut 20,000 jobs, continuing a collapse that will leave it with far fewer than half the 155,000 workers it employed a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans to appoint Bishop John J. Myers of Peoria as the archbishop of Newark misidentified a drug that he directed Roman Catholic hospitals in 1994 to stop giving to rape victims, an order he later reversed. It was the morning-after pill, a combination of hormones used as an emergency contraceptive, not the abortion pill RU-486.

title: Camp in Samoa Draws Criticism in U.S.
description: Showing idyllic tropical scenes, a brochure for the Pacific Coast Academy camp in Samoa promises ''a kind and loving environment'' for troubled children needing help for spiritual, academic and, in some cases, drug and alcohol problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVE, JOAN
description: BOVE-Joan. On July 21, 2001. 99 years and 9 months of love, laughter, and excitement. The families of Dick and Rusty Gelb, and Bruce and Lueza Gelb, and their children: Larry, Lucy, John, Jody, Jane, Richard, Connie, and Jimmy, and their children: Richard and Emily, Matthew and Andy, Nathaniel and Johnny, Serena, Lueza, and Dora, and baby Daniel, will always remember their wonderful Gigi with loving memories. Contributions in her name may be sent to The Red Cross. Funeral services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHABERICK, RUDI KURT
description: SCHABERICK-Rudi Kurt. Age 62, of Lk. Hopatcong, NJ and Breezy Point, NY. At his home on July 23, 2001. Beloved husband of Sheila (Manning). Funeral Friday, July 27th at 12 Noon at Shepherd of the Hills Lutheran Church, Sparta, NJ. Private cremation will follow. Visiting Thrusday 3-5 and 7-9 PM at Goble Funeral Home, 22 Main St., Sparta, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to the Rudi Schaberbick Scholarship Fund, C/O Manuel Fanarjian, Esq., PO Box 795, Dover, NJ 07802-0795. directions goblefuneralhome.com

title: Stocks End Day Higher After Two Days of Losses
description: After two days of heavy selling, stocks rallied today as investors took their cues from a few good earnings reports despite the preponderance of bad ones.

title: South Korean Court Sentences 7 Daewoo Executives to Prison
description: A court today found seven former Daewoo executives guilty of accounting fraud and sentenced them to prison terms of up to seven years, then imposed fines totaling almost $20 billion on them and a dozen of their colleagues.

title: Oh, Brother! Just a Prank
description: Already under fire for allowing a contestant with an arrest record for assaults into the ''Big Brother 2'' house, CBS was confronted yesterday with news that yet another of the show's so-called houseguests had been arrested in the past, under a name he no longer uses.

title: College Hunt: Son, Are We There Yet?
description: THERE'S one thing that drives the parents of a high school senior crazy: listening to parents who say breezily, ''Oh, our Tiffany's known since second grade where she wanted to go to college, she got in early decision, and that was that.''

title: PCB Cleanup May Include Less Dredging
description: With a decision imminent on dredging PCB's from the upper Hudson River, the Bush administration is seriously considering a plan to do a fraction of the dredging that the Clinton administration proposed last year, Democratic elected officials and environmentalists said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Mets, Going Nowhere on Road Trip, More Bad Turns
description: The Mets had drawn within a run of the Florida Marlins in the fifth inning tonight. They had the bases loaded, no outs and their best hitter, Mike Piazza, at the plate.

title: www.state/fun/facts/snooze; Government Sites for Children Aren't the Coolest
description: Ball fields beckon. Bicycles stand poised in the garage. Yet many parents will still hear repeated refrains of ''I'm bored'' this summer.

title: GE CAPITAL BUYS SAFECO UNIT TO BUILD EQUIPMENT LOANS
description: GE Capital, the financing unit of General Electric, agreed to buy the Safeco Corporation's equipment-financing and leasing unit for an undisclosed price to increase loans to fast food franchises. GE Capital, based in Stamford, Conn., said its commercial equipment finance unit will absorb Safeco Credit, which makes equipment loans to restaurant franchises and transportation, manufacturing, and construction companies and is based in Redmond, Wash. GE Capital has been building its franchise business, and will have about $61.7 billion in assets when the purchase is completed.

title: Greenspan Says Fed's Rate Cuts Are Working
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the central bank's interest rate cuts were having their desired effect on the weakened economy, and he again left the door open to further cuts if the slowdown did not bottom out soon.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: William V. McDermott, 84, Combat Surgeon and Teacher
description: William Vincent McDermott Jr., a Boston surgeon who had taught generations of young physicians since proving his mettle as a combat surgeon in World War II, died last Thursday at his home in Dedham, Mass. He was 84.

title: House Republicans May Delay Vote on Patients' Rights Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 — House Republican leaders, short of the votes needed for a victory, said today they would probably postpone action on a patients' bill of rights until after Labor Day.

title: So Big, So Bold, So Often Overlooked
description: IT'S been more than two years since the great Italian wine Barolo -- the king of wines and the wine of kings, as it is informally known in the village that gave it its name -- rated a mention in this space. It might have been yet two years more, except for a lunch I attended a few days ago. The talk was of wine, which was not unusual given that most of the people at the table were sommeliers. Then someone mentioned Barolo. ''Barolo,'' he said, ''is impossible to sell -- no one ever orders it.''

title: Relatives of Doomed Crew Shown Footage of Ship
description: Family members of the sailors who died on the Arctic Rose, a fishing trawler that disappeared in April in the Bering Sea off Alaska, were shown videotape today showing the vessel sitting upright on the sea floor, 428 feet down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, C. BENJAMIN, JR.
description: BRUSH-C. Benjamin, Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y. on July 22, 2001 at 82. Survived by his beloved wife Joan Whiting Brush, sister Carol Brush Banks, two sons and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Larchmont Avenue Church, Larchmont, NY on Thursday, August 9 at 11:00 A.M.

title: Court Rules State Broke Law by Not Doing Impact Studies on New Power Plant
description: The state violated the law by failing to conduct environmental impact studies of the minipower plants that it has installed around New York City, an appellate court has ruled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELISCU, DOROTHY (NEE DEITCHMAN)
description: ELISCU-Dorothy (nee Deitchman). Died suddenly while being treated at the emergency room of the Jersey Shore Hospital on May 25, 2001. Dorothy was an angel who was very beautiful, smart, kind, generous, loving, and had the ability to change peoples' lives for the better. She is survived by her husband, Frank, her daughters, Joanne and Caren, and granddaughter Abigail. Dorothy was a graduate of Hunter College, NYC, and became a school teacher; stopped to have her children and later worked at Fort Monmouth, NJ Army Base as a senior Item's Manager for 25 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERND, ADDIE
description: BERND-Addie, 79. On July 23, 2001. Former owner of Tip Top Printing in Washington Heights. Survived by his wife, Lisa, his daughters, Paulette and Janet, his sons-in-law, Steven and Marc, and his grandchildren, Alex, David, Rebecca and Scott. We will miss his warmth, humor and love. Services today at 1 PM at Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck, New York. In lieu of flowers donations to the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOBENFELD, RUTH
description: LOBENFELD-Ruth. It's been more than 15 years, babe, but you are still the one and only. Love, your Honey

title: New York Turns Into a Lab On the Future of Electricity
description: George Crethan has four new window air-conditioners stacked in the foyer of his Queens apartment, waiting to be installed. They use about half as much electricity as the ones he is replacing, and he will get a $300 rebate check from the state of New York as an added sweetener.

title: Bush's European Theater
description: Midway through President Bush's journey across Europe, from the friendly terrain of Britain to the violent protests in Genoa to the bleak border between Kosovo and Macedonia, a senior German official offered this revised assessment of how the president is viewed by his closest allies.

title: Indonesians Now Await Signs of How Megawati Will Govern
description: Indonesia took a deep breath today as it waited for the formation of a new government that will determine the future balance between reform and stability, civil liberties and tight control.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Opposition Leader Charged
description: In the latest flare-up of political tensions, a leader of the country's new opposition party has been charged with defaming the president, Frederick Chiluba. Edith Nawkiwa, secretary general of the Forum for Democracy and Development, was labor minister until May when she and several other ministers quit to protest President Chiluba's effort to change the Constitution to allow him to stand for a third term. The police said Ms. Nawikwa called the president a ''thief'' during a recent rally. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Trials in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: An Improved Drug Plan in Albany
description: Gov. George Pataki made a fresh offer this week to reform the draconian drug laws that have clogged New York State's prisons with more than 10,000 nonviolent drug users, many of them serving mandatory sentences for relatively minor offenses. The governor's latest proposal, a distinct improvement over the plan he issued in January, would allow thousands more defendants to undergo drug treatment rather than serve long prison terms. It should breathe new life into a flagging effort in Albany to revamp the unjust and unworkable Rockefeller drug laws enacted three decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARLEY, KEVIN
description: FARLEY-Kevin. The students, faculty and administration of the City College of New York/CUNY mourn the untimely passing of our friend & colleague, Kevin Farley, & offer our warmest condolences to his beloved wife Lisa, his son Michael and daughter Tara. A member of the CUNY family since 1982 who also worked at Queens, LaGuardia and Hunter Colleges, Kevin served for the last four remarkable years as the Director of Physical Plant Services at City College. His ability to get things done, his hearty Irish laughter and his large appetite for life will be sorely missed, even as they are permanently manifest in the halls and grounds of CCNY. Kevin loved City College, and City College loved him back. The College is administering a scholarship fund for Michael and Tara. Contributions should be made out to the ''Michael and Tara Farley Scholarship Fund,'' and sent to The City College of New York, Shepard Hall Room 154, Convent Avenue at 138th Street, New York, NY 10031.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Julian Epstein, chief Democratic counsel of the House Judiciary Committee, misstated the position held by his boss, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan. Mr. Conyers is the committee's top-ranking Democrat, not its chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSBORNE, PHILIP B.
description: OSBORNE-Philip B. Writer, editor and poet, July 18, 2001. Memorial Service at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mt. Kisco, New York, on Saturday, July 28th, at 2:00 PM.

title: Hanoi Welcomes Powell, the Foe of 3 Decades Ago
description: Almost 40 years after he first slogged through the jungles of South Vietnam as an American adviser, Gen. Colin L. Powell arrived as secretary of state today in the capital of his former enemy, bringing with him memories of American friends who perished in a war he has caustically called ''a conspiracy of illusion'' and the Vietnamese colleagues who suffered mightily after he left.

title: BUSH, IN KOSOVO, TELLS U.S. TROOPS ROLE IS ESSENTIAL
description: Less than a year after he raised questions about whether American troops should remain in the Balkans, President Bush today told thousands of cheering troops at the largest American military camp in Kosovo that ''America's contribution is essential, both militarily and politically.''

title: Our Towns; Solution Lies Tenth of a Mile Out of Reach
description: AMY MOGEL lives two doors away from a perfect solution to her rather unusual problem.

title: New West Coast College, Born of the Far East
description: On a lavender-covered hilltop halfway between Los Angeles and San Diego, in the midst of miles of look-alike red-roofed tract houses, an architectural and educational marvel reaches skyward above the Pacific, waiting to spring to life next month as the first new private liberal arts college to be built in California in 25 years.

title: Reckonings; Sins of Commission
description: You began saving for your retirement 18 years ago. You could have bought stocks and corporate bonds, but your nephew persuaded you to keep it in the family. So ever since you have been lending him money. Your contributions helped him through some bad financial patches, and recently he used money he borrowed from you to pay off his mortgage.

title: In 'Jenufa,' the Music And Drama Are One
description: Janacek left few lessons for the aspiring opera composer. If he teaches at all, it is by example, offering proof that the contradictory elements of the medium can after all occupy a single point. We experience the operas and follow the thought process, but in the end how speech becomes music and music speech is one of those singular and mysterious events in music, with no past to draw on and no future tradition to serve.

title: In Simeon's 'Court,' 2 Yankees of Sorts
description: The king has won most of the attention, but a few facts have not escaped note about the two American-educated investment bankers who, as of today, are among the most powerful people in the new order of Bulgaria.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Audible Loses Chief And Jobs
description: Audible Inc., an online provider of audio books, magazines and newspapers, announced yesterday that its chief executive had resigned. The company, which has about 86 employees, also said it planned to eliminate 35 jobs -- 40 percent of its work force -- to lower costs. Audible's former president and chief executive, Thomas Baxter, will remain on the company's board. The company's founder and chairman, Donald Katz, has been appointed chief executive, and Robert Kramer, 42, the company's chief technology officer, has been appointed president. Audible, a publicly traded company in Wayne, N.J., said it planned to announce its second-quarter earnings on Aug. 6. Audible's shares rose 8 cents to 58 cents yesterday in regular trading. The company's shares have fallen 88 percent since it first sold shares to the public in July 1999. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Owners of Building Charged In a Collapse That Hurt 11
description: A father and son who owned a Lower East Side building that partially collapsed last summer were charged yesterday with reckless endangerment through improper and dangerous renovations, according to the Manhattan district attorney's office.

title: An Order of Cultural Spying, Supersized
description: LAURIE ANDERSON, the performance artist, has already made 25 pots of coffee at a McDonald's in Chinatown this morning. She's changed out of the standard Mickey D's uniform. Now, a black Prada backpack slung over her shoulder, she's flashing a pretty, dimpled smile as she springs up the steps outside a renovated 19th-century warehouse in TriBeCa where she has a studio loft.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Zomba Invests In Musicnet
description: Zomba, an independent record label, said yesterday that it had made an equity investment in MusicNet, the online music service backed by three major record labels. Under the partnership, Zomba said it would license to MusicNet content from its seven labels, including its flagship label, Jive Records. Terms were not disclosed. MusicNet -- a venture of EMI Recorded Music, BMG Entertainment, AOL Time Warner and RealNetworks -- is creating a service to sell music over the Internet. The companies plan to start the service by the end of the summer. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Prisoner Gets Stay
description: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals granted a stay of execution to Richard William Kutzner, allowing him to appeal a judge's decision that denied him postconviction DNA testing. Mr. Kutzner, who was to be executed today, sought to make use of a new law providing DNA testing for defendants and prisoners. His lawyer said he recently discovered evidence that prosecutors did not disclose to him and that should be tested. Last Friday, a district court ruled that Mr. Kutzner was not entitled to testing and that confidence in his conviction was firm. The stay allows Mr. Marcus to argue for testing. He has 60 days to file a brief with the court. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We found that the adults are as much afraid of the kids as the kids are of the adults.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, BENJAMIN
description: ABRAMSON - Benjamin. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff at the Hospital for Joint Diseases are deeply saddened by the loss of Benjamin Abramson, devoted father of our good friend and colleague, Dr. Steven B. Abramson, Chairman of the Department of Rheumatology and Medicine at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. Dr. Abramson is a longstanding member of our medical staff, who has served with distinction for many years. Benjamin Abramson leaves a grieving family and many friends who will remember him for his kindness and devotion to his family. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Miriam, their children, Steven, Lewis and Susan Nevins, their grandchildren and to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth Chairman of the Board John N. Kastanis, FACHE President and CEO Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief

title: Grants Awarded for New High School Plans
description: The Board of Education has awarded planning grants of up to $250,000 to eight groups with proposals to break up some of New York City's largest and lowest-performing high schools, and to create smaller ones.

title: Nextel and AT&T Wireless Register Losses
description: Nextel Communications Inc., the wireless telephone company controlled by Craig McCaw, and AT&T Wireless Services Inc., which Mr. McCaw sold to AT&T in 1994, posted second-quarter losses today as they spent more to draw customers.

title: Rein In the Cost Of Prescribed Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Said To Want To Sell Unit
description: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., which makes electronic sensors and equipment for secure communications networks, is in talks with Motorola Inc. to buy its military communications unit, the chief executive of L-3, Frank Lanza, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, BERNICE H.
description: ROSNER-Bernice H. The staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York express their deep sorrow at the loss of Bernice H. Rosner, a leading figure in home and community-based health care for more than 50 years. A former Associate Executive Director of VNSNY and, later, CEO of the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, she will be missed for her lifelong commitment to the nursing profession and the highest standards in home care. Carol Raphael, President and CEO, Visiting Nurse Service of New York

title: Schools Are Not Failing
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; In 'Airworld' and in real life, frequent fliers are struggling to keep their mileage accounts up.
description: RYAN BINGHAM, the narrator of Walter Kirn's well-received new novel, ''Up In the Air'' (Doubleday), is a ferociously avid business traveler who lives so much of his life in planes and airports that he regards himself as a full-time resident of a place he calls Airworld.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Volvo Profit Falls
description: Second-quarter profit at Volvo fell 28 percent as demand declined in North America and Western Europe. Volvo, a leading maker of heavy trucks, expects Western European demand to weaken further. Net income fell to 1.36 billion kronor ($127 million), or 3.2 kronor (30 cents) a share, from 1.89 billion ($177 million), or 4.2 kronor a share (39 cents), in the second quarter of 2000.

title: A Climate Pact Without America
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Crabbing Rules Are Challenged
description: Commercial fishermen and seafood processors on Maryland's Eastern Shore have filed a lawsuit in Worcester County Circuit Court challenging new state rules reducing crabbers' workdays to 8 hours from 14 and prohibiting them from catching crabs one day each week. The plaintiffs -- the Chesapeake, Atlantic and Coastal Bays Waterman's Coalition and the Blue Crab Conservation Coalition -- say the regulations, which took effect on Monday, would financially ruin those whose livelihoods depend on Chesapeake Bay blue crabs. Judge Thomas C. Groton III denied the groups' bid to suspend the rules and set a hearing for Aug. 1. Maryland imposed the rules in the first year of a three-year effort to increase the bay's crab stock. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKIN, MAL
description: HENKIN-Mal. Passed on July 11, 2001. Mal was an extraordinary man as he lived an ordinary life. He was brilliantly creative, honest, warm and had certain qualities which were modeled by those who knew him. With a deep baritone voice, long body and kind heart. He was father to Mark and Jon, grandfather, husband and friend. To those of us who loved him, he did not live nearly long enough. We miss him now and forever. Michael

title: Rebel Attack on Airport Shocks Leaders of Sri Lanka
description: An attack by rebels that began on this island nation's main military air base and spilled into its only international airport early today sent hundreds of travelers rushing into the predawn darkness and left leaders questioning how a high-security cordon could have been breached.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: West Haven: Fire Commissioners
description: A judge has ruled that two fire commissioners overstepped their authority when they removed another commissioner and that the ousted commissioner could sue to be reinstated. The State Superior Court judge in Milford, Richard E. Arnold, ruled Monday that the chairman of the Allington Board of Fire Commissioners, Aaron Haley, and a second commissioner, Calvin DeLoatch, could not remove the third commissioner, John Samperi. They had clashed over the hiring of a black fire chief. Mr. Haley and Mr. DeLoatch, both of whom are black, had accused Mr. Samperi, who is white, of making a racist comment following their decision to hire the new chief. Judge Arnold has said he will decide this week whether Mr. Samperi should be reinstated. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: JETS ANNOUNCEMENT EXPECTED
description: The Jets are expected to announce today the signing of their third-round pick, offensive tackle Kareem McKenzie, to a three-year deal. That would leave them with only two draft picks unsigned for training camp, which opens next Monday: receiver Santana Moss, the first-round pick, and running back LaMont Jordan, the second-round pick.

title: Health Official Fined for Gifts From 2 Rabbis
description: The State Department of Health's No. 2 official violated the state ethics law by repeatedly accepting gifts and meals from two Brooklyn rabbis who were seeking access to other health officials in the Pataki administration, the State Ethics Commission said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, RICHARD RODNEY
description: KIRK-Richard Rodney, on July 12th, 2001 at his home in St. Croix. Born in Hendersonville, NC, he graduated in 1955 from the University of the South in Sewanee, TN and in 1958 from the General Theological Seminary in NYC. He was ordained in Newton, NC and in 1968 received a master's degree in psychiatry and religion from Union Theological Seminary. He was on the staff of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine from 1969 until 1976. He helped organize the events surrounding the 1976 Bicentennial celebration in NYC. He was a Director of Manhattan Plaza from 1976 until his retirement in 1997. Requiem Mass on Wednesday, July 25th, 11 AM, at St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46th St.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tire Used as Replacement By Ford to Be Investigated

title: F.C.C. Approves Fox Takeover Of 10 Chris-Craft TV Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to approve Fox Television Stations Inc.'s application to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, which owns 10 television stations.

title: Brazil Eliminated By Honduras
description: Honduras, a late replacement in the 12-team tournament after Argentina withdrew because of security fears, eliminated defending champion Brazil, 2-0, on Monday to set up a semifinal against host Colombia in the Copa America.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaves Invensys
description: The British factory controls maker Invensys said its chief executive, Allen Yurko, 49, would resign in January. Rick Haythornthwaite, the former chief executive of Blue Circle Industries, will succeed him. Invensys also said first-half operating profit would be 30 percent below previous forecasts, the third time it had lowered estimates in 10 months. Job cuts will total 6,000, about double previously announced levels, the company said. Invensys shares fell 15.25 pence (22 cents), or 15 percent, to 86.75 pence ($1.23).

title: An Authentic Gelato, Without a Trip to Italy
description: Gelato is the Italian word for ice cream, but the cold, sweet, creamy stuff that Italians scoop is not an exact equivalent of the American version. Gelato is not frozen as hard as American ice cream, and has a lower butterfat content than top-of-the-line American brands. At Il Gelatone, a new ice cream parlor at 397 Third Avenue (28th Street), Saida Tofani serves the real thing, made on the premises the Italian way. There are usually six to eight flavors, which change from day to day (strawberry, lemon, black currant, chocolate-hazelnut, caramel and deeply winy mixed berry are some), and the assortment always includes plain "milk gelato." (The name does not do justice to that unflavored confection.) Cups and cones are $2.80 to $5.75, and sundaes are $10. Il Gelatone is open daily from 3 p.m. to midnight.

title: Midweek, and the Cook's Cool
description: HERE'S the challenge: you would like to have a relaxed dinner party at home with a few friends, but summer weekends are out -- either you or your friends are then in the country, at the beach or on the road. That leaves weeknights, after everyone finishes a harried day.

title: Milton Gabler, Storekeeper of the Jazz World, Dies at 90
description: Milton Gabler, who founded America's first independent jazz record label, became the first to reissue out-of-print jazz recordings and for years operated what many considered New York City's most comprehensive and knowledgeable jazz record store, the Commodore Music Shop, died on July 20 at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Scientist's Book Is Reviewed
description: Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos National Laboratory nuclear technician, has had to submit a book about his experiences being prosecuted for mishandling weapons secrets to the federal government for review. Dr. Lee was accused of leaking secrets, but prosecutors dropped all but one charge, to which he pleaded guilty, and he was freed last September. His first-person book on the episode, ''My Country Versus Me,'' is written with Helen Zia, a journalist. As a former government employee who handled classified information, he is required to offer books to the government for review. The book is scheduled to be published by Hyperion Books in October, but that depends on the government's releasing the manuscript, which it has had less than two weeks, before then. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Away From the Pack
description: Television news organizations yearn to distinguish themselves from the pack, but they also panic at the prospect of being truly different. This has been notably true in their coverage of the Chandra Levy investigation -- making the decision by ''The CBS Evening News'' to limit its coverage all the more commendable.

title: Top European Trotter Heads Breeders Crown
description: For many years, first at Roosevelt and then at Yonkers, the International Trot attracted the best trotters from overseas. When the race was discontinued after its 1995 running, officials of harness racing's Breeders Crown pondered how to keep attracting the best horses from Europe. They turned to a time-honored solution -- money -- and two years ago raised the purse to $1 million. That attracted a number of the best trotters, and this year they got the very best trotter from Europe.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Projects Approved
description: Nearly $6 billion in federal and state money has been approved for transportation projects in northern and central New Jersey for the next three years. The North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority, which coordinates regional spending, approved the projects Monday. They include $700 million for extensions of the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail system from Jersey City to Weehawken; $151 million for connection of the Newark subway at Broad Street to Newark Penn Station; and $41 million in road improvements to Routes 80, 46 and 23 in Wayne. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: It's Not the Heat or the Humidity; It's the Ozone
description: There was an ozone alert in New York City for the third day in a row yesterday, and with it the usual warning that everyone should avoid strenuous outdoor activities. But did cyclists Dan Plitman and Shayna Kadidal, racing down the Hudson River bikeway in 90-degree-plus heat, show any concern?

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Martinez Makes a Case to Stay a Yankee
description: Tino Martinez lived in Tenafly, N.J., during his first five seasons with the Yankees, but he sold his house after last season and decided to live in Manhattan this season. Martinez always wanted to live in the city and, being a realist, he knew that this year was probably his final opportunity. Everyone, even Martinez, figures he will not return to the Yankees in 2002.

title: Lucent Announces Big Further Job Cuts, and a Large Loss
description: Lucent Technologies, the once-mighty telecommunications equipment giant, announced a large loss yesterday and as many as 20,000 additional job cuts, continuing a dizzying downward spiral that will leave the company with far fewer than half the workers it employed only a year ago.

title: Catering to High Achievers in Math
description: In a small office in a Gothic-style building, four students listened as a professor in a chalk-dusted polo shirt rhapsodized about Euclidean algorithms, Gaussian integers and Fermat's theorem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, NATASHA JEAN
description: DUNCAN-Natasha Jean, on July 21, 2001, at age 21. Beloved daughter of Ian and Ilona. Loving sister of Alec, Scott, James and David Duncan. Dear niece of Isobel Hartley and Helen Armstrong. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, July 27th, 6 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BURGER KING CORP., Miami, part of Diageo P.L.C., named Bennett Nussbaum chief financial officer, succeeding Colin Heggie, who left the company last year. Mr. Nussbaum had been senior vice president and chief financial officer at Kinko's Inc.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shooting At Apartment
description: A group of people, one or more of them standing on a bicycle rack to take aim, fired through a raised first-floor window and shot a man in his apartment about 9 last night on 112th Street between Broadway and Riverside Drive, the police said. Five men were arrested, and a gun was recovered, the police said. The shooting followed an argument. The police did not release the victim's name, but said he was in stable condition with a neck wound. The building, 611 West 112th Street, is a single-room occupancy residence near Columbia University. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Net Falls
description: First-half profit at the Reuters Group fell 21 percent, the company said, adding that it would cut 1,340 jobs, or about 7 percent of its work force, in the face of slowing economic growth. Reuters said net income fell to 269 million ($381 million), or 19 pence (27 cents) a share, compared with 340 million ($483 million), or 24 pence (34 cents) a share, a year earlier. The company also warned of slowing growth for the second half of the year, and, possibly, next year as well. Reuters shares fell 5 percent, to 748 pence ($1.06) a share.

title: Social Security's Fate Hinges On Investing Plan, Panel Says
description: The Bush administration's Social Security commission finished outlining its case today for overhauling the retirement system and faced a firestorm of partisan criticism as it headed into a trickier job: proposing a detailed plan for putting the program on sound financial footing.

title: From 'Eight Men Out' to EBay: Shoeless Joe's Bat
description: The story is told about the time a certain man walked into a liquor store in West Greenville, S.C., that was owned by Shoeless Joe Jackson, who some two decades earlier had been banned from baseball. Jackson, along with seven of his White Sox teammates, had been accused of throwing the 1919 World Series to the Cincinnati Reds for the sake of gamblers.

title: More Weak Profit Reports Push Dow and Nasdaq Lower
description: Stocks fell yesterday as investors grew increasingly frustrated by weak profit reports and by projections that offered few specifics and fewer positive outlooks.

title: Transcript of Renee Boje's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, July 24, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted marijuana legalization activist, Renee Boje, who is fighting extradition from Canada,. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN GAINS. Corn rose 2.6 percent after a government report showed hot, dry weather damaged crops more than analysts expected. In Chicago, corn for December delivery rose 5.75 cents, to $2.265 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, MARY E. (NEE DONLON)
description: McDERMOTT-Mary E. (nee Donlon). On July 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Martin A. McDermott. Loving mother of Mary E. Kennedy, John F. McDermott (both of Massachusetts), Elisabeth M. and George H. Grunig of Belle Harbor, NY, and the late Martin S. McDermott. Cherished grandmother of six. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor, Inc., 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Francis de Sales Church, Thursday, 10AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-10PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIEDLER, BEVERLY
description: FIEDLER-Beverly. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Bringing the Real Police To a Police Procedural
description: THE TWO CHINATOWNS

title: The Travails of Zimbabwe
description: All of southern Africa has an interest in seeing a free and fair election next year in Zimbabwe, where President Robert Mugabe seems prepared to reduce his once hopeful nation to violent ruin in a desperate bid to cling to power. Washington and its friends in the region and beyond need to take steps now that will make possible a level playing field throughout the campaign.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FAIRMONT HOTELS AND RESORTS INC., Dallas, North America's largest luxury hotel chain, said it had bought a 50 percent stake in Boston's Copley Plaza from Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, for $20 million. Fairmont paid $3 million for the right to manage the hotel for the next 50 years.

title: Celebrity News
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Ban On Confederate Flag Shirts
description: A federal judge ruled on Monday that Seminole County students cannot wear T-shirts displaying a Confederate flag to school. The ruling by Chief Judge W. Louis Sands is tentative depending on further information on the potential disruption the shirts might cause and on whether the threat of disruption outweighs free speech rights. He will issue a final ruling on the issue within 60 days. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, THOMAS M.
description: CURRAN-Thomas M. January 5, 1922-July 18, 2001. Beloved husband of Shirley M. Curran. Dear brother of S. Muriel Curran. Greatly missed, his legacy lives on in the lives he touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDMAN, LEO
description: LANDMAN-Leo. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of Rabbi Leo Landman, revered spiritual leader of Congregation Talmud Torah of Flatbush. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Kenneth Auman, Rabbi Elliot Pisem, President

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Differences On Drilling
description: The state's lieutenant governor, Dick Posthumus, left, said this week that he opposed drilling for oil and gas under the Great Lakes, breaking ranks with Gov. John Engler over the issue. Mr. Engler, a Republican like Mr. Posthumus, has said he wants to lift a 1997 moratorium and allow expanded drilling under the lakes, saying the environmental risks are negligible and the potential for oil and gas significant. Opponents say it could harm shoreline habitats and would yield only small amounts of energy. There are seven wells drilled on the shore and reaching deep under the waters of Lakes Michigan and Huron. Mr. Posthumus is expected to seek the Republican nomination for governor in 2002, when Mr. Engler must leave office because of term limits. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; Chinese Group Buys Landmark Site
description: Once, the only way to get a toaster at a bank was to open a savings account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, RUTH ZURKOW
description: BECKER-Ruth Zurkow. On July 23. Wife of the late Dr. Louis Becker. Beloved mother of Jill and Henry. Donations in her memory can be made to the Beth Israel School of Nursing. 212-614-6110.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For AT&T's cable business, on the rebound, is there time enough?
description: IT'S all so clear now. If C. Michael Armstrong had been given the top job at AT&T the first time the company's board chose a successor to Robert E. Allen, Mr. Armstrong might be thinking about his induction speech into a business hall of fame these days rather than about how to fend off an unwelcome takeover bid from some guys from Philadelphia.

title: Former President Carter Is 'Disappointed' in Bush
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has criticized President Bush in a newspaper interview, saying he is deeply disappointed with what he sees as the new administration's conservative bent, particularly in foreign affairs.

title: Chinese Injustice
description: If China's leaders want to move toward an era of more constructive relations with Washington, they will not get there by sentencing United States residents to lengthy jail terms on dubious spying charges just before a visit to Beijing by the secretary of state. Unfortunately, that is just what China did yesterday.

title: New Proposal To Route Power Cable Across Sound
description: Four months after Connecticut regulators rejected a plan to build a power cable across Long Island Sound, saying it would damage oyster beds and provide little benefit to Connecticut residents, the company seeking to build the cable has come up with a new plan that seeks to limit its environmental and commercial impact.

title: Steeped in Family and Faith
description: My father was a tough taskmaster and was unrelenting. He was so worried that we would never learn how to work; he made sure we had plenty to do. From the time I was 12 we had to shine shoes, clean out the basement and mow the lawn. I went out to college at the University of Utah and worked in one of our Hot Shoppes in Salt Lake City. I got there at 4 in the morning and cooked hamburgers and French fries.

title: Clinical Trials, Human Errors
description: As a student some three decades ago, I volunteered to participate in a medical research study. I took part both to make spending money and because I was interested in furthering science. The researchers were trying to develop a treatment for a rare muscle disease, and they wanted baseline data from healthy people on the effects of exercise on heart and lung function.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPP, ROSAMOND PAULI
description: PHILIPP-Rosamond Pauli, 92. On July 18, 2001, in Williamsburg, VA. She was in advertising for 30 years in New York City. An active volunteer and civic leader in NYC, Alexandria, VA, and Williamsburg, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCO, ROGER A.
description: FRANCO-Roger A., 77. Of Santa Barbara, CA, on July 20, 2001. Poet, dreamer, madman and clown. Rest in Peace. Cousin Arnold

title: A Climate Pact Without America
description: To the Editor:

title: Transcript of Jack Curry's Visit to the Major League Baseball Forum
description: Jack Curry, a national baseball writer for The Times, visited the Major League Baseball forum on Wed., July 25. Here is a transcript.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, LILLIAN
description: ROTHENBERG-Lillian. Our much adored Lillian lost her heroic battle to ovarian cancer on July 23, 2001. Teacher, mentor, author and artist extraordinaire, ardently devoted to family and friends. Her passion for life inspired us. Her irresistable smile & wit enchanted us. Her indomitable spirit will live in our hearts forever. Chapel services at Parkside Memorial, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York, Wednesday, July 25 at noon.

title: In Iceland, a Master of Lassitude Stirs in Emotional Hibernation
description: The cagey, wafer-thin Icelandic comedy ''101 Reykjavik'' brims with surliness, from Hlynur, its remorseless, do-nothing protagonist, to its score by Damon Albarn of Blur and Einar Orn Benediktsson of the Sugarcubes. Its writer and director, Baltasar Kormakur, chose a lead actor, Hilmir Snaer Gudnason, with a sly streak. At a screening of ''101 Reykjavik'' at the Toronto Film Festival last year, Mr. Gudnason's facile ennui drew knowing chuckles from like-minded audience members and those who wished they had had his audacity toward indolence.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the author Eudora Welty yesterday misstated the number of O. Henry Awards she received for short stories and misidentified the first of her stories to win one. The total was eight, not six. The first was for ''Petrified Man'' (1939); ''A Worn Path'' won in 1941.

title: A Spirit of Urban Rebellion And a Celebration of Diversity
description: One of the most innovative troupes on the experimental dance scene is Compagnie Kafig, the French hip-hop group presented here by the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGRE, JACK
description: EGRE-Jack. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, N.Y., mourns the loss of a long time member. To Nettie, Martin, Janice, Howard and Garry, our deepest sympathy and condolence. May his memory be a blessing. Laurence A. Feldman, President Myron M. Fenster, Rabbi

title: White House In No Hurry With Options To Kyoto Pact
description: The 178 countries that completed a treaty on Monday aimed at curbing global warming may have to wait a very long time before President Bush, who rejected the pact, puts any alternative on the table, some American officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADISON, DONNA JEAN
description: MADISON-Donna Jean. July 20, 2001, of Bloomfield Hills, MI. Wife of George W. Madison, mother of Kristin Sulena and Jullian Elyse Madison. Daughter of Emalena Davis North, and the late Donald F. Davis, sister of Adrienne Davis Prothro. Funeral Mass at Saint Hugo Of The Hills, 2215 Opdyke, Bloomfield Hills, MI, Friday July 27, 2001, at 11 A.M. Visitation at The William R. Hamilton Co, 820 E. Maple, Birmingham, Michigan Thursday 2-4 and 6-8 P.M. with a Scripture Service at 7 P.M. Memorial Tributes may be made to Gift of Life, or to Michigan Lupus Foundation.

title: Testimony of Priest and Lawyer Frees Man Jailed for '87 Murder
description: A Bronx man was freed from prison yesterday by a federal judge who said he never would have been convicted of murder if the jury had known 13 years ago that a guilt-racked teenager had admitted committing the crime to a priest, a lawyer and others.

title: Two Chinese Residents of U.S. Sentenced to Prison by Beijing
description: A court today convicted two Chinese citizens with permanent residency in the United States of spying for Taiwan and sentenced them to 10 years in prison. A third person, a local Chinese scholar, was sentenced to 13 years.

title: THE BOSS; Steeped in Family and Faith
description: My father was a tough taskmaster and was unrelenting. He was so worried that we would never learn how to work; he made sure we had plenty to do. From the time I was 12 we had to shine shoes, clean out the basement and mow the lawn. I went out to college at the University of Utah and worked in one of our Hot Shoppes in Salt Lake City. I got there at 4 in the morning and cooked hamburgers and French fries.

title: Corn at Work, Cob, Husk and All
description: WHEN American chefs recall their sweetest summer memories, the classic pleasures of the corn fest rank high.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHLAG, ELIZABETH G.
description: OSHLAG-Elizabeth G. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Shanghai's High-Flying Patron Hits Stormy Weather
description: This city's most active patron of the arts has been missing since early June, though the people who know him best know why.

title: Badillo Appeals Ruling On Campaign Fund Match
description: Herman Badillo, the Republican mayoral candidate, appealed to members of the Campaign Finance Board yesterday to count about 125 more donors to help his cash-strapped campaign qualify for matching city funds.

title: 2 Executives Leaving New York Agencies
description: Two top executives at the New York offices of agencies are leaving.

title: Creditors to Liquidate One.Tel of Australia
description: Creditors of the insolvent telecommunications company One.Tel Ltd. voted to liquidate operations, which an administrator had been overseeing since late May.

title: Posada's Potent Bat Lifts Yanks Over Detroit
description: On the bad days, Jorge Posada will return to the dugout after making an out and Yankees Manager Joe Torre will hold up both hands, palms inward. As Torre moves his hands closer, Posada nods, understanding exactly what Torre is driving at: shorten your swing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURLEY, PETER JOSEPH
description: CURLEY-Peter Joseph. On July 24, 2001, of McLean, VA. Beloved husband of Dorothy; loving father of Eileen Wilson, Peter J. Curley, Jr., Anne D. Berube and Claire Curley and loving grandfather of Jack Wilson. Friends are invited to call at the Murphy Funeral Home of Arlington, 4510 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, VA from 7-9 P.M. on Wednesday, July 25 & from 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Thursday, July 26. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 A.M. Friday, July 27 at St. Stephen Martyr Catholic Church, 2436 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington DC. Interment private

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: GlaxoSmithKline Profits Up On Growth in U.S. Drug Sales
description: Helped by strong growth in the United States of its asthma and depression drugs, GlaxoSmithKline said today that its earnings rose 13 percent in the second quarter.

title: Mommy, Where Does Soursop Come From?
description: We all know that the Americas contributed tomatoes, corn and potatoes to the world's diet. But who would think to add pineapple, guava and papaya to that list, let alone the sapodilla and soursop? ''Tropical Fruit'' by Desmond Tate (Periplus, $22.95) a lavishly illustrated book by a writer who lives in Malaysia, explains the origins, history and eventual dissemination of 40 kinds of tropical fruit, including the commonplace (banana, originally from Southeast Asia and now grown around the world); the mangosteen, above; and the weird but inviting (snakefruit, a thick-shelled juicy palm fruit with flesh tasting of pineapple and banana, originally from Indonesia and sometimes called dragon's eggs). The book includes culinary and medicinal uses for each fruit, and trivia: did you know that lime juice is used in ritual washing ceremonies before Malaysian weddings and that in the tropics the banana is used as a snakebite antidote? Many fruit recipes are given, and the next time I find casimiroa in my neighborhood supermarket, I will try the souffl in the book.

title: Privacy Group Is Taking Issue With Microsoft
description: A leading privacy group intends to file a formal complaint with the Federal Trade Commission about Microsoft's plans to bundle its Passport identification system for collecting personal information into its new Windows XP operating system.

title: Bloomberg Quietly Left Four Mostly White Clubs
description: Two months before announcing his bid for mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg quietly began resigning from four exclusive clubs in Manhattan and Westchester County that have predominantly white memberships.

title: U.S. to Resume Farms' Access To Irrigation
description: The interior secretary, Gale A. Norton, said today that she had determined that the federal government could legally allow a small amount of the irrigation water to flow to farmers along the Oregon-California border rather than continuing a cutoff that began in April.

title: House Judiciary Panel Passes a No-Clone Bill
description: The House of Representatives moved one step closer today to tackling the thorny issue of cloning, when the Judiciary Committee, voting along party lines, approved a bill that would outlaw not only cloning people, but also the use of cloning technology to treat disease.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Arrow's New Course
description: Arrow Electronics Inc. announced that its second-quarter net income was ahead of analysts' recently lowered expectations, but warned that it planned to cut 1,000 jobs during the third quarter, which it estimated would save it about $100 million per year. Arrow, based in Melville, N.Y., is the world's top distributor of electronic components. It reported a net income of $7 million, or 7 cents per diluted share, down 92 percent from the $84 million, or 84 cents per diluted share, it reported during the second quarter of last year, when a widespread shortage of electronic components drove prices up. Shares of Arrow rose 22 cents to close at $25.06 in trading yesterday. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Don't Know Much About Art but Know What I Like to Eat
description: Ellen Byrne and Christopher Carlson, a husband-and-wife team, create chocolate bars suitable for framing: miniature paintings with crystallized leaves and flowers embellished with swirls, flourishes and precisely placed nuts. But their careful artistry can vanish in a few bites. The owners of Byrne & Carlson Chocolates in Portsmouth, N.H., they introduced their creatively decorated chocolate bars last year. They use delectable, intensely rich semisweet and bittersweet chocolate from Belgium, France and Venezuela and grow their own mint and pansies, which Mr. Carlson, a confectioner, crystallizes for the candy. The bars, each weighing 4 to 5 ounces, are $4 to $12 and also come in a set of four for $30. The line includes other candies like almond toffee, nut barks, and little dark chocolate wreaths called mendiants adorned with flowers, fruit and nuts, all sold at the shop at 121 State Street in Portsmouth, or by mail from (888) 559-9778. Shipping is extra.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Diplomat Scofflaws
description: Parking-ticket scofflaws at international consulates in New York who do not pay their debts before next Wednesday will risk having their cars seized, the city's Department of Finance said yesterday. Any consulate that has more than $230 in parking tickets since July 1, 1999, could be penalized. The worst offender, according to the department, is Egypt, with $1.6 million in tickets, followed by Nigeria, with $1.1 million, and Kuwait, with nearly $1 million. Australia, owing $10,000, paid its fees shortly after receiving the department warning letter of June 28. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Credit Suisse Is Restricting Investing by Its Analysts
description: Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that it would bar its stock and bond analysts from owning securities in companies they follow, becoming the second big United States brokerage firm to do so.

title: It's Walker Evans Time, And the Getty Is in Luck
description: Two years ago, Weston Naef, curator of the Getty Museum's department of photographs here, decided that it was time to do a show on the photographer Walker Evans.

title: House Republicans May Delay Vote on Patients' Rights Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 -- House Republican leaders, short of the votes needed for a victory, said today they would probably postpone action on a patients' bill of rights until after Labor Day.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: New War Crimes Tribunal For Sierra Leone
description: The Security Council approved the dispatch of a planning delegation to Sierra Leone, which is going to form a tribunal to prosecute about 20 leaders accused of atrocities during the 10-year civil war. The Council also supported a modest funding plan for the tribunal, which was approved last year but has already seen its three-year budget slashed from $114 million to $57 million. Secretary General Kofi Annan called on donor countries to deposit the $15 million already pledged for the tribunal's first year into a trust fund within 30 days. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Ann Billock, vice president at Roth Associates, New York, was named to the new post of executive vice president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBACH, DR. JOSEPH J.
description: MARBACH-Dr. Joseph J. New York Chapter of Hadassah notes with deep sorrow the passing of Dr. Joseph J. Marbach, beloved husband of Judy, member of the Executive Board and editor of Highlights. May his family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Contributions in his memory may be made to New York Chapter of Hadassah. Arline Kempner, President Lois Shallit, Exec. Dir.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, RAE
description: WESTON-Rae. Adored and beloved sister, aunt and great aunt. Cherished forever. Anne P. Lipkind, Wendy and Hillel Black and Harry Black

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Web Site Selling Id's Settles
description: A Web site that offered software to produce false driver's licenses, fake birth certificates and other counterfeit identity documents has settled charges that it violated federal law, the Federal Trade Commission said. The agency said that Jeremy Martinez of Tarzana, Calif., who operated the Web site called Info World, must relinquish $20,000 of illegal gains.
