The amount is based on financial disclosures Mr. Martinez submitted. If the commission determines the statements were false, he could be fined $105,279 -- the amount generated from selling the documents. In December, a federal judge in Los Angeles shut down the site, which offered access to fake identification templates for $29.99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APAT, PRISCILLA
description: APAT-Priscilla. The Partners, Attorneys and Staff of Pearlman Apat and Futterman are deeply saddened by Priscilla's death, and extend our heartfelt sympathies to Burton, Richard and the entire family. Priscilla was instantly adored by all who had the privilege of knowing her. Her radiant smile, effervescent warmth and generosity of spirit touched many, and will be remembered in our thoughts and prayers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Editor in Chief Of Inside.com Steps Down
description: A founder of Inside.com, the media industry Web site that raised expectations about what readers wanted on the Internet and what profits Web sites could reap, resigned yesterday.

title: Some Ports In a Storm
Emission Statement
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Reaffirms Land Transfer
description: In a speech to Parliament, President Robert Mugabe said his government would continue to redistribute white-owned farms to blacks, even though the continued occupation of white-owned land by black squatters has been deemed illegal by the courts. Mr. Mugabe said 100,000 blacks have been resettled and more would move in before the rainy season, the state broadcasting corporation said. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Democrats Sharply Question Consumer-Safety Nominee
description: Democrats denounced President Bush's choice to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission today, saying that the nominee, Mary Sheila Gall, was concerned about industry but not about children and blamed consumers when products from bunk beds to baby bath seats caused injuries.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia To Buy Amber Networks
description: Nokia, the big Finnish cellular phone maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the closely held Amber Networks Inc. for $421 million in stock, to acquire networking gear used to direct Internet traffic. Nokia will exchange an undetermined number of shares based on its average share price on the Helsinki stock exchange over a 10-day period ending five days before the close of the acquisition, a Nokia spokeswoman said. Amber Networks is based in Fremont, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMBEL, WILLIAM
description: GIMBEL-William, 94. Of Atlanta, died July 25. Survivors: wife, Sylvia Ruth Gimbel; children, Dr. Kenneth and Madeleine Gimbel, Atlanta; Dr. Barry and Betty Gimbel, Port Washington, NY; Patricia and Paul Epstein, Wellesley, MA; sister, Regina Gimbel, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Friday, July 27, 2001, 10AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels. Phone 516-487-9600.

title: Cyberspace Isn't So Lonely After All
description: THREE years ago, Robert Kraut, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University, released a shocking study of the Internet's impact. According to his findings, heavy Internet users reported increases in loneliness and depression and saw the size of their social networks decline over time.

title: Stem Cell Research: Politics and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Upholds Court Order Protecting Gardens on City Properties
description: To the jubilation of city gardeners who crowded into a tiny courtroom, a judge in Brooklyn yesterday denied the Giuliani administration's request to lift a court order protecting more than 400 community gardens in the city.

title: G.O.P. POSTPONING VOTE IN THE HOUSE ON PATIENT RIGHTS
description: Lacking the votes needed for a quick victory, House Republican leaders said today that they would delay action on a patients' bill of rights, possibly until after Labor Day.

title: Heinz is putting its money where the young mouths are to promote a line of frozen snacks.
description: HEINZ is stepping up efforts to promote products to the intended eaters rather than to the intended buyers as the company begins an ambitious marketing campaign for a line of frozen snacks centered on Tony Hawk, the popular professional skateboarder.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Sue Furlong, president at the DVC Group, Morristown, N.J., part of DVC Worldwide, was named to the new post of chief operating officer.

title: Sports of The Times; In Harlem, Street Ball Comes of Age
description: ON Tuesday evening at Rucker Park, Bobbie Smooth, the play-by-play announcer, was doing his best to fire up the fans and the players.

title: Sports of The Times; A Pioneer's Hall of Fame Wife
description: GOOD wives and mothers never really die. Helyn Doby will always be in her brick split-level home here on Nishuane Road because she made it a home.

description: To the Editor:

description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Hamas Activist Killed
description: Israelis killed a Palestinian described as an Islamic militant from the Hamas group who had helped plan two bombings in Netanya and other anti-Israel attacks. Witnesses in the West Bank town of Nablus reported that the man, Salah Darwaza, 36, was blown apart when several rockets or tank shells slammed into a car he was driving. The killing was part of Israel's stated policy of singling out key militant figures for death, although the army said it had acted because Mr. Darwaza had been planning a large attack inside Israel. As expected, Hamas leaders promised to avenge the attack. Clyde Haberman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Sales Decline
description: Pohang Iron and Steel said sales in the first half of this year totaled $4.26 billion, a drop of 4.8 percent from the first half of last year. Pohang Iron and Steel, citing a worldwide slump in steel, forecast net income of $620 million for the year, a 20 percent drop from earlier predictions. It reported a net profit of $271 million in the first six months, down $748 million from the first six months of 2000. The chairman, Yoo Sang Boo, said he had no hopes of recovery this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Executive Gives Up Court Fight To Use His Lawn as Copter Pad
description: A multimillionaire in Bedford, N.Y., whose use of a helicopter to ferry him to Manhattan drew complaints from his neighbors about noise and safety has decided to give up his fight for the right to commute via chopper.

title: INSIDE
description: Progress in the Air

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shorter Workweek
description: In two years most Korean bureaucrats will not have to work Saturday mornings. The Labor Ministry said it would introduce a five-day week in the public sector by 2003. People working for private companies may have to wait. The finance minister, Jin Nyum, said the five-day week should be phased in gradually, taking into account the size and type of business. President Kim Dae Jung has said he wants Koreans to work 40 hours each week rather than the current 44 hours, which includes half a day on Saturdays.

title: A Bookshop Catches the Wave Of Surfing Art
description: For surfers in need of inspiration between big wave days, Glenn Horowitz Bookseller in East Hampton has an exhibition of surfing art and homages, including boards with psychedelic graphics (left) designed by the legendary Joel Tudor, posters, books, albums, T-shirts, photographs by Michael Halsband and sculptures by Mike Solomon, who captures the wave's hollow contour in beeswax and wire mesh. The curator, John McWhinnie, said, ''So many worlds collide in the melting pot of surfing.'' The inner world of one surfer, Tony Caramanico, is represented by dozens of notebooks he filled with collages and musings on the perfect wave. The show can be seen through Aug. 16. Information: (631) 324-5511. ALASTAIR GORDON

title: After a Storm, Director Quits Ballet Theater
description: The embattled executive director of American Ballet Theater resigned under pressure yesterday in a continuing crisis for the troupe, one of the world's premier ballet companies.

title: Joseph J. Marbach, 66, Expert on Jaw Pain
description: Dr. Joseph J. Marbach, an expert in the diagnosis and treatment of chronic jaw and facial pain, died on July 22 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 66 and lived in Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a prenatal clinic in Brooklyn that treats immigrant women misspelled the surname of its social worker. She is Josette Crevecoeur, not Crefvecoeur.

title: E-Mail on Your Watch, If You've Got the Time
description: Back in the 1930's, when Dick Tracy phoned friends with his wristwatch telephone, high-tech dreams flooded the comics. But Dick Tracy couldn't receive an electronic message like ''Hey, Tracy: LOL! Signed, Pruneface.''

title: Sales and Rising Prices Rouse Housing Market
description: Existing homes sold at a faster pace than expected in June, an industry report showed today, suggesting that housing will help buoy the economy. Home prices surged to a record.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: G-8 Protester Mourned
description: Nearly 1,000 mourners, including left-wing politicians, attended the funeral in Genoa of Carlo Giuliani, 23, the protester shot by a policeman last week during the G-8 summit meeting. His coffin was decorated with ferns and the flag of his favorite soccer team, Roma. He was the first person killed in antiglobalization protests that began in Seattle in 1999. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: S.E.C. SAYS PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES OVERSTATED EARNINGS
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. said a federal regulator has ordered it to restate earnings after concluding that the company failed to comply with generally accepted accounting principles. The company, which says it has one million policyholders, has said the order, from the Securities and Exchange Commission, to restate earnings would wipe out 64 percent of last year's reported profit and reduce its net worth by $109 million, or 74 percent. Pre-Paid Legal has challenged the S.E.C. order, which was first issued in May, and has said it is considering other options. Pre-Paid, which is based in Ada, Okla., said the S.E.C. rejected its request to meet with Lynn Turner, the chief accountant for the S.E.C., to appeal the decision.

title: Jules Buck, 83, Film Producer And Battlefield Cameraman
description: Jules Buck, a film producer who was a battlefield cameraman for John Huston's World War II documentaries and later helped to launch Peter O'Toole on his movie career, died July 19 in Paris, where he lived. He was 83.

title: A Step Forward in School Governance
description: Five years ago the State Legislature eliminated what had been a de facto sinecure for New York City's 32 local school superintendents by giving the schools chancellor the power to reward good superintendents and fire incompetent ones. At the time, the chancellor lacked performance criteria that would permit valid comparisons among superintendents and among demographically dissimilar schools and districts. But Schools Chancellor Harold Levy unveiled a new evaluation procedure this week that marks an important step forward in holding superintendents accountable for how their districts run administratively and how their students perform academically.

title: In America; Death in the Ashes
description: A counterpoint to the egregious Philip Morris report suggesting that the early death of smokers can benefit a nation's economy is an extensive study by the World Bank that details the chilling -- and very expensive -- toll that cigarettes are taking around the world.

title: Spying on Junior
description: To the Editor:

title: EXXON MOBIL CHIEF TO STAY PAST RETIREMENT AGE
description: Lee Raymond, the chairman and chief executive of the Exxon Mobil Corporation, will remain at the helm of company, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, beyond his planned retirement in 2003 to give the board more time to find a successor. Mr. Raymond had been expected to leave at the company's mandatory retirement age of 65. He will be 63 next month, a spokesman, Tom Cirigliano, said. Exxon's acquisition of Mobil in 1999 delayed the movement of many executives within the company, moves considered necessary to develop the next generation of management, the company said.

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: $30 Million Campaign To Promote KFC Menu
description: The KFC fast food chain is on the offensive, attacking what it calls the ''bland'' and ''ordinary'' fare sold by hamburger competitors in the opening of a $30 million campaign to stimulate sales of its menu items.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANNER, ABRAHAM PASCAL
description: KANNER-Abraham Pascal. The Trustees of the Ida and William Rosenthal Foundation mourn the death on July 22, 2001 of their longtime Trustee and Treasurer. His friendship, good judgment and intelligent guidance for almost 50 years will be greatly missed. Catherine C. Brawer, President

title: Meek or Masterly, A Challenger Awaits
description: WHEN Kenny Salan isn't playing chess online, there is a good chance he is watching chess online, or checking out an online lecture on the game. ''I try to play every day,'' said Mr. Salan, 22, who studies health fitness management at Midwestern State University in Wichita Falls, Tex. After midnight he logs on to observe games between grandmasters, studying opening gambits and mating patterns. ''I watch all of them if I can,'' he said.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Liquor Law Overturned
description: An appeals court in Denver has ruled that billboards, newspapers and other publications can advertise wine and liquor in Utah, overturning part of the state's strict anti-alcohol laws. The three-judge panel ruled that banning the advertisements violated the right of free speech. The ruling also makes the law in Utah more consistent, because the state since 1996 had allowed advertising for beer that was less than 3.2 alcohol. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Little Filly Runs Big as Saratoga Opens
description: She is small, and so lean as to be aerodynamic. And she is inexpensive for the company she keeps as a 2-year-old here in this rich part of the thoroughbred world; she cost just $17,000. But Touch Love entered the Grade II, $100,000 Schuylerville today a perfect two for two and with distinction: she was the only filly in the field of six to have won a stakes.

title: Spying on Junior
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas soared on speculation that a heat wave would raise demand for fuel for air-conditioning. In New York, natural gas for August delivery rose 30.6 cents, or 10 percent, to $3.276 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Lilly Is Still Learning, but Teammates Know How to Win
description: The education of Ted Lilly continued last night. On a sweltering, drizzly night at Yankee Stadium, Lilly absorbed more lessons during his rookie year. Like how to pitch against a team that pounded him one week ago. Like how to pitch with a one-run lead late in a game. Like how to win a close contest. Lilly is still learning.

title: Runoff Vote After Primary in September May be Postponed
description: Faced with hundreds of candidates running for municipal offices, city election officials are considering a postponement of September's runoff election to give themselves more time to count ballots and resolve close races.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTACUZINO, DAN P., MD.
description: CANTACUZINO-Dan P., MD. On July 21, 2001, I lost my beloved husband and best friend, Dan Prince Cantacuzino, MD after a long illness. He will always be remembered by those who knew him for his gentleness, generosity, great knowledge and simple decency. A memorial service will be held at St. Francis Xavier Church, New Milford, CT on Saturday July 28th at 9:30 a.m. The funeral will be at a later date in Bucharest, Romania. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Loaves and Fishes, 40 Main Street, New Milford, CT 06776. In deep sorrow: Barbara Cantacuzino Ernst & Elisabeth Piech Charlotte & Axel Wanivenhaus Florian & Florence Piech Sebastian Piech Philipp, Florian, & Patricia Wanivenhaus Jan Frederic, Lucas, & Elisabeth Piech

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIBEL, ANNETTE
description: HIBEL-Annette. On July 25, 2001. Services Friday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Join her family in celebrating her life. Contributions may be made to Sjogren's Syndrome Foundation, 366 N. Bdwy, Jericho, NY 11753.

title: Mastering the 3-D Universe; On the First Day, He Created Man. It Was a Struggle.
description: People setting out to create 3-D computer-generated art on their personal computers for the first time should remember one thing: It isn't easy. While design software choices -- 3D Studio Max, Bryce 4, Amorphium and so on -- are abundant, none are as intuitive for the user as, say, a word processing program.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about executives who are leaving advertising agencies misstated the old and new titles of Kevin Roddy, who is to succeed Jamie Barrett at the New York office of Fallon Worldwide. He is moving from creative director to executive creative director -- not from associate creative director to creative director.

title: America's Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, DR. PEARL
description: BERKOWITZ-Dr. Pearl. Beloved wife of Sol. Sister of the late Harold Schwartz and Eleanor Waldman. Devoted aunt and great aunt. Clinical psychologist and former Principal of special education schools. Funeral service Friday, 12:30 at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: OPEC Plans A Reduction In Daily Output Of About 4%
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided yesterday to reduce its daily production by about 4 percent, or one million barrels, to buoy crude oil prices amid fears that worldwide oil demand was weakening.

title: Plan Would Waive Tolls for Labor Day
description: State officials are considering making the Garden State Parkway toll-free this Labor Day.

title: Wireless Settlement Offered
description: Five major wireless telephone carriers urged federal officials today to offer NextWave Telecom $4 billion to $5 billion to relinquish its claim to wireless licenses that it acquired several years ago for $4.7 billion, said a spokesman for one company, Verizon Wireless.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Monday about the hiring of the architect Rem Koolhaas as an adviser for Cond Nast magazines misidentified the publisher of his book ''S, M, L, XL.'' It was Monacelli Press, not Taschen America.

title: Man Charged With Beating Of Laborers Is to Go on Trial
description: One of two men charged with beating two Mexican day laborers in Suffolk County last fall is to go on trial on Thursday in a case that has highlighted the tensions over immigrant workers.

title: Dow and Nasdaq Gain After Two Days of Heavy Selling
description: After two days of heavy selling, stocks rallied yesterday as investors took their cues from a few good earnings reports despite the preponderance of bad ones.

title: Tax Credits for Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Rejects New Accord Covering Germ Warfare
description: The United States today rejected an international accord aimed at enforcing a 1972 treaty banning germ weapons but said it would continue looking for ways to salvage the proposal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPHBERG, SARAH GREENBLATT
description: JOSEPHBERG-Sarah Greenblatt. The Officers and Board of Directors of the America-Israel Friendship League extend our sincerest condolences to our friend and colleague Ira Greenblatt on the passing of his beloved mother, Mrs. Sarah (Syd) Greenblatt Josephberg. Syd was a longtime friend and supporter of the AIFL. We will cherish her memory. Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Pres Ilana Artman, Executive V.P.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on July 14 about interpretations of Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' described the work incorrectly. It is a painting, not a fresco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONDEL, MICHAEL L.
description: TONDEL-Michael L. The glow of your spirit is indelibly etched in our hearts. Wendy, Steven, Marnie, and Sam

title: No Retreat on the Hudson
description: As President Bush's chief environmental officer, Christie Whitman has absorbed plenty of abuse for the administration's generally deplorable environmental record. Some of this criticism has been unfair, and in many cases she has taken the fall for policies dictated by others. But Mrs. Whitman will have only herself to blame if she chooses to scale back the Clinton administration's plan that would require General Electric to spend a half-billion dollars to begin the long-overdue task of cleaning the upper Hudson River of toxic chemicals known as PCB's.

title: Roxy Music Returns, Still Eager to Dissect the Good Life
description: Pearly baubles and gossamer lace decorated the Theater at Madison Square Garden as Roxy Music, rock's most rebelliously stylish band, played Tuesday as part of its reunion tour. Bryan Ferry, the band's singer and resident matinee idol, pranced around making flamenco-dancer gestures and deploying his patented vocal swoons. ''All the way is far enough,'' he sang in ''Dance Away,'' neatly summarizing Roxy Music's long journey over glamour's precarious edge.

title: Need for Summer Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Well-Known Agency To Close After 62 Years
description: Warwick Baker O'Neill, a well-known New York agency, said yesterday that it would close after 62 years.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS TO BUY SAGEM UNIT FOR $435 MILLION
description: Johnson Controls Inc., the second-largest maker of automotive interiors and seats, agreed to buy the vehicle electronics unit of Sagem of France for $435 million to add to its electronics technology. The business is expected to have sales of $522 million this year and has about 2,600 workers, mostly in France, Johnson Controls said. Johnson Controls, which is based in Milwaukee, expects to complete the acquisition in October, said a spokesman, Glen Ponczak. Johnson Controls has worked with Sagem since 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALLAN J.
description: COHEN-Allan J. of Somers, NY and Orlando, Florida, died on July 25, 2001 at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, NY. He was 86. On December 24, 1939, he married Betty Thalmessinger. He is survived by his loving wife Betty, daughter Nancy, sons, Donald and Ken, 8 grandchildren, 3 greatgrandchildren, and his brother Malcolm. Calling hours Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clark Funeral Home in Yorktown Heights. Interment Friday 11 A.M. at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Jets Sign Two Draft Picks
description: The Jets signed their second-and third-round draft picks yesterday, leaving only the first-rounder Santana Moss unsigned with the start of training camp two days away.

title: Military Budget Creates Rift in G.O.P.
description: The debate over Pentagon spending has exposed a deep rift within the Republican Party's conservative wing, pitting supporters of tax cuts and smaller government against military hawks who contend that President Bush is shortchanging the armed forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANA, G. MORLEY JR.
description: MORGANA-G. Morley Jr., on July 11, 2001. Most beloved friend, son, brother, cousin and uncle, whose lives his spirit illuminated. He will be profoundly missed. No immediate plans for a memorial. ''Details to follow...''

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Not for Wine Bottles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABLER, MILTON
description: GABLER-Milton. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Milton Gabler on July 20. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Al Fresco Screening With Hot-Tub Seating
description: WHEN James Ronald Whitney moved into a building on Duane Street three years ago, the roof was nothing but tar. Others noticed the stunning view. He saw a screening room with a hot tub.

title: Well-Known Agency to Close After 62 Years
description: Warwick Baker O'Neill, a well- known New York agency, said yesterday that it would close after 62 years.

title: AND YET SO FAR: A special report.; Quest for Mideast Peace: How and Why It Failed
description: Days before the Palestinian uprising erupted in September, Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat held an unusually congenial dinner meeting in the Israeli's private home in Kochav Yair.

title: Studs Terkel Adds His Voice To Experimental Web Venture
description: Studs Terkel, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and for 50 years a voice for Americans who are often not heard, is lending his voice to the Internet.

title: Giuliani's Worshipful Scribe, Without Meat or Irony
description: THE interrogation commences with a clammy handshake in a high-rise hallway outside Money magazine's offices. Ken Kurson, the reluctant interviewee, is worried about being overheard by his co-workers. It concludes with a clammy arm-wrestling session in a private conference room in which Mr. Kurson, all chatted out, prevails. The interviewer cries uncle.

title: Other Immigrants, Envying Mexicans, Demand a Break, Too
description: A proposal from President Bush's top advisers to let more than one million Mexicans living here illegally earn permanent legal status has stirred envy and some anger among millions of non-Mexican immigrants, many of whom are now demanding equal treatment.

title: House Proud; Classic Stories, A Fresh Chapter
description: PEOPLE fall in love with a house the way they fall in love with each other -- totally charmed, head over heels, don't want to change a thing.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lender's Results Disappoint
description: Abbey National's first-half profit rose 12 percent, less than analysts had expected, after Abbey National, one of Britain's largest mortgage lenders, said it had set aside more money than expected to cover potential defaults by United States corporate borrowers. Net income rose to 698 million ($994 million), or 47 pence a share, compared with 626 million, or 42 pence, last year. Analysts had expected a 14 percent rise in income. The bank, whose planned merger with Lloyds TSB was recently blocked by regulators, said it had set aside 64 million to cover potential loan losses in the United States. Abbey National shares fell 10 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BSKYB Loss Grows
description: As it spends heavily to attract viewers to its digital service, the British satellite broadcaster BskyB posted widening losses for the fiscal fourth quarter, its ninth successive quarterly loss, but said it had increased its subscriptions a fifth over the full year. Its shares rose as much as 2.1 percent. The company said it had increased spending on sports, movies, entertainment and interactive services to draw new customers and had expanded its subscriptions 22 percent, to 5.45 million, well ahead of rivals. But fourth-quarter losses were $244 million, roughly a third more than in the period a year earlier. BskyB is controlled by the News Corporation. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: So Many Online Providers
description: To the Editor:

title: Revenue Falls, But Xerox Sees Bright Spots
description: The Xerox Corporation, trying to rebuild its ailing businesses in the face of a slowing economy, said yesterday that its second-quarter revenue was down 13 percent from last year, and that it had lost money for the fourth quarter in a row.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Canadian Nest Eggs In a Nortel Basket
description: The plunge in the telecommunications industry is sending a shock through many Canadians' retirement plans.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From sightseeing in Tennessee to dining in Paris, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Boyd Named Managing Editor of The New York Times
description: Gerald M. Boyd, the deputy managing editor for news at The New York Times, will become the newspaper's managing editor, Howell Raines, the incoming executive editor, announced today.

title: Allegro, Andante, Adagio And Corporate Harmony; A Conductor Draws Management Metaphors From Musical Teamwork
description: ''You are going to have the experience of a lifetime!'' Roger Nierenberg exclaimed as he led a business executive to the podium, turned her toward the National Symphony Orchestra and put a baton in her right hand. ''By putting the baton in your hand you are going to feel the leadership message going out and you're going to feel the responses coming back,'' he said. ''What the orchestra is playing is really emanating from this little thing.''

title: Easing the Crossroads''
description: In an effort to further decongest foot traffic in Times Square, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday the latest phase of the Times Square traffic calming plan. The plan involves expanding sidewalks using asphalt extensions and separating pedestrians from vehicular traffic by installing planters, pavement markings and posts.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from July 26.

title: Ward Is Trying To Alter His Image
description: After spending several hours yesterday morning installing a fence and landscaping a renovated building in Harlem, Charlie Ward presented keys to one of the six condominiums inside to Wannetta Worthy, an excited new homeowner.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Strike Protests Privatization
description: Millions of federal and state government workers went on a one-day strike to protest plans to sell government-owned companies. The strike, which spared defense establishments and the railway system, was successful in the financial capital, Bombay, as well as southern and eastern India. Trade unions who called the strike oppose government reform plans, fearing they would lead to large-scale layoffs of government workers. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Make Fantasies in Your Spare Time
description: DAVID MIKULEC of Danville, Ky., spends his working hours testing software for a printer manufacturer. But at home he is often on the Internet, where he is known by the screen name Atomic Anvil, uploading scenes from his imagination that he has created on his desktop computer.

title: Frances R. Horwich, 93, Host Of 'Ding Dong School' in 50's
description: Frances R. Horwich, the amiable educator who engaged millions of preschoolers as the host of the pioneering children's program ''Ding Dong School'' in the 1950's, died yesterday. She was 93.

title: In Search of Stewartania
description: To the Editor:

title: A Speedier Way to Run Mac Programs on Windows
description: Apple loyalists might consider selling Windows software at a Macintosh trade show akin to a Hatfield's showing up at a McCoy family reunion. But SoftMac Xpress, unveiled last week by Emulators Inc. at MacWorld Expo in New York, is the latest version of software that lets Windows users run Macintosh programs and open Mac files on their Windows machines. The new program, SoftMac Xpress, will work with Windows 98 and 2000 and the next version of Windows XP.

title: Looking at the World of Art, by the Letter
description: Cezanne, Michaelango, Expressionism and oil paint are all part of the world of art and are described in ArtLex, an online art dictionary (www.artlex.com).

title: Smooth Moves in Cool Grooves, Working Double Time
description: Seductive rhythm-and-blues smoothies worked a double shift in Manhattan on Sunday, when Craig David sang at the afternoon show at Summerstage and then R. Kelly finished a two-night stand at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. Each advertised his sexual prowess and promised to fulfill a woman's every need, slowly and thoroughly.

title: Double Fervor for the Moor of Venice
description: The arches of Caramoor's Venetian Theater made an appropriately scene-specific backdrop for Verdi's ''Otello'' on Saturday night. This was the second ''Otello'' that the Bel Canto Project, directed by Will Crutchfield, has taken on at Caramoor this summer.

title: Social Security's Stable Benefit
description: A recent report by the Bush administration's commission to study Social Security claims that African-Americans get a bad deal from the Social Security program. The report says they would do better if the system included private individual investment accounts. But there are good reasons to doubt whether privatization would be as positive as proponents claim.

title: Beyond Zip: Hard Drive Unhitched
description: UNTIL recently the storage-disk maker Iomega gave all of its products onomatopoetic names like Jaz, Clik and Buz. And why not? The first product it named that way, the Zip drive, was a megahit: a 100-megabyte successor to the floppy disk that became so popular it's now standard equipment on many PC's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, GLADYS R.
description: CUNNINGHAM-Gladys R. Of Crestwood on July 24, 2001. Wife of the late William J. Cunningham, mother of Jule A. Saracco, Ursula C. Woodruff and Francis P. Cunningham, grandmother of eight, great grandmother of five. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Thursday and Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood on Saturday July 28 at 10 AM. Donations may be made to St. Vincent Cancer Center or Jansen Hospice.

title: Free Trade With Vietnam
description: During Colin Powell's visit to Vietnam this week, the secretary of state found a nation whose economy has taken more strides toward the future than has its cumbersome, authoritarian government. Vietnam's people are dynamic and optimistic. Roughly 60 percent are younger than 30 years old, the product of half a century of war with France, the United States and China. Though their politically rigid government has yet to conquer corruption and poverty, it has encouraged entrepreneurial activity. Both countries can benefit from a closer relationship. The free trade agreement awaiting approval by Congress can help build those ties.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Rail Company To Reimburse City
description: CSX Transportation agreed to pay overtime costs for Baltimore police, fire and some public works employees stemming from last week's freight train derailment, fire and water main break in a tunnel beneath the city's downtown. CSX Transportation, a unit of the CSX Corporation of Richmond, Va., made the decision after meeting with top aides to Mayor Martin O' Malley, above. Robert L. Gould, a CSX spokesman, said the agreement ''is in no way an acknowledgment of fault or blame. It's just the right thing to do as a corporate citizen.'' Mr. O'Malley's office last night estimated the total costs from the wreck at $1.3 million but said that figure included expenses other than the overtime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HARRY
description: WEISS-Harry. On July 24, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Harriet. Devoted father of Susan and Dr. Norman Sonnenklar and Bette and Dr. Richard Weledniger. Cherished grandfather of Alan, Eric, Risa and Leslie and great grandfather of Jacob, Adam and Harris. We miss you and will always remember the good times. Services Thursday, 12 Noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Pl, (opp LIRR), Great Neck, Long Island.

title: Assessing School Chiefs
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think the relationship is on the upswing now, now that these irritations are behind us, and I know they are anxious to move forward.''

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: GROCERY FOR LOWER MANHATTAN

title: The Persistence of Junk Mail
description: File for bankruptcy protection. Last Sundays Times ran an astonishing story. It reported that Hooters of Augusta, Georgia which is owned by the national chain, had filed for bankruptcy protection after being slammed with a $12 million fine. Its crime: Sending unsolicited junk faxes.

title: A Guessing Game to Rally the Diabetic Child
description: PEOPLE with chronic medical conditions often find the tedium or discomfort of treatment more unpleasant than the disease. Now a medical student has proposed a way of making medical compliance less burdensome: why not turn it into a computer game?

title: Marketing of Entertainment Brings Sharp Debate
description: Entertainment industry executives and Congressional leaders clashed today over demands from lawmakers that the industry take responsibility for its marketing of explicit material to young audiences.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Computer Files on Recount to Be Released
description: Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, reversed her position today and said she would allow reporters to inspect the hard drives of computers used to draft correspondence in the presidential stalemate last November.

title: Siemens, Posting 3rd-Quarter Loss, Fires a Unit Chief
description: Siemens, the German electrical engineering company whose products range from light bulbs to nuclear power plants, fired the head of its telephone networks division today and promised drastic cost-cutting after surprising investors with a worse-than-expected loss of $428 million in the third quarter.

title: That's How the Bubble Bursts: One Goes Down for the 10 Count
description: In June, Interiors magazine shut its doors. Now, One Media, the publisher of One, both a magazine and a Web site, has succumbed to the economic downturn. Its August-September issue, the fifth and final One, is on newsstands now. One, produced in San Francisco, sought a mainstream readership with its breezy architecture and design coverage. One Media, founded 18 months ago by Dana Lyon, former publisher of Wired magazine, raised money as if it were an Internet startup. It employed 40 people, and One's circulation reached 200,000. ''When we look back on this period we'll all be floored by how quickly the economy went south,'' said Stacy Morrison, One's editor in chief. CHRISTOPHER HAWTHORNE

title: A Reunion? Relax. You're Invisible.
description: A FEW months ago I was overcome with nostalgia and self-pity. A former classmate e-mailed me a link to my past. ''Click here,'' he invited.

title: A Vote to Lift a Cuba Ban
description: The House voted again today to approve a measure that would effectively lift the ban on most travel to Cuba. But travelers considering a Cuban vacation should not rush to pack their bags.

title: TIME AGREES TO BUY IPC MEDIA FOR $1.6 BILLION
description: In a push to expand overseas, Time Inc., the magazine unit of AOL Time Warner, agreed to buy IPC Media, a British publisher, for $1.6 billion. The deal will give Time Inc. a place in the British magazine market, where IPC Media publishes titles like What's on TV, a television guide; Loaded, a men's style magazine; and Horse & Hound, an outdoors magazine. IPC Media's largest shareholder is Cinven, which led a $1.2 billion management buyout of the company in 1998 from Reed Elsevier. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Stimulus
description: Singapore's government announced 2.2 billion Singapore dollars ($1.2 billion) of stimulus measures to offset an export slowdown that has thrown the economy into recession. The minister of trade and industry, George Yeo, told Parliament the government would step up infrastructure spending while extending tax breaks and reductions in the employer contributions to the national pension fund that were granted during the Asian financial crisis four years ago. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Mets Win; Please Restrain Your Excitement
description: Even in victory, the Mets can hurt and embarrass themselves. Mike Piazza and Tsuyoshi Shinjo avoided major injuries while scoring runs tonight, and the team set a franchise record for futility.

title: Madonna and the Wiles of Willfulness
description: Nothing holds back Madonna. Not love, not pop expectations, not tastefulness, not religion, not the laws of physics. Her Drowned World tour, which started its sold-out five-night run last night (through July 31) at Madison Square Garden, is a 105-minute pop spectacle as performance art, devoted to the idea that Madonna can do what she wants. Her fans, theoretically, are welcome to take it or leave it.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Farm Bill Advances
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a $7.4 billion emergency farm bill, adding $2 billion more than a measure passed by the House and supported by the Bush administration. Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat and committee chairman, said he expected the full Senate to pass the bill. But Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, said he would recommend that the president veto any bill larger than $5.5 billion.

title: A Hamptons Garage Sale With Diva and Drinks
description: They call it Super Saturday 4. It's a benefit sale in the Hamptons of designer furniture, accessories and clothing, and starts at 1 p.m. on Saturday at Nova's Ark Project, 60 Millstone Road, in Water Mill, N.Y. The goods include spa towels by DKNY (right), selling for half price, $12; wine accessories in a burled wood box (center right), half price at $30; and jasmine-scented candles in painted glasses from Morocco (far right), half price at $18 for a set of three. The event, which benefits the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, will include a performance by Patti LaBelle, an auction and a cocktail party at 8 p.m. in East Hampton. Tickets, $350; reservations, (212) 268-1002. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Summer-School Attendance
description: Given the choice between summer school and repeating a class in the fall, many high school students are forgoing summer school. The Board of Education reported yesterday that attendance among high school students who failed a class in the last school year fell slightly, to 53.6 percent this week from 55 percent two weeks earlier. Among elementary and middle school students required to attend summer school or face having to repeat a grade, 77 percent showed up this week, slightly more than two weeks earlier. Over all, two out of three students enrolled in summer programs have shown up. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Making It the Trailer That Has Everything
description: Last week, Limn, a home furnishings shop in San Francisco, celebrated its 20th anniversary by lifting a 25-foot Airstream trailer like the one below to its roof, next to outdoor furniture. But this is no typical Airstream. Inside are a Gaggenau stainless steel gas stove (bottom), cherry wood furniture and interiors by Roberto Lazzeroni, the art director of Ceccotti Collection, a furniture maker in Italy. ''I've always loved Airstreams and wanted to redo the interior,'' said Dan Friedlander, the owner of Limn. Kits to retrofit 25-foot Airstreams for baths, kitchens, living rooms or sleeping modules (six months for delivery) are $36,000 to $45,000 (plus installation). A furnished trailer is $160,000. Through December, at 290 Townsend Street; (415) 543-5466. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAUMONT, ALAN
description: BEAUMONT-Alan. Former NBC director, died July 19 at home in Lakeville, Connecticut. An early television pioneer, he directed many live television programs, including Wide Wide World and The Home Show with Arlene Francis & Hugh Downs. Mr. Beaumont also directed the country's first-ever color broadcast. Born in British Columbia in 1919 and graduated from the University of Wisconsin, Mr. Beaumont was married for fifty-seven years to Jean Beaumont, who died in 1999. He is survived bu daughter Diana, son Terence, sisters Doris and Donna, and brothers Guy and Denis. Funeral services will be private.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Transportation Bill Dies
description: Republican and Democratic lawmakers declared the state's $8.8 billion transportation package dead as the Legislature wrapped up its third special session with no solution for transportation problems. No agreement was reached on the size of increases for the gasoline tax, weight fees for commercial trucks and an automobile sales tax. Yesterday was the 163th day of the legislative season. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: A Charge Results in a Loss at El Paso Gas
description: The El Paso Corporation, owner of the nation's largest network of interstate natural gas pipelines, reported a second-quarter loss today, citing a $547 million charge related to its purchase of the Coastal Corporation in January.

title: As Flight Delays Ease Off, New-Runway Push Begins
description: New government figures show that flight delays eased markedly in the second quarter of this year, but the airlines and air traffic controllers, describing passengers as still unhappy, will open a campaign on Thursday to build public support for new runways and other improvements.

title: Iraqis Nearly Hit a U.S. Plane
description: A surface-to-air missile came worrisomely close to an American U-2 surveillance plane high above southern Iraq on Tuesday, more evidence that Saddam Hussein's forces are increasingly adept at zeroing in on aircraft patrolling the no-flight zones, a senior Defense Department official said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDMAN, DR. LEO.
description: LANDMAN-Dr. Leo. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a distinguished former dean of its Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies and dedicated alumnus, beloved husband of Shirley. An eminent authority on Jewish history, law, and rabbinics, he was also a former dean of graduate Jewish studies and of undergraduate Jewish studies. A '49 Yeshiva College alumnus and '51 musmakh of YU's affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, he joined BRGS in 1969 as secretary of the faculty and assistant professor of Jewish history and recently served as adjunct associate professor. Active in the Philadelphia community for many years, he has been the longtime spiritual leader of Cong. Talmud Torah of Flatbush, Brooklyn. He was a man of learning and sweetness. To his wife, Shirley; their children, Chana, Dina (and Avi) Cohen, and Dr. Dovid (and Dr. Leora) Landman; grandchildren; and the entire family we offer our heartfelt condolences. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Inmates Stage A Protest
description: Disgruntled about a smoking ban and with other grievances at a maximum-security state prison in Maryland, about 1,200 inmates have holed up in their cells, refusing to come out for work details, meals, recreation or classes. The protest at the Maryland House of Correction in Jessup began on Monday morning when a few inmates refused to leave their cells. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAU, EVA
description: SCHLAU-Eva. AMIT is deeply grieved by the passing of our most devoted AMIT Florida Council Chairwoman. Loved by all, Eva Schlau was a true ''Woman of Valor'', who was the consummate volunteer, having devoted many years to helping AMIT and its mission to ''save the forgotten children of Israel.'' Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Boy Charged In Shooting Of Bronx Girl
description: A 12-year-old boy was charged last night in the death of Taniqua Hall, a 9-year-old Bronx girl who the police originally believed shot herself in the chest accidentally on July 1 after finding a gun at her grandmother's house.

title: Mayor Backs Bill to Make Police Report Race in Frisks
description: In an agreement that ended months of sparring at City Hall, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave his support yesterday to a City Council bill that would require the police to release information on the race of those stopped and frisked by officers. Supporters of the bill said it might help address allegations of racial profiling by the Police Department.

title: Stem Cell Research: Politics and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH/Julia Child; Change of Scene, if Not Cuisine
description: THE voice on the telephone rose and fell in its unmistakable warble, familiar from nearly four decades of television. It made me an offer I could not refuse. ''I will make you a tuna sandwich,'' the voice said.

title: Price-Fixing Indictment
description: Ishihara Sangyo Kaisha Ltd., a maker of titanium oxide and bioscience products, has been indicted by a grand jury in Philadelphia on a charge of conspiring to fix prices of magnetic iron oxide particles, the Justice Department said today. The indictment says the company, based in Osaka, Japan, and co-conspirators set the prices and allocated customers from 1991 to 1998, the Justice Department said. The magnetic iron particles, used to coat polyester film base in video and audio tapes, give the tapes the magnetic quality that allows them to pick up sounds and images. Representatives of the company's United States subsidiary, ISK Americas Inc., could not immediately be reached for comment.

title: Boyd Named Managing Editor of The New York Times
description: Gerald M. Boyd, the deputy managing editor for news at The New York Times, will become the newspaper's managing editor, Howell Raines, the incoming executive editor, announced today.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose as cooling German inflation reinforced expectations the European Central Bank will lower interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 88.10 cents, up from 87.64 cents on Tuesday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Intelsat Names New Chairman
description: Intelsat Ltd., which became a private satellite communications company after almost 40 years as an intergovernmental group, chose the chief executive of Lockheed Martin Global Telecommunications, John V. Sponyoe, to be chairman. Mr. Sponyoe, 62, left, has also served on the boards of the Lockheed Martin Corporation's Comsat and Lockheed Martin Intersputnik units, Intelsat said. Intelsat's chief executive, Conny Kullman, who has held the position since November 1998, and 16 nonmanagement directors, including Mr. Sponyoe, were elected to the board by shareholders last week. Intelsat has obtained licenses from the Federal Communications Commission to operate 17 existing satellites and build 10 new ones at a cost of about $3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, ESTELLE
description: SCHINDLER-Estelle. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Loving mother of Roslyn and Scott and the late Daniel. Cherished grandmother of Jeff and Alan.

title: Books by Blacks In Top 5 Sellers
description: There's something going on out there about African-American writing, and no one really knows what. But there are three novels by and about blacks on the New York Times best-seller list and a fourth that had been on the list and is hovering just below it. No one can recall that happening before, so it seems that this is really astonishing.

title: Senate Extends Sanctions on Libya and Iran
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to extend sanctions against Iran and Libya for another five years, rejecting the Bush administration's efforts to limit the sanctions to a shorter time frame to allow more diplomatic flexibility.

title: An Austere Albany Budget May Not Please Anyone, and That's the Whole Point
description: The stripped-down budget that legislative leaders have agreed to pass next week is not likely to please many people, since it leaves out money for scores of new programs and spending increases for everything from schools to environmental protection to health care.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Profit Is Up
description: The largest bank in Spain and Latin America, Banco Santander Central Hispano, said second-quarter profit rose 30 percent as it trimmed costs and its Brazilian operation began contributing to profit. Net income climbed to 714 million euros ($623 million) from 551 million euros a year earlier. In Latin America, where a possible Argentine debt default and an economic slowdown threaten profit, Banco Santander reduced its work force 10 percent, to 67,000, this year. In Spain, where the economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace since 1996, the bank plans to shut 1,000 of its 5,000 branches.

title: It's a Trolley! It's a Rail Car! No, It's an Optically Guided Bus
description: LAS VEGAS bus drivers may keep their eyes on the road, but in a couple of years some of them will no longer have to keep their hands on the wheel.

title: Into the Groove, and Proving Their Love
description: There are, apparently, an infinite number of ways to show love for Madonna.

title: India's 'Bandit Queen' Is Dead, Gunned Down at 37
description: Phoolan Devi, India's legendary ''bandit queen,'' was killed by masked gunmen outside her home today, the last installment in a soap-operatic life where a rape victim became an avenging outlaw and a champion of the oppressed.

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: Hevesi Picks Staten Island for Campaign Office
description: Aides were mum as to the rent, but it is safe to say that it is probably not $50 a square foot. And it is a bus and a ferry ride away from all the major subway lines. But Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi finally opened his first campaign office yesterday -- in Staten Island, the city's least populous borough.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK UNIONDALE: HIGH POWER DEMAND Long Island's electricity demand came close to exceeding its supply yesterday, the Long Island Power Authority reported. "It was extremely tight," said the utility's chairman, Richard M. Kessel. As temperatures in Hicksville exceeded 97 degrees and humidity climbed past 86 percent, electricity demand peaked in Long Island between 4 and 5 p.m. at 4,443 megawatts, just 94 megawatts shy of capacity. It was the second-highest peak demand ever recorded by the utility. The highest was recorded about two years ago. Earlier in the day, for the first time this summer, the utility warned customers to reduce air-conditioning and other electricity use.   Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWER, CHARLES (''CHUCK'') H.
description: TOWER-Charles (''Chuck'') H. On June 21, 2001, age 81. Beloved husband of Leslie Beran. Loving father of David Tower and his wife Beeke Sell Tower, Christopher Tower, Sondra Tower and her husband Larry D'Amico. Much loved grandfather of Jonah, Niklas, and Johanna. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. A service will be held at 11 a.m., August 4th, at the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, CT.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Presidio Compromise
description: The Presidio, a former Army base, would one day become part park, part neighborhood and part tourist attraction with hotel, shops and museums under a proposal announced by the Presidio Trust. The proposal represents a compromise with environmentalists and neighbors, who have fought to limit development in the rambling, centuries-old park. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: XM Satellite Radio Gets Help From Falling Stars
description: Familiar musicians will seem to fall from the sky to help introduce XM Satellite Radio, a service planning to offer almost 100 channels of music, news, sports and entertainment beginning in September for a $9.99 monthly subscription fee.

title: In Hartford, Pulling Out All The Stops To Halt Crime
description: With community outrage still palpable over the shooting of a girl in the face as she played outside on the Fourth of July, teams of local police officers and state troopers fanned out across Hartford today as part of a new joint effort to quash crime and halt the soaring murder rate.

title: Metro Matters; Falling Down On the Upkeep Of City Parks
description: IN the last three years, New York City has spent $1.5 million improving Queensbridge Park, just north of the Queensboro Bridge. City money paid for reconstruction of four ball fields, lighting for night games, renovation of Vernon Playground and the planting of rose of Sharon shrubs and junipers in a neat triangle near the children's sprinkler.

title: Iran Court Won't Pursue Slain Protester's Case
description: A court has ruled that it has no authority to pursue a murder prosecution in the case of a man who was killed two years ago in a clash between pro-reform students and hard-line vigilantes. The court found that the man brought on the attack by taking part in the protest.

title: Justice Works Out At an Empty Stadium
description: David Justice swung casually and forcefully in the batting cage yesterday afternoon. He loped a few steps to his right and to his left for fly balls, and he trotted across the outfield, all the while testing his strained left groin. The game between the Yankees and the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium was three hours away, but Justice's movements before more than 57,000 empty seats might have been the most important event of the day for the Yankees.

title: Xerox Names Anne M. Mulcahy as Chief Executive
description: Investors may still be waffling on whether the Xerox Corporation's ( news/quote ) entrenched management is the right team to lead the copier company in a digital age, but Xerox's board weighed in with a resounding vote of confidence today, naming Anne M. Mulcahy, its president, to be chief executive.

title: Korea to Ease Restrictions On Who Can Invest in Banks
description: In a major concession to the demands of South Korean business leaders, the finance minister, Jin Nyum, said today that the government would remove some of the longstanding constraints on ownership of banks by the nation's leading conglomerates.

title: Canadian Phone Giant Reports Loss in Quarter
description: BCE, Canada's telecommunications and media giant, said today that it posted a net loss of 31 million Canadian dollars ($20.2 million) in the second quarter, after write-offs and its share of losses in an international cellular phone business. In the corresponding period last year, net profit was 24 million Canadian dollars ($15.6 million).

title: Metro Business Briefing | Grocery For Lower Manhattan
description: A 22,000-square-foot food store and restaurant is scheduled to open on Tuesday at 59 Maiden Lane in Lower Manhattan, a neighborhood that is not known for its wide selection of markets. The new retail operation, Zetuna, is owned by the Amish Market, a small Manhattan grocery chain that operates a two-year-old market at Washington and Cedar Streets. Unlike the Amish Market, which was subsidized by the developers of nearby residential buildings, Zetuna is not receiving a subsidy, said Valerie Lewis, a spokeswoman for the Alliance for Downtown New York, a business group. Jubilee Market, another food store catering to the expanding downtown residential population, opened a year ago on John Street, a block away from Zetuna. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: A Civil Rights Group Suspends, Then Reinstates, Its President
description: Angry board members of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference suspended Martin Luther King III from his job as president last month, concerned that he was letting the civil rights organization founded by his father drift into inaction, the group's chairman said today.

title: Editors' Note; About Mutual Funds
description: As a result of growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is eliminating entries for some of the smallest ones and making its daily table more concise.

title: De Beers Wins and Loses Before Regulators in Europe
description: The European Commission approved a plan today by the De Beers Group of South Africa to establish a diamond retailing venture with the luxury goods company LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Technology Briefing | Software: More Jobs Cut At I2 Technologies
description: I2 Technologies, a maker of business-to-business software, said yesterday that it would cut 587 jobs, or 10 percent of its staff, leaving the company with about 5,300 employees. Last week, the company reported a quarterly loss of $861 million and warned that more cuts lay ahead. I2 has now cut more than 1,000 jobs since it announced revamping plans earlier this year. The job cuts will focus on i2's sales force, but will affect all areas of the company, said Jennifer Tejada, a company spokeswoman. The second-most heavily traded stock on the Nasdaq, i2 dropped $1.69, or 16.4 percent, to $8.60. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Riffs on Anime

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: School Construction Budget
description: The Board of Education will consider today whether to ask city budget officials for permission to start new school construction before the board completes a planned audit and revision of its five-year capital plan. The board wants to start building three schools and an addition to a building. Earlier this month, in response to the disclosure of huge cost overruns in the school construction budget, city officials told the Board of Education that they would closely monitor further requests for new construction money until the board revised its $7 billion capital plan. Board officials blamed high labor and material costs for the cost overruns. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Whistle-Blower Ruling
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered the Police Department yesterday to reinstate an officer who was fired in 1999 after she criticized the tactics of the Street Crime Unit. The officer, Yvette Walton, was dismissed on the same day in April 1999 that she appeared in disguise at a City Council hearing and criticized the unit for what she said was the practice of stopping and frisking people on the basis of race. A federal judge ruled in November that the dismissal was in retaliation for the officer's criticism and thus violated her First Amendment rights.

title: 1 Killed and 1 Severely Hurt When Van Runs Off Pier
description: A 19-year-man died and the friend he was apparently teaching how to drive was in very critical condition yesterday after their van raced off the edge of a Brooklyn pier and plunged into Gowanus Bay, the police said.

title: A Prosecutor's Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Rights to Remain on Powell's Agenda in China
description: HANOI, July 26 — Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, said today that in the wake of the release of three Chinese scholars with American links charged with spying, human rights issues would still remain high on his agenda with senior officials when he visits Beijing this weekend.

title: NTELOS WILL BUY CONESTOGA FOR $408 MILLION
description: Ntelos Inc., a provider of telecommunications services primarily in the South, agreed to buy Conestoga Enterprises Inc. for $408 million in stock and cash. Conestoga, based in Birdsboro, Pa., has about 98,000 telephone customers in southern and central Pennsylvania. Shareholders will receive $335 million, or $40 a share, in Ntelos common stock or in a combination of stock and cash, the companies said in a statement. That would be 26 percent more than Conestoga's closing price of $31.75 Tuesday. Ntelos, which is based in Waynesboro, Va., will also assume $73 million in debt. The companies expect the acquisition to be completed by the end of the year.

title: Union Says Coca-Cola in Colombia Uses Thugs
description: An American labor-rights group and the United Steelworkers union have filed a suit in the United States that accuses Coca-Cola and some bottlers here of using a right-wing paramilitary group to intimidate and, in some cases, assassinate labor organizers. Coca-Cola adamantly rejected the accusations on Monday.

title: Democrats Attack Phrase on Rebate Checks
description: Democrats criticized the Bush administration today for printing ''Tax relief for America's workers'' on the tax rebate checks being mailed out this summer, saying the phrase was a Republican campaign slogan.

title: Straphangers Improvise To Ward Off the Heat
description: It was probably the last thing a New York subway rider wanted to hear yesterday afternoon: the Metro platforms in Washington and many other cities have air-conditioning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENNERICH, WILLIAM S.
description: GENNERICH-William S. On July 23, 2001 of West Hempstead and Shelter Island, NY. Beloved husband of Kathleen Harrington-Gennerich. Adored father of Kathleen Mazza (Jim), Susan and Kristin Gennerich, and Sean (Jennifer) and Patrick Harrington. Loving grandfather of Caroline and Matthew Mazza. Bill retired as Vice President of Labor Relations for Capital Cities/ABC in 1995 after twenty six years. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday at 10 AM, St Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Mashomack Preserve, PO Box 850, Shelter Island, NY 11964 appreciated.

title: Specs: Sources for Rehab Work
description: CARY TAMARKIN'S experience as an architect and developer put him ahead of the pack when it came to a working Rolodex of artisans, creative consultants and materials.

title: War's Legacy: Many in Guatemala Still Fear Army
description: The two soldiers, dressed in battle gear and carrying assault weapons, went to Eulogia Lpez's house with assurances that they had come to guarantee peace and build latrines for the village school.

title: DEVALUATION OF CURRENCY CONTRIBUTES TO EMBRATEL LOSS
description: Hurt by a devaluation of the local currency, the Brazilian long-distance telephone provider Embratel Participaes posted a loss of $15.7 million in the second quarter. The company, which is controlled by the telecommunications provider WorldCom, of Clinton, Miss., suffered $59 million in foreign exchange losses through the servicing of its largely dollar-denominated debt even while revenue jumped 18 percent on strong growth in long-distance and corporate data services. Embratel has accumulated losses of $29 million for the year, compared with a profit of $109 million in the first half of 2000. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Says He Quit 4 Clubs Because They Resisted Diversity
description: Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the reason he resigned from four private social and sports clubs in recent months was that he had been unable to persuade them to embrace greater diversity in membership.

title: Baltimore Journal; Magician Prepares To Hang Up Black Hat
description: ''I watched my brother die from the Alzheimer's,'' said Lou Walston, deftly performing the French Drop sleight of hand, repeatedly making a Liberty half-dollar disappear in a blur and show up in unexpected spots, neat as when he first learned the trick 70 years ago.

title: Scrabble, From 'Zest'To 'Abceghilnoprtuy'
description: WORD FREAK

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASTELLANO, ANNA
description: CASTELLANO-Anna. Dear Mom, love forever. Barbara and Robert

title: Well-Known Agency to Close After 62 Years
description: Warwick Baker O'Neill, a well- known New York agency, said yesterday that it would close after 62 years.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Missing Kurdish Funds
description: Scotland Yard said it was investigating charges that millions of dollars was missing from a campaign to help Kurdish refugees, run by Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire author and disgraced Conservative politician. Lord Archer began a four-year jail term last week after being convicted of perjury in a case involving payments to a prostitute. He claims $80 million was raised by a high-profile 1991 concert. Baroness Nicholson, then a Conservative party official, told the police that ''practically nothing'' reached the Kurds.

title: Two Stations, One Tabloid, One Owner
description: Federal regulators yesterday approved the News Corporation's acquisition of Chris-Craft Industries, paving the way for the company to gain unprecedented control over two of the main broadcast television stations in the New York market.

title: A Piece of Nature for All
description: To the Editor:

title: El Profesor Higgins de Espaol; Bloomberg's Tutor Has a Touch of Eliza in Him, Too
description: Alone and scared, Juan Carlos Ayarza, then a 22-year-old Peruvian, crossed the border illegally into the United States 16 years ago, hopped in a plane from Los Angeles to New York, moved in with a friend who lived in Queens and began dreaming the New Yorker's dream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELHAUT, GLENN D.
description: KESSELHAUT-Glenn D. Beloved husband of Rachel S., devoted father of Benjamin, Matthew and Jeremy. Dear son of Martin and Arlene Kesselhaut. Dear brother of Marcie Bachar and Karen Fewsmith. For service time, please call Riverside Memorial Chapel, 914-664-6800.

title: In Polo (the Players) v. Polo (the Shirt), Lauren Is in the Lead
description: When it comes to polo, or, more precisely, Polo, Ralph Lauren's commercial sense has long outpaced the United States Polo Association's.

title: Partisan Battle Breaks Out Over No. 2 Job in Indonesia
description: Three days after electing a new president virtually by acclamation, Indonesia's legislature plunged back into bitter partisan politics in an electoral battle for the post of vice president.

title: Six Are Dead, Many Missing, As Boat Sinks Off Bahamas
description: A sailboat packed with perhaps as many as 156 Haitians trying to get to the United States ran aground on the reefs surrounding Great Inagua Island in the Bahamas during the past week, leaving six dead and possibly dozens more missing, American and Bahamian authorities said today.

title: Scholars Freed Before Powell Visits Beijing
description: The Chinese government said today that two Chinese citizens with United States residency who were sentenced in Beijing to 10 years' imprisonment for espionage have been granted medical parole. A senior State Department official here said that one of them, Gao Zhan, a researcher at American University in Washington, was on a plane headed for the United States.

title: Group Is Said To Accuse Pacific Bell Of Monopoly
description: A group of California Internet service providers, which rely on the Pacific Bell telephone network to offer high-speed service, plans to accuse Pacific Bell and an affiliate of engaging in anticompetitive practices.

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: Hewlett-Packard Cutting 6,000 Jobs
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, a leading maker of personal computers and printers, said today that it would cut 6,000 jobs, or 6.5 percent of its work force, because of the global slowdown in consumer spending on technology products.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Arrested In Transit Thefts
description: The police have arrested a Queens man who, they said, specialized in stealing from subway motormen. The man, Edward Brown, 19, was arrested Tuesday on burglary and other charges after gaining access to New York City Transit locker rooms in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx and then breaking into motormen's lockers, the police said. Mr. Brown, who has been arrested several times for impersonating transit workers, wore an official transit uniform and carried a motorman's radio and keys, said Sgt. Scott Guginsky of the Transit Robbery Squad. Mr. Brown had even learned enough of the motormen's manual to fool transit workers before stealing their two-way radios and other property, Sergeant Guginsky said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Los Angeles Plans to Offer Public Pay Toilets
description: After a year of debate, the Los Angeles City Council has voted to negotiate a contract with a French company to give the city an amenity that many European cities, and strollers in them, have long enjoyed: public pay toilets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Croat Reports For Trial
description: A Croatian Army general turned himself over to the United Nations war crimes tribunal to face charges linked to the killing of Serbian civilians during Serbian-Croatian fighting in 1993. Gen. Rahim Ademi surrendered after the tribunal's prosecutor pressured Croatia to arrest him and another Croat commander for trial. General Ademi said he was proud of his war record and wanted to clear his name. He is the top Croat among the tribunal's 40 detainees and joins former President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and four other generals at the tribunal's cellblock.

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BEATRICE
description: ROSEN-Beatrice. Beloved aunt of Marvin and Sondra Rosenblum, Carol and Marvin Greene, Sharon and Victor Carosone. Devoted great-aunt of Evan, Jamie, Monica and Jeffrey. Loving greatgreat-aunt of Shannon, Jayson and Jordan. Funeral service Thursday, 12:30 PM, at I.J. Morris, 21 E. Deer Park Rd., Dix Hills, NY.

title: Compaq's Revenue and Income Fall
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, suffering from weak demand and cutthroat pricing in the personal computer market, reported a steep drop in second-quarter earnings yesterday as sales fell 17 percent.

title: Deep in the Desert, No Longer Far Out
description: IF tie-dye T-shirts and Volkswagen Bugs are back, Paolo Soleri can't be far behind. For those who remember him as a Woodstock-era guru of alternative architecture, Dr. Soleri conjures images of trust-fund hippies trekking to Arizona to cast bronze bells in his foundries or to pour the concrete walls of Arcosanti, his hivelike community 65 miles north of Phoenix.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix, Jan 17, 1911 to July 26, 1994. Founder, National Society for Graphology. His golden heart inspires us still. Janice

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a prenatal clinic in Brooklyn that treats immigrant women misspelled the surname of its social worker. She is Josette Crevecoeur, not Crefvecoeur.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLF, ANTHONY LEWIS (TONY)
description: WOLF-Anthony Lewis (Tony) 19 years, how can that be? Though your physical self is no more-you live within us each day in wellsprings of sadness and love. Mom and Sash

title: For a Day, Riders Do It For France
description: French teams in the Tour de France surged to the front early today, attacking left and right until a seven-man breakaway took wing.

title: Economic Scene; Sorting out bundling and antitrust law from a seat at the Saturday double feature.
description: REMEMBER double features? Back in the 1950's, movie theaters used to show two films for a single price. But there was a catch: often only one of the two films was worth seeing.

title: Brooklyn's New Team Overflowing With Fans
description: Shortly before the start of last night's game at KeySpan Park, the ferry from Staten Island floated up to the dock just outside the stadium at Coney Island. But tickets for opposing fans are tough to come by in this New York-Penn League rivalry between minor league teams of the Mets and the Yankees, so few Staten Island Yankees fans trickled off the boat to root on their team.

title: Police Have Not Improved Enough on Courtesy, Survey Finds
description: The New York City Police Department has not gone far enough to improve courtesy, and higher pay should be offered to keep seasoned patrol officers on the street instead of seeking promotions, a law enforcement research group said yesterday.

title: A Missile Shield, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: High Power Demand
description: Long Island's electricity demand came close to exceeding its supply yesterday, the Long Island Power Authority reported. ''It was extremely tight,'' said the utility's chairman, Richard M. Kessel. As temperatures in Hicksville exceeded 97 degrees and humidity climbed past 86 percent, electricity demand peaked in Long Island between 4 and 5 p.m. at 4,443 megawatts, just 94 megawatts shy of capacity. It was the second-highest peak demand ever recorded by the utility. The highest was recorded about two years ago. Earlier in the day, for the first time this summer, the utility warned customers to reduce air-conditioning and other electricity use. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Researcher Sees Early Success Using a 2nd Type of Stem Cell
description: A second kind of human embryonic stem cell appears to have demonstrated promise in repairing damaged tissues by helping paralyzed mice regain some powers of movement.

title: Lewis Agrees to Fight Rahman in November
description: Lennox Lewis has signed a contract to fight a heavyweight rematch against Hasim Rahman in November, Don King, the boxing promoter, said yesterday.

title: Erik Barnouw, Historian of Broadcasting, Dies at 93
description: Erik Barnouw, whose classic three-volume history of broadcasting in the United States defined the sweep, power and foibles of the industry that forever altered communication and public life, died last Thursday in Fair Haven, Vt. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMICK, WILLIAM J.
description: McCORMICK-William J. On July 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Anna (nee Coman). Loving father of William & the late Brendan. Part time employee for 55 years in the Athletic Department of Columbia University. A member of Local 3 I.B.E.W. Reposing at the Riverdale on Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 10 AM St. Margaret of Cortona R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Petrochemical Control
description: In a move to consolidate local holdings, the Brazilian engineering and petrochemicals companies Odebrecht and Grupo Mariani paid $314 million for control of the country's largest basic petrochemical complex, Petroqumica do Nordeste. The consortium, which already held a minority stake in the petrochemicals maker, known as Copene, was the only bidder in the government auction of 23.73 percent of the company's shares. The central bank twice failed to sell the shares, which it assumed in a 1995 bailout of Banco Econmico. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)
