title: Can't Forsake Movies on Tape? DVD Player Doubles as a VCR
description: The march of technology can be a wonderful thing, unless you are tight on space. In that case, the thought of giving up your trusty old VCR for a flashy new DVD player may leave you anxious: you fear you may never be able to watch those homemade vacation videotapes again.

title: Top-Seeded Team Defeated By 64th Seed in Spingold
description: A stunning upset occurred here on Tuesday night in the second round of the Spingold Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships. The top-seeded squad headed by Rose Meltzer of Los Gatos, Calif., lost by 45 imps to the 64th seed. She and her teammates -- Peter Weichsel, also of Los Gatos; Kyle Larsen of San Francisco; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif.; and Alan Sontag of Manhattan -- will represent the United States in the World Team Championships in Bali, Indonesia, in October.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Alden: Rapper Pleads Guilty To Assault
description: The rap performer known as DMX has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of assault and will pay a fine of $1,000 for a March incident in which he threw a food tray at jail guards, the Erie County assistant district attorney, Michael J. McHale, said yesterday. DMX, whose real name is Earl Simmons, made the plea agreement Tuesday night and has 48 hours to pay the fine. Mr. Simmons, 30, was serving a 13-day jail sentence for driving without a license when he clashed with the guards. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Beach House With a Penthouse View
description: JOELLIN COMERFORD knows how to make a grand family gesture. A managing partner at Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting, she spent $400,000 to build a 385-square-foot, coral-colored guesthouse on the roof of her duplex loft in Greenwich Village. With lime-green furniture and wraparound windows, it's like a Santa Monica beach house with views west to the Hudson River, south to Wall Street and east to the Empire State Building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, NATASHA JEAN
description: DUNCAN-Natasha Jean, on July 21, 2001, at age 21. Beloved daughter of Ian and Ilona. Loving sister of Alec, Scott, James and David Duncan. Dear niece of Isobel Hartley and Helen Armstrong. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, July 27th, 6 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: The Persistence of Junk Mail
description: Last Sundays Times ran an astonishing story. It reported that the Hooters restaurant chain had filed for bankruptcy protection after being slammed with a $12 million fine. Its crime: Sending unsolicited junk faxes.

title: Depression His Linchpin, A Novelist Keeps Going
description: For more than 30 years, Hugh Nissenson has been laboring in solitude in the study of his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Sorrow has been his constant companion. Despite an American Book Award nomination for his novel ''The Tree of Life'' in 1985, despite the sometimes extraordinary reviews for his books and despite the opinion of admirers like Cynthia Ozick that he is something of a genius, ''my books have sold nothing,'' Mr. Nissenson, 68, said glumly.

title: Behind That Banal Bar Code, Monsters and Dinosaur DNA
description: BAR codes are found on just about every item sold for the home, from food to kitchen cleansers to cosmetics, allowing the checkout register to identify an item and its price. But as digital devices become smaller and smarter, electronics makers are looking to scanning technology to do everything from opening Internet sites to enabling refrigerators to reorder food when supplies run low.

title: 1978 Study Had Troubles Like a Fatal Hopkins Test
description: Two healthy volunteers in a 1978 asthma study at the University of California at San Francisco fell sick, one seriously enough to be treated at a hospital, after inhaling the drug that led to the death of a young woman in a similar research project at Johns Hopkins University last month.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Sees Chip Sales Falling
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said worldwide sales of flash-memory chips used in cell phones and electronic organizers might fall as much as 30 percent this year, a bigger drop than industry researchers expect. Flash-memory sales are likely to be 25 percent to 30 percent lower industrywide in 2001, Ben Anixter, Advanced Micro's vice president, said at an investment conference in San Francisco. The Semiconductor Industry Association last month predicted a 3 percent decline. Advanced Micro, best known as the Intel Corporation's biggest rival in the computer market, is also the second-largest maker of flash memory behind Intel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Second-Quarter Loss Hits $4.76 Billion at Corning

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Still Wild, Wildly Talkative

title: E.D.S. Posts 17% Rise in Quarterly Profit
description: Reinforcing reports by I.B.M. and others that most of the information technology services sector is faring well in the economic slowdown, Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that it had earned 62 cents a share in the quarter ended June 30, up 17 percent from the 53 cents reported in the period last year.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: 'Wrong Man' Sues
description: After spending 33 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, Peter Limone has filed a $375 million negligence claim against federal officials. Mr. Limone was freed from prison earlier this year when a Justice Department inquiry revealed that informants had told F.B.I. agents that Mr. Limone was not involved in the 1965 killing of Edward Deegan. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Jones Ready to Rumble, But Only in the Ring
description: Roy Jones Jr. may be afraid of Los Angeles earthquakes, but Jones, the world light-heavyweight champion, says he has no fear when it comes to taking on Julio Gonzalez at the Staples Center on Saturday night.

title: Corning Reports $4.76 Billion Loss, Citing Write-Offs
description: Corning Inc. became the latest member of the billion-dollar club yesterday, joining Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks, in reporting at least a 10-digit loss in the second quarter.

title: A Survey of Wall St. Finds Women Disheartened
description: Women on Wall Street have a hard time arguing with the money to be made, but a survey released yesterday of men and women at seven major securities firms suggests that many women are dissatisfied with the extent of progress that has been made to help women advance in the securities industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELKIN, LESLIE A.
description: NELKIN-Leslie A. Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourns the loss of our friend and former associate, Leslie A. Nelkin. We extend our deepest condolences to his family, his colleagues and his many friends. He will be missed by all.

title: New Motto for Giants: Wait Till This Year
description: Nearly six months since their loss in Super Bowl XXXV, the Giants open training camp Thursday, and for most of the team, work toward a new season could not have come soon enough.

title: Above, $700,000 Riverfront Condos; Below, a Toxic Question Mark
description: On a gentle, lumpy hill that runs down to the Hudson River, a landscaper scatters wildflower seeds. Just a few yards away, residents stroll along a pier where new riverfront condominiums sell for $700,000. To the south, the sky rings with the crash of piles being driven into open land, ahead of the hotels, the shops, and apartments now on the drawing board.

title: Top Official to Leave A Foote, Cone Office
description: Rooney Carruthers, who has served for just 15 months as executive creative director at the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, is leaving to pursue other interests in his home country, Britain, the agency said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an Artist at Work article yesterday about Takashi Murakami, whose paintings are produced in studio-factories in Tokyo and Brooklyn, omitted the end of a paragraph and part of a quotation. The passage should have read:

title: A Duty to Warn
description: Lawyers at the American Bar Association's convention next week in Chicago will debate a single question whose answer will affect public health and safety for decades. The issue is whether a lawyer for a company who learns that his client's product is likely to cause physical injury or death should be permitted to warn the public, even if his client objects.

title: Giving Up Privacy For a Bargain Price
description: LAST week I got e-mail from eToys, the online retailer that went out of business last spring. Signed ''Your Friends at eToys,'' it recommended I now do all my toy shopping at KBkids.com, the company that bought eToys' remaining inventory for $5.4 million. Then my good friends at eToys made another suggestion: the letter asked me to approve the transfer of personal information I had given eToys to KBkids.com.

title: PRUDENTIAL AND AN ITALIAN BANK PLAN FUND VENTURE
description: Prudential Financial, one of the biggest life insurers in the United States, said yesterday that it was joining with a leading bank in Italy, Banca Popolare di Bergamo Credito Varesino, to set up a new mutual fund company. The company will offer pension funds to both private and institutional investors. The venture is part of a worldwide expansion by Prudential as it prepares to go public after decades as a mutual insurer owned by its policyholders. Prudential, which is based in Newark, already owns an Italian life insurance company. It is investing $4.5 million in the new venture and will own a 5 percent stake. In the new business, Prudential will supply more than a dozen mutual funds that will be sold through Banca Popolare branches. Joseph Treaster (NYT)

title: New West Coast College, Born of the Far East
description: ALISO VIEJO, Calif., July 20  On a lavender-covered hilltop halfway between Los Angeles and San Diego, in the midst of miles of look-alike red-roofed tract houses, an architectural and educational marvel reaches skyward above the Pacific, waiting to spring to life next month as the first new private liberal arts college to be built in California in 25 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 17 about efforts by Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill to aid the United States steel industry referred incorrectly to the use of open-hearth blast furnaces. Steel companies now rely on basic oxygen furnaces to transform raw iron ore into steel; they do not rely on open-hearth furnaces. The last such furnace closed in 1991.

title: Koizumi Plan to Visit Shrine Raises Warning From China
description: A controversy over a planned prime ministerial visit next month to a Shinto shrine honoring Japan's war dead heated up today with a stern warning by China to call off the ceremony.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC INVESTS IN ENDOTEX, A MAKER OF STENTS
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, which makes artery-clearing devices, said it was collaborating with Endotex Interventional Systems Inc. on products used to widen blood vessels in the neck. Boston Scientific will make an undisclosed investment in the closely held Endotex and has an exclusive option to buy the company, which is based in Cupertino, Calif. Boston Scientific will also distribute Endotex's products internationally. The companies will study coupling Endotex's carotid stent, a mesh tube that holds arteries open, with a Boston Scientific device that captures material dislodged from clogged arteries to keep it from traveling to the brain, where it could cause a stroke.

title: Stainless Steel Elegance Won't Carve Up the Budget
description: Inexpensive flatware is too light in the hand, too shiny and often tries too hard to fit in at Versailles. Now Gourmet Settings, a Toronto company, has produced a stainless steel line in an 18/8 grade, which feels good in the hand, looks like satin-finish Scandinavian designs and has the confidence to be simple. Carry-On, above, in a 20-piece set (four place settings), is $39.99 at Target, (888) 304-4000, or www.target.com (for stores). Other patterns are at Wal-Mart for $29.97, (800) 966-6546 or www.walmart.com. At www.gourmetsettings.com, the entire line (some of it sold for more in stores) can be seen; catalog and information: (800) 551-2649. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBACH, DR. JOSEPH J.
description: MARBACH-Dr. Joseph J. May he experience the peace now, that he strove to give to others during his lifetime. Margo Feiden

title: 2 Big Drug Makers Gain, But Another Is Unchanged
description: Second-quarter profit at the Pharmacia Corporation and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company rose on higher sales of drugs to treat cancer, diabetes and heart disease, the companies said yesterday, while growth at the Schering-Plough Corporation stalled as it struggled to fix manufacturing quality flaws that have delayed a new allergy treatment.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO., Akron, Ohio, won a 10-year contract to supply tires for the U.S. Postal Service fleet of 200,000 delivery vehicles.

title: One Connection, Many PC's: Networking Without the Wires
description: Netgear (www.netgear.com) has released new wireless networking devices for people who don't want to be tethered to a wired network but still want to share reliable video and audio streams through their home high-speed cable or D.S.L. connection.

title: Two Prospects Get Early Start In Hope of Sticking With Rangers
description: Every time over the past two seasons that the Rangers have been rumored to be interested in acquiring a marquee player, the names of their top two prospects, right wing Pavel Brendl and center Jamie Lundmark, have surfaced as potential trade bait. And never more so than over the past few months.

title: Student's-Eye View of a Park in Brooklyn
description: Designs for a Park

title: Hands-Free Calling: Options for the Road
description: NOW that New York State, following the lead of towns and counties across the country, has enacted a law banning the use of hand-held cellular telephones while driving, consumers are left to figure out the best combination of technology to make wireless calling a hands-free experience in the car.

title: Turks Vow to Fight Nuclear Shipments Through Bosporus
description: For years, Turkish maritime authorities have complained about the danger from the rising number of huge oil tankers plying the congested Bosporus, which runs through Istanbul. The warnings took on new urgency this month with Russia's decision to add nuclear waste to the volatile mix of cargo in the narrow strait.

title: Auditors Doubt Amtrak Will Meet Profit Goal
description: Amtrak is unlikely to meet the date Congress set five years ago to break even or face the possibility of liquidation, two outside auditors told a House subcommittee today.

title: Broadway Show
description: Tickets to a Broadway show are getting rather expensive. To help, the Millennium Hotel New York will rebate $35 on one ticket per room per night for stays on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights. The offer is good through Sept. 3, and the stub  for a performance during the stay  must be presented at check-out. The Millennium is a half-block from Times Square, so cab fares won't be a factor. Information: (800) 622-5569 or www.millennium-hotels.com .

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Vietnam Advance, and Pullback

title: Some Ports In a Storm
description: AS we enter the thick of hurricane season, it pays to be prepared. Twenty-nine percent of all hurricanes occur in August, with the statistical peak of storm activity coming this year on Sept. 9 or 10, said Frank Lepore, a public affairs officer at the Tropical Prediction Center in Miami. In the last century, 25 hurricanes struck as far north as New England; the worst of them, in 1938, killed 600 people after making landfall in Massachusetts. The following items will come in handy during any emergency, be it a power blackout, a bad thunderstorm or a raptor attack. And everyone should remember to keep fresh batteries on hand. (Complete information on storms and forecasts is available at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Web site, www.noaa.gov.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, JOSEPHBERG SARAH (''SYD'')
description: GREENBLATT - JOSEPHBERG Sarah (''Syd''), at age 94 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Louis Greenblatt and the late Maurice Josephberg. Loving mother of Ira and Linda and Ann and John Cohen; grandmother of David, Margo and Michael, Ellen, Patti and Eric, Stephanie and Richard, and Linda; great-grandmother of Jordan, Alexander, Marc, Myles and Blake. Funeral services will be private.

title: AFLAC SHARES DECLINE AS GROWTH IN JAPAN SLOWS
description: Shares in Aflac Inc. fell sharply after the company, a leading seller of supplemental health insurance, said growth slowed in Japan, its biggest market. Shares in Aflac fell $3.35, to $28.20 a share. Aflac, which generated about three-quarters of its earnings from Japan in the first quarter, said slower-than-expected sales there stemmed from a lack of demand for a new policy that covered certain forms of cancer. Aflac, based in Columbus, Ga., said its profit fell to $153 million from $202 million a year earlier while its sales were flat at $2.3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: FINKELSTEIN-William. Happy Birthday, Grandpa Bill, in Heaven. Your handsome grandson was born September 6, 2000. Deeply loved, never forgotten. Sister Fay and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, RAYMOND OLIPHANT
description: YOUNG-Raymond Oliphant. On July 24, 2001. Retired V.P. of Citibank and retired manager and agent of Banco Rio de la Plata. Fighter pilot in the R.A.F. during World War II. Predeceased by his loving wife Mary Angela. Devoted father of Patricia and Michael Gallo, Theresa and Serre Murphy and Steven. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Gina, Michael, Brendan and Annabeth. Loving brother of Juna Montgomery. Reposing at William E. Law Funeral Home, 1 Jerusalem Avenue, Massapequa, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at Maria Regina RC Church, Seaford, NY at 9:45AM on Saturday. Family will receive friends Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Lung Association.

title: Stem Cell Research: Politics and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: A Panopticon for Plagiarists
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Hewlett Buys StorageApps
description: Hewlett-Packard said it had agreed to acquire StorageApps, a privately held maker of software for storage systems, for $350 million in stock. Hewlett, which makes personal computers, printers and imaging equipment, said StorageApps software allows for management and transfer of data stored in storage systems made by different vendors. StorageApps, based in Bridgewater, N.J., will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Hewlett-Packard, which has said it intends to expand more into services, storage and software. Citing the ''quiet period'' before its quarterly report on Aug. 16, Hewlett would not comment on the acquisition's expected impact on its earnings. Its shares fell 7 cents, to $25.68. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Essay; Victory For Missile Defense
description: Vladimir Putin yanked the rug out from under Democrats opposed to missile defense.

title: This Time, Prospect of Pink Slips Makes Workers Grim at Lucent
description: A few weeks ago, long before Tuesday's announcement that Lucent Technologies would eliminate 15,000 to 20,000 more jobs, photocopies of fliers went up in a hallway of the company's headquarters here exhorting employees to keep their spirits high.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARTZ, ROBERT
description: SWARTZ-Robert of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Inez (nee Nelson); devoted father of Richard, Barbara Hill and Andrew; dear brother of Claire Trebach; loving grandfather of Hailey, Alex, Hannah, Melissa. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ. Thursday, 10:30am (1-800-378-1892)

title: Mixed Messages in the Pitch-Count Controversy
description: In trying to defuse the pitch-count controversy last week, Sandy Alderson, the Major League Baseball executive who initiated it with a series of e-mail messages, said he thought the umpires had misinterpreted his words. A reading of some of the e-mail shows how the umpires could have inferred a different message from the one Alderson said he meant to deliver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANSIOLI, THOMAS ADRIAN, III
description: FRANSIOLI-Thomas Adrian, III. Of Wenham, MA, died Monday. Born in NY on March 17, 1933, he was the son of the late Thomas and Elizabeth McVickar Fransioli. A graduate of Harvard 1955, and Harvard Business School 1960, he joined the Bank of Boston, specializing in international banking in South America, Europe and Asia, and later with a venture capital group in Boston. He is survived by his wife Mona, 2 daughters, Lena and Christina, & a granddaughter, Zoe. Memorial service will be held on Friday, August 3, at Christ Church, Hamilton, MA. at 10 AM.

title: Metro-North Raises Parking Fees At Some Lots in New York State
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority today approved increases in parking fees at lots it owns at Metro-North commuter train stations in the Bronx and Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties.

title: Condit Turns Down Request To Speak to Private Detectives
description: Representative Gary A. Condit has rejected a request from lawyers for the family of Chandra Ann Levy to meet with private investigators hired to help find the missing government intern, lawyers for the Levy family and those for Mr. Condit said.

title: A Tool Kit for Keeping Windows Up to Date
description: Q. What kinds of things does Windows Update do?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Dies After Knife Attack
description: As her 2-year-old boy and 4-year-old girl watched, a Brooklyn woman was stabbed to death Tuesday night, the police said. Responding to a 10 p.m. report of a domestic dispute, the police said they found the woman, Diana Moran, 26, dead of multiple stab wounds in the kitchen of the apartment she shared with her husband on Flushing Avenue. The husband, Bolivar Moran, 42, was found nearby with stab wounds to his body. He was listed in stable condition late yesterday at Bellevue Hospital Center. Investigators said the Morans' children provided them with a description of the attack. No charges had been filed as of late yesterday, the police said.

title: Threat From Democrats on Missile Test Plans
description: Congressional Democrats are threatening to block the Pentagon's plans to begin work next month on a new missile defense test site at Fort Greely, Alaska, contending that Congress never appropriated financing for such work.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Spying on Junior

title: A Cosmetics Palace With Soft Skin
description: Give me some skin! In essence, that's what the French architect Rgis Pan told the chemists when he was developing a new display material for the MAC SoHo experimental store, inset below, set to open next month. ''I asked myself, 'How can we incorporate skin and body into architecture?' '' he said. His answer was a stabilized polyurethane that quivers like Jell-O but has a pleasant skinlike texture. The resulting free-standing displays, on modular cabinets, have been shaped into sensuous ridges, mountains, swales and terraces to hold lipsticks, eye shadows, brushes and powders. Molds for the displays were created by two computer-controlled laser beams, a process known as stereolithography. Mr. Pan, 32 (inset far right), is executive director of store design for all 400 MAC stores. For this experimental store (another will be built in Japan), he created mirrors, above, which look like half grapefruits, and he used Globlow Lamps by the Swedish company Snowcraft, which inflate to give a soft, white light. He also designed a display floor ''sink'': a square with a nib in the center, which releases a steady stream of water. Customers who have been fingering the lip gloss can wash their hands by wiping them against the wiggly block. ''It's a couture way to look at a store,'' said James Gager, creative director worldwide for MAC. ''It's not a concept for everybody. We wouldn't be putting this in the Midwest.'' MAC will open at 113 Spring Street (Mercer Street). LINDA LEE

title: Armstrong's Ascent Was Never a Sprint
description: Chris Carmichael, Lance Armstrong's coach for more than a decade, was traveling down memory lane, cruising through the years to 1992 and a place far from home.

title: Putting the Ill at Ease
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slow Economy Holding Down Cost of Labor
description: Labor expenses for businesses rose at a slower pace in the second quarter as job cuts and the plunge in manufacturing and a slowdown in the rest of the economy restrained wages and benefits, a government report showed today.

title: Bush Says Plan For Immigrants Could Expand
description: President Bush raised for the first time today the possibility that millions of immigrants from countries other than Mexico who are in the United States illegally might be able to earn permanent legal status over time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, MOE
description: KARP-Moe. On July 25th, 2001. Lived 90 fulfilling years. Survived by Rosalyn, his loving wife of 56 years, children, David (Lisa), Judy (Jaime), cherished grandchildren, Hannah and Jesse, and devoted daughter-in-law, Peggy. Funeral to be held at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave., NYC, Friday, July 27th, 11:30 AM.

title: New York Athletic Commission Voids Camacho Victory
description: The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday overturned the decision by three ringside judges who proclaimed Hector Camacho Jr. the winner against Jesse James Leija in a July 7 bout at the new KeySpan Park in Coney Island.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 'Bandit Queen' Is Cremated
description: With a manhunt on to find her killers, Phoolan Devi, India's ''bandit queen'' was cremated on the banks of the Ganges in Uttar Pradesh, her home state. A mourner was killed as throngs grieved. Ms. Devi, one of India's best-known women, had been a robber, murderer and member of Parliament. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: The Big City; Prosecutors Never Need To Apologize
description: WHEN Jose Morales and Ruben Montalvo stood in court this week, it seemed clear to the judge and many other people that they had been wrongly convicted of a murder 13 years ago in the Bronx. But the prosecution would not rest. Being a prosecutor means never having to say you're sorry.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Ford Gives Its Chairman A Bigger Role
description: The Ford Motor Company tweaked the delicate relationship between its chief executive and president, Jacques A. Nasser, and its chairman, William Clay Ford Jr., with a move intended to increase Mr. Ford's formal role in decision making.

title: Cunard Selects TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: The Cunard Line, a division of the Carnival Corporation, which operates cruise ships like the QE2, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULTON, ANNE O'CONNOR
description: FULTON-Anne O'Connor. Born in New York City and graduate of the Chapin School in 1937, died at age 82, July 12, 2001, at her home in Vineyard Haven, Mass.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox Moves Up an Insider to Be Its Chief
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had named Anne M. Mulcahy, its president and a 25-year employee, to be chief executive, effective Aug. 1. Ms. Mulcahy, 48, will succeed Paul A. Allaire, who will remain chairman until the end of the year.

title: Senate Panel Backs Hate-Crime Coverage for Gays
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to make hate attacks on gays a federal crime and to provide funds to help local law enforcement agencies prosecute such offenses.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Black School Backed In Dispute
description: Cardinal Francis George, the archbishop of Chicago, supports the position of a predominantly black Roman Catholic school in a dispute over youth sports. The school, St. Sabina, was initially rejected by a largely white Catholic league, the Southside Athletic Conference, because some members said they were afraid to hold games in St. Sabina's neighborhood in south Chicago. Later, the league voted to accept St. Sabina, but the school's pastor said it would join only if members agreed not to forfeit games at St. Sabina. Cardinal George on Wednesday called that condition ''legitimate and necessary.'' Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: In Separate Accidents, 2 Drivers Fleeing Police Kill 3 and Injure 1
description: Three people were killed and one man was critically injured yesterday in separate incidents in New York and New Jersey in which speeding drivers trying to flee from the police caused fatal accidents, the authorities said. In New Jersey, it was the second time in a week that a police chase resulted in a pedestrian's death.

title: Aye, in a Harlem Courtyard, The Witching Time of Night
description: The Classical Theater of Harlem's Courtyard Theater on 141st Street is a very pleasant place to be on a summer night. And the two-year-old company, founded by Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, makes excellent use of the space in its current production of ''Hamlet.''

title: Power Learns How to Relax And Ends Losing Streak
description: For the first time this season, the Power found a way to relax before a game, said Emily Janss and Tiffeny Milbrett. Perhaps it was the significance of the contest, a must-win for the Power in its quest for one of the four playoff spots in the Women's United Soccer Association.

title: Senator Says Bush Is Open To Revising Charity-Aid Bill
description: In a meeting with two senators, President Bush indicated a willingness today to rethink legislation that exempts religious groups from state and city antidiscrimination laws, several Senate Democrats and Republicans said.

title: Wry Skepticism About What Jewishness Means
description: ''Voice, Image, Gesture,'' a broad selection of postwar art drawn from the Jewish Museum's permanent collection, is not a show of great art, nor does it frame its contents in a very illuminating way. But as an occasion for viewers to meditate on connections between contemporary art and Jewish identity -- or, to use a word that may better capture what is at stake, Jewishness -- it is richly thought-provoking.

title: Woman Is Shot by Officer
description: ANew York State Police investigator critically wounded a woman yesterday in what officials said might have been an accidental shooting when the authorities stopped a car near Brooklyn College during a drug investigation.

title: 'Tokyo Eyes'
description: Directed by Jean-Pierre Limosin

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Court Ruling On Blood Evidence
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the police could not use unreasonable force in acquiring blood samples from suspects. In 1997, Richard A. Ravotto, smelling of alcohol, was found by officers in an overturned car, the police said. He was taken to a local hospital, where two officers held him down while a nurse took his blood. The test showed his blood alcohol level at triple the legal limit. His lawyer moved to suppress the blood test, but the trial judge denied the motion and an appeals court agreed. Yesterday, Justice Peter G. Verniero said that the police had used unreasonable force to acquire blood from a suspect against whom they already had considerable evidence. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Reform Party Lawsuit
description: In an echo of the Reform Party's fractured presidential nominating convention last year in Long Beach, members of one faction of the party have sued Patrick J. Buchanan and officers of his faction. The suit, in Superior Court in Long Beach, contends that the defendants violated the plaintiffs' rights and conspired to prevent some delegates from participating in the national convention. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNEIVE, JOAN SCARANGELLO
description: McNEIVE-Joan Scarangello, 47. Beloved wife, stepmother, daughter, sister, auntie, godmother, friend. Bronx-born, graduate of Cardinal Spellman High School and American University, Joan's heart directed her life personally and professionally. Whether in fanatic support of her Yankees or in political debate, Joan was an indefatigable champion of whom and what she loved. Joan was smart funny-and you challenged her positions at your own risk. Her physical and mental energy and her love of language led to a distinguished career in journalism. She began her writing and producing career at the NBC Washington Bureau, followed by WRC Radio, and then moved to New York to join ABC Radio, followed by ABCTV's World News Tonight and World News Now. Since 1997, she worked as a senior writer for Tom Brokaw at NBC Nightly News. Ultimately Joan's fine sense memory and love of reading called her to shift her focus to fiction. In the last two years she was writing a novel based loosely on the life of her maternal grandparents. Her family and friends will forever miss her humor, smile, passion, loyalty and inexhaustible love. Joan is survived by her husband, Patrick McNeive; stepdaughter, Frances McNeive; father and stepmother, Frank and Doris Scarangello; her sister and brother-in-law, Mary Ann Tighe and Dr. David Hidalgo; her brother and sister-inlaw, Tom Scarangello & Roxanne Donovan; her nephew, Aaron Tighe and his wife, Kimberly, and nephews, Elliot and Anthony Scarangello. Funeral services will be held on Monday, July 30th, 10 AM, at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. at 80th St. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to fight lung cancer: Thoracic Oncology Service Research Fund, C/O Dr. Mark G. Kris, MSKCC, 1275 York Ave., New York, New York 10021.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Verisign Takes A Big Write-Off
description: The Internet software and services company VeriSign Inc. reported a second-quarter loss of $11.2 billion, or $55.49 a share, including a one-time noncash charge of $9.9 billion related to acquisition costs. In the period last year, the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., lost $453 million, or $3.37 a share. VeriSign, which last year purchased the company that runs the databases for .com, .net and .org addresses, Network Solutions Inc., said sales in the second quarter rose to $231.2 million, up from $70.3 million in the second quarter last year. Shares of VeriSign closed yesterday at $47.17. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: New York's Sewage Was a Texas Town's Gold
description: There is not much here anymore, if there was ever much of anything to begin with. The town's main street is coated in dust, and the old movie house is long shuttered. The one sign of activity -- the traffic moving along elevated Interstate 10 -- is a reminder that the modern world rarely stops here.

title: Freed Chinese Scholar, Still Defiant, Returns to the U.S.
description: After five months in a Beijing jail, an American-based Chinese scholar returned to the United States today and promptly defied the very Chinese authorities who had convicted her of spying and sentenced her to 10 years in prison two days ago.

title: Treating Drug Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Presses to Resume Talks With North Korea
description: SEOUL, July 27 -- Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that United States officials were prepared to go anywhere at any time of North Korea's choice to resume talks on a range of issues, including ending the government's missile program and the heavy deployment of its conventional forces on the border with South Korea.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Ferrer Envisions a New Era Of Activism by Government
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president who wants to be mayor, is waging a campaign to revive what he says is a tradition of activist government abandoned by Rudolph W. Giuliani and bolster ''the other New York'' left out of the city's economic boom.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption yesterday about the Indian woman known as the Bandit Queen, who was killed outside her home in New Delhi, misspelled her surname. She was Phoolan Devi, not Levi.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A New Hotel For SoHo
description: J. A. Jones Construction Group announced yesterday that it would help design and build a new $25 million hotel in SoHo. Work on the building, called the Standard Hotel, is scheduled to begin in the first quarter of 2003, officials said. The building will be at Lafayette and Broome Streets and have 12 stories with 81,000 square feet and 132 guest rooms on a site that stretches the length of a block.

title: Council Approves a Zoning Plan To Revitalize Long Island City
description: The City Council approved a rezoning plan for Long Island City yesterday to allow high-rise development within a 37-block area of low-slung buildings and to attract commercial tenants that might otherwise be tempted to move their back offices to Jersey City.

title: Powell, in Hanoi, Pauses To Put the Past to Rest
description: From the moment his plane first flew over Vietnam on Tuesday to his performance at a foreign ministers' cabaret tonight in the last hours of his visit, memories of fighting a war here more than 30 years ago have crowded in on Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

title: Alcatel Reports a Profit But Plans More Job Cuts
description: Alcatel, joining other telecommunications-equipment makers worldwide, said today that it would pare its work force by about 18 percent this year to reduce operating costs, even as it posted an operating profit of 136 million euros, or about $120 million, in the second quarter.

title: A Minister Who Appreciates a Good Felon
description: ON Good Friday, the Rev. Gordon H. Duggins, who seems to perpetually sweat under his heavy black suit and tight clerical collar, preaches the same sermon every year. It is called ''Why Heaven Needs Felons.''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: James Bidgood -- 'Photoplays From the 60's'
description: Paul Morris

title: Creativity Overhead, Underfoot And Even In the Air
description: WHAT is outdoor sculpture? Judging from the array of art on the streets, in the parks and plazas and at other locations in New York this summer, what isn't? Since the advent of Earthworks, Process Art and Conceptual Art in the early 1970's, outdoor sculpture has been a constantly expanding territory, and this year its borders seem more far-flung and amorphous than ever. Walkers in the city can find assorted bronze sculptures of abstract figures, as well as not-so-abstract spiders and anthills, not far from Central Park; artist-designed manhole covers in downtown Manhattan; and a kaleidoscopic curtain made of recycled umbrella fabric in downtown Brooklyn. Tiny serial paintings by a determined landscapist are visible in several boroughs if you look hard enough, while Madison Square Park has a fragment of a Japanese garden, where it snows three times a week -- but with temperatures approaching triple digits, you have to be very fast to catch it.

title: On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. Ships Enter Hong Kong
description: Two United States warships sailed into Hong Kong's harbor in a resumption of port calls that had been halted by the Chinese government after the mid-air collision between Chinese and American military planes last April. The Guardian and the Patriot, both minesweepers, will anchor in Hong Kong until Monday. In May, when relations between the countries were tense, China denied a request by the Inchon to call at the former British colony Mark Landler (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sorry I have to cut it short. I have to leave now.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's IPO
description: Shares of McDonald's Japan rose 9.3 percent, to 4,700 yen a share, on the Japanese over-the-counter market on their first day of trading. The shares were priced at 4,300 yen in the company's initial public offering. At 4,700 yen a share, the Japanese unit of McDonald's has a market value of 624.9 billion yen ($5.05 billion), the highest of any company listed on the over-the-counter market in Japan.

title: Port Authority Seeks U.S. Aid For Faster Harbor Dredging
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey moved yesterday to persuade Congress to help the agency accelerate the dredging of 240 miles of harbor channels to the 50-foot depths required for the increasing number of supersize cargo ships in the global commercial fleet.

title: New Coach, Old Goal For the Hurricanes
description: College football's best team last season? Oklahoma may have won the Bowl Championship Series and the polls, but no one at Miami was convinced.

title: James J. McCaffrey, 79, Co-Founder of Top New York Ad Agency
description: James John McCaffrey, the co-founder of a New York advertising agency known for campaigns of understated elegance, died on Saturday at a hospital in Bangor, Me. He was 79 and lived in Blue Hill, Me., after residing several years in Castine, Me.

title: Many States Ceding Regulations to Church Groups
description: State officials in Missouri were distressed earlier this year when they received a complaint that a religious boarding school in the rural town of Bethel was punishing students by forcing them to muck out deep pits of manure.

title: Hewlett-Packard to Reduce Its Work Force by 6,000
description: Hewlett-Packard, a bellwether of consumer spending, said today that it would cut 6,000 jobs and that its revenue for the current quarter would be markedly lower than expected, with the company attributing the changes to further deterioration of economic conditions worldwide.

title: Netanya Journal; Be Grateful: That Was No Terrorist, Just a Criminal
description: A car bomb exploded in the heart of town a few days ago, and it turned out to be good news.

title: Cunard Selects TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: The Cunard Line, a division of the Carnival Corporation, which operates cruise ships like the QE2, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

title: A Lawyer, a Listener
description: To the Editor:

title: Choices on Wall St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Digital Defense
description: With many dot-coms blowing up, it is now fashionable to dismiss the Internet as just another tulip mania. That Internet stocks were a classic bubble is without question. But the Internet isn't just tulips, and if you think it is, well, let's talk in five years. By then it will be clear that the Internet is a business evolution -- reshaping how businesses communicate, educate and purchase materials; a social revolution -- connecting people who have never been connected before; and, for both of these reasons, a strategic dilemma that we are just beginning to understand.

title: Sorensen Still Pedaling After All These Years
description: Another long breakaway formed early in the Tour de France today and once again Rolf Sorensen failed to make the train. At age 36, it gets harder and harder to get good position near the front of the pack, to anticipate every move by rivals and to unleash that burst of speed needed to join them as they bolt away.

title: Sports of The Times; Efficiency Makes A Cameo
description: IN a sport gone mad with noise and improvisation and tediousness, it is always refreshing to see good old-fashioned competence at the ballpark.

title: Maserati Turns Heads Again
description: THE sleek silver coupe is attracting more than a little attention in front of the SoHo Grand Hotel on West Broadway. In a neighborhood awash in BMW's, Jaguars and Porsches, this sports car quietly asserts its presence. ''What is it?'' passers-by want to know.

title: UNIONIZATION DRIVE FAILS AT TOYOTA PLANT IN ONTARIO
description: A unionization drive by the Canadian Auto Workers at Toyota Motor Manufacturing Canada ended in failure yesterday when the union asked the Ontario Labor Relations Board not to count votes that were cast in an election on July 6. A Toyota spokesman, Greig Mordue, said the company was pleased by the union's action. A union victory would have been the first instance of a Japanese-owned auto plant's being organized in North America, not counting factories begun as joint ventures. About 94 percent of the plant's 2,440 workers voted, but the union said it had failed to complete a preliminary requirement that it obtain the signatures of 40 percent of the employees asking that the vote be held. The union must wait a year before holding another vote at the plant, which is in Cambridge, Ontario. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: Love in Venice for a Bored Housewife on the Lam
description: At the beginning of ''Bread and Tulips,'' a tour guide delivers a lecture on ancient history to a gaggle of Italian tourists gathered at a ruined temple. As he eloquently invokes the proud Greco-Roman heritage that is the birthright of all Italians -- ''the greatest people in history'' -- the camera quietly subverts his argument, presenting the modern-day heirs of Greece and Rome in all their noisy, materialistic vulgarity.

title: New Jersey Requires Prudential To Refund $25 Million to Drivers
description: The Prudential Group, which insures just under 325,000 vehicles in New Jersey, has been ordered by the state to mail $25.1 million in refunds this fall to its policyholders. An audit of the company's returns showed that it had exceeded the state's 6 percent profit cap for 1998, 1999 and 2000.

title: 2 Senators Challenge Change in Gun Rule
description: Two Democratic senators asked the Justice Department today for documents related to last month's decision by Attorney General John Ashcroft to limit how long the government keeps records of instant background checks of gun buyers.

title: GRUNTAL CLOSES ITS CORPORATE BOND TRADING BUSINESS
description: Gruntal & Company, one of the last remaining independent brokerage firms in the nation, said it had closed its investment-grade corporate bond trading business and eliminated about 30 jobs. Gruntal is the latest in a string of securities firms to cut jobs amid a slowdown in the investment banking business. Randy Bradley, chief information and planning officer, said that Gruntal would ''focus on what is strategic for us -- institutional and individual investor distribution.'' The bond operation focused on dealer-to-dealer transactions and its closing will not affect Gruntal's access to high-grade corporate bonds, Mr. Bradley said. As part of the decision, he said, Gruntal sold its high-grade corporate bond portfolio for an undisclosed amount.

title: Clues of Asthma Study Risks May Have Been Overlooked
description: In the nebulous language of eulogy, Ellen Roche, a bright, healthy, 24-year-old volunteer in an asthma study at Johns Hopkins University, died for the sake of science. In clinical terms, Ms. Roche died because a chemical she inhaled in the study led to the progressive failure of her lungs and kidneys.

title: 'The Monkey's Mask'
description: Directed by Samantha Lang

title: Panel Tones Down Report On Fuel Economy Increases
description: A National Academy of Sciences panel has toned down somewhat a report on automobile fuel economy, suggesting that big increases in the gas mileage of cars and light trucks may be a little harder to achieve than an earlier draft had stated, people close to the panel said this week.

title: An Ensemble So Flexible It Just About Morphs
description: It wasn't so long ago that composers described as eclectic might be expected to weave their works with threads of Romanticism and Classicism, Serial techniques and stretches of Minimalist texture, and perhaps occasional strands of jazz or pop. But eclecticism of that sort generally made a point of staying within shouting distance of the traditional art music mainstream, and it can seem peculiarly narrow beside the omnivorous eclecticism of the German composer Heiner Goebbels.

title: 2nd Man in '87 Murder Case Is Freed After New Testimony
description: A second Bronx man imprisoned for 13 years on a murder conviction was freed from prison yesterday by a federal judge after a priest and a lawyer testified that another man had admitted to the crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, JOSEPHBERGSARAH
description: GREENBLATT-JOSEPHBERGSarah. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved mother-inlaw of our esteemed Board of Overseers member, John D. Cohen. We extend heartfelt condolences to Ann and John, Ira and Linda, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Early Interview in Louima Case Provides Spark for Renewed Interest
description: Sometime after midnight on Aug. 15, 1997, three police supervisors arrived at Brooklyn's 70th Precinct station house to investigate an officer's shooting of a dog earlier in the day. It was a routine assignment, but hardly a routine time for personnel in the 70th Precinct.

title: In Battle for Mayor, Badillo to Enlist 'Guerrillas'
description: Seven weeks after declaring that he wanted to be the next mayor of New York, the Republican candidate Herman Badillo announced the appointment yesterday of the men who would run his campaign and, for the first time, articulated the strategy that he hopes will take him past the primaries and all the way to City Hall.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Power Strike To End
description: A three-day strike by workers at South Africa's main power supplier will end today after the state-owned Eskom Ltd. agreed to raise pay levels close to those demanded by three unions representing most of its workers. The 21,000 workers were to return to work this morning, ending concern that power interruptions could start if there was insufficient labor to fix breakdowns at power stations and carry out routine maintenance tasks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Welfare-Rights Bill
description: Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Stephen DiBrienza, who is chairman of the City Council's General Welfare Committee, introduced legislation yesterday that would require the Human Resources Administration to inform welfare recipients of their rights to education and training. The two men charged that the city's current policy pushed welfare recipients to find work whether they were prepared or not. The bill would also exempt single parents attending college at least half-time from taking work assignments as a condition of receiving their benefits. Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles said the administration would oppose the bill because it reflected ''a fundamental misunderstanding of what works in welfare reform.''

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From a debate on hybrid cars to berating a user with faulty brakes, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Carlo Sammarco
description: Franklin Parrasch

title: New Video Releases
description: Pollock

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARTZ, ROBERT
description: SWARTZ-Robert. The management of Standard Motor Products, Inc. is deeply saddened by the passing of Robert Swartz, an esteemed member of their Board of Directors, on Tuesday, July 24, 2001. In his 50-year association with the company he provided valued counsel and vision. His leadership will be sorely missed.

title: Get Your Hands Off, Ya Big Gorilla!
description: This is not the summer for interspecies cooperation. In ''Cats and Dogs,'' the prissy kitties fling ninja stars at their jowly canine foes while purring oaths of world domination. And in the new version of ''Planet of the Apes,'' Capt. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) is flung through a space-time continuum into the future to a planet where apes rule over humans.

title: Jail Term for Former Penny-Stock Tycoon
description: After making a tearful apology to his family, friends and officials of the federal bankruptcy court, a once-flamboyant penny-stock tycoon, Robert E. Brennan, was sentenced today to nine years and two months in federal prison for money-laundering and bankruptcy fraud.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN DROPS. Corn fell on speculation that rain would quickly rejuvenate plants after a heat wave. In Chicago, corn for delivery in December, after the harvest, fell 1.75 cents, or 0.8 percent, to $2.295 a bushel.

title: U.S. Offers Russia a Blueprint for Talks on Nuclear Weapons
description: Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, offered President Vladimir V. Putin an American blueprint today for talks on building a new nuclear-weapons framework, a process she cast as part of a broader White House plan for ''transforming'' the relationship between Washington and Moscow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOWITZ, HILDA
description: KANTOWITZ-Hilda. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected leader of the Fair Lawn, NJ, Jewish community, beloved mother of Yeshiva College Board member Robert I. (and Robin) Kantowitz-YC Fellows and active leaders of the University-and Jeffrey Kantowitz. Robert Kantowitz is a former vice president of the YC Alumni Association and co-chairman of the President's Circle. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to brothers, Eli and David Graubard; sister, Eve Satz; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: In the Galleries
description: 50's Physique: Vintage Bodybuilding Photography'

title: Cost-Cutting Helps Lockheed Increase Profit 29% in Quarter
description: Lockheed Martin said today that its second-quarter profit rose 29 percent as it cut costs.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Bar To Primary Is Denied
description: A federal judge in Tacoma has rejected a request by state political parties that he permanently bar the state's blanket political primary. Republican and Democratic leaders began challenging the system after the United States Supreme Court ruled in June 2000 that California's blanket primaries, which allow voting across party lines, were unconstitutional. In his ruling on Tuesday, the judge, Franklin D. Burgess, equated an injunction against the primary with rewriting election statutes. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Here Come The British

title: '50's Physique' -- 'Vintage Bodybuilding Photography'
description: Wessel & O'Connor Gallery

title: No Contract Yet, but Jets Expect Moss to Be at Camp
description: With players set to report to the Jets' training camp tomorrow, all indications remain that Santana Moss, the team's top draft pick, will be among them. But as of last night, the Jets and Moss's agent were still trading proposals, and a deal was not yet in place.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stem Cells Hint at Promise For Inborn Brain Diseases
description: In further testimony to the medical promise of stem cells, biologists have found that human neural stem cells can become incorporated in a fetal monkey's brain and share in its development, suggesting a novel way of correcting inborn brain diseases.

title: 18 CNN Journalists Protest Departure of Chief Counsel
description: CNN's journalists, who in the last few months have endured layoffs and management changes without visible complaint, protested this week over the sudden departure of the network's chief counsel, Eve Burton.

title: One Writer's Place in Fiction
description: I was a college senior in 1955 when I met Eudora Welty in the middle of the night at the Durham, N.C., train station. She was coming to give her famous lecture ''Place in Fiction'' at the Woman's College at Duke. In those days, women couldn't leave their dorms after sundown. I'd known Miss Welty's work since I was 14, and I knew she was a great writer. I had strong hopes to be one too, so I took it upon myself to turn up at the station and drive her safely to the hotel. She stayed three days, gave her quietly dazzling lecture, read the only serious short story I'd written and asked me if she could show it to her agent. Could she?

title: Claudia and Julia Mueller, Olu Oguibe, Senam Okudzeto, Ouattara Watts
description: Gorney Bravin & Lee

title: Who Put the Loco In in Loco Parentis?
description: ''Wet Hot American Summer'' takes place on the last day of summer camp in 1981. Among some older (though not necessarily more mature) members of its target audience, the movie may elicit stirrings of nostalgia, not only for the sticky, hormone-addled time of life it evokes but also for the dumb, cheesy summertime farces that flourished in the late 1970's and early 80's.

title: Knicks Could Face Jordan When They Start the Season
description: The N.B.A. released its schedule for the 2001-2 season yesterday, and the Knicks open up with what could be their most ballyhooed regular-season game in years. On Oct. 30, the Knicks start the season against the visiting Washington Wizards, who could be led by Michael Jordan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIESLER, LILLIAN
description: KIESLER-Lillian on July 25, 2001, after a short illness. Widow of the late Frederick J. Kiesler. No funeral or memorial services. Donations in her memory to The National Museum of Women in the Arts, 1520 New York Avenue, North Washington, DC 20009-3920 would be appreciated.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Bears, Bears Everywhere

title: Bush Gives on Patients Bill, But Democrats Want More
description: President Bush offered new concessions to Congress today on legislation to define patients' rights, but Democrats said the proposals did not go far enough to satisfy their concerns.

title: Giants Preach Tranquillity After Run to the Super Bowl
description: The Giants are so determined to avoid controversy in their post-Super Bowl season that even something as simple and time-honored as a training camp holdout was botched and stripped of its usual distracting discord. Linebacker Jessie Armstead may have boycotted the Giants' off-season minicamps and conditioning program this spring over a contract issue, but when he arrived at training camp today he promptly insisted the dispute was not about more pay or a new contract.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Minority Home Ownership Rises
description: More than 13 million minority families owned their homes in the second quarter of this year, setting a record of 48.8 percent, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said. The overall rate is 67.7 percent, with about 72 million American families owning their homes.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Carroll O'Connor on June 22 misstated the name of the British television show from which the American series ''All in the Family'' was adapted. A reader's e-mail message on June 25 pointed out that it was ''Till Death Us Do Part,'' not ''Till Death Do Us Part.'' This correction was delayed for checking because references conflicted.

title: Naked Men in the Road, but Not in the Mail
description: There may be a place in this world for the unashamed depiction of the unclothed male posterior, but the local post office is definitely not it.

title: Sears Decides On Ad Strategy
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has decided to proceed with a strategy from Young & Rubicam Advertising in Chicago and New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group, as the basis for a rebranding campaign.

title: Bush Nominates a Statistician to Direct the Census Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  President Bush today nominated C. Louis Kincannon, a career statistician with a broad background of demographic research in America and Europe, to be the next director of the Census Bureau.

title: Craig Kauffman
description: Sandra Gering

title: Budgeting That Harms Education
description: Five years ago, New York State's education commissioner embarked on an ambitious program to raise school standards and graduation requirements across the state. Gov. George Pataki supported the push for higher standards in the early years and took credit for increases in the education budget. But the executive budget he sent the Legislature this year contained less than a third of the money that the education commissioner said would be needed to give New York's children the tools they need to meet the tough new standards and graduation requirements.

title: Photo Op to Oops
description: As he announced an endorsement, Mark Green inadvertently stepped into a division between rival Hasidic groups in the state. Page B1.

title: Connecticut Court Overturns Residents-Only Beach Policy
description: The state's highest court ruled today that the residents-only policy for the town beach here violated both the federal and state Constitutions, denying nonresidents their fundamental rights to free speech and association.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Power Plants' Sale Delayed
description: NRG Energy Inc. said yesterday that federal regulators delayed the company's $350 million purchase of two power plants in Connecticut because of competition concerns. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission staff will investigate the planned purchase of the plants in Bridgeport and New Haven from Wisconsin Energy Corporation within 90 days, the company said in a written statement. The delay will prevent NRG from completing the deal by June 30, as previously announced, and postpone an expected immediate boost to earnings. NRG, based in Minneapolis, already owns four Connecticut power plants, and federal regulators are concerned that adding two more might allow NRG to manipulate electricity prices, the company said.

title: Williams Wants to Be A Manager
description: Mitch Williams used to enter games to the pounding sound of the song ''Wild Thing.'' He hopes to make much calmer entrances in the future -- carrying out the lineup card as a big league manager.

title: Indonesia Ex-Chief Heads to U.S., Not Without Some Parting Shots
description: Exhausted, bitter, perhaps confused, Abdurrahman Wahid, now the former president of Indonesia, ended his stubborn occupation of his increasingly empty palace today and left the country for a medical checkup in the United States.

title: 'Cool'
description: Cynthia Broan Gallery

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Expelled Senator To Run Again
description: The first Michigan state senator expelled from office by his peers announced that he would try to win back his seat. The man, David Jaye, a Republican from the Detroit suburbs, was expelled after three drunken-driving convictions.A special election for the seat will be held on Sept. 11. John Carpenter (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Houston Bans Gay Bias In City Hiring
description: The Houston City Council has approved an ordinance outlawing discrimination against gay men and lesbians in hiring by city agencies. The measure, which passed 10 to 4 on Wednesday, resurrected a policy overturned in a referendum in January 1985. Conservative leaders have promised to fight the ordinance again. Mayor Lee Brown predicted that the measure would survive. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Pinter's Silences, Richly Eloquent
description: WELL, they have come up in the world, haven't they? Look at them, all tarted up in designer swank and swilling Champagne. And in a fancy, noisy restaurant, to boot, where you can't even hear those famous silences that have long defined their tribe.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Advertising Club of New York named its 2001-2002 board. Bob Mate was named president, succeeding Carla Loffredo, who becomes chairwoman. Mr. Mate is vice president and publishing director at the Meredith Corporation and Ms. Loffredo is senior partner for strategic planning at MindShare, part of the WPP Group. There were additional board appointments. Renee Simons was named senior vice president; she is senior vice president for marketing and communications at J.P. Morgan Chase. Paul Cappelli was named vice president; he is president at the Ad Store. Stephen Block was named vice president; he is corporate vice president at AT&T. And Ronald Fierman was named treasurer; he is executive vice president and managing director at Digital Pulp.

title: Wendell at Center Of Phillies' Interest
description: The Mets have built their team with an emphasis on bullpen depth, and it seems they will deal from that depth as the Tuesday trading deadline approaches.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Juno Online's Loss Shrinks
description: Juno Online Services, one of the first free Internet service providers, said its losses had shrunk as it cut costs and converted subscribers of its free service into paying customers. Juno's net loss for the second quarter of 2001 was $2.6 million, a 73 percent improvement over the first quarter, when its net loss was $9.6 million, and a 94 percent gain from a year earlier, when it reported a loss of $42.9 million. The company reported revenue of $29.4 million for the latest quarter, up from $28.7 million reported for the previous quarter and $29.6 million a year earlier. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: U.S. Seeks to Block A Microsoft Hearing
description: Government antitrust enforcers today urged rejection of Microsoft's bid for a new hearing before the federal court that found the company in violation of antitrust laws.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH WINS F.D.A. RULING ON DRUG PACKAGING
description: Schering-Plough said yesterday that it had won a ruling from the Food and Drug Administration that might lead to a new hepatitis treatment with sales of as much as $2 billion a year. The ruling allows Schering-Plough, a top seller of hepatitis drugs, to market separate packages of Rebetol capsules, which are made by ICN Pharmaceuticals and which are available only in combination with an injectable interferon drug, Intron-A. The separate package is a necessary first step in Schering's plan to sell Rebetol with Peg-Intron, an improved interferon drug that Schering developed with the biotechnology company Enzon. The F.D.A. may rule as early as next month on Schering's application to market Rebetol and Peg-Intron in combination.

title: Economy Grew at 0.7 Percent in Second Quarter of 2001
description: The economy grew at a barely perceptible rate in the second quarter, its weakest pace in eight years, as businesses slashed spending and inventories, the government reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, PETER
description: KING-Peter. On July 10, 2001 in Moldova. Peter started his career designing for Calvin Klein Jeans & was still in the garment industry at the time of his death. Survived by daughters Julie King and Jamie Levitt. Funeral July 31, 2001, 10AM at Gutterman's Inc. For details call: 718-284-1500.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Advertising Club of New York named its 2001-2002 board. Bob Mate was named president, succeeding Carla Loffredo, who becomes chairwoman. Mr. Mate is vice president and publishing director at the Meredith Corporation and Ms. Loffredo is senior partner for strategic planning at MindShare, part of the WPP Group. There were additional board appointments. Renee Simons was named senior vice president; she is senior vice president for marketing and communications at J.P. Morgan Chase. Paul Cappelli was named vice president; he is president at the Ad Store. Stephen Block was named vice president; he is corporate vice president at AT&T. And Ronald Fierman was named treasurer; he is executive vice president and managing director at Digital Pulp.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Goto.com Forecast Lifts Shares
description: Defying the slump in the Internet advertising market, GoTo.com, a pay-for-placement Internet search service, reported a narrower-than-expected loss and said it now expected to be profitable ahead of schedule. GoTo, based in Pasadena, Calif., reported a net loss of $2.9 million, or 6 cents a share, down sharply from the loss of $20.3 million, or 42 cents, a year earlier. Second-quarter revenue nearly tripled to $62.5 million from $21 million. Ted Meisel, chief executive of GoTo, said that in contrast to other advertising-supporting companies, GoTo has had an increase in spending by its advertisers over the last nine months. GoTo shares rose $3.40, to $24.55.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Justice Dept. Is Cool On Verizon Plan
description: The Justice Department said it would not endorse Verizon's application to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania because of problems with the company's electronic billing system. Verizon has made progress in opening the market, said Charles A. James, assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division. ''But the absence of a commercially proven electronic billing system was a continuing concern,'' Mr. James said. A ruling by the F.C.C. is due Sept. 21.

title: Settlement With Umpires Now Hinging on Phillips
description: Two years ago, some umpires blamed Richie Phillips, their union leader, when 22 umpires lost their jobs. Now Phillips apparently holds a pivotal position in their attempt to regain the jobs or gain financial settlements in lieu of jobs.

title: PROFIT RECOVERY GROUP AGREES TO BUY HOWARD SCHULTZ
description: The Profit Recovery Group International, a provider of accounts-payable and auditing services, plans to buy a closely held rival, Howard Schultz & Associates International, for $158.7 million. Profit Recovery will issue about $158.7 million in stock for the purchase and assume as much as $37 million in debt, the company said. Profit Recovery, based in Atlanta, will also assume as much as $14 million in debt to buy British and German licensees of Schultz, which is based in Dallas. The combined company, which will be renamed PRG-Schultz, will have 3,900 clients in 35 countries, and 3,500 employees.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Unusual Divorce Case Ruling
description: In an unusual ruling for a divorce case, a Manhattan judge has awarded almost all of a couple's marital assets, some $17 million, to the wife, Theresa Havell, left, because her husband, Aftab Islam, angry over her request for a divorce, tried to beat her to death with a barbell. Last year, Mr. Islam, now 60, was sentenced to more than eight years in prison for assault. In a ruling dated July 23, Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court said that while marital fault was generally irrelevant to dividing a divorcing couple's assets, the extreme violence of the case warranted an exception. Mr. Islam received $377,000 under the ruling, with another $78,000 in dispute. Ms. Havell, 54, has undergone extensive reconstructive surgery. Mr. Islam is likely to appeal. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Cunard Selects TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: The Cunard Line, a division of the Carnival Corporation, which operates cruise ships like the QE2, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

title: Amid Jingles And Slogans, A Sober Mood
description: Hear that plaintive noise emanating from Madison Avenue? That is the sound of the national advertising economy still bumping along the bottom far longer than industry executives had feared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, LUCILLE STAEBLER
description: MARTIN-Lucille Staebler. 98, died as gracefully as she lived, at home, on July 24, 2001. Wife of the late Murray Martin. Artist, actress, teacher, beloved mother and grandmother of Jack and Lucy Martin Gianino, Bruce and Wilhelmina Martin Eaken, and of Gemina, Antonia, Gian-Murray, Amanda and Webb. Funeral Services Monday, July 30 at 4 P.M. at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 50th Street & Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Saint Bartholomew's Church.

title: Moody's Lowers Argentina's Credit Ratings
description: Argentina's credit ratings were lowered for a second time this month by Moody's Investors Service on concern that the country will not be able to erase its budget deficit to help ensure debt payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, DR. PEARL
description: BERKOWITZ-Dr. Pearl. Beloved wife of Sol. Sister of the late Harold Schwartz and Eleanor Waldman. Devoted aunt and great aunt. Clinical psychologist and former Principal of special education schools. Funeral service Friday, 12:30 at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: 22 Years Later, A Role Emerges

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANUS, ANN
description: HANUS-Ann. On July 26, 2001, of NYC. She worked for 50 years with Guardian Life in NYC, and retired as an Assistant Vice President in 1985. Ms. Hanus was a graduate of Julia Richmond High School and graduated Magna Cum Laude from Baruch City College where she was a member of Beta Gamma Sigma and Beta Alpha Pi. She will be best remembered for her love of the theater, reading and travel. She is survived by her sister Louise Holub. She is also survived by three nieces and one nephew and also great-nieces and nephews, and great-great-nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial will be held today, 11 AM, at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church, 414 East 14th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions to Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church; Baruch College Fund, 17 Lexington Ave, NYC 10010; the American Institute for Cancer Research, 1759 R St, NW, PO Box 97167, Washington, DC 20090.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Festival
description: This is the last weekend of the Lincoln Center Festival 2001. Venues include the New York State Theater, the Walter Reade Theater and Alice Tully Hall, all at Lincoln Center; John Jay College Theater, Amsterdam Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets; La Guardia Drama Theater and Concert Hall, 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue; the Rose Building, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza; and the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street. Tickets: $20 to $90. Film screenings at the Walter Reade Theater are $9; $5 for members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center; $4.50 for those 65 and older at weekday matinees. Screening information: (212) 875-5600. Festival information: (212) 875-5928 or www.lincolncenter.org. Tickets: (212) 721-6500. The schedule:

title: G.E. UNIT AGREES TO BUY $240 MILLION IN WABTEC ASSETS
description: General Electric's transportation unit said yesterday that it had agreed to buy locomotive-repair parts and contracts from the Wabtec Corporation for $240 million. The sale includes locomotive service-contract businesses in Barstow, Calif., and Mexico. The assets being sold accounted for 18 percent of Wabtec's $1.03 billion in revenue last year, a spokeswoman said. Wabtec, a supplier of railroad equipment, will use the proceeds to reduce debt. Wabtec, based in Wilmerding, Pa., expects proceeds of more than $200 million.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Left Field to Left Out? Spencer Hopes Not
description: With David Justice embarking on a minor league rehabilitation stint this weekend and Yankee Manager Joe Torre saying he expects Justice back in his lineup within a week, either Shane Spencer or Chuck Knoblauch figures to lose his starting spot.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Editors' Note; About Mutual Funds
description: As a result of growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is eliminating entries for some of the smallest ones and making its daily table more concise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, E.M.
description: ROSENTHAL-E.M. The officers and Board of Trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations profoundly mourn the death of a cherished friend and colleague. An honorary Vice Chairman, Manny served our sacred cause for many years, always with caring concern and dedication to the great ideals of our faith and our people. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife, Roslyn, his children and all his loved ones. Russell Silverman, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President

title: To Reflect On Or Simply To Admire
description: ''O sweet mirror, invented in order to know that which our own gaze cannot see,'' wrote a French poet five centuries ago. The mirror occupies a special place in the imagination. From ancient times, it has played a role in human society and has been a favorite subject for philosophical, psychological and religious debate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Cabs Sought For Disabled
description: C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, urged the Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday to increase the number of taxicabs that can accommodate wheelchairs. She said that Boston and Toronto had fleets of such cabs but that only two of New York City's 50,000 cabs were accessible to wheelchair users. A conversion of a minivan into such a cab would cost about $5,000 or $10,000, depending on whether the rear of the cab or the safer but more expensive side door was modified. During the last fiscal year, the City Council allocated $250,000 to help pay for such cabs. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: More Friends Hanging Out And Emoting in New York
description: ''Leap Years,'' a new weekly nighttime series beginning on Sunday night, is about five friends living in New York whose friendship transcends all other relationships. It's a Showtime presentation from the producers of ''Queer as Folk,'' so in this cable variation on ''Friends'' everyone gets naked quickly.

title: Rough Ride in the House
