description: No one has gone to the mat more for President Bush than Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the burly, low-key House speaker who long labored as a high school wrestling coach.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Oil Found
description: Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petrleo Brasileiro S.A., or Petrobras, has discovered up to 130 million barrels of additional reserves in four fields along the northeastern coast. The discoveries came as the fields were entering periods of stable or falling production. In one of the largest finds in the last 30 years, the company detected as much as 80 million barrels in one of the fields, which are 10 miles off the coast of the state of Sergipe. With the discovery, Petrobras has extended exploration of the field for two years. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Hevesi Seeks Overhaul of City Election System
description: Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi called yesterday for an overhaul of the city's election system and for advancing the primary by four months, from September to May. The fact that election officials are considering postponing this September's runoff election, he said, indicates problems with the current system.

title: Ferrer Defines the 'Other New York,' and He Discusses His Plans to Help It
description: Here are excerpts of an interview with Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and a Democratic candidate for mayor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. The Times plans to hold similar sessions with each of the other major candidates.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: JDS Uniphase Will Write Down $44.8 Billion in Assets
description: JDS Uniphase, a leading manufacturer of components for telecommunications networks, said yesterday that it was writing down by $44.8 billion the value of companies it had acquired in two years of rapid growth. It was believed to be the largest loss in business history.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Front-Runner For Governor
description: Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend emerged as the front-runner in a new poll of voters regarding next year's race for governor. Of those mentioned as candidates in a Democratic primary, Ms. Townsend led Comptroller William Donald Schaefer, a former governor, 44 percent to 34 percent, with 22 percent undecided. In a general election, Ms. Townsend was favored over Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican, 48 percent to 34 percent, with 18 percent undecided. The poll of 625 voters by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research had a margin of error of five percentage points for the primary and four percentage points for the general election. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: Phillips Wins A Three-Sided Bidding Game

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Restaurant Embezzlement
description: The former manager of a restaurant on the Upper East Side has been accused of using $360,000 of corporate funds for personal expenses that included trips to Paris, clothing from Barney's and meals at Caviarteria. The former manager, Jacques Le Magueresse, 45, was charged with grand larceny for what authorities said were corporate credit-card and other thefts during the three years that he was the manager of Cello, a French restaurant at 53 East 77th Street. A French citizen, Mr. Le Magueresse surrendered his passport before being released on $50,000 bail.

title: Scottsdale Resort in Arizona
description: What does it take to get vacationers to Scottsdale, Ariz., in summer? The Hyatt Regency Scottsdale Resort at Gainey Ranch hopes this works: Through Sept. 5, rates start at $195 a night, and for a stay of three consecutive nights, the fourth night is free. Information: (800) 233-1234 or www.arizonaguide.com/hyattscott .

title: Members of Congress Begin Effort to Get U.S. to Join in Fighting Global Warming
description: With the United States now alone in the world in opposing the treaty to combat global warming, some lawmakers are pressing for Congress to take the lead toward reducing emissions of so-called greenhouse gases, the issue on which the Bush administration has so far kept to the sidelines.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Two Belligerent Brothers
description: Jeffrey Wright, above left, as Lincoln, a retired master of three-card monte, and Don Cheadle as his brother, Booth, an agile shoplifter, star in ''Topdog/Underdog,'' Suzan-Lori Parks's comic drama of hustlers and victims, conners and conned, which opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: 2 High Teams Eliminated In Spingold Bridge Tourney
description: Two top-ranked teams were eliminated from the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Wednesday night.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Death Sentence Upheld
description: The Lahore High Court has rejected the appeal of Ayub Masih, who was condemned to death in 1998 for violating blasphemy laws. He is accused of making derogatory remarks about the Prophet Muhammad. When he was originally sentenced, a Roman Catholic bishop, John Joseph, apparently killed himself in protest. Mr. Masih can now appeal to the supreme court. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Sharks in Shallow Water
description: When you go to a coastal beach, it can be hard to remember that the place you are going borders the last great wilderness on earth. Humans have certainly affected the earth's oceans, routinely polluting and overfishing them, but we have never for a moment lessened the essential wildness of even the knee-deep edge of the seas. This year the reminder of that came in the form of a bull shark, which attacked an 8-year-old boy named Jessie Arbogast on July 6 at the Gulf Islands National Seashore near Pensacola, Fla. What made this story unusual was the fact that the shark was wrestled to shore by the boy's uncle, killed, and the boy's arm retrieved from its mouth and reattached.

title: Sea of Self-Love, but Who's Drowning?
description: Nothing holds back Madonna. Not love, not pop expectations, not tastefulness, not religion, not the laws of physics. Her Drowned World Tour, which started its sold-out five-night run on Wednesday night (through Tuesday) at Madison Square Garden, is a 105-minute pop spectacle as performance art, devoted to the idea that Madonna can do what she wants. Her fans, theoretically, are welcome to take it or leave it.

title: Vallone Gets Testimonials From a Voice of Experience
description: Peter F. Vallone, a candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, will broadcast his first television advertisement today on local cable news stations. Campaign aides described the 30-second commercial, titled ''Experience,'' as the first in a series featuring former Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Auto Venture
description: Hyundai Motor and DaimlerChrysler formed a joint venture to produce diesel engines at a Hyundai plant in South Korea. Called the DaimlerChrysler-Hyundai Commercial Vehicle Company, it will manufacture the engines for trucks produced by DaimlerChrysler, Hyundai Motor and Mitsubishi Motors in Japan. The venture is a major step in cooperation between Hyundai Motor and DaimlerChrysler, which owns 10 percent of Hyundai Motor and 37 percent of Mitsubishi. DaimlerChrysler and Hyundai are each investing $77 million in the venture. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Buster's Daydream Gets Jump In Sanford
description: Sandwiched between his 83-year-old father and Miss USA in the winner's circle, Steve Barberino Jr. couldn't help himself: ''What does this colt have to do to earn the respect he deserves?'' he bellowed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBACH, JOSEPH J.
description: MARBACH-Joseph J. The faculty, students, alumni and staff of Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health mourn the untimely passing of Dr. Joseph Marbach, long-time faculty member of our Department of Sociomedical Sciences. To his wife, children, grandchildren and entire family, we extend our deepest sympathy. Allan Rosenfield, MD Dean

title: A Biased Social Security Report
description: This week President Bush's Commission to Strengthen Social Security released an interim report on the program's prospects. Without making any specific proposals, the report clearly shows a bias toward the kind of reform President Bush favors -- one based on individual accounts invested in market securities. The president rigged the commission to complement, or perhaps supplant, the Social Security Advisory Board created by Congress and President Clinton in 1994. That board has taken a careful, technical approach to appraising Social Security. Mr. Bush's commission has not.

title: Beijing's Turnabout Is Seen as a Maneuver to Mollify the U.S.
description: While the two Chinese citizens with permanent residency in the United States who were convicted this week of spying won medical parole, a third person jailed in the case, Qu Wei, remains in a Beijing jail cell.

title: Sony Posts Loss, Citing Weak Sales And a Recall
description: The Sony Corporation said today that weakening worldwide sales of electronics products and costs arising from a large recall of cellular handsets caused it to lose 30.1 billion yen, or $243 million, in the first quarter. It also cut its profit forecast for the year by 40 percent.

title: Brothers in a Game Where the Hand Is Faster Than the Eye
description: Even the most untrusting New Yorker won't be able to resist Jeffrey Wright's invitation to a little game of three-card monte. Mr. Wright is portraying a retired master of that most basic and complex of sidewalk scams in ''Topdog/Underdog,'' Suzan-Lori Parks's vibrant comic drama of shifting identity and betrayal, which opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: Southern Levitation: Battling Banks' Shares Keep Rising
description: IT'S the greatest election battle of the year, one in which ads from each side twist the record to make one candidate seem wonderful and the other horrible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, LAURENCE B.
description: CLARKE-Laurence B. New York Naval Order of US mourns the passing of its esteemed former Commander. Service 10:30 AM, Thursday, August 2, St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park & 50th St.

title: Mayor of Waterbury Is Arrested in a Federal Child-Sex Case
description: Mayor Philip A. Giordano of Waterbury, who lost a long-shot bid last year to unseat Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and whose city has been teetering on the edge of bankruptcy, was arrested in New Haven this morning by federal agents and accused of luring a minor for sex.

title: SENATE SUPPORTS STRICT STANDARDS ON MEXICO TRUCKS
description: The Senate defied threats from the White House and the Mexican government today and voted overwhelmingly to support efforts to impose strict safety standards on Mexican trucks seeking access to American roads.

title: Bach Plays a Cello Here, and the Cello Likes It
description: The Spanish choreographer Nacho Duato is no stranger to New York. Compaa Nacional de Danza, the company he directs in Madrid, brings back his lava-cascading style of choreography. In ''Bach: Multiplicity,'' a United States premiere that was deliriously received at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night in Lincoln Center Festival 2001, Mr. Duato was relatively restrained.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A bargain is a relative thing. In the rarefied world of Alain Ducasse, a $65 lunch counts as a supersaver discount. This modest three-course option is called the menu salad, and for those who want a taste of Ducasse before taking the ultimate plunge (at the moment, that would be the $250 shellfish tasting menu), it may be the best thing since Broadway twofers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Leader On The Road
description: Kim Jong Il roared through Russia on the Trans-Siberian Railroad with no time off to look at the city where historians say he was born. His train paused just 20 minutes in Khabarovsk, then resumed his official journey to Moscow. His official biographies insist that Mr. Kim, 59, was born in a hut on Mount Paektu, the sacred mountain on the North Korea-China border. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Stocks Relapse As Japan Waits For Changes
description: Japan's stock market, which rallied in the spring on hope that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi would be able to pull the country out of a decade-long slump, has slipped to pre-election levels as the premier has failed to explain how he would handle nonperforming bank loans and as the global slowdown curbs corporate profit.

title: Tax Shelter That Involves Capital Gains Is Disallowed
description: A tax shelter used at least 200 times by very rich Americans and corporations to evade capital gains taxes by manipulating rules on foreign investments was shut down yesterday by the Treasury Department.

title: The Twist of Koizumi's Reforms: Supporters Could Suffer
description: It is in towns like this one, clinging stubbornly to the rugged black cliffs that line the southeastern coast of Hokkaido, where voters will decide this weekend whether Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi will be allowed to reshape Japan with his plans for bold reform.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Bogey at the 19th Hole (It's Lonely Here!)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIBEL, ANNETTE
description: HIBEL-Annette. Your laughter and friendship will always be missed. What a nice lady! Audrey and Alvin

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro fell after stronger-than-expected growth in the money supply dampened speculation about a cut in interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 87.78 cents, down from 88.10 cents on Wednesday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SAF-T-HAMMER, Scottsdale, Ariz., said its subsidiary, Smith & Wesson, the world's largest handgun manufacturer, had reached a three-year agreement with Remington Arms Corp., Madison, N.C., to make parts for some of Remington's Centerfire brand rifles.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Is Still Undecided About Hudson River Cleanup
description: Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told senators yesterday that she still hoped to decide by today whether to go forward with the Clinton administration plan that calls for the General Electric Company to clean up the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELHAUT, GLENN D.
description: KESSELHAUT-Glenn D. The partners, associates and staff of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett are deeply saddened by the passing of their dear friend and respected colleague, Glenn Kesselhaut, a member of the firm since 1990. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Rachel, to his children, Benjamin, Matthew and Jeremy, and to his parents and sisters. We will miss his gentle nature and kindness, his superb counsel and his always present wit and humor.

title: Appeals Court Wants Judge To Consider Latest Findings
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday ordered the trial judge in the Abner Louima case to consider what defense lawyers claim is evidence that proves one of the officers convicted in the case was a victim of mistaken identity.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest To Supply Network Services To AOL
description: Qwest Communications International and AOL Time Warner signed a deal under which Qwest will become a primary provider of high-speed access and other network services to AOL Time Warner. Qwest will also purchase advertising across AOL Time Warner's portfolio of online, print and television outlets.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bow To Shrine's War Legacy
description: The foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, said she would urge Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to cancel plans to visit the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo next month where criminals from World War II are enshrined. Ms. Tanaka told reporters in Hanoi where she was attending a meeting of foreign ministers: ''I don't want him to visit there. This is my consistent view.'' Mr. Koizumi's plans to visit the shrine have drawn heavy criticism from China and Korea, which suffered atrocities by Japan during the war. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Governor Vetoes State Budget
description: Gov. Don Sundquist vetoed the state budget that legislators passed earlier this month, saying it was ''fiscally irresponsible'' to use nearly $600 million in tobacco settlement payments to fill gaps in the state's budget. Governor Sundquist, a Republican, also vetoed the budget last year, and he urged lawmakers not to override him this year as they did last year. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, PHILIP WALSH
description: MOORE-Philip Walsh. Age 81, died in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. July 18, 2001 after a short illness. He is survived by his devoted wife, Phaedra; daughter Jourdan Houston, (Colorado); son Thomas Moore, (Miami); son Ned Moore, (Virginia); six grandchildren; and sister Louise Immer of Thun, Switzerland. He was preceded in death by his son, Philip Moore, Jr. A private family service is planned at the Moore mausoleum in Burmont, Pennsylvania.

title: Times Names Gerald Boyd As Its Next Managing Editor
description: Gerald M. Boyd, a deputy managing editor of The New York Times for the last four years, will become managing editor of the newspaper in September.

title: British Telecommunications Goes Into Red for the Quarter
description: British Telecommunications reported a second-quarter loss today as it felt the pinch from higher interest payments and from losses at its mobile phone operation.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music and Dance Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: U.S. Tells Iraq It May Retaliate For Missile Attack on Spy Plane
description: President Bush declared today that Saddam Hussein ''is still a menace'' and a Pentagon official warned that the United States reserves the right to respond at any time to Iraq's attempt this week to shoot down a U-2 plane with a surface-to-air missile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, DOUGLAS ALAN
description: ZIMMERMAN - Douglas Alan. April 10, 1950 to July 27, 2000. It has been one year since our Douglas passed away. His laughter and extravagance, his delight in living, are remembered with joy. He is dearly loved and deeply missed. Alana, Beth, Ali, Rebecca, and Mark

title: Creative Shifts At Procter & Gamble
description: Procter & Gamble, in another realignment of assignments among roster agencies, is shifting the worldwide creative duties for two brands from one shop owned by the Bcom3 Group to another.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Group Accused Of Drug Dealing
description: The leaders of what prosecutors called a heroin-and-cocaine-dealing ring that catered to Russian immigrants were arrested yesterday. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said that the supplier of the drugs and three others who were running the street operation were also arrested. A six-month investigation led authorities to Bienvenido Castillo, 59, and his wife, Celena Pichardo, 36, who the authorities said packaged the drugs in their Brooklyn apartment and sold them to dealers who distributed them in Rego Park and Forest Hills, where there are large Russian immigrant populations. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: White House Is Said to Strike A Deal Averting Subpoenas
description: The Bush administration has agreed to cooperate with a Senate committee investigating how several sensitive environmental decisions were made, a move that is likely to end the threat that the Democratic-controlled Senate would issue its first subpoenas against the Bush White House, people involved in the matter said today.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Crackdown On BBC Journalists
description: The government suspended the accreditation of correspondents from the British Broadcasting Corporation, saying it could no longer tolerate ''the distortions and misrepresentations'' of its reporting, the state newspaper reported. The move is the latest crackdown on foreign journalists, who have criticized the government's support of black militants who have invaded white-owned farms and threatened white businessmen and opposition party members. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAIN, STEPHEN H.
description: KAIN-Stephen H. Life partner of Darryl Aronsohn. Beloved father of Seth and Lisa, Jill and Larry Karp, Jennifer and Larry Sweetwood. Dear son of Esther and the late Arthur. Beloved brother of Karen and Steven Bachmann, Janet and Edward Greenberg. Adored grandfather of Alex Kain and Daniel Karp. Services today 1PM at Gutterman Woodbury Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury.

title: PERFORMANCE FOOD IS BUYING SPRINGFIELD FOODSERVICE
description: The Performance Food Group, a food wholesaler, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a food distributor, Springfield Foodservice, for $70 million to expand in the Northeast. Performance said it would pay $42 million in stock and $28 million in cash, and assume $15 million in debt for Springfield, which is closely held. Performance, based in Richmond, Va., will get a 140,000-square-foot distribution center in Springfield, Mass., where Springfield Foodservice is based. Springfield Foodservice has 150 employees and ships food to restaurants and schools in Massachusetts, Connecticut and New York.

title: With Some Premiums Higher, A.I.G.'s Income Rises 16%
description: The American International Group said yesterday that second-quarter profit increased 16 percent as the company, a huge insurer and one of the world's largest financial groups, raised prices on policies to businesses and increased sales of life insurance and annuities.

title: Florida Teenager Declares Sorrow for Killing Teacher
description: A 14-year-old boy facing 25 years to life for murder told a judge and the victim's family today that he never intended to shoot his favorite teacher and was sorry for the killing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Soka University of America, a new liberal arts college in California, misspelled part of the name of the firm that drafted the campus master plan. It is Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, not Holtzman.

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: New Train-To-Plane Service
description: The region's first train-to-the-plane service will start on Sept. 30 when the Port Authority of New York opens a new station that will connect New Jersey commuter lines and northeast corridor trains to Newark International Airport by monorail. The service, AirTrain Newark, will go into operation more than a year before a similar service for Kennedy International Airport. The Port Authority approved a plan with New Jersey Transit yesterday that will provide three trains an hour each way between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m.. The fare from Newark's Penn Station will be $6.65, about half the cost of a taxi. The trip from New York's Penn Station will cost $11.15, about one-fourth the cab fare. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Redistricting Panel Takes A Break
description: A commission responsible for redistricting for the State Legislature recessed until Aug. 6 after agreeing on 21 of 35 districts. The commission, three Republicans and three Democrats, decided to recess after tensions arose over the fate of Blaine County, one of Idaho's few Democratic strongholds. A complete plan is due in early September. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about employees who face layoffs at the headquarters of Lucent Technologies in Murray Hill, N.J., misidentified the affected county. It is Union, not Morris.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Forget the Key? Pretty Soon, You Can
description: CAR keys, as you have known them, are going out of business. Keyless door locks and ignition systems, part of an electronics revolution inside the automobile, are spreading from the luxury zone into everyday cars, a trend that is already well under way in Europe.

title: Viacom Exceeds Estimates By a Penny in 2nd Quarter
description: A major media conglomerate announces quarterly results that include strong cash-flow growth while raising doubts about its ability to meet a crucial target for the full year.

title: Robert Lowery, First Black Fire Commissioner, Dies at 85
description: Robert O. Lowery, the city's first black fire commissioner who served at a time when arson-fueled blazes raged through the city's minority neighborhoods, died on Tuesday in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Protests Over Bombing Range
description: Villagers protested against an American bombing range on two fronts. In Seoul, 30 people from Maehyang-ri, by the Yellow Sea southwest of the capital, protested at the offices of Lockheed Martin, which makes the F-16 planes used by American and Korean air forces and operates the bombing range in their village. At the range, villagers tried to break through rows of policemen, demanding that the range be closed. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: United and US Airways Call Off Merger After U.S. Opposes It
description: United Airlines and US Airways announced today that they had called off their proposed merger after the Justice Department threatened to file a lawsuit to block the $4.3 billion deal, calling it anticompetitive.

title: INSIDE
description: New Twist in Louima Case

title: Selection Of Pitches Is Downfall For Keisler
description: Randy Keisler, the Yankees' rookie left-hander, pitched four impressive innings against the Tigers yesterday, then fell apart.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Students' Files On The Web
description: Gov. Roy Barnes ordered an investigation into how personal information about thousands of the state's HOPE scholars ended up on the Internet. The scholarships provide tuition at state colleges and universities for all Georgia high school graduates with B averages. After entering information about the students into computers, state employees neglected to install a security file. That oversight allowed users of the search engine Google to retrieve information about the students. The problem has been fixed. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Same Old Story: The Mets Fall One Play Short
description: In another season, Rey Ordez would have fielded the ball and the Mets' hitters would have come through when needed. But in this lost season, Ordez's fielding is no longer flawless and the Mets' offense is nothing but flawed.

title: Youths in Adult Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about ''Word Freak'' by Stefan Fatsis, an examination of Scrabble, misspelled the name of a company that once owned the rights to the game. It is Selchow & Righter, not Richter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGNER, NATALIE
description: LANGNER-Natalie. On July 26, 2001. Peacefully in her home at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Loving mother of Edie Langner-Landeck, dear sister of Henrietta Wallach and the late Helen Lowenthal. An inspiring teacher and guidance counselor, she was a devoted volunteer. She lived her long life with grace and dignity and touched us all. Funeral services private. Memorial service to be announced. Donations may be made in Natalie's name to the Humanities and Medicine Program at Weill-Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Avenue, Room C118, New York, N.Y. 10021 or to Bank Street College of Education, 610 W. 112 St, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: M.I.T. Physicist Says Pentagon Is Trying to Silence Him
description: A leading critic of the military's missile defense testing program has accused the Pentagon of trying to silence him and intimidate his employer, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, by investigating him for disseminating classified documents.

title: 'Richard II'
description: Directed by John Farrell

title: Pop and Jazz Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE IS BUYING 5 DEALERSHIPS IN 2 STATES
description: Sonic Automotive, the second-largest publicly held auto-dealer group in the nation, is buying five dealerships in California and Texas with $275 million in combined annual sales. Terms were not disclosed. The company is buying Buena Park Honda, Harbor City Honda and West Covina Toyota in Los Angeles; Capitol Ford in San Jose, Calif.; and Nils Sefeldt Volvo in Houston. Sonic, based in Charlotte, N.C., has 165 franchises and 30 collision-repair centers. It generated 2000 sales of $6.05 billion. It ranks behind AutoNation of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which has more than 400 franchises.

title: Determined Armstrong Wins His Fourth Stage
description: ST. AMAND MONTROND, France, July 27 -- In another overwhelming performance, Lance Armstrong won his fourth daily stage in the 88th Tour de France today and fulfilled his desire to show that he is worthy of overall victory when the three-week race ends on Sunday in Paris.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Global Trade: Subsidy Upheld
description: A World Trade Organization panel upheld Brazil's latest program of jet aircraft subsidies. Canada had asked the panel to decide whether Brazil was complying with earlier W.T.O. rulings in a dispute between its Bombardier Inc. and Embraer of Brazil. Bombardier had claimed it suffered losses because of Brazil's subsidies to Embraer. After the W.T.O. sided with Canada, Brazil started the new subsidy program last December.

title: Reconsidering the Privacy of Office Computers
description: If you use a computer at work to send e-mail or surf the Internet, you may be aware of a legal principle that seems to have sprung up overnight: You have no right of privacy in on-the-job online communications.

title: Posing With Satmars, Green Steps Into a Sectarian Thicket
description: It is one of the classic photographs in New York City politics: that of a smiling candidate standing on the steps of City Hall, surrounded by the black-hatted Hasidic Jews who have just endorsed him. The snapshot has taken on an almost superstitious charm in city politics, preposterously suggesting that the candidate has received the support not only of Hasidic Jews -- but of all Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIRSKY, JAN
description: MIRSKY - Jan. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Jan Mirsky on July 22. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. Private services were held. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Calls for Revenge and a Shooting End a Brief Respite in the Mideast
description: A 17-year-old Israeli was killed late Thursday night, presumably by Palestinian gunmen, as he drove with his father along a West Bank road just north of Jerusalem. The Israeli army reportedly responded early today with tank fire at three Palestinian positions on the outskirts of nearby Ramallah.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Office Dress: Baseball Casual; Now, the Only Ties at the Stadium Are in the Scores
description: In the celluloid days of baseball, the pictures from the diamond came through the movie houses. The silver moments from the field were followed by pictures of fans in the stands, a sea of hats and white shirts and dark ties.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: How to Name a Kennedy

title: Macedonia Tension Eases Slightly as Talks Are to Restart
description: Macedonia pulled back again today from the brink of a wider war after top Western diplomats flew here and pressed all sides in this increasingly divided nation to stop fighting and start talking again.

title: Hardy Chekhov Fans Gain Amity, if Not Tickets
description: Chaim Garcia and Ei Avakawa, who are art students, were the first on line, arriving at 4:25 yesterday morning.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Avaya Plans More Job Cuts
description: Avaya Inc. said that it would cut an additional 2,000 jobs, adding to 3,000 cuts announced last month, as the maker of telephone equipment for businesses seeks to counter a decline in sales. Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., also said that revenue in the most recent quarter fell 10 percent, to $1.71 billion from $1.9 billion in the year-earlier period. Net income fell 27 percent, to $24 million from $33 million, the company said. Avaya, which was spun off from Lucent Technologies last year, will have 23,000 employees after the latest round of cuts is concluded. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Leaders Try to Mollify Moderates on Bush Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  In a move that could threaten crucial parts of President Bush's energy plan, House Republican leaders are planning to allow party moderates to offer amendments on environmentally touchy issues involving oil drilling in Alaska and fuel efficiency standards for vehicles.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Financial Group Sees Loss
description: Switzerland's largest financial group, UBS A.G., warned that it expected losses of up to $234 million this year from investments by its private equity business, UBS Capital. The announcement came two weeks after the bank cited tough market conditions when it canceled plans to sell the unit to a management group led by its former chief executive, Pierre de Weck. After the Zurich-based company's first-quarter earnings slumped, it reduced the rate of investments in private equity. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: KeySpan Reports Loss of $6.5 Million
description: The KeySpan Corporation lost $6.5 million in its second quarter after taking a charge of $30.1 million for accounting inaccuracies and higher-than-expected costs at its Roy Kay plumbing and contracting businesses.

title: For Indonesia, A Sea of Troubles
description: Megawati Sukarnoputri, Indonesia's new president, has a mess on her hands. The economy is in tatters, regions are in revolt and the government has almost broken down. So what did Mrs. Megawati do the weekend before becoming president, as the political crisis reached its height? She went to see ''Shrek,'' the animated movie about a friendly ogre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBMAN, RITA S.
description: LEIBMAN-Rita S. Adored wife of the late James J. Leibman. Beloved sister of Bernice Schaffer Bessin. Devoted cousin of Louise and Leo Yanoff. Sister of Violet Nelson. Cherished aunt, great aunt and great, great aunt to her many nieces and nephews. Her loving heart, sage advice and vivacious spirit will be long remembered. Services Friday, July 27th, 9:45AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Ravens' Haughty Billick Says He's Ready for More
description: Brian Billick was talking about his Baltimore Ravens but the description could have fit Brian Billick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVELIS, MARCOS, M.D.
description: RIVELIS-Marcos, M.D. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the passing of Marcos Rivelis, M.D. As a highly respected colleague and member of the medical staff at the Hospital for Special Surgery since 1966, he consistantly provided the highest level of medical care along with deep compassion and an intuitive knowledge of his patients. Dr. Rivelis was a strong supporter of the hospital and founded our own International Center, serving as its chairman for many years, greatly contributing to its growth and distinguished reputation. He was much admired for his medical expertise and his contributions to rheumatologic medicine throughout his career. He will be greatly missed and remembered always. We extend our prayerful condolences to his wife, Ema, and the entire Rivelis family. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman Aldo Papone, Co-Chairman Board of Trustees John R. Reynolds, President and CEO Russell F. Warren, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Stephen A. Paget, M.D. Physician-in-Chief

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA CHINA: U.S. SHIPS ENTER HONG KONG Two United States warships sailed into Hong Kong's harbor in a resumption of port calls that had been halted by the Chinese government after the mid-air collision between Chinese and American military planes last April. The Guardian and the Patriot, both minesweepers, will anchor in Hong Kong until Monday. In May, when relations between the countries were tense, China denied a request by the Inchon to call at the former British colony    Mark Landler (NYT) JAPAN: BOW TO SHRINE'S WAR LEGACY The foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, said she would urge Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to cancel plans to visit the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo next month where criminals from World War II are enshrined. Ms. Tanaka told reporters in Hanoi where she was attending a meeting of foreign ministers: "I don't want him to visit there. This is my consistent view." Mr. Koizumi's plans to visit the shrine have drawn heavy criticism from China and Korea, which suffered atrocities by Japan during the war.    Howard W. French (NYT) SOUTH KOREA: PROTESTS OVER BOMBING RANGE Villagers protested against an American bombing range on two fronts. In Seoul, 30 people from Maehyang-ri, by the Yellow Sea southwest of the capital, protested at the offices of Lockheed Martin, which makes the F-16 planes used by American and Korean air forces and operates the bombing range in their village. At the range, villagers tried to break through rows of policemen, demanding that the range be closed.    Don Kirk (NYT) NORTH KOREA: LEADER ON THE ROAD Kim Jong Il roared through Russia on the Trans-Siberian Railroad with no time off to look at the city where historians say he was born. His train paused just 20 minutes in Khabarovsk, then resumed his official journey to Moscow. His official biographies insist that Mr. Kim, 59, was born in a hut on Mount Paektu, the sacred mountain on the North Korea- China border.    Don Kirk (NYT) INDIA: `BANDIT QUEEN' IS CREMATED With a manhunt on to find her killers, Phoolan Devi, India's "bandit queen" was cremated on the banks of the Ganges in Uttar Pradesh, her home state. A mourner was killed as throngs grieved. Ms. Devi, one of India's best-known women, had been a robber, murderer and member of Parliament.    Barry Bearak (NYT) PAKISTAN: DEATH SENTENCE UPHELD The Lahore High Court has rejected the appeal of Ayub Masih, who was condemned to death in 1998 for violating blasphemy laws. He is accused of making derogatory remarks about the Prophet Muhammad. When he was originally sentenced, a Roman Catholic bishop, John Joseph, apparently killed himself in protest. Mr. Masih can now appeal to the supreme court.    Barry Bearak (NYT) EUROPE

title: Watch Out, Power Elite, for Those Web-Savvy Amateurs
description: NEXT

title: A Senator's Own Brand Of Seven-League Boots
description: His daughter Jessica tells him not to get hit by any cars. His wife, Iris Weinshall, perhaps out of love and perhaps because she is the New York City Commissioner of Transportation, orders him to put on his safety helmet.

title: House, in Rebuke to President, Bars Easing of Arsenic Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 -- In a new setback for the White House on environmental policy, 19 House Republicans joined with 198 Democrats today to bar the Bush administration from easing rules on arsenic in drinking water beyond those set under President Bill Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption yesterday about the Indian woman known as the Bandit Queen, who was killed outside her home in New Delhi, misspelled her surname. She was Phoolan Devi, not Levi.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Trade Group Membership
description: Moldova officially became the newest member of the World Trade Organization, bringing to 142 the number of countries in the international trade arbiter. The former Soviet republic, which borders Romania and the Ukraine, first applied to join the trade body's predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1993. Among the 30 other countries waiting to join the Geneva-based W.T.O., is Russia, which is Moldova's largest trading partner. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: A Locker-Room Theft, and a Telephone Swindle
description: On a busy Tuesday night in mid-July, Marcia Harrison, a 63-year-old sales executive and distance runner, and six other women returned to the locker room of an Upper East Side sports club to find their padlocks removed, and their lockers empty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, NORMAN
description: GOLDBERG-Norman. Died at home in West Windsor, N.J. on Tuesday July 10, 2001, after a lengthy battle with cancer. He was 74 years old. Norman was a successful business executive, working 25 years at Amerada Hess Corporation. Upon retirement, he was coowner and creator of Photo Plus, a retail film processing business in Plainsboro. He is survived by sons Mark and Larry, as well as many family members and devoted friends.

title: Where You Can Stumble on an Artwork
description: The sites and outdoor sculptures in the art review:

title: Chief Accountant of S.E.C. To Leave Post Next Month
description: Lynn Turner, who played a leading role as the Securities and Exchange Commission enacted rules on auditor independence and campaigned against the management of earnings, said yesterday that he was stepping down as the commission's chief accountant.

title: From Taipei, Snapshots Full of Atmosphere Show an Accidental Family
description: The 1990's may well be remembered as a heroic age of Taiwanese art cinema, a period of creative ferment akin to the French New Wave of the late 50's and early 60's. Like Franois Truffaut, Jean-Luc Godard, and Claude Chabrol, a handful of directors -- among them Edward Yang, Hou Hsiao-hsien, and Tsai Ming-liang -- have been making films that simultaneously extend the formal possibilities of the medium and reveal the half-hidden facets and barely audible rhythms of contemporary life.

title: From Oslo to Intifada: A Mideast Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: Wandering Toward Abstraction
description: Aaron Siskind, who produced with the camera what Franz Kline did with the paintbrush, has been so closely identified with Abstract Expressionism that it sometimes seems as if he did nothing else.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Profit At Drug Maker
description: The British-Swedish drug company AstraZeneca said it earned $706 million in the second quarter, topping expectations, as revenue grew 3.2 percent. The company is planning a series of blockbuster drugs as its best-selling Prilosec ulcer treatment faces competition from generic rivals, possibly this year. AstraZeneca said in April that investment in new drugs including Nexium for ulcers, introduced earlier this year, and the anti-cholesterol drug Crestor, to be introduced in 2002, would reduce second-quarter profit.

title: Judge Refuses Some Payments Hanover Seeks From Giuliani
description: The judge in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's divorce case yesterday denied the request of his estranged wife, Donna Hanover, that he provide her with $3,000 a month in support for herself and pay for her personal press secretary. The judge ordered the mayor to pay Ms. Hanover $1,800 a month in temporary child support -- far less than the $3,200 she had requested.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Panel Assails Board Control Of Building
description: A state commission investigating possible mismanagement of New York City schools recommended yesterday that school construction be taken out of the hands of the Board of Education and assigned to ''construction professionals'' who answer directly to the mayor.

title: Women Hoping 'Battle' Will Gain More Fans for Their Game
description: If the major public service provided by the second ''Battle at Bighorn'' on Monday night is prime-time exposure on ABC-TV for great female golfers, then that's fine.

title: Guys, How Does Your Garden Grow?
description: Written and directed by a Brooklyn native, Joel Hershman, ''Greenfingers'' is an all-too-prime example of the globalization of film culture. The film strives to be an adorable Anglo-Irish comedy in the tradition of ''The Full Monty,'' ''Waking Ned Devine'' and ''Billy Elliot,'' and more or less succeeds on those unambitious terms -- which may be what's most disturbing about it. The film is as synthetic as a rubber rose, but it is all but indistinguishable from the organically grown, bred-in-Britain article.

title: Camping Outside the Wal-Mart: The Price Is Right
description: As the sun set behind this cowboy town in northwest Wyoming on Wednesday, a stream of motor homes pulled into the parking lot for the night, many of them on their way to or from Yellowstone National Park, about 50 miles to the west.

title: Russia May Reduce U.S. Scholar's Term
description: John E. Tobin, 24, of Ridgefield, Conn., the Fulbright scholar sentenced in April to serve 37 months on marijuana charges, may find his term reduced for good behavior and could soon be released from a prison camp south of here, a regional spokesman for the Justice Ministry said today.

title: Chasing a Pot of Gold On the Karaoke Circuit
description: ''Jackpot'' is the elusive pot of gold that Sunny Holiday (Jon Gries) is searching for. He's barely a step above the down and out, working the karaoke circuit. He views it as a way to leapfrog into singing his own songs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Panel Tones Down Report On Auto Fuel Economy

title: Accounts
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, Chicago, expanded its relationship with Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group, by naming the agency to handle the sausage account of Jimmy Dean Foods, which had been handled by Berry Brown Advertising, Dallas, now closed. Spending was estimated at $10 million to $20 million. Burnett also creates ads for Sara Lee's Ball Park Franks. A sibling, Starcom, Chicago, the media agency of record for Sara Lee, will handle media for Jimmy Dean.

title: Residential Real Estate; Prices Up in Manhattan, But Fewer Co-ops Sell
description: The economy may be on a bumpy trail these days, but the Manhattan residential real estate market appears to be on solid footing, even as it sends out some mixed signals.

title: Conspiracy Indictment Over Construction Bids
description: A big American construction company and an affiliate were indicted yesterday on charges of participating in a vast criminal conspiracy to cheat the government out of tens of millions of dollars for Egyptian water projects undertaken as part of the Camp David peace accords.

title: Keeping Cool: It's in the Wrist
description: The fan has been a hot item throughout history. This year, street vendors along Fifth Avenue are selling a variety of styles, including the round peacock-feather fan which the Greeks were using in 3000 B.C.

title: On The Street
description: The fan has been a hot item throughout history. This year, street vendors along Fifth Avenue are selling a variety of styles, including the round peacock-feather fan  which the Greeks were using in 3000 B.C.

title: Through the Looking Glass
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Jack Ubaldi, 90, a Chef, Butcher, Author and Teacher
description: Jack Ubaldi, a restaurateur and butcher who won renown late in life as a cooking teacher and co-author of a book about meat, died on July 14 at his home in Queens. He was 90.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Drought Puts Thousands In Peril
description: North Koreans face increasing starvation and disease as a result of another record drought, according to two U.N. agencies. The Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Food Program, relying on a recent joint mission to the North, say immediate food aid is needed to rescue thousands of North Koreans. Approximately two million North Koreans are believed to have died of starvation or disease as a result of a series of droughts over the past five or six years. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Badillo Says He'll Safeguard Progress of the Giuliani Era
description: Herman Badillo, a Republican mayoral candidate, said yesterday that he would govern New York almost exactly the way Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had to protect the ''dramatic improvements that have taken place'' in the last eight years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Financier's Extradition Refused
description: Pin Chakkaphak, former president of the failed Thai investment bank Finance One, avoided extradition from Britain after the London High Court rejected fraud charges brought by the Thai government. The London High Court overruled a lower court ruling, saying there was insufficient evidence to commit Mr. Pin on any of the charges against him. The financier fled Thailand after the 1997 collapse of the nation's biggest nonbank lender, an event that produced a crisis of confidence in Thailand, as economies across Asia tumbled into the region's worst recession in decades.

title: A Free Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; The Vision Thing
description: In 1969 President Nixon renounced the development or use of biological weapons. It was an act of enlightened self-interest. He understood that the wealth and power of the United States could not protect us from weapons that are cheap to make and terrifyingly deadly, so safety lay in persuading the world to eschew them. He then led the way to a 1972 treaty banning the development, production or possession of biological weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNECK, SALLY BLOCH
description: SCHNECK-Sally Bloch. On July 26th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Ray Bloch and the late William Schneck. Loving mother of the late Nancy Bloch. Devoted daughter of the late Dorothy and the late Dr. Louis Shank. Distinguished graduate of Syracuse University and longtime educator in NYC schools. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, July 29th, 7-9 PM. Service on Monday, July 30th, at 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ROSE
description: COHEN-Rose. My beloved Grandma. Your love and kindness are an eternal blessing to me. Freya

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: REAL GAINS. Brazil's real strengthened after the central bank intervened again to sell dollars to help prop it up. In New York, the currency settled at 2.5 reais to the dollar from 2.4835 reais on Thursday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Invites India
description: Following a gesture made at the recent Agra summit, the military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has sent a formal invitation to India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, to visit Pakistan. Mr. Vajpayee gave his informal acceptance when the idea was first presented. No dates have been announced, but Indian officials have said it is unlikely that such a trip could be made this year. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWIGHT, GEORGIE POTTS
description: DWIGHT-Georgie Potts. On July 26, 2001 peacefully at home in New York City in her 96th year. Survived by her son George; her daughter Shelley (Emery); ten grandchildren: Lucinda Dwight, George Dwight II, Margaret Dwight (Perkins), O.T. Bradley Dwight, Susannah Dwight Prout; Jonathan Dwight, Jay Dwight, Leila Dwight, children of her deceased son Jerome; Andrew Emery and Nicolas Emery; and nine great - grandchildren. Memorial service on Thursday, August 2, 11 AM. All Saints Church, 230 E. 60th St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Timothy's Alumnae Assoc. of NY c/o St. Timothy's School, Stevenson, MD 21153.

title: Eyes of Chicago Turn to Plan for a New Landmark
description: This is the Windy City. Transplant home of the Mississippi blues. Land of the deep-dish pizza. Birthplace of the skyscraper. City of the broad shoulders, and the stunning skyline.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bush Opposes Plan by Albany To Subsidize Birth Control
description: The Bush administration has refused to approve a New York proposal to provide subsidized contraceptive services to hundreds of thousands of low-income New Yorkers, placing Gov. George E. Pataki in a political quandary.

title: Trachsel, Piazza and Ordez Give Mets a Lift
description: The Mets played a terrific game last night. They got outstanding pitching from a renewed Steve Trachsel, two home runs from Mike Piazza and a splendid night of hitting and fielding from Rey Ordez.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEISNER, RANDALL
description: HEISNER-Randall. On July 26, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Selma Heisner. Loving father of Carol Lee and Linda Heisner. Passed away peacefully at the age of 93 with his family at his bedside. Services Sinai Chapel, Sunday, July 29, 12:30 PM, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows.

title: After a Court Ruling, Clouds at the Beaches
description: It seemed almost impossible to be in a bad mood on this perfectly sunny summer afternoon, especially sitting on the beach, feet in the sand, with the tide gently rolling in. But Pat Gasparino was angry, really angry, over the State Supreme Court decision on Thursday that struck down Greenwich's residents-only beach policy.

title: Two Senators Stall Final Vote On Mexican-Truck Standards
description: The Senate was tied up in procedural knots today by a pair of Republican lawmakers who used time-honored parliamentary techniques to delay a final vote on a bill that would impose strict -- and, they say, unfair -- safety standards on Mexican trucks seeking access to American roads.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS TO CUT GENERIC DRUG BUSINESS
description: The American Home Products Corporation will exit most of its generic pill and capsule business, cutting 240 jobs, and is considering selling its line of generics delivered by injection. American Home is eliminating 225 jobs at Pearl River, N.Y., and another 15 jobs at unspecified sites. The part of the ESI Lederle generic business to be phased out over the next few months represents less than half of 1 percent of the company's revenue, said a spokesman, Lowell Weiner. The company, which this week reported that second-quarter profit rose 16 percent, said it was scaling back on generics to concentrate on faster-growing and more profitable brand-name drugs, including the Protonix heartburn treatment and Prevnar pneumococcal vaccine.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Repatriating Minority Refugees
description: The government said it was preparing to send back to Vietnam more than 300 refugees who fled across the border from the Central Highlands during a crackdown that followed protests earlier this year. The announcement came despite Vietnam's refusal to allow the United Nations refugee agency access to the region. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Up to and Including Jelly Roll Morton
description: The New Orleans Rhythm Kings, a group of white players of the early 1920's who came from New Orleans but made their name in Chicago, are probably more important when considered in closely annotated context than they are on an uninformed hearing. But a 92nd Street Y concert on Tuesday night, part of the Jazz in July series, gave you a choice of how to look at the band: a charmingly breezy overview if you wanted it that way, or a biographical outline if you cared to pay closer attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, JESSE
description: KAHN-Jesse. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its Beloved Founder, Member and Honorary Vice President. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, CLARENCE G., M.D.
description: ROBINSON-Clarence G., M.D. age eighty, of Brooklyn, and Sag Harbor, on July 26, 2001. Beloved husband of Thelma (nee Lennard). Lovng father of Mary, Michael, and David, of NJ. Also survived by four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Interment St. Andrews Cemetery, Sag Harbor, NY. Memorial donations to Sloan-Kettering Memorial Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York City, would be appreciated.

title: Under a Shroud Of Kitsch May Lie A Master's Art
description: Tommaso Strinati clambers to the top of the rickety scaffold and laughs. ''It's a good thing that all this Baroque work is so unimpressive,'' he says, pointing at the clumsy trompe l'oeil painting covering the wall in front of him. ''Otherwise, we might not have been allowed to scrape it off!''

title: A Former Aide To Schundler Is Criticized
description: A former member of Bret D. Schundler's campaign staff in New Jersey has been sharply criticized by New Hampshire's attorney general for orchestrating an anonymous mail and telephone campaign against a candidate and his wife in the state last September.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about outdoor sculpture in New York City misidentified the sponsor of a video by William Kentridge and the type of screen on which it appears in Times Square. The sponsor is Creative Time; the Public Art Fund has also produced temporary outdoor art projects. The screen is a Panasonic Astrovision, not a Sony Jumbotron.

title: Contract Deal For Workers In Uniform
description: The Giuliani administration has agreed to a tentative contract that would give firefighters, sanitation workers and other uniformed city employees a raise of more than 10 percent over two-and-a-half years, a pact that is more generous than one recently negotiated with the city's civilian workers.

title: Awaiting Plant's Botanical Spectacle
description: The comedian George Burns used to joke about turning a century old. The Delany sisters wrote a best-selling memoir about it. And the Queen Mother embraced it with regal aplomb.

title: Sports of The Times; A Deadly Toll Is Haunting Football
description: MORE than 1,000 mourners were expected to file into the Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist on St. John Street in Lafayette, La., this morning to pay final tribute to Eraste Thomas Autin, 18, a local high school football hero who died Wednesday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Berlin Wall's Long Shadow
description: Three pieces of the Berlin Wall at Leipziger Platz were dismantled for transport to the United Nations headquarters in New York where they will be put on display, city officials said. Berlin presented the segments to Secretary General Kofi Annan earlier this month as a remembrance of the cold war, as symbols to be placed in a memorial garden. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Tiger That Bit Girl Is Killed
description: A rare Siberian tiger that attacked a 7-year-old girl at an animal park last Sunday was put to death by court order. State law required that either the tiger be killed so that its brain could be examined for rabies or the girl undergo a series of rabies shots. The girl's parents said she had had negative reactions to vaccines, so a district judge ordered that the tiger, named Como, be killed. Como, a 400-pound tiger, broke out of its enclosure at the park in Racine. The girl suffered two deep bites. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBNER, GERALD J.
description: EBNER-Gerald J. Of Tenafly, New Jersey on July 27th, 2001, former Councilman of the Borough of Tenafly. Business, civic and community leader. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Lawrence, Eugene and Randall. Brother of Alan. Loving grandfather of Elizabeth, Rachel and Casey Jill. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ on Sunday at 11:30AM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, 350 Engle St., Englewood, New Jersey 07631, in his name.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Giants Have Great Expectations for Themselves, Even If Others Don't
description: Saratoga horse racing was near enough to entice Wellington Mara, the co-owner of the Giants, to whisk by a couple of days ago before the Giants opened their training camp here yesterday.

title: New Leader Chosen for Census Bureau
description: President Bush today nominated C. Louis Kincannon, a career statistician with a broad background of demographic research in the United States and Europe, to be the next director of the Census Bureau.

title: E.P.A. Rejects Use of a Gene-Altered Corn in Human Food
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has decided not to let even trace amounts of genetically modified StarLink corn into human food, officials said yesterday.

title: The Mets Make a Move by Trading Cook and Wendell
description: Turk Wendell popped into Manager Bobby Valentine's office at Shea Stadium before last night's game and confronted him in a joking way. ''Are we O.K., me and you?'' Wendell said. Valentine told him how much he appreciated all he had done for him. It amounted to a farewell.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Falls
description: Lloyds TSB said that first-half profit fell a greater-than-expected 12 percent, to 1.29 billion ($1.84 billion), or 23 pence a share, compared with 1.47 billion ($2.1 billion), or 27 pence a share, last year. Lloyds, like other banks, said it was setting aside more funds to cover potential problem loans. The bank, Britain's fourth largest, increased its reserve for bad debt to 323 million ($461 million), compared with a restated 265 million ($379 million) a year ago. Lloyds continues to look for partners in Europe and the United States after British regulators blocked its planned merger with Abbey National earlier this month. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Debate at America's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Progress on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: WATLEY GROUP, ONLINE BROKERAGE FIRM, PLANS PURCHASE
description: The A. B. Watley Group, an online brokerage firm that is in a partnership with E*Trade Group Inc. to develop a trading system for frequent traders, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy On-SiteTrading Inc. Watley, based in New York, said it would pay about $17 million in cash and stock for On-SiteTrading. Watley began licensing its trading platform to other brokerage firms last August. Its partnership with E*Trade was announced in December and is the largest such licensing agreement for the company. The deal with On-SiteTrading is a way for Watley to increase its cash flow to finance the licensing business, said Russell Keene, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc.

title: The Debate at America's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: With the Whitney Set, Weight Falls on One Man
description: It is a heavy burden being a top-level handicap horse. Literally. Albert the Great, considered the best older horse in the nation, will spot his six rivals 9 to 12 pounds in Saturday's Whitney Handicap, a Grade I race worth $750,000.

title: Pornography Traders Use Internet Outlets
description: The file-swapping services that have grown in popularity as Napster has waned can be used to trade pornography as well as music, presenting a new environment in which minors can be exposed to hard-core photographs and even videos, two members of Congress warned.

title: A Relationship Stretching for Miles Across a Table
description: The table isn't really that long, maybe eight feet or so. Yet within the short single act of Harold Pinter's ''Landscape,'' at the Clark Studio Theater through tomorrow, this plain-looking piece of furniture seems to keep stretching, endlessly and isolatingly, rather like the breakfast table famously shared by Citizen Kane and his wife in Orson Welles's movie.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about efforts to end the violence in Macedonia misstated the title of Javier Solana, a senior European official. He is a foreign policy official of the European Union, not of NATO.

title: Religion Journal; 2 Churches Tackle Racial Themes
description: When two Protestant churches held an unusual joint meeting here from July 12 to 17,, a recurring theme was how to counter racial and religious prejudice, now and as a legacy of the United States' past.

title: The Debate at America's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Threat to Archaeology: The Privy Diggers
description: For a weekend of digging in an old potty hole in Lincoln, Neb., Tim Clements was hauled into court this summer. The charges? Criminal trespass, criminal mischief and theft. What was Mr. Clements doing rooting in a privy? Looking for bottles, dishes and, as one privy digger put it, lots of ''real cool stuff.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Business Briefing column yesterday about plans for the Standard Hotel in SoHo misstated the schedule of the contractor, the J. A. Jones Construction Group. Work is scheduled to begin this fall; 2003 is when it is to end, in the first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELHAUT, GLENN D.
description: KESSELHAUT-Glenn D. HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, joins the family of our past President, Martin Kesselhaut, in mourning the loss of Glenn Kesselhaut, a beloved son, who passed away July 25, 2001. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: For Jones, Boycott Is Bigger Threat
description: The light-heavyweight champion Roy Jones Jr. will be doing one of two things when he defends his title Saturday night against Julio Gonzalez, depending on whom you talk to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, JONATHAN DAVID
description: LEVINE-Jonathan David. Died on Thursday, July 26, 2001 at the age of 23. He was born on November 25, 1977 in NYC to Linda Wagner and Charles Levine. At the age of nine, Jonathan moved to Milford, Pennsylvania and resided in Conashaugh Lakes with his mother. After graduating from Delaware Valley High School in 1995, he moved to Brooklyn, NY and began to seriously pursue his dream of becoming a poet and an artist. Since the age of 18, he has had his poems accepted and/or published over 200 times in literary magazines and journals in the United States, England and Canada. Some publications in which his poetry has appeared include: Along The Path, Blind Man's Rainbow, Bound, Coalition, Converge Magazine, Creative Juices, Critique, Dark Corridors, Dark Heart, The Echo, Emotions, Excess Compassion, Feelings, Goddess Of The Bay, Gotta Write Network, The Iconoclast, In the Arts, INK Literary Review, Leapings, Lucid Moon, Maelstrom, New Authors, Journal, Office Number One, Paper Bugs Magazine, Peer Amid, Perimeter, Penny Dreadful, Pillow Dreams, Pink Cadillac, Poetic Hours, Poetry Now, Poet's Paper, The Poet's Page, Portals, The Quarterly, Red Booth Review, Requiem, riverrun, The Sunday Suitor Poetry Review, Touchstone, Transcendent Visions, Typo Magazine, Ugly Duckling, The Ultimate Unknown, Writer's Exchange, and The Yale Review. Jonathan had a ''Special Corner'' written about him showcasing his poetry, art, and fiction in Requiem. He was also the featured new artist in an issue of Leapings and interviewed about his writing in an issue of Gotta Write Network. His poems appeared on the first page in an issue of Peer Amid, Pink Cadillac, Creative Juices, and Writer's Exchange as well as in the book 2000: Here's To Humanity by The People's Press. Besides having his poetry published, Jonathan's black and white artwork was included over 40 times in some of the previously mentioned publications as well as in The Higginsville Reader. He designed the front and back cover of the 2000 edition of riverrun. During the past year, Jonathan began drawing in color and produced several outstanding pieces. Jonathan has also had articles, short stories, and prose pieces published in some of the previously mentioned publications as well as in Penny-A-Liner. Some of his letters to the editor appeared in the Brooklyn Skyline. Peer Amid Literary Magazine is producing a compact disk compilation of spoken-word poetry that will include two of Jonathan's poems. One of Jonathan's short stories was ''highly commended'' with The Bertha And Philip Goodman Short Story Award by Brooklyn College's English Department.

title: The Fine Art of the Book: A Love Story
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Bank To Pay Settlement
description: Bank of America agreed to pay $35.6 million to settle a claim that the company mismanaged state funds while acting as a trustee and paying agent for state and municipal bonds. The state attorney general's office said the bank and its subsidiaries overcharged for its services, then kept unclaimed principal and interest to cover its mismanagement of funds. Half of the settlement will go to the state, with the remainder divided among bond issuers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOYCE W.
description: GREENE-Joyce W. Died at home in NYC, July 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur B., mother of Jonathan M., and mother-in-law of Denise. She was one of the greatest ladies ever; she was respected for her wit and generosity. She was a friend and caretaker of all animals. Joyce was born in England, 1933. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, August 1st, 7-9 PM, with funeral services Thursday, August 2nd, 5:30 PM. Interment in England. Memorial services will be scheduled at a future date. In lieu of flowers, gifts may given in the name of Joyce W. Greene to the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, 410 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016; 212-532-4455.

title: Neck Injury Forces Ruiz Out of Bout in Beijing
description: The heavyweight title bout between John Ruiz and Evander Holyfield scheduled for Aug. 5 in Beijing has been postponed indefinitely because Ruiz has a neck injury, the boxing promoter Don King said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pirelli's Shares Fall
description: Shares in Pirelli S.p.A., Europe's largest cable maker and a leading tire maker, posted their biggest one-day decline in two and a half years after the company reported first-half results and said it expected a slowdown in the third quarter. The company said it had earned 276 million euros ($242 million), up from 181 million euros a year earlier.

title: Lawmakers Rebuff Bush on Patients' Rights
description: Congressional champions of patients' rights sent a blistering response today to President Bush's latest proposal on the issue, but invited the president to enter high-stakes negotiations to achieve a legislative compromise.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about a slump in advertising spending, misidentified a magazine that is being closed. It is Individual Investor, not Institutional Investor.

title: This Tangled Web, Free of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Otto Wittmann -- Ex-Museum Chief, 89
description: Otto Wittmann, former director of the Toledo Museum of Art, died on July 14 in Montecito, Calif. He was 89.

title: Macedonia Village Is Center Of Europe Web in Sex Trade
description: This village, tucked down in the southwestern corner of the country near the border with Albania, is one of the strangest places in this part of the Balkans. It has the high-walled brick homes and rutted lanes typical of villages here, but amid the hay barns there are more than a dozen neon-lit nightclubs and sex bars with names like Madonna and Paradiso. And beneath the strange combination of rural quiet and nighttime glitz, the place has a very sinister reputation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVRIN, TENA P.
description: GAVRIN-Tena P. July 26, 2001. Peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. She is survived by her youngest sister Deborah Almlof of Victor, NY, three sons David, Ira and Robert, eight grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. A memorial service on August 19 Temple Israel, New Rochelle.

title: Shooting of Woman by Trooper During Drug Raid Appears to Be an Accident, Police Say
description: The shooting of a 27-year-old woman by a New York State trooper during a drug raid in Brooklyn on Thursday appears to have been an accident, the state police said yesterday. The woman, Charmene Pickering, who was not a suspect in the raid, was in critical condition on life support yesterday at Kings County Hospital.

title: Badillo Outlines Plans to Resolve Shortcomings With Police and Schools
description: Here are excerpts from an interview with Herman Badillo, a Republican who is making his fourth attempt to become mayor of New York City. The interview was conducted by reporters and editors from The New York Times, and is the second in a planned series of interviews with each of the major candidates.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Securities Traders Barred
description: Three former Credit Suisse First Boston employees, known as the Flaming Ferraris for a cocktail they used to drink, were barred from securities trading, after an inquiry into an attempt to manipulate the Swedish OMX index in December 1998, Britain's securities regulator said. Among those deemed ''not fit and proper'' was James Archer, 27, the son of Lord Jeffrey Archer, who last week was sentenced to four years in prison for perjury and perverting the course of justice. As an arbitrage specialist who made the trades, Mr. Archer was found to have manipulated the closing price of the Swedish OMX index and of making unauthorized trades on the exchange's computerized system. He was fined 50,000 ($71,300), along with Adrian Ezra, 30. David Crisanti, 37, was fined 100,000 ($142,600), the Securities and Futures Authority said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A SNAIL'S PACE IN SPRING QUARTER
description: Economic growth nearly halted in the second quarter, as businesses made severe cuts in investment and consumer spending grew less quickly than it had at the start of the year, the government said today.

title: Leaders Draft 'Last Ditch' Package to Rescue Ulster Accord
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, said today that they had agreed on a take-it-or-leave-it package of proposals to rescue the faltering Northern Ireland peace agreement and that they would present it to the province's warring politicians next week.

title: The F.C.C. Loosens Its Media Rules
description: The trend toward consolidation in the news business continued this week when federal regulators waived longstanding restrictions and gave Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation control over a second major television outlet in New York City, WWOR-TV (Channel 9). Because Mr. Murdoch already owns The New York Post and WNYW-TV (Channel 5), the ruling gives him an unusual degree of power in local markets. The ruling could also have broad implications for the news business as a whole and, at the very least, may encourage other news organizations to explore the acquisition of multiple outlets in the same geographic area. Although the consequences of the ruling cannot be predicted with precision, Congress may now wish to explore new ways of ensuring diversity and competition in an industry of fundamental importance to free expression.

title: Local Moves Against Union, Toward Ferrer Over Vallone
description: In a setback to Peter Vallone's campaign alliance with District Council 37, the city's huge municipal union, the president of the union's largest local announced yesterday that her 28,000 members were moving to buck District Council 37 and back the candidacy of Fernando Ferrer.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Compaq Computer's quarterly financial results misstated its recent accounting of inventory. Compaq took a charge of $493 million to restructure in the last quarter and expects to reduce inventory by $200 million this quarter. It did not write off unused inventory and does not expect to take a charge in the current quarter. The article also misstated the way the company's loss of $279 million was calculated. That figure indeed included restructuring charges.

title: Suffolk County Votes to Mandate A Living Wage
description: Suffolk legislators, overriding an executive veto, voted today to become the first county in the state to pass a living-wage law for workers employed under county contracts or in projects subsidized by the county.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Violence Sets Back Airline
description: Sri Lankan Airlines, which had three of its aircraft destroyed in an attack on the country's main international airport by the Tamil Tiger rebels, reports that thousands of travel reservations to the island have been canceled. Before the attack business had been good for the carrier, said its chief executive officer, Peter Hill, but now the company will wait for the ''dust to settle'' before it even resumes advertising in Europe and the Far East. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Antitrust Challenge Stops United Merger With US Airways
description: United Airlines' $4.3 billion bid to acquire US Airways died yesterday after the Justice Department said it would go to court to block the deal. The government asserted that the proposed takeover would ''reduce competition, raise fares and harm consumers'' on airline routes across the country.

title: Censors, Spies and Scholars
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- July in Beijing is always hot. On July 1, China celebrated the 80th anniversary of the founding of the Communist Party. In the middle of the month, China was awarded the 2008 Olympics, and the jubilant people of Beijing celebrated in the streets.
