My younger brother, Huang Feng  still on probation after being arrested for notifying the outside world of my own arrest in Beijing last year for publishing a literary journal  reminded me earlier this week, long-distance, that Beijingers were still reveling and still oblivious to the true meaning of the Olympic news. The name Gao Zhan meant nothing to my brother.

title: Scientists Retract Their Claim of New Element
description: Scientists at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California yesterday retracted a 1999 claim that they had created a new, superheavy element.

title: BANK OF AMERICA TO PAY $35.6 MILLION TO SETTLE A CLAIM
description: Bank of America agreed to pay $35.6 million to settle a claim by the office of Attorney General Bruce Botelho of Alaska that the company mismanaged its funds while acting as a trustee and paying agent for state and municipal bonds. The bank and its units overcharged for its services then kept unclaimed principal and interest, which should have been returned to the state's treasury, to cover its mismanagement of funds, according to the claim. Half of the settlement will go to the state, with the remainder divided among other bond issuers. Bank of America said the settlement was not an admission that it owed the state or municipalities any money. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: A Financial Push for Peace in Ireland
description: The major deterrent to making the Northern Ireland Good Friday peace agreement effective has been the unwillingness of the Irish Republican Army to decommission its weapons. Is there a way to make decommissioning more palatable to the I.R.A. and more certain for the Unionists who demand the relinquishing of the I.R.A.'s arms as a part of the peace?

title: HOUSE DEMANDING STRICT GUIDELINES ON ARSENIC LEVELS
description: The House of Representatives voted 218 to 189 today to require the Bush administration to keep in place restrictions on the amount of arsenic allowed in drinking water at least as stringent as those set under former President Bill Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, MARGARET CREAL
description: SHAFER-Margaret Creal. The Bard College community deeply mourns the passing of Margaret Creal Shafer, a longtime friend and integral member of the Bard family and the Hudson Valley cultural community. Her vitality, creativity and energy have played an essential role in the life of the college and of the surrounding communities. She will be deeply missed. Our condolences go out to her children, grandchildren, and great grandchild. Services will be held at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, in Barrytown, New York on Saturday, August 4th. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab, II, Chairman

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth Slows
description: Britain's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the second quarter, down from 2.7 percent a month earlier, the Office of National Statistics said. The rate of growth was the slowest in more than two years, the agency said.

title: PRICES ON FIVE HAIR-CARE PRODUCTS ARE REDUCED
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's leading shampoo seller, cut prices by as much as a third on three of its five hair-care lines to regain sales lost to rivals. Procter & Gamble reduced prices 11 percent on Pert shampoos, 16 percent on Vidal Sassoon shampoos, 33 percent on Vidal Sassoon conditioners and 22 percent on Pantene Essentials hair-care products, a spokeswoman, Maria Burquest, said yesterday. Procter is based in Cincinnati.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS. Venezuela's oil minister said he would meet with his Mexican and Saudi counterparts Sunday, sending crude oil prices higher. In New York, crude oil for September delivery rose 29 cents, to $27.02 a barrel.

title: Moss Talks Inch Toward Deal
description: With the clock ticking toward today's reporting date, the Jets and Santana Moss's agent continued late last night to hash out the final details of a deal that both sides hoped to have completed in time for Moss to join the team for its first meeting tonight.

title: O'Neill's Twilight Is Burning Brightly
description: Paul O'Neill aimed his slide at the back corner of third base in the seventh inning at Skydome tonight and when his foot hit the bag just before the tag, O'Neill thumped his hands together, the briefest sign of satisfaction. His expression never changed, his mouth straight like wire.

title: Funny Thing on Rebate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MARION T.
description: STERN-Marion T. Of Wilmette, Illinois (formerly of New Rochelle, NY) of complications arising from Pemphigus, a rare autoimmune disease. Memorial Services will be held at the Hampton Inn, 5201 Old Orchard Road, Skokie, IL (phone 847-583-1111) on Saturday August 11 from 10:30 to 11:30 A.M. Marion spent her teenage years in Hamburg, Germany, and Bolivia, and her college years after having received a scholarship at Antioch College. She obtained a Master's Degree in Psychiatric Social Work from the School of Social Services Administration of the University of Chicago in 1946. Throughout her professional life she was active in providing mental health and community services to the needy, including a career as Psychiatric Social Worker with the Mental Health Board of the City of Chicago. Even 20 years after she retired from her position, former clients continued to call her for professional guidance and counsel, relying on her warm and outgoing nature for support. Marion is survived by her husband of 59 years, Walter Stern; her son, John Peter Stern and family in Tokyo, Japan; her daughter, Nina Anne Lofstrom of Lake City, Florida, and four grandsons. In lieu of flowers, donations to create an enduring memento to Marion's life in Wilmette may be made to the ''Marion T. Stern Memorial Account'', c/o 514 Ridge Road, Wilmette, IL 60091-2449. There will be a Memorial Service from 10:30 to 11:30 A.M. on August 11, 2001 at the Hampton Inn & Suites Hotel, 5201 Old Orchard Road, Skokie, IL 60077 (phone 847-583-1111), across the street from the Searle Pharmaceutical Building.

title: Insurer Has 11% Operating Income Rise
description: American General, the life insurer being acquired by the American International Group, said today that second-quarter operating income rose 11 percent on gains from the sales of fixed annuities and life insurance.

title: Church & Dwight Profit Up 8.9%
description: The Church & Dwight Company, maker of Arm & Hammer products, said second-quarter profit rose 8.9 percent as sales of its consumer products like laundry detergent and fabric softener surged.

title: Brazil Weighs Replacing Police Strikers With Troops
description: Facing a growing movement of strikes and other protests by police forces across the country, the Brazilian government is threatening to send in the army to replace the police.

title: The City's Beat, With an Iambic Heat
description: Anyone who habitually enfolds New York in a loving embrace -- not just its Gold Coast and its midwinter galas but its pockets of poverty and its packed and pounding subways in midsummer rush hours -- is likely to warm to the exuberant, insightful entertainment titled ''Slanguage.''

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Budget Diversion Proposed
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove proposed diverting nearly three-quarters of the $210 million in annual tobacco payments made to a health trust fund to the state budget. Mr. Musgrove, a Democrat, said the $150 million diversion could draw as much as $450 million in matching federal funds to address pressing health needs and give raises to university professors and state employees.

title: Indian Police Arrest Man Loquaciously Claiming He Killed the 'Bandit Queen'
description: A man claiming to have murdered Phoolan Devi, India's legendary ''bandit queen,'' was arrested today as he boasted of the crime at an impromptu news conference in the lovely hill town of Dehra Dun.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON GIVES DETAILS OF SUIT PAYMENTS
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would award consumers cash and credits to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused it of misleading marketing of Acuvue contact lenses. The suit, filed in 1996, claimed that the eye products unit, Vistakon, misleadingly said a less-expensive one-day Acuvue lens should not be worn as long as a standard Acuvue lens, when in fact both lenses can be used for the same length of time. About six million people bought the lenses in the 1990's, court filings said. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., denied the accusations, and the settlement does not imply wrongdoing, the company said.

title: Concessions To Moderates May Threaten Energy Plan
description: In a move that could threaten crucial parts of President Bush's energy plan, House Republican leaders are planning to allow moderates to offer amendments on environmentally touchy issues regarding oil drilling in Alaska and improving fuel efficiency standards in vehicles.

title: Controversy Fails to Show Up In Charter Revision Proposals
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission was presented yesterday with perhaps the least controversial set of recommendations for charter revision since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office, with no mention of the move for nonpartisan elections proposed earlier by the mayor.

title: Bogot Journal; Soccer Provides a Tonic For Nation's Glum Mood
description: Many said the Copa Amrica the premier soccer event in the Americas, a tournament that leads storekeepers to shutter their shops and lures tens of millions of fans to their television sets -- would be a bust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MILTON, M.D.
description: SINGER-Milton, M.D. The Division of Gastroenterology of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the loss of our dear friend and respected colleague, Dr. Milton Singer. From his private practice in New Jersey, Dr. Singer travelled to Mount Sinai every week for decades to give the benefit of his teaching and experience to our fellows, residents and students. We shall all miss his gentle warmth, quiet grace, sound judgement, and unfailing wisdom. Steven H. Itzkowitz, M.D., Director David B. Sachar, M.D., Director Emeritus The Dr. Henry D. Janowitz Division of Gastroenterology

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Extradition Of Nazi
description: Authorities began extradition proceedings against Anton Gecas, 85, a resident of Edinburgh, who is wanted in Lithuania to stand trial on charges of genocide. The Nazi-hunting Simon Wiesenthal Center says Mr. Gecas, formerly Antanas Gecevicius, was an officer in the police battalion responsible for the deaths of thousands of Jews in Lithuania and Byelorussia between 1941 and 1943. Mr. Gecas is in an Edinburgh hospital and will be arrested when his health permits, a government spokesman said. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Dave Freeman, a Champion In Badminton, Is Dead at 80
description: Dr. Dave Freeman, the only American man to win a world singles championship in badminton and the only one to be ranked No. 1 in the world, died June 28 at San Diego Hospice. Freeman, who lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., was 80 and had Merkle cell carcinoma, his family said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Tribunal May Free Bosnian Serb
description: The only woman held by the United Nations war crimes tribunal, Biljana Plavsic, may be released until her trial begins early next year. The prosecutor's office said it would not oppose her release as long as she stayed in the Netherlands, but judges who must make the decision have not yet taken a stand. Mrs. Plavsic, 71, a former biology professor and hardline Bosnian Serb nationalist, was a wartime deputy to the fugitive leader Radovan Karadzic. She went to the tribunal voluntarily once she learned she was wanted there, but applied for provisional release early this month. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: File-Swapping Is New Route For Internet Pornography
description: The file-swapping services that have grown in popularity as Napster has waned can be used to trade pornography as well as music, presenting a new environment in which minors can be exposed to hard-core photographs and even videos, two members of Congress warned yesterday.

title: The Debate at America's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Kills a Black Suspect In a Gunfight in Cincinnati
description: Three months after major street conflicts between the police and protesting blacks in Cincinnati, a white patrolman killed a black suspect there yesterday in an early morning gun battle.

title: Purchase of Contractor Gives KeySpan Indigestion
description: While other utilities and power companies were announcing banner results, KeySpan, the Brooklyn-based seller of gas and electricity, said this week that it had an $8 million loss in the second quarter.

title: Atlantic City Car Tunnel Opens Briefly, for Pedestrians
description: It has been called more bad names than a cheapskate slot machine, but the Atlantic City tunnel to the growing north end casino district has survived its critics, and opened -- briefly -- today to a shower of confetti and high hopes.

title: Macedonia Talks Are Moved Away From Heated Emotions
description: Western diplomats shuttled among the main political leaders in Macedonia today, laying the groundwork for direct talks over the weekend in a resort town far from the heated emotions that have prodded the country ever closer to outright war.

title: The Debate at America's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: The Debate at America's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Miner's Profit Falls
description: Barrick Gold, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a drop in second-quarter net profit, to $66 million, or 17 cents a share, from $72 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier, mostly because of higher energy costs in the western United States and a lower gold price. The chief executive, Randall Oliphant, above, said higher costs at the El Indio mine in Chile and Goldstrike in Nevada, coupled with lower interest income, would probably result in earnings for the year ''at the lower end'' of earlier estimates of 70 to 75 cents a share. Cash costs for the second quarter rose to $162 an ounce from $144. The average realized price dropped to $340 an ounce from $360, still well above prevailing market prices, thanks to an active hedging policy. Second-quarter output rose to 958,400 ounces from 899,000 ounces.

title: The Man in the White Hat Takes On Other White Hats
description: A TALL bundle of energy with professorial round-rimmed glasses on his long nose, Michael G. Cherkasky is no one's image of a tough guy, but this former New York prosecutor has learned a thing or two in his career about lawyerly street fighting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUZIK, PEARL (ROBBINS)
description: GUZIK-Pearl (Robbins). On July 26th at age 94 in Newton, MA., formerly of NYC and Pompano Beach, FL. Music teacher, opera lover and world traveler. Widow of the late Leo Guzik, attorney and prominent Zionist. Mother of Michael Guzik of Princeton, NJ and Tamara Bliss of Newton, MA. Grandmother of Peter Guzik and Miriam & Stephen Bliss. Graveside service at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY on Sunday, July 29th, at 11 AM. Remembrances may be made to the Pearl R. Guzik Opera Education Fund at the Boston Academy of Music, Charlestown Navy Yard, Charlestown, MA 02129. For information, Stanetsky Chapels 800-842-4280.

title: NESTL WINS APPROVAL FOR PURCHASE OF RALSTON PURINA
description: Nestl, the world's biggest food maker, received European antitrust approval for its $11.9 billion purchase of the Ralston Purina Company after agreeing to give up dog and cat-food brands in three countries. The purchase, which has yet to be approved by United States authorities, would make Nestl the leader of the $25 billion pet-food industry. Nestl, based in Vevey, Switzerland, agreed to sell or license products in Spain, Italy and Greece to allay European Union concerns. Ralston is based in St.Louis.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption yesterday with an article about efforts to end the violence in Macedonia misstated the title of Javier Solana, a senior European official. He is a foreign policy official of the European Union, not of NATO.

title: When a Demystified Bible Became Anathema to Orthodoxy
description: There is a moment in Victor Hugo's famous novel about the Parisian hunchback when the archdeacon of Notre Dame speaks to the King of France. He gestures from a printed book open on his desk toward the arches of the great cathedral. ''Alas,'' he says, ''this will kill that. The book will kill the building.'' The 15th-century priest was predicting that the printing press would shake the foundations of his church, that portable texts and popularized messages would undermine the authority of orthodox religion, stimulating dissent and encouraging independence. Hugo's novel is partly an account of the archdeacon's perverse attempts to retain his fading powers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Turmoil In Nagaland
description: After a week of violent protests in the state of Manipur, the government reversed an earlier decision and will restrict its cease-fire with the outlawed National Socialist Council of Nagalim to the state of Nagaland. The cease-fire had been expanded to include areas outside Nagaland, and citizens in neighboring states feared that had been a first step toward ethnic Nagas claiming more territory. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL INC., Bethesda, Md., the largest U.S. hotel chain, sold its Waikiki Beach Marriott Resort for about $130 million in cash to a group led by CNL Hospitality Corp., a real estate developer. Marriott said it would hold a minority stake in the resort and continue to operate it under a long-term agreement.

title: Armstrong Punctuates Tour With Dash
description: In another overwhelming performance, Lance Armstrong won his fourth stage in the 88th Tour de France today and fulfilled his desire to show that he is worthy of overall victory when the three-week race ends Sunday in Paris.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Vineyard Preservation Deal
description: A $64-million conservation deal on Martha's Vineyard will preserve land that had been scheduled for a 33-house subdivision. The deal, announced by the Nature Conservancy, allows for the construction of six houses, but will otherwise protect the 215-acre former farm, known as Herring Creek. The Nature Conservancy calls the agreement the biggest privately financed land purchase it has ever arranged. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: A Kay Graham Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: London Visitor Travel Card
description: Sometimes, every dollar counts. DER Travel Services, a Rosemont, Ill., company that specializes in travel to Britain, has cut rates on its London Visitor Travel Card. The card is good for unlimited travel on London-area transport and can be bought in increments of three, four and seven days. A Central Zone pass (covering transit zones 1 and 2) is good for the Underground, most London buses, Docklands Light Railway and most National Railways trains in London, and costs $20 for three days (formerly $21), $25 for four days (down from $27) and $30 for a week (from $33). An all-zones pass is $29 for three days, $39 for four days and $58 for a week. Information: (800) 549-3737 or www.dertravel.com .

title: Condit Has Fourth Meeting With the Police
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Representative Gary A. Condit met with the F.B.I. and Washington police officials on Thursday night for a fourth time in connection with the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy, the police and Mr. Condit's lawyer said.

title: Editors' Note
description: COMING ON SUNDAY/GOOD DRUG, BAD DRUG

title: Boy Who Killed a Teacher Gets 28 Years and No Parole
description: A 14-year-old boy who shot his favorite teacher to death on the last day of class a year ago was sentenced today to 28 years in prison without parole, punishment that his family said was just but that the victim's relatives called disappointingly lenient.

title: For Albany, the One Constant Is a Late Budget
description: You would think no one had ever enacted a state budget before.

title: Wei-Sender Team Survives in Toronto
description: After a remarkable turnabout in the final quarter of its semifinal match here Thursday, the team led by Kathie Wei-Sender of Nashville survived into the final of the Women's Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Niagara Mohawk Plans Deal to Curb Prices
description: Niagara Mohawk Holdings, which is selling its power plants to focus on distributing electricity, announced a plan yesterday that is meant to prevent widespread spikes in consumer bills upstate.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS TO BUY REST OF ALLEGRO SYSTEMS
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the largest maker of computer-networking equipment, will acquire the 60 percent of Allegro Systems Inc. it does not own for $109 million in stock to add network-security products. Cisco is issuing shares valued at $181 million for all of the stock of the closely held Allegro, including Cisco's own stake. Cisco bought about 40 percent of Allegro in December for an undisclosed price, said a Cisco spokeswoman, Robyn Jenkins. Allegro has developed hardware and software that Cisco will use to increase the speeds of its own products that let people connect securely over the Internet to companies' internal networks, said Ammar Hanafi, vice president for business development. Allegro is based in Milpitas, Calif. Cisco is based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Punishing Zimbabwe
description: To the Editor:

title: As Much of the Club Scene as a Black Box Can Hold
description: Affecting. Amusing. Annoying. Those, in roughly equal parts, are the words you'll need to describe ''Go-Go Rel,'' a compact two-man show that is drawing crowds at Dixon Place and has been extended through Aug. 11.

title: Looking Back at Camp David
description: In bitter, protracted conflicts like the one between Israel and the Palestinians, each side maintains its own chronicle of events, emphasizing certain details and omitting others. So it has been with the divergent accounts of the collapse of last summer's Camp David peace talks and the months of violence that followed. But those narratives are now being challenged and re-examined. From this exercise can come a better, more realistic understanding of how Israel and the Palestinians can renew their search for a lasting peace.

title: INSIDE
description: Teacher's Killer Sentenced

title: Thailand's Leader Wants to Switch Time Zones
description: With his country's economy seeming to wind down by the day, Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister of Thailand, and his government are considering whether they might not hasten a return to better days by setting the country's clocks ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANA, G. MORLEY JR.
description: MORGANA-G. Morley Jr., on July 11, 2001. Most beloved friend, son, brother, cousin and uncle, whose lives his spirit illuminated. He will be profoundly missed. No immediate plans for a memorial. ''Details to follow...''

title: Credit Cards on Campus
description: Credit card marketers will be back on college campuses come fall semester. They will stand near bookstores, student unions and stadiums, urging students to fill out credit applications and handing out free T-shirts and plastic sunglasses in return. Credit card issuers are eager to reach the college market and universities are eager to offer up their student populations. But their marketing zeal should obligate them to be equally aggressive in educating the students on credit and personal finance.

title: White House Sets Up Clean Air Act Battle
description: The Bush administration wants Congress to combine several of the most contentious air pollution control programs into a more flexible and less intrusive system that is strongly favored by leading electric utilities. In trying to overhaul the Clean Air Act to reduce paperwork for utilities, the White House faces a protracted and politically charged battle in Congress.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on Thursday about the failure of birth control pills to prevent ovarian cancer in women with certain genetic mutations misattributed a statement about the pills. It was Dr. Sholom Wacholder of the Chaim Sheba Medical Center in Israel -- not Dr. Baruch Modan -- who said, ''We think it's premature to prescribe them for these women, and they need to discuss their options with the health care provider.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Powell Says U.S. Wants to Resume Talks With North Korea
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that United States officials were prepared to go anywhere at any time of North Korea's choosing to resume talks on a variety of issues, including ending North Korea's missile program and the heavy deployment of its conventional forces on the border with South Korea.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Desert Stations To Help Migrants
description: The Border Patrol is moving ahead with plans to place six emergency stations in the desert so migrants who have crossed the border can summon help. When a red button is pushed on the stations, a strobe light will flash on top of a 30-foot pole and a radio will signal the Border Patrol office in Yuma. The stations will carry instructions in English and Spanish. The measure is one of several taken after the death of 14 illegal immigrants in the Arizona desert in May. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline on Thursday about the Italian writer Indro Montanelli referred incorrectly to his political views in some copies. Although he was a firm supporter of Fascism in the 1930's, he was not known as a Fascist journalist during his decades of activity after World War II.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 12 about aging motorcyclists referred imprecisely to the movie ''The Wild One.'' Although the movie stimulated interest in Harley-Davidson motorcycles, its star, Marlon Brando, rode a Triumph, not a Harley.

title: Another Stem Cell Debate; Ethics Aside, a Good Business Model Remains Elusive
description: A pioneering biotechnology company claims its cells can cure diabetes and Parkinson's disease. But opponents of abortion object and President Bush considers extending a ban on federally financed research on the cells.

title: Pataki Backs Clinton Plan For Hudson River Cleanup
description: As the wait continued for a decision by the Environmental Protection Agency on dredging PCB's from the upper Hudson River, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday clarified his stance, saying that he supported a cleanup along the lines that the Clinton administration proposed last year and seemingly distancing himself from any scaled-down plan.

title: A Gadfly, With or Without Hair
description: RANGOON  His appetite for sex, drugs and revolution may pale in comparison with rockers elsewhere, but in Burma, Zaw Win Htut stands out as a rebel who must fight to keep the government out of his hair.

title: Suburbia, With Subtitles; Feeding a Hunger for Art Films Where Megaplexes Rule
description: When the Jacob Burns Film Center opened here last month, its founders optimistically hoped to sell 450 memberships within the first year. Instead, they have sold 2,800 in the first eight weeks, and the art cinema, in the geographic heart of Westchester County, has quickly become a cultural phenomenon, drawing moviegoers from as far as Rockland County, across the Hudson River, and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAHLINGER, GERALDINE E. (NEE MCCULLOUGH)
description: DAHLINGER-Geraldine E. (nee McCullough). Of St. Simons Island, Georgia, died peacefully on Wednesday, July 18, in Brunswick, GA, after a long illness. She was the widow of the late Herbert A. Dahlinger, who retired in 1988 from Sterling Bank & Trust Co. of New York. Survivors include a daughter, Susan E. Dahlinger of NYC, and a son, Rev. James H. Dahlinger, S.J. of Syracuse, NY.

title: Plan to Curb Rent and Taxes Approved at Waterside Plaza
description: Residents of the Waterside Plaza housing complex have approved an agreement that would give their landlord a multimillion-dollar tax break while preventing the rents on their apartments from being raised to market levels, tenant leaders said yesterday. The vote was 525 to 61.

title: Law Firm Was Nuclear Industry Lobbyist While Advising Government on Dump Site
description: The law firm hired to advise the Energy Department on how to open a nuclear-waste dump at Yucca Mountain, near Las Vegas, was simultaneously lobbying Congress and the administration on behalf of the nuclear power industry about crucial decisions involving the project.

title: Whitman Begins to Consider Streamlining Pollution Checks
description: The Bush administration wants Congress to collapse several of the most contentious air pollution control programs into a more flexible and less intrusive system strongly favored by leading electric utilities.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Industrial Decline
description: Battered by plummeting prices for semiconductors, overall South Korean industrial output fell 2.7 percent in June from June 2000. That was the first year-on-year drop since October 1998, when the country was still reeling from the 1997-1998 economic crisis. The National Statistics Office said industrial output, 1.9 percent less in June than in May, fell for the third consecutive month. At the same time, the current accounts surplus for June was $1.04 billion, less than half the $2.16 billion surplus in May. Semiconductor production, accounting for 23 percent of output and 15.7 percent of exports, fell 16.1 percent in June from May. The National Statistics Office warned that the slump might last for most of the year amid global economic problems and shriveling export markets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Medication Ordered In Murder Case
description: Russell E. Weston Jr., who was accused of killing two Capitol Police officers in July 1998, can be forced to take medication to make him mentally competent for trial on murder charges, a federal appeals court panel has ruled. Mr. Weston, 44, has a history of paranoid schizophrenia, and for nearly three years he has refused to take medication. His lawyers have said that requiring him to take medication would violate his right to due process and to a fair trial. The three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia disagreed.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Dinosaur Tracks Destroyed
description: A 15-year-old Boy Scout from West Valley City could face charges under the state's Cultural Sites Protection Act for ripping out a rare set of 200 million-year-old dinosaur tracks near Vernal and tossing them into a reservoir. Utah law makes it a third-degree felony for anyone to damage antiquities. Two other Scouts who helped throw rock slabs into the water could be charged with criminal mischief, a misdemeanor. The boys said they did not know that the slabs they threw contained dinosaur prints. The names of the boys were not released.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Growth Slows To 0.7% Rate in Quarter

title: Devil Rays and Marlins? Fans Just Won't Bite
description: In a way, all the empty space surrounding Michael Lawson at the baseball stadium only made the day a little finer. There was no beer being spilled, no blowhard bellowing into his ear. There was just the game, the green field fanning out below him, and row after row of orange, vacant seats.

title: Eyewitness to a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Henson Isn't Ready For Third Base Yet
description: The best-case scenario was for Drew Henson to play a full season at Class AAA Columbus, flourish and be prepared to replace Scott Brosius at third base next season.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu's Loss Grows
description: The electronics manufacturer Fujitsu Ltd. said it lost $448 million in its first quarter, up from a loss of $107.6 million a year earlier and it quadrupled its projected loss for the year. A leading Japanese manufacturer of PC's, telecommunication equipment and semiconductors, Fujitsu said because of falling prices and slow sales, it expects a group net loss of $1.78 billion for the year, up from the $405 million projected in April. The company said about 9,000 of its 42,000 employees are eligible for an early retirement program it recently announced, but did not say how many positions would be cut. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Don Sunseri, 62, Artist, Teacher And Founder of a Workshop
description: Don Sunseri, an artist, teacher and the founding director of Grace, an art workshop program for the handicapped and elderly that became a national model, died on July 19 at his home in West Glover, Vt. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONE, DR. BERNARD WILLIAM.
description: STRONE-Dr. Bernard William. On July 27, 2001 after a long and valiant struggle with Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of Judith. Cherished father of Daniel and Michael and his wife Andrea. Adored grandfather of Noah and Joshua. Distinguished physician. His work is done. He may finally rest in peace. Services will be held on Sunday, July 29, at 9:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 76th St. & Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168th St, NY, NY 10032.

title: Two Images of a Teacher At a Sexual Abuse Trial
description: Depending on whom you believe, Marci Stein was either a caring, generous teacher betrayed by her students, or the worst kind of sexual predator.

title: The Political Uses of Moving On
description: Increasingly, Americans are being told to ''move on'' -- to leave uncomfortable feelings and unpleasant events behind us -- especially when it would be convenient for certain public figures if we forgot them. This month, for example, The New York Times found there had been unequal handling of some military absentee ballots and counting of illegal military ballots in Florida last fall. Ari Fleischer, President Bush's press secretary, in response, offered this airy comment: ''This election was decided by the voters of Florida a long time ago, and the nation, the president and all but the most partisan Americans have moved on.''

title: With Edwards, Jets' Revamping Begins at the Top
description: Earlier this week, Jets Coach Herman Edwards and General Manager Terry Bradway took a walk around Giants Stadium, like wide-eyed tourists getting a peek at the inner sanctum for the first time. This, they were told, is the Jets' locker room. This is how you get to the tunnel. This is where you stand.

title: Essex County To Investigate Police Chases
description: The acting Essex County prosecutor, Donald C. Campolo, said today that his office was investigating high-speed police pursuits of crime suspects that, he said, had resulted in two deaths in two weeks.

title: Scores by Philip Glass for Films From Five Countries
description: Philip Glass has been writing music for films since the mid-1980's, but unlike most other film composers, his scores for commercial hits like ''The Truman Show'' are far less well known than his contributions to experimental films, particularly Godfrey Reggio's sweeping paeans to nature (and humanity's malignant effect on it).

title: Youth Plays Vital Role In M.L.S.
description: Don Garber, the Major League Soccer commissioner, presented a rather favorable picture in his state-of-the-league address yesterday and said the league would announce later this year whether it would expand beyond its current 12 teams.

title: An Uncommonly Spirited Campaign Roils British Tories
description: It is a common voter complaint these days that there is no real difference between candidates, no chance to cast a ballot with conviction and passion. But you will hear quite the opposite lament from Britain's Conservatives as they contemplate this summer's election of a new leader.

title: Israel Is Wary Of Long Reach In Rights Cases
description: A warning went out this week from Israel's Foreign Ministry to government, army and security officials. Be careful in choosing destinations when traveling abroad, it cautioned, because certain nations might be prepared to charge ranking Israelis with violating Palestinians' human rights.

title: China Feud Has New Risks For Taiwan
description: In a sign that Taiwan's political standoff with China is starting to alienate its corporate customers, Dell Computer has criticized the reluctance of the authorities on Taiwan to establish direct trade and transportation ties with the Chinese mainland.

title: To Protect Religions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNETT, DORIS M.
description: HARNETT-Doris M. Of Ridgefield, CT formerly of New York, NY. Wife of the late Thomas A. Harnett. Survived by two sons, Thomas A. Harnett and William A. Harnett, two daughters, Doris A. Harnett and Kathleen Harnett Linger and four grandchildren, Susan, Mary Jane, Eloise and Joseph. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 10:30 AM, St. Mary's Church, Ridgefield, CT. Burial to follow. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Sisters of the Christian Doctrine, Nyack, NY.

title: Editors' Note; About Mutual Funds
description: As a result of growth in the number of mutual funds, The Times is eliminating entries for some of the smallest ones and making its daily table more concise.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They take the most noble thing, the desire for a better life, especially among girls who are ready to take a risk and go abroad, and they destroy them.''

title: Suspect in 3 Murders Agrees to Extradition
description: Joseph Sean Salley, a suspect in a triple slaying above the Carnegie Deli in Midtown who was apprehended in Florida earlier this month, has decided not to fight his return to New York, the authorities said.

title: Censors, Spies and Scholars
description: July in Beijing is always hot. On July 1, China celebrated the 80th anniversary of the founding of the Communist Party. In the middle of the month, China was awarded the 2008 Olympics, and the jubilant people of Beijing celebrated in the streets. My younger brother, Huang Feng -- still on probation after being arrested for notifying the outside world of my own arrest in Beijing last year for publishing a literary journal -- reminded me earlier this week, long-distance, that Beijingers were still reveling and still oblivious to the true meaning of the Olympic news. The name Gao Zhan meant nothing to my brother.

title: Buenos Aires Invents Currency to Pay Bills
description: Buenos Aires, the most populated province in Argentina, has resorted to printing its own currency to settle its bills.

title: Slimmer Dayne Presents New Options
description: A year ago at the Giants' training camp, it was impossible to miss Ron Dayne. The team's top pick in the 2000 draft, Dayne could be found trailing the pack of players running postpractice sprints.

title: Privacy in the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Official History Describes U.S. Policy in Indonesia in the 60's
description: A supposedly secret State Department history, released today by a private research group, discloses new details of United States policy during the 1965 campaign by the Indonesian Army to wipe out the Communist opposition in Indonesia.

title: The Bondage That Produces Chocolate
description: Child labor has deep roots in Africa and is hard to measure.

title: A Do-It-Yourselfer Takes On Home Depot
description: ATLANTA  Walk into a Home Depot during the day, and one thing may strike you by its inescapable presence, another by its conspicuous absence.

title: Dobbs Ferry Coach Defends Parents' Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Adjoining; Rethinking Segregation Beyond Black and White
description: THE waves of immigration to the United States over the last 20 years -- the largest two-decade influx in the nation's history -- have produced new forms of segregation and integration that challenge the traditional meaning of those words. The 2000 census reveals that the issue of black-white segregation has been complicated by new forms of Latino and Asian separateness and mixing.

title: Yearning To Be Safe
description: THAILAND was no good,'' 8-year-old Pyi Son Aung said, his black hair flopping forward on his forehead, his dark eyes open wide. To explain, he held his palms together and cocked his fingers in the time-honored imitation of a gun. ''Brrrr, brrrr, brrrr, brrrr, brrrrrr,'' he shouted as he sprayed the walls of his living room with bullets from an imaginary weapon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, FREDERICK
description: MOSS-Frederick. The Trustees of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange are saddened by the passing of Cincinnati's Chairman. We will miss his counsel, his inquisitive mind, and his sense of humor. The Exchanges send their deepest sympathies to Jan and the other members of Fred's family. David Colker, Bill Brodsky

title: Watching Her Weight
description: As a pediatric- and neonatal-intensive-care nurse, I think Anamarie's symptoms and physical features strongly suggest a possible metabolic or genetic disorder. I have taken care of children with similar attributes in the I.C.U., most of them heavyset. Even here in Manhattan, at major teaching hospitals, these patients' conditions are difficult to diagnose.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: Business; From a British Chain, Lunch in a New York Minute
description: IN the months before Pret A Manger's first New York sandwich shop opened last July, the chief executive, Andrew Rolfe, walked the streets of Manhattan, timing how long it took to get lunch at various potential competitors, from the upmarket sandwich bar Xando Cosi (15 minutes), to the average deli (12 minutes).

title: Word for Word/Boat Names; Sailing the High Cheese: Make Way for the Beeracuda
description: IT'S O-Fish-Hull: There is now more corn on the nation's waterways than in all of Iowa. Hype, you say? Not if you sift long enough through the recreational boat names logged by the 530,000-member Boat Owners Association of the United States (www.boatus.com/names).

title: 'The Invention of Clouds: How an Amateur Meteorologist Forged the Language of the Skies'
description: The Theater of Science

title: Beyond Multiculturalism, Freedom?
description: MULTICULTURALISM, more than an attitude but less than a theory, was a propelling force behind American art of the last two decades. It will define the 1990's in the history books as surely as Pop defined the 1960's. But it came with problems as well as benefits; some of those problems have grown acute. In the 2000's, the time has come to move on to new ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRIS, LOUIS A.
description: FERRIS-Louis A. A former stock broker with a seat on the NYSE and a Vice President at Prudential Bache & Company, died at his home in Harrison, NY on Friday, July 27, 2001. Mr. Ferris was born in New Orleans, LA on October 20, 1914. The cause was cancer his family said. Mr. Ferris was a Captain in the 442nd Infantry, the famous ''Go For Broke'' Nisei unit during World War II. He was proud of his command and his men and called them the bravest group of soldiers he ever had the honor of knowing. His valor under fire earned him the Bronze Star amongst other medals. He continued to communicate with some of the men under his command, and was a benefactor and supporter of the new memorial built and unveiled in Los Angeles in 2000 to honor the 442nd. Mr. Ferris also served in the Korean War. Mr. Ferris is survived by his beloved wife, Lesley to whom he was married for sixtysix years; three children, Neal of San Francisco, CA; Pamela Ferris Olson of Dayton, OH; Lynn Ferris Steinman of Rye, NY; six grandchildren, and one great grandchild. He also leaves a sister, Jessica Feingold. A memorial service will be held at 4PM, Wednesday, August 1, 2001 at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, New York. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: Laura Rigolosi, Diego Ibargen
description: Laura Anna Rigolosi, a daughter of Marguerite Lipton Bronster of Edgewater, N.J., and Dr. Robert Rigolosi of Paramus, N.J., was married last evening to Diego Alberto Ibargen, the son of Susana and Alberto Ibargen of Coconut Grove, Fla. The Rev. Raymond Smialowski, the Roman Catholic chaplain of Trinity College in Hartford, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: American Embroiled in British Subway Debate
description: The tourism-minded British government customarily offers American visitors a warm reception. But all it has shown Robert R. Kiley, the American mass transit expert hired by London's mayor to restore its crumbling subway system, is a cold shoulder.

title: A Second Breakfast Pays Dividends
description: ON some traveling days, my most rewarding activity combines a modest meal with what my mother would tartly call lollygagging. It started when my husband, G. J., the son of Viennese-born parents, introduced me -- on one of our first trips together -- to ''second breakfast,'' or gabelfrhstck in German.

title: Powell Disappoints Critics of Arrests
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he had not raised any individual cases of people detained in China in his meetings with Chinese leaders, but had spoken generally of improving human rights and the rule of law in China.

title: At Rutgers, A Collection Of Collections
description: SOMETHING for everybody is more than a boast at Mason Gross Galleries of Rutgers University here. Seven diverse, mostly New Jersey private collections, have been mined, each getting a room in the galleries.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: East Hampton Government Becomes Farm Landlord
description: Already poised to buy the development rights of 42 acres of farmland at the center of a yearlong debate, the East Hampton Town Board has agreed to go one step further, buying the outright title to the land with the intention of leasing it for farming.

title: Where 'Nimby' Is Taboo, But So Is a Homeless Shelter
description: Marcia Jackson won't say the ''N'' word. She does not want a homeless shelter to move to her block, on 45th Street between First and Second Avenues. But the reasons, she said, have nothing to do with Nimby.

title: On Vieques, a Vote On Navy Bomb Drills
description: The people of Vieques, P.R., are to hold a referendum today on whether the Navy should leave now, stay until 2003 or remain indefinitely. On one level, the nonbinding vote is about as real as the mock invasions that have taken place on the island for 61 years, since any decision rests with the United States government.

title: Investing Diary: A Shrinking Credit Club
description: Increased competition and a greater willingness to take on debt have cost all but a handful of of American companies their triple-A credit ratings, according to Moody's Investors Service.

title: The World; Indonesia May Crumble Without Falling Apart
description: ''I HAVE to preserve the integrity of Indonesia,'' said President Abdurrahman Wahid earlier this year, as he sought desperately, and in vain, to persuade his countrymen not to oust him. ''The moment I step down, Aceh, Riau, Ambon, Maluku, Irian Jaya and Madura will proclaim their independence.''

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Where Pampering Is Part of a Man's World
description: WARM water rained down on Joshua Rosensweig. It poured, 155 gallons a minute, from 10 pulsating jets and showered him from three oversize Roman heads in a treatment room at Rodolfo Valentin, a granite and Corinthian column-filled salon and day spa in Cedarhurst that looks like an over-the-top Las Vegas rendition of a Roman piazza. Lying on a table, covered from chest to toes with a soaked towel, Mr. Rosensweig, a 21-year-old architecture student, sighed, a serene smile on his lips.

description: DANTE

title: Exciting New Changes
description: The New York City Department of Transportation is starting the final stage of the Manhattan Bridge rehabilitation, and that means it's time to get ready for major service changes! Even if your line doesn't normally use the Manhattan Bridge, your service may be affected. In fact, in an effort to include all New Yorkers in this exciting project, we have attempted to affect every subway line in some way. Here are some of the service highlights:

title: Virginia O'Connell, Richard Wong
description: Virginia M. O'Connell, a daughter of Virginia and John O'Connell of Nissequogue, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard C. Wong, the son of Donna and Thomas Wong of New York. The Rev. Brian Barr performed the ceremony at St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church in Smithtown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, DONNA
description: SANDERS-Donna. On July 15, 2001 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Ken Starrett. Cherished sister of Helen Sheley of Greenville, Texas. Her life was spent in the arts of singing and acting. She enjoyed a long career on Broadway, television and at prominent theaters throughout the country. She will be missed by many friends. Memorial service is on Wednesday, August 1, 2001, 6:00 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Contributions can be made in Donna's name to the American Cancer Society, 97-77 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, New York 11374.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 29, 2001
description: Weeks

title: When an Apartment Is Deregulated
description: Q -- I understand that once the rent on a rent-stabilized apartment goes above $2,000 a month, a landlord is no longer restricted to the annual percentage increases approved by the Rent Guidelines Board. When does this take effect, in the same year the rent passes the $2,000 mark or subsequently? Is there any limit on the increase a landlord of an unregulated apartment may impose in a given year? . . . T. Brock, Manhattan

title: Music and Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Spiraling Sports Budgets Draw Fire From Faculties
description: Professors and presidents at a number of large universities with big-time sports programs have expressed concern recently about commercialization and corruption in college athletics, saying the spiraling budgets threaten academic integrity.

title: Jessica Eckle, Winston Fisher
description: Jessica Helen Eckle, a daughter of Margaret Moss of Newtown, Conn., and George M. Eckle of Williamsburg, Va., was married yesterday to Winston Crawford Fisher, a son of Sandra Fisher and Richard L. Fisher, both of New York. Madelynn R. Kirkpatrick, an Episcopal deacon, officiated at a ranch owned by the bridegroom's family near Galisteo, N.M.

title: Susan Lukens, Christopher Solbert
description: Susan Atkinson Lukens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Lukens of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Christopher Oscar Nathaniel Solbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O. A. Solbert of Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. Roddy O'Neil Cleary, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at the bridegroom's home in Charlotte, Vt.

title: In a Surplus Helicopter, An Air Force of 2
description: WRITE it off as a fantasy of mild-mannered reporters everywhere, but I can barely repress the urge to fly.

title: Brookhaven Seeks Growth For Yaphank Landfill
description: The Town of Brookhaven is seeking state permission for a major new expansion of a town landfill in Yaphank that is being clogged by construction and demolition debris.

title: For Nations Traumatized By the Past, New Remedies
description: From temporary offices on Wall Street, a new international human rights group has plunged into work with 14 countries, helping them come to terms with the oppressions that mark their recent past.

title: Meditating on Rap
description: Most hip-hop artists fill their songs with snippets of other people's music, not chanting. But a couple of rap gurus are changing that. Mike D of the Beastie Boys has joined with Bhagavan Das, a Bhakti yoga practitioner, to write and produce ''Now'' (Grand Royal), an album of Hindu chants, due out Aug. 21. And in September, Karuna Records will release ''Breath of the Heart'' by Krishna Das, a performer of chants. The record was produced by Rick Rubin, a founder of Def Jam Records, who has worked with Run DMC and the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAND, SYLVIA
description: GRAND-Sylvia. Passed away on 7/22/01. Outstanding mother, grandmother, aunt, mother-in-law and friend. Your kindness and generosity will be remembered by so many dear friends. We will always cherish your memory and we will never, ever forget you. Your loving family, Mark, Laurie & Lisa Grand, and Karen, Michael, Allison and Steven Ball, and many nieces and nephews. Donations may be sent in her memory to Temple Beth Orr, 2151 Riverside Drive, Coral Springs, FL 33071.

title: Why Opera Isn't the Word For Sondheim
description: AS if by court order, the word ''opera'' is not allowed within 100 yards of Stephen Sondheim. It's hard to blame him. What a convenient, all too convenient, conveyance for upward mobility in the arts. Want to give your downtown light show with synthesizer and vocals a little class? Put it up there with ''La Traviata.'' Forms and the distinctions between them have become so loose in the performing arts that a few of the right words, ''opera'' among them, make social climbing easy.

title: Eudora Welty
description: AUDIO SPECIAL:

title: Holden Reconsidered and All
description: Holden Caulfield turned 67 this month -- 17 plus the half-century that has gone by since ''The Catcher in the Rye'' was published on July 16, 1951. It's difficult to imagine the skinny, smart-mouthed prep school dropout as a white-haired retiree, but not impossible. His teacher, Mr. Antolini, warned Holden that he would become an embittered organization man if he didn't get it together, the kind of guy who'd spend his life ''in some business office, throwing paper clips at the nearest stenographer.'' Just because Holden froze in time instead, a perpetually youthful icon of protest against a corrupted adult world, doesn't mean that he hasn't grown old.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: The Future of Slavery's Past
description: Near the end of the millennium, Mathieu Krkou, president of Benin, made a pilgrimage to the Church of the Great Commission in Baltimore to apologize on his knees to African-Americans for the African role in the slave trade. Then, in December 1999, during a reconciliation conference at which Africans (including Ghana's former president Jerry Rawlings), Americans and Europeans acknowledged and apologized for their ancestors' culpability in the slave trade, Mr. Krkou said all parties, buyers and sellers, ''must confess our responsibility before history for this shameful trade.'' The kingdom of Dahomey, precolonial ancestor to Benin, profited handsomely from the traffic in black slaves.

title: Smithsonian Repairs Priced at $1.5 Billion
description: An independent review of the Smithsonian Institution found that it needs about $1.5 billion to repair and renovate its deteriorating facilities.

title: Beach Books, Henry James to Tawni O'Dell
description: Scan the ''summer reading'' table near the entrance of the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Avenue of the Americas and 22nd Street, and here is a sample of what you'll find: ''The Golden Bowl'' by Henry James, ''Things Fall Apart'' by the Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe and ''The Stranger'' by Albert Camus.

title: TAX BURDEN
description: The state ranked third in combined state and local taxes per person -- $3,698 each -- in 1998, according to census data released last week. Connecticut and New York, were first and second. New Jersey was 16th in taxes as a percentage of income. The state tends to have average municipal taxes, but leads the nation on statewide financing of education, according to James W. Hughes, Dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. Anne Ruderman

title: Laura Eisman and Todd Richter
description: CAN a couple live together, run a business together and still want to marry each other? Three years and three Web sites later, Laura Eisman and Todd Richter found their answer.

title: Puff Daddy
description: THE INVENTION OF CLOUDS

title: July 22-28; India Mourns Bandit Queen
description: Phoolan Devi, India's folkloric ''bandit queen,'' was fatally shot, ending a saga so colorful that the simple facts often overtook the embellishments. A victim of caste prejudice and poverty, she avenged her grievances by leading a gang of desperados in a life of robbery and murder, supposedly including the 1981 massacre of 22 upper-caste men in retaliation for the murder of her lover, a highway robber, and her own gang-rape. She emerged from prison a hero in 1994, and her fame grew with a movie that recounted her humiliations and retaliations. She was elected to Parliament.

title: When Hospitals Shop Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Criticism for S.E.C. Options Plan
description: Microsoft, Verizon Communications, Emerson Electric and other companies are opposing a proposed federal rule that would compel them to disclose the total number of shares paid to employees in stock option plans.

title: From Back Alleys to Beauty Queens
description: THE tattoo stood out on the glimmering chest. There on the shoulder was another. Encircling the wrist of a well-toned forearm was what appeared to be a woven blue band -- but on closer inspection was yet one more tattoo.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Belmont; Close-Knit Bronx Area With Italian Aura
description: FOR hundreds of thousands of Italian-Americans in the metropolitan area and beyond, it is ''the old neighborhood,'' a hallowed place remembered at family gatherings, the setting for countless stories told to children and grandchildren. It is Belmont, the Little Italy of the Bronx.

title: Tighter Requirements For Children's Passports
description: Since July 2, the State Department has been complying with a new law that requires both parents to provide written consent before a passport is issued for a child younger than 14. The law is aimed at reducing the cases of international child abduction by a parent.

title: The Battle Lines Of the Mommy Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Blockbusters Aren't Everything
description: I WAS 16 when I got my first job, as an assistant movie projectionist at the Iris Theater in Philadelphia.

title: Armstrong Cruises to Third Straight Title
description: PARIS, July 29 - After telling his rivals that he has never felt as strong as he does now and that he expects to feel even more powerful next year, Lance Armstrong cruised into Paris today as the winner of his third consecutive Tour de France.

title: Robinson's 3-Pointer Is Decisive For Liberty
description: Trips to Houston have usually ended in disappointment and disgust for the Liberty, losers to the Comets in three of the four W.N.B.A. finals.

title: Electric in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: As Pagers Proliferate, Even Tiffany Joins In
description: WHEN Katie Benetos of Bethpage learned in 1998 that Tiffany & Company had opened a store on Manhasset's prestigious Miracle Mile, she was thrilled. For years, the nearest Tiffany's had been in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Think It Over
description: Hotel rooms should provide a quiet, contemplative haven, but some guests need an even smaller space to do their thinking. The Hotel Monaco in Chicago has added Meditation Stations, curtained-off window nooks, in each of its 192 rooms. The cushioned window sills, some big enough to recline on, can be closed off from the rest of the room with a curtain, leaving a view of downtown Chicago to ponder. For information and reservations, call (800) 397-7661.

title: How F.B.I. Turncoat Struck the Deal That Spared His Life
description: The defense team brought brownies to cut the tension, but that did not help. At his first meeting with federal prosecutors last month, Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent charged with spying for Moscow, seemed un focused, at times hesitant in answering questions about his espionage career, and the session ended with his lawyers fearing he had jeopardized chances for a plea bargain that would spare his life.

title: Soriano's Bat May Aid Yankees in the Stretch
description: TORONTO, July 28  About three or four times in every game now, Alfonso Soriano takes a sweeping, powerful and confident swing, the sort of hack needed to drive the ball and inflict real damage. Sometimes Soriano just misses and fouls the ball straight back to the screen behind home plate.

title: ONLINE SEX OFFENDERS' REGISTRY
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week signed legislation to establish an Internet registry that will include the names, addresses, photographs and vehicle information of moderate- and high-risk sex offenders. It will not include information on first-time juvenile offenders, who are believed to pose a lower risk for repeating their crime. The bill is a follow-up to Megan's Law, which in 1994 established a state sex offender registry and a community notification program.

title: A South-of-the-Border Menu, Minus Tacos
description: IF diners come here to Sonora expecting to find tacos and a bowl of salsa on the table and dishes like tamales, chili con carne and refried beans on the menu, they will be disappointed -- or pleasantly surprised.

title: L.I.A. Doesn't Pursue Island's Broader Interests
description: Matthew Crosson directs the Long Island Association as if he were a petty satrap and Long Island his fief [''L.I.A. at 75: Fighting Off a Challenge From Inside,'' July 22]. Over the past few years, Mr. Crosson has frozen many important initiatives begun by others outside of the L.I.A. sphere. If the initiative didn't line the greedy pockets of the small, select private club of investors who actually control the L.I.A., then it simply did not matter.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Anonymous Anchor

title: Airplane Seating
description: Passengers seeking more legroom on flights may want to consult travel .simplyquick.com, which has a chart listing typical seat pitch by airline, for domestic and foreign carriers. The Web site also features a comparison guide to airline discounters. It is run by SimplyQuick.com, a New Zealand company that says it offers independent research into various consumer Web sites.

title: 'Making' Holograms
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Talented High School Artists
description: High school seniors with a creative bent can see how they measure up nationally by applying for the Arts Recognition and Talent Search, which not only makes cash and scholarship awards but also recommends candidates to the commission that selects presidential scholars in the arts.

title: What's the Buzz? This Man Knows
description: WAYNE J. CRANS stood in the laboratory, one hand poised above a glass cage.

title: Architectural Superstars Tackle Three Hartford Attractions
description: IF one measure of a city is its architecture, Hartford is poised for a growth spurt as three of the city's major cultural institutions have announced multimillion-dollar building projects by high profile architects.

title: When the Client Is a School District
description: ERIK KAEYER confidently strode through the mud here en route to the site of an elementary school that was under construction. Unfazed by the din of saws and hammers, he proudly pointed out such design details as terrazzo flooring, multiple skylights and the vistas of trees revealed through picture windows.

title: Ideas & Trends: How Many Miles Per Gallon?; It's Easy: Add Safety, Mileage, Pollution. Divide by Dollars.
description: WHEN a panel of the National Academy of Sciences was asked a decade ago to assess federal fuel-economy regulations, it warned that higher gas-mileage standards for cars would make the nation's roads less safe and threaten the financial survival of Detroit's automakers and their workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMINS, SCHURMAN, MILDRED
description: CUMINS - SCHURMAN - Mildred. Our woman of valor, our mother. Loving wife to wonderful Leon. Grandmother, great-grandmother. Her memory, a true blessing. Robert and Edward Cumins

description: To the Editor:

title: Are the Mets Finished, Or Merely Refinishing?
description: The fans down the left-field line stood and cheered as Todd Pratt strode to the Phillies' bullpen before yesterday's game. A security guard approached Turk Wendell and thanked him for his friendship over the years. Dennis Cook chatted amiably with a Mets broadcaster.

title: Rebecca MacCarthy, Joshua Dolgin
description: Rebecca Susan MacCarthy, a daughter of Elinor and Edward Dyer MacCarthy of Windham, Me., was married yesterday evening to Joshua Michael Dolgin, a son of Margaret and Kalmon Dolgin of Manhasset, N.Y. Rabbi William Leffler officiated at the Inn on Newfound Lake in Bridgewater, N.H.

description: Shakespeare in the Park

title: On the Cyclones' Home Turf, Some Sightings of the Enemy
description: The Brooklyn Cyclones are on a roll. The team is winning, tickets are almost entirely sold out, and merchandise is being snapped up. Cyclones baseball caps are the nation's second-best seller, topping every major league team except the Seattle Mariners. But the hot streak stops at the ice cream stand.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 15 about the so-called fan's cut of the film ''Star Wars I: The Phantom Menance'' misidentified the studio that released the 1931 film ''East of Borneo,'' which also had a fan's cut. It was Universal, not Columbia.

title: The Bills Are Paid
description: Tucked away in a nondescript office park outside of town is a technological powerhouse with plenty of financial backing that is poised to revolutionize the way people pay bills and manage their finances.

title: For This Scientist, Children Are Like, er, Sponges
description: A square, yellow invertebrate as the next television hero? Who'd have guessed it?

title: Agassi Bides Time, Then Beats Kuerten
description: Down a set to the three-time French Open champion Gustavo Kuerten in today's semifinal of the Mercedes-Benz Cup, Andre Agassi did not panic. He is not the type. Instead, as usual, he persevered. He found a way to get stronger and sharper, and soon it was his opponent who succumbed, as Agassi rallied for a 6-7 (3), 6-3, 6-3 victory at the Los Angeles Tennis Center at U.C.L.A.

title: Dr. Charles Granville Rob, 88, Surgeon Who Aided Churchill
description: Charles Granville Rob, a British-born surgeon who survived his baptism by fire in North Africa to operate on Sir Winston Churchill and Middle Eastern royalty and to teach generations of young physicians, died Thursday at a hospital in Berlin, Vt. He was 88 and lived in Bethesda, Md., and Montpelier, Vt.

title: Perspective; Setting Priorities: Vacation First, Then Opinions
description: Despite the pleas and the demands rising off

title: With a Finger of Lace
description: Lace has been turning up on shoes, bags, pants, tops, dresses, skirts -- virtually everything imaginable. Which now includes fingernails and toenails.

title: Political Briefing; Sufficiently Scorned, But Paid in Full
description: After Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont bolted the Republican Party and became an independent, giving control of the Senate to Democrats, he said contributors to his last election campaign who felt sufficiently scorned could get their money back by sending in a request.

title: Prague Restaurants Move Up in Class
description: ONCE upon a time, not long ago, all restaurants in what was then Czechoslovakia were state owned. Menus were based on recipes from three government-approved cookbooks. And waiters had nothing to gain by being gracious.

title: Toronto Confident Carter Will Stay
description: When Tracy McGrady bolted Toronto to play for the Orlando Magic last summer, it seemed a precursor to the inevitable departure of Vince Carter. McGrady, Carter's cousin and close friend, was the third individual with star power -- Isiah Thomas and Damon Stoudamire were the others -- to leave the young franchise high and dry after a fun and fascinating fling.

title: Plover Lovers Ruffle Some Feathers
description: SO much power for such a small bird.

title: Cathryn Galanter, James Rosenfeld
description: Dr. Cathryn Ann Galanter, a psychiatrist, and James Eric Rosenfeld, a lawyer, were married last evening by Cantor Helene Reps at Studio 450 in New York.

title: A Course for Those Not Born to Lead
description: THOUGH they may never lead more than a conga line, the 20 people who recently graduated from a 10-month course called Leadership Huntington could now qualify for town tour guide, if not town trustee.

title: A Bit of Cheek
description: To the Sports Editor,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, PETER R.
description: WALKER-Peter R. On July 20, at home in New Orleans, of lung cancer, age 54. Artist, designer, playwright, caricaturist. Graduate of Cooper Union 1968. Survived by his wife Katherine, children Mina and Raphael, parents Grace and Harry.

title: A Conservative Diner's 3 Wishes Granted
description: THE Mill River Inn has the best food on Long Island, according to the latest version of the Zagat Survey, a compilation of rating sheets filled out by more than 3,000 Long Island diners. In the recently released book, it ranked second for service and popularity behind Mirabelle and Peter Luger, respectively.

title: Food-Oriented Wines
description: Visitors to Martha Clara Vineyards' Internet site are offered a 360-degree virtual tour of its new tasting room. The bar offers a real tour of low-key summer whites, all recently released.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things'
description: DISAPPEARANCES

title: Pro Leagues' Ratings Drop; Nobody Is Quite Sure Why
description: There has never been a more uncertain moment in the recent history of America's $250-billion-a-year sports industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIBEL, NATHAN
description: REIBEL-Nathan. Died peacefully at Hackensack University Hospital on July 27. He was 94 years old. He practiced law in Elizabeth, NJ, for 65 years and was a past president of the Union County Bar Association. He was married to Helen Welt for 70 years, and will be greatly missed by her, his son Stephen, and his grandsons Noah and Joshua, as well as all who benefited from his abiding concern.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 8 about the fashion designer Hussein Chalayan omitted a credit. The photographs of his clothes were from Firstview.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGNER, NATALIE
description: LANGNER-Natalie. On July 26, 2001. Peacefully in her home at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Loving mother of Edie Langner-Landeck, dear sister of Henrietta Wallach and the late Helen Lowenthal. An inspiring teacher and guidance counselor, she was a devoted volunteer. She lived her long life with grace and dignity and touched us all. Funeral services private. Memorial service to be announced. Donations may be made in Natalie's name to the Humanities and Medicine Program at Weill-Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Avenue, Room C118, New York, N.Y. 10021 or to Bank Street College of Education, 610 W. 112 St, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: SOAPBOX; Eine Kleine Trentonmusik
description: HEARING the scherzo from ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' on the radio the other night unleashed a flood of memories. Suddenly it was the summer of 1965, when, fresh out of high school and looking for work, I first encountered Mendelssohn's youthful masterpiece in the most remarkable of places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOLF, LEOPOLD
description: WOOLF-Leopold. Of Boynton Beach, FL and Somers, NY died July 24 at age 77, after a heroic effort to recover from complications following a kidney transplant. Born in Vienna, Austria, emigrated to the US in 1939. He attended Columbia University and University of Chicago. He served in the U.S. Army's ski troops, and was wounded in Italy. A jeweler's apprentice in Vienna, he became a Master Jeweler and Appraiser, until his retirement in 1994. Known as ''Bob,'' he leaves behind his adoring wife of 52 years, Dorrit, their two sons, Richard of Scarsdale, NY and Matthew of Manhattan, daughter-in-law Jayne and son-inlaw Steven, as well as grandchildren Joshua, Jennifer and Andrew.

title: 'Blue Diary'
description: The Hanged Man

title: Investing; Invading the Land of Q's and Spiders
description: SALVATORE SODANO, the chairman of the American Stock Exchange, informed 700 securities firms earlier this month that the exchange was eliminating fees on some of its premier products, including the Nasdaq 100 Index Shares, known simply as the ''Q'' in the canyons of Lower Manhattan.

title: Unreachable? It's an Ideal Summit Site!
description: ''BIG enough for a group photo, but small enough that nine would be a crowd'' -- that was the charge to location scouts fanning out across the globe seeking venues for future powwows of the leaders of the Group of 8, the world's leading industrialized nations and Russia. Due to the mobs of autograph- and photo-seeking industrial and economic policy fans who badly overtaxed parking spaces, souvenir shops and restrooms in Seattle, Quebec City and Genoa, the Group of 8 explains, locales of future conferences will remain confidential until three minutes before they convene.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Computer Associates Posts Quarterly Loss

title: Trying to Act Saintly Nowadays Can Be a Hair Shirt
description: MAKING piety appealing in a climate of modern skepticism would seem a Sisyphean labor for performers today -- especially women. After all, this is an era in which the word ''purity'' evokes the Food and Drug Administration more strongly than it does personal virtue, and representations of female goodness can suggest age-old stereotypes of unworldly virgins and saintly prigs. How easy is it for an actress to win audience sympathy when portraying outspoken spirituality? Recent interviews with several performers who have undertaken that task indicate it is a tricky one.

title: Cross-State Without Tolls
description: It sounds like a pleasant drive across New Jersey: from Milford in the Delaware River valley, to the hills erupting outside Lambertville, to the scenic fringes of Princeton, through industrial parks near East Brunswick, to the shore in Manasquan. But it's a footrace, a 91.7-mile relay that several hundred runners will compete in next Saturday. The River to Sea Relay has grown annually since its inception in 1996; last year 42 teams competed. Each team's seven runners tackle two legs of the relay, which range from a flat 2.5-mile sprint to a hilly 8.7-mile test near Lambertville called the Beast. Teams provide directions, water and encouragement to their racers over what can be 12 hours of running. The slowest teams begin around 6 a.m.; the fastest leave four hours later. But it does become a race at the end. Last year four teams finished within 15 seconds, but a team's final runner traditionally dashes past the finish line and into the ocean. Phil Coffin

title: Playing Used-Car Detective, Online
description: IN February, months after he started searching the Internet for a limited-production Audi S6, Lee Rosenthal thought he had found his dream car. A dealership in Minneapolis said it had one -- a 1995-model sedan in mint condition with just 67,000 miles.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column last Sunday about Glenda Davenport, a jazz singer, misstated the post office box for ordering her CD, ''Sophisticated Lady.'' The address is P.O. Box 586, White Plains 10603.

title: Nuala Byrne, Douglas Jebb
description: Nuala Anne Byrne and Douglas Schoellkopf Jebb were married yesterday in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel H. Love officiated at Rye Presbyterian Church, where the Rev. Dr. Frederick Drobin, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COAKLEY, VIRGINIA MCPIKE
description: COAKLEY-Virginia McPike. Died gracefully on July 27, 2001, after a long illness. The Larchmont resident was preceded in death by her sister, Gracemarie M. Neville, and her brothers, Edward J. and Frank R. McPike. She proudly served as a Women Airforce Service Pilot (WASP) during World War II. Of the more than 20,000 women who applied for training, fewer than 2,000 were accepted and 1074 won their wings as WASPs. She maintained her pilot's license after the War, and she campaigned for Veterans status for the WASPs which was finally authorized by Congress in 1979. Virginia is survived by 10 nieces and nephews. Visiting hours are 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM on Monday at Fox Funeral Home at 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont. A funeral Mass will be on Tuesday at 10:00 AM at Saints John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont.

title: In Latest Hardy Boys Case, A Search for New Readers
description: There has been another burglary in the idyllic but crime-ridden town of Bayport, and Frank and Joe Hardy are once again on the case. But this time the boys have a new detective technique: looking for clues by hacking into their father's computer.

title: Space Cadets
description: Some kids are beyond proprietary when it comes to their rooms. Especially the well-dressed ones.

title: 'Widower's House'
description: To the Editor:

title: Overcoming Repeatedly
