title: Slowdown's Other Shoe, Hanging Over The Hudson
description: FRIENDS in Manhattan planning a kitchen remodeling tell me that it is practically impossible to find an available electrician anywhere in the city. In the suburbs of northern New Jersey and in Westchester County, nearly every contractor seems to be booked into the fall.

title: Varenne Trots to a Record In Winning Breeders Crown
description: Italian flags surrounded the winner's circle after the seventh race this evening at the Meadowlands Racetrack. When Varenne, the heralded Italian horse, entered the circle with his driver, Giampaolo Minnucci, after winning the $1 million Breeders Crown Trot in a world-record time, a song written by a surgeon for the 6-year-old horse played over the public-address system.

title: OUT THERE: Lignano Sabbiadoro; Euro Pop Hits the Beach: So Hot, So Gritty
description: WHEN life crawled out of the sea, it held a pop music festival. At first it was just the cries and gurgles of dolphins, the lobster's clacking claws. Later, electric guitars were added. Today, that primordial gathering on the sands is celebrated each July at beach resorts around the Italian peninsula. And they call it -- Festivalbar!

title: Controversy Goes Bumper to Bumper With Spencer
description: The boos tail Jimmy Spencer around the Nascar Winston Cup series like the tin cans tied to the bumper of a newlywed couple's car. These boos are a ''Hallelujah Chorus'' to Spencer. Better to be the most unpopular driver than the most ignored driver.

title: Starting Off the Day With Something Big
description: THERE was a time not too long ago when the big network morning television programs seemed to ease their viewers gently into the day. Sober news reports gave way to fashion, cooking, health and beauty segments.

title: Those Charming Steeples Aren't So Quaint Anymore
description: THE Connecticut skyline has always been defined by its church steeples, those towers that rise about the trees and give so many of the state's communities their charm. But in a 21st century twist, these old spires that were originally built to resemble Christopher Wren's stone steeples in London are becoming the camouflage to hide microwave antennas for cell phone companies.

title: Lost in Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: Making It in Sports With a Pen, Not a Ball
description: ELIZABETH GREER of Briarcliff Manor has always loved and been involved in sports.

title: Vallone Maps Victory Route Through Giuliani Territory
description: To follow the mayoral campaign of Peter Fortunate Vallone is to schlep out to the outer reaches of the so-called outer boroughs, to the decidedly unglamorous, solidly middle-class, largely white fringes of the city: Todt Hill on Staten Island, Floral Park and Bensonhurst in Brooklyn. His campaign aides, when learning of their next destination, occasionally gasp from their Flatiron District office, ''Ooh, that's far.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENVIN, JOSEPH
description: BENVIN-Joseph. On July 25, 2001. Loving husband of Emily, loving father of Linda and Carol, loving grandfather of Garrett, Eric, Rachael, Tatiana, Brian and Katelyn. Poppy, you will always be part of our lives. Services will be held Monday, July 30, 10 AM, at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, NY; 516562-6000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, MARY W.
description: ARMSTRONG-Mary W. At age 87, died in Topsham, ME, on July 23, 2001. After graduating from Mt. Holyoke, Mary served 20 years in the Navy. Lt. Commander (Ret.) Armstrong spent the next two decades in the State Department. Mary and the stories about her travels will be sorely missed by her sister, Lucy Bailey, and her nieces, Kathy Armstrong, Susan and Elizabeth Bailey, as well as nephew, John Bailey.

title: Sacred Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Breaking Up Is Harder to Do; New York Law May Fan the Fire in Divorces Like Giuliani's
description: There is a temptation to look for greater meaning in the high-volume Giuliani-Hanover divorce case, especially in legal circles. The ongoing train wreck has raised some uncomfortable questions about whether New York's courts encourage Extreme Divorce, in the way that tabloid talk shows goad the weak-minded into abusing one another.

title: July 22-28; A Fire in the Sky
description: For as long as human beings have watched the sky, shooting stars have portended something -- the birth of a hero, the turning point of a battle, a generous harvest. So what to make of last Monday, when western Pennsylvania was surprised by a fireball in the sky at 6:18 p.m. E.D.T.?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZWIRN, IRVING
description: ZWIRN-Irving. January 27, 1910 to July 9, 1997. Beloved father and grandfather. Remembered with deepest love. Your voice we still hear, your love we still feel. ''Here's looking at you, kid''

title: Keeping Cool: It's in the Wrist
description: The fan has been a hot item throughout history. This year, street vendors along Fifth Avenue are selling a variety of styles, including the round peacock-feather fan, below, which the Greeks were using in 3000 B.C. The round screen fan is thought to have been a Chinese invention; the Japanese claim the folding fan. Another popular summer item is the paper parasol, either as sun protection or to twirl.

title: Watching Her Weight
description: I was disappointed to find no consideration of the ventromedial hypothalamic syndrome as an explanation for this child's problem. The history of birth injury to her head, which probably involved the pituitary and third ventricle (e.g. ''she still has an arched palate''), would provide a source for the syndrome.

title: The Bondage of Poverty That Produces Chocolate
description: One week after leaving his village in neighboring Mali for the first time, Yacouba Diarra, then 14, fell into the hands of a trafficker of children and was smuggled across the border into Ivory Coast's cocoa-producing heartland.

title: Friuli Grape, Transplanted
description: One reason Millbrook Vineyards, owned by the Italophile John S. Dyson, is the leading Hudson Valley winery is its Tocai Friulano. The bright, savory 2000 edition of this Dutchess County white, made from a grape that thrives in Friuli, is a treat. It is herbal, mouth filling and reminiscent of New Zealand sauvignon blancs.

title: A Trenton Bar Caused Trouble, So a Church Bought It
description: An ad used to feature an executive bragging that he liked a company's product so well he bought the company. Last year, parishioners of Union Baptist Church in Trenton gave this concept a twist: they so disliked what a neighborhood business was doing to their community that they bought the business. The church raised eyebrows last December when it finalized its purchase of the Place Bar, a small bar a block away which was a frequent focus of trouble in its West Trenton neighborhood. The church bought the property, on the corner of Wilson and Reservoir Streets, for $67,500 (it did not buy the bar's liquor license) and immediately closed the bar's doors. Union Baptist is negotiating with the City of Trenton and one private property owner to acquire several properties adjacent to the former bar, hoping to renovate all of them and reopen them as a youth services center. The Rev. Simeon D. Spencer, Union Baptist Church's Pastor, recently spoke in the now quiet lounge.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Anonymous Anchor

title: Mother Love, Too Little Or Too Much
description: CHANCE can sometimes be a provocative critic. A few weeks ago, two strangely similar movies opened within a couple days of each other: John Singleton's urban drama ''Baby Boy,'' on June 27, and Steven Spielberg's science-fiction fairy tale ''A.I Artificial Intelligence,'' on June 29.

Rosegard of San Patricio, N.M. The Rev. Edward G. Rice performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dedham. The Rev. Thomas N. Oates, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bride, took part in the service.

description: Following the Hudson River School

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have moved the conversation from bicycle helmet use to bicycle safety. Thank God that the public health world is understanding there is more to bicycle safety than helmets.''

description: IF you are hooked on golf, chances are you have played a few of the many courses around Myrtle Beach, S.C., or Scottsdale, Ariz. Perhaps you have even visited the luxury resorts at Pinehurst in the hills of North Carolina or Pebble Beach on the rocky Monterey Peninsula of California -- or dreamed of doing so.

title: Training, Not Racing, Gives Armstrong His Edge
description: Lance Armstrong has a favorite comeback to people who wonder how he can climb the Alps and the Pyrenees so rapidly in the Tour de France without looking strained. ''You should see my face in January or February,'' he said. ''It's not a pretty face.''

title: Barbara Morgenthau, Hanmin Lee
description: Barbara E. Morgenthau, a daughter of Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, and the late Martha P. Morgenthau, was married yesterday to Dr. Hanmin Lee, a son of Hi Whan Lee and Dr. Chung Ho Lee of Pensacola, Fla. Judge Pierre N. Leval of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan officiated at the home of Anne Morgenthau Grand and Paul Grand, a sister and brother-in-law of the bride, in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Despite Defaults, Junk Bonds Are Jumping
description: OVER all, the economic environment seems sluggish. But things are peppy in the junkyard. More than $64 billion worth of new high-yield bonds were sold in the first half of the year, according to Moody's Investor's Service. That is more than all the junk bonds sold in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTMAN, PHYLLIS M., PH.D.
description: GOOTMAN-Phyllis M., Ph.D. On July 26, after a short illness. Dr. Gootman was a senior Professor of Physiology and Pharmacology at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn, having been on the faculty since 1975. She was a pioneering researcher in newborn physiology, having published over 100 articles, books and monographs, and was an invited lecturer and participant at scientific meetings worldwide. A much respected teacher of almost two generations of medical students, she helped open the door to many successful women now working in the basic sciences, and served as a role model for numerous students of both sexes. She is survived by her husband and frequent co-collabortor, Dr. Norman Gootman, her son Dr. Craig Gootman, and daughter Dr. Sharon Gootman Rosen, as well as her mother Mrs. Ida Adler, brother Dr. Saul Adler of Atlanta, and three grandchildren. A family graveside service will be held July 29, at 11:30 AM.

title: A Plunge in Profits Is Raising Risk For Stock Market and Economy
description: For the first time in a decade, corporate America's profits are plunging, creating what some economists see as significant risks for the stock market and economy alike.

description: Jennifer Capriati moved up to No. 2 in the Sanex WTA Tour rankings on Friday without playing a match.

title: Clinton White House Export: International Trade Lawyers
description: As United States trade representative in the Clinton administration, Charlene Barshefsky was at the center of some of the biggest successes  and the one big mess  of recent American economic diplomacy. She negotiated the deal between the United States and China that should usher Beijing into the World Trade Organization. She was also the ringmaster of the 1999 Seattle trade talks, which ended in chaos. She gained a reputation as a tough negotiator, who could parse the complexities of international trade law in language as colorful as her trademark Hermes scarves.

title: Introduction
description: Lisa Belkin's article on a girl who topped 130 pounds at age 3 prompted some readers to offer their own diagnoses. Others asserted that separating the child from her parents was not the cure, no matter the cause. As to what to do about Japan's affluent ''parasite singles,'' why not turn them into No. 1 aunts?

They wrote for Danny Thomas, Joey Bishop, ''The Dick Van Dyke Show,'' ''I Spy.'' They were hot guys in town. But on one occasion, recalled in Mr. Marshall's 1995 autobiography, ''Wake Me When It's Funny,'' a producer had a problem with their work.

title: Private Sector; Clinton White House Export: International Trade Lawyers
description: As United States trade representative in the Clinton administration, Charlene Barshefsky was at the center of some of the biggest successes -- and the one big mess -- of recent American economic diplomacy. She negotiated the deal between the United States and China that should usher Beijing into the World Trade Organization. She was also the ringmaster of the 1999 Seattle trade talks, which ended in chaos. She gained a reputation as a tough negotiator, who could parse the complexities of international trade law in language as colorful as her trademark Hrmes scarves. Now, after a cooling-off period at the Woodrow Wilson Center, she is going back to the practice of trade law -- this time at the Washington office of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering. Going with her is Robert T. Novick, general counsel of the trade representative's office.

title: Wrapping Nudity In a Cloak of Law
description: LAST year ''nude erotic dancing'' seemed to have become an officially endangered species in the United States. The Supreme Court gave localities the authority to ban all nude dancing in a First Amendment case, City of Erie v. Pap's A.M. (a nude dance club). The requirement of G-strings and pasties, the court said, is a minimal restriction that does not diminish the erotic message.

description: Fabio Taglioni, an engineer and designer who led the transformation of the Ducati motorcycle from its origins as cheap transportation for Italians after World War II to a glamorous, high-performance machine that won racing laurels and the hearts of legions of recreational riders around the world, died on July 18 in his home in Bologna. He was 80.

The move will give the consortium effective control of Telecom Italia, of which Olivetti owns 54 percent.

description: GROTSKY-Estelle. On July 28. Through laughter and song Estelle enriched our lives. She will be missed but always remembered and loved. Wife of the late Paul Grotsky. Sister of the late Saul Moss, Bill Moss, Freda Feuer, the late Carl Moss and Jack Moss. Aunt to nieces and nephews. Services to be held Monday, 1 PM, at the New Montefiore Cemetery. description: Susan S. Denison and Richard M. Caro Jr. were married yesterday evening by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBACKS
description: ROADS: Driving America's Great Highways, by Larry McMurtry. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.) This prolific author (23 novels and counting) cracks open a door on his own life as he crisscrosses the country, ruminating on anything that comes to his eye or mind. The mix includes odd facts, tributes to literary and historical figures and a quizzical look at the books in Hemingway's house in Key West. ''He has a reporter's eye, an affectionate ear for everyday speech and . . . a Dickensian storyteller's facility,'' Timothy Foote wrote here last year. Touchstone has also reissued Walter Benjamin at the Dairy Queen: Reflections at Sixty and Beyond ($12), a collection of personal essays in which McMurtry recalls his Texas childhood and laments what he sees as his failure to ''subvert'' some grand fallacies about the West. In 1999 our reviewer, Thomas Mallon, called this ''part memoir, part commonplace book, part tour de force.''

title: Identifying Diamonds in the Rough Is Scouts' Art
description: On this date a dozen years ago, the Texas Rangers, seven games out of first place in the American League West, decided to bolster their offense for the final two months of the season by adding a good left-handed hitter, Harold Baines. The Rangers were thinking particularly of the seven games they had left with the Oakland Athletics, a contending team with strong right-handed pitching.

title: Helping Vines to Reach Their Full Potential
description: ON a recent jaunt out to eastern Long Island, I stopped at a nursery in Water Mill and thought I'd walked into the hanging gardens of Babylon. A wall of flowering vines -- Thunbergia alata, or black-eyed Susan vine, that little, orange, round-petaled sweetie with a black dot in its center; pale green cobaea, or cup-and-saucer vine; and others I couldn't identify -- extended clear down the length of the greenhouse, from a pole about 20 feet up, right down to my feet.

title: Carole Gordon, Malcolm Stogo
description: Carole Sue Gordon and Malcolm Stogo are to be married today by Rabbi Roger Ross at their apartment in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGOBARDI, VIOLET
description: LONGOBARDI-Violet. Widow of Vincent, mother of Alice Givan, mother-in-law of Curtis, grandmother of Ben and Becky, died on July 25 at the age of 91. She was a longtime and committed member of Brooklyn Friends Meeting and worked devotedly for the Mary McDowell Center for Learning. She had a humane and loving spirit. Her family and friends will miss her. Memorial meeting to be held in early September. Those who wish may make contributions in her memory to the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, 20 Bergen St., Brooklyn, NY 11201.

title: Fun, Not Gay Rights, Is Issue at Scout Jamboree
description: ''We don't discuss it in front of the children,'' the Boy Scouts spokesman said simply of the issue of equal rights for gay people as more than 30,000 young teenagers settled in across 12,000 acres on this military post for the Scouts's quadrennial national jamboree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVRIN, TENA P.
description: GAVRIN-Tena P. July 26, 2001. Peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. She is survived by her youngest sister Deborah Almlof of Victor, NY, three sons David, Ira and Robert, eight grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. A memorial service on August 19 Temple Israel, New Rochelle.

description: The price tag on the cadaver's toe reads: $1,227. That's how much a study sponsored by Philip Morris said the Czech Republic saves on health care, pensions and housing every time a smoker dies.

description: EVERY time Milton M. Berger thinks about the first Montauk Jazz Festival, an event he and a friend dreamed up last September, he says he feels anxious.

title: The Graduate Meets the Slowdown
description: DURING my senior year of high school, I was often accosted by neighbors in my apartment building. ''Wow! I can't believe you're graduating,'' they'd say, invariably adding, ''Where are you going to college?'' For several months, I had to fake a smile, explain that I was still making a decision and act as if I actually remembered who these people were.

title: Bright Lights Aren't Necessarily Safer
description: I disagree with Richard M. Kessel, the Long Island Power Authority chairman, who cited the security benefits of outdoor lighting. As it applies to commercial properties, he is correct, but he is incorrect with respect to residential use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FESSLER, ADELE (NEE RUBINSTEIN)
description: FESSLER-Adele (nee Rubinstein). Of Concordia, Monroe Township, Cranbury, NJ died on Saturday July 21, 2001 age 81 at Princeton Hospital, where during her final week she was surrounded constantly by her children, grandchildren, spouses, infant great-grandson on her hospital 7th floor. She became ill early this year and at once dealt with determination directly and made the decisions required. Her youngest child, Dr. Henry Fessler of Towson, MD, physician and also in research at Johns Hopkins, Baltimore, coordinated medical specialists and her care at Princeton, Johns Hopkins and at home. She was predeceased thirteen years ago August 7, 1988 in Concordia by her cherished and talented husband, Abe. She was a full time working partner in his fur store in Morristown maintaining financial records, showroom sales, while he designed, sold, pursued sculpture and paintings which won prizes and taught adult art classes. Adele was an active office volunteer for many years at Jewish Family Services and remained a lifelong friend of neighbors in Brooklyn, Maplewood, Morristown, Concordia. She is survived by four children, Walter (Carol Blinder), Evelyn (Elliott) Marvel, Harriet (Marv) Goodman, Henry (Joan Meltzer), six grandchildren, Todd and Sari, Michael and Karen, Abigail and Emily, infant great-grandson Ryan Alperstein, younger sister Eleanor Marsh (Chicago), older sister Cecile Mitchell and her husband Sydney (New Rochelle and Manhattan). Adele danced ballet and a Dutch dance at age five in Manhattan's Town Hall and was photographed there together with the famous ballerina Anna Pavlova. In recent years she took frequent bus rides from Concordia to Lincoln Center for ballet matinees. Adele and Abe used to ski, golf, vacation in Florida and she was an incredible perpetual optimist and loved all her friends and relatives. The children and grandchildren have created professional careers and lifestyles in various cities. Adele's family legacy is to strive for education, live actively with grace, dignity, loving kindness and tremendous devotion to all. She will be remembered forever.

title: Private Sector; Hip-Hop and Green
description: It was not the typical environmental call to arms. Fans of the Beastie Boys may have seen a letter on the Web site of the group's founder that reads: ''Dear peoples, though I rarely do stuff like this, pestering the masses, this is a topic that is too vital, too central, and too important to our planet to ignore.''

title: A Face of Armstrong, But Not the Image
description: THE face, according to an old Latin tag, is the index of the soul. If that is true, then Louis Armstrong must have been the happiest of men, for everyone who met him was promptly and permanently disarmed by the warmth of his yard-wide smile; he was born a century ago this Saturday, and in all that time he appears to have made no enemies. The feeling was not necessarily mutual, though; Benny Goodman once made the mistake of high-hatting him at the start of a joint concert tour and was soon reduced to feigning a heart attack to escape the trumpeter's wrath.

title: A Garden's Splendor and a Menu's Meat
description: ALL we could think about as we watched an enormous, well-browned, thick-crusted pie being delivered to a nearby table was the old nursery rhyme about ''four and twenty blackbirds baked in a pie.''

title: Jones Easily Defends His Titles
description: The career of the light-heavyweight Roy Jones Jr. is beginning to enter dangerous territory for him. He is 32, and though boxers are now fighting into their 50's, he is old for a professional fighter. Worse, he is at the age when people begin to forget how great he used to be, and instead of appreciating his skill, there is a Roy Jones watch, a wait for him to make a misstep in the ring.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Independent Agencies Still Overshadow Franchises
description: WORRY that independent realty firms would vanish from the local landscape as national franchises grew has proved unfounded. And while signs bearing the names of GMAC, Prudential, Century 21, Coldwell Banker, ERA and Re/Max proliferate on front lawns across the county, the overwhelming majority of for-sale signs still belongs the small family-owned brokerages, the mom and pop companies with perhaps 10 or 12 sales representatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MARION APPELBAUM
description: KELLY-Marion Appelbaum. Beloved wife, cherished and adored mother-a true best friend. Honored & devoted grandmother. Loving and proud mother-in-law. An outstanding and charitable humanitarian. Loved by all who knew her. A magnificent woman who led an exemplary life. She was how people should be. The world has suffered a great loss. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the Multiple Myeloma Foundation.

title: NEWARK ARCHBISHOP NAMED
description: After an eight-month search, the Vatican announced last week the selection of Bishop John J. Myers of Peoria, Ill., to head the Archdiocese of Newark, the nation's seventh largest. Bishop Myers, 60, a canon lawyer and noted conservative, succeeds Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick, who led the archdiocese's 1.3 million Roman Catholics for 14 years before he was transfered to Washington, D.C. The choice of Bishop Myers came as something of a surprise in Newark, largely because he heads a much smaller diocese, one that is predominantly white and rural. By contrast, the Archdiocese of Newark is one of the nation's most diverse and impoverished.

title: Kyra Bartlett, Andrew Frank
description: Kyra Frances Kelly Bartlett, the daughter of Madelyn M. Shields of Beverly Farms, Mass., and Leslie D. Bartlett of Gloucester, Mass., was married yesterday to Andrew Johnston Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Frank Jr. of Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Wendel W. Meyer performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-29-01: On Language; Connect!
description: Why did the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Joseph Ellis, whose accuracy in writing about the framers of the Constitution remains unchallenged, tell his students fanciful fabrications about his supposed military service in Vietnam?

title: Not Quite Ignored
description: To the Editor:

title: 24 Hours of All 'Moby-Dick,' All the Time
description: FOR many people, reading Herman Melville's ''Moby-Dick'' was not an event. It was an assigned task, performed alone. But this week, for 24 hours straight from noon Tuesday until noon Wednesday, the book will be presented in a different way as Mystic Seaport stages its annual marathon reading of the American classic on the last surviving American wooden whaling vessel, the Charles W. Morgan.

title: The Flowering of an Amagansett Sleeper
description: THIS is the time when the sun is warm, the sea breezes are cool and life is good on the East End. Many of the folks who feel mellow, relaxed and rested after an easygoing day at the beach or on the deck and want to continue their laid-back ways at dinner are unwinding at Ocean's Grillfish & Steak in Amagansett (631-267-6980). Unlike the glitzy, celebrity-centered, expensive, often loud and crowded tourist palace Hamptons restaurants, Ocean's is a spiffy yet informal tropical beachcomber, a couple of hundred yards across the dunes from the Atlantic along the Napeague stretch at 2095 Montauk Highway.

title: Man of a Thousand Faces
description: People recognize Paul Giamatti in public sometimes, but they're not always sure why. ''It's a weird thing,'' says the actor, whose roles have stretched from Andrei Prozorov, the spineless brother in Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' to Pig Vomit in Howard Stern's ''Private Parts'' to a nefarious orangutan who trades human slaves in Tim Burton's new ''Planet of the Apes.'' ''A lot of the time people don't quite know where they know me from. They're not necessarily thinking that I'm a movie actor.''

title: Approaching Energy Needs From a Sensible Perspective
description: Peter Maniscalco's opinion essay, ''Same Old Unwise Ideas on Energy'' [July 15] is an interesting collection of opinions and fables. Explaining our recent political climate regarding Shoreham with references to mythology is clever but useless.

title: Sharon Sieber, Robert Copps
description: Sharon Elizabeth Sieber and Robert Edmund Copps were married yesterday by the Rev. William P. Saunders at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Easy Energy Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Can the Life of the Party Succeed as a City Innkeeper?
description: LULU DE KWIATKOWSKI, the airplane heiress and fabric designer, loves Jeff Klein. So does Rachel Peters, Irving Berlin's granddaughter and a fledgling film producer. Ditto for Ginny Bond, an actress and heir to a Texas oil fortune, who refers to Mr. Klein as merely ''the most incredible human being on the planet.''

title: MUNICIPAL WORKERS' SALARIES
description: The census figures released last week also found that New Jersey's municipal workers were the fourth-highest paid in the nation with an average salary of $45,288 based on figures from March 2000. New Jersey's 315,973 municipal employees rank behind those in the District of Columbia, in New York and California. Teachers in New Jersey's elementary and high schools, considered part of the municipal work force by the bureau purposes, are the highest paid in the nation with an average salary of $51,840. The second highest are Connecticut teachers, with California and New York close behind.

title: So, Technology Pros, What Comes After the Fall?
description: THE American economy may or may not be in a recession -- but the information technology industry surely is, with no sign of an upturn. Lately, Silicon Valley, fabled for its invention, its can-do mentality and its dot-com fever, is looking a lot less fabled.

title: Sitting Idle, Capriati Moves Up to No. 2
description: Jennifer Capriati moved up to No. 2 in the Sanex WTA Tour rankings on Friday without playing a match.

title: Wolfgang's Sister
description: The subject of Sharon Chmielarz's virtuoso new poetry collection, THE OTHER MOZART (Ontario Review Press/Norton, $21.95), was a classical music prodigy, called ''a little master'' of the art, who performed for royal 18th-century audiences. But this Mozart -- Maria Anna, nicknamed Nannerl -- is remembered mostly for being the older sister, by four years, of Wolfgang Amadeus. Nannerl was a budding composer as well as a performer; her own extraordinary career ended at 18, when the children's ambitious father, Leopold, foresaw that Wolfgang, as a boy, would enjoy a far more lucrative career, and poured all the family resources into making him a star. Drawing heavily from the Mozart family's letters, Chmielarz creates a marvelously effective fusion of biography and poetry: 65 lyric poems tell an engrossing chronological story while standing on their own for their elegant language and lending rich musicality and imaginative license to their subject. In an array of free verse styles, a chorus of distinctive voices speak: from patriarch Leopold, with his gruff odes to wealth (''Money is / the point of music'') to boyish, headstrong Wolfgang (''what else, Nannerl . . . could I have done?''). But Nannerl's deftly modulating voice is the lead, by turns funny, frustrated, ribald, joyous and bitter, as she plainly recognizes that, for Wolfgang, she is ''a tax on his conscience.'' She ultimately teaches music (''A note is a shard / Of a thought''), falls in love and adapts to an unhappy marriage of convenience (''my first-born planted like a talent''). Ultimately, the collection's scope and sophisticated artistry resemble a symphony's, and the tone struck is movingly elegiac. Megan Harlan

title: Shakeout in Fiber Optics
description: On Thursday JDS Uniphase, a company specializing in fiber-optic communications, announced what may be the biggest loss in corporate history -- $50.6 billion for the last fiscal year. In early 2000, before using its stock to buy several competing companies that proved to be vastly overvalued, JDS Uniphase had a market capitalization in excess of $200 billion. Today it is worth about $11 billion. Most of its competitors -- including such giants as Agilent, Alcatel, Corning, Lucent and Nortel -- have also plunged in value. The excessive optimism that boosted share prices is only partly to blame. A slow-developing, less-than-competitive market for consumer communications also blocked the way. That part of the equation, at least, bears improving.

title: Children's Books
description: This

title: What to Do When the Novelty of a Tattoo Wears Off
description: YOU'VE got a tattoo, but now what?

title: July 22-28; Killer, 14, Gets 28 Years
description: On the last day of class in May 2000, Nathaniel Brazill, 13, was suspended for throwing water balloons at his middle school in South Florida. He returned to school with a gun, and, after his favorite teacher, Barry Grunow, 35, refused to let him into his classroom to say goodbye to two girls, Nathaniel opened fire. Nathaniel, now 14, has been sentenced to 28 years in prison without parole, and ordered to earn a high school equivalency diploma and enroll in an anger management course. The case, along with that of another 14-year-old convicted of murder, Lionel Tate, has raised questions about Florida's harsh treatment of young criminals. Dana Canedy

title: Our Towns; To Senecas, Casinos Cut Deep and Open Old Wounds
description: THE prospect of casino gambling in western New York is breeding political intrigue in Albany. All the big names and powerful forces are arrayed on various sides, posturing, threatening, offering to trade chits for chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, MARGARET CREAL
description: SHAFER-Margaret Creal. The Bard College community deeply mourns the passing of Margaret Creal Shafer, a longtime friend and integral member of the Bard family and the Hudson Valley cultural community. Her vitality, creativity and energy have played an essential role in the life of the college and of the surrounding communities. She will be deeply missed. Our condolences go out to her children, grandchildren, and great grandchild. Services will be held at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, in Barrytown, New York on Saturday, August 4th. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab, II, Chairman

title: Ciao, Italy. Having a Great Time Here. You Could Be, Too.
description: ''When you are in the Big Apple, you must be careful about the girls,'' said Stefano Spadoni. ''They are very dangerous.''

title: U.S. List Warns Of Trouble Spots
description: IT has never been as easy or as affordable to travel the world as it is today, but headlines of faraway wars, crime, insurrections, terrorist attacks, diseases and natural disasters can be enough to make the average tourist think twice.

title: The Battle Lines Of the Mommy Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; A Hillside Where Nature Ruled
description: THE hillside looks terrible,'' said our visitor, a matronly Westchesterite who had dropped by one Sunday afternoon soon after we moved up to Larchmont from the city. ''It's so scraggly -- all those trees coming up in the middle of the irises. You really have to do something about it.''

title: Approaching Energy Needs From a Sensible Perspective
description: The practical consequence of Peter Maniscalco's approach is quite elitist. Only those of means will be able to afford the spiraling energy prices and the sharp downturn of the economy that is sure to be the consequence of the policies he advocates.

title: Xenia, Paleolithic Princess
description: THE SEVEN DAUGHTERS

title: The Mosquito Herself
description: Consider the most common mosquito on earth, one that is likely resting in somedark corner of your very own home or, if you are reading in bed on a warm summer evening, about to issue its faint buzz--do you hear it right now?--in your ear.

title: Losses Mount at Kansai While the Airport Sinks
description: WHEN it opened to great fanfare in 1994, Kansai International Airport in Japan was widely regarded as an engineering marvel. Situated atop a 1,300-acre artificial island in the bay off Osaka, Japan's second largest city, it was the first large-scale airport to be built on reclaimed land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVER, GERTRUDE
description: KRAVER-Gertrude. Of Delray Beach, FL, on July 25, 2001. Loving wife of Charles, sister of Marjorie, sister-in-law of Richard, Henry and Moe, aunt of Adam. Private service Mt. Ararat Sunday, July 29.

title: Astrophotography
description: Astrophotography is a special adaptation of ordinary photography. Some interesting photographs of stars can be made even with inexpensive equipment. A fixed 35-millimeter camera is mounted on a sturdy tripod. The camera shutter is opened to the widest aperture or f-stop. Focus the lens at infinity. A fast film with a rating above 400 should be used to record the greatest number of stars.

title: Translating the Body Language of Success
description: RAYMOND C. McGRAIME describes himself as a secret agent, someone who works in the shadows. He grins when he says this so that his listeners -- on this afternoon about 140 businesspeople convened at the Sheraton Long Island in Smithtown -- understand that he is stretching a point. His real message is this: Over the next hour he intends to teach them some basic nonverbal communication skills that, when applied with skill and discretion, could help them rise to the top.

title: Letter: Chang, Kogan, Ma
description: Music and Learning To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISKOVSKY, IRENE
description: LISKOVSKY-Irene, 92. On July 25, 2001. Formerly of Fort Lee, NJ. Devoted wife of the late Charles Liskovsky. Mother of George and Lenore Brager and Isaac and the late Evelyn Levine. Grandmother of Amy, Robert, Simma and Mark.

title: Company Says $3 Million Was Paid to Supplier's Wife
description: Executives at Surge Components in Deer Park announced last week that during the past winter unnamed ''management personnel'' had made $3 million in payments to a supplier's wife in return for what it described as help obtaining components.

title: France Tops List For Most Clean Beaches
description: France leads the way this year in the 2001 Blue Flag awards for clean shores, with 403 beaches and 85 marinas earning the distinction -- the most of the 21 European countries represented in the survey. Among those honored are several beaches in Antibes and Cap-d'Ail on the Riviera. Last year, France received only 107 of these awards after a TotalFinaElf oil tanker shipwreck fouled miles of coast.

title: Reaching Out, and Inching Back
description: In a state as conservative as Virginia, it is not easy to run for office as a Democrat. But Mark R. Warner, a former Democratic state chairman, is having a try at it. He is running for governor.

title: Mets Capitalize on a Familiar Wendell Habit
description: Turk Wendell got the sign from Todd Pratt as Robin Ventura waited in the batter's box. This was Shea Stadium in Flushing, not Thomas J. White Stadium in Port St. Lucie, Fla. This was a regular-season game, not a spring training intra squad tuneup. This was bizarre.

description: This

title: Roadies
description: FLIGHT OF THE SWAN

title: Helping Vines to Reach Potentials
description: ON a recent jaunt out to eastern Long Island, I stopped at a nursery in Water Mill and thought I'd walked into the hanging gardens of Babylon. A wall of flowering vines  Thunbergia alata, or black-eyed Susan vine, that little, orange, round-petaled sweetie with a black dot in its center; pale green cobaea, or cup-and-saucer vine; and others I couldn't identify  extended clear down the length of the greenhouse, from a pole about 20 feet up, right down to my feet.

title: Who Will Win in November? For Starters, the State Police
description: Richard Nixon was a master at sifting through the ashes of self-inflicted defeat and finding the seeds of some future triumph. Deng Xiaoping survived three purges before becoming China's communist dictator. But even those towering figures in the pantheon of political comebacks would have to marvel at the attempted rehabilitation under way on behalf of the Good Ol' Boys Network of the New Jersey State Police.

title: Sara Ely, Alex Hulse
description: Sara Sterling Ely, a daughter of Stephen Ely of Locust Valley, N.Y., and the late Susan Barclay Ely, was married yesterday to Robert Alexander Hulse, the son of Nancy Nicholson of Onteora Park, N.Y., and Robert D. Hulse of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: Driving Mrs. Kaplan
description: WHILE being driven to the cemetery, 85-year-old Esther M. Kaplan, Polish-born and Mount Vernon-raised, kept her fellow travelers entertained with tales of her love life.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: PIPE DREAM

title: A Chance to Reconnect For Mentally Ill Addicts
description: Brandi Wells set off from her Upper West Side apartment for East Harlem on Thursday night fighting memories of a decade of failure. With a mixture of hope and dread churning her stomach, Ms. Wells, a 28-year-old artist with cascading brown hair and freckled skin, told herself that tonight, her sad crusade would end differently.

title: Letters
description: Lisa Belkin's article on a girl who topped 130 pounds at age 3 prompted some readers to offer their own diagnoses. Others asserted that separating the child from her parents was not the cure, no matter the cause. As to what to do about Japan's affluent "parasite singles," why not turn them into No. 1 aunts?

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-29-01: The Ethicist; Tipping Points
description: My fiance works as a waitress at a high-end restaurant where the wait staff must pool their tips and split the pot each night. This is meant to give everyone the same amount of money and to nurture teamwork. The problem is, some waiters pocket part of their tips, unfairly taking a greater share of the night's money. Should she start doing the same or continue to lead by example? Anonymous, New York

title: QUICK BITE/Monroe Township; Over the Verrazano to Your Table
description: A newly transplanted couple from Hoboken learned the easy way one recent Sunday why Bella Italia pork store and catering establishment in Monroe Township, Middlesex County, is developing a reputation as a personal-service store. ''We were clueless people asking for help,'' said Deborah Maston. ''They offered to pound out my chicken cutlets,'' she said of the owner, Giovanni Sgroi, and his son, John Jr. Her husband, Jason, added: ''They showed me the difference between cans of special tomato sauce.'' The Sgrois came to Jersey nine months ago after operating J&J Meats in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn for 27 years. Many former Brooklynites find Mr. Sgroi, and ask, ''What are you doing here?'' What he is doing is offering such items as fresh mozzarella, prepared dishes like rigatoni and filleto di pomodoro ($2.99 a serving), broccoli rape ($4.50), spinach or whole-wheat pasta with garlic ($4.99)-- ready for take-out, perhaps to one of the tables outside. It is a store to which he and his family -- his wife, Maria; his sons, John Jr. and Sal; and his daughter, Anna Maria -- commute each day from Staten Island. The essence of the venture is captured by an unofficial slogan: ''A little from Italy, a little from Brooklyn, a little for Jersey.''

title: Political Briefing; Seeking Imperfection? Here's Your Man
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas has enjoyed mainly high job-approval ratings since he took office five years ago. But in that period, Mr. Huckabee, a Republican, has committed several gaffes, verbal and otherwise, and with re-election only 15 months off, the buzz in Little Rock is that those slips could be rich fodder for his political enemies.

title: INVESTING WITH/Kathryn D. Beyer and Jeffrey D. Lorenzen; Vintage Bond Fund
description: THE Victorian mansion built in 1896 for a banker in Des Moines provides appropriate offices for Kathryn D. Beyer and Jeffrey D. Lorenzen, co-managers of the $40 million Vintage Bond fund.

description: To the Sports Editor,

title: Barbara Fisher, Jack Resnick
description: Barbara Alice Fisher and Dr. Jack Alan Resnick were married on Thursday by Cantor Daniel Rous at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.

title: The View From/Fairfield; For Y.M.C.A. Instructors, It's Have Pool, Will Travel
description: IT is a sunny day and Colin Noonan, his turtle-print swim trunks flapping, is making a beeline for the in-ground swimming pool in the backyard of his friend George. But a few feet from the edge he is stopped in his tracks.

title: The Nation; Another Reason Mr. Smith Goes to Washington
description: LIKE the rest of America's proud workforce, the nation's federal representatives rise each day and stride into their appointed rounds, heaving committee gavels, breaking down gridlock and greasing the gears of democracy. Quite unlike most of the workforce, however -- even other federal employees -- Congress members can look beyond their years of sweat and toil toward a fully cost-of-living adjusted, rapidly accruing retirement plan.

title: A Do-It-Yourselfer Takes On Home Depot
description: WALK into a Home Depot during the day, and one thing may strike you by its inescapable presence, another by its conspicuous absence.

title: Area's Pigeon Racers Are a Dying Breed
description: THREE years ago, Rami Ghrewati's neighbor in Mount Kisco discovered that he kept 100 pigeons on his property and complained to town officials. After several appearances before the zoning appeals board, Mr. Ghrewati won the right to keep his coop, but the legal reprieve may turn out to be a Pyrrhic victory.

title: London
description: With its resurgent South Bank, London -- always one of Europe's great walking cities -- now offers visitors a new array of paths to stroll along the Thames while enjoying views of the city and its constantly changing architecture.

description: To the Editor:

title: Maria Perunic, George Djurasovic
description: Maria Christine Perunic, a daughter of Miriana Perunic of Williston Park, N.Y., and the late George Perunic, is to be married today to George Djurasovic, a son of Mara Dobric Djurasovic and Milenko Djurasovic of Union, N.J. The Rev. Djokan Majstorovic will perform the ceremony at the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava in New York.

title: Where the Cell Antennas Are Sprouting in Churches
description: CELL phone antennas have been affixed to churches in every corner of Connecticut. Here is a list of some of the other churches housing antennas.

title: Suzanne Jacobson, Matthew Kirsch
description: Suzanne Beth Jacobson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Kenneth Jacobson of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Matthew Laurence Kirsch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Bruce Kirsch of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Hewitt Greene officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Children's News Service Collapses
description: Children's Express burst on the scene at the 1976 Democratic National Convention, when a 13-year-old reporter scooped the national media with Jimmy Carter's choice of Walter F. Mondale as his running mate. And in 1988, it was an 11-year-old Children's Express reporter who discomfited Dan Quayle with a question about whether a girl raped by her father should be able to get an abortion: that year, the group's campaign coverage won an Emmy and a Peabody Award.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT'S a crime that only people who manage to go to the theater know August Wilson's work. At least THE PIANO LESSON (1995), his second Pulitzer Prize-winning drama (the first was ''Fences''), was made into a television movie. Charles Dutton stars as Boy Willie, who has driven in a watermelon truck from Sunflower, Miss., to Pittsburgh to talk his sister, Berniece (Alfre Woodard), into selling the piano so he can buy some very important cotton land. If Berniece is reluctant, she has good reason. The piano was bought by the owners of their slave-forebears for the price of two of those forebears, and its carvings are of the black family's members and events. The next generation ''stole'' the piano, and Berniece's father died in a fire because of it. Lloyd Richards directed both the film and the original Broadway production -- Sunday and Wednesday at 9 p.m., Thursday at noon on Odyssey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACHNES, ELEANOR, M.D.
description: YACHNES-Eleanor, M.D. July 29, 2000. She loved analysis, synthesis and everything in-between. We miss her everyday. Her children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, LAURENCE BREEN
description: CLARKE-Laurence Breen. Of Manhattan, passed away suddenly on Friday, July 20, 2001 at New York Presbyterian Hospital after a brief but valiant struggle with leukemia. Born in New York City in 1924 of William J. Clarke and Grace Breen Clark. Educated at Collegiate School in Manhattan, Yale University, B.A. and Master's in International Relations '45W and Columbia Law School '49. He served honorably in the U.S. Navy during W.W. II, rising to the rank of Lieutenant, commanding a Sub Chaser in the Pacific Theater. He was a retired civil trial attorney and also enjoyed an operatic career. He was a member of the U.N. Association, Yale Club, University Glee Club, Council of the Americas, The Navy League, Amateur Comedy Club, Military of Foreign Wars and was a Commander in the Naval Order. Survived and very much loved by his son William J. Clarke, his daughter Lauren Clarke-Bennett and grandson Taylor Clarke Bennett. Memorial services to be on Thursday, August 2nd, 2001, at 10:30AM in the Chapel of Saint Bartholomew's Church, where he was a member. Following the service, he will be laid to rest at Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to either the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 212 448-9206 or the Navy League Scholarship Fund 212-825-7333 will be appreciated.

title: Ansel Adams, the Artist Who Preceded the Celebrity
description: ANSEL ADAMS died 17 years ago, yet an endless stream of posters, calendars, books and computer screen savers have made his photographs of thundering crags and glittering groves seem more popular than ever. Now an exhibition commemorating Adams's 100th birthday -- the first major reassessment of America's best loved photographer since his death -- seeks to rescue Adams from ubiquity and reclaim him for high art.

title: Very Expectantly Yours
description: The incidence of twin births has climbed more than 55 percent over the last 20 years, and department stores are now packaging some baby supplies to meet the two-fold challenge. Baby Gap provides shopping guidelines: for instance, four to six bodysuits for a single baby, eight for twins. F.A.O. Schwarz, which opened its F.A.O. Baby department last spring, helps the expectant put together twin layettes, including bedding, outfits and toys ($200 to $500 each). For the full duo-deluxe treatment, Saks Fifth Avenue has started offering custom-made layettes for multiples, above. After asking prospective parents key questions (''Do you have household help? How often will you do laundry? Are you scheduled for an early delivery?''), consultants help determine the correct sizes and quantities of snap undershirts, one-piece outfits, bibs, towels and the like. The clothes are packed in identical white Moses baskets, along with desired baby accessories like stuffed animals and blankets. To top it off, there is a kind of twin discount: a $350 single layette will run $600 for twins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAZ, ZELL HURLBERT
description: DRAZ-Zell Hurlbert. Of Concord and Truro, MA, July 26. Mother of Douglas of South Egremont, MA, Christian of Boston, Griswold and his wife Heather of Wellfleet, MA. Also survived by two grandsons, Emmett and Julian, both of Wellfleet. Memorial service Saturday, Sepember 29th, at 11AM in the First Parish in Concord. Family requests that donations in her memory be made to American Friends Service Committee, 2161 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02140. Joseph Dee & Son Funeral Service, Concord.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Donna McMahon's ambitious first novel, DANCE OF KNIVES (Tor/Tom Doherty, $25.95), takes place in a 22nd-century Vancouver some 50 years after an unspecified ''Collapse'' has altered the city almost beyond recognition. Amid rubble left by riots and worse, ever-shifting alliances of occupational guilds, street gangs and paramilitary groups maintain an uneasy order.

title: Is the Bush Energy Policy the Right One?
description: All sides of the political spectrum were well represented this week but the most common and loudest refrain came from those who decried Bush's energy policy is short-sighted at best, and greedy at worst. Readers frequently cited Bush and Cheney's links to the oil and coal Industries. The wounds of Florida were fresh as Bush's legitimacy to make policy was also questioned.

title: Looking Deep Into Lyme, And Ahead to New Galleries
description: THE current exhibition at the Florence Griswold museum opened in February and will close in November, a noticeable departure for a museum that customarily schedules several shows a year. But it is a show for all seasons. Its subject is not just the art produced at the Lyme Art Colony, but rather a consideration of the entire picture, one that embraces geography and entomology, as well as the rich social history of the Lyme area.

title: Letters: The Battle Lines of the Mommy Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Habitats/Upper West Side; For an Ex-Miss America, A New Role: Ownership
description: WHEN the tears are flowing and the crown is being settled onto the head of the new Miss America, no one ever thinks about what happens later, after the year of stardom.

title: The Big Business Of Fond Farewells
description: WHEN the final episode of the long-running sitcom ''M*A*S*H'' finished on Feb. 28, 1983, the flow in two of New York City's water mains reportedly increased by 320 million gallons.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARFUNKEL, CARRIE
description: GARFUNKEL-Carrie. We miss you more each year, as time goes by. Your loving children and grandchildren.

description: Alexis Ford Audette, a daughter of Anna Held Audette and Louis Girard Audette of New Haven, was married yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., to Sanjiv Gururaja Rao, a son of Shanta and Gururaja Rao of San Luis Obispo, Calif. Betty Olson-Jones, a friend of the couple's, officiated, having been appointed a deputy marriage commissioner for the wedding by Alameda County, Calif.

title: A Weaker Dollar Could Help the U.S. (and Europe)
description: MERCK, McDonald's and Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing provide reminders of how the strong dollar is making matters worse for American investors by eating into sales and earnings.

title: Divers Find Body in Rockaway Drownings
description: A body recovered by divers yesterday about a mile from the shore at Far Rockaway, Queens, was identified as one of the three New Jersey girls who drowned when they were overtaken by a strong current as they swam in the Atlantic Ocean last week, the police said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Neverland and Beyond
description: COOL FOR YOU

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, PHILIP WALSH
description: MOORE-Philip Walsh. Age 81, died in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. July 18, 2001 after a short illness. He is survived by his devoted wife, Phaedra; daughter Jourdan Houston, (Colorado); son Thomas Moore, (Miami); son Ned Moore, (Virginia); six grandchildren; and sister Louise Immer of Thun, Switzerland. He was preceded in death by his son, Philip Moore, Jr. A private family service is planned at the Moore mausoleum in Burmont, Pennsylvania.

title: 'Hunt for Strikes'
description: To the Sports Editor,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURSEL, EROL, M.D.
description: GURSEL-Erol, M.D. On July 20, 2001. He was born in Istanbul, Turkey, June 20, 1931. He grew up in Turkey and came to the U.S. in 1961. He attended medical school in Istanbul and continued his medical education in New York. He completed great contributions to medicine. He is survived by his loving wife Sevgi, son Ali, daughter Sumru, son-in-law Ahmet, daughter-in-law Diane, grandson Malik and granddaughter Sevgi. He was a giving and devoted person to all. While he will be greatly missed his legacy will live on through the lives he touched. A memorial service was held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, New York, on July 22.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-29-01; Aftershock
description: People who live in Birmingham, Ala., are shocked when they hear it described as a bad, bad place. Their experience is just the opposite. One day this spring, I returned late from lunch to the trial of Thomas E. Blanton Jr., a former Ku Klux Klansman charged with the murder of the four black Sunday-school girls who died in a bomb blast at the 16th Street Baptist Church on Sept. 15, 1963. At the courtroom door, a guard stopped me. ''Your mother wants you to know that she's going to be sitting downstairs,'' he whispered. Later, as the defense attorney headed out to meet the international press, he paused and said solicitously, ''Diane, your mom's looking for you.''

title: Marching Through Georgia
description: SHERMAN

title: A Landscape Designer's Hideaway
description: EVEN in a city as spectacular as Rio, a time comes when you feel you just have to get away from it all, if only for a few hours. So early one recent Sunday morning my wife, Clotilde, and I got into our car and headed west along the coast from our apartment in Ipanema, past the Sun Belt-inspired suburban sprawl and clutter of the Barra da Tijuca until we reached a tranquil green refuge known as the Stio Roberto Burle Marx.

title: Mets' Trades Indicate Recovery From Illusion
description: Displaying admirable consistency, the Mets began play yesterday 30th out of 30 major league teams in runs scored, 30th in batting average, 30th in total bases, 30th in slugging percentage, 28th in home runs and 28th in runners left on base. They stand today as the only team in the majors that has scored fewer than 400 runs this season.

title: 'The Rackets'
description: Days like this Jimmy Dolan figured he had the best job in the world. He stood on the side porch of Gracie Mansion and watched as the sun began to rise behind Hell Gate Bridge. The waters of the East and Harlem rivers met in a turbulent swirl imbued with the soft, encroaching light of dawn. A seagull wheeled overhead, then dove for prey in the wake of a police boat. He checked his watch, then sipped his steaming coffee. The liquid warmed him, and absentmindedly he picked a piece of lint off the front of his navy blue suit jacket. Election year in the Apple and he was right in the mix.

title: 'Dante'
description: Dante the Florentine

title: By the Sea, Writing Mothers Need Not Choose
description: This house tells a story about writing and mothering. It tells of women who bring children here to try their hand at both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, BERNICE LEWIN
description: SCHREIBER-Bernice Lewin. On July 26, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of Selina Morris and Ken Grinspoon, Lenore Schreiber and Charles Figg, Scott and Evelyn Schreiber. Dear sister of Robert Lewin. Adoring grandmother of Jessica, Pamela and Mark, Eric and Tera & Michael. Visiting Sunday 6-8 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Graveside service Monday 10 AM at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. The family will receive at the home of Selina Morris.

title: Off the Road With Kerouac In Northport
description: AFTER the long-delayed publication of his book ''On the Road'' in 1957, Jack Kerouac was suddenly a famous author. By the summer of 1960, when he left Northport on a cross-country train trip to San Francisco, he was the media-anointed king of the beatniks.

title: Concerts and Cobblestones In Olinda
description: THE ancient church-stuffed, art-crazed town of Olinda, four miles north of Recife in the Brazilian state of Pernambuco, can be a refreshing change of pace for travelers in Brazil. For those seeking a break from the thong-focused Brazilian beach culture, Olinda, once a place of landowners rich from the sugar trade, is a place for spectacular walks along hilly cobblestone streets, and has no beach where you would ever want to swim. Those overwhelmed by the high-pitched frivolity of Rio, the sheer size and cultural depth of Salvador or the grittiness of So Paulo can master Olinda's 300-acre-wide old colonial town in about a two-hour walk, which can and should be followed by a dip in a hotel pool.

title: DataBank; In 2nd-Quarter Declines, 3rd-Quarter Worries
description: Stocks were buffeted last week by a spate of dismal second-quarter earnings reports that led many investors to conclude that the third quarter would be no better and could be worse. But some still held out hope for a turnaround in the final three months of the year.

title: Jennifer Marell, Mark Pawlak
description: Jennifer Deane Marell and Mark Walter Pawlak were married last evening by Rabbi Phyllis M. Shapiro at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Case Pits Tadition Against Move to Enforce the Rules
description: BANGKOK — In Thailand's slow- motion revolution from the rule of men to the rule of law, the test ahead could not be more stark.

title: The Renaissance Man Is a Giants Linebacker
description: Dhani Jones (pronounced da-HAH-ni) is one of those rare athletes whose scope, vision and interests transcend football, a 23-year-old Giants linebacker who worked for the Loews Corporation as a sales and marketing intern this summer, a painter, a model, a photographer, a guy who dabbles in woodwork and in the music business, where he is building a company called Headbanger Records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOYCE W.
description: GREENE-Joyce W. Died at home in NYC, July 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur B., mother of Jonathan M., and mother-in-law of Denise. She was one of the greatest ladies ever; she was respected for her wit and generosity. She was a friend and caretaker of all animals. Joyce was born in England, 1933. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, August 1st, 7-9 PM, with funeral services Thursday, August 2nd, 5:30 PM. Interment in England. Memorial services will be scheduled at a future date. In lieu of flowers, gifts may given in the name of Joyce W. Greene to the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, 410 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016; 212-532-4455.

title: Spy Charges Still Puzzle Freed Chinese Scholar
description: Almost every year since 1989, Gao Zhan has returned to her native China, mainly to visit her elderly parents in Nanjing. Her father is seriously ill with a bad heart.

title: The Alchemy of OxyContin
description: Paula is taking me on a driving tour of Man, the tiny West Virginia town where she has spent her entire life. Because I don't know my way around the hollows and gullies and creeks that carve through these hills, Paula is at the wheel. And because Paula isn't a morning person, we've set out on our tour at midnight. It's dark; the only illumination comes from our headlights cutting through the mist that rolls down from the hills.

title: When Hospitals Shop Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: The Nation: Social Security Check; It's Agreed: We Have a Crisis. Unless We Don't.
description: DEBATES about changing Social Security are invariably ideological, political and even emotional. But they are also technical, involving complicated financial calculations. And when slash-and-burn partisanship meets trust-fund accounting, the result is sure to be confusing -- and perhaps disheartening -- to anyone with a stake in the retirement program.

title: America on the Sidelines
description: During the presidential campaign, George W. Bush often said that a country as powerful as the United States should be humble in its relations with other nations. That was good advice, but since taking office Mr. Bush has shown a surprising disdain for the kinds of treaties and international agreements that set the tone for America's engagement with the world and that have figured prominently in Washington's foreign policy for most of the years since World War II. The administration's hostile attitude communicates a sense of arrogance and contempt for international cooperation that ill serves American interests.

title: Investing Diary: A Shrinking Credit Club
description: Increased competition and a greater willingness to take on debt have cost all but a handful of of American companies their triple-A credit ratings, according to Moody's Investors Service.

title: Secrets and Lies
description: BLUE DIARY

title: Finally, a Very Scary Bridge Is Being Replaced
description: LIKE most commuters who must cross over the Sikorsky Bridge driving to work, John Bimonte has his own tale to tell from his 11 years of riding in his Lincoln Continental along Route 15 from North Haven to his job in both Stamford and Bridgeport.

title: Investing; Recreational Vehicle Makers See Gold in a Graying Market
description: SHARES of many big makers of recreational vehicles have soared recently, and many analysts say the stocks of at least some of the companies are likely to keep climbing.

title: Sports of The Times; Pinch-Hitter Longing To Be Everyday Player
description: THIS is not how things were supposed to turn out in Metland.

title: These Pajamas Never Sleep
description: Pajama bottoms from Le Meridien Hotel in Beverly Hills have been transformed into outerwear for conspicuous communicators. In black or white, the cotton-knit pants have three pockets with embroidered lettering for Le Pager, Le Phone and Le PalmPilot. Introduced for ''V.I.P. guests,'' they began to show up in Sunset Boulevard clubs and at the Starbucks in Brentwood. They became available a few weeks ago in Le Meridien's gift shop (310 246-2018) for $39.95, and more than 1,000 pairs have been sold.

title: The Future Is a Foreign Country
description: WILSON'S GHOST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENHAUS, MINNIE
description: ROSENHAUS-Minnie, 83. Of West Palm Beach, FL, died July 26, 2001. Survived by husband Mac, sister Celia, children Bunny, Elaine and Gerald, 8 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. Funeral service at ''Gutterman's,'' Woodbury, L.I. at 1PM today. Contributions may be made to Boca Friends for Cancer Research, attention: Roberta, 561-498-0014.

description: Anonymous Anchor

title: A 3rd Consecutive Victory Puts Benjamin Out in Front
description: Three of this year's seven co-winners of the World Open Tournament in Philadelphia are establishing an informal club of would-be monopolizers of this series. For Aleksandr Goldin of Russia, this was his second victory in four attempts. For Alexander Ivanov of Massachusetts, it was his second triumph in a row. But Joel Benjamin of Manhattan is in the lead with three consecutive victories.

description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.)

title: Ram's Horn Sounds at Club And Old Walls Still Stand
description: On the stage of the Knitting Factory in Lower Manhattan, Jeremiah Lockwood, the lead musician for Sway Machinery, breaks into a long solo wail created by blowing a shofar, quite literally a ram's horn. Usually heard only inside synagogues on High Holy Days, the shofar last left an enduring mark on a broader audience back when Joshua blew down the walls of Jericho.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 15 about the photographer Sebastiao Salgado's five favorite photographs omitted a byline. The reporter was Liz Welch.

title: Ultraviolet Light, an Old Friend With a New Use
description: Ultraviolet light makes fingernail polish dry faster. It binds polymers so that ink from glossy magazines doesn't rub off on readers' hands. And for many years, particularly in Europe, it has been used as a primary treatment for water systems to kill bacteria and viruses.

title: A Chance To Shine
Bosoms and Buses: Memories of 50's New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Danielle Hurlburt, Jeremy Galland
description: Danielle Lee Hurlburt, the daughter of Roxaina and Danny Hurlburt of Lowville, N.Y., was married there yesterday at her parents' dairy farm to Jeremy Rubin Galland, a son of Nora and Alvin Galland of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Joseph McGuire, the Lewis County judge and surrogate, officiated.

title: Watching Her Weight
description: No one can explain why 4-year-old Anamarie Regino is twice the average height for her age, but her doctors focused solely on her weight, blamed her parents for ''overfeeding'' her and ultimately removed her, screaming, from her family (Lisa Belkin, July 8).

title: A Small Place Reaches for Ballet's Big Time
description: THIS little country, only two-thirds the size of Florida, has one of the most bustling of Asia's ''tiger'' economies. Its capital city, with a financial district bristling with postmodern skyscrapers in a machismo display of international clout, has long had its eye on the future. Except, that is, in one particular -- and, to many eyes, peculiar -- instance: classical ballet.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: 'Cleopatra' on DVD: Extravagant, Except in Quality
description: CLEOPATRA." More than two years in the making. A cast of thousands. Starring Elizabeth Taylor, Rex Harrison and Richard Burton. "Not a terrible film by any means," said Martin Landau, who played the Roman officer Rufio in the movie, directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. It was pretty bad, though, despite its front-rank talent. When it opened in the summer of 1963, the film was as notorious for its extravagant production costs as for the tumultuous affair between Burton and Ms. Taylor that had begun on the set. On screen, the machinations in Roman and Egyptian high places had their moments, but artistically "Cleopatra" was swallowed by its gilded pavilions. For all the gigantism, one critic called it a mouse.

title: Beginning and End
description: If postpartum care stops when a new mother and her baby are unceremoniously dumped out of the hospital 24 hours after a birth, it is only surprising that there are not more tragedies. For all the deficiencies of the system in Britain, one area where it gets it right is in the care of new mothers. Every mother and baby is visited daily by a community midwife for 10 days. This period may be extended if the midwife feels that her presence is required medically or if she feels that the mother needs a sympathetic ear in the absence of other support systems. When the mother is released from her care, a health visitor takes over to advise about vaccinations and local services like support groups and state benefits. Both of these professionals are on call for mother and baby for as long as they need them.

title: Oprah Of the Other Side
description: What comes after life? It is a question that has flustered philosophers, birthed religions and stumped history's greatest minds. Now an answer comes not from a theologian or a scholar but from a baby-faced former ballroom-dance instructor from Long Island, a man who grew up wanting to own his own deli but instead is the host of a cable television show on which he claims to talk to the dead. John Edward, the 31-year-old star of ''Crossing Over With John Edward,'' the hit Sci Fi Channel show that goes into national daytime syndication Aug. 27 (at 3 p.m. on CBS in New York), has been called everything from a charlatan to a messenger from heaven. In the process, he has also managed to unite an unlikely coalition against him, become something of a pop icon and create a whole new genre of television: the psychic talk show.

title: ATLANTIC CITY TUNNEL
description: The Atlantic City Expressway Connector was set to open last week, with a warning: use it or pay for it. The $330 million, 2.3-mile tunnel and ramp system was conceived in 1995 by the former Mirage Resorts chairman Stephen A. Wynn as public-private partnership that would provide a direct auto route to a proposed casino in Atlantic City's Marina District. The South Jersey Transportation Authority says it needs 14,000 additional cars at its Pleasantville toll plaza, which eastbound drivers must pass through to reach the connector, to pay its $60 million share of the cost. With only one of the new Marina District casinos, the 2,010-room Borgata, scheduled to open next year, and no ground-breaking date for MGM-Mirage Resorts property there, the authority is considering the construction of a toll booth on the connector itself to make up for any shortfall, though it has no plans to put one there for now. Bill Kent

title: Commercial Property/Wilmington, Del.; An Industrial Riverfront Setting for Online Firms
description: LOOKING out the half-moon windows of Arkadi Kuhlmann's executive suite, it's easy to see why the Dutch banking and insurance giant ING Group chose to locate its new online savings bank in a 1885 warehouse on the Christina River.

title: Brazil Weighs Replacing Police Strikers With Troops
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28  Facing a growing movement of strikes and other protests by police forces across the country, the Brazilian government is threatening to send in the army to replace the police.

title: Islanders to Vote Today On Vieques Bomb Drills
description: The firing range that has been the make-believe battlefield for countless invasions on the eastern tip of this tiny island was silent. Instead, the only booming noises came from the bands and people who packed the town plaza Friday night and into this morning to demand that the United States Navy cease fire and leave immediately, not in May 2003 as President Bush recently announced.

title: Lynn Sammartano, Alexander Flint
description: Lynn Ann Sammartano, the daughter of Ruth and Anthony Sammartano of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married there today to Alexander Murray Flint, the son of Carol and George Flint of Edwinstowe, England. The Rev. John O'Brien will perform the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAUM, SELIG
description: FLAUM-Selig. Beloved husband of Beverly. Devoted father of Deborah and Rena. Dear brother of Joseph & Terry Salzman. Services were held Friday, July 27, 2001.

title: A Fight Over Park Permits Is the Latest in a Long War
description: Ethel Bates has few friends in the Parks Department. So Ms. Bates, the 72-year-old coordinator of the Marcus Garvey Park Conservancy, was not surprised when her application to hold three concerts in that Harlem park in August was denied.

title: On a Council In Transition, Incumbents See Big Opportunity
description: While hundreds of candidates throughout New York fight over City Council seats, a handful of little-known officials are already maneuvering inside City Hall, seeking to become the next generation of leaders. These dozen or so Council members who are not losing their jobs to term limits have been huddling for months, plotting to take control if they can win re-election.

title: Playland: Treasured Spot Or Money Pit?
description: THE waves lapped against the shore, almost in rhythm to the lilting fox trot played on the boardwalk by the Milt Gerver Orchestra. Dozens of elderly people danced in front of the bandstand as Mr. Gerver smiled in his crisp white blazer.

title: July 22-28; Genoa Death Investigated
description: The funeral of Carlo Giuliani, the 23-year-old anti-globalization demonstrator, was calm. But Italians are still bitterly divided over the violence that exploded in Genoa and the police tactics used to combat it, especially a predawn raid on protest organizers' headquarters, in which dozens of unarmed people were beaten. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi pledged that there would be no cover-up during investigations. And he said Italy could be proud of the ''dignified'' way it managed the summit meeting, held behind a wall of 13-foot metal grates. But next year's meeting, to be held at a remote ski resort in western Canada, will be a smaller affair.

description: JEREMY THRANE

title: Private Sector; When the Limelight Turns Harsh
description: JEFFREY C. WALKER does not seek the spotlight. But that is exactly where Mr. Walker, 45 and a former accountant, has found himself because of his high-profile job at J. P. Morgan Chase, the second-largest bank in the country after Citigroup. And lately, the publicity has been especially uncomfortable.
