title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOVEICHIK, REBBITZIN ELLA (NEE SHURIN)
description: SOLOVEICHIK-Rebbitzin Ella (nee Shurin). Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of an aishet chayil and educator, beloved wife of Rabbi Aaron Soloveichik, devoted alumnus, renowned Talmudic scholar, and RIETS rosh yeshiva. Rabbi Soloveichik, continues a family tradition begun in 1929, when his father, Rabbi Moshe Soloveichik, joined the RIETS faculty, and furthered by his brother, the late Rabbi Dr. Joseph B. Soloveitchik and himself. We extend sincere condolences also to her children: Moshe (and Debra) Soloveichik, Eliyahu (and Esther) Soloveichik, Yosef (and Leah) Soloveichik, Rachel Leah (and Rabbi Raphael) Marcus, Tovah (and Rabbi Gershon) Segal, and Chayim (and Pircha) Soloveichik; her siblings: Rabbi Aaron Shurin, a member of the Stern College for Women faculty; Rabbi Tzvi Shurin; Rabbi Israel Shurin; Chaviva Zwick; Chasida Berkowitz; and Donna Peikes; her adored 37 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren; and 30 nieces and nephews, including Rabbi Dr. Haym Soloveichik, faculty member of our Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies. A loving and nurturing partner of her husband for 53 years, Rebbitzin Soloveichik was a widely admired teacher in Chicago's Hannah Sacks Girls School, where she taught Bible, Jewish History, Hebrew, and Yiddish. The rabbinic adage ''Eshet Chaver Kechaverthe wife of a great scholar is regarded as a scholar'' describes her perfectly; she earned that accolade through her loyalty to family and to her multitude of students throughout all circumstances. May this noble and erudite matriarch in Israel be a ''righteous pleader'' for all Israel, and may her entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: A Bicycling Mystery: Head Injuries Piling Up
description: Millions of parents take it as an article of faith that putting a bicycle helmet on their children, or themselves, will help keep them out of harm's way.

title: CHINESE UNSWAYED AS POWELL PUSHES U.S. MISSILE PLAN
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell ended his first meeting with China's leaders today sounding upbeat and saying the two sides would talk more about human rights and weapons sales. But he made little headway in overcoming opposition to the Bush administration's plans for a missile shield.

title: Septic Contractors Required To Train for Special License
description: Westchester County has enacted legislation to clean up septic systems that will require septic contractors, beginning next April, to take a special training course and obtain a license.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNECK, SALLY BLOCH
description: SCHNECK-Sally Bloch. On July 26th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Ray Bloch and the late William Schneck. Loving mother of the late Nancy Bloch. Devoted daughter of the late Dorothy and the late Dr. Louis Shank. Loving aunt of Erica Englander and A. Robert Towbin. Distinguished graduate of Syracuse University and longtime educator in NYC schools. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, July 29th, 7-9 PM. Service on Monday, July 30th, at 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Sights That Once Could Thrill Only Birds
description: SOMETHING happens when the pilot of a single-engine airplane dips his right wing down low so you can get a better view of the Statue of Liberty. Your stomach just rolls with the tiny Cessna Sky Hawk II and your hand juts out instinctively, seeking support. You are only 700 feet above the Hudson River, thousands of feet below the altitude for optimum safety, a thought that rattles through your skull with every bounce of the 1,800-pound plane.

description: Isabel Maria Amador Manalo and Jeffrey David Kwaterski were married yesterday by the Rev. Stan A. Drongowski at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Madison, Wis.

description: KING-Peter. On July 10, 2001 in Moldova. Peter started his career designing for Calvin Klein Jeans & was still in the garment industry at the time of his death. Survived by daughters Julie King and Jamie Levitt. Funeral July 31, 2001, 10AM at Gutterman's Inc. For details call: 718-284-1500.

title: 'Flight of the Swan'
description: Very few people know that Madame, the famous Russian ballerina, visited our island from April to September 1917. But my husband, Juan Anduce, and I remembered the time vividly. A few weeks ago, on April 23, 1932, Madame lay dying in an obscure hotel in Amsterdam, asking for her swan costume. "Play the last measure softly," she whispered to the friends who stood around her, the newspaper headlines quoted. No sooner did she pass away, as she lay still warm in her coffin, than her husband, Victor Dandré, was speeding toward London in search of the marriage license which would assure him of his inheritance: magnificent Ivy House, the mansion surrounded by English gardens and a lake full of swans that once belonged to the painter William Turner and which Madame had purchased with her savings. But I knew he'd never find it. I had destroyed the license, a yellowed parchment written in Cyrillic characters, years before. When I read the article I was overwhelmed with recollections.

title: Luxuriating in the Sprawl of That Early 70's Sound
description: GEORGE HARRISON'S first solo record, the triple-LP ''All Things Must Pass,'' was a grandiose declaration of independence. It arrived on record store shelves in November 1970, seven months after the Beatles' breakup, in a box that looked as if it should contain ''Gtterdmmerung,'' and there was Wagnerian bombast in the reverb-swathed songs concocted by Mr. Harrison and his producer, Phil Spector. The album was, among other things, a Beatles post-mortem; its title and stark black-and-white cover photograph of Mr. Harrison -- long hair, long face, a solitary figure in the garden of a country estate -- sent a clear message: the Beatles are gone, the 60's are over, the vibes are bad.

title: The Nation; Curbing the High Cost Of Health
description: A MODEST proposal: give every American an M.R.I. as part of a yearly checkup. The scans will surely catch disease at an early stage for a few, and they won't harm anyone. True, they may cost a few thousand dollars per person, but in America cost is not allowed to affect medical decisions. Indeed, the subject of cost is taboo, even in the face of the threat that health-care premiums will rise beyond the reach of millions of poor and low-income families.

title: For This Restaurant Owner, There's Politics in a Glass
description: At first glance, Liquors, a dimly lighted restaurant decorated with sequined tapestries and oil paintings, does not seem unusual. Soft music wafts past a bar displaying liquor bottles from around the world.

title: Rene Olson, James Russell
description: Rene Alicia Olson and James Russell were married yesterday at Quilty's, a restaurant in SoHo. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated.

title: Here's to You, Mrs. Robinson: A New Band in the 'Burbs
description: THREE Christmases ago while decorating wreaths with their children and having a ''Martha Stewart moment,'' two suburban housewives had an epiphany. Instead of making wreaths, why not draw upon their musical background and form a rock band?

title: At Dawn, It's a Different World
description: BY 5 a.m. the newsstand at the Long Beach railroad station sets out El Diario and The Wall Street Journal and more than 20 other papers. That's the same time the bakery opens its doors for seeded rye. The cappuccino bar next door starts pouring Mocha Java at 7 sharp.

title: Where the Discussions Are Weighty but No One Minds
description: No one wore a Greek-style tunic, but there were plenty of sandals in evidence at the most recent meeting of Socrates Cafe at a bookstore on 86th Street.

title: Seeing the Right Performer at the Right Moment
description: I HAVE looked it up, and apparently ''East of Eden'' was released in England in July 1955. So I could have seen it in that brief space before Sept. 30 and the crumpled Porsche in the rolling blond hills outside Paso Robles, Calif. But I know I didn't: I was watching and playing cricket, I daresay, or trying to get a girlfriend. I was only 14 and, no matter the indignation I would have felt then if so charged, I'm sure now that I was a child still. What this amounts to is that James Dean was dead before I ever saw him. I must have read about ''East of Eden,'' must have gathered that this newcomer had arrived. But I didn't rush to the movie, because of cricket or girls, because I was sour on what I guessed was a Bible picture (there seemed so many then), and because I had no idea who Julie Harris was.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column on July 1 about the Kitchen, a multidisciplinary arts center in Manhattan, misidentified the founder of a summer institute there. She was Elise Bernhardt, the Kitchen's executive director; Pia Massie heads the summer institute.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Chevrolet Avalanche; Ride 'em, Urban Cowboy
description: OUR nose knows when you draw close to this small Great Plains city. Unless you have had the foresight to roll up the windows and set the air-conditioner to ''recirc,'' blocking the outside air, your olfactory senses are treated to the historically accurate aroma of a Wild West cowtown.

title: The Battle Lines Of the Mommy Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, BEATRICE
description: MEYERS - Beatrice, eighty - six, died in New York City on July 9th, 2001, the daughter of Oscar and Rose (Resnick) Meyers. She was born in New York and raised in Frackville, PA. She returned to NY to make her long career in the women's wear industry as a buyer for Allied Stores. Active as a volunteer for many organizations and charities, Ms. Meyers was a lifetime member of National Council of Jewish Women and was recognized as Volunteer of the Year in 1991. Among her many interests were travel, opera, theatre and bridge. She leaves behind many friends and is survived by a niece, Judith Meyers of New York City, and two nephews, Dr. David Meyers of Baltimore, Maryland, and Dr. Jeffrey Meyers of Swarthmore, PA. Contributions in her memory may be made to National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section, 820 2nd Ave, New York, New York 10017.

title: If You Build It, He Will Skim
description: THE RACKETS

title: Political Briefing; Reaching Out, And Inching Back
description: In a state as conservative as Virginia, it is not easy to run for office as a Democrat. But Mark R. Warner, a former Democratic state chairman, is having a try at it. He is running for governor.

title: Executive Director for Crossroads
description: After abandoning its 2000-2001 season in the face of mounting debt, Crossroads Theater Company has hired a new executive director and plans to present a short season of works beginning in the late fall. Les Edwards, the former president and chairman of Aaron Davis Hall in Harlem and corporate communications director at Time Warner, will be the playhouse's first executive director.

title: Beyond the Gingerbread
description: ENTERING Cape May after two or three hours on the highway, your eyes fixed on the signs reading ''Center City/Beaches,'' you could easily overlook the factorylike compound to your left, just beyond the Cape May Bridge. It looks like something out of the industrial landscape you've left behind, as far removed from Cape May's broad white beaches and sumptuous Victoriana as Bruce Springsteen is from, well, Queen Victoria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEERY, THOMAS J.
description: SEERY-Thomas J. Of N. Massapequa on July 27, 2001 after a long and courageous battle. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Maureen and Chris Pomarico and Brian and Kimberly Seery. Cherished brother of Margaret Seery. Reposing at William E. Law Funeral Home, 1 Jerusalem Ave., Massapequa, NY. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday 9:45 am at Maria Regina RC Church, Seaford, NY. Int. Holy Rood Cemetery. The family will receive friends Sunday evening 7-9:30 pm and Monday 2-5 and 7-9:30 pm. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the American Cancer Society, 839 Stewart Avenue, Garden City, NY 11530.

title: It's Only Rhyming Quatrains, but I Like It
description: Jhn Leland's (July 8) delightful parsing of rock lyrics reminded me of teaching English lit at City University and reaching into popular music to illustrate rhetorical techniques, from alliteration to zeugma. Now, listening to favorite songs from the 1960's and 70's, I'm struck by the tenderness, wisdom and artistry of those lyrics.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-29-01: Questions for Andrew Spielman; Once Bitten
description: Q: What's the first thing you think of when you are bitten?

title: New Drug-Law Plan Still Needs Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckonings; Rebate and Switch
description: There was an odd, almost whining tone to the speech Lawrence Lindsey, the White House's top economist, gave in Philadelphia last week. Mr. Lindsey said that he was ''disturbed'' to find that any doubts remain about the tax cut passed two months ago, that the cut is ''an obvious success story.'' Clearly, Mr. Lindsey is feeling the heat: many people, even those who enthusiastically supported George W. Bush's campaign, are starting to have second thoughts about his tax cut.

title: At 90, Still In Pursuit Of Beauty
description: IN the first half of the 20th century, when photographing celebrities was not the tightly controlled enterprise it is today, George Daniell picked up his Leica and headed for the stars. He made casual appointments with famous subjects he wanted to shoot, and bumped into others at restaurants or on travels. He had the photographer's most coveted gift: a knack for being in the right place at the right time.

title: Plenty of Organ Music, All Free
description: In its quiet camp meeting way, Ocean Grove maintains its summer position as a seaside hub of musical activity. The Great Auditorium's free organ programs are central to daily concerts and recitals ranging in repertory from serious listening through light classics to sing-it-yourself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAIN, STEPHEN
description: KAIN-Stephen. My advisor, my accountant and my friend. I wish you had gotten an extension. Hit them straight! Steve Harrison

title: Art Calls: A Wink, A Wiggle And Off They Go
description: AS a Jewish girl from the Bronx and a former television producer, Doris Elena Konig never expected to become a belly dancer. But when several acquaintances saw her dancing at parties and mentioned she had the perfect movement style and body type, she decided to give it a try. Now, appearing onstage as Dorit, the Hebrew translation of her first name, she heads to work at midnight with heavy eye makeup and a glittering bindi on her forehead to shimmy and shake at local clubs.

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: Hardcover Fiction
description: This

title: Free Trade Needs a Chance to Sell Itself
description: I have just started a new club. Anyone can join, but I particularly want to sign up President Bush and his trade representative, Robert Zoellick. The club is Free Traders against Fast Track. Let me explain, starting with a confession.

title: Washington Talk; Senator Looks to Home With Bill on Manure Use
description: Hundreds of millions of tons of cow and pig manure accumulate every year in the United States. If it were piled into trucks, which of course it never would be, the line would stretch bumper to bumper from San Francisco to New York, according to a calculation once made by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: The Battle Lines Of the Mommy Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Rod Stewart Touring Again
description: After a brief recording hiatus and a battle against thyroid cancer, the veteran rocker Rod Stewart has returned with a new CD, ''Human,'' his voice intact, and a tour. The ''Forever Young'' balladeer retains his signature rasp, and as in his prime, remains one of rock's most energetic performers. He'll perform songs from the vintage-sounding ''Human'' on Saturday at the Tweeter Center in Camden. Robbie Woliver

title: July 22-28; Coca-Cola Accused
description: In Colombia, the fact that union organizers are gunned down is nothing new, since hundreds have been murdered in the last decade, most by right-wing paramilitaries. But a suit brought by an American labor rights group and the United Steelworkers of America says that some companies regularly hire out paramilitary gunmen to intimidate and kill in order to break labor unions. The suit, filed against Coca-Cola and three of its bottlers, charged that the defendants ''contracted with or otherwise directed paramilitary security forces that utilized extreme violence and murdered, tortured, unlawfully detained or otherwise silenced trade union leaders.'' Coke issued a strong denial, and one bottler said it was considering legal action against the International Labor Rights Fund of Washington D.C. and the Steelworkers.

title: A Little All-Star Soccer And a Lot of Spectacle
description: Major League Soccer's sixth All-Star Game, this afternoon at Spartan Stadium, was the on-grass equivalent of the freewheeling, midseason showcases offered by the N.H.L. or the N.B.A.

title: The Young and the Renters
description: South Williamsburg and Wall Street have two of the highest concentrations of renters under 25 in New York City, according to the 2000 census. But youth is about all they have in common.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: For an Area of Jarring Notes, a Move Toward Melody
description: To urban planners, Queens Plaza and the surrounding area of Long Island City is a Rubik's Cube: a bewildering puzzle with an infinite number of incorrect arrangements.

title: For Sale: Minimalist Condos, No View
description: IT wasn't until Michael Friedman bought a car a year or two after moving from Manhattan back to his native Brooklyn in 1981 that he remembered how his schoolteacher father, Louis, had circled the block again and again hoping to find a parking spot on the street. And after he finally found one, he hesitated to move the car from its space rather than repeat the ordeal.

title: July 22-28; China Releases 2 Scholars
description: China convicted and released two Chinese citizens with permanent residency in the United States who had been held for more than five months on charges of spying for Taiwan. Gao Zhan, a 39-year-old sociologist, and Qin Guangguang, a 46-year-old former academic who had been working for a pharmaceutical company in Beijing, were each sentenced to 10 years in prison and then released on medical parole after an appeal from Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. The resolution removed an irritant before Mr. Powell arrived in Beijing, but as many as a dozen U.S. citizens and permanent U.S. residents remain in Chinese detention on similar charges.

title: In the Region/Long Island; 7 Homes Planned at Former Estate Held by College
description: FRONTING on busy Northern Boulevard east of Glen Cove Road is one of Long Island's still intact Gold Coast estates -- 101 acres of rolling fields and woods with a magnificent Georgian-style mansion designed by the architectural firm of Carrre & Hastings for Alfred I. du Pont, a one-time head of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the chemical company.

title: WINE UNDER $20
description: One reason that Millbrook Vineyards, owned by the Italophile John S. Dyson, is the leading Hudson Valley winery is its Tocai Friulano.

title: Robin MacFarlane, Jerry Tempelman
description: Dr. Robin Mae MacFarlane and Jerry Tempelman were married yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Gregory S. Cootsona at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: As Indonesia Redefines Itself, So Does Its Military
description: It was just a routine roll call, said the generals reassuringly -- a showy late-night deployment last week of nearly 100 tanks around the presidential palace.

title: When Hospitals Shop Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONWAY, STEPHEN J.
description: CONWAY-Stephen J.. 54. Former resident of London, England, died on Tuesday, July 24, 2001 in Overland Park, K.S. after a brief illness. Born in Mt. Kisco, New York, lived in London for the past 6 years. He was a graduate of Boston College and received his MBA at Harvard Business School. He was formerly president of the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation. He was senior Vice President of Knowlogy, Inc. in Cairo, Egypt and managing director of EvaluTek.Com in London, England. Surviving is his wife, Mary Y. Conway, a son, Christopher, and a daughter, Kendra. Services will be held at noon, Tuesday July 31, 2001 at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church, 55 Valley Road, Katonah, New York. Interment will be at Saint Francis Cemetery in Mt. Kisco, New York. Memorial donations can be made to The Stephen Conway Memorial Fund, , C/O L.R. Clifton-Bligh, 9 Highview Road, Pound Ridge, NY 10576.

title: Shimmering Beauty in a Sweltering City
description: She.

title: July 22-28; Children's News Group Fails
description: For 25 years, young reporters from Children's Express, in their trademark yellow and red T-shirts, have been a fixture of political conventions, asking tough questions and breaking stories for the grown-up media to follow. But at the news bureaus in New York, Washington and Marquette, Mich., the bad news about their own organization came as a shock this month: Children's Express has run through all the foundation grants that kept it going and, with no new support in sight, ceased its operations, $2.4 million in debt. Tamar Lewin

title: Up Against a Fashion Wall: A Spin on Guerrilla Tactics
description: THERE are designers who press their gowns on movie stars in the hope of a red-carpet testimonial on Oscar night. There are designers who dress socialites with the expectation of free advertising when the women's photographs run in the news columns.

title: Helping Vines To Reach Potentials
description: ON a recent jaunt out to eastern Long Island, I stopped at a nursery in Water Mill and thought I'd walked into the hanging gardens of Babylon. A wall of flowering vines -- Thunbergia alata, or black-eyed Susan vine, that little, orange, round-petaled sweetie with a black dot in its center; pale green cobaea, or cup-and-saucer vine; and others I couldn't identify -- extended clear down the length of the greenhouse, from a pole about 20 feet up, right down to my feet.

title: Mali Heled, Simon Kinberg
description: Mali Heled, the daughter of Terry and Simca Heled of New York, was married on Thursday to Simon David Kinberg, a son of Dr. Monica Menell-Kinberg and Jud Kinberg, also of New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

title: Rare Blend Of Beautiful And Blunt
description: LENA HEADEY is well settled in London these days, but at heart she remains very much a Northern lass -- that is, warm, informal, irreverent, self-deprecating and probably more forthright than is recommendable for a fetching young actress trying to make her name in movies today. But that's what happens when you are raised in Yorkshire: you don't put on airs and graces, and you speak your mind.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; For Campers, Refurbished Buildings and Hopes
description: This summer, 28 new buildings with handsome red trim are dressing things up at two camps here, where tens of thousands of boys and girls from New York City have taken their first forays into the wilds of nature.

title: A Pair of New Musicals Evolving at the O'Neill
description: SOME people are less interested in a finished work of art than in the art of putting it together. That's why rough sketches by painters, partially chiseled shapes by sculptors and early drafts by writers hold an eternal fascination, providing a peek into the soul, a clue to the secrets of the creative spirit.

title: Woman Is Shot While Fighting a Robber
description: A 70-year-old Brooklyn woman was listed in stable condition with a gun shot wound to her face yesterday after trying to fight off a robber who had entered her home, the police said.

title: 'Better Day Coming: Blacks and Equality, 1890-2000'
description: EMANCIPATION AND RECONSTRUCTION

title: And Then There Were 9: A Shrinking Credit Club
description: Increased competition and a greater willingness to take on debt have cost all but a handful of of American companies their triple-A credit ratings, according to Moody's Investors Service.

title: New Rules On Loans For Co-ops
description: LAST month, Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law amendments to the state's Uniform Commercial Code, a law relating to commercial transactions. The amendments, which took effect on July 1, rewrite the portion of the code that governs the pledging of personal property as security for a loan. And while the topic might seem to be somewhat arcane, real estate lawyers say that the changes will have an impact on co-ops and co-op shareholders across the state.

title: Judy Chen, Ned Cooper
description: Judy Yi-An Chen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. H. Chen of Plano, Tex., was married yesterday in Summit, N.J., to Edward Niles Cooper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Weeks Cooper of Summit. Msgr. Robert E. Harahan officiated at the Grand Summit Hotel.

title: Runner To Lead U.S. Team
description: MONTHS after his hopes of running for his adopted country in the Olympics were dashed, Ossining's Khalid Khannouchi, the marathon world-record holder, will finally get to represent the United States.

title: Parker Takes Precautions After Cancer Scare
description: This summer, Glenn Parker's 12th in the N.F.L., training camp could wait.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: Madonna Connections, Strings Attached
description: THE V.I.P. ticket office for the Madonna concerts was on the 27th floor of a Midtown hotel that's popular with music industry types. On Wednesday, the day the Drowned World Tour opened in New York, a constant, quiet stream of people walked into a junior suite to present their confirmation faxes for tickets.

title: Nothing but the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISHBERG, DENA DASKOVSKY
description: FRISHBERG-Dena Daskovsky. The Boards and Staff of Masorti Foundation for Conservative Judaism in Israel and the Masorti Movement extend condolences to Mary Lou Allen, wife of Foundation President Rabbi Daniel R. Allen, and family, on the death of her mother, Dena Daskovsky Frishberg. May her name be for a blessing in the House of Israel. Masorti Foundation for Conservative Judaism in Israel Rabbi Gordon Tucker, Chairman Joan Kemeny, Paru, VP for Dev. Masorti Movement Dr. David Breakstone, Chairman Rabbi Ehud Bandel, President

title: Parasites in Prt--Porter
description: Having spent almost three years as an expatriate in a Japanese office surrounded by ''kawaii para-chan,'' I would like to add a footnote to Peggy Orenstein's excellent article (July 1) on footloose and fancy-free young Japanese women.

title: The Nation; The Necessary Risks of Medical Research
description: ''FATAL Disease Cured by New Therapy'' it's the headline of researchers' dreams.

title: Primates Barely Hanging On
description: THE muriqui is the biggest monkey in South America, and one of the loudest. Twenty of them filled the trees over my head, swinging hand over hand, leaping and running on razor-thin branches like high-spirited, acrobatic 8-year-olds.

title: Owners Ask for a Run to Give Dogs Their Day in the Park
description: Sam Tarantola says that when he walks his black Labrador, Louie, in the main part of Wolfes Pond Park in Prince's Bay, he must continually protect the dog from being run down by bicyclists, runners, in-line skaters and other bipedal menaces.

title: Chirac Fights Back as France's Pre-Election Politics Evolve Into a Brawl
description: The uproar over President Jacques Chirac's use of cash to pay for hundreds of thousands of dollars of airplane tickets degenerated into an all-out political brawl this week, as a Parliament committee considered whether to turn the president's financial disclosure statements over to a group of investigating judges.

title: How to Spend a Rebate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONE, DR. BERNARD WILLIAM
description: STRONE-Dr. Bernard William. On July 27, 2001 after a long and valiant struggle with Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of Judith. Cherished father of Daniel and Michael and his wife Andrea. Adored grandfather of Noah and Joshua. Distinguished physician. His work is done. He may finally rest in peace. Services will be held on Sunday, July 29, at 9:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 76th St. & Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168th St, NY, NY 10032.

title: INSIDE
description: Taking On College Sports

title: House Social-Security Bill Shows Trade-Offs for Bush
description: Offering a detailed look at what it might take to overhaul Social Security, two influential members of Congress have developed a proposal that would achieve President Bush's goal of creating investment accounts for all workers -- but at the cost of substantial cuts in guaranteed benefits.

title: Sports of The Times; Mr. Edwards, Are We Still In Jetland?
description: HERMAN EDWARDS says the person he most would have liked to meet was Mother Teresa.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARDACH, HOWARD
description: BARDACH-Howard, July 26, 1998. Remembering a dearly loved and loving companion and best friend. Always in my heart... Zara

title: In Reviving Camden, Let the Games Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Teapot, Big Tempest
description: SOUTHAMPTON'S Anti-Bias Task Force has a new member who says she does not feel welcome. Phyllis Murphy, who identifies herself as a born-again Christian and is well known locally for her letters to the editor branding homosexuality a sin, was appointed in April soon after she had called the task force membership ''rude, arrogant and opinionated'' in a letter to Supervisor Vincent J. Cannuscio.

title: No Change at Top as German Wins Stage 19
description: EVRY, France, July 28  With his frosted hair, golden earring and embryo strut, Jimmy Casper looks like a bicycle team's sprinter. Sometimes he even rides like one.

title: Spurning Mall, Saks to Stay in Garden City
description: SAKS FIFTH AVENUE has decided to abandon plans to move its Garden City store to the nearby Roosevelt Field mall and instead will stay and renovate its Franklin Avenue location.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDMAN, PROFESSOR LEO
description: LANDMAN-Professor Leo. The faculty, dean, students, and board of directors of Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies of Yeshiva University mourn the loss of their former dean and distinguished colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, children, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Arthur Hyman, Dean Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman Board of Directors

title: Too Young to Drive, Old Enough to Surf
description: NEXT

title: Finnish-Built Swans Gaining in Popularity
description: After the 17-man crew of the Swan 56 Neva scrambled to drop the spinnaker during the first race of the Swan American Regatta earlier this month off Newport, R.I., the professional foredeck hand and America's Cup veteran Wally Henry offered this summation: ''Never have so many worked so hard to sail so slowly.''

title: Private Sector; How to Build a Museum in Motown
description: In his previous life as chief engineer for the cost-conscious Chrysler Corporation, Franois Castaing brought vehicles to life in rapid time with limited budgets. Now, he has lent those skills to the new Detroit Science Center.

title: One Set of Rules For Both Sexes
description: To the Sports Editor,

title: Senators Urge Bush to Back Family Planning Proposals
description: Twenty-two senators are asking the Bush administration to reverse its opposition to nearly a dozen state proposals that seek to use federal money to provide contraceptive services to low-income Americans.

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Madrid's Big Three Extend Summer Hours
description: Art lovers visiting Madrid can spend more time viewing the treasures of the city's three main museums, which are extending their hours this summer as part of a plan by the regional government to promote Madrid's cultural attractions.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Lisa Marie; A Vargas Girl in the City
description: SHE is a walking, talking Vargas girl, a woman of such otherworldly ripeness that her fianc, Tim Burton, has cast her as Vampira (in ''Ed Wood''), a seductive Martian (in ''Mars Attacks'') and a seductive ape (in the new film ''Planet of the Apes''). Now for some vital statistics.

title: Dance Listings
description: CENTRAL PARK SUMMERSTAGE  Chamecki Lerner; Eun Me Ahn will perform. Rumsey Playfield, mid-park at 72nd St. (212- 360-2777) Fri., 8:30. Free.

title: Silicon Alley Journal; Dot-Coms Are Dead, Long Live Dot-Com Parties
description: With the dot-com bubble not only burst but evaporated, one might presume that the mood at pink-slip parties around Silicon Alley these days would be decidedly funereal rather than funky.

title: Wonder Bread's Match: Peanut Butter Slabs
description: Scientists at Oklahoma State University spent nearly three years figuring out how to shorten the time it takes to make a peanut butter sandwich. Their answer: eliminate the smearing.

title: Liberties; Apetown, My Hometown
description: I needed a break from politics.

title: Ayatollah, Reviewing Islamic Law, Tugs at Ties Constricting Iran's Women
description: From his simple surroundings, the Grand Ayatollah Youssef Saanei has issued many stunning edicts over the years, the most controversial dealing with women.

title: The Nation: Separate and Unequal; You Can Come In. You Stay Out.
description: UNITED STATES immigration policy is not fair. Never has been. Probably never will be.

title: A Festival of Concerts and Classes
description: TEN years ago, the members of the Emelin Trio founded what they hoped would become ''an international gathering of world-renowned artists and aspiring students'' at Marymount College in Tarrytown. With each succeeding summer, their dream became more of a reality, and now the Summit Music Festival stands among the pre-eminent teaching institutes in the New York metropolitan area.

title: In Russia, Capitalism Of a Certain Size
description: NIKOLAI SHILIN is a big man. For years, he could buy clothing only at one store. But after the Soviet Union collapsed in 1990 and Russia became a market economy, his search for suits that fit -- size 50, to be exact -- made him rich.

title: PREDICTING A SLOWDOWN
description: New Jersey's economy is beginning to feel the effects of the downturn in the nation's economy, and slow growth will continue at least through the end of next year, according to an analysis by the Rutgers University Economic Advisory Service. New jobs will top out at 40,000 for 2001 and 2002 combined, compared with 100,000 new jobs created in the state in 2000 alone, said Dr. Nancy H. Mantell, director of the service, which is part of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning. The average unemployment rate will go from 3.8 percent last year to 4.3 percent this year to just under 5 percent over the next several years, according to the predictions. Karen DeMasters

title: Torrid Yankees Can Feel Clemens's Strain
description: Roger Clemens walked wordlessly past teammates in the sixth inning today, trailed by their concerned stares. The Yankees have won every game Clemens has pitched since May 20, but there is some doubt about when Clemens will pitch again, after he felt discomfort in his right groin muscle today.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Sweet Smell of Excess
description: IN spite of tepid reviews, ''America's Sweethearts'' -- a half-baked attempt to update the grand screwball tradition in an age of gross-out humor -- earned $30 million in its first weekend, a respectable showing against the dinosaurs of ''Jurassic Park III.'' The movie's strong opening probably had something to do with the box office clout of Julia Roberts, who plays the put-upon assistant (and younger sister) of a preening, narcissistic film star.

title: July 22-28; Nearly Global Emissions Pact
description: Surprising even themselves, 178 countries ended a marathon bargaining session in Bonn with agreement on the rules of the Kyoto Protocol, the first climate treaty requiring industrial powers to cut emissions of gases linked to global warming. President Bush kept the U.S., the biggest source of such gases, on the sidelines, saying the treaty was unfair and costly. He continued to decline to say when he might propose another approach. The inaction seems to have goaded Congress, where both Democratic and Republican aides say that measures calling for cuts in emissions are likely to pass this year. Andrew C. Revkin

title: A Cunning Climber, Armstrong Joins the Gods of Cycling
description: PARIS, July 29  After telling his rivals that he has never felt as strong as he does now and that he expects to feel even more powerful next year, Lance Armstrong cruised into Paris today as the winner of his third consecutive Tour de France.

title: In Seattle, Wagner's Stock, At Least, Continues To Rise
description: PERHAPS we should expect the city that gave us Windows, grunge and designer coffee on every street corner to behave a bit quixotically. In 1975, Glynn Ross, the founding general director of the tiny, 11-year-old Seattle Opera, got the mad notion of mounting Wagner's complete ''Ring'' tetralogy, uncut, in one week. At the time, only one American opera company had ever done so: the Metropolitan Opera, once, in 1939. Mr. Ross pulled it off, successfully enough that the Wagner habit stuck.

title: Beginning and End
description: Lauren Slater's essay (The Way We Live Now, July 8), prompted by the effects of postpartum hormonal depression upon Andrea Yates in Texas, was well taken. However, when I first learned of the Yates tragedy, I wondered about the moral culpablity of the husband. It would be interesting to know more about the family dynamics of this couple. For example, whose desire was it to have five children in the span of seven years? Who demanded the home-schooling program (placing the mother in perpetual guardianship)? How empathetic was he to his wife's previous bouts of depression, which must have been a recognized pattern?

title: July 22-28; Farewell Performance
description: The curtains parted on the backstage drama at American Ballet Theater, one of the world's premiere ballet troupes, when its executive director, Louis P. Spisto, resigned under pressure. During his administration, ticket revenues and contributions grew, but the company also endured a wave of employee departures, protest resignations by angry trustees and a drift of donors unsettled by what critics called Mr. Spisto's mercurial management style. Doreen Carvajal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, ALAN J.
description: GREENSTEIN-Alan J. Of Bellerose, NY, on July 27, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Arlene. Beloved father of Mark, Sharon, Jennifer, Lisa, Abby, Stacey and David. Loving grandfather of Spencer, Styles, Stefani, Jenna, Justin, Tyler, Corey, Jake, Jessica and Steven. Services will be held at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury on Mon, 11:45 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNUS, CHARLOTTE H.
description: MAGNUS-Charlotte H. Jersey City, NJ. On July 25, 2001. Belovedwife of the late Ludwig. Dear mother of the late Martin. Cherished grandmother of Sharon and Deborah. Beloved mother-in-law of Sue. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Dispelling the Myth That Options Help Shareholders
description: INVESTORS' hard-earned money is not the only thing that has been lost since the technology stock bubble went pfft. Also gone is the credibility of a host of bull-market conceits. They include the hilarious notions that new-economy companies would be invulnerable to the traditional economic cycle, that valuations were not important when it came to buying stocks, that the invention of the Internet rivaled that of electricity.

title: Buckingham Palace Expands Garden Vistas
description: Visitors to Buckingham Palace during August and September this year will get a little something extra on their route: a 1,475-foot walk along the front of the palace and the south side of the palace garden, from which there are views over the west part of the garden and the three-and-a-half-acre lake.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: STRANGERS IN TOWN

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Reform Meeting Rallies Around Buchanan
description: The last time the Reform Party held a national convention here, in early 2000, there were shouting and shoving matches, with maybe a blow or two struck, and the police were called in to restore order, or some semblance of it.

title: A Prodigy Who Opted Out Opts Back In
description: THE most astonishing line in the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Major Barbara'' is not in the script. It's in the program, in the Who's Who in the Cast section, next to a photo of a distinguished-looking silver-haired actor. ''David Warner,'' it says simply, ''is making his American stage debut.''

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: 14 Years After Slaying, Theories, Not Answers

title: Mostly Quiet Amityville Harbors Intimidator on High School Court
description: Jason Fraser, Amityville High School's soon-to-be senior center, is 6 feet 10 inches of knees, elbows and muscle. And although he is a little bit light at only 210 pounds, he is perhaps the most intimidating schoolboy defender in the nation.

title: Predictable Midlife Crisis
description: YOU can guess what ''Harry and Thelma in the Woods'' has to offer just from the synopsis. A middle-age couple ''revisit the romantic wooded area where they first consummated their relationship,'' the publicity says. So you know you're in for good-natured bickering, a midlife crisis, a separation and a reconciliation.

title: School Districts' Question: To Cut, or Not to Cut?
description: In New York City, school officials sent out a memo on Thursday to district superintendents giving them hard-nosed instructions -- and a two- week deadline -- for making $120 million in cuts required under the austerity budget state legislative leaders agreed to last week:

title: McNabb Provides Stability at a Troubled Position
description: As he has done since the Philadelphia Eagles drafted him two years ago, quarterback Donovan McNabb has attacked his off-season with almost maniacal passion. While many players understandably spent their downtime at the beach, McNabb was busy trying to improve himself, studying hours of game film and working out to increase his stamina and strength.

title: Postcard Nostalgia Of a Vanished City
description: From the Copacabana nightclub to the Trylon and Perisphere of the 1939 World's Fair, images of a New York that no longer exist or has been transformed are the focus of ''Lost New York in Old Postcards,'' an exhibition starting Aug. 11 at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Down on the Farm: A City Spread Appears Headed for a Last Harvest
description: John Klein Jr., 36, does not want to see the last working farm in New York City plowed under. But he said that his father, John Klein Sr., had just signed a contract to sell the two-acre spread to a Flushing developer with plans to build 22 two-family houses.

description: To the dwindling Polish community in this waterfront town bustling once again -- the changes at the local church say it all.

title: Japanese Parties Hope Celebrities Will Be a Ticket to Success
description: For Atsushi Onita, a professional wrestler whose usual battle cry when he enters the ring is, ''Fire!'' the most important issue in Japanese elections on Sunday is parental supervision of children.

Survived by daughter Tacy Ammons of Southern Pines, daughter Michael Ann Berman of Jupiter, FL, son Peter A. Feinman of New York, NY, six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

Survived by her son George; her daughter Shelley (Emery); ten grandchildren: Lucinda Dwight, George Dwight II, Margaret Dwight (Perkins), O.T. Bradley Dwight, Susannah Dwight Prout; Jonathan Dwight, Jay Dwight, Leila Dwight, children of her deceased son Jerome; Andrew Emery and Nicolas Emery; and nine great - grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Timothy's Alumnae Assoc. of NY c/o St. Timothy's School, Stevenson, MD 21153.

description: WEISBORD-Stella. 95. On July 27, 2001. Her joy of life and great generosity will be missed by her family and friends. Services on Monday July 30, 4:00 PM at Woodridge Cemetery, Glen Wild, NY. Donations in her memory to Alzheimers Association, Hadassah or the charity of your choice.

title: Editorial Observer; The Vanishing Glory of the Modern Monarchy
description: In the old days, a deposed monarch desirous of power would raise an army. Today, as King-turned-Prime Minister Simeon II of Bulgaria did this spring, he shakes hands at shopping centers and hands out waffles to voters as he campaigns for election. This is progress.

title: Putting a Price on the Priceless
description: Tenants desire light and air, but how much are they really worth? For the residents of a six-story condominium who lost their views, the answer is $150,000, according to the court ruling in their case.

title: A Cleaner Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Only You Can Save Your Sons'
description: In her article (July 8), Elizabeth Rubin quotes ''Putin's infamous oath,'' referring to the Chechens: ''We will rub them out, even in the toilet.'' Is this what our president saw in the soul of Putin when, as he reported, he looked into his eyes?

title: All the Lonely People
description: ANTARCTICA

title: Private Sector; None of the Above From Down Under
description: Anna Murdoch Mann, former wife of Rupert Murdoch, the News Corporation chairman, not only has broken a three-year silence about the end of their 31-year partnership, she has done it by giving an exclusive interview to Australian Women's Weekly, the magazine with the biggest circulation in their home country. It happens to be owned by Kerry Packer, Mr. Murdoch's Australian rival.

title: Business Diary: Wonder Bread's Match
description: Scientists at Oklahoma State University spent nearly three years figuring out how to shorten the time it takes to make a peanut butter sandwich. Their answer: eliminate the smearing.

title: Clearing the Password Buffet
description: Yuri Pikover's pet peeve is leftovers. Specifically, he has a problem with leftover user ID's and passwords that hang around a company's computer system even after an employee no longer needs them, because of a promotion, transfer or dismissal.

title: In Opera By the Bay, Drama Offstage
description: ON Wednesday, Pamela Rosenberg officially takes over as the new general director of the San Francisco Opera: one of the best things to happen to American opera in a long time. It's important, of course, because San Francisco is a leading American opera house, and any opera lover on the international scene tends to track what goes on there. But the real excitement lies in what Ms. Rosenberg is planning.

title: Streetscapes/Crosby Street in SoHo; A Tale of Two Designations: Landmarked and Not
description: ANYONE who likes the cozy thought that landmark designation ''saved SoHo'' must at some time ponder the conundrum of Crosby Street. A block east of busy Broadway, only one side of Crosby Street was included in the 1973 SoHo Cast-Iron Historic District designation. Now, even several years after fancy stores and restaurants have arrived on this quiet backwater, it is difficult to tell which side of Crosby Street has been protected for almost three decades and which has not.

title: New Drug-Law Plan Still Needs Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURNANE, ALICE MARIE, MD.
description: MURNANE-Alice Marie, MD. Beloved daughter of Alice, devoted sister of David, Patricia, Esther, and Irene Bradshaw. Loving aunt. Mass of Resurrection 10 AM August 1st at St. Stephen's Church, 142 East 29th Street. Interment Dunsany Churchyard, Ireland.

title: Eviction Fight Inspires Rally To Aid Center In East Village
description: Nearly 300 supporters fighting the eviction of the Charas/El Bohio Community Center in the East Village marched through Alphabet City yesterday, winding noisily past $13.95 brunch advertisements and the stares of sidewalk diners in a neighborhood much changed since Charas took over a decrepit school building east of Tompkins Square Park in 1979.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-29-01: Gaming; Mixed Greens
description: The people who dream up made-for-TV sporting events have at last ventured into the laboratory from which the rest of television emanates -- the one where the ratings scientists do experiments with sexual chemistry. In prime time tomorrow evening, under the lights at Bighorn Golf Club in Palm Desert, Calif., the two best female golfers in the world, Karrie Webb and Annika Sorenstam, are scheduled to play a match with Tiger Woods and David Duval, just back from the British Open. In an allusion, perhaps, to television's first foray into gender warfare -- the 1973 tennis match between Bobby Riggs and Billie Jean King -- this event has been dubbed by some as the Battle of the Sexes. It isn't. Woods-Sorenstam and Duval-Webb are going to compete against each other as teams, with men and women taking alternate shots.

title: Arts Cuts in the North Not Quite as Painful as Predicted
description: UNDER a legislative mandate to funnel more money to arts groups in South Jersey, the state arts council at its annual meeting last week cut operating grants to 19 groups in the north and scaled back other projects to come up with the cash.

title: Rules of the Road
description: New this summer, Avis is providing a free 32-page driving guide with European car rentals. Besides international road signs and a list of useful phrases in French, German, Spanish and Italian, the guide includes telephone numbers for United States passport and Customs offices abroad, a guide to passenger and luggage capacities of European cars, driving tips and a list of national holidays for various countries. By requesting the guide at the same time they make European reservations, customers will receive the lowest rate available.

title: Cleaning Up the Stables, But Not With a Shovel
description: The barrels of drinking water were coated with green algae, and the stench of ammonia billowed from the barn, which had not been cleaned in months. Bill Lombardi, director of the Gloucester County Animal Shelter, began to gag.

title: Watching My Back
description: He charged at me, shouting something in Czech. It was the middle of the night in Prague. My girlfriend and I were there for New Year's, and as we strolled through a deserted business district, two young men came bounding out of a pedestrian underpass. Loud, menacing and drunk, one ran up and shoved me, then missed with a liquor-slow karate kick. I shoved back. We squared off, staring.

title: July 22-28; Bush in Europe, Part 2
description: At the annual economic summit meetings of the world's major industrialized countries and Russia, people are supposed to die of boredom, not gunshot wounds. But the death of a protester in Genoa at the hands of the Italian police was only the most violent of several unscripted moments during President Bush's second swing through Europe. He scored a big victory with Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, who agreed that talks over reducing nuclear arms should be linked to discussions about ending the Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty and building missile defenses.

title: July 22-28; The Going Rate: 25 Cents
description: There are few public amenities that have caused more debate in American cities than public toilets, with most, including New York, opting for inaction. The concern has been that they would be magnets for the homeless, prostitution and drug use.

title: Stops and Frisks
description: To the Editor:

title: White Denim Redux
description: The fashion impact of the Jacqueline Kennedy exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art reverberated through the summer: Jack Rogers sandals, Palm Beach prints and dark, Hollywood-style sunglasses. Now, as summer moves into fall, Mrs. Kennedy's apparently ineluctable chic will continue for at least a few more months, in the form of the signature white jeans she favored as Jackie O.

title: Bright Lights Aren't Necessarily Safer
description: Light pollution of Long Island's night skies [''Night's Light Dims Stars and Irks Residents,'' July 15] is another consequence of technological innovation applied to excess, just as was cell phone use behind the wheel.

With Season Gone Bad, Piazza and Mets Play Spoilers

Piazza, the Mets' franchise player, was greeted at home plate by a mob of teammates, who celebrated by pounding his helmet like a piata.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILIAN, JORDAN
description: LILIAN-Jordan. On July 28, 2001, surrounded by his loving family. Loving husband, proud father and grandfather. He is survived by Elaine, his wife of 11 years, his children Stuart, Jonathan, Ann and Brad, and nine grandchildren. His first wife Sylvia predeceased him in 1989. He was in the furniture business for 50 years and retired as president of A. L. Myers in 1995. He was a member of Congregation Sons of Israel in Briarcliff Manor, co-founded by his grandfather A. L. Myers. Services will be held at Congregation Sons of Israel, 1666 Pleasantville Rd., Briarcliff Manor, on July 31 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Congregation. For further information, call Hellman Garlick Memorial Chapel 914-762-5501.

title: A Democratic Primary Is Primarily a Turf War
description: Democrats slightly outnumber Republicans in Pennsylvania, but Republicans have been more adept in recent years at winning elections. The state's governor, lieutenant governor and most cabinet members are Republicans, as are both United States senators and 11 of 21 House members. Republicans also control both houses of the Legislature.

title: Extended Family Mourns Girl Who Drowned in Queens
description: She was a pious girl who memorized Koranic verse and prayed five times a day, a dutiful daughter who helped her father with his finances and massaged his aching back, family members said.

description: ''Hi! How are you? I send you this file in order to have your advice.''

title: CITY POLICE WORK LOSING ITS APPEAL AND ITS VETERANS
description: Police departments in cities across the nation are facing what some call a personnel crisis, with the number of recruits at record lows, an increasing number of experienced officers turning down promotions to sergeant or lieutenant and many talented senior officers declining offers to become police chiefs, executive recruiters and police officials say.

title: U.S. Scholar Convicted as Spy in China Returns to Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, July 30  Li Shaomin, a Chinese-born American scholar convicted by Beijing of spying for Taiwan and deported to the United States last week, returned to Hong Kong this evening to take up his teaching job here.

title: The Battle to Save Shays-Meehan
description: This week marks the beginning of yet another critical phase in the struggle to rescue campaign finance reform from the determined opposition of the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives. It also brings an important test of conscience for all members of the House who, in one way or another, have previously expressed support for Shays-Meehan, the bill that seeks to diminish the influence of soft money in American politics.

title: Internet Services Must Help Fight Online Movie Pirates, Studios Say
description: Anyone who wanted to see 20th Century Fox's ''Planet of the Apes'' over the weekend had a choice: pay to see it in a theater or get it free over the Internet, where pirated copies surfaced within hours of its release on Friday.

title: Dr. Bernice L. Neugarten, 85, Early Authority on the Elderly
description: Dr. Bernice L. Neugarten, an authority on aging who identified a growing trend among older people to pursue more active lives and introduced the concept of the young-old and the old-old, died on July 22 at her home in Chicago. She was 85.

title: Accounts
description: Schering-Plough Consumer Health Care Products, Liberty Corner, N.J., expanded its relationship with Zenith Media, New York, by naming the agency to handle consumer broadcast media buying for brands like Coppertone, Dr. Scholl's and Lotrimin, with annual spending estimated at $80 million. The assignment had been at TN Media, New York, owned by True North Communications, now part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Zenith, owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe, also handles media for Schering-Plough drugs sold directly to consumers.

title: In America; Unmasking The Poor
description: The poor are pretty well hidden from everyone except each other in the United States. You won't find them in the same neighborhoods or the same schools as the well-to-do. They're not on television, except for the local crime-casts. And they've vanished from the nation's political discussion.

title: Teamsters May Stall Bush Goals For Mexican Trucks and Trade
description: A lobbying campaign led by the Teamsters union to keep Mexican trucks off American roads is on the verge of handing organized labor a major legislative victory over President Bush, endangering one of his most cherished foreign policy goals and reminding the White House of the political muscle still flexed here by labor unions.

Services were held.

Retired Director of the Anesthesia Department and Respiratory Care at Bayshore Community Hospital in Holmdel, NJ. Brother of Victoria Wysochansky. Uncle of Elyse Bedikian Marfino, Karen Bedikian and Edward Bedikian. Also survived by numerous family members and friends. Funeral Services will be offered in St. Mary Armenian Church, 200 W. Mt. Pleasant Ave., Livingston, NJ on Thursday August 2 at 11AM. Visitation in St. Mary Armenian Church on Wednesday 2-9 PM, with evening prayers at 8 PM. Interment Restland Memorial Park. Bedikian Memorial, 200 W. Mt. Pleasant Ave., Livingston, NJ 07039 or St. Stephanos Armenian Church, 1184 Ocean Ave., Elberon, NJ 07740. title: President of Urban League Calls for Review of Inequity
description: The head of the National Urban League called on the Bush administration today to conduct a comprehensive review of the ''pervasive racism'' in the criminal justice system, from racial profiling to the number of blacks on death row.

title: Powell Upbeat About Relations After a Visit With Chinese
description: The images of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Chinese leaders beaming at each other in their meetings this weekend, and a rare interview with the secretary broadcast today by Chinese state television, illustrate just how quickly the roller coaster relationship between the United States and China can turn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, JESSE
description: KAHN-Jesse. Died at age 98 on July 27 after a short illness at his home in Great Neck, NY. He was the honorary vice president and had been for many years the counsel and a trustee of Temple Beth-El of Great Neck. He was a founding partner of the law firm of Safir & Kahn of Manhattan and a founder of the Association of Trial Lawyers of the City of New York. He was widely known and liked in Great Neck, where he had lived since 1931. He was married for more than 60 years to the late Florence Abraham Kahn. He is survived by three children, David Kahn and Miriam Harris, both of Great Neck, and Louis Kahn, of Teaneck, NJ, by grandchildren Rebecca Harris, Nancy Harris Sidford, John Harris, Deborah Kahn, Diana Kahn, Oliver Kahn, and Michael Kahn, and by six greatgrandchildren, Aaron, Rachel, and Sarah Sidford and Daniel, Benjamin, and Adina Harris. Funeral at 2 PM, Monday, at Temple Beth-El. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont. Donations may be made in his name to Temple Beth-El 11023 and to Friends of Hospice, 1845 Northern Blvd., Manhasset 11030.

title: Clemens Is Optimistic About Quick Recovery
description: Roger Clem ens played first base today or the role of a first baseman, anyway, as his teenage son Koby took instruction from the Yankees coach Willie Randolph on how to turn a double play. Clemens stepped and threw as he tossed the ball, jumped a bit to reach a couple of throws, moving like someone who does not have a serious groin muscle injury.

Funeral Tuesday 9:15 AM from the McManus-Lorey Funeral Home, 2084 Horse Block Road, Medford. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at Church of the Resurrection, Farmingville. description: In Thailand's slow-motion revolution from the rule of men to the rule of law, the test ahead could not be more stark.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Repairs For 'Sick' Building
description: Widespread complaints by workers about difficulty breathing have prompted the state to spend $325,000 to evaluate and repair the headquarters of the Departments of Revenue and Social Services. The State Bond Commission approved the emergency request to fix the 19-story building, which officials suspect is riddled with water leaks, said Patrick T. Nolan, a spokesman for the Department of Public Works. Hundreds of state workers have complained of respiratory problems and have asked to be moved out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANTZ, JANE IRIS
description: KRANTZ-Jane Iris. Of West Nyack, died on July 27, 2001, at age 74. Born in NYC, on July 15, 1927, to Sigmund and Sadie (nee Theise) Steinheimer. On December 22, 1946, she married Rabbi Abraham Krantz. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her children Jeremy Krantz (wife Robin) of Cortlandt Manor, NY, Melissa Krantz (husband David Fleisher) of Harrison, NY, and Deborah Feldman (husband Marc) of Woodland Hills, CA. Also survived by seven grandchildren and predeceased by a sister Beverly Wegbreit. For information, Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809. www.zionmemorialchapel.com

title: Patents; A method of collecting consumer data renews questions about patents on business practices.
description: THE battle to capture the attention of consumers and to influence how they spend money has resulted in an entire industry called customer relationship management. The idea is to help companies attract new buyers, identify valuable customers and win consumer loyalty. To do that, many companies build profiles consisting of the biographies and buying habits of consumers so the companies can customize marketing and tailor their sales pitches.

title: Swiss Reinsurance Company Plans to Buy a U.S. Counterpart
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company, one of the world's largest insurers of insurance companies, is buying Lincoln Reinsurance, the largest life reinsurance company in the United States, for $2.5 billion, the companies said last night.

title: Prof. Derek Freeman Dies at 84; Challenged Margaret Mead
description: Professor Derek Freeman, who challenged Margaret Mead, provoking a fierce anthropological controversy, died July 6 in Canberra, Australia. He was 84.

description: Internet users upset about the process for registering addresses with the new dot-biz extension have complained that the system is being run like a lottery, and a new lawsuit says that is exactly what it is.

description: GANS-Maurice G. Attorney Extraordinaire, died peacefully at home on July 28, 2001. Son of the late Judge Julius and Sylvia Gans. Loved dearly by his wife Carol; daughters and sons-in-law, Linda and Jack Juppe, Judy and Michael Nash, Patrice and Howard Winston, Keri and Bart Labiner; son and daughter-in-law John and Arlene; daughter-in-law Kathleen Carroll; grandchildren John, Jennifer, Erik, Marc and Morgan. title: Letting the Dollar Alone
description: Currency markets have been wondering whether the United States might moderate its strong-dollar policy. On July 19, President Bush pointed out that the dollar's high value relative to other currencies had dampened demand for American exports and hurt corporate profits, suggesting the need for corrective action. But on Thursday Paul O'Neill, the secretary of the Treasury, joined his two most recent predecessors in backing the strong-dollar policy that has helped to keep inflation and import prices low, and foreign investment high, during the past decade. Propping up or weakening the dollar would require interventions that might do more harm than good. For the time being, Mr. Bush and Mr. O'Neill should sit back and allow economic trends to influence the currency's position.

title: MediaTalk; Our Cover Article, Brought to You by . . .
description: Over the years, the line has blurred between news and advertising. Even so, a magazine in Nevada may have broken new ground: sponsorships of cover articles.

title: Landslide in Japan For Governing Party
description: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party roared to victory in a critical vote for the upper house of Parliament, clinging firmly to the coattails of Junichiro Koizumi, the most popular prime minister in postwar history. The party won more than half of the 121 contested seats in the 247-seat upper house.

title: Convicted in Youth, Inmates Accept Fate and Look Ahead
description: Marcus Dixon, 18, was watching the news on television in his cell block at a Nevada state prison on Friday when the report came on that a Florida judge had sentenced 14-year-old Nathaniel Brazill to 28 years in prison without parole for killing his teacher. Nathaniel had committed a terrible crime and deserved to be punished, Mr. Dixon said in a telephone interview from the prison on Saturday.
