title: El Seco Journal; New York Garment Mogul Takes Business Home
description: If there is truth in New York City's famous anthem, then Jaime Lucero, a dishwasher turned garment-district millionaire, can make it anywhere. And 25 years after migrating to the city of skyscrapers from the mountains of central Mexico, he seems determined to match his success back home.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bullet Hits Sleeping Boy
description: A sleeping 6-year-old boy was wounded yesterday morning when a stray bullet sliced through the wall of his home in Hollis, the police said. The boy, whom the police did not identify, was in bed when he was hit in the leg, officials said. Investigators said that houses and cars in the neighborhood were riddled with bullets from the shooting and that they did not believe that the boy was an intended target. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Political Memo; Being Mike Bloomberg, Without a Script or a Doubt
description: That Michael R. Bloomberg thinks a lot of himself is one of the incontrovertible truths of his successful business career. It may also help to explain why Mr. Bloomberg has not always appeared politically sure-footed as he passes the midway point in his bid to become the Republican choice for mayor.

title: Eudora Welty's Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Talk of Parks, Lifeguards And Trains
description: From subways to schools to parks, the men who want to be mayor of New York spent much of yesterday unveiling plans for recruiting lifeguards, adding classroom space and reducing subway dragging incidents.

title: Snowed In on a Summer Evening by Two Pinteresque Winters
description: Katie Mitchell, the director of ''Mountain Language'' and ''Ashes to Ashes,'' the seemingly disparate one-acts that made up the final theatrical program of Lincoln Center Festival's celebration of Harold Pinter, tied the plays together with a snowstorm. ''Mountain Language'' opened with one; it faded away to reveal a line of prisoners along a prison camp wall. ''Ashes to Ashes'' ended with one, revealed beyond the walls of the living room that held the play's confrontation between husband and wife.

title: Edward Gierek Dies at 88; Polish Communist Reformer
description: Edward Gierek, Poland's Western-oriented Communist leader for 10 years until he was toppled in 1980 by food protests and strikes that led to the creation of Solidarity, the Soviet bloc's first independent trade union, died yesterday in the southern Polish town of Cieszyn, Reuters reported. He was 88.

title: In His Heroes' Footsteps
description: Nikos Pollias, a four-time winner of the Athens Marathon, is accompanied by the ghosts of two famous Greek runners as he trains for the most important race of his life, the marathon at the 2004 Summer Olympics.

title: Examples of Greatness Are Across the Street
description: With an eventful first week of the meet nearly in the books, horse enthusiasts have plenty to chew on here at the Spa, which they are doing, intoxicatingly, morning, noon and night.

title: Yankees Gain Rave Reviews In a Sweep Of Toronto
description: Ronald Reagan was a lock in 1984 and the Kennedys are unbeatable in Massachusetts, but in baseball there are not supposed to be any sure things. There are too many variables, with one hot pitcher capable of reversing momentum.

title: A Bedeviling Question in The Cadence Of English
description: As an Indian writer living in New York, I find myself constantly asked a question with which my American confreres never have to contend: ''But whom do you write for?''

title: Got sticking power? A tagline and a mustache stop a slide in milk consumption.
description: BARELY eight years have passed since the campaign first started. But the dairy industry's ads, with the ''Got milk?'' tagline, have made a lasting mark on the American consumer landscape.

title: Why Gamble With Our Safety Net?
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian-American Team Wins At Tournament Semifinals
description: A star-studded group including four Italian world champions faced a Cinderella foursome in the final of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here today at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, as well as information about errors that call for correction. Messages may be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). For comments on an editorial: letters@nytimes.com. For newspaper delivery questions: 1-800-NYTIMES (1-800-698-4637).

title: Feeding Frenzy; Big Magazine Publishers Get Bigger, As the Smaller Ones Get Gobbled Up
description: If you think of the magazine marketplace as a long table laden with epicurean goodies, then companies like Time Inc., Primedia, Advance and Gruner & Jahr, are the Henry VIII-like gourmands, elbowing their competitors out of the way as they tear at the rack of lamb and scoop up the crme brle, getting bigger and bigger as they sweep the stray magazine or small publisher into their expanding gullets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELTMAN, OSCAR
description: GELTMAN-Oscar. On July 28. Beloved husband of the late Constance Rosenbluth Geltman. Son of Israel and Ann Silverstone Geltman. Passed away peacefully at the age of 95. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Vieques Voters Want the Navy To Leave Now
description: In a symbolic but emotional victory, residents here voted today by more than two to one in favor of demanding the immediate departure of the United States Navy from this small Puerto Rican island, whose eastern tip has been used for mock invasions, bombing runs and target practice for more than six decades.

title: Extending Disney's Family
description: The Fox Family cable channel had been sitting on the auction block for months as its primary owners, the News Corporation and Saban Entertainment, sought to unload it.

title: Costly Drug Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN INGEN, BERNARD JOSEPH JR. ''BERNIE''
description: VAN INGEN-Bernard Joseph Jr. ''Bernie''. 78, of Jewett, NY, died on July 28, 2001, at Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, NY. Survived by his loving wife Maria, daughter Cora and son B.J. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Theresa's R.C. Church, Windham, NY. Calling hours Monday, 5-8 PM, at Decker Funeral Home, Main St, Windham, NY; 518-734-3535. Interment Saratoga National Cemetery. Donations may be made to Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, NY 12401, attn: Unit 4SMC or ICU.

title: Israeli Helicopters Attack a Palestinian Police Base
description: Israeli helicopter gunships fired at least three missiles at the main Palestinian police headquarters in Gaza City today, the Israeli army said, wounding seven police officers. The attack came on the same day that six Palestinians died in an unexplained explosion near the West Bank city of Nablus.

title: New Economy; Why a movie by Spielberg failed to excite a public that was tried of technology.
description: AS quietly as a robot drifting into sleep mode, the science fiction fantasy ''A.I.: Artificial Intelligence'' recently slipped from the box office top 10, a mere four weeks after its debut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COAKLEY, VIRGINIA MCPIKE
description: COAKLEY-Virginia McPike. Died gracefully on July 27, 2001, after a long illness. The Larchmont resident was preceded in death by her sister, Gracemarie M. Neville, and her brothers, Edward J. and Frank R. McPike. She proudly served as a Women Airforce Service Pilot (WASP) during World War II. Of the more than 20,000 women who applied for training, fewer than 2,000 were accepted and 1074 won their wings as WASPs. She maintained her pilot's license after the War, and she campaigned for Veterans status for the WASPs which was finally authorized by Congress in 1979. Virginia is survived by 10 nieces and nephews. Visiting hours are 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM on Monday at Fox Funeral Home at 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont. A funeral Mass will be on Tuesday at 10:00 AM at Saints John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont.

title: Nominee for F.B.I. Director Vows to Turn Agency Around
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 — President Bush's nominee to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation received a warm and respectful reception on Capitol Hill today, and he vowed to spend all his energy on turning the agency around.

title: British Telecommunications Rejects Bid for Local Telephone Wires
description: British Telecommunications has rejected an initial $11.4 billion offer for its local telephone wires from a consortium led by Babcock & Brown, an American asset-finance company, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Why Gamble With Our Safety Net?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Municipal Workers' Pay
description: Teachers, police officers and other municipal workers are paid more in New Jersey than their counterparts earn in all but three states, a census report released last week said. New Jersey workers are paid an average of more than $45,000 a year, behind only California, New York and the District of Columbia. New Jersey teachers are, on average, the nation's highest paid. James W. Hughes, a professor of public policy at Rutgers University, said, ''New Jersey residents demand a high level of municipal and county services and are willing to pay the price.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, MARGARET CREAL
description: SHAFER-Margaret Creal. The Bard College community deeply mourns the passing of Margaret Creal Shafer, a longtime friend and integral member of the Bard family and the Hudson Valley cultural community. Her vitality, creativity and energy have played an essential role in the life of the college and of the surrounding communities. She will be deeply missed. Our condolences go out to her children, grandchildren, and great grandchild. Services will be held at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, in Barrytown, New York on Saturday, August 4th. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab, II, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENVALD, JEROME K.
description: GREENVALD-Jerome K. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Rabbi Robert (Reuven), Stuart and Alyssa and Jennifer and Gary Goffner. Loving grandfather of Jessica, Hunter, Perry, Jason and Amanda. Services today, 9:30 AM, at BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: China Grins and Bears It
description: With Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit here this weekend, and in anticipation of President Bush's planned visit in October, the Chinese have begun putting on their most charming face.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Two Killed After Party
description: Two unidentified men were killed in a shooting early yesterday a few blocks from a party they had just left, the police said. One victim was shot while sitting in his car on the corner of Varsity Road and Kerrigan Boulevard. The other man was killed on the sidewalk while trying to flee. The police said several fights had erupted at the party and at least two gunshots had been fired into the air. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Harold Land, 73, Saxophonist Who Made a Splash in the Bop Era
description: Harold Land, a West Coast tenor saxophonist who had a brush with the jazz pantheon through a brief tenure with the Clifford Brown-Max Roach Quintet in the mid-1950's, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 73 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: On Television; TV Works in Mysterious Ways for Pat Robertson
description: Three years ago, the televangelist Pat Robertson turned his wrath on the city of Orlando and Disney World, which was hosting an event called ''Gay Days.''

title: Arnold Office Resigns From PNC Account
description: The McLean, Va., office of Arnold Worldwide, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, has ended its two-year relationship with PNC Bank, after taking on assignments from another banking client, the Citizens Financial Group. Billings for the PNC Bank account were estimated at $30 million.

title: Tax Rebate (Vote Ploy?)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVER, JAMES H.
description: GAVER-James H. Of Secaucus, NJ, on Thursday, July 26, 2001. Mr. Gaver was a 1963 graduate of Yale University and was employed by the Federal Reserve Bank, New York, NY, from 1967 to 1997, where he rose to the position of Vice President. Beloved brother of Dean A. and Charles Gaver Jr. Loving uncle of three nieces and two nephews. The family will receive their friends at the Vander Plaat Colonial Home, Inc., 13-31 Saddle River Rd., Fair Lawn, NJ, Tuesday, July 31, 2001, 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Yale University would be appreciated.

title: Giants' Offense Assumes a Strut in Workouts
description: The Giants put all their pads on this weekend and started hitting each other in earnest, which is much rarer than it may seem. In the five or six months of an N.F.L. season, it is astounding how seldom the players do any real hitting or tackling in practice. Because of the risk of injury and the millions invested in salaries, the reality is that there is little full-speed, or even three-quarter-speed, contact in an entire season of practices.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Sarah Bolton was named to the new post of marketing manager at Dwell magazine, San Francisco, published by Pixie Communications. She had been a consultant.

title: A Cunning Climber, Armstrong Joins the Gods of Cycling
description: After telling his rivals that he has never felt as strong as he does now and that he expects to feel even more powerful next year, Lance Armstrong cruised into Paris today as the winner of his third consecutive Tour de France.

title: Leaping Into the Void With a Dance Feast
description: The only dependable sources of dance on television today are advertisements and ''Ally McBeal.'' One wonders why, given that dance is certainly the most excitingly visual of all the theater arts. But MetroArts/13 has leaped into the void with ''Celebrating Modern Dance,'' a weeklong series that will be shown tonight through Sunday on the Metro TV and MetroLearning cable channels.

title: Despite Truce and Talks, Pessimism Spreads in Macedonia
description: Someone had blown up the house of an ophthalmologist in the village of Tearce. Timbers still smoldered on Saturday.. Red roof tiles littered the street like blocks from a child's toppled tower. A retired professor who lived nearby, Mirko Krstevski, took a look around. Then he loaded up blankets, clothes, crates of eggs from his neglected chickens and left town.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: 'The last thing people think of when they see a pedicab is freedom, but it is a kind of freedom, believe it or not. You can make your own schedule, pretty much. And you get to meet the people -- good people, bad people, you've got it all. I always introduce myself. People develop the skill of telling their life story in a few minutes -- they talk fast, talk rich -- and you find out things. I have a few of my life stories that I tell, too. It's theater on wheels. It's based on a true story. Me and my passengers, we are a mobile institution.'' interview by Catherine Saint Louis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSEX, MARIE L.
description: ESSEX-Marie L. Age 64, of Trumbull, CT, died on Friday, July 27, 2001. Mrs. Essex, a well recognized fashion illustrator and fashion educator, was a member of the Parsons Fashion Design Department over 40 years as a fulltime faculty, Associate Chair for 10 years, and its Chair from 1996-2000. Survivors include her beloved husband, Jack T. Essex, a son, Harry Essex of NYC, a sister, Vivian Ascenzi and her husband Orlando of Bedford Hills, NY, several nieces and nephews. Donations to Mercy Corps International or Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. Viewing at the Abriola Parkview Funeral Home, 419 White Plains Rd., Trumbull, CT, Monday, 4-8 PM. Funeral Mass Christ the King Church, Trumbull, CT, 10 AM, Tuesday. Interment St. Francis Cemetery, Mt. Kisco, NY, 1 PM, Tuesday.

title: Buying Back Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Bears Sign Terrell To Five-Year Deal
description: The Chicago Bears signed wide receiver David Terrell, their first-round draft pick out of Michigan, to a five-year contract. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Essay; Not Arafat's Fault?
description: The negotiators of the process that led to the terrorist war against Israel have independently reached consensus on how to protect their posteriors: because everybody was responsible for last year's failure at Camp David, nobody can be held accountable.

title: Sports of The Times; Should the Mets' Fans Even Dare to Dream?
description: A NUMBER of years ago the novelist Sinclair Lewis wrote a book with the title, ''It Can't Happen Here.'' Never mind the subject matter, but the notion would certainly have been applicable to the tenants of Shea Stadium for much of this season. Repeat as National League champs? How about National League chumps? Get back in the World Series? You serious? Look at the standing: the Mets have a better chance of beating out the nearly expired Expos for last place in the N.L. East than getting even a wild-card spot in the playoffs.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Residency Rule For Candidates
description: A federal judge has ruled that New Jersey's strict residency requirement for legislative candidates violates the United States Constitution's equal-protection clause. Jay R. Schwartz and Dennis Gonzalez sued the state after being barred from running for the Assembly in Passaic County. Because of redistricting and their moves to different towns, they had not lived in their districts for a full year. But with the June 26 primary over, the impact of the July 19 ruling by the judge, Dickinson R. Debevoise, above, of Federal District Court in Newark, was uncertain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOYCE W.
description: GREENE-Joyce W. Died at home in NYC, July 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur B., mother of Jonathan M., and mother-in-law of Denise. She was one of the greatest ladies ever; she was respected for her wit and generosity. She was a friend and caretaker of all animals. Joyce was born in England, 1933. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, August 1st, 7-9 PM, with funeral services Thursday, August 2nd, 5:30 PM. Interment in England. Memorial services will be scheduled at a future date. In lieu of flowers, gifts may given in the name of Joyce W. Greene to the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, 410 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016; 212-532-4455.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bayonne: Barge Worker Is Killed
description: A barge worker died yesterday after he was crushed between two barges and fell into the water when the vessels separated, the police and Coast Guard officials said. Officials said Walter Romanoski, 45, of Northport, N.Y., was conscious in the water near the Claremont Terminal in Bayonne, south of the Statue of Liberty, when Coast Guard rescuers reached him just before 2 p.m. Mr. Romanoski was placed in a basket, hoisted onto a New York Police Department boat and taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, where he was pronounced dead on arrival, said Detective Eugene Canapi, a police spokesman.

title: For Lawyers, Duty Is to Client
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSS, CHARLES B.
description: MOSS-Charles B. We think of you all the time. We will love you forever. Paula, Jinny and Charley

title: Germany's Need for Immigrants
description: Germans will have to overcome their traditional discomfort with immigration if their nation is to remain an economic power over the next half-century. A high-profile bipartisan commission appointed by the government recognized this reality when it called recently for a new immigration policy, one that would allow the entry of 50,000 foreign qualified workers a year. The ruling Social Democratic Party plans to draft new legislation based on the commission's findings.

title: Staticky Reception For Nuclear Families On Prime-Time TV
description: No one has ever directly accused me of being a successor to Donna Reed, but lately I've been feeling an urge to wear pearls and a shirtwaist dress around the house. If I'm going to be an anachronism, I may as well dress the part.

title: E-Commerce Report; Success using contrary notions: grow modestly and actually make money doing business on the Web.
description: AMAZON's decision last year to trade growth for profitability was welcomed by investors who had feared that the enormous e-tailer would grow itself straight into Chapter 7. Since then, the company's stock has had more ups and downs than a San Francisco seismograph, offering further evidence of how challenging a task it is to tighten the reins on a sprawling e-commerce operation.

title: Labonte Slithers Through the 'Tunnel Turn' for a Victory
description: The turn is only 60 feet wide, and those who hurtle through it at 180 miles an hour say it sometimes feels as narrow as an unlighted hallway. Bobby Labonte figured he might as well try to overtake Dale Earnhardt Jr. at that spot, despite the risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILCHRIST, PAMELA
description: GILCHRIST-Pamela. Of Chappaqua, NY, died at Northern Westchester Hospital Center on Saturday, July 28, after a five-year battle with breast cancer. Born November 26, 1935, to the late Washington Roebling and Pamela Lowerre (McCaughey) Vogeley, she is survived by her husband, Bruce Gilchrist, son, Lawrence Charles Rubin of Brewster, NY, daughter, Pamela Nancy Rubin of Pound Ridge, NY, brother Thomas Roebling Vogeley of Doyleston, PA, (formerly of Pound Ridge), and four grandchildren, Benjamin Kyle Rubin, Lawrence Yale Rubin, Sydney Rose Rubin and Christopher Robert Noonan, four nieces, three nephews, eight grandnieces and three grandnephews. Her sister Elizabeth deWarem (Vogeley) Hantscho (formerly of Pound Ridge) died in 1985 of breast cancer. Private interment at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY, will be followed by a Memorial Service at 12 noon on Saturday, August 4, at the First Congregational Church, 210 Orchard Ridge Road, Chappaqua, NY.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: 2 More Agencies Decide to End Operations
description: Add two more agencies to the growing list of ones closing.

title: In the House, He's the Man in the Middle, and Loving It
description: REPUBLICAN moderates in the House had long had a touch of the Rodney Dangerfield problem: they did not get much respect.

title: Texans Cheer Tour Victory
description: In a downtown brew pub decorated with yellow balloons and yellow ribbons, a capacity crowd of cycling fans and supporters of the Lance Armstrong Foundation gathered this afternoon to cheer Armstrong, their fellow Texan, as he won the Tour de France. The loudest cheer came when the video screen showed Armstrong cycling in his yellow jersey holding a large Texas flag.

title: Jail Time in the Digital Age
description: Dmitri Sklyarov is a Russian programmer who, until recently, lived and worked in Moscow. He wrote a program that was legal in Russia, and in most of the world, a program his employer, ElcomSoft, then sold on the Internet. Adobe Corporation bought a copy and complained to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the program violated American law and that, by the way, Mr. Sklyarov was about to give a lecture in Las Vegas describing the weaknesses in Adobe's electronic book software. Two weeks ago, the F.B.I. arrested Mr. Sklyarov. He still sits in a Las Vegas jail.

title: For Lawyers, Duty Is to Client
description: To the Editor:

title: Protestant Teenager Is Killed in Belfast Drive-By Shooting
description: LONDON, July 30 — Protestant paramilitaries killed an 18-year-old Protestant man and wounded a Catholic friend in a drive-by shooting Sunday night on a group of teenagers as they stood talking outside a Gaelic football park in north Belfast.

title: A Peacetime Battle
description: The battle raging within the Pentagon over strategy and budgets, which has become as intense and intemperate as any in recent memory, is much more than the traditional confrontations between the military and the civilian leadership over turf, money and numbers of troops.

title: Agassi Defeats Old Friend Sampras
description: One superstar is a married man, the other five months from fatherhood. They are boys no longer. But on the stage that made them famous, Pete Sampras, 29, and Andre Agassi, 31, are not yet ready to surrender their spaces to the next generation.

title: Cable's Instinct For the Racy And Repetitive
description: July 17 was an uneventful day in the investigation into the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy, the Washington intern.

title: Street Celebrations After Soccer Victory
description: Thousands of soccer fans reveled in streets across the region yesterday over Colombia's victory in a Latin American soccer tournament. Several arrests were reported and traffic was tied up, but the celebrations were generally peaceful.

title: All-Stars' Dream Becoming Reality
description: It was a story with enough plucking of heartstrings to fire up the imagination of any Hollywood screenwriter. Consider the one-line pitch: a team of scrappy Little League players from the gritty streets of the Bronx go head to head against well-financed suburban boys in a surprise bid for the Little League World Series.

title: Stars on the Screen, the Moon Up Above
description: The suburban drive-in movie theater -- that iconic site of American adolescent lust -- may have gone the way of the Partridge Family. But few things being sweeter in summer than watching movies in the moonlight, New Yorkers are spreading their blankets and kicking off their workday shoes to relish the romance of open-air cinema again: On rooftops, along riverbanks, in neighborhood parks, free outdoor film screenings have sprouted all over the city in recent years.

title: Paul Giamatti Is a Character Actor for Our Age
description: People recognize Paul Giamatti in public sometimes, but they're not always sure why. ''It's a weird thing,'' says the actor, whose roles have stretched from Andrei Prozorov, the spineless brother in Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' to Pig Vomit in Howard Stern's ''Private Parts'' to a nefarious orangutan who trades human slaves in Tim Burton's new ''Planet of the Apes.'' ''A lot of the time people don't quite know where they know me from. They're not necessarily thinking that I'm a movie actor.''

title: Respect Eludes Dominant Jones
description: After the light-heavyweight champion Roy Jones Jr. had finished the beating he inflicted on Julio Gonzalez on Saturday night at the Staples Center, Gonzalez left the ring with a swollen face, and Jones emerged with what he said was a swollen left hand. Guess which ailing body part -- Gonzalez's head or Jones's hand -- causes more concern in the boxing world?

title: A Battle Over a Group's Fate and a Neighborhood's Soul
description: Last March, an eclectic event was held at Performance Space 122: a Purim party and spaghetti supper for an East Village organization with Puerto Rican roots. It was for the Charas/El Bohio Community Center, whose long fight against eviction has now come down to the wire.

title: Melee at Jerusalem's Most Sacred, and Explosive, Site
description: Jerusalem and its sacred places returned to the center of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today when Palestinians on an elevated Muslim compound hurled stones at Jews praying below, provoking a battle with the Israeli police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGOBARDI, VIOLET
description: LONGOBARDI-Violet, 91, on July 25, 2001. With profound sorrow, our community mourns the loss of Violet, a founding board member of the Mary McDowell Center for Learning and our constant inspiration. Her commitment to creating a school in Brooklyn to nurture children with special needs, support their parents and serve the community touched everyone who knew her. We looked to her keen intelligence and honesty to meet our challenges and her warmth to transform us into an extended family. Her friendship, love and zest for life will remain the model for us all. The Board, Faculty, Staff, Students and Parents of the Mary McDowell Center for Learning

title: Metro Matters; Free Theater, But the Lines? Unspeakable
description: TO be clear from the outset, we do not knock free Shakespeare (and Chekhov) in the park. We love and revere Joseph Papp's great legacy.

title: Why Gamble With Our Safety Net?
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Figaro' Frolic Played for 21st-Century Laughs
description: So strong was the buzz surrounding the Salzburg Festival's new ''Nozze di Figaro'' that one felt bad for not liking it more. Mozart profits from a band of attractive young singers, but this is a director's show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTIN, GLADYS
description: VALENTIN-Gladys. While vacationing in Florida passed away as a result of injuries sustained in a car accident on July 26, 2001. She had very strong religious beliefs and had dedicated her life to the Lord Jehovah. A dedicated wife, Gladys is survived by her husband Neftali Valentin, and by her parents Gilberto and Luz Martell of the Bronx, NY. She is also survived by her beloved sister Milagros Rivera and her children Michael and Tania Rivera, her brother Rafael Martell and his wife Diana, and his two daughters Cindy and Betsy Martell, and his son Rafael, her brother Pedro L. Martell of Miami, FL, sister Carmen and husband Isidro Marrero and their children Matthew, Marcus and Danny, her sister Luz Vidal and her son Jonathan, her other sister Diana and her two children Eric and Erika Rodriguez, her other sister Ramonita and husband Eddie Diaz, her brother Robert and wife Jazmin Martell and brother Julio Martell. Gladys, you have left a void in our life that we will never be able to fill, and you will forever be in our hearts.

title: Satellite Radio's Bet on Dissatisfied Listeners
description: After years of audience stability in radio, listeners are now impatiently switching off far more quickly than they used to. Listening has slipped 11 percent since the early 1990's, according to Arbitron audits.

title: Eclectic And Subtle Brute Force
description: Oscar Peterson, playing on Friday night at the Blue Note to a packed house that had begun lining up outside four hours early, was a reliable, one-man factory of amiable hybrids. He connected good-natured blues stomping, sentimental melody and classical allusions, all rendered in busy but authoritative virtuosity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, FREDERICK
description: MOSS-Frederick, 72. Died on July 27 after a long battle with cancer; his family was at his side. He is survived by his beloved family: wife, Jan; children, Rebecca Guyver, Benjamin Moss, Katherine Kehoe, Joseph Wayland; brother Gerald Moss; and nine grandchildren. A loving husband, father and grandfather, ''King'' will be missed and remembered always for his fine mind, his acerbic wit, his integrity and his inability to bore. Mr. Moss was a graduate of Columbia Law School and had a long and distinguished career as a senior executive in the Securities Industry and was, at his death, Chairman of the Board of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange. A memorial service will be held, at a later date, on Great Cranberry Island, Maine. If you wish to honor his memory, please do a kindness for someone in need.

title: City Homeownership Plans Lift Neighborhoods, Study Says
description: A survey of home sales in what were among the city's most desolate neighborhoods indicates that new construction and renovation of existing housing through city-subsidized programs that promote homeownership significantly increased property values on neighboring blocks.

title: Judge in Colombia Halts Spraying of Drug Crops
description: First came farmers' complaints about skin rashes and destroyed banana groves, for which they blamed American-supported aerial spraying to destroy coca and heroin poppy crops. Then the governors of four southern provinces, galvanized by constituent complaints, went to Washington and Europe to lobby for alternatives.

title: Crisp Weather for Spoofing and Musing
description: If ever there was an evening made for the Tanglewood Festival here, it was Saturday: sensuously cool and clear. And if ever there was a program made for such an evening, it was Robert Spano's with the Boston Symphony Orchestra: lithe yet limpid works by Tchaikovsky, Stravinsky and John Harbison.

title: U.S. Scholar Convicted as Spy Allowed Back Into Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, July 30  Li Shaomin, a Chinese-born American scholar convicted by Beijing of spying for Taiwan and deported to the United States last week, returned to Hong Kong this evening to take up his teaching job here.

title: Telecom Italia Falls to Pirelli and Benetton : Redrawing the Map Of Italian Capitalism
description: ROME  Italian capitalism was hit by its second earthquake of the summer this weekend as Pirelli and the Benetton family moved to take effective control of Telecom Italia, the heavily indebted phone, Internet and television company, in a deal worth 7 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROTSKY, ESTELLE
description: GROTSKY-Estelle. On July 28. Through laughter and song Estelle enriched our lives. She will be missed but always remembered and loved. Wife of the late Paul Grotsky. ''You'll never walk alone.'' For any additional information contact the I. J. Morris, Inc., Funeral Home, 1-800-624-8282.

title: New Software, New Scrutiny For Microsoft
description: Three years ago, Microsoft was preparing to introduce a new version of its Windows operating system. The personal computer industry was eagerly awaiting the new offering. But federal and state antitrust regulators worried that Windows 98 would tighten Microsoft's grip on the computer industry and inhibit competition in ways they believed were illegal.

title: Pirelli's Takeover of Olivetti Is a Reversal for an Executive
description: When senior executives met on Friday in Milan at the home of Marco Tronchetti Provera, the chief executive of the Italian tire and cable company Pirelli, to put the finishing touches on a deal that would give Pirelli effective control of Olivetti, Roberto Colaninno, Olivetti's chief executive, was not there.

title: Yankees Add Hitchcock to Bolster Rotation
description: Sterling Hitchcock has a reconstructed left elbow and has pitched three games in the majors this year, and the Yankees are not expecting him to lead them into October after they swapped two minor leaguers to San Diego for the left-hander yesterday. But Hitchcock will add stability to a rotation that has been laden with rookies this season.

Under a hazy half moon and a blanket of artificial stars, New Jersey's most all-American band gave the cheering crowd plenty of corn and apple pie along with the fireworks obligatory at every arena rock show.

title: New West Coast College, Born of the Far East

description: The oldest girls' camp in the United States is celebrating its 100th season this summer, and remarkably little has changed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEPINNA, GEORGE
description: DePINNA-George. Happy birthday daddy. Not a day goes by that I don't miss you. Love you so much-N.M.I.

title: Vanishing Wetlands of the Musical Sort
description: Peter Shapiro knew the life of the club he owns, Wetlands, was drawing to an end when he saw scaffolding and other signs of urban renewal slowly working their way northward along Hudson Street in TriBeCa. Last week the construction frenzy finally reached the doorstep of Wetlands, at the corner of Laight Street, and the office building that houses it was sold to an architect and a group of local residents who want to convert the space into apartments. The club, which was on a short-term lease, is to announce today that it will be closing in mid-September. For music fans, already reeling from the loss of a number of clubs in a city whose administration is seen as hostile to night life, the shuttering of Wetlands, which opened in 1989, is a major blow.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Argument Leads To Violence
description: An argument between two men yesterday at Roosevelt Avenue and 111th Street in Corona left a bystander in extremely grave condition in the hospital, the police said. One of the men pulled a knife, and the other responded by taking out a handgun and firing shots, the police said. A bullet struck the bystander, who was not identified, in the back of the head, the police said. The man who fired ran, and the victim was taken to the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Labor Day in New York City
description: Labor Day weekend is a time for one last blowout before summer's over. It will be a little easier to say goodbye to summer in New York City with a package offered by the Gorham, a 115-room hotel on West 55th Street. Guests who stay Aug. 31 through Sept. 4 (Friday to Tuesday) pay for only three of the four nights, at a rate of $155 a night for a deluxe room -- down from the usual $285 rate. Even one-night stays are cheaper, at $169 a night on Aug. 31 or Sept. 1 and $125 on Sept. 2 or 3. And for those who drive into the city, parking is included with a minimum two-night stay at $175 a night (but once the car is parked, it must stay in the garage  until you check out, anyway). All rates are based on availability. Information: (800) 735-0710 or www.gorhamhotel.com .

title: Far From Mexico, Making a Place Like Home
description: Here, the Mexicans live in run-down apartment complexes rather than in small houses of sun-baked brick. They work in a factory casting toilets and sinks rather than fishing for tilapia in Chapala Lake. They practice soccer on a lush high school field rather than on a dusty pebble-strewn pitch.

title: White House Says the U.S. Is Not a Loner, Just Choosy
description: In his first six months in office, President Bush has abandoned a treaty on fighting global warming, rejected protocols enforcing a ban on germ warfare, demanded amendments to an accord on illegal sales of small arms, threatened to skip an international conference on racism and vowed to withdraw from a landmark pact limiting ballistic missile defenses.

title: Tunnel Vision; Helpfulness So Precious It's Kept Under Glass
description: It is not easy to project human warmth from behind bulletproof glass. Especially when the glass has a big bullet hole in it, right at forehead level, reminding the guy on one side that people on the other side have been known to carry more than money and want more than MetroCards.

title: A Diviner of Meaning in Political Names and Lists
description: AS the September primaries approach, hundreds of attention-starved politicians are working the city like entertainers at an enormous birthday party, making balloon animals in the living room while the children sit in the den, watching Barney. Still, certain surnames get bandied about: Badillo, Bloomberg, Ferrer, Green, Hevesi, Vallone, Skurnik.

title: An Escort Into the Land Of Sickness
description: A colleague who's an oncologist called to say he had referred a patient to me. I thanked him and didn't think much about it until I was seated opposite the patient, an elderly man, beginning the consultation.

title: Bush Fails to Win Support On Hill for 'Fast Track' Trade
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Saying they did not have enough votes to prevail this week on President Bush's top trade priority, Republican leaders of the House today postponed until the fall the effort to grant the president broad authority to negotiate new trade agreements.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Paper Maker's Loss
description: The South African pulp and paper group Sappi Ltd. has reported a 41 percent drop in profit for its third quarter. ''We are close to the bottom of the market,'' the chairman of Sappi, Eugene van As, said. Sappi's net income, before one-time items, fell to $55 million in the quarter, from $95 million a year earlier.

title: Tangled Issues in Congress: Cloning and Stem Cell Study
description: With more than 260 members of Congress now on record in support of federal financing for embryonic stem cell research, a related controversy, cloning, is now forcing lawmakers to draw explicit limits on how far they think embryo experiments should go.

description: This thoroughly Russian village near the city of Nizhny Novgorod has been host this summer to very unusual guests -- children from Chechnya being given respite from what is for them nearly a lifetime of war at home.

title: Annan Says Race Conference Must Chart Way for Future
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, told the National Urban League today that the world conference against racism next month is aimed at preventing future problems, not becoming mired in old ones.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Route From Mexico Is Chosen
description: The State Department of Transportation chose a two-lane highway, U.S. 287, on the eastern side of the state, rather than six-lane Interstate 25, as the preferred path of Colorado's stretch of the Ports-to-Plains trade highway for commercial traffic to and from Mexico. To satisfy New Mexico's preference for I-25, the Colorado officials also recommended using a New Mexico state highway, Route 87, to link I-25 and other highways with Laredo, Tex., the start of the Port-to-Plains trade highway. A final route is subject to Congressional approval. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Kmart Cuts Price Of Net Access
description: Shifting its pricing strategies again, the Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce the price of monthly Internet access through its BlueLight.com premium service and eliminate its free basic service. BlueLight, an independent company in which Kmart holds a majority ownership, said that at $8.95 a month, the new service is the lowest-priced major provider offering unlimited Internet access. The company currently charges its subscribers $9.95 a month for 100 hours of Internet access. Until February BlueLight offered consumers free, unlimited Internet access. As the Internet advertising market sank however, BlueLight began limiting free use of its service to 12 hours a month and charging those who wanted more time. Kmart said yesterday that remaining subscribers to this free basic service would be disconnected on

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the efforts of an American transportation expert, Robert R. Kiley, to reorganize London's subway system referred incorrectly in some copies to a pending court ruling. A High Court judge ruled yesterday that the British government had the right to impose its plan. The ruling did not concern an injunction barring the release of critical studies by consultants.

description: The balmy weather complemented the barmy mood on Saturday afternoon at Summerstage, when August Darnell, the mastermind behind Kid Creole and the Coconuts, the fabulous post-punk, proto-hip-hop vaudeville troupe, donned his zoot suit and led his entourage through a rare return to home turf. Few artists could demand that nonchalant New Yorkers form a conga line in midafternoon, but Mr. Darnell has been bringing the party to cosmopolitan crowds for more than 20 years, and he asked the most of his fans on this special occasion.

Services were held.

description: Three months after the disappearance of the intern Chandra Ann Levy, police officials here are preparing to scale back the searches of remote stretches of the city that they have conducted in recent weeks in their hunt for Ms. Levy, a police spokesman said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panamsat To Cut Work Force
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, the largest operator of commercial satellites, plans to cut an undisclosed number of employees and has moved its headquarters to Wilton, Conn., as part of a plan to consolidate operations. The company expects to complete staff cuts in the United States and abroad by Aug. 31, a spokesman, Scott Tagliarino, said. Some employees have been offered severance packages, he said. without being more specific. The company has been hurt by lower spending by telecommunications companies that lease space on its satellites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWARTZ, ROBERT
description: SWARTZ-Robert. With the passing of Robert Swartz, Bed Bath & Beyond has lost not only a dedicated and extremely capable director, but we have lost a wonderful and loyal friend. From the day the company opened its first door in 1971, Bob was always there to lend his wisdom and experience in his own kind way, never seeking anything in return. His contribution to our success will never be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his devoted wife, Inez, their children and grandchildren. Leonard Feinstein Warren Eisenberg Co-Chairmen, Bed Bath & Beyond

title: Split-Off From Mormons Assumes a New Name
description: People who know this city, near the Kansas border, will probably identify it as Harry S. Truman's hometown, where his presidential library stands. But, of course, there is more, like the blocklong complex of religious buildings with a stainless steel tower rising in a graceful spiral that reflects the Midwestern sunlight.

title: Brooklyn Girl, 9, Playing on Balcony, Falls to Her Death
description: A 9-year-old girl playing on the terrace of her 18th-floor apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, apparently leaned too far over the balcony and fell to her death yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: First Sex-Offender Report
description: A total of 5,270 convicted sex offenders were classified as of March 31 as having the potential to repeat their offenses, requiring some form of community notification under Megan's Law, the first annual report on the subject said. Among them, 2,388 were classified by county prosecutors as low-risk, or Tier 1 offenders, requiring notification of local police; 3,007 were classified as moderate-risk, or Tier 2 offenders, requiring notice to police, schools and some community groups; 325 were classified as high risk (Tier 3), requiring Tier 2 notification plus notice to neighbors and some other individuals. The State Supreme Court ordered annual reports in 1995, when it upheld the constitutionality of the law, which took effect last year after several appeals.

title: A Countersuit In Software Proxy Battle
description: The messy battle between the Texas billionaire Sam Wyly and Computer Associates became a bit messier yesterday when Mr. Wyly sued the company in response to a lawsuit that Computer Associates had filed against him earlier.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: JETBLUE GETS KENNEDY LEASE Jet Blue Airways and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have agreed on a five-year, $60 million lease that will enable JetBlue to more than double its operations at Kennedy Airport.

title: Giants' Special Teams Fall A Few Feet Short of Perfect
description: On Sunday afternoon, the Giants' new special-teams coach, Fred von Appen, characterized the state of the team's kicking game as muddled. And sure enough, this morning at Giants training camp even the Giants' place-kickers were suddenly thrown into the punting mix, booting spirals as they dusted off their form. It looked like an open casting call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, EVELYN
description: FREEMAN-Evelyn. Age eightyfour, on July 29, 2001. Beloved wife for forty-six years of the late John Freeman, devoted mother of Louis and Mitchell, adored grandmother of Isabel, Eric, Jonathan and Dylan. Her loving heart, independent spirit and remarkable fortitude will be missed by many. Funeral service Tuesday, July 31, 11 am at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Evelyn's name to the American Lung Association of New York, 432 Park Avenue South, NY NY 10016.

Loving father of David, Judith and Daniel, and their spouses, Marilyn, George Davison and Jennifer Conlin; beloved grandfather of Jessica, Katie, Sam, Alice, Harriet, Florence and Charles; brother of Mary Jane Pollack; and devoted husband of the late Lois Borwick Herman. A remarkable gentleman who led by example in pursuing high civic, artistic and personal ideals. We will honor him always. Memorial service on Monday, August 6, at 11:30 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom or the Franklin & Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in Hyde Park, NY.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Corruption Arrests
description: The head of the asset management department at Shanghai's state-owned Jinjiang Group has been charged with corruption, company officials said. Chen Yanning, 46, the son of a senior military officer in the Sichuan-Chengdu Military Region, is being held in a case that has already led to the detention of Chen Bangke, a patron of the arts and opera producer. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: He Gave Names to Clouds and Renown to Himself
