title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New And Faster Chips From Intel
description: The Intel Corporation began selling its fastest line of microprocessors for thin-and-light notebook computers yesterday. Intel said at least 10 major computer makers, including Dell and I.B.M., plan to build mobile machines with the Pentium III processor-M chips, which compete with products from Transmeta and Advanced Micro Devices. The microprocessors, code-named Tualatin, use copper wires instead of aluminum and feature 0.13-micron circuit lines, allowing Intel to fit smaller circuits onto each chip. Intel said the chips consume as much as 40 percent less power and run up to 20 percent faster than 0.18-micron chips, a potential help to manufacturers trying to make small notebooks run faster while using less battery power. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Cap Gemini Profit
description: The computer services company Cap Gemini reported a 15 percent increase in first-half profit yesterday, helped by the acquisition of Ernst & Young's consulting unit. Net income at Cap Gemini rose to 110 million euros ($97 million) from 96 million euros a year earlier, the company said. It bought the Ernst & Young unit last year to increase its American business.

title: Death at the Hands of Science
description: The recent death of a healthy young woman participating in a research project at Johns Hopkins University has cast a disturbing pall over the elaborate protective mechanisms that are supposed to ensure the safety of all biomedical research supported by the federal government. This is the second time in two years that a research volunteer has died in a medical experiment at a prestigious university. If even the best of the nation's medical institutions are experiencing such problems, there is reason for concern.

title: Giuliani Is No-Show at Clinton Party
description: The party in Harlem yesterday to welcome former President Bill Clinton drew a crowd of several thousand. But there was at least one invited notable missing: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: When Stars Get Fatter

title: Armstrong Delivers Dollars for Sponsors
description: Lance Armstrong's third straight Tour de France victory on Sunday was a stunning accomplishment.

title: JOINT VENTURE IS FORMED TO MAKE SWISS ARMY WATCHES
description: The maker of the Swiss Army Knife, Victorinox, and its American distributor, Swiss Army Brands, have formed a company to sell a Swiss Army brand of watches. The new company, Victorinox Swiss Army Watch, will sell the watches outside the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. The company expects to begin selling the watches in Italy in October. Victorinox of Ibach, Switzerland, is the majority shareholder of Swiss Army Brands of Shelton, Conn.

title: Moving Beyond the Kyoto Impasse
description: Much is being made of the Bush administration's exclusion of the United States from an agreement reached by 178 countries last week to move forward on combating global warming. But both those who deplore the Bush administration's snub and those who agree with the president that America couldn't afford to join in are losing sight of the long view. To really head off climate change, the world must eventually make even larger (much larger) cuts in its emissions of greenhouses gases than those envisioned in the Kyoto agreement and its refinements in Bonn. But we have some time. The Kyoto protocol calls for reductions from 2008 to 2012. In fact, the large reductions can wait for another decade or two after that. But to make these cuts in time, we must begin now to engage private business and private inventiveness in attacking the problem.

title: In Harlem, a Hero's Welcome For New Neighbor Clinton
description: Former President William Jefferson Clinton officially began his post-presidency in Harlem yesterday in front of an adoring audience that gave no acknowledgment that he had ever left office.

title: MGM MIRAGE TRYING TO ACQUIRE ILLINOIS CASINO COMPANY
description: MGM Mirage, the casino company controlled by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, said yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire a company that is working to build a casino near Chicago. MGM Mirage said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had begun a 30-day period of talks to buy Emerald Casino of Rosemont, Ill. MGM, based in Las Vegas, has requested a meeting with the Illinois Gaming Board. In January, the board denied Emerald's request for a license for a casino in a Chicago suburb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZBERG, DR. DANIEL B.
description: SALZBERG-Dr. Daniel B., 87, orthodontist and environmentalist of Croton-on-Hudson, died on July 23rd. Survived by Norma, his loving wife of more than 64 years; children, Susan and Laurie of Croton, and Richard of Santa Cruz, California.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Deregulating Electricity
description: The state officially begins deregulating retail electricity today when it puts into effect a test program that allows customers of the state's privately owned utilities to shop for power. More than 90,000 residential customers have already signed up to do so. The program, authorized by a 1999 law to deregulate electricity, allows up to 5 percent of any utility's customers to switch to other utilities. When full-scale deregulation begins in January, competition will be open to all retail customers. Homeowners should begin receiving bills from their new providers later this month. Municipally owned utilities and electric co-operatives are exempt from the program. Richard A. Oppel Jr. (NYT)

title: BIG BOY RESTAURANTS SAYS 'NO COKE. PEPSI'
description: The restaurant chain Big Boy Restaurants International has chosen PepsiCo as its exclusive beverage supplier, replacing the Coca-Cola Company, its supplier for 65 years. Big Boy, based in Warren, Mich., said the agreement called for PepsiCo, based in Purchase, N.Y., to supply fountain beverages, frozen carbonated beverages and bottled drinks in 170 Big Boy outlets. Big Boy said yesterday that it had made the decision partly because of Pepsi's efforts to maintain quality. PepsiCo, based in Purchase, N.Y., has also developed a intranet site that will permit the restaurants to communicate with company headquarters, Big Boy said.

title: Young Singers Challenged and Thriving at Glimmerglass
description: Since 1996, when Paul Kellogg, the longtime director of Glimmerglass Opera here, became the artistic and general director of the New York City Opera, he has cultivated an innovative working relationship between the two companies. Co-productions are introduced at Glimmerglass, where Mr. Kellogg remains artistic director. Here they can be worked on under near-ideal summer festival conditions. Eventually the productions make their way to the City Opera, as will three of the four from this summer: Handel's ''Agrippina,'' Chabrier's ''toile'' and Britten's ''Rape of Lucretia.'' Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro, the fourth work, is a co-production with the Florida Grand Opera.

title: Serbia Finds Where Bodies Are Buried, and Investigates
description: Capt. Dragan Karleusa, deputy head of the police organized crime unit in Belgrade, is amazed to find that he now leads an ever-expanding investigation into war crimes.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Assaults Near Rutgers
description: The police have reported a string of five break-ins and sexually related assaults in off-campus student residences at Rutgers University since June 11. Three of the incidents may be related, said Joseph Catanese, New Brunswick's police director, who called the series of incidents ''exceptionally out of the ordinary.'' The police have made one arrest so far, and have posted fliers urging students to lock their doors and windows.

title: Key Lawmaker Is Reported Near Deal With Bush on Rights Bill
description: Representative Charlie Norwood, the Georgia Republican who has been leading a six-year effort to enact a patients' bill of rights, was moving close to an agreement with the White House on compromise legislation that could be put to a vote in the House of Representatives this week, Mr. Norwood's spokesman said tonight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Verizon May Write Down Big Fiber Optic Investment
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest provider of local phone service, is expected to write down today a large part of a $1.7 billion investment it made in a company that builds fiber optic networks in metropolitan areas, people close to the companies said.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From which vegetables to refrigerate to making hush puppies at home, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the financial results of JDS Uniphase, the maker of components for telecommunications networks, misstated the name of a company bought by JDS Uniphase in 1999. It was the Optical Coating Laboratory, not Coding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDEN, RICHMOND YOUNG, SR.
description: HOLDEN-Richmond Young, Sr., of Weston, MA and Quogue, Long Island, NY on July 24, 2001. He was the former President of J.L. Hammett Co. and a late WW II Veteran. Husband of the late Mary Jane (Muzzy) Holden. Father of Richmond Y. Holden, Jr. of Doxbury, MA, Jeffrey S. Holden of Weston, MA, Mary Cort Atkinson of Atlanta, GA, and Luisa H. Holden of Weston, MA. Also survived by ten grandchildren. A memorial service was held on Friday, July 27 at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, MA. Donations in Mr. Holden's memory may be made to the J.L. Hammett Co Education Foundation Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 859057, Braintree, MA, 02185. For information, call J.S. Waterman and Sons, 781-235-4110

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, MARY LOUISE
description: CARROLL-Mary Louise, of Red Bank and East Quogue, NY died Monday at the Hospice Center of Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ. Surviving are her husband of 47 yrs, Martin J. Carroll Sr., nine children and spouses, Cathleen Carroll of Ocean Grove, NJ; Edmund & Sharon Carroll of Whitehouse Station, NJ; Martin & Hilary Carroll of Holmdel, NJ; Lederle & Kent Eberhardt of State College, PA; John & Lisa Carroll of Middletown, NJ; Karen & Ben Yang of Medford, NJ; Tim & Marianne Carroll of Hoboken, NJ; Marie Louise & Bob Lutkewitte of Colts Neck, NJ; Helen Carroll of Nutley, NJ; 9 grandchildren and a host of dear friends & family. Visitation Wednesday 7-9 PM at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Colts Neck, NJ; Funeral Mass Thursday 9 AM at St. Mary's; Interment at St. Catharine's Cemetery, Sea Girt.

title: Survival: Down Syndrome Life Spans Lengthen
description: From 1968 to 1997 the life expectancy for people with Down syndrome increased sharply, but white patients had far longer lives than black patients, according to a report by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

title: The Scientific Flip Side
description: To the Editor:

title: From Alaska to Vermont to the Major Leagues?
description: Two years ago in Alaska, all eyes were on the high school pitcher until three eagles flew overhead, and a battle in the skies ensued.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: FRONT ROW
description: Military Style

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDDOCH, RANDOLPH IAN EDGAR (RANDY)
description: RIDDOCH-Randolph Ian Edgar (Randy). Director of Student Health Services at The New School University. Died of a heart attack July 25, 2001 at the age of 40. A man who truly loved and was truly loved by many. Services: The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Ave, Friday August 3, 11am. Donations to St. John the Divine Building Fund.

title: Letters: Ethics and Embryos
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRITZMAN, BERNARD
description: KRITZMAN-Bernard, bravura pianist, died July 20 at home in NYC. He was an authority on classical reproducing pianos. Survived by his beloved sister, Anne Gordon, and brothers, Calvin and Irwin.

title: Value of Volunteering
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Charged With Abuse Looks On as Teenager Says She Molested Him
description: A 16-year-old boy told a jury in explicit detail today that his ninth-grade teacher instructed him on the finer points of sex, and later performed oral sex on him, after he went to her two years ago for help with schoolwork.

title: Woods and Sorenstam Capture a Sloppy Battle
description: The Battle at Bighorn, the 2001 version, will not go down as an epic. The play tonight was erratic, especially given the caliber of the golfers who starred in this prime-time, made-for-television special.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Court Bars Prominent Divorce
description: The Court of Cassation, the highest appeals court, threw out a petition to forcibly divorce Nawal el-Saadawi, a prominent feminist writer. The petition was filed by her husband because, he said, she had renounced Islam. Ms. Saadawi, 70, pronounced herself happy with the verdict but said she would continue to combat the law permitting such divorces. She had criticized Islam in a newspaper, but said she had been quoted out of context. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Victory For Subway Privatization
description: A High Court judge ruled that the government can impose a $18.5 billion privatization plan for the London subway. The plan has been condemned as costly and unsafe by the London Transport commissioner, Robert R. Kiley, an American credited with rescuing systems in New York and Boston. Justice Jeremy Sullivan found against Mayor Ken Livingstone, who argued that the Government could not force him to accept a proposal ''incompatible'' with his obligation to run a ''safe, integrated, efficient and economic'' network. Any appeal would be heard in September. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Italian Phone Deal Raises Some Old Insider Issues
description: The change in ownership of the Italian phone company Telecom Italia coming so soon after a turnover of control at Montedison, the Italian chemicals and power conglomerate, suggests that big changes are afoot in the way Italy Inc. operates. But a closer look finds that less may be changing than meets the eye.

title: If Russia Is Our Partner
description: To the Editor:

title: E. Lawrence Tabat; Executive, 88
description: E. Lawrence Tabat, the former chairman and chief executive of the Dictaphone Corporation, a maker of dictating systems, which was acquired by Pitney Bowes, died on July 25 in Tequesta, Fla., where he lived. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIDDE, JOHN L.
description: KIDDE-John L. The Directors, Officers and Staff of Mahler & Emerson, Inc. deeply regret the loss of our esteemed friend, director and long-time supporter and express our condolences to his wife Ruth and his family. Herbert W. Mahler John W. Priesing

title: Old Station House Returns to Police Duty; Headquarters of First Precinct Until 1973 Will House the Police Museum
description: ''Close Old Slip.''

title: Hugo Princz, 78, U.S. Winner Of Holocaust Settlement, Dies
description: Hugo Princz, a United States citizen who survived the Holocaust and won a 41-year battle for reparations from Germany, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Highland Park, N.J. He was 78.

title: Family Relieved as Body of Last Rockaway Drowning Victim Is Found
description: The body of the last of three girls from Paterson, N.J., who were swept away by riptides in Far Rockaway last week was found yesterday.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Leader At Smith
description: Smith College has appointed Carol Tecla Christ, a professor of English who was executive vice chancellor and provost at the University of California at Berkeley, as its next president. Smith, a small liberal arts college for women, is much different from Berkeley, a large elite public university, where Ms. Christ has spent 30 years, including six as executive vice chancellor and provost. ''It's the difference that attracts me,'' she said. She will move to Smith's campus in Northampton next spring, succeeding Ruth Simmons, who became president of Brown University. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORBLITT, BEATRICE
description: HORBLITT-Beatrice, of White Plains, NY, died Monday, July 30, at the age of 90. Wife of the late Saul. Beloved mother of Eileen Reiter and Stephen Horblitt. Sister of Harriet Hopp and Marvin Spitzer. Grandmother to Suzanne (Mark) and David Reiter. Funeral service Wednesday, 12 Noon, at the Ballard - Durand Funeral Home, where the family will receive friends from 11:30-12 Noon. Interment will follow at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings, NY. Memorial contributions to White Plains Hospital or O.R.T.

title: Hidden Cameras Capture World of the Rare and Wild
description: In the steamy Indonesian darkness, a Sumatran rhinoceros slops through a swamp. Click.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about measures in Congress to block Mexican trucks from entering the United States misstated the affiliation of Joan Claybrook, a consumer safety advocate who commented on Teamster lobbying against the trucking. She is the president of Public Citizen, not Common Cause.

title: Gilmar Might Join MetroStars
description: IVAN GAZIDIS, deputy commissioner in charge of signing players for Major League Soccer, said yesterday that GILMAR of Brazil was the front-runner to replace CLINT MATHIS on the MetroStars. NICK SAKIEWICZ, general manager of the MetroStars, said Gilmar should join the team in two weeks.

title: National Briefing
description: NEW ENGLAND

title: Indiana and Toronto Advance in Playoffs
description: Opening-round play in the Arena Football League playoffs ended Sunday with the fifth-seeded Indiana Firebirds' 58-41 victory over the Carolina Cobras. The weekend was underscored by the Toronto Phantoms' 64-57 victory over the Dragons last Friday night.

title: Watch This Space
description: When Santana Moss streaked down the sideline at Jets practice this morning, a step ahead of Aaron Glenn, the crowd waited for the result. But not for long. Nobody waits long when Moss is running, and this time, when Vinny Testaverde's pass went past Moss's fingertips, the crowd groaned. And then roared.

title: Democrats to Let Navy Pay for Cheney's Electricity
description: Senate Democratic leaders have decided for now to allow Vice President Dick Cheney to shift all the electricity bills for his official home to the Navy, a plan that had been criticized by Democrats as evidence of a double standard.

title: FUEL EQUIPMENT COMPANY BUYING DANISH MANUFACTURER
description: Roper Industries, which makes control systems for oil and gas transportation, has agreed to buy Struers Holdings of Denmark, which makes testing equipment, for $139 million. Roper, based in Bogart, Ga., also lowered its earnings forecast for its third quarter and the year. Third-quarter earnings will be 38 cents to 40 cents a share, the company said. Analysts expected 51 cents a share.

title: HOME DEPOT CHANGING THE WAY IT PICKS AND BUYS GOODS
description: Home Depot is revising the way it selects and buys merchandise to get better prices and to improve efficiency. The company said its store-support center in Atlanta will buy many of the items sold in its stores, based on advice from the company's eight North American divisional offices. Earlier this month, Home Depot appointed Jerry Edwards senior vice president for merchandising. That filled a vacancy created when Mark Baker resigned after sales at stores open at least one year fell 3 percent in the first quarter. Home Depot shares fell 10 cents to $49.55.

title: A Political Stone-Thrower Runs in Rockaway
description: John Baxter may have coined the most honest campaign slogan of all this political season.

title: Reports Show Consumer Spending Up, but Confidence Is Down
description: American consumers increased their spending in June, especially on expensive items like cars and refrigerators, but their confidence about the economy over the next few months has recently deteriorated, raising questions about whether such spending can continue at its current pace.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: New Trials In Sectarian Violence
description: The high court ordered a retrial in a case involving some of the worst sectarian violence ever in Egypt. The ruling overturned the convictions four Muslims among 38 Copts and 54 Muslims on trial, a verdict some saw as lenient. Two Muslims and 19 Copts died in clashes in the south in December 1999. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: South Korean, Once Held as Spy, Plans a University in Pyongyang
description: YANJI, China  Kim Chin Kyung was detained for six weeks in North Korea in 1998 and threatened with a death sentence by his interrogators.

title: Liberalizing Trade, to the Benefit of All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVRIN, TENA
description: GAVRIN-Tena. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: PROMOTIONAL PRODUCTS COMPANY FILES FOR CHAPTER 11
description: HA-LO Industries, a distributor of promotional products, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing a series of losses and the acquisition of Starbelly.com. HA-LO, based in Niles, Ill., listed $100 million in assets and $80 million in debts in papers filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. The company sells T-shirts, pens and other items that can be customized with corporate names or logos. In April, HA-LO took a second-quarter charge to write off its $240 million purchase of Starbelly.com, an Internet seller of apparel sporting company logos. The company also lost money after it tried to expand beyond its promotional-products business. HA-LO reported an operating loss of $64 million last year.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Grain Merger
description: Citing competition and a need to cut costs, two big Canadian food and grain processors agreed to merge yesterday, forming a company with 4.9 billion Canadian dollars ($3.2 billion) in sales. United Grain Growers, a former cooperative that went public in 1993 and is 42 percent owned by Archer Daniels Midland, will combine with Agricore, a cooperative with 84,000 members. Archer will own 19 percent of the combined company, Agricore United, and has an option to raise its stake to 25 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: VITAL SIGNS: MEASUREMENTS; Tracking Faith, Race and Blood Pressure
description: Among African-Americans, practicing a religion seems to lower blood pressure, a study conducted at Duke University found. But that did not appear to be the case among whites.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Quarter Loss For Terra Lycos
description: Terra Lycos, the largest Internet service provider in Spain and Latin America, reported a narrower-than-expected second-quarter loss because of higher revenue from Internet access charges. The loss before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization narrowed to 65 million euros ($57 million) from 69 million euros in the year-earlier period.

title: Israeli Attack Kills at Least 8 Palestinians in the West Bank
description: NABLUS, West Bank, July 31  At least eight Palestinians, including two senior Hamas officials and two young brothers, were killed today in an Israeli attack on an office of the militant group in the West Bank.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Toy Store Is Started
description: Amazon.com and Toys ''R'' Us announced yesterday that they had begun Imaginarium.com, an online store for specialty and educational toys. The site is the third online effort the two companies have taken on together, after the introductions of Toysrus.com last fall and Babiesrus.com earlier this year. The two companies first allied in August 2000, when Amazon took over fulfillment for Toysrus.com. Imaginarium, which once had 41 stores in 13 states, was purchased by Toys ''R'' Us in January of 1999. The online toy market has proved tricky for some companies like eToys, a well-financed Internet toy retailer which declared bankruptcy earlier this year. Still, Amazon and Toys ''R'' Us are betting that specialty toys are more likely to be a winner online. The companies say they will offer one of the Internet's best specialty selections of learning toys and will allow parents to search for toys according to the specific skills they would like their child to develop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADIN, MIGNONNE PALITZ
description: LADIN-Mignonne Palitz. Died at home on July 29, 2001, surrounded by family. She was married to Dr. Philip Ladin. After his death, she launched a career as manager of The Brooklyn Philharmonia Symphony Orchestra. She pioneered the practice of bringing public school children to symphony concerts, was a founding member of The American Symphony Orchestra League and was active in the NY State Council for the Arts. After retirement, she did graduate work in anthropology at Columbia University and Hunter College, and curated many exhibititions helping to preserve the art of Native American basket weaving. She is survived by her son, Peter A. Ladin of Florida; a daughter Patricia L. Carlin of Manhattan; grandchildren, Philip and Timothy Ladin and Jennifer and John Carlin; and four great-grandchildren. Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, Aug 1, at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Brooklyn Philharmonia Free Schooltime Concert Fund, 1 Hanson Place, Suite 1806, Brooklyn, NY, 11243.

title: Surprising Results in Welfare-to-Work Studies
description: Early studies of families in three welfare-to-work programs have found unexpected evidence that their adolescent children have lower academic achievement and more behavioral problems than the children of other welfare households.

title: Pearson's Deals Finding Less Favor Among Investors
description: Just a year ago, stock of Pearson P.L.C. the British publisher, was soaring. Under Marjorie Scardino, the American who joined Pearson as chief executive in January 1997 with a mandate to reshape the stodgy media empire, Pearson was seen to be shedding dull businesses, buying faster-growing assets and embracing an online future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPELL, FRIEDA GINSBERG
description: KOPELL-Frieda Ginsberg. Frieda ''Fritzi'' Kopell, a resident of New Rochelle died Monday July 30 at the age of 90. Pre-deceased by her beloved husband Meyer Kopell and sister Alice Kaye. Survived by daughters Linda Levine and Nancy Kopell. Sons-in-law Mark A. Levine and Gabriel Stolzenberg, sister Lois Katz, grandchildren David (Susan) Levine and Robert (Laurie) Levine and one great-grandchild Matthew Levine. Funeral service will be Wednesday 11AM at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, where the family will receive friends from 10 to 11AM. Interment will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Alan Green, former ambassador to Romania, was reprinted in error. Mr. Green died on March 23, not last Friday; the obituary was published on March 27.

title: Nominee to Lead F.B.I. Vows to End Mistakes
description: Robert S. Mueller III, President Bush's choice to lead the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today at his Senate confirmation hearing that the agency had been tarnished by serious problems and said that employees who committed blunders must be held accountable.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SYMPTOMS; Biological Warfare Agent Resurfaces
description: A researcher in the Army's leading anti-bioterrorism laboratory accidentally infected himself with a dangerous bacterial disease of horses and people that had not been seen in a human in this country for more than 50 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airport Results
description: BAA, which operates Heathrow and Gatwick Airports, said profit in its first quarter rose 1.9 percent despite a fall in revenue. Net income climbed to 103 million ($147 million), while revenue fell 2.5 percent, to 547 million. The company said livestock diseases kept tourists from visiting Britain, contributing to the decline. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, IRVING
description: SHERMAN-Irving. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our friend and mentor, Irving Sherman. His tireless efforts enriched the lives of those he knew and saved the lives of many who had never heard his name. Irving played an important role in enabling countless Jews to escape the Nazis and in getting urgently needed money to those Jews left in dire straits. Irving's direct activities with JDC stretched from the early 1930's well into the 1980's. As our Treasurer and a member of JDC's Board of Directors, Irving provided the type of leadership and counsel that made JDC a major force in Jewish Rescue and Relief. Principled and esteemed, his contribution and sacrifice will never be forgotten. Our condolences to his wife, Marie, and the entire family. Eugene J. Ribakoff, President Michael Schneider, Executive Vice President Jonathan W. Kolker, Chairman of the Board

title: S.& L. Fails, Along With A Friendship
description: In 1989, Alvin Dworman, a prominent New York real estate investor, approached his old friend Jay Pritzker, of the noted family that owns the Hyatt hotel chain, about investing in a failed savings and loan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Mother Charged In Drowning
description: A woman was charged with criminally negligent homicide yesterday in the accidental drowning of her 10-month-old daughter, who was left alone for 10 minutes on Sunday in the bathtub of their Kingsbridge Heights apartment, the police said. The woman, Marie Rodriguez, had left the baby, Rene Castro, in an infant basin that floated as the tub filled, the police said. But the baby fell in when Ms. Rodriguez left the room to do housework, the police said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Value of Volunteering
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Pays Over $7 Million for Defense in Embassy Bombings Case
description: Costs for the defense in the embassy bombings case in Manhattan have exceeded $7 million, making it possibly the second most expensive criminal defense ever paid for by the federal government, according to newly released court records and interviews.

title: Net Is Down 56% At Parker Hannifin
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation, a maker of hydraulic equipment, said today that its fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell 56 percent as the slow economy hurt sales.

title: Strindberg's Deep Anxiety, But No Words
description: August Strindberg has long been accepted as one of the greatest -- and sometimes the most daunting -- of European playwrights. His plays startle and seduce, as happened in June at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with ''The Ghost Sonata.'' In London, his ''Dance of Death'' gave Laurence Olivier the last great triumph of his long career, and a new production will open in New York in September.

title: More Experts Grow Wary As the Dollar Keeps Rising
description: Is it time to rethink the strong dollar policy?

title: Value of Volunteering
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyson's Profit Cut in Half
description: Profit at Tyson Foods Inc. fell by more than half in its fiscal third quarter as the company, the largest poultry producer, increased its advertising and sold its chicken at lower prices.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Electronics Profits
description: LG Electronics reported net income of $767 million for the second quarter, quadruple the amount for the period last year, mainly because of gains on the sale of some operations to Royal Philips Electronics. A drop in operating profit, to $150 million from $220 million last year, was attributed largely to declining exports of computers and monitors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Boy, 6, Dies Of Skull Injury During M.R.I.
description: Outside of the X-ray, perhaps no other medical examination is as well known or as safe as the magnetic resonance imaging test, which is conducted eight million times a year in the United States on patients ranging from people with brain tumors to famous athletes with knee injuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAIN, HARVEY J.
description: DAIN-Harvey J. December 22, 1908-July 28, 2001. Former Director of the Post-Graduate Center for Mental Health in New York City. A decorated war hero. Survivors include his wife Beatrice, daughter Barbara Nemiroff of San Diego, sons Jeremy of NJ and Peter of NY, and six grandchildren.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Patients'-Rights Law Signed
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed legislation yesterday to let patients sue their health maintenance organization for failing to provide medical treatment or services. Under the Health Care Accountability Act, patients or their heirs can sue for pain and suffering if damaging health effects or death occur because of delays or denial of treatment. Patients would not have to go through an appeals process before filing suits under the law, which goes into effect in 90 days.

title: Value of Volunteering
description: To the Editor:

title: Commission Urges Overhaul of Election System
description: A commission headed by the former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford on Tuesday will recommend a major overhaul of the nation's election system in response to last year's electoral turmoil in Florida.

title: Returning All the Works of Langston Hughes to Print
description: Langston Hughes was born in Joplin, Mo., but he did not stay there long. He was already living with his grandmother in Lawrence, Kan., when a year later a white lynch mob burned the black neighborhood of his birthplace. Rural Kansas, not Missouri, was home to his earliest memories, his first novel and some of his best poetry.

title: Regular Pap Tests Remain a Crucial Detection Method
description: Cervical cancer was once the leading cancer killer of American women. Now, thanks largely to the widespread use of an early detection exam, it is the seventh.

title: Fanny Brennan, Surrealist, 80; Lived in Paris
description: Fanny Brennan, an American painter of small, meticulously executed surrealist still lifes, who spent her childhood in the legendary circle of artists and writers gathered around Sara and Gerald Murphy in Paris, died on July 22 at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 80.

title: Software Is Called Capable of Copying Any Human Voice
description: AT&T Labs will start selling speech software that it says is so good at reproducing the sounds, inflections and intonations of a human voice that it can recreate voices and even bring the voices of long-dead celebrities back to life. The software, which turns printed text into synthesized speech, makes it possible for a company to use recordings of a person's voice to utter things that the person never actually said.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SURVIVAL; Down Syndrome Life Spans Lengthen
description: From 1968 to 1997 the life expectancy for people with Down syndrome increased sharply, but white patients had far longer lives than black patients, according to a report by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABITT, MITCHELL J.
description: BABITT-Mitchell J. 43, of Armonk, N.Y. on July 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted father of Andrew, Stephanie and Matthew. Loving son of Ivan and Ilse Babitt. Brother of Bruce and Gail. Services will be today, 11AM, at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Rd at Route 22, Armonk, N.Y. Entombment at Ferncliff Mausoleum, Hartsdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers donation may be made to Congregation B'nai Yisrael.

title: BORDEN SELLS MOST OF ITS PASTA BUSINESS TO NEW WORLD
description: The New World Pasta Company, the maker of Ronzoni and other brands of pastas and noodles, has agreed to acquire the bulk of the Borden Foods Corporation's pasta business in the United States, Canada and Italy. New World Pasta will pay $43.1 million for the units, which have more than $210 million in annual sales, a Borden Foods spokeswoman, Lynn Anderson, said yesterday. The transaction includes two factories in the United States, two in Canada and two in Italy. About 1,000 Borden employees at the six sites will be offered jobs with New World Pasta, Ms. Anderson said. New World Pasta is based in Harrisburg, Pa. Borden Foods of Columbus, Ohio, is part of the closely held Borden Inc., which is selling its pasta operations to focus on other business.

title: Car Calls May Leave Brain Short-Handed
description: Scientists have bad news for people who think they can deftly drive a car while gabbing on a cell phone.

title: Missile-Shield Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: New Prosecutor Consults On State Trial for Nichols
description: Dozens of victims of the Oklahoma City bombing and survivors of the dead met with a new prosecutor today to discuss whether Terry L. Nichols, now serving a federal sentence of life in prison, should be tried on state murder charges in the killing of 160 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATKIN, GUS
description: SLATKIN-Gus, age 95. Loving sister to Rose, Ely and the late Frieda, Charles, Irving, Lou. Beloved aunt to Carole, Laura, Linda, Alan, Joan; dear friend to Billie Howard and Marge Benson. Valiant, generous, loyal to us all. We will cherish and miss her always.

title: The More Things Change . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Eviction Protest Banned
description: Citing security concerns, officials in Luanda barred a march to protest the eviction of thousands of families from the Boavista neighborhood, the government reported. This month the government forced 13,000 families to move into tents, saying their homes were unsafe. Two people were killed in clashes with the police. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Light in the Shadows of Arles
description: The famous Maison Jaune, at Arles, which Vincent Van Gogh rented, furnished, painted and filled with his pictures to receive his friend Paul Gauguin in the autumn of 1888, no longer exists. It disappeared in an Allied bombardment in 1945, and where it stood there now functions a small hotel called Terminus Van Gogh. Not long ago, the landlady showed me a photograph of the ruin left by the bomb's impact, an event of which she was a witness.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the efforts of an American transportation expert, Robert R. Kiley, to reorganize London's subway system referred incorrectly in some copies to a pending court ruling. A High Court judge ruled yesterday that the British government had the right to impose its plan. The ruling did not concern an injunction barring the release of critical studies by consultants. Details appear today in the World Briefing column, on Page A10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKIN, RUTH K.
description: ARKIN-Ruth K. On Sunday, July 29, at 101 years. Beloved wife of the late Irving W. Arkin. Much adored mother and mother-in-law of Donald and Linda Arkin and Jane Rosenthal. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, William, Sondra, Kenneth, Susan, Alan and Dr. Donna Arkin.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EMDEN, HARRY D.
description: EMDEN-Harry D. In cherished memory of a beloved father and grandfather. Passed away July 31, 1971. Forever in our hearts. Howard, Jeffrey, James, Robert

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Murder Conviction Reversed
description: The State Supreme Court has thrown out the 1996 murder conviction of a young man in the shooting of a 4-year-old boy, ruling that the trial judge should have allowed testimony that another man had bragged of the shooting. Maurice Williams, now 21, was convicted of firing a gun through a first-floor apartment window in Atlantic City in October 1995, killing Kareem Davis, 4, in what the authorities said was a continuation of a dispute at the house two nights earlier. Mr. Williams said that another Atlantic City man, Derrick Martin, who had been killed by the time of the trial, had fired the shot, and that there were corroborating witnesses. Justice James Zazzali wrote that it was not the trial judge who should decide whether secondhand versions of events proved anything, but rather the jury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESENOFF, NORMAN
description: NESENOFF-Norman of Syosset on July 29, 2001. Loving husband of Goldie. Beloved brother of Bernie and Judy, and Debbie and Arnie. Devoted father of Dr. Mitchell and Marjorie Nesenoff, Rabbi David and Nancy Nesenoff, Mr. Marc and Linda Lawrence, and Mr. Perry Nesenoff. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Naomi, Adam, Ashley, Clyde, Gracie and Nico. Founder of CES Industries, Inc. Former Commodore of Englewood Yacht Club, and graduated first in his class with Bachelor and Master degrees from City College and Columbia University. Loved dancing, magic, boating, traveling, telling jokes, and most of all, his family. Funeral Services Tuesday, 12:00 Noon at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Protestants In Ulster Kill Youth, A Protestant
description: Protestant paramilitary groups killed an 18-year-old Protestant and wounded a Catholic friend of his in a drive-by shooting on Sunday night aimed at a group of teenagers as they talked outside a Catholic Gaelic football park in North Belfast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRIS, LOUIS A.
description: FERRIS-Louis A. A former stock broker with a seat on the NYSE and a Vice President at Prudential Bache & Company, died at his home in Harrison, NY on Friday, July 27, 2001. Mr. Ferris was born in New Orleans, LA on October 20, 1914. The cause was cancer his family said. Mr. Ferris was a Captain in the 442nd Infantry, the famous ''Go For Broke'' Nisei unit during World War II. He was proud of his command and his men and called them the bravest group of soldiers he ever had the honor of knowing. His valor under fire earned him the Bronze Star amongst other medals. He continued to communicate with some of the men under his command, and was a benefactor and supporter of the new memorial built and unveiled in Los Angeles in 2000 to honor the 442nd. Mr. Ferris also served in the Korean War. Mr. Ferris is survived by his beloved wife, Lesley to whom he was married for sixtysix years; three children, Neal of San Francisco, CA; Pamela Ferris Olson of Dayton, OH; Lynn Ferris Steinman of Rye, NY; six grandchildren, and one great grandchild. He also leaves a sister, Jessica Feingold. A memorial service will be held at 4PM, Wednesday, August 1, 2001 at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, New York. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Arrests In Death Of 'Bandit Queen'
description: Three men were arrested in Uttar Pradesh in connection with the killing of the ''Bandit Queen,'' Phoolan Devi, last week. On Friday the police arrested a prime suspect, Sher Singh Rana, and Naresh Dayal, a senior state official, said the three men ''seemed to corroborate Rana's claims that he alone has masterminded the murder,'' Reuters reported. Ms. Devi, who abandoned life as a bandit and became a legislator, rose to notoriety in 1981 after the killing of 22 upper-caste men in Uttar Pradesh. She denied leading the massacre but said her career of crime was driven by revenge for her rape by upper-caste men. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Liberalizing Trade, To the Benefit of All
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I guess we've gotten to the age where we've seen so many movies that with some of these movies we're like, 'Wait a minute; this was the same movie that I saw 5 or 10 years ago but with a different character.' It's kind of boring.''

title: Return of Computer 'Worm' Feared Today
description: The rogue computer program known as Code Red is about to strike again, computer security experts and federal officials warned yesterday.

title: Mr. Clinton's Harlem Renaissance
description: After a faulty start in January, Bill Clinton's second launch of his ex-presidency fared much better yesterday in central Harlem. A crowd that included the actress Cicely Tyson and Representative Charles Rangel -- who kept referring to Harlem's most prominent new tenant as ''our president'' -- welcomed Mr. Clinton so warmly that he looked almost giddy about the end of his post-presidential exile. ''You were always there for me,'' he crooned, noting that his audience mirrored the diversity of the entire world.

title: El Bolsn Journal; Patagonian Woodstock Suffers From Popularity
description: The aging hippies, who came to this rustic Patagonian town to grow their own fruits and vegetables, make their own handicrafts and escape the repression of bygone military governments still wear beards, beads and ponytails.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERZUOLI, FRANCES R. (NEE AMPOL)
description: TERZUOLI-Frances R. (nee Ampol), on July 28, 2001. Beloved wife of Andrew J. Loving mother of Andrew J. Jr., Richard J., Dr. Robert J. and the late Maryann M. Cherished grandmother of Christine Joy Terzuoli. Funeral Thursday, 10am, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 11am at Resurrection R.C. Church. Interment Resurrection Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Preserving Fertility While Treating Cervical Cancer
description: Raquel and Tony Rivas had their life in order. They had married, built a house and were ready to start having children. But a visit to the gynecologist led to frightening news: Ms. Rivas had cervical cancer.

title: Treasury Is Planning to Borrow to Cover Cost of Tax Rebates
description: The Treasury said yesterday that it would borrow the money needed for the tax rebates now going to taxpayers as part of President Bush's $1.35 billion tax cut.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the former Polish leader Edward Gierek yesterday misidentified his successor as head of the Communist Party. The successor was Stanislaw Kania, not Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title: A Shiny New Crib For Nurturing Off Broadway Plays; On 42nd Street, Playwrights Horizons Is Gaining More Seats and Studio Space
description: There were times when the air-conditioning failed and staff members had to clamber up on the roof to open a skylight, when the Fire Department ordered the curtain held until safety lights could be strung in the aisle, when an actress ran onstage yelling, ''Somebody is ripping off the dressing rooms!''

title: Ethics and Embryos
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: 'Clean Image' For Police
description: The government fired 156 police officers, accusing them of murder and selling and renting weapons, the state news agency reported. Officials said they hoped to give the force ''a clean image.'' Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Stocks End Higher on Consumer Spending Report
description: Stocks rose today, with blue-chip issues posting solid gains, as investors were heartened by upbeat economic data that showed unexpected strength in consumer spending.

title: Miscellany
description: Gerbig, Snell/Weisheimer, Columbus, Ohio, was renamed inChord Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, CHARLES N.
description: HENDERSON-Charles N. 84 of Erwinna, PA, died July 24, 2001. Former organist at St. George's Church, NYC, and editor of The American Organist magazine. Survived by daughters Sarah and Ann and grandson Dubois Thomas.

title: INSIDE
description: Debate on Cloning

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTMAN, PHYLLIS M., PH.D.
description: GOOTMAN-Phyllis M., Ph.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Dr. Phyllis M. Gootman, Professor of Physiology and Pharmacology, and Professor of Pediatrics, a distinguished member of our faculty for more than a quarter century. A pioneering researcher in the field of physiology of newborns and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, Dr. Gootman was a widely respected educator and mentor. Our deepest sympathies are extended to her husband, Dr. Norman Gootman, her children, Dr. Craig Gootman and Dr. Sharon Gootman Rosen, her mother, Mrs. Ida Adler, and her brother, Dr. Saul Adler, as well as to other family members, colleagues and friends. John C. LaRosa, MD, President Eugene B. Feigelson, MD, Dean of the College of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, PETER M.
description: HIRSCH-Peter M. Age 65. On July 29, 2001, following a courageous battle with thyroid cancer. After studying Graphic Design at Pratt Institute, Peter became an art director at Douglas Simon, Inc. and subsequently a principal partner and Creative Director at DKG Advertising, which later became Calet Hirsch & Spector. Over the course of his forty year career, Peter produced award-winning work which was always noted for innovation, creativity and humor. Under his leadership, DKG was named Agency of the Year by Advertising Age. He was also personally honored as one of the Top 100 Creative People in the U.S. and one of the Top Graphic Designers. Peter was an accomplished writer, photographer and lecturer. His most recent achievement was the documentary film ''The Search for a First Century Jewish Community'' detailing an archaelogical dig in Crimea. He leaves behind his beloved wife Patricia, their daughter Julie Rosenblatt, son-in-law Neal Rosenblatt, mother Ida Moskowitz, sister and brother-in-law Sue and Arnie Kogen, nephew Jay Kogen, and niece and grand niece Jill and Samantha Weisbeck, plus an army of friends and relatives whose lives will always be better for having known him. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, July 31, 2001, at 3:30PM. Contributions may be made to Community Funds Inc. for The Peter M. Hirsch Memorial for Thyroid Cancer Research, 2 Park Ave, N.Y., N.Y. 10016.

title: New Political Star in Japan
description: With his informal manner, high energy and ambitious agenda, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi cuts a striking contrast with most of Japan's stolid postwar leaders. Though his three months in office have not brought significant relief from Japan's decadelong recession, and he has promised only many more months of economic pain, Mr. Koizumi is exceedingly popular. On Sunday his magnetism brought impressive gains for his Liberal Democratic Party in voting for Parliament's upper house, an election the governing coalition once worried it might lose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRYSTAL, RUTH
description: CRYSTAL-Ruth. Of West Orange, on July 30. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Howard Crystal and Barbara Cohen. Dear sister of Elaine Glenn. Loving grandmother of Adam, Shana, Andrew and Michael. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack, NJ on Tuesday, July 31, at 10:30 AM. Should friends desire, contributions to The Ruth Crystal Music Scholarship Fund would be appreciated.

title: Report on Fuel Economy Is Less Optimistic in Final Form
description: As the House prepares to debate this week how much automakers should improve the fuel economy of new automobiles, a federal panel produced a carefully hedged report today saying that considerable gains were possible but might pose safety risks.

title: Mideast Dreams, and Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Status of Patients' Rights Bill Is Debated
description: WASHINGTON -- The White House and key lawmakers narrowed their differences in one major area of patients' rights legislation Tuesday, but Democrats disputed suggestions they were close to an overall compromise on a bill that would meet President Bush's terms.

title: Toilet Spiders? Not Real, but Good for a Scare
description: The world can be a scary enough place without tales of deodorants that cause cancer, asbestos-laden tampons and, perhaps most alarming of all, the dreaded arachnius gluteus, a spider said to lurk beneath toilet seats waiting to bite those who sit.

title: G.E. Finance Unit Will Acquire Heller Financial for $5.3 Billion
description: General Electric's financial services subsidiary, GE Capital, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Heller Financial for $5.3 billion in cash, or $53.75 a share.

title: Fresh From a Deal, Lincoln National Looks to Expand
description: Soon to be flush with cash from the sale of its volatile reinsurance business for $2.5 billion, the Lincoln National Group said yesterday that it was on the prowl for acquisitions.

title: Wider Area to Get Meters Limiting Truck Parking
description: A system to ease Midtown Manhattan traffic congestion by charging trucks for parking while they load and unload has been so successful that it is being expanded to a wider area, according to New York City transportation officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMER, ANNE C.
description: RAYMER-Anne C. 53. Of South Bend, IN, formerly of Long Island died July 28. Survivors: husband Dr. John D., children Carolyn, Janet and Thomas, parents William and Alice (Robbs) Raymer, sister Deborah (Emmanuel) Lamendola, brother William (Patricia) Pells. Services 2:00 PM Wednesday. Details call 219-232-1411.

title: Bringing out a new spirit that hopes to succeed flavored vodkas in the trendier watering holes.
description: SINGLE-FLAVORED vodkas, from raspberry to lemon to pepper, seem oh so yesterday.

title: Mideast Dreams, and Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Gleanings From the Grab Bag, Obliquely Delivered
description: In the world of pop, vagueness is an underrated gift. Melodies that noncommittally wander around the brain can be just as potent as those that hit hard. And lyrics might just be better when they only half make sense, leaving more room for the listener to personalize the message. As in romance, pop love can hit harder when the attraction is inexplicable.

title: As Audiences Discover Frugality, Pop Culture Starts Feeling a Chill
description: Business is good at the Cactus Bar in downtown Chicago, but only because it's bad elsewhere.

title: Reliance on Welfare Windfall May Prove Costly for State and City, Report Warns
description: State and city budgets have become increasingly dependent on welfare windfalls that may evaporate in an economic downturn or in the reworking of the federal welfare overhaul next year, a nonpartisan city budget agency warns in an analysis to be released today.

title: An American Without Tears Tweaks the Tour
description: Now that he has won three Tours de France, Lance Armstrong is inevitably being compared with the American who did it first, Greg LeMond -- and being compared unfavorably.

title: Italians and Americans Win Bridge Title
description: The Spingold Knockout Team Championship, concluding the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, was won here on Sunday by two experienced Midwest experts and four Italian world champions. George Jacobs of Burr Ridge, Ill., and Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill., were teamed with the Italians: Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace, who won the World Olympiad team title for their country in Maastricht, the Netherlands, in October. Play was almost even for the first half, but they then surged to win by 50 imps.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Koizumi Rethinks Visit To Memorial
description: One day after helping his Liberal Democratic Party secure a major victory in parliamentary elections, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi hinted that he would reconsider his pledge to visit a shrine to Japan's war dead on Aug. 15. ''My basic principle is that I want to make the visit,'' he said, ''but I will listen to what others have to say.'' Mr. Koizumi has come under intense criticism from China and South Korea, and from his own coalition partners, over plans to visit a Shinto shrine that deifies 14 war criminals. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARDERE, BARBARA
description: GARDERE-Barbara. 7/31/00. Our guardian angel, forever with us. Jeff, Deyanira, Gary, Q, Puma and Sebastian

title: Capriati Moves Up To No. 2 in Ranking
description: Jennifer Capriati has climbed to a career-high No. 2 in the women's world tennis ranking. Capriati, winner of this year's Australian and French Opens, has not played since the Wimbledon semifinals more than three weeks ago. She overtook her fellow American Venus Williams to move behind Martina Hingis, who tops the ranking for the 62nd consecutive week.

title: A New Atomic Clock May Push Precision to the Next Level
description: The world's most precise timepieces are accurate to within a few millionths of a billionth of a second, losing or gaining a second every 20 million years or so. A new type of atomic clock has the potential to do far better, to be accurate to within a second every few billion years.

title: New York Taking First Step To Be Host for 2012 Games
description: The 2012 Summer Olympics are 11 years away, but a crucial step in New York City's bid to be their host begins today when a site-evaluation task force from the United States Olympic Committee inspects the sites proposed for those Games.

title: A 'Dark Remedy' Is Now Generating Light
description: Rock Brynner, 54, historian, writer, former road manager for The Band and for Bob Dylan and son of the late actor Yul Brynner, knows both sides of the story of the drug thalidomide.

title: Mideast Dreams, and Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHUGH, JANET
description: McHUGH-Janet, 63, born 6 October 1937, in Redding, Calif., passed away peacefully in the Bronx on 29 July 2001, following a long illness. She worked at Columbia University in the Projects and Grants Department. She attended Vassar College Class of 1959 and studied history and classics. Her student years ignited a lifelong passion for books and the study of antiquity. She devoted a quiet private life to research, study and travel, collecting for a study of the history of costume through the ages. Her mother, Alice, and her brothers, Patrick and Thomas McHugh, survive her. Her family cherishes her memory. A family memorial will be held in Fort Fairfield, Maine, and interment will be in 29 Palms, Calif.

title: Sports of The Times; A Woman Takes On The System
description: IT took five months for Alison Jennings to explain to her parents why her grades had plummeted, her self-esteem was shattered and her college life at Oklahoma State University had virtually ground to a halt.

title: Mideast Dreams, and Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholar Back In Hong Kong After Trial In Beijing
description: Li Shaomin, a Chinese-born American scholar convicted by Beijing of spying for Taiwan and deported last week to the United States, returned here this evening to resume his teaching job.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Smithtown: Virus Closes Campground
description: The Blydenburgh County Park campground in Suffolk County has been closed to overnight visitors after mosquitoes collected from the area were found to be infected with the West Nile virus, said Kristine A. Smith, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Health. The county health department also limited the hours of the rest of the park. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Antics of Strong-Minded Friends (and Tipsy Birdbrains)
description: Choreographers mixed styles and themes in ''Cross-Pollination,'' a program on Saturday night at the Cunningham Studio. The results varied considerably in effectiveness.

title: 76ERS NOT EXPECTED TO MATCH OFFER
description: The Philadelphia 76ers still have until Thursday to match the offer sheet center Todd MacCulloch signed July 19 with the Nets, which was worth $34.035 million over six years. But Aaron Goodwin, MacCulloch's agent, was optimistic that the 7-foot center will be starting for New Jersey this season.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on expectations that a heat wave would increase demand for fuel to generate electricity. In New York, natural gas for September delivery rose 15.9 cents, to $3.353 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, ALVIN K.
description: GREENFIELD-Alvin K. The Officers, Board of Trustees and Rabbis of Temple Avodah in Oceanside, N.Y. express their deepest sympathy to Sybil Greenfield and family on the passing of our dear friend, Alvin K. Greenfield. He was one of the founding fathers of this Temple and a beloved past President. He also inspired us for many years by blowing the Shofar on the High Holidays. His generosity and forethought enabled us to thrive throughout the years.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sale By Swissair
description: As part of its effort to dispose of money-losing stakes in regional airlines, the Swissair Group has sold the second of its French units, AOM-Air Libert. A French court on Friday approved the sale of the carrier to a former Air France pilot, Jean-Charles Corbet, who bought it for one French franc. Swissair will contribute $173 million for the carrier's revamping. The shares rose 7 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, EDITH M.
description: JACKSON-Edith M. July 30, 2001 of Little Neck, NY. Retired teacher, JHS 67. Beloved wife of the late Ben E. Jackson. Devoted mother of Anthony. Cherished grandmother of four granddaughters. Graveside services/interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI, NY, Tuesday 12 noon. Contributions may be made to American Cancer Society, 30 Speen St, Framingham, MA 01701.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PERCEPTIONS; Smells Used to Explore Schizophrenia
description: Schizophrenia is best known by its active symptoms, like paranoid delusions, but it also has passive ones, like an inability to experience pleasure. A report published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggested that studying the sense of smell could help shed light on some of the symptoms.

title: In Mideast, a Day of Resounding Violence
description: The state of Israeli-Palestinian relations is looking more and more like a police blotter. That was conspicuously so today as bombs, mortars, missiles and knives left casualties on both sides across the length of the land.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe May Not Meet Forecast
description: Adobe Systems Inc., the largest maker of graphics-design software, may not meet its fiscal third-quarter sales forecast as the United States and Asian economies slow. Adobe expects to meet its profit estimate, excluding some costs, in the quarter ending Aug. 31, the company said yesterday in a statement. Sales of all products may lag because of ''weaker than expected'' economic conditions. Sales of Adobe's Photoshop picture-editing software slowed as corporate and graphics customers delayed purchases on concern that economic growth will not pick up, the chief executive, Bruce Chizen, said in June. Shares of Adobe fell $2.52, to $40.84, yesterday after dropping as low as $38.

title: Cheney Campaigns for Schundler In Test of Conservatism's Appeal
description: Bret D. Schundler began testing the Bush administration's political currency in this state tonight, as Vice President Dick Cheney appeared with him at a crowded campaign fund-raiser here, calling Mr. Schundler a ''leader of conviction and purpose'' whom New Jerseyans should view as a ''must-hire'' governor.

title: Today's Bike, Built for Speed Demons
description: To the Editor:

title: French Barge Cruises
description: Sometimes a little extra can bring a lot more. That's the stated premise, anyway, behind a deal offered this autumn by eWaterways.com, an Internet site selling canal and riverboat trips. These are six-night trips through the canals of Burgundy aboard one of three barges: the Litote (carrying 20 passengers), the Mirabelle (24 passengers) and the Marguerite (20 passengers). Here's how it works: the cruise-only price is $1,999 a person, based on double occupancy, but for an extra $9, you also get round-trip economy air fare from most major United States cities to Paris, two nights in a three-star Parisian hotel (with Continental breakfast and hotel taxes), round-trip transfers from Paris to the barge, and all meals, bar drinks, lunch and dinner wines, sightseeing and use of bikes on the barge trip. The departure dates from the United States are Nov. 2, 9, 16, 23 and 30. Information: (800) 217-4447 or http://www.ewaterways.com .

title: Fair Opens With Talk Of the Blast That Killed 4
description: People could not resist. Steeped in midsummer heat, they approached the annual county fair as it opened today with much the same anticipation as ever, but then had to wander past the 4-H barns to the place where the antique steam tractor blew up last night and killed four people.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Tobacco Buyouts Succeed
description: The state's pioneering effort to reduce its tobacco crop by paying farmers to stop growing it has exceeded expectations and will eliminate much of the crop next year. State officials said 674 farmers signed up for the buyout, about 68 percent of those eligible, farmers who grew tobacco in 1998. That is expected to cut the state's 2002 tobacco yield by 6.6 million pounds, about 81 percent of the 1998 yield. ''We are ending tobacco growing, but beginning a new era of farming that will produce new life-sustaining crops,'' Gov. Parris N. Glendening said. Each year for a decade, the program will offer farmers who agree not to grow tobacco $1 for each pound they grew in 1998. Maryland is receiving 5 percent of the settlement with the cigarette industry, or about $7.8 million a year, to finance the buyouts. The figure is based on the average price farmers received from 1996 to 1998. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Sale of Ethanol To Be Widened
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company, the biggest ethanol producer in the nation, said today that it planned to begin selling the fuel additive in the New York area later this year, anticipating growing demand from Eastern states.

title: New York City Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Rocket Science, Served Up Soggy
description: On his day job in 1982, Lonnie G. Johnson, a 32-year-old aerospace engineer, was preparing an interplanetary spacecraft for its atomic battery. But he dreamed of inventing something that would change life on earth.

title: Measurements: Tracking Faith, Race and Blood Pressure
description: Among African-Americans, practicing a religion seems to lower blood pressure, a study conducted at Duke University found. But that did not appear to be the case among whites.

title: Quiet Anniversary for Civil Unions
description: Roger Phelps's lower lip quivered and Elgin Hodgins's voice broke as the two promised to love each other today, tomorrow and forever. Mr. Hodgins recently came within inches of dying of cancer. Mr. Phelps, his partner for 18 years, saw him through.

title: Perceptions: Smells Used to Explore Schizophrenia
description: Schizophrenia is best known by its active symptoms, like paranoid delusions, but it also has passive ones, like an inability to experience pleasure. A report published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggested that studying the sense of smell could help shed light on some of the symptoms.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Exxon Mobil Unit Fined
description: The Australian unit of the Exxon Mobil Corporation has been fined $1 million after being found guilty in June of 11 charges in an explosion and fire at a gas plant in the southeastern state of Victoria. A jury found that the unit, Esso Australia, had failed to adequately train employees and provide a safe environment at the plant where an explosion in 1998 killed two, injured eight and cut gas supplies to Melbourne for almost two weeks. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Karen Coleman and Jack Sullivan, media directors at Starcom North America, Chicago, were named senior vice presidents. Starcom North America is part of the Starcom MediaVest Group, a unit of the Bcom3 Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDIKIAN, ARMAND E., M.D.
description: BEDIKIAN-Armand E., M.D., of Holmdel, NJ formerly of Newark, NJ on July 27, 2001. Retired Director of the Anesthesia Department and Respiratory Care at Bayshore Community Hospital in Holmdel, NJ. Brother of Victoria Wysochansky. Uncle of Elyse Bedikian Marfino, Karen Bedikian and Edward Bedikian. Also survived by numerous family members and friends. Funeral Services will be offered in St. Mary Armenian Church, 200 W. Mt. Pleasant Ave., Livingston, NJ on Thursday August 2 at 11AM. Visitation in St. Mary Armenian Church on Wednesday 2-9 PM, with evening prayers at 8 PM. Interment Restland Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Armand E. Bedikian Foundation c/o Linda Patruno, 2177 Windfield Drive, Wall, NJ 07719 or St. Mary Armenian Church Endowment Fund-Armand E. Bedikian Memorial, 200 W. Mt. Pleasant Ave., Livingston, NJ 07039 or St. Stephanos Armenian Church, 1184 Ocean Ave., Elberon, NJ 07740. For information contact Quinn-Hopping Funeral Home of Livingston.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Medical Marijuana Legal
description: Under one of the most permissive laws anywhere, seriously ill Canadians with prescriptions can grow, buy and smoke marijuana to alleviate pain. But many doctors show little enthusiasm for the measure, saying marijuana has no proven medicinal value. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Mideast Dreams, and Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSH, HARRY
description: GERSH-Harry. Died July 30. 88. Author, reporter and editor, speech writer for Gov. W. Averell Harrimon, public relations director for The Segal Company. Survived by his children John and Ruth, his niece Miriam Diamond and his nephew Paul Foreman. Funeral will be Thursday on Martha's Vineyard. For info 508-693-1495

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOYCE W.
description: GREENE-Joyce W. Died at home in NYC, July 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur B., mother of Jonathan M., and mother-in-law of Denise. She was one of the greatest ladies ever; she was respected for her wit and generosity. She was a friend and caretaker of all animals. Joyce was born in England, 1933. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, August 1st, 7-9 PM, with funeral services Thursday, August 2nd, 5:30 PM. Interment in England. Memorial services will be scheduled at a future date. In lieu of flowers, gifts may given in the name of Joyce W. Greene to the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, 410 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016; 212-532-4455.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, ROBERT
description: ROSENBAUM-Robert, on July 20, 2001. The faculty, staff and students of the Queens College Speech-Language-Hearing Program deeply mourn the death of Robert Lee Rosenbaum. His sensitivity, passion, wisdom, and enduring commitment, for almost half a century, to the undergraduate and graduate programs in SpeechLanguage Pathology and to the Speech-Language and Hearing Center will be remembered and treasured forever. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Evelyn; to his children, Paul and Jennifer, and to his grandchildren. A memorial service will be planned for the fall 2001 at Queens College.

title: Foreign Affairs; Noblesse Oblige
description: Beyond the normal sniping that always goes on between Europe and America, there is today a real disagreement about what it means for America to be the world's leader. The Bush team thinks being the world's only superpower means never having to say you're sorry, and the Europeans think being the world's most powerful democracy means always having to ask permission.

title: Cool Economy Shrinks Number Of Visitors to New York City
description: A million fewer tourists came to New York City last year than were expected, new data show, and the projection for 2001 has been cut by nearly two million, as the cooling economy curtails the surge in visitors both from the United States and abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERPICO, JOHN R.
description: SERPICO-John R. on July 30, 2001, at age seventy-three. Beloved husband of Antoinette. Devoted and loving father of Helen Ann, Sebastian, Maddelen Lavoro, John Jr., and Ann Marie Kern. Cherished grandfather of Marlelle, Paul, Sebastian & Amanda. Also survived by his brothers and sisters Ralph, Theresa De Caprio, Samuel & Anthony. Dear Uncle to many loving nieces and nephews. Beloved lawyer and friend to his many devoted clients, an attorney much respected and loved by all. Reposing Torregrossa & Sons F.H., 79th St, Brooklyn, NY 2-5, 7-10. Funeral Mass St. Bernadettes 9:30 am, Thursday. Moravian Cemetery.

title: Long Shot and Favorite Score
description: One was sent off at 37-1, the other as an odds-on favorite, but both Light Dancer and Voodoo Dancer were victors today in the Lake George Stakes, a Grade III race for 3-year-old fillies.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Vallone Says He Is Best One To Maintain the City's Gains
description: Warning that New York faced a crisis because of the imminent departure of dozens of elected leaders forced out by term limits, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, said yesterday that he should be elected mayor because he could assure stability in City Hall and protect advances New York had made over the past decade.

title: Today's Bike, Built for Speed Demons
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Use Technology and T.L.C. to Hold On to Fans
description: As producer of the L.P.G.A.'s Web site, Shirley Allen does more than write articles and update photographs. In a sense, she serves as an online concierge.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Schools Are Urged To Drop Indian Names
description: The State Board of Education has asked schools to eliminate American Indian logos and team nicknames because it says the names promote racial stereotypes and demean Indian culture. The Department of Education plans to begin an educational campaign in local school systems on the subject and report to the board in four months. State officials identified about 30 Maryland public schools that use American Indian names. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Bilingual Program Overhaul May Be Scaled Back, Levy Says
description: The widely heralded and long-planned overhaul of bilingual education in New York City, aimed at greater use of English and more parental choice, is in danger of becoming a small-scale pilot project because the state has not allocated the needed money, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said last week.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: LAWYERS CONSIDER EASING RESTRICTION ON CLIENT SECRECY
description: For the first time in nearly 20 years, the American Bar Association is considering an expansive update of ethics rules for lawyers, which if approved would give attorneys more freedom to divulge their clients' secrets if such revelations would prevent fraud, injury or death.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Clean-Up At Uranium Sites
description: The European Union started work to reduce exposure to radiation and prevent pollution from an estimated 3.2 million cubic yards of uranium tailings from a Soviet-era processing plant on the Malii-Suu River. The tailings are covered with earth and there are fears that erosion will wash the material into the fertile Ferghana Valley. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLER, LEO
description: BRESLER-Leo. Beloved husband of Rose. Cherished father of Laurence and Akiko. Loving grandfather of Marie and Terence. Died at 92 after a long, full life. Graveside services 11:30 AM today at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, NY.

title: A Tough Union Backs Change; Schools Benefit
description: For years, the Hartford teachers' union relished its reputation as the most militant in the nation. It got its members the highest teacher salaries despite their students' having the lowest test scores in the state.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Radioactive Waste Site: A Shift In Strategy
description: After spending 14 years and $4.5 billion to figure out whether Yucca Mountain is dry and stable enough to entomb highly radioactive waste for 10,000 years, the Department of Energy is shifting its focus from geology to the protective powers of titanium and steel.

title: Playing with Science
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
